headline: Summer in the City
text: Here are 10 new hot spots to drink, party, play and chill in the city.

headline: 10 New Hot Spots if Summer Needs Sizzle
text: A SUMMER share in the five boroughs? A gay-themed circus? A subway to the next Jersey Shore? Forget about the Jitney. Summer offers plenty of reasons to stay in New York. Here are 10 new hot spots to drink, party, play and chill in the city.

headline: Turkish Aid From Flotilla Begins Arriving in Gaza
text: GAZA — One month after Israeli commandos killed nine Turks in a raid on a flotilla trying to break the Gaza blockade, the ships’ cargo of aid has begun to arrive here by land, starting Wednesday with 82 second-hand battery-powered scooters for the handicapped.

headline: Deal Restores Public Housing Subsidies
text: A brewing housing crisis that could have resulted in thousands of struggling families losing their rental subsidies has been averted, officials said, thanks to an intricate $32 million plan devised by city and state agencies that received federal approval on Wednesday.

headline: Setting an Example of Austerity at the Élysée Palace
text: PARIS  The French, like the English, may not like to talk about money, but they have an appalled fascination with it. And with budget austerity in the air here and “new taxes” a forbidden phrase, President Nicolas Sarkozy is instead focusing on symbols  canceling state garden parties for Bastille Day, ending presidential hunts at Château de Chambord and pushing his ministers to reduce their lavish expenses and bloated staffs.

headline: In Civil Suit, Mixed Verdict for Accuser and Officer
text: For nearly two years, a Brooklyn man has given various audiences his account of the abuse he says he suffered at the hands of the police, describing how one officer pinned him to the floor of a subway station and repeatedly rammed an object between his buttocks as other officers looked on.

headline: Veterans at St. Louis Center Are Told of Exposure Risk
text: ST. LOUIS  The Department of Veterans Affairs sent letters to more than 1,800 veterans this week, cautioning that they may have been exposed to a host of blood-borne diseases while undergoing dental work at the city’s Cochran V.A. medical center.

headline: Varied Bills for Special Interests Move Quietly Through Albany
text: ALBANY  Check-cashing stores could make high-interest payday loans. Funeral homes could offer all-in-one package deals that are now banned in New York and that critics say prey on the families of the recently deceased. And so-called rubber rooms, where New York City schoolteachers languished during disciplinary proceedings until officials moved to close them this year, may soon reopen, this time for city firefighters and police officers.

headline: Oakland Prepares for Response to Trial Verdict
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Officials in Oakland are girding for the verdict in a closely watched trial of a former transit police officer accused of murdering an unarmed black man on a subway platform on New Year’s Day 2009.

headline: Economies in Latin America Race Ahead
text: LIMA, Peru  While the United States and Europe fret over huge deficits and threats to a fragile recovery, this region has a surprise in store. Latin America, beset in the past by debt defaults, currency devaluations and the need for bailouts from rich countries, is experiencing robust economic growth that is the envy of its northern counterparts.

headline: Report Says City Elections Should Be Nonpartisan
text: In a reversal, a prominent government watchdog said Wednesday that it now supported eliminating the role of parties in city elections, adding momentum to an effort to bring the issue before voters in November.

headline: The Kagan Hearings: Some Reviews
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Family Ritual in Haiti Is Threatened
text: When she talks about summers in Haiti, Naila Zephyr’s voice turns dreamy: The sea is “blue and clear and nice.” The sun sets right over the water. On the way home from the beach, she buys stewed conch in paper cups from roadside vendors, an indelible taste of childhood. Family houses are full of aunts and cousins and food and love.

headline: For Fans, a Time Machine to the Heyday of Hip-Hop
text: When Bronx parks and playgrounds were throbbing with a new music called hip-hop, Christie Z-Pabon was just a young Catholic schoolgirl in Perryopolis, Pa.

headline: Should Oil Drilling in the Gulf Be Put on Hold?
text: To the Editor:

headline: When the Roads to Suburbia Lead to a Suspected Spy Ring
text: Suburban spies! Who knew?

headline: Black Landowners Fight to Reclaim Georgia Home
text: HARRIS NECK NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, Ga.  When the managers from the federal Fish and Wildlife Service talk about this 2,800-acre preserve of moss-draped cypress, palmetto and marsh, they speak of endangered wood stork rookeries and disappearing marsh habitat, dike maintenance and interpretive kiosks.

headline: Top French Schools, Asked to Diversify, Fear for Standards
text: PARIS  France is embarking on a grand experiment  how to diversify the overwhelmingly white “grandes écoles,” the elite universities that have produced French leaders in every walk of life  and Rizane el-Yazidi is one of the pioneers.

headline: Giving Birth in Manhattan
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Negro League Players, a Measure of Recognition
text: COLUMBIA, Mo.  Only something so heavy could lighten their burden. Three men gripped a 150-pound headstone around the edges, lugged it 40 feet across the grass and lowered it into the dirt.

headline: PGA Tour Should Not Get Comfortable in Philadelphia
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. – The return of the PGA Tour to the Philadelphia area for the first time since 2002 with the AT&T National’s temporary two-year run opening at Aronimink Golf Club on Thursday has predictably created a groundswell of excitement about whether the tour has any plans for a permanent event here.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,400 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,132 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: At 11, Turning a Love of Animals Into a Job
text: Sean Dewhurst is a New York City pet-sitter with a fifth-grade education. He will enter sixth grade in the fall, at St. Ann’s School in Brooklyn Heights. He started a dog-walking and cat-sitting service last year in the Carroll Gardens neighborhood of Brooklyn, where he lives with his parents, his three siblings and his cat, Jackie Robinson. Sean, who is 11, has earned $750 so far, and is considering making pet-sitting a career. He is accepting new clients  he put his e-mail address on the fliers he taped to utility poles  but he’s tied up this week and next. He’s at sleepaway camp.

headline: Google News Offers the Daily You
text: What if you woke up every morning to find a customized newspaper on your doorstep?

headline: Sore Back and Hard Turf Sideline Reyes for a Night
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  After enjoying an injury-free spring, Jose Reyes, perhaps the most influential player on the Mets, was scratched from the starting lineup Wednesday with a stiff lower back. The injury, however, did not appear to be serious.

headline: The Tax Treatment of Domestic Partner Benefits
text: Updated | 3:15 p.m.

headline: Banned Trailers Return for Latest Gulf Disaster
text: VENICE, La.  In the wake of Hurricane Katrina, they became a symbol of the government’s inept response to that disaster: the 120,000 or so trailers provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency to people who had lost their homes.

headline: Google to Add Pay to Cover a Tax for Same-Sex Benefits
text: Working for a company as rich as Google comes with an incredible number of fringe benefits: the free food, the free laundry, the doctor on duty at company headquarters and the impressive five months of maternity leave with full pay and benefits, to mention a few.

headline: Second-Act Aces
text: I used to be a connoisseur of stories about young, doomed geniuses: the F. Scott Fitzgeralds or Vincent van Goghs who died early, broke and crushed, going to their graves before anyone appreciated them. Doomed alcoholic youth were even better, an added edge to their stunted nobility.

headline: Microsoft Kin Discontinued After 48 Days
text: SAN FRANCISCO  That didn’t take long.

headline: Killers Stalk Politicians as Iraq Seeks Government
text: MOSUL, Iraq  Since Iraq’s parliamentary elections in March, killers in this violent northern city have stalked members of the Iraqiya Party, which won the most seats, part of a nationwide outbreak of violence directed at officials and other civic leaders.

headline: With a Focus on Recruiters, Not a Recruiter to Be Found
text: The military office was locked down tight, which is fine if it’s in Fort Knox, but not ideal if it’s a recruiting station in the middle of the crossroads of the world on a sunny summer morning.

headline: Talks on Global Whaling
text: To the Editor:

headline: Harsh Words for G.O.P. From Obama
text: RACINE, Wis.  President Obama leveled a harsh indictment against Congressional Republicans on Wednesday, accusing them of doing the bidding of bankers and oil executives while cutting “working folks loose to fend for themselves.”

headline: This Year at AT&T National, Woods Has a Different Role
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  It might have looked like business as usual at 6:40 a.m. Wednesday, when the Tiger Woods dawn patrol kicked off the pro-am at Aronimink Golf Club on the eve of the fourth edition of the AT&T National. In most ways, it was. But in other ways, changes  both subtle and substantial  abound at the tournament that Woods helped create in 2007.

headline: Gratitude for Stonewall
text: To the Editor:

headline: M.T.A. Contractor Pleads Guilty to Underpaying Workers
text: The owner and the vice president of a construction contracting firm that performed hundreds of millions of dollars of work for the city’s transit system and other public-works projects pleaded guilty on Wednesday to underpaying more than 300 workers by about $600,000.

headline: Confirm Elena Kagan
text: Elena Kagan delivered an impressive performance at her Senate confirmation hearing. Assuming the commitments she made were authentic and not simply designed to tranquilize the members of the Judiciary Committee, she could act as an important brake on the current Supreme Court’s alarming tendency to bulldoze through decades of settled precedents. She deserves confirmation as an associate justice.

headline: Turkish and Israeli Officials Meet Secretly on Raid Crisis
text: TEL AVIV — The Turkish foreign minister and an Israeli cabinet member met secretly in Europe on Wednesday to try to defuse the crisis that erupted after Israel’s deadly raid on a Turkish aid boat bound for Gaza.

headline: Battle for LeBron James Begins in Earnest
text: AKRON, Ohio — Before LeBron James became a high school basketball prodigy, an N.B.A. star or the most highly coveted free agent the league has seen, he was a child here. His goal, as he has repeated several times, was to land this city, his city, on the map.

headline: The Fed and Your Credit Card
text: Congress passed legislation last year banning many of the worst practices of credit card companies and ordered the Federal Reserve to issue new rules to ensure that late charges and all other penalties  a major source of abuse  are “reasonable and proportional.”

headline: Small Schools
text: School reform advocates are rightly excited about a persuasive new study showing that New York City’s small, specialized high schools are outperforming larger, more traditional schools, significantly narrowing the graduation-rate gap that currently exists between white and minority students across the city.

headline: Not Anyone’s Daughter
text: Advocates have been fighting to end female genital mutilation across Africa and parts of the Middle East and Asia, marking progress one village at a time. The battleground extends to immigrant communities in the developed world, which still value this horrifying ritual.

headline: Officer and Professor Faulted for Confrontation at Home
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The Harvard professor Henry Louis Gates Jr. and the Cambridge police sergeant who arrested him last July missed opportunities to “ratchet down” an avoidable confrontation that set off a national debate on race, class and policing, according to a report released Wednesday by an independent panel.

headline: Diplomacy, Sanctions and Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: Afghan Shift Puts Top U.S. Civilians in Tricky Spot
text: WASHINGTON — As General David H. Petraeus takes command in Afghanistan, the two top American civilian officials in the war face an uncertain and tricky future, working with a newly empowered military leader, under the gaze of an impatient president who has put them on notice that his fractious war council needs to pull together.

headline: Politics Blog Questions Polling Data It Has Used
text: The political blog Daily Kos said Tuesday that it could not trust the data it has used in its weekly poll featured prominently at the top of the Web site, raising questions for the second time in a year about the veracity of a widely used polling company.

headline: G.O.P. Rival Criticizes Blumenthal on Integrity
text: Linda McMahon, the likely Republican nominee for the United States Senate in Connecticut, mounted an aggressive attack Wednesday on Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, who continues to hold an edge in the polls, for misrepresenting his military record.

headline: TARP, the Bailout Fund Everyone Loves to Hate, Could Make Its Exit Early
text: WASHINGTON  While testifying on Capitol Hill last week about the government’s bank bailout program, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner likened the hearing to a eulogy for the initiative.

headline: The Most Unhappy Fellow
text: Our Independence Day weekend winner of the title of Most Unhappy Person in Washington is: John Boehner, the House minority leader.

headline: Massachusetts: Psychiatrist Departs After Baby Einstein Controversy
text: After months of estrangement, Dr. Alvin F. Poussaint, a prominent psychiatrist, is leaving the Judge Baker Children’s Center in Boston and closing his Media Center, which for 16 years fought harmful media influences on children. The break came after Dr. Poussaint and the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood  a group the Media Center oversaw  complained that Disney was falsely marketing its popular Baby Einstein videos as educational. Last fall, Disney offered refunds to Baby Einstein buyers. The Judge Baker Center, uncomfortable with the aggressive advocacy work, evicted the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood and told Dr. Poussaint not to discuss Baby Einstein products with the news media. He is moving to the Harvard Medical School, where he is a faculty associate dean.

headline: Chancellor’s Slip Benefits Tobacco Research
text: The chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, has donated $134,000 from the sale of her stock in the nation’s largest cigarette company to the university’s tobacco control center, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Prominent Drug Chief to Sell Abraxis BioScience to Celgene for $2.9 Billion
text: LOS ANGELES  The nation’s richest pharmaceutical industry executive has done it again.

headline: 2 Suitors for Newsweek Are Said to Be Ruled Out
text: WITH a 5 p.m. Thursday deadline approaching for the final round of bids, at least two people were preparing to make offers for Newsweek while two others were told by the magazine’s owners that their bids would not be considered.

headline: A.C.L.U. Sues Over No-Fly List
text: The American Civil Liberties Union on Wednesday filed suit against top Justice Department and F.B.I. officials on behalf of 10 Americans and legal residents on the government’s no-fly list, including 5 who are stranded overseas. They have been given no information about why they are on the list, the lawsuit says. Ben Wizner, an A.C.L.U. staff lawyer, called the government’s actions “un-American and unconstitutional.” The Justice Department had no comment. The no-fly list has roughly doubled to 8,000 names since the failed bombing of a Detroit-bound airliner on Dec. 25, officials familiar with the list said.

headline: Lawyers Dispute Suspects’ Intent in J.F.K. Bomb Plot Trial
text: A federal jury on Wednesday heard sharply contrasting versions of the intent and the ability of two Guyanese men charged with conspiring to attack Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Despite Arrests, Working to Rebuild Russia Ties
text: WASHINGTON  They doffed their jackets and bonded over burgers, talking about everything from trade and geopolitics to their families. Everything, that is, except the spies that the government of one had hidden in a house just a few miles away and that the government of the other was about to arrest.

headline: In Manhattan, Apartment Sales Rose but Prices Were Flat
text: The number of apartments sold in Manhattan rose significantly in the last three months, but prices were flat, with some categories dipping slightly compared with the previous quarter, according to sales reports to be released on Thursday by the city’s largest brokerage firms.

headline: British Court Rejects European Rights Laws for Nation’s Troops
text: LONDON  Britain’s Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that the nation’s soldiers in combat abroad were not protected by European human rights law, reversing lower court rulings that the Defense Ministry said would hamper the British war effort in Afghanistan.

headline: Funds for Race to the Top May Be Cut
text: House Democrats have attached a provision to a war financing bill that would spend $10 billion to help school districts avoid teacher layoffs, paying for it, in part, with cuts to Education Department programs previously financed by last year’s stimulus bill. One program facing trims would be Race to the Top, the competition that rewards states promising to create more charter schools and carry out other initiatives. The department has been planning to give $3.4 billion to winners this year, but the jobs provision would reduce that to $2.9 billion.

headline: W. S. Merwin to Be Named Poet Laureate
text: W. S. Merwin acknowledges that his relatively reclusive life on a former pineapple plantation built atop a dormant volcano in Maui, Hawaii, will be disturbed by the Library of Congress’s announcement on Thursday naming him the country’s poet laureate.

headline: Aid Is Cut to Programs for Sex-Crime Victims
text: At a time when the Police Department is examining how it trains its officers to handle sex crimes, the City Council has eliminated financing for programs that help victims of sexual assault, including sexually abused youths, young men and immigrants.

headline: Finding Home and Inspiration in the World of Nature
text: The rap against W. S. Merwin’s poetry has been that it is obscure and abstract, as aloof as a balloon on the end of a string. It’s true that he’s an elegant poet, easy to admire but hard to care deeply about.

headline: Breakfast Order
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s Thursday and trickery is afoot! Answers are over, under and, in the very center of the grid, over and under. For a complete explanation, check below.

headline: A New Team Tackles Mamet’s Moral Fable of Pride, Prejudice and Susceptibility
text: Eddie Izzard has the face of a fallen angel, of a rumpled cherub who grew up way too fast once he landed in hell. That face alone makes this British actor and comic a solid choice for the role of Jack Lawson, the Mephistophelean lawyer in “Race,” David Mamet’s terse moral fable of pride and prejudices at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. True, James Spader had played the part to near perfection when the show opened in December. But I had hopes that Mr. Izzard, a brilliant stand-up portraitist of human perversity, might give a jolt of shock therapy to an often glib and mechanical play.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bills on Secondhand Smoke and Domestic Workers’ Benefits Advance
text: In a flurry of activity late Wednesday, state lawmakers in Albany wrestled with a number of high-profile bills  including measures aimed at helping domestic workers and protecting young children from secondhand smoke.

headline: The Two Sides of a Barbed-Wire Fence
text: KARMEL, West Bank

headline: A Night Later, Hernandez More Than Matches Lee’s Complete Game
text: The Seattle ace Cliff Lee, the big apple of New York City’s eye as baseball’s trading deadline approaches, arrived in the Bronx with the spotlight on him. But the performance Felix Hernandez produced Wednesday night was impossible to ignore.

headline: U.S. Changes Tariff Status of Some Goods
text: WASHINGTON  Some tires from Thailand, wood flooring from Brazil and gold rope necklaces from India will cost more in the United States as a result of an annual review by the Obama administration of a trade program intended to help developing countries.

headline: Man in New York Subway Plot Tied to Senior Qaeda Figure
text: The central figure in a failed suicide plot to bomb three New York City subways lines last year had contact with an elusive and feared senior Qaeda operative who spent his youth in Brooklyn and has eluded American authorities for at least seven years, a counterterrorism official said on Wednesday.

headline: In Hunts Point, Celebrating an End to Sludge
text: The acrid odors that seep from a Hunts Point sewage plant have tormented neighborhood residents for years. They have kept children indoors, stifled street life and, for many local advocates, symbolized the disregard they believe the city has for this low-income community in a much-put-upon section of the South Bronx.

headline: Luring LeBron
text: As one of the biggest free agency periods in N.B.A. history commences, cities are launching full campaigns to land the game’s biggest star.

headline: House Panel Votes to Ease Cuba Travel Restrictions
text: WASHINGTON — The House Agriculture Committee voted Wednesday to reverse a decades-long ban on United States citizens traveling to Cuba and to ease restrictions on the sale of American commodities there.

headline: New Estimate of Strength of Al Qaeda Is Offered
text: ASPEN, Colo.  Michael E. Leiter, one of the country’s top counterterrorism officials, said Wednesday that American intelligence officials now estimated that there were somewhat “more than 300” Qaeda leaders and fighters hiding in Pakistan’s tribal areas, a rare public assessment of the strength of the terrorist group that is the central target of President Obama’s war strategy.

headline: Investors Are Wary of Petrobras Sale
text: Petrobras, the Brazilian energy giant, has taken a beating of late. But don’t blame BP for it all.

headline: Brooklyn Park Is Ready to Rock, but Some Neighbors Aren’t
text: The singer Neil Sedaka, a sleepy city park and two synagogues by the sea: only in New York  and only in Brooklyn, maybe  could those elements be part of a raging feud.

headline: Day 71: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: E.P.A. Releases Data on Dispersants

headline: The Good Driller Award
text: Boston

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Photo Replay: June 30
text: A look back at the day in sports, with Wimbledon upsets and rain delays in Puerto Rico.

headline: Damages Control
text: WHEN corporations like Exxon, State Farm and Phillip Morris lose tort cases, juries occasionally award, in addition to compensation for the plaintiff’s injuries, extensive punitive damages.

headline: Stanley Wagner, New York Winery Owner, Dies at 83
text: Stanley Wagner, a vintner who three decades ago was one of the first people to open a winery in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York, and whose wines quickly earned state and national recognition, died on Saturday at his home in Lodi, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: New Data Shows China’s Growth Is Slowing
text: HONG KONG — Two closely watched measures of the manufacturing sector in China declined in June in the latest sign that Beijing’s efforts to scale back stimulus have begun to moderate the growth of the world’s largest developing nation.

headline: Bloggingheads: Republican Squishiness
text: Conor Friedersdorf of The American Scene and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate whether the G.O.P. should move further right.

headline: 4-Year-Old Girl Falls Into Elevator Shaft
text: A 4-year-old girl fell more than 20 feet down an elevator shaft on the Upper East Side on Wednesday afternoon, fire officials said.

headline: Iran: Death Sentences for Torture
text: A Web site linked to the Intelligence Ministry reported Wednesday that a military court had sentenced two men to death and nine others to jail for torturing three protesters to death last summer at the notorious Kahrizak detention center. The Web site, Jahan news, did not identify the defendants and said that the verdicts were not final. It also said that 33 others were accused of attacking a student dormitory in Tehran. Opposition leaders have accused the authorities of torturing and raping detainees last summer after mass arrests in a crackdown on protests.

headline: Israel: Hamas Lawmaker Held
text: A Palestinian lawmaker affiliated with Hamas was arrested Wednesday for ignoring an Israeli order effectively expelling him from Jerusalem, where he lives. Israel had recently revoked the Jerusalem residency permits of the lawmaker, Muhammad Abu-Teir, and three other Palestinian parliament members because of their affiliation with Hamas. Israel considers Hamas, a militant movement that has carried out numerous attacks on Israel, a terrorist organization. The police said Mr. Abu-Teir had ignored a court order to vacate his home and would appear in court on Thursday. Richard Falk, the Palestinian rights investigator for the United Nations, criticized the move as part of a “larger, extremely worrying pattern of Israeli efforts to drive Palestinians out of East Jerusalem.”

headline: Israel: Defense Minister to Meet Palestinian Premier
text: Defense Minister Ehud Barak said Wednesday that he would meet in the next few days with the Palestinian prime minister, Salam Fayyad. It would be the first such high-level contact between Israeli and Palestinian officials in five months. At the moment, the two sides are speaking to each other through George J. Mitchell, the Obama administration’s Middle East envoy.

headline: Nepal: Prime Minister Resigns
text: Prime Minister Madhav Kumar Nepal resigned Wednesday after 13 turbulent months in office, fulfilling the terms of a fragile deal with Maoist rebels to salvage the country’s fledgling democracy. In a televised address, Mr. Nepal said he was stepping down “for the sake of consensus” and to help end the country’s political stalemate. The Maoists, which ended a 10-year insurgency in 2006 and won a plurality in elections two years later, had refused to recognize the new government and demanded the prime minister step down.

headline: French Seek 10 Years for Noriega
text: Prosecutors requested the maximum 10-year prison sentence on Wednesday for Manuel Noriega, the former Panamanian dictator convicted of laundering drug money. Mr. Noriega had been sentenced to 10 years on the same charges after being tried in absentia in 1999, but demanded a new trial after he was extradited from the United States in April. Mr. Noriega, who had worked for the C.I.A., argued Tuesday that the charges were based on an “imaginary financial set-up orchestrated by the United States.”

headline: Belgium: National Archives Affected in Raid of Church Offices
text: The police officers who raided offices of the Roman Catholic Church last week in a sexual abuse investigation also took documents from the National Archives, that body said Wednesday. “As far as we know, it is the first time in the history of the Belgian National Archives that records that are kept here are seized by the judicial authorities,” the archives said in a statement. The documents seized from the archives concerned about 30 allegations of sexual abuse.

headline: Rainy Night and Sloppy Play Work in Mets’ Favor
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  A lashing tropical storm set the stage for a sloppy conclusion to Major League Baseball’s three-day Caribbean excursion. Rain poured for close to two hours, pushing back the start of a game that featured numerous mishaps and mistakes, beginning with Jose Reyes injuring his oblique muscle during batting practice.

headline: Weighing Ray Allen’s Value
text: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com. He grew up in Connecticut watching the Bird-era Celtics with his father and hating Chuck Person. He now lives in Manhattan and dreams of a day in his adult lifetime when the Celtics and the Knicks are both elite teams.

headline: Amazon Introduces a New Kindle DX With Lower Price
text: Amazon.com is not giving up on its large-screen Kindle DX.

headline: TARP Could Make Its Exit Early
text: While testifying on Capitol Hill last week about the government’s bank bailout program, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner likened the hearing to a eulogy for the initiative.

headline: News Quiz | July 1, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Word of the Day | renege
text: renege •\ri-ˈneg also -ˈnag, -ˈnig; re-\• verb, noun

headline: 2 Suitors for Newsweek Are Said to Be Ruled Out
text: With a 5 p.m. Thursday deadline approaching for the final round of bids, at least two people were preparing to make offers for Newsweek while two others were told by the magazine’s owners that their bids would not be considered, Jeremy W. Peters reports in The New York Times.

headline: Corey Allen, Actor and Director, Dies at 75
text: Corey Allen, who directed dozens of television shows but was best known for his performance in a searing car sequence from the groundbreaking film “Rebel Without a Cause,” died Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: New Data Show China’s Growth Slowing
text: Two closely watched surveys of the manufacturing sector in China fell in June in the latest sign that Beijing’s efforts to scale back stimulus measures have begun to moderate the growth of the world’s largest developing nation, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Loan Giants Threaten Energy-Efficiency Programs
text: The Obama administration is devoting $150 million in stimulus money for programs that help homeowners install solar panels and other energy improvements, which they pay for over time on their property tax bills, Todd Woody reports in The New York Times.

headline: Outdoor Gizmos
text: Products that help make hiking, camping and other recreation safer or at least add a new dimension.

headline: Mobile Phone Enhancements
text: Cases, chargers, speakers and other options make your phone more than just a plain old handset.

headline: Ex-A.I.G. Exec Calls Bailout Too Generous
text: The former head of the American International Group unit that nearly crippled the insurer said the 2008 taxpayer bailout of up to $182 billion was too generous to customers like Goldman Sachs, Reuters reports.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Comessation
text: Today’s word, in association with the illustrious Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Spies in Our Midst
text: WHO were arrested on Monday, June 28, 2010, on charges of spying for Russia?

headline: Portrait Innovations Hopes for $75 Million I.P.O.
text: Portrait Innovations Holding, which operates portrait studios, plans to raise $75 million in a initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: ABB Clears Way for Emerson on Chloride
text: ABB, the Swiss engineering company, said Thursday that it would not continue its effort  to buy the British company Chloride by matching Emerson Electric’s improved offer of $1.5 billion.

headline: Second Quarter Ends With Dow Down 10%
text: The stock market rounded out its worst quarter since late 2008 on Wednesday with a late slide that spared few blue chips, The New York Time’s Christine Hauser reported.

headline: Senate Takes Up Small-Business Jobs Bill
text: From Robb Mandelbaum at You’re the Boss:

headline: With Woot Deal, Amazon Expands Its Inventory
text: Amazon.com, which sells millions of products, said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Woot, a site that sells one item at a time.

headline: Goldman’s Cohn Reaching Out to Clients
text: Gary D. Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, said he’s working overtime these days to stay in touch with clients as the firm weathers its battle with regulators, Reuters reported.

headline: Accel Invests in ModCloth, a Social Shopping Site
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: DynCorp Shareholders Approve Buyout
text: DynCorp International said Wednesday that shareholders had approved the company’s acquisition by the private equity firm,  Cerberus Capital Management, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Should Students Get to Evaluate Their Teachers?
text: Opinionator blog contributor Stanley Fish, a longtime university professor, reflected in two recent posts on “the dangers of relying on student evaluations.” (Columnist Ross Douthat also weighed in on the subject.) Should schools have students evaluate their teachers?

headline: HiSoft Raises $74 Million as I.P.O. Prices Slip
text: HiSoft Technology International and its stockholders priced American depositary shares of its initial public offering at $10 each, below the expected range, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Tate & Lyle Sells  Sugar Business to U.S. Firm
text: Britain’s Tate & Lyle said Thursday it is selling its European sugar refining business to American Sugar Refining for £211 million ($314 million) in cash, as it focuses on producing ingredients for industry.

headline: The G-20’s China Bet
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: At London Art Festival, Edification and Sales
text: Twenty-five of the world’s leading art dealers and three major auction houses launched Master Paintings Week last year in London, hoping to take the intimidation factor out of classical art. They opened their doors wide, letting it be known that they would be just as happy to increase visitors’ knowledge of art as to sell them a $500,000 painting. The public took so well to the experience that organizers will follow up with the sequel from July 4 to 9.

headline: A.I.G. Chief Threatens to Quit if Chairman Stays
text: It seems that the botched sale of the American International Group‘s Asian life insurance unit has led the company’s chief, Robert H. Benmosche, to lay down that most stark of ultimatums concerning the company’s chairman: It’s either him or me.

headline: Yahoo Board Approves $3 Billion Stock Buyback
text: Yahoo approved a plan to repurchase up to $3 billion of its common stock over the next three years, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: San Francisco 49ers 2010 Season Preview

headline: Giving Money Directly to the Poor
text: Today’s idea: Instead of relying on the waste-ridden global aid industry to build roads and schools, it’s often better to just give money directly to the poor, a new book argues.

headline: Actares Joins Calls for UBS to Pursue Managers
text: Actares, the Swiss shareholder group, has joined calls that UBS bring to account the former managers who presided over the depreciation of illiquid securities by more than $50 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: N.Y. Hedge Fund Tax Re-Ignites Conn. Rivalry
text: It seems that the plan by Gov. David A. Paterson and New York’s legislative leaders to tax out-of-state hedge fund managers may have ignited something of a dispute with Connecticut, another stronghold of the industry.

headline: Bringing a Reality TV Business Competition to Afghanistan
text: When most Americans look at Afghanistan, it’s through their televisions, and what they see is a war-ravaged country that has been living a nightmare for decades, a place the United Nations describes as having “a pervasive culture of impunity and a weak rule of law,” where “freedom of expression is threatened … ill-treatment and torture are used to force confessions,” and “few people have access to redress mechanisms, especially women.”

headline: Counting (and Filing) the iPhone Apps
text: When Steve Jobs unveiled the new iOS4 (the latest iPhone operating software), he bragged about a new feature that lets you organize your downloaded apps into logically named folders. (Truly, it’s a fantastic feature.)

headline: It’s the Fourth of July. Do You Know Where Your Summer Went?
text: It’s almost the Fourth of July, the apex of summer. So why does it feel like it’s already last call at the barbecue and the beach volleyball court?

headline: Looking for a Few Good S.E.C. Officials
text: While the Securities and Exchange Commission has been looking to cull hedge fund talent to help its task force better understand the industry, some hedge funds have been turning the tables — going out and hiring former regulators of their own, Reuters reports.

headline: Ecosystem vs. an Endangered Culture
text: Conservationists tend to think of wildlife sanctuaries as the most beneficial possible use for a given piece of land, for air, water and endangered species alike. But what if there is a competing claim from an endangered culture?

headline: Australian Buyout Market Shows Signs of Life
text: Two private equity deals involving Australia’s CHAMP Private Equity, signed Thursday, gave industry observers their first glimpse of a possible rebound in the country’s buyout market, which had gone dark since the onset of the financial crisis.

headline: From the Master of Speed Comes a Lean, Green City Car
text: It’s a long way from the McLaren F1 and the Mercedes-Benz SLR McLaren to a tiny city car, but Gordon Murray, the legendary engineer whose Formula One racecars have won 50 grand prix, likes a challenge.

headline: Postcards From the ‘Tour d’Admission’
text: For seven summers, a group of college counselors from across the country have climbed on bicycles to travel from college to college on an informal, saddle-bound fact-finding mission that I like to think of as the Tour d’Admission. Last July, I was fortunate to spend a day riding with this peloton, such as it was, from Franklin and Marshall to Elizabethtown Colleges in southern Pennsylvania. This summer, the group has set its tour in California, and the participants will be filing regular dispatches to The Choice from the road, beginning around July 6. This is the inaugural post in their travelogue. – Jacques Steinberg

headline: Providence Buys Australia’s Study Group
text: Study Group, an international education company, said Thursday that it has been sold to the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners for 660 million Australian dollars, or $570 million, in cash.

headline: Fortis Healthcare in $2.3 Billion Parkway Bid
text: Fortis Healthcare, a chain of hospitals based in New Delhi, on Thursday offered about 3.2 billion Singapore dollars, or $2.3 billion, for the three-quarters of the Asian hospital operator Parkway Holdings that it does not already own.

headline: The Fed and the 1938 Recession

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The good news is, Spain sold a bunch of bonds without much trouble — a 3.5 billion euro thumbs up, if you will — but the bad news is that Moody’s says it may soon downgrade that debt. The European Central Bank, meanwhile, stepped up to the plate with 111 billion euros to soften the expiration of about four times that in loans that banks needed to pay back Thursday.

headline: Zvonareva Reaches Wimbledon Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Vera Zvonareva of Russia outlasted Tsvetana Pironkova of Bulgaria in a hard-fought semifinal, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, to reach the Wimbledon final for the first time.

headline: Turkey Says Syria Detains 400 Kurdish Separatists

text: A record drop in pending home sales and a slowdown in the construction market contributed to a sluggish outlook for the economy Thursday, highlighting the significance of government stimulus measures and job growth.

text: Q.

headline: Poetry Pairing | July 1, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: Mamas, Don’t Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Vampires: ‘Twilight’ Goes Country
text: At this stage in the life cycle of the “Twilight” phenomenon you’ve seen the movies parodied by everyone under the sun (and moon): “Saturday Night Live,” Jimmy Fallon, the “Jersey Shore” cast, even vintage-video-game enthusiasts. But have you seen the Bella-Edward-Jacob saga satirized by the self-mocking country musician Colt Ford, who knows he’ll never serve as a body double for Robert Pattinson?

headline: Treasury Sells 1.1 Billion More Citi Shares
text: 12:26 p.m. | Updated The Treasury Department said Thursday that it has sold about 1.1 billion more of its common shares in Citigroup, as the government continues to unwind the stake it took in the bank as part of its bailout program.

headline: Defined by Soccer: Jacob Bopape a k a Babes
text: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa for the World Cup to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. Based in Alexandra — a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people — the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.

headline: Nocturnalist | At a ’60s Flick, Mod Reigns
text: Up a candlelight-flickered staircase, through a darkroom cobwebbed with clotheslines bearing ruby-lit pictures, past a writer’s desk strewn with photographic proofs, guests at a film screening in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, stepped into the past on Wednesday night: a Swinging ’60s photo studio where a Britpop band rocked out while a gaggle of actors with Twiggyesque doe eyes struck poses in the center of the room, vying for their moment in front of a photographer’s lens.

headline: Morgan Stanley Hires Cravath Partner as Legal Chief
text: 11:00 a.m. | Updated We’ve added the internal announcement from James Gorman.

headline: Storm Continues to Hinder Work on Oil Spill
text: Hurricane Alex, was downgraded Thursday morning to a tropical storm, but it continued to halt progress on containment work in the Gulf of Mexico and threatened to disperse oil farther into the marshes along the Mississippi Delta.

headline: Debate Heats Up Over Oil Sands
text: The debate is heating up over whether the Obama administration should approve a huge new pipeline called Keystone XL that would bring oil extracted from the earth in Alberta, Canada, all the way to Texas for refining. The State Department must grant approval for any transnational pipelines, based on the “national interest.” And as we’ve written, politicians and citizens are divided over whether imported oil sands oil is in the national interest, and how energy needs should be balanced with environmental and safety concerns.

headline: On Our Radar: The Urban Chicken Farmer
text: Tips for the neophyte urban chicken farmer.

headline: New Round of E.C.B. Funding Tempers Optimism
text: FRANKFURT — Higher-than-expected demand for cash from the European Central Bank on Thursday signaled that many banks were still unable to get the funds they needed on the open market, setting back policy makers’ efforts to take banks off life support.

headline: Four Cities Vie for 2012 Democratic Convention
text: Where will President Obama formally open his re-election bid by accepting the Democratic nomination for a second term?

headline: Lindsey Graham, This Year’s Maverick
text: Lindsey Graham was sitting in a sedan early one morning and contentedly discussing the various fellow South Carolina conservatives who dislike him — Tea Partiers, Constitutionalists, immigration hardliners — when Van Cato, his upstate regional director, lifted a hand from the steering wheel and said: “That’s the leader of them right there. There’s his sign. He’s running for Greenville County Council.”

headline: Serena Williams Cruises Into Final
text: Serena Williams defeated Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic, 7-6 (5), 6-2, to advance to her sixth Wimbledon final. Superb serving by Williams was the difference in the match, as time and again Williams thwarted a rally by Kvitova with a service winner, or an ace.

headline: Illegals
text: Undercover Russian agents operating without diplomatic cover.

headline: Thursday Reading: Home Buyers’ Tax Credit Deadline Is Extended
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Franklin and Rice Team Up for Benefit Concert
text: One’s the Queen of Soul, who performed at the inauguration of President Obama; the other’s a classically trained pianist who has worked with Yo-Yo Ma, and was also the former secretary of state and national security adviser to President George W. Bush. Can these two women share a stage and raise money for programs that support inner-city youth programs and education initiatives? They certainly can.

headline: Five Choreographers to Honor Cunningham at River to River Festival
text: Just a few days after the death of their company’s namesake choreographer, dancers from the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gave a memorable performance as part of the 2009 River to River Festival, which drew more than 3,000 people to Battery Park City in Manhattan. Now, almost a year later, five choreographers will pay their respects to Cunningham in a program titled “We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An EVENT for Merce,” on the Esplanade Plaza at Battery Park City on July 26 at 6 p.m. Lucinda Childs, Bill T. Jones, Susan Marshall, Jon Kinzel and Faye Driscoll will present new dances created for the occasion, as well as existing works inspired by Cunningham’s Events pieces. The musicians David Eggar, Geoff Gersh and Kotchy will also perform at the free event, which is also presented by arts>World Financial Center and the Battery Park City Authority and produced by the choreographer Annie-B Parson. “Rather than speeches or prayers, we use his structures to remember him on this day,” Ms. Parson said in a statement. “We try them on our work, just for a day, as a way to remember the father of postmodernism.”

headline: Young People: Hopeful, or Just Realistic?
text: Yesterday I wrote about survey findings that showed young people were most optimistic about their earnings over the coming year. In fact, the older the respondent, the less likely they were to say their financial circumstances would improve in the next year.

headline: Stock Rises as Icahn and Lions Gate Continue Duel
text: Carl C. Icahn predicted that the stock price of Lions Gate Entertainment would go down after his $7-a-share hostile tender offer expired. Instead, the stock went up on Thursday as the billionaire financier and the movie studio issued dueling press releases shortly after the stock market opened, each declaring a victory of sorts.

headline: Panel Chairman Presses Goldman Sachs on Its Mortgage Bets’ Market Effect
text: A Congressional commission questioned Goldman Sachs and the American International Group executives on Thursday about the way the companies set prices on complex mortgage securities during the financial crisis, when buyers for such assets were scarce.

headline: Williams Makes the Final as Her Serve Does the Work
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Unfamiliarity reigned in the women’s singles semifinals at Wimbledon. Three players ranked outside the top 20 remained. Two were unseeded and unknown. One, Tsvetana Pironkova, lost in doubles qualifying before this tournament.

headline: Follow the Free Agents, 140 Characters at a Time
text: The race is on to court and land N.B.A. free agents and you can follow the action on Twitter, as several of the major players are regularly posting their thoughts in 140-character bursts.

headline: How Mariano Rivera Dominates
text: Most Yankees fans are aware that the key to Mariano Rivera’s success as a closer has been his signature cutter. But to understand exactly how this pitch has worked for Rivera, watch the above video. The Times’s Graham Roberts, Shan Carter and Joe Ward have put together an eye-opening interactive graphic to accompany James Traub’s profile of Rivera in Sunday’s Magazine.

headline: New Vehicle Sales Slowed in June
text: DETROIT  Sales of new vehicles in the United States slowed in June, automakers and analysts said on Thursday, raising concerns that the market’s recovery could be stalling after months of slow but encouraging gains.

headline: A Holiday Weekend, for James and His Suitors
text: So, how are you celebrating LeBron Day? Yes, it’s officially a holiday now. So feel free to skip work, wander around and look at the murals painted in the King’s honor, click between the scores of videos about the King’s impending move, or just face the sun in your favorite “Please Pick Us, LeBron” pose.

headline: Five Questions for High School Musical Award Winner
text: On Monday night, two students each won a $10,000 scholarship when the second annual National High School Musical Theater Awards, also known as the Jimmys, were handed out at the Marquis Theater. (The awards are named after the theater owner James Nederlander, whose company co-sponsored the event.)

text: A nonprofit research group has deployed a new tool for gathering information on conditions in the Hudson: an environmental monitoring station that tracks physical, chemical and biological changes in the river in real time.

text: They’re creepy and they’re kooky, mysterious and spooky. They’re altogether ooky, but one of them has a surprisingly soft side.

headline: Senate Stalwart Returns to Chamber One Last Time
text: Senator Robert C. Byrd made one last visit to the Senate floor on Thursday to allow his colleagues, staff members and the public to bid him a Capitol farewell after his death Monday at 92.

text: The Knicks and the Nets hope that LeBron James’s talents include reversing their embarrassingly low TV ratings.

headline: Climate, Obesity and the Aflac Duck
text: In the wake of Chris Mooney’s latest analysis of ways to bridge the science-society gulf, I’ve been engaged in a fascinating e-mail discussion with a range of people either engaging in, or analyzing, climate communication. Several responses, alluding to everything from the obesity epidemic to the Aflac duck, are worth highlighting here.

headline: Inter- ‘Office’ Memo: Ricky Gervais Wishes Steve Carell Good Luck
text: Though NBC and the producers of “The Office” have yet to comment publicly on Steve Carell‘s recent statements that he plans to leave that comedy after its coming seventh season — one presumes they’re not thrilled — Mr. Carell has received a warm send-off from his trans-Atlantic counterpart, Ricky Gervais.

headline: Paragliding Over Mosul – Because Iraq Just Isn’t Dangerous Enough Already
text: MOSUL, Iraq – The risk-averse will tell you that it takes a special sort of foolishness to jump from a mountain with just a paraglider strapped to your back.

headline: Two First Class Flights to Hong Kong for Economy Prices
text: If you’ve been searching for an affordable flight to Hong Kong this year, today is the day to buy. Starting at 2 p.m. E.S.T., the American Express online marketplace Daily Wish is offering two (only two) round-trip first-class tickets from New York, Los Angeles or San Francisco for $2,000 each (normally, each is a whopping $25,940!).

headline: America, Illustrated
text: IN an age when Democrats and Republicans are barely on speaking terms, you might not think that decades-old paintings of freckled schoolboys and their loyal mutts could help revive the conversation about what we value as a nation. Yet Norman Rockwell’s cheerful America has lately acquired a startling relevance both inside and outside the art world, in part because it symbolizes an era when connectivity did not require a USB cable.

headline: Harmony and Freckles for Tough Times
text: Images from a new exhibition of works by Norman Rockwell.

headline: Talk Therapy Can Be Potent Medicine
text: I’d just finished a family session one Thursday morning when my emergency line rang. A faint voice croaked: “Dr. Deitz. Please. Can you help me?”

headline: Case Study | Rhubarb Syrup
text: Rhubarb grew like weeds in Wisconsin, where I grew up. As young hellions we would pick it, tear off the elephant-ear leaves (which are mildly poisonous) and dip the stalks in sugar to eat. That fibrous green tang remains one of my Proustian tastes of summer. Nowadays I have to buy my rhubarb at the greengrocer, but even at three bucks a pound I consider it a grand find and pounce while I can. I wish I could preserve the taste for the rest of the year, but I’m not a jam maker. So recently I decided to try my hand at making a drinking syrup with it.

headline: Diageo Uses Scotch to Plug Gap in Pension Plan
text: LONDON — Diageo, the maker of Johnnie Walker whiskey, found an innovative way to plug a gaping deficit in its pension plan: put aside 2 million barrels of maturing whiskey from its distilleries in Scotland.

headline: The Chameleons of Madagascar
text: Photographs from Christopher J. Raxworthy’s expedition in search of new chameleon species in Madagascar.

headline: In a Space Probe’s Journey, a Test for Japan
text: TOKYO — The Japanese are calling it a miracle. The Hayabusa space probe returned last month from a seven-year, 382-million-mile round trip to an asteroid, giving a much-needed confidence boost to a country worried that its technological prowess might be waning.

headline: Nascar Nationwide Series Ready to Race New Cars This Weekend
text: Races in the Nascar Nationwide Series, the next rung down on the stock-car ladder from the Sprint Cup Series, only seem to draw attention when Danica Patrick is driving.

headline: Behind The Star, The Coach
text: A BALLET coach means different things to different dancers, but hitting on the right one is like striking gold. In 1986, when Julie Kent joined American Ballet Theater, she was called to a one-on-one rehearsal with Georgina Parkinson, the company’s British ballet mistress.

headline: Practicing What He Once Preached
text: SELDOM is the road not taken as plain to see as in the case of the conductor Will Crutchfield.

headline: The Swype Revolution?
text: It's tough reviewing an Android phone, as I did in today's column. You're reviewing not just a phone, but also its cell network and, most hopelessly of all in limited space, a huge and complex operating system.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Perils of Being Too Funny
text: This summer Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood will be sharing space in their Theater Talkback column with selected visitors from the theater world.

headline: The Well-Tempered Shostakovich
text: IN 1950 Shostakovich attended a competition in Leipzig, Germany, held to honor the bicentennial of Bach’s death. There he was overwhelmed by the Russian pianist Tatiana Nikolayeva’s performance of Bach’s “Well-Tempered Clavier,” two sets of 24 preludes and fugues each. The experience inspired Shostakovich to compose his own set of 24 preludes and fugues in all the major and minor keys (Op. 87). And inspired is the right word, because Shostakovich wrote this magnum opus for piano, 240 pages in the printed score, in just three and a half months.

headline: Huckabee Trying Out a Daily Show for News Corp.
text: Mike Huckabee, the weekend Fox News Channel host and possible 2012 presidential candidate, is getting a six-week tryout as a daily talk show host.

headline: 10 Ways to Use NYTimes.com for Research
text: Whether your topic is the Great Depression or great books, outer space or immigration, George Washington or Barack Obama, here are ten ways to find useful, reliable materials for personal, academic or professional research projects on NYTimes.com.

headline: GABRIEL FAURÉ’: Piano Quartets
text: Trio Wanderer; Antoine Tamestit, violist. Harmonia Mundi HMC 902032; CD.

headline: Europe’s New Austerity: Will It Work?
text: As Europeans start to feel the effects of cuts in social welfare benefits, popular anger is spreading. In Spain, where new austerity measures coincide with a 20 percent unemployment rate, protesters disrupted transit in Madrid this week. In Greece, strikers shut down public services. Ireland, which the government has slashed pay for nurses, professors and other public workers by up to 20 percent, is faced with more belt-tightening.

headline: Per-Capita Emissions Rising in China
text: Carbon dioxide emissions per person in China reached the same level as those in France last year, the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency said Thursday.

headline: BJ’s Shares Climb on Possibility of Buyout
text: Shares of BJ’s Wholesale Club jumped more than 15 percent on Thursday after a private equity firm disclosed that it had bought a large stake in the company and said it planned to talk with the retailer’s management about the possibility of taking the company private.

headline: A Brooklyn Bar’s All-Star Rotation of Mixologists
text: Other bars have impressive lists of cocktails. Tom Chadwick’s bar Dram, which opened in Williamsburg three months ago, has an impressive list of cocktail makers.

headline: The State Budget Disaster
text: An already storm-tossed economy is about to receive a thorough drenching, as states across the nation face a collective budget shortfall of $140 billion this summer.

headline: 36 Hours in Bogotá, Colombia
text: THERE seems to be a fine line between a drug-war battlefield and a hip bohemian city, and Bogotá has crossed it. In just a few years, this subtropical city has clamped down on violence, cleaned up its act and emerged as the trendy capital of Colombian cool, safe enough to visit but still seedy enough to feel far from home. With its stretches of drab urban jungle, Bogotá is not conventionally pretty and its pleasures not immediately clear. But it rewards intrepid travelers who hop across its archipelago of neighborhoods to unearth artistic and cultural gems.

headline: Credit Still Tightening, Fed Governor Says
text: WASHINGTON  The level of outstanding credit in the American economy continues to fall as strong and weak banks alike pull back on lending, worsening the prospects for businesses and consumers to regain their footing, a Federal Reserve governor said Wednesday.

headline: Hair Pulling, Blinking, Tics and Tourette’s
text: Tics and involuntary movements are a hallmark of Tourette’s syndrome, an odd and little understood disorder that has been linked to various abnormalities in the brain. But tics can appear in other illnesses too. Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale Child Study Center are experts on Tourette’s and recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about the syndrome. Here, they address readers concerned about tics, tremors, hair pulling, eating disorders and other ailments that may be related to Tourette’s.

headline: TimesCast | July 1, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on the Kagan hearings, Charlie Crist's independent Senate race, a Tour de France update and a south Louisiana community still recovering from Katrina and the oil spill.

headline: On Edge, Awaiting Jobs Data
text: The June jobs report, which comes out on Friday, will probably look very bad, reinforcing worries that the recovery is teetering. But first impressions might be deceiving.

headline: Storm Slams Mexican Coast
text: BROWNSVILLE, Tex.  Hurricane Alex, the first of the season, largely spared South Texas but churned through fishing villages a hundred miles south on the gulf coast of Mexico, ripping off roofs and forcing evacuations.

headline: Boehner v. White House — Continued, Again
text: Representative John A. Boehner, the top Republican in the House, certainly doesn’t seem to mind being in a war of words with the White House.

headline: Ex-Spy Is a Long Shot to Oust Schumer
text: The last time Gary Berntsen went after such a formidable adversary in hostile territory, he was commanding a small band of fellow spies and commandos in pursuit of Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan after 9/11. After helping drive the Taliban from power, they tracked him to the mountains of Tora Bora, only to see him slip away.

headline: Driving Your Children to Drink
text: Here’s something you might already have guessed — as a parent you have very little influence over whether your child tries alcohol. That’s one finding from a survey of 5,000 children between the ages of 12 and 19, by researchers at Brigham Young University’s College of Family, Home and Social Sciences. Whatever the approach of the parent — strict versus laid back, warm versus distant — the kids who responded were equally likely to take a drink.

headline: Gritty Kiwi Port to Hip Enclave in New Zealand
text: Ahuriri’s transition from seedy port to charming suburb has been decidedly slow.

headline: ‘Promises, Promises’ Says a Little Prayer for LeBron
text: It’s not clear yet whether the newly minted N.B.A. free agent LeBron James will sign with the New York Knicks for many, many millions of dollars. But will he do it for a song? The cast of “Promises, Promises” seems to think it’s worth a shot. In the video above, Mr. James is reminded of all the qualities that might make New York an appealing place to live and play — from Gray’s Papaya to Jazz at Lincoln Center to the abundance of his beloved Fruity Pebbles cereal — in a song performed by that Broadway show’s backup singers. (Apparently, Kristin Chenoweth and Katie Finneran are fine if he stays with the Cleveland Cavaliers.)

headline: La Paz’s Bowler Hat Row
text: One of the postcard images of La Paz is traditionally dressed Bolivian women in layered skirts and a bowler hat. They’re ubiquitous, and many of the women wear the hat, known as “bombín” attached to just the tip-top of their head. How they get them to stay on, I’ll never know.

headline: Once Were Warriors: The Return of Uruguay
text: The World Cup just keeps on going. It’s unstoppable for one month every four years, generating a frenzied cavalcade of villains. Today it’s Cristiano Ronaldo being scolded by former Portugal legend Luis Figo after Tuesday’s loss to Spain for spitting at a cameraman (perhaps) and complaining about the coach (Ronaldo denies the complaining part); the president of Nigeria so angered by the national team’s poor performance that he has withdrawn the Super Eagles from all international competition for two years; and Ashley Cole facing death threats for allegedly texting “I hate England.”

headline: Court Says City Must Keep Struggling Schools Open
text: A state appellate court ruled unanimously Thursday that the city must keep open the 19 schools it moved to close for poor performance, upholding a March ruling from a lower court.

headline: Multiple Savings Accounts, Multiple Goals
text: Personal finance management Web sites like Mint.com and HelloWallet aren’t the only ones trying to make it easier for you to save for your financial goals. A growing number of banks are offering features intended to help you allocate various savings accounts to specific goals.

headline: A Race for Second at the Grand Prix
text: The leader of the tournament won her sixth game on Thursday to take a commanding lead with only four rounds to play.

headline: James Hears Nets’ and Knicks’ Pitches
text: CLEVELAND  They came by private jets, in droves, with fancy presentations and boxes stuffed with technological wizardry. There is nothing simple, or economical, about courting basketball’s greatest free agent.

headline: Gaza's Summer Escape
text: Three years after an economic blockade, a group of surfers in Gaza are sharing what few surfboards there are to teach young people how to ride the waves.

headline: Jazz Breaks Out All Over at the Montreal Jazz Festival
text: Jazz turns up in unexpected places at the Montreal International Jazz Festival. Of course, straight-up jazz — the stuff that in the days of record stores was filed somewhere in the corner beneath a John Coltrane poster — is everywhere among the festival’s 700 events, although even that isn’t always easy to classify: Herbie Hancock, for example, brought songs from his John Lennon-inspired “Imagine Project” album. But when a jazz festival also includes indie-rock and hip-hop groups, Syrian electro-folk singers, Eastern European-style brass dance bands and banjo-playing former Ramones, it can be surprising where jazz threads turn up, and in five concerts on Wednesday night they turned up all over.

headline: Palestinian President Reaches Out to Israelis
text: TEL AVIV  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, made a rare effort to reach out directly to the Israeli public, calling on Israel’s leadership to step up peace efforts while suggesting that his people were growing weary waiting for a state.

headline: Confirmation Is Likely, but Not G.O.P. Support

headline: In Amsterdam, a Jazz Beat

headline: Robert and Clara and Sting and Trudie
text: Crossover projects in classical music have traditionally been matters of opera singers or big-ticket instrumentalists performing jazz, pop or folk music, usually not as well as the musicians who perform this material full time. But since the late 1980s, crossover has moved in the other direction too. Stewart Copeland and Roger Waters have written operas; Paul McCartney has written a stream of orchestral, choral and piano works; Elvis Costello has composed a ballet; and Sting  Mr. Copeland’s onetime colleague in the Police  has undertaken several performance projects, most notably “Songs From the Labyrinth,” a 2006 CD of John Dowland songs and lute pieces, performed with a pop singer’s freedom and unpolished vocal tone.

headline: Obama Urges Fix to ‘Broken’ Immigration System
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama pressed Congress on Thursday to adopt a sweeping plan to fix a “fundamentally broken” immigration system, taking on a volatile issue that has inflamed passions in a weak economy heading into the fall midterm campaign.

headline: Britain Curbing Airport Growth to Aid Climate
text: In a bold if lonely environmental stand, Britain’s coalition government has set out to curb the growth of what has been called “binge flying” by refusing to build new runways around London to accommodate more planes.

headline: Restaurant Review: Bibiana Osteria-Enoteca in Washington, D.C.

headline: Locavore Lodging Picks Up Steam

While locavore lodging is not new to eco-resorts, it has cropped up in unlikely —  less rural — settings.

No? Well, the punch line, which involves the three of them seated on the train, has to be seen rather than heard.

headline: Mafiosos’ Retreats, Peacefully Repurposed in Sicily
text: IT could have been the rural retreat of a hedge-fund magnate or an Italian prince: a two-story villa of beige stucco and stone, perched in isolation on a rise overlooking the Jato Valley in northern Sicily. The front doors opened onto a refurbished dining room with high ceilings, terra-cotta tile floors and a row of stone arches that suggested a Roman amphitheater. Antique brass lanterns, pottery and other curios hung from the walls. Soft light filtered through the windows. It was getting toward lunch, and in the spacious kitchen, three chefs were preparing dessert: miniature pastries made with honey and chestnuts cultivated in nearby orchards. A narrow staircase wound upstairs to the villa’s three rustic bedrooms, with 10 beds, each of which looked out upon pale-green meadows sloping upward toward bald-faced granite mountains.

headline: Arts Thrive in Leipzig, Bach’s Backyard
text: ON a recent Saturday night in Connewitz, an emerging neighborhood of artists and students in Leipzig, Germany, the streets were buzzing. At Werk II, a former factory complex, a group of hoodie-clad 20-somethings drank beer in a cobblestone courtyard, waiting for the Canadian indie rock band Wolf Parade to perform after a guitar-heavy set from the Dutch band We vs. Death.

headline: Lacking G.O.P. Largess, Crist Turns to Democrats
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Gov. Charlie Crist seemed very much in his element as he worked the room at a fund-raiser here last week  clapping backs, leaning in for small talk, touching an elbow here and a shoulder there, always making sure to introduce himself: “Hi, I’m Charlie.”

headline: Scientists Cite Fastest Case of Human Evolution
text: Tibetans live at altitudes of 13,000 feet, breathing air that has 40 percent less oxygen than is available at sea level, yet suffer very little mountain sickness. The reason, according to a team of biologists in China, is human evolution, in what may be the most recent and fastest instance detected so far.

headline: China Asserts Role in Choosing Dalai Lama
text: SHIGATSE, Tibet  Reincarnations of Tibetan spiritual leaders, including the Dalai Lama, must be approved by the Chinese central government, a senior Communist Party official said. The remarks were among the clearest indications yet that China will appoint a reincarnation of the Dalai Lama after the current Dalai Lama dies, setting off a struggle with exiled leaders of the Chinese territory over Tibetan Buddhism.

headline: Things We Already Knew
text: The Congressional Budget Office is out with another dire report on our long-term fiscal trajectory, and for some reason liberal commentators have decided to tout the C.B.O.’s “current law” scenario — in which all kinds of politically unpalatable tax increases and spending cuts take effect, instead of being set aside the way the C.B.O. expects them to be — as evidence that our situation is more manageable than it looks.  “The surprising message from the Congressional Budget Office,” Matt Yglesias writes, “is that despite aging and health care costs if we allow — as scheduled — the Bush tax cuts to fully expire and allow the [Alternative Minimum Tax] to afflict more and more relatively well-off but not super-rich people, then we’re in decent shape. It’s a call not to action, but inaction.”

headline: Answers About Gay Youth in New York, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Kai Wright, the author of “Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York” (Beacon Press, January 2008), who is responding to readers’ questions about gay youth in New York City, the challenges they face and the future lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community they are creating.

headline: Off the Menu: One Less Bouley Restaurant, Three More Birdbath Bakeries
text: David Bouley is closing his restaurant Upstairs, at 130 West Broadway, on Saturday. On July 19 12 it will become Bouley Studio, a catering operation that will also offer cooking classes. On Wednesday and Thursday nights he will have special dinners for the public in the second-floor space prepared by visiting chefs. There will be 28 seats and no reservations. On the street level, there will be a store selling breads, pastries and some prepared foods like sandwiches, burgers and roast chicken. There will be some seats outside.

The bay’s salt marshes, islands and shallow waterways provide a home to hundreds of species of birds and marine life, from peregrine falcons to sea turtles.

headline: With Her Will, Serena Williams Finds a Way
text: I watched Serena Williams win over Petra Kvitova in its entirety, and I came away thinking that Serena wins with her mind and her serve. She has such extraordinary belief in herself that she often seems to will herself through the tough moments of a match. Her serve seems to be the outward manifestation of her inner belief, and she has the champion’s ability to play her finest tennis when it counts the most.

text: ISLAMABAD  Two suicide bombers struck Pakistan’s most important Sufi shrine on Thursday night, a devastating attack by hard-line militants on the moderate, more flexible blend of Islam that is practiced by most Pakistanis.

headline: Letter: What Is I.B.M.’s Watson?
text: While an artificial-intelligence system like Watson can produce some striking connections, it nevertheless embodies a decisive limitation as it seeks to simulate human problem-solving performance: it begins by using logic. But when mathematicians, scientists and other experts at problem-solving are studied and asked to elucidate their problem-solving processes, they regularly report that they work first in intuitive images, irreducible to logic and often visionary or dreamlike. It is only after they have “seen around the corner” that logical reasoning is engaged, to systematize the findings and make them coherent. The ultimate challenge for computer science is not artificial intelligence but artificial imagination.

headline: Why Job Growth May Be Better Than It Seems
text: Tomorrow’s jobs report will probably look bad, as Catherine Rampell explains. The bad headlines news could be just a mirage — if the private sector adds a lot of jobs (say, 150,000 or more) while the Census cuts a lot of jobs. Or the report may actually be bad — if private-sector job growth was as weak in June as it was in May (41,000) and the recovery seems to be stalling.

headline: Letters: My Father’s Broken Heart
text: Katy Butler’s fearlessly written memoir struck a chord with me. At age 83, shortly after fulfilling a lifelong dream of obtaining a college degree, my proud and proper father had triple-bypass and valve-replacement surgery and was never the same, emotionally or intellectually. His heart and lung rhythms could never be properly regulated, so he received a pacemaker, which extended his foggy and diminished life until 93. My parents, and many of their generation, revere doctors and would never dare question this bill of goods that they are sold. I cheer the memory of Katy’s mother. Her staunch self-reliance in the face of her husband’s and then her own decline is remarkable.ANN L. HYMANNew York

headline: Toyota Says Faulty Engines in 137,000 Cars in the U.S.
text: 5:07 p.m. | Updated  Lexus said on Friday that the models being recalled were the 2006-8 GS, IS and LS with the 3.5-liter V-6 or 4.6- and 5-liter V-8 engines. Toyota said “there is a remote possibility that abnormal engine noise or idling may occur,” but stalling was also possible. The automaker said the “likelihood of a customer vehicle experiencing this condition is two-tenths of 1 percent. Lexus has received no reports of accidents or injuries related to the problem. No vehicles from the current 2010 model year nor 2009 are affected.”

headline: Icahn Buys More Lions Gate Stock After Offer Ends

headline: At Box Office, ‘Twilight’ Continues to Knock ‘Em (Un)dead
text: With “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” now playing in 4,468 theaters in North America – the widest opening on record – the movie’s vampires and werewolves are expectedly setting the box office on fire. “Eclipse” sold $68.5 million on Wednesday (including the 12:01 a.m. showings), breaking a record for the biggest mid-week gross in history, according to Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the series. (“Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” which sold $62 million on a Wednesday last summer, will now have to make do with second place.) Opening-day audiences were 80 percent female, which has become standard for the “Twilight” series, based on the best-selling books by Stephenie Meyer. The question for “Eclipse” was never about whether it would open big – that was a given – but whether it would generate bang-up repeat business and lure even more fans to the franchise. The answer will come in the days ahead but exit polls signal that “Eclipse” could achieve those goals through strong word of mouth: CinemaScore, the market research company, said audiences rate the film an A, which is higher than the grade given to its predecessor, “The Twilight Saga: New Moon.”

headline: An Explosion of Samsung Galaxies
text: About two weeks ago, I wrote about the Samsung Captivate, the first of the company’s new Galaxy S class of phones, scheduled for introduction on the AT&T network. Now, several other carriers —Sprint, T-Mobile, Verizon and U.S. Cellular — have announced that they will carry their own Samsung Galaxy phones.

headline: Domestic Workers’ Rights Bill Passes
text: ALBANY — New York lawmakers on Thursday approved the first law in the nation granting workplace rights to domestic workers such as nannies and housekeepers, a major victory for workers’ advocates and one with sweeping implications for the estimated 200,000 such workers in the New York City metropolitan area.The Assembly was also poised to pass a law that would allow no-fault divorce by married couples. The law, which has already passed the State Senate, would make New York the last state in the nation to allow for some version of no-fault divorce.

C. Sabathia said.

headline: Alex Moves Inland
text: At about 10pm EDT, Alex made landfall in a rural part of Mexico between the towns of La Pesca and Punta de Piedra at an intensity of 90kts and 948mb. It was on an intensifying trend, which tends to make the conditions a bit more severe than if it were weakening or steady at the time (the storm is more coupled with the boundary layer and stronger winds can mix down to the surface). There have been several tornadoes already reported in association with Alex, mostly in the Brownsville area. Rainfall is the big problem for northern Mexico and southern Texas. Cameron County (the southern tip of Texas) received anywhere from 5-9″ of rain yesterday, and it’s not over. An additional foot of rain is possible over these areas as the storm decays. Up by Galveston, nearly 2″ of rain fell as of this morning. Unfortunately, I wasn’t able to locate any real-time rainfall totals from Mexico, but general reports are claiming 6-12″ have fallen so far in coastal areas and 20″+ over the higher terrain further inland.

headline: Jealousy, Blow Thy Mighty Winds!
text: There’s a whole lot of yelling going on in the country of Sicilia, where the king’s psychotic jealousy has put everyone on edge. In Michael Greif’s emotionally blunt production of “The Winter’s Tale” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, voices are raised to the heavens in agitation, indignation, supplication, imprecation and protestation. In this mythical land of wonder and woe, the motto seems to be that if you have something to say, say it with volume.

headline: Reordering Borders of Illusion and Reality
text: The choreographer Christine Elmo has described her work as “performance that hyper-accentuates the fourth wall.” In her one-off dance “This is the end,” Wednesday night at the Kate Werble Gallery, Ms. Elmo’s witty representation was dead on. In this nontraditional space she manipulated the sensation of order and chaos, using audience members to fill in the borders of the performance area like a frame, or demanding that they go elsewhere.

headline: Assessing Great Directors
