headline: Back When Men Shared Secrets
text: No one’s been better than Ann Beattie at dropping a couple of brand names, book and movie titles or references to food and fashion to conjure a particular time and place and circumstance. The smart young denizens of the ’70s and ’80s who populate her best-known fiction tend to be clever, artsy types who, if they haven’t attended a notable university or law school, are taking night-school courses in poetry. They smoke joints, drink wine spritzers, eat ramen noodles, underline Russian novels and quote Wallace Stevens. They wear jackets from L. L. Bean, listen to Lou Reed, make mixtapes and know things like how to identify a Limoges plate without looking at the back.

headline: Inspiration Through Movement

Casting is the key here, and Ms. Finzi chose wisely: Irlan Santos da Silva and Isabela Coracy, teenagers when the film was made, leap off the screen as effortlessly as they fly through the air onstage. Mr. Santos da Silva is particularly mesmerizing, as a dancer and a personality; there’s not much suspense regarding whether he will land a spot with a major ballet company.

The report released today examined the last of four focused questions about his work methods. A panel cleared him of wrongdoing on three questions in February.

text: Every spring American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet play opposite each other at Lincoln Center, naturally inviting the old essay command, compare and contrast.

headline: Commentary That’s Both Visual and Vocal
text: Marina Abramovic’s survey has come and gone, but another longtime performance artist is at large in the Museum of Modern Art. You probably won’t see this one, but you’ll definitely hear visitors carrying out her instructions to step up to a microphone and scream.

headline: Kagan Reminds Senators: Legislation Is Your Job
text: WASHINGTON  Supreme Court confirmation hearings are usually designed to probe a nominee’s conception of the role of the justices. But this week’s questioning of Elena Kagan turned into a tutorial on Congressional responsibility.

headline: Filmmakers Get Personal
text: Depending on who’s watching, a better title for “Great Directors” might be “A Few Great Directors and Some Highly Competent Ones.” Truth in advertising aside, this spasmodically entertaining documentary from Angela Ismailos chronicles her globe-trotting goal of interviewing 10 of her personal cinematic heroes.

headline: Art? Life? Must We Choose?
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  The Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College here may or may not have intended a pair of summer exhibitions on view at its CCS Galleries and Hessel Museum of Art as a parable for the ideological rifts that characterize our artistic moment. But that is the combined effect of “Philippe Parreno” and “At Home/Not at Home: Works From the Collection of Martin and Rebecca Eisenberg.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Art

headline: Anthems of All Kinds Sail to the Stages
text: THE Fourth of July is approaching rapidly, and just behind it comes the deluge: summer shows at every turn, of all stripes. There are eclectic festivals, outdoor park concerts, big-tent nostalgia-rock tours, and sweaty shows in out-of-the-way spaces with questionable commitment to air-conditioning.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Chevy Volt’s Rollout to Include New York City
text: The Chevrolet Volt is expanding its horizons, with General Motors’ chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., announcing Thursday that the plug-in hybrid, due at the end of this year, would be introduced in four additional states: Texas, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: An Alternate Universe of Art
text: Images from a pair of summer exhibitions at Bard College.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: DAN ZANES JAM & JUBILEE

headline: Floating Away
text: “Beautiful Islands,” the fourth documentary from the Japanese filmmaker Tomoko Kana, captures the effects of global warming on the inhabitants of imperiled islands: the South Pacific archipelago of Tuvalu; Venice; and Shishmaref, Alaska.

headline: Climate Scientist Cleared of Altering Data
text: An American scientist accused of manipulating research findings on climate science was cleared of that charge by his university on Thursday, the latest in a string of reports to find little substance in the allegations known as Climategate.

headline: Theater Listings: July 2 — 8
text: Theater

headline: The Swype Revolution?
text: It’s tough reviewing an Android phone, as I did in today’s column. You’re reviewing not just a phone, but also its cell network and, most hopelessly of all in limited space, a huge and complex operating system.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Cantwell to Back Financial Regulation Bill
text: 7:23 p.m. | Updated  Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, is planning to announce her support of the sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system.

headline: Nine to Know: Three Triples in One Game
text: It was Henry Aaron who said: “The triple is the most exciting play in baseball. Home runs win a lot of games, but I never understood why fans are so obsessed with them.”

headline: Uneasy Friend
text: I opened a Facebook account, hoping my teenage daughters would “friend” me. (They did not.) But a 16-year-old classmate of theirs did ask me to be her friend, and I accepted. Since then, the girl has posted several swear words, an ill-conceived rant about baby-sitting, and some mild sexual content. I’ve considered sending her an anonymous note about how these postings might negatively affect her. I don’t want to confront her on Facebook, and I’d hate for her to retaliate against my daughters. What should I do?

headline: Disney Buys Tapulous, Maker of Music Game Applications
text: The Walt Disney Company said on Thursday that it had bought Tapulous, a start-up company that makes music-based games for the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: France Calls Google a Monopoly
text: It is fun to run a monopoly. But in the long run, it can be a lot less enjoyable to own one.

headline: The Tangle of Biology and Choice
text: EVER since I figured out in high school that my parents had married at 21 not for love, although there had been that, but because of an unplanned pregnancy, I have wondered about the implications of this truth. It forced me not only to reimagine who my parents were  that they’d been impulsive once, capable of making the mistakes they had so often warned their children about  but also to question what their relationship meant.

headline: Empire of Desire
text: If any readers have doubted that David Mitchell is phenomenally talented and capable of vaulting wonders on the page, they have been heretofore silent. Mitchell is almost universally acknowledged as the real deal. His best-known book, “Cloud Atlas,” is one of those how-the-holy-hell-did-he-do-it? modern classics that no doubt is — and should be — read by any student of contemporary literature.

headline: Photo Replay: July 1
text: A view of the day in sports, including one misunderstood home run, as well as preparations for the Wimbledon final, the Tour de France and  World Cup soccer.

headline: For Holiday, Paterson Is Vetoing, and Vetoing
text: ALBANY — Except for an occasional break to rest his hand, Gov. David A. Paterson spent most of Thursday vetoing thousands of legislative earmarks as lawmakers prepared to depart for the Fourth of July holiday with the state’s budget incomplete and negotiations at a near halt.

headline: Stowaways That Are Disgusting, Even Deadly
text: What do mice, mosquitoes, scorpions and maggots have in common? They all breeze past airport security, and they do not seem to mind flying coach.

headline: Against Ghana, Uruguay Will Be the Villain Again
text: JOHANNESBURG  Uruguay Coach Óscar Tabárez, a former school teacher, has a keen sense of history. He knows his team can’t escape its past, but he is confident it can write a new chapter Friday, when Uruguay plays Ghana in a quarterfinal at Soccer City.

headline: The Chip That Stacks Adds a Multigrain Twist
text: IS there any such thing as a healthy-sounding snack that also tastes good? Procter & Gamble is betting that the answer is yes by introducing a multigrain version of its popular snack-in-a-canister, Pringles.

headline: In Blow to Bloomberg, City Must Keep 19 Failing Schools Open
text: A state appellate court ruled unanimously on Thursday that New York City must keep open 19 schools it wanted to close for poor performance, blocking one of the Bloomberg administration’s signature efforts to improve the educational system.

headline: A Lone Figure, Standing Upright Amid the Cyclone
text: THE American silent cinema of the 1920s gave us three great comedians: Harold Lloyd, whose hyperkinetic optimism seemed the perfect embodiment of his epoch; Charles Chaplin, whose Victorian sentimentality was just a touching bit behind it; and Buster Keaton, who was so far ahead of his time that we’re still running to catch up with him.

headline: Supermodel Called to Testify at War Crimes Trial
text: PARIS  Diamonds may well be a girl’s best friend, but perhaps no longer for the model Naomi Campbell, who was summoned Thursday to appear at a war crimes trial to state under oath whether she was given a handful of diamonds by Charles G. Taylor, the deposed president of Liberia.

headline: Auto Sales Fail to Reflect Statistical Indicators
text: Auto sales should be accelerating in the United States — at least according to a spate of rosy statistics. But June’s numbers, released on Thursday, showed annual sales stuck in the low 11 million, better than last year, but way off the typical rate of 16 million before the crash. If only customers weren’t so jittery about the economy.

headline: Israelis, Palestinians and the Divide
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Haiti’s Quake, Another Form of Horror
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mythic Past, Resonating in the Present
text: MUMBAI

headline: In South Africa, Diversions Far From the Field
text: Pilanesberg, South Africa

headline: Armstrong, Under Cloud, Has 2,000 Miles to Go
text: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  At the Tour de France’s team presentation Thursday, Lance Armstrong pedaled onto an outdoor stage in this cycling-crazy city, where the number of commuters on bikes seems to rival those in cars.

headline: Obama and Guantánamo
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paul and Kirk Post Seven-Figure Quarters
text: July may barely be here, but candidates’ fund-raising totals from the second quarter are already starting to trickle out.

headline: How We Vote for President
text: To the Editor:

headline: Decades of Untapped Authority
text: Before he became pope, Benedict XVI held a critical decision-making position in the Vatican that had authority over cases involving priests who sexually molested children, but did not assert it for many years.

headline: Church Office Failed to Act on Abuse Scandal
text: In its long struggle to grapple with sexual abuse, the Vatican often cites as a major turning point the decision in 2001 to give the office led by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger the authority to cut through a morass of bureaucracy and handle abuse cases directly.

headline: Car Pools on Bridge: New Fares, New Anxiety
text: Nikki Schrager, a 67-year-old sculptor, hopped in the gray Acura beneath the freeway near Lake Merritt and quickly violated the first unwritten rule of casual car pooling: the driver always controls the radio.

headline: Plus Sizes for Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toyota Recalling 270,000 Lexus Cars
text: Toyota Motor said Friday that it was preparing a global recall of 270,000 cars, including luxury Lexus sedans, to fix an engine problem that could cause them to stall.

headline: China Puts Best Face Forward With News Channel
text: SHANGHAI  The Xinhua News Agency, China’s dominant news service and the propaganda arm of the Communist Party, introduced a 24-hour English-language news channel and is preparing to open a prominent newsroom in Times Square, part of an expensive push to increase the reach and influence of the Chinese news media overseas.

headline: 2 Nuclear Power Plants Approved by Finland
text: The Finnish Parliament approved the construction of two nuclear power plants on Thursday, the latest victory for proponents of atomic energy in Europe.

headline: Brokers’ Entrance Into Market Bodes Ill for Renters
text: In Armistead Maupin’s beloved novel “Tales of the City,” Anna Madrigal personified the archetypal San Francisco landlord  a caring, free-spirited matriarch to the colorful residents of a quirky, old building.

headline: Tax Accord With Mining Firms
text: The prime minister of Australia, Julia Gillard, reached an agreement with mining companies on a new resources tax, ending a dispute that had cost her predecessor, Kevin Rudd, his job.

headline: Berlin Footnotes
text: Berlin

headline: Keeping Score: 149 Pitches? Once Shouldn’t Hurt
text: Arizona Diamondbacks Manager A.J. Hinch did something odd after his pitcher Edwin Jackson threw a no-hitter last Friday: He defended his decision not to pull Jackson from the game. When a starter has not allowed any hits, a manager ought to feel comfortable leaving him in the game.

headline: A Math Problem Solver Declines a $1 Million Prize
text: Grisha Perelman has finally spoken.

headline: Lobbyist Says It’s Not About Influence
text: WASHINGTON — On the eve of a critical Congressional vote last week on a sweeping measure to regulate Wall Street, the prominent lobbyist Tony Podesta met with one of the lawmakers to go over some final language and discuss the effect it could have on his many corporate clients.

headline: The Uptown Outpost Called the Hispanic Society
text: AUDUBON TERRACE started with so much promise, a visionary acropolis for a growing city. But the stupendous neo-Classical complex at 155th and Broadway wound up high and dry, far from the madding crowd of museums, and three of its five constituent organizations have decamped.

headline: Kidnap Victim Wins Settlement
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The California Legislature approved on Thursday a $20 million payment to Jaycee Dugard, who was kidnapped as an 11-year-old and held captive for 18 years, and the two children she bore by her abductor.

headline: Pay Your Nanny on the Books
text: Los Angeles

headline: Two Competing Visions of a European Economy
text: BRUSSELS  The market storm over the fate of the euro has calmed to prevailing winds, but there is considerable nervousness here over the economic health of Spain, the impact of austerity on long-term growth and continuing differences between France and Germany over the economic direction of the European Union.

headline: Terrorists’ Magazine, Now in English
text: The English is crude and clunky, almost to the point of being laughable. The pictures look like bad Photoshop jobs.

headline: East African Countries Form a Common Market
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  The world’s newest common market was created Thursday when a regional bloc of five east African countries freed up the movement of people, products and capital across borders, furthering East Africa’s dream of broad political unification.

headline: Obama Signs Into Law Tighter Sanctions on Iran
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday signed into law new unilateral American sanctions on Iran that go beyond the penalties imposed by the United Nations last month as he tries to escalate the pressure on Tehran to halt its nuclear enrichment program.

headline: The Hamptons for Procrastinators
text: SUMMER is in full swing in the Hamptons. On the beaches, surfers and piping plovers vie for sand space, and at the Bridgehampton Polo Club the games have begun. In East Hampton, the fresh lobster salad at Claws on Wheels is selling briskly at $60 a pound. Every weekend, the parade of cars from the city snags horribly in Water Mill. And renters have returned in large numbers to snap up houses from Southampton to Montauk.

headline: Knicks Have Little to Offer LeBron James
text: For two years, the Knicks have been selling hope at exorbitant prices and depositing the receipts in a high-risk account, to be used primarily this summer on LeBron James. All along, there has been a disquieting undercurrent to the plan, the specter of presumption or delusion.

headline: A New Web Site Aims to Track the Use of Taxpayer Money in New York
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s office spent a total of $5,500 on three alcohol purchases at a liquor store on the Upper East Side. The New York City Board of Elections spent more than $472,000 on car service over five months.

headline: Woods’s Practice Partner Eclipses Him at the AT&T
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  Although Arjun Atwal of India has won 10 times around the world and has played in more than 100 PGA Tour events, he is not among the tour’s most recognizable players. But Atwal, perhaps best known as Tiger Woods’s regular practice-round partner, made good use of the sponsor exemption that Woods helped him get and shot a 66 on Thursday to tie for the lead in the AT&T National at Aronimink Golf Club.

headline: Rising Tide of Money Erodes a Long Island Holdout
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — Not long before dark, a large crowd gathered as usual last Saturday at the Montauket Hotel, perched high on a bluff over Fort Pond Bay and known as the best spot on the East End of Long Island to watch the sunset. On the back patio, a man in a “Clam Power” T-shirt lifted an Amstel Light and bellowed along with a Springsteen anthem: “No retreat, baby!”

headline: Christie Gives In, a Little, on Property Taxes
text: TRENTON  Gov. Christopher J. Christie backed away on Thursday from his call for a state constitutional amendment to limit property tax increases to 2.5 percent per year, but insisted that a bill capping taxes passed by the Legislature did not go far enough.

headline: A New Cadre of Factory Workers
text: Employers are now looking to hire higher-skilled workers who can operate sophisticated machinery and demonstrate higher math proficiency than was previously required of the typical assembly line worker.

headline: Among Some, High Marks for Health Care Overhaul’s Beginnings
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama gets high marks, even from some Republicans, for the way he has begun carrying out the new health care law in the 100 days since it was signed. And a new poll suggests a small increase in favorable views of the measure since May.

headline: Uzbeks Accused of Inciting Violence in Kyrgyzstan
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Dozens of Uzbek community, religious and political leaders have been arrested recently by the local police and accused of inciting ethnic violence, rights groups say.

headline: Graduation Is the Goal, Staying Alive the Prize
text: CHICAGO  The bonding moment between Veronica Tinajero and the student she calls Big Sunshine came during one of their first meetings.

headline: High-Rise Dwellers Live the High, High Life
text: MOST Manhattanites look out their windows at the familiar sight of other buildings  or perhaps in at their neighbors’ windows (oops!)  but there are a few who tower over everyone else, in apartments at the top of the skyline. Up there the views are panoramic: entire parks, some half dozen bridges and a whole lot of sky.

headline: Former Afghan Envoy Fights Dismissal
text: Peter W. Galbraith, the former No. 2 United Nations official in Afghanistan, has brought a case against Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, alleging wrongful dismissal and defamation. He is seeking unspecified compensation and reinstatement to a similar position. The case is expected to be heard in September by the United Nations Dispute Tribunal, which settles employment issues within the world body, where national courts have no jurisdiction. Mr. Galbraith, an American diplomat who was dismissed in October 2009 over his accusations that the United Nations was ignoring widespread electoral fraud, said he was pursuing “accountability.” Farhan Haq, a spokesman for Mr. Ban, said the secretary general had no comment.

headline: Judge Hears Arguments on Health Overhaul Challenge
text: RICHMOND, Va.  For the first time since President Obama signed the health care law, the federal government faced off in open court Thursday against one of the 21 states that are seeking to invalidate the law by challenging the requirement that most Americans obtain insurance.

headline: Congressman Seeks Inquiry on Trailers
text: A Mississippi congressman asked the Justice Department on Thursday to investigate the use of potentially contaminated FEMA trailers to house cleanup workers involved with the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Immigration Promise
text: President Obama’s first major speech on immigration had the eloquence and clarity we have come to expect when he engages a wrenching national debate. In declaring the welcome of strangers a core American value, in placing immigrants at the center of the nation’s success and future, Mr. Obama’s exhortation was worthy of the late Senator Edward Kennedy, whose memory he respectfully summoned on Thursday. “Anybody can help us write the next great chapter in our history,” he said, regardless of blood or birth.

headline: Bad News Back Home
text: How bad does it have to get before Congress notices? Kevin Sack reported in The Times on Thursday that budget shortfalls have led 11 states to close enrollment in programs that provide drugs to people with H.I.V. and AIDS. Worse, the number of those turned away is expected to surge in the months ahead as more states defer enrollment and cut eligibility.

headline: When Less Was More
text: We tend to think of the decades immediately following World War II as a time of exuberance and growth, with soldiers returning home by the millions, going off to college on the G.I. Bill and lining up at the marriage bureaus.

headline: Google vs. China, the Sequel
text: As the Chinese Communist Party sees it, its very hold on power depends on tightly controlling the access of ordinary Chinese to information about their country, their rulers and the world at large. When Google decided in March to stop self-censoring search results in China by automatically redirecting queries to its uncensored service in Hong Kong, no one should have been surprised if Beijing rejected the scheme.

headline: Vatican: Pope Picks Interfaith Official
text: Pope Benedict XVI named a Swiss theologian on Thursday as the new head of the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity, an office responsible for the Vatican’s often delicate relations with Eastern Orthodox Christians, Muslims and Jews. Widely seen as a traditionalist, the theologian, Archbishop Kurt Koch, above, 60, is bishop of Basel and has served as head of the Swiss Bishops Conference. He replaces Cardinal Walter Kasper, 77, who won plaudits as the Vatican’s leading promoter of interfaith dialogue and helped defuse tensions between Benedict and Muslims and Jews.

headline: Factory Jobs Return, but Employers Find Skills Shortage
text: BEDFORD, Ohio  Factory owners have been adding jobs slowly but steadily since the beginning of the year, giving a lift to the fragile economic recovery. And because they laid off so many workers  more than two million since the end of 2007  manufacturers now have a vast pool of people to choose from.

headline: Day 72: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: House Passes Bill to Increase Compensation to Victims

headline: Past, Present and Future Justice
text: Everyone will have a favorite moment from Elena Kagan’s Supreme Court confirmation hearing: the nominee’s crack about spending Christmas Day in a Chinese restaurant, for example, or Senator Tom Coburn’s too-clever-by-half effort to draw out her views on the constitutionality of the health-care mandate by asking whether Congress could require every American “to eat three vegetables and three fruits every day.” (Of course Solicitor General Kagan knew what the Oklahoma Republican was driving at, but she wasn’t about to play. “It sounds like a dumb law,” she replied.)

headline: New Leader of Guatemala Investigations
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations has appointed Costa Rica’s attorney general, Francisco Dall’Anese, to lead an international panel fighting organized crime and corruption in Guatemala. Mr. Dall’Anese will replace Carlos Castresana, the outspoken Spanish jurist who resigned last month, complaining that Guatemala needed to do more to reform its justice system. International prosecutors on the International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala have been working with their Guatemalan counterparts to investigate powerful groups that have infiltrated the country’s justice system. As attorney general, Mr. Dall’Anese led corruption investigations of two former Costa Rican presidents.

headline: The Spies Who Came In From the Shopping Mall
text: “A provocation?” asked Mikhail Tripolsky, the editor in chief. “A double game?” he asked his deputy, Leah Moses. The old cold war spy phrases reverberated in the Russkaya Reklama newsroom on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn. The two journalists labored to make sense for their Russian émigré readers of the bizarre spy ring that’s allegedly been snooping and lolling about for years in all the bourgeois comforts of American capitalism.

headline: A Life on the Water, Drying Up
text: Capt. Pete Lacombe has the cabernet nose of a man who spends too much time in the sun. He would prefer to be underwater, diving or showing tourists the wondrous coral reefs of the Florida Keys, but the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has largely kept him onshore.

headline: Jay-Z vs. Spike Lee: Nets May Have the Edge
text: Shoulder-to-shoulder they stand, the new marketing symbols of the New Jersey Nets: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the team’s principal owner, and Jay-Z, the hip hop mogul who has owned a small stake in the team since 2004.

headline: How Two Questions Caused Death Penalty Misstep
text: After five months, the death penalty trial of Ronell Wilson had entered its last few minutes when a federal prosecutor presented some parting thoughts for the jurors to consider as they deliberated.

headline: Such, Such Are His Joys
text: On Wednesday, the essayist Christopher Hitchens announced that he has cancer of the esophagus and will soon begin chemotherapy. There are others who know him better than I who can reflect on his illness.

headline: Accompaniment for Oysters
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I liked this puzzle for a variety of reasons. First, it had a good-looking grid. Second, it was an interesting construction. Third, it had a slightly different vibe to it. Fourth, there were some clever and different clues.

headline: ‘Age-Friendly’? Sometimes, Anyway
text: For some New Yorkers who will never see 65 again, there was reason to smile at the news this week about, of all things, a comic-book figure. Wonder Woman is 69 years old, bless her Amazonian heart, but she’s still going strong. The old gal has even been given a thorough makeover to keep her rocking on for years to come.

headline: Myths of Austerity
text: When I was young and naïve, I believed that important people took positions based on careful consideration of the options. Now I know better. Much of what Serious People believe rests on prejudices, not analysis. And these prejudices are subject to fads and fashions.

headline: N.H.L. Free Agents Are Busy, Too
text: Only a few hours after free agents were allowed to negotiate with any National Hockey League club, defenseman Paul Martin, who had spent his entire six-year N.H.L. career with the Devils, was reported to have agreed to a five-year, $25 million contract with Pittsburgh.

headline: Street Killings Prompt Police to Increase Overnight Patrols
text: The Police Department is increasing overnight patrols after a recent spate of killings on the street, mostly in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 1, 2010

headline: Albany Approves No-Fault Divorce and Domestic Workers’ Rights
text: ALBANY  Lawmakers on Thursday crossed two historic thresholds governing the realm of the home, making New York the first state to grant workplace rights to domestic employees and the last to allow some version of no-fault divorce.

headline: Santana Has Strong Outing, but Mets’ Bats Have Jet Lag
text: WASHINGTON  After a draining three-day trip to Puerto Rico that culminated in a rain-delayed finale late Wednesday night, a weary group of Mets arrived at their hotel here at 7 a.m. Thursday. The conditions, especially for starter Johan Santana, were hardly optimal to prepare for a major league game later in the day.

headline: Elise Boulding, Peace Scholar, Dies at 89
text: Elise Boulding, a sociologist, pacifist feminist and scholar who wrote extensively about conflict resolution in both personal and global relations and who helped establish the academic field known as peace studies, died June 24 in Needham, Mass. She was 89.

headline: Latest Electric Car Will Be a BMW, From the Battery Up
text: BMW lifted the veil this week on its planned battery-powered car, in an indication that it is serious about building a new class of vehicle and delivering substantial numbers to showrooms by 2013.

headline: NASA Extends Its Shuttle Countdown
text: The end of the space shuttle era will end a little later. NASA announced Thursday that the launching of the last space shuttle flight was now intended for early next year. With two flights remaining, the shuttles had been scheduled to be retired by September. But the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer, which was to be taken to the International Space Station next month, ran into technical difficulties, pushing that mission to late November. That flight has now been further pushed back, to Feb. 26, 2011. The launching of the second-to-last shuttle mission has also been delayed, to Nov. 1 instead of Sept. 16.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Tries Again With Gun Ordinance
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago proposed a new gun ordinance Thursday after a Supreme Court ruling this week made the city’s ban on handguns unenforceable. The new ordinance would require owners to register guns and receive safety training. Gun stores would be banned in the city, and guns would be prohibited outside the home. The City Council planned to meet Friday to vote on the proposal.

headline: Someone to Watch Over Them
text: The Chicago school system is the proving ground for an ambitious program to save lives by assigning round-the-clock advocates to the students who are deemed most at risk of being shot.

headline: Oregon: Police Explain Decision to Revisit Gore Case
text: The Portland police on Thursday explained their decision to reopen an investigation into accusations that former Vice President Al Gore made unwanted sexual advances toward a masseuse at a Portland hotel in 2006. In a release, the department said that there were “procedural issues,” including a lack of “command-level review,” when detectives interviewed Mr. Gore’s accuser in 2009. That interview came after several failed efforts to interview her by the police shortly after the incident is supposed to have occurred.

headline: With Verdict in Officer’s Trial Near, Oakland Braces for Violence
text: Evan Shamar, a San Francisco wedding photographer, organized the protests last year after Johannes Mehserle, a BART police officer, fatally shot Oscar Grant III, an unarmed black man, on the platform of the Fruitvale station on New Year’s Day 2009. Thousands took to the streets, and Mr. Shamar said he went home that day, shattered, when the protests turned violent.

headline: In Finishing Comics, a Son Completes a Legacy
text: Mark Bode knew as a toddler that he wanted to be an artist and work with his famous father, Vaughn Bode, the San Francisco underground comics creator. But after his father died in 1975, when Mark was 12, he devoted himself to a different kind of collaboration: polishing his father’s legacy.

headline: Cubs Make Fans Feel Like Wet Noodles
text: The Toyota sign is finally up, an obvious yet unobtrusive sentry standing watch above the left-field bleachers at Wrigley Field. That, folks, is a revenue stream.

headline: Hispanic Sets Agenda for Unions
text: Jorge Ramirez proudly displays a set of boning knives and a sharpening stone in his office high above Millennium Park. The blades belonged to his father, Ruben, a butcher from Mexico who in the 1960s organized meatpacking plant workers in the Back of the Yards neighborhood and the Randolph/Fulton Market.

headline: Blagojevich Trial Shines a Light on Real Politics
text: Rod R. Blagojevich works a salad bar like Bill Clinton worked a rope line.

headline: RV Business Revives, Spreading Economic Benefits Widely
text: ELKHART, Ind.  Working so hard on the assembly line that his T-shirt was soaked, Clint Lehman hustled to build a camper trailer meant for someone else’s vacation. He could not have been happier.

headline: Louis Moyroud Dies at 96; Helped Revolutionize Printing
text: In decades past, the words on this page would have been produced by melting lead to shape it into lines of type that would make up the newspaper’s columns — a process that was universal in the printing industry.

headline: Friday’s Matchups: Netherlands vs. Brazil and Uruguay vs. Ghana
text: Netherlands vs. Brazil

headline: Stocks Fall Ahead of Friday’s Employment Report
text: Stocks fell Thursday as manufacturing and labor market data heightened fears of a double-dip recession before Friday’s crucial employment report.

headline: House Passes $80 Billion War Spending Bill
text: The House approved a war spending bill on Thursday with a provision that would include $10 billion to help school districts avoid educator layoffs, paying for the effort, in part, with $800 million in cuts to several of President Obama’s key education initiatives.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about efforts by Broadway producers to draw more black theatergoers erroneously included two productions among those that have used focus groups or canvassed audience opinions. While “Memphis” and “Race” have done so, “Fences” and “Fela!” have not.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Elliott Kastner, Who Produced Literary Films, Dies at 80
text: Elliott Kastner, a producer whose affinity for literary writers and man’s-man movie stars resulted in films like “Harper,” “Where Eagles Dare,” “The Long Goodbye,” “The Missouri Breaks” and “Equus,” died on Wednesday in London, where he had lived and worked for many years. He was 80.

headline: Mexico Makes Arrest in Killing of U.S. Consular Worker
text: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican police said Friday that they had arrested a gang leader who confessed to ordering some of the most horrifying killings in the border city of Ciudad Juárez, including the killing of a pregnant American consular employee and her husband.

headline: Bill Aucoin, Manager of the Rock Band Kiss, Dies at 66
text: Kiss burst on the music scene in the early 1970s with flames, smoke, sirens and explosions. Band members in black leather, high heels and Kabuki-influenced makeup spit fake blood and belched fire to entertain wailing pubescent audiences.

headline: Rammellzee, Hip-Hop and Graffiti Pioneer, Dies at 49
text: Rammellzee, an early graffiti writer, hip-hop pioneer and performance artist whose style influenced the Beastie Boys and Cypress Hill, died on Sunday in Far Rockaway, Queens, where he grew up. He was 49 and lived in Battery Park City in Manhattan.

headline: News Quiz | July 2, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Word of the Day | demotic
text: demotic •\di-ˈmä-tik\• adjective

headline: ‘Twilight Saga: Eclipse’ Devouring Box Office
text: With “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” now playing in 4,468 theaters in North America  the widest opening on record  the movie’s vampires and werewolves are, as expected, setting the box office on fire. “Eclipse” sold $68.5 million on Wednesday (including the 12:01 a.m. showings), breaking a record for the biggest midweek gross in history, according to Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the series. (“Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” which sold $62 million on a Wednesday last summer, will have to make do with second place.) Opening-day audiences were 80 percent female, which has become standard for the “Twilight” series, based on the best-selling books by Stephenie Meyer. The question for “Eclipse” was never about whether it would have a big opening, but whether it would generate bang-up repeat business and lure even more fans to the franchise. The answer will come in the days ahead, but exit polls suggest that “Eclipse” could achieve those goals through strong word of mouth: CinemaScore, the market research company, said audiences rate the film an A, which is higher than the grade given to its predecessor, “The Twilight Saga: New Moon.”

headline: Disney Buys Tapulous to Drive Mobile Strategy
text: The Walt Disney Company said on Thursday that it had bought Tapulous, a start-up company that makes music-based games for the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch, The New York Times’s Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: Prince Charles Defended for Criticizing Buildings
text: A secretary for the Prince of Wales, below, said that the prince considers it his role to represent “the views of ordinary people” on architecture and urban planning, amid a dispute over his involvement in the development of the Chelsea barracks in London, The Guardian reported. Last week a London high court ruled that Qatar Diar, the property company of the Qatari royal family, had breached its contract with a partner company after it withdrew a planning application for a multimillion-dollar development designed by the architect Richard Rogers for the site of a former army barracks. In a letter, the prince wrote that Mr. Rogers’s designs were “unsuitable” for a site so close to the Royal Hospital, which was designed by Christopher Wren, leading Mr. Rogers to accuse the prince of “an abuse of power” and “unconstitutional behavior.” The high court last week said Prince Charles’s campaign against Mr. Rogers’s design was “unwelcome,” reopening the debate about the prince’s role in planning decisions. In the past he has criticized contemporary architecture while favoring restoration and preservation efforts. But Michael Peat, the private secretary to Prince Charles, told The Guardian that the prince opposed the designs because “it is part of the Prince of Wales’s role and duty to make sure the views of ordinary people that might not otherwise be heard receive some exposure.”

headline: Franklin and Rice Stage a Joint Benefit Concert
text: One’s the Queen of Soul, who performed at President Obama’s inauguration; the other’s a classically trained pianist who has worked with Yo-Yo Ma and was the secretary of state and national security adviser to President George W. Bush. Can these two share a stage and raise money for programs supporting urban youth programs and education initiatives? They certainly can. On July 27, Aretha Franklin and Condoleezza Rice will perform at the Mann Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. The benefit concert, which will also feature the Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Rossen Milanov, is billed on the Mann Center’s Web site as “an evening of classics and R-E-S-P-E-C-T,” during which Ms. Rice, above right, will play selections by Mozart and Ms. Franklin, left, will perform songs from her album “A Woman Falling Out of Love.” Ms. Franklin said in a statement that Ms. Rice is “a consummate classical pianist,” adding, “Since I sing the arias, I thought that we could do something, a bipartisan effort for our favorite charities.”

headline: Gervais Wishes Carell Well After ‘Office’
text: Though NBC and the producers of “The Office” have yet to comment publicly on Steve Carell’s recent statements that he plans to leave that sitcom after its coming seventh season  one presumes they’re not thrilled  Mr. Carell has received a warm send-off from his trans-Atlantic counterpart, Ricky Gervais. Mr. Gervais, a co-creator of the original BBC version of “The Office,” and who starred as David Brent, the oafish paper-company manager who inspired Mr. Carell’s Michael Scott character, wrote on his blog (rickygervais.com) that Mr. Carell’s departure was “of course inevitable (and sad), but I wish him all the luck in the world.” He added: “It was expected of me, as executive producer, to persuade him to stay on. With syndication in full swing the more successful the show remains, the more billions we all make. It was tempting, but the truth is, I believe he is doing the right thing. He’s fulfilled his contract and more, and is a huge film star now.” Mr. Gervais, above left, suggested that Mr. Carell, right, “should move on, continue to do great work, and buy a new house every time ‘The Office’ is repeated somewhere,” but did not comment on the widespread suggestion that an ideal replacement for Mr. Carell on “The Office” could be Mr. Gervais himself.

headline: Exit at Ballet Hispanico
text: Ballet Hispanico’s executive director, Verdery Roosevelt, is leaving the company after 31 years in the job, rounding out a generational shift at the troupe and school. Her departure comes a season after that of Tina Ramirez, its artistic director, who founded the company in 1970. Ballet Hispanico announced no replacement for Ms. Roosevelt, saying the new artistic director, Eduardo Vilaro, would assume her administrative duties in a “transitional period.”

headline: Despite Recession, the Met and Moma Have a Year of Increased Attendance
text: More than 5.2 million people visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art during the fiscal year that ended Wednesday, the institution’s best performance since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Despite the impact of an economy in recession, the number of visitors was up more than 10 percent over the comparable period a year earlier. “Attendance fell by a million” after 9/11, said Harold Holzer, a spokesman for the museum, “and has been working its way back” ever since, “hovering around 4.7 million” in recent years. Visitors from abroad accounted for nearly 40 percent of the attendance, and the single most popular exhibition was “Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art” (above), which opened on April 27, will close on Aug. 15 and has already attracted more than 380,000 visitors. The Museum of Modern Art also reported robust growth in attendance during the fiscal year just ended, drawing more than three million visitors, a record, despite discouraging economic conditions. That was an increase of about 9 percent over last year, with two exhibitions performing especially strongly: “Monet’s Water Lilies” drew 857,386 people, and “Tim Burton” attracted 810,511.

headline: Five Choreographers to Honor Cunningham
text: Just a few days after the death of their company’s namesake, choreographer dancers from the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gave a memorable performance as part of the 2009 River to River Festival, which drew more than 3,000 people to Battery Park City in Manhattan. Now, almost a year later, five choreographers will pay respect to Cunningham in a program, “We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An EVENT for Merce,” on the Esplanade Plaza at Battery Park City on July 26 at 6 p.m. Lucinda Childs, above, Bill T. Jones, Susan Marshall, Jon Kinzel and Faye Driscoll will offer dances created for the occasion, as well as existing works inspired by Cunningham’s Events pieces. The musicians David Eggar, Geoff Gersh and Kotchy will also perform. The event is presented by arts>World Financial Center and the Battery Park City Authority and produced by the choreographer Annie-B Parson.

headline: Reality vs. Reality
text: In the battle of reality competitions on Wednesday, “America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC to first place in the ratings while Fox ranked second with a two-hour ”So You Think You Can Dance.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Talent” attracted 12.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., considerably more than any other program that night. In comparison, “So You Think You Can Dance” delivered an average of 5.8 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. NBC garnered more modest numbers during the rest of prime time as a rebroadcast of Monday’s installment of “America’s Got Talent” drew 7.3 million at 8 and a rerun of “Law & Order: SVU” won the 10 p.m. hour with 6 million viewers. CBS ranked third on the night, followed by ABC; both broadcast lineups entirely of repeats.

headline: Hitchens to Undergo Treatment for Cancer
text: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy. Mr. Hitchens, left, a former smoker who recently quit, made the announcement in a statement through his publisher on Wednesday. “I have been advised by my physician that I must undergo a course of chemotherapy on my esophagus,” he said. “This advice seems persuasive to me. I regret having had to cancel so many engagements at such short notice.” The book, “Hitch-22,” has been on the New York Times best-seller list for three weeks and has received generally favorable reviews.

headline: U.S. House Approves Limits on Pharmaceutical Dealmaking
text: The U.S. House approved a measure restricting the ability of drugmakers to enter agreements that the Federal Trade Commission has said keep generic medicines off the market, Bloomberg News reports.

text: Bank of China shares were halted from trading in Hong Kong and Shanghai after a report said the nation’s third-largest lender by market value plans to raise as much as 60 billion yuan ($8.9 billion) in a rights offer.

headline: G.M.’s Whitacre Says 2010 ‘Great Year’ for I.P.O.
text: General Motors‘ chief executive, Ed Whitacre, said on Thursday that despite low consumer confidence levels, 2010 is a “great year” for a G.M. initial public offering, Reuters reported.

headline: Lobbyist Says It’s About Information, Not Influence
text: For weeks now, the two biggest issues in Congress have been cleaning up Wall Street and cleaning up the Gulf Coast.

headline: A.I.G. Chief and Chairman to Work Out Differences
text: American International Group’s  chief executive, Robert Benmosche,  and its chairman, Harvey Golub, at odds over a botched sale of the company’s Asian life unit, have agreed to work out their differences, a source familiar with the situation said on Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline: Fred Drasner and Avenue Capital Submit Bids for Newsweek
text: The media executive, Fred Drasner, and the investment firm, Avenue Capital Group, submitted separate offers to purchase Newsweek magazine ahead of Thursday’s deadline for final offers, unnamed sources told Bloomberg News.

headline: A BJ’s Buyout Makes Sense, Analysts Say
text: News that private equity firm Green Equity Investors has bought a large stake in BJ’s Wholesale Club, with a view to potentially taking the retailer private, had investors and some analysts applauding the move Thursday, The Boston Globe noted.

headline: Do You Believe in Equal Rights for Women and Men?
text: A new report shows that many people around the world believe that men should receive favorable treatment in some areas, particularly employment and education. What do you think?

headline: U.S. Agency Invests $455 Million in Middle East
text: A United States trade promotion agency will invest up to $455 million in five private equity funds in the Middle East and North Africa as part of President  Obama’s push to bolster ties with the Muslim world, Reuters reported.

headline: Welsh Property Trust Cancels I.P.O. for 2nd Time
text: Welsh Property Trust, the real estate investment trust, on Thursday canceled plans for its initial public offering for the second time in four weeks, after a big price cut on its shares still couldn’t get the deal done, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Investors Close First Republic Buyout
text: An investor group led by Colony Capital and General Atlantic have sewn up their deal to buy First Republic from Bank of America with $1.86 billion in new equity capital, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Tesla Shares Sink as I.P.O. Excitement Wanes
text: Shares of Tesla Motors sank Thursday as the fervor surrounding the electric car maker’s blowout public offering washed away.

headline: Afghan Bombers Storm U.S. Aid Office
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six militants armed with suicide bombs stormed the compound of an American contractor working for the United States Agency for International Development in the northern city of Kunduz on Friday, killing four security officers in an assault that left all the attackers dead, according to Afghan officials and the aid contractor.

headline: Britain’s Chloride Seals Deal With Emerson
text: Chloride Group, the British power supply company, said Friday that it has accepted an improved takeover bid from the American  competitor, Emerson Electric,  that values it at £997 million ($1.5 billion).

headline: Seattle Seahawks 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Can Medical Technology Solve the Health Care Problem?
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Pool Party! (Location: Near Roman Colosseum)
text: Have you ever dreamed of taking a dip, lounging poolside, or sipping cocktails in the shade of the Colosseum in Rome? The summer festival All’Ombra del Colosseo set on the Caelian Hill overlooking the Colosseum valley is probably as close as you can get.

headline: AutoNavi Shares Rise 8% in Debut
text: Shares of  AutoNavi, the Chinese digital map services provider, rose 8 percent in its first day of trading Thursday, following the company’s $107.8 million initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: German Parliament Approves Trading Curbs
text: German lawmakers on Friday approved a government bill that would cement in law and extend curbs on speculative trading practices following the country’s abrupt imposition of restrictions in May, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Suicide Bombers Strike Sufi Shrine in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD  The death toll rose to 42 on Friday after suicide bombers struck Pakistan’s most important Sufi shrine, a devastating attack by hard-line militants on the moderate, more flexible blend of Islam that is practiced by most Pakistanis.

headline: How Wagner Called Hollywood’s Tune
text: Today’s idea: Richard Wagner, pioneer of the leitmotif and the grand synthesis of performance arts, is also the father of the modern film score, an article says — and the father of “sonic branding” in advertising, says another.

headline: Dana Petroleum Surges After K.N.O.C. Takeover Approach
text: Dana Petroleum, a British oil and gas explorer, surged by the highest amount in 19 months in London trading after a takeover approach from Korea National Oil, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: GroupSpaces Attracts Top Investors
text: Index Ventures has ponied up for a $1.3 million financing round for GroupSpaces, a British start-up that provides tools for groups and communities to manage and promote themselves online.

headline: See You in August (I Hope)
text: A big white fish sits in the middle of every room I enter.

headline: Shalom Auslander’s Voice Lessons
text: Over at Tablet, Shalom Auslander (he of “Foreskin’s Lament”) sits down to gear himself up to write and finds his voice being drowned out by a chorus of ardent and doubting others: there’s his mother (“Why must you do this?”) and father (“Do this and you’ll be sorry”), Icarus (“I think I can do this!”) and Daedalus (“I told you that you couldn’t do this”). James Joyce, Dave Eggers, Hitler, Ron Jeremy and Garrison Keillor all weigh in (what, no Ira Glass?), egging him on or foretelling that he’ll soon have egg on his face.

headline: Lions Gate Goes for Poison Pill (Again)
text: As Carl C. Icahn moved to increase his position in Lions Gate Thursday, the movie studio hit back with a maneuver of its own: a poison pill designed to thwart the billionaire investor’s effort to win control of the Santa Monica-based studio.

headline: Skype Puts Video Calls on Your TV
text: Skype has left the desktop.

headline: Lagardére to Begin Canal Plus I.P.O.
text: Lagardère said it would start the process for an initial public offering of its 20 percent stake in the  pay-television company Canal Plus France, after failing to reach an agreement to sell the holding to Vivendi, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: An Inadvertent Star Turn for Ducati
text: When the film “Knight and Day,” starring Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz, was released a couple of weeks ago, most of the publicity focused on the film’s leading actors, who portray a couple hounded across the globe in a series of chases and stunts. The film was a bit of an underachiever at the box office, and some critics weren’t impressed. (Writing in The Times, A.O. Scott called the film a “loud, seemingly interminable, and altogether incoherent entry in the preposterous and proliferating ‘action-comedy’ genre.”)

headline: N.Y. Hedge Fund Tax May Fall by the Wayside

text: Brad DeLong deals with the substance of this Economist leader; despite complete lack of evidence, the Economist still believes in the confidence fairy. But notice one more thing: the Economist’s blithe declaration that

headline: Tip of the Week: Stripping Formats From a Word Document
text: Microsoft Word lets you format your text with many choices of fonts and styles, as well as in the form of numbered lists, bullet points, indented text and other conventions of modern word-processing. But when a document becomes too cluttered and unwieldy with a lot of formats, there’s a quick and easy way to strip the styles from the text so you can start over. Just select the text and press the Control key and Space bar to convert the selection to plain, unformatted text.

headline: South Africa Convicts Ex-Police Chief
text: JOHANNESBURG  Jackie Selebi, the former police commissioner of South Africa and once a signal figure in international law enforcement, was found guilty of corruption here on Friday.

headline: Berdych Advances to Wimbledon Final
text: John Martin provided live analysis of Tomas Berdych’s victory over Novak Djokovic in the first men’s semifinal at Wimbledon on Friday.

headline: Hybrid Plant Shelved in California
text: The developer of a hybrid biomass solar power plant to be built in California has abruptly canceled the project, underscoring the challenges the state faces in meeting its ambitious renewable energy goals.

text: The train that is the nation’s economic recovery has slowed noticeably, unable to generate enough jobs in the last two months to keep pace with population growth, much less reduce the vast numbers of unemployed Americans.

headline: New ‘Spider-Man’ Finds Its New Spider-Man
text: Normally the eve of a holiday weekend is an opportune moment for an organization to announce drastic layoffs or to put out reams of documents for dirt-diggers to sift through. For Sony, this is the ideal time to announce that it has found a new actor to star in its lucrative “Spider-Man” movie franchise.

Still others spun with seeming aplomb — right before thwacking into a fellow dancer. Thursday was the third evening of the annual Midsummer Night Swing festival, which includes 15 nights of dancing to live music outdoors in Damrosch Park, in the southwest corner of Lincoln Center’s grounds.

headline: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Changes
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: 10 Lilith Tour Dates Are Canceled
text: In a major blow to the 2010 Lilith Tour, the female-centric music festival has announced the cancellation of 10 of its planned dates in July and August.

headline: The Early Word: 9.5 Percent
text: The unemployment rate fell to 9.5 percent in June, even as the economy shed around 125,000 jobs — in large part because of the loss of temporary census jobs.

headline: The Aesthetics of the iPad
text: At its christening in April, the Apple iPad was declared an instrument for consumers of media — a sort of cultural spoon. This struck many as bad news. Though the Web would seem to have blurred the line between content producers and content consumers, old antagonisms die hard. Producers are still imagined as lean, fierce and manly, where consumers are seen as feminized, passive and fat. Alex Payne, a tech entrepreneur, found the iPad disturbing: “a digital consumption machine.” On the great tech site Boing Boing, Cory Doctorow — while resolving never, ever to buy an iPad — took the trouble to remind us that a consumer is (in the novelist William Gibson’s acid words) “something the size of a baby hippo, the color of a week-old boiled potato, that lives by itself, in the dark, in a double-wide on the outskirts of Topeka.”

headline: Hollywood on the Danube
text: BUDAPEST — This picturesque capital in the heart of Central Europe has played many roles over the years.

headline: Markets Head Into Holiday on a Losing Streak
text: Stocks ended the week lower after the government’s jobs report showed another month of weak employment.

headline: City Hall Blues
text: The really bad economic news these days is not from the private sector. Manufacturing companies continue to see higher orders, although the rate of growth has slowed. And today’s job report shows that private sector employment is rising, although not as rapidly as earlier in the year.

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Apologize Well?
text: Everywhere of late, people are saying they are sorry. Gen. Stanley McChrystal, for one, after talking ill of his commander in chief. Or the BP chief executive, Tony Hayward, apologizing for the destruction caused by his company’s oil well. Or Representative Joe Barton apologizing to Hayward and then apologizing for that apology.

headline: The Vuvuzela as Cultural Artifact
text: The drama, the spectacle, the emotion, the persistent low-grade background hum: even before the first weekend of the monthlong World Cup tournament was over, it was clear that at this gathering of some of the planet’s finest athletes, the first breakout star wasn’t a Ronaldo or a Messi; it was an uncountable number of vuvuzelas. “The plastic horns have become a major subplot of the World Cup,” ESPN.com declared, and who could disagree? At an event notable for national grudges with intricate histories, playing out before an expected record worldwide audience, this simple, slightly silly, mass-produced noisemaker/instrument became a highly unlikely symbol of cultural meaning.

headline: The Origins of  ‘One-Off’
text: Donn Barclay e-mails: "I have been hearing and reading the phrase 'one-off' more and more lately. It seems to me that it is a serious bastardization of 'one-of,' as in short for 'one of a kind.' Frankly, it makes absolutely no sense at all."

headline: An American (Vietnamese, Jewish, Catholic) Story
text: It is for a special occasion one recent Sunday that I pull my car into the Jumbo Buffet & Grill parking lot in Harrisburg, Pa., with three of my four foster Vietnamese grandchildren in tow. Jonah, who is 8, just received his first communion in a magnificent midtown church where Masses are held in English and Vietnamese. Lunch at Jumbo Buffet, an Asian-style, all-you-can-eat restaurant, always involves overeating, but we’re excited to celebrate Jonah’s new status in the church.

headline: The Statesman
text: A three-part documentary, “Turmoil and Triumph: The George Shultz Years,” will be shown on PBS on three consecutive Mondays starting July 12. It’s very positive. Yes it is. I’m not complaining. I’m flattered.

headline: Properly Speaking the Improper?
text: I was hired to do the voice-over for a French version of the annual video report of a high-profile religious organization. The video opposes gay marriage, a view untenable to me. During the recording session, I noticed various language errors. Nobody there but me spoke French, and I considered letting these errors go, my guilt-free sabotage. Ultimately  I made the corrections. As a married gay man, I felt ethically compromised even taking this job. Did I betray my tribe by correcting the copy?  SIMON FORTIN, NEW YORK

headline: Inside the List
text: SWEET SIXTEEN: Stephanie Plum, the bounty hunter heroine of Janet Evanovich’s “Sizzling Sixteen,” blazes past Glenn Beck and Stieg Larsson to give Evanovich her 11th consecutive No. 1 hardcover bestseller in the Plum series. If this installment doesn’t have as lip-smacking a title as the previous one, “Finger Lickin’ Fifteen” (new at No. 3 on the mass-market fiction list), consider some of the alternatives submitted to a contest on Evanovich’s Web site last summer. It’s easy to see why she passed on “Slip Slidin’ Sixteen,” “Sloppy Sixteen,” “Tight Jeans Sixteen” and “Latrine Sixteen,” though “Hunk of Sixteen” and “Damn Skippy Sixteen” have a certain potential.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Food for Thought
text: There’s a smorgasbord of new books on lists this week. The softcover edition of “Batman: R.I.P.,” in which the reports of the Caped Crusader’s death are greatly exaggerated, enters at No. 7, while the second volume of “Chew,” about a federal agent who gets psychic impressions from the food he eats, is at No. 10. This latest installment finds him investigating a strange fruit that tastes an awful lot like chicken, which has long been outlawed by the Food and Drug Administration after a widespread outbreak of the bird flu. Yum! (When Vol. 1 hit the list back in January, we talked to John Layman, a writer of the series, about his casting picks for a potential “Chew” film.)

headline: At Her Fingertips
text: From  “The Thorn Birds”  to  “Brideshead Revisited”  to “White Teeth,” the multigenerational family tale can almost always be described in certain ways: it will be long, it will take place over several decades or centuries, its narrative will be tethered to the history of a particular place. But while we may think we know what such a story looks and sounds like, Jane Mendelsohn uses her third novel, “American Music,” to quietly redefine the genre. Although the novel takes place over several generations and more than 80 years of American history (and nearly 400 years of world history), it’s less than 250 pages long. How can something so slim cover so much ground? This breadth is achieved through a series of haunting impressions that trace the story of a family, the history of 20th-century America and the evolution of American music.

headline: Sizing Up Law Firms, Beyond the Fees
text: Early each year and usually with great fanfare, The American Lawyer releases its 100 list, which ranks law firms by various financial metrics.

headline: On Our Radar: Deep-Sea Mining
text: The Chinese government announces plans for deep-sea mining; it will seek copper, nickel and cobalt 5,000 feet down in international waters.

headline: Dyspeptic Living
text: Say hello to Wilson, the eponymous hero of Daniel Clowes’s latest novel-­in-comics. Perhaps he is a hero of our time. But if that phrase makes all you comp-lit majors think of Lermontov’s Pechorin, think again: this haggard, middle-­aged fellow is no dashingly depressive duelist or seducer. Wilson hectors people in coffee shops and hits on his ex-wife with sweet nothings like, “As you know, I certainly never minded a larger woman.”

headline: Friday Reading: Guarantees for Oil-Free Stays
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Singing the Poet Electric
text: “On Whitman” is the second book in Princeton’s series Writers on Writers — here, a poet on a poet. Its author, C. K. Williams, enthusiastically recommends Walt Whitman, and resorts (understandably) to a great deal of quoting. Enthusiasm is an appealing quality, but it calls out for some ­accompanying astringency, and the exclamatory nature of Williams’s prose can become excessive. He makes Whitman the ancestor to the hedonistic sexuality of the ’60s, noting how he broke through “violent repressions”:

headline: Apple Speaks on the Matter of the ‘Death Grip’
text: On Friday, Apple addressed the new iPhone 4’s so-called Death Grip problem, in which holding the phone a certain way may cause reception strength to drop and calls to be lost.

headline: Global CO2 Trends Show Scope of Climate Challenge
text: 1:16 p.m. | Updated There’s still thinking in many quarters that if the United States acts to restrict its emissions of carbon dioxide, the long-lived greenhouse gas at the heart of the climate challenge, the fast-growing developing countries of the world will voluntarily follow. Global data on emissions of carbon dioxide vividly illustrate the wishful nature of such thoughts when considered against powerful underlying trends.

headline: Bleak Outlook for Long-Term Unemployed
text: If you’ve already lost your job, your prospects for finding a new one are looking dismal. Especially if you lost your job a long time ago.

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | Deployment to Afghanistan
text: Our Student Challenge will continue all summer long, and we’ll regularly choose a “favorite” student comment to feature. You can still enter this week’s Challenge here.

headline: The Rebbe of Graceland
text: Bernie Karp, the teenage hero of “The Frozen Rabbi,” Steve Stern’s new novel, is an overfed 15-year-old, scorched to the core from too much television. While searching for a slab of meat in his parents’ basement freezer, the better to simulate the real thing during his compulsive acts of self-love, Bernie finds instead an old rabbi, frozen in a block of ice.

headline: Teaching Children to Apologize
text: “Say you’re sorry,” we tell our children, as if these are magic words, like “Please” and “Thank you” and “Abracadabra.”

headline: Complaint Box | Carding Me? At My Age?
text: I’ve lived twice as long as Mozart, and I look it. Yet it’s not unusual these days to be told I can’t buy a beer until I show an ID. “Nuts” is the four-letter word I will use to describe this lunacy. Carding someone with white hair and liver spots all over his hands is a waste of everyone’s time — mine, those behind me waiting for a beer and the poor counter person following management’s orders.

headline: Worse Than 1982?
text: We’ve previously spent some time comparing the recent recession to the 1980-82 downturn. A new analysis by David Rosnick of the Center for Economic and Policy Research suggests unemployment may be worse than it ever was in the 1980s, even though the unemployment remains lower than the 1982 peak of 10.8 percent:

headline: Nadal Beats Murray to Reach Wimbledon Final
text: 1:22 p.m. | Updated Andy Murray had all of Britain again hoping he could break through at their beloved Wimbledon, especially with his usual tormentor, Roger Federer, already bounce from the draw, but Murray could not get past Rafael Nadal in the semifinals Friday, losing, 6-4, 7-6 (6), 6-4.

headline: Coyote Attacks Put a Suburb on the Alert
text: RYE, N.Y.  Firefighters have searched for them with heat-sensing cameras. Police officers, under orders to kill, have fired shots at them outside dark golf courses. Nerve-racked parents have stayed up late researching their behavior online.

headline: Failure of State Soda Tax Plan Reflects Power of an Antitax Message
text: To understand why Gov. David A. Paterson’s proposed tax on sugary sodas has apparently gone down the drain  despite strong support from good-government groups, editorial pages and health advocates  it is only necessary, political analysts say, to compare these two advertising campaigns:

headline: Ungoverned
text: Meet Eliot, Irwin and the Impostor. Eliot — last name Spitzer — you may already know. He was the jut-jawed, flinty-eyed New Yorker who rose to nationwide fame as the state’s attorney general, the scourge of crooked Wall Street analysts and self-dealing bankers. He swept into the governor’s mansion in 2007 with the biggest electoral mandate in state history and then resigned a year later, disgraced and humiliated, amid revelations that he had patronized prostitutes. Irwin and the Impostor we’re meeting for the first time, courtesy of two books that chronicle Spitzer’s dramatic fall and seek to illuminate, with mixed success, how a seemingly promising career in politics went to such spectacular ruin.

headline: Britain’s Bold Runway Veto
text: Even as heat-trapping emissions from industry are declining in much of the developed world, those from transport continue to rise relentlessly. Flying in particular is a growth industry – in terms of both business and emissions.

headline: French Cooking Made Healthful
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman provides an update of one of the mainstays of classic French cuisine: the rich and creamy white sauce called béchamel:

headline: Getting a New Knee or Hip? Do It Right the First Time
text: THERE is nothing like a new hip or knee to put the spring back in your step. Patients receiving joint implants often are able to resume many of the physical activities they love, even those as vigorous as tennis and hiking. No wonder, then, that joint replacement is growing in popularity.

headline: Toyota Safety: The Million-Dollar Question
text: After my post giving the details of Toyota’s Star Safety System, one reader, using the handle “metrichead,” requested more information on another Toyota safety-related advertising campaign.

headline: Berdych Will Meet Nadal in Wimbledon Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England  The men’s singles finalists at Wimbledon got that far despite opposing styles, pedigrees and strengths.

headline: Ben Franklin Is a Big Fat Idiot
text: I cede pride of place to no man in my esteem and affection for the founding fathers. Obviously, some — Thomas Jefferson, George Washington, Alexander Hamilton — inspire slightly more awe than others (Button Gwinnett, Elbridge Gerry). But even the least renowned of the founding fathers is a titan by comparison with the leaders of today. A titan, I say.

headline: Dirty Politics
text: Washington political thrillers are, for the most part, born to be boring. The hero is usually some high-minded lawyer who’s become disillusioned after placing his trust in a corrupt government official who happens to be a blood relative. Either that or he’s some high-minded former spy who jeopardizes life and pension by coming out of retirement to get mixed up in a preposterous plot involving assassins from un­pronounceable nations.

headline: Up Front: David Pogue
text: As this issue went to press, David Pogue had 4,613 Facebook friends.

headline: Humanity’s Database
text: According to “The Facebook Effect,” Facebook is the second-most-visited Web site on earth (after Google). The average member spends almost an hour there each day. It has more than 400 million active users — over 20 percent of everyone on the Internet — and is growing by 5 percent a month.

headline: Getting Joint Replacements Right
text: Although joint replacements are now routine, they are not fail-safe, reports Lesley Alderman in the Patient Money column.

headline: Hatch Opposes Kagan
text: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican, has announced he will not support Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court, saying he had concerns about her legal experience and judicial philosophy.

headline: Will Sun Valley Yield Any Deals This Year?
text: Last year, the annual Allen & Company media retreat in Sun Valley, Idaho, gave rise to the biggest media deal of 2009, Comcast‘s purchase of a controlling stake in NBC Universal.

headline: China’s Daughter
text: In 1929, an American woman traveled from her home in China to settle her severely impaired daughter in a New Jersey institution. She did so with borrowed money, as she could not afford the fees. The parting was excruciating; she was, she recalled, “nearly destroyed by grief and fear.” The house felt empty on her return to Nanjing, but she knew precisely what to do: “This I decided was the time to begin really to write.”

headline: Latest Andaz Amenity: Farmer’s Market
text: Of all the amenities we featured in our budget boutique roundup, this one was missing: a farmers’ market. Beginning July 10, the Andaz Wall Street, the new Hyatt hotel designed by the Rockwell Group, will play host to a weekly outdoor farmer’s market.

headline: Fighting for Survival
text: Call it the Marley Industrial Complex: an unrelenting stream of companies and commodities branded by a certain late, great Jamaican reggae singer. Aside from the spate of albums, box sets and commemorative editions, there’s the official clothing line, candles, sundry home furnishings and Marley Coffee Inc. There are documentaries and tribute shows, a museum in Jamaica and a resort in the Bahamas (I once stayed there, in the Kinky Reggae room, relishing Get Up, Stand Up cocktails at the Stir It Up bar). There are books upon books: about Marley’s life, his early life, the making of his albums; coffee-table volumes; photo essays; highbrow academic texts; tell-alls by those close to him (mother, wife, son, manager). There’s been so much Marley-related ink spilled that “Bob Marley: The Complete Annotated Bibliography” codifies more than 400 editions of the books.

text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Rodriguez Approaches 600 Home Runs
text: Alex Rodriguez may not have remembered what day it was, or in which inning he homered, but he did know one thing Thursday (not Sunday): he is only five homers from 600.

headline: Vidya Venkateswaran and Stephen Curran

text: Starbucks’ restrooms notwithstanding, New York’s public washrooms may not always shine with cleanliness, or even privacy. But there are always exceptions, if you know where to go.

text: In an article in today’s paper, I explore an apparent mismatch that manufacturing employers report between the skills they need and the skills available among the ranks of the unemployed.

headline: E.U. Plans to Deal With Debt Crisis Run Into Bumps
text: PARIS — The huge financial safety net for the euro zone patched together nearly two months ago was trumpeted as a triumph of solidarity. But as often happens in the European Union, commitments made in Brussels can get complicated once the leaders get back home.

headline: Land of Sugar Cane and Shortstops
text: Baseball, like Hollywood and democracy, has long been one of America’s chief global exports. The proconsuls who ruled the Philippines in the early 20th century brought bats and gloves to teach Filipinos the principles of manly competition and fair play. Lately, however, the tide has turned in the other direction. Baseball doesn’t feel so quintessentially American to today’s Americans. And as the lulling rhythms and pastoral setting of a sport shot through with nostalgia have weakened that sport’s hold on young people here, the ranks of major- and minor-league franchises have increasingly been filled with citizens of the far-flung baseball colonies, where the game is still a craze. Baseball has been revived by immigration. In “The Eastern Stars,” Mark Kurlansky notes the startling fact that by 2005, about one-quarter of the players in the minor leagues came from the Dominican Republic.

headline: Remembering a Crime That Shook a City
text: Ronell Wilson was begging for mercy.

headline: World Cup Live: Uruguay vs. Ghana
text: An unbelievable finish at Soccer City in Johannesburg put Uruguay through to the semifinals and Ghana out of the tournament in absolutely heartbreaking fashion.

headline: Anniversary of Accident Marked at Rock Festival
text: The annual Roskilde music festival began in Denmark on Thursday with a memorial to mark the 10th anniversary of an accident in which nine people were killed during a concert performance, The Associated Press reported. Patti Smith threw nine roses to the crowd as Lenny Kaye, her longtime bandmate, read the names of the concertgoers who were killed.

headline: To Save the Union
text: Henry Adams made his first visit to the floor of the United States Senate in May 1850,when he was 12. It was, he recalled, a “pleasant political club,” a “friendly world” where even slaveholders seemed “genial and sympathetic.” Adams didn’t mention the contemporary controversy over the vast territory recently acquired by conquest from Mexi­co: Would slavery be legal in the states that would eventually emerge from the region? While angry Americans demanded an answer, members of Congress debated and dithered. Then in August they approved a series of bills known as the Compromise of 1850, which resolved the political crisis by making no one happy.

text: CAPE TOWN  He is no longer the world’s greatest player, no longer the man the Germans will have to hassle and contain if they are to win their World Cup quarterfinal against Argentina on Saturday.

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Paperback Row
text: ZEITOUN,  by Dave Eggers (Vintage, $15.95.) Eggers’s tale of a middle-aged Syrian-American in New Orleans who spends a week rescuing neighbors from the post-Katrina flood only to be imprisoned by FEMA after he is mistaken for a terrorist is “21st-century Dickensian storytelling . . . a character-driven potboiler with a point,” our reviewer, Timothy Egan, said. “Fifty years from now, when people want to know what happened to this once great city . . . they will still be talking about a family named Zeitoun.”

headline: Could Crystals Sponge Up the Carbon?
text: As a climate change prevention strategy, carbon capture and storage is nowhere near ready for prime time. On the storage side of the equation, major questions remain on how and where to sequester the billions of tons of gas produced by power plants and industry every year. Another stumbling block, known as the parasitic energy cost, is the amount of energy needed to strip carbon out of power plant emissions. Carbon capture technologies being tested today, like amine scrubbing, exact an energy penalty as high as 30 percent, a vast and perhaps untenable expense to utilities and society.

headline: JaMarcus Russell and the Jets?
