headline: Dispatch | Gay Tel Aviv
text: That Tel Aviv, not a huge city but a high-octane one, has become the new gay mecca of the Mediterranean is something of an open secret, both in the Middle East and increasingly, outside it, too. Unfailingly sunny and tirelessly tolerant, its energy level is at once intense and beguilingly relaxed. In the run-up to Tel Aviv’s Gay Pride, which fell on June 11 this year, there were not one but two New York-based gay tours to Israel – Steele Travel’s Milk & Honey tour and one promoted by Chelsea’s own gay adult-entertainment impresario Michael Lucas, whose nine-day journey covered Israel from top (the Golan Heights) to bottom (Eilat), and, like Steele’s, allowed time for a foray into Tel Aviv’s full-throttle after-hours gay scene.

headline: Activists Beg Obama to Step Up Climate Push
text: A coalition of environmental organizations sent President Obama a letter on Friday pleading for him to intervene in the stalled Senate negotiations on climate and energy legislation. The groups, which have been largely supportive of the president’s energy policies, expressed concern that time was running out for any action on climate change this year. Only the president’s personal and persistent attention can break the stalemate, they say.

headline: When Grilling Today Fills Tomorrow’s Cravings

headline: More Blacks See Hope in Economy
text: The Great Recession hit American blacks harder than it did whites. Blacks were more likely to lose their jobs, and those who kept them were more likely to have their pay or hours reduced. Black homeowners are also far more likely than whites to own homes that are no longer worth what they owe on the mortgage.

headline: Death on Facebook
text: They say war isn’t real until you’re getting shot at or shooting at someone, but the true reality of war doesn’t hit until you lose one of your own. This terrible knowledge is shared amongst the comrades, family and friends of some 5,517 Americans who have lost their lives fighting for their country in Iraq and Afghanistan over the past eight years. For the first time since the war began, I now regrettably count myself amongst those who personally know the terrible cost of war. A friend, First Lt. Joe Theinert of Sag Harbor, N.Y., was killed in an ambush in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, on 4 June.

headline: New York’s Soda Tax Plan Dies After Industry Ad Campaign
text: Gov. David A. Paterson’s proposal to tax soda seems to have fizzled as lawmakers eliminated the controversial measure while cobbling together a state revenue bill. The penny-an-ounce tax on soda and other sweet drinks would have helped shrink New York’s ballooning deficit and, its supporters say, cut down on obesity.

headline: Brazil, a World Cup Favorite, Is Sent Home
text: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa  Brazil had never really been under duress in the World Cup until the quarterfinals on Friday. How would it react, with resilience or agitation? Could it take a punch or did it have a glass jaw?

headline: Nascar, Through the Looking Glass
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

headline: Free Agency Ushers in End of Tampering Season
text: After meeting LeBron James on Thursday, Knicks Coach Mike D’Antoni expressed confidence that his team had made a good pitch to the star free agent.

headline: In Mexico, Unlikely Allies Hope to Defeat Resurgent Party
text: TLAXIACO, Mexico  Gabino Cué is running for governor of Oaxaca State as the candidate for so many parties that his campaign is handing out a pamphlet explaining how to mark the ballot.

headline: What Recovery? For the Unemployed, the Pain Gets Worse
text: IF my columns last year had a theme, it was, not surprisingly, learning to live in a recession. I wrote about job hunting, how to talk to friends who had been laid off, cutting back on spending and coping with uncertainty.

headline: Montreal Jazz: A Conversation With André Ménard
text: MONTREAL — The Montreal International Jazz Festival is enormous, and it grows a little bit every year. The 31st edition, with more than 700 concerts over 12 days, ends on Tuesday with a festival first: a Mardi Gras parade through the city, complete with floats from New Orleans and music by Trombone Shorty and Allen Toussaint.

headline: A Long-Distance Runner With an Imposing Profile
text: BEAVERTON, Ore.  A few years ago, two things could be counted on at the University of Wisconsin. Chris Solinsky could be found barreling around a track, and onlookers could be found wondering who he was.

headline: A Continent’s Hopes Are Swatted Away
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: Skip the Scotch, Just Have a Swig of Mellowberry
text: FOR years, college students and C-suite executives alike have managed to stay perky through parties and deadlines by guzzling so-called energy drinks like Jolt, Red Bull and Rockstar.

headline: Sorting Out Climate ‘Camps’
text: It’s only natural for humans to try to sort things — as in the assignment of Hogwarts students to various houses in the Harry Potter books and films. There have been a lot of attempts to categorize the varied assemblage of people with strongly held positions on the scope of, and threat from, the building human influence on the climate system. Convinced and unconvinced. Deniers. Alarmists. Skeptics. I’ve found at least one category that I think is justified — stasists — so I don’t utterly reject such attempts.

headline: Blue Bird Buses Are Being Recalled
text: About 5,300 school buses made by the Blue Bird Corporation are involved in three different recalls. They involve a fire hazard, the possibility that the driver’s seat may collapse and the possible loss of steering, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Guests Took Back Their Wine
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Obama and Clinton Honor Byrd
text: CHARLESTON, W. Va. – Hundreds of West Virginians and dozens of family members and friends gathered here Friday to pay tribute to Robert C. Byrd, the longest-serving senator in history. President Obama, former President Bill Clinton, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and several of Mr. Byrd’s colleagues in Congress spoke of his humble roots, voracious appetite for knowledge, inspiring oratory and fierce devotion to his home state.

headline: Wade Again Visits Bulls; Knicks Go After Stoudemire
text: For the first 36 hours of free agency, the N.B.A. seemed to revolve around a modest office building in downtown Cleveland. By the end of the second day, the focus and the intrigue had shifted dramatically, 343 miles to the west, to downtown Chicago.

headline: The Moviegoer | Oh, the Horror!
text: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

headline: Bypassing Equity Funds, Wealthy Families Try Direct Investing
text: The 2008 financial crisis had several unexpected outcomes, but one of the surprising ones was an increased willingness by wealthy families to invest directly in private companies and forgo private equity funds.

headline: TimesCast: House Race in Ohio
text: On the latest edition of TimesCast, The Times’s Jeff Zeleny takes a look at a key House race in Ohio, assessing whether the Democratic voters who elected President Obama to office in 2008 will return to the voting booths to help the Democratic incumbent in the November midterms.

headline: Is Chess Boring to Watch?
text: For many years, chess players and organizers have puzzled over how to make the game more appealing for television, à la poker. So far, no one seems to have come up with a solution. Now there is a tongue-in-cheek suggestion from Geico, the insurance company.

headline: Elisabeth Weinberg, Matthew Stine
text: Elisabeth Weinberg and Matthew Stine are to be married Sunday at Skylight Studios, a loft in New York. Rabbi Andy Bachman is to officiate.

headline: Mitchell Gold and Tim Scofield
text: WHEN Mitchell Gold, now 59, arrived in Manhattan in 1974, he “was young, fresh out of college and closeted,” he recalled. He took a job selling pillows at Bloomingdale’s, and remembered going out with women and usually finding that “the waiter was more interesting, or her brother.”

headline: Ilana Silverman, Jonathan Bortinger
text: Ilana Fern Silverman, a daughter of Ellen B. Silverman and David M. Silverman of Lake Worth, Fla., is to be married Sunday evening to Dr. Jonathan Zev Bortinger, a son of Nancy J. Bortinger and Arie Bortinger of Ridgewood, N.J. Rabbi David J. Fine is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J.

headline: Michelle Parikh and Nate Brown
text: Michelle Katherine Parikh and Harold Nathaniel Brown were married Saturday at the Belvedere Mansion, an inn in Staatsburg, N.Y. Russell D. Weatherspoon, a New Hampshire justice of the peace and an instructor of religion at Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., officiated.

headline: For the Wealthy, a New Interest in Direct Investing
text: The financial crisis that began in 2008 underlined a number of weaknesses in investors’ portfolios, and one of them was the limitations of private equity investments. Many of the wealthy individual investors in those funds were forced to sell other assets to meet demands for additional capital from private equity firms or had to sell their stakes in the funds at deep discounts to get out early.

headline: Cadillac Drives Off, Again, to New Creative Ad Agency
text: The Cadillac division of General Motors is changing creative agencies for the second time in six months.

headline: In U.S., Wimbledon Works on NBC Time
text: NBC’s tape-delaying of Wimbledon semifinals matches remains one of the most perplexing practices in television sports.

headline: The New iPhone’s Other Performance Problem
text: Earlier today Apple addressed a problem with its antenna and signal strength display on its new iPhone 4 in an open letter to customers. The problem, known at the “death grip” appears to result in worse reception and dropped calls when the phone is held a certain way when the signal strength is low.

headline: Tess Kim and Albert Ju
text: Dr. Tashil Ryu Kim and Dr. Albert Changwon Ju were married Saturday in Naperville, Ill. The Rev. H. Jason Reed officiated at Wesley United Methodist Church.

headline: For Stylish Ears
text: For the Fourth of July weekend, many Americans want to show their Team America spirit by waving little American flags in the air or sporting a U.S.A. emblazoned T-shirt. Now, proud Americans can take it up a notch. Earloomz, a company that specializes in Bluetooth earpieces, will begin selling a number of newly designed earpieces, including ones with American flags.

headline: New Works at City Ballet
text: A look at the new ballets this season at New York City Ballet.

headline: Another Unstuffy Team Tennis Season to Begin Monday
text: Tennis at Wimbeldon is a formal affair: Players have to wear white, afternoon tea is served at three p.m. and cheering is polite enough for the Queen Elizabeth to attend.

headline: Lightweight Golf Bags That Are Practical and Stylish
text: It’s nice to have a golf bag you can comfortably carry, but if you’re playing in a fancy event, you don’t want your bag to look cheesy, either. Fortunately, a lot of companies are now making lightweight bags that are smart and stylish, too. Start with the Collegiate by Nike ($150, golfsmith.com), which weighs five pounds and has a full-length apparel pocket as well as mesh pockets for a water bottle and accessories. It’s functional and its straps have an air cushioning design that is easy on your shoulders.

headline: The Coveted but Elusive Summer Internship
text: IT’S been a rough summer so far for the Baltimore Orioles, Miley Cyrus and (it goes without saying) BP. Now, summer interns may have joined the list.

headline: Cadillac Switches Creative Ad Agencies

headline: Weekend Fare
text: With the opening of Bier International, at 2099 Frederick Douglass Boulevard, between 113th and 114th Streets, Harlem gets its first beer garden just in time for the holiday weekend. It was bound to happen. Everyone from suit-and-tie clad bankers to skinny hipsters in plaid have flocked to beer gardens popping up in the city, from the meatpacking district to the Lower East Side. Marcus Samuelsson plans to open Red Rooster near Bier International and Ryan Skeen briefly headed the kitchen at 5 & Diamond just down the street. About half of the 20 international brews on tap at the beer garden will be available this weekend.

headline: An Enduring Religious Web Site Is Poised for a Next Phase
text: Rupert Murdoch sells topless Page 3 girls to England, and he sells “fair and balanced” television commentary to America. But until last week, his most eccentric product was Beliefnet.com.

headline: Study of Waterboarding Coverage Prompts a Debate in the Press
text: A study released this week of the four biggest newspapers in the United States said that in the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, there was “a dramatic shift in coverage away from nearly a century of practice recognizing waterboarding as torture.”

headline: McConnell Opposes Kagan
text: Republicans are starting to line up against Elena Kagan. The latest no vote is the party leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.

headline: Let’s Try to Make Sense of the ‘Death Grip’
text: Whoa. Just unbelievable.

headline: The Fourth of July, Just a Little Early
text: Who says Americans have to celebrate the Fourth of July with Tchaikovsky’s hackneyed concert overture, “1812,” an exaltation of czarist Russia at the expense of Napoleonic France?

headline: Balletic Drumming, Playful and Precise
text: Manu Katché is a drummer of watchful effervescence, attuned to the tiniest particulars of rhythm and timbre but intent on a feeling of unthinking ease. His playing suggests precision without premeditation, which is one reason for his success along a certain pop bandwidth: you’ve probably heard him, whether or not you’ve realized it, backing Peter Gabriel or Sting. It’s less likely that you’ve encountered him as a solo artist. “This is my first gig with my band in the States,” he said at the Highline Ballroom on Thursday night.

headline: The Ritual of the First Date, Circa 2010
text: THERE are nearly four million single people in New York City. A number of them are not as original as they think.

headline: Hey, Small Spender
text: THE rich are always with us. But sometimes they keep a lower profile than others. In an era of global economic recession — an unshaven whisker’s edge from Depression — as the unemployment rate in the United States shuffles around 10 percent, as former fat cats like the faux-financier Bernard L. Madoff languish behind bars and as second homes and pleasure boats clot the  “For Sale”  columns of want ads, conspicuous consumption is out. Pitchfork populism is in. The hour of bling has blung. And yet... Bottega Veneta dares to sell tie-dyed T-shirts for $330 each, while Apple has sold three million iPads in 80 days (at $499, minimum) to somebody. Who has the money? Nobody’s telling.

headline: International Program Catches On in U.S. Schools
text: CUMBERLAND, Me. — SAT, ACT, A.P. ... I.B.?

headline: Urban Artisans: A Collective Thrives in Brooklyn
text: A proclamation from Marty Markowitz, the excitable Brooklyn borough president, is no rarity. But receiving it under the head of a quasianimatronic wolf-creature, while, around the corner, a guy upholsters a seat cushion in brown argyle, and another blends cocktails by bike  that is something special.

headline: Karts for Drivers More Interested in Virtual Than in Reality
text: I don’t drive in real life.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 2
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include storm damage in Queens, a lobsterman’s livelihood in danger, the Gay Pride parade and budget vetoes.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Our writers explore 12 trips that allow travelers to revisit American history, including a drive in Alabama that follows in the footsteps of civil rights marchers, a visit to the garages of California where Hewlett-Packard and other technology companies were born and the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State, where a Makah village once stood.

headline: G.M. Aims for Mid-August I.P.O. Filing
text: 6:08 p.m. | Updated General Motors is aiming for mid-August to file for an initial public offering, in what would be its biggest step yet toward paying back its bailout by the federal government, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

headline: An Adult Sparkler for the Holiday
text: The Fourth of July weekend is shaping up to be beautiful in New York City — hot and bright, with low humidity. Part of what makes this holiday so appealing for me is the ritual emptying of the city as New Yorkers with someplace to go, go. Folks, you know I love you. But as Dan Hicks once sang, “How can I miss you when you won’t go away?’’

headline: What Art Will Make a Ballet’s Life Less Brief?
text: Ballets are written on air. Few live longer than a year or two. Yet it’s standard practice in the ballet world to refer to new choreography as “lifeblood.” Peter Martins, ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, used the term in his opening-night speech when introducing the company’s just-ended Architecture of Dance season, the series of programs featuring seven commissioned premieres.

headline: Burnett Rights Ship, but Bullpen Capsizes Again
text: Over the course of an 11-inning afternoon Friday, the Yankees bucked one trend and continued two others. After muddling through the worst month by a starter in team history, A. J. Burnett responded with six and two-thirds scoreless innings. He left with a lead, but the Yankees’ two recent nuisances  bullpen troubles and a failure to hit with runners in scoring position  conspired to send them to a 6-1 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: Abigail McDonough, Jeremy Merkelson
text: Abigail Elizabeth McDonough and Jeremy Ben Merkelson are to be married Sunday at King Family Vineyards in Crozet, Va. The Rev. Dr. Peter G. James, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate, with Cantor Nancy R. Ginsberg participating. The couple met at Yale, from which they both graduated, he cum laude.

headline: Time for the Second Story?
text: A beekeeper should try to replace some of the brood comb every year or so.  The brood comb, where the queen lays eggs, is heavy-duty comb – not the light wax that is found in comb honey or beeswax candles.  This thicker comb serves as the nursery for thousands of new bees, and to keep a hive healthy, it should be replaced on a regular, rotating basis.

headline: Hip-Hop Traditionalism in Two Variations
text: A little over two years ago, the New Orleans rapper Jay Electronica played what was billed as his first New York performance at the Nokia Theater, opening for Mos Def. It was, politely speaking, a disaster, sloppy and uncentered and poorly received.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 2
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: ‘Mambo’ Author Returns to His Muse
text: MIAMI — Oscar Hijuelos stopped abruptly on Calle Ocho at a mural of Latino celebrities.  “Wow,”  he said, pointing to colorful portraits of people he knew: Celia Cruz, Cuba’s queen of salsa, and Tito Puente, the drummer extraordinaire.

headline: Pre-empt Avoided by Purists Pays Off Well
text: Last weekend at the Sheraton Gateway Suites in Chicago, the same location as the open trial, an under-21 trial was held. This decided the two United States teams to compete in the World Youngsters Championship in Philadelphia in October.

headline: Thomas Jefferson Changes His Mind
text: The rough draft of the Declaration of Independence, written by Thomas Jefferson with edits in the hands of Benjamin Franklin and John Adams, has long fascinated historians, who have used it to track the evolution of the founders’ thinking. Now, relying on new technology, scientists at the Library of Congress have confirmed a longtime suspicion that in one spot where Jefferson wrote the word “citizens,” he had originally written “subjects” – as in subjects of the British crown – but rubbed it out before the ink dried.

headline: New ‘Spider-Man’ Finds Its New Spider-Man
text: Usually the eve of a holiday weekend is an opportune moment for an organization to announce layoffs or to put out reams of documents for dirt-diggers to sift through. For Sony, this is the ideal time to announce that it has found a new actor to star in its lucrative “Spider-Man” movie franchise. The studio said Andrew Garfield, right, a relatively unknown 26-year-old actor, would replace Tobey Maguire as that red-and-blue web-slinger as well as his nebbishy alter ego, Peter Parker, according to The Hollywood Reporter’s Heat Vision blog (heatvisionblog.com). Mr. Garfield’s credits include the Terry Gilliam movie “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus” and David Fincher’s coming film about Facebook, “The Social Network.” The three “Spider-Man” movies that starred Mr. Maguire and were directed by Sam Raimi have sold more than $2.4 billion in tickets worldwide. But at the start of the year Mr. Maguire and Mr. Raimi left a planned “Spider-Man 4” film because of creative differences. Instead, Sony hired Marc Webb (“(500) Days of Summer”) to direct a new movie that will return Spidey to his modest origins. (And be released in 3-D in 2012.)

headline: Forging a Festival for Black Playwrights
text: Does the world need another festival for emerging playwrights? Lynn Nottage, above, answered with an emphatic yes this week by hosting a fund-raiser in her Brooklyn home to benefit the establishment of the New Black Fest, a festival aiming to showcase innovative work by and about black people from around the world. Its organizers and supporters are busy raising money and seeking out advisers in time for an autumn inaugural festival, which would include readings and panel discussions. “This is not about separation, it’s about inclusion,” said Ms. Nottage, who won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize in drama for “Ruined,” about women in a Congolese brothel. “It’s about inviting people who don’t get access.” Katori Hall (of the Broadway-bound play “The Mountaintop”) and Suzan Lori-Parks (“Topdog/Underdog”) were among the playwrights attending the benefit. By the end of the night, $7,000 had been raised as the hat was passed among about 45 people from the world of film and theater, including Sandra Oh (“Grey’s Anatomy”), Russell Hornsby and Chris Chalk (of the Broadway revival of “Fences”), Eisa Davis (“Passing Strange”), the directors Malcolm Lee and Charles Randolph-Wright, and David Dower, associate artistic director of Arena Stage in Washington. Ms. Parks said the new festival would not only nurture and introduce new talent but also help African-Americans “remind each other that we are a great and powerful people,” she said.

headline: Pee-Wee’s New Movie
text: Our bow ties haven’t stopped spinning since Variety reported that Paul Reubens is working on a new Pee-wee Herman movie, to be produced by Judd Apatow, the writer-director of “The 40-Year-Old Virgin” and “Knocked Up.” The news has a lot of people wondering what such a collaboration will yield  “Not the least of which is me,” Mr. Reubens, above, in character, said by telephone. Mr. Reubens, who is preparing his live “Pee-wee Herman Show” for Broadway, has spoken often about two Pee-wee-centered film scripts he has written that would continue the adventures of his manic character, seen in “Pee-wee’s Big Adventure” and the CBS children’s series “Pee-wee’s Playhouse.” But what Mr. Apatow wanted, Mr. Reubens said, was “a reality-based world and a linear road movie.” So that’s the path that Mr. Reubens and a co-writer, Paul Rust, are working along, for now. The Pee-wee character seems synonymous with a youthful innocence, while Mr. Apatow has a sensibility that can be naughty and often rude  but, Mr. Reubens said, “So can mine.”

headline: ‘Wipeout’ Draws a Crowd
text: ABC’s quirky obstacle-course reality show “Wipeout” topped the ratings on Thursday night, but CBS eked ahead for the evening with repeats of its crime shows “CSI” and “The Mentalist.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Wipeout” delivered 8.6 million viewers, followed by the new crime show “Rookie Blue” (6.8 million). NBC finished in fourth place behind Fox, which earned 5.8 million for its reality show “So You Think You Can Dance.”

headline: Murals Come Home to the Hispanic Society
text: An oasis of culture far uptown has reinstalled a series of celebrated works by Joaquin Sorolla y  Bastida, after a tour they took in Spain.

headline: Lilith Tour Cancels 10 Concerts
text: In a major blow to the 2010 Lilith Tour, that female-centered music festival has announced the cancellation of 10 of its planned dates this month and in August. The canceled concerts were scheduled for Salt Lake City (July 12); Montreal (July 23); Raleigh, N.C. (Aug. 4); Charlotte, N.C. (Aug. 6); West Palm Beach, Fla. (Aug. 10); Tampa, Fla. (Aug. 11); Birmingham, Ala. (Aug. 12); Austin, Tex. (Aug. 14); Houston (Aug. 15); and Dallas (Aug. 16), the tour’s press representatives said in a news release. An Aug. 8 date in Atlanta is still listed on the festival’s Web site (lilithfair.com). No immediate reason for the canceled dates was given, but disappointing ticket sales was the likely culprit. In a statement, Terry McBride, a founder of the Lilith festival, said: “We are in the midst of one of the most challenging summer concert seasons with many tours being canceled outright. Everyone involved with the tour would like to apologize to the fans and artists scheduled to play in these markets, and express appreciation for all the support for the festival’s return. Lilith remains the only tour of its kind, and we are confident that fans will be amazed by what each date has to offer.” The Lilith festival, which is playing its first dates since 1999, said that its kickoff performance last weekend in Calgary, Alberta, drew more than 9,000 concertgoers.

headline: Culture Budget Reprieve: New York Eases Cuts
text: The New York City cultural-budget dance has a pattern: the mayor proposes drastic cuts, cultural organizations protest, and in the end the City Council restores most of the money. This year’s routine played out no differently, with cultural organizations, which had braced for huge cuts in the budget for the 2011 fiscal year, instead coming out close to where they did last year. The budget passed by the Council on Tuesday includes roughly $150 million for the Department of Cultural Affairs, compared with the $159 million that was allocated last year. (The 2010 fiscal year ended on Wednesday.) Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had proposed a $49 million cut, but the mayor and the Council ultimately restored $40 million. “We were all in scenario-planning for doomsday,” Arnold L. Lehman, above, the director of the Brooklyn Museum and chairman of the Cultural Institutions Group, said.

headline: Your Tax Dollars at Work — Making Apps
text: The Apple App Store, the Android Market and BlackBerry’s AppWorld have a surprising new competitor.

Lipez of South Portland, Me., is to be married Sunday at the Gilsland Farm Audubon Center in Falmouth, Me., to Nolan Ladislav Reichl, the son of Marina E. Reichl of Eugene, Ore., and Daniel Reichl of Plzen, the Czech Republic. Judge Marjorie O. Rendell, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, is to lead the ceremony; the bride’s father, a judge of the Federal Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Portland, Me., is to solemnize the couple’s marriage certificate.

headline: Andrea Mitchell, Jamel Donnor
text: Andrea Elaine Mitchell and Jamel Kevin Donnor were married Saturday afternoon at St. James Parish Church in Holetown, St. James, Barbados. The Rev. Wayne McD. Kirton, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Julianne Mifflin, Daniel Austin
text: Julianne Scott Mifflin, a daughter of Marsha Scott Mifflin and Kenneth E. Mifflin of Greenwich, Conn., was married there Saturday to Daniel Caldwell Austin, a son of Jane Matthews Austin and Dr. Charles B. Austin Jr. of Mechanicsburg, Pa. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Greenwich, where he is the rector.

headline: Kristina Hoge, Jake Bronstein
text: Kristina Hoge and Jake Bronstein were married Saturday evening at Studio 450, an event space in New York. The Rev. Gloria Carlson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Christine Parsons, Jordan Lustig
text: Christine Ellen Parsons and Jordan Michael Lustig were married Friday in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Larry C. Ralston, a Baptist minister, officiated at Chatham Bars Inn.

headline: Annette Stamatelatos and Kirk Ceballos
text: Annette Denise Stamatelatos and Kirk Ceballos were married Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn. The Rev. John K. Lardas, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony at St. Constantine & Helen Cathedral, where he is the presiding priest.

headline: Rachel Specter, Dan Levy
text: Rachel Specter and Dan Levy are to be married Sunday at Walnut Grove, a party space at the Tierra Rejada Ranch in Moorpark, Calif. Rabbi Robert D. Judd is to officiate.

headline: Jonna Hamilton, Lindsay Harrison
text: Jonna Lyn Hamilton and Lindsay Claire Harrison are to be married Sunday evening at Odiorne Point State Park in Rye, N.H. Nicole H. Hanrahan, a friend of the couple who was ordained as a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism for the occasion, is to officiate.

headline: Joan Lynch, Kevin Owens
text: Joan Torchiana Lynch and Kevin Michael Owens were married Saturday at their summer home in Asbury Park, N.J. Andrew Stephan, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony, officiated.

headline: Monitoring Teenage Phones and Facebook
text: Last week readers submitted numerous questions about cyberbullying to our expert, Elizabeth K. Englander, a professor of psychology and the founder and director of the Massachusetts Aggression Reduction Center at Bridgewater State College, which provides antibullying and antiviolence training programs and resources to schools and families. In the coming week, we’ll offer more answers to selected questions about bullying.

headline: G.M. Is Said to Consider Filing Soon for Offering
text: General Motors is aiming to file an initial public offering of stock in mid-August, taking its biggest step yet toward repaying the federal government, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Becoming a Citizen the Naturalized Way
text: The United States deported 387,790 people in the 2009 fiscal year, but to hear Shyconia Burden of Citizenship and Immigration Services describe it, you would think we’re desperate for new recruits. “The goal is to naturalize as many people as want to become U.S. citizens,” she told me one recent day in the waiting room of the New York district office where she, an effusively warm community relations officer, has been working since she was 15.

headline: Multitasking, With Time for the Roses
text: Jennifer J. Raab, who has been the president of Hunter College for nine years, has also been an urban planner, corporate lawyer, campaign manager and, before leading Hunter, chairwoman of the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission. She is married to Michael Goodwin, a New York Post columnist and Fox News contributor whom she met while working as press secretary for the city’s planning commissioner. On Sundays, Ms. Raab unwinds at home in Riverdale with her husband and daughter, Miranda Goodwin-Raab, 17. Her stepson, Scott Goodwin, and his wife, Jennifer, sometimes join them from Manhattan.

headline: The Spies Next Door (Almost)
text: Weeks before the F.B.I. carted off the Murphys of Montclair as Russian agents, my wife was wandering through their backyard, holding a furtive cellphone conversation.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE BATHING SUIT STAND at Astoria Pool sells goggles for $4 and towels for $10. But the big sellers are padlocks ($7), which are required for admission to all city pools, which opened on Tuesday for the season, so that swimmers can secure their belongings in lockers. “Locks are our best-selling item because people show up without realizing that you cannot get in without it,” said Hany Sadek, 49, who runs the stand under a canopy near the pool entrance. “I sold more than 100 on opening day.”

headline: Readers’ Questions Answered
text: This week’s inside information includes the lyrics “I’ve sacrificed and bunted my heart,” and word on radiation at Grand Central and automated water meters.

headline: At Arboretum, a Flowery Legacy of a Gilded Age
text: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.

headline: An Idol Going Home
text: KATIE STEVENS may be 17 and of a socially networked generation that devalues discretion, but she can keep a secret.

headline: On the Street | Glory!
text: Eagles are on the watch on this most important celebration, the Fourth of July. The wearing of the colors is a traditional expression of patriotism, and a popular fashion, too.

headline: Paterson Urged to Veto Limit on Stop-and-Frisk List
text: To police officials, a computer database full of the names and addresses of people questioned by officers in millions of street stops in New York City is a core tool in their fight to keep reducing crime.

headline: Interesting Signing by Mets
text: The Mets have signed Brian Bruney, the K-Rod nemesis and former Yankees relief pitcher, to a minor league contract. Last year, Bruney criticized Francisco Rodriguez’s post-save antics. During a Subway Series game, Rodriguez confronted him on the field during batting practice.

headline: Out of Breath in Venice
text: When Truffaldino (Alex Morf) first takes the stage in “The Servant of Two Masters,” he looks and behaves a little like the young Ron Howard in his “Happy Days” period. As time passes, more of his mischievous side emerges, and he could easily pass for one of the Smothers Brothers. Then he starts doing cartwheels and pratfalls, and it’s clear that he’s a much more physical actor than either of those look-alikes of the past.

headline: A Comedic Rap on Shakespeare, D.J. Included
text: Well, now they’ve gone and done it. They’ve covered up the view.

headline: G.O.P. Leader Draws Criticism Anew
text: WASHINGTON — Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, drew fierce criticism and a call for his resignation on Friday after declaring at a party fund-raiser that the United States was on the wrong side of history with its conflict in Afghanistan, a military fight he called “a war of Obama’s choosing.”

headline: A Voice in Egypt for an Arab Age of Reason
text: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt

headline: The Harmony of Jill and Julia
text: JILL SOBULE, the singer and songwriter, met the “Saturday Night Live” alumna Julia Sweeney at a TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference in Monterey, Calif., in 2006. And they were both a little creeped out.

headline: Despite Raid, Mostly Business as Usual for Israel and Turkey
text: TEL AVIV — Since the deadly Israeli raid on the Gaza flotilla, Turkey has recalled its ambassador from Jerusalem and banned Israeli military planes from the country’s airspace, while its prime minister has called the Jewish state “a lying machine.” Israel, for its part, has warned its citizens not to travel to Turkey.

headline: A Music Festival Stretches Out
text: SIX years ago, the Pleasantville Music Festival debuted as a modest folk-based event attended by 800 people. This year, more than 6,000 guests are expected for a day of blues, rock, world music and more. The performers will include Jakob Dylan, the Bacon Brothers (Kevin and Michael) and Rusted Root.

headline: A Film Festival With Repeat Showings
text: The Long Island International Film Expo, now in its 13th year, is welcoming back at least 15 filmmakers who have previously shown their work at the festival, which will run July 8 to 18 at the Bellmore Movies. It will include panels, parties and the screening of 156 films, including 37 from filmmakers with a connection to Long Island and 38 foreign films from 19 countries.

headline: Mentor Says McChrystal Is ‘Crushed’ by the Change in His Circumstances
text: WASHINGTON  The White House sent a powerful signal this week by permitting Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal to retire with all of his four stars, but the general’s most important mentor, Adm. Mike Mullen, still described him as “crushed” during the shock of a transition from commanding nearly 100,000 American troops in Afghanistan to living in exile on the Potomac.

headline: Come for Art, Stay for the Golf
text: FOR reasons ranging from fashion to sky-high club fees, artists and golf courses generally don’t mix. Miniature golf, however, is a different story, at least in Jersey City.

headline: Uruguay Trades Penalty for Chance at Victory
text: JOHANNESBURG  Twice at the end of the night, Luis Suárez thrust his left arm skyward. The first time was to stop Ghana forward Dominic Adiyiah’s header from crossing the goal line for a certain score that would have eliminated Uruguay from the World Cup in extra time of a quarterfinal. The second was to celebrate his team’s berth in the semifinals after it won a penalty-shootout.

headline: Still Rivals, but This Time Their Colors Reflect That
text: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  With Lance Armstrong nowhere in sight, miles away at his team’s hotel, Alberto Contador surveyed a room filled with reporters at the Tour de France on Friday and exhaled.

headline: After Surviving, Learning to Live
text: A wounded soldier and those in his immediate circle speak about his recovery after the loss of all four limbs.

headline: As Fireworks Go, So Goes the Economy
text: ST. HELENA, Calif.  On Friday afternoon, as a steady stream of S.U.V.-loving chardonnay sippers inched along Highway 29, the dutiful members of local American Legion post were proudly pursuing a far more sober mission: selling sparklers, snappers and smoke bombs at a roadside fireworks stand, just as they have since Nixon  another patriotic Californian  was president.

text: Daniel Drezner, left, of Tufts University and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic discuss the cultural errors of the Russian spy ring.

headline: A Mission in the Desert
text: A mission in the insurgent badlands of northern Iraq provided a vivid example of what American forces still do on the ground and, military officers said, would be able to do after the August deadline for the end of the combat mission in Iraq.

headline: Don Coryell, Innovator in N.F.L.’s Passing Game, Dies at 85
text: Don Coryell, the San Diego Chargers coach who became an architect of pro football’s modern passing game with his spectacular offense known as Air Coryell, died Thursday at a hospital in La Mesa, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Spirit Intact, Soldier Reclaims His Life
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Illinois Stops Paying Its Bills, but Can’t Stop Digging Hole
text: CHICAGO  Even by the standards of this deficit-ridden state, Illinois’s comptroller, Daniel W. Hynes, faces an ugly balance sheet. Precisely how ugly becomes clear when he beckons you into his office to examine his daily briefing memo.

headline: July Fourth Weekend Quiz
text: I. Know your states:

headline: You Say God Is Dead? There’s an App for That
text: An explosion of smart-phone software has placed an arsenal of trivia at the fingertips of every corner-bar debater, with talking points on sports, politics and how to kill a zombie. Now it is taking on the least trivial topic of all: God.

headline: This Land: Rebuilding Hope
text: In St. Bernard Parish in Louisiana, a former school now known as Camp Hope has been adapted to help meet the challenges created first by Hurricane Katrina, and more recently by the gulf oil spill.

headline: Will the Jobless Cost Democrats Their Jobs?
text: “Today’s employment report shows continued signs of gradual labor market recovery,” crows Christina Romer, the head of the president’s council of economic advisers. “Private nonfarm payroll employment increased by 83,000 in June and the unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point to 9.5%. June marks the sixth month in a row that private sector employment has increased. These continued signs of healing are important …”

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: The Problem That Transcends Race
text: I want to start by getting back to a poster from last week who called me out for saying that Riggins, in all his former football-star glory, had so few opportunities. I thought about this a lot. The poster claimed that if there were a job worth having in Dillon, the boosters would actually give it to Riggins. But of course the point here — and the point of the show in general to a large extent — is that there are so few jobs actually worth having there. (And as far as Riggins’s squandering opportunities, it simply would not have felt in keeping with his character if he’d stayed in college. Not everyone is cut out for college and not everyone should be expected to go. Part of what is so painfully evocative about “Friday Night Lights” is that it gives us a sense of an America where very little is possible without an exit from small-time life or an education.)

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,134 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: War in Iraq Defies U.S. Timetable for End of Combat
text: NEAR TULUL AL-BAQ, Iraq  President Obama has set an August deadline for the end of the combat mission in Iraq. Here at this makeshift desert camp in the insurgent badlands of northern Iraq, a mission is under way that is not going to stop then: American soldiers hunting terrorists and covertly watching an Iraqi checkpoint staffed by police officers whom the soldiers say they do not trust.

headline: Stepping In as Arizona Manager, Gibson Displays His Famously Fiery Attitude Again
text: PHOENIX  Kirk Gibson is most famous for a home run he hit while hobbled. Now he will try to turn around a ball club that is also in bad shape.

headline: Greece: Sixth General Strike Scheduled for Next Week
text: Greece’s unions called a sixth general strike for Thursday, the day Parliament votes on a pension overhaul, as attempts to smooth growing dissent over the changes. The General Confederation of Labor, Greece’s largest union group for workers at private companies, will hold a new nationwide 24-hour strike, to be joined by the union for civil servants. Prime Minister George Papandreou told his finance minister at a private meeting on Thursday that there would be no law to freeze wages, as reported recently, the Athens News Agency reported. The labor confederation is seeking a wage increase of nearly four percent by 2012 and is also concerned about plans to reduce pension payments and proposed new arbitration rules.

headline: Rise of the Religious Left
text: Which political party’s members are most likely to believe that Jesus will definitely return to earth before midcentury? The Republicans, right? Wrong. The Democrats.

headline: Well Out of Lead, Woods Says He Sees Reasons for Optimism
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  After Tiger Woods shot a 70 on Friday that left him closer to the cut line than to the lead in the AT&T National, he said something that should resonate with weekend golfers everywhere.

headline: A Jobs Program That Works
text: Is it possible that there is a federal stimulus program that is putting many thousands of struggling individuals to work and is getting rave reviews not only from Democrats but from officials in conservative states like South Carolina and Mississippi?

headline: High-Rise, or House With Yard?
text: The question starts to hang in the air sometime after the children arrive, and the apartment in the city begins to feel a little tight: Should we consider moving to a house in the suburbs?

headline: Canada: Bomb Explodes at Office of Armed Forces Recruiters
text: A bomb exploded at a Canadian Armed Forces recruiting office in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, early Friday, causing extensive damage. The newspaper La Presse in Montreal later received a faxed message from a group calling itself Résistance Internationaliste, claiming responsibility for the explosion. The message denounced Canada’s military role in Afghanistan and the pledge of allegiance made by Canadian troops to Queen Elizabeth II, who is on an official visit to Canada.

headline: Spend or Scrimp? Two Sides in White House Debate
text: WASHINGTON  Not since the first years of the Clinton administration has a White House had to debate whether to give precedence to stimulating the economy or reducing budget deficits. Now, as the recovery shows signs of faltering, that debate is playing out within the Obama administration, with a twist compared to the 1990s: the economic and political teams have switched sides.

headline: From New Age to Old School in Arizona
text: PHOENIX — Jerry DiPoto was three minutes into his first news conference as the Arizona Diamondbacks’ interim general manager when a large video camera fell off its tripod and banged on the ground just a few feet from him.

headline: A ‘Kagan Doctrine’ on Gay Marriage
text: Washington

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Congress, Sanctions and Iran
text: The United States already bars nearly all trade with Iran. Congress tightened those restrictions even further last week when it voted to punish foreign companies and banks and American overseas subsidiaries that do business with the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps in Iran and its many front companies. Firms selling gasoline to Iran also are targeted.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 2, 2010

headline: Snack Like a Surfer
text: You don’t have to be a surfer to hang out at any of the three Fins restaurants at the Jersey Shore, but it might help you to understand some of the menu if you are.

headline: The Power of the Veto Pen
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York won’t be finished with his work after spending several days vetoing about 6,700 items in the state budget. After trying to keep the $136 billion budget under (sort of) control, Mr. Paterson will still need to have that veto pen handy.

headline: Ambitious Recipes in Simple Surroundings
text: THE crowds don’t come to the Belford Bistro for the location, or for the décor. It’s a mile and a half from the New York ferry, farther from a decent beach. It’s tucked off Route 36 in a corner of Monmouth County best known, if it is known at all, as a onetime trolley junction.

headline: In a Refuge Haunted by Katrina, BP Swirls In
text: ARABI, La.

headline: Wines for a Picnic
text: Five new releases from Macari Vineyards in Mattituck are neatly suited to backyard and beach picnics.

headline: Recipes for Summer, Beachfront Included
text: NAVY BEACH in Montauk is a perfect destination for summer dining. A beachfront restaurant that opened in May, it has wall-to-wall windows offering majestic views of sunsets on Fort Pond Bay; the vista includes two piers formerly used by the Navy, which had a base here.

headline: Once a Year, a Pie Rules
text: At Zephs’, a peach of a restaurant in Peekskill that takes big inspiration from seasonal produce, the phone started ringing in early May with calls from customers clamoring for sour cherry pie. That local cherries would not be ripe for another month or two  typically in late June  attests to the popularity of Vicky Zeph’s latticed handiwork.

headline: Sensible Rules, Soon
text: President Obama did the right thing in December when he repealed the 21-year-old ban on federal financing for programs that give drug users access to clean needles. Almost nothing has happened since because the Department of Health and Human Services still has not issued the new rules that states and localities need before they can use any federal money to expand existing exchange programs or start new ones.

headline: Welcoming the Laureate
text: The most public honor an American poet can receive is to be named poet laureate  officially Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress. The library describes the poet laureate as “the nation’s official lightning rod for the poetic impulse of Americans,” which conveys the potential excitement of the position even if it makes the job sound more dangerous than it likely is.

headline: An Eating Contest Will Be Missing a Top Eater
text: Say it ain’t so, Takeru!

headline: Spain Avoids Fouls by Keeping the Ball
text: JOHANNESBURG  The Spanish soccer players are so well behaved here at the World Cup that theirs is one of the least penalized teams contending for the title.

headline: Fighting, but Not Calling It Combat
text: NEAR TULUL AL-BAQ, Iraq – In an air conditioned tent here in the middle of the desert, surrounded by a security wall of armored vehicles, the chatter drifted to America’s other war.

headline: A Brief, Sweet Season of Sour Cherries
text: “GOOD morning, young folks! Ready to pick?” That was the greeting from Billie Jo Tunis, who for 16 years has worked the cherry season— as well as apricot, peach, pear and apple seasons — at LoveApple Farm, in Ghent, N.Y. When a customer said she might be ready to pick cherries once she had had a cup of coffee, Ms. Tunis pointed to a tray of dimpled pastries. “We have warm cherry turnovers, right from the oven,” she said. “Now, who could resist one of those with a cup of coffee?”

headline: Old-Fashioned Sodas That Never Go Out of Flavor
text: THE numerous tin advertising signs on the walls of the bottling shop at Avery’s Beverages look like museum pieces, colorful promotions for Pop Kola, Silver Seal Sodas, Varuna, Nichol Kola, Wynola, Ted’s Creamy Root Beer and other brands from the distant past. The greatest relic of all, however, may be Avery’s itself, an independent soda producer that has been supplying New Britain with a flavorful array of soft drinks since 1904.

headline: Like Vinyl Records
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — A crossword is ultimately about how it solves. Was it fun? Did it offer a good challenge? Were there interesting words in the grid? How about the clues?

headline: Papers Show Moynihan in Full Voice Under Nixon
text: He complained about the “Schrafft’s in the basement” color scheme proposed for the White House mess. He warned of the alienation of American blacks. He predicted the potential impact of global warming. He scoffed that anyone could seriously think the public still supported the Vietnam War. And he repeatedly chided his White House colleagues, saying they were making policy on the basis of unproved assumptions.

headline: A U.N. Agency for Women? Yes! But Those Names...
text: UNITED NATIONS  A certain hallowed ritual around the United Nations holds that to ensure a truly auspicious beginning, any new branch of the world body needs a really first-rate acronym.

headline: Nurse-Patient Ratios
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amid Warehouses, Gourmet Sandwiches, Yoga Classes and Yarn
text: For years there wasn’t much to see on this industrial block near the border of Bushwick and East Williamsburg. Welders sprayed iron sparks inside Metro Hi-Tech Steel and Builders, and garbage trucks dumped trash into the BFI Waste Systems warehouse.

headline: The Sounds of Free Agency
text: Two days into N.B.A. free agency, Billy Joel appears to be doing somewhat better than the Knicks. His song “New York State of Mind,” written in the 1970s, is suddenly being cited in all sorts of places as teams court players and players banter with reporters.

headline: After Call, Student Faces Deportation to China
text: Everyone knowledgeable about the criminal case against Zhai Tiantian seems to agree on one point: During a telephone call on April 15 to the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., Mr. Zhai completely lost his cool.

headline: Montenegro Convicts Man for 1990 Brooklyn Murder
text: A man the authorities chased for nearly two decades, from Brooklyn to the Bronx and through Belgium and Albania, was convicted in Montenegro on Friday for the 1990 murder of a woman whose body was found dismembered and left in bags near the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Corrections
text: A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about “The Screwtape Letters,” at the Westside Theater on West 43rd Street, misstated the closing date and was erroneously included among “Last Chance” theater entries. The run has been extended, and the play is scheduled to close on Sept. 30, not Sunday.

headline: A Stoudemire Addition and Lee Subtraction Might Not Benefit Knicks
text: In extending the free-agent forward Amar’e Stoudemire a maximum contract offer for five years and nearly $100 million, the Knicks moved themselves deep into the free-agent pool, with the desire to add an All-Star capable of averaging 20 points and 10 rebounds.

headline: The Mets Prepare to Take On Strasburg
text: WASHINGTON  When the hard-throwing rookie Stephen Strasburg takes on the Mets and the knuckleball pitcher R. A. Dickey on Saturday, it will be a contrast in styles, age, temperament and most everything else.

headline: The Cost of Living in the City vs. the Suburbs
text: The suburbs often begin to look a lot more attractive to certain city dwellers after they have children. Or maybe they simply begin to ache for a small patch of green to call their own. On the other hand, empty nesters can grow tired of mowing the lawn and feel the pull of urban life.

headline: In Justice Confirmation Hearings, Echoes of the Tea Party
text: Elena Kagan’s confirmation hearings this week were the first of the Tea Party era. When Republicans pressed Ms. Kagan on the Constitution’s commerce clause and whether she was a legal progressive, they were speaking not just about academic abstractions, but about the very ideas that animate the rebellious, conservative movement.

headline: Day 73: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Little Danger Seen for East Coast

headline: Budget Deficit and Wars’ Cost Draw Fire on the Home Front
text: WASHINGTON  The debate in Congress over an $82 billion war spending bill has opened up a war of a different sort  a fierce clash between House Democrats and the Obama White House over two highly sensitive issues: the nation’s huge budget deficit and the lingering wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Friday about the movie producer Elliott Kastner erroneously credited a distinction to one of his productions, the 1977 movie “Equus.” It was not in fact the first movie with a screenplay by the playwright Peter Shaffer. (“The Public Eye,” in 1972, was the first screenplay for which Mr. Shaffer received screen credit; he also worked on a screenplay for the 1963 film “Lord of the Flies,” although it was not used.)

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Rookie’s Instincts Help Mets Hold On
text: WASHINGTON  Francisco Rodriguez was not having much good fortune throwing the ball toward home plate Friday, so with the game hanging in the balance, he turned and fired in the opposite direction. With that, the Mets avoided a potentially disastrous outcome.

headline: The Physics of a Phenom: The Strasburg Machine
text:
When the Washington Nationals rookie Stephen Strasburg faces the Mets on Saturday afternoon, his 100-mile-an-hour fastballs and
big-breaking curves will crash into the strike zone more through basic mechanics than magic.

headline: Holiday Observed on Monday Independence Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Independence Day Holiday Observed on Monday
text: NEW YORK

headline: Hundreds Gather in West Virginia to Honor Senator Byrd
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  Hundreds of West Virginians, two presidents and dozens of family members and friends gathered here Friday to pay tribute to Robert C. Byrd, the longest-serving senator in American history.

headline: Juniors Watch: Pliskova Family Aiming for Second Slam
text: When Kristyna Pliskova of the Czech Republic takes the court for Saturday’s girls final at Wimbledon, she needn’t look beyond her own family for inspiration.

headline: Boat Collision in New York Harbor Kills 1
text: A man was killed and two others were injured in New York Harbor on Friday evening when their pleasure boat was rammed by another boat apparently being driven by a man who was intoxicated, the police said.

headline: Analysis: Nadal’s Transformation
text: Rafael Nadal’s tough straight sets win over Andy Murray was a testament to Nadal’s ability to adapt.. He has worked hard to add to his game, beefing up his serve and forehand to keep Murray on the defensive for most of the match. Under the guidance of his uncle Toni Nadal, Nadal has transformed himself from a player who wears down opponents with his consistency, speed and defense, to a player who excels at striking first and moving forward.

headline: Best Rangers Team Ever? LOL ;-)
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. – The Texas Rangers are the only major league team that has never won a postseason series. Even the Washington Nationals’ ancestors, the Montreal Expos, won a division series once, in 1981. But never the Rangers.

headline: Arnold Friberg, Painter of Historical Scenes, Is Dead at 96
text: Arnold Friberg, a widely popular artist of historical and religious scenes whose painstaking quest for stunning realism led him to Valley Forge, Pa., on a winter’s day to paint what became a famous portrait of George Washington praying in the snow, died Thursday in Salt Lake City. He was 96.

headline: Beryl Bainbridge, Mordant Novelist, Is Dead at 77
text: Beryl Bainbridge, whose sparely written, mordant novels, often with a dark comic edge, made her one of the most distinctive and admired voices in postwar British fiction, died on Thursday in London. She was 77.

headline: U.S. Wins Seventh Straight Title
text: Andrea Duran hit a two-run homer in the fifth and the United States defeated Japan, 7-0, on the mercy rule in Caracas, Venezuela, to win the world softball championship for the seventh year in a row.

headline: Impressive Field at World Open
text: The annual event in Philadelphia has attracted some of the best grandmasters from all over the world.

headline: Remembering Don Coryell, Innovator and Aerial Conductor
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Don Coryell died Thursday at age 85.

headline: A Quick Trip to the Nascar Hall of Fame
text: For Sunday’s Automobiles section, I wrote about a daylong tour I took with two friends through the heart of present-day Nascar in western North Carolina. The story focuses on the race shops in the Charlotte area, many of which are open to the public, but it also touches on the region’s pivotal role in Nascar’s past, from the sport’s bootlegging origins to the legendary drivers who first earned their stripes in the Tar Heel State.

headline: Serena Williams Sweeps to Fourth Wimbledon Title
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- Serena Williams of the United States powered her way to an easy, 6-3, 6-2 victory over Vera Zvonareva of Russia on Saturday to capture her fourth Wimbledon singles crown.

headline: They Did Their Homework (800 Years of It)
text: THE advertisement warns of speculative financial bubbles. It mocks a group of gullible Frenchmen seduced into a silly, 18th-century investment scheme, noting that the modern shareholder, armed with superior information, can avoid the pitfalls of the past. “How different the position of the investor today!” the ad enthuses.

headline: Bidder Beware
text: IT’S a shareholder’s worst nightmare. A company is in play, with two potential acquirers circling it, but the board of directors and others running the enterprise  who are supposed to snare top dollar for shareholders  favor bidders who are dangling the biggest rewards for directors and senior executives.

headline: World Cup Live: Germany vs. Argentina

headline: The Recording Industry, on the Ropes

headline: All-Star Rosters Are Taking Shape

He could win the National League title this season, and because he is retiring, he could skip the chore that falls to the pennant-winning manager the next summer: guiding the All-Star team and selecting some pitchers and reserves.

headline: Two Men With Imaginations Bigger Than Their Stomachs

headline: Becker’s Brash Run in ’85 Made Powerful Impression

headline: Flying the Company Flag

headline: The Great Rupture

They scroll through online job listings, availing themselves of free Wi-Fi, as they pass another drizzly afternoon in the temporary office of the age.

headline: Biden Offers Diplomacy Amid Impasse in Iraq

headline: Peavy and White Sox Find Themselves
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jake Peavy fooled himself at the end of last season. In three starts for his new team, the Chicago White Sox, Peavy went 3-0 with a 1.35 earned run average, 18 strikeouts and 6 walks. It was all an aberration.

headline: After 149-Pitch Outing, a Mere 88, but No Pain

headline: A Golf Tournament Where the Course Is One of the Stars
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  To anyone looking back from Aronimink Golf Club’s huge first green, down the 437 yards of a fairway that dips into a valley and stretches back up a hill to the elevated first tee, it is easy to understand why the revered golf course architect Donald Ross singled out Aronimink as his masterpiece.

headline: U.S. Fails to Complete, or Cuts Back, Iraqi Projects

headline: Riders Gird for Four Challenging, Engrossing Stages of the Tour
text: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  In the toughest, most varied Tour de France in recent history, the 198 riders do not have to be the best in every stage to pedal into Paris on July 25. But they do have to survive the hard days. There are plenty of them in this year’s Tour.

headline: The World Cup, Present and Future
text: Tonya Antonucci, a former Stanford player and Yahoo executive, is the commissioner of Women’s Professional Soccer. The league, in its second season, features top players from around the world. The World Cup in South Africa is soccer’s biggest stage, but next year’s Women’s World Cup from June 26 to July 17 in Germany should grab attention here because the United States is a strong contender.

headline: Hundreds Killed and Injured as Fuel Tanker Explodes in Congo
text: DAKAR, Senegal  A fuel tanker overturned, caught fire and exploded in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Friday evening, killing more than 200 villagers, some of whom had been trying to gather fuel from the leaking truck, officials in Congo said Saturday.

headline: Two Great Lunch Spots in La Paz. Just Don’t Ask Me for Their Names.
text: With my escape to Cochabamba and my time holed up in the Hostal República working on video No. 2, I didn’t get much time to explore La Paz. But I did do something I very rarely do when traveling: I ate the same meal twice. Since I always want to try as many places as I can, that only happens if I have something once and can’t stop thinking about it.

David H. Petraeus, used his first public appearance here on Saturday to underscore the need to “achieve unity of effort and common purpose.”

headline: Prime Number: 10
text: THE AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS OF DOLLARS, that a drunk British oil futures broker lost last year placing bets on Brent crude futures. Steven Noel Perkins had just returned home from a liquor-soaked golf weekend when he sat down and began placing the bets on his laptop, according to a report by Britain’s Financial Services Authority. He continued to drink through the night as he placed more than $520 million in trades, at one point pushing the price of oil to an eight-month high. The trades ended up costing his firm $10 million. Mr. Perkins was fined and barred from the financial services industry for five years. He has also stopped drinking, the F.S.A. said.

headline: A Booming Serena Williams Keeps Title
text: WIMBLEDON, England  At the end of the Wimbledon women’s singles final Saturday, Serena Williams turned toward her family in the stands. She flashed 10 fingers, then 3 fingers, for a total of 13  her updated tally of Grand Slam singles titles.

headline: My Picks for the All-Star Rosters
text: I’ve been picking the All-Star teams since I was a kid, just never for publication. It’s easy – you sit down with the stats, write down the candidates, and start cutting until you reach the roster limit. As Homer Simpson said, “Now it’s time for the easiest part of any coach’s job: the cuts.”

headline: Lost in Translation
text: “TOY STORY 3” EARNED NEARLY $227 MILLION in North America in its first two weekends. But the blockbuster has flopped in Russia, The Los Angeles Times reports, taking in only $4.8 million in its first 10 days. Why the deep freeze in a market where “Shrek Forever After” earned about $38 million over a comparable span? One answer, says the paper, may be that Russians are unfamiliar with the story. The first two “Toy Story” movies were released in the 1990s, before an explosion in theater growth.

headline: Analysis: Can Berdych Beat Nadal?
text: Perhaps the question going into the Wimbledon men’s championship match on Sunday is not if the first-time finalist Tomas Berdych can defeat the former champion Rafael Nadal, but what he must do to have a chance.

BILL AUCOIN, FORMER MANAGER OF THE ROCK BAND KISS, died last week. His marketing savvy helped build the band’s huge success. In 1977, The New York Times sent Colette Dowling to explore the hysteria over the band, whose leather-clad members in Kabuki-influenced makeup would spit fake blood and belch fire: “There are plenty of groups featuring youth, dynamism and at least a modicum of talent. But that is not at all what’s wanted by the fans of Kiss. ... What they want is outrageousness. (‘Outrageous,’ spoken with heavy emphasis on the ‘rage’ and overweening approval in the voice, is today’s slang for defiant or flamboyant behavior, going against the rules: ’50’s-style rebellion with a twist. Think of James Dean in drag.)”

headline: Appeals Court Sides With Detainee

But it has become the latest source of friction between Israel and the United States in a relationship that has lurched from crisis to crisis over the last few months.

headline: Postcards From a Faltering Economy: Four American Views

headline: Byrd and the Bard
text: SHAKESPEARE scholars, and the literary community generally, have selfish motives for missing Robert Byrd, the West Virginia senator who died last week at 92. Historians will long debate his complicated legacy, but scholars will no doubt agree that he was the greatest Shakespeare-quoter in American political history. His death marks the passing of an entire style of literate politics.

Einarsson, who had been the chairman of the committee to have Fischer freed following his arrest and detention in Japan.

But then the fan would have missed seeing the Yankees blitz the Toronto Blue Jays for 11 runs  or as many as they had scored in their previous 41 innings.

headline: Fourth of July 1776, 1964, 2010

Of all the countless attempts to dispel that shadow over the nation’s birth, few were more ambitious than the hard-fought bill Lyndon B. Johnson signed into law just in time for another Fourth of July, 46 summers ago.

headline: Russian Mayor Irks Security Agency, and Suffers

text: When the Deepwater Horizon drilling platform set off the worst oil spill at sea in American history, it was flying the flag of the Marshall Islands. Registering there allowed the rig’s owner to significantly reduce its American taxes.

text: CINCINNATI — The congressman was dripping with sweat, and his face was as red as a tomato as he moved through a crowded park here, passing out dozens of plastic cups bearing his name.

headline: No Place for Jingoism
text: The contrast in tone between the new national space policy unveiled by President Obama last week and the policy adopted by the Bush administration four years ago is striking. The Bush policy was jingoistic, unilateral in approach, and resistant to arms control in space. The Obama policy is cooperative, international in approach, and open to a verifiable arms control treaty to restrain the development of space weapons.

headline: The Right to Be Wrong
text: The Supreme Court has long held that newspapers and other publications have the right to be wrong, as long as they did not err deliberately or with negligence. As Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote in 1974, “the First Amendment requires that we protect some falsehood in order to protect speech that matters.” Unfortunately, the court missed an opportunity to uphold that principle when it refused to take an important First Amendment case last week.

headline: Liberty Thoughts
text: Today we celebrate an event that took place in the 18th century. It is an unusual event to commemorate with a holiday — not the first shot in a battle or the toppling of a government but the broadcasting, as it was in those days, of a proposition about the nature and the rights of human beings. How fruitful, how reasonable, how correct that proposition was, we have seen again and again throughout our history. That proposition was the Declaration of Independence.

headline: Making His Putts, Rose Expands His Lead to Four Strokes

headline: Mets Solve Strasburg but Collapse in the Ninth
text: WASHINGTON  The Mets had accomplished most everything they had hoped for Saturday. They stood in defiantly against the rookie sensation Stephen Strasburg, scored a couple of runs off him, and forced him out of the game after five innings. They received another command performance from their knuckleball pitcher, added insurance runs in the late innings and took a two-run lead into the ninth.

headline: Tomales Elk Preserve
text: The California grizzly may be extinct but the Tule elk, another species native to this state, has mounted quite a comeback from its near-extinction in the Civil War era. Thanks to sanctuaries like the 2,781-acre Tomales Point Reserve, on the northern tip of the Point Reyes peninsula, the elk population has risen from fewer than 30 in 1874 to 4,000 to 5,000 statewide. The animals are best viewed during summer’s “rutting season” when males bugle and duel to impress and accumulate females. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Death Raises Questions About Web Site for Speeding Cyclists
text: After Jack Backus, an Oakland cyclist, sped down a hill in Joaquin Miller Park recently, he raced home to upload information about the ride to a Web site called Strava.

headline: Green Developments, and Tension Aplenty
text: In his new book, Peter Calthorpe, the renowned Berkeley-based urban designer, sounds many a familiar environmentalist note. Paying explicit homage to Buckminster Fuller, he talks of “whole systems design” and “climate responsive buildings,” and issues dire warnings about global warming and peak oil and the dangers of our car-based lifestyle. He rejects “bigger is better” consumerism and advocates nothing less than a “new configuration for the American Dream.”

headline: A Program’s Legacy in Jobs and Lives
text: The private Daybridge School, which opens in Olympia Fields next month, may prove to be a testament to educational vision. For now, it’s an homage to serendipity, given the help afforded by President Obama’s economic stimulus package.

headline: Public Housing Residents Await Urgent Transfers
text: After her apartment was repeatedly broken into, Georgina Jenkins thought she had found a ticket out of Alemany, the public housing project known to residents as the Black Hole. The San Francisco Housing Authority had placed her on its priority transfer list, reserved for tenants facing immediate danger or urgent medical need, according to Ms. Jenkins and her attorney.

headline: Solis Wants Ordinance to Help Break ‘Code of Silence’
text: Alderman Danny Solis (25th Ward) called on Friday for an ordinance that would enlist Internet technology to protect the anonymity of witnesses who report crimes to the police.
