headline: Where Drink Is Cheap and War Talk Is Real
text: There was no bar quite like Blackhawk V.F.W. Post 7975, where $3 bought a drink and a tale from Bill Nowlin, the post’s commander  burp guns, Korean rice patties, firefights, hand-to-hand combat. For $5, Joe Makowski, the quartermaster, blended a concoction of rum and fresh fruit, adorned with a paper parrot tethered to a straw.

headline: Your Comments on my Gaza Column
text: My Sunday column is from Gaza, where I argue that Israel should not just ease the trade restrictions but lift them. The problem with closing off Gaza, quite aside from the injustice of collective punishment, is that it tends to foster just the extremism that most threatens Israel and the entire Middle East. The constituencies for moderation and peace — civil society and the business sector — have been nearly destroyed and silenced, while Hamas appears to have been strengthened.

headline: Benny Powell, Who Played Trombone With Count Basie, Is Dead at 80
text: Benny Powell, a trombonist who performed or recorded with everyone from Frank Sinatra to Screamin’ Jay Hawkins but who was best known for his long tenure with Count Basie’s big band, died on June 26 in New York. He was 80.

headline: For Many Wimbledon Fans, the Waiting Is Not the Hardest Part
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Eight days after Wimbledon began, Rose Stanley, identified by club officials as a South African resident visiting her son in London, accepted Queue Card 10,516 as she entered the line inside the golf course.

headline: Charles S. King, Range Rover Designer, Dies at 85
text: Charles Spencer King, a British engineer who led the team that developed the Range Rover as the ultimate vehicle for the landed aristocracy, and who watched in dismay as his creation became an international symbol of gas-guzzling conspicuous consumption, died June 26 in Coventry, England. He was 85.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 3, 2010

headline: Loan Giants Opt to Block Energy Programs
text: Two government-chartered mortgage finance companies are unlikely to accept loans on homes that are part of a special program that lets homeowners repay the cost of energy improvements through a surcharge on their property tax bills, according to Energy Department officials.

headline: Liberty Falls in Phoenix
text: Liberty guard Cappie Pondexter scored 21 points in her first game in Phoenix since her trade to New York, but the Mercury defeated the Liberty, 97-82, on Saturday night. Candice Dupree led the Mercury with 24 points.

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Consolidating Lawsuits

headline: Correction
text: The cover article on June 6 about the World Cup in South Africa, with reports from six residents about five of the host cities there, misstated the name of a coffeehouse in Pretoria on Church Square. It is Cafe Riche, not Cafe Rouge.

headline: Vows: Annette & Kirk
text: Annette Stamatelatos is a singer and songwriter known professionally as Annet Artani. She met Kirk Ceballos, a talent agent, but resisted his pursuit until he proved his mettle when she needed him the most.

headline: Materials Take Spotlight at London Art Show
text: A new exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery in London is putting the focus on the actual materials that become art. It’s also giving 60 of the 400 pieces in the impressive Daskalopoulos Collection their first London showing.

headline: Petraeus Takes Command of Afghan Mission
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Gen. David H. Petraeus took command of the troubled Afghan war on Sunday, warning of hard days to come but promising to persevere until the government and army here are strong enough to stand on their own.

headline: Kansas City Chiefs 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Preserving Its Piece of the Pie
text: Dow Chemical, which uses a lot of energy plus copious amounts of natural gas as an ingredient of the chemicals it manufactures, is sitting pretty for the moment because the price of that fuel is down sharply. Still, it is worried about the future.

headline: Nadal Beats Berdych to Win Wimbledon Title
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Shutting down his opponent’s weapons at every stage, Rafael Nadal of Spain defeated Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic, 6-3, 7-5, 6-4, to win his second Wimbledon title and regain the crown he surrendered a year ago.

headline: White Population Rises in Manhattan
text: For the first time since the 1970s, a majority of Manhattan’s population is non-Hispanic white, according to an analysis of census estimates.

headline: Japanese Interest Payments
text: So Dan Senor and I had a little tussle on This Week over how much of Japan’s budget goes to interest payments; he said a quarter, I said that he was wrong.

headline: An Entertaining Book by Christina Kim
text: The United States Women’s Open begins Thursday, and if you want a glimpse into life on the women’s professional tour, Christina Kim’s new book, “Swinging From My Heels” (Bloomsbury), takes you inside that world with dozens of funny, sincere and insightful tales. Though framed as a diary chronicling the 2009 season, the book, co-authored by Alan Shipnuck of Sports Illustrated, is also a narrative of Kim’s life. Brash and bawdy, Kim has a lot to say and knows how to tell a story. She also brings some of her famous golfer friends along for the ride.

headline: After Seizing the Moment, a Victorious Nadal Holds On to It
text: WIMBLEDON, England  For the longest time, Rafael Nadal clung to his championship keepsake. He carried it, cradled it, even signed autographs with it tucked away in his right arm.

headline: Green Groups Press Obama on Energy and CO2
text: 1:10 p.m. | Updated On the Green blog, John Broder has posted a letter that was sent to President Obama on Friday pressing him to get directly involved in crafting Senate legislation that would cut oil use and emissions of greenhouse gases. The letter warns that only the president can overcome the special interests pushing for stasis on energy policy. It’s a public nudge to a president who has been treated with kid gloves by the core of the traditional environmental movement — known around Washington as “The Green Group.”

headline: Same Kind of Crime, Different Accent
text: PITY the “Law & Order” purist. Now that the mother ship has been canceled after 20 seasons, what are you supposed to do if “SVU” leaves you cold, “Criminal Intent” bores you, and the thought of this fall’s “Law & Order: Los Angeles” scares the hell out of you? If only the real thing will do  and if you’ve seen every rerun on TNT and USA at least twice  there is still one place to turn.

headline: Giving Voice to the Young and the Reluctant
text: THE ingredients add up to a certified hit: An earnest, young teacher intent on building the choir of his dreams. Ragtag high schoolers wrestling with adolescent angst. Feuding faculty members. Bullies who think singing is for losers. Success. Failure. And, oh, those showstopping tunes.

headline: ‘Still Missing’
text: SESSION TWO

headline: BP Wants Partners to Help Shoulder Spill Cost
text: BP has said repeatedly that it will pay for the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. But its actions show that it does not intend to go it alone.

headline: All-Star Rosters Are Set, and Mets’ Pelfrey Misses Out
text: The Yankees found that it is good when their manager helps select the American League roster for the All-Star Game. The Mets found that, perhaps predictably, the same does not apply when the manager of their chief divisional rival helps create the National League roster.

headline: Cast Party
text: Images from Jim Caruso’s weekly gathering at Birdland.

headline: The Showboats Must Go On (Even on Their Nights Off)
text: Bites from the Broadway bug can be deep, incurable and  for both actors and fans  easy to scratch, even on nights when not much is playing onstage.

headline: On This Show, the Setting Is a Headliner, Too
text: In the second season of “Live From the Artists Den,” a music series on PBS, the singer-songwriter Tori Amos serenades a crowd of about 100 people. The difference is that the performance is not on a traditional stage but in an ornate room designed by Louis Comfort Tiffany at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan.

headline: Two Mets Are All-Stars, but Not Pelfrey
text: WASHINGTON — David Wright and Jose Reyes were selected to the National League All-Star team Sunday, but Mike Pelfrey was not, despite a 10-2 record and 2.93 earned run average.

headline: Crashes Become the Talk of the Tour After a Treacherous First Stage
text: BRUSSELS  The riders in the Tour de France crossed the finish line of Stage 1 on Sunday, some wincing and wounded, others so angry that they could only growl after a crash-filled afternoon had ruined their day.

headline: Status Quo Preserved at Women’s Grand Prix
text: Nana Dzagnidze of the Republic of Georgia guaranteed herself at least a tie for first after most of Sunday’s games ended in draws, preserving her one point lead.

headline: Senior Republicans Question Steele’s Ability to Lead
text: Three prominent Republican lawmakers on Sunday questioned whether Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, can effectively lead the party after he called the conflict in Afghanistan a misguided “war of Obama’s choosing.”

headline: Sony Remakes Its Music Company Act
text: PARIS — At an outdoor theater in Berlin that has played host to U2, R.E.M. and the Rolling Stones, Sony Music Entertainment plans to stage a very different kind of show next month.

headline: Acting President in Poland Wins a Narrow Victory
text: WARSAW  Poland’s acting president fended off a stiff electoral challenge on Sunday from the twin brother of the leader who died in a plane crash in April.

headline: Lessons in Music and Compatibility
text: The Books

headline: German Community in Jo’burg Delights in Team’s Performance
text: Jackie Bischof is a South African freelance writer living in Johannesburg.

headline: Government in Pakistan Calls Meeting on Terrorism
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In an unusual sign of accord between the two major political parties, Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani announced over the weekend that the government and the opposition would hold a national conference on ways to combat terrorism.

headline: Finding the Right Amount of Selfishness
text: In sports it can be good to be selfish. Around the Ajax youth academy a story is often told of the young Johan Cruyff. For those who do not know, Cruyff is considered the best player the Netherlands has ever had. Internationally he ranks among the greats, just slightly behind Maradona and Pele.

headline: Crowds Flock to Vampires (of Course) and ‘Airbender’ (Surprise!)
text: LOS ANGELES  “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” drew an estimated $161 million out of North American theaters in its first five days of release, a spectacular if not quite record-breaking result. And in a surprise, audiences defied critics to make “The Last Airbender” No. 2.

headline: A Sacrifice in 7 Hearts and an Excess of Caution
text: Four teams entered the under-21 trial held in Chicago on June 26 and 27. After 32-board semifinals and a 48-board final, the team of Adam Kaplan, Adam Grossack, Alex Hudson, John Marriott, Jourdain Patchett and Jesse Stern had qualified as one of the United States teams in the World Youngsters Championship for the José Damiani Cup in Philadelphia in October.

headline: An Abduction and Its Chilling Aftermath
text: Annie O’Sullivan is a real-estate saleswoman hosting an open house when a smiling, affluent-looking prospective buyer named David appears. “It was one of the most genuine smiles I’d seen in a long time, and a face you just had to smile back at,” Annie observes.

headline: Beethoven’s Variations and Endless Imagination
text: Long before Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations became the springboard for Moisés Kaufman’s 2009 play, “33 Variations,” the composition was a fertile source for speculation. The back story is clear enough: In 1819 Anton Diabelli, a music publisher and composer, sent a humble waltz of his own devising to the most prominent composers of the Austrian Empire, asking each to write a variation for inclusion in what Diabelli conceived as a patriotic anthology.

headline: French Scandals Over Expenses Force 2 to Resign
text: PARIS  Two French government ministers resigned suddenly on Sunday, apparently pushed by President Nicolas Sarkozy, after new attention was brought to spending scandals involving Cuban cigars and a private jet.

headline: Turn Around and Watch the Music
text: A springy figure in a hooded black cloaklike dress, Cameron Mesirow didn’t quite know where to look on Saturday. From the improvised outdoor stage at MoMA P.S. 1 she was able to survey all the afternoon’s distractions. In the far distance people bounced on balance balls and frolicked under a spray mist. Closer to her the space that was ostensibly the dance floor was only lightly populated; the bigger crowds were clustered tight against the side of the building that was blocking the sun.

headline: On the Town With Stoudemire
text: Amar’e Stoudemire continued to feel right at home in New York City on Sunday. In fact, he was right behind home plate, in front-row seats provided by Joba Chamberlain for a few innings of the Yankees’ game against Toronto.

headline: Friendship in an Age of Economics
text: When I was 17 years old, I had the honor of being the youngest person in the history of New York Hospital to undergo surgery for a herniated disc. This was at a time in which operations like this kept people in the hospital for over a week. The day after my surgery, I awoke to find a friend of mine sitting in a chair across from my bed. I don’t remember much about his visit. I am sure I was too sedated to say much. But I will not forget that he visited me on that day, and sat there for I know not how long, while my humanity was in the care of a morphine drip.

headline: Juniors Watch: Pliskova and Fucsovics Claim Titles
text: The Pliskova sisters are not yet in the league of the Williams sisters or the Bryan twins, but with Kristyna’s 6-3, 4-6, 6-4 victory over Sachie Ishizu of Japan in the Wimbledon girls final on Saturday, they now have two junior slam titles between them.

headline: Straightforward, Straight-From-Texas Rock
text: ALEJANDRO ESCOVEDO “Street Songs of Love” (Fantasy)

headline: Teachers’ Union Shuns Obama Aides at Convention
text: NEW ORLEANS  For two years as a presidential candidate, Barack Obama addressed educators gathered for the summer conventions of the two national teachers’ unions, and last year both groups rolled out the welcome mat for Education Secretary Arne Duncan.

headline: Love That Look, Wonder Woman
text: Fan reaction to the decision by DC Comics to change the traditional costume of Wonder Woman, below, has run from welcoming to guarded to enraged. But the new costume does have at least one prominent superfan: Tim Gunn, the mentor to the designers on “Project Runway,” who has experience with outfits that are too costumey. “I love Wonder Woman’s new look,” Mr. Gunn told newsarama.com, a Web site that covers comic books. “Considering how superheroes operate, you want freedom to move and move quickly,” he said. “Capes and cloaks can be easily removed if they get caught on something. Gowns and dresses, not so much. The more form-fitting, the better. So tight pants or skinny jeans, sure.” Mr. Gunn also noted that the move away from bright costumes to more natural-looking clothing could be a plus. “I would imagine that this new look will allow Wonder Woman to morph into situations in a less noticeable manner and, thereby be even more effective at combating evildoers,” he said. Pro or con, one thing is certain: Wonder Woman has not been talked about like this in ages.

headline: Lady Gaga Is Fantastic
text: It wasn’t too long ago that your popularity could be measured by the amount of Esprit shirts and Izod shorts counted at your school lunch table. Now Facebook has brought popularity into the digital age, giving members solid evidence of how much they’re liked by the number of “fans” they can accumulate on their Web pages. And on Friday Lady Gaga, the 24-year-old whose real name is Stefani Germanotta, became the first living person to have more than 10 million fans, according to numbers gathered by Famecount.com, a British group that measures online popularity. By Sunday Lady Gaga had accumulated 10,333,791 fans, beating out strong contenders like President Obama, who had only 9,670,042 million. In a video posted on her Facebook page Lady Gaga thanked “all the little monsters” who helped put her over the top. But she shouldn’t let the fame go to her head just yet. It may be a while before she can overtake Michael Jackson, who has over 14 million fans, or the most popular Facebook star of all, Texas Holdem Poker, an online game with more than 20 million fans.

headline: Polanski Decision Due Soon, Swiss Say
text: Swiss officials said this weekend that they were close to deciding whether to extradite Roman Polanski to the United States, The Associated Press reported. The justice ministry spokesman, Folco Galli, said that “it won’t be long” before a decision was made, but would not give further details. In 1977, after being arrested in California, Mr. Polanski, above, pleaded guilty to having unlawful sex with a minor, but he fled the United States in 1978 before sentencing. He was arrested in Switzerland on Sept. 26 and has been under house arrest there since.

headline: Mehta to Conduct Concert Near Gaza
text: Zubin Mehta, a former music director for the New York Philharmonic, will conduct the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra in a short concert on Monday near the Gaza border in southern Israel, The Associated Press reported. The program of classical and Israeli music was planned in support of demands for the release of Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier who has been held prisoner by Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip for four years. Mr. Mehta, the chief conductor of the Teatro del Maggio Musicale Fiorentino in Florence, Italy, said he hoped the program would inspire Gazans to pressure the Hamas government to allow the Red Cross to visit Sergeant Shalit. The concert will coincide with a 12-day march heading to Jerusalem by thousands of protesters who want the government to do more to obtain the sergeant’s release.

headline: Peas in 3-D
text: Just in case their Space Age costumes and repetitive dance beats didn’t jump out at you enough, the Black Eyed Peas have decided to have a 3-D concert-tour movie made, and by none other than that 3-D specialist, the director James Cameron. “We have the biggest director because we are the biggest group on the planet,” will.i.am, a member of the group, told Vibe magazine. “People will be able to see us in the theater with the 3-D glasses and everything,” he said. The film, to be shot in South America, will document the band’s tour, following a story line devised by Mr. Cameron, “which will be dope,” will.i.am said. It will also include footage of the band’s concerts. A release of the film is expected early next year. The Peas are in the middle of their “E.N.D. World Tour 2010,” which will continue through the summer, with shows in Europe and North America.

headline: Restless Bones of Caravaggio
text: The presumed remains of the master Renaissance artist Caravaggio went on display in Tuscany on Sunday, Agence France-Presse reported. His bones, held in a crystal urn, were transported to Porto Ercole by boat in a symbolic tribute to the original trip that brought Caravaggio there in the late 16th century. The bones were exhumed from an unmarked grave in a local cemetery in 1956, then stored in a church there until a campaign began to determine their authenticity. The urn went on display at the historic Forte Stella and will be there for one month in conjunction with an exhibition of photographs detailing the work of the team of microbiologists, art historians and anthropologists who helped to identify the bones. The team estimated that Caravaggio died in about 1610, between the ages of 38 and 40. By some accounts he died of malaria in the marshy Maremma region of southern Tuscany, but the team has found that he also probably had syphilis and lead poisoning.

headline: Grand Ayatollah Fadlallah, Shiite Cleric, Dies at 75
text: Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the top Shiite cleric in Lebanon, whose writings and preachings inspired the Dawa Party of Iraq and a generation of militants, including the founders of Hezbollah, died Sunday morning in Beirut. He was 75.

headline: Biden, in Iraq, Urges Leaders to Form Government
text: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. drew an analogy to the signers of the Declaration of Independence on Sunday in exhorting Iraqi leaders to end the paralysis that has stalled the formation of a government since the parliamentary elections four months ago.

headline: ‘The Cove’ Finally Opens in Japan
text: “The Cove,” the Oscar-winning documentary that revealed the clandestine killing of dolphins in Taiji, Japan, has finally had its first showing in that country, The Associated Press reported. Theaters in Tokyo and Osaka canceled opening screenings earlier this summer because theater owners said they feared for the safety of moviegoers after receiving threats from protest groups who considered the movie to be “anti-Japan.” The documentary, directed by the photographer Louie Psihoyos, opened to full houses in six small cinemas around Japan on Saturday with a significant amount of protesting from both sides of the issue. (Pro-whaling protesters in Tokyo, left.) Aside from police officers ending a few altercations between supporters of the film and angry nationalists, the protests proved to be no deterrent for moviegoers. “I didn’t know about dolphin hunting,” Tomokazu Toshinai said as he entered a theater. “Whether it’s TV or movies, Japanese have a right to know these things.” A theater in Nagoya said that it would show “The Cove” along with “Whalers and the Sea,” a documentary sympathetic to the Japanese whaling industry. Another 18 theaters plan to screen “The Cove” later this year.

headline: Analysis: Nadal’s Contained Fury
text: “A wild patience has taken me this far,” is a line from the great American poet Adrienne Rich, and it perfectly describes how Rafael Nadal plays tennis. Watching his straight set win over Tomas Berdych, I was struck by how Nadal plays with unbridled energy and passion, but he’s also calm and contained mentally. In his match with Murray in the semifinals, and again on Sunday against Berdych, there was a sense of inevitability to each match. The scores of each set were close, but you just knew that Rafa wouldn’t get broken, and that at some point Murray and Berdych would blink.

headline: Separate
text: It’s just a jump to the leftAnd then a step to the rightWith your hands on your hipsYou bring your knees in tightBut it’s the pelvic thrust that really drives you insane,Let’s do the Time Warp again!

headline: Karpov Disputes Rival’s Nominations
text: Last week, the World Chess Federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fédération Internationale des Échecs) announced the two slates of candidates for its top offices. The announcement said that the incumbent, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, had been nominated by Russia, Argentina and Mexico, while the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, had been nominated by France, Germany and Switzerland.

headline: Thames Wins It in 10th After Rivera Can’t Close Door in 9th
text: The Yankees have reached the halfway point in their season, 81 games into the year, with the best record in baseball. But Manager Joe Girardi said Sunday that his team could be better.

headline: After 54 Hot Dogs, the Spectacle Began
text: It was not long after Joey “Jaws” Chestnut locked down his fourth consecutive win at the Nathan’s International Hot Dog Eating Contest on Coney Island, when things began to get interesting on Sunday.

headline: The Pitfalls in Identifying a Gifted Child
text: Thirty-seven states have some sort of mandate to address the needs of gifted and talented students in public schools. While many parents and teachers have mixed views about the tests used to identify talent and “giftedness,” the programs are strongly supported by many parents who cannot afford to send their children to private schools. They are hard to overhaul, for various reasons.

headline: Queen Elizabeth to Visit Manhattan on Tuesday
text: She was a vivacious young queen when she first saw New York City in 1957, regal in white gloves but as dazzled as any tourist taking in the Statue of Liberty and the skyline of Manhattan from the deck of a rumbling Army ferry. She wanted her first sight of the magical city “as it should be approached,” she said — from the harbor.

headline: A House With a Role in the Revolution Is Now Left Unprotected
text: NORTH WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.

headline: Day 75: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Choppy Seas Interrupt Cleanup

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,402 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,137 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

headline: Widow Urges an End to a Deadly Construction Practice
text: The plea from the widow of one of six workers killed by an explosion at a Connecticut power plant in February was poignant and sincere, but also sadly familiar.

headline: Two Cricket Clubs Face Off Again, More Than a Century Later
text: On July 18, 1886, The New York Times  as it often did in those pocket-watch-and-frock-coat days  reported on a cricket match, a big one, played between the Staten Island Cricket Club and a visiting squad from Merion, Pa. The occasion was the debut competition at the Staten Island field, although, by all accounts, it was a miserable display.

headline: Should Schools Police Cyberbullying?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Education Dollars
text: To the Editor:

headline: Antibiotics in Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Natural Gas and Its Effects on Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Diagnosing Alzheimer’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Just When Cup Had Its Theme, Story Takes a Sudden Turn
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: Nickelodeon Tries Again to Move to the Big Screen
text: LOS ANGELES  The Nickelodeon brand is finally getting the red-carpet treatment from Paramount Pictures.

headline: Take Me to the River. Finally.
text: THIS summer, with the debut of the Brooklyn Bridge Park, as well as the expansion of Manhattan’s Hudson River Park and Governors Island, New Yorkers have celebrated the reclamation of the waterfront. But the effort, laudable though it is, obscures a not-so-insignificant historical misunderstanding: we are in fact claiming the waterfront, not reclaiming it.

headline: Republican Senators Denounce Steele’s Remarks
text: WASHINGTON  Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, sought to contain a growing furor within his party on Sunday as three Republican lawmakers questioned his effectiveness because of his suggestion that the military conflict in Afghanistan was not winnable and was “a war of Obama’s choosing.”

headline: Nighthawks State of Mind
text: IN 1941, Edward Hopper began what would become his most recognizable work, one that has become an emblem of New York City. “‘Nighthawks,’” Hopper said in an interview later, “was suggested by a restaurant on Greenwich Avenue where two streets meet.” The location was pinpointed by a Hopper expert, Gail Levin, as the “empty triangular lot” where Greenwich meets 11th Street and Seventh Avenue, otherwise known as Mulry Square. This has become accepted city folklore. Greenwich Village tour guides point to the lot, now owned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and tell visitors that Hopper’s diner stood there. But did it?

headline: Rodriguez Bounces Back Against the Nationals to Wrap Up a Trying Trip
text: WASHINGTON  The Mets may have discovered the best way to avoid the dreaded walk-off loss Sunday, and the solution was simple. By scoring nine times and carrying a four-run lead into the ninth inning, the Mets created a gap too large even for their erratic closer to squander, ensuring there would be no celebrations at the plate by the home team on this holiday.

headline: Sumo Figures Barred in Japan for Gambling
text: TOKYO  Japan’s national sport of sumo ejected a top wrestler and a coach on Sunday and slapped punishments on nearly two dozen others for their involvement in gambling run by organized crime.

headline: On Steinbrenner’s 80th Birthday, a Chance to Reflect
text: On a lazy spring day in Tampa, in the fifth inning of a meaningless exhibition game, Andy Pettitte decided to check in with the Boss, the soon-to-be octogenarian and longtime contrarian.

headline: Closing an Old Polluter May Not Ease Emissions
text: GUANGZHOU, China  Workers at the vast Guangzhou Steel mill here poured molten metal for the Great Leap Forward in the late 1950s, fought street battles during the Cultural Revolution a decade later and made many of the steel reinforcing bars used to build China’s export factories over the next 30 years. But as part of a national energy-efficiency mandate, the historic mill is to be closed, starting in stages later this year.

headline: China Fears Consumer Impact on Global Warming
text: GUANGZHOU, China — Premier Wen Jiabao has promised to use an “iron hand” this summer to make his nation more energy efficient. The central government has ordered cities to close inefficient factories by September, like the vast Guangzhou Steel mill here, where most of the 6,000 workers will be laid off or pushed into early retirement.

headline: Closing a Historic Steel Mill
text: The closing of Guangzhou’s famous steel mill in China may yield only modest benefits in energy efficiency, and it is not necessarily a triumph of political will.

headline: On the True Scoreboard, James Is the Hunter, Not the Prize
text: The 19-hour flight to New York from Johannesburg last week provided ample time for reflection. For thoughts about a month spent in South Africa, the World Cup and all its stellar performances. With so much to think about, it was easy to lose track of the burning issues of the sports world in the United States.

headline: ‘Summer Hours’
text: All it takes is a short walk in the woods to put you back in the food chain. As unpleasant as mosquitoes are, I’m just glad there’s still a food chain to be in.

headline: German Is Off Bench and on Verge of Goal Record
text: CAPE TOWN — It is not all about youth for this revamped and captivating German national team. It is not all about the thrill of newcomers discovering that their talents match up with established figures like Wayne Rooney and John Terry of England or Lionel Messi and Gabriel Heinze of Argentina.

headline: Punishing the Jobless
text: There was a time when everyone took it for granted that unemployment insurance, which normally terminates after 26 weeks, would be extended in times of persistent joblessness. It was, most people agreed, the decent thing to do.

headline: Making Friends With a Robot Named Bina48
text: BRISTOL, Vt.  Ten minutes into my interview with the robot known as Bina48, I longed to shut her down.

headline: A Soft Spot for Circuitry
text: Nothing Eileen Oldaker tried could calm her mother when she called from the nursing home, disoriented and distressed in what was likely the early stages of dementia. So Ms. Oldaker hung up, dialed the nurses’ station and begged them to get Paro.

headline: The Pessimism Bubble
text: This is a day for hangovers and sunburns, discarded sparklers and spent rockets smoking weakly on brown lawns. Yesterday was all euphoria and patriotism  a chance to forget about the unemployment rate, the deficit, the oil spill and whichever political party you hold responsible for the country’s sorry state. But now it’s time to sit around in your undershirt, put off cleaning the backyard grill and contemplate all the things you spent the Fourth of July trying not to think about.

headline: Pro-Am With a Talented Field
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Justin Rose barely had time for the victory in the AT&T National at Aronimink Golf Club to sink in before he was headed to the airport to catch a chartered jet from Philadelphia to head across the pond to Limerick, Ireland, for the J.P. McManus Invitational Pro-Am. It’s a charity fund-raiser that features a stunning array of the world’s best golfers, including Tiger Woods, Lee Westwood, Ernie Els, Jim Furyk, Luke Donald, Rory McIlroy, Graeme McDowell and Padraig Harrington.

headline: Horses Kill 1 and Injure 23 at Iowa Parade
text: A Fourth of July parade in eastern Iowa turned to mayhem on Sunday when a pair of runaway horses lunged into the crowd and trampled 24 people, many of them children. At least one person was killed, and several others were seriously injured.

headline: Rikers to Consolidate 2 Academic Programs
text: A pair of longstanding academic programs for young inmates on Rikers Island, including one dating to the Koch administration that was a first for a United States correctional facility, are being merged into a single system, city officials said.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Companies Find Ways to Bypass Ban on Earmarks
The Fourth of July at a 98-Degree Angle
Holiday Observed on Monday, Independence Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: The Court’s Aggressive Term
text: John Roberts Jr., the chief justice of the United States, did not write the most important opinion of his court’s just concluded term, the one that allowed unlimited corporate and union spending in election campaigns. But his concurring opinion in that case, Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, is the best guide to the court’s most unsettling tendency.

headline: More Questions About Avandia
text: The safety of the diabetes drug Avandia looked increasingly suspect late last month after two major studies found that it raises the risk of cardiovascular ailments. Then a third study seemed to exonerate Avandia, sowing more confusion. Expert advisers to the Food and Drug Administration will soon deliver a more definitive judgment, but at this point patients should probably be asking their doctors about alternatives.

headline: Gambling Fever
text: Gamblers aren’t the only ones prone to jackpot delusions. Politicians all over see casinos as magic revenue chests that will help them avoid painful spending cuts, escape the trap of no-tax pledges and make budget gaps vanish. New York is no exception.

headline: Water and Grasses
text: I am just home from a solo drive across country, accompanied by my thoughts and the lovely, implacable songs of Lori McKenna. I didn’t solve any problems, for all my thinking, but I did a lot of looking. And, to use the wonderful old phrase, I will tell you what. In America the rivers are full  the Yellowstone, the Cheyenne, the Missouri, the Rock, the Mississippi. They reach up into the boughs of the trees that overarch them and sweep their shadows away downstream.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 4, 2010

headline: Pakistan Army Finds Taliban Tough to Root Out
text: RAZMAK, Pakistan  On an operating table at a makeshift trauma center at this military base in North Waziristan, a Pakistani soldier lay anesthetized, blood-soaked bandages applied in the field just an hour earlier a testament to a near-fatal wound.

headline: Resurgent Guerrero Helps Rangers Chase Playoff Spot
text: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Vladimir Guerrero wears a bright blue Superman T-shirt in the clubhouse before every game. He has done so since his years with the Montreal Expos, when he played the role across major league diamonds.

headline: Israel Grows Uneasy Over Reliance on Migrant Labor
text: TEL AVIV  Perched 22 stories above an affluent suburb of this prosperous seaside city, three Chinese construction workers inched their way along the arm of a crane last autumn and refused to budge. Facing deportation because of expiring visas, theirs was an act of desperation aimed at getting thousands of dollars in wages they claimed their Israeli employer had illegally withheld.

headline: Knicks Quietly Make Another Run at James
text: The Knicks added an unexpected wrinkle and some intrigue into the LeBron James derby over the weekend by stealthily convening a second time with his agent, Leon Rose.

headline: A Language Thrives in Its Caribbean Home
text: WILLEMSTAD, Curaçao  Thousands of languages spoken by small numbers of people, including many of the Creole languages born in the last centuries of human history, are facing extinction. But a little-known language spoken on a handful of islands near the coast of Venezuela may be an exception.

headline: Retailers Devise Novel Ways to Revive Sales
text: Tired of waiting for spending to rebound on its own, retailers are taking matters into their own hands. Stores like Sam’s Club, Target, Toys “R” Us, Staples and Office Depot are offering unconventional promotions meant not only to attract visitors to stores, but also to get them feeling profligate.

headline: Old Movie Houses Find Audience in the Plains
text: LANGDON, N. D.  Every Friday through Monday night, from her perch behind the Skittles and the M&M’s, Amy Freier awaits the faithful at the historic Roxy Theater. There is Dale Klein, the school bus driver (large Diet Pepsi with a refill). And there is Jeannette Schefter, the social worker (large plain popcorn, medium Diet).

headline: Week After Folding, Rose Wins Steadily
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  After 12 years of working, sweating and wondering when he would finally win in the United States, Justin Rose has begun to make it look easy. Rose won his second tournament on the PGA Tour in a month on Sunday, taking the AT&T National on a day nearly as hot as he was.

headline: Once-Dominant Party in Mexico Seems Resurgent
text: MEXICO CITY  The political party that governed Mexico for 71 years before voters shunted it aside appeared headed for a strong showing in gubernatorial elections on Sunday, which analysts saw as a sign of growing concern about the country’s rising insecurity from violent drug gangs.

headline: Cricket Rematch in Staten Island
text: Two cricket clubs face off for a rematch on a Staten Island field, more than a century later.

headline: Houston’s Clergy Unites to Urge Support for Immigration Reform
text: HOUSTON  The Rev. John W. Bowie knows it is hard to sell the people in his neighborhood on the idea that they should support changing immigration laws to give illegal immigrants a path to citizenship. His church lies in one of the oldest black settlements in the city, where unemployment is high and many people see immigrants as competitors for jobs.

headline: Microsoft Calling. Anyone There?
text: Microsoft’s engineers and executives spent two years creating a new line of smartphones with playful names that sounded like creatures straight out of “The Cat in the Hat”  Kin One and Kin Two. Stylish designs, an emphasis on flashy social-networking features and an all-out marketing blitz were meant to prove that Microsoft could build the right product at the right time for the finickiest customers  gossiping youngsters with gadget skills.

headline: ‘Summer Hours’
text: A film by Jeff Scher about warm sun, cool water and a few mosquitoes.

headline: Unearthing Doubts About Caravaggio’s Remains
text: PORTO ERCOLE, Italy  Four hundred years after Michelangelo Merisi, the painter known as Caravaggio, died in this coastal Tuscan town  wretched, feverish and on the run from numerous enemies  what are said to be his remains received a hero’s welcome on Saturday.

headline: Revival of the Main Street Theater
text: The small town Main Street movie theater is thriving in North Dakota, the result of a grass-roots movement to keep storefront movie houses at the center of community life.

headline: A Political Clash Over Deficits Stalls Legislation to Address Jobs
text: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress headed for a recess over the weekend having failed to agree on legislation to address the nation’s fragile employment picture, with both parties placing starkly different bets on the political consequences of their positions.

headline: A Leader Board Awash in Taste
text: Nick Faldo has a crisp shiraz with a hint of licorice. The Jack Nicklaus cabernet sauvignon has aromas of blackberry, red plum and cedar. Luke Donald’s wines include a subtle but spicy claret. Mike Weir has produced four Canadian wines, including a pinot noir. Arnold Palmer weighs in with a chardonnay and Annika Sorenstam a syrah. Greg Norman makes more than a dozen red, white and sparkling wines. Ernie Els owns a flourishing vineyard in South Africa.

headline: Outspoken Is Great, Till It’s Not
text: Wanted: Political blogger covering the conservative movement. Must be provocative and write with a strong point of view although not in a way that would reveal bias or offend any of your potential subjects. Social media a plus until it’s not. Must be completely transparent, unless that proves embarrassing to the newspaper. Send sanitized résumé, innocuous clips and nonpartisan references to The Washington Post.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Corrections
text: A capsule summary on Thursday about a review of Shakespeare’s “Merchant of Venice,” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, referred incorrectly to Al Pacino’s role in the production. As the review correctly noted, he plays the infamous character Shylock  not the title character Antonio, who is played by Byron Jennings.

headline: A Prospective Raise in Postal Rates Riles Magazines
text: Magazine publishers are preparing to go to war with the United States Postal Service over an emergency rate increase that the postmaster general is expected to ask for on Tuesday.

headline: At Yahoo, Using Searches to Steer News Coverage
text: Welcome to the era of the algorithm as editor.

headline: A Cover Credit for Clothing
text: On the latest cover of Men’s Health magazine, Kellan Lutz, a Calvin Klein model and an actor in the “Twilight” movie series, stands shirtless in jeans while a big headline in the upper left-hand corner blares “Beach Muscle Now!” The tiny type in the opposite corner reads: “Kellan wears Calvin Klein Jeans.”

headline: Sports Replay: July 4
text: July 4 around the world, from the Tour de France to Fenway Park.

headline: Larry King Dreams a Little
text: After announcing the end of his 25-year-old talk show last Tuesday, Larry King waited all of half an hour before daydreaming about the next line on his résumé.

headline: Gaps in Watchdog Journalism Reflected in News From a Trial
text: Readers who came across a public radio blog documenting the five-week trial of a former Chicago police commander on charges of perjury and obstruction about cases involving torture under his command had to wonder where in the world WBEZ Chicago found so much expertise.

headline: Independence-on-Hudson
text: A small village nestled along a rail line on the banks of a revived river in northeastern North America was a very special place as dusk spread on Independence Day and Gandalf Murphy and the Slambovian Circus of Dreams played in the runup to fireworks.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and the auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include the I.S.M. service index for June (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims; consumer credit for May (Thursday); and wholesale inventories for May (Friday).

headline: On Twitter, a Close-Knit Network
text: If Kevin Bacon had a Twitter account, he would most likely be within six degrees of separation from nearly everyone else on the site.

headline: An Undervalued Stock but Only for the Brave
text: Three years on, Blackstone may finally be worth a look from bargain-hunting investors. In June 2007, Steve Schwarzman and Pete Peterson shook up the private equity world by taking their firm public. They landed a market valuation of some $30 billion, which appeared too rich even during those heady days. Times have changed.

headline: Energy Needs of China’s Consumers Swamping Efficiency Gains
text: Keith Bradsher has filed an important story showing how the energy demands of China’s emerging consumer class are overwhelming the central government’s efforts to cut industrial energy waste and blunt growth in carbon dioxide emissions.

headline: News Quiz | July 5, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Fourth of July Fireworks
text: Fireworks displays across the country celebrated the Fourth of July.

headline: On The Economist’s Cover, Only a Part of the Picture
text: 1:53 p.m. | Updated

headline: Mexican Democracy, Even Under Siege
text: MEXICO CITY  Campaign offices had been bombed, candidates had been threatened and killed, and dead bodies were even hung from bridges on the morning of the polling.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Toploftical
text: Today’s word, in association with the substantial Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Geologist’s Sentence Is Questioned
text: BEIJING  American officials reacted with dismay and puzzlement on Monday to the eight-year prison sentence imposed on an American geologist because he bought a database on China’s oil industry.

headline: Leftist Activist Is Slain in Philippines
text: MANILA  An official of the largest leftist political party in the Philippines was shot dead on Monday, in what may have been the first political killing since President Benigno S. Aquino III took office last week, officials said.

headline: San Diego Chargers 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Rocking the Party at London’s Kew Gardens
text: London’s annual “Swing into Summer” party, held at the pastoral Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew, doesn’t have modest ambitions: organizers call it a “party for the planet.” The event, which attracts about 6,000 music lovers per year, celebrates its 25th season this year from tomorrow through Saturday.

headline: Cougar Capitalism
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Boogie Boards | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

headline: A New Tool to Teach Children About Money
text: Bill Dwight used to teach his children about money using detailed spreadsheets that tracked their allowances and spending.

headline: Q.&A.: Reporting E-Mail Scams and Spoofs
text: Q.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: We’re asking this question every Monday this summer for our Summer Reading Student Challenge. You can post your answer here anytime until next Monday, July 12, when we’ll close this post and open a new one with the same question.

headline: Numberplay: Your Money or Your Logic
text: Would you pay $20 for an envelope containing either $10 or $40?

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Grilled Watermelon and Tomato Salad
text: Six years ago, when Daniel Humm, the 33-year-old executive chef at Eleven Madison Park, was traveling in Barcelona, Spain, he discovered cooks grilling slices of melon and serving them at a tapas bar. They were juicy and smoky but not cooked. “I had the idea in my head for several years,” he said.

headline: Plan XVII For Europe
text: So, I was reading Jean-Claude Trichet’s latest about how austerity will be expansionary, not contractionary, because confidence will conquer all, and I realized what it reminded me of. You see, while traveling I reread Barbara Tuchman’s The Guns of August, and there it was: Plan XVII:

headline: Chad & Freude
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have devised unlikely television shows based on absurd wordplay.

headline: Bobby Fischer Is Exhumed
text: The remains of Bobby Fischer, the American chess champion, were exhumed Sunday night in the cemetery of Laugardaelir Church in Iceland, according to a report in The Reykjavik Grapevine.

headline: I Weep For America
text: Judging from the comments on this post, we’re suffering from a potentially catastrophic sense-of-humor deficit.

headline: Uruguay and the ‘Real Hand of God’
text: You can’t help but hear the incongruities in some of the things being said ahead of Tuesday’s Netherlands-Uruguay semifinal in Cape Town.

headline: Losing Independence
text: Thoughts occasioned by fireworks, barbecues and flags: Why are we so surprised and dismayed, those of us who take care of older Americans, when they resist the help we want to provide? Or torpedo the plans we’ve so carefully researched?

headline: Ask a Window Cleaner
text: This week, Andrew Horton, who has been a window cleaner for more than two decades and knows the secrets of the trade and safety practices, responded to readers’ questions about his career.

headline: Dzagnidze Coasts to Victory at Grand Prix
text: After starting with 7 wins in 8 games, Dzagnidze finished with three draws, which was more than enough to claim first place.

headline: Monday Reading: Miles or Points?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Marketing Revolution in Real Estate
text: When Michele Kleier wanted to sell a nine-room apartment at 1125 Park Avenue in 1977, her brokerage firm paid for a one-and-a-half-line classified newspaper advertisement that offered the rough location (“Park Ave. — Low 90s”) and succinctly read “Superb condition. Sun filled. Excel. maint.” With that ad, she found a buyer willing to pay $145,000, today’s inflationary equivalent of $522,000.

headline: No All-Star Game for Pettitte, at Least for Now
text: It was not hard to notice there were six Yankees headed to the All-Star Game when the American League roster was announced Sunday. Not seeing Andy Pettitte among them, however, initially caused some confusion.

headline: For a Former Carriage Horse, a Grassy Sanctuary
text: What happens to the city’s carriage horses after they retire from clopping along the streets has long been a subject of mystery and contention.

headline: As Deutsche Bank Tower Shrinks, Dispute Rages on Costs
text: After a fatal fire and years of delays and bickering, the former Deutsche Bank tower is now only 12 stories tall, and that means the end of demolition is finally in sight for the jet-black skyscraper  once 41 stories tall  that was mortally wounded on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Agency Agreed Wildlife Risk From Oil Was ‘Low’
text: The federal agency charged with protecting endangered species like the brown pelican and the Kemp’s ridley sea turtle signed off on the Minerals Management Service’s conclusion that deepwater drilling for oil in the Gulf of Mexico posed no significant risk to wildlife, despite evidence that a spill of even moderate size could be disastrous, according to federal documents.

headline: Walking on the Beach, Waiting for the Semifinals
text: DURBAN, South Africa  Waiting for the Germany-Spain semifinal on Wednesday, I am discovering a whole other World Cup  with the Indian Ocean right outside my hotel window.

headline: Start-Up Airlines in a Struggle to Survive
text: In the airline industry, the fittest do not always survive. But that has not stopped start-up carriers like Virgin America from trying.

headline: Remembering a Simpler (Better?) Time in Real Estate
text: Apartments being prepared for sale in 2010 are gussied up and promoted more than any pageant queen or bride. There’s an exhausting social whirl of Web promotion, glossy brochures, videos, open houses — and that’s just for a dimly lit studio in Chelsea.

headline: Dior: Electric Gardens
text: PARIS — John Galliano’s new haute couture collection for Dior is both faithful to the house and as fresh as a daisy.

headline: Who Is Better for Knicks — Stoudemire or Lee?
text: The first big star to join the Knicks this summer might arrive at the cost of the only star they have developed in the last decade. If Amar’e Stoudemire comes, David Lee most likely will go.

headline: Fuel Price Strike Cripples Cities Across India
text: Protests against a recent increase in fuel prices shut down markets, schools, airports and businesses across India, and thousands of people were arrested as violence flared in some cities.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Dead Man'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at "Dead Man," Jim Jarmusch's hallucinatory Western.

headline: Origins of Tournament in an Infamous Prison
text: ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa  Sedick Isaacs approached the infamous and windswept prison here, now closed, and pounded the door knock. His first trip here, on Dec. 1, 1964, had not been so voluntary or droll. He was bound in chains at the time and dumped out the back of a truck, not to leave for 13 years.

headline: Photo Replay: July 5
text: Teams got ready for the World Cup semifinals in South Africa while London prepared for the 2012 Olympics.

headline: Turning East, Turkey Asserts Economic Power
text: ISTANBUL  For decades, Turkey has been told it was not ready to join the European Union  that it was too backward economically to qualify for membership in the now 27-nation club.

headline: Indonesian Firm Accused of Clearing Rain Forests
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The environmental group Greenpeace has accused one of the world’s largest pulp, paper and palm oil companies of aggressively clearing Indonesian rain forests and throwing into doubt a landmark billion-dollar deal that aims to fight climate change by curbing deforestation.

headline: Memories Of Scare Tactics Past
text: When writing about previous invisible attacks of the invisible bond vigilantes, I almost forgot what else was going on during the first of those imaginary onslaughts: the spring of 2009 was also the period of the great inflation scare, in which everyone from Glenn Beck to Federal Reserve presidents was warning us that an awful surge in prices was just around the corner. Funny how that didn’t happen.

headline: Clinton Seeks to Reassure Russia’s Neighbors
text: MOSCOW  At the end of a trip intended to reassure Russia’s neighbors that the Obama administration would not forget them in its push to improve relations with Moscow, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton resorted to the simplest of diplomatic formulations, telling Georgia, the United States “can walk and chew gum at the same time.” Mrs. Clinton repeated the argument like a mantra during her five-day swing through Ukraine, Poland, Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia: that the “reset” will not force the United States to sacrifice its influence or policies in the post-Soviet space.

headline: Carrying Mystical Tea? Maybe It’s Best to Be Discreet
text: MY business partner, Nicky Dawda, who’s an India native, and I travel to many estates around the world tasting and selecting teas for our company, l’Âge de Thé. Finding the right teas is very important to us, and it’s something that we take a lot of pride in.

headline: Sumo’s Ties to Japan Underworld Go Beyond Limits
text: TOKYO  Japan’s ancient sport of sumo had already fallen on hard times from damaging scandals and declining popularity. Now, an even more sinister problem has been added to its list of woes: ties to the criminal underworld.

headline: Maker of Goal-Line Technology System Renews Effort to Persuade Soccer Board
text: When tennis balls landed close to the lines at the recently completed Wimbledon tournament, a high-tech monitoring system was ready to review disputed calls.

headline: Narcocorridos
text: Mexican ballads celebrating the exploits of drug barons.(Narcotics + Corrido.)

headline: Israel Details Easing of Its Gaza Blockade
text: JERUSALEM  Israel on Monday announced details of the easing of its blockade of Gaza, and the Israeli defense minister held a rare face-to-face meeting here with the Palestinian prime minister in a flurry of activity apparently intended to show diplomatic momentum ahead of the Israeli prime minister’s meeting with President Obama, scheduled for Tuesday in Washington.

headline: A ‘Winter’ Vegetable Shines in Summer
text: Though beets are often thought of as a winter vegetable, they are at their best now  tender and sweet, and filled with nutrients like folate, magnesium and potassium.

headline: As LeBron James Decides Future, Past Gives Clues
text: A decision will soon be made. But first, LeBron James must balance his hometown loyalty against the intrigue of entering a larger market. He must weigh his desire to dominate the N.B.A. against his stated goal of becoming a billionaire.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Dead Man’
text: Jim Jarmusch‘s film “Dead Man”, released in 1995, stars Johnny Depp as William Blake, an accountant traveling to a frontier town, and features appearances by Iggy Pop, Billy Bob Thornton, Crispin Glover and, in his last film role, Robert Mitchum.

headline: More Than Raging Sea, Oil Threatens Inn
text: ORANGE BEACH, Ala.  When Hurricane Ivan churned along this Gulf Coast town in 2004, it ravaged the beachfront inn that Darrell Finley has managed since 1995. Waves dragged six feet of sand into the rooms. Saltwater corroded brass chandeliers and rotted mahogany doors. Wind blew out stained-glass windows and scattered Art Deco furniture.

headline: Product Placement Grows in Music Videos
text: WHETHER it’s for a Virgin Mobile phone or Miracle Whip dressing, Lady Gaga will do the pitch. In the video for her single “Telephone,” she flashes those and a handful of other brands  providing one of the splashiest examples yet of product placement in music videos.

headline: The Benefits of Blowing Your Top
text: The longing for President Obama to vent some fury at oil executives or bankers may run far deeper than politics. Millions of people live or work with exasperatingly cool customers, who seem to be missing an emotional battery, or perhaps saving their feelings for a special occasion. People who  unlike the mining operators in the gulf  have a blowout preventer that works all too well.

headline: Semifinal Referees Announced; Conspiracy Theories Abound
text: DURBAN, South Africa — The referees for the semifinals were announced today, and the full list of candidates to officiate the final four games was posted.

headline: Risks: Smallpox Vaccine and Sexual Contact
text: A woman in her 20s from Washington State was infected with the vaccinia virus used in smallpox vaccines earlier this year after sexual contact with her boyfriend, a member of the military who had been vaccinated five days earlier, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports.

headline: K-Rod Pitches In, Again and Again
text: Maybe Francisco Rodriguez needs a day off.

headline: X-Ray Laser Resurrects a Laboratory No Longer in the Vanguard
text: In the first experiments conducted at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory in Menlo Park, Calif., since its outdated particle accelerator was converted into the world’s brightest X-ray laser, scientists managed to create what they called hollow atoms, giving just a preview of the kind of science expected to be done there. At high X-ray energies, the two innermost electrons, rather than the less tightly bound outer electrons, were knocked out first, as if peeling an onion from the inside out.

headline: Robben Island Soccer League
text: The notorious South African prison was the home to an inmates’ soccer league that provided the foundation for the country to eventually host the 2010 World Cup.

headline: Utah’s Gun Permit Popular With Nonresidents
text: James Roe, a 64-year-old computer consultant from rural Pennsylvania, spent a recent Saturday in a Pittsburgh suburb learning about riflings, hangfires and powder charges. The gun safety class was for people seeking a concealed-firearm permit in Utah, some 1,500 miles away. Never mind that Mr. Roe has not been to Utah in 20 years and has no plans to visit anytime soon.

headline: Taking the ‘Wild’ in Wildlife Seriously
text: Burgeoning populations of wild animals in cities and suburbs throughout the country may thrill folks who rarely, if ever, see such creatures outside a zoo or museum, but these animals can wreak havoc on human health and safety.

headline: A ‘Forest Fire of Hair Loss,’ and Its Scars
text: Matt Kelley was 38 when he first noticed a round, hairless spot in his beard. Within six weeks, every inch of his body that once had hair  including his eyebrows, eyelashes, arms and head  was completely bald.

headline: Patient Voices: Alopecia
text: Mysterious bald spots, unproven treatments, a new reflection in the mirror - what is it like to suddenly lose your hair? Six people with alopecia speak.

headline: Bureaucracy Stymies Pro-Kremlin Youth Retreat
text: MOSCOW  For years, the Kremlin has sponsored a summer retreat where thousands of young people from across Russia, screened for ideology, camp on a lake and attend seminars with the country’s leaders and political experts. Outsiders have rarely been permitted.

headline: The Claim: Exposure to Plants and Parks Can Boost Immunity
text: THE FACTS

headline: The Health Benefits of Nature
text: In this week’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores whether more exposure to plants and parks can improve health.

headline: Reporting What the Public Wants to See 127 Years From Now
text: A warning to all the people who bemoan the shoddy and salacious state of cable news: The Onion thinks it’s only going to get worse.

headline: Recalibrated Formula Eases Women’s Workouts
text: If you are a woman who exercises, get ready to do some math.

headline: Imam Entangled in Bomb Plot Leaves Country
text: They were among the last words he will perhaps ever utter in this country. Expressed, said his lawyer, without irony or bitterness. “God bless America.”

headline: On a 99-Degree Day, Cooling Off by Any Means Available
text: At 3 p.m. in Bryant Park on Monday, the most envied man was Thomas Tavarez.

headline: Clinton Reassures Georgia
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton visited Georgia, reassuring its leaders that they still have American support.

headline: Bewitching Girl, Bewildered Clan, Colliding Wills
text: “Bintou” is a bubbling caldron of a play, a show in which everything  a Greek chorus, a series of intertwined monologues, a bit of dance  is thrown into the pot and stirred around. It’s an angry and exciting mix, one whose weaknesses are readily overcome by an abundance of energy.

headline: Mets Make Moves to Shore Up Bullpen
text: The Mets’ overtaxed bullpen received some help with a pair of moves Monday. The team announced that it put Fernando Tatis on 15-day disabled list with right shoulder sprain and recalled the left-hander Raul Valdes from Class AAA Buffalo.

headline: Nut? What Nut? The Squirrel Outwits to Survive
text: I was walking through the neighborhood one afternoon when, on turning a corner, I nearly tripped over a gray squirrel that was sitting in the middle of the sidewalk, eating a nut. Startled by my sudden appearance, the squirrel dashed out to the road — right in front of an oncoming car.

headline: Only One Ready to Play Nice
text: A group seeking civility in politics has found that among all sitting governors and members of Congress, only one is willing to promise decorum in his political discourse.

headline: A Hatred That Resists Exorcism
text: Is there anything left to be said about anti-Semitism? By now surely the outline is clear: how hatred of Jews grew out of early Christianity’s attempts to supplant Judaism; how the demonization of Jews in the Middle Ages turned violent; how the hatred was given its name by a 19th-century German journalist; and how it reached cataclysmic fulfillment in the Holocaust.

headline: As if Being a Teenager Wasn’t Bad Enough
text: Think of a contemporary version of Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” in which an egotistical scientist’s creation is not a hideous-looking monster but a well-mannered teenage girl who quotes Shakespeare, listens to Tom Petty and uses Facebook and YouTube. This is the high-concept premise of Laurence Gonzales’s lumpy new novel, “Lucy.”

headline: China: A Dangerous Blood Clot Is Linked to Hours Sitting and Playing a Game
text: Doctors from Hunan Province in China are reporting a syndrome that might be described as modern medicine meeting “The Joy Luck Club.”

headline: Ringo at 70: ‘I’m Not Hiding From It, You Know’
text: Ever since Ringo Starr vowed, on a well-known cover of Buck Owens’s hit “Act Naturally,” that he’d become “the biggest fool to ever hit the big time,” the renowned rock ’n’ roll drummer has done all right for himself. As a member of the Beatles and as a solo artist, Mr. Starr has sold more than a few records, won some Grammy Awards and even had a minor planet named for him. But on Wednesday Mr. Starr will reach a very special milestone: he turns 70 years old.

headline: From a Forest to a Family, One Tree at a Time
text: No new game company has been more successful over the past couple of years than Zynga. From Mafia Wars to FarmVille, Zynga has essentially defined the latest generation of games on Facebook. It almost goes without saying that Facebook has become a ubiquitous, nigh indispensable element of so many people’s social existence, and it is the rare Facebooker indeed who has not fielded requests and seen status updates from a Zynga title. I played Mafia Wars off and on for at least a year.

headline: Glimpsing the Father Who Was
text: Watching my widowed father age as he neared 90 was like watching an old photo fade: every time I saw him, he was a little less himself. Day by day, Leo, a humanist, a devoted Central Park South dentist, a lover of opera, golf and political debate, shriveled into a generic old man, irascible and self-absorbed. Though Prozac brought him back from serious curmudgeonliness  “You call this soup hot? What are you, an idiot?”  he remained a poor facsimile of the person he had been. I pictured his mind as a sieve through which bits kept dropping out.

headline: The Body, Whole or in Parts
text: The young Polish painter Jakub Julian Ziolkowski is the subject of quite a bit of buzz and clamor among collectors. Born in Zamosc, Poland, in 1980, he had his first three solo shows in his homeland in 2004, starting at the Academy of Fine Arts in Krakow, where he studied. In 2005 he had his first solo outside Poland, at Galerie Martin Janda in Vienna. In 2006 his second non-Polish solo took place at the London gallery of the contemporary art juggernaut Hauser & Wirth, on view during the Frieze Art Fair. I remember seeing that show and finding it riveting but retro, like some unexpected Eastern European offshoot of the Italian Transavantgarde of Sandro Chia and Enzo Cucchi.

headline: Ask an Expert About Alopecia
text: A surprising 2 percent of the population suffers from alopecia areata, a mysterious condition that causes hair loss from all or part of the body. In the latest installment of Patient Voices, six men, women and children talk about the effects of alopecia on their lives.

headline: Behind Bluegrass Harmonies, a Trapdoor That Opens to New Beats
text: KATONAH, N.Y.  It’s easy to imagine the Punch Brothers as a rock band. I mean, what’s rock and who cares, but I’m talking about materials: electric guitars and digital distortion and drums, rather than the untreated sounds of mandolin, fiddle, banjo, acoustic guitar and double bass.

headline: ‘Timothy Galoty & the Dead Brains’
text: Images from an exhibition of paintings by the artist Jakub Julian Ziolkowski.

headline: Precision Drilling
text: As BP gets closer to finishing the first of two relief wells intended to plug the well leaking in the Gulf of Mexico, engineers are using special equipment that allows them to drill with more precision.

headline: Stella Adler Studio Expands to India and the Philippines
text: Aspiring Bollywood actors can now study at the same school that trained Marlon Brando, Robert De Niro, Warren Beatty and other famous American actors. The Stella Adler Studio of Acting, which was founded in 1949 by Adler, a student of Constantin Stanislavski and a former member of the Group Theater, is partnering with a new acting school in India, which will open in September and be run by the Bollywood director Rahuul Rawail. Another Adler workshop is expected to open in the Philippines in January 2011. The Stella Adler Studio already has partnerships in Mexico, Trinidad, France and Germany, and is in discussions to open a school in Japan.

headline: Knicks Get a Marquee Free Agent: Stoudemire
text: After two years of roster purging and payroll slashing, the Knicks got their first big payoff Monday and could hardly contain their optimism  rules, contracts and official signing dates notwithstanding.

headline: Hitting a Tiny Bull’s-Eye Miles Under the Gulf
text: HOUSTON — To hear the people at Baker Hughes tell it, a drill string — length after length of narrow pipe that can extend for miles into the earth — is far from a rigid assembly of high-strength steel. It is more like a wet noodle.

headline: Documentarians Are Honored
text: The George Eastman House museum of photography and film in Rochester will give the George Eastman Medal of Honor to the filmmaker Ken Burns above right, and his writing partner Geoffrey C. Ward, right, for their contributions to cultural and racial awareness, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Burns has used the George Eastman House to do research for many of his documentaries on American history, which include “The Civil War” and “The War,” about World War II. The medals are to be awarded Aug. 13.

headline: Remains of Bobby Fischer Are Exhumed in Iceland
text: The remains of Bobby Fischer, the American chess champion, have been exhumed at the cemetery of Laugardaelir Church in Iceland, according to a report Monday in The Reykjavik Grapevine, a magazine. The exhumation was ordered by the Icelandic Supreme Court to determine if Fischer, above, is the father of Jinky Young, a 9-year-old Filipino girl. Olafur Helgi Kjartansson, the sheriff of Selfoss, the town near the cemetery; the Rev. Kristinn Agust Fridfinnsson, the pastor of Selfoss; members of the local parish; medical workers; and several law-enforcement officers oversaw the exhumation, according to The Grapevine. Since Fischer’s death in 2008 there has been a dispute over his estate involving competing claims by Marilyn Young, Jinky’s mother; Miyoko Watai, general secretary of the Japanese Chess Association, who said she married Fischer in 2004; and two of Fischer’s nephews, Alexander and Nicholas Targ. The estate is said to be worth at least $2 million, and Fischer left no will. Marilyn Young filed her claim in Iceland last November. Among the documents she provided were pictures of herself with Fischer and Jinky, and postcards to Jinky signed “Daddy” that she said were from Fischer. She has also produced records showing that Fischer gave her money in 2006 and 2007 for Jinky, according to RUV, a public broadcaster. Ms. Young had sought to retrieve samples of Fischer’s DNA from the National Hospital of Iceland, where he died, but none had been preserved.

headline: Polish Translation Award
text: Danuta Borchardt has won the 2010 Found in Translation Award for her translation of the novelist Witold Gombrowicz’s “Pornografia,” published last year by Grove Atlantic. The award is given annually by the Polish Book Institute in Krakow, the Institute of Polish Culture in London and the Institute of Polish Culture in New York for the finest translation of Polish literature into English to have appeared in book form in the preceding year. The winner receives roughly $3,000 and a three-month residency in Krakow. “Pornografia,” first published in 1960, is set in Poland during World War II and involves a pair of Warsaw intellectuals who visit a country estate and try to manipulate the sex lives of two young people they meet there.

headline: Adopt a Hitchcock Film
text: The British Film Institute is seeking donations to restore nine early Alfred Hitchcock films, Reuters reported. On its Web site, bfi.org.uk, the Institute described the films, which date from the 1920s and are all silent, as “in urgent need of restoration.” Donations of all sizes will be accepted: a contribution of about $40 can restore 50 centimeters of film, the Institute says, while a gift of $150,000 can restore a whole film. The nine films include “The Lodger” (1926), which was hailed on its release as “the finest British production ever made” by the trade journal Bioscope. The Institute said that if it raises enough money, it will also commission a new score for each film.

headline: 59E59 Theaters to Present Sylvia Plath’s Only Play
text: The fall season at 59E59 Theaters will include “Three Women,” the only play by Sylvia Plath, above, in a production by the London company Inside Intelligence. Plath wrote “Three Women” as a radio play, and it was performed on BBC radio in 1962, the year before she committed suicide. The production was first presented in London in 2008. 59E59 will pair it with “Wish I Had a Sylvia Plath,” a play by Edward Anthony that centers on Esther Greenwood, the heroine of Plath’s novel “The Bell Jar.” The season will also include two Irish plays  “Absolution,” written and performed by Owen O’Neill and produced by Dublin’s Guna Nua Theater, and “Exit/Entrance” by Aidan Mathews  as well as British plays that have yet to be announced. ... The Chocolate Factory’s fall 2010 season will include dance, theater, music and multimedia performances by artists including Brian Rogers, Neal Medlyn, Ivy Baldwin, Pele Bauch, Anneke Hansen, Melanie Maar and Tara O’Con. The arts facility is in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: In a World of Throwaways, Making a Dent in Medical Waste
text: The health care industry has a garbage problem.

headline: Exercise: Activity and Mental Health in Women
text: People who are physically active appear to be at lower risk for cognitive impairment late in life, and for women, a new study suggests, physical activity during the teenage years may provide the greatest benefit.

headline: Testosterone Gel Trial Ends After Heart Issue
text: A federally financed study to see if testosterone gel helps frail elderly men build muscle and strength was abruptly halted late last year after participants taking it suffered a disproportionate number of heart attacks and other serious cardiac problems, and one died of what was apparently a heart attack.

headline: Patterns: Added Sugar and High Blood Pressure
text: A new study suggests that foods high in added sugar may increase the risk of high blood pressure.

text: For a 14th straight year, James S. Kaplan spent the Fourth of July walking in the middle of the night among ghosts of the American Revolution.

David Paterson is being urged to veto a bill that would prohibit the New York City Police Department from adding any more innocent individuals to its vast computerized database of personal information on the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers stopped, questioned and often frisked by police officers.

headline: Small City in Iowa Reels After Parade Accident
text: BELLEVUE, Iowa  Looking back, a brief pause in the annual Heritage Days parade here on Sunday was the closest people would get to a warning that anything had gone wrong. The parade, one of scores across the country but part of this small city’s most significant, long-standing celebration of the year, was 45 minutes under way when the floats stopped coming for a moment. Then a blur of black hurtled by.

text: NEW DELHI  Protests against a recent increase in fuel prices shut down markets, schools, airports and businesses across India on Monday, and thousands of people were arrested as violence flared in some cities.

headline: Why Bonobos Don’t Kill Each Other
text: Brian Hare, an assistant professor at the Duke Institute for Brain Sciences at Duke University, and Vanessa Woods, a research scientist in the Department of Evolutionary Anthropology at Duke, do comparative studies on the cognitive development of bonobo apes, chimpanzees and humans. Ms. Woods, 33, a former journalist from Australia, has just published a book about their marriage and work, "Bonobo Handshake: A Memoir of Love and Adventure in the Congo." We spoke last month after they had appeared at the World Science Festival in New York City. An edited version of the conversation follows:

headline: Big Animals, Slower Reflexes
text: It takes an elephant much longer to notice a fly and flick it away than it takes a shrew, and the reason is not that the elephant’s great brain is too busy with philosophy, or that it simply does not concern itself with flies.

headline: Souvenir Shirts to Support Braden Anger Him Instead
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  For $25, fans here can wear their support of Dallas Braden. The Athletics have been selling green T-shirts that say, “Get Off My Mound”  what Braden, in a bit of spicier language, yelled at Alex Rodriguez in April when Rodriguez crossed over the pitcher’s mound on his way back to first base. Braden would rather the fans save their money.

headline: Tirade Offers Insight on Would-Be Bomber
text: When Faisal Shahzad, the suspect in the failed Times Square bombing, pleaded guilty last month, the judge asked whether he knew what he had been doing was a crime.

headline: Sides Form Over Threat to Saturday Mail Service
text: WASHINGTON — As federal regulators consider a proposal to cut most Saturday postal deliveries, the business community is sharply divided about the consequences of switching to five-day service.

headline: For Male Finches, Range Comes With Muscle
text: When it comes to singing, male zebra finches outdo prima donnas, singing over a wide range that starts almost an octave above middle C but soars higher than any coloratura soprano. Female zebra finches, on the other hand, are limited to a few one-note low frequency calls.

text: An interactive panorama shows the progression of work on the memorial pool site at ground zero.

headline: Way Back When Sperm Whales Were Able to Chew Their Food
text: Sperm whales lack teeth on their upper jaws and so have no way of biting into prey. Instead, they ingest and swallow prey, most often squid, by suction.

headline: Pools Near Completion at Ground Zero
text: An interactive panorama shows the progression of work on the memorial pool site at ground zero. Once they are filled with water, the pools will sit at the bottom of two 28-foot-deep voids marking the location of the twin towers.
