headline: Are Profits Hurting Capitalism?
text: A STREAM of disheartening economic news last week, including flagging consumer confidence and meager private-sector job growth, is leading experts to worry that the recession is coming back. At the same time, many policymakers, particularly in Europe, are slashing government budgets in an effort to lower debt levels and thereby restore investor confidence, reduce interest rates and promote growth.

headline: Takahashi to Skip Start as Mets Add to Bullpen
text: Mets Manager Jerry Manuel seemed to direct a message at General Manager Omar Minaya on Sunday when he complained about the workload that has burdened his relievers. Whether or not that was the case, Minaya was listening.

headline: Russia and 2 Neighbors Form Economic Union
text: MOSCOW  The leaders of Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan took their longest stride to date in linking their economies, forming a customs union that they say will soon evolve into a more ambitious common market, with Russia at its hub.

headline: A Universe in Bloom
text: “Ah, Sissinghurst,” people say, “the garden.” And of course the extraordinary place where I live is famous as a garden. In the 1930s, my grandparents, the poet Vita Sackville-West and the diplomat and writer Harold Nicolson, made a garden here in the ruins of a great Elizabethan summer palace. In effect (but not pedantically), they recreated the old house’s vanished rooms and corridors with living things — irises and dahlias, roses and magnolias all contributing to a poignant and poetic half-remaking of the past.

headline: Taking a Stand, Then a Deduction
text: Americans, often working through Jewish and Christian charities, are able to receive tax breaks for donations that support settlement activity in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.

headline: A Portraitist, and His Images of the Famous, Come to Light
text: Faces of great men, and a grande dame or two, peek out from the linseed-scented clutter of Robert Seyffert’s studio in the South Bronx. Their portraits, rendered in luminous oils or bold strokes of charcoal, resonate with life, though they were made almost a century ago.

headline: Waiting for a Trade Policy
text: The White House has announced that it wants to move ahead with a long-ignored trade pact with South Korea. The deal was reached by former President George W. Bush, but with President Obama planning to visit South Korea for a summit meeting of the Group of 20 major economies in November, he has now committed to resolving the outstanding issues and submitting the treaty for ratification after the fall elections.

headline: China, the Sweatshop
text: The labor strife spreading through China’s factory cities has clearly frazzled the government. Last month, it deployed Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, a k a “Grandpa Wen,” who told laborers at a Beijing subway station that the government and society “should treat migrant workers as they would their own children.”

headline: Tax-Exempt Funds Aid Settlements in West Bank
text: As the United States seeks to end a four-decade Jewish settlement enterprise, the American Treasury helps sustain the settlements through tax breaks on donations to support them.

headline: An Unwise Cut in School Aid
text: President Obama has rightly threatened to veto the House version of a spending bill that includes damaging and unnecessary cuts to his signature education grant program, known as the Race to the Top.

headline: One Person, No Vote?
text: After the election disaster in Florida 10 years ago, Congress mandated the use of new voting machines and most of the country complied. With the major exception, that is, of the State of New York.

text: In the afterglow of the rockets’ red glare and the cold embers of millions of barbecues, what could be said about the humble Monday that followed?

headline: Okun’s Law and Today’s Joblessness
Private Equity Firm in Talks for an Investment in Spain
text: The two main shareholders of Abertis Infraestructuras, an operator of highways, are in talks with the private equity fund CVC Capital Partners about a possible investment, according to a filing with regulators. No decision has been made on whether to proceed, said Criteria CaixaCorp, which owns 28.5 percent of Abertis, and Actividades de Construcción y Servicios, which has a 25.8 percent stake. “The described transaction is in the stage of analysis and may not come about, be structured in a different way or be on a different scale,” Criteria said in its statement. Shares in Abertis soared as much as 13 percent before being suspended by the market operator in Madrid.

headline: Daiwa Buys Units of Belgian Bank
text: The Daiwa Securities Group, one of the largest brokerage firms in Japan, agreed to buy the KBC Group’s convertible bond and Asia equity derivatives units for about $1 billion. KBC, the Belgian bank, has been trying to raise money to repay government aid. Daiwa is paying about $200 million for assets and about $800 million for the trading position. The deal is subject to regulatory approval.

headline: Three Die in Fairfield, N.J., Plane Crash
text: A small plane crashed in Fairfield, N.J., while attempting to land Monday evening, killing the pilot, a Manhattan rheumatologist, and her two passengers, officials said.

headline: After a Drowning, Rallying for a School
text: There are biking trips across the Brooklyn Bridge, hikes and camping in the Catskills and visits to a farm in Puerto Rico. While at some schools students spend much of the month of June watching movies or signing yearbooks, those at the Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science and Engineering take a series of intensive field trips, centered on themes like architecture and the environment.

headline: Golf and Motherhood on Conflicting Courses
text: After a long day on the golf course, Cristie Kerr relaxed on a cushioned seat opposite her husband, Erik Stevens, and savored every moment of an orange sherbet sunset from the patio of the Mirabel clubhouse, a quick cart ride from their home in North Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Tour-Provided Day Care for a Dwindling Group of Mothers
text: On her way to the golf course, Mhairi McKay extricates herself from her 14-month-old son’s tearful clutches and delivers him to the L.P.G.A. Child Development Center. Then she scoots around the corner and braces herself.

headline: Tuesday’s Game: Uruguay vs. Netherlands
text: World Cup Semifinal: Uruguay vs. Netherlands2:30 p.m. EasternTV: ESPN, UnivisionTwo teams with deep World Cup traditions meet in a semifinal in Cape Town. Uruguay has won the tournament twice — in 1930 and 1950 — but has not reached this stage in 40 years. The Netherlands, famed for decades for elegant play, reached consecutive finals in 1974 and 1978 but has never won the Cup. Diego Forlán and Luis Suárez have led Uruguay with three goals each, but Suárez is unavailable for this match; his intentional goal-line handball — cynical or brilliant, depending on your view — saved his team in the dying seconds of regulation time against Ghana but earned him a red card and a one-game suspension. The gritty play of Mark van Bommel in the Netherlands’ midfield gives Robin van Persie, Arjen Robben and Wesley Sneijder the freedom to attack. Sneijder, an eagle-eyed playmaker, has scored four goals.

headline: An Orphan Family in Haiti

headline: Haitian Orphans Have Little but One Another
text: CROIX-DES-BOUQUETS, Haiti — More than five months after the earthquake that killed her single mother, Daphne Joseph, 14, lost her bearings a second time when she was forced to leave the makeshift orphanage where she had felt at home.

headline: New York Fights to Be Repaid by Candidates
text: Few cities are as generous as New York when it comes to matching political contributions raised by candidates for public office.

headline: Quirk on Runoffs Allows Some to Keep Thousands
text: New York City’s efforts to recoup taxpayer money it has awarded to candidates running for office have been hampered over the years by delays, legal fights, poor record-keeping and the plain defiance of some candidates determined not to give back extra campaign cash.

headline: Need a Job? Help Wanted at the N.Y. Philharmonic
text: The nation is bleeding jobs, unemployment stands at almost 10 percent, and lines run long at job fairs. But in one microscopic sliver of the economy, the pickings are rich: major orchestras.

headline: Weah to Seek Liberian Presidency
text: George Weah, the 1995 world player of the year, said he would run for the Liberian presidency again after losing in 2005. He will face President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf in October 2011 after losing to her in Liberia’s first election after a 14-year civil war.

headline: Pelfrey Comes Undone After a Reversed Call
text: At 6 feet 7 inches, Mike Pelfrey cuts an imposing figure on the mound, and his performances this season have similarly commanded respect. But he started Monday’s game with added motivation to pitch well.

headline: Heirs Of Picasso and Klee Meet at Swiss Art Exhibition
text: Claude Picasso, above right, a son of Pablo Picasso, and Alexander Klee, left, the grandson of Paul Klee, have met for the first time, Agence France-Presse reported. The Zentrum Paul Klee in Bern, Switzerland, is currently hosting an exhibition, on view until Sept. 26, exploring the relationship between the artists’ work, and their descendants met there last week. Paul Klee met Pablo Picasso, who was two years his junior but the more famous of the pair, only twice. Klee responded strongly to Picasso’s work, while maintaining his individual style, his grandson told the news agency. “It’s thought he was slightly afraid of Picasso’s influence,” Alexander Klee said.

headline: Clement Finch, a Pioneer in Hematology, Dies at 94
text: Dr. Clement A. Finch, a pioneering hematologist whose research on iron helped improve nutrition and led to advances in diagnosing and treating anemia, died June 28 at his home in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 94.

headline: News Quiz | July 6, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: K1 Group Fraud Suspect Dead During Extradition Attempt

text: OAKLAND, Calif.  The visiting bullpen at Oakland Coliseum is in foul territory near the right-field line, in full view of fans, players and right-handed pitchers who need only swivel their heads to detect activity. His pitch count at 101, Javier Vazquez easily might have noticed Dustin Moseley warming up before the seventh inning began. Vazquez’s exit was imminent  but he could control it, and he did.

headline: Alitalia to Join Alliance of Air France-KLM and Delta
text: The Italian carrier Alitalia will join an alliance of Air France-KLM and Delta Air Lines that shares revenue and costs on trans-Atlantic routes, giving the group access to Europe’s third-biggest market, Reuters reported.

headline: BP Wants Partners to Help Shoulder Spill Cost

headline: Flurry of Energy and Mining Acquisitions in Australia
text: There has been a flurry of acquisitions of Australian companies by their Asian neighbors, the Financial Times reported, partly attributed to a revised minerals tax introduced by the new government. China remains interested in access to global energy and mining sectors.

headline: Is Blackstone Undervalued (At Last)?
text: Three years on, the Blackstone Group may finally be worth a look from bargain-hunting investors, Breakingviews says. In June 2007, Steve Schwarzman and Pete Peterson shook up the private equity world by taking their firm public. They landed a market valuation of some $30 billion, which appeared too rich even during those heady days. Times have changed, the publication suggests.

headline: Lloyds Sells Private Equity Unit to Coller Capital
text: Lloyds Banking Group has agreed to sell its private equity business to the buyout firm Coller Capital, accelerating its plan to offload peripheral units and refocus on its core lending activities.

headline: Carrefour May be Seeking Buyers in Southeast Asia
text: Carrefour SA, the world’s second- biggest retailer, plans to exit Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand, and is seeking offers for its operations in the Southeast Asian countries, four people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: K.K.R. Said to Near N.Y.S.E. Listing With Pay Details

headline: For Brazil’s Bankers, Little Payday in Petrobas?

headline: Hilcorp Energy Shares the Wealth
text: How would you like to own a company that can afford to offer its employees the chance to earn a bonus of $50,000 toward a new car? I know I would. That’s exactly what Hilcorp Energy, a Houston-based company, is offering its associates if they can fulfill the goal they set in 2005 to double the appraised value of the company by the end of 2010. And that’s one of the reasons I think Hilcorp is one of the elite role models out there demonstrating how well open-book management can work.

headline: You Say It’s Your Birthday? Help Ringo Starr Celebrate When He Turns 70
text: Ever since Ringo Starr vowed, on a well-known cover of Buck Owens’s hit “Act Naturally,” that he’d become “the biggest fool to ever hit the big time,” the renowned rock ’n’ roll drummer has done all right for himself. As a member of the Beatles and as a solo artist, Mr. Starr has sold more than a few records, won some Grammy Awards and even had a minor planet named for him. But on Wednesday Mr. Starr will reach a very special milestone: he turns 70 years old.

headline: China Seeks to Halt Book That Faults Its Prime Minister

headline: For a Premier Lab, a Zero-Energy Showcase
text: The federal government has just finished construction on a zero-energy office building, the nation’s largest, and is hoping that commercial developers will follow its lead. The 222,000-square-foot Research Support Facility is on the Department of Energy’s National Renewable Energy Laboratory campus in Golden, Colo. Just over 800 employees will occupy the building once it officially opens in late August.

headline: Armani: Glamour at Midday
text: PARIS — Shortly after 11 a.m. I left my hotel and rounded the corner into the Place Vendôme, crowded with tourists in shorts and sandals, and, streaming slowly past the Ritz, a line of black sedans delivering guests to the Giorgio Armani couture show, in the far corner of the square presided over by Napoleon’s statue. The sun was glaringly bright, adding to the contrast between the regular folks and the fashion people. Near the curb I watched a cameraman squat low to photograph a woman as she scrambled out of her car. Not the most favorable position — for her. More photographers waited in the shadows of the corner and along a short length of black carpet, set off by velvet ropes, by the entrance.

headline: Letter: The Coconut Salesman
text: It is wonderful, but whatever else The New York Times is, it is still so, so . . . New Yorkish. How else to explain editors allowing the use of the term “coconut milk” in David Baez’s Lives essay when what Baez was being fed by the Nicaraguan coconut salesman was “coconut juice” or “coconut water,” the cloudy, thin liquid that comes sweet from a freshly opened coconut. Coconut milk is a thick, viscous cooking base wrung out of the white, oily meat of the coconut.

headline: Letter: Questions for Tzipi Livni
text: So Livni’s parents were Irgun “freedom fighters”? Why should they not be condemned as “terrorists”? Or is this term reserved only for those expelled from their homes and land by “romantic” Zionists and then subjected to a decades-long dehumanizing military occupation and a siege of medieval intensity?

headline: Letters: The End of the Line
text: Roger Lowenstein, in his article on the public-pension-fund crisis, ignores a key piece of the math. Teachers and state and local workers in the past have accepted a social contract with government, exchanging a lower wage and loyalty in return for job security and benefits, most notably health and pension benefits. Today, job security no longer exists. Health benefits have eroded. Cutting pensions, or worse, converting to defined contributions, effectively ends the contract. The paradox for taxpayers is that the historic benefits package never made up for the wage differential, which resulted in lower taxes. It is already difficult to attract talent to public service; and you do get what you pay for. In exchange for sufficiently eroded benefits, governments and school districts will be forced to pay much higher wages, and taxpayers much higher taxes, for the same work.

headline: Should Schools Search Cellphones?
text: Cyberbullying is a growing problem in schools everywhere, as described in Jan Hoffman’s story “Online Bullies Pull Schools Into the Fray.” Readers recently submitted numerous questions about cyberbullying to our expert, Elizabeth K. Englander, a professor of psychology and the founder and director of the Massachusetts Aggression Reduction Center at Bridgewater State College. The center provides anti-bullying and anti-violence training programs and resources to schools and families. Here, Dr. Englander addresses the issue of personal privacy and the school’s role in monitoring cellphones.

headline: Letters: Tuna’s End
text: As Paul Greenberg documents, tuna, like other large, somewhat glamorous animals, capture our attention as they pass through the benchmarks we set (threatened, endangered) on the way to extinction. The truth is that every animal and every natural resource that we find commercially useful is somewhere on that pathway. We are many times more efficient at harvesting such resources than the resources are at replenishing themselves, and we seem to have no restraint.

headline: Letter: What a Liberal Court Should Be
text: Noah Feldman is correct that the current Supreme Court does notpossess a bold, liberal stalwart, but that does not mean that progressive judicial philosophy has lost significant influence on the court’s liberals. At least since Brown v. Board of Education, an underlying premise in the liberal vision is the idea that justice can be accessed through equality. This premise has been advanced as a central legal remedy to end segregated public facilities and unfair discrimination on the basis of race and gender. While it’s true that contemporary liberal justices may not express this philosophy in such expansive and bold terms as in the past, the premise of interpreting the Constitution in a way to ensure justice through equality has been a unifying liberal judicial vision for half a century and still plays a key role in contemporary liberal jurisprudence.

headline: La Scala Loses a Director for ‘Barber of Seville’
text: A production of Rossini’s “Barber of Seville” at La Scala that has been delayed by an opera workers’ strike has now lost its director, Agence France-Presse reported. The Milanese opera house said on Monday that Jean-Christophe Spinosi, the French conductor, had withdrawn as director of the opera and will be replaced by Michele Mariotti, the Italian conductor. In a statement on its Web site La Scala said, “Due to the impossibility of maintaining a serene and constructive work relationship, Jean-Christophe Spinosi has decided by mutual agreement  with the Teatro alla Scala management to withdraw from  the current production.”

headline: The Passing of an Ocean Explorer
text: 11:54 p.m. | Updated John Diebold, a passionate prober of the ocean’s depths and seabed for some four decades, died on July 1 at age 66 of a heart attack, according to the press office for the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, where Diebold worked. The photo above, from one of his Antarctic trips, is posted on his his Facebook page. The pasted-in penguin suited Diebold’s sense of humor, said David Corcoran, one of his brothers and a longtime colleague of mine on the Science desk of The Times. [Here’s a great photo gallery of 40 years of Diebold’s activities, at sea and ashore.]

headline: Asked & Answered | Christine Vachon

In 2005, Killer Films was honored with a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. On her roster this summer is Ruba Nadda’s “Cairo Time,” which will be out in theaters next month, followed up by “Cracks,” the directorial debut of Jordan Scott. Vachon is currently shooting the HBO miniseries “Mildred Pierce,” with her frequent collaborator, the director Todd Haynes (“Far From Heaven”).

headline: Carven | A Robe Is a Robe

(If only the white page showed such promise for chicness or had the same slimming effect.) Henry, a 31-year-old Givenchy graduate, took things in a new direction this spring, when he marked his debut with a ready-to-wear collection. Cocktail dresses, slinky tailored skirts and roomy taffeta coats — all staples of the elite midcentury Parisian wardrobes that Carmen de Tommaso (aka Madame Carven) once outfitted — have been updated and made accessible to a younger generation that’s more practique than aristo.

headline: Buy Local in Portugal
text: Whenever I travel abroad, one of my first pit stops is the local farmacia. I’m always in the market for old-school apothecary products or those nifty Birkenstock-like house sandals you can only find in German drug stores. Recently, I hit the mother lode at A Vida Portuguesa, a general store tucked on a side street in Lisbon’s Chiado neighborhood. The shop, housed in a former soap factory, features traditional, handcrafted products from all over the country, from toothpaste (the national brand, Couto, comes in a smart-looking orange tube) to countless tinctures and pomades (in handsome green glass bottles). Some of the products, like the pretty Claus Porto soaps, are more popular, while the Bordalo Pinheiro ceramics are harder to come by. Perhaps this amazing archive of authentic Portuguese products is a serious stand against the globalization and fast retailing that seems to have taken over the rest of the E.U. But for me, well, I’m just a sucker for all that hip retro packaging.

headline: Passport Fees to Increase
text: Passport fees are increasing effective July 13, the State Department recently announced. The cost of getting a brand-new passport for someone 16 or older has jumped 35 percent, to $135 from $100, and for those under 16 has increased by nearly 25 percent, to $105 from $85. If you’ve already got your passport, you’re not immune: the cost of renewing your passport for those 16 and over has increased 47 percent, to $110 from $75.

headline: Now Showing | Karl Lagerfeld’s Shopping Fever
text: Karl Lagerfeld continues to expand his side career as a director. Following his cinematic debut in St.-Tropez with the film “Remember Now,” Lagerfeld has cast his favorite models in a new short, “Shopping Fever,” which is packaged as the teaser for a melodramatic, full-length silent feature. Karl’s muse, Baptiste Giabiconi, appears in the role of a hotel valet who caters to the fashion needs of a couple of wealthy teenagers played by Abbey Lee and Dree Hemingway. The girls are decked out in the fall/winter 2010/2011 pre-collection, bien sur, and their hotel rooms are accessorized with countless Chanel shopping bags. It sheds a whole new light on product placement.

headline: Lifting Voices and Spirits Is a Choirmaster’s Mission
text: “The Choir” was so popular and acclaimed when it was first broadcast in Britain, three years ago, that a certain conventional wisdom has fomented around its debut here  a sense that we ought to be as grateful for its arrival as we are for Joshua Reynolds portraits or wellies. The series (beginning Wednesday on BBC America) is virtuous reality television, a kind of “Pygmalion” meets “Glee,” conceived not so much to lift the spirits as to bench press them from the basement of Selfridges to the top of Big Ben. This is precisely the kind of project that excels at making you feel bad if you don’t like it.

headline: The Parking Lot as ‘Solar Grove’

A few firms had been building carports with solar panels for some time, but none had acquired a major presence or branched out much beyond the residential market.

headline: Swoons Follow Nick Jonas, on and Off the London Stage

headline: The Case Against the ‘Malaise’ Speech
text: My column on Monday made a disparaging reference to Jimmy Carter’s famous “malaise” speech (in which, yes, he never actually used the word “malaise”), citing it as an example of the pessimism bubble that inflated in late-1970s America. Recently a narrative has sprung up, on the “crunchy” right as well as on the left, that argues that Carter was prescient rather than over-pessimistic, and that America would be better off today if we’d heeded his indictment of consumerism and self-indulgence, rather than spurning him for the go-go optimism of Ronald Reagan. This is not a crazy idea, since in many ways the speech’s moral critique of American life was powerful, timely, and as applicable today as it was then. (Here’s a snippet: “In a nation that was proud of hard work, strong families, close-knit communities, and our faith in God, too many of us now tend to worship self-indulgence and consumption. Human identity is no longer defined by what one does, but by what one owns.”) You can debate whether it’s appropriate for a chief executive to play the prophet, but if Carter had stopped talking halfway through the address, confined himself to calling for moral renewal, and stayed away from economic policy, the “malaise” speech would look like a plausible indictment of the excesses of late-modern America — excesses that are very much still with us today, and contributed in varying ways to our current economic dislocations.

headline: Watch Who You’re Calling a Weed, Buddy!

Yellow wood sorrel and wild garlic pushed against Asiatic dayflowers and an aggressive wisteria, and all of it was surrounded by Japanese stilt grass, an invasive plant more commonly called packing grass because it is thought to have come to the United States as packing material in shipments from the Far East.

headline: Drug Manufacturing Jobs Are Shrinking in the West

headline: Sondheim Seen in Light and Shadow
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  So charmingly frolicsome, so scarily intense. Two sides  and two ages  of one man’s life can be discovered roughly 20 miles apart in the Berkshires this week, glowing and glowering across the hills like the bright and hidden sides of the moon. These contrasting aspects of Stephen Sondheim, that most multifaceted of composers of musicals, are embodied by two thoughtfully assembled shows that reflect different chapters in his life. Experienced as companion pieces, they also suggest the extraordinary distance that Mr. Sondheim, who turned 80 in March, traveled in between.

headline: A Talent for Writing, and Falling Into Things
text: It may not be a surprise to learn that the British novelist William Golding, whose “Lord of the Flies” (1954) supplanted “The Catcher in the Rye” as the bible of tortured adolescence in America, did not have a happy childhood. But the details will put a sweat on your forehead. “He was oversensitive, timid, fearful, lonely,” John Carey writes in this excellent biography, the first to be written about Golding (1911-1993). “He was alienated from his parents and his brother and had no friends.”

headline: Britain Pledges Inquiry Into Torture
text: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron announced on Tuesday that Britain’s new coalition government would appoint an independent inquiry into allegations that its security services, MI5 and MI6, colluded with the Central Intelligence Agency and other foreign organizations in the rendition and torture of terrorism suspects held in foreign prisons after the 9/11 attacks.

headline: Theater Director Resigns in New Jersey
text: The executive director of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., Mark W. Jones, below, has resigned. The resignation, reported in The Star-Ledger of Newark, was submitted on June 24. Mark Hoebee, the theater’s artistic director, has taken on the new title of producing artistic director and said that a search was under way for a managing director with whom he would share leadership of the organization. Efforts to reach Mr. Jones on Tuesday were unsuccessful. Mr. Jones, who came to the theater in November 2007, helped to bring the Paper Mill back from the financial brink with a real estate deal in June 2008.

headline: Lincoln, McClellan, And Stimulus
text: There’s now a lot of talk about the fact that U.S. corporations are sitting on a lot of cash, but not spending it. I don’t find that particularly puzzling: with huge excess capacity, why invest in building even more capacity. But almost everyone seems to agree that if we could somehow get businesses to spend some of that cash, it would create jobs.

headline: La Scala Loses Director For ‘Barber of Seville’
text: A production of Rossini’s “Barber of Seville” at La Scala that has been delayed by an opera workers’ strike has now lost its director, Agence France-Presse reported. The Milanese opera house said on Monday that Jean-Christophe Spinosi, the French conductor, had withdrawn as director of the opera and would be replaced by Michele Mariotti, the Italian conductor. In a statement on teatroallascala.org, its Web site, La Scala said, “Due to the impossibility of maintaining a serene and constructive work relationship, Jean-Christophe Spinosi has decided by mutual agreement with the Teatro alla Scala management to withdraw from the current production.” The first performance of “The Barber of Seville” at La Scala, which was to be on Friday, has already been canceled because of a strike by the opera’s musicians, performers and other artists, who have been protesting a plan passed by the government that would freeze hiring and reduce bonuses by 50 percent, among other cost-cutting measures.

headline: Praise From Scorsese? Not So Fast, Grint
text: There’s hardly an actor working today who wouldn’t sell his soul to Lord Voldemort for an enthusiastic endorsement from Martin Scorsese, below. Alas, what appeared to be that director’s praise for a star of the “Harry Potter” film franchise has disappeared in a puff of smoke after Mr. Scorsese said he hadn’t seen any of the movies. According to a widely disseminated report published in the British newspaper The Sun, Mr. Scorsese said he hoped to find a role for Rupert Grint, the 21-year-old actor who plays Ron Weasley in the Potter films. The Sun also quoted Mr. Scorsese as favorably comparing Mr. Grint to Leonardo DiCaprio, who starred in Mr. Scorsese’s films “The Departed” and “Shutter Island,” among others. But in a statement on Tuesday, Mr. Scorsese wrote, “With respect to the Harry Potter films, regrettably I’ve never seen them and therefore am not able to discuss them or the performances of the talent in them in any way.” A call to a telephone number listed for The Sun at its Web site went unanswered on Tuesday morning, and an e-mail request for comment did not immediately yield a reply.

headline: ‘Bachelorette’ Rules the Night on Monday
text: ABC led in the ratings on Monday night as a two-hour installment of “The Bachelorette” garnered the night’s largest audience, 9.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network won over all despite trailing in the 10 p.m. hour with “True Beauty” (5.1 million), which lagged behind CBS’s rerun of “CSI: Miami” (7.1 million). CBS ranked second on the night with repeats of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 (6.8 million), while NBC, in third place, broadcast “Persons Unknown” at 8 (3 million), followed by “Last Comic Standing” from 9 to 11 (4.4 million). Fox finished in fourth place with repeats of “Lie to Me” at 8 (3.4 million) and “The Good Guys” at 9 (2.7 million).

headline: Men At Work Told To Pay ‘Down Under’ Royalties
text: A judge in Sydney, Australia, ruled on Tuesday that the Australian band Men at Work must share some of its royalties for the 1980s hit “Down Under” with the publisher of a classic children’s song, The Associated Press reported. If the flute solo on “Down Under” (the No. 1 hit on which Men at Work praises its homeland, “where beer does flow and men chunder”) is instantly evocative for you, it was even more familiar to Larrikin Music, which holds the rights to “Kookaburra Sits in the Old Gum Tree.” Larrikin said that song, written by Marion Sinclair in 1934 for the youth organization Girl Guides, was the source of the flute solo. Justice Peter Jacobson of Australian federal court agreed and said that EMI Songs Australia and the authors of “Down Under,” Colin Hay and Ron Strykert, must pay the publisher 5 percent of the royalties they made from the song since 2002 and from any future earnings. EMI said it would appeal.

headline: ‘Alchemist’ Graphic Novel: Words Into Pictures
text: Since “The Alchemist” was first published in 1988, that quasi-mystical novel by Paulo Coelho, left, has inspired countless band names and vision quests, and has been translated into more than 60 languages. There has been perhaps one significant omission, however, which its publisher now intends to remedy. On Tuesday HarperOne, the HarperCollins imprint that releases Mr. Coelho’s novels in the United States, said it would publish a graphic-novel adaptation of “The Alchemist” in December. The adaptation will be produced by Sea Lion Books, a Georgia-based publisher, with art by Daniel Sampere. Though an illustrated version of “The Alchemist” was previously produced, HarperOne said it had been unable to persuade Mr. Coelho to consent to the full graphic-novel treatment until he saw a presentation from Sea Lion Books. “They basically sent some preliminary artwork to Paulo with a passionate letter, and that struck him,” Gideon Weil, executive editor of HarperOne, said in a telephone interview. “He’s like, ‘These guys get it.’ ”

headline: Givenchy Still Life
text: I loved Willy Vanderperre’s somber group portrait of models in Riccardo Tisci’s fall couture collection for Givenchy. Instead of a show, Mr. Tisci presented 10 looks on forms, as well as Mr. Vanderperre’s portrait (front and back views) in a gilded set of rooms in the Place Vendôme. Frida Kahlo inspired the religious and anatomical details in the long dresses and embroidered cat suits, done in a palette of porcelain, blush-pink and gold, with exposed zippers and long silk fringe, like human hair.

headline: ‘Our Town’ Evolves, as a Former Emily Tries Management
text: THERE is precisely one word of dialogue in Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town” that reveals something personal about the play’s Stage Manager, a kind of all-knowing god of Americana who narrates the bittersweet story of small-town life, love and loss. The detail  another character refers to the Stage Manager as “sir”  is telling inasmuch as it underscores the authority that the Stage Manager must convey to deliver heartbreaking truths with full force. And, of course, “sir” confirms that the Stage Manager is a man.

headline: Rival Museums Retrace Route of China’s Imperial Treasures
text: CHONGQING, China — On a sweltering morning last month, a white-haired guide trudged up a muddy path, leading a group of scholars toward a bamboo grove on the outskirts of this western Chinese city. The site, he said, was where a large portion of China’s imperial treasures were once hidden inside several big wooden sheds.

headline: When the First Sip Is the Sommelier’s, Not Yours
text: STEPHEN SILBERLING, a tax lawyer who considers himself a knowledgeable wine drinker, could not contain his astonishment as he told me of his recent experience in a New York restaurant. He had ordered a 2007 Chapoutier Côtes du Rhône Belleruche, a wine he and his date had enjoyed so much the previous week that they decided to drink it again. As they sipped their first glass, however, they both thought the wine tasted different, and they debated whether it was flawed.

headline: Data Shows Growth in Asia May Be Slowing
text: HONG KONG  In the latest signs that the rate of growth in the Asia-Pacific region is easing, the Australian central bank kept interest rates steady on Tuesday and a critical economic index in Japan slipped in May.

headline: Is Yemen the Next Afghanistan?
text: Just before dawn on Dec. 24, an American cruise missile soared high over the southern coast of the Arabian peninsula, arced down toward the dark mountains above the Rafadh Valley in Yemen's Shabwa province and found its mark, crashing into a small stone house on a hillside where five young men were sleeping. Half a mile away, a 27-year-old Yemeni tribesman named Ali Muhammad Ahmed was awakened by the sound. Stumbling out of bed, he quickly dressed, slung his AK-47 over his shoulder and climbed down a footpath to the valley that shelters his village, two hours from the nearest paved road. He already sensed what had happened. A week earlier, an American airstrike killed dozens of people in a neighboring province as part of an expanded campaign against Al Qaeda militants. (Although the U.S. military has acknowledged playing a role in the airstrikes, it has never publicly confirmed that it fired the missiles.)

headline: India’s Drug Industry Takes Off
text: India’s drug industry was once notorious for making cheap knockoffs of Western medicines and selling them in developing countries.  But India is now starting to take on a more mainstream role in the global drug industry.

headline: Urbani Truffles Opens in New York
text: Glass vases are piled with truffles in the windows of the sleek new American headquarters of Urbani Truffles. It’s a combination showroom, demonstration kitchen and sales office, like the one Urbani runs in Umbria, Italy, near Spoleto. And it is open to shoppers, who will find an array of truffles. The only fresh ones in season now are the big summer truffles on display, black outside, taupe inside, with a scent like white truffles. There are truffle products of all kinds, including oils and paste. A delightful newcomer is a line of truffle sauces in eight combinations: white truffles with white mushrooms or porcini; and summer truffles with artichokes, tomatoes, mushrooms, cream or red or green pesto. Though a mere six ounces, each can provides enough deeply flavorful sauce for two to four servings of pasta. The sauces can also be stirred into risotto or served with grilled meats, fish or eggs.

headline: With These Chips, Who Needs Salsa?
text: New on the snack front are two chips made with legumes and without gluten. You can’t eat just one Flamous Organics Falafel Chip, which could easily shove tortilla chips off the dip tray. Made with chickpeas, corn and black beans, the regular style delivers plenty of cumin, and the spicy adds a blast of pepper.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Seasonal Farm Stands

headline: D’Artagnan Imports Ham From a Once-Rare Pig
text: Woolly-haired Mangalitsa pigs, once a disappearing breed from Hungary and prized for their creamy fat, have made a comeback. Hams from the pigs, called Mangalica in Spain, are being cured there, near Segovia, and being imported and distributed by D’Artagnan. The deep burgundy slices, streaked with mellow fat, are rich, salty and sweet, similar in color and flavor to Iberico ham from Pata Negra pigs, but more buttery, and half the price.

headline: Noma's Shrimp and Sea Urchin Powder
text: One of the Danish chef René Redzepi's intricate dishes, deconstructed.

headline: The Pleasant Crunch of Purslane
text: It’s not a summer icon like sweet corn, but you don’t have to wait for purslane, with its pleasant crunch and lemony tang. There seems to be more of this succulent plant than ever in the Greenmarkets, with several varieties available. They’re delicious, versatile, inexpensive and packed with nutrients like vitamin C and omega-3 fatty acids. In Turkey, the leaves and chopped stems are tossed with garlic, salt and yogurt thinned with a little olive oil. Mint, diced tomatoes, potatoes or beets can be added, and a dusting of sumac, Aleppo pepper or chili flakes adds flourish. Purslane can also be mixed into soups and stews at the end of cooking, and does well in a vichyssoise.

headline: Jersey Swaps, a Ritual With a Story
text: The United States had lost to Brazil, 1-0, in the 2003 Confederations Cup, but when the final whistle blew that night in Lyon, France, the American defender Gregg Berhalter walked off the field with a memento from a tough night.

headline: Obama Bypassing Congress on Medicare Job
text: President Obama will bypass Congress and appoint Dr. Donald M. Berwick, a health policy expert, to run Medicare and Medicaid, the White House said Tuesday.

headline: A Flick of the Head, a Nod to the Past
text: CAPE TOWN  Though simply saying “The Dutch” will bring a smile to the lips of many a lifelong soccer fan, the reality is that the Dutch have made a national rule of faltering in the decisive phases of the World Cup.

headline: Reviewing Kenmare
text: This week’s restaurant review is of Kenmare, the scene shop Paul Sevigny and Nur Khan opened on Kenmare Street this spring, with a generous infusion of money from Louis Ceruzzi and a menu from Joey Campanaro. I don’t like it much as a restaurant, but that may hardly matter. Places like Kenmare aren’t really about the food. They’re about who’s there and whether they know you. It’s a big city. That works for some people.

headline: A Summer Membership With Privileges
text: AT a certain income level, conventional rules about style simply fly out the convertible making its way to Sagaponack for the weekend. Fit? Meh. A little airspace masks the rolls and curves of good living. Matching? As if. Looking fastidious means you’re trying too hard, or thinking about trying too hard.

headline: Nokia to Sell Its Business in Modems
text: Nokia said on Tuesday that it would sell its wireless modem business, which has been hurt by Chinese competition, to Renesas Electronics of Japan for $200 million.

headline: A Capitalist Enclave in North Korea Survives
text: DORASAN, South Korea  Every day, hundreds of South Korean managers and engineers gather here at the steel and glass bus terminal to make an unusual commute, through the minefields and tank traps of the demilitarized zone and into an industrial park that sits just across the border in North Korea.

headline: Apple Blocks App Developer
text: Apple said that it had banished a developer and his applications from the company’s online store after he breached the accounts of users and engaged in fraudulent purchases.

headline: Jim Brown Files Appeal in Video Game Case
text: The retired football player Jim Brown asked an appellate court Tuesday to reverse a decision by a federal judge dismissing his lawsuit against the video-game publisher Electronic Arts.

headline: Building One Big Brain
text: For your own sake, focus on this column. Don’t think about your Facebook feed or your inbox. Don’t click on the ad above or the links to the right. Don’t even click on links within the column.

headline: Woods’s Answers Fit the Questions
text: Tiger Woods’s quick turnaround trip across the Atlantic to a pro-am in Ireland did not end well. His spotty play, a less-than-cordial interview session and his abrupt departure Tuesday from the town of Adare to fly to Florida less than a week before he will return to Scotland for the British Open Championship at St. Andrews raised questions about his mental preparedness for the season’s third major championship.

headline: Mayor Leans Toward a Smoking Ban at Parks and Beaches
text: After being caught off guard when the city’s health commissioner first proposed the idea, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Tuesday that he was leaning toward seeking a ban on smoking at city parks and beaches.

headline: To Address Its Housing Shortage, Paris Cracks Down on Pied-à-Terre Rentals
text: PARIS  Many people buy a pied-à-terre in Paris to use for a few weeks a year and to rent the rest of the time. Most of them don’t realize, however, that they are breaking the law. Now, the city government is trying to address the problem with a more direct approach to enforcement.

headline: Vatican Approaches New Abuse Rules
text: ROME  In an effort to rein in the sexual abuse crisis threatening the church, the Vatican is inching toward introducing changes to canon law to make it easier to discipline pedophile priests, Vatican officials say.

headline: Arizona Law Causes Split for Border Governors
text: PHOENIX  For nearly 30 years, the governors of the states that line both sides of the United States-Mexico border have gathered to celebrate border bonhomie. They issue proclamations and pledges to work together, air grievances and concerns behind closed doors and pose for the cameras in symbolic showings of cooperation.

headline: Canada: Board to Investigate Police Actions at G-20 Meeting
text: The board that supervises the Toronto Police Department said on Tuesday that it would begin an independent review of the force’s actions during the Group of 20 summit meeting in June. The police were criticized for allowing violence by some protesters to go unchecked one day and overreacting to protests the next day. More than 900 people were arrested, including many who said they were not participating in protests or any violent acts.

headline: The Queen Breezes In for an Afternoon
text: Her Majesty swept into town in the baking hours of the early afternoon and was gone by early evening, a tantalizingly concise blip of a royal visit. It was not even queen for a day, but five active hours of her presence nonetheless managed to infuse a drowsy, blisteringly hot summer afternoon with a jolt of magic.

headline: As Mercury Rose, So Did Smell of Trash
text: Just after a long three-day holiday weekend, in the middle of a scorching triple-digit afternoon on Tuesday, on a patch of sidewalk in Chinatown outside the seemingly wise Confucius Plaza at Bowery and Bayard Street, a pile of trash simmered in the New York sun.

headline: For a Royal Visit, English From the Hat Down
text: Days before she was to meet Queen Elizabeth, Vicki Downey bought three effusively festooned hats to add to her collection of nearly 100.

headline: Wal-Mart Fighting $7,000 Fine in Trampling Case
text: Wal-Mart Stores has spent a year and more than a million dollars in legal fees battling a $7,000 fine that federal safety officials assessed after shoppers trampled a Wal-Mart employee to death at a store on Long Island on the day after Thanksgiving in 2008.

headline: One U.S. Prosecutor in Brooklyn Is Behind Many Terrorism Convictions
text: In March, the Justice Department released a lengthy list of its successful terrorism prosecutions since 9/11, part of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s response to Republican criticism that the Obama administration had mishandled several international cases by bringing them in the federal courts rather than before military commissions.

headline: East Swelters in Triple Digits; More to Come
text: BOSTON  Children at a day camp near here were pulled from the swimming pool once an hour so the lifeguards could plunge in and cool off. Commuter trains in Washington were slowed because of overheating tracks. Horse-racing tracks were closed in Philadelphia and Wilmington, Del.

headline: American Dream Is Elusive for New Generation
text: GRAFTON, Mass.  After breakfast, his parents left for their jobs, and Scott Nicholson, alone in the house in this comfortable suburb west of Boston, went to his laptop in the living room. He had placed it on a small table that his mother had used for a vase of flowers until her unemployed son found himself reluctantly stuck at home.

headline: Lackluster Field for Home Run Derby
text: On Tuesday, Major League Baseball announced the first six participants for Monday’s Home Run Derby in Anaheim: Miguel Cabrera of the Tigers, Robinson Cano of the Yankees, Corey Hart of the Brewers, Matt Holliday of the Cardinals, David Ortiz of the Red Sox and Vernon Wells of the Blue Jays.

headline: One Company Left in Bidding for Aqueduct Slot Franchise
text: The largest gambling company in Southeast Asia is the last company standing in the latest competition for the franchise rights to operate 4,500 electronic slot machines at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens.

headline: Egypt: Bus Driver Kills 6 on Morning Commuting Trip
text: A bus driver for an engineering firm, possibly angered that colleagues cut him out of a scheme to steal antiquities, shot and killed six employees on a company shuttle bus Tuesday morning before surrendering to the authorities, local investigators and Egypt’s Interior Ministry said. Six other employees were seriously wounded in the attack. The driver, Mahmoud Taha Ahmed Seweilam, 54, who worked for the Arab Contractors Company for more than 20 years, stopped his bus around 8 a.m. in a Cairo suburb, pulled a machine gun from under his seat and asked two employees to step off the bus, where he shot them, the authorities said. Mr. Seweilam then got back on to the bus and began firing indiscriminately before driving the bus to work, where he turned himself in.

headline: Louisiana and Scientists Spar Over How to Stop Oil
text: With oil hitting Barataria Bay, a vast estuary in southeast Louisiana that boasts one of the most productive fisheries in the country, local parish officials hatched a plan in May to save the fragile ecosystem: they would build rock dikes across several major tidal inlets between the bay and the Gulf of Mexico to block and then capture the oil.

headline: Britain’s Inflation Pain Poses Risk for Recovery
text: LONDON  Committee members at the Bank of England and some economists have been puzzled by persistently high inflation in Britain, causing some concerns that the country’s recovery might stagnate.

headline: Front-Runner Emerges for Tower Partnership
text: After weeks of negotiations, a front-runner has emerged in the search for a private partner at 1 World Trade Center, the $3.3 billion skyscraper under construction at ground zero.

text: “Semper Paratus” is our guide,Our fame, our glory too.To fight to save or fight to die,Aye! Coast Guard, we are for you!

headline: Santana Helps Himself and Mets
text: Manager Jerry Manuel popped out of the dugout with one out in the ninth inning Tuesday night and walked deliberately toward Johan Santana, who was protecting a shutout for the Mets. With the potential tying run coming to bat, Manuel asked Santana how he was feeling.

headline: Stoudemire and Knicks Wait to See Who Will Join Them
text: Amar’e Stoudemire had plenty to say in his not-quite-official introduction to New York, whether the topic was knees, Knicks or LeBron James. He spoke in bold assertions, a habit that Coach Mike D’Antoni cheerfully referred to as Stoudemire’s “bravada.”

headline: For the Reds’ Rhodes, Pitching Becomes a Tribute
text: Arthur Rhodes will leave tickets for five people at the All-Star Game on Tuesday in Anaheim. His mother will be there, and two sisters, a niece and his 16-year-old daughter, Jade. Five women supporting a 40-year-old rookie All-Star.

headline: Republican Emerges as Obama’s Annoyer-in-Chief
text: WASHINGTON  As a sign of the pride Representative Darrell Issa takes in annoying the Obama administration, consider his account of a recent exchange with Rahm Emanuel, a former congressman and now the White House chief of staff. In describing the episode  a chance encounter outside the House gym  Mr. Issa smirked and raised his middle finger.

headline: Let Goldman Be Goldman
text: Poised as we are for the most comprehensive financial reform in this country since the Great Depression, it is time to fess up to the fact that it likely would not have occurred without a concerted effort by the Obama administration and the Democratic-controlled Congress to demonize Goldman Sachs.

text: OAKLAND, Calif.  At the All-Star Game next Tuesday, Manager Joe Girardi may confront an unfamiliar situation. If the American League is leading entering the ninth inning, he cannot turn to Mariano Rivera.

text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  For some in President Obama’s White House, Missouri remains the state that got away, nearly two years after his election.

It was performed last year, not two years ago.

text: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel satisfied their short-term political goals with an Oval Office meeting on Tuesday. It is less clear that they achieved much of substance.

headline: Drug Company Payoffs
text: Before heading home for a weeklong recess, the House of Representatives passed a bill on July 1 that would crack down on a devious tactic used by some pharmaceutical companies. The tactic, known as “pay for delay,” involves business deals in which the makers of patented brand-name drugs pay generic competitors to delay the introduction of cheaper alternatives.

headline: Greeting the Heat
text: Will it make you feel better to know that it was 111 degrees in Riyadh on Tuesday? Or that 117 degrees is the predicted high for Baghdad on Wednesday? Those temperatures, as uncomfortable as they are, are normal for this time of year in that part of the world. In New York City, Tuesday’s peak temperature  103 degrees at 3:11 p.m.  brought the city uncomfortably close to its all-time record high: 106 degrees on July 9, 1936. It was even closer to its second-highest high, a near-record many of us remember: 104 degrees on July 21, 1977.

headline: Sweet Honey on the Block
text: FOR the first time in more than a decade, New York’s beekeepers are claiming their summer perches on the city’s rooftops. Bowing to a citywide campaign, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene recently removed honeybees from the Health Code’s register of “venomous insects” and other prohibited animals. Not surprisingly, the New York City Beekeepers Association saw a sizable bump in enrollment for its spring classes.

headline: Shin Is on the Mend After Appendectomy
text: OAKMONT, Pa. — Jiyai Shin held the No. 1 world ranking for seven weeks, ascending to the top spot after Lorena Ochoa’s retirement. She might still be there if not for an emergency appendectomy the week of the L.P.G.A. tour stop in Springfield, Ill.

headline: Stuffed Peppers, Lamb’s Head Soup, Canyons and Condors in Arequipa, Peru
text: To a person with a sweet tooth versed in Latin American desserts — by which I mean me — Arequipa, Peru, sounds like a delicious place. From its name comes the word arequipe, which is what Colombians and Venezuelans (though not Peruvians, oddly enough) call their versions of dulce de leche.

headline: Racial Motive Alleged in a Justice Dept. Decision
text: WASHINGTON  A former Justice Department lawyer hired during the Bush administration alleged on Tuesday that the department scaled down a voter-intimidation case against the New Black Panther Party last year because his former colleagues do not want to protect white people’s civil rights.

text: Last year, we wrote that Twitter was considering e-commerce as one of its revenue models. On Tuesday it unveiled its first foray into selling products.

headline: A Tortuous Journey for Kohlberg Kravis I.P.O.
text: One of the most eagerly anticipated numbers in finance has finally been revealed. The co-founders of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, collected a combined $44 million last year, according to a filing on Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. That’s plenty, but a far cry from the $611 million that the Blackstone founders, Stephen A. Schwarzman and Peter G. Peterson, pocketed the year before their private equity firm’s 2007 initial public offering.

headline: Bob Probert, 45, Renowned Hockey Brawler, Dies
text: Bob Probert, a strapping forward for the Detroit Red Wings and Chicago Blackhawks who became one of hockey’s most accomplished brawlers but struggled with drug and alcohol abuse, died Monday in Windsor, Ontario. He was 45.

headline: Bobby Gonzalez Is Accused of Stealing
text: The difficult year for the former Seton Hall basketball coach Bobby Gonzalez continued when he reported to the Millburn, N.J., police on Monday and was charged with shoplifting and criminal mischief.

text: DURBAN, South Africa  Philipp Lahm refuses to relinquish the spotlight he recently commanded. Not before Lahm, an unlikely German star, has a chance to make a curtain call at the World Cup.

headline: Was the East Anglia Incident a Crime? Yes.
text: July 18, 2012, 7:05 p.m. | Updated Today saw the publication of the Independent Climate Change Email Review, the last of three inquiries into issues raised by the unauthorized release of thousands of files and e-mail messages from the climatic research unit of the University of East Anglia in Britain.

headline: Lawmakers Oppose Canadian Pipeline
text: Facing a decision on a proposed pipeline to bring Canadian crude oil to the United States, the Obama administration is confronting growing resistance from politicians who oppose the project or, at the very least, urge further study before approval.

text: NEW ORLEANS  All along the Gulf Coast for the past two months, the threat of oil hitting shore has kept communities on edge.

headline: After a Fall
text: The report on Breaking News Network‘s scanner noted a person out the window and another person barricaded in an apartment at Willis Avenue and East 135th Street in the Bronx; the Mitchel Houses. Ángel Franco, a staff photographer at The New York Times who is creating a series called “At the Sirens’ End,” responded to the call. What he found when he arrived was in a way surreal: the scene of the crime — if it was a crime at all (the police wouldn’t say one way or the other whether the victim had been pushed) — was 15 stories in the air. All one could do was look up, unless you were an emergency services officer donning body armor to go into the apartment. A pair of small, black, high-top sneakers marked the spot where the victim, a women, had fallen to earth. All the police would say about her condition was that she still had a pulse when they arrived. She had been rushed to a hospital. Neighbors filled in the picture a bit. Her name was Wanda. She was sweet, slight and sociable. When Mr. Franco returned to the building later, he found a touching memorial already taking form.

headline: Perez and Beltran Play Well in St. Lucie
text: The Mets have surely not missed answering questions about the embattled starter Oliver Perez for the past month. But that may change soon.

headline: Phys Ed: Your Brain on Exercise
text: What goes on inside your brain when you exercise? That question has preoccupied a growing number of scientists in recent years, as well as many of us who exercise. In the late 1990s, Dr. Fred Gage and his colleagues at the Laboratory of Genetics at the Salk Institute in San Diego elegantly proved that human and animal brains produce new brain cells (a process called neurogenesis) and that exercise increases neurogenesis. The brains of mice and rats that were allowed to run on wheels pulsed with vigorous, newly born neurons, and those animals then breezed through mazes and other tests of rodent I.Q., showing that neurogenesis improves thinking.

headline: Eleanor R. Morse, Dalí Collector, Dies at 97
text: Eleanor R. Morse, whose enthusiasm for Salvador Dalí led her, with her husband, to amass an important collection of the artist’s work and found the Salvador Dalí Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., died on Thursday at her home in St. Petersburg. She was 97.

headline:
Talks on a Rapid End
to Russian Spy Case
text: Less than two weeks after arresting 10 people suspected of being secret Russian agents, the federal government is in talks with lawyers for the defendants about a broad and rapid resolution to the case, according to people who have been briefed on the discussions.

headline: U.S.C. Recruit Can Leave
text: Seantrel Henderson, the offensive lineman considered by most analysts to be the nation’s top high school football recruit of the class of 2010, has been released from the letter of intent that he signed with Southern California. Last month, U.S.C. was hit with a two-year bowl ban, four years’ probation and loss of scholarships among other penalties for improper benefits involving the former Trojans running back Reggie Bush.

headline: Robert Butler, Aging Expert, Is Dead at 83
text: Dr. Robert N. Butler, a psychiatrist whose painful youthful realization that death is inevitable prompted him to challenge and ultimately reform the treatment of the elderly through research, public policy and a Pulitzer Prize-winning book, died Sunday in Manhattan. He was 83 and had worked until three days before his death.

headline: Cesare Siepi, Renowned Italian Opera Singer, Dies at 87
text: Cesare Siepi, the renowned Italian bass acclaimed for his vocally suave, swashbuckling portrayal of Mozart’s Don Giovanni, died on Monday in Atlanta, where he had lived for 25 years. He was 87.

headline: Ann Waldron, Biographer of Southern Writers, Is Dead at 85
text: Ann Waldron, who wrote biographies of Southern writers and books for children and young adults, but then — at 78 — decided that she’d rather concoct tales about gruesome murders on the campus of Princeton University, died Friday at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 85.

headline: Con-Ed Nerve Center Fights to Keep Lights On
text: From the 19th floor of Consolidated Edison’s headquarters in Manhattan, generators were dispatched to supplement a burning substation. Emergency alerts were relayed to major customers and companies. The go-ahead was given to cancel Little League night games on Staten Island to conserve the wattage used by field lights.

headline: News Quiz | July 7, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: K.K.R. Going Public Next Week

That was fine with Sabathia, who rarely fares well at his boyhood ballpark. Sabathia worked seven and two-thirds innings in the Yankees’ 6-1 victory against the Oakland Athletics on Tuesday, but Rodriguez just could not help himself again.

headline: A Spot of Paris in London for Bastille Day
text: As France’s Les Bleus crashed out of the World Cup, a disgruntled president Nicolas Sarkozy abruptly canceled the annual Bastille Day bash on July 14 at the Elysée Palace (austerity measures were cited). No problem. Parisians eager to enjoy their national holiday can hop on a Eurostar train and head to London, where, three days early, the largest Bastille day celebration outside of France will take place in Battersea Park.

headline: Don’t Expect a Full Labor-Market Recovery

headline: BP’s Hayward Flies to Abu Dhabi to Meet ‘Partners’
text: BP‘s embattled chief executive is in Abu Dhabi to meet business partners, amid speculation that the oil giant is looking to drum up cash to cover clean up costs from the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Case for Voluntary Taxes
text: Today’s idea: Voluntary taxes, some say, offer a politically palatable way to raise additional revenue and perhaps even strengthen American patriotism and citizenship.

headline: Ex-I.B.M. Executive in Galleon Case Says Affair Was Business
text: Robert Moffat, the former I.B.M. executive who admitted to charges of insider trading in the Galleon hedge fund investigation, wants people to know that his affair with co-defendant Danielle Chiesi was not about sex.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Her Own Wax Figure’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: And in Today’s Morning Take-Out:

headline: Women and Growing Companies
text: I’ve learned there are lots of resources for women who want to build growing companies, and I’ve listed a few below. Are there others we should all know about? Please share your favorites.

headline: Obama to Report on Plan to Increase Exports
text: President Obama, who pledged in his State of the Union address to double American exports over five years, will make the case on Wednesday that his plan is “on track’’ and will name 18 business and labor leaders to a new export council to advise him, the White House said.

headline: Will Work for No Pay
text: WHO are finding it difficult to land internships?

headline: British Troops to Hand Over to Americans in Afghan Hot Spot
text: LONDON  Britain announced Wednesday that 1,000 of its troops in Afghanistan will hand over to American Marines by October in the hotly contested Sangin region of northern Helmand Province, where the British have lost nearly 100 of the 312 British soldiers who have died in the war.

headline: Afghan Strike by NATO Kills Soldiers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO pilots mistakenly attacked Afghan soldiers who had laid a trap for Taliban militants and killed at least five of the soldiers on Wednesday, a devastating case of friendly fire in a conflict still troubled by miscommunication among allied forces, Afghan officials said.

headline: Q.&A.: Web Design for Beginners
text: Q.

headline: Lexus Takes Its Comedy-Fueled Debate Series on the Road
text: The comedians Tracy Morgan, Andy Samberg and Jamie Kennedy, and the singer Mark McGrath probably aren’t the first names that come to mind when you think of the vanguards of environmentalism. But each will moderate a debate in a series covering four major cities and organized by Lexus to promote its new compact hybrid, the CT 200h, which goes on sale early next year.

headline: China Commentary Slams U.S. for Steel Suspicions
text: China’s official Xinhua news agency on Tuesday criticized a group of 50 United States lawmakers for calling for an investigation into Chinese investment in the American steel industry, saying the action amounted to protectionism, Reuters reported.

headline: Private Equity Rides Again
text: With an increase in secondary buyouts and a stock market more friendly toward initial public offerings, the private equity industry seems headed for something of a revival after grinding to near a stand-still during the financial crisis, The Deal Magazine writes.

headline: Sudden Surplus Calls for Quick Thinking
text: Engineers say that if the power grid becomes more reliant on renewable energy, a lot of new transmission lines will have to be built at some point or there will be unhappy consequences. Mostly this problem has been predicted rather than experienced. But the future may have arrived last month, when the Bonneville Power Administration, a federal agency that oversees power transmission in the Pacific Northwest, had more energy than it could comfortably use.

headline: Live From Sun Valley, Day One
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — The moguls have arrived.

headline: Markets See Biggest Rally Since May
text: For a day, at least, Wall Street got its groove back.

headline: Maven Research Lands $1 Million in Seed Funding
text: Maven Research, an online microconsulting platform, announced that it has received $1 million in seed funding from a group of investors including Accel Partners.

headline: E.U. Antitrust Chief Looking at Google Allegations
text: The European Union‘s antitrust chief said Wednesday that he was looking ”very carefully” into allegations that Google had unfairly demoted the Web sites of rivals in search results, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Kubica Extends Contract With Renault
text: Robert Kubica, the Polish driver who is currently sixth in the championship and has scored two podium finishes this season for the Renault team – which, by the way, is better than Michael Schumacher has done at Mercedes – will stay with Renault until the end of 2012, the team announced Wednesday.

headline: Indian Soldiers Are Deployed to Restore Order in Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI  The Indian Army deployed on the streets of the disputed region of Kashmir on Wednesday, seeking to quell angry street protests that have convulsed the valley.

headline: Examining the Complaints About American Rifle Reliability
text: Since late last year, At War has looked at issues surrounding small-arms choices and performance in the Afghan war, by American units and insurgents alike. We’ll continue this theme with two quick posts in the next few days: one serving as a follow-up to the continuing conversation about American rifle reliability, the other a closer look at the small arms that Afghan fighters have been wielding against Marines and government forces in Marja.

headline: She Can’t Kick the Habit: Whoopi Goldberg Back in ‘Sister Act’
text: To everything there is a season: one day you’re the streetwise lounge singer who hides from the mob by taking refuge in a convent; the next day you’re that convent’s seemingly intractable leader (who secretly possesses a heart of gold).

headline: Simpson Thacher’s Finley Joins Blackstone
text: John G. Finley, a veteran mergers and acquisitions lawyer and a partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, has joined the  Blackstone Group as a senior managing director and chief legal officer. Mr. Finley, who headed Simpson’s global mergers and acquisitions group and has worked on some of the biggest transactions in history, will start at Blackstone on Sept. 1.

headline: Graphic Content | A Fount of Fonts
text: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the MFA Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

headline: U.S. Seeks to End Spy Case Quickly
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Study Finds Language Help for Immigrants Lacking
text: New York is, of course, a city of immigrants. But for residents who speak little English and need government assistance, it is in Manhattan, the heart of the city, that they are least likely to get help applying for food stamps, subsidized medical care and other public benefits in their native language, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Climategate Fever Breaks
text: The Independent Climate Change Email Review is finished and, within its constrained mandate, has cleared climate scientists and administrators at the University of East Anglia of claims of malfeasance rising out of the contents of folders of e-mail messages and files extracted from computers there and posted around the Web last November. Two other inquiries with slightly different focal points also cleared the scientists and school. (As I wrote last night, there is still a glaring unanswered question: Was a crime committed in releasing or extracting the files?)

headline: Spoiler-Free Reasons to Get Excited About the New ‘Mad Men’ Season
text: As card-carrying members of the media elite we were fortunate enough to receive our “Mad Men” Season 4 promotional packages in the mail Tuesday. And while it would be totally unfair of us to spoil crucial plot elements from the show’s July 25 premiere (did you hear that the story jumps ahead to the far-flung future of 2168?), there are a few non-spoiler-y details we think we can safely share.

headline: Russian Reportedly Pressed to Sign Confession Ahead of Possible Prisoner Exchange Deal
text: Update | 11:26 a.m. My colleague Andrew Kramer in Moscow has more on this story, including an interview with the scientist’s mother.

headline: Nsikoism & The Soup Pot of the Enemy
text: A Nigerian description of a political culture in which individuals act in blind self interest – thwarting the efforts of others – just as crabs attempt to escape a basket. (Nsiko = crabs)

headline: Russian Pianist Charged in Rape of Thai Boy
text: BANGKOK  Mikhail V. Pletnev, a Russian piano prodigy turned world-renowned conductor and composer, has been charged with raping a 14-year-old boy in Thailand.

headline: Defined by Soccer: Nancy Majola
text: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa for the World Cup to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. Based in Alexandra — a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people — the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.

headline: Wednesday’s Game: Germany vs. Spain
text: World Cup Semifinal: Germany vs. Spain2:30 p.m. EasternTV: ESPN, UnivisionA surplus of attacking skill will be on display when Spain and Germany meet for this semifinal match in Durban. Germany’s Miroslav Klose, 32, with 14 goals in his Cup career, needs just one more to tie Brazil’s Ronaldo for the all-time record. Mesut Oezil, 22, and Thomas Mueller, 20, have complemented Klose’s veteran craft with youthful vigor, but Mueller is suspended for this match. Germany’s field-devouring attack is contrasted by the meticulous passing and probing of Spain. Fernando Torres scored the winning goal for Spain when these teams met in the Euro 2008 final, but the striker has played below his capacity in this Cup. David Villa has picked up the slack, scoring five goals so far to bring his career total to 43 goals in 63 games for Spain.

headline: Early Word: American Exports
text: President Obama plans to talk about exports and the economy this morning, and the White House said that he “will name 18 business and labor leaders to a new export council to advise him,” The Times’s Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes.

headline: Ridley Scott Wants Your YouTube Moments
text: Pick a day. Ask people to record what’s going on in their lives — getting a haircut, having a birthday party, taking a nap, whatever — and post the video on YouTube. Turn the video into a feature-length documentary.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Rising Passport Fees
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Are There Any Benefits to a Heat Wave?
text: The City Room blog asked this question yesterday as the temperature in New York City climbed to a record-breaking 103. We invite you to post your own serious or funny responses here, just as adult readers did there. Even if your own region isn’t currently experiencing sizzling conditions, what benefits can you imagine for a heat wave where you live?

headline: Teaching the Heat Wave: Games, Lessons and More
text: To mark the record-breaking heat on the East Coast this week, we offer a heat-wave fill-in, a list of lessons on weather (including one on “the science of cold” just for the relief it might offer to imagine it), a Student Crossword and a Student Opinion question to which you’re invited to post funny or serious responses: “Are There Any Benefits to a Heat Wave?”

headline: Obama Asks Court to Reinstate Ban on Deepwater Drilling
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has asked a federal court in Louisiana to reinstate the ban on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, saying the moratorium was a rational response to the unparalleled emergency of the BP oil spill.

headline: Do You Earn More Than Your Parents Did?
text: Here is yet another wrinkle in the eternal debate over who had it tougher, father or son (or, mother or daughter):

headline: British Panel Clears Scientists
text: A British panel on Wednesday exonerated the scientists caught up in the controversy known as Climategate of charges that they had manipulated their research to support preconceived ideas about global warming.

headline: A Home (Barely) Fit for Two Mrs. Roosevelts
text: For the first time in 67 years, people are living in a certain rather famous town house on East 65th Street — up on the sixth floor, where the original occupants’ laundry flapped in the breeze long ago.

headline: Steps Point to Possible Swap of Spy Suspects With Russia
text: WASHINGTON  Just days after the F.B.I.’s sensational dismantling of a Russian spy ring, the American and Russian authorities on Wednesday were negotiating an exchange of some or all of the 10 accused agents for prisoners held in Russia, including a scientist convicted of spying for the United States.

headline: Yankees Not Worried About Rivera, Yet
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Not until after the World Series last fall did Mariano Rivera reveal that he had been pitching with a sore right oblique muscle. He did not allow a run in five and one-third innings against the Phillies.

headline: Banana Republic Goes ‘Mad’ Again
text: The Banana Republic clothing chain owned by Gap Inc. is back for a second year of promoting a season premiere of “Mad Men,” the AMC series about advertising in the 1960s.

headline: French Court Sentences Noriega to 7 Years
text: PARIS  The former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega was convicted Wednesday of money laundering and sentenced by a French judge to seven years in prison.

headline: Bosh Joins Wade; James’s Announcement Is Next
text: The first radical shift resulting from N.B.A. free agency took place with Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh announcing Wednesday that they will pair together with the Miami Heat.

headline: Lessons to Learn From Medicare Pilot
text: If you don’t succeed, try, try again. But make sure not to repeat the same mistakes.

headline: Ryan and Hoffman Will Not Appear at Jerusalem Film Festival, Organizers Say
text: 11:12 a.m. | Updated

headline: Intel Working on Black Box for Your Car
text: Bad news for one company may be good news for another. Case in point: Toyota’s woes with recalls and mysterious acceleration problems may turn out to be a boon to tech companies like Intel, which already has its sights set on getting into your next car.

headline: Juanita M. Kreps, Commerce Secretary, Dies at 89
text: Juanita M. Kreps, who was President Jimmy Carter’s secretary of commerce from 1977 to 1979, the first woman and the first economist to hold a post traditionally occupied by men with business interests, died Monday in Durham, N.C. She was 89.

headline: Does LeBron Deserve 60 Minutes on ESPN?
text: Eyes were rolling nationwide with the news Tuesday night that LeBron James has decided to name the team he will sign with as a free agent during an ESPN hourlong special Thursday at 9 p.m.

headline: Off the Menu: Bouchon Bakery
text: Thomas Keller plans to open a second Bouchon Bakery in New York next March. It will replace the Dean & DeLuca at 1 Rockefeller Plaza (48th Street). But it will not have a restaurant component like the Bouchon Bakery in the Time Warner Center. “In good weather there will be about 45 tables outdoors, but there will be no waiter service,” he said. Sébastien Rouxel, the pastry chef for Bouchon uptown, will take on this project, too, where all the baking will also be done in-house. Tiffany Jones will be the chef de cuisine for both Bouchons, in charge of savory items. Mr. Keller said that a few years ago he thought about a chain of Bouchon Bakeries in New York, but his plans have been scaled back. “We’ll take it one step at a time,” he said.

headline: Qaeda Leader Indicted in New York Subway Plot
text: Meeting with violent Salvadoran gangs in Honduras. Seeking radioactive material at a university in Hamilton, Ontario. Running an import-export business and teaching English  wife and child in tow  in Morocco. Hiding out in Suriname.

headline: The (Unnamed) Source for News
text: Welcome to the new depths of absurdity courtesy of the N.B.A.’s current three-ring circus of free agency, led by LeBron James. Consider that the nadir is not even the news that James will announce his decision about a team on live television, and it’s not even that ESPN is reporting as breaking news that James will make his announcement on ESPN.
