No, the supreme silliness prize is awarded to ESPN for reporting it based on an anonymous independent source.

headline: Letter: New Orleans Still Vibrant
text: To the Editor: “In New Orleans, New Life by the River” (June 27) reminded me once again of the beauty and vibrancy of my neighborhood. After finishing the article, I dined at the Creole-inspired Ralph’s on the Park, where I savored grouper, shrimp and tuna caught fresh off our coast. Then I strolled through the French Quarter appreciating the history and culture all around, ending the evening on Frenchmen Street at some of the jazz clubs.

headline: Night Comes Alive in Madeira
text: THE subtropical island of Madeira, sometimes called the Pearl of the Atlantic, has long held sway over the unhealthy and the elderly British. The Anglo roots on this Portuguese island are long-standing, thanks to a royal marriage in the 16th century.

headline: Letter: Dining Options in Oakland
text: To the Editor: I was pleased to read the Choice Tables column extolling five new food spots in my hometown (“In Oakland, Innovation Is on the Menu,” June 27). You could easily have mentioned another handful of recently opened restaurants without any decline in quality: Picán (picanrestaurant.com), upscale Southern; Sidebar (sidebar-oakland.com), a bistro; Hibiscus (hibiscusoakland.com), Creole; Chop Bar (chopbar510.com), new American; and Brown Sugar Kitchen (brownsugarkitchen.com), nouvelle soul food. This doesn’t include all the great Korean, Ethiopian/Eritrean, Japanese or Spanish restaurants — on Telegraph Avenue alone. Oakland truly knows how to eat.

headline: Walking With the Herds in Kenya
text: I STOOD in a makeshift workshop in Njoro, a town in the Great Rift Valley of Kenya, as residents assembled bows and arrows for battle. On the hay-scattered lawn, at the end of a brown dirt road past abandoned wheat fields and eerily deserted houses, an earnest young man named Samuel showed me how to use the weapon: dip the arrow into frog poison, secure it into the bow, aim and then shoot. “I need to protect my family,” he told me.

headline: Grammys Change Award Rule After Lady Gaga No-No
text: It’s no help to Lady Gaga now, but the Recording Academy said on Wednesday that it had changed a Grammy Awards rule that prevented the chameleon-like pop star from being nominated as best new artist for this year’s awards, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Shakespeare, and Good Eats in Oregon
text: WHILE the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, currently in the midst of its annual nine-month-long run, has long been a magnet drawing culture seekers to Ashland in southern Oregon, the scenic town has never been much of a destination for food enthusiasts. But a number of new and wide-ranging restaurants are redrawing the town’s culinary map.

headline: Petacchi Wins Stage Full of Wounded Riders
text: REIMS, France  As if Stage 4 of the Tour de France were just another day of racing, the cyclists sprinting toward the finish line Wednesday ducked their heads, pumped their legs and fearlessly flew forward.

headline: On Our Radar: A Warming Antarctic
text: The Antarctic Peninsula is warming at five times the global average, according to a new study in the journal Science. The region’s average winter temperatures have risen 6 degrees Celsius since 1960.

headline: Where Guests Help Head ’em Up
text: A LEISURELY dinner hour is drawing to a close at the J Bar L ranch in southwest Montana, and a party of guests is still abuzz with the excitement of the day. Eyes bright despite fatigue, they swap tales of how they’d spent the day herding cattle. A high point for some was a veterinary procedure in which cows were held immobile in a chute while a vet made an incision in a flank and reached in arm-deep to pull out the ovaries.

headline: Bernhard Willhelm | Hardcore Couture
text: As if his lederhosen don’t invite enough Brüno comparisons, Bernhard Willhelm wants to talk about kinky sex. The German-born, Paris-based designer’s latest men’s collection was inspired by “the sexuality of my generation” — by fetishes (he mentioned “Spandex”) and the online communities (from Facebook to the nude photo-rating site TangoTime) where people feel increasingly safe to flaunt them. “It seems like people live out that sexuality only on the Internet,” Willhelm says. “But in real life they don’t really feel it.” Set in Paris en plein air amid traffic signs, fluorescent-colored smoke bombs, and a knee-high blanket of white soap suds, Willhelm’s presentation late last month  — with its gas-masks, skeleton prints, and a Japanese happi coat emblazoned with the word “SEXSI!” — sought to reflect this online-only realm of carnal intrigue. In some cases, Willhelm even printed out photos from Internet dating profiles and laminated them onto clothes.

headline: In the Philippines, the Next Phuket?
text: DON’T try to hoof it to the newly relocated Jungle Bar, at least not from Boracay’s main strip, White Beach, where it used to be a mainstay — you’ll never find it. Instead, hail a motorized rickshaw to Bulabog Beach, hang a right past a barren strip of bamboo shacks, and look for the colorful, ghoulish lanterns dangling from the coconut trees, which give this tiki bar the quirky feel of a Tim Burton-inspired guerrilla camp. The décor will probably be familiar to most Bob Marley-listening beach bums, right down to the rooster named Pedro dozing on the bar, the shirtless Filipinos eating grilled fish, and the $10 cocktails with profanity-laced names. All that’s missing is a drum circle.

headline: What We’re Reading: Dirty Money
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: They Grow Up So Quickly, Don’t They?
text: THE title of Lisa Cholodenko’s wonderful new film, “The Kids Are All Right,” quotes an ancient youth-culture anthem by the Who: a song released before the parents of many of today’s teenagers were born. At least for members of my generation (to stick with the Who’s back catalog for a moment) the phrase’s original defiance has given way to anxious, fingers-crossed hopefulness. In the context of Ms. Cholodenko’s movie  a comedy of domestic manners and misunderstandings set amid the liberal-minded American middle class  “The Kids Are All Right” is a statement shadowed by an implicit question: Aren’t they?

headline: Commercials in a Dentist’s Office? O.K., I’ll Bite
text: A television commercial about how the calcium in milk can benefit dental health is being shown in — natch — dentists’ offices.

headline: Why Isn’t Investment Higher?
text: Truly, we live in a time of mass delusion — or maybe make that elite delusion — where there are lots of things that everyone believes, without a shred of evidence to back that belief. Here’s one more: everywhere you go, you encounter the claim that businesses aren’t investing, they’re just sitting on piles of cash, because they’re worried about future government policies.

headline: Welcome to the Hospital California
text: Sometimes patients say things so true it’s painful. A few months ago someone about to be discharged snarled at me, “This place is like a prison!” And then he thought about it and said, “No, it’s not — it’s like the Hotel California.”

headline: How Can You Tell Economists Have a Sense of Humor?
text: How can you tell economists have a sense of humor? They use decimal points.

headline: Denver Broncos 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Top Drug Executive Salaries
text: Fred Hassan of Schering-Plough was the highest paid pharmaceutical executive in the nation in 2009, thanks to a $33 million “golden handshake” when Merck bought the company, according to the annual Top 10 list of drug industry pay compiled by the Web site FiercePharma.

headline: Sun Valley: While Moguls Hobnob, Their Kids Play
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — It’s a time-honored tradition for the attendees of the Allen & Company media confab to bring their kin to the weeklong festivities. (Owen Van Natta, formerly of MySpace, was one of several executives to roll up to the Sun Valley Lodge on Tuesday in a big car with his family.)

headline: Sun Valley: The Security Cordon Tightens
text: Michael J. de la Merced/The New York Times

headline: TimesCast | July 7, 2010
text: A daily news cast

headline: He’s a Billionaire, and the Press Gets Just a Trailer
text: The billionaire mayor has finally put the press in its place — in a trailer park outside his front door.

headline: Tips on Settling Defaulted Federal Student Loans
text: If you’ve defaulted on your federal student loan debt — that is, gone at least a year without payments — you may feel as if you have no options other than drowning in debt.

headline: Paris Couture: Gaultier’s Dragons
text: Before Jean Paul Gaultier’s show this afternoon, I popped backstage to say hello and absorb a little madness — I mean, direction. He told me he sold more pieces last season than in any year since he started doing haute couture. “And I don’t mean we’re making money with couture; we are not,” he said. But it was a good season. He then rambled a bit about the new collection, and I gathered that it drew on the essence of Paris couture — shapes, silhouettes. “The Paris woman is everywhere today,” he said, and laughed. “Everywhere but Paris.”

headline: Function Over Style? A Surprise From the Dutch
text: The Dutch are not behaving themselves. Just look at their victory over Uruguay. If someone had told you before the World Cup that the Netherlands would enjoy a 3-2 triumph at the semifinal stage, you’d imagine a game replete with skill and thrill.

headline: Beet, Citrus and Avocado Salad
text: This is a beautiful salad of contrasting flavors and textures. The juicy, acidic grapefruit plays off the earthy beets and the creamy, nutty avocado.

headline: Mixed Spring Greens Salad With Roasted Beets
text: I love tossing beets with about any green salad, but especially in a mesclun (mixed baby spring greens) salad. Usually the mixture contains some red lettuces and greens, like baby red chard or kale, and the colors go nicely together. If you can’t find a good mix of baby greens, arugula is a perfect alternative.

headline: World Cup Live: Germany vs. Spain
text: With the hardened, entrenched word “underachiever” at last pried from its reputation and flung into its past, Spain systematically topped Germany on Wednesday night in Durban and went streaming into the glamorous soccer nation’s first-ever World Cup final.

headline: Grated Raw Beet Salad
text: People who swear they hate beets love this salad. It’s a North African-inspired mixture of grated, uncooked beets dressed with orange and lemon juices and a small amount of olive oil. It makes a great starter when you’re serving something robust as a main course, like a couscous.

headline: To Build Exports, Obama Vows to Push Stalled Trade Pacts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who vowed in his State of the Union address to double American exports over the next five years, said on Wednesday that he would renew efforts to renegotiate long-stalled free-trade agreements with Panama and Colombia and persuade Congress to adopt them.

headline: Elena Kagan’s Science Problem, and Ours
text: Will Saletan has an excellent piece on Elena Kagan’s role, as a Clinton administration legal advisor, in doctoring the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists statement on partial-birth abortion to make it more congenial to the pro-choice side of the argument. He makes the essential point, which is that this incident reflects badly on Kagan, worse on the ACOG — but worst of all on the various judges who then assumed, in decision after decision, that the ACOG statement could be treated as The Scientific Answer to the partial-birth abortion question, pure and undefiled by any crass political considerations. “This is the scandal’s real lesson,” Saletan writes. “Judges should stop treating the statements of scientific organizations as apolitical. Such statements, like the statements of any other group, can be loaded with spin …  All of us should be embarrassed that a sentence written by a White House aide now stands enshrined in the jurisprudence of the Supreme Court, erroneously credited with scientific authorship and rigor.”

headline: A Last Conversation With Dr. Robert Butler
text: “I think a lot of older people are sitting on their asses, playing golf, and not making a contribution to society.”

headline: Close Encounters of the ‘Weeds’ Kind: Richard Dreyfuss Joins Showtime Series
text: The producers of “Weeds” have been a bit ambiguous about where exactly Nancy Botwin, the drug-dealing mom played by Mary-Louise Parker, and her family will be fleeing for the show’s coming sixth season. Could one of their destinations be a sleepy Northeastern resort town still haunted by a toothless old shark who chewed up its tourists in 1975? Maybe, maybe not, but either way, Richard Dreyfuss — who’s really making the most of the 35th anniversary of his starring role in “Jaws” — will be joining the “Weeds” ensemble for at least four episodes of Season 6, press representatives for the Showtime comedy said on Wednesday. A news release described the character played by Mr. Dreyfuss (whose film credits also include “Close Encounters of the Third Kind,” “American Graffiti” and “The Goodbye Girl”) as “an unexpected character from Nancy’s past.” The new season of “Weeds,” which has its debut on Aug. 16, will also feature as guest stars Alanis Morissette and Jennifer Jason Leigh, as well as Linda Hamilton, Peter Stormare and Mark-Paul Gosselaar, but not the show’s co-star Elizabeth Perkins, who previously announced she was leaving the series.

headline: ‘The Decision,’ Brought to You By …
text: Madison Avenue will show up on Thursday night when the basketball star LeBron James reveals on ESPN his decision about where he will play next season and beyond.

headline: Vain Glorious | Sugar Plum Lips from Fresh
text: Who: Fresh

headline: A New Controller for Virtual Racers
text: As evidenced by the recent E3 Expo, driving games, like Sony’s highly anticipated “Gran Turismo 5,” are getting increasingly advanced, with popular roads and racetracks being rendered within millimeters of the real things.

headline: In an Italian Enclave in the Bronx, Signs of Mexico Begin to Show
text: In 1986, when he was 14, Ramiro Cariño slipped across the Mexican border and made his way to New York. He moved in with an older sister on 187th Street in Belmont, the neighborhood known as the Little Italy of the Bronx.

headline: Unhappy Helicopter Parents
text: Every so often a TV producer calls me to ask if I could supply a real live “helicopter parent” for a segment on the subject. My answer is always the same: I have never met anyone who would describe themselves that way.

headline: Stephen Colbert on Law School Grade Inflation
text: We recently wrote about grade inflation at law schools, which is being done deliberately to help students look more attractive in a tough job market. Stephen Colbert is now on the case.

headline: Indictment Unsealed in Russian Spy Case
text: Updated 4:14 p.m. | A federal indictment against 11 people accused of being secret agents for Russia was unsealed on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, as negotiations were under way that could result in their guilty pleas and possible deportation.

headline: A New Look for the Spill on the Web
text: The federal government has opened a new Web site for all news related to the oil spill and will soon phase out the site that it jointly ran with BP from the start of the Gulf of Mexico disaster in April. The government official in charge of handling the spill, Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard, said in a news release that the new site, www.RestoreTheGulf.gov, “is designed to serve as a one-stop repository for news, data and operational updates related to administration-wide efforts to stop the BP oil leak and mitigate its impact on the environment, the economy and public health.”

headline: Self-defeating Austerity
text: The WSJ’s economics blog has an interesting piece about how failing to extend unemployment benefits may actually end up increasing the deficit in the longer run, by pushing marginal older workers into disability. But this is actually a much broader point. There’s a quite good case to be made that austerity in the face of a depressed economy is, literally, a false economy — that it actually makes long-run budget problems worse.

headline: Lobbyists Scrap Plans for Distracted Driving Coalition
text: The Drive Coalition, an effort by lobbyists to reframe the debate about distracted driving, has fallen apart.

headline: Michael Moore Added to Oscar Board
text: So now it’s Gov. Michael Moore. Mr. Moore, the intrepid documentarian behind “Capitalism: A Love Story” and other films, were among the new governors elected to the board of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said on Wednesday. Mr. Moore joined the director Kathryn Bigelow and the film editor Anne Coates among those joining the board for the first time.

headline: Night Life on Madeira
text: Night clubs are a beguiling addition to Madeira’s prime asset: spectacular scenery.

headline: Adinkra Patterns and Corn Cob Energy
text: Our three-ring circus continued over the weekend with mixed success. I followed up the inspiration from the classroom and interviewed the Boakye family of Ntonso, famous adinkra patternmakers. Paul Boakye did not speak much English, but his brother Gabriel translated. They were happy to hear about the possible use of adinkra in math education, but it took us a great deal of time to actually have a conversation about geometry.

headline: Artist’s Daughter Wants Videos Back
text: It is a treasure trove of letters, paperwork, photographs and film that document the New York artistic and literary scene from the 1940s through the 1980s.

headline: Dita Von Teese in  Fashion, and Out of It
text: Dita Von Teese, the burlesque performer, is often in the front row at fashion shows. She’s sort of family, you know. Today, though, she was on the runway at Jean Paul Gaultier, wearing a dreamy black gown and then — well, very little. A beautiful corset. What a body she has. Everybody looked!

headline: Huffington Post Buys Pollster
text: The Huffington Post is venturing into the wonky but increasingly popular territory of opinion poll analysis, purchasing Pollster.com, a widely respected aggregator of poll data that has been a major draw for the Web site of The National Journal.

headline: Don’t Look for a TV in Television’s Future
text: I have seen the future of television, and it doesn’t involve a television.

headline: Should We Create Jobs or Balance the Budget?
text: Gail Collins: David, I was very interested in your column attacking the idea of a second stimulus. In fact, I was so interested that I almost put down my copy of this week’s New York Magazine, which has a big profile of you and your “charming, levelheaded optimism.” I agree totally with that assessment, although I part company with the author when it comes to your suits, which are certainly not shapeless.

headline: Process Filled With Hope And Hype Nears Finish
text: After two years of anticipation and eight days of intrigue, the LeBron James free-agency saga is nearing its fateful and surreal conclusion.

headline: In-Store: Star Power
text: The global gourmet Alain Ducasse checks off his shopping list. Sandra Ballentine reports.

headline: Eminem Tops Chart Again
text: Eminem maintained his dominance of the Billboard album sales chart for a second week as his latest release, “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope), sold 313,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album, which was Eminem’s sixth straight studio album to make its debut at No. 1, sold 58 percent fewer copies than last week but had no stiff competition for the top spot. Drake‘s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money), came in a distant No. 2 for a second straight week, with sales of 105,000, down from 157,000.

headline: Crimes of Heat, Odor and Perception
text: Heat waves passing over the city are often followed by attendant waves of crime. At least, this is the theory over at The Brooklyn Paper, which wonders whether McCarren Park in Greenpoint/Williamsburg is experiencing a bit of the latter after a string of recent incidents, including a rape, a shooting and several robberies. Uptown, the Columbia University community is similarly on edge after an assault in Riverside Park on Monday.

headline: Ignore Generic Financial Advice (Except This Post)
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. The Power of Nature: Neighbor of Russian spies says, “They couldn’t have been spies ... look what she did with the hydrangeas.”

headline: Postcards From the ‘Tour d’Admission': Starting With a Bang
text: For seven summers, a group of college counselors from across the country have climbed on bicycles to travel from college to college on an informal, saddle-bound fact-finding mission, a kind of Tour d’Admission. This summer, the group has set its tour in California, and the participants will be filing regular dispatches to The Choice from the road. Today’s dispatch is from Kirk Blackard, director of College Guidance at Christ School of Asheville, N.C, and Bruce Hunter, director of College Counseling at Rowland Hall in Salt Lake City.

headline: Obama Promises Push on Trade Pacts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who vowed in his State of the Union address to double American exports over the next five years, said on Wednesday that he would renew his efforts to renegotiate long-stalled free trade agreements with Panama and Colombia and persuade Congress to adopt them.

headline: Spanish Conductor to Take On Tanglewood and the BBC Philharmonic
text: LENOX, Mass.— The Tanglewood Music Festival’s timing was pretty good. Shortly after the festival engaged the little-known Spanish conductor Juanjo Mena to fill in for an ailing James Levine, the BBC Philharmonic in Manchester, England, announced on Tuesday that Mr. Mena would become its chief conductor.

headline: Streetwise Saint Joins Mexico Drug War
text: Mexico City gang youth have adopted a first century saint as their idol. A septuagenarian American priest who speaks their language wants to cash in on their unconventional fervor to help them.

headline: Mobile Web Use and the Digital Divide
text: The image of the affluent and white cellphone owner as the prototypical mobile Web user seems to be a mistaken one, according to a report published Wednesday by the Pew Research Center’s Internet and American Life Center.

headline: Speaking God’s Language, With a Gangster Dialect
text: MEXICO CITY  Frederick Loos was cussing like a sailor the other night, which was surprising given that he is a Roman Catholic priest and his foul-mouthed discourse was delivered from the pulpit to hundreds of faithful gathered before him.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Dance Into Trouble on Patrol
text: A YouTube video that’s gone viral in recent days — showing six Israeli soldiers performing a mock dance routine to the tune of a global pop hit while on patrol in the West Bank city of Hebron — is a reminder that while the war of ideas in the Middle East might have ancient roots, it is often waged by young people more interested in contemporary youth culture than age-old texts.

headline: The Chanel Lion Roars
text: Suzy Menkes talks with Stéfan Lubrina, the designer who built the surprising set for Chanel's haute couture show.

headline: Election Donation Accusations Ensnare Sarkozy
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was officially drawn into a growing scandal on Wednesday after prosecutors opened a preliminary investigation into allegations that the richest woman in the country made an illegal cash donation to his 2007 election campaign.

headline: Elmhurst, Queens, 11:55 A.M.
text: Seventeen firefighters were injured battling a five-alarm fire in a seven-story apartment building at 86-16 60th Avenue in Queens, including three who suffered from heat exhaustion and a captain who sustained second-degree burns. The other injuries were minor.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Jenna Lee Moves to Fox News from Fox Business
text: Fox News Channel is transferring an anchor from the Fox Business Network over to the mothership.

headline: A Plucky Solar Plane Faces the Night
text: With favorable weather and a forecast of clear, sunny skies, the Solar Impulse, an experimental solar-powered plane, took off from an airfield in Switzerland early Wednesday morning with a goal to stay aloft for a full 24 hours.

headline: A Congressman’s Abs Garner Yeas
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Weekend in Vancouver
text: Vancouver is often heralded as one of the world's most livable cities.

headline: Building Vancouver’s Olympic Future
text: Vancouver is preparing for the 2010 Winter Games.

headline: Spending for Stability in China’s Far West
text: BEIJING  A year after ethnic protests in western China left at least 200 people dead, China’s central government has announced a plan to spend more than $100 billion in the region to “promote the fast and healthy development of the western areas,” according to a government newspaper.

headline: A Lighthearted Setting for Serena Williams’s Next Match in New York
text: Serena Williams, fresh off her Wimbledon championship, is ready to return to New York in a much different setting than the pressure-packed one last September that ended with her controversial rant at a lineswoman in the semifinals of the United States Open.

headline: Teaching a (City) Child to Ride a Bike
text: Nicole Sprinkle’s daughter is 3 years old, and her mother has bicycles on her mind. It’s one of the many ways that city kids are different, she writes in a guest post today, and having grown up in the suburbs, those differences still take Nicole by surprise.

headline: Trailing in Election, and Fighting for Every Vote
text: To look at his résumé, you would never count out Juan Navarro.

headline: Airstrike Complicates Afghanistan Fight
text: KABUL – If the accounts provided today by top Afghan officials are accurate, the first NATO airstrike gone awry under the new command of Gen. David H. Petraeus killed five Afghan soldiers who seemed to be doing precisely the sort of operation that not enough ever do: Setting a trap – in the middle of the night, no less – to catch or kill militants in a dangerous part of the country where the Taliban are strong.

headline: Baucus Objects to Recess Appointment
text: 5:14 p.m. | Updated  The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, joined a chorus of Republicans on Wednesday in criticizing the White House for bypassing Congress and appointing a Medicare chief while the Senate was in recess.

headline: Manchin Won’t Name Himself as Senator
text: Governor Joe Manchin III reiterated Wednesday that he would not appoint himself to West Virginia’s newly vacant Senate seat. But he appeared to back holding a special election to replace the late Robert C. Byrd this November instead of waiting until 2012. And he suggested that he could run himself.

headline: Leona Helmsley, Self-Styled Hotel Queen, Is Dead
text: Mrs. Helmsley, who died at 87, came to be widely regarded by the public as a 1980s symbol of arrogance and greed.

headline: Answers From a Window Cleaner
text: Following is the first set of responses from Andrew Horton, who has been a window cleaner for more than two decades and knows the secrets of the trade and safety practices.

headline: Some ‘American Idol Live!’ Tour Dates Are Canceled
text: Much like the dreams of millions of “American Idol” viewers who hoped to see a certain latter-day Janis Joplin manquée win that singing competition in May, at least seven dates on the show’s “American Idol Live!” summer tour have evaporated, The Associated Press reported. When the tour, which features the Top 10 “American Idol” contestants from the 2010 season, was announced, it was to run from July 1 (in Auburn Hills, Mich.) to Sept. 16 (in Portland, Me.). But a revised schedule posted on the Web site of the tour promoter Live Nation listed seven canceled dates in August and September, including stops in Omaha, Neb.; Kansas City, Mo.; Toronto; and Cleveland. A concert scheduled for Sept. 14 at the CONSOL Energy Center in Pittsburgh was still listed.

headline: Disney Ordered to Pay Damages in ‘Millionaire’ Suit
text: The Walt Disney Company on Wednesday was ordered to pay almost $270 million in damages to Celador, the British production company that created the hit game show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” over a decade ago.

headline: Flint Tools From Happisburg
text: Three-dimensional models of flint tools created using a state-of-the-art micro-CT scanner at the Natural History Museum, London.

headline: Close-Up and Personal Luxury
text: Suzy Menkes talks with Riccardo Tisci, whose haute couture collection for Givenchy this year shows a different side of the sometimes-flamboyant designer, full of intricacies in lace and feather fringes in white, gold and brown.

headline: A Mediterranean Take on Copper Fennel
text: Copper fennel?

headline: Google Makes the iPhone YouTube App Obsolete
text: What’s the difference between the new version of YouTube’s mobile Web site and the Apple-created YouTube application that is installed on every iPhone? The Web site is a lot better. At least that’s the subtext of a video that YouTube released as it announced the overhaul of the mobile site on Wednesday.

headline: Submit Your Photos: Why We Travel 2010
text: Share your best travel photos and tell us the backstory. Where did you go and why? What’s happening in your photo? What does it mean to you? A selection of the top images will appear in the Travel section. (Please limit your contributions to one or two photos, and do not submit photos that have been altered in any way.)

headline: Frances McDormand to Star in Broadway’s ‘Good People’
text: Based on her Academy Award-winning performance in “Fargo” it can be safely said that Frances McDormand knows her way around a regional accent. (Admit it: you heard Marge Gunderson saying, “Oh, yah,” in your head before you finished reading the previous sentence.) It’s a skill that should serve her well when Ms. McDormand returns to Broadway in Manhattan Theater Club‘s coming production of “Good People,” the new David Lindsay-Abaire play.

headline: Darn Tough Vermont
text: How a Vermont sock manufacturer withstood the pressure to outsource and created a leading outdoor specialty sock brand.

headline: On the Beach in Boracay
text: Boracay remains the crown jewel of the Philippine Islands.

headline: The ‘Black Y’ Remembered
text: African Americans in Evanston, Ill., attended the Emerson Street branch of the Y.M.C.A. because the main branch excluded them.

headline: At Rooftop Farm, Crops Are Ready to Harvest
text: Brooklyn Grange is open for business. The one-acre commercial farm on an industrial rooftop above Long Island City, Queens, held its inaugural “vegetable cutting” ceremony on Wednesday featuring appearances from City Councilman Jimmy Van Bramer and Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, seen above flanking Ben Flanner, the grange’s chief farmer, in the cauliflower patch. The farm, at 37-18 Northern Boulevard, is already producing basil, Swiss chard, kale and a dozen other crops and selling them on site every Tuesday and Thursday. It’s also open daily to visitors.

headline: Clues of Britain’s First Humans
text: The last time the British Museum claimed that the earliest known human was British, some 98 years ago, its evidence was the Piltdown skull, which the British archaeological establishment did not concede was a forgery until 1953.

headline: Can Honest Tea Say No to Coke, Its Biggest Investor?
text: HONEST TEA makes juices and teas with natural sweeteners, including the pouch drinks Honest Kids. In early 2008, Coca-Cola took a 40 percent interest in the Bethesda, Md.-based company, which had revenue of $47 million last year. Coke has an option to buy the whole company next year.

headline: Now Recorded on Film, Memories of ‘the Black Y’ Provoke Smiles and Tears
text: EVANSTON, Ill.  In his barbershop on Church Street here, 78-year-old Sam Johnson can close his eyes and dance once more as a teenager inside the cracker box Emerson Street branch of the Y.M.C.A.

headline: Barge Strikes Tourist Boat in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — A placid Wednesday afternoon on the Delaware River here suddenly turned into mayhem when a barge plowed into an amphibious vessel packed with tourists that had stalled in the water.

headline: Across or Down, Anchorage Is Alive
text: Changes in downtown Anchorage offer visitors a few reasons to linger in the state’s most populous city.

headline: A Michael Jackson Tour, for Travelers
text: Little more than a year after the death of Michael Jackson, a travel company is offering fans a chance to embark on a pilgrimage by taking a world tour of destinations billed as the King of Pop’s favorites. The tour, offered by the London-based company STA Travel, spans  all the continents save Antarctica.

headline: Leno: ‘It Was So Hot …’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, the East Coast is suffering from just a terrible heat wave. In fact, on Wall Street, stockbrokers were jumping out of windows just for the cool breeze on the way down.

headline: A Weekend in Copenhagen
text: The Danish capital features contemporary art and innovative restaurants.

headline: ‘Hot! … Hot! … Hot!’
text: Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines.

headline: Can Honest Tea Take Coke’s Money and Keep Its Own Culture?
text: In a case study we’ve just published, Elizabeth Olson writes about a culture clash involving Coca-Cola and Honest Tea. Not long after Coke invested in Honest Tea — a small, entrepreneurial maker of organic teas and kids juices — executives with the multinational noticed that the smaller company’s packaging featured the phrase “no high fructose corn syrup.” The executives construed the phrase as an implicit rebuke of Coke products. “We got a strong request to change the wording,” said Seth Goldman, co-founder and chief executive of Honest Tea.

headline: Getty Buys Turner’s ‘Rome’ for $44.9 Million
text: J.M.W. Turner‘s final painting of Rome, “Modern Rome — Campo Vaccino” (1839), was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum at a Sotheby’s auction in London on Wednesday evening for $44.9 million. The price, which includes Sotheby’s fees, is a record for the artist at auction, outstripping an 1841 view of Venice, “Giudecca, La Donna della Salute and San Giorgio,” which sold in April 2006 at Christie’s in New York for $35.9 million. “This painting transcends even Turner; it’s his best, it’s Turner at the top of his game,” Scott J. Schaefer, the Getty’s curator of paintings, said in a telephone interview from London after the sale. “Turner often suffers from condition problems, but this painting has been behind glass for about 150 years. It’s never been touched.” The painting, which is in its original frame and had been on loan to the National Galleries of Scotland in Edinburgh since 1978, depicts the Italian capital bathed in a cloudy light. It has been on the market only once before, in 1878, when it was bought in London by the fifth Earl of Rosebery, who briefly served as prime minister after Gladstone. It has remained in the family ever since.

headline: The Key to This Crisis? Sign Up for Gun Training
text: Alpha Protocol is one of those games that is just good enough to make you really upset.

headline: Iraq Suicide Bombing Strikes Shiites
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber blew himself up among a crowd of Shiite pilgrims at a police checkpoint in Baghdad on Wednesday night, killing at least 28 people and wounding 81 others despite intensive efforts by Iraqi security forces to foil such attacks.

headline: Baucus Objects to Recess Appointment
text: Over at The Caucus blog, The Times’s Robert Pear details objections made by Senator Max Baucus, the Democratic chairman of the Finance Committee, to President Obama’s decision to appoint Dr. Donald Berwick to head Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: Paris Couture Shows
text: The shows aren’t as spectacular, but the ideas are still there.

headline: TV on a PC or Phone Has Some Drawbacks
text: Trying to watch TV on the Internet is frustrating.

headline: A Cloning Scandal Rocks a Pillar of Science Publishing
text: Science magazine has seen its share of controversies over the years: papers questioned and withdrawn and occasional accusations of scientific fraud. But none of those incidents, says Science's executive editor, Monica M. Bradford, can compare to the turmoil that has been shaking the magazine for the last month.

headline: Full Spectrum, Less Spectacle
text: Paris

headline: 36 Hours in Copenhagen
text: COPENHAGEN is making news these days. Beyond clichéd tourist sites like the Little Mermaid and Tivoli amusement park, the Danish capital has emerged as one of the most eco-minded and creative cities in Northern Europe. Top-notch contemporary art is proliferating, and a fledgling fashion scene is starting to take off. After dark, a bevy of innovative restaurants has burnished Scandinavia’s gastronomic credentials, most notably Noma, which in April was ranked first on the S. Pellegrino World’s 50 Best Restaurants list. Meanwhile, upstart jazz and world music clubs are creating a night life without borders. And when it’s time to stagger home, Copenhagen finally obliges: the futuristic, driverless Metro is now open all day and night.

headline: Imogene + Willie, Charting in Nashville
text: Nashville was already a bona fide jeans town when Carrie and Matt Eddmenson opened their denim emporium Imogene + Willie in early 2009.

headline: Opera Bits and Pieces, Gently Scrambled
text: “Opera is, by and large, all about the world of fiction,” the conductor Bramwell Tovey announced from the podium shortly into a concert by the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening. In part he was referring to the evening’s program, “La Dolce Vita,” a collection of popular arias and pleasant instrumental knickknacks gathered mostly from French and Italian operas.

headline: Trailer: Alpha Protocol
text: Alpha Protocol, a role-playing and action game from Sega, follows a secret agent on a paramilitary mission.

headline: More On Low Business Investment
text: Via Mark Thoma, the San Francisco Fed offers data on commercial vacancies:

headline: How I Saved My Company: Darn Tough Vermont
text: A family-owned business founded in 1978, Darn Tough Vermont was thriving until about five years ago. “Then outsourcing happened,” says Ric Cabot, who owns the company along with his father. Manufacturing work started going overseas in search of low-cost labor, and business fell off drastically. “We had to do something in order to survive,” says Mr. Cabot. You can watch the video below to see what the company did. One hint: a sign that hangs in the Vermont mill where all of the company’s socks continue to be manufactured proclaims, “Nobody ever outsourced anything for quality.”

headline: She Wants More Than Her MTV
text: “Have you had a popsicle? They’re sooo good,” said SuChin Pak, known to a generation of screaming teenagers as the sweet and chipper on-air correspondent for MTV. “Let me buy you one!”

headline: Expanded Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria to Open in January
text: The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria will open its expanded and redesigned home — featuring a new glass entrance, grand staircase and lobby video wall — on January 15, the museum is to announce on Thursday.

headline: Makeup That Lasts and Lip Balms That Don’t
text: Beauty products in bright, waterproof colors; a class offers relief for feet tortured by heels.

headline: Hitler Youth Alumni and the No. 7 Train
text: Since it runs through one of the most ethnically diverse areas in New York City, the No. 7 train has become a symbol for the melting pot. But not even John Rocker, the Atlanta Braves pitcher who compared the subway line to riding through Beirut, could imagine bumping into a charming Nazi on a ride through Queens.

headline: A Flush of Funding for Carbon Capture
text: In the endeavor to reduce greenhouse emissions, carbon capture and storage technology continues to generate a lot of interest.

headline: Taking the Guesswork Out of Braces
text: LOOKING at a three-dimensional model of her teeth, Sara McClure didn’t recognize her smile. The image her orthodontist had pulled up on a laptop didn’t show her upper-row gaps  rather, it showed the perfect alignment that would be hers in 13 months.

headline: CNN Drops Editor After Hezbollah Comments
text: CNN on Wednesday removed its senior editor for Middle Eastern affairs, Octavia Nasr, from her job after she published a Twitter message saying that she respected the Shiite cleric the Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, who died on Sunday.

headline: 'The Tempest'
text: Christopher Plummer plays Prospero and Julyana Soelistyo is Ariel in this excerpt from a production at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario. (Video courtesy of the festival)

headline: Time Takes a Step Away From Free Web Content
text: Time has decided to dive head first into an issue that has bedeviled many a news organization before it: how to wean online readers off their addictions to free content.

headline: Eurofile | Is Marseille France’s Next Great Food City?
text: In Alexander Lobrano’s new column, Eurofile, the author of “Hungry for Paris” writes about the best tables (and beds) on the continent.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
text: In New York, it is 9/11. In Madrid, it is 3/11. In London, it is 7/7. And Wednesday, 7/7/10, marked the fifth anniversary of the terrorist attack by four bombers, their weapons concealed in backpacks, who took their own lives and those of 52 travelers on three subway trains and a double-decker bus. Oli Scarff of Getty Images recorded the moment at the 7 July Memorial in Hyde Park. The posts at left in the photograph are the bottoms of stainless-steel pillars, each more than 11 feet high. The memorial consists of 52 pillars arranged in patterns recalling the four locations of the attack. Visitors can walk around and through this open-air hypostyle hall, which was designed by the architectural firm Carmody Groarke and the Arup engineering firm. It was dedicated last year, on the fourth anniversary.

headline: Turkish Court Rejects Parts of Constitution Overhaul
text: ISTANBUL  Turkey’s highest court on Wednesday struck down parts of a controversial government package aimed at restructuring the country’s Constitution and highest legal bodies, but rejected the opposition’s attempt to discard the changes altogether.

headline: E.U. Foreign Chief Hopes for Iran Talks
text: STRASBOURG, France  After an exchange of letters with Iran, Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s new high representative for foreign policy, said Wednesday that negotiation was the only possible solution to the problem of Iran’s nuclear program, and she expressed confidence that new talks with Iran could begin in the fall.

headline: TV Land’s ‘Cleveland’ to Stay Hot for Second Season
text: As if Betty White needed any more good news these days, it looks like she’ll have enough work to keep her busy to the ripe old age of 89. On Wednesday, the TV Land cable channel said it was ordering a second season of “Hot in Cleveland,” its hit comedy series about a dithering N.B.A. superstar who can’t decide which multimillion-dollar offer he wants to accept — wait, scratch that: “Hot in Cleveland” stars Valerie Bertinelli, Jane Leeves and Wendie Malick as three women who move to the Rust Belt from Los Angeles, and Ms. White as their saucy landlady. The debut episode of the show’s current 10-episode season on June 16 drew 4.75 million viewers. TV Land said the show’s second season would be 20 episodes, with production to begin in October and a premiere tentatively scheduled for January.

headline: Keeping Score: Dynamic Duos Like Wade and Bosh Rarely Mean a Championship
text: Neil Paine is an analyst at Basketball-Reference.com, an online encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores.

headline: You Made Me Wear This
text: IT’S been hot lately, which makes getting dressed in the morning a little harder. I want something cool enough for the five-block walk to the subway, but warm enough for an air-conditioned day at the office.

headline: For Those Facebook Left Behind
text: Last month, the standards editor at The New York Times wrote a memo that shocked — shocked! — bloggers everywhere. He asked Times writers to avoid using the word “tweet” (as in, “to say something on Twitter”).

headline: Whose Bling Is Better?
text: Kanye West, seen here wearing a pyramid ring and a pendant of Horus, the Egyptian god of the sky, visits the “Tutankhamun and the Golden Age of the Pharaohs” exhibition at the Discovery Times Square Exposition. That’s Mr. West on the left, with the golden coffin of King Tut’s great-grandmother Tjuya on the right.

headline: Nice Goal! How’d You Like to Be a Model?
text: DURING a typically unremarkable performance at this year’s World Cup, in which the United States team was ousted in the Round of 16, there was at least one crowning achievement for the Americans, a shot heard around the world.

headline: Sun Valley 2010 in Pictures
text: Nati Harnik/Associated Press CBS‘s Leslie Moonves, left, strolls through Sun Valley with Kelly Meyers and Universal Studios’s Ron Meyers on Wednesday.

headline: Restaurant-Style Spareribs in Your Backyard
text: Zakary Pelaccio, the chef and restaurateur, was in Malaysia recently, continuing his research on the flavors that have brought him relative fame in the food world of New York City, what he called in an e-mail message the appeal of “strong cocktails, chili, palm sugar and smoky fat.”

headline: For Web-Financed Film Projects, a Curtain Rises
text: Kickstarter is a concept: a Web site that puts together creative types seeking money with backers willing to chip in micro- and macro-payments, a way to crowd-source the financing of ideas. Started last year, the company has become an unexpected influence on indie culture, a new model for a D.I.Y. generation.

headline: Fatty ’Cue Spareribs
text: 2 cups fish sauce (preferably Three Crabs brand; see note)

headline: New Yorkers Still Have Highest Wages
text: 10:08 a.m. | Updated Once again, New York County — that is, Manhattan — had the highest average weekly wage in the country, according to new Labor Department data for the fourth quarter of 2009.

headline: Sex and the Single Man
text: In 1953, you founded Playboy magazine in Chicago and invented the notion of the sexually triumphant American male. Yet “Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel,” a documentary by Brigitte Berman opening in New York on July 30, depicts you less as a purveyor of soft-core porn than as a noble champion of First Amendment rights. Is that actually how you see yourself?  I think the major thing I managed to accomplish was playing some part in changing our social and sexual values, and I take a lot of pride in that. When I was in college, middle-class kids couldn’t live together before they got married.

headline: Using Song to Paint a Self-Portrait
text: “The George Cukor of cabaret directors”: that label was applied to Eric Michael Gillett by his manager, Arthur Shafman, Mr. Gillett announced with sheepish pride on Tuesday evening at the first show of his five-night engagement at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. For a change, Mr. Gillett, an idiosyncratic, fearlessly emotive baritone, was his own director, performing the music of Harold Arlen. Accompanying him were the reliable pop-jazz pianist Don Rebic, who feigned the look of a bluesman in a slouch hat, and Matt Wigton on bass.

headline: Couture Scorecard | Givenchy Wins!
text: Lions, and tigers, and bones! Oh, my! As couture week reaches its zenith, Scorecard knows the jury’s still out on whether the usual king of the jungle “roared” — but in a perennial quest for the new, Riccardo Tisci’s Kahloesque wispy Chantilly lace-dégradé ostrich feather constructions masking little skulls blew critics away.

headline: To Those With Nothing, Soccer Is Everything
text: CAPE TOWN  Jessica Hilltout, a nomadic, Belgian-born photographer, loaded sacks of deflated soccer balls onto the roof of a battered yellow Volkswagen Beetle last year and began a seven-month road trip across Africa to document the continent’s love of the game. She found it in villages where children played with joyous abandon on dusty patches of ground, sandy beaches and lush fields, far from the stadiums where Africa’s first World Cup would be held.

headline: Grassroots Soccer
text: Jessica Hilltout, a Belgian-born photographer, spent seven months last year traveling through Africa and capturing the continent’s love for the game, in advance of the World Cup in South Africa.

headline: Dance New Amsterdam Faces Possible Eviction
text: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, faces possible eviction on July 14 from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway because the organization owes more than half a million dollars in rent, Catherine Peila, the executive director, said Wednesday. “With the high rent and the recession, we didn’t earn enough money to pay the rent,” Ms. Peila said in an interview. “The arts community should really be revved up: we serve 8,000 students, we employ 250 people a year, and we moved to Lower Manhattan to revitalize the area.” In a statement released Wednesday, the organization, founded in 1984, said it wanted to maintain its mission of teaching dance, commissioning choreographers and presenting performances to the public. It is seeking a meeting with Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month, and with city agencies to work out an agreement for lower rent to match current market rates and for a nonprofit tax abatement, Ms Peila said. A representative of Fram Realty could not be reached for comment. Over the years, Dance New Amsterdam has presented Mark Morris, Urban Bush Women and David Dorfman, among other artists.

headline: The Persistence of M. Night Shyamalan
text: Time has not been kind to the defense of M. Night Shyamalan that I penned four summers ago, just before the release of his first true stinker of a movie, “Lady in the Water.” Not that I would take those arguments back, exactly: I’m still happy to defend all of his pre-“Lady” work, the much-derided “The Village” included, against the many critics who soured on Shyamalan earlier on. But if you describe someone as “a filmmaker of rare talent and creativity,” as I did, and then they follow your vote of confidence by releasing “Lady,” “The Happening,” and now “The Last Airbender” (currently the worst-reviewed movie of the summer, below “Furry Vengeance” and “Sex in the City 2″) on an unsuspecting public … well, let’s just say I wouldn’t blame anyone who cited Shyamalan as exhibit A in the case against my critical acumen.

headline: Financier Wilbur Ross Invests in a New Jersey Bank
text: Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the financier who amassed his fortune by snapping up out-of-favor coal, steel and auto parts companies, is adding to his collection of banks.

headline: Paris Couture: Chanel
text: Karl Lagerfeld presents the Chanel haute couture show at the Grand Palais in Paris.

headline: When New-Wave Drug Dealers Run Afoul of an Old-Wave Cartel
text: “Don Winslow is an author currently living in the United States, most recognized for his crime and mystery novels.” That’s the one-sentence entirety of the biographical notice Mr. Winslow has attracted on Wikipedia, though he has a dozen novels, a couple of movie deals, a slew of ardent reviews, a whip-cracking way with words and a whole lot of Southern California surfer baditude to his credit.

headline: Where to Find High-Tech Braces
text: ADOPTION of 3-D imaging for orthodontia is still spotty across the country. Here’s how to find a doctor near you.

headline: Until Cryonics Do Us Part
text: There are ways of speaking about dying that very much annoy Peggy Jackson, an affable and rosy-cheeked hospice worker in Arlington, Va. She doesn’t like the militant cast of “lost her battle with,” as in, “She lost her battle with cancer.” She is similarly displeased by “We have run out of options” and “There is nothing left we can do,” when spoken by doctor to patient, implying as these phrases will that hospice care is not an “option” or a “thing” that can be done. She doesn’t like these phrases, but she tolerates them. The one death-related phrase she will not abide, will not let into her house under any circumstance, is “cryonic preservation,” by which is meant the low-temperature preservation of human beings in the hope of future resuscitation. That this will be her husband’s chosen form of bodily disposition creates, as you might imagine, certain complications in the Jackson household.

headline: Cuban Government Vows to Release 52 Prisoners
text: MEXICO CITY  The Cuban government on Wednesday agreed to release 52 political prisoners in the coming months, a dramatic move that may ease international criticism as well as save the life of a prominent dissident who has been on a hunger strike for four months to push for the liberation of inmates.

headline: Getty Buys Turner’s ‘Modern Rome’ For $44.9 Million
text: J. M. W. Turner’s final painting of Rome, “Modern Rome  Campo Vaccino” (1839), above, was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum at a Sotheby’s auction in London on Wednesday evening for $44.9 million. The price, which includes Sotheby’s fees, is a record for Turner at auction, outstripping an 1841 view of Venice, “Giudecca, La Donna della Salute and San Giorgio,” which sold in April 2006 at Christie’s in New York for $35.9 million. “This painting transcends even Turner,” Scott J. Schaefer, the Getty’s curator of paintings, said in a telephone interview from London after the sale. “It’s his best. It’s Turner at the top of his game. Turner often suffers from condition problems, but this painting has been behind glass for about 150 years. It’s never been touched.” The painting, which is in its original frame and had been on loan to the National Galleries of Scotland in Edinburgh since 1978, depicts the Italian capital bathed in a cloudy light. It has been on the market only once before, in 1878, when it was bought in London by the fifth Earl of Rosebery, who briefly served as prime minister after Gladstone. It has remained in the family since. (One of the earl’s descendants, Harry Dalmeny, is deputy chairman of Sotheby’s in Britain.)

headline: Grammys Change Rule After Lady Gaga No-No
text: It’s no help to Lady Gaga now, but the Recording Academy said on Wednesday that it had changed a Grammy Awards rule that prevented that chameleon-like pop star from being nominated as best new artist for this year’s awards, The Associated Press reported. Lady Gaga would seem to have been a jewel-encrusted, raccoon-mask-wearing shoo-in for the best new artist Grammy in 2010, except that her song “Just Dance” was nominated in the best dance recording category in 2009, thus making her ineligible in the new artist category, according to the award’s regulations at that time. (The Zac Brown Band won the award.) On Wednesday the Recording Academy, which oversees the awards, said previous Grammy nominees could be eligible for the new artist award as long as they haven’t released full albums or won any Grammy Awards.

headline: They’re Trained to Handle Your Problems
text: At the 311 help-line center downtown Manhattan, the number of calls rose with the mercury. At the top of the list: gushing fire hydrants. Those calls made up 4,226 of the 372,166 calls so far this month.

headline: Eminem Tops Chart Again
text: Eminem maintained his dominance of the Billboard album sales chart for a second week as his latest release, “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope), sold 313,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album, which was Eminem’s sixth straight studio record to make its debut at No. 1, sold 58 percent fewer copies than last week but had no stiff competition for the top spot. Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money), came in a distant No. 2 for a second straight week, with sales of 105,000, down from 157,000. The top debut album, The-Dream’s “Love King” (Def Jam), reached the No. 4 spot on the chart, with sales of 58,000. The soundtrack to “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” (Chop Shop/Atlantic), rose seven slots to No. 3, with sales of 65,000, thanks to the release of the film. The 34th volume of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” held the fifth spot for the second straight week, with sales of 45,000.

headline: Movie Museum to Unveil Renovation in January
text: The Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, will open its expanded and redesigned home  featuring a new glass entrance, grand staircase, lobby video wall and theater (above)  on Jan. 15, the museum is to announce on Thursday. “I had always felt that a museum about the movies should have some sense of glamour,” Rochelle Slovin, its director, said. “That is part of what we’ve now gotten from this project.” The $67 million renovation, designed by the architect Thomas Leeser, added three stories, nearly doubling the size to 97,700 square feet from 50,000.

headline: ‘Talent’ in the Lead
text: “America’s Got Talent” led the ratings on Tuesday as 11.7 million viewers tuned in to the NBC reality competition, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS ranked second on the night, and Fox placed third with a two-hour edition of “Hell’s Kitchen” (6.8 million) while ABC finished in fourth, averaging 3.8 million for both “Downfall” and “Primetime.”

headline: Frances McDormand Returning to Broadway
text: Judging by her Oscar-winning performance in “Fargo,” it can be safely said that Frances McDormand knows her way around a regional accent. It’s a skill that should serve her well when she returns to Broadway in Manhattan Theater Club’s coming production of “Good People,” the new David Lindsay-Abaire play. On Wednesday press representatives for the production said Ms. McDormand would play the role of Margie Walsh, a woman from South Boston (a k a Southie) who turns to a mysterious old flame, hoping he’ll solve her financial problems. “Good People” will be directed by Daniel Sullivan (“The Merchant of Venice”) and is scheduled to begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Feb. 8 and open March 3.

headline: Ryan and Hoffman Pass on Jerusalem Festival
text: Organizers of the Jerusalem Film Festival said that Meg Ryan had canceled a scheduled appearance and that Dustin Hoffman had withdrawn from discussions to take part, joining a growing number of artists and performers who have canceled trips to Israel in recent weeks. Yigal Molad Hayo, the associate director of the Jerusalem Cinematheque, the primary theater where the festival is held, told The Jerusalem Post that Ms. Ryan’s representatives cited a scheduling conflict. But he said he believed the recent raid by Israeli commandos on a Gaza-bound flotilla played a role in the decision. Regarding Mr. Hoffman, Mr. Molad Hayo said, “We were very close to reaching an agreement with him, then the flotilla happened, and correspondence was ended.” A representative for Mr. Hoffman said in an e-mail message that there was “no truth” to the Jerusalem Post report. A representative for Ms. Ryan did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

headline: Norman Foster to Leave the House of Lords
text: The British architect Norman Foster has given up his seat in the House of Lords, his office said Wednesday. According to reports in the British press Mr. Foster, who lives in Switzerland, surrendered his seat to hold on to his tax status as a nonresident of Britain. Under a new requirement all peers must pay taxes on their earnings worldwide. Mr. Foster, who designed the Hearst Tower in New York, the London office building known as the Gherkin and the revamped Reichstag in Berlin, was the fifth peer to quit the House of Lords before a deadline on Wednesday after which members had to become British residents for tax purposes. “This outcome is purely a result of the new legislation,” said Katy Harris, a spokeswoman for Mr. Foster. “His home is in Switzerland, and he has no current plans to change where he lives.”

headline: Lawyer Sues Firm for Failing to Pay Overtime
text: A lawyer is suing his former New York-based employer, alleging that the law firm violated federal labor laws by not paying time-and-a-half for overtime.

headline: Theater Talkback: Facing the Elements
text: Many highly accomplished, highly acclaimed actors have emoted from the boards of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, serious marquee names like Meryl Streep, Christopher Walken, Colleen Dewhurst and Al Pacino. But it is understood that when such performers sign for a run of Shakespeare in the Park, they’ll be sharing the stage with another, even bigger star – that is, if she’ll let them. Though she goes by many names, we’ll call her Nature.

headline: How G.O.P. Senators Plan to Vote on Kagan
text: While President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court is expected to be confirmed by the Senate, many Republican lawmakers have been critical of her.

headline: Web Design for Beginners
text: Q. Is there any inexpensive Web design software that works on Mac and Windows and would be easy enough to learn for people maintaining a simple nonprofit site?

headline: Another Way to Fight Mischief on Facebook
text: As Facebook’s popularity has soared, it has become an attractive place for spam, scams and malware. And while Facebook is often quick to remove such mischief, a tool for protecting profiles would be useful to many people.

headline: 239 West 14th Street, 4:36 P.M.
text: Minutes after Spain sealed its victory over Germany to advance to the World Cup final, partisans burst out of La Nacional restaurant and gave the red-cape treatment to a city bus. No one was injured.

headline: BP Tries to Reassure Shareholders
text: For more than 10 weeks, BP has focused on the challenge of plugging its gushing oil well a mile below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico. It has also struggled to placate angry gulf residents and government officials and reassure a public frustrated by the company’s inability to stop the spill.

headline: Mets’ Plans for Perez Still Uncertain
text: Oliver Perez has been out of sight for the Mets for a month. It appears more than ever that the Mets would prefer to keep it that way.

headline: Networks See Dip in Key Audiences for Late Shows
text: Six months after NBC’s disastrous late-night experiment ended, Jay Leno is back at 11:30 and back on top in the ratings. But all is not well in the kingdom of late night.

headline: A Margin of 42 Imps Is Sometimes Deceiving
text: If you read that one team won a knockout match by 42 international match points, you would probably assume that it wasn’t tough sledding for the winners. But occasionally you would be wrong  as with the final of the open trial that was held last month. Martin Fleisher’s team defeated John Diamond’s by those 42 imps, but two boards could have reversed the result. We will look at them today and in Saturday’s column.

headline: Paris Couture: Valentino
text: Behind the scenes and show images from the Valentino haute couture show in Paris.

headline: A Renovation and Relocation in Cambodia
text: A majestic 1915 wooden house, once the home of a wealthy timber merchant, was moved from a remote island to Siem Reap, Cambodia.

headline: In Cambodia, a House With Legs
text: SIEM REAP, Cambodia

headline: Valentino: Up in the Air
text: A thick mob of people, mostly young and nearly all clutching cameras, stood in the blazing 6 p.m. sun outside the entrance to the Valentino show in the Place Vendôme. They extended to the curb, and guests had to walk through a narrow path the onlookers seemed reluctant to provide. Liz Hurley was inside, in a pretty fuchsia slip dress, but most of the other V.I.P.’s were young socialites and, of course, models. The throng was waiting for them, a glimpse of someone famous and beautiful.

headline: Inkster Looks Back at U.S. Open Disappointment
text: OAKMONT, Pa. — Eighteen years haven’t erased Juli Inkster’s scorn. She returned here for the second United States Women’s Open to be held at Oakmont Country Club as indignant as ever about a ruling that contributed to her 1992 defeat to Patty Sheehan in an 18-hole playoff.

headline: A Family Design Collaboration
text: Carmine and Lydia Caponigro’s bright, modern apartment in an adult community was transformed with help from their daughter, the editor of a home décor magazine.

headline: Styling a Downsized Life
text: SUFFERN, N.Y.

headline: Even Tourists Have Tips for Staying Cool
text: How to be a tourist in New York on one of the hottest days of the year? Visitors to Manhattan were dripping with tips Wednesday.

headline: As Revis and Mangold Wait, Jets Take Care of Ferguson
text: Kristian R. Dyer covers the N.F.L. for FoxSports.com and is the publisher of the subscription site GreenAndWhiteReport.com, which covers the Jets. He can be reached at KristianRDyer@yahoo.com and followed at twitter.com/kdyer1012.

headline: Do U.S. Donors Drive Israeli Politics?
text: Updated, July 8, 12:40 p.m. | Michael Barnett, a professor of international affairs, joins the discussion.

headline: Votto, the Reluctant Candidate, Wants Your Vote
text: Every player and staff member of the Cincinnati Reds was dressed the same way Wednesday afternoon. A fresh shipment of red “Vote Votto” T-shirts had arrived in their Citi Field clubhouse, and each of the Reds slipped one on.

headline: Sales at Ochre and Others
text: Ochre, a home furnishings store in SoHo, is having a sale through Aug. 9, with selected items marked down 10 to 70 percent (a floor model Snooze sofa in pink linen, originally $7,800, is $5,000; vintage painted wood shelving, regularly $8,900, is $3,200; and the Crimson glass collection, originally $20 to $98, is $10 to $49); 462 Broome Street (Greene Street), (212) 414-4332 or ochrestore.com.

headline: Talking With the Artist Karen Kimmel
text: Karen Kimmel has had a prolific career as a conceptual and installation artist, yet she is better known as the woman behind the Los Angeles gallery-retail space KBond, now defunct, which she owned with her husband, James Bond, a music industry veteran and an owner of the Undefeated sneaker shops. Recently, the 43-year-old mother of two started a new venture — Kimmel Kids, a line of educational tools and toys aimed at getting children and their parents involved in making art. The Exchange Collection, one of her first efforts, is a set of laser-cut plastic stencils, neon pencils and a coloring book, all packaged in a very stylish zippered canvas case. The starter set is $80, the “ultimate” one is $120.

headline: To Get in, the Deer Have to Knock
text: Those who prefer not to do their own digging but want a vegetable garden can call on Teich Garden Systems. Its no-fuss approach to growing started in 2005, when Mark Teich, a Wall Street trader, made his wife a free-standing garden: raised beds enclosed by a sturdy wooden frame, wrapped — both underneath and on top — in mesh netting to make it impervious to marauding deer, rabbits, woodchucks, etc. Friends loved it, and a business was born.

headline: Floor Cloths With Diversity
text: Sheila Bridges, a Manhattan interior designer, has reinterpreted the traditional floor cloth, using images “that are more reflective of our diverse population,” she said.

headline: Studio Anise in SoHo
text: Paul Anis has been an assistant professor of French at the University of Hartford, a market manager for B&B Italia furniture, and is now on his third career: entrepreneur and interior designer. In May, Mr. Anis, 40, opened the first floor of his sleek SoHo showroom, Studio Anise; late last month, he opened the floor downstairs as well. On display are Acheo kitchens (starting at $18,000), Agape bathrooms (tubs, left, start at $9,000), De Padova furniture (sofas start at $3,200) and Wall and Decò wallpaper (starting at $11 a square foot).

headline: At Ikea, Lights Out for Incandescents
text: Attention, Ikea shoppers: if you can’t imagine life without the warm glow of incandescent light bulbs, the time to stock up is now. On Aug. 1, the Swedish retailer will begin phasing out the bulbs in its North American stores, with the intention of eliminating them entirely by Jan. 1, 2011. The move comes ahead of new federal energy-efficiency standards for light bulbs that will make many incandescent bulbs obsolete.

headline: Italian Design From Reused Materials
text: Although one doesn’t usually associate Italian design with sustainability, Regenesi, a company started last year in Bologna, is determined to change that. As Maria Silvia Pazzi, its founder and chief executive, put it: “We firmly believe that with great design, we can give beautiful new life to materials that would otherwise end up in landfills.”

headline: Joan Parker: Vanquishing Sadness With Design
text: After the death of her husband, the mystery writer Robert B. Parker, Joan Parker found she felt better by rearranging the furniture in their unusual home.

headline: A Summer Rental of One’s Own
text: THIS spring, in ripe midlife, after years of thinking and talking about it, I finally rented a summer house of my own. This may not sound like a major feat to those who own weekend getaways in the Hamptons or Connecticut or have been renting for years. But to someone like me, who habitually shies away from taking charge in the hope that someone better equipped will do so instead, it rates as a real achievement, a kind of upper-middle-class rite of passage that I was not ready for until now.

headline: Death and the Private Eye
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Shopping With Jaime Salm
text: The Philadelphia-based designer shopped for hammocks and hanging chairs.

headline: Hammocks and Hanging Chairs
text: GROWING up in Colombia, Jaime Salm loved to swing from the trees. “We’d go to our friend’s farm on weekends — he had a huge hammock that five of us would pile into — and others would try to push it hard enough that it would loop over the branch,” said Mr. Salm, 32, an owner and the creative director of Mio, a Philadelphia design firm specializing in sustainable furnishings.

headline: Suddenly, Mobile Music Services Seem to Be Everywhere
text: Music subscription services never quite struck gold with Internet users, but now that the smartphone is becoming the era’s standard listening device, a new gold rush is on.

headline: World Cup Replay: July 7
text: Images from the semifinal match between Spain and Germany at the World Cup in South Africa.

headline: N.B.A. Increases Salary Cap for Next Season
text: The N.B.A. announced a new salary cap of $58.04 million on Wednesday night, a higher-than-expected figure that could bolster several teams.

headline: Question on Lips at Open: How Far Over Par?
text: OAKMONT, Pa.  To prepare for this week’s United States Women’s Open, Mike Davis of the U.S.G.A. suggested that the 156 players in the field study footage from the 2007 men’s Open, which was also held here at Oakmont Country Club.

headline: Heat Wave Continues in New York
text: New Yorkers got creative with their cooling-down techniques on the fourth day of a record-breaking heat wave.

headline: Time Moves to Limit Free Content Online
text: Time has decided to dive headfirst into an issue that has bedeviled many a news organization before it: how to cure online readers of their addiction to free content.

headline: Facing Tough Economic Realities
text: To the Editor:

headline: Climate Whitewash, Blackwash and ‘Mushroom Clouds’
text: The reactions to the Independent Climate Change Email Review are flowing around the blogosphere, including — predictably — many shouts of “whitewash” by critics of climate science and proclamations of vindication by the scientists and institution thrust into the spotlight after the unauthorized release of a batch of e-mail strings and files revealed the sometimes-unseemly back story behind climate research. More cheers came from champions of aggressive cuts in greenhouse gases, as did at least one complaint about a mistaken interpretation of how the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change functions.

text: To the Editor:
