text: HITTING THE SHELVES

headline: Exclusive Soccer Club? Not Anymore
text: Durban, South Africa

headline: Browsing | East Hampton Retail Scene Thriving
text: Several new stores have moved in along Main Street.

headline: Bloggingheads: Should Steele Resign?
text: David Weigel of MSNBC and David Frum of FrumForum debate whether Michael Steele should leave his position.

headline: Energy Department Lags in Saving Energy
text: WASHINGTON  Like flossing or losing weight, saving energy is easier to promise than to actually do  even if you are the Department of Energy.

headline: Owner of Exploded Rig Is Known for Testing Rules
text: Transocean is the world’s largest offshore drilling company, but until its Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April, few Americans outside the energy business had heard of it. It is well known, however, in a number of other countries  for testing local laws and regulations.

headline: ESPN Clears the Lane to Go One-on-One With James
text: Like the president of the United States asking networks to clear time for a prime-time address, LeBron James solicited ESPN for an hour of its time Thursday night to address the nation on a matter of critical importance.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Pleads Guilty in Terror Case
text: WASHINGTON — A Guantánamo Bay detainee on Wednesday pleaded  guilty to conspiring with Al Qaeda and to providing material support for terrorism, setting up the first conviction before a military commission under the Obama administration.

headline: Haiti’s Eternal Weight
text: Atlanta

headline: CNN Fires Middle East Affairs Editor
text: CNN on Wednesday removed its senior editor of Middle Eastern affairs, Octavia Nasr, after she published a Twitter message saying that she respected the Shiite cleric Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah.

headline: Money in the Bank? No, Sandwich in a Can
text: DENVER — Is putting a sandwich in a can and calling it a “Candwich” the next can’t-miss billion-dollar idea?

headline: Managing the Met’s Wardrobe
text: If a diva gains weight on the sly, it is Lesley C. Weston’s duty to discreetly ensure that her costume expands in sync with her rib cage when she sings that big aria on opening night. Ms. Weston, 57, is head of costumes for the Metropolitan Opera. A graduate of the drama division at Juilliard, she gave up performing at 26 after opening Ethel’s Feathers, a vintage clothing shop in Chelsea, and worked three years for a Broadway costumer before joining the Met in 1985. Sidelined by an aneurysm in 2003, she took up writing and was nominated for a Pushcart Prize in 2008. She lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, a retired antiques dealer.

headline: Retailers Fight the Doldrums With Daring (and 3-D)
text: NEVER mind the store detectives that retailers hire to keep an eye on the customers. Maybe the industry needs a Sherlock Holmes or Jessica Fletcher type of detective to solve this most puzzling of mysteries: Will the latest signs of a weakening economy discourage consumers from spending money in the back-to-school, fall and holiday shopping seasons?

headline: Brotherhood and Politics, Consorting!
text: TEANECK, N.J.

headline: Backers Say Russian Inmate Torn by Possible Deal
text: MOSCOW  Until this week, Igor V. Sutyagin was being held in a prison camp not far from the Arctic Circle, near the site of what were some of Stalin’s most infamous gulags. His supporters say the location was apt, describing him as a political prisoner in Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia.

headline: Illinois Law Requires Testing All Rape Kits to End Backlog
text: CHICAGO  Facing criticism that physical evidence from sexual assault cases in Illinois often went unanalyzed, Gov. Patrick J. Quinn this week signed a law requiring the police to test all rape kits. State officials and victims’ advocates said it is the first such law in the nation.

headline: Patient Spain Delivers a Knockout
text: DURBAN, South Africa  While it is the world’s most popular sporting event, the World Cup has always been as exclusionary as it has been exclusive, essentially a public event held at a private club.

headline: V.A. Is Easing Rules to Cover Stress Disorder
text: The government is preparing to issue new rules that will make it substantially easier for veterans who have been found to have post-traumatic stress disorder to receive disability benefits, a change that could affect hundreds of thousands of veterans from the wars in Iraq, Afghanistan and Vietnam.

headline: Successes Nurtured in Barcelona
text: DURBAN, South Africa  The names and the numbers on the backs of the red-and-blue jerseys could fool anyone not paying close attention. Did Spain score in the 73rd minute against Germany in the semifinal of the World Cup on Wednesday night, or was it Barcelona, maybe, against Bayern Munich?

headline: Facebook Makes Headway Around the World
text: Sergey Brin, a Google founder, takes issue with people who say Google has failed to gain a foothold in social networking. Google has had successes, he often says, especially with Orkut, the dominant service in Brazil and India.

headline: Let Treasury Rescue the States
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: James’s Tough Call: To Leave Home Court or Not
text: The tattoo across his back reads Chosen One, but those who know LeBron James best say his obsession with basketball has more to do with a unique sense of team.

headline: Obama’s Lincoln Moment
text: There must be, in the glaring light of an anxious, heat-stinging summer, an image or two from the past appearing in President Obama’s White House.

headline: Disney Nears Sale of Miramax to Tutor and Colony
text: The Walt Disney Company is nearing a sale of its Miramax Films unit to an investor group led by construction executive Ronald N. Tutor and the private equity firm Colony Capital for $600 million to $700 million, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: For Democrats, Debt Debate and Familiar Ring of Disunity
text: WASHINGTON  In case you’ve been out of the country for the last 25 years and were afraid that nothing had stayed the same, here are some current events you may find comforting: Bon Jovi is touring. The Russians are spying on suburbia. And Democrats in Washington are squabbling over the direction of their party.

headline: Off-Track Betting’s Defunct Rescue Plan Was a Winner for Consultants
text: The New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation — burdened by its unique blend of politics, bureaucracy and horse racing interests — has long excelled at finding new ways to burn through the millions of dollars that pour under its tellers’ windows each year.

headline: This Is the Way Durant Signs: Not With a Bang but on Twitter
text: One of the linchpins to the N.B.A.’s future agreed to a contract extension on Wednesday, without free-agent summits or the aid of a television network.

headline: The Constitution Trumps Arizona
text: The Obama administration has not always been completely clear about its immigration agenda, but it was forthright Tuesday when it challenged the pernicious Arizona law that allows the police to question the immigration status of people they detain for local violations. Only the federal government can set or enforce immigration policy, the government said in its lawsuit against the state, and “Arizona has crossed this constitutional line.”

headline: In Europe, a Move to Ease Curbs on Growing Biotech Crops
text: BRUSSELS  After decades of pushing nations to surrender more power to the European Union, the bloc is pulling back on efforts to assert its authority over one highly contentious issue, genetically modified foods.

headline: Obey the Law on the Mentally Ill
text: Nearly a year has passed since a federal court ruled that New York violated federal disability law by warehousing mentally ill people in highly restrictive “homes” that are in some ways worse than the psychiatric hospitals they were meant to replace. The court rightly ordered Gov. David Paterson to give about 4,500 mentally ill people the option of moving into supported housing, where they could live independently with the help of social service organizations.

headline: Europe Seeks to Ban Food From Clones
text: The European Parliament asked on Wednesday for a ban on the sale of foods from cloned animals and their offspring, the latest sign of deepening concern in the European Union about the safety and ethics of new food technologies.

headline: Serving Gulf Seafood, and Keeping the Faith
text: NEW ORLEANS  Keith Chancley, the senior shucker at one of the oldest oyster bars in the French Quarter, leaned against the cold counter during lunch hour with a knife in idle hands and nothing to shuck. Plenty of fat Louisiana shellfish  procured by the hardest means  rested in chopped ice. But nobody wanted them.

headline: Disney Is Told to Pay $270 Million in ‘Millionaire’ Suit
text: The Walt Disney Company on Wednesday was ordered to pay almost $270 million in damages to Celador, the British production company that created the hit game show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” more than a decade ago.

headline: Huffington Post Acquires an Opinion Poll Service
text: The Huffington Post is venturing into the wonky but increasingly popular territory of opinion poll analysis, purchasing Pollster.com, a widely respected aggregator of poll data that has been a major draw for the Web site of The National Journal.

headline: New Ventures Win Old Financiers
text: Some big companies have found success backing innovations; it can be a smart way to support an employee with a potential invention while sharing the risk.

headline: Finally, a Medicare/Medicaid Chief
text: President Obama made a sensible move Wednesday when he bypassed the Senate and appointed Dr. Donald Berwick, an expert on reducing health care costs, to oversee Medicare and Medicaid. Republican senators had made it clear that they would use confirmation hearings to distort his record and rehash their arguments against the recently enacted health care reforms, mostly to score political points for the November elections.

headline: Afghan Companies Say U.S. Did Not Pay Them
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A number of Afghan construction companies working on contracts for American and NATO military bases in Afghanistan have accused American middlemen of reneging on payments for supplies and services, and in one case of leaving the country owing Afghan companies hundreds of thousands, even millions, of dollars.

headline: Artifacts of J. Edgar Hoover’s Life Find a Home
text: WASHINGTON  Thousands of artifacts related to J. Edgar Hoover’s personal and professional lives will finally find a home at the future National Law Enforcement Museum here, decades after the death of the longtime director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Arizona Challenge Does Not Focus on Profiling
text: PHOENIX  In the public outcry that followed passage of Arizona’s new immigration law, President Obama and other critics worried that it would lead to racial profiling. But while that concern has dominated the public debate and inspired a round of boycotts of the state, it played little role in the actual legal challenge the administration filed Tuesday against the law.

headline: The Curious Mystery of the Sidewalk Tombstone
text: You can find just about anything on the sidewalks of New York, so when John Lankenau happened upon a tombstone while walking his dog one night a few years ago, he took his grim discovery in stride. Then he did what any self-respecting citizen would do: He carted the two-and-a-half-foot-high granite marker, which weighed several hundred pounds, home for safe-keeping.

headline: With Partner Selected, Trade Center Project Discredits Some Naysayers
text: The announcement on Wednesday that the powerful Durst real estate family had won a hotly contested bidding contest for a stake in 1 World Trade Center represented a remarkable turnaround in the fortunes of the $3.3 billion skyscraper since its inception six years ago.

headline: Cuomo Finds Pattern of Workers’ Inflating Pensions
text: Many New York state and local government workers pad their pensions by drastically increasing their overtime in their last years of employment, according to a report released Wednesday by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Corrections
text: The biographical note accompanying an Op-Ed essay on Wednesday, about beekeeping in New York City, incorrectly rendered the name of the institution with which the author, Hugh Raffles, is affiliated. It is the New School, not the New School University.

headline: Tourist Boat Capsizes in Accident in Philadelphia
text: A barge rammed into an amphibious tourist “duck boat” on the Delaware River in Philadelphia, capsizing the small boat and sending the 37 people aboard into the river.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Testing Eyesight and “Ransomware”
text: On this week’s New York Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Ramesh Raskar, an M.I.T. Media Lab associate professor, about a system he and his students developed that uses a cellphone screen, a small plastic device and software to test vision and calculate eyeglass prescriptions. According to Dr. Raskar, the results are as reliable as a more conventional method of testing eyesight. The system, called the Near-Eye Tool for Refractive Assessment, is inexpensive to produce and use, and because cellphones are so widespread it has the potential to help millions of people around the world with impaired vision, Dr. Raskar says.

headline: In Praise of Israeli Civil Society
text: Here are a couple of additional points about Israeli civil society that I couldn’t shoehorn into my Thursday column.

text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Robinson Cano has a sore lower back, but he arrived at Oakland Coliseum on Wednesday afternoon expecting to compete in Monday’s home run derby, and he told reporters as much.

headline: Open to Go On Without Mallon
text: OAKMONT, Pa. — For the first time in 23 years, Meg Mallon is not competing in the United States Women’s Open.

text: The left-hander Jon Niese was a wild card for the Mets entering this season. He held promise, to be sure, but he had only two major league wins to his name.

headline: Disney Is Said to Be Nearing a Deal for Miramax Films
text: The Walt Disney Company is nearing a sale of its Miramax Films unit to an investor group led by a construction executive, Ronald N. Tutor, and the private equity firm Colony Capital for $600 million to $700 million, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,403 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Jim Bohlen, Who Led in Creation of Greenpeace, Dies at 84
text: Jim Bohlen, whose snap decision to sail to Amchitka Island, Alaska, to protest an underground nuclear test led to the creation of the environmental organization Greenpeace, died Monday in Comox, British Columbia. He was 84 and lived in Courtenay, British Columbia.

headline: Britain: Ruling for Gay Asylum Seekers
text: The Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the right of gay asylum seekers not to be deported if they could show that they faced persecution in their home countries. The court ruled unanimously in favor of two men  a Cameroonian who fled his country after being attacked by an angry mob, and an Iranian who was attacked and expelled from school when his sexuality was discovered  who had lost appeals against deportation in a lower court. The lower court judges had ruled that the men could live “reasonably tolerable” lives in their home countries if they concealed their sexuality. The Supreme Court said that “to compel a homosexual person to pretend” that his sexuality does not exist amounted to denying “his fundamental right to be who he is.” The coalition Conservative-Liberal Democrat government embraced the ruling, which reversed the policy of the former Labour government.

headline: Russia: Government Criticizes Clinton
text: The Foreign Ministry criticized Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday for using the word “occupation” in referring to Russian forces in the breakaway Georgian enclaves of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Russia says its military was invited to deploy troops in the regions, which it considers sovereign countries. “Therefore, Secretary Clinton’s use of the term ‘occupation’ has no basis,” a ministry statement said. “There is not a single Russian serviceman on Georgian territory.” Mrs. Clinton made the remarks in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Monday, challenging Russia to abide by a French-brokered cease-fire agreement that would require it to withdraw its forces to prewar positions. Most countries  except Russia, Venezuela, Nicaragua and Nauru  consider the regions part of Georgia.

headline: Israel Hicks, Director of August Wilson’s Cycle, Dies at 66
text: Israel Hicks, a prolific stage director who worked Off Broadway and in regional theaters across the country and who in 2009 completed a nearly 20-year project directing August Wilson’s entire decade-by-decade cycle about the black experience in 20th-century America, died on July 3 in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 66 and lived in White Plains.

headline: China: Dalai Lama’s Birthday Ignored
text: A Foreign Ministry spokesman said China preferred to ignore the Dalai Lama’s birthday and instead remember two dates in modern Tibetan history: those of Tibet’s “peaceful liberation” and Serf Emancipation Day. The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s spiritual leader, turned 75 on Tuesday. “I can only remember two dates,” the spokesman, Qin Gang, said Tuesday. He said one was March 28, 1951, when the Chinese Army took over central Tibet, and the other was May 23, 1959, after the Chinese Army suppressed a Tibetan uprising, a day the government recently designated Serf Emancipation Day.

headline: The Many Roles of Joel Grey
text: The sparkling eyes of Joel Grey belie a darkness well known to those acquainted with his haunting portrayal of the Hitler-era master of ceremonies in the musical “Cabaret.”

headline: News Quiz | July 8, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Yankees Do All the Little Things and Sweep Athletics
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  The highlight of a game is sometimes mistaken for its pivotal moment. There is a difference. When the fourth inning began Wednesday night, Mark Teixeira was set to bat seventh. Then, with two outs and no one on base, Brett Gardner faced a two-strike count. He worked a walk to ignite the Yankees’ five-run rally, capped by a three-run homer by Teixeira.

text: preeminent •\pre-ˈe-mə-nənt\• adjective

headline: Alan Bennett New CEO of H&R Block
text: H&R Block named Alan M. Bennett as its new president and C.E.O. Wednesday after its previous chief executive, Russ Smyth, resigned to take another C.E.O. post, The Associated Press reports.

headline: James Has Mastered the Media, but Not the Postseason
text: One of the many twists to the decision by LeBron James to announce his intentions on ESPN on Thursday is that, despite all his prowess during the regular season, he has largely been a bust when it matters most: During the playoffs.

headline: BP Struggles to Regain Shareholder Confidence
text: For more than 10 weeks, BP has focused on the challenge of plugging its gushing oil well a mile below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico. It has also struggled to placate angry gulf residents and government officials and reassure a public frustrated by the company’s inability to stop the spill, The New York Times’s Jad Mouawad reports.

text: Shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will begin trading over-the-counter Thursday, nearly a month after the government-sponsored mortgage buyers said they could no longer meet the requirements of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

text: In what undoubtedly is a first, the world’s top-ranked player, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, who is 19, has taken on a second career: fashion model.

headline: Emmy Champ ’30 Rock’ Gets New Challengers in ‘Glee’ and ‘Modern Family’

headline: Helping Both the Victim and the Bully
text: What do you do if your child is traumatized by online bullying? And what can be done to help bullies understand the impact of their actions? Those are among the questions about cyberbullying readers asked our expert, Elizabeth K. Englander. Dr. Englander is a professor of psychology and the founder and director of the Massachusetts Aggression Reduction Center at Bridgewater State College, which provides anti-bullying and anti-violence training programs and resources to schools and families.

headline: Budgeting for a Child
text: After the government last month released its annual tally of what it costs to raise a child to age 18 ($222,360), I received an e-mail message from a reader, A., who is looking for advice on how to find a more practical number. That lump sum is interesting as a conversation starter, she says, but it isn’t much help in trying to budget for an actual child.

headline: The Emmy Nominees

headline: Shops Emerge From Ruins of Jackson Heights Fire
text: A little more than four months ago, a faulty boiler in a furniture store ignited a fire that raged for hours in Jackson Heights, Queens, destroying eight mom-and-pop shops in a squat landmark building at the corner of 37th Avenue and 84th Street. By the time firefighters tamed the flames, all that was left was charred wood and fallen bricks.

headline: Early Word: Spy Swap in the Works
text: Today could bring an end to the sensational spy drama that began almost two weeks ago when the F.B.I. arrested 11 people on charges of being part of a Russian espionage ring after trailing them for nearly a decade. Russian and American officials have been discussing an exchange of some or all of the suspects for prisoners in Russia, and the lawyer for a Russian scientist accused of revealing secrets to the West said her client could be freed today in a top-secret swap in Britain, The Times’s Ellen Barry and Scott Shane report. The scientist, Igor V. Sutyagin, after consistently maintaining his innocence, signed a document this week admitting guilt.

headline: Hurdles for a Natural Gas Transition
text: Natural gas might emerge as a “bridge” fuel in controlling carbon dioxide emissions, but switching over from coal would cost hundreds of billions of dollars — not even counting the cost of the gas, according to a study sponsored by the American Public Power Association.

headline: Poetry Pairing | July 8, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: Julianna Margulies of ‘The Good Wife’ on Her Emmy Nomination (and Possible Inspiration?)

headline: Telecast Adds a Dash of Suspense to Emmy Nominations
text: The reading of the prime-time Emmy nominations is generally a suspense-free zone, but Sofia Vergara managed to change that during this year’s announcement, carried live on Thursday morning on the “Today” show on NBC. After the accent she wields for comic effect on “Modern Family” had given inventive new shadings to names like Ian McKellen and Kyra Sedgwick, she came to a complete halt halfway through one of the nominees for best actress in a drama. Her fellow reader Joel McHale gallantly stepped in, finishing the name: Hargitay.

headline: On Our Radar: China’s Food Security
text: China wrestles with food security issues as ethanol production causes a jump in corn prices. “Producing fuel ethanol has not only cost plenty of food but also doesn’t help much in ensuring China’s energy security,” a state energy official tells The China Daily.

headline: Seeing Things | Gaetano Pesce in L.A.

The exhibition — the first of the iconoclastic designer’s work to be shown on the West Coast — provides a comprehensive overview of Pesce’s remarkable 40-year career and includes prototypes, production models and rarely seen video footage.

headline: Practical Traveler Tip | Gel Inserts
text: Gel shoe inserts are not permitted, but shoes constructed with gel heels are allowed and must be removed and screened. Michelle Higgins reports.

headline: Practical Traveler Tip | Get the 311
text: 3.4 ounce bottles; 1 quart-sized, clear, plastic, zip-top bag; 1 bag per passenger placed in screening bin. Michelle Higgins reports.

headline: The Perfect Traveler
text: The Practical Traveler demonstrates the difference between the Perfect Traveler and the Problem Traveler.

headline: Obama Presses BP to Recover More Oil
text: WASHINGTON — With a weeklong window of favorable weather opening in the Gulf of Mexico, the Obama administration is pressing BP to move quickly on two operations that could double the amount of oil captured from the gushing well.

headline: Practical Traveler Tip | Bag the Wires
text: Innocent items can actually appear to be potential threats in an X-ray image, simply by the way they're packed. Michelle Higgins reports.

headline: Now Serving | Los Angeles Cake Revival
text: Addicted to cake at an early age, I watched helplessly as bakeries, department-store tea rooms and restaurants in my native Los Angeles met the wrecking ball, taking with them my favorite recipes (and pretty much all of my childhood happiness). Enter my savior, Valerie Gordon, of Valerie Confections , who has brought back some of California’s best-loved desserts with her “vintage cake” collection. What started with Blum’s coffee crunch cake has grown to include the Brown Derby grapefruit cake, Bullock’s Wilshire coconut cream pie and Chasen’s banana shortcake.

headline: Practical Traveler Tip | Underwire Bras
text: Transportation security officers have to identify any metal that is detected at the checkpoint. Michelle Higgins reports.

headline: Practical Traveler Tip | Wrapped Gifts
text: If a security officer needs to inspect a package, they may have to unwrap your gift. Michelle Higgins reports.

headline: TimesCast | July 8, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on terror arrests in Norway, the Lebron James media circus and discrimination against lesbian soccer players in South Africa.

headline: How Much Can The Fed Help? (Wonkish)
text: OK, there are signs that the Fed is nerving itself up to do something more to support the economy. The question is, how much are the kinds of actions likely to be on the table likely to matter?

headline: Chinese Artist Who Led Protest Has Been Jailed, His Wife Says
text: BEIJING  Wu Yuren, an artist who helped lead an unusually bold public protest last winter over a land dispute, has been languishing in a Beijing jail for almost six weeks after having been beaten by police officers, his wife said on Thursday.

headline: Matthew Weiner of ‘Mad Men’ on His Emmy Nomination (and the Future of the Show?)
text: For its third season, the AMC cable series “Mad Men” was nominated for 17 Emmys including best drama, an award it has won every year it’s been on television.

headline: Europe Resumes Sharing Bank Data With U.S.
text: BRUSSELS  The European Parliament on Thursday moved to mend a rift with the United States as it approved restarting a program to track financial and bank transfers that the United States says is vital to its effort to fight terrorism.

headline: Live From Sun Valley, Day Three
text: 1:57 p.m. | Updated SUN VALLEY, Idaho — For years, the Allen & Company annual retreat here has been the birthplace of mega-deals that have reshaped the media landscape. Exhibit A: the sale of ABC to the Walt Disney Company. Exhibit B: the sale of a majority stake in NBC Universal to Comcast.

headline: Pit Bulls, Elephants and Grizzlies, Oh My!
text: Whether they’re pit bulls, grizzlies or elephants, Sarah Palin says to expect a stampede of lipstick-clad moms at the polls in November.

text: You'd think it'd be pretty easy to live within the copyright laws, or at least to understand them: If you want something of value, you pay for it.

headline: Considering Tactics, Transfers and Recruits
text: On Tuesday, the clock began ticking for Gov. David A. Paterson on whether he would sign, veto or passively adopt controversial legislation aimed at curtailing some policing powers in New York City.

headline: A City’s Motto: I ♥ Tap Water
text: New York City is so proud of its tap water that the Bloomberg administration has come up with a product line to trumpet its quality and promote it as an affordable and sustainable alternative to bottled water.

headline: No Easy Answers in the Copyright Debate
text: You’d think it’d be pretty easy to live within the copyright laws, or at least to understand them: if you want something of value, you pay for it.

headline: Why Did I Survive?
text: This past spring I took off the uniform, stowed away my desert combat boots and began a new journey. Five years earlier I had entered the Army as a naïve 18-year-old fresh from high school graduation, excited about the prospects of deploying to combat and proving myself in battle.

headline: How Republican Senators Plan to Vote on Kagan
text: Elena Kagan, President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court, is expected to be confirmed by the Senate, despite the opposition of Republican lawmakers who have been critical of her. The question is: How many Republican votes will she get? Mr. Obama’s previous nominee, Sonia Sotomayor, received nine Republican votes. Of those nine, none face re-election this year, three are retiring and a fourth — Mel Martinez of Florida — has already left the Senate. Here is where the Republicans stand so far based on their public statements. The most recent announcements of intent are at the top.  Go to Graphic …

headline: Movie About Facebook Will Open the New York Film Festival
text: Here’s a bit of news you may want to share on Facebook, Twitter or whatever it is you Web-savvy kids are using these days: “The Social Network,” David Fincher‘s much anticipated movie about the creation of Facebook, has been selected for opening night at the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday.

headline: Four Are Indicted in Suburban N.Y. Hotel Killing
text: WHITE PLAINS  From the moment Ben Novack Jr. was found bludgeoned, bound and gagged inside a hotel suite in a wealthy New York suburb a year ago, the details of his life and violent death have grown more peculiar with each disclosure.

headline: Poor Records Thwart Investigation of Federal Safety Agency
text: An investigation into whether the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration made good use of about $900 million on research projects has stopped, in part because the safety agency’s records are “incomplete.”

headline: Going Long and Short on the Budget
text: So says Laurence Seidman of the University of Delaware. His solution is threefold.

headline: 13-Year-Old Boy Is Shot in Queens
text: Updated, 3:57 p.m. | A 13-year-old boy was shot in the leg as he left summer school in Far Rockaway minutes before noon on Thursday, according to the police.

headline: Defined by Soccer: Issac Kungwane a k a Shakes
text: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa for the World Cup to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. Based in Alexandra — a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people — the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.

headline: Hotel Review: W Washington in Washington, D.C.
text: For years, the nation’s capital was known for hotels that looked like George Washington could have slept here. Tradition, not trendiness, was the desired vibe. So the decision to create a W overflowing with fashion-forward details was gutsy. As it turns out, the hotel, which opened last fall, is a hit, thanks in part to the rooftop bar that attracts throngs of attractive 20-somethings nightly. Obviously, families with small children are not W’s target demographic — something that I realized on a recent Saturday evening as I fought my way through the crowded lobby with my 7-year-old twins. Still, once we were safely in our room, the boys loved the whimsical décor, the cozy bed and the amazing city views.

headline: Now Rolling | London Bike Cafes
text: Now that London’s cycling subculture has reached the level of a populist movement, bike cafes like Container Cafe, Lock 7 and the summer pop-up Rapha Cycle Club are the city’s latest hip hangouts. A recent addition is Look Mum No Hands, a bar, cafe and workshop in a lofty garage space on busy Old Street in Shoreditch. If you’ve visited any other haunts in East London, you can imagine the place: Edison light bulbs, a staff sporting asymmetrical haircuts, old tires and bike parts hanging from exposed ceiling pipes. Vintage bikes and heirloom tomatoes dress up the window displays, and a scattering of desks and built-in benches fill up most of the room.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Storm clouds clear over Cook Inlet, near Anchorage, Alaska.

headline: Restaurant Review: Tuna in Rome
text: Despite its name and location, Tuna, which opened in October 2008 on the Via Veneto, is not your typical tourist trap. On the contrary, few tourists make it to the restaurant, which, indeed, serves only seafood. Italian businessmen and politicians, with a smattering of the idle rich, make up most of the clientele.

headline: As Octopus Ponders Final Choice, Parrot Tips Dutch to Take World Cup
text: German, Dutch and Spanish television stations are preparing to broadcast live from an aquarium in Oberhausen, Germany, on Friday, when an octopus named Paul, whose handlers claim he can predict the outcome of World Cup soccer matches, will attempt to call the last two games of the tournament.

headline: Next Installment of Bridge Project Is Delayed
text: The final installment of the Bridge Project, a three-year collaboration between the Brooklyn Academy of Music and two London theatrical stalwarts, the Old Vic Theater and Sam Mendes’s Neal Street Productions, has been postponed a year until 2012 because of scheduling issues, according to Jackie Green, a press representative for the Bridge Project.

headline: Tampa Bay Bucs 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Readers' Photos: Heat Wave
text: With July came blistering heat. Readers in the New York City area share their experiences in pictures.

headline: As Octopus Ponders Final Choice, Parrot Tips Dutch to Take World Cup
text: German, Dutch and Spanish television stations are preparing to broadcast live from an aquarium in Oberhausen, Germany, on Friday, when an octopus named Paul, whose handlers claim he can predict the outcome of World Cup soccer matches, will attempt to call the last two games of the tournament.

headline: Questions to Nick Kristof
text: Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof responds to a reader's question: "Would it have been possible for Rwanda to achieve almost full recovery without autocratic power?"

headline: Is Jousting the Next Extreme Sport?
text: The gates of the Gulf Coast International Jousting Championships opened at 6 p.m. one Friday in January at a 4,500-seat arena 13 miles outside Pensacola, Fla. Some of the spectators were dressed in leather doublets and velvet gowns; some wore jeans and cowboy hats or American-flag-patterned do-rags. Most seemed to have come out of idle curiosity rather than any previous knowledge of the sport. “From what I hear, the combat’s going to be smackin’,” a man named Paul Johnson told me, punching his knuckles together. He estimated he had seen the movie  “A Knight’s Tale”  a couple dozen times, and he hoped this event would measure up. He leaned over to a man in front of him. “When they ride in, are they going to be hitting really hard?” he asked.

headline: Popcast: Miley Cyrus, Robert Randolph and Alejandro Escovedo
text: This week Jon Pareles and Jon Caramanica on Miley Cyrus and her new album; Nate Chinen on “We Walk This Road” by Robert Randolph; plus “Street Songs of Love,” the new CD by Alejandro Escovedo. Jon Pareles is the host.

headline: Times Square, 10:07 A.M.
text: Surveyors’ markings glowed with extra mystery after this morning’s downpour.

headline: Bingo on the Go
text: Our recent family road trip to my sister’s farm in Pennsylvania seemed shorter this year, thanks to a 99-cent app, Road Trip Bingo from Bright Bunny Studios.

headline: The Photographs of Joel Grey
text: Joel Grey’s name is usually known to appear on marquees and in opening credits. But over the past seven years, as Randy Banner reports on the Lens blog, the award-winning actor has become recognized as a photographer. Mr. Grey’s newest work was captured using a 1.3-megapixel Nokia cellphone. View more of Mr. Grey’s photographs here.

headline: European Plane Maker Submits Bid for U.S. Tankers
text: WASHINGTON  The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company submitted an 8,800-page bid on Thursday for a $35 billion Air Force tanker contract amid tensions over whether European subsidies would give it a cost advantage over Boeing.

headline: Joke: How Many D.O.E. Workers Does It Take to…
text: The incandescent light bulb’s days are numbered. Under federal law, the 100-watt bulbs are supposed to be taken off the shelf next year, followed later by the more common 40- and 60-watt models.

headline: MDC Again Combines Two Agencies
text: MDC Partners, the Toronto-based agency holding company, has made a name for itself with several spates of acquisitions. Such buying sprees are often followed by phases of digestion, absorption and consolidation, and that is what is now taking place with MDC — and, as is typically the case, not without some bumpy patches.

headline: Doubt Is Cast on Claims That Sarkozy Took Cash
text: PARIS  The former accountant of France’s richest woman denied to the police that she had told a French Web site that President Nicolas Sarkozy had taken envelopes of cash from her boss, Liliane Bettencourt, according to a report in the newspaper Le Monde on Thursday.

headline: On the Stump, Obama Offers Reassurance on Economy
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Standing on a sparkling clean factory floor, with a fleet of battery-powered trucks behind him, President Obama on Thursday confronted a challenge: how to reconcile the grim reality of 9.5 percent unemployment with the necessity of defending his economic policies in a midterm election year.

headline: Further Adventures in Fake Deficit Hawkery
text: One of the prime arguments of the austerity now now now people has been that you can’t do the sensible thing — run deficits while the economy is depressed, then turn to budget-balancing once recovery is well in place — because that will lack credibility. Only by imposing immediate suffering, at great cost to employment, can you convince the invisible bond vigilantes that you really mean business.

headline: ABC Makes Changes to Coming Cop Drama
text: ABC is stripping the fake-documentary feeling out of “Detroit 1-8-7,” its forthcoming cop drama, New York Magazine reported on Wednesday.

headline: Iku-Men
text: Stay-at-home fathers in Japan.(Iku-ji [child-rearing] + Men.)

headline: Merck Plans Layoff of 15% of Work Force
text: The $41 billion merger last year of the drug giants Merck and Schering-Plough has a human cost for pharmaceutical industry employees.

headline: Tap Water That’s Good Enough to Wear
text: New York City’s fresh-from-the-Catskills tap water, long renowned for its relative purity and tastiness, now has its very own merchandising campaign. The city has introduced a line of glasses ($5), T-shirts ($23), decanters and water bottles bearing an “NYC Water” logo. The swag is available at the online CityStore and at the New York-centric housewares purveyor Fishs Eddy. The water itself is not for sale, except through the tap. Read all about it on the Green blog.

headline: What Clown Wrote This Script?
text: I FIRST saw her on “The Late Show With David Letterman.” It was the rare occasion when I was home from work before midnight, and I was lying in bed trying to unwind.

headline: Still Crazy After All These Years
text: Mark Thoma asks, “What happened to Ed Prescott?”

headline: Quote Unquote | Fringe Benefits
text: -Rumi Neely, Fashion Toast blogger, is surprised by her newfound fame as a Forever 21 model. Since when is appearing in an ad campaign license to wear fringe?

headline: Overcoming Insomnia Without Drugs
text: Dozens of insomnia sufferers had questions for the Consults blog about alternatives to sleeping pills. Here, Shelby Freedman Harris, a psychologist and director of Montefiore Medical Center’s Sleep Disorders Center, discusses the benefits of cognitive behavioral therapy, which can rival or exceed medications in providing long-term relief from insomnia.

headline: Court Delays Muslim Cleric’s Extradition to U.S.
text: LONDON  The extradition of Abu Hamza al-Masri, an Egyptian-born Muslim cleric wanted in the United States on terrorism charges, was delayed again on Thursday after he won a new stay of a British court order from Europe’s human rights court.

headline: Government Filing Connects Polgar to Criminal Case
text: For the first time, a criminal case against a member of the United States Chess Federation has asserted a direct link in the behavior of the accused, Gregory Alexander of Everett, Wash., and Susan Polgar, the former women’s world champion who was a board member of the federation until she was dismissed from it last year.

headline: 3 Britons Convicted in Plot to Blow Up Airliners
text: LONDON  The longest and costliest terrorism prosecution in British history came to an end on Thursday when three men were found guilty in a London court of plotting to commit murder in a case that centered on a 2006 conspiracy, with links to Al Qaeda, to attack seven trans-Atlantic airliners bound for the United States and Canada with “liquid bombs.”

headline: Casting Announced for ‘The Scottsboro Boys’
text: Joshua Henry, currently a co-star of “American Idiot,” will play the key role of Haywood Patterson in the Broadway production of ”The Scottsboro Boys,” the Kander and Ebb musical that begins previews on Oct. 7 at the Lyceum Theater.

headline: 'There Are Worse Things I Could Do'
text: Stockard Channing sings "There Are Worse Things I Could Do" in a clip from the new sing-along version of "Grease."

headline: Pasadena Playhouse Emerges From Bankruptcy
text: The Pasadena Playhouse has emerged from Chapter 11 and plans to mount a production this fall, the theater announced on Thursday.Two months after it filed for bankruptcy protection, the playhouse’s reorganization plan was approved on Wednesday by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles.

headline: Second Round of Medicare Rebates Sent
text: The Obama administration is sending $250 checks to more than 300,000 older Americans who paid higher drug costs in the Medicare coverage gap known as the “doughnut hole,” officials announced Thursday.

headline: Samurai Shopper | East Is East
text: My first apartment in New York City was on the Upper East Side: a minuscule railroad flat long on light, short on space. The area was safe, shabby-genteel, likewise the shopping: second-rate markets, orthopedic gear and nowhere to revel when the day was done.

headline: Doubts About Cuomo’s Support of Gay Rights
text: As a landmark gay marriage bill hurtled toward an uncertain vote last year, New York’s Democratic leaders scrambled to corral support. Gov. David A. Paterson delivered impassioned speeches, Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand headlined a giant rally and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn shuttled back and forth to Albany to lobby lawmakers.

headline: Proving You’re a Good Parent
text: How to measure good parenting? What if a stranger had the power to declare that ours was not good enough?

headline: Feeling the Heat
text: It’s a little cooler today — a little — so here for your enjoyment is a slide show featuring readers’ photos of the blistering heat wave of the last few days.

headline: A Flint Neighborhood Digs Out
text: Flint, Mich., finds itself the centerpiece of a national debate about so-called shrinking cities. But on East Piper Avenue, some people are trying to make use of one of the few abundant resources in the city: land.

headline: Cutting the Deck and Hoping for Clues
text: In South Carolina prisons, more than 10,000 packs of playing cards have been sold that depict the victims of unsolved crimes, in hopes that information will surface.

headline: Eradicating Cogongrass
text: The Alabama Cogongrass Control Center has been charged with combating "the perfect weed."

headline: The American Dream at Auction
text: The Furse home was one of several foreclosed properties that were auctioned off by REDC, a real estate auction company, in Utah in June.

headline: A Mill Town Moves On
text: In 1993, a paper mill, built in Augusta, Me., in 1830, employed more than 500 people. Soon after, though, the mill closed, reopened, then closed again, and now it is being demolished.

headline: Florida Town Strives to Be Counted
text: A Florida woman rallies her home town to be accurately represented in the 2010 census.

headline: Sweat and Service on the Homefront
text: A group of volunteers working in North East, Md., are part of a rising tide of young people signing up for AmeriCorps, a national service program.

headline: Seeking a Home With No Certain Address
text: Just when several dozen homeless people thought they'd found a safe haven, the Providence, R.I., overpass shielding their tent city began to crumble.

headline: Keeping V-J Day Alive
text: Friday was the 14th of August: a dog day to many but always V-J Day to some, including World War II veteran Albert Perdeck.

headline: For Younger Women, a Smaller Wage Gap
text: The gender wage gap is much narrower for younger workers, according to a new Labor Department report on women in the work force.

headline: Renault Offers Sneak Peek at Its DeZir Concept Car
text: Renault has provided a sneak preview of its new concept car, due to be unveiled at the Paris auto show at the end of September.

headline: ‘Grease Sing-Along’? There Are Worse Things You Could Do
text: If your chills are multiplying, it’s probably because the movie “Grease” is returning to theaters. Paramount has re-released the 1978 musical hit, this time in a sing-along version with animated subtitles. Viewers can decide all over again whether or not Rizzo (Stockard Channing), one of the more world-weary teens on film, could do anything worse than go with a boy or two, as illustrated above. The film is now playing in 12 cities and set to open in five more on July 15. Much like with “Paranormal Activity,” Paramount is using social networking as part of the marketing campaign for “Grease Sing-Along.” If the movie is not being screened in your hometown, potential audiences are encouraged to “demand it” on the film’s official Web site.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Stanton Tailor Shop
text: A tailor in a tiny storefront on Stanton Street has been drawing customers from all over New York since 1991.

headline: Artists Challenge City’s Limit on Vendors
text: A group of unhappy artists is seeking to block a plan by the city to significantly reduce the number of art vendors in city parks.

headline: Plain Truth in the Eye of a Tailor
text: I CAN usually count on Pablo to tell me the plain truth. “Return them,” was his edict last summer on a new pair of designer jeans. Pablo has seen me in every pair of jeans I have purchased over the last eight years, along with untold dresses, coats and T-shirts. As I stood on the platform in the back of Stanton Tailor Shop, waiting for him to pin the jeans to the perfect length, we looked at each other in the mirror. He was right; I had chosen badly.

headline: A Dose of the Tribeca Film Festival in Atlantic City
text: MTV’s “Jersey Shore” may have relocated to South Beach, but there’s still a chance to get a taste of some very different South Jersey action this summer, at least in Atlantic City. On Thursday is the debut of the Tribeca Cinema Series at Caesars Atlantic City, a partnership between Caesars and the Tribeca Film Festival that will feature four films through Sunday, shown on the beach on a 33-foot-long, 20-foot-tall screen perpendicular to the shore.

headline: Reid Finds Grist for Ads in Angle’s Comments
text: For Republicans, the juiciest Senate target of this election year is almost certainly Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader from Nevada.

headline: Lugar Attacks Romney on Nuclear Treaty
text: Senator Richard G. Lugar, one of the Republican Party’s senior voices on foreign affairs, fired back Thursday at Mitt Romney over his opposition to the new nuclear treaty with Russia, accusing Mr. Romney of “hyperbolic” rhetoric that is divorced from the reality of arms control.

text: Classical

headline: The Insider | Peter Som
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof will cherish each of the fourteen Emmy nominations for the final season of “Lost,” but they were most satisfied by the nomination for Matthew Fox, the protagonist who had never received a nod before.

text: Jazz

text: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, takes a look at how the classic bloody is changing for the better.
