text: Around Town

headline: YouTube Question on Rwanda
text: Over the next several days, Nick will be responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today’s question asks Nick if Rwanda would have been able to enjoy its “full economic recovery” without an “autocratic approach.”

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Breaks an Emmy Record, and Lorne Michaels Is Cool With That
text: Here are three words we never expected to hear from Lorne Michaels: “It’s all good.”

headline: More Late-Night Drama?
text: Who will be able to resist tuning in to NBC on Aug. 29 to see what happens if Conan O’Brien wins the award for best comedy/variety series for “The Tonight Show,” the program he used to host on that very network?

headline: Bloody Mary, the Liquid Salad
text: I grew up thinking of the bloody mary as a joyless drink. It was a corrective after a night of head-cramping excess: the pitiable hair of the shameful dog. Or it was a quasi-sanctioned, quiet way for the booze-dependent to begin a sort of intravenous drip of alcohol early in the day. Either way, the bloody mary struck me as medicinal.

headline: Monitor Again Rejects Westchester Housing Plan
text: For the second time in the 11 months since Westchester County signed a landmark housing desegregation agreement, a federal monitor has rejected  its plan to create hundreds of homes for moderate-income people in predominantly white communities.

headline: McClatchy News Group Ends Polling
text: The McClatchy newspaper chain will conduct its last poll this month, which will leave the company’s 30 daily newspapers around the country without their own polling data just before the midterm elections.

headline: 9 Stores Fined for Propping Doors Open
text: Nine stores in Manhattan and the Bronx have been hit with $200 fines for leaving their doors open on hot days in the hope that the escaping cool air will lure sweaty customers. They are the first fined as part of a new law passed in 2008.

headline: House Tour: Essex, N.Y.
text: WHAT 4-bedroom, 1.5-bathroom house of 2,100 square feet on 3.5 acres.

headline: A Place Like Home
text: Lisa Cholodenko, the director of "The Kids Are All Right," narrates a look at her film.

headline: Judge Defers Civil Lawsuit for Adviser in Fraud Case
text: A civil lawsuit brought by federal regulators against a financial adviser suspected of stealing millions of dollars from celebrity clients was temporarily halted on Thursday by a federal judge in Manhattan who said a criminal case against the adviser should be dispensed with first.

headline: Meeting Again, at the Auction House
A Stretch Limo Is the Vehicle for Flights of Fancy
text: A black limousine pulled into LentSpace on Wednesday evening to signal the beginning of Yoshiko Chuma’s latest outdoor work, “A-C-E One,” or, as one youngster in the audience put it, “Look, Daddy, there’s a car service coming in.”

headline: An Intrepid Group Surveys an Idiosyncratic Composer
text: For the International Contemporary Ensemble, an intrepid and adventurous new-music group based in Brooklyn and Chicago, presenting brash sounds and fresh discoveries is all in a day’s work, though stellar musicianship and infectious enthusiasm prevent any whiff of routine from tainting its labors. On Wednesday evening those qualities made its members ideal emissaries for Edgard Varèse, a maverick composer whose works will be featured during two concerts in this year’s Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: An Intro to the Hottest Social Networks
text: A basic course on social networking, for those who don't know Twitter from Foursquare.

headline: Special Election Okayed for West Virginia
text: West Virginia’s attorney general has determined that Gov. Joe Manchin III can call a special election this year to fill the vacancy created by the death of Robert C. Byrd, clearing the way for a contest in November to fill the remaining two years of Mr. Byrd’s term.

headline: James Could Join Modell in Infamy
text: If LeBron James does, indeed, leave the Cleveland Cavaliers for the Miami Heat, he will be linked in the city’s sports history to Art Modell, who took the Cleveland Browns to Baltimore in 1996. Modell’s relocation of the Browns outraged the city, much as the prospect of James leaving the Cavaliers has.

headline: Photographs That Tell Unsettling Tales
text: Is a mosquito bite a form of travel? Maybe, according to a photograph by Dennis Oppenheim. It shows the pest alighting on human flesh but offers this thought to compensate for the inevitable itchy welt: “The blood now conforms to the interior configuration of an insect, thereby placing part of you in a state of aerial displacement.”

headline: He’s Off to Join the Circus
text: “How was I?” a trapeze artist named Clémence (Julie-Marie Parmentier) asks Vittorio (Sergio Castellitto), a traveler, supposedly en route from Milan to Barcelona, who has paused to indulge in a mellow, offhand way the universal childhood dream of running off to join the circus.

headline: Plain Truth in the Eye of a Tailor
text: I can usually count on Pablo to tell me the plain truth. “Return them,” was his edict last summer on a new pair of designer jeans. Pablo has seen me in every pair of jeans I have purchased over the last eight years, along with untold dresses, coats and T-shirts. As I stood on the platform in the back of Stanton Tailor Shop on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, waiting for him to pin the jeans to the perfect length, we looked at each other in the mirror. He was right; I had chosen badly.

headline: After Music From a Bridge, Why Not a Tower?
text: It may have seemed like a crazy idea to some, but it worked.

headline: Fresh Perspective on Familiar Pop Master
text: Inspired by mundane images, Roy Lichtenstein managed to create art that has become the stuff of legend: illustrations of advertisements for things like foot medication, hot dogs and BB guns, not to mention his signature reinterpretations of comic book images. The work of Lichtenstein, who died in 1997, has been studied and studied again, exhibited in museum retrospectives and galleries, like the show of still lifes now on view at Gagosian in Chelsea. It seems impossible there is anything new left to see.

headline: Spinning Goes Boutique
text: SPINNING, the trademarked indoor cycling program created 18 years ago, has obviously surpassed trend status. A staple at many gyms, the music-and-mantra-driven cardio cocktail is particularly appealing to New York cyclists because it provides a safe way to burn calories and ride with abandon without crashing into a U.P.S. truck.

headline: Seeing (and Playing) Music of Everyday Life
text: The time-based arts have certainly expanded their foothold in New York’s major museums over the last few months. In February the Guggenheim’s rotunda was transformed into a highly compressed life’s journey by the ever-austere Tino Seghal and a crew of specially trained volunteers. As visitors walked up the ramp, they were handed off to progressively older and increasingly voluble and philosophic guides. The empty spiral became, literally, a six-tiered mortal coil.

headline: Emmy Nominations Validate Broadcast Gambles
text: Fox took a big risk last year with “Glee,” a campy musical comedy about a cast of high school misfits. On Thursday that risk paid off 19 times over as “Glee” picked up that many Emmy nominations, including nods for best comedy series and in all four acting categories.

headline: Postscript
text: The Orchard obtained a liquor license in 2007, and serves wine, beer and cocktails. The restaurant is no longer B.Y.O.B.

headline: Couture Scorecard | Valentino Wins!
text: What is it with X-ray chic this couture season? And Scorecard doesn’t mean fashion’s perennial jutting-clavicles thing — though Jean Paul Gaultier’s runway-cum-burlesque show did put Dita Von Teese’s on fine display in a bedazzled boned corset. On the final day of shows, Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli finally sunk their teeth in at Valentino, trading in the founder’s signature va-va-voom for a black gazar micromini-clad vampiric coven. We’re looking at you, K-Stew.

headline: The Late Great Charles Schwab Mansion
text: ALMOST everyone in New York knows the Frick Collection, at Fifth Avenue and 70th Street, and the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, at Fifth and 91st, the pair of stupendous mansions built by the steel titans Henry Clay Frick and Andrew Carnegie. But their architectural majesty was only two-thirds of a ferric triad, the last the house of Charles M. Schwab, the Carnegie protégé who became the head of United States Steel and then Bethlehem Steel.

headline: ‘Christian Marclay: Festival’
text: Photos from a new exhibit at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: NYC Restaurant Week, an Adventure Course in Alley Pond Park and Amateur Astronomy
text: New York can make a hungry miser’s dreams come true. NYC Restaurant Week begins on Monday, and that means meals at hundreds of the best restaurants are available for a steal. The fixed prices can buy a fancy lunch at Blue Fin for $24.07 and an elegant dinner at the Red Cat for $35. Or just stop by the Restaurant Week Truck, which will be serving summer soups from restaurants like A Voce and Delmonico’s for just $6 a bowl. Visit nycgo.com/restaurantweek for a list of restaurants, to make reservations or to locate the truck. (Through July 25; the truck operates through July 16; prices do not include drinks, tax or tip.)

headline: Quality Time With Dad on the Edge of a Cliff
text: SURROUNDED by three teenage girls and their fathers, a rock climbing guide calls out the ABC’s of the sport: A is for anchor; B is for buckle; C, carabiner; and so on, until she gets to G and H.

headline: Resources for Figuring Out Medicare
text: My father, who is about to turn 65, is trying to make sense of the Medicare materials he has received in the mail so he can make the right decisions about coverage.

headline: Pill Maker Declines to Specify Size of a Recall
text: When Procter & Gamble announced a recent recall of some Scope mouthwash with defective child-resistant caps, it disclosed the extent of the recall  35,000 bottles  in a government news release.

headline: G.E. Has a ‘Capital’ Idea
text: Can a warm and fuzzy, people-focused advertising campaign help restore the reputation of the bruised financial unit of General Electric?

headline: I.M.F. Says Growth to Continue, but at Slower Pace
text: HONG KONG  The world economy will grow faster than expected this year, but the recovery remains overshadowed by major risks and the pace of growth is likely to slow, the International Monetary Fund said Thursday in its latest assessment of the global economy.

headline: Top European Court Rules Against Portugal in Dispute Involving Telefónica
text: MADRID  Europe’s highest court ruled Thursday that the Portuguese government had used an illegal method to block an attempt by Telefónica of Spain to buy full control of a Brazilian wireless venture it holds with Portugal Telecom.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: “The soldiers from Task Force Thor have one of the most dangerous and boring jobs in southern Afghanistan,” Ben Gilbert reported in February, in the segment “On I.E.D. Patrol in Afghanistan,” on Public Radio International. “They drive up and down the roads at seven miles per hour, looking for I.E.D.’s. Their massive armored vehicles are equipped with ground-penetrating radar, radio jammers and cameras mounted on long mechanical arms.” At that time, patrols were finding an improvised explosive device every four or five days.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘JOHN TARTAGLIA’S IMAGINOCEAN’

headline: Downtown Dining
text: Restaurant critics of The New York Times recommend these Lower East Side spots:

headline: Film Series and Movies Listings
text: Movies

headline: To the Ramparts of Comedy, Playfully Profane
text: If there’s a definitive illustration of the adage that whatever doesn’t kill you makes you stronger, it may be the early years of George Carlin’s stand-up-comedy career.

headline: A Sharp Focus on Design When the Package Is Part of the Product
text: SALES of facial tissue during the cold and flu season are, appropriately enough, feverish, but not so during the summer. In the four weeks that ended July 12, 2009, for example, revenue for the products totaled $57.8 million, compared with $92.4 million in the four weeks ending Jan. 24, 2010, a difference of nearly 60 percent, according to SymphonyIRI Group, a market research company whose data does not include Wal-Mart sales.

headline: Pinch Hitters At Tanglewood
text: LENOX, Mass.

headline: Secrecy Another Echo of Cold War Swaps
text: Update | Friday | 10:08 a.m. My colleagues Nicholas Kulish, Peter Baker and Ellen Barry report that “Russian and American officials traded prisoners in the bright sunlight on the tarmac of Vienna’s international airport on Friday.” After the exchange, “The planes soon took off again, presumably heading back to Russia and the United States in a coda fitting of an espionage novel.”

headline: A Half-Empty Feeling as Stoudemire Signs Up
text: On the Madison Square Garden floor was a small stage, and on that stage was a table with four chairs. In one of those chairs was a supreme athlete, one of the best players in the N.B.A. The player inspired grandiose statements.

headline: Meet the Sperm Donor: Modern Family Ties
text: I’m tempted to start this review by falling back on a tried-and-true movie critic formulation and saying something like “Lisa Cholodenko’s  ‘Kids Are All Right’ is the best comedy about an American family since ...” Since what? Precedents and grounds for comparison seem to be lacking, so I may have to let the superlative stand unqualified for now.

headline: Charming Village, Check; Quirky Residents, You Bet
text: Stephen King’s novella “The Colorado Kid” features two old men who run a small newspaper in Maine, a female summer intern and a 25-year-old mystery. In “Haven,” a new television series ever so slightly based on the novella, the two newspapermen (now brothers) have become comic relief, and the young woman has taken center stage. Instead of a reporter she’s an F.B.I. agent who’s touchy (she’s an orphan) but vulnerable (she reads young-adult novels).

headline: Borders Crossed, Moved and Defied
text: The words “border,” “frontier,” “frontera” (Spanish for border or frontier) and “barrera” (barrier) flashed on a video screen between images of a chain-link fence. It was the Central Park SummerStage concert on Wednesday night headlined by Nortec Collective Presents: Bostich and Fussible, who are electronica conceptualists from Tijuana.

headline: Lunar Toons and Cookie Capers
text: Is there a meaningful distinction to be drawn between exercising the imagination and just making up a bunch of stuff? When it comes to children at play, probably not: the pleasure of inventiveness matters more than the quality of the particular inventions. But children’s entertainment, made by grown-ups at great expense in anticipation of even greater profit, is another matter. The difference between inspired creation and frantic pretending is the difference between magic and mediocrity, between art and junk, or to cite a conveniently available example, between “Toy Story 3” and “Despicable Me.”

headline: A Co-op Bought With ‘Eloisa Money’
text: The author known as Eloisa James, a k a Mary Bly, and her husband have bought a $1.7 million apartment in Morningside Heights.

headline: Will Conan O’Brien (Ex-NBC) Win Some Emmys (Shown on NBC)?
text: The Emmy Awards just became must-see TV.

headline: Collecting the Relics Of a Poetic Year
text: EVERY few years poetry, like jazz or punk rock, is pre-emptively eulogized by pessimists. Contemporary culture moves quickly, and the poet conjured by the collective imagination  brooding and solitary, with a notebook and a portrait of Dylan Thomas tucked under the pillow  is rarely clutching a Smartphone or trawling Facebook.

headline: Lower East Side Tale, Refracted Nine Times
text: Heaven knows the tired old New York art world could use a fresh story or two. This summer it gets one, secondhand, in  “Lush Life,”  a big and unusually ingenious group show spread over nine galleries, all but one on the Lower East Side.

headline: Interpreting ‘Lush Life’
text: A map and photos of the nine-gallery show inspired by Richard Price’s novel “Lush Life.”

headline: Senate Panel Near Agreement on Bill to Roll Back NASA Changes
text: NEW ORLEANS — Republican and Democratic leaders on the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation are moving toward an authorization bill that would reverse large swaths of President Obama’s proposed changes to NASA’s human space flight program, a ranking Republican involved in the talks confirmed.

headline: Dance New Amsterdam Faces Possible Eviction From Its Home
text: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, faces possible eviction on Wednesday from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway because it owes more than half a million dollars in rent, Catherine Peila, the executive director, said Wednesday. “With the high rent and the recession, we didn’t earn enough money to pay the rent,” Ms. Peila said in an interview. “The arts community should really be revved up: we serve 8,000 students, we employ 250 people a year, and we moved to Lower Manhattan to revitalize the area.” In a statement released Wednesday, the organization, founded in 1984, said it wanted to maintain its mission of teaching dance, commissioning choreographers and presenting performances. It is seeking a meeting with Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month, and with city agencies to work out an agreement for lower rent to match current market rates and for a nonprofit tax abatement, Ms Peila said. A representative of Fram Realty could not be reached for comment. Over the years, Dance New Amsterdam has presented Mark Morris, Urban Bush Women and the South African troupe Sduduzo Ka-Mbili/Juxtapower (with Charmaine Trotman, above), among other artists.

headline: Swisher Edges Youkilis for All-Star Berth
text: SEATTLE — Nick Swisher’s enthusiastic multimedia campaign for a berth on the American League All-Star team paid off Thursday, when he narrowly defeated Kevin Youkilis of Boston to earn the final spot on the A.L. roster. On Twitter, where Baron Davis, Jessica Alba, Ivanka Trump and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg endorsed his candidacy, Swisher expressed his appreciation: “THANK YOU!!!”

headline: Coming ABC Cop Show Drops Its Documentary-Style Look
text: ABC is stripping the fake-documentary feeling out of “Detroit 1-8-7,” its coming cop drama, New York Magazine reported on Wednesday. When the series was announced in May, ABC said it would be similar to the sitcoms “The Office” and “Modern Family,” which have characters talking directly to the camera, as in a documentary. But the network recently decided to reshoot some scenes in the first episode so that there were no more nods to an imaginary camera crew. ABC was worried that the style would put distance between the characters and the audience, but real-life events also had an effect. Just days after the series was announced, The Detroit News reported that the city’s mayor, Dave Bing, had banned camera crews from riding along with police officers. The decision followed the death of a 7-year-old Detroit girl during a police raid being filmed by the A&E cable channel. “We’re trying to do a show that’s realistic,” an executive producer of the show, Jason Richman, told the magazine. “And we suddenly found ourselves with a premise that would no longer be viable.” ABC has another fake documentary this fall, a relationship drama called “My Generation.”

headline: ‘Hot in Cleveland’ Is Renewed
text: As if Betty White needed any more good news, it looks as if she’ll have enough work to stay busy to the ripe age of 89. On Wednesday, the cable channel TV Land said it was ordering a second season of “Hot in Cleveland,” its hit comedy series about a dithering N.B.A. superstar who can’t decide which multimillion-dollar offer he wants to accept  wait, scratch that: “Hot in Cleveland” stars Valerie Bertinelli, Jane Leeves and Wendie Malick as women who move to the Rust Belt from Los Angeles, and Ms. White, above, as their saucy landlady. The debut episode of its current 10-episode season on June 16 drew 4.75 million viewers. TV Land said the second season would be 20 episodes, with production to begin in October and a premiere tentatively scheduled for January.

headline: Ambiq Micro Wins Another Business Competition
text: Last week at the 2010 D.F.J.-Cisco Global Business Plan Competition, Ambiq Micro, a microchip technology start-up, won a $250,000 investment from Draper Fisher Jurvetson, the venture capital firm, and Cisco. So far this year, according to Scott Hanson, chief executive, Ambiq Micro has taken in $333,000 in awards and cash grants from business plan competitions.

headline: Fincher Movie About Facebook Will Open New York Film Festival
text: “The Social Network,” David Fincher’s much anticipated movie about the creation of Facebook, has been selected for opening night at the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday. “The Social Network,” is directed by Mr. Fincher (“Zodiac,” “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button”), left, with a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin (“The West Wing”) adapted from Ben Mezrich’s book “The Accidental Billionaires.” Starting in the long-ago year of 2003, it tells how the Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg (played in the film by Jesse Eisenberg) helped hatch an idea that became the wildly popular Facebook Web site  and the complications that its success quickly yielded. Scott Rudin, a producer of the film, said it was told in an “All About Eve” style, from multiple points of view, including the perspectives of other young entrepreneurs who sued Mr. Zuckerberg, saying the site was their idea. “Everybody believes they’re right,” Mr. Rudin said in a telephone interview. “But the movie leaves you to make up your own mind about what you feel about how Facebook was founded.” The film festival will have the premiere on Sept. 24, before the movie is released Oct. 1. The festival runs through Oct. 10, with additional films to be announced.

headline: Break in London-Brooklyn Bridge
text: The final installment of the Bridge Project, a three-year collaboration between the Brooklyn Academy of Music and two London theatrical stalwarts, the Old Vic Theater and Sam Mendes’s Neal Street Productions, has been postponed a year, until 2012, because of scheduling issues, said Jackie Green, a press representative for the Bridge Project. The ambitious project made its debut in 2009 at the academy with Mr. Mendes directing a single cast of British and American actors in productions of Shakespeare’s “Winter’s Tale” and Chekhov’s “Cherry Orchard” that later traveled to Britain, Singapore, New Zealand, Spain, Germany and Greece. The second installment, featuring “As You Like It” and “The Tempest,” was done in Brooklyn this year. Mr. Mendes directed the productions, currently in repertory at the Old Vic, where Kevin Spacey is artistic director. The plays for the third round have not been announced, but Mr. Mendes, also a film director, has a busy schedule directing a new stage musical of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” in 2011 and “King Lear” for the Royal National Theater in 2012.

headline: Turning Swords Into Slapsticks
text: Behold the mighty samurai, standing tall and vigilant, their hard faces fixed in forbidding scowls. Tremble as they draw their long swords and assume their martial positions. Watch as they stumble and fall, shouting at one another like forcibly separated school bullies, after having had their ankles tied to those of three other men. Observe them as, still solemn-faced, they join a ritualistic chorus line, dancing delightfully across the stage to what sounds like accordion tango music.

headline: As Guinea Moves Forward, the Old Order Has Its Defenders
text: CONAKRY, Guinea  History is sometimes in sharpest focus from the loser’s perspective. An unprecedented free election here last month set people dancing in the street, but the mood was more measured in the quiet backrooms of those now on the wrong side of history’s cusp.

headline: ‘Talent’ Proves the Ticket for NBC
text: For the second night in a row, NBC scored highest in prime time as its reality competition “America’s Got Talent” delivered the largest audience on Wednesday, 11.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC led not only at 9 but also in the hour preceding “Talent,” as its game show “Minute to Win It” edged ahead of its mostly rerun competitors at 8, drawing 6.9 million viewers. Fox ranked second with a two-hour “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10 (6.3 million). During the 10 p.m. time slot, NBC’s rerun of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (5.7) finished just behind CBS’s repeat of “CSI: NY” (6.8 million) but ahead of ABC’s rerun of “Castle” (4.3 million). CBS finished third over all for the night, while ABC was fourth. Both networks broadcast all-repeat lineups.

headline: Haute Couture 101
text: The day after the couture shows is typically when magazines do their photo shoots, snagging the dresses they want to tell a story and often working around a house’s client schedule. There is something of a church-and-state divide in couture, with clients in private appointments with a saleswoman on the couture side of a house — separate salon, separate entrance — and editors giving their interpretations of the clothes.

headline: First Winner in the James Sweepstakes
text: People may complain this evening about LeBron James’s decision to choose among his free-agent suitors via a television special, but the staff of the Boys & Girls Clubs of America will not be among them.

headline: Theater Listings: July 9 — 15
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Even in the Rising Heat, She Stays Pretty Cool
text: Those who need a break from the romantic travails of Bella Swan  and who like a best-seller-list tie-in for their moviegoing  will welcome the release of “The Girl Who Played With Fire,” the second installment in the Swedish trilogy based on Stieg Larsson’s novels. Hollywood remakes are not far off, but what Anglophone actress could match the intense rightness of Noomi Rapace for the role of Lisbeth Salander? Ellen Page? Carey Mulligan (listed as “rumored” on the IMDB Web site)? Miley Cyrus?

headline: Bloggingheads: Tolerable Taliban?
text: Robert Wright of Bloggingheads.tv and Robert Kagan of the Carnegie Endowment debate withdrawal from Afghanistan.

headline: LeBron Live: Blogging the Decision
text: Andrew Keh and Thomas Kaplan of The New York Times, along with Neil Paine, an analyst with Basketball-Reference.com, will provide updates and analysis of tonight’s announcement by LeBron James.

headline: Fighting ‘Hard’ and ‘Soft’ Counterinsurgency on Holy Ground
text: YAHYA KHEL, Afghanistan — American troops in Afghanistan’s Paktika Province called in a helicopter strike against Taliban fighters who ambushed them here Tuesday night, killing several. The missile strike narrowly avoided doing serious damage to a mosque where some of the fighters were hiding, underlining both the risks and the potential benefits of using air power to support ground troops.

headline: In South Africa, the Chosen Few
text: In a society where merely playing soccer can lead women to be accused of homosexuality, a group of women in South Africa has come together despite threats of violence and even death.

headline: Beverly Sills’s Co-op on the Market
text: OPERA singers aren’t generally considered celebrities in the United States, but Beverly Sills certainly fits the description. She had a renowned voice and was an unyielding advocate for the arts  as well as a guest host on “The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.”

headline: She Had Us at Privyet
text: So much remains a mystery about the duplicitous and racy New York life of Anna Chapman, so let this be heard loud and clear: Do svidanya, Anya. My uzhe skuchayem po tebe.

headline: Stone Phillips Buys an ‘Oasis in the Sky’
text: STONE PHILLIPS was a co-host of “Dateline NBC” for some 15 years. He brought a widely discussed gravitas to his role as anchor until he left the show in 2007, a victim of the network’s budget cuts.

headline: U.S. to Provide $25 Million to Help Buy AIDS Drugs
text: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Thursday that she would provide $25 million more to help states buy life-saving medications for people with H.I.V. or AIDS.

headline: Like Shooting Humans in a Jungly Alien Barrel
text: “Certainly there is no hunting like the hunting of man, and those who have hunted armed men long enough and liked it, never really care for anything else thereafter.” In “Predators,” that silly pronouncement by Ernest Hemingway is solemnly repeated by Royce (Adrien Brody), a grim, humorless mercenary who finds himself mysteriously transported to an alien hell.

headline: In the Coils of Big Copper
text: “Here, as sudden and surprising as a lost city of legendary times, was a metropolis of nowhere: nearly a hundred thousand people atop the earth’s mineral crown, with nothing else around but the Rocky Mountains and the witnessing sky.” So observes Morrie Morgan, the hero of Ivan Doig’s new novel, “Work Song” (and of an earlier one, “The Whistling Season”), upon his arrival in Butte, Mont., in the postwar heyday of 1919. The Western landscape is a strong component in the book, yet this is one of the few passages that allude to Montana’s Big Sky. Instead, Doig concentrates on interior ­spaces: the majestic town library, the modest dining room of the fetching widow Grace Faraday’s boarding house, and the most deeply interior settings of all — the copper mines, where men labor under perilous conditions. Butte suffers from a violent history, and the mining industry plagues daily life. Grace’s husband died in a mining fire, and her boarding house frequently shakes from underground ­dynamite. Poverty threatens to overtake the whole city: one kid is so skinny his nickname is “Russian Famine.”

headline: To Their Own Beat
text: If you’re like me, you tend to regard plot summaries as a necessary boredom at best. They’re the flyover country between a reviewer’s landing strips of judgment, revealing almost nothing about the way a book actually works, almost nothing about why it succeeds or fails. If plot were the crucial measure, there’d be no difference between a story about the fish that got away and “Moby-Dick.” Reading such summaries (or writing them) is usually as beguiling as listening to some addled fan of  “Lost”  explain what happened on that botched rune of a show.

headline: Too Young for Driver’s Licenses, but With Full-Throttle Ambitions
text: “Racing Dreams,” Marshall Curry’s absorbing documentary examination of the world of professional auto racing, comes at its subject craftily: from below. Instead of profiling the superstars of stock-car racing, glorifying the sport and relating its history, it concentrates on three up-and-coming competitors in its unofficial Little League, the World Karting Association.

headline: When It Comes to Stats, Soccer Seldom Counts
text: People in soccer have historically paid little attention to statistics, arguing that the only way to judge players is to see them in action. Often, the only numbers associated with the beautiful game are the score and the time on the clock  if you can find them.

headline: Revisiting the Irascible RV Pitchman Who Went Viral
text: Why the fuss? That question may cross your mind while watching “Winnebago Man,” a small, mildly entertaining documentary whose director, Ben Steinbauer, chases down Jack Rebney, a retired salesman of recreational vehicles. Five years ago, Mr. Rebney’s profane caught-on-video rants posted on YouTube made him an Internet sensation.

headline: Photo Replay: July 8
text: A view of the day in sports, with long jumps in Switzerland, high temperatures at the Tour de France and high drama in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: A Knuckleballer Keeps His Fingers Crossed
text: Baseball has tried to reject Robert Alan Dickey. It has stolen his money. It has forced him to relearn everything he knew about how to do his job. It has ignored him when he succeeded, stung him when he failed. It has shaken him by the shoulders, imploring him to quit and chase his fallback career as an English professor.

headline: The Battle of the Teammates Dominates Talk in Silverstone
text: SILVERTSTONE, England — I don’t know if this is a mark of having a hand on the pulse of the story, or if it just shows how unoriginal I am. (Please no flames. :-)) Whatever it is, for the past several days I have been preparing my two-page special report for the preview to the British Grand Prix this weekend, and my main story is about the tension and dynamics between the top teammates in the Formula One series as we head into the halfway point of the year.

headline: Maoists Rebelling in India
text: Ananth Narayan Mahadevan’s “Red Alert: The War Within” deserves credit for veering off the beaten Bollywood path to take on an unusual subject  India’s Maoist rebels, the Naxalites. But the film, much of it set in a rebel camp in Andhra Pradesh, seems torn between two storytelling modes: episodic with a documentary flavor and action-driven pulp. It makes a hash of both.

headline: Media Executives Flock to Sun Valley Conference
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho  Gulfstreams and Falcons. Buffett and Brin. Angling for trout and ice skating to “Bad Romance.”

headline: An Amateur Tames a Tricky Open Course
text: OAKMONT, Pa.  As the amateur Kelli Shean’s name shot up the leader board at the United States Women’s Open on Thursday, spectators exchanged quizzical glances.

headline: San Francisco Is Possible Host for Cup
text: San Francisco is the only United States city being considered to host the next America’s Cup yacht race in 2013 or 2014, the defending champion BMW Oracle Racing team said. Four European locations that were not identified remain in contention.

headline: Tough Time for Zombie Bait
text: Knowing that, in horror movies, the worst abominations are usually in the attic, the characters in the Spanish film “[REC] 2” spend most of their time charging in that direction. Picking up mere minutes after “[REC]” (and its lesser American remake, “Quarantine”) left off, this hyperventilating sequel follows a small paramilitary team into a sealed Barcelona apartment building whose residents have succumbed to a mysterious, rage-inducing virus.

headline: Judge Topples U.S. Rejection of Gay Unions
text: BOSTON  A federal judge in Massachusetts found Thursday that a law barring the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriage is unconstitutional, ruling that gay and lesbian couples deserve the same federal benefits as heterosexual couples.

headline: Greece Approves Pension Overhaul Despite Protests
text: ATHENS  Greece took a big step toward overhauling its debt-plagued economy on Thursday by forcing through a pension bill that would sharply pare down the country’s welfare state by increasing the retirement age and reducing benefits.

headline: Goal for High School Smoking Is Unmet
text: The nation has failed to reach its 2010 health goal of reducing high school smoking to 16 percent, federal officials said Thursday in a report calling for a resurgence of antismoking advertising to counter the tobacco industry’s $12 billion marketing campaign.

headline: Where Roots and Soccer Intersect
text: In this city where at least one-fourth of the population traces its origins to Spanish-speaking lands, it seems reasonable to assume that Spain will be the people’s favorite against the Netherlands for the World Cup soccer championship on Sunday.

headline: Merck Plans to Lay Off About 15% of Workers
text: The $41 billion merger last year of the drug giants Merck and Schering-Plough has a human cost for pharmaceutical industry employees.

headline: City Savors a High of 89 as a 4-Day Heat Wave Ends
text: Few New Yorkers experienced the heat wave the way Robert Najdek did: out on a blistering street in Flushing, Queens, from 7 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. daily, tearing up the old roadway so that a new one can replace it, in triple-digit temperatures that shattered meteorological records.

headline: Biggest Defaulters on Mortgages Are the Rich
text: LOS ALTOS, Calif.  No need for tears, but the well-off are losing their master suites and saying goodbye to their wine cellars.

headline: Questions Arise About Executive’s Pay at Dodgers Charity
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers paid one of their highest-ranking executives more than $400,000 from the team’s charity in 2007, which accounted for one-quarter of the foundation’s nearly $1.6 million budget that year  compensation more in line with overseeing a $100 million charity.

headline: U.S. Says Renminbi Still Needs to Rise
text: The United States Treasury Department says China’s currency, the renminbi, “remains undervalued” and needs to rise more, but it stopped short of branding the country a currency manipulator.

headline: Miami in Pinstripes: the New Evil Empire
text: In the moment LeBron James uttered the words “South Beach” on Thursday night in front of a national television audience, the country witnessed the birth of an Evil Empire  the Yankees of professional basketball  with that slick-haired hombre, Pat Riley, at the helm.

headline: The Pride and Prejudice of ‘Local’
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  Eric Bechard is perfecting the new provincialism.

headline: Smugglers in Iraq Blunt Sanctions Against Iran
text: PENJWIN, Iraq — Even as the United States imposes new sanctions on Iran, one of the biggest gaps in the American strategy is on full display here in Iraq, where hundreds of millions of dollars in crude oil and refined products are smuggled over the scenic mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan every year.

headline: Public and Private: Restoring a Montana Spring Creek
text: A couple of weeks ago, I walked along a spring creek in the upper Madison Valley, just south of the town of Ennis, Mont. As my guide, Jeff Laszlo, explained, the creek is one of the unnamed tributaries of the Madison River, fed by innumerable springs along the valley’s rich bottomland. The creek meanders for miles before it reaches the Madison, gaining water, providing spawning grounds for fish and invaluable wetland habitat for birds. I looked on in disbelief, because the section we were hiking  nearly eight miles of cold, clear waters  did not exist before 2005.

headline: Britain’s Budget Pain
text: We’ve found a lot to like in the first two months of Britain’s new coalition government.

headline: Ringo at 70
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Medium Is the Medium
text: Recently, book publishers got some good news. Researchers gave 852 disadvantaged students 12 books (of their own choosing) to take home at the end of the school year. They did this for three successive years.

headline: A.I.G. Bailout and the Fed
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pity the Poor C.E.O.’s
text: Job creation has been disappointing, but first-quarter corporate profits were up 44 percent from a year earlier. Consumers are nervous, but the Dow, which was below 8,000 on the day President Obama was inaugurated, is now over 10,000. In a rational universe, American business would be very happy with Mr. Obama.

headline: Loophole May Have Aided Theft of Classified Data
text: WASHINGTON  The soldier accused of downloading a huge trove of secret data from military computers in Iraq appears to have exploited a loophole in Defense Department security to copy thousands of files onto compact discs over a six-month period. In at least one instance, according to those familiar with the inquiry, the soldier smuggled highly classified data out of his intelligence unit on a disc disguised as a music CD by Lady Gaga.

headline: Opening a Big Store in China, Apple Remains a Market Underdog
text: SHANGHAI  Although Apple is widely admired in China, most fans of its products here have been buying their iPhones, iPods and Mac computers from smugglers who operate through underground electronics markets.

headline: Officer Guilty in Killing That Inflamed Oakland
text: A white Bay Area transit officer was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter on Thursday by a Los Angeles jury in the shooting death of an unarmed black man on Jan. 1, 2009, ending a closely watched trial that percolated with racial tension and cries for peace in the city of Oakland, Calif., where the killing occurred.

headline: The Best and the Brightest
text: New York continues to introduce new lampposts. Here’s a look at some of the city’s iconic designs.

headline: Chatting With Google: China, Apple and More
text: 9:49 p.m. | Updated SUN VALLEY, Idaho — In an Allen & Company conference chock-full of assorted media moguls, it seems there’s one thread unifying them all.

headline: ‘Grim Sleeper’ Arrest Fans Debate on DNA Use
text: LOS ANGELES  The arrest in the case of the “Grim Sleeper”  a serial killer who terrorized South Los Angeles for two decades  has put one of the hottest controversies in American law enforcement to its first major test.

headline: With Recovery Continuing, European Banks Leave Rates Alone
text: The European Central Bank on Thursday left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, and its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, expressed cautious optimism that Europe’s sovereign debt crisis was easing and that the euro area economy was growing faster than expected.

headline: Fire Damages a Condo Building in the East Village
text: A fire roared across the roof and top floor of an upscale condominium building in the East Village on Thursday afternoon, temporarily displacing residents, shutting local streets and blanketing the neighborhood in thick plumes of smoke, the Fire Department said.

headline: Fleshing Out the Lives of Others
text: OFTEN maligned yet ever popular, the biopic is surely the most reductive of movie genres. All biographers face the task of wrangling the unruly particulars and generally undramatic shape of a life and a career into a coherent narrative. Writers working on doorstop-size volumes find this hard enough; a two-hour movie wrestles with the same challenges more acutely  and is much more likely to fail.

headline: Blunt General Appointed to Lead Forces in Mideast
text: WASHINGTON  A four-star Marine general known equally for blunt speech, combat prowess and understanding counterinsurgency warfare will be nominated to command American forces across the Middle East, officials said Thursday.

headline: Draft Avoids Condemning North Korea in Ship Attack
text: UNITED NATIONS  Key Security Council members have agreed on a statement, presented to the council on Thursday, that condemns the sinking of a South Korean warship that left 46 sailors dead, but avoids singling out North Korea for the attack.

headline: Gay Marriage: Whose Decision?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Promise of Cleaner Air
text: The Obama administration has proposed new air-quality rules that represent another important step in the long, litigious struggle to clean up older power plants. But there is still a considerable distance to go before Americans, especially those in large cities, can enjoy truly healthy air as envisioned by the Clean Air Act of 1970. That will require the administration to keep its promise to seek even tougher standards over the next two years, including restrictions on regulated pollutants like mercury.

headline: Western Sahara: The Moroccan Ambassador’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Should We Ease Curbs on Travel to Cuba?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Pope’s Duty
text: When rolling scandal forced the American Catholic bishops conference to take action against pedophile priests, the prelates issued a tough policy requiring accused child molesters be reported immediately to secular authorities. This mandate finally acknowledged that crimes against children should take priority over bureaucratic church policies that served to cloak rogue priests and bishops in a fog of ecclesiastical evasion.

headline: Israel Vows to ‘Take Risks’ in Talks With Palestinians
text: Declaring that he intended to “confound the critics and the skeptics,” an upbeat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told an audience of foreign policy experts in New York on Thursday that he was ready to begin direct peace talks with the Palestinians “next week” or even sooner. “Just get on with it,” he said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 8, 2010

headline: The Meek Emerge as the Mighty Fall
text: The poor are teaching the rich a lesson. It used to be that the world’s less developed nations were the problem children — giving plutocrats too much power while running irresponsibly large budget deficits and failing to overcome deep internal imbalances. Now, rich countries look like the new poor.

headline: In the July Heat, a Cold-War Comeback
text: “IN Russia,” the French director Christian Carion said, “there are no coincidences.” But there are at the movies: When Mr. Carion’s espionage drama, “Farewell,” opens in American theaters on July 23, the movie, set in the waning years of the cold war, will do so opposite the big-ticket studio movie “Salt,” in which Angelina Jolie plays a C.I.A. officer accused of being a Russian spy, and “Countdown to Zero,” a documentary about the nuclear perils of the post-Soviet era. And in a well-timed twist that carries its own whiff of cold-war-era conspiracy, all three films will come out in the aftermath of the arrests of 11 people accused of being Russian agents and said to have been living and working in the United States for more than a decade.

headline: After Quake, Haitians With Dreams Look for an Exit
text: ANSE À GALETS, Haiti  Kesia Damas complains every day about losing her favorite teacher. Mr. B introduced her to drama, taught her art and inspired her to dream of a film career far more glamorous than this dusty village.

headline: Pitched Blade
text: And in the ENDThe love you takeIs equal to the love you make.

headline: Love and Other Contradictions
text: Verboten!

headline: Swisher Wins Vote by Fans, and With It Last A.L. Spot
text: SEATTLE  To take his mind off the competition for the American League’s final All-Star berth, Nick Swisher tried sleeping late on Friday morning. Judging by his Twitter feed, he was not so successful.

headline: Election to Replace Byrd Gets Official’s Approval
text: WASHINGTON  West Virginia’s attorney general has determined that Gov. Joe Manchin III can call a special election this year to fill the vacancy created by the death of Senator Robert C. Byrd, clearing the way for a contest in November to fill the remaining two years of Mr. Byrd’s term.

headline: Scientists Criticize Study on Genetics of Old Age
text: A study on the genetics of centenarians that was published last week in Science, a leading scientific journal, has come under criticism from geneticists who say it has obvious weaknesses, is probably incorrect and should not have been published in a premier journal.

headline: Rulings Raise Doubts on Policy on Transfer of Yemenis
text: WASHINGTON  Six months after President Obama halted all transfers of Guantánamo Bay detainees to Yemen, the moratorium is coming under escalating pressure from federal judges  raising doubts about its sustainability.

headline: Vietnamese Hoard U.S. Dollars as a Hedge Against Inflation
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  The Ha Tam jewelry shop here sells foreign currency the way a filling station sells gasoline. So it was only seconds after pulling in on his motorbike that Quan Phan had swapped a fistful of Vietnamese dong for a neat stack of $100 bills  United States $100 bills, to be precise.

headline: Awaiting the Call Outside an Unlikely Epicenter
text: GREENWICH, Conn  Carrying optimism and a lawn chair, Mike Correa arrived at the Boys & Girls Club here more than 12 hours before LeBron James announced his decision.

headline: Only Winning Heat Can Attract Breezy Fans
text: MIAMI  In deciding to take his high-flying act to the Miami Heat to join Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh in remaking the franchise, LeBron James needs to know that bringing another title to a city that tasted one just a few years ago will be only the beginning  for him and all of South Florida.

headline: N.B.A.’s Season of Suspense Ends
text: With one dramatic declaration, lasting 16 words and only a few seconds, LeBron James shook the sporting world and the N.B.A. on Thursday, announcing that he would play next season for the Miami Heat.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,143 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: The Russian Agents’ Real Identities
text: These are the real names of the Russian agents, which they provided to a federal judge in New York on Thursday, and the aliases that they used.

headline: Lots of Twitter Speculation, if Not Proper Punctuation
text: Like most celebrity-fueled minidramas, “LeBron James Free Agency Mania” was played out with maddening thoroughness on Twitter.

headline: Court Rejects Moratorium on Drilling in the Gulf
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Thursday turned down the Obama administration’s effort to enforce a six-month moratorium on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Day 79: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Obama Presses BP on Procedures to Recover More Oil

headline: French News Web Site Shakes Sarkozy Camp
text: PARIS  At dinner parties there is talk of a French Watergate, but with at least one big difference: the would-be Woodwards and Bernsteins behind the biggest scandal to hit the presidency of Nicolas Sarkozy work on the Web instead of at a newspaper.

headline: Portland's New Provincialism
text: Portland is confronting the contradictions that come when keeping it local makes for global success.

headline: ESPN Gets Choice, Not Interview, Right
text: No one at ESPN had more at stake in being right on Thursday than Chris Broussard, the network’s N.B.A. reporter. Everything in ESPN’s coverage of LeBron James’s decision-making flowed from Broussard’s claim that James would bolt from the Cleveland Cavaliers, spurn the Knicks, Nets and Bulls, and sign with Miami.

headline: Columbia Scientists Prepare for a Threat: A Dirty Bomb
text: During World War II, scientists from the Center for Radiological Research in Manhattan toiled on the Manhattan Project, working feverishly to develop an atomic bomb before Nazi Germany did.

headline: Nine Stores Fined for Propping Doors Open in Heat
text: Nine stores in Manhattan and the Bronx have been hit with $200 fines for leaving their doors open on hot days in the hope that the escaping cool air would lure sweaty customers. They are the first to be fined as part of a law enacted in 2008.

headline: Council Cuts Health Plan That Helped Poor People
text: A program that for a decade helped New York City’s poor and elderly navigate their way through insurance problems  and that became a model for a similar federal program  has become a casualty of city budget cuts, an administrator of the program said on Thursday.

headline: Creamer’s Comeback Reaches the Open
text: OAKMONT, Pa. — Knockdown shots and chips were beyond Paula Creamer’s grasp, literally, after she had surgery on stretched ligaments in her left thumb at the end of March.

headline: A Dining Club for Those With Adventurous Stomachs
text: For Mark Garrison, the freshly dismembered octopus squirming on the plate was the biggest challenge. For Zach Zaman, it was the filleted water bug before him. And for Lauren Seebacher, it could have been the cod sperm.

headline: Anti-Car Crusade, Fueled by Gulf Spill, Takes a Station Hostage
text: The Arco gas station at Fell and Divisadero Streets in San Francisco has become a flashpoint for two issues that inflame local passions.

headline: A Movement in Museums and on the Street
text: Observant locals may have noticed a quirky phenomenon lately: poles supporting traffic signs and streetlights that have been encased in brightly colored knitted covers, like dogs in winter sweaters.

headline: The Ecology of Foreclosures
text: Two years ago, when I began writing about the housing crisis, I got to know a bungalow in Sulphur Springs, a Tampa, Fla., neighborhood that was famous in the 1920s for its sprawling oaks, giant water slide and shopping arcade, but which is now a ghetto. The oaks are still mostly there, but the water slide is long gone, the arcade a parking lot for a dog track. Suffer Springs is what a lot of folks call it these days.

headline: Despite a Rare Pedigree, Plan for Affordable Housing Collapses
text: The deal was brokered recently in private by an unusual team of rivals, including one of San Francisco’s most prominent developers and a vociferous housing activist. The result, by all accounts, was unprecedented: an estimated $50 million for affordable housing in the city each year.

headline: Police Unit Eliminated in Oakland
text: For two weeks, Larry Benson had been calling the police about the vacant house down the block that had been overrun by squatters and stripped of copper piping. But Mr. Benson, who heads a crime prevention group in the Golden Gate neighborhood of Oakland, had not heard back from Nadia Clark, the “problem-solving officer” assigned to the area.

headline: What Do You Think of the LeBron James ‘Spectacle’?
text: For days, basketball player LeBron James built an intense air of suspense around the question of which team he would join to end his period as a free agent. Why do you think there was so much attention to this story? And what do you think of his decision to join the Miami Heat?

headline: For Cleveland Fans, Heartbreak Is a Familiar Feeling
text: FAIRLAWN, Ohio  The LeBron James free-agency story has been a multicourse feast for Cleveland’s sports talk radio hosts, and a delicious diversion from the last-place Indians. But an hour and a half before the announcement, it was too late to talk about James’s options; those bones had been picked clean.

headline: Stunned but Not Surprised by a Single Word: Miami
text: Standing in darkness outside Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, scores of Knicks fans huddled in the summer heat around iPhones and BlackBerrys, awaiting the decision to end all decisions.

headline: Where the Prices Are Low, and the Customers Few
text: Depending on how you look at it, the Discount Mega Mall at 2500-14 North Milwaukee Avenue is either an eyesore or a hot spot for the frugal.

headline: Man Stabs Four People in Chelsea, Police Say
text: An apparently deranged man wielding a knife went on a rampage in Chelsea on Thursday evening, stabbing four people and smashing a storefront on West 14th Street, the police said.

headline: For Rookie Wonder, a Rare Seat on the Bench
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Chicago Company Puts Its Stamp on Man U

headline: Law Came Too Late for Some Rape Victims
text: With considerable fanfare this week, Gov. Patrick J. Quinn signed into law a measure to improve rape investigations by Illinois authorities. But it came too late for women like Christina.

headline: Keeping Score: In All-Star Calculations, Some Fall Short
text: As in every season, the selection of All-Stars has led to much discussion and debate among fans and columnists. Players like Joey Votto, Kevin Youkilis and Jered Weaver were initially left off their leagues’ rosters, and curious alternatives like Omar Infante, Ryan Howard and Ty Wigginton made the teams.

headline: Iran: Merchants on Strike for 3rd Day
text: Widespread strikes continued for a third day on Thursday at Tehran’s central bazaar, according to Iranian news sites, as merchants protested a proposed tax increase on their earnings.

headline: Unsung Allies Battle Starvation in Africa
text: The picture of starvation in Africa is one we think we know.

headline: Share of College Spending for Recreation Is Rising
text: American colleges are spending a declining share of their budgets on instruction and more on administration and recreational facilities for students, according to a study of college costs released Friday.

headline: Smartphone Patent Suits Challenge Big Makers
text: NTP, a patent-holding company best known for prying a settlement of more than $600 million from the maker of the BlackBerry, is now suing the other big names in the smartphone industry: Apple, Google, Microsoft, HTC, LG and Motorola.

headline: Haiti’s Island Departure Gate
text: La Gonâve, the main island off Haiti’s coast, has become the main departure point for people fleeing the earthquake’s devastation and seeking better lives elsewhere.

headline: Hot Weather in a Warming Climate
text: The headline above is a play on the headline from a March 2008 post, “Cold Weather in a Warming Climate,” written when climate stasists were crowing about snow falling in Johannesburg and Baghdad.

headline: Knicks Send Lee to the Warriors
text: With LeBron James off the board, the Knicks began refilling their roster Thursday night by completing a multiplayer trade built around David Lee.

headline: Swap Idea Emerged Early in Case of Russia Agents
text: This article was reported by Peter Baker, Charlie Savage and Benjamin Weiser and written by Mr. Baker.

headline: Joya Sherrill, Who Sang With Ellington and Goodman, Is Dead at 85
text: Joya Sherrill, who sang with Duke Ellington as a teenager, toured the Soviet Union with Benny Goodman and was one of the first African-American performers to host a children’s television show, died on June 28 at her home in Great Neck, N.Y. She was 85.

headline: Apple Still Underdog in China, Despite New Store
text: Although Apple is widely admired in China, most fans of its products here have been buying their iPhones, iPods and Mac computers from smugglers who operate through underground electronics markets.

headline: Gilbert, Cavs’ Owner, Calls James’s Decision a Betrayal
text: Cleveland fans, you can still hold your heads high: The curse has been lifted!

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the Kickstarter Film Festival misstated the number of projects financed by Kickstarter, a Web site that plays matchmaker for filmmakers and financial backers. It has financed more than 1,500 projects, not more than 5,000.

headline: News Quiz | July 9, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Corrections
text: A movie review last Friday about “Only When I Dance,” a documentary that tracks two students at the Centro de Dança ballet school in Rio de Janeiro, misspelled part of the surname of one of the dancers. He is Irlan Santos da Silva, not Santos de Silva.

headline: Rodriguez Heats Up Late and Yankees Win
text: SEATTLE  Alex Rodriguez’s performance Thursday night mirrored his season. It took a while for him to get going, but the Yankees were glad he did. After halting rallies in his first three at-bats, Rodriguez walked in the eighth and scored the tying run. In the ninth, he overwhelmed Mariners closer David Aardsma for the second time in a week, lashing a go-ahead two-run single that boosted the Yankees to a 3-1 victory.

headline: EADS Bids on Air Force Tankers Amid Tensions
text: The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company submitted an 8,800-page bid on Thursday for a $35 billion Air Force tanker contract amid tensions over whether European subsidies would give it a cost advantage over Boeing.

text: jingoist •\ˈjiN-(ˌ)go-ist\• noun

headline: Temasek Moves Into New Territory With SeaTown
text: Temasek Holdings, Singapore’s state investment company, may commit more capital to its Seatown Holdings Pte unit and push ahead with plans to invite outside investors.

headline: Exxon’s XTO Deal Is Proving a Long Hedge
text: Exxon Mobil Corporation’s $31 billion hedge is way out of the money, Breakingviews says. Gas prices have tumbled since the company agreed to pay that amount for the gas producer XTO. That doesn’t make the deal a bust. A carbon tax might make the XTO purchase look smart, but Exxon benefits for as long as Congress twiddles its thumbs, the publication argues.

text: NTP, a patent-holding company best known for prying a settlement of more than $600 million from the maker of the BlackBerry, is suing the other big names in the smartphone industry: Apple, Google, Microsoft, HTC, LG and Motorola, writes The New York Times’s Steve Lohr.

headline: K.K.R. Prospects for Gas, Without the Leverage
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which led the record takeover of electricity provider TXU in 2007, is making a new bet on rising energy prices, this time without the leverage, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Something New Under the Sun
text: WHAT is the Solar Impulse?

headline: Yahoo Farms Out For-Sale Home Listings to Zillow
text: Yahoo is turning over its listings of homes for sale and other local real estate advertising to an online specialist in the field, Zillow.com, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Rothschild’s Vallar I.P.O. Raises $1.1 Billion
text: Vallar, Nathaniel Rothschild‘s investment vehicle, raised £707.2 million ($1.07 billion) in an initial public offering in London, beating a target announced last month, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Double Dip Fears Send Investors to Cash
text: Equity funds worldwide suffered more than $11 billion of net outflows in the first week of July, while money market funds saw the biggest inflows in 18 months amid fears of a double-dip recession, EPFR Global said on Friday, Reuters reported.

headline: Sumitomo Might Invest up to $5 Billion in U.S. Bank
text: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japan’s second-largest bank by market value, may spend as much as $5 billion buying a stake in a United States commercial lender in the next three years, a top executive told Bloomberg News.

headline: Judge Defers Civil Lawsuit for Adviser in Fraud Case
text: A civil lawsuit brought by federal regulators against a financial adviser suspected of stealing millions of dollars from celebrity clients was temporarily halted on Thursday by a federal judge in Manhattan who said a criminal case against the adviser should be dispensed with first, The New York Times’s Colin Moynihan reported.

headline: Recovery Sees European Banks Leave Rates Alone
text: The European Central Bank on Thursday left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, and its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, expressed cautious optimism that Europe’s sovereign debt crisis was easing and that the euro area economy was growing faster than expected.

headline: BC and Silver Lake Make $3.1 Billion Buyout
text: BC Partners and Silver Lake Partners have agreed to purchase MultiPlan. The transaction is values the health-care business at $3.1 billion, according to news reports, citing people close to the deal.

headline: Bomber Attacks Meeting of Tribal Elders in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber attacked a group of tribal elders gathered near the headquarters of the civilian government in Mohmand on Friday, killing more than 60 people and wounding more than 100, a senior Pakistani security official said.

headline: SonicWall Sets July 23 Meeting to Approve Deal
text: Network security technology provider SonicWall sent a letter to shareholders Thursday, ahead of a special meeting later this month, asking them to approve a takeover by an investor group, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Election to Replace Byrd Gets Official’s Approval
text: West Virginia’s attorney general has determined that Gov. Joe Manchin III can call a special election this year to fill the vacancy created by the death of Senator Robert C. Byrd, clearing the way for a contest in November to fill the remaining two years of Mr. Byrd’s term, The New York Times’s Carl Hulse reported.

headline: Stocks Regain Momentum Late in the Day
text: The latest weekly jobs report on Thursday propelled stocks for the third day this week, building on gains that analysts hope will be sustained after corporate earnings season begins.

headline: Ford Adds Sprint Nextel’s Hance to Board
text: Ford Motor has expanded its board to 14 members by adding Sprint Nextel Chairman James Hance Jr. as a director, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Burkle Testifies in Barnes & Noble Poison Pill Case
text: The billionaire Ronald Burkle testified on Thursday that he doesn’t want to buy Barnes & Noble and was shocked when the bookseller adopted a poison pill plan after he increased his stake in it.

headline: For Wealth Managers, $10 Trillion Up For Grabs
text: The global private banking sector has the potential to nearly double its size thanks to about $10 trillion of untapped wealth that is still up for grabs, Reuters reported, citing the Scorpio Partnership’s annual benchmark.

headline: Dustin Keller on a Taste of Italy
text: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down. Today, he is writing a restaurant review of Trattoria L’Incontro in Queens (2176 31st St., Astoria)

headline: Celebrating Paris in the Summer
text: Paris can seem deserted in the summer, as if the whole city is off on vacation. But in 1989, Jack Lang, the French minister of culture, recognized that not only do plenty of Parisians stay in town — but that they are joined by thousands of visitors, hoping to experience some of that famous French culture.

headline: Retail Supplier Li & Fung Signs Raft of New Deals
text: Li & Fung, the biggest supplier to retailers including Wal-Mart Stores, rose the most in five months in Hong Kong after announcing acquisitions and agreements that may generate $1 billion in sales next year, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Warns on N.Y. Tax Plan
text: In an interview with Forbes’ Billions blog, the hedge fund manager Leon Cooperman gave his view of the plan recently floated by Gov. David A. Paterson and New York’s legislative leaders to tax out-of-state hedge fund managers.

headline: North Korea Says American Tried to Kill Himself in Prison
text: SEOUL, South Korea  An American serving an eight-year sentence in a labor camp in North Korea has been hospitalized after trying to kill himself, the North’s state-run Korean Central News Agency reported on Friday.

headline: Travel, a Form of Collecting
text: Today’s idea: “We approach the world, futilely, as collectors,” an essay says; travel demonstrates this as much as any acquisition.

headline: Oakley Backs Macro Hedge Funds
text: Global macro hedge funds are likely to prosper in current volatile markets, while portfolios betting on mergers should profit from a lack of competition, said a fund manager at Oakley Alternative Investment Management, Reuters reported.

headline: Paulson Funds Said Hit by Steep Losses in June
text: For the second month in a row, John A. Paulson suffered acute losses at his flagship funds, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Citigroup Said to Expand Asia Energy Business
text: Citigroup‘s Asia energy-trading team is expanding by hiring at least another five staff, including two traders, and has also ventured into physical oil trading in the past 12 months, Reuters reported, citing industry sources.

headline: China Renews Google’s License
text: SHANGHAI  The tense standoff that began in January with Google’s unprecedented rebuke of China’s Internet censorship rules appeared to ease on Friday with a compromise that might allow both sides to claim a partial victory.

text: Theranos, a maker of devices that monitor drug reactions, has received $45 million of a planned $100 million funding round, VentureBeat reported, citing a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Ocado’s I.P.O. Valuation Leaves City Skeptical
text: Ocado, the British online grocer, may have a lot of convincing to do on its two-week roadshow for an initial public offering that would value  the company at as much as £1.3 billion ($2 billion).

headline: Consumer Watchdog Warns of Online Car Dealer Scams
text: Thousands of people looking for a bargain on a used car have been scammed by Internet con artists stealing the identity of legitimate car dealers, according the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

headline: Tip of the Week: If Google Calendar or Gmail Fails to Load
text: Is Google Calendar or Gmail not loading — and you’re not sure if it’s you or Google having the problem? Take a quick trip to Google’s Apps Status Dashboard to see if there are any reported problems with many of the company’s services, including Google Talk, Google Docs and Google Groups.

headline: Tainted Dairy Products Seized in Western China
text: BEIJING  Two years after a national health scare over melamine-tainted milk products rocked China’s dairy industry, inspectors in western China’s Qinghai Province have seized 76 tons of dairy ingredients laced with the same industrial chemical, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported Friday.
