text: First there were statisticians. Then there was Paul the octopus. And now, say hello to Mani the parakeet.

headline: Late Night Laughs at Emmy Outcomes
text: Jay Leno was nothing if not gracious in defeat on Thursday, hours after learning that “The Tonight Show” had been nominated for four Emmy Awards – for episodes that were hosted by his successor-turned-predecessor, Conan O’Brien – while his own incarnation of “Tonight” received none. In his opening monologue (posted above), Mr. Leno poked fun at a few Emmy snub victims, including his rival late-night host David Letterman, something called “Mel Gibson’s Salute to Black History Month,” and himself.

headline: What Is That New Phone Really Going to Cost?
text: Phenomenal phones are flooding the market. In the past few weeks the new iPhone 4, the HTC 4G EVO, Droid X and HTC HD2 debuted, all phones with fast processors and big screens.

headline: The Heat Wave and the Climate Divide
text: The temperature hit 103 degrees in Central Park on Tuesday, part of a record-breaking heat wave. Extreme heat also scorched much of the rest of the East Coast, from Boston to Virginia. Brownouts and blackouts threatened as residents reaching for air-conditioner controls strained the power grid. And the heat reached beyond the United States, with record temperatures recorded in Pakistan and China.

headline: James’s Really Big Show a Throwback
text: “The Decision” was being watched closely by Madison Avenue as well as by sports fans.

headline: What Went Wrong?
text: The Obama administration is in a difficult spot. It’s now obvious that the stimulus was much too small; yet there’s virtually no chance of getting additional measures out of Congress. The administration has chosen to deal with this by trying to have it both ways — condemning Republicans, rightly, for obstructionism, while at the same time claiming, falsely, that we’re still on the right track.

headline: Today In Instant Neener Neener
text: Business Week, last week.

headline: Health Plan That Helped the Poor Is Cut
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Off the Menu: The Darby
text: Alexandra Guarnaschelli, and her partners in Butter in NoHo, Richie Akiva and Scott Sartiano, have taken over the space that was Nell’s until 2004, and plan to reopen around Labor Day as a swanky supper club called The Darby, at 246 West 14th Street.

headline: Rilance
text: A French portmanteau that describes an approach to deficit reduction which combines rigor and growth.

headline: ‘Today’ Wedding Contest Will Now Include Same-Sex Couples
text: NBC will change the application process for the “Today” show’s “Modern Day Wedding Contest ” so that same-sex couples are permitted to participate, the network said Thursday.

headline: Nocturnalist | ‘Silent’ in Name Only
text: At a dingy basement rock show in in Ridgewood, Queens, on Thursday night, a member of the band Run DMT stepped from behind the mikes and toward the crowd. As the guitars shrilled, he began to smear red paint violently across his face. He then lofted a bottle of pancake syrup over his head and poured it down his body, squirting it into his ears. Next, he stuck Monopoly money to the ooze, and capped off the performance by sucking down a whole mango. The audience cheered.

headline: The Early Word: Spy Swap in Action
text: Just as quietly as they came, the 10 convicted Russian sleeper agents arrested by the F.B.I. last month were whisked across the Atlantic and landed in Vienna today.

headline: When Did We First ‘Rock the Mic’?
text: Talk about a culture clash. Last month I found myself playing snippets of old-school hip-hop over tinny laptop speakers for a roomful of lexicographers at Oxford University. The occasion was the Fifth International Conference on Historical Lexicography and Lexicology, an erudite gathering of scholars interested in exploring the work of dictionaries structured on historical principles.

headline: Art as Security System
text: I’ve never spent time in Detroit, but I’ve seen an awful lot of images of the city in the last several years. And those images have been pretty awful, offering a version of the place defined by abandonment and decline. “Ruins porn,” as it’s been called, undermines even hopeful tales of creative renewal. The idea that artists can treat the city like a canvas ends up suggesting that it is a lost cause, an entire metropolitan area written off as raw material for upcycling. The net effect is a part of America depicted as if it exists in some distant reality — somebody else’s problem, nothing to do with us.

headline: When to Out a Transgender Dater?
text: I  am a  straight  woman,  and  I was set up on a date with a man.  We got along well initially, but I grew concerned about how evasive he was about his past. I did some sophisticated checking online — I do  research professionally — and discovered that he is a female-to-male transgender  individual. I then ended our relationship. He and  I live in Orthodox Jewish communities.  (I believe he converted shortly after he became a  man.) I think he continues to date women within  our group. Should I urge our rabbi to out this person? NAME WITHHELD, N.Y.

headline: Night of 130 Teenagers
text: My girlfriend Nancy’s 16 year-old son wanted to give a party at her home in Hancock Park, an old, upscale neighborhood in Los Angeles. He said there were going to be about 70 kids attending, almost all of them from his private high school, where the tuition runs more than $20,000 a year. Not exactly my alma mater, Gardena High, if you read me.

headline: J. Crew Helps Preppy Go Euro
text: J. Crew published its first catalog in 1983, three years after Lisa Birnbach’s “Official Preppy Handbook” codified a peculiar style of comportment and dress associated with rich enclaves on the East Coast. By the time J. Crew showed up — a full-fledged lifestyle manual that seemed to put on sale the whole preppy modus vivendi — Birnbach’s book was enshrined as both satire and tip sheet. J. Crew came to function the same way: with its anodyne clubby name and clothes that ripped off L.L. Bean, Brooks Brothers and J. Press, J. Crew seemed to spoof the preppy style while making it available.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Under the Covers
text: “Cover Run: The DC Comics Art of Adam Hughes” arrives at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week. This collection features Mr. Hughes’s cover illustrations of shapely characters like Wonder Woman, Catwoman and Power Girl, as well as sketches and commentary. Mr. Hughes, who in 2003 won the comics industry’s Eisner Award for best cover artist, answered questions about his work by e-mail.

headline: Sun Valley: Waiting for (and Finding) Google
text: 11:43 a.m. | Updated Google’s chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, told DealBook on Friday that the company was pleased by the renewal of the search giant’s operating license for mainland China.

headline: Egghead Alert at Confirmation Hearings
text: If you had the impression during the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings that Elena Kagan was speaking slowly, e-nun-ciat-ing clearly, choosing words of few syllables and punctuating each simple phrase with a sweetly, self-consciously ingratiating smile, you probably were on to something.

headline: Talent to Spare, but There’s Only One Trophy
text: JOHANNESBURG — And then there were two. In the 64th game of a tournament that has stretched our imagination and at times bewildered our ability to know what is coming next, two very decent teams, the Netherlands and Spain, will contest the World Cup final of 2010.

headline: ‘Shot in the Arm’ for an Ambitious Plan for 34th St.
text: A radical reimagining of Manhattan’s 34th Street, which would include the first bus lane in the city to be physically separated from other vehicles, will receive more than $18 million in federal funds, the United States Department of Transportation said on Thursday.

headline: ‘Much Ado’ for Heidi and Stew at Shakespeare on the Sound
text: It’s arguably the biggest news to come from southern Connecticut since a certain highly coveted N.B.A. free agent announced there that he was leaving his home state and heading for South Beach – or, at least, the newest news. The creative team of Stew and Heidi Rodewald said on Friday they will contribute to a third entry in a series of musical adaptations for Shakespeare on the Sound, and are creating music and songs for a production of “Much Ado About Nothing” for next summer. As with Shakespeare on the Sound’s 2009 staging of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” which featured a score by Stew, and the company’s current “Othello,” for which Stew wrote the music with Ms. Rodewald,  “Much Ado About Nothing” will be directed by Joanna Settle, the company’s artistic director, press representatives  said in a news release. The set designer Andrew Lieberman and the costume designer Tilly Grimes will also return for “Much Ado About Nothing,” which will be presented at Pinkney Park in Rowayton, Conn., and Baldwin Park in Greenwich, Conn. Casting for the romantic rivals Beatrice and Benedick, among other characters, has not yet been announced.

headline: Tesla May Get Some Company: The Supercar Goes Electric
text: INTRODUCED in New York in 1954, the Mercedes-Benz 300SL was a stunningly advanced machine, the first production car to trade a carburetor for fuel injection.

headline: Might We Do as the Romans Do?
text: Three years ago, the Italian energy giant Eni began what is now a summer tradition: from June 1 to Sept. 1, the company sets the thermostat in its corporate office buildings 1 degree Celsius (1.8 degrees Fahrenheit) higher than it had in summers before 2007. It also allows employees to “take off their ties” – that is, wear lighter, more casual clothes to work.

headline: Winging It One More Time
text: IN a beloved cliché of any time-machine movie, the intrepid traveler goofs up the controls and emerges in a cosmically awful predicament — in the midst of the Spanish Inquisition, say, or at the molten core of the earth.

headline: Carrier Lowers Costs With Coupons
text: A small Wisconsin mobile phone carrier has figured out a clever way to lower the cost of its phone service while providing its customers with discounts on retail goods and services.

headline: Top Women and Young Players in Action in St. Louis
text: The United States Women’s and Junior Championships start Saturday in St. Louis. As with the United States Championship, the venue will be the Chess Club and Scholastic Center of Saint Louis. The championships will run concurrently.

headline: Oakland Mayor Supports Federal Inquiry on Shooting
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Even as city residents cleaned up after a night of looting and vandalism, Mayor Ron Dellums of Oakland said he supported a federal investigation that is under way on the death of Oscar Grant III, a young unarmed black man who was shot and killed by a white transit police officer.

headline: Last PT Cruiser Rolls Off the Assembly Line
text: The bulky, retro-styled Chrysler PT Cruiser — its fans found it positively alluring, its detractors called it bulbous and cheaply made — becomes an automotive legend on Friday when the final PT comes off the line at Chrysler’s plant in Toluca, Mexico.

headline: Fun Facts to Know and Tell Ahead of Sunday’s Final
text: • Johan Cruyff, the great Dutch footballer of the 1970s who also played for and coached Barcelona, says he is supporting Spain in Sunday’s final. “Spain, a replica of Barca, is the best publicity for football,” Cruyff wrote in his Thursday column in the Barcelona newspaper El Periodico de Catalunya. “Who am I supporting? I am Dutch but I support the football that Spain is playing.” Here is Cruyff dribbling — a skill at which he was unsurpassed:

headline: Lincoln Center Festival’s ‘Demons': Must-See Or Must-Sell?
text: When Lincoln Center Festival first announced its stage production of “The Demons” – a marathon 12-hour play adapted from the Dostoyevsky novel, performed in Italian with English supertitles, in a warehouse on Governors Island that is a 20-minute walk away from the ferry stop – Patrick Healy wrote in The New York Times that the show was a contender to be the season’s “must-must-must-see show, the snob hit that separates the true sophisticates (at least in their own minds) from the cultural chaff.”

headline: A Handbuilt Twist to an Industrial Icon
text: NASHUA, N.H.

headline: Disparities in Recall Disclosure
text: Last month, McDonald’s recalled about 12 million Shrek-themed glasses because the designs on them contained tiny amounts of cadmium, a metal that has the potential to cause health problems with long-term exposure.

headline: Better Antitheft Technology, but Smarter Car Thieves
text: BASED on the advertisements, it would seem that technology has made it impossible  or at least stunningly foolhardy  to steal a car. Tracking systems with GPS can pinpoint any vehicle and direct the authorities straight to the crooks. But while the technology may be getting better, professional car thieves have stepped up their game, too, meaning that some tracking systems may be better than others.

text: From Paul Krugman’s latest column in The New York Times:

headline: Complaint Box | The Beach as Landfill
text: Things I saw on the beach one morning: an empty vodka bottle, four blackened cigar stubs, numerous cigarette butts, two different broken flip-flops, a large jagged piece of broken glass (this I picked up and carried to the nearest trash receptacle), an abandoned striped beach towel — soaked now by the high tide — and a fresh pile of dog feces. There is always a fresh pile of dog feces, even though there are signs on all entrance paths to the beach stating that from June 1 to Sept. 15 dogs are not allowed on the beach.

text: France’s PSA Peugeot Citroen and China Changan Automobile Group plan to invest $1.2 billion to set up a joint venture to make small, low-emission cars in China, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Industry Spending Dips for Doctors’ Classes
text: Spending on postgraduate education for doctors declined in 2009 for the second year in a row, as did biomedical industry support for the programs, according to a new report from the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education.

headline: 2011 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG
text: The new SLS AMG combines head-turning style with head-snapping performance.

headline: App Smart Extra: Mspot and Sirius XM
text: Thursday’s App Smart column highlights new and old music services doing battle on mobile handsets. Two apps did not make that list, but they deserve an honorable mention.

headline: ‘The Good Man Jesus and the Scoundrel Christ’
text: Mary and Joseph

headline: In the Name of the Father, the Sons . . .
text: Belief in the divinity of Jesus of Nazareth and belief in the virtue of his teachings are not at all the same thing. Writing to John Adams in 1813, having taken his razor blade to the books of the New Testament and removed all “the artificial vestments in which they have been muffled by priests,” Thomas Jefferson said the 46-page residue contained “the most sublime and benevolent code of morals which has ever been offered to man.” Ernest Renan, in his pathbreaking “Life of Jesus” in 1863, also repudiated the idea that Jesus was the son of God while affirming the beauty of his teachings. In rather striking contrast, C. S. Lewis maintained in his classic statement “Mere Christianity”: “That is the one thing we must not say. A man who was merely a man and said the sort of things Jesus said would not be a great moral teacher. He would either be a lunatic — on the level with the man who says he is a poached egg — or else he would be the Devil of hell. You must make your choice. Either this man was, and is, the Son of God; or else a madman or something worse.”

headline: In the Still of the Night
text: Sleep is a mystery. No one is sure why we sleep, how it evolved or how much of it we need. We don’t know what dreams are, or the nature of sleep-walking (or its variants, among them sleep-eating, sleep-copulating and sleep-murdering). Even promising discoveries like rapid-eye-movement sleep lead to more mysteries. REM at first seemed synonymous or synchronous with dreaming — but it isn’t. There are non-REM dreams, and REM activity may be distinct from dreaming.

headline: Caution Still Reigns at Sun Valley
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — It has become by far the watchword at the Allen & Company retreat here this year.

headline: Love’s Pestilence
text: Since 1998, the New York Public Library has housed a manuscript so blistering that researchers are probably required to don oven mitts before handling it. Consisting of a long-overlooked autobiographical fragment by Claire Clairmont, who was Mary Shelley’s stepsister, Lord Byron’s lover and the inspiration for Henry James’s “Aspern Papers,” it has the declared intention of showing what “evil passion” sprang from the pursuit of free love by Byron and Percy Bysshe Shelley. “Under the influence of the doctrine and belief of free love,” Clairmont states, “I saw the two first poets of England . . . become monsters of lying, meanness, cruelty and treachery — under the influence of free love Lord B became a human tyger slaking his thirst for inflicting pain upon defenceless women.” Her indictment, which Daisy Hay says is now being published for the first time, comes only at the end of “Young Romantics” yet sends a blast of scorching fury back across the entire book. For Clairmont’s charges, however hyperbolic, have about them a degree of truth. Not just for her but for Mary Shelley and other women, participating in the communal, proto-1960s life of “English poetry’s greatest generation,” as Hay’s subtitle puts it, was ultimately less thrilling than damaging. This, at least, is the dominant impression I took away from “Young Romantics,” even if it isn’t Hay’s thesis or even drift.

headline: Postcards From the Edge
text: Early in “The Lovers,” Yvonne, a middle-aged American vacationing in Turkey, finds a book on the shelf of her rental house called “The Woman’s Guide to Anal Sex.” She flips through it, then moves on to discover some homemade pornography under the couch and an odd device in the guest room that turns out to be a sex swing. Instead of embarrassment or excitement or surprise — or horror or nostalgia or curiosity — she feels little in response to these erotic items strewn about her thousand-dollar-a-week accommodations. Since many middle-class women from New England traveling alone for the first time in 30 years wouldn’t be so unflappable, Yvonne’s story can be seen from the start as an unusual and engrossing exploration of marriage, parenthood and the accidents that can end and reconfigure lives.

headline: A Savage Mountain
text: The front-page story resounded across the globe: Aug. 2, 2008, was fast becoming the deadliest day ever on the world’s second-highest mountain. K2, in the Karakoram range of northern Pakistan, was living up to its lethal reputation. Eleven fatalities amid unthinkable, and sometimes contradictory, tales of ­he­roics and folly. A book (or a dozen) would, of course, follow.

headline: Questions of Travel
text: Wearing tan slacks and a plain shirt, the poet Elizabeth Bishop entered the crowded Brazilian port of Santos on a damp, drizzly morning in November 1951, glimpsing warehouses painted in fading colors of pink, yellow and blue. Marianne Moore had seen her off in New York with the gift of a pot of white chrysanthemums. It wouldn’t be a long visit, or so the two friends assumed, never suspecting that Bishop would make a home in Brazil for the next 17 years, mostly with the charismatic architect Lota de Macedo Soares, whom she had met in 1942 in New York.

headline: Broadway Musical About Ray Charles Is Delayed
text: It’s going to be a few more months before an actor playing Ray Charles on a Broadway stage is told to hit the road, Jack, and begs like a man in a trance to be set free. On Friday, the producers of “Unchain My Heart,” a musical based on the life of Mr. Charles, the soul and R&B performer, said they were delaying the production’s opening until next spring. It had originally been announced to open at the Barrymore Theater on Nov. 7; in a statement, the producer Stuart Benjamin said there were “logistical reasons” for the change of date. “Unchain My Heart” is directed by Sheldon Epps from a book by Suzan-Lori Parks (“Topdog/Underdog”) and is to star Brandon Victor Dixon (“The Scottsboro Boys”) as Ray Charles.

headline: ‘Lay the Favorite’
text: Chapter One: The Crew

headline: Cranking It Up
text: James Zabala’s 1926 Ford Model T speedster was assembled from spare parts.

headline: Taking a Gamble
text: Six 40-inch televisions, each showing a different sport; a banquet table cluttered with hockey digests and Yoo-Hoo; the boss sausaged into tube socks and armed with a copy of “Hide Your A$$et$ and Disappear”: no, this is not your typical workplace. But then, professional sports betting — a sordid, florid microworld lurching along the edge of society, not to mention legality — is not your typical job. And Beth Raymer’s account of her years in the peripatetic employ of high-stakes sports bettors is not your typical gambling memoir or, really, your typical memoir at all.

headline: Vision and Revision
text: Toward the end of May, a freshly roasted chestnut of the mystery genre appeared on Masterpiece Theater:  “The Mirror Crack’d From Side to Side”  by Agatha Christie. Audiences of contemporary television detective drama have grown used to stylish, clinical programs in which unshockable cops and coroners scan the evidence of grisly slayings. The chief suspense derived from each episode lies in which state-of-the-art device will reveal the “how” of the killing. But the personable, low-tech concerns of  “The Mirror Crack’d”  remind us of an empathetic era, not long vanished, when the question mark that hovered over any crime scene wasn’t so much “How did it happen?” as  “Why?”

headline: Now Showing | SITE Santa Fe Biennial
text: Sarah Lewis and Daniel Belasco got the idea for the latest SITE Santa Fe Biennial, which they co-curated, seven years ago. It was while working for Robert Storr, the curator on the fifth SITE biennial (this one is the eighth), that they came across animated works by Kara Walker and Raymond Pettibon. “It was the first time Walker activated her silhouettes, and she did it in an eight-minute piece called ‘Testimony,’” Lewis recalls. “It was parallel to Raymond Pettibon’s ‘Repeater Pencil.’ We looked at those works and both thought they exemplified a new aesthetic, of artists activating their paintings, drawings or other works with high-tech means, but to create something homespun. And that’s when we decided we should do a show about that very aesthetic.”

headline: Hedge Funds Thrive on Fixed Income in First Half
text: First-half performance figures are showing the same pattern for hedge funds as for more mainstream investors — the most successful were in fixed income, the least successful in stocks, Reuters reported.

headline: GLC’s Bell Takes Issue With Dalio’s Gossip ‘Principle’
text: Ever since Dealbreaker posted a draft of Ray Dalio’s “Principles,” Bridgewater Associates‘ unofficial handbook, the hedge fund manager has taken some heat in certain corners of the news media for his philosophies. (The Financial Times’s columnist Lucy Kelly, for example, called Mr. Dalio “deluded, insensitive, emotionally illiterate, simplistic, breathtakingly smug, weird and plain wrong.”)

headline: Friday Reading: Beware of Used Car Scams
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Pentagon Reinstates Banned Guantánamo Reporter
text: After weeks of sparring with the media over First Amendment issues, the Pentagon has agreed to allow a Miami Herald reporter it expelled from Guantánamo Bay in May back onto the naval base.

headline: In the Hamptons, Going Against the Tide
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  In the exclusive world of the Hamptons, the playground of the rich and famous like the billionaire George Soros and the fashion designer Calvin Klein, Evelyn Konrad is far from being a boldface name.

headline: A New Low in James’s Race to the Top
text: A truly astounding thing happened Thursday night: with LeBron James’s “The Decision” universally expected to be a cultural low point, the moment sports stardom turned into pure narcissism and sports journalism turned into pure schlock, it managed to come in under expectations. People expected James’s hour-long circus to be horrendous; it was worse.

headline: Unwanted Parenting Advice From Strangers
text: Alice Dunn is 3 months old. Her mother, Lillian, is on maternity leave right now from the New York City Department of Health, where she works in the Physical Activity and Nutrition Program. Usually Lillian loves going out and about with Alice, who likes to smile at strangers and is fairly easy-going in public.

text: Big-law quality at little-law price: It’s what many clients crave.

text: Bank of America is seeking to capitalize on its sponsorship deal with Major League Baseball by introducing a commercial with a baseball theme during the Fox coverage of the All-Star Game on Tuesday.

headline: For Goodness’ Sake
text: Secure your own oxygen mask before assisting anyone else, we are urged at the beginning of every flight. Altruism often requires that we take care of ourselves first, which is exactly what the subject of Oren Harman’s enthralling book “The Price of Altruism” tragically failed to do. The scientist George Price was an obscure and enigmatic figure, unknown outside his field of study. Born near New York City in 1922 and originally trained as a chemist, Price worked on the Manhattan Project, at Bell Labs and at I.B.M. before moving to London in 1967, after botched surgery for thyroid cancer. There he became a population geneticist and tried to solve the mystery of altruism with brilliant mathematical formulas. He had trouble solving his own problems, though. Having shown little sensitivity to others in his previous life (he abandoned his wife and daughters and was a lousy son to his aging mother), Price swung to the other extreme. Long a staunch skeptic and atheist, he became a devout Christian, gave up all his possessions and dedicated himself to caring for the city’s vagabonds. By the age of 50, he was as gaunt as an old man, with rotting teeth and a raspy voice. He killed himself in 1975.

headline: News Quiz: Who Needs LeBron Edition
text: The Lede remains disappointed that LeBron James did not, as we had hoped, justify the big build-up to his ESPN special on Thursday night by announcing, “This fall I’m going to take my talents way to the east and join CSKA Moscow, because I am both a free agent and a Russian agent.”

headline: The Apostate
text: Almost 25 years ago, Richard Gilman wrote a wonderful account of his conversion from Judaism to Catholicism and his subsequent loss of faith; what begins as a tale of finding faith becomes, amid Gilman’s feeling that the church is stifling him sexually and intellectually, a story of “faith dissolved.” Devotees of Gilman’s “Faith, Sex, and Mystery” can place Eric Lax’s new book right next to it on their shelves.

headline: LeBron James and Taxes
text: And now onto the question that is on everybody’s minds: How does LeBron James’s decision to join the Miami Heat affect his taxes?

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | Learning to Live Without Limbs
text: Our Student Challenge will continue on a weekly basis all summer long, and we’ll regularly choose a “favorite” student comment to feature. Through Sunday, you can enter this week’s Challenge here.

headline: An Opiate of the People
text: The most dispiriting aspect of our belated environmental consciousness is the realization that many of the delightful substances we put into our mouths — like cold bottled water and imported produce — have costs that far outweigh the immediate gratification they deliver. In “Sugar: A Bittersweet History,” her thorough, workmanlike new study, Elizabeth Abbott reminds us that this has been true for centuries. A hundred years before Pushkin described ecstasy as “a glassful of tea and a piece of sugar in the mouth,” the demands of the sugar economy had ripped apart African communities and forced slaves across the Atlantic to work sugar cane plantations. Abbott’s book, which discusses the effects of sugar on everything from the Haitian revolution to Hitler’s Germany, serves as a grim reminder that a consumer’s choices register on a gigantic scale, and are therefore as much political as personal.

headline: Two Bodies Pulled From River in ‘Duck Boat’ Crash
text: A body believed to be that of the second of two missing Hungarian tourists was recovered Friday afternoon from the Delaware River in Philadelphia, where a barge plowed into a stalled sightseeing boat this week, dumping 37 people into the water.

headline: The Gift of Kindness
text: For every birthday and special occasion, my aunt gives me a piece of jewelry. She’s an avid collector, and I suspect it brings her pleasure to give me pieces that she’s chosen carefully. But I rarely like her jewelry; it’s not my style at all, and I never wear it — which you’d think she’d have noticed by now. Still, I feel guilty, and would rather she buy herself jewelry with the money. Would it be wrong to tell her this?

headline: Two Felled by Heat at Lady Gaga Show
text: Two people attending Lady Gaga’s performance on NBC’s “Today” show Friday morning were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center with minor cases of heat exhaustion, Fire Department officials said.

headline: The Big Picture
text: In “The Men Who Would Be King,” Nicole LaPorte chronicles how Steven Spielberg and his generational peers David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg — all showbiz veterans — banded together during the Clinton era to form DreamWorks SKG, their own custom-­designed production studio and the first new Hollywood studio in 60 years. But instead of celebrating the three men’s effort, LaPorte’s counternarrative constantly sneers at it.

headline: Both Webber and Silverstone Pass a Test
text: The first day of practice at the British Grand Prix with the redesigned track has ended, and the man who flipped out at the Valencia Street circuit less than two weeks ago finished at the highest level of the time sheets instead of just high up in the air.

headline: Show Us Why You Travel
text: Our colleagues at In Transit are inviting Times readers to share their best travel photos and tell the stories behind them. Where did you go and why? What’s happening in your photo? What does it mean to you? A selection of the top images will appear in the Travel section. Please limit your contributions to one or two photos. Do not submit photos that have been altered in any way. Also, you’re encouraged to give yourself credit by using your full, real name. If you’re looking for inspiration — or just a bit of armchair adventuring — please see last year’s show: “Why We Travel: Readers’ Photos 2009.”

headline: A Taste of Sun Valley’s Lighter Activities
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — While there’s plenty of heavy discussion at the Allen & Company conference here — the prime minister of Singapore, Lee Hsien Loong, will speak Friday morning — there’s also plenty of time for fun.

headline: Expat Intrigue
text: Lisa Brackmann’s first novel gets off to a fast start and never lets up. Its foul-mouthed narrator, Ellie Cooper, is a 26-year-old former National Guard medic who’s landed in Beijing, still traumatized by what she experienced in the “sandbox” of Iraq. Her marriage to Trey Cooper, employed by a Blackwater-like outfit operating in China, has fallen apart, and now, in between hookups with a local artist, she’s spending a lot of time popping Percocet, guzzling beer at karaoke bars and sipping coffee at Starbucks.

headline: Mahler’s Second Symphony, the Tilson Thomas Way
text: Lenox, Mass. – Music of cinematic scope. A world of village bands and folk ensembles. “Shtick.”

headline: In Sickness
text: Cancer is a dark and bleak journey. And the best writing about it, like the best travel writing, brings back rumors and news to us — vivid and unsparing — from a far land that most of us do not ever expect to visit.

headline: Hayek: The Back Story
text: Last month, a funny thing happened on the way to the best-seller list. A 66-year-old treatise by a long-dead Austrian-born economist began flying off the shelves, following an hourlong endorsement from a right-wing television host better known for pumping political thrillers than for rocking political theory.

headline: Inside the List
text: DON’T PRAY ON ME: When Christopher Hitchens announced recently that he would be undergoing chemotherapy for esophageal cancer, bloggers began debating whether it would be appropriate to pray for the famous atheist and author of “God Is Not Great.” “Hitchens MUST outlive Kissinger,” the British columnist Johann Hari wrote on Twitter, referring to the man Hitchens, in his memoir “Hitch-22” (No. 15 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week), calls a “liar, murderer, war criminal, pseudo-­academic” and — perhaps most unforgivably — “bore.” But Hari added: “I forbid everyone from praying for him. He would HATE that.” While Hitchens himself doesn’t seem to have issued any official directives, prayers have rolled in from Elizabeth Scalia (no relation to the Supreme Court justice) at First Things, Greg Kandra at The Deacon’s Bench and Pat Archbold at The National Catholic Register. (Pray, but “keep it to yourself,” one commenter advised Archbold. “He will know the difference when he converts.”)

headline: The Author Takes a Star Turn
text: AMONG the millions of videos on YouTube, somewhere amid the sneezing pandas, weepy Lindsay Lohan and smoking Indonesian toddler, are thousands of videos of authors talking — often skittishly, often against a black backdrop, often to no discernible audience — about their most recent work.

headline: Up Front: Brenda Wineapple
text: Brenda Wineapple has spent much of her own literary career writing about writers: from her first book, “Genêt: A Biography of Janet Flanner,” published in 1989, to her most recent, “White Heat: The Friendship of Emily Dickinson and Thomas Wentworth Higginson,” which was a finalist for the 2008 National Book Critics Circle award for biography. Now director of the Leon Levy Center for Biography at the Graduate School of the City University of New York, Wineapple has written about a diverse array of poets from John Greenleaf Whittier to Gertrude Stein.

headline: Meaningful Renewal to Mets and Braves Rivalry
text: One of the most contentious rivalries of baseball’s wild-card era has lain dormant for a half decade while a new rivalry with new villains supplanted it. But this weekend, old foes will again be joined in conflict, and for the first time in years familiar names like Chipper Jones and Bobby Cox will again take on a villainous appeal.

headline: Pope Names New Leader of Order Beset by Scandal
text: MILAN  Pope Benedict XVI appointed a senior Vatican official on Friday to take control of the Legionaries of Christ, the powerful worldwide religious order rocked by scandal after it emerged that its charismatic founder had molested underage seminarians and secretly fathered several children.

headline: Weekend Competition: Kicking the Bucket

headline: What We’re Reading: Motorcycle News
text: • Casey Stoner, who won the 2007 MotoGP championship while riding for Ducati, will join Honda’s factory team for the 2011 season. The most surprising element of the plan may be that Honda plans to retain its current riders, Dani Pedrosa and Andrea Dovizioso, and compete with three riders. Long-standing rumors suggest that Valentino Rossi will join the Ducati team, but official confirmation has been elusive, even as Rossi, the six-time MotoGP champion, ventured onto a track for the first time since he fractured his leg in a frightening crash in early June. He put in 26 laps.

headline: Ethics and the Greenhouse
text: One of the toughest realities attending debates over what to do, or not do, about the growing human influence on the climate system is that more science does not necessarily clarify society’s, or individual’s, responses.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE THOUSAND AUTUMNS OF JACOB DE ZOET,  by David Mitchell (Random House, $26.) Mitchell’s historical novel about a young Dutchman in Edo-era Japan is an achingly romantic story of forbidden love and something of an adventurous rescue tale.

headline: Paperback Row
text: LOST IN THE MERITOCRACY: The Undereducation of an Overachiever, by Walter Kirn. (Anchor, $14.95.) As a boy, Kirn learned to succeed at education without really trying. “I was the system’s pure product,” writes Kirn (inset), “sly and flexible, not so much educated as wised up.” At Princeton, he learned to attack the Western canon he hadn’t read, skipping “straight from ignorance to revisionism.” Eventually he abandoned the pose and began to really learn. His memoir “combines penetrating shrewdness with remarkable blind spots,” Laura Miller said in the Book Review. BORN ROUND: A Story of Family, Food, and a ­Ferocious Appetite, by Frank Bruni. (Penguin, $16.) Bruni, who was The Times’s restaurant critic for five years (he’s now a writer at large for the magazine), writes with verve and honesty about his lifelong love-hate relationship with food. The book “is like the Italian dinners Bruni loves — served up noisy, fun, heaping and delicious,” our reviewer, Dominique Browning, said.

headline: James’s Sponsors (and ESPN) Seem Short of Heat, Buzz-Wise
text: The marketers that sponsored “The Decision” on ESPN on Thursday night, during which LeBron James revealed his move to the Miami Heat, are not benefiting from much of a lift, at least according to a company that monitors blogs, message boards and social media posts to determine the “buzz” among consumers.

headline: ‘Play Away Please': Chasing a Passion and Paying the Price, Happily
text: The Old Course at St. Andrews, site of this week’s British Open, is hardly a typical golf course, so perhaps it is fitting that “Play Away Please, The Tale of the Sale of Golf’s Greatest Icon” (Mainstream Publishing) is not your typical golf book. When the starter’s box at the Old Course, one of golf’s most recognizable structures, was put up for auction during a 2001 renovation, the author, John Peter Hagen, decided to bid on it. It was a dream and a belief in the power of a symbol — the decades-old little box had sent off all the great golfers of the 20th century, countless duffers, and presidents and kings, too. And from it, at the start of every round, came three stately words: Play Away, Please.

But there are other prizes to be had here, including the Golden Boot, for the tournament’s top scorer, the Golden Ball for the most outstanding player and the, um, award for the best young player of the tournament. Perhaps it can be called the golden learner’s permit or something.

headline: Sunny Spies Under Those Sunny Skies
text: THE last time we saw a young female television character slip into a pencil skirt, blazer and the odd wig in the name of national security it was the third week of September 2001. “Alias,” J. J. Abrams’s outrageous C.I.A. series that had a five-season run on ABC, was a dark show for a dark time. Living-room sofas took on the contours of the therapist’s couch as viewers vicariously sought to work through their anxiety about the country’s safety and the people scheming, sleuthing and spying to protect it.

headline: Dodgers’ Fate Hinges on Owners’ Divorce

headline: High-Tech Matisse
text: AROUND 1913 Henri Matisse seemed to be at the top of his game. In his mid-40s he was, at last, an international star, despite American critics who pronounced his new brand of modernism coarse or vulgar because, they said, he made naked women seem beastly.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Set for Another Run in Imax Theaters
text: “Avatar” will be back on 3-D Imax screens in August, and it will be longer than ever. Imax and 20th Century Fox on Friday said they planned to re-release James Cameron’s science fiction epic for a two-week run beginning Aug. 27. The film, which already had a running time of 162 minutes, will include eight minutes of new material. Fox executives had been mulling a re-release ever since “Avatar,” which came out last Dec. 18, got nudged off of Imax screens in March by Walt Disney’s “Alice in Wonderland.” The blockbuster has sold about $2.7 billion in tickets worldwide.

headline: In Nevada, Obama Defends Economic Policies

headline: BP Is Ready to Put Tighter Cap on Runaway Well

headline: M.T.A. Service Cuts Reach a Museum
text: The New York Transit Museum laid off two full-time and two part-time employees this week, in accordance with required payroll reductions across the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its agencies. The museum is financed by donations and revenue from admissions and sales in its store, but its staff members are officially employed by the M.T.A. The M.T.A. is facing a financial crisis and recently made significant service cuts. At the museum, the full-time staff has been reduced to 18 from 21, through the layoffs and one vacancy going unfilled. Aaron Donovan, an M.T.A. spokesman, said that operations and hours would not be affected. The museum had 566,169 visitors last year at its two locations, in Brooklyn  and at Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Spill Commission Hires Science Adviser
text: The seven-member commission assembled by President Obama to investigate the BP spill has hired Richard A. Sears, a longtime Royal Dutch Shell scientist, engineer and offshore drilling expert, to be its chief technical adviser. Mr. Sears is on loan to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as a visiting scientist at the university’s Laboratory for Energy and the Environment.

headline: Jazz Concert in the Park Canceled
text: Organizers have canceled the Great Jazz on the Great Hill concert, scheduled for 2 to 5 p.m. on Saturday in Central Park, because of thunderstorm predictions. Cheryl L. Duncan, a spokeswoman for the concert, said the performers — including Jimmy Heath, Ray Mantilla, Dion Parson and Brianna Thomas — had been informed of the cancellation about midday on Friday, soon after the decision had been made. There is no rain date. The concert was being presented by Jazzmobile in collaboration with the Central Park Conservancy at the Great Hill, at 106th Street and Central Park West. An allied children’s workshop preceding the concert has also been canceled.

headline: Michael Tilson Thomas Looks Back on Bernstein and Mahler

Room, board and tuition are covered, with money to run the program coming from donors and ticket revenues from concerts offered by the Tanglewood Festival.

headline: Boy Meets Girl. Desire Clashes With Piety.

If you answered “an onstage murder,” you’re more likely than the average audience member to accept “The Little Death, Vol. 1,” a vibrant, enigmatic new work that opened on Thursday at St. Mark’s Church in the Bowery, as the opera it is billed to be.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: A suicide bomber attacked a group of tribal elders gathered near the headquarters of the civilian government in Mohmand, Pakistan, Jane Perlez and Ismail Khan report. More than 60 people were killed and more than 100 were wounded, a senior Pakistani security official said. The bomber detonated a car laden with explosives in the bazaar at Yakaghund, the administrative center of Mohmand, a tribal area, where elders were gathered over tea before a scheduled meeting with the assistant political agent, the security official said. The blast blew a crater nearly five feet deep, and victims were trapped in the rubble of scores of destroyed shops.

headline: The Spanish Game of Keepaway
text: When I watch Spain play at this World Cup, I get the feeling of what it must have been like to attend a dinner party with Oscar Wilde as a guest. You contemplate your leg of lamb and glass of Cote du Rhone, just waiting, waiting to get a word in, as the world’s greatest wit holds forth. He coins aphorisms about the lamb and the tablecloth. He rattles off a couplet on the merits of jogging inebriated while wearing a bowler hat. He discourses for an hour on the Byzantine empire and Racine and then when he’s done, throws in an epistle in Latin with the ease of a waiter dropping a napkin.

headline: Yankees’ Talks to Get Cliff Lee Hit a Snag

headline: Weekend Fare

Tasting tickets (ranging from $26.62 to $154.74) are available online  for the extravaganza, which runs from 11:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Half the net proceeds will benefit Just Food NYC and Slow Food NYC.

headline: Kids’ Money Questions: Will We Run Out of Money Now That You Have No Job?

headline: Ceviche, a No-Cook Meal

headline: Kids’ Money Questions: How Much Do You Make?

headline: At Delacorte and Other Stages, Nature Is a Star

But it is understood that when such performers sign up for a run of Shakespeare in the Park, they’ll be sharing the stage with another, even bigger star  that is, if she’ll let them. Though she goes by many names, we’ll call her Nature.

headline: Strutting and Wiggling to Hail of Witty Wordplay
text: These are early days in his career, but Chase Brock is turning out to be one of those prolific choreographers whose productivity is more substantial than the actual product. When placing him in context, it’s standard to bring up his career on Broadway (he performed in a revival of “The Music Man” as a teenager); his artistic precociousness (now 26, he formed a company four years ago); and, lately, his intriguing side project (he choreographed “Dance on Broadway” for the Nintendo Wii).

headline: They Loved ‘Big Brother’
text: The 12th edition of “Big Brother” earned a solid start in the ratings on Thursday as 7.3 million viewers tuned in to the CBS reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates, the most for a “Big Brother” premiere in three years. CBS led the night’s ratings over all, garnering 6.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. for a repeat of “CSI” and 8.6 million at 10 for a rerun of “The Mentalist.” ABC ranked second as its game show “Wipeout” (7.9 million) managed to outperform the “Big Brother” debut in the 8 p.m. slot. The network attracted lower ratings the rest of the night, however, drawing 6.4 million for “Rookie Blue” at 9, and 5 million at 10 for “Boston Med.” Fox, which broadcast “So You Think You Can Dance” at 9 (6 million) following a rerun of “Glee” (3.9 million), finished in third place over all.

headline: ‘Today’ to Allow Same-Sex Couples in Contest
text: NBC will change the application process for the “Today” show’s “Modern Day Wedding Contest” so that same-sex couples are permitted to participate, the network said Thursday. The change was announced after a campaign by Glaad, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, and a meeting between the organization’s representatives and the “Today” executive producer in New York. “Our intent was not to be discriminatory or exclusive,” the network said in a statement. “Today” said it had extended the Friday deadline for wedding applicants by three days so that same-sex couples could apply, and “moving forward, we ensure that our future wedding contests will be inclusive of all couples.” The contest is a staple of “Today,” the most popular morning show on television. It allows viewers to vote on every detail of a couple’s wedding, which is then broadcast live on the show. Even though same-sex couples will now be allowed to apply, it does not guarantee an appearance. “Today” producers sort through the applications and pick four finalist couples, and viewers take it from there, voting for which one should actually win the wedding and the all-expenses-paid honeymoon. The ceremony will take place on “Today” in October.

headline: ‘Avatar’ to Get Another Run in 3-D
text: “Avatar” will be back on 3-D Imax screens in August, and it will be longer than ever. Imax and 20th Century Fox said on Friday said that they planned to rerelease James Cameron’s science-fiction epic for a two-week run beginning Aug. 27. The film, which had a running time of 162 minutes, will include 8 minutes of new material. Fox executives had been mulling a rerelease ever since “Avatar,” which came out last Dec. 18, got nudged off Imax screens in March by Walt Disney’s “Alice in Wonderland.” The blockbuster has sold about $2.7 billion in tickets worldwide. (Above, Neytiri, played by Zoe Saldana, left, and Jake, played by Sam Worthington.)

headline: Pasadena Playhouse Out of Chapter 11
text: The Pasadena Playhouse in California has emerged from Chapter 11 and plans to mount a production this fall, the theater announced. Two months after it filed for bankruptcy protection, the playhouse’s reorganization plan was approved on Wednesday by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles. In February, the playhouse laid off its entire staff of 37 and was scheduled to close its doors because of deep debt. During its 90 years in operation, the playhouse has presented productions  most recently “Looped,” starring Valerie Harper  that have moved to Broadway, but it has also closed and filed for bankruptcy before. News of the playhouse’s struggles led to a $1 million matching pledge from anonymous donors, which helped to put the theater on better footing. The city, along with the theater’s board, staff members and advisers, “have all combined to create a plan to resurrect the Playhouse from years of unbearable debts,” the theater’s executive director, Stephen Eich, said in a statement. “Although we will be moving slowly in the future to ensure financial responsibility and stability, we will in fact be back.”

headline: For Sun Valley, a Conference That Brings Wealth
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — For local whitewater raft guides and yoga instructors alike, few weeks are better here than this one.

headline: City Police Officer Takes on the Swamps
text: No wonder crime shows have become so tic-infested lately, full of lead characters with fake psychic powers, obsessive-compulsive issues, hearing loss, whatever. Turns out that being a plain old lovable rogue is harder than it looks.

headline: A Cop Fights Crimes in and Out of the Station
text: Among this summer’s crop of new crime dramas, “The Bridge” is the one to root for, if only because its heart is in the right place. A co-venture of CBS, where it begins with two episodes on Saturday night, and the Canadian network CTV, the series is in the “NYPD Blue” and “Southland” vein, trying for realism. It isn’t in those shows’ league, but it’s a welcome change from the glossy triviality of other summer filler like “Rookie Blue” or “The Good Guys.”

headline: Not in My Baghdad Yard – Civic Protest, Iraqi-Style
text: BAGHDAD — I was driving past Qadisiya Park and I saw six shiny white banners strung tree to tree. The banners read, in neat blue and green print, “We urge Baghdad City Hall not to turn Qadisiya Park into a commercial plaza.” It was signed by “The people of Qadisiya district.”

headline: Living in NoHo
text: A downtown neighborhood that makes up in style what it lacks in size, with historic buildings and splashily added condominiums.

headline: Organic Drinks on the Go
text: On a recent morning at the Christopher Morley Park farmers’ market in Roslyn-North Hills, Dominic Chimienti, 36, of New Hyde Park, and his 4-year-old son, Jake, stood in front of the bright green Urban Oasis Cafe truck and considered the blackboard menu of organic juices and smoothies.

headline: Susan Cernek and Robert Giampietro
text: Susan Elizabeth Cernek and Robert Vincent Giampietro were married Saturday at Gedney Farm, an inn and party space in New Marlborough, Mass. Donna R. Thomas, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Abortion in the Eyes of a Girl From Dillon
text: Seated at Tami Taylor’s kitchen table, Becky Sproles wrenchingly lays out her dilemma: The only child of an embittered single bartender who gave birth to her when she was a teenager, Becky is faced with the prospect of recycling her mother’s past and she doesn’t know what to do.

headline: Reform Bill Retools Lending
text: THE financial reform bill still awaits final touches from the Senate, but now that Congress appears to have agreed on most of the principles in the new legislation, mortgage borrowers can get a glimpse of future lending practices.

But in the age of the iPad and the smartphone, two of the larger brokerages in New York — Halstead Property and the Corcoran Group — have made an investment in video as a marketing tool, though they differ on the best way to use it.

text: JUST over a year ago, Mark and Alejandra Ryan arrived in New York with little more than, as he put it, “a healthy dose of naïveté.”

headline: A Studio That Stretches to Fit
text: THE rambling apartment on the Left Bank of Paris where the writer Mary McCarthy settled in the 1960s was by all accounts an alluring place. In oral histories about the writer’s life and times, long-ago visitors wax rhapsodic about the William Morris wallpaper, the Meissen demitasse cups. They replay dinner parties at which celebrated artists and literary figures gathered to drink wine and savor Ms. McCarthy’s cooking.

headline: The March of the Conversions
text: IN the hierarchy of tradeoffs that a Manhattan apartment buyer inevitably has to make, one in particular has reigned supreme: if you wanted prewar charm you were probably going to end up in a co-op.

headline: Shaun Osher
text: Mr. Osher, 43, is a founder and the chief executive of the CORE Marketing Group, a boutique brokerage firm that markets luxury residential developments as well as individual homes throughout the New York region.

headline: NoHo
text: ON New York’s streets, finding a comfortable place to sit outdoors usually requires ordering something off a menu. While busy sidewalks may offer many delights, they are known to be short on free benches.

headline: ‘Much Ado’ on the Sound
text: It’s arguably the biggest news to come from southern Connecticut since a certain highly coveted N.B.A. free agent announced there that he was leaving his home state and heading for South Beach  or, at least, the newest news. The creative team of Stew and Heidi Rodewald, above, said on Friday that they would contribute to a third entry in a series of musical adaptations for Shakespeare on the Sound, and are creating music and songs for a production of “Much Ado About Nothing” for next summer. As with Shakespeare on the Sound’s 2009 staging of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” which featured a score by Stew, and the company’s current “Othello,” for which Stew wrote the music with Ms. Rodewald, “Much Ado About Nothing” will be directed by Joanna Settle, the company’s artistic director, press representatives said in a news release. The set designer Andrew Lieberman and the costume designer Tilly Grimes will also return for “Much Ado About Nothing,” which will be presented at Pinkney Park in Rowayton, Conn., and Baldwin Park in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 9
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include July 4th fireworks, keeping cool in a heat wave and a visit from Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Music From a Bridge, So Why Not a Tower?
text: The composer Joseph Bertolozzi recorded a broad range of sounds from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He hammered on I-beams and guardrails, whacked thick cables, sent steel pellets down the inside of a bridge tower and recorded the sounds. Mr. Bertolozzi, of Beacon, N.Y., turned them into a composition, “Bridge Music,” which can now be heard at listening stations on each side of the bridge, as well as at 95.3 FM on the radio in parks at either end. Now in his sights: the Eiffel Tower. Mr. Bertolozzi, armed with testimonials from politicians and music experts and the fruits of his bridge labors, wants to do something similar on the monument in Paris. He submitted his proposal to the Paris mayor’s office, which referred the matter to the Eiffel Tower’s administration. A tower spokeswoman, Marthe Ozbolt, said in an e-mail message that the request was being taken seriously and would be examined. Ms. Ozbolt noted that the project was linked to the tower’s 125th anniversary, in 2014, “So there is still time!” Mr. Bertolozzi said he was encouraged. “I can’t believe it, man,” he said. “It’s not a definite yet, but hey, it’s moving in baby steps.”

headline: It’s the Big Swing, Part 2: How the Open Trial Was Lost
text: The diagrammed deal, Board 110, is the second big-swing slam deal from the final of the open trial held last month. As with Board 99, described in Thursday’s column, the pair for the John Diamond team reached a small slam that was not bid by Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein for the Martin Fleisher team.

headline: Four Brothers Far Beyond a Pizzeria
text: LA VOLPE is the American dream realized. The restaurant is owned by members of the Volpe family who arrived on Long Island from Sicily in 1985 and opened Anton Pizzeria in Center Moriches two years later. The success of that venture ultimately led to the building of La Volpe, a large villa-style place that opened across the street in 2006. It incorporated the pizzeria (still named Anton) in the building.

headline: Knicks Zero In on Felton
text: The Knicks are on the verge of signing the free agent Raymond Felton, who will become the team’s starting point guard in the 2010-11 season. Felton, who won an N.C.A.A. championship with North Carolina in 2005, has played five seasons in the N.B.A., all with the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: Cliff Lee Traded to Texas Rangers
text: The Texas Rangers were bystanders for the playoffs in the first decade of the 2000s, but they are intent on returning this season, bankruptcy court or not. That became apparent on Friday, when the Rangers traded for the All-Star left-hander Cliff Lee, who had seemed to be headed to the Yankees.

headline: Seasonably Cold
text: The pastel interior at Gelatissimo — Key lime walls, mango yellow countertop, papaya-colored tables — complements the colorful gelati in its freezer case: a large range of sumptuous flavors that Nuccia Mazzoneggo has been offering her customers in New Canaan for the past five years. Out of a rotating list of about 60, up to 22 flavors are available at a given time (from $3.75 to $6.25 a serving, depending on size). All are made on the premises by Ms. Mazzoneggo in batches no larger than a gallon and a half.

text: In this new series, a co-venture of CBS and the Canadian network CTV, a cop fights internal corruption as well as street crime.

text: A plotline in the NBC series involves a character's unwanted pregnancy.

headline: Vegetarian Specialties With Indian Flair
text: YOU don’t have to be a vegetarian to enjoy many of the dishes at Navaratna in downtown Stamford. Most Indian chefs know the secret of making vegetables exciting, but at Navaratna, Ramesh Masilamani, the chef and owner, takes this skill to new heights.

headline: Turning the Page on the Page Turn
text: On Thursday a tidbit of news circulated around the Web that Microsoft had filed a patent application in late 2009 hoping to lay claim to the look and feel of page turns on a touchscreen device.

text: Torico in Jersey City started as a simple delicatessen but soon became a hot spot for ice cream when one of the owners developed a craving for it.

text: When Nicholas Longrich stumbled upon a fossilized fragment from a previously unknown dinosaur genus in the basement of the American Museum of Natural History in New York, he rejected the traditions that usually govern dinosaur nomenclature.

headline: An Amateur Returns to Reality
text: OAKMONT, Pa. — Less than 12 hours after her storybook round at the United States Women’s Open, Kelli Shean returned to Oakmont Country Club with her eyes half shut. She was so excited after her opening 70, she didn’t get much sleep, and on her first nine, fatigue overwhelmed her.

headline: Shadi Khadivi and Jason D’Cruz

headline: Federation Is Sued; Ilyumzhinov Claims More Support
text: Several national federations and the presidential campaign of Anatoly Karpov filed a lawsuit against the World Chess Federation on Thursday in the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland. The lawsuit, which was filed by White & Case, a Manhattan firm, is seeking to have the ticket of Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the incumbent who is running for re-election, disqualified.

headline: Agency Drops Mel Gibson After Latest Episode
text: Mel Gibson has been dumped by his agency.

headline: Beauty for the Palate and for the Eyes
text: DAYS after visiting Uproot, I am thinking of fine things: the Riedel water glasses — impossibly thin, delicate cylinders that reflect ambient light and make the liquid inside appear all the more desirable; the soaring wall of colored glass that feels churchlike and inspires attention to the meals; and finally, the food on the plates.

headline: Defined by Soccer: Ricardo Rico Kutumela
text: Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa for the World Cup to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. Based in Alexandra — a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people — the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.

headline: Demetra Marcus, Blaine Bell
text: Demetra A. Marcus and Blaine A. Bell were married Saturday at Beaulieu Garden, a vineyard in Rutherford, Calif. Bishop William E. Swing, who retired from the Episcopal Diocese of California, performed the ceremony.

headline: Special Session on West Virginia Election
text: Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia on Friday said he would call the state legislature into special session next week to take up the issues surrounding the succession of Robert C. Byrd, with a special election in November likely.

text: THOSE who have long urged stodgy American orchestras to let a new generation of conductors take charge and shake things up have to be pleased with, even amazed at, what is going on.

headline: Film Society of Lincoln Center Replaces Its Director
text: In an apparent shake-up, the Film Society of Lincoln Center on Friday named a new executive director, Rose Kuo, replacing Mara Manus, the former executive director of the Public Theater who had been hired with some fanfare less than two years ago.

headline: Dena Twain, Timothy Sims
text: Dena Rose Twain and Timothy Jackson Sims were married Saturday at the Barksdale-Isom House in Oxford, Miss., an event space and bed-and-breakfast inn. Judge Mickey Avent, who sits on the Justice Court of Lafayette County, Miss., officiated.

headline: Inspired Teacher, Engaged by Music, Not Labels
text: WE’RE often told that Manhattan’s new-music scene was neatly divided across the middle during the 1960s. Rigid modernist composers reigned in uptown academia while anything-goes experimentalists ruled in downtown lofts: diametrically opposed factions separated by a growing midtown arts complex named Lincoln Center, which ignored them both.

headline: Teach Me to Dance Like Fred or Fela
text: A MAN leaned over to change from cordovan loafers into gold slippers as people started filing into Carlos König’s salsa class in Midtown Manhattan on a recent humid night. Dropping briefcases, handbags and backpacks on folding chairs at the side of the room, many women also slipped out of their flats and donned sexy dancing sandals. Ranging in age from 20 to 78, the group included chief executives, teachers and police officers. When Eddie Palmieri’s vibrant “Malagueña Salerosa” began flooding the fluorescent-lighted room, they looked for partners and listened for the beat.

text: The Texas Rangers might want to thank the other 29 major league teams for helping them land Cliff Lee from the Seattle Mariners.

headline: More Killings May Be Linked to ‘Sleeper’

A team of detectives Thursday began combing through 30 cold-case homicide files with similarities to those already linked to Lonnie D. Franklin Jr., the man accused of serial killings spanning 25 years.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: The paradisiacal island of Madeira has a new attraction: burgeoning night life. Henry Alford explores the majestic landscape by day and club-hops by night.  He writes: “A younger breed of traveler is increasingly drawn to this 35-by-14-mile volcanic island, where new boutique hotels, roads and night life are a beguiling addition to Madeira’s age-old prime asset: spectacular scenery in the form of dramatic sea cliffs and hundreds of miles of levadas, or irrigation channels, that make for terrific hiking.”

headline: Pentagon Ends Guantánamo Reporters’ Ban

headline: Glimpses of Cuba and Its Paradoxes

headline: Chinese Separatists Tied to Norway Bomb Plot
text: BEIJING  The arrests on Thursday of three men in Norway and Germany accused of orchestrating a terrorist bomb plot seemed like another routine raid by a Western government in the continuing campaign against groups linked to Al Qaeda. But one detail stuck out: Norwegian officials said one of the men was a Chinese Uighur, and all three supposedly belonged to a group that advocates separatism in western China.

headline: Leno: ‘Watching the Matches From His Cave’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, the big story in Washington is the Obama administration has had the Justice Department file a lawsuit to block Arizona’s tough new immigration law. The government is saying Arizona’s new law is unconstitutional. See, legally, there’s only one entity that can determine who can come work in this country. And that, of course, is Wal-Mart.

headline: Kerr Among Clubhouse Leaders
text: OAKMONT, Pa.  Cristie Kerr knows how to play a golf course, but sometimes she has trouble working a room. Asked how mentally exhausting it was to play the Oakmont Country Club course, Kerr said she was so tired after her first round of the United States Women’s Open that she could have only one glass of wine with dinner instead of two or three.

headline: Opulent and Elegant, Dresses as Art
text: The dim lighting and reverent installation of the main exhibition at the Bruce Museum invite the kind of stillness and awed contemplation usually reserved for works of art. But the icons on view are not important pieces of painting and sculpture or rare artifacts unearthed from faraway civilizations. They are dresses, 24 of them, most acquired from donors in Connecticut and New York. And their variety of form, opulence of drape and richness of ornament argue forcefully for the justice of such exalted treatment.

headline: W.N.B.A.’s Taurasi Considers a Breather
text: PHOENIX  While the N.B.A.’s best player has decided to play in Miami next season, the best player in the W.N.B.A. is considering taking a hiatus from the league.

headline: Tara Copeland and Andrew Eastwick

headline: With Gloves Off, Obama Stumps for Reid
text: LAS VEGAS  President Obama wrapped up a two-day campaign swing on Friday with a full-throated defense of his economic policies and a warm-hearted embrace for the Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, a onetime boxer who is counting on the president to help him fight his way through a tough re-election race.

headline: Henry Expected To Join Red Bulls
text: The speculation that Thierry Henry will be joining the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer has been around longer than the French team’s stay in South Africa for the 2010 World Cup. The rumor may become reality on Thursday  the club has called a news conference at Red Bull Arena to introduce its newest designated player. It has long been accepted wisdom that Henry, a striker who has played for Arsenal and most recently for Barcelona, will be the next addition to the M.L.S. club. He has been released from his contract in Spain and has long expressed an affinity for the New York area and the United States. In its news release, the club touts “100 Rumors, 50 Names and 1 Star” who will soon join the club.
