headline: A Closer Look at the Art, Until ‘Beep!’
text: GINA QUINONES walked gingerly into a room at the Cloisters on a May afternoon and gasped in delight upon seeing the famed Merode Altarpiece, a vivid 15th-century triptych depicting the Annunciation.

headline: U.S. Widens Tax Inquiry Into HSBC
text: Federal prosecutors are ramping up their criminal investigation into HSBC concerning its sale of offshore tax services to wealthy Americans suspected of evading taxes, according to two people briefed on the matter and to court papers.

headline: Major SUNY Donor Links an Even Bigger Gift to Flexibility on Setting Tuition
text: He rarely grants interviews and is largely unknown in Albany circles. But as state lawmakers battle over Gov. David A. Paterson’s controversial proposal to overhaul New York’s public universities, James Simons, a hedge fund manager who is one of the world’s wealthiest men, has emerged as a powerful behind-the-scenes force.

headline: A Statement Hits Home as Cleveland Stews
text: CLEVELAND  David Loomis, a marketing consultant and professor, is soft-spoken and friendly. His pleasant personal demeanor reflects his professional commitment to what might be described as holistic branding. He preaches that “marketing is everything we do,” and among the guiding principles listed on his Web site are: “Build bridges,” “Be diplomatic” and “Don’t draw conclusions too early.”

headline: When Albany Got Things Done
text: Oh, Albany! Imagine getting nostalgic about this state’s government. But two new collaborations recall an era four decades ago when the Legislature was among only four in the country granted the highest rating by the Citizens Conference on State Legislatures, a prominent civic group, and when the governor of New York was widely hailed as a hero.

headline: Weighing the Possibility of Bankruptcy for BP
text: With pockets as deep as BP’s — its assets are worth more than $260 billion — the possibility that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection because of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill is considered remote by many industry experts.

headline: John Makin’s Hair Is On Fire
text: He’s politically conservative, and is based at a right-wing think tank. But his warning about the looming danger of deflation reads just like something I or Jan Hatzius (Goldman’s chief economist — never mind the Blankfein stuff, the econ group is very good, and very pessimistic) might have written. Except Makin is even more gloomy, warning that we might enter deflation this year.

headline: The Cozy Italian Wine Bar, All Dressed Up
text: There are restaurants that define a genre, and restaurants that define a street corner. This uptown, upscale offshoot of ‘ino in the West Village — which helped seed the trend of tiny Italian wine-and-sandwich bars — somehow manages to do both at 24th Street and Third Avenue. Similar to the three downtown hangouts also started by the brothers Joe and Jason Denton, but like little else in this nondescript precinct nestled amid Gramercy Park, the Flatiron district and Kips Bay, ‘Inoteca e Liquori Bar is its siblings “all dressed up,” said Jason Denton. With a robust cocktail menu in addition to wines, snacks, pastas and small plates, it feels more like a full restaurant, attracting a business and neighborhood crowd to its cozy wood-paneled bar and marble-walled dining room. True to its casual roots, though, it is still the kind of place where you might be seated or served by Mr. Denton.  DIANE CARDWELL

headline: Pulse
text: What Liya Kebede is wearing now; Balenciaga’s classica bags now in pony; the hottest lipstick colors of the summer and more items.

headline: Bloggingheads: News for Dummies
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Michelle Cottle of The New Republic debate the intelligence of cable news.

headline: Criticism Grows as James Arrives in Miami
text: As the fans and players of the 29 other N.B.A. franchises cringed at the union of LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, Miami did what it does best — partied.

headline: Basis of Ruling on Gay Unions Stirs Debate
text: A judge’s decision on Thursday declaring that a state law allowing same-sex marriage in Massachusetts should take precedence over a federal definition of marriage has exposed the fractures and fault lines among groups working to bolster states’ rights.

headline: Readers’ Questions Answered
text: Q. Why is Madison Square Garden called a garden? Was it ever a garden?

headline: Rangers Get Lee; Yanks Feel Used
text: The Yankees know how the game works. General Manager Brian Cashman  echoing the sage of the organization, Yogi Berra  often says a deal is never final until it is final. After all, George Steinbrenner once signed David Wells over Christmas Eve cheeseburgers, persuading Wells to back out of an agreement with the Arizona Diamondbacks.

headline: Staying Behind Bars on a Claim of Innocence
text: He is either innocent or a madman. Whichever one he is, Everton Wagstaffe will not go quietly.

headline: Intrigue and Ambiguity in Cases of 4 Russians Sent to West in Spy Swap
text: WASHINGTON  When Aleksandr Zaporozhsky, one of four Russians delivered to the West in this week’s spy swap, landed at Dulles International Airport on Friday to join his family in the United States, it was only the latest unexpected twist in a classic story of espionage and deception.

headline: Caustic Government Report Deals Blow to Diabetes Drug
text: WASHINGTON  A federal drug official on Friday dealt a severe blow to the popular diabetes drug Avandia, issuing a scathing review of a major clinical trial that its manufacturer has been using to argue that the drug was safe.

headline: 13 Artists, and Just as Many Themes
text: The 13 artists exhibiting in “in.flec.tion,” at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art, seem to have nothing in common. They work in a variety of styles and media — painting, sculpture, video — and share no theme.

headline: A Blues Festival, Now in Harmony
text: FOR a while, it seemed as though audiences might be singing the blues instead of hearing them in Riverhead next weekend. The board of the Vail-Leavitt Music Hall, which has run the Riverhead Blues and Music Festival since 2006, and the Riverhead Chamber of Commerce both sought permits to hold the same festival in the same place at the same time. Local news reports referred to political squabbling, and Newsday reported that perhaps there would be no festival at all.

headline: In India, Castes, Honor and Killings Intertwine
text: KODERMA, India  When Nirupama Pathak left this remote mining region for graduate school in New Delhi, she seemed to be leaving the old India for the new. Her parents paid her tuition and did not resist when she wanted to choose her own career. But choosing a husband was another matter.

headline: The LeBron Angle to Everything
text: LeBron James is moving! Lindsay Lohan is crying! Paul the Octopus says Spain will win the World Cup!

headline: Illegal Workers Swept From Jobs in ‘Silent Raids’
text: BREWSTER, Wash.  The Obama administration has replaced immigration raids at factories and farms with a quieter enforcement strategy: sending federal agents to scour companies’ records for illegal immigrant workers.

headline: A Quiet Neighborhood Talks About Policing Itself
text: The streets of the enclave called Country Club in the northeast Bronx have names plucked from Wagnerian operas Lohengrin, Parsifal, Siegfried and Valhalla. They enhance the neighborhood’s air of civility, and that aura has been strengthened for many years by a low crime rate. The last murder in the 45th Precinct, which includes Country Club, was in January 2009.

headline: Restoring a Hallowed Vision
text: “We’re going to show that there is a different day in America  that working people are sick and tired of the bosses getting million-dollar bonuses and the workers getting the short end of the stick.”

headline: Korean War Panel Finds U.S. Attacks on Civilians
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A commission charged with investigating wartime atrocities has found that American troops killed groups of South Korean civilians on 138 separate occasions during the Korean War.

headline: Redefining Marriage
text: For 14 years, as states, courts and many Americans began to change their minds on the subject, the federal government has clung to its official definition of marriage as only between a man and a woman. On Thursday, a federal judge in Massachusetts finally stood up and said there was never a rational basis for that definition. Though we are a little wary of one path Judge Joseph L. Tauro took to declare the definition unconstitutional, the outcome he reached is long overdue.

headline: New York Truck Companies Investigated for Fraud
text: Federal and local authorities are investigating whether what they say is a network of trucking companies  some of which worked on 1 World Trade Center and the Second Avenue subway  has defrauded union benefit funds, according to court papers and people briefed on the inquiry.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: After the Flotilla
text: Nearly six weeks later, Turkey and Israel are still stoking anger over the disastrous Israeli attack on a Gaza-bound aid ship. Their posturing and threats are playing into the hands of extremists. Both countries need to find ways to cool things down.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 9, 2010

headline: Help for Damaged Warriors
text: For too long, scores of thousands of veterans afflicted with post-traumatic stress disorder have been denied proper treatment and much-needed help. While routinely hailed as heroes in home-front salutes, only about half of the more than 150,000 men and women diagnosed with P.T.S.D.  suffering flashbacks, emotional numbness and other debilitating symptoms  have been approved for disability claims by the veterans department.

headline: West Virginia: Legislature to Consider Special Election
text: Gov. Joe Manchin III on Friday scheduled a special session on July 15 for the Legislature to decide whether the state should hold a special election this year to choose a successor to Senator Robert C. Byrd. Mr. Manchin can appoint an interim senator to serve until an election is held either this year or in 2012. The governor, a Democrat, has said that he might run for the seat, but that he would not appoint himself to it. State Attorney General Darrell McGraw said an election could be held in November, while the state’s top election official, Secretary of State Natalie Tennant, has said an interim senator appointed should serve until 2012, when the seat was up for election. The death of Mr. Byrd on June 28 has complicated Democrats’ efforts to pass financial-regulation legislation. Senate Democrats need 60 votes to win passage, and they now control 58 votes.

headline: Gays Can’t Wed in New York, So a Politician Won’t Either
text: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, buys his bagels at H&H, his groceries at Fairway and his coffee at Lenny’s (Starbucks is, after all, a Seattle company). He roots for the Jets, exercises in Riverside Park and pops into the Museum of Natural History.

headline: Excerpts From the ‘Autobiography of Mark Twain’
text: One hundred years after his death, the University of California Press is publishing the “Autobiography of Mark Twain: The Complete and Authoritative Edition” in a series of three volumes, edited by Harriet Elinor Smith and the editors of the Mark Twain Project. It will be the first time the entire text has appeared in print. Here are some of Twain’s spicier comments, all drawn from Volume 1.

headline: Floodwaters Inundate Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  There are times when the Rio Grande is little more than a trickle running through a concrete ditch separating Mexico and the United States.

headline: New York City’s Illegal Non-Hotels
text: The Web sites show happy young travelers bunking within a few blocks of Broadway. And they offer a place to stay in such a glamorous, expensive city for only $15 a night. The problem is that a growing number of these “hotels” are unsafe, unsanitary and illegal.

headline: Bill Clinton to Officiate at Congressman’s Wedding
text: Bill Clinton is not giving away his daughter Chelsea’s hand in marriage for another three weeks. But he is going to get a little practice at the altar on Saturday, when he officiates at the wedding of Representative Anthony D. Weiner and Huma Abedin, a longtime aide to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Dead for a Century, Twain Says What He Meant
text: Wry and cranky, droll and cantankerous  that’s the Mark Twain we think we know, thanks to reading “Huck Finn” and “Tom Sawyer” in high school. But in his unexpurgated autobiography, whose first volume is about to be published a century after his death, a very different Twain emerges, more pointedly political and willing to play the role of the angry prophet.

headline: Iraq: Suicide Car Bomber Strikes Army Checkpoint
text: Five people were killed and 18 others were wounded Friday when a suicide car bomber detonated his vehicle at an Iraqi Army checkpoint in western Baghdad, the authorities said. Three soldiers were among the dead. Iraqi authorities also said 75 people were killed and more than 400 others wounded during attacks on Shiite pilgrims in Baghdad during the annual procession to the shrine of the eighth-century Imam Musa al-Kadhim, which ended Thursday.

headline: European Bank’s Economist Is Optimistic on Sovereign Debt, but Critics Are Wary
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank’s de facto chief economist said Friday that “the worst is over” for Europe’s sovereign debt crisis and expressed optimism about the Continent’s growth, underscoring similar comments by the head of the bank in what seemed to be a concerted effort to restore confidence in the euro area’s economy.

headline: With Its Economy Strong, South Korea Raises Rates
text: HONG KONG  Barring any surprises, interest rates in the United States and much of Europe look set to stay steady until next year. But in fast-growing Asia, the cost of borrowing has begun to creep up again.

headline: Rwanda: Editor Is Arrested and Accused of Defamation
text: Agnes Uwimana, the editor of the private newspaper known popularly as Umurabyo, was arrested on Friday on charges of defaming the president and espousing genocide ideology, the police said. Ms. Uwimana angered authorities over articles they said threatened state security and denied Rwanda’s genocide. Umurabyo is the third private newspaper in Rwanda to face legal trouble before coming elections. She was convicted of genocide ideology and faces up to 50 years in prison if convicted again.

headline: France: Police Search Offices of Heiress’s Wealth Manager
text: The police on Friday searched the Neuilly-sur-Seine offices of Patrice de Maistre, the wealth manager for Liliane Bettencourt, the heiress to the L’Oréal fortune, in an effort to uncover evidence tied to allegations that Mrs. Bettencourt evaded taxes and gave cash illegally to politicians, including Nicolas Sarkozy and his successful 2007 presidential campaign. Mrs. Bettencourt, France’s wealthiest woman, lives in Neuilly, the Paris suburb where Mr. Sarkozy was mayor. Mrs. Bettencourt, Mr. de Maistre and Mr. Sarkozy have denied any involvement in a scandal that began with Mrs. Bettencourt’s butler secretly taping conversations about tax evasion and political favors.

headline: Make Social Security Pay, Today
text: Washington

headline: Field’s Pair
text: “I can’t deny the fact that you like me, right now, you like me!”

headline: Automatic for the People
text: Athens, Ga.

headline: Reyes Is Willing to Do What It Takes to Play
text: Life keeps getting stranger for Jose Reyes as he tries to figure out a way to stay in the lineup despite a sore oblique muscle.

headline: Condemnation of Ship’s Sinking Is a ‘Victory,’ North Korean Says
text: The North Korean envoy to the United Nations, Sin Son-ho, called a statement condemning the sinking of a South Korean warship, which the Security Council passed unanimously Friday, “our great diplomatic victory.” The statement condemned the March torpedo attack, which killed 48 sailors on the Cheonan, without singling out North Korea as responsible, although it did note that a South Korean inquiry had found North Korea to blame. Li Baodong, the ambassador from China, which helped block direct condemnation of North Korea, said the statement moved matters in “the right direction” because it urged “the parties concerned” to avoid escalating tensions.

headline: James’s Decision Means a New Plan for the Knicks
text: A single phrase  “South Beach”  sent stacks of spreadsheets into the shredder and turned a dozen Plan B’s into reality.

headline: The Write-Off Recovery
text: THE slowdown among small businesses may well be the most worrisome problem in our ailing economy. Small businesses generate the majority of new jobs; if they falter, the rest of the private sector will, too.

headline: Preparing to Face, or Join, Yanks. Then, Neither.
text: SEATTLE  Cliff Lee sent Jack Zduriencik, the general manager of the Seattle Mariners, a text message Friday morning with a simple but complex request: “Am I pitching tonight?” Zduriencik did not know yet. “I’ll be in touch with you shortly,” he wrote back.

headline: Spain, United on the Field and Off
text: Remember when Spain was considered too regionally fractious to field a national team strong enough to truly contend for the World Cup title? A team whose players were supposedly too loyal to their various regions — Andalusia, Catalonia, the Basque Country, Galicia and so on — to unite as an effective selección española, and whose fans were supposedly too riven by regional differences to unite behind it?

headline: Three Ways to Jump-Start the Economy
text: Three people offer their solutions to the stalled economy.

headline: Mets and Braves Resume Rivalry, With Familiar Results
text: Before this weekend, Citi Field had known nothing of the Mets’ once-fierce rivalry with the Atlanta Braves.

headline: They Have Just the Parrot Lamp for You
text: Each week, about 150 vendors bring their wares to the Brooklyn Flea in Fort Greene.

headline: Sergei Tretyakov, Spy Who Fled to U.S., Dies at 53
text: Sergei Tretyakov, a high-ranking Russian spy who defected to the United States after the end of the cold war, died on June 13 at his home in Florida. He was 53. His wife, Helen, announced his death on Friday on the Washington radio station WTOP.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns @nytimes.com.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: The Problems With Naked-Body Airport Scans Exposed
text: I just walked through my first Rapiscan 1000 at Chicago’s O’Hare airport.

headline: Saturday’s Game: Germany vs. Uruguay
text: Germany vs. Uruguay

headline: Exports Hit Record in China as Trade Gap Surges
text: China’s trade surplus for June widened to the highest level this year and exports for the month climbed more than expected, hitting a record. The gains add pressure on the government to let the nation’s currency appreciate after a report from the United States Treasury said the currency, the renminbi, “remains undervalued.”

headline: A Test for Your Budget and Your Coffee Table
text: In the short history of sports megabooks, there has been a 75-pounder about Muhammad Ali, a celebration of Pelé that was a shapely 35 pounds, and a history of the Super Bowl that tipped the publishing scales at 85 pounds.

headline: Missing Out on Lee, Yanks Move On and Beat Mariners
text: SEATTLE  A clear gap already existed between the Yankees and the rest of the American League, and the gulf would have widened Friday had they succeeded in acquiring Cliff Lee. They did not, so they were forced to play the Seattle Mariners with only eight All-Stars in their dugout. Somehow, they managed to win their seventh consecutive game, leaning on seven impressive innings from Phil Hughes and two home runs by Mark Teixeira to defeat the Mariners, 6-1, at Safeco Field.

headline: Disappointing Results at Birth Control Company
text: Conceptus, a maker of a form of permanent birth control, said Friday that its quarterly results fell short of forecasts, setting off a 20 percent decline in its share price. In a preliminary statement of its second-quarter results, Conceptus said it lost 1 to 2 cents a share on sales of $36.8 million to $36.9 million. The company had forecast sales of $39.5 million. The company also lowered its full-year forecast. Stock in Conceptus, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., fell $3.12, to $12.67 a share. The company plans to release its full results in August.

headline: Fiat to Move Production of One Model to Italy
text: Fiat will proceed with an investment of 700 million euros ($875 million) to produce its Panda model at a domestic plant, even though it drew opposition from a large union. The chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, clarified Fiat’s plan for the factory, in Pomigliano near Naples, in a letter to company’s employees. “I write to you as a man who has and still believes firmly in the possibility of building together, in Italy, something great, something better and long-lasting,” Mr. Marchionne said in the letter. In a referendum last month about 60 percent of workers at Pomigliano, Fiat’s least productive factory, supported the company’s proposals to add shifts, shorten sick leave and reduce strikes as part of a plan to transfer Panda production from Poland. Four out of five unions representing the 5,000 workers at the site backed Fiat’s plan. Mr. Marchionne wanted support from all five of the labor groups. Fiat currently produces Alfa Romeo models at the Pomigliano plant.

headline: Classic Ad: Mercedes
text: It’s true: the Wheels blog tends to favor the kitschy, the embarrassing, or the downright corny car commercials of the past. But we have our sentimental side, too.

headline: Urban Forager | From Sidewalk Cracks, a Side Dish
text: As I was running up the outdoor steps to my doctor’s office on Staten Island recently, I saw the succulent trailing tendrils of purslane growing nearby. As far as I could see across the dry, scorched lawn, purslane was the only plant thriving in the brutal summer heat.

headline: Climate Panel Struggles With Media Plan
text: The 831 researchers who will contribute to the next round of assessments of climate science and policy options by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change have been sent a letter admonishing them to “keep a distance from the media” and send any press inquiries about the work of their author groups to supervisors.

headline: Maybe One iPad Recipe Begins, ‘Dip Apple in Kraft Caramels’
text: Among the mainstream packaged-goods marketers, Kraft Foods is among the most adventurous in trying out new ways to reach consumers like social media. Now, Kraft is getting all experimental again with an application for the Apple iPad.

headline: Handling a Heckler
text: Video | Comedian loses crowd but wins it back just as quickly:

headline: Death Toll Climbs in Attack on Tribal Meeting in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The death toll from Friday's suicide bomb attack on a group of tribal elders near the headquarters of the civilian government in Mohmand rose to more than 100 on Saturday, officials said, wounding more than 80.

headline: Saturday Word: Military Matters
text: President Obama announced on Saturday that the Veterans Affairs Department will start taking steps to make benefits and treatment more accessible to veterans with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

headline: Leno: ‘People Got Confused’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, last night, in a special one-hour show on ESPN, LeBron James addressed the nation. And a lot of people got confused. In fact, when Glenn Beck saw it, he called LeBron a Muslim and demanded to see his birth certificate.

headline: Arid Australia Sips Seawater, but at a Cost
text: BRISBANE, Australia  In Australia, the world’s driest inhabited continent, early British explorers searching for a source of drinking water scoured the bone-dry interior for a fabled inland sea. One overeager believer even carted a whaleboat hundreds of miles from the coast, but found mostly desert inside. Today, Australians are turning in the opposite direction: the sea.

headline: YouTube Question: Who’s Your Favorite Philosopher?
text: Over the next several days, Nick will be responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today, Nick discusses his favorite philosopher, or as the question put it, his favorite “source of ethical values”: Sir Isaiah Berlin.

headline: Title in Hand, Brees Embraces Platform
text: On a recent sweltering afternoon in Times Square, people might have been too busy searching for an open hydrant to pay much attention to the man wearing a New Orleans Saints jersey tossing copies of the soon-to-be released Madden NFL 11 video game into the crowd.

headline: In Formula One, Team Concept Is Being Tested
text: The Formula One season that reaches its halfway point at the British Grand Prix at Silverstone on Sunday has not been similar to recent years in which one or two drivers collect most of the victories and steal the show.

headline: Second Body Identified in Philadelphia Boat Crash
text: Authorities in Philadelphia on Saturday identified the second body recovered from the Delaware River as that of a missing 20-year-old Hungarian tourist, and mourners later attended a private service honoring both young passengers of a sightseeing boat that capsized after being rammed by a barge three days earlier.

headline: Bringing the World to Africa Through Art and Soccer
text: 2010 Fine Art is an international exhibition and sale of original art work commissioned for the World Cup.

headline: In Celebration of Soccer Artistry, a Mix of Styles
text: JOHANNESBURG  For most South Africans, soccer looks like the images in Clint Strydom’s high-contrast black and white photographs. Barefoot pre-teen boys sporting broad smiles kicking a ragged ball through sand and dirt in KwaZulu Natal.

headline: Success in Sports Lifts Spirits in Spain
text: MADRID  Wednesday morning saw the first running of the bulls in Pamplona in what is probably Spain’s best-known annual festival.

headline: A Player Worth Remembering in a Year When He’ll Be Missed
text: At his best, Severiano Ballesteros played golf in bursts of genius. At the 1983 Masters, he teed off in the final round a stroke behind Raymond Floyd and Craig Stadler, and a stroke ahead of Tom Watson, but with a birdie-eagle-par-birdie start (four holes, only 12 strokes, thank you), he soared into the lead, shot a 69 and won by four.

headline: Indian Pioneer Learning as He Goes
text: Coimbatore, India, is many hard miles from the asphalt-paved speed bowls in the United States, where a 33-year-old driver named Narain Karthikeyan has come to chase fame and fortune  and perhaps something bigger  in Nascar’s truck-racing division.

headline: Teams Looking for a Little More Bounce From Bobbleheads
text: Are bobbleheads old hat? That is the question some baseball executives are asking.

headline: 6 Americans Killed in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Militants killed five American service members on Saturday in five separate attacks as casualties continued to mount in what has become, by far, the deadliest year since the 2001 invasion. Another American soldier died Saturday from what military officials described as an “accidental explosion.”

headline: Marching Bands
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Variety puzzles like this one remind me of driving a car in Britain. You get reminded of the fun you had when you were first learning the basic rules but you need to concentrate in new ways. Much of what you know still applies — the gas pedal is still on the right — but now you’re shifting gears with your left hand. Whatever instincts you have must be challenged and, for goodness’ sake, look both ways before you venture into the grid!

headline: For Riley, It’s Act VI of Showtime
text: Patrick James Riley turned 65 in March, the retirement marker for many but apparently the age of reinvention for him. Just when Riley seemed to be on the verge of fading into professional irrelevance, he executed an unprecedented triple play, touching all the recruiting bases and positioning himself for a climactic act of a six-decade career that could resemble the finale of a summer fireworks show.

headline: The Cornerback and the Ex-Con
text: POMPANO BEACH, Fla.  The cornerback steered his custom truck through familiar streets. The ex-convict sat shotgun and pointed out landmarks, this “drug hole,” that “crack house,” the best routes for eluding the police.

headline: Celebrating South Africa and a Job Done Well
text: Sandton, South Africa

headline: For Final, South Africans Put Past Aside
text: JOHANNESBURG  Given that the Dutch are former colonial masters and their descendants instigated the harsh racial policies of apartheid, one might think that many South Africans, blacks especially, would not cheer for the Netherlands against Spain on Sunday in the World Cup final.

headline: ‘If FIFA Applied Sharia Law’
text: Ahead of Saturday’s expected return to World Cup action by Uruguay’s Luis Suárez — the striker who boasted about intentionally using his hands to keep his team from losing to Ghana at the quarterfinal stage — South African political cartoonist Zapiro expressed his dismay in a drawing that appeared under the headline, “The Unfair Hand of God: A Continent’s Hope Thwarted by Cheating Uruguayan.”

headline: Wall St. Hiring in Anticipation of an Economic Recovery
text: While much of the country remains fixated on the bleak employment picture, hiring is beginning to pick up in the place that led the economy into recession  Wall Street.

headline: Cyclists’ Alpine Times May Hint at Past Doping
text: LES ROUSSES, France  When the riders in the Tour de France head into the Alps on Sunday, tackling the first high mountains of this year’s race, all eyes will be on them. Stopwatches will be ticking.

headline: Synthetic Marijuana Spurs State Bans
text: ST. LOUIS  Seated at a hookah lounge in the Tower Grove district, Albert Kuo trained his lighter above a marbleized glass pipe stuffed with synthetic marijuana. Inhaling deeply, Mr. Kuo, an art student at an area college, singed the pipe’s leafy contents, emitting a musky cloud of smoke into the afternoon light.

headline: Veteran Players Lobby U.S.G.A. for a Women’s Senior Open
text: OAKMONT, Pa.  On a golf range last fall in Palm Harbor, Fla., a woman in a row of middle-aged professional players advanced the idea of trying to qualify for the next United States Senior Open, a tournament associated with men but technically not limited to them.

headline: A Dutch Great Helped Transform Spain’s Game
text: JOHANNESBURG — Catalonia did not play in the World Cup here. It has never participated in the tournament and, because it is not a recognized member of FIFA, it quite possibly never will.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Jon Stewart, a sexist?

headline: So Hot That...
text: Yes, it was hot last Tuesday, July 6, when the temperature hit 103 degrees in Central Park, a record for the date. But the hottest day ever in New York City was July 9, 1936, when the mercury reached 106 degrees in Central Park. Here’s how The Times reported it:

headline: Ambitious Effort Begins to Contain All Spill Oil
text: NEW ORLEANS  Crews removed a cap from atop BP’s out-of-control well in the Gulf of Mexico on Saturday, beginning an ambitious engineering effort that could fully contain the huge oil leak but will also make matters worse, at least temporarily.

headline: Prime Number
text: 2: The estimated amount, in millions of dollars, that Wal-Mart Stores has spent in legal fees battling a $7,000 federal fine, which was assessed after shoppers trampled a Wal-Mart employee to death at a Long Island store in 2008.

headline: Smile for the Camera. Blow into the Sensor. Uncork the Wine.
text: Want to buy wine in Pennsylvania? You have to go to a state-owned liquor store. But that may be about to change.

headline: Some Players Are Not All-Stars, but They Are All-Important
text: John Sterling, the longtime radio voice of the Yankees, often observes in his broadcasts that you cannot predict baseball. And he is right, of course. If we could, why would we watch?

headline: ‘If FIFA Applied Sharia Law’
text: Ahead of Saturday’s expected return to World Cup action by Uruguay’s Luis Suárez — the striker who boasted about intentionally using his hands to keep his team from losing to Ghana at the quarterfinal stage — South African political cartoonist Zapiro expressed his dismay in a drawing that appeared under the headline, “The Unfair Hand of God: A Continent’s Hope Thwarted by Cheating Uruguayan.”

headline: Severed Trees in Orchards Mirror Afghan History
text: BATI KOT DISTRICT, Afghanistan  The main road into Afghanistan from the east traverses a flat, parched countryside, past flimsy roadside bazaars and squalid villages. Then, the terrain abruptly changes: arid land gives way to vast olive groves that spread for miles, as if a giant dropped a Mediterranean island into Central Asia.

headline: Data on Balkan Wars Found in Home of Suspect
text: THE HAGUE  For their latest raid on the Belgrade home of Gen. Ratko Mladic, the police had studied architectural plans and brought a new device provided by a foreign government: a camera capable of looking through wood, bricks, even reinforced concrete.

He is also a studio analyst for TBS. Ripken was named to 19 American League All-Star teams and memorably homered in his last All-Star Game, in 2001 in Seattle’s Safeco Field. The complete interview is at nytimes.com/bats.

headline: Computers at Home: Educational Hope vs. Teenage Reality
text: MIDDLE SCHOOL students are champion time-wasters. And the personal computer may be the ultimate time-wasting appliance. Put the two together at home, without hovering supervision, and logic suggests that you won’t witness a miraculous educational transformation.

headline: Time to Wake Up, Sleeper Spy
text: MOSCOW — Some complained that they could not scrape up a single grapefruit or tangerine in the markets. Others pined for contact with friends in the West, which was off limits forever (the K.G.B. made absolutely certain of that). One recalled his dismay upon returning in the 1960s and visiting a Moscow factory: “What a dreadful mess.” Only a few years later, he dropped dead, as if he were never able to readapt to Soviet life.

headline: Manuel Focuses on Bullpen
text: The Mets were in the sweepstakes for Cliff Lee, but they never got close to making a deal with the Mariners. Instead, it was the Yankees who seemed about to acquire Lee on Friday before the Rangers swooped in.

headline: When the Game’s on the Line
text: I GREW up in Rockaway Beach, Queens. I’ve always been an athlete. In the 1950s, when I started playing tennis as a preteen, there weren’t many women who played, so I’d join my father and his friends at the Belle Harbor Yacht Club.

headline: Red Bull Winging It at Silverstone

After Sebastian Vettel qualified on the pole and teammate Mark Webber finished second, a hair’s length behind, Webber sat through the post-qualifying news conference tight-lipped and closed off.

headline: Some Europeans Aren’t Crying Over a Weak Euro

headline: Finding a Refuge in Ginnie Mae Funds
text: IN the depths of the financial crisis in 2008, many real estate, stock and corporate bond investments plummeted. Some investors were able to find refuge in bond funds that held Treasury securities. But there was another haven: funds that invest in mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae.

headline: Our Life, Between Sea and Oil
text: I WAS born and raised on Bayou Lafourche, 30 miles from Grand Isle, which is Louisiana’s only inhabited barrier island and also the setting of Kate Chopin’s 19th-century novel of maternal disorientation, “The Awakening.” But “Frankenstein” offers the more appropriate narrative lesson for the Deepwater Horizon disaster. Mary Shelley begins her story with the anti-hero Victor Frankenstein declaring his admiration for scientists who “penetrate into the recesses of nature.” Full of hubris, he “pursued nature to her hiding places,” bringing horror upon his family and community. He has no foresight, only the belief that “maternal nature” can be manipulated by unvetted technology.

headline: Managers Find Havens in Gold, China and Real Estate
text: MUCH went awry in the stock market in the second quarter, and stock mutual funds suffered accordingly, losing an average of 10 percent, according to Morningstar. Even so, the quarter’s better performers managed to limit losses and, in a few cases, grub out some gains. They found havens both in expected places, like gold and China, and in unpredictable ones, like real estate.

headline: Lee Goes to Texas; Hughes Goes to 11-2

headline: The Hard Work of Gun Control
text: Thirteen days ago, the Supreme Court undermined Chicago’s ban on handguns by applying the Second Amendment to the states, ruling that people have a right to protect their homes with a gun. Four days after that, Chicago passed another handgun restriction that edged right up to the line drawn by the court. And on Tuesday, a group of gun dealers and enthusiasts sued the city again to overturn the new law.

headline: A Climate Change Corrective
text: Perhaps now we can put the manufactured controversy known as Climategate behind us and turn to the task of actually doing something about global warming. On Wednesday, a panel in Britain concluded that scientists whose e-mail had been hacked late last year had not, as critics alleged, distorted scientific evidence to prove that global warming was occurring and that human beings were primarily responsible.

headline: Security Council Blinks
text: “Lowest common denominator” is too often the standard at the United Nations. Even then, the Security Council’s new statement on the sinking of the South Korean warship Cheonan is absurdly, dangerously lame.

headline: At the Water’s Edge
text: The Central Park Reservoir  the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir  was a wonderful place to be last week while temperatures in New York City were climbing above 100 degrees. A pod of young Canada geese were there, enjoying the comparatively cool water. Runners, amazingly intrepid, shuffled along the shaded gravel path, and a group of tourists took turns taking photos of each other against the backdrop of Manhattan.

headline: A Big Kick for Spain
text: HIS name is Paul, he has eight legs and he flaunts a flexibility that would put to shame the ethics code of any self-respecting investment bank on Wall Street. What’s more, he’s one of the stars of the World Cup blazing on zillions of TV screens around the world. Yet Paul has never set foot on a soccer field, never kicked a ball and to this day most of his running has been devoted to chasing lobsters. Paul, you see, is an octopus.

headline: Gee, Officer Krupke, I Need Those Violins
text: IN 1983, as a young violinist, I had the rare luck to form a friendship with Leonard Bernstein. One summer evening the following year, during dinner, Bernstein uttered a sentence that changed my life, “Why don’t you play ‘West Side Story’ with me? I’m recording it in the fall.” I placed my soup spoon down carefully, for as you may imagine, he had secured my full attention at that particular moment.

text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Hundreds of displaced families live perilously in a single file of flimsy shanties planted along the median strip of a heavily congested coastal road here called the Route des Rails.

headline: Enigmatic Jobless Man Prepares Senate Campaign
text: MANNING, S.C. — On a blisteringly hot afternoon here, Alvin M. Greene talked in a perfunctory way about his improbable candidacy for the United States Senate. But his voice intensified with grievance when the subject turned to his short-circuited career in the Army, from which he was discharged in August involuntarily.

headline: Lawmakers Defend Social Security’s Chief Actuary in Clash With Commissioner
text: WASHINGTON  A rift has developed between the Social Security commissioner and the agency’s chief actuary, causing members of Congress to worry about possible interference with the work of the actuary’s office just as lawmakers begin hearings on the future of Social Security.

headline: A School Closing That Some See as Fiscal Responsibility, Others Racism
text: BILOXI, Miss.  It still looks like a happy, thriving school: child-size chairs in the cafeteria, yellow buses in the parking lot, a marquee sign that declares “Tomorrow’s Leaders Begin Here.”

headline: Analysis Triples U.S. Plutonium Waste Figures
text: WASHINGTON — The amount of plutonium buried at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State is nearly three times what the federal government previously reported, a new analysis indicates, suggesting that a cleanup to protect future generations will be far more challenging than planners had assumed.

headline: Reyes Pulled From Game
text: Jose Reyes left Saturday’s game against the Braves with an apparent injury after he made a long throw to first base from the grass in shallow left field in the seventh inning. The Mets did not immediately provide information on the injury. Ruben Tejada replaced him at shortstop with one out in the inning.

headline: Motorist With Car Trouble Is Killed in a Hit-and-Run on Staten Island
text: A 47-year-old woman who had car trouble was killed early Saturday after she was hit by a drunken driver on a one-way street in Staten Island where she had pulled over, the authorities said.

headline: Sweat | Bats Right, Slides Left
text: Cory Vaughn, a slugging outfielder and son of the former major league All-Star Greg Vaughn, is the new star of the Brooklyn Cyclones. Here is a little scouting report on him: He slides into base on his left hip, and when patrolling right field, in the shadow of the famous Coney Island Parachute Jump, he is loath to dive on his right side.

headline: Mets Wince as Pelfrey Is Hit Hard (Again) and Reyes Is Hurt (Again)
text: A thoroughly bad day became a near disaster for the Mets on Saturday, a day when they took three steps backward in their goal of regaining the National League East title.

headline: Ed Limato, Flashy Old-School Talent Agent to the Stars, Dies at 73
text: LOS ANGELES  In an industry packed with over-the-top personalities, the talent agent Ed Limato had no trouble standing out. His typical work day started like this: Clad in a salmon pink Richard James suit, he would charge into the office and rattle the keys to his Aston Martin convertible in a morning salute to his pet fish. Then, with a flourish of his arm, he would summon his three assistants by shouting, “Let’s talk to the stars.”

headline: Bank Bailout Is Potent Issue for Fall Elections
text: WASHINGTON  The vote in 2008 to bail out Wall Street was framed as the only way to avert an economic meltdown and relieve financial institutions of their most poisonous holdings. For many members of Congress, it turns out that the vote itself was toxic.

headline: Anglican Group Hits Impasse on Women
text: LONDON  The Church of England moved another step closer to an unbridgeable schism between traditionalists and reformers on Saturday when its General Synod, or parliament, rejected a bid by the archbishop of Canterbury to strike a compromise over the ordination of women bishops aimed at preserving the increasingly fragile unity of the worldwide Anglican Communion.

headline: Rev. William R. Callahan Dies at 78; Dissident Who Challenged Vatican
text: The Rev. William R. Callahan, a Roman Catholic priest and self-described “impossible dreamer” whose vociferous and organized opposition to Vatican policies prompted Jesuit officials to expel him from their order, died on Monday in Washington. He was 78.

headline: The N.B.A.’s Consolation Prize
text: When the Detroit Pistons appointed Joe Dumars as an executive a decade ago, his first big task was to try to persuade Grant Hill, a former teammate of his, to remain with the organization. Dumars could not do it. Hill decided to join the Orlando Magic, which had cleared payroll room to attract that summer’s biggest free agents.

headline: Roberto Suarez, Founder of El Nuevo Herald, Dies at 82
text: Roberto Suarez, a Cuban refugee whose career in journalism started late  in the mailroom of The Miami Herald  but who rose to become president of the company and the founder and publisher of the newspaper’s independent Spanish-language sister, El Nuevo Herald, died Wednesday at his home in Miami. He was 82.

headline: Spike Lee Smells a Conspiracy
text: The shock of seeing LeBron James in a blinding white Heat jersey was still fresh, and Spike Lee was searching for the right words. Eventually, he decided to borrow some.

headline: Soccer Soothes a Sense of Discontinuity for a Bosnian Immigrant
text: From Nelson Algren to Saul Bellow, Chicago has produced a succession of writers who found their muse in the city’s boisterous neighborhoods, its rich cast of characters, its nervy, urgent energy.

headline: Tribune Co. Embarks on a Risk-Filled Reshaping of WGN
text: The Tribune Company has come under scrutiny over the past few years for the jarring changes that a management team, laden with radio industry executives, has made to its stable of newspapers. But it is the dramatic and risky revamp occurring inside the bankrupt media company’s flagship radio station, WGN-AM 720, that is now making headlines, as its big fan base grows increasingly angry and its grip on the city’s radio advertising market loosens.

headline: Vaccination Rate Lags As an Epidemic Spreads
text: A statewide whooping cough epidemic has not changed how Danielle Lawson of San Anselmo feels about vaccinating her 5 1/2-month-old daughter.

headline: The Pulse: City Reviewing Policy of Paying Burge Bills
text: The City of Chicago is reviewing whether it is required to continue paying for the civil defense of Jon Burge, the former Chicago police commander, after his recent federal conviction for lying about the torture of suspects in police custody.

headline: The Pulse: New Permit System Is Causing Delays
text: Chicago's new system for processing construction permits is causing delays of almost two months, infuriating builders, architects and permit expediters.

headline: Looking Beyond Economic Orthodoxy to Create American Jobs
text: Andy Grove, one of the founders of the Intel Corporation and a true father of Silicon Valley, is doubtlessly among the most brilliant business strategists of his generation. Yet he has always cut against the grain when it comes to trade issues, championing government support for high-tech industries through much of the 1980s and 1990s and warning of the grave threat to American competitiveness posed by Asian electronics companies.

headline: Dutch Windmill
text: At seven-and-a-half stories high, the old Dutch Windmill in the northwest corner of Golden Gate Park rises above the surrounding trees. Built in 1902 to supply fresh water for the park’s extensive landscaping, the windmill was significantly cheaper to run than the original “sprinkling wagons”  but electric pumps quickly rendered it obsolete. A motor installed last year by San Francisco Recreation and Park Department means park visitors can again watch the windmill’s sails spin.

headline: Oakland Police Planned for Calm After Verdict
text: At 8 p.m. Thursday, a wall of police officers stretching curb to curb slowly made its way up Broadway in downtown Oakland. They gripped batons and wore helmets with plastic visors as they advanced on hundreds of protesters, a few of whom were hurling rocks and plastic bottles.

headline: When Adversity Comes Calling, Some Actually Answer the Door
text: When Kenneth I. Starr, a New York financial adviser to celebrities, was arrested in May on suspicion of a $30 million fraud, the police entering his apartment found him hiding under a pile of clothes in a closet.

headline: Correction
text: An answer in the Q&A column on June 27 about suggested activities in Vienna and Salzburg misstated the policy on passports for entering Bavaria. Passports are not required to enter Bavaria, which is a German state, from Austria.

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the use of epic poems in Indian films this summer misidentified both the actor and the movie in which he is the title character. The actor is Vikram  not Abhishek Bachchan  and he stars in “Raavanan,” not “Raavan.” (“Raavanan” is the Tamil version of “Raavan,” which is in Hindi and stars Mr. Bachchan.)

headline: Palestinian Civil Disobedience
text: My Sunday column is on an issue that has interested me for years: the possibility of Palestinians using nonviolent resistance on a massive scale to help change the political dynamic in the Middle East and achieve a two-state solution.

headline: Kelly Williams, Patrick Verel
text: Kelly Marie Williams and Patrick Jeremy Verel were married Saturday by the Rev. Steven J. Peterson, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Mary’s Church in East Islip, N.Y. The Rev. John R. Moore also took part in the ceremony.

headline: With Blessing, Swisher Joins Home Run Derby
text: SEATTLE  Nick Swisher said he was flattered when his agent, Joe Bick, called Saturday morning to tell him he had been selected to participate in the Home Run Derby. Then Swisher called Yankees Manager Joe Girardi. And the hitting coach, Kevin Long. And the general manager, Brian Cashman. And his father, Steve. And his brother, Kendall.

headline: Gyna Villard, Micah Uhrlass
text: Gyna Villard, a daughter of Marie Helene Villard of Stamford, Conn., and Jean Michel R. Louis of Lawrenceville, Ga., was married Saturday to Micah John Uhrlass, a son of Ann and Richard Uhrlass of Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. Patson A. Agard, a minister of the Christian Brethren Assemblies, officiated at the Good Tidings Gospel Chapel in Brooklyn.

headline: Red Bulls Extend Unbeaten Streak to 5
text: Goalkeepers Bouna Coundoul of the Red Bulls and Troy Perkins of D.C. United each made one good save in a 0-0 tie in Harrison, N.J.

text: LeBron James decided on Saturday to come to New York. But unfortunately for the Knicks, he is not staying here for long. And he probably won’t be playing any basketball.

text: OAKMONT, Pa.  If Paula Creamer were Stephen Strasburg, she would have been pulled from the Oakmont Country Club course around the seventh hole of her third round of the United States Women’s Open on Saturday.

headline: Lopez Grand Slam Costs Vazquez Win
text: SEATTLE  The Yankees have not had much to complain about during this trip, receiving excellent starting pitching and consistent middle-of-the-lineup production. It almost made them forget about one of their lone concerns before it reappeared Saturday night, when the bridge to Mariano Rivera creaked, then collapsed, in a disastrous eighth inning. Called on to preserve a one-run lead, Joba Chamberlain loaded the bases with one out before Jose Lopez crushed a grand slam.

headline: In Rome, Opera in Ruins
text: Visitors to Rome often marvel at the astonishing integration of ancient structures into the city’s modern fabric. Shops, an embassy and a gelateria all sit atop the ruins of a first-century stadium; apartments lean on the Theater of Marcellus; even the mayor’s office claims a Republican-era records hall as its foundation. This month, the eye-opening ruins of the Baths of Caracalla are joining the fun, hosting ballet and opera performances.

headline: Carolina Panthers 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: S.B.A. Lending Plunged in June
text: With the expiration of stimulus provisions that made Small Business Administration loans more attractive to borrowers and lenders — and with efforts to renew those provisions stalled in Congress — S.B.A.-backed lending all but collapsed in June.

headline: Curious Interview With the Head of the Chess Federation
text: In a recent interview, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation and the small Russian republic of Kalmykia, talked about his belief in astrology, his meeting with mystic Baba Vanga, and the time that he supposedly gave Bobby Fischer $100,000 as payment for lost royalties from the unauthorized translation into Russian of his book, “My 60 Memorable Games.”

headline: Cap Connector Is Installed on BP Well
text: NEW ORLEANS  BP said Sunday that it had made progress toward installing a new cap that could contain all of the oil spewing from its out-of-control well in the Gulf of Mexico, and that a flotilla of skimmers was helping to collect the additional oil leaking while the procedure was under way.

headline: July’s Political Best Sellers
text: A few new books have moved onto this month’s list of best sellers, and the steady rankings of several others through the summer months demonstrate their popularity and staying power.

headline: Japan’s Ruling Party Suffers Setback
text: TOKYO  Japan’s governing Democratic Party suffered a stinging setback in midterm elections on Sunday that showed growing voter disappointment with the party’s apparent inability to deliver on promises to revamp the country’s sclerotic postwar order.

headline: Way Back Machine | A Sycophant’s Sycophant
text: You could certainly make the argument that New York’s upper classes hardly want these days for personal attention, surrounded as they are by helicopter pilots who fly them to the Hamptons and private stylists who make haircut house calls. But even with today’s apparently recession-proof forms of conspicuous consumption, it would be hard to find a servant with the all-encompassing talents — the cradle-to-grave service — of Isaac H. Brown.

headline: Trending Toward Deflation
text: Inflation has been falling, but how close are we to deflation? I found myself wondering that after observing John Makin’s combusting coiffure, his prediction that we might see deflation this year.

text: SILVERSTONE, England – The defining moment of the British Grand Prix on Sunday was described by one commentator as poetic justice for Mark Webber.

text: JOHANNESBURG – This first World Cup in Africa marks Spain’s first appearance in the final. And the match today between La Furia Roja and the Netherlands will see the winner capture its first World Cup championship.

headline: Bob Sheppard, Voice of the Yankees, Dies at 99
text: Bob Sheppard, whose elegant intonation as the public-address announcer at Yankee Stadium for more than half a century personified the image of Yankees grandeur, died Sunday at his home in Baldwin, on Long Island. He was 99.

text: HARRISON, N.J. — One of Thierry Henry’s best buds in the sports world — the Phoenix Suns guard Steve Nash — Saturday night popped into the press room at halftime of a thoroughly forgettable Red Bulls-D.C. United match that still had 45 minutes to go.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Eleven police officers and a district governor were killed in three separate attacks by the Taliban in northeast Afghanistan, NATO and local officials said Sunday.

Members who voted for the Bush administration’s $700 billion Wall Street bailout in 2008 are finding that choice – instead of the health care vote as Republicans predicted –  toxic on the campaign trail, The Times’s Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn report.

headline: Crisis Awaits World’s Banks as Trillions Come Due
text: FRANKFURT — The sovereign debt crisis would seem to create worry enough for European banks, but there is another gathering threat that has not garnered as much notice: the trillions of dollars in short-term borrowing that institutions around the world must repay or roll over in the next two years.

text: MORZINE-AVORIAZ, France  Nearly 12 minutes after the top riders in the Tour de France finished the eighth stage Sunday, Lance Armstrong pedaled across the finish line, looking like a man defeated.

headline: A Voice That Stayed Above the Fray
text: JOHANNESBURG  Bob Sheppard liked the air of mystery about his age. It was funny watching such a solid person, based in faith and education, grow a trifle coy about the year of his birth. But he was always specific about being born on Oct. 20.

headline: Mets Feeling Better About Themselves After Santana Shuts Down Braves
text: The Mets came into this weekend’s series against Atlanta with a goal of sweeping the Braves and pulling into a tie for first place in the National League East. By Sunday, they just wanted to win a game.

headline: An Unlikely Pair Bond on the Homicide Beat
text: “Rizzoli & Isles,” though it sounds like the name of a personal-injury law practice, is actually the title of a new police procedural on TNT (beginning Monday) that is kind of like a “Cagney & Lacey” for the postfeminist, post-personal-trainer age. Set in Boston and based on characters created by the novelist Tess Gerritsen, the show centers on the professional and personal relationship of two women: Jane Rizzoli, the only female detective in the homicide division; and Maura Isles, a medical examiner who walks mincingly around her crime scenes in heels, apparently undeterred by the fear of blood stains on expensive leather.

headline: Investors Expect Profits and Seek Clues to Future
text: Many Americans are still waiting for an economic recovery. But for corporate America, a recovery of sorts is already at hand.

headline: Be It Ever So Awful, No Place Like ...
text: Frank Mackey grew up on a cramped Dublin cul-de-sac called Faithful Place. Street name notwithstanding, Frank had no fidelity to the neighborhood. A horrendous trick of fate drove him out of there two decades ago, and he turned his back on his difficult working-class family. But as Tana French’s expertly rendered, gripping new novel begins, Frank has to go home again.

headline: ‘Despicable Me’ Gives Universal a Hit
text: LOS ANGELES  It took nothing less than attempted Moon theft to end a months-long losing streak for Universal Pictures.

headline: Resisting a Trump Temptation
text: The 50th European Team Championships ended in Ostend, Belgium, on July 3. The winners were France (women’s), Italy (open) and Poland (seniors).

headline: Veiled Threats?
text: In Spain earlier this month, the Catalonian assembly narrowly rejected a proposed ban on the Muslim burqa in all public places — reversing a vote the week before in the country’s upper house of parliament supporting a ban. Similar proposals may soon become national law in France and Belgium.  Even the headscarf often causes trouble.  In France, girls may not wear it in school.  In Germany (as in parts of Belgium and the Netherlands) some regions forbid public school teachers to wear it on the job, although nuns and priests are permitted to teach in full habit.  What does political philosophy have to say about these developments?   As it turns out, a long philosophical and legal tradition has reflected about similar matters.

headline: Futures Game Is a Home Game for Yanks’ Austin Romine
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Greetings from the Futures Game at Angel Stadium, where the U.S.A. team is taking batting practice. As I write this, the Yankees’ Class AA catcher, Austin Romine, is taking his cuts in the cage. It’s a familiar spot for him.

headline: The Revenge of Felipe II
text: Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition football team!

headline: A Jam Band Counting on a Style of Its Invention
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.  The terminology can’t be trusted when it comes to Garage a Trois, a band consisting of the drummer Stanton Moore, the saxophonist known as Skerik, the percussionist Mike Dillon and the keyboardist Marco Benevento. That’s four people, not three, despite the group’s chosen name; it doesn’t have much stake in garage rock, either. And while Garage a Trois fits the profile of a jam band, its music feels more focused and less freewheeling than that particular pigeonhole might suggest.

headline: Fatal Amour With Fever of Youth
text: In an interview a few years ago the young Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova spoke a few prophetic words: “I would love to suffer onstage.”

headline: YouTube Question: Views on Islam
text: Over the next several days, Nick will be responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today, Nick discusses his views on Islam, which a YouTube questionner had asked about vis a vis a recent, provocative book review of “Nomad” by Ayaan Hirsi Ali.

headline: Special Offer!

But we’re not done. Solve right now and we’ll throw in a fifth entry that cross-references them all! (Just pay separate shipping and handling.)

headline: Mr. Secretary, This Is Your Life (in Plenty of Detail)
text: It’s not a prank, and it’s not “Punk’d.” PBS really is presenting a three-hour documentary about George P. Shultz, the former secretary of state.

headline: The Foment Is Fermenting and Vice Versa
text: The wild-eyed dreamers and furtive schemers of Fyodor Dostoyevsky’s novel “The Demons” don’t just leap off the page: they grab your lapels with white-knuckled fists and glare into your soul, whispering their fervent hopes about a new world order. They spout dire predictions for the future of Russia while staggering around your apartment gesticulating wildly, knocking over furniture and scaring the neighbors.

headline: Eighty-two All-Stars? Believe it.
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – Here’s something amazing. Do you know how many players are All-Stars this season? Would you believe 82? It’s true.

headline: Channeling a Convicted Tabloid Star
text: To make it clear from the beginning, Khaela Maricich is not working on songs for Lindsay Lohan’s comeback album, has not been, and, barring a fantastical turn of events in which myth is given flesh  and in which Ms. Lohan, savagely calculating, is bestowed with a special-achievement Oscar for her recent life performance as a faded cautionary tale  will not be.

headline: Games Give South Africa Hope in Fighting Woes
text: CAPE TOWN  As host of the most-watched sporting event on earth, South Africa set out to reinvent itself in the eyes of the world, casting off its reputation as a place defined by violent crime, poverty and AIDS. To a remarkable degree, it succeeded. But as the World Cup ended Sunday, what most surprised South Africans was how much the monthlong sporting extravaganza had changed the way they see themselves.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the trade deficit for May (Tuesday); retail sales for June import prices for June and business inventories for May (Wednesday); the Producer Price Index for June, weekly jobless claims, industrial production and capacity utilization for June, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for July (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for June and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for July (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: What Have We Learned?
text: Sometimes it’s useful to step back slightly from the current fray and ask what we’ve really learned about macroeconomics over, say, the past year and a half. Here’s how I see it: in early 2009 there was a broad divide between two policy factions. One, of which I was part, declared that we were in a liquidity trap, which meant that some of the usual rules no longer applied: the expansion of the Fed’s balance sheet wouldn’t be inflationary — in fact the danger was a slide toward deflation; the government’s borrowing would not lead to a spike in interest rates. The other side declared that we were in imminent danger of runaway inflation, and that federal borrowing would lead to very high interest rates.

headline: Jubilant Opening Chords in the Berkshires
text: LENOX, Mass.  Michael Tilson Thomas was on the podium for the opening concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s summer season here at Tanglewood on Friday night, conducting an incisive, engrossing and triumphant performance of Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony. Despite the hot, humid weather, Mr. Thomas drew brilliant playing from the orchestra, magisterial singing from the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and inspired performances from the two vocal soloists: the luminous soprano Layla Claire and the extraordinary mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe.

headline: Guarding a Legacy From Nigeria to Broadway
text: PHILADELPHIA  Femi Kuti, the Nigerian singer and saxophonist, admits to being delighted that “Fela!,” the Broadway musical about his father, Fela Kuti, is a hit, attracting new fans to Afrobeat, the politically charged musical genre that Fela created and Femi plays. Even so, he is not planning to see the Tony-winning show during a trip to New York for a performance Monday night in Lincoln Center’s Midsummer Night Swing series.

headline: Alternative Latin’s Festival of Fusion
text: “Walls, borders and roadblocks/They make me laugh,” sang Roco of the Mexican band Maldita Vecindad (the Damned Neighborhood), in Spanish, as the floor of SummerStage turned into what he called a “ceremonial circle”: a frantic, happy mosh pit. The band’s Saturday afternoon set was the climactic concert presented by this year’s Latin Alternative Music Conference, the 11th annual gathering for aficionados of music that’s much harder to classify or confine than to enjoy.

headline: An Artist Is Chided for Mandela Portrait
text: South Africa’s ruling party, the African National Congress, said it was “appalled” by a painting that depicts an autopsy of Nelson Mandela, which recently went on display in a Johannesburg shopping center, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting, by the artist Yuill Damaso, both above, shows Nkosi Johnson, a South African AIDS activist who died of the disease in 2001 at the age of 12, making an incision into Mr. Mandela’s body as South African leaders  including Archbishop Desmond Tutu, President Jacob Zuma, former president Thabo Mbeki and the opposition leader Helen Zille  look on. The painting is fashioned after Rembrandt’s “Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.” The congress issued a statement on Saturday in which it called the painting “racist” and condemned the work as “an act of witchcraft” and “an affront to values of our society.” Mr. Damaso told The Saturday Star that he did not mean to disrespect Mr. Mandela, who turns 92 on Sunday and is in frail health, but rather to honor him. “He achieved great things by working hard, and he has so much influence on the country and the world, but the painting shows that he is just an ordinary man,” Mr. Damaso said.

headline: A Host Returns to the Y
text: As president of Jujamcyn Theaters, Jordan Roth presides over five Broadway houses, but this fall he will be going uptown to take the stage of the 92nd Street Y. Mr. Roth is returning for a second series as the host of Broadway Talks, a series of conversations with New York theatrical performers. The season begins on Sept. 19 with Billie Joe Armstrong of the band Green Day and Michael Mayer, who directed “American Idiot,” the musical based on the band’s music. Also on the roster are David Hyde Pierce, who will be starring in a revival of David Hirson’s comedy “La Bête,” and Elaine Stritch, who takes over for Angela Lansbury in “A Little Night Music” on Tuesday. “I’ve just loved it,” Mr. Roth said of the series, “both the process of researching and digging into these artists’ lives to prepare and finding our way on what always becomes an unexpected journey.” Information: (212) 415-5500, or 92Y.org/lectures.

headline: Gratuitous Gratuity?
text: Many golfers are unsure of tipping etiquette on the golf course.  Bill Pennington and Bryan Jones clear it up.

headline: Transit Service Cuts Also Reach Museum
text: The New York Transit Museum laid off two full-time and two part-time employees last week as part of required payroll reductions across the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its agencies, which are facing a financial crisis, said Aaron Donovan, an authority spokesman. The museum is financed by donations and revenue from admissions and sales in its stores, but its staff members are officially employed by the authority. At the museum the full-time staff has been reduced to 18 from 21 through the layoffs and one vacancy going unfilled. Mr. Donovan said that operations and hours would not be affected. The museum had 566,169 visitors last year at its location in Brooklyn and at Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Dustin Hoffman Question at Jerusalem Film Fest
text: Organizers of the Jerusalem Film Festival retracted an assertion that Dustin Hoffman had withdrawn from discussions to appear at the event after an Israeli commando raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla, The Jerusalem Post reported. Yigal Molad Hayo, associate director of the Jerusalem Cinemathèque, the main theater where the festival is held, had told The Post last week that he and his colleagues were “very close to reaching an agreement” with Mr. Hoffman before the raid. Representatives for Mr. Hoffman told The New York Times there was “no truth” to this account. On Saturday Mr. Molad Hayo told The Post that the festival’s “aspirations never reached the level of direct discussion” with Mr. Hoffman’s office and asked that the “misleading claim be completely retracted.”

headline: Publisher Plans a Palin Biography for Children
text: The Christian book publisher Zondervan wants to bring Sarah Palin’s story to a possibly undiscovered audience: 9-to-12-year-olds. In September Zondervan will publish “Speaking Up,” an admiring biography of Ms. Palin aimed at young readers, The Associated Press reported. Zondervan, a division of HarperCollins Publishers, released a biography of the Brazilian soccer player Kaká in April, and books on Bono and the football player Tim Tebow are due in September. According to Kathleen Kerr, an acquisitions editor for Zondervan’s Zonderkidz division, the biography of Ms. Palin is unauthorized and will make no mention of her daughter Bristol Palin’s unplanned teenage pregnancy.

text: On Friday, Day 80 of the oil spill, much of the Gulf of Mexico still looked bruised and battered, just as it did the week before, and the month before that. So for a different perspective, CNN went scuba diving.

headline: Bombers Kill More Than 50 in Attacks in Uganda Capital
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  At least three bombs exploded Sunday in a synchronized attack on large gatherings of World Cup soccer fans watching the televised final on outdoor screens in this normally peaceful capital, turning a boisterous night of cheering into scenes of death and panic. The police and witnesses said more than 50 people were killed, including some foreigners, among them at least one American.

text: Ten summers ago, when Bob Sheppard was not yet 90, I stepped into his tiny booth at Yankee Stadium and asked him for his first memory of being at the ballpark.

headline: Clerics to Work Within Schools of Iran’s Capital
text: Iran’s educational authorities will send 1,000 religious clerics into schools in Tehran to tamp down Western influence and political opposition, newspapers reported on Sunday.

headline: Finishing Haiti’s Unfinished Work
text: SIX months have passed since the earthquake that shook the coast of Haiti. But for the people who live there, today is just another day in the long process of rebuilding and re-imagining their future amid a hurricane season that threatens to undo the progress they’ve made.

headline: Field Intruder Tries to Dress Up World Cup Trophy
text: JOHANNESBURG — Minutes after Fabio Cannavaro, who four years ago won the World Cup with Italy, delivered the World Cup trophy to the field at Soccer City to be handed over to the winner of Sunday night’s match, a fan ran onto the field and tried to put a hat atop the trophy as it sat on its podium.

headline: Felton’s Biggest Cheerleader on the Knicks Is the Coach’s Brother
text: LAS VEGAS  In the spring of 2000, Dan D’Antoni was in the market for a guard to team with his son Nick on an Amateur Athletic Union team he would take around the country.

headline: A Fixture That Became a Rarity
text: There once existed in every city barroom a sort of scruffy, lively, lovely symphony that played without rest and without ovation. But its members are falling away; background sounds once familiar have been silenced. The jangle of the pay phone on the wall, the click of the lighter, the snap and hiss of a match being lighted.

headline: The Feckless Fed
text: Back in 2002, a professor turned Federal Reserve official by the name of Ben Bernanke gave a widely quoted speech titled “Deflation: Making Sure ‘It’ Doesn’t Happen Here.” Like other economists, myself included, Mr. Bernanke was deeply disturbed by Japan’s stubborn, seemingly incurable deflation, which in turn was “associated with years of painfully slow growth, rising joblessness, and apparently intractable financial problems.” This sort of thing wasn’t supposed to happen to an advanced nation with sophisticated policy makers. Could something similar happen to the United States?

headline: Training Soldiers in Pakistan
text: Pakistani Army soldiers undergoing training by Americans at a base southeast of Islamabad.

headline: Distrust Slows U.S. Training of Pakistanis
text: WARSAK, Pakistan  The recent graduation ceremony here for Pakistani troops trained by Americans to fight the Taliban and Al Qaeda was intended as show of fresh cooperation between the Pakistani and American militaries. But it said as much about its limitations.

headline: Democrats Corral Votes on Bank Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Final passage of sweeping legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial regulatory system is now a question of when  not if  according to Senate Democrats. Yet, there still seem to be a lot of questions about when.

text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  It was a finely honed machine, this United States Census team, and it had a good run. But in the coming days and weeks, many of its members will experience the pain of unemployment  once again.

headline: A Beloved Bollywood Extra Draws Indians

headline: For Dutch Captain, a Long Career Closes

headline: New Director Is Named at San Francisco Theater
text: Ellen Richard, a former executive director of the Second Stage Theater and former managing director of the Roundabout Theater Company, has been named executive director of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. The theater’s board is expected to make the announcement on Monday. In a telephone interview on Sunday, Ms. Richard, above, said she was looking forward to the administrative challenges presented by the San Francisco theater, which is in the first year of a 10-year plan to expand its facilities, improve its educational programs and build audiences. Another big draw, she said, would be working with the theater’s artistic director, Carey Perloff, who is celebrating her 18th year at the American Conservatory Theater. “When you take these kinds of jobs, you’re looking to find somebody you can have a good relationship with and respect,” said Ms. Richard, who left Second Stage in June 2009. After her arrival, in 2006, she oversaw the purchase of the Helen Hayes Theater and the critically acclaimed productions of “Everyday Rapture,” “Next to Normal” and “The Little Dog Laughed.” .

headline: Stopping and Frisking, Again and Again and Again
text: When night falls, police officers blanket some eight odd blocks of Brownsville, Brooklyn. Squad cars with flashing lights cruise along the main avenues: Livonia to Powell to Sutter to Rockaway. And again. Dozens of officers, many fresh out of the police academy, walk in pairs or linger on corners. Others, deeper within the urban grid, navigate a maze of public housing complexes, patrolling the stairwells and hallways. This small army of officers spends much of its energy pursuing the controversial Police Department tactic known as “Stop, Question, Frisk,” and it does so at a rate unmatched anywhere else in the city.  [NYT]

headline: Lopez Facing Possible Lawsuit After Canceling Cyprus Show
text: A hotel in Cyprus said that it might sue Jennifer Lopez after the singer withdrew from a scheduled performance for fear that the show would be construed as making a political statement, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lopez was to perform at the Cratos Premium hotel and casino complex in Turkish-occupied northern Cyprus on July 24, an event that Greek Cypriots had said would further polarize the country, which has been divided since the 1970s and whose northern region is recognized only by Turkey. Ms. Lopez’s representatives said last week that she would not perform the concert, citing their “sensitivity to the political realities of the region.” But Murat Bozoglu, the chief executive of the company that runs Cratos Premium, told Agence France-Presse that Ms. Lopez’s contract for the show had not been canceled. “If she does not show up for the concert, we will begin a procedure in the courts to claim $35 to $40 million in damages,” Mr. Bozoglu said.

In an instant, a key artery into the city is rendered useless, stranding thousands of passengers all along the New York-New Haven corridor.
