headline: Parents’ Real Estate Strategy: Schools Come First
text: When Ann and Jonathan Binstock started shopping for an apartment in Manhattan in 2007, their first call was not to a real estate broker. Instead, they hired an education consultant, to show them where the best schools for their daughter, Ellen, were. After the consultant suggested the most desirable zones , they chose a two-bedroom apartment near Public School 87 on the Upper West Side. Public records show it cost $1.975 million.

headline: The Unemployment Rate Race
text: Among developed countries, the United States still has an above-average unemployment rate, according to data released today by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: Asked  & Answered | Tim Hamilton
text: The Iowa-born designer Tim Hamilton is not one to shy away from his roots. “My vision comes from where I grew up and the experiences I’ve had,” Hamilton says. Nevertheless, the all-American boy-makes-good clichés don’t quite ring true. Hamilton may have Midwestern roots and a C.V. that includes stints at Ralph Lauren and J. Crew, but his sympathies are more British punk than Ivy League preppy — it’s not hard to imagine Joe Strummer, circa 1980, suiting up in one of Hamilton’s rapier-thin blazers. (His women’s line, which he introduced last fall, is equally sharp.) And his references tend to be peppered with black humor. His spring 2011 men’s collection, which was scheduled to be staged during the recent men’s shows in Paris but was canceled at the last minute due to budgetary constraints, was inspired by the Belgian artist Michaël Borremans’s somber portraits of workers in their uniforms. “The surfaces were very chic and painterly,” Hamilton explains. “But they all looked depressed — that’s where the dark part comes in.” The Moment caught up with Hamilton to talk about his love of British youth culture and why the Corn Belt is more avant-garde than you might think.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Rio Bravo'

headline: Old Masters and Modern Science
text: LONDON  At first blush “Close Examination: Fakes, Mistakes and Discoveries,” here at the National Gallery, has the quaint, cheerfully scholastic earnestness of a science fair. Some 30 pictures from the permanent collection, most of them culled from storage, have been enlisted to anchor a flurry of wall texts, X-rays and the sort of enlarged microscopic cross sections of layered pigments and varnish vaguely resembling the cautionary photographs of plaque that elementary school teachers flourish before floss-wary fourth graders.

headline: Who Really Won in South Africa?
text: From his office inside Holy Cross Anglican Church in Soweto, Father Steve Morero has seen the tour buses come and go by the hundreds.

headline: Moving Your Family

headline: Early Match Could Determine U.S. Women’s Champion
text: The two highest seeds, Irina Krush and Anna Zatonskih, meet Monday in the third round of the championship and if there is a winner, that player will be the favorite to win the title.

headline: Harvey Pekar, Who Chronicled Ordinary Lives in ‘American Splendor’ Comics, Dies
text: Harvey Pekar, the irascible writer who spun the mundane details of his own life and the quotidian existences of his fellow Cleveland residents into comic-book narratives, and who showed that the comic-book panel could include everyday feelings of anxiety and disappointment as easily as it does the adventures of costumed heroes, has died, The Plain Dealer of Cleveland reported. He was 70.

headline: Putting Schools First During an Apartment Search
text: In this week’s installment of my column, The Appraisal, I speak to young parents who bought or rented in certain school districts — and then learned that, because of overcrowding or changes in the shape of school districts, their children can’t attend the schools for which they had moved. One solution to this problem: new schools. I focus on the Upper West Side, where the developer behind a new project has included a new school in his plans. But parents want a  bigger school — bigger, even, than education department officials say the neighborhood needs.

headline: Salads for Summer
text: When it’s steaming outside, the last thing you want to do when you arrive home from work is cook. But you won’t have to turn to take-out if you organize your summer meals around main dish salads and prepare most of the ingredients ahead of time.

headline: Poll Shows Afghans’ Frustration With Corruption
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Corruption in the distribution of mundane social services in Afghanistan has doubled since 2007, derailing government legitimacy and providing the Taliban with political capital, a recent national survey indicates.

headline: A New Approach to Biofuel in Africa
text: The biofuel concept: If you just burn plant materials, you put out a lot of bad pollutants. But if you heat the materials in a container without oxygen (“pyrolysis”), you leave most of the carbon as “biochar,” which makes an excellent soil additive (in fact Amazon Indians built up rich soils over hundreds of years using biochar). The gas that is given off by pyrolysis can be processed into clean-burning fuel. All of which sounds great, but skeptics point out that Africa is a prime target for biofuel land grabs, which destroy small farms and forest preserves. Hence the importance of using agricultural residues like corn cobs, and researching the impact.

headline: Numberplay: The Pyramid of Shame
text: Last week we discussed a variant of “The Two Envelope Paradox” in which our protagonist, Brittany, had a well thought-out strategy for maximizing gain in a classroom game. Her reasoned argument failed, though, because of the tiny detail that wealth is not infinite. Today, we will discuss more sinister versions of this logical fallacy, including the infamous pyramid or Ponzi scheme.

Not that Mr. Meyers, the “Saturday Night Live” head writer, performer and anchor of its “Weekend Update” news satire, has much time to mourn: he and his writing team are busy preparing for the ESPY Awards, the annual celebration of athletic achievement that Mr. Meyers will host on Wednesday night.

headline: Knopf to Publish Sotomayor Memoir
text: Sonia Sotomayor, the Supreme Court justice, will write a memoir to be published by Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher announced on Monday. The book does not yet have a publication date or a title, but it was described by Knopf as a “coming-of-age memoir by an American daughter of Puerto Rican immigrants.” Sonny Mehta,  chairman and editor in chief of the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group, said in a statement that Ms. Sotomayor’s achievements “will prove an inspiration to readers around the world.” Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, declined to disclose financial terms of the agreement.

headline: Amid Violence and Instability, Iraqi Government Lies Idle

On Monday  another day of staggering heat here  parliamentary leaders delayed a session scheduled for this week, raising questions about whether their inaction is now breaking the law.

Mr. Reitz, who will start in early September, will succeed Ellen Richard, who left Second Stage in June 2009 and was just named executive director of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco.

headline: Greenwich Village, 12:33 P.M.

headline: Blame’s Net Catches Lung Cancer Patients
text: When it comes to advocacy and research funds, the leading cancer killer in the United States  lung cancer  clearly gets short shrift. People with the disease are commonly assumed to have brought it upon themselves by smoking. And the 10 to 15 percent of lung cancer patients who never smoked are typically tarred with the same brush. One-tenth of men and one-fifth of women with lung cancer have never been smokers, and in some parts of the country  Northern California, for example  as many as 35 percent of women with lung cancer never smoked or lived with smokers.

headline: Ask an Expert About Lung Cancer
text: People with lung cancer, the leading cancer killer in the United disease, are commonly assumed to have brought it upon themselves by smoking, explains Jane Brody, the Personal Health columnist, in this week’s Science Times. Yet “one-tenth of men and one-fifth of women with lung cancer have never been smokers,” she writes, “and in some parts of the country — Northern California, for example — as many as 35 percent of women with lung cancer never smoked or lived with smokers.”

headline: Sounds Good, Looks a Little Odd

While other manufacturers strive to make their headsets smaller and less obtrusive, Etymotic has gone in the other direction. Opting for function, the EtyBlu2 includes a boom mic that wraps around the face, ending in a foam windscreen, tempting onlookers to shout, “Operators now standing by!”

text: Eli Lilly is about to try a new tack to help flagging sales of its new anti-clotting drug, Effient. It will urge doctors to test patients taking a rival drug, Plavix, to see if it is working. If it isn’t, doctors would presumably switch patients to Effient.

headline: Childhood: Obesity in Young Subjects Drops in Study

headline: Regimens: Glucosamine’s Benefits Are Disputed
text: Many people with chronic lower-back pain and osteoarthritis take glucosamine, a natural compound found in healthy cartilage, despite mixed evidence about whether it alleviates pain or disability. A study claiming to be one of the largest and longest trials of the supplement suggests that it does neither.

text: Over the weekend, while attending a meeting of hundreds of specialists involved in softening the blows from natural hazards, I met Ben Smilowitz, the executive director of Disaster Accountability Project, a nonprofit organization trying to track the performance of aid agencies and organizations.

headline: Hazards: Erectile Dysfunction Drugs and S.T.D.’s
text: Men who take drugs for erectile dysfunction have more sexually transmitted diseases than non-users, before and after they start using the drugs, a study finds.

headline: Documentary Revisits Jones’s Bid for Slam in 1930
text: On Tuesday at 8 p.m., to mark the 80th anniversary of Bobby Jones’s Grand Slam, the Golf Channel will broadcast a special: “Bobby Jones’s Year to Remember.” I got a chance to view the program in advance over the weekend, and it’s full of terrific insights into Jones, into Jones’s golf game and, most of all, into the tremendous pressure Jones was under in his attempt to win the Grand Slam in 1930.

headline: South Africa Wonders What Lies Beyond the Cup
text: JOHANNESBURG — For the first time in more than a month, this kinetic and crowded city was free from the toots and blasts of the vuvuzela. The plastic horns fell silent a day after the World Cup final and the ubiquitous vendors who were selling Spanish flags at traffic lights and orange Dutch scarves in parking lots took Monday off.

headline: Bomb Blasts in Uganda Timed to Cup Final
text: At least three bombs exploded on Sunday night killing at least 70 people in the Ugandan capital of Kampala while the match between Spain and the Netherlands under way in South Africa.

headline: Avandia’s Sales Drop Far Behind Actos

headline: Giving Away the Family Pet
text: Families have pets for many reasons, but near the top of most lists is “for the children.” That was our reason. My younger son started lobbying for a dog when he was 3, and soon was carrying dog treats in his pockets to feed the neighborhood pets, and keeping a photo album of snapshots of himself with local Labradors and goldens and beagles and poodles.

headline: Dining With ‘The Demons’
text: “The Demons,” the Peter Stein-directed Lincoln Center production based on Dostoyevsky’s novel and realized on Governors Island this past weekend, may not have been perfectly organized, but it was pretty close. And the food, provided by Tom Colicchio’s ’wichcraft, was, if not adventuresome, then something that many cafeterias, fast-food operations and certainly most entertainment events could benefit from exploring.

headline: Gandhi’s Advice for Israelis and Palestinians
text: Writing from the West Bank town of Bilin, where there are weekly protests against the path of Israel’s separation barrier, my colleague Nicholas Kristof has sparked a discussion of “the possibility of Palestinians using nonviolent resistance on a massive scale to help change the political dynamic in the Middle East and achieve a two-state solution,” in a column and a blog post.

headline: Desperate Addicts Inject Others’ Blood
text: Desperate heroin users in a few African cities have begun engaging in a practice that is so dangerous it is almost unthinkable: they deliberately inject themselves with another addict’s blood, researchers say, in an effort to share the high or stave off the pangs of withdrawal.

headline: Brown to Vote Yes on Financial Regulation
text: From David Herszenhorn at The Caucus:

headline: A Scientist Takes On Gravity
text: It’s hard to imagine a more fundamental and ubiquitous aspect of life on the Earth than gravity, from the moment you first took a step and fell on your diapered bottom to the slow terminal sagging of flesh and dreams.

headline: Reactions to Polanski Ruling
text: After nearly a year of courtroom wrangling in California and abroad, Monday’s decision leaves the legal case roughly where it has been for decades: Roman Polanski is free to return to his home in France, and remains a wanted man in the United States.

headline: Asbury Park Sunbathers: Keep Your Tops On
text: Despite the Jersey Shore’s reputation as a perpetual party zone, a recent move by Asbury Park, N.J., is reminding visitors of their family values. On Wednesday night, the city shot down a proposal that would allow women to go topless on its beach’s northern end.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Frances Faye
text: In the late 1950s, the cabaret scene on the Sunset Strip was so feverish, you could hear Christine Jorgensen and Frances Faye in different rooms on the same night without leaving the building. Jorgensen played the Interlude; Faye the Crescendo downstairs. Jorgensen’s set included “I Enjoy Being a Girl,” sung, apparently, without irony. A robust performer even on a bad day, Faye could be heard through the floorboards, violently slapping the piano keys and inquiring, “Gay, gay, gay, is there another way?”

headline: Small Government or Flat Government?
text: In its concluding paragraphs, my column today hints briefly at a tension that I’ve been interested in for a while: The potential divide between conservatives who are primarily interested in smaller government (a group in which I count myself) and conservatives who are more interested in what you might call “flatter government” — that is, government that isn’t in the business of redistributing wealth.

headline: Rubio Rakes In the Money
text: Marco Rubio’s Senate campaign continues to rake in the contributions, raising more than $4.5 million during the recently completed second quarter, according to a statement released Monday.

headline: Tuli Kupferberg, Poet and Singer, Dies at 86
text: Tuli Kupferberg, the poet, singer and professional bohemian who went from being a noted Beat to becoming, in his words, “the world’s oldest rock star” when he helped found the Fugs, the bawdy and politically pugnacious folk-rock group, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86 and had been a longtime resident of Greenwich Village.

headline: 12 Reasons to Look Beyond the Usual Wine Selections
text: IT’S entirely possible to go through life eating nothing but the most familiar foods, reading books by the customary best-selling authors or listening to a stock set of composers. Taking great pleasure in the same things over and over is not a bad thing.

headline: 3 Sentenced in London for Airline Plot
text: LONDON  Three men convicted last week of involvement in a 2006 plot to bomb trans-Atlantic airliners were sentenced in a London court on Monday to life imprisonment, with the judge telling them they would serve a minimum of 20 years for their roles as “foot soldiers.”

headline: New Scan May Spot Alzheimer’s
text: A small company with a new brain scan for detecting plaque, the hallmark physical sign of Alzheimer’s disease, presented its results on Sunday at an international conference in Hawaii, and experts who attended said the data persuaded them that the method works.

headline: In the Ring
text: Christina Cruz first put on boxing gloves for the same reason as most women — for fitness.  But now she wants to box in the Olympics.

headline: Surgery: Poorest 2 Billion Remain in Dire Need of Fully Functioning Operating Rooms
text: The world’s wealthiest two billion people get 75 percent of all the surgery done each year, while the poorest two billion get only 4 percent and often die or live in misery as a result, according to a new study published in the medical journal Lancet.

headline: Learning to Live With Conflicts of Interest

headline: The Shoe Corkscrew, and Other Picnic Tricks
text: Let’s start the week with some tidbits from the weekend, in no particular order except that the video at the bottom of this post — of a Frenchman teaching the world to open a bottle of wine with a shoe — is not to be missed. Allons!

headline: Doom Feared as Asian Carp Advances
text: With the country’s attention riveted on the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the news in late June that a live Asian carp had been caught in the Chicago Area Waterway System, just six miles from Lake Michigan, registered only a blip on the radar of the national news media.

headline: Postcards From the ‘Tour d’Admission': Bike Friendly
text: For seven summers, a group of college counselors from across the country have climbed on bicycles to travel from college to college on an informal, saddle-bound fact-finding mission, a kind of Tour d’Admission. This summer, the group has set its tour in California, and the participants will be filing regular dispatches to The Choice from the road. Today’s dispatch is from Kirk Blackard, director of college guidance at Christ School of Asheville, N.C, and Bruce Hunter, director of college counseling at Rowland Hall in Salt Lake City. Bill Dingledine, president of the Southern Association for College Admission Counseling and an independent counselor from Greenville, S.C., contributed to this article.

headline: Accepting That Good Parents May Plant Bad Seeds
Suit Seeks to Double Size of House
text: The Supreme Court is being asked to decide whether the House of Representatives should be enlarged to produce a fairer distribution of political power.

headline: When Good Parents Have Bad Children
text: Parents often get blamed when their children go astray — whether it’s an ill-behaved toddler or an adult rehashing a troubled childhood during a therapy session.

headline: Dining With ‘The Demons’
text: Over on the ArtsBeat blog, Mark Bittman discusses his dining experience at the Lincoln Center production of “The Demons,” directed by Peter Stein, based on Dostoevsky’s novel and realized on Governors Island this past weekend, a 15-hour affair door to door.

headline: Seashells by the Thousands, and the Stories They Tell
text: How many different kinds of seashells are there? No one can say for sure. Tens of thousands of mollusks are known to science and there are certainly far, far more out there waiting to be discovered.

headline: From ‘The Book of Shells’
text: Photos from a big and heavy guide to mollusks and the external skeletons they call home.

headline: Q. Did You Ever Smoke Pot? A. It’s Complicated.
text: Many years ago, when I was a resident in pediatrics, an adolescent patient asked me if I had ever smoked pot. It wasn’t a friendly question, more an oh-yeah-says-you response to my own inquiries, warning me off.

headline: House Fans and Mosquitoes
text: If you are looking for a chemical-free way to repel mosquitoes, you may already have the solution in your home. Turn on the fan, reports Anahad O’Connor in today’s Science Times.

headline: Talking to Kids About Your Drug Use
text: “Have you ever used drugs?”

headline: Obama Talks Exports (and Baseball)
text: It’s fairly common for presidents hosting foreign leaders to mention trade between the United States and the visitor’s country. So perhaps it should be no surprise that when the president of the Dominican Republic came calling on Monday, President Obama would cite its well-known export of baseball players.

headline: Now Booking | Diane Von Furstenberg for Claridge’s
text: In 1983, Diane Von Furstenberg sold her cosmetics business, flew to London and promptly ensconced herself at Claridge’s. “I felt I had made it,” she said recently at a cocktail party. “I was young and kicky.” Older now but kicky as ever, she’s designing 20 rooms for the hotel, bringing her unapologetically exuberant style to an Art Deco landmark. The three rooms completed so far — the others, each unique, will be done by the end of the year — include headboards blooming with Chinese roses and floors covered in silk leopard-print rugs, along with finishing touches like custom-made cashmere blankets and zebra-print bathrobes. Amid all the floral and jungle textiles, she’s also created quiet corners where guests can primp surrounded by handmade dressing tables and leather traveling trunks.

headline: How Microbes Defend and Define Us
text: Dr. Alexander Khoruts had run out of options.

headline: Checking In on the Job Creation Tax Credit
text: It’s still too early to know whether the job creation tax credit signed into law last March is having any effect, Treasury Department officials said on Monday.

headline: Paradise for Fishermen Becomes One for Scientists
text: Just off New York City lies the Hudson Canyon, a deep gash in the seabed that runs for hundreds of miles. Charter boats and commercial fishermen have long known that the canyon’s headwaters swarm with tuna, swordfish, monkfish, tilefish, red crabs and other sea life.

headline: U.S. Issues Revised Offshore Drilling Ban
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar issued revised rules on Monday for a six-month moratorium on deepwater oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, replacing an earlier one that had been declared invalid by federal courts.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in Music Critic’s Suit Against Cleveland Plain-Dealer
text: Jury selection began on Monday in a music critic’s lawsuit against his employer, The Cleveland Plain-Dealer, and the Cleveland Orchestra in Ohio’s Cuyahoga County Court of Common Pleas. The critic, Donald Rosenberg, filed the suit after he was removed in September 2008 from reviewing the orchestra. He said orchestra management pressed the newspaper into sidelining him because it objected to a string of negative reviews he gave to the orchestra’s music director, Franz Welser-Most. He remains on the paper’s staff.

headline: Russian Suicide Bomb Ring Foiled, Government Says
text: MOSCOW — Russian security services have broken up what they described as a terrorist cell in a Muslim region of the country that was preparing female suicide bombers for attacks on major Russian cities, officials announced on Monday.

headline: For a Proton, a Little Off the Top (or Side) Could Be Big Trouble
text: For most of us, 4 percent off around the waist — a couple of belt notches — would be a great triumph.

headline: YouTube Question: Girls’ Education
text: Throughout the week, Nick has been responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today, Nick answers a question about the progress being made in the area of girls’ education.

headline: Readers Tell Others to Pick Up After Themselves
text: In a 1970s commercial, a human-size owl in a green Pilgrim-like hat skipped down a street, trailed by dozens of light-footed children who all sang along to a catchy tune that carried a public message: “Give a Hoot, Don’t Pollute.” In the same decade, an Indian surrounded by a polluted river let a tear roll down his cheek, saddened by the detritus that floated around his canoe. Both public service announcements addressed littering, a problem that has gotten out of hand in certain areas, according to Kathy Stevenson, who wrote this weekend’s Complaint Box in the Metropolitan section.

headline: Europeans Weigh Details of Stress Test, and How Much to Disclose
text: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers met Monday to start two days of discussions partly aimed at deciding how much information to reveal after they complete tests on the ability of banks to survive if governments default on their debts.

headline: Quote Unquote | Brand Allusions
text: –Russell Brand dissects his aesthetic for Vogue UK, collision being the operative word.

headline: Help for the Friendless, but at a Price
text: Heaven and hell both serve as backdrops in “I’ll Be Damned,” the elongated sketch of a musical now at the Vineyard Theater. But the true spiritual location of this faux-naïf tale of a latter-day Faust seems to be just around the corner from “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood.” Or perhaps down the street from “Pee-wee’s Playhouse.”

headline: The Meaning of Credibility
text: In response to today’s column, a number of people have suggested that the Fed essentially defines credibility purely in terms of hitting its inflation target.

headline: 400 Park Geese Die, for Human Fliers’ Sake
text: They have been a familiar sight around the lake in Prospect Park in Brooklyn: Canada geese, scores of them. To some residents, the birds and their fuzzy offspring are charming hints of wildlife amid the bricks of the city. Recently, when one was found with an arrow through its neck, park rangers tried to corral it to administer first aid.

headline: From the Police to the Met: A Renaissance Man
text: If the story is to be believed, there’s some schadenfreude to be found in a tale that Sting tells about being booed the first time he performed at an opera house. It was in 1987, as Sting recounted recently, that he stepped onstage to sing “The Ballad of Mack the Knife” with the Hamburg State Orchestra, and he noticed “a group of people, all with blue and gray hair, and jewels and fur,” who were jeering him before he’d opened his mouth.

headline: Cold War-Style Spying Is Back (How Quaint)
text: Now that the suburban moles have been sent home to Moscow, it’s hard to see how Bravo will ever be able to pull off the obvious and much-needed spinoff, “The Real Russian Spies of New Jersey.”

headline: This Situation Is Different (Wonkish)
text: One thing I’ve argued many times on this blog is that when assessing the record of fiscal policy, you have to make allowance for the fact that things are different when you’re in a liquidity trap.* Estimating the average effect of fiscal shocks in all regimes, as opposed to those rare occasions when you’re in a liquidity trap, tells you little about how things work now. That’s why I really liked the Almunia et al work on fiscal policy in the 1930s, which tried to focus on a period resembling where we are now.

headline: Chinese Factories Now Compete to Woo Laborers
text: ZHONGSHAN, China — If Wang Jinyan, an unemployed factory worker with a middle school education, had a résumé, it might start out like this: “Objective: seeking well-paid, slow-paced assembly-line work in air-conditioned plant with Sundays off, free wireless Internet and washing machines in dormitory. Friendly boss a plus.”

headline: From West Africa, a Recipe for Spicy Trans-Atlantic Funk
text: Orchestre Poly-Rythmo de Cotonou, from Benin, belongs on the very short list of the world’s greatest funk bands. More than four decades into its career, most of them spent touring Benin and nearby West African countries, the 10-man orchestra made its blistering North American debut on Sunday night at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. Its founder and one of its main composers, Clément Mélomé, was on saxophone.

headline: Knopf To Publish Sotomayor Memoir
text: Sonia Sotomayor, right, the Supreme Court justice, will write a memoir to be published by Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher announced Monday. The book does not yet have a publication date or a title, but it was described by Knopf as a “coming-of-age memoir by an American daughter of Puerto Rican immigrants.” Sonny Mehta, chairman and editor in chief of the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group, said in a statement that Ms. Sotomayor’s achievements “will prove an inspiration to readers around the world.” Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, declined to disclose financial terms of the agreement.

headline: Atlantic Theater Reveals Lineup for 25th Season
text: A Harold Pinter double bill, a festival of 10-minute works by 25 playwrights and premiere productions by David Auburn (“Proof”), the filmmaker Ethan Coen and Lucy Thurber (“Scarcity”) will make up the 25th season of the Off Broadway Atlantic Theater Company, its leaders said on Monday. The short-play festival, May 18 to June 26, will comprise newly commissioned work by playwrights with ties to the Atlantic  including Annie Baker, John Guare, Craig Lucas and David Mamet  in recognition of the 25th anniversary of the Chelsea-based theater. The season will begin on Sept. 3 with Ms. Thurber’s new play, “Bottom of the World,” about a woman coming to grips with the death of her sister. Next up will be the two Pinter plays, “The Collection” (first performed in 1962) and “A Kind of Alaska” (first performed in 1982), which are to run Nov. 3 to Dec. 12. Mr. Auburn’s adaptation of “The New York Idea,” an early 20th-century play by Langdon Mitchell, is scheduled to run Jan. 6 to Feb. 13. The Atlantic and St. Ann’s Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater company, will produce Mr. Coen’s new work, “Four Pickups,” described by the Atlantic as four short plays linked to pickup trucks, and scheduled for April and May. All productions for the 2010-11 season will take place on stages other than Atlantic’s main stage on West 20th Street at the Linda Gross Theater, which will be undergoing its first renovation since the Atlantic opened there.

headline: Pursuing Harmony, With Just a Bare Bulb Illuminating the Way
text: The first thing you need to know about Saburo Teshigawara is that his body, though sinewy, moves like a long, graceful piece of ribbon, giving off the sensation that if you peeked underneath the skin there would be no bones or muscles to interrupt the flow.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
text: Somalia’s most feared insurgent group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility Monday for the coordinated bombings that killed more than 70 people in Uganda as crowds gathered to watch the final match of World Cup. Josh Kron and Mohammed Ibrahim report that the Shabab have been waging a relentless insurgency against Somalia’s weak transitional federal government, and that they have repeatedly threatened Uganda and Burundi for contributing troops to the African Union’s effort to stabilize the country.

headline: Judge Reduces Fine In Downloading Case
text: A federal judge has reduced damages by nine-tenths of the original amount in a closely watched music downloading case. Last July a jury awarded $675,000 to four record labels for the 30 songs downloaded and shared by Joel Tenenbaum, a graduate student at Boston University. But on Friday the judge, Nancy Gertner of United States District Court in Massachusetts, ruled that the penalty was “unconstitutionally excessive”  bearing “no meaningful relationship” to the government’s “legitimate interests in compensating copyright owners and deterring infringement”  and lowered the amount to $67,500. The Recording Industry Association of America said in a statement that it would “contest this ruling.”

headline: ‘Brother’ Still Big for CBS
text: “Big Brother” and “60 Minutes” lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, both programs drew an average of 7 million viewers. NBC ranked second, earning 5 million viewers from 9 to 11 for a rerun of “America’s Got Talent.” ABC was third, garnering its lowest ratings at 9 and 10 with new episodes of “Scoundrels” (3 million) and “The Gates” (3.2 million). Fox finished in fourth place with mostly reruns of its comedies.

headline: Hulk Casting Decision Angers Norton’s Agent
text: Marvel Entertainment’s decision not to cast Edward Norton as the angry emerald hero the Hulk in a film has touched off an exchange between Marvel and Mr. Norton’s representatives that is almost as heated as a comic-book battle. HitFix.com reported that Marvel was not asking Mr. Norton, who played Bruce Banner and his alter ego in “The Incredible Hulk,” to reprise his role in “The Avengers,” a film planned for 2012 that will unite some of the company’s best-known superheroes. Marvel said its decision “is definitely not one based on monetary factors, but instead rooted in the need for an actor who embodies the creativity and collaborative spirit of our other talented cast members.” In a swift rebuttal, Mr. Norton’s agent Brian Swardstrom wrote to HitFix.com that Marvel’s statement was “a purposefully misleading, inappropriate attempt to paint our client in a negative light.” Marvel cast Mr. Norton to portray the Banner and Hulk characters for a 2008 remake after a 2003 “Hulk” movie was a box office disappointment. Mr. Norton was also allowed to rewrite the script of his film, and there were rumblings that he and the studio clashed over creative decisions in the weeks before “The Incredible Hulk” was released.

headline: Insects as Model Animals
text: Jeremy Niven spends his days at Cambridge University running locusts across ladders and through mazes, trying to figure out how bugs think. Dr. Niven, 34, studies the evolution of brains and neurons in insects and other animals, like humans. We spoke during a break in last month's World Science Festival in New York, where he was a guest presenter, and then again later via telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows:

headline: After Canceling Concert, Lopez Faces Possible Suit
text: A hotel in Cyprus said it might sue Jennifer Lopez, below, after the singer withdrew from a scheduled concert for fear that it would be construed as making a political statement, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lopez was to perform at the Cratos Premium hotel and casino complex in Turkish-occupied northern Cyprus on July 24, an event that Greek Cypriots have said would further polarize the country, which has been divided since the 1970s and whose northern region is recognized only by Turkey. Ms. Lopez’s representatives said last week that she would not perform the concert, citing “sensitivity to the political realities of the region.” But Murat Bozoglu, chief executive of the company that runs Cratos Premium, told Agence France-Presse that Ms. Lopez’s contract for the show had not been canceled. “If she does not show up for the concert, we will begin a procedure in the courts to claim $35 to $40 million in damages,” Mr. Bozoglu said.

headline: Absent-Minded Mishaps on a Big Day
text: I ALWAYS envisioned myself as one of those cool frequent fliers breezing through the airport. I’m not that person.

headline: Telling Tales Through Many Movements
text: BECKET, Mass.  Not all standing ovations are created equal. There are the limited ones, when a few partisans rise and then some scattered groups are goaded up by peer pressure. There are the gaudy affairs, when viewers are applauding the occasion  and themselves.

headline: Missing Myths
text: For reasons unclear, one of my recent columns — one that I was rather proud of — has gone missing from the list at the right of this blog. Is is an ex-column? Is it pushing up the daisies? No — some kind of technical glitch.

headline: The Future Arrives for a Soprano, as She Steps Into a Demanding Role
text: KATONAH, N.Y.  In the finals of the 2007 Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, the young American soprano Angela Meade knocked out an audience at the Met with a magisterial and vocally sumptuous performance of “Casta Diva,” Norma’s famous aria from the great Bellini opera that bears her name. Her performance can be seen on “The Audition,” the revealing recent documentary by Susan Froemke about the finals for the competition that year.

headline: Organizers of Art Show Convicted in Moscow
text: MOSCOW  The trial of two prominent Russian intellectuals over a 2007 contemporary art exhibition at the Sakharov Museum here that included works on religious themes ended on Monday with a guilty verdict and fines but no jail time for the defendants.

headline: Sarkozy Urges Official to Quit Party Post
text: PARIS — In an effort to put allegations of illegal political donations behind him, President Nicolas Sarkozy went on national television Monday evening and urged his embattled labor minister, Éric Woerth, to quit as treasurer of their political party.

headline: Where Sparky May Go After His Final Walk
text: At their worst animal lovers are an embarrassment  especially to the animals they adore. The cat is not dignified by the owner who keeps a dozen other cats; no dog wants to submit to a team of hair stylists just to have a shot at Best in Show. In the relationship between humans and the animals over whom, the Bible tells us, we have dominion, Homo sapiens is the besotted fool.

headline: Referees’ Calls May Get Lost in Their Translation
text: Fans who angrily questioned several calls made by soccer referees in this year’s World Cup won’t be surprised at a report in the journal PLoS One that found inherent bias in referees.

headline: Love Among Finches: It’s Not All About Looks
text: Handsome men may turn the heads of women, but for those less attractive, sociability and friendliness also seem to seduce the fairer sex. The same is true for male house finches, according to a new study.

headline: A Mass Mating Signal Over the Smoky Mountains
text: In early June of each year, thousands of male fireflies in the Smoky Mountains flash in harmony across the night sky.

headline: For Tours, 2010 Has Been a Tough Sell
text: As CD sales have plunged over the last decade, the music industry has increasingly looked to touring for income. And for a decade the live market has grown significantly, with greater revenues posted each year on steadily rising ticket prices.

text: Tonight’s Home Run Derby features some of the game’s top sluggers. Continue reading for live updates from Anaheim.

headline: Snowe to Back Financial Regulation Bill
text: Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, said Monday that she was prepared to support the final version of legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial regulatory system, putting the Senate in a position to complete the bill by week’s end.

headline: J.&J. Will Buy a Stroke-Treatment Company for $480 Million
text: The market for medical devices used in the treatment of strokes is heating up.

headline: Travel Managers’ Goal: Seeing Air Fees Upfront
text: WHEN I buy an airplane ticket, I like to know exactly what my flight is going to cost, and for the most part, I can easily figure it out. But that is not necessarily true for the corporate travel managers and the people in your company who approve your expense reports.

headline: U.S. and Afghanistan Debate More Village Forces
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  With American commanders pushing to expand the number of armed village forces in areas where their troops and the local police are scarce, the Afghan president is signaling that he has serious concerns that such a program could return the country to warlordism, challenging the power of the central government.

headline: Fring and Skype Embroiled in Bitter Blog Fight
text: The latest Silicon Valley squabble sounds like an unusually esoteric episode of “Gossip Girl.” This one involves a couple of mobile Internet-based phone services.

text: BOSTON  The Fenway Frank. The Dodger Dog. The Cincinnati Cheese Coney. They are, for better or worse, the gastronomic benchmarks at baseball stadiums across the country, and as much a gustatory ritual as beer, peanuts and Cracker Jack.

headline: Apache’s Talks With BP Raise Leverage Concerns
text: It is potentially hazardous to swallow a meal a third your size. But it could make sense for Apache Corporation to grab $10 billion of BP’s Alaskan assets. The company’s flair for squeezing oil from older wells makes it an ideal buyer.

headline: International Court Adds Genocide to Charges Against Sudan Leader
text: PARIS  The International Criminal Court in The Hague said Monday that it had issued a second arrest warrant for President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, this time for three counts of genocide.

headline: Harvey Pekar, ‘American Splendor’ Creator, Dies at 70
text: Harvey Pekar, whose autobiographical comic book “American Splendor” attracted a cult following for its unvarnished stories of a depressed, aggrieved Everyman negotiating daily life in Cleveland and became the basis for a critically acclaimed 2003 film, died on Monday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 70.

headline: Contador Shrugs at Rivals’ Stumbles
text: MORZINE, France  Sitting on the back porch of his Alpine hotel Monday, Alberto Contador did not appear to be fazed by the latest drama surrounding this year’s Tour de France.

headline: Tuli Kupferberg, Bohemian and Fug, Dies at 86
text: Tuli Kupferberg, a poet and singer who went from being a noted Beat to becoming, in his words, “the world’s oldest rock star” when he helped found the Fugs, the bawdy and politically pugnacious rock group, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: New Holdup in Pending Rangers Sale
text: The pending sale of the Texas Rangers, already a tortuous tale, added a strange chapter Monday when the group seeking to acquire the team sought an injunction against the team to prevent it from soliciting higher bids.

headline: Backers Give ‘Son of Sam’ Image Makeover
text: During a yearlong string of shootings before his arrest in the summer of 1977, David Berkowitz, known as the Son of Sam, killed six people and wounded seven others in New York City.

headline: At U.S. Open, 15-Year-Old Gives Glimpse of Potential
text: OAKMONT, Pa.  A financial adviser was pitching his services to the parents of Alexis Thompson on the Oakmont Country Club veranda. His timing was propitious; Thompson had just survived the cut in the United States Women’s Open, assuring her of her first payday since turning professional last month.

headline: Old Bones Yield a New Age of Dinosaurs in Thailand
text: BAAN NA KUM, Thailand  When the rains come and the rivers swell, giant bones tend to wash up in this remote rice-farming corner of Thailand.

headline: Barefoot Run Ends in Bahamas
text: SEATTLE — His ride ended the way it began: shoes off, in the islands. Just not his islands.

headline: Power Pitchers Emerge, Shifting Focus of the Game
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Phil Hughes was about 10 when home runs started soaring out of major league parks with suspicious frequency. As a teenager, he would ride his bike 25 minutes to Angel Stadium, watch from the upper deck and root for the long ball. At Foothill High School in Santa Ana, though, he was more suited to pitch.

headline: Abuse Took Years to Ignite Belgian Clergy Inquiry
text: WESTVLETEREN, Belgium  Behind an aggressive investigation of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Belgium that drew condemnation from the pope himself lies a stark family tragedy: the molestation, for years, of a youth by his uncle, the bishop of Bruges; the prelate’s abrupt resignation when a friend of the nephew finally threatened to make the abuse public; and now the grass-roots fury of almost 500 people complaining of abuse by priests.

headline: How to Lose a Legacy
text: An “heirloom” is an object steeped in family history, handed down from generation to generation: your mother’s wedding dress, your grandma’s espresso cups, your great uncle’s underwear. You can’t buy an heirloom at Pottery Barn or Ikea. It comes via gift, bequest or a heated sibling brawl. But who’s to say you actually want this stale old stuff?

headline: Plan to Remove Bronx Expressway Gains Traction
text: For more than a decade, a plan pushed by some South Bronx residents and transportation advocates has sat on the fringes of the State Transportation Department’s to-do list, in part because it would be a radical undoing: tearing down the Sheridan Expressway.

headline: Beyond Guns: N.R.A. Expands Agenda
text: WASHINGTON  Fresh off a string of victories in the courts and Congress, the National Rifle Association is flexing political muscle outside its normal domain, with both Democrats and Republicans courting its favor and avoiding its wrath on issues that sometimes seem to have little to do with guns.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Despite a Diminished Field, Sluggers Swing for the Seats
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  David Ortiz delivered his big bat and booming personality to the Home Run Derby on Monday night. But when a diminished slugger can conquer a diminished field  as Ortiz did, defeating Hanley Ramirez in the final round  it may be time to wonder whether the derby, with home runs declining and many of baseball’s most prominent sluggers giving it a pass, has lost some of its juice.

text: “The one thing you’re not going to get me to do is speculate.”

headline: An Economy of Grinds
text: If you go to business conferences, you know that at lunch it is definitely better to be seated next to a prince than a grind. Princes, who can be male or female, are senior executives at major corporations.

headline: Without James, Knicks Focus on Improvement
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  In another dimension, Donnie Walsh might have attended a news conference on Monday to officially introduce the newest member of the Knicks  LeBron James. But that dream was demolished when James instead opted for the Miami Heat.

headline: Fire in Village Shows That Wood Decks, if Not Cared for, Can Be a Hazard
text: Flames licked over the parapet of a Greenwich Village building on Monday morning and black smoke billowed into the air after a wooden roof deck ignited.

headline: After Attacks in Uganda, Worry Grows Over Group
text: WASHINGTON — The deadly bombings in Uganda during the World Cup final have deepened worries among American authorities about another once localized Islamic group that is spreading its terrorism across borders, using a playbook written by Al Qaeda.

headline: Bid for Trophy Becomes a Test of Iroquois Identity
text: The Iroquois national lacrosse team was hoping to spend Monday getting acclimated in England as it prepared for its first game in this year’s world championships.

headline: Well Spoken on the Art of Speaking
text: Bob Sheppard, who became the Yankees’ public-address announcer about the time Methuselah was trying out at third base, proved to be pretty good at political forecasting.

headline: New Jersey Puts 2% Cap on Local Property Taxes
text: New Jersey lawmakers on Monday imposed a 2 percent limit on annual property tax increases by local governments, trying to gain control of one of the state’s most contentious issues.

headline: Outside the Casino

headline: Annoyance at a Barbecue
text: Comment display has been erratic for this post, but all of the comments are now displayed, although in somewhat jumbled order. Our apologies for the inconvenience.

headline: World Cup Final Sets Record
text: Spain’s 1-0 victory over the Netherlands in the World Cup final Sunday was seen by an average of 15.5 million viewers on ABC, the most in the United States for a men’s final, and 8.8 million on Univision, a record for a Spanish-language network in the United States, according to the Nielsen Company.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about plans to rerelease the film “Avatar” for two weeks starting on Aug. 27 referred incorrectly to two characters shown in an accompanying picture. Zoë Saldana and Sam Worthington perform the roles of the characters Neytiri and Jake. They do not merely provide voices for them.

headline: The Social Life of a Serial Killer
text: In the years since his arrest, David Berkowitz has attracted an array of friends and acquaintances outside of prison who are drawn by his religious conversion and redemption story.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Nick Jonas, who is starring in “Les Misérables” in London, used an outdated title for the Disney Channel series in which he appears with his two older brothers. While it was formerly called “Jonas,” it is now “Jonas L.A.”

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: South Africa’s Soccer Future
text: What happens now? It’s a question that’s been asked from the moment South Africa was awarded the World Cup. Now that it’s all over, what happens to the stadiums? What happens to the economy?

headline: Cutting and Pasting: A Senior Thesis by (Insert Name)
text: A friend who teaches at a well-known eastern university told me recently that plagiarism was turning him into a cop. He begins the semester collecting evidence, in the form of an in-class essay that gives him a sense of how well students think and write. He looks back at the samples later when students turn in papers that feature their own, less-than-perfect prose alongside expertly written passages lifted verbatim from the Web.

headline: No Honor, Only Horror
text: There is much to admire in India today, including its vibrant democracy and economy and its rich traditions. It should also lead the way in protecting and empowering women by ending so-called honor killings.

headline: Europe Curbs Its Bankers
text: Excessive pay for bankers, and huge rewards for risk-taking, brought this country and the world to the brink of financial disaster. The Obama administration recognized the problem and then did far too little about it. It appointed a tough pay czar, but it only gave him the power to forbid excessive pay at banks that had not yet reimbursed the Treasury for their bailout. The Federal Reserve has issued pay guidelines, but it has not set limits on cash pay or taxes on remuneration to reduce bankers’ perverse incentives.

headline: A Yellow Light to DNA Searches
text: For nearly 25 years, a serial killer stalked South Los Angeles, murdering at least 10 people. He was caught last week through the use of a much-debated DNA technique that involves tracking down relatives of convicted criminals. The technique, known as familial searching, has significant potential as a crime-fighting tool and is likely to spread to other states now that it has passed its first successful test in this country. But there must be stringent safeguards to prevent abuse.

headline: Both Frail and Feisty, Fidel Castro Goes on TV
text: MEXICO CITY  In one of his first public appearances since falling ill four years ago, a frail-looking Fidel Castro went on Cuban television on Monday night and warned in a near whisper that the United States was increasing the chances of nuclear war in the Korean Peninsula and Iran.

headline: Plan for Female Bishops
text: The Church of England’s General Synod ruled on Monday that the church will go ahead with a plan to appoint female bishops by 2014, with only minimal concessions to traditionalists opposing the move. Citing the fact that all of the disciples of Jesus were men as evidence that women bishops would be contrary to biblical beliefs, the traditionalists had pressed for creation of a separate body of “complementary” male bishops with independent authority, established in church law, to minister to traditionalists in dioceses where female bishops are appointed.

headline: Memoir Recounts Tumult in Downing Street After Inconclusive British Election
text: LONDON — “You have to make a decision. I have made mine. It is final. I am going to the palace. Goodbye.”

headline: In Sudan, War Is Around the Corner
text: FOR many good reasons, Americans are doubting our ability as a nation to positively influence events abroad. We’re involved in two conflicts with dubious outcomes and we’ve begun to question whether any step we take, anywhere, will be the right one. But it was not long ago that the United States intervened abroad in a bold way that led to undeniably positive results.

headline: Collusion by Big 3? N.B.A. Says Not Likely
text: LAS VEGAS  LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh became Miami Heat teammates last week, turning a shared dream into reality and unleashing a torrent of suspicion: Had they planned it all along? If so, was this collusion? Tampering? Illegal?

headline: Saltwater Fly-Fishing’s Prize Catch
text: SAN DIEGO  The green fairways of Torrey Pines Golf Course were visible through a veil of marine fog as our 24-foot skiff rolled on gentle swells a mile or so offshore. My reverie of contending in a future United States Open on the storied links was broken by my angling companion Geoff Roach’s exclamation: “We’ve got one coming in!”

headline: North Korea Postpones Meeting on Warship Sinking
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea abruptly postponed a meeting with the American-led United Nations Command that had been scheduled to take place on Tuesday to discuss the March sinking of a South Korean warship.

headline: In Braves’ Infante, Even Utility Players Have All-Star
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  When Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel picked Omar Infante for the National League All-Star team, it was one of the most puzzling choices in the game’s history. Infante was not even an everyday player. That day, July 4, he pinch-hit for Atlanta and struck out to end the game.

headline: N.C.A.A. Sets Tournament Plan
text: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)  The N.C.A.A. unveiled its plans for the 68-team men’s basketball tournament Monday, opting for a format that involves the lowest seeds and last at-large qualifiers in a “First Four” round.

text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – When Philadelphia Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel picked Omar Infante for the National League All-Star team, it was one of the most puzzling choices ever. Infante was not even an everyday player. That day, he pinch hit for the Atlanta Braves and struck out to end the game.

headline: Empty Chairs, Empty Tables, Empty Beds
text: MOSCOW — The rooms depicted in Mari Bastashevski’s project, “File 126 (Disappearing in the Caucasus),” are neat as a pin, suffused with light, as carefully arranged as a brand new doll house.

headline: Diabetes Drug Maker Hid Test Data, Files Indicate
text: In the fall of 1999, the drug giant SmithKline Beecham secretly began a study to find out if its diabetes medicine, Avandia, was safer for the heart than a competing pill, Actos, made by Takeda.

headline: George W. Webber, Social Activist Minister, Dies at 90
text: The Rev. George W. Webber, a Protestant minister and educator whose quest to make religion more socially relevant led him to remake a major seminary, start storefront churches in East Harlem and begin a program to educate prison inmates as pastors, died Saturday at his home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 90.

headline: Second Stage Names New Executive Director
text: The Off Broadway company Second Stage Theater has hired Casey Reitz, the director of development at the Public Theater, as its new executive director overseeing the group’s business side, Carole Rothman, the Second Stage artistic director, said on Monday. Mr. Reitz, who will start the job in early September, will succeed Ellen Richard, who left Second Stage in June 2009 and was recently named executive director of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. The appointment of Mr. Reitz, who has helped oversee the Public’s $35 million capital campaign for building renovations, comes as Second Stage is preparing for its 32nd season and continuing work toward buying the Helen Hayes Theater, which would become the first Broadway house owned by the nonprofit theater company. Second Stage acquired the rights to buy the Helen Hayes in 2008; the theater is continuing to raise money for the purchase, a spokesman for Second Stage said on Monday, and intends to begin producing shows in the theater in 2012. Second Stage originally hoped to begin mounting shows there this year, but that has been delayed by the challenge of fund-raising and the need to renovate the theater.

headline: Clara Claiborne Park, 86, Dies; Wrote About Autistic Child
text: Jessy, the 8-year-old daughter of Clara Claiborne Park, would step around a spot of light on the floor for hours, or incessantly run a chain through her fingers. She would sit and stare through people around her as though they were not there. A word she learned one day would fade from her memory the next.

headline: Woods Appears to Be Confident but Is Searching for Consistency
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The ancient town that sits hard by the North Sea has many moods, and some have been on display for the last three days. A cold, gray mist clung to the Old Course like a shroud on Saturday. By Sunday, the sky had cleared and the chill wind had begun to gust to 50 miles per hour. On Monday, it was cloudy and eerily calm — a grim harbinger of the forecasted storms or a precursor of the golf to come.

headline: BP Investors Seek Damages, Despite Ruling

The ruling would bar the majority of the oil company’s shareholders from damages in the United States, The Financial Times reports.

Two years later, the first beautifully engineered, split windshield Porsche 356s were sold through official channels in the United States, thus marking 2010 as their 60th anniversary.

headline: With Pesto, In Season Is Best
text: I look forward each year to that first batch of pesto, which is something I honestly believe cannot be made with the insipid basil of winter, no matter where it comes from. Great basil cannot be grown in a greenhouse, and cannot be grown out of season. In this, it’s like the tomato. (The so-called vine-ripened tomatoes invented in Holland may be redder than the orange plastic-wrapped specimens of my youth, but they don’t taste any better.)

headline: Italy Arrests Hundreds in Mob Sweep
text: ROME  The Italian police arrested more than 300 people, including local government officials, and seized millions of dollars in property, money, weapons and drugs across the country on Tuesday in one of the most extensive law enforcement operations against the crime syndicate known as ’Ndrangheta.

headline: ‘Die Hard’ Director Faces Prison Sentence
text: John McTiernan, the director of “Die Hard” and “The Hunt for Red October,” has pleaded guilty — again — in a case linked to an investigation of a prominent private detective who worked for Hollywood’s rich and famous. Mr. McTiernan admitted on Monday to lying to the F.B.I. and to a judge in connection with a probe of the investigator, Anthony Pellicano, according to The Associated Press. He faces up to a year in prison. The director pleaded guilty four years ago to lying to agents but later successfully moved to have the plea voided. Mr. Pellicano was sentenced to 15 years in prison in December 2008 for illegal wiretapping.

headline: Tesla Says It Is Testing an Electric Car Prototype for Toyota
text: Just a few months after Toyota and Tesla Motors announced a collaboration on an electric car, a Tesla spokeswoman says a prototype has already been built and is undergoing testing.

headline: Will Anything Curb China’s Appetite for Rare Wildlife?
text: Pity the scaly anteater, or pangolin. It is hardly what anyone would call charismatic megafauna, so it doesn’t spark big campaigns by wildlife conservation groups. The reclusive, nocturnal animals could surely vanish from southern Asia with hardly anyone noticing (there are other species in Africa). Two of the four Asian pangolin species are listed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. (The Malayan pangolin pictured above is safe, living in one of Singapore’s national parks.)

headline: A Summer Roundup: Goldman, Playboy and More
text: While I was on vacation over the last two weeks, the deal world appears to have been in suspension, maybe waiting for financial reform to move ahead.

headline: More Opera Coming to a Movie Theater Near You
text: The Metropolitan Opera has made live broadcasts in movie theaters a staple across the malls, multiplexes and art houses of the world. But competitors have emerged, including the Royal Opera House in London. That company is now expanding its offerings through a new deal with Emerging Pictures, a network that provides digital transmissions of events to movie theaters. In an agreement announced on Tuesday, Emerging Pictures will become the North American distributor of shows from the Royal Opera’s media arm, Opus Arte. The shows will include live performances of operas and ballets, as well as filmed productions of Shakespeare plays from the Globe Theater, for which Opus Arte has the rights. The first event to be shown under the new arrangement will be the opening-night performance of Mozart’s “Così fan Tutte” on Sept. 10 at Covent Garden.

headline: Job Openings Ratio Little Changed in May
text: The number of unemployed workers in May outnumbered job openings in America by a ratio of 4.67 to 1, according to data released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: From the Archives: the Steinbrenner Legacy

headline: Gaza-Bound Ship Diverts to Egypt, Averting Clash

headline: White Beans With Pesto
text: Use pistou made with basil for this salad, or one of the more unusual pestos, like arugula pesto or chermoula. The pesto will contrast beautifully with the creamy flavor of the beans.

headline: Inside Out | Having Your Fill
text: These are some of my favorite things — small vessels in glass, ceramic or creamware. I buy them here and there; some are expensive, some cost hardly anything at all. But they make up the little still lifes in one’s house. I often buy them for myself with photo shoots in mind, but some of the pieces shown here belong to a client, and the colored glass vases are from William Yeoward. They were not the ones that cost hardly anything (!), but they do cost almost nothing to fill. You literally need three stems, and gathered together they are so pretty.

headline: Toffee, Pretzels and Beer Rolled Up in One
text: Nicole Greene, a Chicago-based confectioner who sells sweets online, has come up with a clever riff on English toffee. She makes hers with beer, coats the crisp squares with milk chocolate and then rolls them in nuts and pieces of pretzel sticks. There you have beer-and-pretzel toffee (hold the mustard) with that welcome touch of salt. Ms. Greene also has a summer line with strawberry-lemonade truffles and lavender-peach caramels. The name of her company, truffletruffle, refers to chocolate truffles and to her slightly funky-tasting shortbreads made with black truffle butter.

headline: Financial Bill to Close Regulator of Fading Industry

So perhaps the most remarkable piece of the financial regulation bill that Democrats hope to send the president this week is the directive to dismember and close the Office of Thrift Supervision.

headline: From Belgium, a Gingery Spread
text: For a taste of Christmas in July, there is a new spekuloos spread made from gingerbread cookies of that name that are a traditional treat for St. Nicholas Day (Dec. 6) in Belgium. It’s the creamy stuff that gets slathered on the Belgian waffles sold by the Wafels & Dinges truck. Thomas DeGeest, a native of Louvain in Belgium, has won a Vendy award for his truck’s desserts, and then triumphed over Bobby Flay in a waffle-making contest on the Food Network, thanks to the spread. Now, the gingery, delicately spiced spread, which looks just like smooth peanut butter, is available in jars to use on your own waffles, as well as in sandwiches, cookies and on French toast.

headline: Behind the Scenes of a Live World Cup
text: This year’s World Cup coverage put a heavy emphasis on live, in-game updates and analysis.

headline: In Park Slope, Fornino Adds a Takeout Shop
text: Now that the Park Slope outpost of his Williamsburg, Brooklyn, pizzeria, Fornino, is up and running, Michael Ayoub, above, is opening a takeout shop next door, with a view of the kitchen. Items on the regular menu can be ordered to go, and there are homemade sausages and pasta sauces for home cooks. Grilled pizzas are sold fully cooked or with the crust grilled on one side only, to be topped with your own kitchen creation. Among the 17 varieties is Pizza Vinny Scotto, for the chef who died three years ago and was known for grilled pizza at his restaurant Gonzo in Greenwich Village. His sister, Donna Scotto, now runs the takeout shop at Fornino.

headline: Citrus Drinks From European Groves
text: Simple, very lightly sweetened citrus ades are wonderful to keep chilled for summer sipping. Bella Lula organic lemonade and orangeade, made near Paris and now available in the United States, are two such products, enhanced with a whiff of Moroccan mint. And Italian Volcano, a company that uses organic fruit from near Mount Etna on Sicily, has introduced a delightful limeade.

headline: Iraq’s Modern Art Collection, Waiting to Re-emerge
text: BAGHDAD  What’s left of Saddam Hussein’s showcase collection of 20th-century Iraqi art is crammed into three dingy galleries of a formerly grand museum on Haifa Street here. The rest of the building once known as the Center for Contemporary Art has become a warren of offices and cubicles fortified by bricks, barbed wire and sandbags and closed to the public.

headline: Appeals Court Strikes Down Indecency Rule
text: A United States appeals court tossed out the indecency policy of the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday, calling it a violation of the First Amendment.

headline: Rain Could Wash Out Shanghai Symphony in Central Park
text: They flew thousands of miles to play in Central Park to publicize Shanghai’s Expo. But if the rain keeps up on Tuesday, the Shanghai Symphony musicians will go home on Wednesday without playing a note in public. The orchestra was to share the stage with the New York Philharmonic and the pianist Lang Lang in the Philharmonic’s first free parks concert of the summer, but no rain date is planned. The Philharmonic, which received a fee from the Chinese orchestra in exchange for the appearance, said a decision together with the New York City Parks Department would not be made before 6 p.m. The Philharmonic has another program planned for the Great Lawn on Wednesday night.

headline: A Double-Dip Recession? No, Thank You.
text: It’s been almost two years since the economy hit the brakes. Now I keep reading about the possibility of a double-dip recession. If you listen to economists, the odds of this happening seem to range from very likely to next to nil. Of course, the odds of getting an accurate prediction might be just as good if you go to a fortune teller (or perhaps a lack-of-fortune teller, in this case).

headline: Male Models Are Just Like Us
text: They may travel the world, mingle with top designers and take home mucho freebies, but behind the scenes, male models are — to borrow a phrase from the tabloids — “just like us!” (Well, if we all got our zits concealed by the makeup maven Pat McGrath.) We asked the model and friend of T Matthew Hitt to record some of the action around the shows, capturing his peers in idle mode. Alas, they still look better doing nothing.

headline: Remembering Steinbrenner as a ‘Seinfeld’ Star
text: The Yankees owner George Steinbrenner, who died on Tuesday morning at the age of 80, may have been most recognized for his role as a baseball monarch. But he also played one on TV. Or, at least, he was regularly mimicked on the television show “Seinfeld” when the character George Costanza had a tenuous employment for the most hated and loved Yankees teams of the 1990s.

headline: Commander in Iraq Warns of Attacks on U.S. Bases

headline: A Few Clues About Unfinished Larsson Book
text: It could be that the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson was just weeks and a little more than 100 pages away from finishing the fourth manuscript in his best-selling Millennium series. According to an e-mail message that John-Henri Holmberg, a friend of Mr. Larsson, provided to The Associated Press, Mr. Larsson was 320 pages into a 440-page book when he died at age 50 in November 2004. Mr. Larsson had planned to finish the book by December 2004, Mr. Holmberg added. The manuscript is believed to be in the custody of Eva Gabrielsson, Mr. Larsson’s companion, but she has declined to make it public. If published, a fourth novel in the series would almost certainly be a best seller, based on the intense interest in the first three books about Lisbeth Salander and the journalist Mikhael Blomkvist.

And in a social setting with strangers, he was a nice guy, pleasant and friendly.

headline: Two Friendships: A Response

When one is lucky, one finds interlocutors who are willing to share that thought, add to it in one way or another, or suggest a different direction. In the comments from readers of my earlier post, “Friendship in an Age of Economics,” I have been fortunate.

headline: Steinbrenner Remembered as Despot and Hero
text: He was an outsider from Cleveland who became one of those unforgettable New York characters: deep-pocketed and domineering, a victory-at-all-costs cutthroat, not shy about twisting arms  or the law. But he delivered: 11 American League pennants, 7 World Series championships. And as the years passed, it turned out that he even had something of a soft side, difficult as it was to see or believe.

headline: Letter: Limited Rewards
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Card Choice: Miles or Points” (July 4), I just wanted your readers to be aware that some credit cards may offer bonus points, but if you use them for travel, you may not be happy. I was told that with the American Express Blue Card, points could be used for travel. I had hoped that after years of accumulating points, my husband and I could take a luxurious trip. When I went to the Rewards area, I found that I could book only through American Express Travel, that not all airlines were included and that my bonus points would be translated into the dollar amount of the trip. Even though the airlines were charging less at their sites, I ended up getting two economy round-trip flights from Kennedy Airport to Los Angeles International Airport that cost over $900 using 180,156 points! And I could not transfer these points to another type of card.

headline: Letter: A Delayed Flight
text: To the Editor: “Airlines Play the No-Fault Card” (July 11), about how little airlines do for customers when a flight is canceled, echoed much that I’ve heard from family and friends. But my traveling companion and I lucked out on July 4, when our Delta flight from La Guardia Airport to Fort Myers, Fla., was delayed because of mechanical reasons. A gate agent explained that if our flight was delayed more than four hours, Delta would give us a $100 credit for our “inconvenience” as well as meal vouchers. Shortly afterward, it was announced that our flight would indeed be delayed for four hours, and we were told that Delta now would book us on another airline if we chose not to wait. We got on an American flight to Miami, with a drive to our final destination.

headline: Reviewing Má Pêche
text: This week’s review is of Má Pêche, David Chang’s newest restaurant, his largest and his first outside of the East Village. You can get a fine Midtown lunch there, a good pre-theater meal, and an amazing seven-course beef dinner that runs $85 a head, with at least six people attending. This is worth doing at least once or twice in your life, especially if you end the meal not with dessert (none are served) but with a wheel of totally ripe, super-stinky Époisses, along with some warm baguette.

headline: Political Rifts Reappear in Northern Ireland Riots

headline: Má Pêche

The seats at the restaurant have backs to them. They are comfortable. There is plenty of space.

headline: Voices: Boss Watch Was a Postgame Stakeout
text: In the fall of 2005, the assignment sounded terrific to a 21-year old news clerk on The Times’s foreign desk: Steinbrenner duty. I had never covered any professional sporting event and for this, I’d watch from the Yankee Stadium press box until the eighth inning, when I would head down downstairs and wait by the exit through which Steinbrenner normally walked as he headed to his car after games.

headline: George Steinbrenner, R.I.P.
text: I grew up a Red Sox fan in the 1980s, when the Sox were pretty good, the Yankees were increasingly lousy, and George Steinbrenner, their bombastic owner, was a national joke. We Sox fans didn’t need to hate him; serious Yankee fans did that for us, bemoaning the constant psychodrama, the managerial revolving door, the ill-advised spending sprees and the trades that always seemed to ship off good young players to get veterans who were just about to pass their peak. Those were the Yankees of Steve Trout and Ed Whitson, Andy Hawkins and Mel Hall, the Ken Phelps-for-Jay Buhner trade and the long slow decline of Don Mattingly, their only true 1980s great. And then they were the Yankees of Howard Spira, the gambler who Steinbrenner paid to gather dirt on Dave Winfield, leading to the Yankee owner’s suspension from baseball “for life”  in 1990. His team went 67-95 that year, 71-91 the next, and it seemed like Steinbrenner would be remembered as the owner who saved Yankee baseball in the 1970s only to destroy it a decade later.

headline: Freed Cuban Prisoners Vow Defiance
text: MADRID  Flashing victory signs and expressing defiance, the first seven political prisoners released by President Raúl Castro of Cuba arrived in Madrid on Tuesday and vowed to continue their opposition to the island’s Communist leadership.

headline: A Boy’s Slice of Paradise Is Time Alone With Dad
text: In “Alamar,” a luminous semi-documentary film that plays on the border of reality and fiction, Natan Machado Palombini, a young boy, goes on an enchanted expedition with his father to the Banco Chinchorro, the largest coral reef in Mexico. The bonding of the son and his father, Jorge Machado, a lean, mustachioed Mexican fisherman who will return Natan to his Italian mother at the end of the trip, portrays a tender, ritualistic passing of knowledge, experience and love from one generation to the next.

headline: Sky Patrol | Porter Airlines
text: Typically, short-haul commercial flights are something to be endured, not enjoyed. In the case of Porter Airlines, however, getting there is half the fun. The Toronto-based boutique fleet’s comfy leather seats and seamless service come at the cost of coach but feel like flying private. O.K., maybe I’m getting a little carried away. But on two recent flights from Newark to Toronto, I zipped through check-in, security and customs, and because Porter operates out of Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport, you’re only a short ferry ride away from the heart of downtown. Add to this business-class-level lounges (the one at Billy Bishop is particularly well appointed), state-of-the-art equipment (fast, clean and quiet Bombardier 400 turboprops) and a fairly flexible booking structure. Not to mention the adorable uniforms: the female flight attendants wear tailored navy suits and dresses with jaunty pillbox hats from the Canadian label Pink Tartan while serving up the complimentary snacks, soft drinks, beer and wine. It may not be the same as flying on your own G5, but all in all the experience is pretty uplifting.
