headline: When a Dweeb Learns He’s Magic
text: “The Sorcerer’s Apprentice” is the latest movie about an ordinary fellow  it’s almost always a fellow  who is, all of a sudden and to his great astonishment, dragged into an epochal, supernatural battle between good and evil. The fellow in question this time is the distinctly unpromising Jay Baruchel, a gangly Canadian ectomorph who got the girl (though not much of an audience) in “She’s Out of My League” and who trained the cartoon dragon in “How to Train Your Dragon.” Here he plays an N.Y.U. physics major named Dave who tinkers with a giant Tesla coil in his subterranean laboratory and pines for Becky (Teresa Palmer), a pretty music lover who was his childhood crush.

headline: A Loft in Munich
text: A one-bedroom loft apartment with a rooftop terrace is on the market for 770,000 euros ($975,000).

headline: Toyota Extends Warranty on Troubled 2001-3 RAV4
text: 10:17 a.m. | Updated

headline: Pictures of the Day: Madrid and Elsewhere
text: Seven former political prisoners from Cuba seemed joyful Tuesday after they and their families were flown to freedom in Madrid, The Associated Press reported. They are the first of 52 dissidents the Cuban government has promised to free. In an action that would have once seemed unthinkable, Cuba agreed last week to liberate all those who were still imprisoned from a 2003 crackdown. Spain agreed to accept the first group of exiles.

headline: Final YouTube Question: Hope
text: Over the past several days, Nick has been responding to questions submitted via YouTube from readers. Today, for the final installment in this series, Nick discusses what he’s hopeful about for the future.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
The Wines of Vitovska Grapes
text: In my column I discuss a dozen esoteric grapes that are the basis of wonderful wines worth getting to know. It should have been a baker’s dozen, because I left out one of my favorite oddballs, vitovska.

headline: Perspectives on George Steinbrenner
text: Notable people who knew George Steinbrenner remember the Yankees' boss.

headline: The Great Goose Roundup, the Aftermath
text: For those living around Prospect Park in Brooklyn, the disappearance of nearly 400 Canada geese late last week set off a sense of unease. This honking, flying, vibrant presence, loved by some, loathed by others,  had simply vanished. On Tuesday, after people learned just what had happened — the geese were rounded up, crated and then gassed to death by the United States Department of Agriculture — their absence was especially palpable.

headline: Credit Eases for Hedge Funds and Private Equity
text: Wall Street’s largest dealers eased credit terms during the spring to hedge funds and private equity firms that borrow against securities and trade over-the-counter derivatives, according to a Federal Reserve survey, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Piers Morgan a Step Closer to ‘Larry King’ Chair
text: Update: The latest version of this story has been published here.

headline: Breakup for Woods: With His Putter
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The only breakup Tiger Woods was interested in discussing  Tuesday at the British Open was the one between him and the trusty putter he has used since 1999 to win 63 of his 71 tournaments, including 13 of his 14 major championships.

headline: An Artificial Heart Its Makers Say Could Be a Standard Replacement
text: PARIS  It is a long-held dream: an artificial heart to replace one that is damaged or diseased. Now, a French company says that it has the technology to make the implantation of it a standard surgical procedure.

headline: Armstrong Investigation Heating Up
text: Federal authorities investigating possible fraud and doping charges against Lance Armstrong and his associates have issued grand jury subpoenas to witnesses, according to several people briefed on the case.

headline: In San Juan, Marrying Urban With Rural
text: San Juan, Puerto Rico — Five years ago, Michy Marxuach was at a crossroads. Her husband wanted to live in the countryside and she wanted to stay here in the city’s historic district.

headline: Senator Wants to Know if BP Lobbied for Release of Lockerbie Convict
text: On Monday, Senator Frank Lautenberg, a New Jersey Democrat, called on the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations “to investigate the role that BP may have played in securing the early release” of Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, a former Libyan intelligence officer who was convicted of murder for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

headline: AIDS Agency Gets a New Home, and a Founder’s Ire
text: Gay Men’s Health Crisis, an organization that emerged in the early days of the AIDS epidemic, now serves 15,000 clients from its space at 119 West 24th Street in Manhattan. So when its landlord, F. M. Ring Associates, decided to raise the organization’s rent  to more than $8 million a year from $6 million  it faced a crisis of its own.

headline: A Rural Oasis in the City
text: In San Juan, a subtly modern and painstakingly simple home.

headline: New York to London: Karpov to Hold Another Fundraiser
text: As part of Anatoly Karpov’s effort to finance his campaign for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fédération Internationale des Échecs), he is planning to hold a fundraiser in London on Sept. 8. The event will be at Simpson’s in the Strand, which includes the Grand Divan, a legendary gathering place to play chess over the years.

headline: Britain Revokes Citizenship of Russian Émigré in Spy Swap
text: BRITAIN  The British citizenship of Anna Chapman, a 28-year-old Russian émigré who was one of 10 Russian “sleeper agents” involved in last week’s spy swap between the United States and Russia has been revoked and her passport has been invalidated, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Nannies Still Draw a Keen Audience
text: Consider Marie, Lola and Grace, fictional nannies all.

headline: The Culture Wars Shift to School Halls
text: FROM fourth grade to high school, at school board meetings and in state assemblies, temperatures are rising over censorship, control, religion and education. The battle over who teaches what, and how, has become one of the fiercest arenas of the culture wars.

headline: Homes on the Market for $210,000
text: Properties in Ohio, Georgia and Wisconsin.

headline: Publisher Has Court Date In Dispute Over ‘Shack’
text: A federal judge is expected to hear arguments next month in the legal skirmish that has broken out over the novel “The Shack,” a story of redemption and loss with Christian themes that has sold more than 12 million copies, The Los Angeles Times reported. William Paul Young, the book’s author, sued his former partners at Windblown Media and his marketer and distributer, Hachette Book Group, in a California state court in November, arguing that he had been deprived of more than $8 million in lost royalties from sales of the book, The Los Angeles Times reported on Tuesday. In March Windblown Media countersued for $5 million in federal court, calling Mr. Young’s lawsuit “ridiculous.” Hachette jumped in with its own motion on July 2, saying the case belonged in federal court. Judge John F. Walter of the United States District Court in Los Angeles is expected to hear arguments on Hachette’s motion in August.

headline: The Art of Opening a Clam
text: Randazzo's Clam Bar in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, has been in Paul Randazzo's family for four generations.

headline: Jury Selection Continues In Music Critic’s Suit
text: Jury selection entered a second day on Tuesday in a music critic’s lawsuit against his employer, The Plain Dealer of Cleveland, and the Cleveland Orchestra. The critic, Donald Rosenberg, filed the suit in the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court after he was told in September 2008 that he would no longer be reviewing the orchestra. He said that orchestra management had pressed the newspaper into sidelining him because it objected to a string of negative reviews that he had given to the orchestra’s music director, Franz Welser-Most. Mr. Rosenberg, 58, who remains on staff, accused the paper and its editor of age discrimination and retaliation, and accused the Musical Arts Association, the orchestra’s governing body, and several of its officials of defamation and tortious interference. The matter caused concern among music critics, who accused the paper of caving in to the orchestra. The Plain Dealer denied that was the case, and orchestra officials argued that they were only expressing their opinion.

headline: ‘Die Hard’ Director Pleads Guilty, Again
text: John McTiernan, below, the director of “Die Hard” and “The Hunt for Red October,” has pleaded guilty  again  in a case linked to an investigation of a prominent private detective who worked for Hollywood’s rich and famous. Mr. McTiernan admitted on Monday to lying to the F.B.I. and to a judge in connection with a probe of the investigator, Anthony Pellicano, according to The Associated Press. He faces up to a year in prison. The director pleaded guilty four years ago to lying to agents but later successfully moved to have the plea voided. Mr. Pellicano was sentenced to 15 years in prison in December 2008 for illegal wiretapping.

headline: ‘Secret’ Author To Reveal More Insights In ‘Power’
text: Now that Rhonda Byrne, below, has shared “The Secret,” she has moved on to “The Power.” That is the title of her next book, a follow-up to “The Secret,” which has spent more than three years on best-seller lists and has more than 19 million copies in print, according to Atria Books, her publisher. Atria, part of Simon & Schuster, will publish “The Power” on Aug. 17. In “The Secret” Ms. Byrne told readers how to attain health and happiness by learning the law of attraction. In the new book, her publisher said, “She shows how perfect health, incredible relationships, a career you love, a life filled with happiness, and the money you need to be, do, and have everything you want, all come from the power.” Her publisher added, “ ‘The Power’ is the handbook to the greatest power in the universe  the power to have everything you want.” Ms. Byrne’s popularity has been helped by Oprah Winfrey, who promoted “The Secret” relentlessly on her talk show.

headline: U2 Reschedules 16 Concerts For Next Year
text: U2’s summer concerts in North America, postponed in May to allow Bono, above, the band’s lead singer, to recover from back surgery, have been rescheduled for next year. The 16 shows will now begin on May 21 at Invesco Field in Denver (where the band was to have played on June 12 this year), and continue through July 23, 2011, when U2 will play at TCF Bank Stadium in Minneapolis. The show at New Meadowlands Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., originally scheduled for Monday, will now be on July 20, 2011. The band has posted the full schedule on U2.com. Tickets for the original shows will be honored on the new dates, said Live Nation, the tour’s promoter.

headline: Berra Looks Back Fondly on a Foe Turned Friend
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  Yogi Berra was caught by surprise Tuesday when he learned that George Steinbrenner had died. Berra chatted with Steinbrenner on the phone at 8 a.m. on July 4, wishing him a happy 80th birthday, and Steinbrenner, as always, asked Berra a playful question.

headline: A March of Deadly Sins, One by One
text: LESLYE HEADLAND was having trouble choosing among the anatomically semi-correct party favors in the X-rated section of a Ricky’s NYC drugstore on the far West Side of Manhattan. On her way to her first-ever bachelorette party, for a friend getting married in a few days, she didn’t want to arrive empty-handed. Would the phallic ring-toss set be too much? Would a little package of deceptively innocent-looking whistles be better?

headline: Friend Offers a Clue To Partial Larsson Book
text: It could be that the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson was just weeks and a little more than 100 pages away from finishing the fourth manuscript in his best-selling Millennium series. According to an e-mail message that John-Henri Holmberg, a friend of Larsson’s, provided to The Associated Press, Larsson was 320 pages into a 440-page book when he died at age 50 in November 2004. Larsson had planned to finish the book by December 2004, Mr. Holmberg added. In the e-mail message Larsson wrote, “The plot is set 120 kilometers north of Sachs Harbor, at Banks Island in the month of September.” The manuscript is believed to be in the custody of Eva Gabrielsson, Larsson’s companion, but she has declined to make it public. If published, a fourth novel in the series would almost certainly be a best seller, based on the intense interest in the first three books about the computer hacker Lisbeth Salander and the journalist Mikhael Blomkvist.

headline: Hungry Girl Offers a Real Take on Diet Foods
text: LISA LILLIEN, the Internet weight-loss goddess also known as Hungry Girl, is into French manicures and Brazilian hair straightening. But her palate is American to the core, right down to its weakness for a signature dish served at Planet Hollywood restaurants.

headline: Oil Spill’s Impact on Gulf Seafood Remains Uncertain
text: THE oil from the broken well 40 miles off the Louisiana coast keeps getting closer to the plate.

headline: Leader of the Pack: ABC’s ‘Bachelorette’
text: ABC led the ratings on Monday night for the fourth consecutive week as 9.5 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour edition of “The Bachelorette,” according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other program came close to matching that network’s reality show. CBS’s comedy reruns averaged 6.3 million from 8 to 10 p.m. opposite “The Bachelorette,” while CBS’s repeat of “CSI: Miami” won the 10 p.m. slot with 6.6 million viewers, outperforming both ABC’s “True Beauty” (5 million) and NBC’s “Dateline” (5 million). NBC eked out a third-place finish, garnering 5.2 million at 8 for a rebroadcast of an “America’s Got Talent” episode from last week and 4.7 million at 9 for “Last Comic Standing.” Fox was fourth with “Lie to Me” (5.6 million) and “The Good Guys” (3.5 million).

headline: New Works Already Laden With Memories
text: Pilobolus, practically a summer institution at the Joyce Theater, has long represented a lighter side of dance that mirrors the balmy spirit of the season: muscular, entertaining and full of heat. But the company opened its four-week engagement at the theater on Monday evening on a melancholic note: last month Jonathan Wolken, one of its artistic directors, died from complications of a stem cell transplant. In 1971 he named the company after a spirited fungus.

headline: Savory Ham and Gruyère Bread
text: Time: About 1 1/2 hours

headline: Pilobolus Dance Theater's 'Hitched'
text: A sequence of photographs from the dance.

headline: The Hors d’Oeuvres That the French Call Cake
text: ONLY the French could take a muffin recipe and turn it into an hors d’oeuvre.

headline: Cafe ‘At Your Mother-in-Law’
text: TWO short blocks from the Brighton Beach Boardwalk in Brooklyn, in the heart of Little Odessa, it’s a joy to spot this sunny cafe where families, buddies and beachgoers can tumble in and cool down. Don’t be perplexed by the improbably short name in Cyrillic characters (and a second name, Elza Fancy Food, in English); just look for the bright orange awning on Brighton Fourth Street.

headline: Toomey Outpaces Sestak in Second Quarter
text: Score this round – in the fund-raising battle, that is – for Pat Toomey.

headline: ‘Barefoot Bandit’ Deported to the U.S.
text: NASSAU, the Bahamas — Colton Harris-Moore, the teenage fugitive known as the Barefoot Bandit, was deported to the United States on Tuesday evening, hours after pleading guilty to a single count of illegally landing an airplane in this island nation, a State Department official said.

headline: Met’s Fare: Some Classic, Some Quirky
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s Summer Recital Series opened on Monday night with a free performance at Central Park SummerStage, an enjoyable program of arias, duets, trios and American songs sung by three appealing artists.

headline: What You Get for ... $210,000
text: SHAKER HEIGHTS, OHIO

headline: Battles Waged Between Bodies and Wills
text: One of the great things about site-specific art is the way it can make you reconsider a space you’ve passed any number of times without much thought. Take the narrow courtyard next to the John Street United Methodist Church. On Monday afternoon Deganit Shemy and Company performed “2 kilos of sea” there, a premiere presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s free Sitelines 2010 series (in association with the River to River Festival).

headline: Timeline: The Boss’s Legacy
text: A pioneer of modern sports ownership, George Steinbrenner placed his formidable stamp on a sporting world powerhouse: the Yankees.

headline: Take a Little Thoreau, Mix With Spunky Jazz
text: The idea behind David Karsten Daniels’s latest project, the album “I Mean to Live Here Still” (Fat Cat), is clear and unsurprising, and in fact a little obvious. Mr. Daniels, a singer-songwriter from Texas who lives in San Francisco, wanted to illuminate some verse and prose written by Henry David Thoreau and went about it by collaborating with a rowdy jazz group.

headline: Fresh Works, Played Amid the Rumbles and Chirps
text: The sounds of birds chirping merrily filled the air in the picturesque setting of the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday night. Overhead an airplane groaned across the sky, its sound magnified by the courtyard garden’s manifold hard surfaces. Outside the gate a caravan of buses rumbled past, slowly and loudly.

headline: Invincible Ignorance
text: Just in case you had some lingering notion that anyone in the Republican party was fiscally responsible, Mitch McConnell has weighed in in support of Jon Kyl:

headline: A Tough Mistress and the Servants Who Fail Her
text: BECKET, Mass.  Everyone knows at least one person who seems never to pause for breath in conversation, running on, yet saying precious little. It’s terrible to be stuck in a room with such a talker.

headline: New York Presses Banks on Foreclosures
text: Hoping to succeed where Washington has largely failed, New York City’s comptroller, John C. Liu, and six large unions plan to begin a campaign on Wednesday to press the biggest banks to do more to prevent foreclosures in the New York area.

headline: Online Photo Storage Competition Heats Up
text: The competition for free online photo storage got a little hotter Tuesday.

text: 7:36 p.m. | Updated

headline: Voices: The Parking Pass Interview
text: My first assignment as a Yankees beat reporter in the mid-1980s was to cover spring training at the team’s former home in Fort Lauderdale. I received a press credential in the mail, but if I wanted a parking pass I had to meet withGeorge Steinbrenner.

headline: Notable Clam Shacks Around New York
text: Seven seafood shacks spread across New Jersey, Brooklyn and Long Island, serving a local specialty.

headline: Slurping Seashells
text: “THAT right there is a top-neck clam,” said a man sitting at the counter in Randazzo’s in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, about five minutes before noon on a weekday as the sun blazed down on Emmons Avenue outside. He was pointing at the fresh-shucked bivalve in front of him on an icy plate, perhaps 2 3/4 inches across the heavy span of its shell, its pink and orange flesh glistening in its own liquor.

headline: Portugal Turns to Former Colony for Growth
text: LISBON  António Cunha Vaz, along with his mother and sister, was part of a mass exodus of Portuguese from Angola in 1975, when it gained independence before descending into a devastating civil war.

headline: Here’s Why the Cookie Crumbled
text: The global banking crisis that began in 2007 has brought some good books into being, volumes historians will consult when reflecting on these hard times. It has also given us some wild cards, unexpected treats that belong on the shelf once labeled belles-lettres but now more commonly known (thanks to Dave Eggers’s annual paperback anthologies) as nonrequired reading.

headline: Live Analysis: 2010 All-Star Game
text: Just 21 hours after surviving last night’s Home Run Derby, where he hit only one fewer longball than Arizona’s Chris Young, Times reporter Alan Schwarz is in the press box in Anaheim live-blogging tonight’s All-Star Game — giving up-to-the-minute updates on all the great plays, celebrity sightings, and scorecards that look like Jackson Pollock paintings.

headline: On Opening Clams
text: Not everyone travels out for clams — though if you do, please tell us your favorite places to do so in the comments below. No, some dig their own, or buy them at the Greenmarket, only thinking later, the lemons cut and the iced platter waiting: How do you open these things?

headline: U.S. May Label Pakistan Militants as Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON  The new American military commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David H. Petraeus, is pushing to have top leaders of a feared insurgent group designated as terrorists, a move that could complicate an eventual Afghan political settlement with the Taliban and aggravate political tensions in the region.

headline: Khaki Still Struggles With Commitment Issues
text: SO sure, whatever. James Dean wore khakis. Amelia Earhart. Chet Baker. Hemingway, too. All more rugged than I.

headline: Fine-Tuning Tradition at Open’s Old Course
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  Among the most amazing things about the Old Course here is that it never gets old. More astonishing, in this era of instant tradition and shortened attention spans, is that neither has it become obsolete.

headline: Steinbrenner Had Quiet Passion for Olympics
text: While his legacy will always be firmly planted in baseball, George Steinbrenner saved some of his trademark chutzpah for the Olympics, developing a reputation as an influential figure who revolutionized the way American athletes are supported and who served as a quiet benefactor to individual competitors.

headline: Covering Steinbrenner
text: Times columnist Dave Anderson discusses George Steinbrenner's legacy with the Sports Editor Tom Jolly.

headline: Food Policy Chief Leaves Job, and City Seeks a Successor
text: New York’s first food czar, serving in a position considered groundbreaking when the city established it in 2007, quietly left the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg late last month.

headline: Heads Turn as a Bridge Floats By
text: SAUGERTIES, N.Y.  Kent Waddell started his day Tuesday by heading to the Hudson River with his bloodworms and fishing rod. But he saw something on the river that made him race home and put his fishing gear away.

headline: From the Boss's Mouth and Back
text: Bombastic, opinionated and therefore ever-quotable, George Steinbrenner uttered some memorable lines in his 38 years of owning the Yankees.

headline: Texas Oil Baron Is Promoting Solar Energy
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: George Steinbrenner and His Ego
text: David Brooks: Gail, I have to admit I’ve always had a soft spot for unpleasant people. This comes to mind as a result of the death of George Steinbrenner.

headline: They’re Not All Champions, Are They?
text: LONDON  The role of governments, royalty and the masses in welcoming home sports players as if they were soldiers from a war is becoming embarrassing.

headline: Phoenix Game Is Subject of Protest
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The flags inside Angel Stadium flew at half-staff in honor of George Steinbrenner on Tuesday, but the flags of protest on the concourse outside the park — reading, “We Are All Arizona” and “Immigrant Families Are American Families” — signaled that the All-Star Game had other unpleasantries in wait.

headline: Free Agents of All Stripes
text: The Yankees signed well over 100 free agents during George Steinbrenner's tenure. Here are some of the notable signings and how well they did for the Yankees.

headline: Europe’s Bank Test Results Expected Soon, but Details May Lag
text: BRUSSELS  Top European finance officials said Tuesday that results of banking stress tests would be released on July 23 but that some national regulators could take longer to release more detailed information on certain lenders.

headline: Different Theory of Fatal Crane Fall Is Offered
text: Which broke first, the slings or the tie-in beams?

headline: The Pride of the Yankee
text: New Canaan, Conn.

headline: Argentina Senate to Vote on Gay Marriage
text: BUENOS AIRES  Already known for having one of the most gay-friendly capitals in the world, Argentina is in the throes of a debate this week over granting the broadest marital protections to gay people in Latin America.

headline: F.C.C. Indecency Policy Rejected on Appeal
text: A federal appeals court struck down a Federal Communications Commission policy on indecency Tuesday, saying that regulations barring the use of “fleeting expletives” on radio and television violated the First Amendment because they were vague and could inhibit free speech.

headline: George Steinbrenner
text: If you’re a longtime Yankees fan  especially if you lived through the Billy Martin era  you probably have a personal thesis on the character of the boss, George Steinbrenner, who died at 80 on Tuesday. It was impossible to relate to the team without relating to its owner.

headline: Winfield Recalls Reconciliation With Steinbrenner
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – Few players have ever had a relationship with their team owner as miserable as the one Dave Winfield had with George Steinbrenner.

headline: With Liberty and Connectivity for All
text: When you write a column suggesting that maybe the Internet is weaving the human race into a giant superorganism, you naturally wonder whether readers will think you’re crazy. So last week, having written that column, I checked out the comments section.  “Yes,” wrote someone from Minnesota known as Greenpa, “the superorganism is quite real. As I’ve been saying for 40 years, to anyone I thought would not instantly run for the men in white with the big butterfly nets.”

headline: The Long and Short of It Is, Mickelson Likes His Chances
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — For one reason or another, Phil Mickelson has not always been totally enamored of the British Open, a major championship his game would seem to suit quite well. Other than a solo third-place finish at Troon in 2004, he has never really threatened in his 16 appearances.

headline: CNN Nears Deal to Fill King’s Slot
text: Piers Morgan, the bad-cop judge on the hit NBC show “America’s Got Talent,” is poised to take over Larry King’s coveted time slot on CNN, a move smoothed by an imminent deal between the two media giants that own the channels, NBC Universal and Turner Broadcasting.

headline: Reversal Upholds Detention of Yemeni at Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the detention of a Yemeni man at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, reversing a District Court judge who had ordered the prisoner freed on the grounds that there was “no reliable evidence” that he was a member of Al Qaeda.

headline: On Facebook, Telling Teachers How Much They Meant
text: Darci Hemleb Thompson had been on the lookout for Alice D’Addario for many years. From her home in Hampton, Va., Ms. Thompson, 49, who is married and has a 12-year-old daughter, was determined to find Ms. D’Addario on the Internet. She tried every search engine and networking site she could find.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Steinbrenner and the City: A Whirlwind
text: Maybe the rule against speaking ill of the dead does not apply to rich lunatic uncles.

headline: Bank Hit With Sanctions in Suit Over Terrorist Aid
text: A bank based in Jordan that had been accused of providing financial services to terrorists was hit with judicial sanctions on Tuesday for repeatedly failing to obey a court order to produce requested documents in the case  a six-year-old lawsuit filed by the victims of terrorist attacks.

headline: Rules Seek to Expand Diagnosis of Alzheimer’s
text: For the first time in 25 years, medical experts are proposing a major change in the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier.

headline: As a Brigade Returns Safe, Some Meet New Enemies
text: FORT BLISS, Tex. — The soldiers of the Fourth Brigade, First Armored Division, have been home from Iraq for three months now, the danger of snipers and roadside bombs no longer a threat, the war for them over.

headline: House Fire in Queens Kills Mother and Son
text: A pregnant woman and her 2-year-old son died in a house fire early Tuesday in Queens, officials and neighbors said.

headline: Local Traffic Would Worsen Without Sheridan, Study Shows
text: A plan to demolish the Sheridan Expressway, allowing South Bronx residents easier access to the Bronx River and rerouting heavy truck traffic, would increase congestion on local roads, state officials said Tuesday.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Challenges Tea Party on Racism
text: One of the nation’s largest and oldest civil rights groups passed a resolution Tuesday calling for Tea Party groups to weed “racist elements” out of their ranks.

headline: California May Drop Its Official State Rock
text: LOS ANGELES — Empirically speaking, geologists are not a particularly irascible group. But those who make their living studying rocks, minerals and gems in California — and increasingly those scientists beyond the state’s borders — are enraged over a bill in Sacramento that would knock serpentine, the official state rock, off its mantel.

headline: Nets, Through Owner, Ask Fans to Be Patient
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov’s tenure as the owner of the Nets is still shrouded with anticipation and intrigue. He arrived from Russia as the N.B.A.’s richest owner, but at its core, the N.B.A. is structured to deliver an even playing field, or in this case, an even court.

headline: Torre Reflects on 12 Years of Enormous Expectations
text: LOS ANGELES  Shortly after the Yankees had beaten the Mets for their fourth World Series title in five seasons, Joe Torre met with George Steinbrenner.

headline: Planned Sign of Tolerance Bringing Division Instead
text: The Cordoba House was supposed to be a monument to religious tolerance, an homage to the city in Spain where Muslims, Jews, and Christians lived together centuries ago in the midst of religious foment.

headline: Monty Python Member
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — We’ve got six-sevenths of a week rolled into today’s theme. It’s a fun idea that uses a very limited palette.

headline: Corrections
text: A television column on Saturday about a decision by a character on “Friday Night Lights” to have an abortion, and how the subject of abortion has been handled on other shows, referred incorrectly to the Roe v. Wade ruling, which established a constitutional right to abortion. The ruling was made by the Supreme Court; it did not involve “passage,” as with legislation.

headline: Iran: Strike by Merchants Spreads at Tehran Bazaar
text: A strike that began last week at the gold and textile sections of the bazaar in Tehran as a protest against a government plan to increase the income tax on merchants grew on Tuesday to other sections, according to the Web site Khabar Online. The strike, the second major protest since 1979 at the bazaar, which had traditionally sided with the government, began after rumors circulated that the government planned to increase taxes up to 70 percent. It has continued despite government efforts to reach a compromise with the merchants by lowering the planned tax increase to 30 percent last week and to 15 percent on Monday.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on July 2 with an article about the Iron Mule Short Comedy Film Festival at 92Y TriBeCa, using information from a publicist, carried an erroneous credit. The picture, a scene from the film “Broad City,” was by Eric Michael Pearson, not by Katie Osgood.

headline: His Final Victory Is a Yankees Empire Restored
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Yankees had more All-Stars on Tuesday than any other major league team. They are the reigning World Series champions, with the best record in baseball. They have a gleaming new stadium in the Bronx and a thriving cable television network. Their empire is fully restored, the way George Steinbrenner wanted.

headline: Corrections
text: SPORTS

headline: Russian Is 3rd Center Knicks Add to the Mix
text: LAS VEGAS  The Knicks added another 7-footer to the roster on Tuesday but are no closer to resolving their woes at center.

headline: Senator Riding in Car During What Witnesses Call Hit-Run

headline: Community Advocate Drops Bid for Espada’s Seat

headline: A New, and Necessary, Moratorium
text: Despite legal challenges from industry, complaints from local politicians and bad rulings from unsympathetic judges, the Obama administration has rightly chosen to reaffirm its decision in May to suspend deep-water drilling activities in the Gulf of Mexico. On Monday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar issued a second moratorium to replace an earlier ban that was tossed out in federal court. It is as strong as the first ban and, if anything, more tightly argued.

headline: Obama Says Budget Nominee Is Fit for ‘Hall of Fame’

headline: The Spies Who Loved Us
text: I was on vacation when the story broke that 11 Russians had been charged as sleeper agents planted in America by Moscow’s spy agency to gather intelligence on the United States and to recruit moles who could gain access to our top secrets. My first reaction was: This may be the greatest gift to America by a foreign country since France gave us the Statue of Liberty. Someone still wants to spy on us! Just when we were feeling down and out, the Russians show up and tell us that it’s still worth briefcases of money to plant people in our think tanks. Subprime crisis or not, some people think we’ve still got the right stuff. Thank you, Vladimir Putin!

headline: “It’s Only Wednesday”
text: It wasn’t just a cold and windy night in early June as Ángel Franco waited; it was raining so hard that water had begun to seeping into his camera equipment. Then came the call: four shootings at West 35th Street and Surf Avenue in Brooklyn — the Coney Island Houses. On his way, Mr. Franco passed a couple of vehicles that had crashed at West 17th Street and Surf Avenue, one of which was evidently the getaway car. A bit farther along, some police officers searched for weapons as others sought brief refuge from the downpour. Not long before, a man and a 16-year-old girl were having a dispute in a courtyard of the housing development when the girl’s 19-year-old brother came out to separate them. An argument followed, The Times reported. “Shots rang out moments later, and the mother of the two teenagers, who had just stepped out of the apartment, was struck in the head. The father of the woman identified her as Victoria Rogucki and said she had seven children, including 2-year-old twins. ‘She was trying to keep them from fighting,’ said the father, Charles Rogucki, 71, adding that Ms. Rogucki is his youngest child. An officer at the crash scene reflected on the disheartening events. “It’s only Wednesday,” he said, rain running down his face.

headline: Phys Ed: The Men Who Stare at Screens
text: In 1982, researchers affiliated with the Cooper Institute in Dallas surveyed a large group of well-educated, affluent men. The researchers were interested in the men’s exercise habits, but they also asked, almost incidentally, about their indolence. Specifically, they inquired about how many hours each day the men spent watching television or sitting in a car. (This was before you could do both at once.) Over the years, the survey’s main results were used to reinforce a growing body of science about the health benefits of regular exercise.

headline: Florida: Dengue Fever Outbreaks Reported
text: About 5 percent of the population of Key West has recently been exposed to the virus that causes dengue fever, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday. Some people have no symptoms but some become severely ill. Dengue is common in the tropics but had been largely wiped out in the United States. There were 27 known cases in Key West in 2009, and this year there have already been 12. Officials fear that if it takes hold in Key West, it can spread to other Southern cities, where the mosquitoes that transmit it are common. There is no vaccine and no cure.

headline: NASA Not Faulted in Manager’s Removal
text: NASA did nothing improper in removing the head of its return-to-the-moon program, the agency’s inspector general told Congress on Tuesday. The leaders of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation requested an investigation after NASA removed Jeffrey M. Hanley as manager of the program, known as Constellation, in May. The Obama administration would like to cancel Constellation, and the senators questioned whether Mr. Hanley’s removal was part of an effort to kill it without Congressional approval or a reprisal against him for defending the program. Paul K. Martin, the inspector general, concluded that there was no evidence supporting either concern, and that the move resulted from e-mail messages Mr. Hanley had sent to senior NASA officials that led them to conclude he could no longer lead the program.

headline: Will ‘Solar Trees’ Sprout in Parking Lots?

headline: The New Abortion Providers
text: On a clear and mild March day in 1993, the Operation Rescue leader Randall Terry spoke at a rally in southern Florida against abortion. “We’ve found the weak link is the doctor,” he told the crowd. “We’re going to expose them. We’re going to humiliate them.” A few days later, Dr. David Gunn, an abortion provider, was shot and killed outside his clinic in Pensacola, Fla., about 500 miles away. It was the first of eight such murders, the extreme edge of what has become an anti-abortion strategy of confrontation.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes to Restrict Avandia
text: A majority of the advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration voted today to restrict the sales of Avandia, a controversial diabetes drug, because of its potential risk for causing heart attacks. The 33-member advisory committee was deeply divided. Twelve voted to remove Avandia from the market altogether; 10 for continued sale but with new label revisions and possible restrictions; 7 to add more warnings and 3 for no change at all. But the votes can also be viewed as a decision by a majority, 21, to continue allowing sales of Avandia, with more restrictions. A final decision will be made by the F.D.A. at a later date.

headline: Asked & Answered | Aaron Rose
text: The art-world multihyphenate Aaron Rose is a man of many hats. As a curator throughout the 1990s, his Alleged gallery showcased the work of artists like Shepard Fairey, Ed Templeton, Mike Mills and Barry McGee and also spearheaded the hip-hop-inflected D.I.Y. movement, which Rose went on to celebrate in the traveling exhibition (and accompanying documentary) “Beautiful Losers.” The group’s motto, “Make something from nothing,” revels in the creative process itself and fuels Rose’s multifarious — and occasionally utopian — ambitions.

headline: Pity the Toothless Pangolin
text: Chinese customs officials in southern Guangdong Province have intercepted a boat with a grisly illegal cargo: nearly eight tons of frozen pangolin carcasses (2,090 of them!) as well as 4,000 pounds of scales stripped from their bodies. Six traffickers posing as fishermen had been paid to transport the pangolins from Southeast Asia, part of the animal’s native habitat, to China.

headline: Student Loan Default Rates Come Under Scrutiny
text: Defaulting on student loans is a serious matter, and The Chronicle of Higher Education has recently unearthed data finding that students are defaulting at rates far higher than previously thought. In an article on Sunday entitled “Government Vastly Undercounts Defaults,” The Chronicle studied numbers on the repayment of student loans going back 15 years, finding that defaults only increased over time.

text: ABOARD THE RESOLUTE, 50 miles off Louisiana  BP stopped collecting oil from its runaway well on Wednesday afternoon, beginning a critical test that could halt the rush of oil into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time since the disaster began three months ago.

headline: Letterman: ‘The Big Spy Swap’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: If you know anything about the big spy swap here in New York City, there were 10 spies and they were running around New York City stealing secrets. They arranged a big spy swap. It was very exciting. We sent them 10 spies, and they sent us four spies, plus a Cuban pitcher.

headline: Leno: ‘We Can’t Get Osama’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: A lot of people continue to be very upset by the fact that we can’t get Osama bin Laden. Osama bin Laden? We can’t even get Roman Polanski.

headline: Senate Democrats and President Draw Energy Road Map
text: President Obama has invited select Democratic senators to join him for lunch at the White House on Wednesday to talk about energy legislation as he and Senate Democrats resolve to make a strong push to pass a bill before the August recess, according to an official briefed on the situation.

headline: Reminders That Nothing Lasts Forever
text: News of George Steinbrenner’s death on Tuesday left me with the sobering feeling that part of my life had come full circle. In some ways the announcement was anticlimactic, as if I had witnessed the Boss’s life fading away, bit by bit, through my bedroom window.

headline: New Lil Wayne Album Could Be Out Before Lil Wayne
text: The prodigious productivity of Lil Wayne apparently knows no bounds — not even a stint in prison will prevent him from putting out new material, even if he’s not readily available to promote it. Lil Wayne, who in March was sentenced to a year at Rikers Island  in New York for attempted possession of a weapon after a gun was found on his tour bus in 2007, could be out for good behavior in eight months — a date that could coordinate nicely with a fourth-quarter release for his next album, “Tha Carter IV.” But why wait that long? Cortez Bryant, the chief executive of Lil Wayne’s Young Money record label and a co-manager of the rapper, whose real name is Dwayne Carter Jr, told Vibe.com that he is planning to put out a new EP of Lil Wayne material,  “I’m Not a Human Being,” even sooner. “I’ll probably drop it on his birthday, Sept. 27,” Mr. Bryant said, adding that he would probably “put it out virally and maybe package it up for Christmas. Give ’em a hard copy later for fan appreciation.”

headline: Disabled Triathletes Unhappy About Rules Changes
text: Aaron Scheidies has won four triathlon world titles, but his primary goal for the New York City Triathlon on Sunday is simply to finish without crashing.

headline: S.E.C. Examines Integrity of Proxy Voting
text: 5:39 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously to seek public comment on the proxy system, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports, providing more details of the agency’s meeting.

headline: Bits Pics: Controlling the Robots Below
text: Robots are playing an important role in trying to stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. In this image, BP workers — known as robotic pilots — work with a remotely operated vehicle, or an R.O.V., on the Discoverer Inspiration ship in the Gulf of Mexico. They are remotely controlling the robot and trying to connect and test new caps on the runaway well in an effort to stop the gushing flow of oil.

headline: Belfast Riots Morph for YouTube Generation
text: Police officials and former militants in Northern Ireland struggled to contain, and make sense of, a third night of rioting by crowds that included children so young one community leader told the BBC that the streets of north Belfast in the early hours of Wednesday looked like “a Euro Disney theme park for rioters.”

headline: Testing the Android Waters
text: I’ve seen it a thousand times: Sit down for coffee or a meeting and those in attendance automatically reach for their cellphones and place them on the table. It’s almost like a subconscious signal that says ‘I’ll be sitting here for a while.’

headline: Playing the ‘Mad Man’ Card in Carrier Dispute
text: The clock is winding down on a carriage deal between AT&T and Rainbow Media, the parent company of AMC, IFC and WEtv, and the two sides are at odds over a possible fee increase.

headline: Guns in Frail Hands
text: She is a 90-year-old widow with mild Alzheimer’s disease, and her son is begging her, for safety’s sake, to give up something she considers essential to her independence and sense of control.

headline: JPMorgan Names Senior Investment Banking Executives
text: JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday named Jeff Urwin and Kevin Willsey as its new co-heads of investment banking for the United States and Canada.

headline: A Warm Atlantic Stokes Hurricane Fears
text: Stretching from the coast of West Africa to the Caribbean is a band of warm water several hundred miles wide where most Atlantic tropical storm systems “spin up,” gaining speed and size as they move toward the eastern seaboard and the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Armstrong Distances Himself From Doping Inquiry
text: CHAMBÉRY, France  Lance Armstrong, a focus of a federal investigation into possible fraud and doping on the now-defunct United States Postal Service cycling team, distanced himself from that investigation Wednesday, saying that he was just a rider for the team and had no knowledge of what went on within its management.

headline: Bentley Wins Runoff in Alabama
text: A retired physician received the Republican nomination for Alabama’s open governor’s race on Tuesday, winning a runoff election handily against an establishment-backed opponent once considered the favorite.

headline: Rebel Sell | Jeffery-West Shoes

headline: Walking the Line
text: The High Line is one of the most thoughtful, sensitively designed public spaces built in New York in years. Nicolai Ouroussoff reviews.

headline: After High Line’s Success, Other Cities Look Up

headline: An All-Star Send-Off
text: The timing of George Steinbrenner’s death on Tuesday might definitively prove that the Fates do indeed have a sense of humor, or least that they have watched more than a few “Seinfeld” episodes. Yes, after a career trying to construct his own All-Star teams in pinstripes, the Boss died on the day of an All-Star Game, and one in which his manager of the moment might have driven him stark raving mad by leaving one of his megastars on the bench as a rally fizzled.

headline: Term Limits Appear Headed for Fall Ballot
text: Come November, New York voters will almost certainly be asked to decide one of the most contentious questions in recent political history: term limits. But exactly how the question is phrased remains up for debate.

headline: Fidelity and State Street Win in Brown Deal
text: By bargaining for his backing of the proposed overhaul of financial regulation, Senator Scott Brown appears to have won concessions for two major firms in his home state of Massachusetts.

headline: Will Financial Overhaul Prevent Bailouts?
text: The passage of the sweeping financial regulatory bill is imminent and the question that many are asking is whether it will prevent future banking bailouts. There are conflicting views. The sponsors vow that it will, and former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. told DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin that had the bill been in effect in the fall of 2008, he would have been able to take over Lehman Brothers and the American International Group without the financial system crumbling.

headline: Here He Comes: Micky Dolenz Joins Tiffany and Deborah Gibson in Horror Movie
text: There are some news stories so engrossing and so dense with information that they can’t be contained within a single article. The BP oil spill. The financial reform bill. And now the casting of the coming Syfy original movie “Mega Python vs. Gatoroid.”

headline: Just a Cough, or Lung Cancer?
text: What’s the best way to catch lung cancer early — when doctors are most likely to be able to cure it? Several readers had questions on the Consults blog about early symptoms and testing of lung cancer. Dr. Derek Raghavan, director of the Taussig Cancer Institute at the Cleveland Clinic, responds.

headline: How Honest Tea Stood Up to Coke
text: The case study we published last week chronicled the back and forth between Honest Tea and Coca-Cola, its biggest investor. Written by Elizabeth Olson, the piece explained that Coke executives had asked Honest Tea to remove the words “no high fructose corn syrup” from its juice pouches because the executives considered them an implicit rebuke of Coke products that do contain the syrup. “We got a strong request to change the wording,” said Seth Goldman, co-founder of Honest Tea.

text: Team RadioShack earned its first stage victory of the Tour de France on Wednesday, Bastille Day, but not from Lance Armstrong.

And until now, the artist had remained a bit of a mystery.

headline: Report Warns of Risks to China’s Bank System

By that I mean the carbon dioxide policy pushed by George W. Bush in his campaign against former Vice President Al Gore for the presidency in 2000.

headline: White House to Host a Broadway Concert Next Week
text: A couple of Broadway’s most prominent advocates – President Obama and his wife, Michelle – will continue to do their part for the New York theater by bringing some of it to the White House on Monday. Representatives for Mrs. Obama said on Wednesday that the White House would continue its concert series with a performance at 7 p.m. on Monday by a lineup of prominent Broadway talents, including Nathan Lane, Idina Menzel, Audra McDonald, Brian d’Arcy James, Chad Kimball, Tonya Pinkins, Marvin Hamlisch, Karen Olivo and Assata Alston, preceded by remarks from the president.

text: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said on Wednesday that he would vote against a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system because he said Democrats were using an accounting “gimmick” to pay for administrative costs of the bill and because the legislation, over all, was simply not tough enough on Wall Street.

headline: Kaplan Takes the Editorial Reins at Fairchild
text: Peter W. Kaplan, the former New York Observer editor who left the grittiness of the newspaper business for the more refined, coiffed world of Condé Nast, will become the next editorial director of Fairchild Fashion Group, part of Condé Nast. There, he will oversee titles including Women’s Wear Daily, Menswear, Footwear News and Menswear.

headline: Rwanda Opposition Figure Found Dead

headline: Summer Growmance
text: Alexandra Reau’s bountiful backyard.

headline: Field Report: A Michigan Teen Farms Her Backyard
text: Lawn mowing and baby-sitting are standard summer jobs for the enterprising teenager. Alexandra Reau, who is 14, combines a little bit of each: last year, she asked her dad to dig up a half acre of their lawn in rural Petersburg, Mich., so she could farm. Now in its second season, her Garden to Go C.S.A. (community-supported agriculture) grows for 14 members, who pay $100 to $175 for two months of just-picked vegetables and herbs. While her peers are hanging out at Molly’s Mystic Freeze and working out the moves to that Miley Cyrus video, she’s flicking potato-beetle larvae off of leaves in her V-neck T-shirt and denim capris, a barrette keeping her hair out of her demurely made-up eyes. Who says the face of American farming is a 57-year-old man with a John Deere cap?

headline: Is the Internet So Crowded It’s Over?
text: Maybe Prince was onto something after all.

headline: Rice Raises Nearly $3 Million in Attorney General Race
text: Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney and Democratic candidate for attorney general, has raised more than $2.9 million over the last six months and has more than $4.1 million in the cash on hand, according to a campaign official, who requested anonymity because Ms. Rice had not yet submitted her formal paperwork to the state’s Board of Elections.

headline: Eli Broad Offers $7.7 Million for Museum Site
text: The Los Angeles philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad has decided to put his money where his art will (probably) be. Mr. Broad has told city and county officials that he is willing to pay $7.7 million for a 99-year lease on a plot of city-owned land in downtown Los Angeles where he has expressed interest in building a museum for his vast collection of contemporary art, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Greenpoint Food Market Isn’t Reopening Until at Least September

headline: Appeals Court Hears Arguments in Chevron Documentary Case
text: Lawyers appeared in front of a federal appeals panel in Manhattan on Wednesday for arguments about whether a filmmaker should be required to turn over to the Chevron Corporation roughly 600 hours of unseen footage from a documentary he made about a class-action lawsuit over pollution in the Amazon.

headline: New Reports of Fiscal Impropriety by Sarkozy Aide
text: PARIS  Two days after President Nicolas Sarkozy sought to bring an end to a damaging furor over allegations about his labor minister’s handling of political donations, fresh accusations against the official surfaced Wednesday, this time relating to the sale of a government-owned horse-racing track and the estate around it.

headline: Social Networking Butterfly
text: IT was a rainy Tuesday night and Rex Sorgatz, a rail-thin man with spiky red hair and Sol Moscot glasses, walked into a birthday party held at Tom & Jerry’s, a bar in NoHo that has become a go-to place for New York’s Twitter class. A circle of friends who occupy the digital elite closed in, all shouting “Rex!”

headline: A Desire to Win Helps End a Streak of Futility
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  As Scott Rolen launched himself headfirst at the third-base bag, it was as if he were turning back the clock to 1970 when another Cincinnati Red had no intention of losing an All-Star Game  Pete Rose, who barreled into Ray Fosse at home.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: THE HAIR OIL Of late, argan oil has become a go-to ingredient for backstage hairstylists at fashion shows who want to tame frizz and bring out shine. Moroccanoil has a line of ultra-light products starring argan oil. Now there’s another salon-only brand, Orofluido, a leave-in product that mixes three oils: argan (for strengthening), cyperus (for silkiness) and linseed (for shine). It’s $39.95 at select salons, including two in Manhattan, Più Tono and Coiffure.

headline: Shopping With Brent Ridge and Josh Kilmer-Purcell
text: Two city boys turned farmers went shopping for pieces that evoke the feeling of the country without the dirt.

headline: Animal Autopsies in Gulf Yield a Mystery
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — The Kemp’s ridley sea turtle lay belly-up on the metal autopsy table, as pallid as split-pea soup but for the bright orange X spray-painted on its shell, proof that it had been counted as part of the Gulf of Mexico’s continuing “unusual mortality event.”

headline: Asian Carp Threat: Real or Overblown?
text: On Monday, I wrote about the Asian carp, an invasive species that has been steadily making its way up the Mississippi River toward Lake Michigan. Many in the Great Lakes region fear that the fish, a voracious filter feeder and prolific breeder, could wreck havoc on the region’s fisheries by disrupting the food chain, as it has done in parts of the Mississippi, Missouri and Illinois Rivers.

text: The Treasury Department made waves when it announced earlier this year that it would begin selling the 7.7 billion shares it held in Citigroup, granted as part of the financial giant’s bailout during the crisis.

text: A massive investigation is under way to find out what killed hundreds of endangered sea turtles in the Gulf of Mexico in the weeks after the BP oil spill.

headline: If Your Child Wants to Be Dick Tracy
text: Dick Tracy had a two-way wrist radio, and later a two-way wrist TV.  And, next  month, for $50, you’ll be able to hand something close to your child, when the SpyNet Video Watch arrives in stores.

headline: City Finds Space For New Schools
text: The Department of Education and the city teachers’ union announced a solution on Wednesday to a math equation that had been plaguing them since this spring: how to fit 16 new and expanding schools into space occupied by 19 existing schools.

headline: Chair Lift | Give Your Table an Update
text: A good friend inherited a Victorian circular oak dining table. The table has great sentimental value, but the matching oak and cane chairs — high-back and ornate — needed to go. He wanted something up to date but not hyper-modern (no plastic, no chrome). I suggested a bentwood chair like the ones that Thonet has been manufacturing for years, which would relate to the Victorian design of the table but still feel modern. He liked the idea but not the price tag (the chairs are about $400 a piece), and he was concerned about the sturdiness of the caned seats, an issue he had with the original chairs.

headline: Retirement for Dummies
text: Ah, the joys of retirement. No more long days on the job for this dummy. No more slamming into offset barriers at high speed. No more skull fractures or knee replacements. Just a nice quiet spot at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History in Washington, where he can spend the rest of his days in the permanent collection.

headline: ‘Immigrant’ List Sets Off Fears
text: SALT LAKE CITY — A list of 1,300 Utah residents described as illegal immigrants has sown fear among some Hispanics here, and prompted an investigation into its origins and dissemination.

headline: 10 Ways to Age Like a Frenchwoman
text: 1 Look out for No. 1: “Frenchwomen are more elegant, more aware of their femininity,” says Dr. Michel Soussaline, a Paris plastic surgeon. “They simply take care of themselves better.”

headline: Aging Gracefully, the French Way
text: Paris

headline: Apps We Wish We Had
text: The original 2007 iPhone had only one screenful of software icons, believe it or not. You couldn’t install any new ones of your own. It took a whole year before Apple opened the iPhone app store, making it possible for the masses to download and install new apps (programs) and, in the process, creating a whole new gadget category.

headline: A Show of Power From Dimon and JPMorgan
text: Jamie Dimon is not the modern-day John Pierpont Morgan. He is not the new king of Wall Street, and he’s certainly not President Obama’s BBF (best banker friend). At least, that’s what he will tell you over lunch at the Park Avenue headquarters of JPMorgan Chase, the descendant of the House of Morgan that came through the global financial crisis bigger, stronger and healthier than its rivals,  Eric Dash of The New York Times reports.

headline: The Brothers Galkin: It Runs in the Family
text: THERE was probably little doubt that Matthew Galkin would someday find his way to New York. Even when he was a teenager in Highland Park, Ill., his classroom work suggested that a more willing audience might be found in the big city than in the upscale suburbs north of Chicago.

headline: Cricket and Baseball Find Common Ground in Show
text: LONDON  There was a time when the discreet men in blazers who run Lord’s cricket ground in London would have considered it an abomination to equate baseball with cricket in any fashion. Yet, there it is, an exhibition behind the famed Lord’s pavilion, cricket’s holy of holies, celebrating the similarities  and, in case anybody thought cricket’s traditionalists had run up the white flag, the differences  between cricket and baseball.

headline: Vernon Baker, Belated Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 90
text: Vernon Baker, who was the only living black veteran awarded the Medal of Honor for valor in World War II, receiving it 52 years after he wiped out four German machine-gun nests on a hilltop in northern Italy, died Tuesday at his home near St. Maries, Idaho. He was 90.

headline: Taking the Worry Out of Donating
text: Q. How do you know if a charity group is legitimate? I get a lot of donation requests but I’m unfamiliar with a lot of the groups.

headline: Teacher Fired Over Field-Trip Drowning of Girl, 12

headline: MileMeter
