headline: May the Best Flusher Win
text: What does the Grand Canyon have in common with the world’s largest toilet? They’re both stops on the Environmental Protection Agency’s latest promotional campaign, a “We’re for Water” cross-country road trip aimed at educating consumers about water-saving behavior and products certified through the agency’s WaterSense program.

headline: Dance New Amsterdam Gets Reprieve on Possible Eviction
text: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, has received a postponement of a possible eviction from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway, Catherine Peila, the group’s executive director, said Wednesday.

headline: Russia Plan to Help Iran Challenges Sanctions
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s energy minister announced a broad program of cooperation with Iran in the oil, natural gas and petrochemical industries on Wednesday that appeared to invite Russian companies to contravene sanctions the Obama administration adopted just two weeks ago.

headline: Recalling Steinbrenner, the Horseman
text: Steve Davidowitz, the horse racing handicapper and author, saw a side of George Steinbrenner that not so many Yankees fans see — the breeder and racetrack owner. Steinbrenner’s family has long been involved in horse racing through its Kinsman Stable, based in Ocala, Fla. Steinbrenner was also a part owner of Tampa Bay Downs in the 1980’s. As recently as 2005, Steinbrenner had the Kentucky Derby favorite, Bellamy Road, who finished seventh.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Are Sued in California
text: The California attorney general’s office on Wednesday sued Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over actions by the mortgage finance companies that have derailed a popular financing program that allows homeowners to pay for energy efficiency improvements through a surcharge on their property taxes.

headline: Rocker, Strings Attached
text: Early in the going at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night Sting led a singalong, arms waving as if to conduct the well-appointed crowd. The song was “Englishman in New York,” a delectable trifle with a coy premise  dandyism in the rough, more or less  inspired by the Oscar Wildeish author Quentin Crisp.

headline: They Meet. They Part. They ... What? Again?
text: Today’s the big day for David Nicholls’s “One Day,” the no-Sweden, no-vampire fiction hit of the summer. July 15: that’s the one day of the title, the date when this novel’s two star-crossed characters, Emma Morley and Dexter Mayhew, have their guaranteed karmic meet-and-greet every year. They need not even physically cross paths for these brushes to occur.

headline: In Java, Risking the Wrath of a Volcano
text: THE scene was straight out of a Hieronymus Bosch painting. A line of workers in black rubber boots struggled up a steep trail that emerged from the volcanic crater of Mount Ijen on the Indonesian island of Java. On their shoulders, each carried a pole with two baskets of bright yellow chunks of sulfur that had been hacked out of a rock wall near the crater lake.

headline: DIS | The Kids Are All Right
text: Meet six of the artists, designers and writers (and one opera singer) behind the year-old dismagazine.com. According to its mission statement, the collective is determined to “disrupt the dismal dissemination of fashion discourse.” Which explains the kind of fashion shoots they style, sometimes using women’s underwear worn below the knee, a men’s dress shirt fashioned as a pair of pants or an earring made from a small bag of marijuana. It’s as if Dazed & Confused stocked its fashion closet with Etsy.com. “The only thing shallow about style is how people consider it,” says Lauren Boyle, member of the collective and its spokeswoman. Next up: an online shop, DisOwn, which will sell its featured products.

headline: Wall St. Lawyer Joins Next Jump as I.P.O. Looms
text: Matthew L. Biben, a former deputy general counsel at Bank of New York Mellon, has joined the e-commerce and Internet advertising company Next Jump as its general counsel and chief administrative officer, signaling that Next Jump is gearing up for an initial public offering.

headline: On Our Radar: A Greenhouse for Algae
text: Exxon’s $600 million experiment with algae biofuels moves to the greenhouse.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: An article in The New York Times on Wednesday, “Trapped by Gaza Blockade, Locked in Despair,” concerns Palestinians in Gaza, most of whom are descended from refugees of the 1948 war that created Israel. Their struggles — among them, the loss of a formal local economy and a bitter rivalry between Palestinian factions — are documented in a related slide show, “Locked in Gaza.”

headline: Comic-Con Nixes Wet T-Shirt Scene in ‘Piranha 3-D’
text: The director of “Piranha 3-D,” Alexandre Aja, has a message for Comic-Con, the annual pop culture confab: You don’t want my R-rated footage of a wet T-shirt contest that turns into a blood bath? Then I don’t need you.

headline: Imagining Evolution as a Two-Way Street
text: Mamas, don’t let your sons grow up to be chimpanzees. Here’s how: Avoid experiments in which you fertilize your egg with chimp sperm and then have it implanted in your womb.

headline: A Place to Shop at Tavern While You Wait
text: Call it the concession stand on the Green.

headline: After Plenty of Sleep, No Birds in Traps
text: Saturday, July 10

headline: Revolution? Da. Sexual? Nyet.
text: MOSCOW

headline: A Caged Bird Sings the Blues About a Life of Not Fitting In
text: “A Night at the Tombs,” a solo show by the transgender performer Bianca Leigh about the time she spent a night in the Manhattan Detention Complex, sounds as if it ought to be spunky or scandalous. But  not uncommon in transgender theater  it turns out to be largely tease, because nothing much happened during that night of incarceration.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Mile Meter
text: MileMeter likes to think of itself as the “anti-insurance insurance company.” It sells auto insurance by the mile — which means that the less you drive, the less you pay for insurance. And yet, despite that appealing notion, when the global financial crisis hit, the company actually made the decision to shut down — because it couldn’t raise the money to get started. Watch the video below to see how Chris Gay, founder and chief executive, managed to keep the company alive.

headline: Poll Finds Pessimism on the War
text: The public is growing pessimistic again about the course of the war in Afghanistan, where casualties among American and allied troops have been running high.

headline: G.M. to Offer 8-Year Guarantee for New Electric Car’s Battery
text: In an effort to lure early adopters who might hesitate at dropping more than $30,000 on a mass-market electric car, General Motors said on Wednesday that it would guarantee the battery on its forthcoming Chevy Volt for eight years or 100,000 miles  better than the typical five-year or 100,000-mile warranty it typically offers for the powertrain on its conventional cars.

headline: Marshals Determine Causes of Two Rooftop Fires
text: Fire Department officials announced on Wednesday that marshals had determined the causes of two roof deck fires that took place in the span of a single week in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Packing in Labels Galore
text: AT 25 Park, a new women’s boutique in the meatpacking district, many labels fit into its small jewel-like space. For a night out, there is an Elizabeth and James black feather dress ($595) or a Gryphon pink and brown maze miniskirt ($345). It also carries children’s clothing (pictured), including Dagmar Daley ($150), Eberjey ($75) and Lola and James AC/DC ($75); 25 Park, 805 Washington Street (at Horatio Street); (212) 734-2525, 25Park.com. The store also has locations in Bridgehampton, N.Y.; Malibu, Calif.; and Deal, N.J.

headline: Captain Phil’s Death Draws Record Ratings for ‘Deadliest Catch’
text: About 8.5 million viewers watched the “Deadliest Catch” episode on Tuesday night that documented the death of Captain Phil Harris.

headline: Transfer of Prison in Iraq Marks Another Milestone
text: BAGHDAD — The United States plans on Thursday to transfer to the government of Iraq the last American-run prison, another milestone in the winding down of America’s war here but also dredging up memories of one of its most serious misdeeds.

headline: What Is The Fed Thinking?
text: OK, so the June Fed minutes are out. Here are the economic projections:

headline: Germany Raids Bank Offices in Tax Evasion Inquiry
text: BERLIN  Credit Suisse’s offices in Germany were searched Wednesday as part of an investigation into accusations that its employees might have helped clients evade taxes, prosecutors in Düsseldorf said.

headline: Picture This Bathing Suit
text: WE ARE HANDSOME, an Australian brand, combined 20 photos to create the hand-sewn “Los Angeles” bathing suit (also pictured,  “Africa,”  each $265).

headline: From New York, a Salsa Group With Street Cred
text: At its shows in Europe and across the United States the 11-piece orchestra La Excelencia is often introduced to audiences as personifying “salsa from New York.” So it is paradoxical that on its home turf the band’s hard, tough sound and fondness for lyrics that address social issues has led traditionalists to regard the group as somehow outside the salsa mainstream.

headline: La Excelencia in the Bronx
text: Photographs from the New York salsa group’s recent performance at Lehman College Auditorium.

headline: A Retail Internship
text: WHO needs a Wall Street internship? For their summer job, three Syracuse University students  Beau Wollens, Drew Taggart and Jack Doyle (pictured)  rented a storefront on the Lower East Side and opened a pop-up store, C’est Beau. Mr. Wollens, the store’s namesake, had worked at Nom de Guerre since he was 15. “I decided to work my leftover clothing connections,” Mr. Wollens said. The nouveau vintage styles are up to 80 percent off. Reason Clothing flannel shirts are $50; Pegleg NYC anoraks are $40; Nom de Guerre blazers are $200. Also, vintage sunglasses including Ray-Bans are $100 to $200. C’est Beau, 55 Delancey Street (at Allen Street). Open noon to 8 p.m. daily until July 31.

headline: Westerners on White Horses…
text: I recently answered a series of questions from readers via YouTube, and one in particular has sparked a very interesting discussion. The question was why many of my columns about Africa seem to portray “black Africans as victims” and “white foreigners as their saviors.” Here’s my off-the-cuff answer, as transcribed by The NYTPicker, which was mildly critical of my explanation:

headline: Storm Alert: A Growling Groundswell Is Brewing
text: Salome, from northern Virginia, is a doom-metal band with no bass player: one of the few. It can get by without one. It has a drummer, Aaron Deal, who creates patient authority with his bass drum, self-contained snare fills and double cymbal crashes, and a guitarist, Rob Moore, who plays slow, detuned single notes and chords, sealed in low frequency.

headline: S.E.C. Soliciting Comment on Investor Proxy System
text: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it wanted to hear from the public about several issues related to the proxy system, the process by which shareholders elect directors and vote on corporate governance proposals.

headline: Scouting Report
text: HITTING THE SHELVES

headline: You Can’t Pop Up Forever
text: MONTAUK, N.Y., will be the end of the road for the Alice + Olivia pop-up shop and party bus that travels in a vintage Airstream (in Manhattan for a pit stop and photo op). The camper started at the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in June and rolled through the South with a stylist, makeup artist, music and good will. “We donated clothes to flood victims in Nashville and raised money in Alabama to save the beaches,” said Stacey Bendet, the line’s designer. Look for it at the Surf Lodge, 183 Edgemere Street, Montauk, on July 17 noon to 8 p.m.

headline: For FarmVille Players, a Crop From a Real Organic Farm
text: OPERATING a successful farm is a notion that is thriving in the virtual world. Some 20 million people check into FarmVille daily to plow pretend fields or buy, plant and harvest crops on online farms.

headline: Sugar Minott, Reggae Star, Dies at 54
text: Sugar Minott, a popular Jamaican singer whose joyful, lilting voice bridged four decades of transformation in reggae music, died Saturday in Kingston, the nation’s capital. He was 54.

headline: Country Furnishings for City Dwellers
text: LIKE many stressed-out New Yorkers, Brent Ridge and Josh Kilmer-Purcell envisioned a simpler life when they bought a country home. But the house they purchased in Sharon Springs, N.Y., in 2007, came with an entire farm — and since they have taken on its day-to-day operation, life has been anything but relaxed.

headline: Princess and Prince Transcend the Realms
text: Musing upon the subject of loss, Canadian poets and hair-metal philosophers concur: You don’t know what you’ve got till it’s gone. A performance of Mozart’s eternally fresh singspiel,  “Die Zauberflöte”  (  “The Magic Flute”  ), in the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Tuesday night proved the reverse is also true: You don’t know what you’ve missed till it’s back.

headline: A Concert in the Park
text: The Shanghai Symphony Orchestra and the New York Philharmonic performed in Central Park.

headline: Pakistan Bans Film Involving Bin Laden
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An Indian comedy about a Pakistani reporter who tries to win points to emigrate to the United States by interviewing an Osama bin Laden look-alike has been banned here, two days before it was supposed to open.

headline: Vain Glorious | pureDKNY – It’s Not Plain Vanilla
text: Who: DKNY Fragrances.

headline: My Obama Problem
text: John Boehner, March 2009:

headline: Turning Snapshots Into Works of Art
text: Several companies offer options for digital photographs beyond simple enlargement. These services cost more than the one-hour photo hut, but the results can be stunning.

headline: Storm Strikes Haven for Displaced Haitians
text: Heavy wind and rain earlier this week turned the Corail-Cesselesse camp north of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, from a supposed haven for earthquake-displaced families into a disaster site.

headline: An Outdoor Concert Takes Shelter in a Church
text: New York’s parks are full of music in the summer, much of it presented by major organizations with substantial financing. The Washington Square Music Festival, now in its 52nd season, has always been more of a grass-roots endeavor and has long cultivated the notion that it is an expression of the Greenwich Village community that surrounds its home, Washington Square Park. And though the festival has its own donors, the current financial pinch is affecting it acutely: on Tuesday evening listeners who attended the free concert were urged to put a dollar in a basket that was passed through the audience during the intermission.

headline: Two Weeks Without a Toilet
text: THIS is my new tub, a Rubbermaid Roughneck XL plastic bin. What do you think — is the lime green too much?

headline: Legal Question
text: Does the Fed have the right to do a helicopter drop, i.e., just hand out cash? My guess is not: it’s empowered to buy assets, which is what it does in an open-market operation, but not just to give stuff away.

headline: Bennet Leads Money Chase in Colorado
text: Senator Michael Bennet, the Colorado Democrat trying to fight off a primary challenge, announced Wednesday that he raised about $1.25 million during this year’s second quarter.

headline: 18th-Century Ship Found at Trade Center Site
text: In the middle of tomorrow, a great ribbed ghost has emerged from a distant yesterday.

headline: Iraq’s Imperiled Modern Art
text: BAGHDAD – If a blog about war seems an unlikely place to see photographs of paintings and sculptures, consider this. In May, the 5th Squadron, 7th Cavalry Regiment of the Third Infantry Division organized an art exhibition with a black-tie opening night in Dora, still one of Baghdad’s most troubled neighborhoods, if less troubled than before.

headline: With Sketchpads and Guns, Semper Fi
text: Quantico, Va.

headline: A Pop-Up Shop in the Hamptons
text: The New General Store, a pop-up home furnishings shop open July 16 to 18 in a meadow in Watermill, N.Y., will sell “modern country-house furnishings,” said Tricia Foley, the interior designer running it. Ms. Foley, who had two New General Store pop-up shops last year at her home in Yaphank, N.Y., added, “Everything is practical.”

headline: From Georg Jensen, a Collection in Stainless Steel
text: For those who long for but can’t afford Georg Jensen’s silver hollow-ware, the company has been introducing a few well-known items in stainless steel, in its Masterpieces collection. The latest is the 1302 tray by Verner Panton, a k a the Car Crash tray. “Our silversmiths always find nicknames for their favorite pieces, and this one became the Car Crash,” explained Ulrik Garde Due, the chief executive. “But Panton originally looked at it more as a sheet of paper he was crumpling.”

headline: Cassandra Time
text: Has it really been 16 months since I wrote this?

headline: Talking With Alice T. Friedman
text: Alice T. Friedman, an architectural historian and professor of American art history at Wellesley, has a new book, “American Glamour and the Evolution of Modern Architecture” (Yale University Press; $65), that links the work of postwar architects like Morris Lapidus, Philip Johnson and Richard Neutra to a single quality: glamour. Critics liked to trash the glamorous — as they did the photographs Julius Shulman took of Neutra’s Kaufmann Desert House, published in Life magazine in 1949 — as tawdry eye candy, too eager to sell itself, too beautiful to be proper modern architecture, doomed to be mere fashion. But glamour, Professor Friedman proposes, is no mere aesthetic; it is a sensual, emotional and magical sensibility that percolated up from American popular culture, elevating the ordinary — a toaster, say — into the extraordinary.

headline: Let It Rain! (After the Music, of Course)
text: Mother Nature must have been watching out for the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday night when this summer’s Concerts in the Parks series began on the Great Lawn at Central Park. For the first time in the 46-year history of this summer music tradition, the Philharmonic was sharing a parks program with a guest ensemble, the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra. All day Monday the forecasts were predicting a strong likelihood of thunderstorms.

headline: Tracking the Day’s Business News, From Markets to Mergers
text: Professional investors and Wall Street executives have Bloomberg terminals and a small army of assistants, analysts and brokers to keep them fully updated on business news at any given moment.

headline: A Stylish Sink for Tiny Spaces
text: For years, European designers like Philippe Starck and Marcel Wanders have had a monopoly on high-end bathroom fixtures. But AF New York, in the Flatiron District, is hoping to change that.

headline: Walls That Invite Children to Make Their Marks
text: Kids Glass from Skyline Design consists of clear panels of safety glass with patterns printed on the back. Children (or adults) can draw on it in regular marker, which cleans up easily with window cleaner or a chalkboard eraser.

headline: Federal Oversight for Troubled N.Y. Youth Prisons
text: Four of New York’s most dangerous and troubled youth prisons will be placed under federal oversight, strict new limits will be imposed on the use of physical force by guards, and dozens of psychiatrists, counselors and investigators will be hired under a sweeping agreement finalized on Wednesday between state and federal officials.

headline: A China Cabinet That Doubles as a Safe
text: A burglar breaking into a home might not expect to find money and jewels locked inside the piece of furniture that holds the china. But if it is an EAN buffet, it doubles as a safe, with two compartments that can be secured with an electronic lock.

headline: Sales at Christopher Spitzmiller and Others
text: During Christopher Spitzmiller’s sale, through July 21, slightly imperfect lamps are up to 55 percent off (the Aurora Double Gourd lamp with 23-karat gold gilt base, originally $1,990, is $895); 248 West 35th Street (Eighth Avenue), (212) 563-1144 or christopherspitzmiller.com.

headline: Son Sees ‘Fela!,’ After All
text: In the end the Nigerian band leader Femi Kuti couldn’t pass up the opportunity to see “Fela!,” the hit Broadway musical about the life of his father, Fela Anikulapo Kuti, creator of the Afrobeat sound  not after the producers of that Tony-winning show offered him the guarantee he had been lobbying to hear. So on Tuesday night he went to the Eugene O’Neill Theater and watched his own family’s complicated history unfold onstage, where afterward Mr. Kuti hugged the actress Lillias White, above, as Sahr Ngaujah, who plays Fela, talked to the crowd. Mr. Kuti had vowed to see “Fela!” only if the show were brought to Lagos, where in the 1970s Fela built a nightclub and residential compound to perform and criticize the corruption and human rights abuses of Nigeria’s military rulers. But arriving in New York from a show in Philadelphia, he watched the World Cup final with Stephen Hendel, a producer of “Fela!” During the game, “I made him a promise that the show will go to Lagos,” Mr. Hendel said as he escorted Mr. Kuti to his seat. Said Mr. Kuti, “I’m impressed.” He added, “It’s an excellent play.”

headline: Farewell to ‘The Hills,’ With a Wink and a Nod
text: “The Hills” ended on Tuesday night with a wink to all the fans and critics who have questioned its semi-scripted nature over the years. After Kristin Cavallari said goodbye to her former boyfriend, Brody Jenner, on a quiet street, the Hollywood sign gleaming in the distance, the camera pulled back to reveal that Mr. Jenner was standing on a studio back lot, implying that the coming-of-age-in-tinseltown stories were never as real as they appeared. It was arguably the most buzz-worthy moment on “The Hills” this season, its sixth and last on MTV. The once-innovative show has been waning, having peaked in its third season with an average of 3.8 million viewers. This season it was averaging 2.3 million, and Tuesday’s finale was watched by 2.95 million viewers, according to the Nielsen Company. On a live “after party” after the finale on Tuesday, Mr. Jenner said: “As you saw in the end  what’s real and what’s fake? You don’t know. Our relationship the entire time could have been fake. You don’t know, you don’t know.”

headline: From The Great White Way to the White House
text: A couple of Broadway’s most prominent advocates  President Obama and Michelle Obama, the first lady  will continue to do their part for New York theater by bringing some of it to the White House on Monday. Representatives for Mrs. Obama said on Wednesday that the White House would continue its concert series with a performance at 7 p.m. on Monday by a lineup of prominent Broadway talents including Nathan Lane and Audra McDonald, right, Idina Menzel,  Brian d’Arcy James, Chad Kimball, Tonya Pinkins, Marvin Hamlisch, Karen Olivo and Assata Alston. PBS will broadcast the concert as “A Broadway Celebration: In Performance at the White House” on Oct. 20. The President and the first lady made headlines last year when their evening’s itinerary in New York included a stop at the Broadway revival of “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone.” Mrs. Obama and her daughters, Sasha and Malia, have also attended the Broadway musicals “Memphis” and “The Addams Family,” whose casts are represented on the White House concert bill by Mr. Kimball and Mr. Lane.

headline: ‘Talent’ Takes on All-Stars
text: “America’s Got Talent” remained resilient in the ratings on Tuesday despite intense competition from Major League Baseball’s annual All-Star Game, the top-rated program on the night. But Nielsen’s preliminary estimates indicated that fewer viewers tuned in to Fox’s broadcast of the All-Star Game than the 14.6 million who watched last July. Still, Fox appeared to win the night easily, with NBC a solid second due largely to the 11.5 million viewers who watched “America’s Got Talent” from 9 to 11 p.m. CBS, in third, posted strong ratings for reruns of its crime shows. ABC ranked fourth.

headline: Appeals Court Hears Arguments Over Outtakes
text: Lawyers appeared in front of a federal appeals panel in Manhattan on Wednesday for arguments about whether a filmmaker should be required to turn over to the Chevron Corporation roughly 600 hours of unseen footage from a documentary he made about a class-action lawsuit over pollution in the Amazon. In May a federal district judge ordered the filmmaker, Joe Berlinger, to turn over outtakes from “Crude,” the documentary that he made about the suit brought in Ecuador against Texaco  now owned by Chevron  charging that the company contaminated drinking and bathing water in Amazonian rain forests. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan had ruled that the footage could be subpoenaed because it fit the standard established by precedent: it was nonconfidential, was likely of relevance to the case being tried and could not be otherwise obtained by the defense. Maura J. Wogan, an attorney for Mr. Berlinger, vigorously disputed those determinations, telling a three-judge panel of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals that Judge Kaplan had issued “a broad and unprecedented order” that would result in a chilling effect on her client and on other journalists if upheld. Speaking a few minutes later, Randy Mastro, a lawyer for Chevron, told the judges that “this is a case about plaintiffs’ lawyers who decided that they wanted to star in a movie,” and so could not believe that their actions would remain private. As the proceeding progressed the judges signaled that they might narrow the focus of Judge Kaplan’s decision and perhaps require Mr. Berlinger to produce a smaller amount of material.

headline: Eminem Holds Top Spot
text: Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) is No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a third week, with 229,000 sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to just under 1.3 million, though its sales have fallen significantly each week. “Recovery” is the first album to hold the No. 1 spot for three weeks since Sade’s “Soldier of Love” in March. Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) holds at No. 2 with 74,000 sold, and “Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty” (Def Jam), the new album by Big Boi of OutKast, opened at No. 3 with 62,000. The soundtrack to “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” (Chop Shop/Atlantic) is No. 4 with 45,000 and Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) is No. 5 with 43,000.

headline: Eli Broad Ups His Ante To Build Art Museum
text: The Los Angeles philanthropist and art collector Eli Broad, below, has decided to put his money where his art will (probably) be. Mr. Broad has told city and county officials that he is willing to pay $7.7 million for a 99-year lease on a plot of city-owned land in downtown Los Angeles where he has expressed interest in building a museum for his vast collection of contemporary art, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday. Mr. Broad has considered at least two other sites for the museum, which he has pledged to build with his own money  up to $100 million for construction and $200 million more for an endowment. He had explored the possibility of leasing the downtown site for $1, a common arrangement for cultural institutions, but that idea was criticized by Michael Antonovich, a Los Angeles County supervisor. In an interview Mr. Broad said such criticism “blows my imagination, frankly,” adding that “any city in America would like to get a museum built if they didn’t have to pay for it.” But a spokeswoman for Mr. Broad told The Times that he had changed his mind about the lease because he wanted “everyone to be supportive and satisfied.”

headline: Two More Republicans Plan Nays for Kagan
text: Senators John Thune of South Dakota and John Cornyn of Texas announced today that they planned to vote against Solicitor General Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court. See which other Republicans have taken a stand and their statements about Ms. Kagan on our Kagan Vote Tracker.

headline: ‘The Boys in Concert’ Returns Fire Against ‘Jersey Boys’
text: Oh, what a nightmare: following a lawsuit brought by several creators of the Broadway musical “Jersey Boys” against four members of the show’s original cast, those performers have filed a vehement counterclaim that’s enough to make big girls — and boys — cry.

headline: Upstart Music Site Becomes Establishment
text: Early each weekday morning, the indie music Web site Pitchfork posts five new album reviews. Hours later a 22-year-old reader named David downloads them onto his BlackBerry, reads them on his way to work and muscles out a rambling but surprisingly fluid response using his phone’s MemoPad function: no links, no capital letters at the start of sentences, just adrenalized response.

headline: Cycling Bloggers Scour Armstrong’s 2005 Testimony
text: Updated | 7:56 p.m. As my colleague Juliet Macur reported on Wednesday morning from France, Lance Armstrong, “a focus of a federal investigation into possible fraud and doping on the now-defunct United States Postal Service cycling team,” flatly denied that he had been one of the team’s owners before 2004, when it was sponsored by the government agency.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Summertime is family time, but it’s not always a day at the beach. This month’s bumper crop of brood-centric novels plumb catastrophes, coming of age, ruptures and reconciliation.

headline: The Roots of a Rivalry
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — We always knew that the competition between Tom Watson and Jack Nicklaus was fierce, even before they squared off in 1977 at the Duel in the Sun at Turnberry, which Watson won by a stroke after closing 65-65 to Nicklaus’s 65-66. That kicked off a rivalry that has since settled into a comfortable friendship as they have aged.

headline: Golub Resigns as A.I.G.’s Chairman
text: 7:39 a.m. | Updated The New York Times has more on Harvey Golub’s resignation.

headline: Keeping Animals Out of Flower Beds
text: I LIVE in a northern suburb of New York, close enough to a local truck route that there is a constant rumble from the nearby intersection. But in the evening, when the traffic slows and the light softens, it feels as if I’m in more-remote country.

headline: For Moles, a Garden Becomes a Buffet
text: The damage done to a fledgling flower garden.

headline: At a Close Match in Belgium, a First-Round Bidding Choice
text: First today, look at only the North hand. After two passes and a one-diamond opening on your right, would you make a takeout double or overcall one spade?

headline: The Stimulus, From a Political Perspective
text: Depending on the political perspective, President Obama’s economic stimulus program is either a crowning achievement for Democrats heading into the November elections or their most glaring blunder.

text: President Obama had what his press secretary called a “fairly lengthy meeting” on Wednesday with Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, to talk about the economy.

headline: Prospects Abound Among the Kurds

Despite Settlement Freeze, Buildings Rise

headline: Cheer, Then Gloom, on Talks for Peace Deal in Mideast
text: JERUSALEM  In the upbeat atmosphere after their recent meeting in Washington, the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, and President Obama expressed hopes of an imminent resumption of direct Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and of achieving a peace deal  within a year, according to Mr. Netanyahu, or in Mr. Obama’s case, before the end of his term.

headline: Toyota Concedes 2 Flaws Caused Loss of Control
text: DETROIT — Toyota said Wednesday that its investigation of about 2,000 vehicles reported to experience sudden acceleration found evidence that sticking accelerator pedals and interference by floor mats — the subjects of two big recalls — did indeed cause some of the incidents.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Few Women Go: A Building Site
text: Sharon Darling, 24, is a graduate of a program at Nontraditional Employment for Women, a group that prepares women for union jobs in the building trades, and has been an apprentice with Electricians Local 3 for nearly a year. In five years, she will attain the status of mechanic, earning $40 to $50 an hour and the authority to delegate grunt work like hauling 90-pound bales of wire to apprentices like her. She lives in Midwood, Brooklyn.

headline: Pius Njawé, Noted African Journalist, Dies at 53
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Pius Njawé, one of Africa’s most celebrated journalists, died in a car accident on Monday in Virginia, according to his newspaper’s Web site and news agency reports. He was 53.

headline: Marrack Goulding, Former Chief Peacekeeper for the U.N., Dies at 73
text: Marrack I. Goulding, who for seven years as an under secretary general of the United Nations oversaw peacekeeping missions around the world  at times coming under fire himself  died Friday at a nursing home in Somerset, England. He was 73 and lived in London.

headline: Photo Replay: July 9
text: A look at the day in sports, including scenes from the British Open and the Tour de France.

headline: Packers Report Lower Profits Amid Higher Player Salaries
text: Escalating player salaries continued to chew into the profits of the Green Bay Packers last year, the team said Wednesday during its annual earnings report.

headline: Singapore Forecasts 15% Economic Growth
text: HONG KONG — Singapore is on pace to be among the world’s fastest-growing economies this year, after a spurt in the first half prompted the government on Wednesday to project an expansion of as much as 15 percent for 2010. That would be four times the pace at which the United States economy is expected to grow.

headline: A.I.G. Chairman Resigns, Citing Clash With Chief
text: The conflict between the American International Group’s chairman and its chief executive had been quietly building for months, and in recent days it became so palpable that many at the company were wondering which of the two men would survive the coming showdown.

headline: Apple Plans News Conference to Discuss iPhone 4
text: 6:35 a.m. | Updated Correcting length of time between introduction of original iPhone and price cut.

headline: Run Silent. Run Deep. Run Obsolete.
text: QUILCENE, Wash. — We’re digging clams and picking oysters on one of the longest days of the year. It’s a huge bounty, this frutti di mare, bringing to mind what the natives always said about Puget Sound: when the tide is out, the table is set.

headline: Finances in Dispute as Bargaining Looms
text: LAS VEGAS  The N.B.A. finals were a ratings hit. Season-ticket sales are booming. Fans have been transfixed by a spectacular free-agent market.

headline: The Bad News Bears
text: Today’s additions to the category of No Good Can Ever Come of This:

headline: Even Without iPhone, Verizon Is Gaining on AT&T
text: It is a question that the nation’s early adopters keep hearing from friends: when is the iPhone coming to Verizon?

headline: Records Show Doubts on ’64 Vietnam Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — In an echo of the debates over the discredited intelligence that helped make the case for the war in Iraq, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday released more than 1,100 pages of previously classified Vietnam-era transcripts that show senators of the time sharply questioning whether they had been deceived by the White House and the Pentagon over the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin incident.

headline: Monserrate Seeks Seat in State Assembly
text: Hiram Monserrate, who three months ago failed to regain the State Senate seat he had lost after being convicted of misdemeanor domestic assault, is again running for office, this time for a Queens Assembly seat.

headline: No Jail for Ex-Officer in Encounter With  Bicyclist
text: A former police officer convicted of lying about an encounter he had in Times Square that sent a bicyclist tumbling to the pavement will not receive any further punishment for his crime, a judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Some Humble Pie for a Concert Beast
text: Audiences have been staying away from the expensive, commercial events that Live Nation, the giant concert promoter, organizes in big arenas.

headline: Bloggingheads: Pity Small Businessmen?
text: Annie Lowrey, left, of The Washington Independent and Reihan Salam of The Daily Beast debate whether over-regulation is hurting the economy.

headline: News Outlets in Utah Decline to Reveal ‘Immigrant’ List
text: The letters arrived in plain, unmarked 8 1/2-by-11 envelopes, with no return address.

headline: South Korea: Military Exercises Planned With the United States
text: The United States and South Korea are expected to hold joint military exercises soon in the Yellow Sea, a response to the sinking of a South Korean warship in March, the Pentagon said Wednesday. North Korea has been widely blamed for the sinking, which killed 46 sailors. Geoff Morrell, the Pentagon spokesman, said that the United States would go ahead with the plan despite Chinese concerns. “This is a matter of our ability to exercise in the open seas, in international water,” he said. “Those determinations are made by us, and us alone.” Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton are to complete the plans for the exercises at a meeting with their counterparts in Seoul next week.

headline: 2 New York Institutions Want to Keep Ponzi Gifts
text: Before Hassan Nemazee, the once-powerful business executive and Democratic donor, pleaded guilty to engineering a nearly $300 million Ponzi scheme, he gave $1.1 million to a wide range of charities and educational institutions and an additional $845,000 to political candidates and parties.

headline: Nestlé Will Drop Claims of Health Benefit in Drink
text: According to a recent Nestlé ad campaign aimed at parents, a drink called Boost Kid Essentials was so good for children that it could keep them from getting colds and missing school.

headline: Seduction, Slavery and Sex
text: Against all odds, this year’s publishing sensation is a trio of thrillers by a dead Swede relating tangentially to human trafficking and sexual abuse.

headline: On the Heels of a Recession
text: During times of financial pressure, high fashion brings out the most gravity-defying shoes.

headline: Could Be Time for Clintons to Trade Up
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

headline: Economics Behaving Badly
text: IT seems that every week a new book or major newspaper article appears showing that irrational decision-making helped cause the housing bubble or the rise in health care costs.

headline: The Avandia Saga Continues
text: A panel of expert advisers to the Food and Drug Administration delivered a confusing verdict on Wednesday after two days of hearings on the safety of the diabetes drug Avandia. A majority of the 33-member panel expressed concern that Avandia raises the risk of heart attacks compared with other diabetes drugs. But a majority also voted to leave the drug on the market anyway, with various degrees of restrictions or warnings.

headline: Video Shows Failed Bomber Before Attack
text: An Arabic-language television channel has broadcast excerpts of what it said was a martyrdom video by Faisal Shahzad, who pleaded guilty last month to trying to detonate a bomb in Times Square.

headline: The Google Algorithm
text: Google handles nearly two-thirds of Internet search queries worldwide. Analysts reckon that most Web sites rely on the search engine for half of their traffic. When Google engineers tweak its supersecret algorithm  as they do hundreds of times a year  they can break the business of a Web site that is pushed down the rankings.

headline: Whittling Away the Petroleum Reserve
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar announced last week that he will open 1.8 million acres of the National Petroleum Reserve in northern Alaska to oil and gas leasing. He pledged to protect habitat for migratory birds and caribou near Teshekpuk Lake, an ecologically sensitive area inside the 1.8 million acre tract  welcome news. Even better news would be a pledge by the secretary to go slow on any future development in the reserve.

headline: Rewrap the Fondue Pot for Bristol Palin
text: He was the off-again, on-again boyfriend who stripped for Playgirl and gossiped about her family on “Tyra.” She was the teenage mother who had embarked on some image polishing of her own, posing on magazine covers and appearing on television as a bright-eyed spokeswoman for abstinence.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Wi-Fi on Trains and U.S.B. 3.0
text: This week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast features a look at Wi-Fi on the railroad, with Walt Baranger of the News Technology group at The New York Times dropping by to talk about the issues involved in providing Wi-Fi service on trains. Amtrak has already introduced it on its Acela trains in the Northeast and has long-term plans for nationwide WiFi, but significant cost and technological challenges mean that very remote areas may have service gaps, Mr. Baranger says.

headline: Egypt: Building Collapse Kills 7
text: Seven men were killed and another was seriously injured when an apartment that functioned as a boarding house collapsed in the historic Darb al-Ahmar neighborhood of Cairo early Tuesday morning.

headline: Egypt: Ship Headed For Gaza Awaits Instructions Off Port
text: A ship, the Amalthea, that had aimed to break the Israeli blockade of Gaza floated two nautical miles off the port of El Arish on Thursday morning, apparently waiting for instructions about when and whether to dock, according to Gen. Gamal Abdel Maqsoud, the port’s director. The voyage was sponsored by a charity run by Saif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, son of Libya’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The cargo, 1,500 tons of goods, including food and medical supplies, will be handed over to the Egyptian Red Crescent, then transported to Gaza, General Maqsoud said. The ship sailed from Greece on July 10, and was met by the Israeli Navy, which warned the crew against approaching Gaza.

headline: Arrest Puts End to a War on Brooklyn Trees
text: To the residents of Prospect Heights in Brooklyn, he was simply known as Steve.

headline: 66 Across
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to describe my experience solving this puzzle and ask if yours was at all similar:

headline: Fund-Raising Before House Vote Draws Scrutiny
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers take contributions every day from corporate executives and lobbyists hoping for their votes. The question of whether that represents business as usual in Washington or an ethics breach is at the heart of a far-reaching Congressional ethics investigation that is stirring concerns throughout Washington and Wall Street.

headline: Scores to Go
text: Nine Cuban political prisoners tasted freedom this week after they were allowed to fly to exile in Spain. They pledged to keep fighting for democracy in Cuba. They must not fight alone.

headline: NYRA Cuts a Deterrent to Cheating
text: The financially strapped New York Racing Association, under pressure from horsemen, said Wednesday that it would abandon its practice of isolating horses in a security barn used to deter drug cheats when its premier meet opens July 23 in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

headline: Beltran Comes Back, Complicating the Mets’ Picture
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The Atlanta Braves finished the first half of the season with a four-game lead over the Mets in the National League East, but when the teams meet again in Atlanta in two and a half weeks, the Mets will have a five-time All-Star in their lineup.

headline: France: Georgian Media Grouploses Fight With Satellite Operator
text: A Georgian media group that had accused a French satellite operator of caving in to Russian pressure to keep its television station off the air lost a court battle against the operator this week. The group, Georgian Public Broadcasting, had sued Eutelsat, based in Paris, saying it had reneged on a contract to broadcast the channel, a Russian-language news service apparently meant to counter the anti-Georgian propaganda in Russia’s state-owned network. Eutelsat denied the claim, saying it never had a contract with the Georgians. In January, the satellite operator announced a contract with Gazprom Media, an arm of the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom, for the same satellite capacity the Georgians said they had been promised. Henri d’Armagnac, a French lawyer for the Georgians, said they would appeal the court’s decision, which was rendered Monday.

headline: Early Fund-Raising Success for One, but No Clear Leader in Attorney General’s Race
text: Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney and a Democratic candidate for attorney general, has raised more than $2.9 million over the last six months and has more than $4.1 million in cash on hand, her campaign announced on Wednesday.

headline: A Horse With Ties to Steinbrenner Wins at Belmont
text: A daughter of one of George Steinbrenner’s best horses broke her maiden in impressive fashion Wednesday at Belmont.

headline: Candidate for Governor in Colorado Apologizes
text: A former congressman who is running for governor of Colorado faced accusations of plagiarism this week for writings on water issues and on North Korea.

headline: Corrections
text: SPORTS

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Challenge: Capturing a Life in a Patch
text: It is hard enough to summarize a life in a book. It is nearly impossible to do it in a small decal.

headline: Bigger Than Beckham? Henry Arrives
text: Thierry Henry’s arrival as a player with the Red Bulls stands a far better chance of stimulating soccer in the United States than the David Beckham acquisition.

headline: Everybody Is Talking About the Weather at the British Open
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  It is never news when it rains here. The well-worn bromide the Scots have for it, “Nae rain, nae wind, nae golf,” usually is enough to spur tourists off the couch and out to the links in a downpour. But when windblown rain turns all but the sturdiest gust-buster umbrellas inside out and temperatures fall into the 50s, as they did Wednesday, then it is time for the pros to take over.

headline: Health Plans Must Provide Some Tests at No Cost
text: WASHINGTON  The White House on Wednesday issued new rules requiring health insurance companies to provide free coverage for dozens of screenings, laboratory tests and other types of preventive care.

headline: Steinbrenner Farewell to Begin With Impromptu Tribute
text: The Yankees will return to the field in the Bronx on Friday night and will hold their annual Old-Timers’ Day on Saturday, and both of those games appear to be shaping up as informal public tributes to George Steinbrenner, whose long reign as owner of the Yankees ended with his death on Tuesday.

headline: Apple Plans Briefing on iPhone 4
text: Apple said that it planned to hold a news conference on Friday to discuss the iPhone 4 as concerns about problems with the device’s antenna continued to mount. Steve Dowling, a spokesman for Apple, would not give details of who would speak at the event, which is expected to be held at the company’s headquarters in Cupertino, Calif.

headline: Unknown Is a Nominee for Alabama Governor
text: ATLANTA  A relatively unknown Alabama state representative won the Republican nomination for governor on Tuesday, easily defeating a well-financed, establishment-supported opponent in a runoff election.

headline: Wanting Maradona to Stay
text: Argentina’s soccer federation said it would offer to keep Diego Maradona as coach for up to four more years. Maradona and Julio Grondona, the federation president, were expected to meet next week to discuss the offer, according to a federation spokesman, who added that there was no Plan B for another person to take the job.

headline: Project’s Fate May Predict the Future of Mining
text: BLAIR, W.Va. — Federal officials are considering whether to veto mountaintop mining above a little Appalachian valley called Pigeonroost Hollow, a step that could be a turning point for one of the country’s most contentious environmental disputes.

headline: A Mining Bellwether
text: At the center of a bitter storm that could sharply restrict the controversial practice of mountaintop mining in Appalachia.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,161 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Day 85: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Turtle Hatchlings Are Released Into Atlantic

headline: Bill Would Ease Telecommuting for U.S. Workers
text: Federal agencies would be required to establish policies that encourage more employees to work from home under a bill passed, 290 to 131, by the House on Wednesday.

headline: China Is Successfully Taming Growth
text: BEIJING — The Chinese economy has slowed from its blistering pace of growth earlier this year as the government has tried to ward off inflation and rein in a runaway property market, government data showed Thursday.

headline: Senate Democrats to Pursue a Smaller Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Senate Democrats have decided to press ahead in the next two weeks with a scaled-back energy bill that limits carbon pollution by power plants but not by other industries in an effort to salvage the legislation before midterm elections.

headline: Iran: Scientist Returns Home
text: An Iranian nuclear scientist who American officials say defected to the United States and then had second thoughts was given a hero’s welcome when he returned to Tehran early Thursday morning. The scientist, Shahram Amiri, 32, added details to his claims that he had been abducted by the C.I.A. and Saudi intelligence. A wreath of flowers was placed around his neck as he was greeted at Imam Khomeini International Airport by family members, including his 7-year old son, red-eyed from crying, and a grinning foreign Ministry official.

headline: Zhao and Zatonskih Lead Championships
text: The defending champion leads the U.S. Women’s Championship, while an underdog is in control of the U.S. Junior Championship.

headline: Word of the Day | arrogance
text: arrogance •\ˈer-ə-gən(t)s, ˈa-rə-\• noun

headline: China Reins in Its Rapid Growth
text: BEIJING — China’s economy has slowed from its blistering growth earlier this year after the government took measures to ward off inflation and rein in a runaway property market, government data released on Thursday showed.

headline: A Risky Campaign Tactic: Unpleasant Truth
text: WARWICK, R.I.

headline: California: Oakland Dismisses 80 Officers
text: After failed negotiations over pensions with the police union, Oakland laid off 80 officers Tuesday. The layoffs came less than a week after rioting in the center of the city following a verdict of involuntary manslaughter in the case of a white transit officer who shot an unarmed black man in the back in January 2009. Facing a $31 million budget deficit, officials said they had little choice but to lay off the officers, bringing the force down to 696.

headline: U.S. Says Scientist Aided C.I.A. While Still in Iran
text: The Iranian scientist who American officials say defected to the United States, only to return to Tehran on Thursday, had been an informant for the Central Intelligence Agency inside Iran for several years, providing information about the country’s nuclear program, according to United States officials.

headline: Arnold Kramish, Expert on Nuclear Intelligence, Dies at 87
text: Arnold Kramish, a physicist who survived an explosion while working on the Manhattan Project and later became an expert on nuclear proliferation and espionage, died on June 15 in Washington. He was 87 and lived in Reston, Va.

headline: BP Says Oil Flow Has Stopped as Cap Is Tested
text: NEW ORLEANS  BP said Thursday that it had capped its hemorrhaging well, at least temporarily, marking the first time in 86 days that oil was not gushing into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: News Quiz | July 15, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Europe Struggles to Match Success of U.S. Bank Tests
text: Europe’s struggle to thrash out a thin outline of its bank stress test and agree on consistency bodes ill for hopes that the exercise will provide the transparency and resolve needed to revive investor confidence, The New York Times’s Steve Slater and Boris Groendahl reported.

headline: Even Without iPhone, Verizon Is Gaining on AT&T
text: It is a question that the nation’s early adopters keep hearing from friends: when is the iPhone coming to Verizon?

headline: Lackluster Trading Debut for AgBank
text: Agricultural Bank of China got off to a muted start in its trading debut in Shanghai on Thursday after raising $19.2 billion in one of the world’s biggest initial public offerings, with investors closely watching the shares as a barometer of market appetite for large offerings in general, and for bank shares in particular, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Europe Clears Trans-Atlantic Air Alliance
text: British Airways, American Airlines and Iberia won European Union antitrust clearance on Wednesday to deepen their Oneworld alliance on trans-Atlantic routes and better compete with rival groups, Reuters reported.

headline: Making Something From Nothing
text: WHO is Aaron Rose?WHO is Sister Corita?WHO has been an artistic inspiration to you?

headline: VisionChina Signs  New Deal With Beijing Subway
text: The Chinese digital advertising company, VisionChina Media, said Wednesday that it had signed a five-year contract with Beijing’s subway system, The Associated Press reported.

text: Today’s word, in association with the brilliant Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: C.P.P. Bids $3.4 Billion for Australia’s Intoll
text: Canada’s second-biggest pension manager has made a C$3.5 billion ($3.4 billion) takeover approach for the Australian toll-road operator,  Intoll Group, sending shares in the target soaring more than 30 percent, Reuters reported.

headline: Private Equity Firms Said to Consider Bid for NBTY
text: The private equity firms Blackstone Group and Carlyle may acquire the American  nutritional supplements maker,  NBTY, Reuters reported on Wednesday, citing a source familiar with the situation.

headline: K.K.R. Said to Raise $800 Million for China Fund
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, whose shares will start trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, is seeking to raise $800 million to invest in China, Asia’s biggest private- equity market, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: What’s the Best Public Outdoor Space in Your Area?
text: Here in New York City, there are, of course, many famous parks and beaches, but the recent success of the High Line seems to be motivating other cities to “reclaim relics” as public space. What do you think is the best public outdoor space in your community? Why?

headline: AECOM Buys Tishman Construction in a Global Move
text: An engineering and design firm, the AECOM Technology Corporation, said on Wednesday that it had acquired the privately held Tishman Construction Corporation, Reuters reported.

headline: Report Warns of Risks to China’s Bank System
text: A week after the Agricultural Bank of China raised nearly $20 billion from global investors in one of the biggest stock offerings in history, analysts are warning about growing risks to China’s banking system.

headline: Markets Finish Flat After Fed’s Report
text: Major indexes ended largely unchanged Wednesday as investors took note of a report that the economic recovery was likely to be slower than expected.

headline: Piraeus Proposes Buying Stakes in Greek Lenders
text: Piraeus Bank, Greece’s fourth- biggest bank, proposed buying “significant” stakes in two state-controlled Greek lenders, signaling the beginning of a possible round of consolidation in the industry, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Negotiator Chosen to Meet Philippine Separatists
text: MANILA  President Benigno S. Aquino III announced Thursday that he would revive talks with Islamic separatists in the southern Philippines, appointing a law professor known for supporting the land rights of Muslims to serve as chief negotiator.

headline: North Korea and U.N. Command to Discuss Warship Sinking
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korean military representatives held preliminary talks on Thursday with the American-led United Nations Command to set up a meeting between generals on both sides to discuss the sinking of a South Korean warship.

headline: Trader Leaves Deutsche for Alphabet Management
text: Nelson Saiers, a managing director for proprietary derivatives trading at Deutsche Bank, left Germany’s biggest lender to work for Alphabet Management, a hedge fund that specializes in options, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Lions Gate Said to Renew M.G.M. Advances
text: The prospect of a Lions Gate–Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer merger appears to be heating up, after Lions Gate reportedly made a formal merger presentation to the steering committee of creditors overseeing its rival.

headline: Jones Soda Raises $1 Million in Deal With Investor
text: Jones Soda said Wednesday that it planned  raise about $1.1 million in a private stock sale to Glengrove Small Cap Value, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Future of Finance: International Edition
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Tennessee Titans 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Abu Dhabi Fund and Prudential in Property Venture
text: An Abu Dhabi state investment company is teaming up with Prudential Financial to invest in real estate in the Emirati capital and abroad, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Oxford Resource Shares Drop in Market Debut
text: Shares of Oxford Resource Partners dropped in their market debut, after the steam coal producer priced shares of its initial public offering near the bottom of a reduced range, The Associated Press reported.

headline: BNY Mellon’s Wealth Management Arm Weighs  Deals
text: After clinching a deal last month to expand into Canada, the chief of Bank of New York Mellon‘s wealth management arm is apparently hunting for more acquisitions.

headline: Lehman’s Big JPMorgan Case Set for Trial In 2012
text: No one ever said the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy case would be easy, or quick.

headline: Glaxo Plans $2.3 Billion Liability Charge
text: GlaxoSmithKline, the British pharmaceutical company, said on Thursday that it would take a second-quarter charge of $2.36 billion related to legal cases involving its drugs Avandia and Paxil.

headline: American Creativity in Decline
text: Today’s idea: For the first time, research shows American creativity in decline, but an article says neuroscience could help reverse the drop, if only educators would get on board.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Exceeds Forecasts
text: JPMorgan Chase & Company kicked off earnings season for the nation’s big banks on Thursday with news of a strong gain in second-quarter profit.

headline: N.T.T. Pays $3.2 Billion for Dimension
text: The Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corporation has put some of that $10 billion burning a hole in its pocket to use in a $3.2 billion deal to buy South Africa’s Dimension Data.

headline: In a Boost for Sillerman, CKX Amends Poison Pill
text: It seems that the play by the former CKX chief,  Robert F. X. Sillerman,  to take over CKX, the majority owner of the “American Idol” brand, just got a little easier.

headline: Carlyle to Buy NBTY, a Vitamin Maker
text: The Carlyle Group agreed on Thursday to buy NBTY, a maker of vitamins and nutritional supplements, for $3.8 billion in cash, in one of the largest leveraged buyouts of the year.

headline: Then and Now: The Retreating Glaciers
text: In 1921, George Mallory, a British mountaineer, took a black-and-white photograph of Mount Everest. The photo, now legendary, shows the world’s highest peak in the distance and an S-shaped river of ice running toward the foreground: the Rongbuk glacier.

headline: JPMorgan’s Second-Quarter Profit Rises 76%
text: JPMorgan Chase kicked off earnings season for the nation’s big banks on Thursday with news of a strong gain in second-quarter profit, The New York Times reported.

headline: The Finnjet Art Car Fails at Auction
text: The fantastically frivolous Finnjet probably won’t be taking off for a new home anytime soon.

text: And in Today’s Morning Take-Out:

headline: Goldman Said to Propose ‘All-in-One’ Settlement
text: Goldman Sachs and the Securities and Exchange Commission have held settlement talks about the possibility of simultaneously resolving the fraud lawsuit against the bank and some of the agency’s lower-profile probes of the firm’s mortgage department, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Shares Struggle on Weak Manufacturing Data
text: The markets struggled to gain ground on Thursday amid economic worries and concerns about the effects of legislation that Congress passed governing on the financial sector.

headline: The Early Word: All Economy
text: President Obama travels to Holland, Mich., to attend the groundbreaking of the last of nine factories that Compact Power, an electric car company, will build using stimulus funds.

headline: Gaza-Bound Ship Docks in Egypt Instead
text: CAIRO  A Libyan ship that tried to break Israel’s blockade of Gaza docked in the Egyptian port of El Arish on Thursday afternoon as the ship’s sponsor, a son of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said that the boat had shifted course because the Israeli government agreed to allow Libya to support building and reconstruction in Gaza.

headline: Sports Comedy for Sports Non-Fans: Recapping the 2010 ESPYs
text: Whether you’re a die-hard sports fan or someone who regards athletic competitions as an unpleasant reminder of gym classes past (a description that may or may not apply to this blogger), the 2010 ESPY Awards offered plenty to laugh at. Hosted by Seth Meyers of “Saturday Night Live,” with crucial assists from some of the top names in film and television comedy, the awards show, on Wednesday night, found entertaining ways to engage the attention of viewers who long ago lost track of whether or not Brett Favre is still playing in the N.F.L.

headline: Buried Maritime History in Lower Manhattan
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Nocturnalist | Liberté, Egalité, Rosé
text: There were garlicky escargots in ramekins, liquorish-scented pastis in glasses and pommes frites in wax-paper sleeves along the bar at a bistro in TriBeCa on Wednesday night —  all tossed back by scores of French and French-loving patrons under a ceiling clustered with blue, white and red balloons. They raised glasses of rosé to July 14, Bastille Day.

headline: Carter, Reagan, Revenue
text: One common reaction of conservatives, when you point out that the experience of the last 20 years offers zero support for the idea that tax cuts pay for themselves, is to start shouting “Jimmy Carter! Reagan! Supply side roolz!”

headline: Acer’s Race to No. 1 Continues
text: From time to time, Acer executives will pound their chests and announce plans for the company to overtake Hewlett-Packard as the world’s top computer seller. The proclamations have historically elicited chuckles from the PC peanut gallery, which has viewed such a feat as rather unlikely.

headline: McIlroy Sets a Fast Pace at St. Andrews
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The early starters in the British Open awakened as if in a dream Thursday, to a still, soft morning with a light misting rain. If this really was St. Andrews, and that really was the Old Course sitting out there defenseless, wrapped up in a ribbon for the taking, then it was time to make a move or get out of the way.

headline: Charles Mackerras, a Wide-Ranging Conductor, Dies at 84
text: Charles Mackerras, a conductor who championed the work of Czech composers, especially Janacek, and had associations with many of Britain’s major orchestras and opera houses, died Wednesday night, his management agency said. He was 84.

headline: A Brief Note On Comment Policy
text: Various people moderate comments on this blog. Sometimes it takes a while; if your comment hasn’t shown up yet, it’s not about you, it’s because nobody was available. And no, there isn’t a conspiracy to reject unfavorable comments.

headline: A.B.A. Takes Its Final Swat at Financial Bill
text: The American Bankers Association, no great fan of numerous parts of the financial regulatory bill, has taken one last shot at the legislation ahead of its expected final passage by the Senate on Thursday. The A.B.A.’s president, Edward L. Yingling, warned in a statement that the bill “unnecessarily adds to the already crushing regulatory burden faced by traditional banks.”

headline: Christian Marclay at the Whitney: Two Critics Weigh In
text: “Christian Marclay: Festival” at the Whitney Museum is aptly titled, since some form of music, much of it live, will be audible at all times during the show’s run. In the late 1970s, Mr. Marclay, an artist-composer-performer, became one of the first musicians to use a turntable as an instrument, but he is equally known in the art world for music-related collages and skillfully edited videos. His penchant for placing equal emphasis on the visual and the aural permeates the Whitney show. Most of the works on display — whether they are made of found objects, images, album covers, LPs, clothes, film footage or texts — can be used as musical scores. And they will be used, often several times during the show’s run, by a rotating roster of musicians that includes some of the biggest names from the avant-garde music scene. An artist as dedicated to mixing media as Mr. Marclay deserves the attention of critics from more than one discipline. Roberta Smith, the New York Times art critic who reviewed the exhibition on July 8, and Nate Chinen, one of The Times’s music critics, discuss his work from their respective perspectives.

headline: ‘Bloody Bloody’ Will Do Broadway, With Its Original Andrew Jackson
text: Though he was better known as an opponent of the Electoral College and the Second Bank of the United States than a lover of the theater, Andrew Jackson is finally headed to Broadway. headline: This Time the Dream’s on Me
text: The relationship between movies and dreams has always been — to borrow a term from psychoanalysis — overdetermined. From its first flickerings around the time Freud was working on “The Interpretation of Dreams,” cinema seemed to replicate the uncanny, image-making power of the mind, much as still photography had in the decades before. And over the course of the 20th century, cinema provided a vast, perpetually replenishing reservoir of raw material for the fantasies of millions of people. Freud believed that dreams were compounded out of the primal matter of the unconscious and the prosaic events of daily life. If he were writing now, he would have to acknowledge that they are also, for many of us, made out of movies.

headline: 36 Hours in Nantucket
text: NEAR the beginning of “Moby-Dick,” Ishmael explains why he decided to set sail from Nantucket: “There was a fine, boisterous something about everything connected with that famous old island.” Today, nearly 160 years after being written, that characterization still rings true. Though its downtown cobblestone streets and windswept fringes are now filled with expensive (some say exorbitant) restaurants and elegant cocktail bars, the island still has a swagger. To see it in full swing, linger over pints at one of the many harborside pubs, especially at sundown when sailors and fishing boats return to port.

headline: Asked & Answered | Musician/Mathematician Caribou
text: “I really thought people were going to dislike this album,” said Caribou (a k a Dan Snaith), whose new album, “Swim,” recently topped the electronic and college music charts. “I just thought it would be too weird and eccentric for people.” To hear for yourself, check out Caribou this Friday, July 16, when he performs on Governors Island. The Moment caught up with the London-based musician who spoke to us by phone from the back of a rental van en route to New York.“Swim” is decidedly less pop than your past recordings. How did you arrive at this intensive electronic dance music sound?When I finished “Andorra” [Caribou’s 2008 album] and started composing and arranging music for this album, I started making two different records: one with tracks to D.J. that were more dance oriented and another focused on composition. The two approaches synthesized, and the result is “Swim.”

headline: On Florida Beaches, Let There Be Dark
text: .The BP oil gusher has focused attention on just one of many threats to sea turtles. One that is likely far more significant is simply artificial light. I encourage you to watch this video shot earlier this month on the beach in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., showing sea turtle hatchlings emerging from their sandy nests at night and, attracted by the city lights, heading inland instead of out to sea. The city has an ordinance mandating dark beaches, but it’s a tough one to enforce, it seems. Below you can read an excerpt from the blog post on the video at Ocean Wire that alerted me (along with Twitterers Ken Peterson and seaturtle.org):

headline: Postcards From the ‘Tour d’Admission': End of the Road
text: For seven summers, a group of college counselors from across the country have climbed on bicycles to travel from college to college on an informal, saddle-bound fact-finding mission, a kind of Tour d’Admission. This summer, the group has set its tour in California, and the participants will be filing regular dispatches to The Choice from the road. Today’s dispatch is from Kirk Blackard, director of college guidance at Christ School of Asheville, N.C, and Bruce Hunter, director of college counseling at Rowland Hall in Salt Lake City. Bill Dingledine, president of the Southern Association for College Admission Counseling and an independent counselor from Greenville, S.C., contributed to this article.

headline: Success With Starlings, and Meeting the Chief
text: We awoke early this morning to put in a long day of trapping in the village. The kids should be back in school, so we hoped that we would be able to work without too much disruption. Wilson drove over just after sunrise to begin setting up while I finished getting a few things ready at camp. While walking over to the village a few minutes later, I noticed a large mixed-species flock of starlings foraging on the ground in an enclosed area of houses. Although Wilson had found a few smaller flocks foraging in the village, they were moving around quickly and would be difficult to catch. We decided to move our gear to this new area instead. Within a few minutes of setting out the traps, the birds were cautiously exploring our bait. In under an hour, we caught three birds — all superb starlings. Things were looking up.

headline: Austan Goolsbee, Renaissance Man?

headline: Prayers For Christopher Hitchens
text: The whole public discussion about whether Christians and other believers should be praying for Christopher Hitchens, currently stricken with throat cancer, strikes me as a rather unfortunate exercise. Surely it goes without saying that he should be prayed for, but surely it would be better if the people doing the praying kept it to themselves a little more. Talking about it all the time can seem a bit smug, or even Pharisaical. You may recall that Jesus had some rather sharp remarks about this sort of thing:

headline: Ristretto | Espresso Apollo (The Eagle Has Landed)
text: Two weeks ago, Bluebird Coffee Shop in the East Village was one of three coffee bars in the United States to take a new espresso blend from Counter Culture Coffee for a test drive. It was shipped with the tantalizing label “Espresso X,” even though the name had already been chosen: Espresso Apollo, after the god of light.

headline: Jared Paul Stern Selling Country House
text: JARED PAUL STERN was a gossip columnist for The New York Post until four years ago, when a scandal forced him off Page Six. Now Mr. Stern, who writes for the Web site Luxist and has a clothing line called Skull & Bones, is selling his country house in Albany County, near Oak Hill, N.Y. A late-19th-century three-bedroom, it is listed for $379,000.

headline: The Oyster Economy
text: As oily waters threaten Louisiana's oyster industry, the economic impact is stretching further onto higher ground.

headline: Flexing Mom Muscles
text: BESIDES a night of uninterrupted sleep, there’s nothing new mothers crave more than getting back into prebaby shape. In New York they can get a little help with that by taking one of several exercise classes created just for them. Besides addressing the needs of women who’ve recently given birth by strengthening the abdomen, toning the arms and trimming the hips, most of these workout options allow baby along too.

headline: In California, a University Tries to Enroll Students that Reflect a Diverse State
text: Which college in the United States gets the most applicants? It’s not Harvard or Yale; it’s the University of California, Los Angeles.

headline: Back in Time on Governors Island and at Lincoln Center
text: Misers who long for the wild abandon of the Roaring Twenties but don’t want to spend Gatsby’s fortune in the process should take one of the free ferries from Manhattan or Brooklyn to Governors Island this weekend for the annual Jazz Age Lawn Party. Picnickers can relax on the lawn at Colonels Row, while daddy-o’s and flapper girls get hot to the music of Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra. There will be Charleston lessons, pie-recipe contests, hat parades and other revelries from the era. Period attire is encouraged, and outside food is welcome, but alcohol must be purchased on the island. The lawn party is Saturday and Sunday, as well as on Aug. 28 and 29, from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; $10 to enter; $7 in advance. (A five-minute walk from the Manhattan ferry landing, near Castle Williams; dreamlandorchestra.com or govisland.com.)

headline: From a Gulf Oyster, a Domino Effect
text: BAYOU GRAND CAILLOU, La.

headline: Rendering the Landscape Less Traveled By
text: Rackstraw Downes paints beautiful pictures of ugly places. He is drawn to the kind of spots in Manhattan and its environs that most people hurry past: dank, cavernous areas with dirty puddles below highway and subway overpasses, industrial buildings and their parking lots, litter-strewn ditches, lumber and scrap yards, sidewalks passing by cyclone fencing trimmed by razor wire. In Texas, where he winters, he paints bleak, flat, sun-baked landscapes relieved by metal barns and oil well pumps.

text: DealBook’s Cyrus Sanati is watching the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s press conference regarding its $550 million settlement with Goldman Sachs. The event is being led by Robert Khuzami, the agency’s director of enforcement.

headline: New ‘Clear Day’ Will Get an Off-Broadway Run
text: Off Broadway’s Vineyard Theater will present director Michael Mayer’s new version of the musical “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever” beginning in January 2011, with a reworked book by Peter Parnell that is expected to include many changes in the story from earlier stage and film incarnations.

headline: Have You Friended Your Teachers on Facebook?
text: Life is high school. And middle school. And elementary school. Or so it seems from the many people who just can’t let go of their feelings for a particular teacher, even well into middle age.

headline: It’s Just a Phone
text: It’s just a phone.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Art

headline: Paws and Tails Welcome at a Disney Resort
text: Things seem to just keep getting better for pets. First came dog purses and pet day spas, then came catios – patios for cats. Now there is even travel tailored to dogs.But Best Friends Pet Care is taking pet travel to new heights — and excess — with a 50,000-square-foot resort at Walt Disney World in Florida for your four-legged friend.

headline: Life on the Road, Colectivo Style
text: There’s a six-leg route to get from Chachapoyas, Peru, to Vilcabamba, Ecuador, the first major tourist attraction over the border. The very, very helpful folks at the official iPeru tourist office in Chachapoyas (and they were even better in Arequipa) make it easy with a printout of the step-by-step process, together with prices. Getting there with a mix of collective taxis, minivans and buses takes a day or two.

headline: Pitchforked | Where to Eat in Chicago This Weekend
text: This weekend, Pitchfork hosts its fifth music festival: three days of indie bands, vinyl sales and craftsy tables for the man-Keds crowd, culminating in Pavement’s reunion show on Sunday night. We asked Chicago food and music experts where to eat and drink (and shop) between, say, Wolf Parade and LCD Soundsystem.

headline: Marclay at the Whitney: Calling Bruce
text: Today Roberta Smith, a Times art critic, and Nate Chinen, one of The Times’s music critics, discuss Christian Marclay’s work from their respective perspectives. “Christian Marclay: Festival” runs through Sept. 26 at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
