headline: An Obsessive Director’s Revolutionary, Unrealized Film
text: The legend of the lost masterpiece is a staple of cinematic lore, and every so often material surfaces to give credence to the myths. The recent restoration of Fritz Lang’s  “Metropolis”  brings today’s audience a big step closer to seeing that groundbreaking film in the form its director intended, and the combination of archival digging and serendipity has shed light on many other significant works that have been forgotten or compromised.

headline: Pelosi Makes Nice With the White House
text: Probably not a shocker: Nancy Pelosi, in public at least, looks like she wants to move on past the White House press secretary’s recent assertion that control of the House is up for grabs in November.

headline: BP, Shell and the Design of Deep Wells
text: You’ve doubtless heard that BP has, on the 87th day of the oil gusher and in its 10th try, apparently stopped the flow of oil from its Macondo well (the current stoppage is a test of the new system). That’s great news, of course, presuming the tests show that the well, from top to bottom, can hold the immense pressure of the gas and oil still pressing upward from deep in the earth. Otherwise, the process could lead to new leaks beneath the seabed, just as turning off the nozzle on a damaged garden hose causes leaks to spring elsewhere.

headline: New PR Team for ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: The Broadway press agent Adrian Bryan-Brown and his firm, Boneau/Bryan-Brown, have resigned from the forthcoming musical production of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the lead producer of the show said on Thursday.

headline: In the Catskills, Unable to Give Up Crime
text: Dave Gurney has just retired as New York City’s star homicide detective and moved to the foothills of the Catskills to begin a new life, a situation not unlike that of first-time novelist John Verdon. (Not the homicide part, presumably.) Mr. Verdon was an advertising executive who retired to upstate New York before deciding on a more artistic pursuit. And if “Think of a Number” is any indication, he’ll have no trouble forgetting about that day job. The transition couldn’t be much smoother.

headline: I Write Like … Yeah, Right
text: The literary blogosphere has been buzzing for a few days now about I Write Like, a new “analyzer” that lets you plug in some of your prose to see which famous writer you most sound like.

headline: Con Ed to Pay $1 Million to Settle Inquiry Into Fatal Explosion
text: State utilities regulators agreed on Thursday to allow Consolidated Edison to pay $1 million to end an investigation into an April 2009 gas explosion that destroyed a house in Queens and killed one of its residents.

headline: Intimate Interiors, Vividly Revealed
text: Black and white has long been the default setting for South African photography, the obvious way to acknowledge systematic oppression. Black and white also confers a journalistic seriousness, as in the work of David Goldblatt and Roger Ballen (and maybe even nonphotographers like William Kentridge).

headline: Wandering in Dublin With Dylan
text: The music of Bob Dylan winds through Lance Daly’s “Kisses” like the call of a twangy pied piper beckoning two preteen runaways deeper into the night as they wander through the streets of Dublin after dark at Christmastime. A small slice of Irish kitchen-sink realism embellished with fairy-tale fantasy,  “Kisses”  may strike you as either ingeniously magical or insufferably cute, depending on your taste. But more than the story, which circles back on itself, the natural performances of its young stars, Shane Curry and especially Kelly O’Neill, nonprofessional actors, lend the movie a core of integrity.

headline: So Print Is Kaput?
text: Several new journals, and a recent visit to a great little magazine shop in Berlin, again make one think we are entering a differentage of print. (Of special interest is Tony Judt’s moving essay “Words” in The New York Review of Books.) Though it’s clear that mainstream publications are challenged by the Internet, small magazines keep turning up. One of the funnier, readable fashion mags to come along in a while is I Like My Style Quarterly, a spinoff of ilikemystyle.net, a social network site started two years ago by Adriano Sack. He’s a journalist who divides his time between Berlin and New York and writes a style column for the German newspaper Welt am Sonntag. I Like My Style is about the size of a small-town phone book with a ruggedly assured world view of style seekers.

headline: West Side Project Wins Grant for Urban Design
text: The National Endowment for the Arts on Thursday announced $3 million in grants to city governments and other organizations around the country for urban design projects, including $100,000 for advanced work on a cultural building planned as part of the redevelopment of the railyards on the West Side of Manhattan. The idea for the building, which has been little noted in the New York cultural world until now, envisions a new breed of cultural site  a kind of combination museum and rental exhibition space, which would be self-supporting.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tehran and Elsewhere
text: An Iranian scientist returned to Tehran on Thursday to an uncertain future. American officials say he gave “significant, original” information about his country’s nuclear program but then turned his back on a C.I.A.-provided resettlement package of around $5 million, David E. Sanger and Mark Mazzetti report.

headline: Beautifully Bleak
text: An interactive look at the work of the artist Rackstraw Downes.

headline: For a Good Cause, A Fourth of Mahler
text: Playing Mahler for charity seems to be a slowly growing phenomenon. In 2006 Neeme Jarvi conducted members of the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the New Jersey Symphony and other ensembles in a performance of Mahler’s Second Symphony (“Resurrection”) in a benefit for Riverside Church. Last year George Mathew presided over “Mahler for the Children of AIDS,” a charity concert in which a similarly constituted orchestra played the Third Symphony at Carnegie Hall.

headline: My Wile E. Coyote Moment
text: No, not one of these. Out back, near the stream, we got a good view of something too big to be a fox.

headline: ‘Think of a Number’
text: Chapter 1: Cop art

headline: Tylenol Plant Lays Off 300
text: A unit of Johnson & Johnson involved in recent recalls of Tylenol and other over-the-counter drugs said late Thursday afternoon that it would overhaul manufacturing at the company plant that made the affected drugs, laying off about 75 percent of the plant’s employees.

headline: Bring Your Squeegee
text: HOW do you get 1.6 million people onto a 20-square-mile island?

headline: No. 17 Bares Its Teeth at British Open
text: ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND — If the intent was to make a difficult hole more difficult, British Open organizers appear to have succeeded. The modified par-4 17th hole was by far the most challenging hole on the Old Course during the first round of the British Open. That should come as no surprise considering the decision to move the tee back 40 yards this year, increasing the hole’s length to 495 yards.

headline: Crickets, Bonfires And Dance Alfresco
text: MOUNT TREMPER, N.Y.

headline: A Water Island Compound Is Private, but Not Too Remote
text: ALAN WANZENBERG, an architect based in New York City, was the longtime partner of Jed Johnson, the designer and Andy Warhol protégé who died in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 in 1996.

headline: Mystery at Drayton Hall: Hunt for a Watercolor
Cartoons Are Invading the Upper East Side
Brush Up Your Shakespeare; Brush Off the Sets
text: WORDS, words, words. Not sets, lights or props.

headline: Access to Testimony at Issue in Polanski Case
text: LOS ANGELES  After Swiss authorities this week refused to extradite Roman Polanski to the United States because they were denied access to secret testimony about his expected sentence on a decades-old sex charge, officials in Washington and Los Angeles were left facing an uncomfortable question: Why was a judge in the case allowed to believe that the Swiss had no interest in the sealed account?

headline: Theatrical Smorgasbord
text: A guide to other summer theater festivals for the adventurous.

headline: Strike at Bazaar Spreads Beyond Tehran
text: A strike at the traditional bazaar in Tehran continued into a second week on Thursday, spreading beyond the original gold and garments sectors and to at least two other major cities, news Web sites reported.

headline: Bringing Fun to Brooklyn
text: MARTY MARKOWITZ’S duties as the Brooklyn borough president include appointing community board members and overseeing a budget for capital projects. But one morning this week his platform was all about fun, which he advocated with all the vigor of a contested campaign issue.

headline: Tragedy and Comedy, Starring Pac-Man
text: What if the gorilla in Donkey Kong is really an abusive, down-on-his-luck meathead straight out of a Tennessee Williams script who keeps his handicapped blond paramour (the princess) captive in their top-floor apartment, periodically thrashing the Italian building superintendent (Mario), who attempts to climb the stairs to alleviate the woman’s suffering?

headline: Dance New Amsterdam Gets Reprieve On Eviction
text: Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan (above, Foofwa d’Imobilité in “Musings” there in January), has received a postponement of an eviction from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway, Catherine Peila, the group’s executive director, said. The organization owes more than half a million dollars in back rent to Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month. Amsterdam representatives were to appear in court on Wednesday but reached an agreement with Fram Realty on Tuesday to postpone eviction proceedings until Aug. 26, Ms. Peila said. “The landlord will come back to us in a week with new terms,” she said in an interview. “Before Aug. 26, our goal is to have a lower rent so we can continue as a viable organization. We also want the city to consider a tax abatement.” Dance New Amsterdam has received more than $7,000 in donations, Ms. Peila said. Fram Realty did not respond to a message seeking comment.

headline: ‘Piranha 3-d’ Scene Won’t Play at Comic-Con
text: The director of “Piranha 3-D,” Alexandre Aja, has a message for Comic-Con, the annual pop confab: You don’t want my R-rated footage of a wet T-shirt contest that turns into a bloodbath? Then I don’t need you. Comic-Con, which starts on Thursday in San Diego, decided recently that “Piranha 3-D” footage Mr. Aja planned to show at the convention was too graphic and that he could tone it down to, say, the PG-13 level or have a panel discussion without it. Mr. Aja, whose films include “The Hills Have Eyes,” went with a third option. The “Piranha 3-D” presentation will now take place at 10 p.m. Thursday at the UA Horton Plaza, a theater near the San Diego Convention Center. “It’s frustrating,” Mr. Aja said by phone from Montreal, where he is finishing the picture, “because I was so excited to show this at Comic-Con  I made the movie for that crowd.” Yes, but “Piranha 3-D,” out Aug. 20, wouldn’t have captured nearly as much attention with the initial plan.

headline: ‘Harry Potter’ Lawsuit Comes To the U.S.
text: The plagiarism accusations that dogged J. K. Rowling in Britain have now reached Scholastic, her American publisher. The estate of Adrian Jacobs, an author who died in 1997, filed suit in United States District Court in New York on Tuesday, asserting that Ms. Rowling’s fourth “Harry Potter” book, “Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire,” was partly copied from Mr. Jacobs’s 1987 book, “The Adventures of Willy the Wizard.” Mr. Jacobs’s estate previously brought similar legal action against Ms. Rowling and her British publisher, Bloomsbury. Those cases have not been resolved. Kyle Good, a spokeswoman for Scholastic, said on Thursday that the publisher considered the claims in the lawsuit to be “completely without merit.” Ms. Rowling has said that she had not heard of Mr. Jacobs until 2004, and had not read his book.

headline: Guggenheim Director Solidifies Abu Dhabi Role
text: The director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, Richard Armstrong, below, appears to be consolidating control over the development of the Guggenheim’s enormous new branch in Abu Dhabi. When Mr. Armstrong took over the Guggenheim in 2008 from Thomas Krens, who began the Abu Dhabi project, the Guggenheim said Mr. Krens would continue consulting on it, setting up what seemed like a potentially difficult power-sharing arrangement. But the Guggenheim’s spokeswoman, Eleanor Goldhar, said this week that Mr. Krens’s involvement would conclude by the end of the year. Asked if that was a change of plans, Ms. Goldhar said that Mr. Krens’s role “was always connected to the creation of the building,” designed by Frank Gehry, rather than the planning of the museum’s program. But at the time that Mr. Krens stepped down as director, and as recently as last year in an interview in the Russian-language magazine Snob, Mr. Krens seemed to envision a larger role. Mr. Krens, who did not respond to requests for comment, pioneered the concept of the global museum during his 20-year tenure at the Guggenheim, opening branches in Bilbao, Spain; Berlin; and Las Vegas.

headline: A Death Proves a Draw for ‘Deadliest Catch’
text: About 8.5 million viewers watched the “Deadliest Catch” episode on Tuesday night that documented the death of one of the reality show’s stars, Capt. Phil Harris. It was the highest-rated broadcast for the Discovery Channel in 10 years, the channel said, and the third-highest in its history, behind “Raising the Mammoth” and “Walking With Dinosaurs,” in 2000. Tuesday’s episode was the culmination of a month’s worth of shows about the aftermath of a stroke Captain Harris suffered last winter in the midst of filming. It did not depict the captain’s death but did include his emotional conversations with his sons, Josh and Jake Harris. Later, Josh was shown calling Jake and breaking the news of their father’s death. He said, “We lost Dad, dude.”

headline: ‘Andrew Jackson’ to Move to Broadway in the Fall
text: Though he was better known as a fierce foe of American Indians and the Second Bank of the United States than a lover of the theater, Andrew Jackson is finally headed to Broadway. After weeks of rumbling, the Public Theater announced on Thursday that there would be a Broadway transfer of “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” the hit satirical emo-rock musical about the seventh president that ran previously at the Public’s LAB and main stage. The Public said the Broadway production of “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson” would retain its lead, Benjamin Walker, right. The production is headed to the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, where it will begin performances on Sept. 21. It is written and directed by Alex Timbers with music and lyrics by Michael Friedman.

headline: Goldman Pays $550 Million to Settle Fraud Case
text: WASHINGTON  Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay $550 million to settle federal claims that it misled investors in a subprime mortgage product as the housing market began to collapse, officials said Thursday.

headline: ‘Jersey’ Legal Spat Grows
text: Oh, what a nightmare: after a lawsuit brought by several creators of the Broadway musical “Jersey Boys” against four members of the show’s original cast, those performers have filed a vehement counterclaim that’s enough to make big girls  and boys  cry. In March, the “Jersey Boys” playwrights, Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, as well as two Four Seasons band members, Frankie Valli and Bob Gaudio, sued Christian Hoff, J. Robert Spencer, Daniel Reichard and Michael Longoria, all alumni of that show’s cast. At issue was the touring production “The Boys in Concert,” in which the “Jersey Boys” veterans perform songs of the 1960s and ’70s, including some made famous by the Four Seasons. The suit contended that the tour misleadingly suggested a connection to the Tony-winning show. In a counterclaim filed last week in United States District Court in New York, lawyers for the former “Jersey Boys” stars said the creative team and Dodger Theatricals, among the show’s producers, were “motivated by petty vindictiveness and malice” and “using bully tactics better suited for the schoolyard.” They are seeking an injunction allowing them to continue the tour as well as damages of “no less than $1 million” and a jury trial.

headline: Michelle Raab and Angus Mitchell
text: ALTHOUGH Angus Mitchell owns a hair salon in Beverly Hills, Calif., and grew up in the beauty industry, he has always avoided mirrors. “I never liked what I saw,” said Mr. Mitchell, 39.

headline: Triathlon Training With Chopin
text: The water is seeping into my goggles, swishing back and forth. I am trying to turn my head sideways to gasp air. My arms are alternately thrusting forward and pulling back, but they don’t leave enough time to get my mouth above water level. I am not sure what my feet are doing. My body doesn’t seem to cohere. It seems composed of random pieces. I’m starting to lose any sense of rhythmic motion. Everything is happening too fast. This is swimming?

headline: More to Life
text: “To Age or Not to Age,” Robert Kane Pappas’s documentary about scientific experiments in life extension, makes a digressive, disorganized hash of a fascinating topic. Mr. Pappas, who narrates the film, tells of reading articles in The New York Times four years ago about the molecular biology of calorie restriction and how David Sinclair, a Harvard scientist, discovered resveratrol, a substance in the skin of grapes that produced some of the same benefits. Dr. Sinclair had studied at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology under Leonard Guarente, who in 1995 discovered a gene that controlled the longevity of yeast. Dr. Sinclair later teamed up with Christoph Westphal, founder of the biotech company Sirtris, which is working to synthesize a longevity drug based on resveratrol.

headline: Why Good Songs Happen to Bad Schoolboys
text: Before discussing why “With Glee,” a delightfully daffy musical at the Kirk Theater, is the perfect summer show, let’s give credit to Igor Goldin, its director, and Antoinette DiPietropolo, its choreographer, for some spectacular inside-the-box thinking.

headline: Fools for Love
text: About a year ago, I fooled around with a guy friend whom I’d been interested in for a long time. That night, he told me he’d wanted to do so for a long time, too. We used to talk for hours and hang out all the time. Now, it’s awkward between us, and I don’t know why. We hardly speak when we bump into each other, and we never arrange to meet. Neither of us are “feelings” people; still, I’d love to talk with him about this. I know it won’t make him love me, but should I do it anyway?

headline: A Jazzman and a Witch Rendezvous in the Park
text: The New York Philharmonic usually fills the programs for its Concerts in the Parks series with crowd pleasers from the heart of the classical canon, and that is probably as it should be. Part of the mission, after all, is to persuade listeners who have come out of curiosity, or who love the music but are not Philharmonic regulars, to consider hearing the orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Geniuses to the Rescue With the Aid of Teenagers
text: If you go looking for “Friday Night Lights” this Friday night and find what looks like a Hallmark Channel movie instead, don’t be alarmed; your show will return. For this week, Procter & Gamble and Wal-Mart are filling a couple of hours of NBC’s schedule with “The Jensen Project,” the second in a series of “family-friendly” television movies the two consumer giants are producing.

headline: Bite Apple, Kiss, Sing: How Paradise Was Lost
text: At this point in history it cannot be easy to find anything original to say about original sin. Theologians and poets and painters have been ruminating on the fall of man for many a long century. Still, the new show “Falling for Eve,” which recounts the early days of biblical creation in alternately jokey and sentimental fashion, makes for a numbingly bland 90 minutes of musical theater. Sinning has rarely seemed so insipid.

headline: A Nordic Epic
text: Nicolas Winding Refn’s desire to be taken seriously as a filmmaker would be touching if it weren’t so insistent. The first thing you see in  “Valhalla Rising”  is his name stretching the full width of the screen, the letters several feet high if you’ve taken the trouble to go to a theater.

headline: Theater Listings: July 16 — 22
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: A History of How We Got From Here to There
text: Wanderlust is a good impulse for the Soho Think Tank to follow right now; after 16 years of cultivating some of the city’s most innovative theater artists at the Ohio Theater, this Obie award-winning company has to vacate its Wooster Street home. The Think Tank will soon begin a three-year residency at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan. After that, who knows?

headline: Appeals Court Rules Filmmaker Must Give Some Footage to Chevron
text: 8:27 p.m. | Updated

headline: Secret Laughs
text: Mildly amusing for the first 30 minutes, “Operation: Endgame” is a foul-mouthed spoof of secret-agent silliness. Set on the day of President Obama’s inauguration, the movie descends into a sterile, fluorescent-lit bunker to observe two rival teams of government assassins, all named for Tarot cards and all seriously disturbed.

headline: Goldman’s Fine: 10.2 Market Days of Earnings
text: 7:30 p.m. | Updated A colleague pointed out that we should use only days on which the market was open for our calculations. That means the Goldman fine amounts to about 10.2 days of earnings, based on its first-quarter results.

headline: White House Says Stimulus Funds Responsible for Battery Progress
text: On Thursday, as President Obama toured a Michigan electric car battery plant supported with $151 million in stimulus money, his administration was on the offensive to prove that the Recovery Act had been money well spent. Part of that push is focusing on the “tens of thousands of American jobs” that have come out of federal battery investments.

headline: Financial Reform
text: David Gillen, deputy business editor, talks with Nelson D. Schwartz, business reporter, on how banks will deal with the financial reform legislation.

headline: The Rich and the Miserable
text: A baffling journey to a pointless destination,  “The Contenders”  offers a suffocating wallow in the lives of the rich and miserable. Confined to a single location — a snazzy beachfront property — and a lone weekend, the action (such as it is) centers on four friends who have convened to celebrate the birthday of a fifth. Rather ungraciously the guest of honor dies in an off-camera bedroom before the rest of the group can murder her with their tongues.

headline: That Reyes & Beltran Reunion Will Have to Wait
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A mere 23 minutes after posting their lineup via e-mail, the Mets made a change and Jose Reyes was scratched for Thursday’s game against the Giants.

headline: It’s Over for Goldman, but Not for Fabrice Tourre
text: Fabrice P. Tourre, the “fabulous Fab” in the Goldman Sachs securities fraud case, is still facing plenty of legal problems.

headline: Goldman Says Settlement Is ‘the Right Outcome’
text: Goldman Sachs has released a statement regarding its $550 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The full text of the response is below.

headline: Up Front: Daniel Handler
text: If you have children, you probably know Daniel Handler as Lemony Snicket, the persecuted biographer of the Baudelaire siblings in “A Series of Unfortunate Events.”

headline: Innocence Lost
text: Nothing conforms to expectations like a novel that subverts expectations. John Brandon’s terrific new novel, “Citrus County,” opens with a slap in the face to the adage that an author ought to identify his hero by having him do something nice for a kid:

headline: Henry Says He Joined Red Bulls to Win
text: HARRISON, N.J.  The scoreboards at Red Bull Arena announced the arrival of the club’s newest star: “Bienvenue Thierry Henry!”

headline: Love Among Pompeii’s Ruins Extends to Dogs
text: POMPEII, Italy — One of Pompeii’s most famous mosaics is of a leashed dog with the warning “cave canem,” or beware of the dog.

text: As they drove together along the back roads of Kennedy International Airport on a surveillance mission, the older of the two men pointed out the fuel tanks yet again, re-emphasizing the main target of the terrorist attack they had been planning for months.

headline: Obama Pushes Agenda, Despite Political Risks
text: WASHINGTON  If passage of the financial regulatory overhaul on Thursday proves anything about President Obama, it is this: He knows how to push big bills through a balky Congress.

headline: Financier Gets 12 Years for Stealing $292 Million
text: A Park Avenue financier and political donor who pleaded guilty to stealing $292 million from three banks in a Ponzi scheme was sentenced on Thursday to 12 years in prison.

headline: Transit Cuts, an Agony Without End
text: Wednesday was Bastille Day, a fitting day for public hearings on the latest cuts planned for the subways. You just knew there was a guillotine around, poised to drop on a lot of people.

headline: When the Bride Takes a Bride, Businesses Respond
text: EAST POINT, Ga.  When the Palladinos were planning their wedding, they found that traditional bridal magazines were all but useless in addressing their particular questions.

headline: The Diaspora Need Not Apply
text: WHO is a Jew? It’s an age-old inquiry, one that has for decades (if not centuries) provoked debate, discussion and too many punch lines to count  all inspired by what many assumed was the question’s essential unanswerability. But if developments this week are any indication, the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, might soon offer an official, surprising answer: almost no one.

headline: Introduced as Nets G.M., King Stresses Teamwork
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Dressed in a black suit and red tie, Nets Coach Avery Johnson stood to the side of the stage while Billy King was introduced as the franchise’s general manager.

headline: Lazio Appears Far Behind Cuomo in Fund-Raising
text: Republican hopes of recapturing the governor’s mansion in Albany have just taken a serious financial hit.

headline: China: Charges in Wrongful Jailing Case
text: Six police officers have been charged in a case of police torture that emerged in April when a man who had been wrongly jailed for 10 years for killing a fellow villager was freed, state media reported Thursday. Five officers in Henan Province have been charged with forcing a confession from the wrongly imprisoned man, Zhao Zuohai, and one officer has been charged with dereliction of duty, according to China Daily. Based on the false confession and a body found in the village well, Mr. Zhao had been convicted of killing a man. In June, the supposed victim turned up alive.

headline: Keeping Score: Who Was Best for the Boss?
text: George Steinbrenner had many great players after he took over the Yankees in 1973, and some of them will be back in the Bronx on Saturday at Old-Timers’ Day. But who is the greatest of all?

headline: With a Bow Tie and a Glove, the No. 1 Giant Relishes His Seat
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Bill Neukom sat in the front row of AT&T Park on a cool Friday night earlier this season making eye contact with his San Francisco Giants players and urging them on as they came and went from the dugout.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Obesity Drug
text: A federal advisory committee voted narrowly against endorsing a drug vying to become the first new prescription medicine for obesity in more than a decade, signaling heightened concerns for possible health risks associated with a new generation of diet pills.

text: The penultimate episode of the third season revolved around the assassination of President Kennedy.

text: A look at the day in sports, including scenes from the British Open, the Tour de France and Major League Baseball.

headline: Arizona Halts Photo Enforcement of Speed Laws
text: PHOENIX  At the first tick of the clock Friday, an array of automated cameras on Arizona freeways aimed at catching speeders were to stop clicking.

headline: Sentence Is Sharply Increased for Lawyer Convicted of Aiding Terror
text: A federal judge on Thursday increased the sentence of Lynne F. Stewart, a disbarred lawyer convicted of assisting terrorism, to 10 years  nearly five times as long as her original sentence.

headline: For Cuomo, Both Politics and Family Fit in the R.V.
text: MAHOPAC, N.Y.  Every summer, thousands of recreational vehicles take to the road, lazily cruising down the blacktop across America. This year, one will be carrying the Democratic candidate for governor of New York.

headline: After Years of Anticipation, a Subdued Public Offering for Kohlberg Kravis
text: THE barbarians didn’t exactly storm the gate. Tiptoed was more like it.

headline: In Dresser Drawer, Recalling a Chivalrous Steinbrenner
text: Michael Schriner contacted The Times this week about the friendship between his mother, Mary Jane Schriner, and George Steinbrenner when they were teenagers in Ohio.

headline: Congress Passes Financial Reform
text: There was more than enough in the financial reform bill  now on its way to President Obama  to merit broad support. Yet, for Thursday’s final Senate vote on the bill, 60 to 39, just three Republicans joined 57 Democrats to support reform. In the House, only three Republicans voted for the bill when it passed that chamber in June, 237 to 192.

headline: Bush Aide Says Some C.I.A. Methods Unauthorized
text: WASHINGTON — A former Bush Justice Department official who approved brutal interrogation methods by the C.I.A. has told Congress that he never authorized several other rough tactics reportedly inflicted on terrorism suspects — including prolonged shackling to a ceiling and repeated beatings.

headline: Red Sox Pay Tribute to Steinbrenner at Fenway
text: BOSTON  Baseball’s schedule-makers create any number of twists in the course of a season. But on Thursday, they unintentionally outdid themselves. The Red Sox returned to action after the All-Star break one day before the Yankees did and as a result ended up honoring George Steinbrenner with a moment of silence before the Yankees could stage their own tribute in the Bronx on Friday.

headline: With Settlement, Blankfein Keeps His Grip
text: The word spread through Wall Street just before 3:30 Thursday afternoon: It looked as if Lloyd C. Blankfein had finally struck a deal.

headline: Sponsor of Flotilla Tied to Elite of Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish charity that led the flotilla involved in a deadly Israeli raid has extensive connections with Turkey’s political elite, and the group’s efforts to challenge Israel’s blockade of Gaza received support at the top levels of the governing party, Turkish diplomats and government officials said.

headline: Apple Is Not Expected to Recall Troubled iPhone
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As Apple prepared to address the mounting controversy surrounding the antenna of the iPhone 4, one thing appeared clear: the company does not plan to recall the popular device.

headline: Yankees Plan Salutes to Steinbrenner and Sheppard
text: The Yankees will hold a tribute to George Steinbrenner before Friday night’s game against the Tampa Bay Rays at Yankee Stadium. The tribute will also honor the longtime Yankees announcer Bob Sheppard, who died Sunday, two days before Steinbrenner died.

headline: A Tale of Two Targets
text: The Senate spent this week searching for ways to water down the modest greenhouse gas emissions targets in the House-passed energy bill, which opponents claim  wrongly and shortsightedly  will injure the economy. The British, French and German environmental ministers showed a lot more sense this week.

headline: France Will Not Repay Haiti Reparations
text: Updated | Friday | 9:13 a.m. Some Haitians suspected the announcement was too good to be true: that France would pay their nation $22 billion to make up for forcing the former French colony to pay an equivalent sum in exchange for its independence in the nineteenth century. Well, those who were suspicious were proved right Thursday when an elaborate hoax was revealed.

headline: Harrington’s Faint Hopes
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland – Padraig Harrington will need to turn things around in a hurry if he hopes to get into the weekend with any chance of winning his third British Open. The winner of the 2007 Open at Carnoustie and the 2008 Open at Royal Birkdale, Harrington started with a 73 that included one of two double bogeys made at the easy first hole.

headline: What About Air Safety?
text: Last year’s crash of a commuter plane near Buffalo, which killed 50 people, highlighted the need for more stringent pilot training and tougher rules about how long pilots can fly before they are required to rest.

headline: Now We Know Who’s Winning
text: Finally, there is a surefire way to win at New York City’s off-track betting establishment: Get yourself hired as a consultant. The Off-Track Betting Corporation is officially bankrupt. Yet it still paid out more than $2 million in consulting fees in the last year and now has plans to pay plenty more this year.

headline: Debate Over Arizona Immigration Law Comes to U.S. Court
text: PHOENIX  Partisans in the debate over Arizona’s stringent immigration law squared off for the first time in federal court Thursday, providing an early glimpse into the legal arguments that will be used in the coming battle over the new law.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Remaking Park Ave. Into a Spot to Splash
text: For those New Yorkers who never received a coveted invitation last summer to dive into Dumpsters converted into pools in Brooklyn, there is a much easier alternative this year: Park Avenue.

headline: Redo That Voodoo
text: Republicans are feeling good about the midterms  so good that they’ve started saying what they really think. This week the party’s Senate leadership stopped pretending that it cares about deficits, stating explicitly that while we can’t afford to aid the unemployed or prevent mass layoffs of schoolteachers, cost is literally no object when it comes to tax cuts for the affluent.

headline: For Securities Industry, Finance Law Could Bring New Light to Derivatives
text: When financial markets came unglued two years ago, few Americans had heard of derivatives, much less their more esoteric forms like credit-default swaps and collateralized debt obligations. Since then, derivatives have been central to the debate over how tightly to regulate Wall Street’s freewheeling ways.

headline: The Gospel of Mel Gibson
text: Let us enter, you and I, into the moral universe of the modern narcissist.

headline: Texas Remains Stoic as Spill Hits Its Shores
text: GALVESTON, Tex. — The crayons and paper were out, but not too many children made it to family day at the Ocean Star Offshore Drilling Rig and Museum.

headline: Microsoft Co-Founder to Give Away Half of His Fortune to Philanthropy
text: Paul Allen, who founded the Microsoft Corporation with Bill Gates, announced on Thursday that he planned to give more than half of his estimated $13.5 billion fortune to philanthropy.

headline: An Encouraging Sign in Loan Loss Reserves
text: Don’t count on a rebound in business to lift bank stocks — but they might not need it. That’s the message to glean from JPMorgan’s second-quarter results. Granted, the bank’s performance was hardly disastrous, especially considering the recent slowdown in trading across the industry. But almost a third of the bank’s profit came from a $1.5 billion gain on releasing reserves for loan losses.

headline: Is the ‘Kennedy Court’ Over?
text: A report in The Daily News last week that Justice Anthony M. Kennedy has no plans to retire left me shaking my head.

headline: A Senate Run Brings Wrestling Into Spotlight
text: In his heyday, Allen Ray Sarven appeared regularly on the World Wrestling Entertainment circuit, flattening opponents with diving leg drops from atop the ropes.

headline: Senate Committee’s NASA Plan Cuts Moon Program
text: A Senate committee on Thursday unanimously agreed to a blueprint for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration that cancels the agency’s return-to-the-moon program, starts investments in commercial companies that could build rockets to take astronauts to low Earth orbit and speeds development of a heavy-lift rocket for more distant missions.

headline: Governors’ Conference to Move
text: PHOENIX  A conference of border governors from the United States and Mexico that Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona had canceled after the Mexicans refused to come here because of the state’s immigration enforcement law is being salvaged by Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico.

headline: What Isn’t There an App For?
text: In my Times column, I offered some ideas (courtesy of my Twitter followers) for phone apps that do not exist but should.

headline: At School in Harlem, Resentment Over Girl’s Drowning on a Field Trip
text: As the academic year at Columbia Secondary School in Harlem drew to a close, students, parents and teachers reeled from the death of a 12-year-old pupil on a class field trip to a beach last month.

headline: Speculation, and Clues, About Unearthed Ship
text: Two days after construction workers discovered the keel of a centuries-old wooden ship at the site of the new World Trade Center, New Yorkers continued to speculate about what might have caused the mysterious vessel to come to rest amid layers of landfill.

headline: Beyond the Veil: A Response
text: I’m extraordinarily grateful to the many people who posted comments on my piece, “Veiled Threats?”  I note that many have come from educated and active Muslim women (in countries ranging from the U. S. to India), who have expressed a sense of “relief” at having their convictions and voices taken seriously.

headline: Baker’s Accessory
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s nice to see Mel Rosen’s name in The New York Times again. His puzzlemaking goes back quite awhile (as a crossword editor as well), but he’s contributed only a few puzzles here in recent years.

headline: U.S. Court Orders Safety, Not Deportation, for Woman Facing Torture
text: Saying that government lawyers let their zeal for victory in a deportation case outweigh their responsibility to be fair, a federal appeals court last week ordered the United States to provide a haven for a woman facing the likelihood of torture in China.

headline: Louisiana: Man Charged in Post-Katrina Shootings
text: A white man accused of shooting three black men in New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina was charged on Thursday with a federal hate crime. The man, Roland J. Bourgeois Jr., 47, is accused of firing a shotgun at men he suspected of being potential looters, seriously wounding them. According to a five-count indictment unsealed by federal prosecutors, he warned another black resident that he would shoot at “anything coming up this street darker than a paper bag” and displayed a victim’s bloodied baseball cap. The shooting occurred in the Algiers Point neighborhood of New Orleans in September 2005, three days after Katrina struck Louisiana, leaving armed groups of citizens to protect their homes against looting. If convicted, Mr. Bourgeois, who now lives in Mississippi, faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.

headline: Praise for Steinbrenner From Limited Partners
text: For 37 years, the limited partners of the Yankees existed in the shadow of George Steinbrenner. Some are titans in their own realms. But in the Yankee sphere, Steinbrenner was the partner of all partners. His control of the team may not have rendered other investors mute, but they did not have the power to alter his management.

headline: Bloggingheads: Sexist Comedy?
text: Journalist Maureen Tkacik, left, and comedian Lizz Winstead discuss charges of sexism at "The Daily Show."

headline: Reunion of Beltran and Reyes Is Delayed
text: SAN FRANCISCO — So excited to finally write the names of Carlos Beltran and Jose Reyes in the same lineup, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel just assumed the two would be able to play Thursday night against the Giants. So early in the afternoon, Manuel went ahead and did it.

headline: Woods Avoids a Distraction
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland – Tiger Woods has received a warm welcome from St. Andrews fans since his arrival Sunday, and he has not encountered anything resembling heckling  on the Old Course premises.

headline: Paterson to Sign Bill Limiting Retention of Street-Stop Data
text: Gov. David A. Paterson will sign legislation prohibiting the New York Police Department from electronically storing the names and addresses of people stopped on the streets but found to have done nothing wrong, several people with knowledge of the governor’s intentions said Thursday.

headline: AT&T and Rainbow Reach Cable Deal
text: The cable fee fight of the week, between AT&T and Rainbow Media, ended on Thursday with a new deal between the companies.

headline: Netherlands: Friction in the Hague
text: After a clash between judges and prosecutors over evidence, judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Thursday ordered a Congolese warlord conditionally freed. It was the second time that friction over procedures nearly torpedoed the trial of the warlord, Thomas Lubanga, who is charged with recruiting child soldiers in 2002-3. The order came after prosecutors defied orders to turn over information to the defense about an anonymous witness. While it is unlikely that Mr. Lubanga will go free anytime soon, the order was tantamount to a stern warning to the prosecutors. The prosecutors said they would appeal.

headline: Tanzania: Tribunal Lawyer Killed
text: A lawyer for the United Nations tribunal for the Rwandan genocide was shot and killed in Tanzania, the police said Thursday. The authorities at the tribunal said that the lawyer, Jwani Mwaikusa, was shot in front of his home in Dar es Salaam on Tuesday. Documents were stolen from his car, and Mr. Mwaikusa’s nephew and neighbor were also killed. Mr. Mwaikusa represented an elderly genocide suspect who was sentenced last month to 25 years in prison. The killing comes nearly a year after another lawyer at the tribunal was found dead in his home in Arusha.

headline: Israel: Military Court Convicts 2
text: An Israeli Army officer and a soldier were convicted by a military court on Thursday for their involvement in shooting a rubber bullet at the foot of a bound and blindfolded Palestinian in the West Bank in 2008. Both were found guilty of unbecoming conduct. The officer was also found guilty of attempted threats, and the soldier of unlawful use of a weapon. The Palestinian, a leader of protests against Israel’s West Bank barrier, was lightly wounded. The episode drew widespread attention after it was captured on video.

headline: Iroquois Lacrosse Team Misses Game in England
text: The Iroquois national lacrosse team was supposed to open the world championships on Thursday night with a much-anticipated game against host country England.

headline: No Summer Vacation for Chess
text: It has been and continues to be a busy period for chess.

headline: Robert Galambos, Neuroscientist Who Showed How Bats Navigate, Dies at 96
text: Dr. Robert Galambos, a neuroscientist whose work included helping to prove how bats navigate in total darkness and deciphering the codes by which nerves transmit sounds to the brain, died June 18 at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 96.

headline: Day 86: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Oil Flow Stops as Cap Is Tested

headline: France: Mosque Vandalized in Normandy
text: The police opened an investigation on Thursday after vandals left swastikas and anti-Islam slogans on a mosque in northern France. The slogans, like "Islam out of Europe" and "neither Islam nor Burqas," along with swastikas and Celtic crosses, were found Wednesday on the wall of a partly constructed mosque in Hérouville-Saint-Clair, a suburb of Caen, Normandy. The French immigration minister, Eric Besson, said the act "showed not only tremendous cowardice but also extreme stupidity." A prosecutor said the vandalism had taken place on Tuesday night, a few hours after the lower house of Parliament voted to approve a ban on the wearing of veils, such as burqas, that cover the face in public places.

headline: France: $22 Billion for Haiti? Mais Non.
text: The Foreign Ministry was investigating a sham Web site on Thursday that purported to be the ministry’s own and which claimed that France had agreed to repay Haiti for a vast Napoleonic-era indemnity. The site said France would pay Haiti $22 billion, the equivalent, plus interest, of the 90 million gold francs Haiti was forced to pay France after its independence in 1804. The Foreign Ministry said there were no plans to return the money. Bernard Valero, a spokesman, said that the ministry had not yet identified the site’s creators, but that the ministry was considering judicial action in response to “what we want to believe is a joke.” In the wake of the January earthquake that devastated Haiti, France canceled Haiti’s $70 million debt and pledged an additional $350 million in relief aid.

headline: As Manager, Sandberg Still Has the Same Passion
text: DES MOINES  Ryne Sandberg might be the only Hall of Famer managing a minor league baseball team, but there’s nothing ceremonial about the post.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Blagojevich Defense Team Scrambles After a Quick Prosecution
text: Since the corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich began five weeks ago, a jury has heard recordings of his uttering an expletive more than 200 times, seeking big jobs for a vacant United States Senate seat and searching urgently for ways to make money in exchange for state action. With crassness apparently proven beyond a reasonable doubt, the prosecution felt the jury had its fill.

headline: On Display, the Mayor as Epicure
text: The grill in the Jefferson Park neighborhood promises the Bungalow Belt’s traditional fast-food favorites: “The Chicago Way: Beef, Burgers, Dogs.”

headline: For Some Robbers, It Can Be Easy as a Sunday Morning
text: I’ve always known there are “50 Ways to Lose Your Lover” (Paul Simon), “Three Coins in a Fountain” (Frank Sinatra) and “Eight Days a Week” (Beatles). Now I know there are “21 Things a Burglar Won’t Tell You” (Chicago Police Department, 19th District).

headline: Bland? Yes, and Thus Worth Preserving
text: The North Beach library seems ordinary.

headline: Questions About Path of AIDS Walk Money
text: A crowd of 25,000 is expected to trek through Golden Gate Park on Sunday for the annual AIDS Walk, which promises to raise nearly $3.5 million “benefiting the San Francisco AIDS Foundation and other H.I.V./AIDS organizations serving the Bay Area counties,” according to the event’s slogan.

headline: Festivals Help Rep Movie Houses Hang On
text: In 2005, Gary Meyer, founder of the Landmark theater chain and the director of the Telluride Film Festival, embarked upon an ill-fated experiment: He converted the Balboa Theater into repertory programming to capitalize on a hole in San Francisco’s rep house scene that was created when Anita Monga left the Castro Theater the previous year.

headline: As Dellums’s Support Fades, the Black Vote Splits
text: Teola Sanders has supported Mayor Ronald V. Dellums of Oakland for over 40 years.

headline: Good Fútbol Won the World Cup
text: What is good fútbol?

headline: City’s Unemployment Rate Fell to 9.5% in June, the 6th Straight Monthly Dip
text: Despite the end of thousands of jobs for federal census takers, New York City’s unemployment rate ticked down again in June, the sixth straight monthly decline, to 9.5 percent, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Boyfriend Charged in Fatal Queens Fire
text: A 23-year-old Queens man was charged on Thursday with setting a fire that killed his pregnant girlfriend and her 2-year-old son, the authorities said.

headline: Officials Call Results of Well Test Encouraging
text: A day after BP closed off the flow of oil from its runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, officials said the signs from a crucial test of the well’s condition were encouraging.

headline: Two Officers Are Accused of Lying About Searches
text: A New York City police sergeant lied to cover up several unlawful stops and seizures in Manhattan and forced subordinates to falsify paperwork to justify the stops, authorities said Thursday in announcing the indictment of two officers.

headline: Word of the Day | comeuppance
text: comeuppance •\(ˌ)kəm-ˈə-pən(t)s\• noun

headline: Zatonskih Holds Lead for Women’s Title; Two Are Tied for Junior Crown
text: The defending champion continues to lead the U.S. Women’s Championship, while the top seed is now tied for the lead of the U.S. Junior Championship.

headline: Beltran Returns, Full of Emotion, as the Mets Fall
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As he prepared for his first appearance in a major league game in over nine months, Carlos Beltran thought about all the time he had missed following knee surgery in January, and all the work he had done in Port St. Lucie, Fla. to get back in shape and ready to play again.

headline: Vonetta McGee, Film and TV Actress, Dies at 65
text: Vonetta McGee, a film and television actress originally known for blaxploitation pictures like “Blacula,” “Hammer” and “Shaft in Africa,” died on July 9 in Berkeley, Calif. She was 65 and a Berkeley resident.

headline: Charles Mackerras, Elegant Conductor, Dies at 84
text: Charles Mackerras, an Australian conductor who played a crucial role in establishing Janacek’s operas in the West; made important discoveries about vocal ornamentation in Mozart operas; and was an elegant conductor of Gilbert and Sullivan’s operettas and Mozart, Mendelssohn and Brahms symphonies, died on Wednesday in London, where he lived. He was 84.

headline: News Quiz | July 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: AgBank Ekes Out Gains in Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: The Agricultural Bank of China still hopes to clinch the title of the world’s biggest stock market listing, but its market debuts in Shanghai and Hong Kong have so far been anything but breathtaking, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Would-Be Burglar’s Tools: Gun, Cane, Oxygen Tank
text: The police are still searching for a man in his 60s or 70s who struck a Madison Avenue clothing store last Friday evening, firing three shots from a gun before fleeing.

headline: Banks Seek to Keep Profits as New Oversight Rules Loom
text: The ink is not even dry on the new rules for Wall Street, and already the bankers are a step ahead of everyone else.

headline: Financial Oversight Bill Signals Shift on Deregulation
text: Congress approved a sweeping expansion of federal financial regulation on Thursday, reflecting a renewed mistrust of financial markets after decades in which Washington stood back from Wall Street with wide-eyed admiration, The New York Times’s Binyamin Appelbaum and David M. Herszenhorn report.

headline: V.C. Investments Climb 53% in 2Q
text: Venture capitalists funneled more money into start-ups in the United States in the second quarter, indicating continuing confidence that the economy is on the mend, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Survey of Bankers Shows Slowing Economic Recovery
text: A survey of rural bankers in 10 Midwest and Plains states released on Thursday indicated a setback in the recovering economy, The Associated Press reported.

headline: AT&T U-Verse Reaches Deal to Keep AMC,’ Mad Men’
text: Averting a standoff over programming fees, AT&T said on Thursday it has reached a deal to keep channels AMC, IFC and WE tv on the tube for its 2.3 million U-verse TV subscribers, The Associated Press reported.

text: Today’s word, in association with the splendid Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: No Catastrophes From Europe Stress Tests Expected: Juncker
text: There should be no “big catastrophes” from stress tests on European banks, but the reviews should be tough, the chairman of euro zone finance ministers, Jean-Claude Juncker, was quoted as saying, Reuters said.

headline: AgBank Said to Ask H.K. I.P.O. Advisers for 36% Cut
text: The Agricultural Bank of China is negotiating a 36 percent cut in underwriter fees for its $10.5 billion initial stock sale in Hong Kong to reflect talks with corporate investors that the lender handled itself, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people with knowledge of the matter.

text: Citigroup said in a letter to the federal securities regulator that it had unintentionally classified as much as $9.2 billion of repurchase agreements as sales at one point, when they should have been shown as borrowings, Reuters reported.

headline: S.Korea’s Honam to Buy Malaysia’s Titan for $1.27 Billion
text: South Korea’s Honam Petrochemical will pay 1.52 trillion won ($1.27 billion) to buy Malaysia’s largest petrochemical maker Titan Chemicals to expand its capacity and its overseas revenues, Reuters reported.

headline: U.K. Fraud Office Drops Probe of Dynamic Decisions
text: Prosecutors at Britain’s Serious Fraud Office dropped a probe into the hedge fund Dynamic Decisions Capital, saying they didn’t find enough evidence for a prosecution, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: For Derivatives, Law Could Bring New Light
text: When financial markets came unglued two years ago, few Americans had heard of derivatives, much less their more esoteric forms like credit-default swaps and collateralized debt obligations. Since then, derivatives have been central to the debate over how tightly to regulate Wall Street’s freewheeling ways.

headline: Toll Rises From Twin Suicide Bombings at Iranian Mosque

The show, which runs through Sept. 12, has transformed the space into a so-called “Surreal House,” exploring the power and mystery of the home in our collective imagination.

text: Today’s idea: Maslow’s “hierarchy of needs” is out of date, a team of evolutionary psychologists argues. Let’s replace “self-actualization” with “parenting” to better reflect our fundamental drive to propagate the species.

headline: Draft Law Revives Practice of Soviets
text: MOSCOW  The lower house of the Russian Parliament passed a draft law on Friday allowing the country’s intelligence service to officially warn citizens that their activities could lead to a future violation of the law, reviving a Soviet-era K.G.B. practice that was often used against dissidents. The president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, is expected to sign it into law shortly.

headline: Getting the Not-Quite-Right Stuff From I Write Like
text: Days after its latest version was opened to the public, the Web site I Write Like has rapidly gained a following with Internet users and especially among bloggers with bandwidth to burn. Because who doesn’t get a thrill from copying and pasting their workaday keyboard peckings into a blank white box and being told by an anonymous computer algorithm that it somehow resembles the polished and enduring prose of Jane Austen or David Foster Wallace? What’s not fun about seeking the hidden connections between the outputs of Margaret Atwood and Mel Gibson, or between Kurt Vonnegut and Lourdes Ciccone?

headline: Indian Effort on Spies Squeezes Phone Operators
text: NEW DELHI — As India prepares to adopt new import regulations designed to thwart spying and sabotage, the country’s mobile phone operators say the costs of implementing the rules could squeeze their thin profits even further and accelerate an impending wave of consolidation in the industry.

headline: The Security Council Sits on its Hands
text: The U.N. Security Council is expected to meet today to discuss African peace and security issues, including how to prevent mass atrocities there. Presumably the Security Council will again refuse to address seriously the most important African peace issue — the prospect of a new north-south war in Sudan in the coming months.

headline: A Fund-Raising Gap

headline: Digital Diplomacy
text: It was a Wednesday night in San Francisco’s SoMa neighborhood, and Jared Cohen, the youngest member of the State Department’s policy planning staff, and Alec Ross, the first senior adviser for innovation to the secretary of state, were taking their tweeting very seriously. Cohen had spent the day in transit from D.C.; Ross hadn’t eaten anything besides a morning muffin. Yet they were in the mood to share, and dinner could wait. It wasn’t every day they got to tweet about visiting the headquarters of Twitter.

With wildly windy, rainy, sunny, chaotic Scottish weather as a backdrop, golf came alive Friday in all its manifestations in a British Open that could turn out to be as memorable as any in the 150 years of golf’s oldest championship.

headline: Frogs, Boiling Water, And Central Banks
text: Like others, I’ve been warning that policy makers in the United States are defining normalcy down — accepting high unemployment and below-target inflation as just the way things are. It’s not just an obsession with inflation risks; it’s an abdication of responsibility for the economy, even if prices are falling rather than rising.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Different Kind of Caped Crusader
text: There are five new books on the manga list this week and they are all from VIZ Media. Sitting at No. 1 is Volume 14 of “Ouran High School Host Club,” a series about Haruhi, a poor girl at a rich school, who is forced to work – as a boy – for the school’s all-male club. In the latest installment, a love triangle develops that may shake the club apart.

headline: Yevraz
text: A proposed non-cash currency to be shared by Belarus, Kazakhstan and Russia.

headline: When Funny Goes Viral
text: One weekend this spring, close to 1,000 people gathered on the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to attend a sold-out conference devoted to the question “What is awesome on the Internet?” While the event included presenters and moderators with respectable research credentials from the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard and the like, what they had gathered to examine, more or less seriously, is what might be called the ROFL universe. ROFL, which became familiar in the age of texting, stands for “rolling on the floor, laughing” and can serve as a shorthand response to the most ephemeral, silly and frankly unimportant-seeming manifestations of pop entertainment in the early 21st century: absurdly captioned pictures of cats, goof-off remixes of YouTube videos, unlikely Web celebrities, quick-hit visual jokes with unprintable punch lines and sporadic references to Rick Astley.

headline: Strangers on a Train
text: When I travel alone, my preference is to keep it that way. I’m not really one for chatting people up in hotel bars or for reeling out my anecdotes or listening to theirs. Which is why my heart sank, a few weeks ago, when a man entered my chamber just as the overnight train from Moscow to St. Petersburg departed the station.

headline: The Russian Immigrant’s Handbook
text: Your new novel, “Super Sad True Love Story,” a superliterate sendup of consumer culture, is set in New York in the near future, when books are extinct, eternal life can be purchased by a rich elite, the subway offers business class and see-through jeans are the latest fashion. How do you feel about the word “dystopia”?  “Dystopia” is my middle name. I was born in the Soviet Union, and then we moved to Reagan’s America. We immigrated in 1979, just in time for the Gipper.

headline: Paralyzed by Debt
text: Last month, my wife and I refinanced our mortgage. Though the rate was lower and we could have afforded more debt, we paid down a chunk of the balance. Don’t ask me why — it just felt better to owe less money. Time was, such thrift would have been hailed as patriotic. Now it threatens the economic recovery. Less borrowing means less to spend.

headline: Young Conductors: Old Fires Burn, Too
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is ‘One-Year Anniversary’ Redundant?
text: Neale Gifford writes: "One practice that annoys me is the use of 'one-year anniversary' or 'five-year anniversary' instead of 'first' or 'fifth.' Reason? Anniversary is derived from the Latin annus meaning 'year.' " Ed Morman writes of "n-year anniversary," "It's not very mellifluous and it is, of course redundant. Help me bring back 'nth anniversary.' "  Gifford and Morman aren't alone in their irritation. A few years ago, when The San Francisco Chronicle ran a headline reading, "Four-year anniversary draws protests," an irate reader left a profanity-riddled voicemail that unkindly insinuated what substance could be found between the ears of Phil Bronstein, then the editor of The Chronicle. (The same reader was even more offended by the appearance of "pilotless drone" in the newspaper, and his recorded rant became something of a Web sensation.)  The New York Times, too, is hardly immune to this redundancy. The June 28 edition, for instance, featured an article on Dylan Ratigan's "one-year anniversary at MSNBC" and another stating that New York's first gay pride parade commemorated "the one-year anniversary of the Stonewall uprising." Philip Corbett, the newsroom's style guru, has frequently complained about this usage in his "After Deadline" blog but laments that his reminders have "little effect."  What has happened to the word anniversary? Even though the idea of yearly recurrence is built into the word etymologically, that idea has been clouded over centuries of use. And when an element of a word's meaning becomes more opaque, redundancy is one method, however inelegant, that gets used to unmuddy the waters.

headline: Correction
text: An article on June 27 about the 30th anniversary of the movie “Airplane!” erroneously attributed a distinction to the film. “Airplane!” became the third-highest-grossing comedy in box-office history after it came out in 1980  behind “National Lampoon’s Animal House,” in first place, and “Smokey and the Bandit.” It is not “the highest-grossing comedy in box office history.”

headline: Letters: The Closer
text: With so many superstar athletes conducting themselves with an overblown sense of entitlement, it was inspiring to read about the quiet dignity of Mariano Rivera. His commitment to a team approach, his role as a mentor to teach and counsel younger players, his dedication to his family and his vision for a better world for underprivileged children make him a role model not just for children but also for all of us.

text: A baby planner? It’s the latest trend, according to at least one local news program.

text: Robert Draper’s profile of Senator Lindsey Graham was a refreshing look at bipartisanship. Too bad more of his Congressional colleagues aren’t following suit.

headline: Finally, Easy Backup for Multiple PCs
text: Simple backup has always been an oxymoron. But I just tried a device that could change that: The Clickfree C2N drive can automatically back up Windows PCs and Macs over a home network with real set-it-and-forget-it ease.

headline: 2011 BMW 5 Series
text: There’s nothing flashy or superficial about the redesigned 5 Series.
