headline: Defending Your Dystopia: Albert Brooks Visits the Near-Future in His First Novel
text: In his feature films, Albert Brooks has traveled across the country (almost eventually) and to the afterlife, so for his first novel, there was only one place left for him to go: the future.

headline: Letter: I’ll Take a Scoop of Prosciutto, Please
text: I enjoyed the article about Jake Godby and his creative ice creams, and I was not repulsed by any of the strange flavors, until I reached the end of the article and the dessert described as “soaked in wart syrup.” Now, that did disturb me. Unfermented beer is wort, and I can well imagine what a tasty syrup it would make. But I think I’ll skip the wart syrup.

headline: Complaint Box | Uneasy Riders
text: The sound is unlike any other: a dry, scraping noise made by a skateboard’s wheels as they roll across a concrete surface — part of the city’s summer cacophony. I heard it just the other day, coming up fast behind me as I waited for the light to change at 21st Street and Park Avenue South. Turning quickly, I expected to see a teenager in baggy pants wheeling down the sidewalk, motioning for me to get out of the way. Instead, it was a fortysomething guy who looked like bald, portly Kevin from “The Office.”

headline: July 18 — 24
text: Classical

headline: Letter: Questions for George Shultz
text: In Deborah Solomon’s insightful interview, former Secretary of State George Shultz acknowledges being the chairman of a Committee for the Liberation of Iraq that “supported the war.” The former secretary of state then admits this was a committee that “never met” and that he didn’t “even know who the members of it were.” This is a statesman?

headline: Friday Reading: Banks Adapt to New Rules
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Letters: Tuna’s End
text: Thank you for Paul Greenberg’s excellent article (June 27) on the plight of the bluefin tuna. I attended the U.N. meeting on endangered-species trade in Qatar that Greenberg refers to. He omits the most talked about moment of the conference: the night before the crucial vote, the Japanese delegation flew in bluefin tuna and threw a party for friendly delegates. The science on bluefin tuna is unequivocal, and so is, apparently, Japan’s contempt for the U.N. body.

headline: A New Senator for West Virginia
text: 3:57 p.m. | Updated Gov. Joe Manchin of West Virginia named his former general counsel, Carte Goodwin, to temporarily fill the United States Senate seat of the late Robert Byrd.

headline: Banging Out a Revolution In Just 91 Measures
text: MUSICAL revolutions often come in generous portions. Think of Monteverdi’s operas; Beethoven’s “Eroica” and Ninth Symphonies, C sharp minor Quartet and “Hammerklavier” Sonata; and Wagner’s “Ring” cycle and “Parsifal.” Compared to those monuments, the French-American composer Edgard Varèse’s “Ionisation” barely amounts to a flyspeck. The work’s 91 measures are generally dispatched in less than six minutes, hardly the girth of an epic.

headline: Letters: What a Liberal Court Should Be
text: Noah Feldman (June 27) elegantly points out a dangerous trend in conservative judicial activism, particularly in the court’s Citizens United decision, to empower corporations at the expense of individual voters, which threatens to seriously undermine our republican form of government. I disagree, however, with his suggestion that the antidote to this trend is a new progressive constitutional outlook, which he says is needed to justify judicial restraint in the court’s review of Congress’s powers to regulate the national economy. A new interpretation of the Constitution is neither required nor helpful. We need less judicial activism, not further manipulation of the Constitution until its bedrock principles of liberty and democracy cease to have meaning. A new progressive constitutional vision is not needed; let’s try to preserve what we have.

headline: Letters: My Father’s Broken Heart
text: Katy Butler’s article (June 20), which so many have found moving and heartbreaking, may have left the impression that Jeff Butler’s book, a story of how segregation and apartheid came to Cradock, his town in South Africa, will never be published. It was, in effect, finished before his stroke and his death, except for reconfiguration and editing of a concluding section and verification of sources, both now completed by his close friend and Wesleyan University colleague Richard Elphick. It will be published by the University of Virginia Press in 2012. As Jeff’s editor over many years, I considered it before his illness, as I do now, a tour de force. Authors have an afterlife that may be lasting, the life of their books.

headline: Skateboard Aesthetics on Two Wheels
text: Indianapolis

headline: The Passion, Without Hyperbole
text: THE Swiss composer Frank Martin, who died at 84 in 1974, lived through the decades when pointless stylistic battles were waged within the field of contemporary music, and composers faced pressure to take sides. Martin never did. His detractors called him a conservative, which, in comparison with audacious modernists, he was.

headline: Olivier Messiaen: ‘Visions de l’Amen’
text: Messiaen drew from his primary inspirations — birds, his Roman Catholic faith and his wife, the pianist Yvonne Loriod — in this work written for two pianos.

headline: Gulf Crabbers Seek Eco-Endorsement
text: Faced with possible ruin as a result of the oil spill, Louisiana blue crab producers are doing what 209 other fisheries around the world have done in recent years: seek to improve their standing by having their catch certified as environmentally sustainable by the Marine Stewardship Council.

headline: Spy Swap Forced  Prosecutors Into Balancing Act
text: On June 29, two days after the arrests of 10 Russian agents in New York and three other states, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, called an emergency meeting of his closest aides. Their criminal case, he was aware, was fast becoming a deal being orchestrated by politicians and diplomats.

headline: Inside the List
text: OFFSIDE: The sun has barely set on the World Cup, and the National Football League is already taking over the pitch. The New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees’s inspirational “Coming Back Stronger: Unleashing the Hidden Power of Adversity,” enters at No. 3 (the square root of his jersey number!) on the hardcover nonfiction list, while his coach, Sean Payton, drops to No. 9 with “Home Team.” Meanwhile, Kendra Wilkinson — the former live-in playmate of Hugh Hef­ner and current wife of the Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver Hank Baskett — sticks to baseball metaphors in “Sliding Into Home,” new at No. 4. At least let’s hope that’s a baseball metaphor.

headline: Driving the Nissan Leaf Electric Car Reveals Range Variability
text: MALIBU, Calif. — Test driving a preproduction version of the Nissan Leaf electric car here this week, I was reminded of the old story about the guy who installed so many fuel-saving devices on his car that when he started it up and drove away, his gas tank overflowed.

headline: Only Disconnect
text: Since fiscal year 2008, I have been permanently attached to my iTelephone. As of two weeks ago, I am a Facebooking twit. With each post, each tap of the screen, each drag and click, I am becoming a different person — solitary where I was once gregarious; a content provider where I at least once imagined myself an artist; nervous and constantly updated where I once knew the world through sleepy, half-shut eyes; detail-oriented and productive where I once saw life float by like a gorgeously made documentary film. And, increasingly, irrevocably, I am a stranger to books, to the long-form text, to the pleasures of leaving myself and inhabiting the free-floating consciousness of another. With each passing year, scientists estimate that I lose between 6 and 8 percent of my humanity, so that by the close of this decade you will be able to quantify my personality. By the first quarter of 2020 you will be able to understand who I am through a set of metrics as simple as those used to measure the torque of the latest-model Audi or the spring of some brave new toaster.

headline: The Old Neighborhood
text: Tana French’s mysteries are like big old trees: the deeper their roots, the more luxurious the foliage they wave in your face. Like her two previous mysteries, both set in Dublin, FAITHFUL PLACE (Viking, $25.95) is sunk in local history, drawing on a tangle of family ties and generational feuds for its thick plot about the impact on a poor-but-proud community when a 22-year-old murder comes to light. Although the story revolves around its sympathetic narrator, a tough-minded police officer who wised up years ago and made a clean break from the old neighborhood, the street he grew up on is the novel’s main character and the source of its raging vitality.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A VISIT FROM THE GOON SQUAD,  by Jennifer Egan (Knopf, $25.95.) In her centrifugal, unclassifiably elaborate narrative, Egan creates a set of characters with assorted links to the music business and lets relentless time have its way with them.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BOTH WAYS IS THE ONLY WAY I WANT IT,  by Maile Meloy (Riverhead, $15.) The 11 stories in this collection, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2009, are written with Meloy’s characteristic restraint and mastery of detail. Her characters are flawed and often act out of desperation, yet despite the frequent presence of death and infidelity, the stories’ tone is not grim. Our reviewer, Curtis Sittenfeld, called Meloy a “talented and unpredictable writer.”

headline: Weighing the Trade-Offs in the Goldman Settlement
text: Peter J. Henning and Steven M. Davidoff provide a post-mortem of the Goldman Sachs settlement.

headline: We Three Things | Water Colors
text: It is too hot. My constant craving is to be submerged in a cool pool: the sound of kicking overhead, of bubbles and muffled splashing. Everything is slower and suspended underwater. I spend as much time as possible in the deep end, and when I’m not there, I seek out that submersible summer feeling. Watch this 1993 music video directed by Jem Cohen, and feel your body temperature drop.

headline: New Card Rules May Cost BofA Billions in Revenue
text: Bank of America took more than a few analysts and investors by surprise on its earnings call Friday by disclosing that the pending financial regulatory overhaul may cost the firm $10 billion or more.

headline: ‘On Whitman’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making the Team as a Sympathy Pick
text: I coach a youth all-star baseball team. After tryouts, our league director chose the 13 best players for our team, leaving about six kids unselected. Among those is a boy whose father recently died of cancer. The boy is not very good at baseball, about the worst among those who tried out. The community is pressuring the director to “do the right thing” for the boy and a family coping with tragedy. They say some things transcend baseball skill. But what about the better player whose spot he would be taking? What is “the right thing”? NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

headline: Poor Franklin
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond Facebook’s Reach
text: To the Editor:

headline: Man as an Island
text: In the late 1960s, some 15 years after the publication of “Lord of the Flies,” William Golding confessed to a friend that he resented the novel because it meant that he owed his reputation to what he thought of as a minor book, a book that had made him a classic in his lifetime, which was “a joke,” and that the money he had gained from it was “Monopoly money” because he hadn’t really earned it. Golding was drinking heavily at the time (he had a lifelong struggle with alcoholism) and one may have to take his bitterness advisedly, but these remarks reveal an interesting artistic conundrum. What is it like to owe virtually your entire reputation as a writer to a single book? One thinks of J. D. Salinger, Ralph Ellison, Joseph Heller — to cite only the 20th-century American exemplars — but such one-book writers are legion in all literatures. John Carey seems to allude to the category in this biography’s subtitle (even though Carey eventually disputes the implication). However, if anyone thinks of William Golding today, it is almost certain that his name will be conjoined with his extraordinary first novel.

headline: Boards and Bikes
text: Some skateboarders have found new expressions of freedom in motorcycles.

headline: Love Among the Ruined
text: Every character we encounter in Nic Pizzolatto’s first novel, “Galveston,” is orphaned, disgorged by either a loved one or the sun-boiled landscapes of Texas and Louisiana. It’s 1987. Roy Cady, a drunk in his early 40s, has just learned he has terminal lung cancer. Roy collects debts and occasionally kills people for Stan, a mob boss in New Orleans. But Stan has recently taken up with Roy’s girlfriend, and Roy’s continued existence now proves an irritant. When Stan sends Roy into an ambush, the intended killers are killed instead. Only Roy and a teenage prostitute, Raquel (Rocky) Arceneaux, survive. They flee Louisiana together and head for Texas.

headline: Afraid of the Dark
text: Theodor Adorno said, ­“After Auschwitz, to write a poem is barbaric,” which is true — about ­Auschwitz. His statement is a measure of the horror of the death camps, not the pointlessness of poetry. Who says poetry has a point anyway? It’s more important than that.

headline: The Tolstoys’ War
text: Sophia Tolstoy has returned to the public eye, thanks in no small part to Helen Mirren, who recently portrayed her onscreen. In the tumultuous final months of her husband’s life, Sophia and Leo Tolstoy found themselves in perpetual conflict. In despair, Tolstoy left their country home, Yasnaya Polyana, on Oct. 28, 1910, taking to the road in the middle of the night, putting 48 years of marriage behind him. He died soon thereafter in a remote railway station, with his wife outside begging to be let in. She was turned away by Vladimir Chertkov, Tolstoy’s disciple and close friend, who suggested that any glimpse of her would hasten her husband’s end. Chertkov relented only when Tolstoy was in a coma, at the point of death.

headline: Born to Check Mail
text: While reading “Hamlet’s BlackBerry,” I sporadically paused to check my iPhone — whenever its ping signaled the arrival of a new e-mail message. I hated to turn away from William Powers’s elegant meditation on our obsessive connectivity and its effect on our brains and our very way of life. But I did anyway.

headline: Cook’s Tour
text: Anthony Bourdain was exceptionally well positioned to bang out “Kitchen Confidential” in 2000: he’d spent 28 years behind restaurant stoves and had a couple of noirish novels to his name. The memoir exposed the darkest corners of New York’s kitchens and dining rooms. Now, after 10 years as a food-world celebrity and BFF of top chefs, he’s even better positioned to dish it out to the industry and its four-star hype machine. Unfortunately, as the title of his new essay collection, “Medium Raw,” warns, he gives it to us half-cooked.

headline: Schumacher Prepares for an Emotional Return to Germany with Mercedes
text: Naturally, Formula One team press releases will not contain anything offensive or threatening to a team’s image, and they will generally portray a rosy story — especially the press releases relating to a team’s home Grand Prix. But I have no doubt that there was truth behind Michael Schumacher’s seeming platitudes about returning to Hockenheim for the German Grand Prix next week for the first time since his retirement, especially since he will be driving a Mercedes racing car.

headline: Actos Ads Jump on Avandia’s Setback
text: It did not take long for Takeda Pharmaceuticals to begin a new advertising campaign for its diabetes product after the Food and Drug Administration hearing Wednesday on the safety of a rival pill.

headline: Literary Compass
text: When her husband, Raymond Smith, died of pneumonia in February 2008, Joyce Carol Oates was writing a review of a book about boxing. “No one could know the effort,” she recalls in her preface to “In Rough Country: Essays and Reviews,” “that went into this single ‘review.’ . . . No one could guess that there is a break in the essay between the second section and the section that begins with the words ‘From the bare-­knuckle era of John L. Sullivan’ — the pages before were written by a woman with a husband, the pages following were written by a woman who had lost her ­husband.”

headline: Creature Comforts
text: Friends come into your life from unexpected directions, friendships go through hard times, friendships sometimes end — these themes are explored in two new books using stories of a dog befriending a frog and a rabbit befriending a bird.

headline: Hocus-Pocus
text: I admit it. When I read the last two pages of “Abby Carnelia’s One and Only Magical Power,” a novel for 8- to-12-year-olds, I cried. On the surface this is a tale about a regular girl with a pointless magical power. But it got me with its message of discovering and appreciating your own gifts — even if those gifts mainly consist of the ability to spin a hard-boiled egg by pulling on your ears.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf

headline: New Woe for Lilith Fair: Carly Simon Injured
text: More bad news for Lilith Fair. Two weeks after the package tour — a revival of Sarah McLachlan’s successful woman-centric lineups of the late 1990s — canceled 10 dates, most likely (but not officially) because of weak ticket sales, Carly Simon has announced her withdrawal from three shows because of an injury. On Thursday the tour’s organizers said that Ms. Simon would not perform at the Comcast Center in Mansfield, Mass., on July 30; the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on July 31; and Hartford on Aug. 1. “Last week, Simon suffered an injury by seriously fracturing and breaking her foot, which will prevent her from performing at these shows,” a statement said.

Whether they are made with quinoa or wheatberries, pasta or beans, most of the ingredients can be prepared ahead of time, then tossed together for an easy picnic or outdoor get-together.

headline: Family Albums
text: Long ago and far away, Aristotle called poetry (by which he meant imaginative writing in general) “a more philosophical and serious business than history; for poetry speaks more of universals, history of particulars.” He was describing the difference between the events we know to have happened to such-and-such a person on such-and-such a date and the wide scope of human reactions to those events. And, by extension, of the way imaginative writing can grab at our hearts to make history live beyond the limits of facts.

headline: Losing Weight the Smartphone Way, With a Nutritionist in Your Pocket
text: FOR most of us, the formula for losing weight is a simple one: eat less, exercise more. But humans are anything but simple, and the majority of Americans struggle endlessly with losing pounds and keeping them off.

text: SEOUL, South Korea  A propaganda poster recently smuggled out of North Korea depicts the North Korean military smashing an enemy warship in half, a scene evocative of the sinking of a South Korean warship earlier this year.

headline: Using Your Phone to Lose Weight
text: There’s always something new in the world of losing weight. Now there are weight-loss programs you can keep in your pocket. In this week’s Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about the applications available for download on your smartphone that are designed to help you count calories, track pounds lost and make weight loss more accessible than ever.

headline: One Bride for 2 Brothers: A Custom Fades in India
text: MALANG, India  Buddhi Devi was 14 when she was betrothed. In India, that is not unusual: many marry young. Her intended was a boy from her village who was two years younger  that, too, was not strange. But she was also supposed to marry her future husband’s younger brother, once he was old enough.

headline: Tehran in Chains
text: Do modern communications ultimately hobble or enable dictatorship? Of all the unanswered questions from Iran’s 2009 post-election upheaval — prematurely labeled in the West as the “Twitter revolution” — this remains one of the most urgent and perplexing. Technology, conventional wisdom runs, punches holes through iron curtains. An interrogator can still extract a false confession under duress. But as Roxana Saberi writes in  “Between Two Worlds,”  the prisoner can recant on ­YouTube immediately upon release.

headline: Believer’s Bazaar
text: A dancer who is worshipped as a part-time god; a female mystic who inhabits a cremation ground, drinking from skulls; a sculptor of Hindu idols who believes he is creating live deities; a Tibetan monk who enrolls in the Indian Army in the hope of returning to his homeland but ends up killing Pakistanis. These are not characters in lurid fiction, but a sample of the devotees William Dalrymple encounters in his absorbing “Nine Lives: In Search of the Sacred in Modern India.”

Our live updates from the event are below.

headline: Made in Germany
text: By 1900, nearly everyone agreed that there was something special about the Germans. Their philosophy was more profound — to a fault. So was their music. Their scientists and engineers were clearly the best. Their soldiers were unmatched.

headline: China’s Instant Cities
text: This year China will add more than 17 million people to its urban population. To house this unprecedented wave of migration from the country side, cities like Shanghai and Guangzhou are building countless high-rise residential towers at breakneck speed.

headline: At the Speed of Thought Balloons
text: “This book is for ‘ideal readers’ only!!!” declares the copyright page of Dash Shaw’s new graphic novel, “BodyWorld.” He’s kidding, of course (the same page goes on to request, “Please read in bed naked”), but it’s a clever way to point out that this isn’t a particularly straightforward piece of work. “BodyWorld” is a psychedelic, romantic, science-fictional high school melodrama, the sixth book by a 27-year-old cartoonist who made his name in 2008 with the ambitious “Bottomless Belly Button.” A hard-core experimentalist, Shaw enthusiastically tosses one dizzying visual technique after another at his ­readers, because his story constantly heads into territories where simple narrative artwork isn’t enough.

headline: Jennifer Deal, Jeremy Redburn
text: Jennifer Andrea Deal and Jeremy Andrew Redburn were married Saturday at Ogontz, a music and arts camp in Lyman, N.H. Andrew D. Munts, a minister in the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness and the bridegroom’s uncle, officiated.

Welcome to the life of a New York freelance dancer.

headline: Strong Winds, and a Mist Net for Sparrows
text: The strong winds that greeted us on our first night, nearly blowing the tents over as we slept, never died down. If anything, they have increased in intensity. While this doesn’t normally impact catching birds when we use traps, today it seemed to affect our work. We arrived back at the women’s cooperative by 6:30 a.m. The birds showed up around 8, but they spent most of the morning in the trees and rarely came to the ground. We think the wind forced them to stay on the branches most of the time. The superb starlings only came to ground once, and didn’t approach the traps. Luckily, the white-crowned starlings were a bit more cooperative today, and we managed to catch four. Just like yesterday, they seemed most inquisitive in the early morning, then disappeared by mid-morning.

headline: Popcast: Remembering Tuli Kupferberg and More
text: Tuli Kupferberg was a Beat poet who became “the world’s oldest rock star,” an old-school lefty, a ribald comedian and a longtime hero of the counterculture of New York and beyond. On this week’s Popcast, Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario of The Times discuss the life and legacy of Mr. Kupferberg, who died on Monday at age 86. “If you scratch a cynic, you’re going to find a sentimentalist,” Mr. Ratliff says in the conversation, “and underneath everything Tuli sang about how love was good and war was bad.”

headline: Creating Sabbath Peace Amid the Noise
text: THERE are people for whom the Sabbath never went away  Seventh-day Adventists, Hutterites, Jews whose fathers and mothers never stopped walking in the ways of their fathers and mothers.

headline: Science Academy Charts CO2 Impacts Degree by Degree
text: The National Academies, the country’s leading scientific advisory group, has published the latest in a decades-long string of reports laying out the robust science pointing to an increasingly human-influenced climate. This report, “Climate Stabilization Targets: Emissions, Concentrations, and Impacts Over Decades to Millennia,” provides a fresh degree-by-degree guide to impacts on river flows, rainfall, coasts and other factors that matter enormously over the next few decades as human populations crest.

The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Each post will list five things Paul likes, five things he doesn’t like about each team. Today’s team, No.49, is South Florida. Pre-Snap Read also has a longer South Florida preview.

headline: Letterman’s Blackmailer Gets Emmy Nod. Letterman Doesn’t.
text: Robert Joel Halderman, in jail for trying to extort money from David Letterman, is nominated for a News and Documentary Emmy Award. Coincidentally, Mr. Letterman’s “Late Show” was not nominated for an Emmy in the outstanding variety, music or comedy series. His show had been nominated for 26 years in a row

headline: It’s Time to Start Worrying Again
text: THE unlikely summer blockbuster of 2006, “An Inconvenient Truth”  the global-warming documentary based on Al Gore’s slide-show lecture  proved that socially conscious movies about calamitous subjects could raise awareness and also do big business. (It earned nearly $50 million at the global box office on its way to winning an Oscar.)

headline: Get the Look … Now!
text: Funny — rather, awfully convenient — thing about fashion: The next season’s shows always feature clothes that correspond with the current weather. Instead of waiting until spring 2011, why not test out some of the great looks seen in Europe now? We dissected three of our favorite collections and put together the necessary elements to achieve the looks (on the cheap, at that). Get the look … now!

headline: Is the Tide Turning on Deforestation?
text: For decades, logging has eaten away at the Brazilian Amazon, often called the “earth’s lungs” for its ability to generate vast amounts of oxygen through photosynthesis. Experts estimate that roughly 20 percent of the rain forest has been destroyed, with much of it turned into ranchland or farms. Other primeval forests around the world, from Indonesia to Cameroon, are similarly threatened.

The companies said they hoped to produce the car, with a Tesla powertrain, in the United States in 2012. A Toyota spokesman, John Hanson, said that other markets were being considered.

headline: Off the Menu: Lafayette Espresso Bar and Marketplace
text: Dorina Yuen, who opened Oro, a cafe and wine bar in NoLIta, in 2008, has teamed up with Christiane Celle, Antoine Verglas and Judy Tan to open Lafayette Espresso Bar and Marketplace on July 20. Ms. Celle, the founder of the Calypso clothing stores, now owns the Clic galleries, and is married to Mr. Verglas, a photographer. Lafayette, a 250-square-foot storefront, will serve made-to-order juices, espresso and drip coffee brewed to order, and sell sandwiches and salads, as well as an array of local artisanal food products like Brooklyn Brine pickles, Anarchy in a Jar preserves, vegan Cavemen Cookies and homemade granola.

headline: What We’re Reading: Trailers
text: Here’s what the tech editors and reporters of the New York Times have been reading online:

headline: Structured Like a Mutual Fund, Traded Like a Stock
text: Exchange-traded funds seem to be advertised as a magic bullet for whatever ails an investor. They’re easy to buy and sell. Many have low fees. What they hold is transparent. And because there are so many of them  more than 1,000 in the United States, according to Forefront Advisory  investors can invest in very specific ways, singling out telecommunication companies, for instance, or European government debt.

headline: State Secret: Chelsea Clinton’s Wedding Plans
text: ONE weekend afternoon in April, Dan Bleen, the manager of Le Petit Bistro, an upscale French restaurant in Rhinebeck, N.Y., a quaint Hudson Valley town, received a mysterious telephone call from the owner of Astor Courts, the centerpiece of a nearby 50-acre estate. The caller wanted to make a reservation, she told him, “for some very special guests,” whose identities she would reveal moments before they arrived.

headline: Apple Goes on the Offensive
text: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Many expected a mea culpa from Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive. Instead, he turned the iPhone 4’s antenna problems into a marketing event on Friday.

headline: Investing in Exchange-Traded Funds
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan discusses the claims that have been made about exchange-traded funds. Its proponents have been saying recently that the funds are an ideal way to deal with volatile markets because they allow people to invest in particular niches but can be bought and sold more easily than a mutual fund.

headline: American Sprinter Drops Out With Broken Wrist
text: MENDE, France  After riding for more than a week at the Tour de France with a broken left wrist, Tyler Farrar, the top American sprinter here, wanted to keep going in Friday’s Stage 12.

headline: For Elizabeth Warren
text: I don’t have any idea what’s really going on with regard to the new head of the Consumer Financial Protection Board. As Matt says, such an appointment would raise the agency’s profile, and help attract first-rate staff.

headline: Cocktail Recipe: ABC Kitchen Rye Whiskey Manhattan

I love Manhattans in their original form, made with rye rather than with bourbon or blended whiskey. As for the other components, bitters and vermouth, well, they tend to fade from the picture.

headline: The Boys of Summer, Behind the Scenes
text: If timing is everything in baseball, then the MLB Network, the cable channel controlled by Major League Baseball, is in the groove with the new reality show “The Club.” The series focuses on the men who run the Chicago White Sox, a promising team that was written off after stumbling through the first two months of this season. But as “The Club” makes its premiere on Sunday night, the Sox are on a roll, having won 9 straight going into Friday night’s game, and 26 of their last 31, as they fought back into first place in their division.

headline: Finally in Front of His Own Hit Parade
text: IS it possible for a musician to emerge unscathed from the kind of early success enjoyed by the singer-songwriter Jimmy Webb? In the late 1960s, when he was barely 21, Mr. Webb was showered with Grammys for writing the Glen Campbell hits “By the Time I Get to Phoenix,” “Wichita Lineman,” “Galveston” and the Fifth Dimension’s “Up, Up and Away.” Then there was “MacArthur Park,” the grandiose quasi-symphonic “cake out in the rain” popularized by the Irish actor Richard Harris and in 1978 remade into a disco fantasia by Donna Summer.

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ Washington Tour Stop Is Scrapped
text: A two-week engagement of the musical “Dreamgirls,” scheduled to begin July 28 at the National Theater in Washington, has been canceled because “advance ticket sales have failed to meet expectations,”  according to a statement from the producers released on Thursday.

headline: Outlaws, Vampires and Other Party Starters
text: Jerrod Niemann

headline: On the Trail of Chelsea Clinton’s Wedding
text: It’s the New York-to-Washington social event of the season: The impending marriage of Chelsea Clinton, 30, former presidential daughter, to Marc Mezvinsky, 32, an investment banker at 3G Capital Management and a son of two former Democratic members of Congress. But the event is so cloaked in secrecy that even guests do not know the locale. Read Sheryl Gay Stolberg’s and Nate Schweber’s story on the upcoming nuptials in Times’s Style section.

headline: From Boards to Bikes
text: Rick Eusey and Lee Bender see their motorcycles as an opportunity for creative expression.

headline: Time Filled With Doctors and Therapists
text: It’s often an offhand remark or a small moment that crystallizes the difference between life before children and life after.

headline: Cablevision Customers Unable to Access E-Mail
text: Some Cablevision customers were irate on Friday after suffering an e-mail outage for more than 24 hours,  which took away access to their Cablevision e-mail accounts.

headline: Another View: A Victory for the Rule of Law
text: Senator Ted Kaufman, Democrat of Delaware, argues that the Goldman Sachs settlement proves that regulators can rein in Wall Street from its excesses and manipulations.

headline: Morphoses
text: Images from the New York premiere of Christopher Wheeldon's company at New York City Center.

headline: Shadows and Fall Guys, Even in Sunshine
text: FILM noir may be hard to define as a genre, but it’s easy to market. Such is the seductive power of the term — with its associations of shadows and smoke, of hapless men hamstrung by fate, of tough women operating outside the boundaries of conventional Hollywood morality — that it’s enough to put the label on the cover of a DVD to transform overlooked movies into salable commodities.

headline: Clean Water, Melting Ice, Carbon Cuts
text: Here’s a quick roundup of posts, images and developments that I find notable for various reasons:

headline: Google Buys Metaweb to Improve Search Results
text: There are some Web searches that Google doesn’t handle so well — like finding a famous person’s birthday, or searching for a word that means many different things. Search for “Boston,” for example, and all the top links are about the city in Massachusetts. But Boston is also the name of a band and 26 other cities.

headline: Have Pig, Will Dig
text: A step-by-step guide to roasting a whole hog in a pit.

headline: Mad Men City | Send Us Your Early ’60s Photos
text: Of all the characters in “Mad Men,” the AMC television series about advertising agencies in the 1960s, perhaps none is as distinct as New York City itself. Again and again, the city takes center stage — its bars, restaurants, office buildings, apartments, and of course, its people.

headline: A Bushwick Mansion Where Music Fills the Halls
text: A CENTURY ago, when Bushwick, Brooklyn, reigned as a center of the American brewing industry, a beer baron may have lived in the prim black-and-white mansion topped with a steeple on Bushwick Avenue. But even in his wildest dreams, this Victorian captain of industry would never have envisioned what the old place would be like a hundred years later.

headline: Arts Groups Use Twitter to Compete for Grant
text: 5:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: Jeffrey R. Gural
text: Mr. Gural, 68, is the chairman of Newmark Knight Frank, which provides real estate brokerage and consulting services worldwide. The company also manages 150 buildings in the New York City area, of which its principals have an ownership interest in 41, including the Flatiron Building.

headline: A Falling Homeownership Rate
text: AS foreclosures have risen nationwide, the homeownership rate has dipped, to around 67 percent as of late 2009 from a high of 69 percent in 2006, according to the Census Bureau. But a recent report by the New York Federal Reserve Bank puts the actual figure at nearly 62 percent, and that rate, the authors contend, is cause for concern.

headline: Another Way for Condos to Go Green
text: THE famous Jersey tomato — known for its delectability, and its ubiquity (seemingly no back garden is complete without a Big Boy or a beefsteak) — is about to make its debut as an amenity at a high-rise condominium complex.

headline: Condos Morph Into Rentals
text: JOSEPH MURISON, a painting contractor, has just renewed his $1,760-a-month lease on the Bay Shore apartment he first rented in July 2009.

headline: Costly Addresses, Bargain Prices
text: IT took Tim Ward and Ruth Turoff more than two years to find a house that they could afford in Hastings-on-Hudson, a community with spectacular views across the river to the Palisades in Rockland County. Mr. Ward, a mixed-media painter who exhibits in Manhattan and Philadelphia, was drawn to the village by its connection with painters like Jasper Francis Cropsey, a member of the Hudson River School of artists in the second half of the 19th century.

headline: Whatever Happened to Mystery?
text: WHERE have all the sphinxes gone? There’s not a person on this planet today who could make my heart stop as it did when I saw Greta Garbo on Madison Avenue. It was the last day of 1985, on an afternoon steeped in that merciless brightness you associate with early winter in the city, and, suddenly, there she was: a bulky fur coat, a knitted watch cap and an unpainted face, as closed as a fist, behind big sunglasses that had no aspiration to trendiness.

headline: 3 Auto Dealer Tactics the Overhaul Missed
text: Sometime next week, President Obama will finally sign a financial reform bill. Plenty of banks will have to deal with messy new rules, but one big winner in the “spare me from further regulation” sweepstakes was auto dealers.

headline: The Fall of Temporary Apartment Walls
text: AFTER graduating from Duke University this spring, Karan Sabharwal landed a job in finance in New York City. He had a plan to make Manhattan living affordable.

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: Sponsor-Owned Units

headline: For Brooklyn Buyers, a Matter of Morning Coffee
text: GEOFF HILL and Mike Korn did not know how much living space they needed, but they learned the hard way that 600 square feet was not enough.

headline: University Heights, the Bronx
text: LAST September, when Mary Robison was paying $1,550 for a one-bedroom apartment in Hell’s Kitchen with a view of an alley, she got her introduction to the Bronx. Through a mutual friend she met a man who lived in Fordham Hill Oval, a sprawling gated community of co-ops and rentals in University Heights, a neighborhood overlooking the Harlem River in the northwest Bronx.

headline: Ludlow Street, Light and Dark
text: EARLY one Saturday morning in June, a Heineken truck was picking up empties at the corner of Ludlow and Stanton Streets. Dominican workers were hauling pickles up from the basement of Katz’s Deli. The bourgeoisie were out walking their dogs. The dry cleaner was opening up for the day  after the big whirring street cleaner had been through, but before the guy in the Lower East Side Business Improvement District jumpsuit had started sweeping up the zillions of cigarette butts left over from another night on Ludlow Street.

headline: Reviving a Modernist Development in the Hamptons
text: THE Houses at Sagaponac  a 70-acre development in a wooded section of East Hampton  was meant to showcase modern architecture at moderate prices. Ten years ago, the impresario Harry J. Brown Jr. recruited dozens of prominent architects, including Zaha Hadid, Philip Johnson and Richard Meier, to design houses that he said would recall a time when the East End of Long Island was known for crisp, contemporary buildings.

headline: Yo-Yos, Loan-Packing and Other Good Times at the Auto Dealer
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I take a look at some of the goings-on at auto dealers now that they’ve won an exemption from oversight by the new consumer financial protection agency.

headline: Solondz Nurtures His Indie Cred
text: IF Todd Solondz, assiduous chronicler of suburban ugliness, perversity and despair, had directed “Charlie’s Angels: Full Throttle,” what sort of movie would have invaded theaters? Would Cameron Diaz’s goofy Natalie have started a rocky romance with a man with cerebral palsy? Would Lucy Liu’s tough-as-nails Alex have attacked a Planned Parenthood office? Would Bernie Mac’s dutiful Bosley have harbored a secret sexual fetish steeped in racial taboos? These are the sorts of themes Mr. Solondz has explored in his offbeat, frequently queasy oeuvre, and so he was surprised when, in the early aughts, Drew Barrymore met with him to discuss the possibility of him overseeing the “Charlie’s Angels” sequel.

headline: World Cup Final Ball Goes for $73,769 at Auction
text: Derided and ridiculed as a glorified, lightweight beach ball, the Adidas ball (the Jabulani for the majority of tournament; but the gold-trimmed Jo’bulani for the final between Spain and the Netherlands) used in last Sunday’s title match was sold at auction for $73,769.

headline: The Moviegoer | Checking in With Chiwetel
text: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tigris River and Elsewhere
text: It was hot on Friday in Baghdad (Slide 1), Rome (Slide 3) and Dhaka, Bangladesh (Slide 2). It was hot in June, too. In fact, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said this week that last month was the warmest June on record.

headline: Most Important Meal of the Day
text: During the overland trip from Peru to Ecuador, stuck for the night in San Ignacio. A 10-nuevo-sol ($3.72) hotel, very basic and barely satisfactory. Company, nil. Dinner, deeply, deeply fried chicken at what had stopped being a restaurant and started being an all-male drinking hole hours earlier.

headline: Loosening the iPhone Death Grip
text: Wow — just wow.

headline: Photos Reveal Receding Himalaya Glaciers
text: “There’s a lot of people who either don’t understand climate change that well and the effects that it’s having, or they want to deny the effect it’s having. These pictures are worth a thousand words. We haven’t done anything to them except print them.”

headline: A.I.G. to Pay $725 Million in Ohio Case
text: The American International Group, once the nation’s largest insurance group before it nearly collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $725 million to three Ohio pension funds to settle six-year-old claims of accounting fraud, stock manipulation and bid-rigging.

headline: Pandit Says Citigroup Can Absorb Curbs on Fees
text: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, sounded rather upbeat on Friday about his bank’s ability to absorb losses in revenue caused by the new financial regulations passed by Congress, in contrast to the feelings of heavy concern at rival banks like JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America.

headline: Tricked, Rwandan Refugees Are Driven Home, U.N. Says
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  About 1,700 Rwandans seeking asylum have been herded onto trucks at gunpoint and driven across the border to Rwanda in what the United Nations has called an illegal operation to repatriate refugees.

headline: Oxygen-Toting N.Y. Store Robber Dies in Car Chase in Md.
text: Police investigators who had been looking for an armed man in his 60s or 70s who robbed a Madison Avenue store last week while attached to an oxygen tank have ended the search. Turns out the suspect — identified as Arthur Williams, 63, of Gadsden, Ala. — died last weekend in a car accident in Maryland, the authorities said.

headline: Chic in Review | MObama’s Got a Brand-New Bag
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: War Photographers Among the Warriors
text: James Clark, Nate Danger Geist and Andres J. Lugo may not be the first names that would come to your mind if you were asked to list accomplished war photographers. But their work, seen here, exemplifies a remarkable development in the documentation of war: professional caliber photography — available to the public almost instantly — taken by the men and women who are also fighting the battles

headline: One-Man Whirlwind Visits Broadway
text: “This is huge,” Harry Connick Jr. declared on Thursday evening at the Neil Simon Theater, where he made his first Broadway concert appearance in 20 years in a show that runs through July 29. Huge would describe not only the musical forces amassed on the stage  a swing band on one side, a string section on the other and in the center a grand piano that Mr. Connick pounced on with ferocious vigor  but also Mr. Connick’s undiminished determination, at 42, to do it all.

headline: Letters
text: Exploring Dreamland

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, July 16
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Following Lincoln Through History
text: When Bill T. Jones was 5, as he is fond of reminiscing, Lincoln was the only white man he was allowed to love unconditionally. The ramifications of such a statement run deep, but in “Fondly Do We Hope ... Fervently Do We Pray,” Mr. Jones has created a pedantic production inspired by Lincoln  overly emphatic in terms of theater and breezily limited in terms of dance  that is less forceful than force-fed.

headline: Layered Vegetable Torte
text: Mark Bittman makes a vegetable torte with eggplant and summer squash.

headline: On Ellis Island, a Kinship With the Huddled Masses
text: ON a breezy, clear summer morning, Eddie Izzard  the British actor, comedian, transvestite and aspiring politician  took a trip to Ellis Island. He’d wanted to go ever since he first set a stiletto-heeled foot in this country in the 1990s, but never got around to it.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Social networking first influenced the travel world a decade ago by connecting travelers with people who had a free couch, writes Benji Lanyado. The next generation of couchsurfing is social B&B networks, which connect travelers to people willing to rent out their apartments. Mr. Lanyado put himself on the travelers’ market with a profile that read “Hello there. I am a 26-year-old from London. I like Chinese food and early ’90s Italian football shirts” and found matches in London, Paris and Barcelona. He gives all three a test run.

headline: Complaints Against Harlem Principal May Be Investigated
text: City Education Department officials said on Friday that they had received more complaints from teachers at Columbia Secondary School in West Harlem, where a field trip to an untended beach ended in the drowning of a 12-year-old girl.

headline: A.I.G. to Pay $725 Million to Resolve Fraud Claims
text: 6:52 p.m. | Updated The American International Group, the nation’s largest insurance group before it collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $725 million to three Ohio pension funds to settle claims of widespread fraud, The New York Times’s Michael Powell and Mary Williams Walsh report.

headline: At Garden, Mild Waves From the King of Mellow
text: Just a few small tweaks, and Jack Johnson’s show at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night would have been perfect. First, the time of day  his songs are meant for lazy beach afternoons. Hearing them after sunset feels disorienting. Second, the location: the Garden, it’s just so claustrophobic, so air-conditioned, so indoors. Let those breezy rhythms breathe. Third, the crowd: let’s lose about 17,000 or so of those people, swaying arrhythmically to Mr. Johnson’s songs, light as tissue paper.

headline: Director Accepts Limits on Chevron to Footage
text: When a judge ordered a documentary filmmaker in May to turn over to Chevron all the unused footage from his 2009 film about an environmental controversy in Ecuador, the director, Joe Berlinger, called the ruling “a trampling of the First Amendment and the journalist’s privilege.”

headline: Layered Vegetable Torte
text: Roasting the vegetables first is the key.

headline: A Vegetable Torte Starts at the Grill
text: VEGETABLE torte was not in my repertory until recently. I thought there was something a wee bit fussy about it, something a bit ’80s. But I kept encountering these non-pastry cakes and enjoying them, so it was time to make one of my own.

headline: Gun Control as Economic Stimulus
text: Federal tax revenue on the sales of firearms and ammunition rose 45 percent in the last fiscal year. That is the highest annual increase on record, according to a new report from the Treasury Department’s Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau.

headline: American Success Story
text: In this portion of the May 8, 1972, interview with Dick Cavett, Arthur Godfrey talks about his youth in New York City, contributing to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's funeral broadcast and how the president helped him become a pilot.

headline: Canada’s Defense Chief Rejects Criticism of F-35 Jet
text: OTTAWA  Canada’s defense minister rejected suggestions on Friday that the F-35 fighter jet was unnecessarily sophisticated and costly for the country’s relatively small air force.

headline: Latest Accessory of a Well-Equipped Band: A Festival of Its Own
text: MARIAVILLE, N.Y.  Around 2 a.m. on Friday on a wooded hillside here, about 30 miles northwest of Albany, a few thousand young music lovers poured into the humid summer darkness from a tent where they had just seen an up-and-coming band with a two-word name. The first word is Holy. The second is anything but.

headline: A Rewarding Vegetable Torte
text: Full disclosure: strictly speaking, this vegetable torte is not “minimalist.” It takes more preparation and time than I usually like, it requires some assembly and two cooking stages, and you’ll need a springform pan (you have one if you’ve ever made cheesecake). But there are no fancy techniques involved, and it’s impressive-looking, delicious, and “good for you.” Check it out.

headline: Continuing Problems For Lilith Fair
text: More bad news for Lilith Fair. Two weeks after the package tour  a revival of Sarah McLachlan’s successful woman-centric lineups of the late 1990s  canceled 10 dates, most likely (but not officially) because of weak ticket sales, Carly Simon, below, has announced her withdrawal from three shows because of an injury. On Thursday the tour’s organizers said Ms. Simon would not perform at the Comcast Center in Mansfield, Mass., on July 30; the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on July 31; and Hartford on Aug. 1. “Last week, Simon suffered an injury by seriously fracturing and breaking her foot, which will prevent her from performing at these shows,” a statement said. Lilith’s problems are widely seen in the concert industry as part of a broader pattern of slow sales this summer. Last week the trade magazine Pollstar said grosses for the Top 100 tours in North America were down by 17 percent from the same period last year.

headline: Brooks to the Future in His First Novel
text: In his feature films Albert Brooks, right, has traveled across the country (eventually) and to the afterlife. So for his first novel, there was only one place left to go: the future. “I’ve always liked to think ahead,” Mr. Brooks, the comedian, filmmaker (“Lost in America”) and actor (“Broadcast News”) said in a telephone interview. “Not stupid-far ahead. A hundred years doesn’t interest me. But 20 years interests me, and more for what happens to humans as opposed to things.” That’s the not-too-distant future Mr. Brooks will explore in “2030: The Real Story of What Happens to America,” a novel that St. Martin’s Press will publish in May 2011, the publisher announced on Friday. As St. Martin’s described the book in an e-mail message, “2030” takes place at a time when “a population that has finally been freed from the scourge of cancer is dramatically aging, sparking resentment against the ‘olds’ and leading to a nation so hamstrung by entitlements and debt that its only way out are solutions heretofore unthinkable.”

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ Won’t Go To Washington
text: A two-week engagement of the musical “Dreamgirls,” scheduled to begin on July 28 at the National Theater in Washington, has been canceled because of lackluster ticket sales. A statement from the producers released on Thursday said the engagement “has been canceled as advance ticket sales have failed to meet expectations.” The show was scheduled to run through Aug. 8 as part of a national tour that includes 12 more cities and is currently booked through Jan. 2. The producers hope to take “Dreamgirls” to Washington “at a later time,” the statement said. Directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, the revival of the 1981 Broadway musical about a Supremes-like singing trio opened last November at the Apollo Theater in New York, the setting for the show’s opening and closing scenes.

headline: Jailed Man Is Nominated for an Emmy
text: Robert Joel Halderman, below, in jail for trying to extort money from David Letterman, has been nominated for a news Emmy Award. Along with six of his former colleagues at CBS News, he is up for an Emmy in the category called “outstanding continuing coverage of a news story in a news magazine.” He was a producer on a “48 Hours Mystery” episode, “American Girl, Italian Nightmare.” His nomination came as a surprise to some in the TV business, given that he was dismissed by CBS after he was arrested in the extortion attempt. When asked whether CBS News nominated Mr. Halderman, a “48 Hours” spokesman said: “For more than two years, a team of journalists worked very hard on this important hour. The producers of ‘48 Hours’ felt that not to nominate their work would unfairly deprive the many other dedicated journalists involved of recognition they had earned.” Pleading guilty last March, Mr. Halderman admitted to having tried to extort $2 million from Mr. Letterman last year. The incident caused Mr. Letterman to tell his “Late Show” viewers about his affairs with female staff members. Mr. Halderman was sentenced to six months in jail in May.

headline: A Boost for Beer-Can Chicken
text: A FEW years ago, I tried to make beer-can chicken. The recipe called for balancing a whole chicken on a half-empty can of beer, then grilling it over indirect heat. The steam generated from the beer was supposed to keep the chicken moist, while the indirect heat bronzed the skin without turning it black.

headline: Reality Showdown
text: ABC’s “Wipeout” edged ahead of CBS’s “Big Brother” in the ratings on Thursday night as these two reality shows faced off in the 8 o’clock time slot. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Wipeout” delivered 7.8 million viewers, compared with 7 million who tuned in to “Big Brother,” but CBS managed to lead the night over all with solid ratings for repeats of its crime shows “CSI” (6.7 million) and “The Mentalist” (7.4 million). ABC’s “Rookie Blue” earned decent ratings at 9 (6.4 million), while the network drew a more modest audience at 10 for “Boston Med” (4.7 million). Fox finished third, and NBC ranked fourth.

headline: ‘Clear Day’ for Off Broadway
text: The Vineyard Theater will present the director Michael Mayer’s new version of the musical “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,” beginning in January. The original Alan Jay Lerner/Burton Lane musical, about a young woman with ESP who seeks help from a psychiatrist only to discover that she was also a woman who lived in 18th-century Britain, opened on Broadway in 1965, starring Barbara Harris and John Cullum. Vincente Minnelli’s 1970 film version starred Barbra Streisand and Yves Montand. Peter Parnell’s new book, which will be based on the original Lerner story, is expected to make changes in some characters and time periods, mix material from the stage and film versions and eliminate some production numbers, Mr. Mayer said in an interview in June. No casting or performance dates have been announced for the Vineyard production.

headline: On the Street | Unwilted
text: Men kept their habitual dress intact during the heat and humidity of the last two weeks, not counting the waits on steamy subway platforms, when suit jackets were carried.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, July 16
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a drug dealer turned author, an Olympic hopeful, and an archeological find at the World Trade Center site.

headline: A Summer Hike on Cadillac Mountain
text: The First Family escaped the humidity of Washington on Friday, traveling to Bar Harbor, Maine, for a short vacation on Mt. Desert Island. President Obama, along with his wife, Michelle, and daughters, Malia and Sasha, packed the first afternoon full of bike-riding in Acadia National Park, hiking Cadillac Mountain and stopping to pick up an ice cream cone in town. No word as yet where the family plans to eat dinner, but in those parts, one can’t go wrong with lobster.

headline: From One Benefactor, Diverse Seeds in Theology
text: At the end of “Hannah’s Child,” the gossipy yet very moving new memoir by the theologian Stanley Hauerwas, the author thanks one Alonzo McDonald for financing the sabbatical that made the book possible.

headline: University Doesn’t Want Film of Artist’s Children
text: After it came to light last week that films and videotapes made by the artist Larry Rivers included footage of his two daughters naked, New York University informed his foundation that it did not want those materials included as part of the archive it was purchasing, said John Beckman, a spokesman for N.Y.U.

headline: Double-Decker Jets From Dubai Will Resume
text: Emirates Airlines is planning to reintroduce its Airbus A380 double-decker jumbo jet to the United States by resuming  flights between Kennedy and Dubai on Oct. 31. The flight’s amenities include fully enclosed suites for first-class passengers, five-course meals prepared in a private kitchen in Dubai for first- and business-class passengers, and on the upper deck, showers and a full-service cocktail lounge.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A bevy of ethnic festivals will take place this weekend. On Saturday, the Cool Japan Festival  in the East Village (Fourth Avenue between Eighth and Tenth Streets), from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. will offer sample dishes from a number of restaurants in the neighborhood. In Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the Arab American Bazaar, from 1 to 8 p.m. at Shore Road Park, 79th Street and Shore Road, will feature live music, dance performers and food vendors. On Sunday, Astoria, Queens, is home to the  Peruvian Independence Fair,  from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Crescent Street at 36th Avenue, and Indonesian Food Bazaar (from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. outside the Al-Hikmah Mosque at 48-01 31st Avenue at 48th Street). In Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens, a Colombian Independence Day festival from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. should include lots of food.

headline: James Did the Knicks Some Good
text: LeBron James did not choose to take his talents to New York, but as a consolation prize he gave the Knicks a fantastic boost at the box office. The team has sold out its season-ticket allotment for the first time in nine years.

headline: Iran’s President Renews Pressure on Conservatives
text: TEHRAN — Having successfully suppressed the opposition uprising that followed last summer’s disputed presidential election, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his supporters are now renewing their efforts to marginalize another rival group — Iran’s traditional conservatives.

headline: Human (and Mathematical) Equations
text: Zeroes, ones, twos and threes glide and slide, shimmy and leap before your eyes in the quietly mesmerizing play “A Disappearing Number,” a production from the British company Complicite that plays through Sunday as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. The familiar little digits we use for all sorts of mundane purposes, like marking time and counting money, slowly begin to acquire talismanic power as they swim across the video screens onstage or blink from a clock in the corner.

headline: Still Learning the Leader’s Name? Start With an ‘Oh!’
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  They are still getting familiar with Louis Oosthuizen at St. Andrews. On Friday, the second day of this British Open, reporters were still double-checking the pronunciation of his name.

headline: How Some Yankees Heard the News
text: Seven of the Yankees’ eight All-Stars were in Anaheim, Calif., when they learned Tuesday morning that George Steinbrenner had died. The other, Mariano Rivera, was on a brief vacation, resting the knee and oblique injuries that compelled him to withdraw from the game. He said he heard about Steinbrenner’s death from a variety of channels, but he did not actually believe it. So he called Ben Tuliebitz, the team’s traveling secretary, “to make sure that it was legit.”

headline: Lucy Lueders-Booth and Duc Nguyen
text: Lucy Lueders-Booth and Duc Nguyen were married Saturday at Edgewood Farm, an events space in Deer Isle, Me. The Rev. Allen Myers, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: The Guest Who Stirred Up Film Audiences, Now Onstage
text: The purist is the natural enemy of the avant-garde, so it’s no surprise that in reviews and discussions of the polarizing work of the Flemish director Ivo van Hove, this hypothetical traditionalist often makes an appearance. Forever wedded to convention, this conservative audience member is usually expressing priggish displeasure at some radical spin on a great work.

headline: Harriet Blacker and Henry Spector
text: Harriet Blacker and Dr. Henry Theodore Spector are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Lee Friedlander at the couple’s weekend home in Sherman, Conn.

headline: Two New Lightweight iPad Cases
text: Apple sold its own iPad case by the bunches when the device was released, but now that independent companies have had time to design their own, much better choices await.

headline: Danielle Tobias, Joshua Gadharf
text: Danielle Beth Tobias and Joshua Aaron Gadharf were married Saturday evening at Temple Israel in West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi Paul Yedwab officiated and Rabbi Harold Loss took part.

headline: Cara Protzko, Jayson Baron
text: Cara Teresa Protzko and Jayson Victor Baron are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Richard H. Berman at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Kathleen Milnamow, Eric Stern
text: Kathleen Kerrigan Milnamow, a daughter of Nancy B. Milnamow and Robert J. Milnamow of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Eric David Stern, a son of Dr. David M. Stern and Dr. Kathleen S. Stern of Cincinnati. The Rev. Brigitta Remole performed the ceremony at the Wilton Congregational Church, where she is senior minister.

headline: Anne Waterman, Bass Bassin
text: Anne L. Waterman and Darin H. Bassin were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York. Dr. David M. Posner, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated.

headline: Courtney Napoles, Daniel Cohen
text: Courtney Denise Napoles, a daughter of LaWayne D. Napoles and J. George Napoles II of Okemos, Mich., was married Saturday to Daniel Lee Cohen, the son of Shelly Cohen and Ira S. Cohen of Stony Brook, N.Y.

headline: Alyssa Litoff, Joshua Gordon
text: Alyssa Barrett Litoff and Joshua Todd Gordon were married Saturday at Rosecliff, a mansion in Newport, R.I.

headline: Amanda Weicker, Christopher Ix
text: Amanda Joy Weicker, a daughter of Lisa Hull Weicker and Scot B. Weicker of Riverside, Conn., was married Saturday to Christopher Prouty Ix, a son of Mildred Gilmore Ix and Robert E. Ix of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Mark A. Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Church in Greenwich.

headline: Lindsay Dorrance, T. J. Ortenzi
text: Lindsay Calbraith Dorrance and Anthony Joseph Ortenzi were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Marie L. Buffaloe, a Presbyterian minister, at the Conewago Manor Inn in Elizabethtown, Pa.

text: Hayley Kitt Matz and David Randall Meadvin were married Saturday evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Cantor Tracey Scher officiated.

headline: Karen Kaplan, Joel Solomon
text: Karen Jennifer Kaplan and Joel William Solomon were married Saturday evening on Shelter Island, in New York. Cantor Debra Stein officiated at the Pridwin Beach Hotel & Cottages.

headline: Abby Wehr, Charles Diemar
text: Abby Lynne Wehr, the daughter of Teresa and James Wehr of South Windsor, Conn., was married in Manchester, Conn., Saturday to Charles Craig Diemar, a son of Eleanor and Robert Diemar Jr. of Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. Kevin P. Cavanaugh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church, where he is pastor.

headline: Cristiana Pieroni, Andrew McGee
text: Dr. Cristiana Geny Pieroni and Andrew David McGee were married Saturday evening at the Central Park Boathouse in New York. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated.

headline: Louisa Conrad and Lucas Farrell

Farrell and Thomas H. Farrell of Kaohsiung, Taiwan and Kennebunk, Me. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew’s Church, where he is rector.

headline: Emma Mittelstaedt, James Burnham
text: Emma Kathryn Mittelstaedt and James Mahoney Burnham were married Saturday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort and country club in St. Helena, Calif. Dr. Frank R. Parrish, a minister of the International Church of the Foursquare Gospel and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

text: Gayley Morris Woolston and Edward Bion Piepmeier were married in New Haven Saturday. The Rev. David C. Cobb, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church, where he is the rector.

headline: Abigail Povich, Scott Weinstein
text: Abigail Lee Povich, the daughter of Judith L. Povich and Michael E. Povich of Ellsworth, Me., was married Saturday in Bar Harbor, Me., to Scott Regan Weinstein, the son of Irma Weinstein and Lawrence Weinstein of Norfolk, Va. Leading the ceremony, at the Bar Harbor Regency, was the bride’s father, who as a lawyer admitted to the Maine bar was authorized to officiate.

headline: Katharine Lusk, Nicholas Stipinovich
text: Katharine Adams Lusk and Nicholas Stipinovich were married Saturday in Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Benedict Kiely, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Blessed Sacrament Church, where he is pastor.

headline: Susan O’Hare, Alasdair McBarnet
text: Susan Jane O’Hare and Alasdair Matthew McBarnet were married Saturday. Carissa Templeton, a Rose Ministries officiant, performed the ceremony at Battery Gardens in Manhattan.

headline: Avery Eyre, Benjamin Lovejoy
text: Avery Cooper Eyre and Benjamin Nickerson Lovejoy were married Saturday at the Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Andrew G. Butler III, an Episcopal priest and the church’s assistant rector, led the ceremony.

headline: Grandpa, I Think Lady Macbeth Just Swore
text: LONDON  The little girl was about to experience a British rite of passage, her first Shakespeare play, but she had a question first: “Will it be very scary?”

headline: Emily Lucas, Joseph Turilli
text: Emily Ann Lucas, a daughter of Virginia L. Lucas and Jerome D. Lucas of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Joseph Duilio Turilli, a son of Carol Ann Turilli and Dr. Nicholas J. Turilli of North Kingstown, R.I. The Rev. Marcel L. Taillon, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the assistance of the Rev. Joseph G. Fonti at St. Dominic’s Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.
