text: Rebecca Graham Whidden, a daughter of Anne Derry Whidden and Roger G. Whidden of New York, was married Saturday to Christopher Snow Rogers, a son of Deborah Westin Rogers and Bruce A. Rogers of Richmond, R.I. The Rev. David R. Adams, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the summer home of the bride’s parents in Brooksville, Me.

headline: Kitty Moore, G. Alan Marlatt
text: Kitty Moore and G. Alan Marlatt are to be married Sunday at the Lakeside Event Center in Seattle. Jhampa Shaneman, a lay Buddhist minister, is to officiate.

headline: Uchenna Hicks, Steven McFarland
text: Uchenna Latrice Hicks and Steven Ray McFarland were married Saturday evening at Bubby’s, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Lexi Lee, Justin Sullivan
text: Alexandra Lee, a daughter of Elizabeth Brownell Lee and James B. Lee Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married Saturday evening in Williamstown, Mass., to Justin Patrick Sullivan, a son of Brian J. Sullivan of Lowell, Mass., and the late Mary Ann Sullivan. The Rev. Gary C. Caster, a Roman Catholic priest, led the ceremony at Chapin Hall at Williams College, where he is the Catholic chaplain.

headline: Edward Farley and Matthew Horowitz
text: Edward Thomas Farley and Matthew Bret Horowitz were married Saturday at Equinox Resort and Spa in Manchester, Vt. Dr. Ann R. Garment, a friend of the couple, was appointed by the State of Vermont to solemnize the marriage as a one-day temporary officiant.

headline: Bid To Trade Box Office Futures Dies
text: Plans to open exchanges that would trade in movie box office futures died on Thursday, as the financial-regulatory legislation passed by the Senate includes a provision banning the proposed practice. The legislation was already passed by the House and has moved to President Obama for his signature. Proposed exchanges from Cantor Fitzgerald and Veriana Networks had worked their way through review at the Commodities Futures Trading Commission but ran into Congressional opposition as film studios, theater owners and organizations representing directors and other workers lobbied fiercely against them. The companies argued that futures trading would be a useful hedging device for film companies, but the studios, led by the Motion Picture Association of America, said box office futures would be easily manipulated and of no use to the big film companies.

headline: A King Kills an Entry and Swallows a Queen
text: OPATIJA, Croatia  The 10th European Youth Pairs Championships is taking place through Saturday in this town in northwest Croatia, on the Adriatic Sea.

headline: A Day for Farewell in the Bronx
text: As the Yankees returned to work after the All-Star break, players, opponents, fans and team employees shared their memories of George Steinbrenner and Bob Sheppard, who died earlier this week, at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Losing the Crusades — A Blessing?
text: On my family’s recent trip to Israel, one of the topics we were debating was whether the loss of the Crusades was ultimately a good thing for Christianity, and the loss of the Second Temple ultimately a good thing for Judaism.

headline: Celebrating Summer, Sunsets and the Sounds of Jazz
text: BACK in 1979, when Mark Morganelli was presenting jazz in his East Village loft, he inadvertently gave the drummer Jimmy Cobb a check that bounced. Mr. Cobb  who was already a prominent figure in jazz, having appeared with Miles Davis on classic records like “Kind of Blue” and “Sketches of Spain”  was unaccustomed to receiving bad checks.

headline: The Piano Teacher Sings in Go-Go Boots
text: PARENTS who sign their children up for piano lessons with Francine Wheeler of Newtown, Conn., invariably get a lot more than they bargained for. Ms. Wheeler, 42, is far from your typical “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star” kind of teacher. She has been known to take students to perform at nearby retirement homes, she teaches belt-it-out singing, and she is something of a rock star.

headline: The Sting of Scandal, Public and Private
text: “Nothing says scandal like a living room with a shredder,” one character remarks dryly during the opening minutes of “Sunlight,” commenting on the mess in the home of a beleaguered college president.

headline: Lowdown Schemes and High Dysfunction
text: When it comes to dysfunction, the Talley clan is no slouch. In “Fifth of July,” by Lanford Wilson, members of the family vent their collective spleen with a vengeance. The opening salvo of the so-called Talley Trilogy, “Fifth of July,” first produced in 1978, is receiving a robust outing at Bay Street Theater, Sag Harbor, in a co-production with the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts.

headline: Playing Ball With the Devil
text: “Baseball is only one-half skill,” the coach in “Damn Yankees” tells his dejected team, the Washington Senators. He sings about the other half, “You’ve gotta have heart.”

headline: 33 Select Films Over 10 Days
text: Jews in American baseball, flood victims in the Netherlands and Russian musicians in Paris are among the subjects of movies in the 15th Annual Stony Brook Film Festival, opening on Thursday at Stony Brook University.

headline: Seafood, and Lots of It
text: New Wave Seafood is no longer new; it’s been around for 25 years. But the wave it has been riding — fresh fish, a fair share caught in area waters — never gets old.

headline: You Can’t Stop the Aerosol
text: “Hairspray” is a simple story. A fat girl becomes an overnight local TV star on her favorite teenage dance show, and as a result she changes the world. Or at least brings the civil rights movement to Baltimore.

headline: Buried in Rocks, but Keeping Her Chin Up
text: Mark Lamos knows a hard sell when he sees one.

headline: Flights Are Delayed, but Lives Go On
text: He’s a straight-arrow businessman in the standard-issue suit and tie, with standard-issue black luggage and a computer case. She’s a mop-haired flake in clogs and a long, gathered skirt, toting colorful fabric bags and a large brownish cylinder  it could be some kind of artisanal bread or salami, but turns out to be, of all things, a rain stick. Clearly, the two characters in Steven Dietz’s “Shooting Star” live in different worlds.

headline: War, Money and Other Silliness
text: War is absolutely not a glorious business. And rich people really shouldn’t have servants. Or if they do, they should treat them as equals.

headline: Rock Fans, Grab Your Cameras
text: The Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter Andy Kim has had his share of Top 40 success, including writing and performing the 1970s hit “Rock Me Gently” and writing, with Jeff Barry, the Archies’ chestnut “Sugar, Sugar.” So at this point he is sanguine about participating in an event some might consider not especially rock ’n’ roll. Like a convention.

headline: An Old Brick Mill Turns to a New Purpose
text: THE menu said gazpacho, but the pastel-colored soup looked like no gazpacho I had ever met. More stew than soup, it was a cool, summery jumble of corn kernels and diced potato, bathed in thickened cream sweetened with pureed corn “milk,” topped with crab and avocado. Calling it gazpacho was a sleight of hand in character with much about the Mill at 2t, an inventive, charming and rather quirky restaurant in Tariffville.

headline: A Field Trip to an Apple Lab
text: In the wake of a hastily called news conference to defend its popular iPhone 4 smartphone this morning, Apple invited 11 reporters (including me) to visit one of its wireless testing labs.

headline: No Ordinary Greek Delights
text: Esther Luongo Psarakis may have a familiar-sounding story, but what she sells at Taste of Crete, her specialty food company and store in Hillsborough, is out of the ordinary. The treats include a spread called tomato caviar ($8.99 for a 7.6-ounce jar) and a dessert topping of figs in honey with chocolate and ginger ($8.99 for 14.1 ounces).

headline: Boxee Readies Its Set-Top Box
text: Boxee, software that allows users to watch movies and TV shows from the Web on a television, is preparing to introduce a set-top box in a few months.

headline: A Weekend Spot by the Waterfront
text: FOR many beachgoers stalking the northern reaches of New Jersey’s shoreline, Atlantic Highlands is a blip on a GPS device, an easily overlooked exit on the strip of Route 36 connecting the Garden State Parkway to the sandy pleasures of Sandy Hook.

headline: If Mother Nature Made Ice Cream
text: The Blue Pig has been a source of gourmet ice cream for years. But the new owner, Lisa Moir, who reopened the shop in May, has taken gourmet to the next level.

headline: A Brew Pub With Ambitions
text: BACON-FLECKED ice cream? Even knowing that Birdsall House, a new beer bar in Peekskill, sources its delicious pork locally from nearby Hemlock Hill Farm, I still felt some trepidation as I ordered the unusual dessert. But all worries disappeared with the first bite. The crispy, smoky meat paired perfectly with the creamy, maple-flavored ice cream and — not for the first time — I thought, “This is a creative kitchen.”

headline: Specialty Goods Find a Traditional Niche
text: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.

headline: Bangladesh, With Low Pay, Moves In on China
text: GAZIPUR, Bangladesh  The eight-lane highway leading from the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, narrows repeatedly as it approaches this town about 30 miles north, eventually depositing cars onto a muddy, potholed lane bordered by mangroves and small shops.

headline: China Tests New Controls on Twitter-Style Services
text: BEIJING  China’s biggest Internet companies are testing new controls on some local alternatives to Twitter to prevent them from becoming channels for the proliferation of content the authorities dislike.

headline: Was Steinbrenner Just Lucky?
text: Before he bought the New York Yankees, George Steinbrenner tried to buy the Cleveland Indians.

headline: Philharmonic Paid Maazel $3.3 Million in Last Year
text: Lorin Maazel earned $3.3 million in his final season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, a figure representing a $500,000 increase over the previous season, according to the orchestra’s newly filed tax return.

headline: Social Security in a Sluggish Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nightmare in Apt. 9B
text: SOMETHING was wrong in Apartment 9B.

headline: Shifting Politics in Presidents’ Vacations
text: BAR HARBOR, Me.  It has been 100 years, the local newspaper reports, since a sitting president chose this picturesque seaside village as his vacation spot. When William Howard Taft arrived in July 1910, he sprained his ankle playing golf, the captain of his yacht got “a terrible sunburn” and the townsfolk made such a ruckus about who would entertain him that Mr. Taft decided to give a speech from the bandstand on the village green.

headline: Espada, Under Investigation, Faces a Well-Financed Opponent
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the State Senate majority leader, has already been accused by New York’s attorney general of using his network of health clinics for personal gain and is under investigation by federal prosecutors.

headline: Cars at Curbside, Available to Share
text: In a city blessed with every variety of public transportation, car traffic is awful and parking is even worse. Yet some people still insist, against all logic, on owning a car.

headline: Bagels and Books (and a Few Scores)
text: Alan Gilbert, 43, the music director since September of the New York Philharmonic, doesn’t listen to much classical music on Sundays. Instead, he and his wife, Kajsa William-Olsson, 39, devote the day to their daughters, Noemi, 6, and Lia, 5 months, and their son, Esra, 4. The couple met while Mr. Gilbert was chief conductor of the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra; Ms. William-Olsson, who is Swedish, was a cellist there. When they moved to New York, they decided to live on the Upper West Side, where Mr. Gilbert grew up.

headline: Why No Players at Sheppard’s Funeral?
text: The Yankees were represented at Bob Sheppard’s funeral Mass on Thursday by, among others, General Manager Brian Cashman. But no one who ever wore a Yankees uniform was seen in the Church of St. Christopher. Manager Joe Girardi and Derek Jeter, the team’s captain, were asked why no one attended.

headline: Panel Restores Medals to Jones’s Teammates
text: The relay teammates of Marion Jones can keep the Olympic medals they won at the Sydney Games. The Court of Arbitration for Sport announced Friday that it had overturned a decision by the International Olympic Committee to disqualify the team because Jones admitted to doping.

headline: A Long Jump to Manhood
text: HIGH above the Hudson River, at the tip of the New York mainland, a few teenage boys stood expectantly on the cliffs. Looking like tall, reedy sprouts amid the jumping spots they call Jungle and Capone’s Chair, the shirtless boys scanned the horizon, searching for someone to impress.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE INTERCONTINENTAL NEW YORK TIMES SQUARE, a sleek new 36-story, 607-room tower at 44th Street and Eighth Avenue, has fancy Italian exercise equipment that syncs with your iPod. The machines look too hip to hop on, and who needs a gym anyway, when you’re chasing the fast-walking hotel manager, Drew Schlesinger, on a tour of the place?

headline: In Asia, More Than 5,000 Are Charged With Gambling
text: In coordinated raids across Asia, police investigators arrested more than 5,000 people and seized nearly $10 million in a monthlong operation to smash sophisticated soccer gambling dens that took bets via cellphones and Web sites.

headline: How a Reward Led to a Tragedy at the Beach
text: The kids begged in the way that only 12-year-olds can, like drill bits spinning at 3,000 tireless revolutions a minute. The principal had promised a trip to the beach for the class that raised the most money in a walk-a-thon. And the sixth graders in the House of Einstein  their school, Columbia Secondary, groups students into houses  had tied for first.

headline: For People on the Margins, a Ministry Steps Outdoors
text: A barefoot woman with a head full of tangled locks staggered into a circle of worshipers, trying to hold up her head as the preacher delivered a sermon. She found a worn patch of grass and sat, lowering her head between her knees and nodding as the minister spoke of God’s love and loving thy neighbor.

headline: S.E.C. Split Reported on Goldman
text: The commissioners of the Securities and Exchange Commission were divided on whether to approve the $550 million settlement with Goldman Sachs, which ended months of negotiations over a securities fraud case, people with knowledge of the vote said Friday.

headline: Getting Slim Just by Riding the Subway
text: The subway is the ultimate multitasker’s delight, a fast-moving all-purpose room that allows New Yorkers to speed toward their destination while simultaneously escaping the city altogether, through their phones’ movie downloads or that handy-dandy throwback, the paperback. A commuter might look up from the spreadsheet on her lap to absorb an unspoken fashion tip from the fellow rider who found a wearable version of the high-waisted pouf skirt. Another might glance up from his legal brief to find the scene before him: a simmering negotiation over space, an angling for a date  a strategy breakthrough. Or free live theater.

headline: Are Tea Parties Racist? Is Al Qaeda?
text: On Tuesday, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People released this statement: “Over 2,000 N.A.A.C.P. delegates today unanimously passed a resolution—as amended—called ‘The Tea Party Movement,’ asking for the repudiation of racist Tea Party leaders.”

headline: Bards of Soccer, and Perhaps Love
text: NO doubt, this was New York’s most popular and highly watched World Cup series: packed bars, crowds spilling out onto sidewalks, team jerseys dotting the streets. It was also — perhaps not coincidentally — marked by a month’s worth of attraction and flirtation. The following poems about men, women and FIFA soccer were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.  ALAN FEUER

headline: Without the Boss, Some Lapsed Fans Rethink the Yankees
text: Joe Raffetto lives deep in New York Yankees country (the state of New Jersey). When he talks about the Yankees he has loved  that is the word he uses, without even thinking about it  he speaks not of Jeter, Posada and Rivera, but of Berra, DiMaggio and Rizzuto.

headline: After Much Bad News, Wary Acceptance of Good
text: Percy Baulden, a New Orleans firefighter, says that about a month ago he found himself coming down with an ailment that he has named “oil well fatigue.” The symptoms included a feeling of hopelessness and chronic irritation at the mention of “BP,” “Deepwater Horizon” and any combination of the usually innocuous terms “spill,” “containment” and “cap.”

headline: Tweet Less, Kiss More
text: I was driving from Washington to New York one afternoon on Interstate 95 when a car came zooming up behind me, really flying. I could see in the rearview mirror that the driver was talking on her cellphone.

headline: Goldman Settlement Is Said to Split S.E.C.
text: The commissioners of the Securities and Exchange Commission were divided on whether to approve the $550 million settlement with Goldman Sachs, which ended months of negotiations over a securities fraud case, people with knowledge of the vote said Friday evening.

headline: Tribute at Stadium: Silence Early, Cheering Late
text: As Yankee Stadium fell silent early Friday evening, Frank Sinatra’s voice wafted over the loudspeakers. Sinatra was singing “My Way,” a tune that George Steinbrenner no doubt knew well and with which he surely identified.

headline: Iraq-Austerity, Updated
text: After I posted this, Chris Hayes emailed me to point out that I had, in fact, made a very similar comparison back in February:

headline: The Family Car(go) Bike
text: Kelly Craig and her daughters ride their cargo hauling tricycle instead of taking their car, a taxi or the subway.

headline: Let’s Repeal 2010
text: This has been a bad summer for almost everybody — celebrities, shrimpers, Washington insiders, Tea Party outsiders, people who prefer pleasant weather. So far, my list of who did well only includes the Spanish soccer team and Paul the prophetic octopus. Plus, according to Senator Jim Bunning, George Steinbrenner. The Kentucky Republican praised the Yankee owner in the Senate Finance Committee for being “smart enough to die in 2010,” when the estate tax is temporarily suspended.

headline: A Dream of a New Life Is Painted Black by Oil
text: WAVELAND, Miss.  When she retired five years ago, Dia D’Ingianni bought a beach house here, drawn by the sugary white sand, the warm water that stays shallow a long way out, and the charming town.

headline: Short List Emerges for Consumer Guardian
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, savoring Congressional approval of a far-reaching financial regulation bill, now faces a crucial choice over who will lead the powerful new consumer guardian created by the legislation.

headline: Heat Roster Isn’t Only One Overhauled
text: Outside South Beach, All-Stars and quality players will soon begin their transitions to new teams, resulting in a few seismic shifts that will give the N.B.A. a face-lift next season beyond the annual draft and the musical chairs of coaches and front office executives.

headline: After The Fall
text: John Quiggin writes:

headline: Taking an Alternative Path in Fighting the Disease
text: Ideas about how to treat Alzheimer’s fall into two main categories. The main one pins its hopes on blocking amyloid beta peptides that form areas of plaque on the brain. But there is also another protein, tau, that is part of the disease. Tau is damaged when patients have Alzheimer’s, chemically modified so it wrecks structures inside cells that are used to transport chemicals.

headline: Drug Trials Test Bold Plan to Slow Alzheimer’s
text: Marilyn Maldonado is not quite sure why she is at the Memory Enhancement Center in the seaside town of Oakhurst, N.J.

headline: West Virginia Governor Picks Ex-General Counsel to Succeed Byrd
text: WASHINGTON  West Virginia’s governor, Joe Manchin III, announced on Friday that he had chosen Carte P. Goodwin, his former general counsel, to temporarily fill the Senate seat long held by Robert C. Byrd.

headline: More of Our Man Godfrey
text: I’m glad to see how many readers/viewers liked revisiting — or visiting for the first time — Arthur Godfrey.

headline: Pakistani Legislators Face Accusations of Faking Their Degrees
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In a national scandal that has evoked outrage as well as laughter, dozens of Pakistani Parliament members have been accused in recent months of possessing fraudulent university degrees.

headline: Haiti at Six Months
text: Six months after Haiti’s earthquake, the situation is bleak. Of the 1.5 million people displaced, 28,000, so far, have been moved to safer transitional housing. The rest huddle in tents and pray that the next rains won’t wash their meager belongings away. Crime is resurgent and everyone is desperate for some sign of recovery.

headline: Injustice for Children
text: If New York abides by the settlement it reached this week with the Justice Department, mentally ill children in four of the state’s infamous youth prisons will finally get decent psychiatric care and will no longer be subject to brutal disciplinary practices. As important as it is, however, the settlement cannot be a substitute for the overhaul of the state juvenile justice system proposed by Gov. David Paterson’s juvenile justice task force.

headline: Studies Halted at Brain Lab Over Impure Injections
text: Columbia University has quietly suspended research at a nationally prominent brain-imaging center and reassigned its top managers after federal investigators found that it had routinely injected mental patients with drugs that contained potentially dangerous impurities.

headline: Fighting AIDS on Limited Budgets
text: With the AIDS epidemic still spreading rapidly around the globe, public health programs have to use their resources a lot more effectively. The need for greater efficiency in a time of limited resources is an important theme of President Obama’s new national AIDS strategy. The same argument is being made by the United Nations agency that battles the epidemic and by Bill Gates, whose foundation plays an influential role in financing a global response.

headline: Tone-Deaf in Rome
text: There was not much to like in the Vatican’s news conference this week about its pedophilia scandal, but among all the defensive posturing and inept statements, there was one real stunner: The citing of the movement for the ordination of women as a “grave crime” that Rome deems as offensive as the scandal of priests who sexually assault children.

headline: Iroquois Defeated by Passport Dispute
text: WESTBURY, N.Y.  The 23 players on the Iroquois national lacrosse team expected to spend this week vying for a world championship.

headline: Our New Life, in Blood and Color
text: Kampala, Uganda

headline: At Camp, Make-Believe Worlds Spring Off Page
text: The oracle sat with her back to the hill, a breeze riffling the ruby scarves tied to her folding camp chair.

headline: Photo Replay: July 16
text: A look back at the day in sports, including a gusty British Open and a slightly calmer Tour de France.

headline: For Kenneth Feinberg, More Delicate Diplomacy
text: NEW ORLEANS — Kenneth R. Feinberg, hopping in and out a Learjet, a helicopter and several S.U.V.s, took his gift for oratory to four towns in southern Louisiana on Thursday to make his pitch to locals: The $20 billion fund from BP to compensate those harmed by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, and they should get their share.

headline: For New York’s G.O.P., a Fund-Raising Gap
text: The state Republican ticket is in financial distress, starting at the top.

headline: On State Pay Cuts, Judge Rebuffs California Governor
text: LOS ANGELES  A California judge on Friday declined a request by the Schwarzenegger administration to compel the state controller to reduce the pay of 200,000 state workers to the minimum wage while lawmakers muddled though a budget impasse.

headline: Just Add Water
text: The stories of seven of the 55 public fountains maintained by New York City’s Department of Parks and Recreation.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Great Year to Die
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Stephen Spruiell of National Review debate the estate tax.

headline: Energy Secretary Emerges to Take a Commanding Role in Effort to Corral Well
text: WASHINGTON  Energy Secretary Steven Chu may hold a Nobel Prize in physics, but he has no training in geology, seismology or oil well technology. Nevertheless, he has stepped in repeatedly to take command of the effort to contain BP’s runaway well, often ordering company officials to take steps they might not have taken on their own.

headline: In Christie’s Cap on Superintendent Pay, a War on Local Government
text: The map of New Jersey is sliced into more than 1,100 municipalities and school districts, many of them tiny. The cherished principle of local control, and the abundance of local governments, lie at the core of the state’s political culture.

headline: Tepid Start for Trading in Agricultural Bank of China
text: The Agricultural Bank of China still hopes to clinch the title of the world’s biggest stock market listing, but its market debuts in Shanghai and Hong Kong have been anything but breathtaking. Agricultural Bank shares closed at 3.27 Hong Kong dollars (42 cents), up 2.2 percent from its offering price of 3.20 Hong Kong dollars. That was better than the 0.8 percent gain that the Shanghai-listed shares managed on their mainland China introduction on Thursday, but lackluster compared with the bank’s Chinese peers when they first traded over the last few years. The Shanghai-listed shares slipped 0.4 percent, ending Friday at 2.69 renminbi (40 cents), just above their issue price of 2.68 renminbi. If the bank exercises an “over allotment” option and issues up to 15 percent more shares, its I.P.O. could end up topping that of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, another state-controlled Chinese bank.

headline: Judge Allows City to Limit Art Sellers in Parks
text: A federal judge on Friday declined to block a policy that would sharply reduce the number of artists in city parks, saying it did not appear to violate free-speech rights.

headline: A Tribute Via ‘Seinfeld’ and TBS
text: TBS will honor George Steinbrenner next week by showing 10 “Seinfeld” episodes that featured a character in the guise of the Yankees’ longtime principal owner. The voice of the “Seinfeld” Steinbrenner belonged to Larry David, the show’s co-creator, and the back and flailing arms were the actor Lee Bear’s. The episodes will be shown Monday through Friday at 7 and 7:30 p.m., Eastern time.

headline: One of a Grand Trio
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — We’ll be taking a step back in time below, but first, let’s focus on the present, a nice puzzle today by Mark Diehl.

headline: A Star Keeps Rocking in the Not-So-Free World
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

headline: Fountains, Fountains, Everywhere...
text: EACH spring, the 55 public fountains maintained by the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation are brought back to life by an infusion of roughly 1.3 million gallons of water. Then they work their aquatic magic, self-sustained by circulation pumps, powered by hydraulics and in most cases protected by bromine filtration systems. (No chlorine because it’s too harsh on century-old stone and bronze statuary.)

headline: Texas Judge Reprimanded in Death Row Case
text: A judicial panel on Friday reprimanded a Texas judge who declined to keep the courthouse open for a last-minute appeal from a death row inmate.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Police Cite Help From Stop-and-Frisk Data in 170 Cases
text: This spring, while investigating the separate beatings of two Mexican men in Staten Island, detectives from the Hate Crime Task Force used electronic records of routine street stops that had been made to zero in on an informant who had been stopped and questioned in the area.

headline: In Attorney General Race, Five Seek to Stand Out
text: The five Democratic candidates for New York attorney general met for their first televised debate on Friday, seeking to establish and define themselves in a wide-open campaign in which much of the electorate appears up for grabs.

headline: Dog Days of Obama
text: This summer has not been kind to this president.

headline: Uncertainty in Lineup Sure Thing for the Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With the return of Carlos Beltran on Thursday, the Mets had hoped that stability would finally be reintroduced to a team in flux. Instead, the Mets went into the weekend with another jumbled lineup, an altered pitching rotation and a vague hope that everything would be fine in a few days.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

text: Testing of Capped Well Continues

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns @nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405 or to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Step Taken to End Impasse Over Cybersecurity Talks
text: A group of cybersecurity specialists and diplomats representing 15 countries has agreed on a set of recommendations to the United Nations secretary general for negotiations on an international computer security treaty.

headline: Christo’s Impact
text: Christo’s outsize environmental constructions have made him an internationally known, but not always well-understood, figure in the art world for decades.

headline: Bureaucracy Meets Art, Delighting Christo
text: DENVER  Assessing a work of art using in-depth technical analysis sounds a bit like writing a scholarly treatise about a joke. If you peer inside too deeply, armed with numbers and equations, does “Mona Lisa” still dazzle? And is “A man walks into a bar...” still funny?

headline: Mexico: 4 Die in Car Bombing, Thought to Be First in Drug War
text: Four people, including two federal police officers, were killed in what the Mexican Army said on Friday appeared to be first case of a car bomb in the country’s drug war. The explosives were detonated by a cellphone call, sending the car into two police trucks in the border city of Ciudad Juárez. The secretary of public security said that the attack late Thursday appeared to be in retaliation for the arrest earlier in the day of a top drug lieutenant, Jesús Armando Acosta Guerrero, the operations leader of La Linea, the enforcement arm of the Juárez cartel.

headline: Kyrgyzstan: European Group to Send Police to Monitor for Ethnic Violence
text: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe agreed to a request by Kyrgyzstan’s provisional government on Friday to send police monitors to the south of Kyrgyzstan, where ethnic violence last month left hundreds dead. But it fell short of the outside help Kyrgyzstan’s leaders have been pleading for to help quell tensions among ethnic Kyrgyz and Uzbeks, who clashed in four days of rioting in June that destroyed much of the southern city of Osh. The agreement, which requires approval by the organization’s 56 member countries, would provide 52 unarmed police officers to assist and monitor the Kyrgyz police, with the option to send 50 more later.

headline: Watson Says Goodbye With a Kiss
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The Scottish have embraced Tom Watson for 35 years, dating to his first British Open appearance, at Carnoustie in 1975, when he formed a bond with the people and the country synonymous with the game he loves. And with each of his five British Open titles, the man from Bucyrus, Kan., has become more and more an honorary Scotsman.

headline: France: Group Claims Responsibility for Making Fake Web Site About Haiti
text: A group calling itself the Committee for the Reimbursement of the Indemnity Money Extorted From Haiti took responsibility on Friday for an elaborate hoax this week in which an actor posing as a French government spokesman announced that France would reimburse Haiti money it had been forced to pay after winning its independence in the 19th century. The fake announcement was posted Wednesday on a near-replica of the French Foreign Ministry’s Web site. The ministry said it was considering legal action against the site’s creators, who identified themselves in a statement as “a group of activists from France, Canada and the United States.” They said France did owe Haiti $21,685,135,571.48, the sum the Haitian government asked France to pay it in 2003, to make up for 90 million gold francs it was forced to pay French landowners driven out by the revolution.

headline: Armstrong Foe Subpoenaed in Cycling Probe
text: RODEZ, France  Federal authorities have served Greg LeMond, the three-time Tour de France champion, with a grand jury subpoena in the investigation of fraud and doping allegations involving Lance Armstrong and his cycling teams.

headline: Nasty Exchanges in First McCain-Hayworth Debate
text: Perhaps divining that there was nothing that the people of Phoenix would long for more on a 106-degree Friday night at 7 p.m. than watching a political debate, Senator John McCain finally faced off with his Republican primary rival J. D. Hayworth with less than two months remaining before voters go to the polls. A Tea Party latecomer, Jim Deakin, also joined the fray in the first debate of the race.

headline: Iroquois Lacrosse Team Remains in U.S.
text: Britain refused to accept tribal passports, stranding the Iroquois lacrosse team in New York.

headline: For Swisher and Yankees, a Long but Rewarding Day
text: As Nick Swisher was leaving the clubhouse for the interview room, he let out a sigh.

headline: David Blackwell, Scholar of Probability, Dies at 91
text: David Blackwell, a statistician and mathematician who wrote groundbreaking papers on probability and game theory and was the first black scholar to be admitted to the National Academy of Sciences, died July 8 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Peter Fernandez, Voice of Speed Racer in the U.S., Dies at 83
text: Peter Fernandez, who provided the rat-a-tat voice of Speed Racer when that animated Japanese television series came to the United States  and who wrote the American lyrics for the show’s theme song  died Thursday at his home in Pomona, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: Hank Cochran, Writer for Country Music Stars, Dies at 74
text: NASHVILLE  Hank Cochran, a singer and songwriter who wrote major hits for Patsy Cline, Burl Ives and Eddy Arnold and whose songs appeared on the country charts for more than four decades, died Thursday at his home in Hendersonville, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 74.

headline: Zito Makes Sure the Mets Waste Another Good Start
text: SAN FRANCISCO  For the second game in a row the Mets faced a Cy Young Award-winning pitcher, and did so without their most dynamic player in the lineup. Not coincidentally, for the second straight game they failed to score a run.

headline: Laugh Lines, R.I.P.
text: A note to readers: This post is the last for the Laugh Lines blog, started three years ago as a place for amusing stuff on the Web, curated to the sensibilities of Times readers. The blog’s end is a function of the reality of limited resources in a medium where any number of worthy experiments are possible, but all can’t be sustained.

headline: The Saturday Word: Obstruction and Appointments
text: In his weekly national address, President Obama continued to criticize Republican senators for opposing two of the Democrats’ major proposals to help financially strapped Americans — the extension of unemployment benefits and the small business lending bill.

headline: Bits Pics: Twitter Traffic During the World Cup
text: The image above is cropped from a larger data visualization, created by Twitter, showing the use of  Twitter  during the World Cup.

headline: Climate Panel Clarifies Its Media Plan
text: One of my high school English teachers, Carlton J. Pinheiro, was a big fan of Mark Twain and once told us that the humorist supposedly had an interesting way of writing a letter. He’d write the missive, rip it up, and then write the letter he would actually send.

headline: What Business Can Learn From Chess
text: The current issue of Forbes India features a cover story about Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, who is a national hero in his country. The subtitle of the story is “What Anand can teach you about winning.”

headline: Amid Tests, BP Sees No Signs of Damage to Well
text: As the Gulf of Mexico entered a third day free of fresh oil from BP’s blown-out well, the government on Saturday extended a test that has so far shown no signs of damage in the 13,000-foot-deep hole.

headline: Frustration and Despair as Job Search Drags On
text: CARLISLE, Ky.  In her well-thumbed, leather-bound Bible, Terri Sadler recently highlighted in bright pink a passage in the Gospel of Matthew.

headline: The Men Who Ended Goldman’s War
text: LAST Wednesday at around 3 p.m., the Securities and Exchange Commission and Goldman Sachs settled an epic, seismic battle  one waged over whether the storied investment bank defrauded investors in a transaction that regulators said Goldman had built to self-destruct.

headline: Leader Still Setting Himself Apart
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  From the first day of the 139th British Open, the smart money knew that the South African golfer Louis Oosthuizen would vanish from the leader board like mist in the wind. But the smart money forgot to tell him that.

headline: De Facto Double Dips
text: From Ed McKelvey at Goldman Sachs, which has been very good at calling recent economic trends (no link):

headline: Long Journey Takes Nava Right Where Red Sox Need Him
text: BOSTON  Standing in front of his tiny locker in the Red Sox’ clubhouse, Daniel Nava pulled out his wallet and offered a reporter an old driver’s license  one he has held on to since he was a sophomore in high school.

headline: Conventional Madness, Revisited
text: In late May I had a, um, negative reaction to the latest OECD Economic Outlook. Not only did the report call for immediate fiscal austerity; it called for a sharp rise in US interest rates over the next year and a half, even though its own forecasts projected very high unemployment and below-target inflation at the end of 2011. The only justification given for this monetary tightening was the fact that “some long-term measures of inflation expectations have increased.” This was a reference to the TIPS spread, the difference between the interest rate on ordinary government bonds and bonds indexed to inflation.

headline: For the British Open, Rooms With Any View Will Do
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The small town of St. Andrews on the eastern coast of Scotland can lay claim to a number of historical firsts that belie its modest size. It is the site of Scotland’s oldest university, and where golf and Scottish Presbyterianism were founded.

headline: In N.B.A., Knicks Are Feeling Optimistic
text: LAS VEGAS  The transformation was more deliberate than dazzling, a subtle, fundamental evolution. The Knicks set out this summer to buy stardom and instant credibility. They settled for an extensive makeover.

headline: Hamas Moves to Enforce Water Pipe Ban in Gaza
text: GAZA  In its latest attempt to try to impose a conservative Islamic way of life on Gaza, Hamas started this weekend to enforce a ban on smoking water pipes in public.

headline: I Would Do Anything For Stimulus, But I Won’t Do That (Wonkish)
text: It’s really not relevant to current policy debates, but there’s an issue that’s been nagging at me, so I thought I’d write it up.

headline: Fair Fare Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Occasionally I get a note from someone who’s worried that the title of the acrostic post is giving away something about the quote. The truth is, the title is usually composed of a clue, or part of a clue, tacked on to the word “acrostic.” Nothing more than that.

headline: Women’s Role in Holocaust May Exceed Old Notions
text: JERUSALEM  Amid the horrors of the Holocaust, the atrocities perpetrated by a few brutal women have always stood out, like aberrations of nature.

headline: Jones Never Stays Long, but He Always Leaves His Mark
text: WASHINGTON  Last week, while athletes with higher profiles flocked to Los Angeles for the ESPY Awards, Thomas Jones taped public-service announcements inside the nondescript United States Department of Labor building here. He arrived an hour early and came alone.

headline: Querrey Rebounds From a Scary Fall to Resume His Steady Climb
text: NEWPORT, R.I.  Sam Querrey is the rising, top-20 American tennis player who did not play an 11-hour first-round match at Wimbledon. He merely reached the fourth round.

headline: Cabrera Is Making a Triple Crown Run
text: We interrupt the Year of the Pitcher to bring a compelling second-half story line from the batter’s box: Miguel Cabrera’s pursuit of the first Triple Crown in baseball in 43 years.

headline: What’s Holding Women Back?
text: Last week, I attended the annual Aspen Ideas Festival, which features discussions with leading experts and thinkers across industries. This year’s program covered five tracks, including one called “Women + Girls: The Solution.” The agenda refers to a point made by festival presenters: only by helping women and girls achieve their full potential and using all of the brainpower available to us, can we hope to solve the world’s problems.

headline: Twins Find Meaning In 3-Part Endurance Test
text: It would not be an optical illusion if, in the final meters of the New York City Triathlon on Sunday, two chiseled 5-foot-3 women wearing yellow-and-black Livestrong stretch suits appeared in striking distance of each other after swimming 1,500 meters, cycling 40 kilometers and embarking on a 10-kilometer run.

headline: Beneath Divides Seemingly About Race Are Generational Fault Lines
text: WASHINGTON — Newt Gingrich woke up last week with an idea to heal America. This is not a remarkable event; Mr. Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, wakes up with about five new ideas most days, many of which are instantly snuffed out by the cold reason of daylight. In this case, though, he had an intriguing idea for his brethren in the Tea Party movement, which the N.A.A.C.P. had just accused of brooking racism: he suggested that they reach out to local chapters of the civil rights group and propose a series of joint town-hall-style meetings around the country.

headline: Driven by a Fear of Failure
text: Older reporters reminded me continually that the George Steinbrenner I covered for The New York Times in the late ’90s was much different, much more sedate, than he had been in his first years as the Yankees’ owner, when Steinbrenner made his reputation as the manager-firing, player-baiting, headline-making Boss.

headline: A Life Up in the Air and in Hotels
text: Most of the world knows Jacques Rogge, the president of the International Olympic Committee, as the man who helps open the Olympic Games. Rogge, 68, keeps a full schedule as an international sports diplomat, meeting with leaders around the globe. But his job as president, which he has held since 2001, is only Rogge’s most recent career. He competed on the Belgian sailing team in the 1968, ’72 and ’76 Olympics, and also played for a time on the national rugby team. He spent three decades working as an orthopedic surgeon in Belgium before moving to Lausanne, Switzerland, to run the I.O.C. KATIE THOMAS

headline: A Match for (Computer) Bragging Rights
text: Though chess games between humans still generate the most interest, computers have long since replaced them as the best players. The chess elite routinely use computers to analyze openings, and annotators rely on them to find missed variations or the correct moves of games that they are reviewing.

headline: Palin Wades Into Republican Midterm Primaries
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga.  The latest candidate to win the most coveted Republican prize of the election year stood on the steps of a gazebo here and reminded voters of a new reason to support her in the crowded race for Georgia governor.

headline: Boss Is Gone, but Hard Feelings Remain
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Fighting Words
text: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on Tea Party groups last week to weed out “racist elements.”

headline: Mickelson’s Hopes Slip With Two Swings
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Phil Mickelson came to the Old Course with high hopes of adding a British Open to his major championship resume. But the hopes were dashed today, after two bad swings with a 5-iron cost him three strokes and moved him out of contention for the claret jug.

headline: First Thought at St. Andrews: Two-Putt
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  If this were an average golf tournament, the putting green that sits next to the first tee at this British Open would provide more than enough space for proper preparation. The rectangle of green is 40 paces across, well over 100 feet. But in the peculiar, throwback world of the Old Course at St. Andrews, this is a limited testing ground.

headline: Factory Defies Sweatshop Label, but Can It Thrive?
text: VILLA ALTAGRACIA, Dominican Republic

headline: Mystery Disease Spreads Anxiety
text: As the International AIDS Conference begins in Vienna on Sunday, 33 million people are infected with the disease; the number grows by a million a year.

headline: Prime Number
text: The number of countries that allow same-sex couples to marry same-sex couples to marry, according to Lambda Legal, a legal advocacy group. Argentina was the latest country to join the list — and the first in Latin America — after the country’s Senate narrowly approved the unions last week following a bitter fight between President Cristina Fernández and the Roman Catholic Church. The other countries allowing gay couples to wed are the Netherlands, Belgium, Canada, Spain, South Africa, Norway, Sweden and Iceland. Twenty-three other countries recognize same-sex couples through partnership registration, case law or other policies, according to Lambda Legal.

headline: The Rupee Gets Its Own Mark
text: The United States dollar has its symbol, $. So does the British pound, £; the Japanese yen, ¥; and the Euro, €. But not the Indian rupee, until now.

headline: Second, and Third, Thoughts Over Killing of Prospect Park Geese
text: After the killing of nearly 400 Canada geese in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, many parkgoers railed against the government agencies that had rounded up the birds. Most focused on the morality of the killings.

headline: Unlikely Tutor Giving Military Afghan Advice
text: WASHINGTON  In the frantic last hours of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s command in Afghanistan, when the world wondered what was racing through the general’s mind, he reached out to an unlikely corner of his life: the author of the book “Three Cups of Tea,” Greg Mortenson.

headline: Ranchers and Drug Barons Threaten Rain Forest
text: EL MIRADOR, Guatemala  Great sweeps of Guatemalan rain forest, once the cradle of one of the world’s great civilizations, are being razed to clear land for cattle-ranching drug barons.

headline: Pleas by Conscientious Objectors Evolve
text: WASHINGTON  Answering the G.I. Rights Hotline for the last 11 years, J. E. McNeil has counseled thousands of soldiers who want to become conscientious objectors and get out of the service.

headline: No One Was Trapped in New Jersey Garage Wreckage, Officials Say
text: After searching all night in the wreckage of a collapsed steel-and-glass canopy and a parking garage underneath it, emergency workers in Hackensack, N.J., concluded on Saturday morning that no one had been trapped inside, the authorities said.

headline: NATO Soldiers Are Killed by Homemade Bombs in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Five NATO soldiers were killed in southern and eastern Afghanistan amid reports of new fighting in Nuristan, a remote northeastern province of Afghanistan, officials said Saturday.

headline: A Spill Into the Psyche, and a Respite
text: Out on the Gulf of Mexico, where the surface has come to resemble a floating intensive-care unit — all those hulking ships laden with specialized machinery, bobbing in wait for the next emergency — something good finally happened last week. If only provisionally, oil stopped spewing into the sea.

headline: U.S. Backs Trial for Four Detainees in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The chief judge asked God’s forgiveness if he had reached the wrong decision, and then he sentenced four members of an Afghan family charged with making bombs: two brothers to 10 years in prison and two other family members to time already served.

headline: More Glimmers of Good News
text: Yes, the cap seemed to have at least temporarily helped. Still, times are dreary — in the economy, in the national mood, overseas. Isn’t anything positive happening? We tried hard to find better news out there.

headline: Civilian Convoy Attacked in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A convoy of civilian vehicles was attacked in a tribal region near the Afghan border on Saturday, with numerous casualties.

headline: Top Women’s Rivalry Revived at Tournament for U.S. Title
text: Rivalries always make chess more interesting. Bobby Fischer versus Boris Spassky, Garry Kasparov versus Anatoly Karpov, Veselin Topalov versus Vladimir Kramnik were all great theater. But they were all rivalries between men.

headline: Gay Parade in Warsaw Meets Jeers From Some
text: WARSAW  Rainbow flags flying, Village People and Madonna songs pumping from the floats, drag queens waving like royalty to the crowds: some things are the same at gay pride parades everywhere. But the thousands of police officers holding back clusters of jeering, egg-throwing youths here on Saturday served as a reminder that Poland was not quite Holland when it came to gay demonstrations.

headline: Free. What Now?
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE SALERNO, Afghanistan — It was around midday under a searing Afghan sun, and the six detainees tottered to the back of an American Chinook helicopter, clutching onto their prayer mats and Meal Ready To Eat boxes. The hot rotor wash tried to rip their belongings from their hands onto the landing zone at this Forward Operating Base in Khost Province, in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: Iran Says Pakistan Is Harboring Rebels
text: Iran’s deputy police chief accused Pakistan on Saturday of providing a haven for members of an armed rebel group that has claimed responsibility for the deadly twin suicide bombings last week in front of a mosque in the southeastern city of Zahedan.

headline: 20 Arrested Over Attacks in Uganda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  The police have arrested a second batch of suspects in connection to last Sunday’s terrorist attacks in this capital that killed 76 people, and they said suicide bombers were probably involved in the attacks.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 18
text: 8:48 a.m. | Updated  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who made some news himself over the weekend, sits at the top of the Sunday ticket, appearing on ABC’s “This Week” to discuss President Obama’s agenda, the economic recovery and the War in Afghanistan, among other things.

headline: ‘Gibbs-Gate’: 16 Words Can Be a Big Issue in Politics
text: WASHINGTON — As White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs utters thousands of words in public every week as he promotes and defends President Obama. But it was just 16 words on a talk show last Sunday that consumed the days that followed — and that by week’s end Republicans were gleefully dubbing “Gibbs-gate.”

headline: Vinokourov, in His First Tour Since a Doping Ban, Takes a Stage
text: REVEL, France  Three years after being thrown out of the Tour de France for blood doping, the Kazakh rider Alexandre Vinokourov made a clear statement on Saturday to his competitors: In his first Tour since being disgraced at this race, he is as fast and as tough as ever.

headline: Steinbrenner: The Boss Unbound
text: Even the most devotional hymns to George Steinbrenner, the Yankee’s principal owner, who died last week at age 80, aired the man’s sturm and his drang, his outbursts of pettiness and tyranny. That was George: hated to lose; loved to compete; needed to be on top of the mountain.

headline: Holding Bankers’ Feet to the Fire
text: KUDOS to the Federal Housing Finance Agency, overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the crippled mortgage finance giants. While some in Washington have continued to coddle the big banks even after they drove our economy into the ditch, this agency seems serious about recovering money for taxpayers by holding bad financial actors to account.

headline: Admiring a New Stadium (and a Shorter Distance to Deepest Center Field)
text: One of George Steinbrenner’s enduring legacies will be helping to build the $1.5 billion new Yankee Stadium.

headline: A Defector Goes Home, but to What End?
text: WASHINGTON — When Shahram Amiri, the Iranian scientist, took his C.I.A. handlers by surprise last week by un-defecting back to Tehran, he was gambling with his life.

headline: Honk if You Love the Canada Goose
text: When 400 Canada geese that lived in Prospect Park in Brooklyn were rounded up and gassed last week, there was a predictable uproar. The geese were compared to rats and cockroaches. The humans who wanted them killed were called bloodthirsty and callous. Certainly the move, by the United States Department of Agriculture, raised a lot of questions about geese and humans, one of the less polite being, “What good are geese, anyway?”

headline: Never Duck the Tough Questions
text: This interview with Dawn Lepore, chairwoman and chief executive of Drugstore.com,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Ms. Lepore is also a director of eBay and The New York Times Company.

headline: The Weight of the Past
text: We might not think about them, or even notice them, but paperweights peeking out amid the colorful pageantry of a newsstand help give a city like New York its distinctive spirit and texture.

headline: You Want My Personal Data? Reward Me for It
text: LIFE, as they say, imitates art. And the way things work commercially today across much of the Web recalls that chapter in “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer” where Tom cajoles his guileless friends into whitewashing Aunt Polly’s fence. They supply the labor, but he gets the reward.

headline: Bye-Bye Batteries: Radio Waves as a Low-Power Source
text: MATT REYNOLDS, an assistant professor in the electrical and computer engineering department at Duke University, wears other hats, too  including that of co-founder of two companies. These days, his interest is in a real hat now in prototype: a hard hat with a tiny microprocessor and beeper that sound a warning when dangerous equipment is nearby on a construction site.

headline: To the Mat on Global Warming
text: SHORTLY after losing the 2000 presidential election, Al Gore embarked on an arguably even more ambitious campaign: to save the planet from destruction by global warming. His efforts, which included his documentary film “An Inconvenient Truth,” won him a Nobel Prize. But Mr. Gore has not yet achieved his goal of convincing America to limit the industrial pollution that causes climate change.

headline: Of Scoundrels and Scandals
text: An exhibit in New York highlights major financial scandals throughout the nation’s history, the first involving William Duer, a Washington official whose subsequent financial speculation helped cause the Panic of 1792.

headline: Berra Misses Old-Timers’ Day After Fall
text: Although Yogi Berra collected his 10 World Series rings from 1947 to 1962, he is still a major presence in the Yankees’ organization. He frequently visits the Yankee Stadium clubhouse and talks with the current players.

headline: More On Deficit Limits
text: Jamie Galbraith responded to this post in comments; what he said, and my counter-response, below the fold:

headline: Mamedyarov Draws Even With Ponomariov in Dortmund
text: The two leaders are well ahead of the rest of the field in the elite Sparkassen Chess-Meeting tournament.

headline: Head for the Hills? No Way, He Says
text: LONG before he began studying economics, Jeremy J. Siegel charted the ups and downs of the Dow Jones industrial average on the walls of his childhood bedroom. That fascination with stocks has never ebbed.

headline: California Treasure Hunt
text: In the third part of the Continental Picture Show series, Alec Soth rents a metal detector, and sets out to find what others have lost.

headline: What Germany Knows About Debt
text: IN many countries, including the United States, there are calls for the government to spend more to jump-start the economy, and to avoid the temptation to cut back as debts mount.

headline: Letters: Junk Food, Junk Media
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: 104 Days of Waiting
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Minding the Mill
text: I’M 81 and have been working since I was 13. In junior high school, I ripped old fabric off of chairs and sofas for a furniture re-upholsterer. This was during World War II, so the men had gone to war, the women were taking the men’s jobs, and kids could be hired because there was still more to do. I think I made as much money finding coins in the creases of the furniture as I got paid.

headline: Admiring New Stadium, Without the Depth
text: One of George Steinbrenner’s enduring legacies will be the $1.5 billion new Yankee Stadium. In fact, some have dubbed it The House That George Built.

headline: The True Calling That Wasn’t
text: WHAT if you’re not happy in your job? Is it possible that you’re in the wrong career entirely?

headline: Eduardo Sánchez Junco, Founder of Fawning Magazine, Is Dead at 67
text: If you want to be the subject of a stunningly flattering profile in Hello magazine, one of Britain’s most widely read celebrity weeklies, all you really need are a title, a castle and a pen with which to endorse the handsome check that will surely be sent your way  or, in a pinch, if you are untitled but sufficiently boldface, just the pen.

headline: Standardized English Tests Are Halted in Iran
text: WASHINGTON  The Educational Testing Service has announced that it is temporarily suspending registration for its tests in Iran, including the popular Test of English as a Foreign Language, in what may be one of the first tangible effects of the new sanctions levied against the country by the international community.

headline: Two Perspectives of Steinbrenner
text: There were many sides of George Steinbrenner. But his employees got a certain view of the Boss, and there was not much tender loving care while they worked under him.

headline: How Can Obama Rebound?
text: Though BP managed to stop the spread of oil from its broken well last week, President Obama has been able to do little to stop the drop in his public approval ratings, which now, according to a new ABC News-Washington Post poll, hover just above 40 percent. Add these numbers to the comment by Robert Gibbs, the president’s press secretary, that Democrats could lose control of the House in the November elections, and it equals trouble for the president in 2012. So what does Mr. Obama need to do to shore up his base, woo back independent voters and win a second term? The Op-Ed editors asked political experts to suggest a few plans of attack.

headline: As Facebook Users Die, Ghosts Reach Out
text: Courtney Purvin got a shock when she visited Facebook last month. The site was suggesting that she get back in touch with an old family friend who played piano at her wedding four years ago.

headline: Insurers Push Plans That Limit Choice of Doctor
text: As the Obama administration begins to enact the new national health care law, the country’s biggest insurers are promoting affordable plans with reduced premiums that require participants to use a narrower selection of doctors or hospitals.

headline: Correction: Factory Efficiency Comes to the Hospital
text: An article last Sunday about hospitals' use of efficiency techniques often found in manufacturing misspelled the surname of a management professor at Boston University, who said that there were limits to performance-improvement methods in hospitals. He is George Labovitz, not Lebovitz.

headline: Rome Fiddles, We Burn
text: If the Vatican is trying to restore the impression that its moral sense is intact, issuing a document that equates pedophilia with the ordination of women doesn’t really do that.

headline: Critical Periods
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Loved it! My Sunday post two weeks began the same way, but it’s true again. This is the sort of subtle and clever wordplay that butters my biscuit.

headline: The Good News About Mel Gibson
text: FOR Fourth of July weekend fireworks, even Macy’s couldn’t top the spittle-spangled eruptions of Mel Gibson. The clandestine recordings of his serial audio assaults on his gal pal were instant Web and cable-TV sensations  at once a worthy rival to Hollywood’s official holiday releases and a compelling sequel to his fabled anti- Semitic rant of 2006. A true showman, Gibson offered vitriol for nearly all tastes, aiming his profane fusillade at women, blacks and Latinos alike. The invective was tied together by a domestic violence subplot worthy of “Lethal Weapon.” There was even a surprise comic coda, courtesy of Whoopi Goldberg, who, alone among Gibson’s showbiz peers, used her television platform on “The View” to defend her buddy’s good character.

headline: Can We Talk?
text: On July 7, CNN fired its senior editor of Middle East affairs, Octavia Nasr, after she published a Twitter message saying, “Sad to hear of the passing of Sayyed Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah,” one of the most prominent Lebanese Shiite spiritual leaders who was involved in the founding of the Hezbollah militia. Nasr described him as “one of Hezbollah’s giants I respect a lot.”

headline: Jackson Fondly Recalls Steinbrenner
text: The headlines about the feuding between Reggie Jackson and George Steinbrenner in 1977 are a distant memory now.

headline: Our Beaker Is Starting to Boil
text: David Breashears is one of America’s legendary mountain climbers, a man who has climbed Mount Everest five times and led the Everest IMAX film team in 1996.

headline: Free Speech for Broadcasters, Too
text: Some private functions of the body can be described on broadcast television, but not others. Some four-letter expletives can be said on the air at 10:05 p.m., but not at 9:55 p.m. Characters in some prime-time movies can speak as adults actually do, but not in other movies because they have less artistic value. This irrational and erratic regime of restriction has been swept away by a federal appeals court at the request of broadcasters who have become exasperated by the Federal Communications Commission’s rules.

headline: Meanwhile in Basel
text: The new financial reform will go a long way to limit the vast new risks created by modern finance. The banks, which fought the legislation tooth and nail, are not giving up. They are now working to weaken new international banking rules.

headline: Jobs for the Picking
text: The United Farm Workers union has issued a call to unemployed American citizens:

headline: A ‘Rocky’ Moment for Pitt’s Lewis
text: Philadelphia has long embraced the story of Rocky Balboa, the fictional fighter from the streets whose resiliency and work ethic became part of the city’s lore. But now western Pennsylvania has its own Rocky in the form of Pittsburgh running back Dion Lewis.

headline: Changing Stance, Administration Now Defends Insurance Mandate as a Tax
text: WASHINGTON  When Congress required most Americans to obtain health insurance or pay a penalty, Democrats denied that they were creating a new tax. But in court, the Obama administration and its allies now defend the requirement as an exercise of the government’s “power to lay and collect taxes.”

headline: Biden Owes $219,000 for Campaign Violations
text: WASHINGTON  The Biden for President campaign committee owes the Treasury more than $219,000 because it accepted excessive campaign contributions and understated the value of a trip taken on a private plane in the 2008 campaign, the Federal Election Commission said in a new report.

headline: Spokes | Hauling Cargo, No Car Necessary
text: When Lela Rose needs to take her two children to school or pick up a bag of potting soil or transport a large chair, she doesn’t grab the keys to the family vehicle. Instead, she hops aboard her cargo-hauling tricycle.

headline: Out of Work, and Suddenly Taking Orders
text: BARATARIA, La.  The order came at 6 a.m. The BP cleanup boats were getting ready to leave. Robin Palmisano, a wiry shrimper not given to many words, was to gather his crew and drive them three hours to the Venice dock. Pronto.

headline: Star Man
text: Mau Piailug will never be as famous as Capt. James Cook, a master of the classic European feat of discovering places with people already in them. But Piailug, who died last week at the age of 78, could have matched Cook’s voyaging island for island across the vast immensity of the Pacific, and without charts, compass or sextant. He was a palu, a master navigator, one of the last experts in the ancient art of Pacific Ocean wayfaring.

headline: 60 Years of Adventures on Way Back to the Bronx
text: On Don Johnson’s first visit to the old Yankee Stadium as a rookie pitcher in 1947, he took the subway but got off at the wrong stop and found himself in front of Sugar Ray Robinson’s bar in Harlem.

headline: Steinbrenner Is Talk of Old-Timers’ Day, but a Beloved Yankee Is Missing
text: A few months after George Steinbrenner took over as the Yankees’ principal owner in January 1973, Ron Blomberg met his new boss for the first time. Blomberg knew nothing about Steinbrenner, but he thought he did.

headline: W.T.O. Ruling Upsets Chief of Jet Maker
text: LONDON  The chief executive of the parent company of Airbus expressed frustration over the weekend at a recent decision by the World Trade Organization to delay a report on European claims that Boeing has received billions of dollars in federal subsidies.

headline: How Successful Is Teach for America?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Burnett Loses His Control, Then He Loses His Cool
text: A. J. Burnett wore bandages on the palms of his hands as evidence of his bizarre outing Saturday afternoon.

headline: Israel and the Flotilla
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,162 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American last week:

headline: Referendum in Sudan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time for the U.S. to Act Against Clerical Sex Abuse
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Environmental Impact of Oil Spills
text: Every oil spill is different, but the thread that unites some major ones is a growing scientific awareness of the persistent damage that spills can do.

headline: After Oil Spills, Hidden Damage Can Last for Years
text: On the rocky beaches of Alaska, scientists plunged shovels and picks into the ground and dug 6,775 holes, repeatedly striking oil  still pungent and dangerous a dozen years after the Exxon Valdez infamously spilled its cargo.

headline: Once a Year, a Chance for All That History to Come Alive
text: Nobody sells history like the Yankees.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: The Roof of the World, Melting
text: My Sunday column looks at new photographs that document the melting of glaciers in the Himalayas. The difference between today’s photographs and those of 80 years ago, from the same vantage points, is stunning.

headline: Representing a Nation Without Inserting Politics
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  They have been walking and working together on some of the world’s finest golf courses for the last seven years, but on Sunday, Louis Oosthuizen and his longtime caddie, Zack Rasego, will experience something new. They will walk and work the Old Course at St. Andrews for the final round of the British Open with the golf world’s full attention.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Day of Decisive Results (10) at the U.S. Championships
text: Anna Zatonskih, the defending champion, maintained her lead at the U.S. Women’s Championship, while Ray Robson, the top seed, took over the lead of the U.S. Junior Championship.

headline: Old-Timers Recall Bob Sheppard
text: From Mantle to Matsui, the common thread that linked generations of players who wore Yankees’ pinstripes was that Bob Sheppard introduced them all.

headline: Blog’s Readers Enjoy a Good Whodunit
text: Authors these days know it is not enough just to write well. Or often. Eventually, unless you are Stephen King  or have somehow ensured that a steady stream of cash will flow into your publisher’s coffers  you are going to have to get out there and sell your book.

headline: Reconfiguring the View on the Far South Side
text: The office of David Doig, a real estate developer, in an 11-story building just west of the Bishop Ford Expressway at 111th Street, affords a view of economic disarray fit for an urban archaeologist  and the contours of Chicago’s consumer future.

headline: Chicago Draws Up Plan to Prosper in 2040
text: As the Chicago Metropolitan Agency for Planning sees it, Chicago in 2040 will no longer be battling its suburban neighbors for growth and prosperity opportunities.

headline: The Pulse: Got Available Ground? Want Free Vegetables?
text: In return for vegetables rather than money, some Kenwood residents are letting their properties be used by community gardeners - many of them strangers - who are strapped for space.

headline: The Pulse: Judge Contributed to Candidate’s  Campaign
text: Scott Lee Cohen, the affluent Chicago pawnbroker who is running for governor as an independent, might seem an unlikely candidate to receive financial backing from a Cook County judge.

headline: EADS Looks Outside Europe to Fuel Growth
text: LONDON  With government budgets across Europe set to shrink significantly in the coming years, the parent company of Airbus predicted that the group’s military business would become increasingly focused on markets in Asia, Latin America and the Persian Gulf and it hinted that the outsourcing of European aerospace jobs to those regions was all but inevitable.

headline: With Success of Young Mets, It May Be a Dull Deadline
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In the conversations the Mets had with the Mariners regarding Cliff Lee before Lee was traded to the Texas Rangers, Seattle General Manager Jack Zduriencik asked that the left-handed pitcher Jon Niese be included in any package.

headline: Gaining Strength by Taking Power Away from Sacramento
text: You could feel the angst  and the anger  among the civic-minded Bay Area residents who gathered at the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco last week to discuss what ails California.

headline: Halo-Halo
text: An elaborate, refreshing dessert, halo-halo is a favorite summer treat in the Philippines. Locally, perhaps the most Pinoy (Filipino) place to savor halo-halo is at the Jollibee restaurant in Market Plaza in Daly City. It was the first United States location for that Filipino fast-food chain, which has over 1,800 outlets worldwide.

headline: A Crusade to Avert Pension Crisis
text: Jeff Adachi has taken up an unusual cause for a San Francisco public defender: Dramatic increases in public-employee contributions to the city’s pension plan. He said his ballot initiative to require just that was necessary to prevent San Francisco from sliding into bankruptcy.

headline: Armstrong Uses Second Team to Help Spread His Message
text: REVEL, France  Federal prosecutors are moving ahead with a criminal investigation into whether Lance Armstrong defrauded his sponsors and doped during his cycling career. Yet at the Tour de France  the race that helped turn Armstrong into a worldwide icon  his image is still thriving.

headline: Proposal for Marijuana Factories Prompts a Battle for Control
text: A proposal to create four large-scale marijuana factories in Oakland has touched off a turf war in the lucrative market for medicinal marijuana. Established local merchants are trying to hold their ground against entrepreneurs who are seeking to gain a foothold in the rapidly evolving industry.

headline: Photo Reply: July 17
text: A look at the day in sports, including Old Timers’ Day at Yankee Stadium, soccer, tennis and field hockey.

headline: Mets’ Scoreless Drought Ends, but Not Their Losing Streak
text: SAN FRANCISCO  On another grim night by the Bay for the Mets, perhaps the most encouraging thing that occurred  and that included two home runs from Ike Davis  took place in a batting cage underneath the stands three hours before the first pitch was thrown.

headline: Wright Gets a Hit (and Isn’t Hit) Against Cain
text: SAN FRANCISCO – For the first time since he was beaned by a Matt Cain fastball last year, David Wright stepped in against Cain, the Giants starter, and registered a hit in three at-bats against him in the Giants’ 8-4 victory over the Mets.

headline: Vows: Cara and Jayson
text: Cara Protzko and Jayson Baron met on a scavenger hunt at Fordham University. Three years later, Jayson proposed after they were evacuated from their building at midnight.

headline: Lessons From an Old Oil Spill
text: The 1969 West Falmouth oil spill is the most closely monitored in history. Scientists have used it to understand the long term impacts of oil on coastal ecosystems.

headline: Dozens Killed in Iraq Suicide Attacks
text: BAGHDAD  In the deadliest of a recent string of attacks against former insurgents who switched sides to fight alongside American forces, more than 40 people were killed by a suicide bomber here Sunday morning as they lined up outside an Iraqi Army base to receive their paychecks.

headline: Braving Crowds at Hong Kong Book Fair
text: The Hong Kong Book Fair is so popular that it drew more people last year (900,000) than recent legislative by-elections (579,000).

headline: A Showcase for the Young and the Talented
text: The Biel Chess Festival has attracted some strong players in recent years, but the field in this year’s elite section, which begins Monday, is unusual as all of the participants are young — more than half are still teen-agers.

headline: The Tax Deduction for Job Searches
text: Spending your summer searching for a job? If so, you may be able to deduct some of your job-search-related expenses from your tax bill, including fees associated with résumés, referrals, job counseling, employment agencies and some travel.

headline: Prison Break Precedes Afghan Conference
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents used a prison break, a suicide attack and homemade bombs on Sunday to make their presence felt just two days before a major international conference that is to bring dozens of foreign ministers here.

headline: Beyond a Gulf Cleanup
text: In Sunday’s paper, my colleague Justin Gillis and I present a science-based analysis of the environmental future of the Gulf Coast. It’s fairly optimistic, considering how badly polluted the coastline appears today in many places.

headline: $4 Million for Chess, but With a Catch
text: As the election for the top positions in the World Chess Federation nears, both of the campaigns have promised money to finance chess programs and tournaments around the world.

headline: Wasps to Fight Thai Cassava Plague
text: BANGKOK  Entomologists deployed the first wave of an army of 250,000 tiny wasps over the weekend in a campaign to eradicate a plague of mealybugs that threatens to devastate Thailand’s $1.5 billion cassava crop.

headline: The Obamas Are Returning to Washington
text: BAR HARBOR, Me. – Some people are speed readers. President Obama, it seems, is a speed vacationer.

headline: Afghanistan and Pakistan Sign a Trade Deal, Representing a Thaw in Relations
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Afghanistan and Pakistan signed a landmark trade agreement on Sunday, auguring a thaw between these two perennially suspicious neighbors and handing the Obama administration a rare victory in its beleaguered war effort in Afghanistan.

headline: South African Keeps Nerves, and the Field, at a Distance
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Throughout a march toward the British Open championship that went from improbable to inexorable with each stride down the Old Course’s hardening fairways Sunday, three things about Louis Oosthuizen did not change: his demeanor, his swing tempo and his resilience.

headline: BP Hopes to Keep Well Closed, but Seep Is Detected
text: After three days of encouraging pressure tests, a senior BP official said Sunday that the company’s recently capped well in the Gulf of Mexico was holding up and that BP now hoped to keep the well closed until it could be permanently plugged. But government officials were more skeptical and cited a new potential problem.

headline: More Stimulus Despair
text: I’ll be frank: the discussion of fiscal stimulus this past year and a half has filled me with despair over the state of the economics profession. If you believe stimulus is a bad idea, fine; but surely the least one could have expected is that opponents would listen, even a bit, to what proponents were saying. In particular, the case for stimulus has always been highly conditional. Fiscal stimulus is what you do only if two conditions are satisfied: high unemployment, so that the proximate risk is deflation, not inflation; and monetary policy constrained by the zero lower bound.

headline: A Whale of a Whoops in a City Council Race
text: It’s one thing, in the heat of a campaign, to overlook a taxi receipt buried in the back of a wallet. But how does an elected official who has run several six-figure campaigns in New York fail to include her campaign’s largest bill on expense reports filed at the time of her last race?

headline: The Sunday Word: Maine Edition
text: The Obama family is scheduled to fly back to Washington today, after a whirlwind short vacation in Maine.

headline: Webber Regrets – but Not Entirely
