text: In an interview with the Daily Mail newspaper in Britain, Mark Webber said that he had been too critical of Red Bull Racing in public about the way he was treated at the British Grand Prix last weekend. His team had handed over his front wing to Sebastian Vettel, his teammate, when the latter broke his during the practice session on Saturday morning.

headline: Zsa Zsa Gabor Hospitalized After Fall
text: The actress and singer Zsa Zsa Gabor was taken to Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center on Saturday night after breaking her hip in a fall at her home, the Los Angeles Times reported. Ms. Gabor, 93, was reaching over to answer the phone when she fell out of her bed in her home in Bel Air on Saturday evening, according to her long-time publicist, John Blanchette.

headline: Biden Responds to McChrystal’s Words
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Sunday that he did not feel personally attacked by the derisive remarks by Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal and his aides in a Rolling Stone article published last month. But he suggested that General McChrystal’s firing as the top commander in Afghanistan was necessary.

headline: Racer Collapses Near End of Triathlon
text: A 31-year-old London man was in critical condition Sunday after collapsing near the finish line of the New York City Triathlon, race officials said.

headline: Burnett Apologizes to Yankee Teammates
text: The Yankees right-hander A.J. Burnett said he apologized to his teammates for Saturday’s outburst in which he cut both his hands and had to leave the game after slapping plastic paper-holders mounted on a door in the clubhouse.

headline: Pettitte Leaves Game With Groin Injury
text: A day after A.J. Burnett had to be removed from his start in the third inning with cuts on his hands, Andy Pettitte left the third inning of Sunday’s game against the Rays with a strained left groin.

headline: Unwelcome at School, and at Home, Too
text: A coming-of-age story, “Udaan” is an impressive debut feature by Vikramaditya Motwane that covers familiar first-film ground with emotional conviction and freshness. A kind of Indian cousin to Truffaut’s “400 Blows,” “Udaan” follows the fortunes of Rohan (the sweet-faced Rajat Barmecha), an aspiring writer whose horizons shrink when he’s kicked out of prep school. He is sent home to Jamshedpur, an industrial town in northeast India, to live with a father he hasn’t seen in years and a 6-year-old half brother, Arjun, he didn’t know he had.

headline: Young Players From Greece Earn a Title
text: OPATIJA, Croatia  The 10th European Youth Pairs Championships ended here on Saturday afternoon. The winners of the junior (under 26) event were Konstantinos Doxiadis and Vassilis Vroustis from Greece, who finished just ahead of Janis Bethers and Martins Lorencs from Latvia. Third were Joanna Taczewska and Artur Wasiak from Poland.

headline: Moral Camouflage or Moral Monkeys?
text: After being shown proudly around the campus of a prestigious American university built in gothic style, Bertrand Russell is said to have exclaimed, “Remarkable. As near Oxford as monkeys can make.” Much earlier, Immanuel Kant had expressed a less ironic amazement, “Two things fill the mind with ever new and increasing admiration and awe … the starry heavens above and the moral law within.” Today many who look at morality through a Darwinian lens can’t help but find a charming naïveté in Kant’s thought. “Yes, remarkable. As near morality as monkeys can make.”

headline: Senior E.U. Emissary Visits Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — The European Union’s top foreign policy official visited Gaza on Sunday and called for further pressure on Israel to allow freer movement of people and goods out of the Palestinian territory.

headline: New CDs
text: RICK ROSS

headline: A New Label’s Mission: Indian Music
text: Could there be more global hits like “Jai Ho” in the future? Universal Music thinks so.

headline: Bit of an Oversight
text: Art experts at Yale University have discovered that a painting that has been at Yale for decades was done by the Spanish artist Velázquez. The painting, “Education of the Virgin,” above, had been thought to be the creation of an unknown artist when it was donated to Yale in 1925, The Associated Press reported. And, separately, the Vatican newspaper L’Osservatore Romano has reported that a new painting by the Italian artist Caravaggio might have been found in Rome. The article, appearing while Italy is celebrating the 400th anniversary of Caravaggio’s death, said further analysis would be necessary before “The Martyrdom of St. Lawrence” could be attributed with certainty to him, The A.P. reported.

headline: Pilgrim, the Final Volume
text: The story of the 20-something slacker Scott Pilgrim, below, created, written and drawn by Bryan Lee O’Malley, will conclude on Tuesday with the release of Volume 6, “Scott Pilgrim’s Finest Hour.” Oni Press has announced that the final chapter in Scott’s battle to win the heart of Ramona Flowers will have a first printing of 100,000 copies. Impatient readers have another option: More than 150 comic-book stores will be open at midnight on Monday selling the 248-page book. At Comic-Con International, starting Thursday in San Diego, fans can take part in the Scott Pilgrim experience, including designing T-shirts with the cast of “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World,” starring Michael Cera and directed by Edgar Wright and scheduled to be released on Aug. 13.

headline: Snipes’s Appeal Denied
text: The actor Wesley Snipes has lost his appeal of a prison sentence he received in 2008 for three misdemeanor tax charges, Reuters reported. In February 2008 a court in Ocala, Fla., sentenced him to three years in jail for willfully failing to file tax returns for 1999 to 2004. During that time he earned more than $38 million appearing in several movies, including two sequels to the popular vampire thriller “Blade.” In the appeal Mr. Snipes said that he should have been considered for probation and that the lower court should have allowed him to argue for a change of venue from Florida, where Mr. Snipes has a home, to New York, where he was born. The ruling did not specify where Mr. Snipes would be serving his sentence.

headline: Zsa Zsa Gabor in Hospital
text: The actress Zsa Zsa Gabor was taken to Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center on Saturday night after breaking her hip in a fall at home, The Los Angeles Times reported. Ms. Gabor, 93, was reaching over to answer the phone when she fell out of bed in her home in Bel Air on Saturday night, according to her publicist, John Blanchette. “Her family is by her side,” the hospital said in a statement to The Times. “No other information is available from the hospital per the family’s request.” Early Sunday Ms. Gabor’s husband, Prince Frederic von Anhalt, told The Times that she had broken her hip. Mr. Blanchette said Ms. Gabor had broken several bones; he added that Ms. Gabor, who was partly paralyzed after a car accident in 2002 and who had a stroke in 2005, had been “pretty much bedridden and wheelchair bound for the last eight years.”

headline: Castillo to Return, Perez to Relieve, Takahashi to Start Again
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Luis Castillo is expected to rejoin the Mets on Monday in Arizona, Manager Jerry Manuel said. He also said Oliver Perez could rejoin the team soon to pitch out of the bullpen against left-handed hitters, and not in place of Hisanori Takahashi.

headline: Joel Grey to Direct ‘Normal Heart’ Reading
text: Joel Grey, right, is to direct a staged reading of “Normal Heart,” the semi-autobiographical drama by Larry Kramer about the early years of the AIDS epidemic, to celebrate its 25th anniversary. The reading, presented by the producer Daryl Roth, is scheduled for Oct. 18 at the Walter Kerr Theater. Mr. Grey appeared in the 1985 production at the Public Theater, when he replaced Brad Davis as Ned, the activist based on Mr. Kramer. After seeing the show with Mr. Davis onstage, Mr. Grey said in a telephone interview, he told Mr. Kramer that “this is overwhelming and so devastating and important that I’ll never forget it.” He told Mr. Kramer he would love to step in if the role of Ned were to open up, and soon after he had his chance. “It was the most profound work experience,” Mr. Grey said. “Reading it again felt so fresh to me,” he added. “I was startled at all the issues that still remain 25 years later.” Mr. Grey directed a similar staged reading at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles in May, to raise money for an H.I.V./AIDS charity there. The New York reading will raise money for two organizations: the Actors Fund, which provides a range of services to people in the performing arts, and Friends in Deed, which supports people with H.I.V./AIDS and other life-threatening illnesses. Casting has not been announced.

headline: ‘Lost’ Cleans Its Attic
text: Still mourning the end of the television show “Lost”? Perhaps owning a prop or costume would help. Profiles in History, an auction company specializing in Hollywood memorabilia, plans to auction more than 1,000 lots, including props, costumes and set pieces, on Aug. 21 and Aug. 22 in the Barker Hangar at the Santa Monica Airport in California. (Yes, it’s that big.) Among the items on the block will be Hurley’s winning lottery ticket, Locke’s wheelchair, Benjamin Linus’s fake “Henry Gale” identification, Charlie’s guitar and some larger items, including the Dharma van. Further information is available at profilesinhistory.com.

headline: Broadway for Lunch
text: The annual Broadway in Bryant Park series, presented by the radio station 106.7 Lite FM, is for the 10th year offering lunchtime concerts by cast members from Broadway and Off Broadway shows, to be held on Thursdays at 12:30 p.m. (through Aug. 12). This week, cast members from “Chicago,” “A Little Night Music,” “Falling for Eve” and “Rock of Ages” are to perform. The schedule is at bryantpark.org.

headline: ‘Through the Night’ at Union Square Theater
text: Daniel Beaty, below, will perform his solo piece “Through the Night,” Off Broadway at the Union Square Theater starting Sept. 10, the show’s producer, Daryl Roth, is expected to announce today. A mix of prose, poetry and monologues, “Through the Night” follows the interlocking stories of several black men and boys, the youngest 10, who experience “an unexpected epiphany on the same evening that changes their lives forever,” according to production materials. Mr. Beaty, who won an Obie Award in 2007 for his play “Emergency” (formerly known as “Emergence-SEE!”), will play all of the characters in “Through the Night.” Charles Randolph-Wright will direct, as he did for a production of “Through the Night” in May at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights. Several actors, including Bill Cosby and Ruby Dee, participated in post-performance talks for that production; they and others have signed on as “artistic ambassadors” for Ms. Roth, planning to do publicity and spread the word about the show on their e-mail lists. In a telephone interview Mr. Cosby said he became involved with “Through the Night” because “it provides a new, fresh viewpoint on human beings and human behavior, on the way an interesting set of lives is unfolding in America today.” Opening night is scheduled for Sept. 26.

headline: ‘Inception’ Exceeds Box-Office Dreams
text: LOS ANGELES  Guess what? Movies don’t have to be sequels or animated to do enormous box-office business in the summer.

headline: Woodland Walk With Mahler, Full of Colors and Contrasts
text: LENOX, Mass. — From the moment it was announced, a performance of Mahler’s epic Third Symphony at the Tanglewood Festival here on Saturday night promised to be a highlight of the season. James Levine, who has shaped memorable versions of this paean to nature in a variety of settings — including at least one outdoors, at the Aspen Music Festival in 1999 — was to conduct talented fellows of the Tanglewood Music Center, mostly young professionals, in the annual Leonard Bernstein Memorial Concert in the Shed.

headline: As Top Riders Pull Away in Tour, Others Wonder What Went Wrong
text: AX 3 DOMAINES, France  With 568 punishing miles left in the Tour de France, some riders finally accepted their fate Sunday.

headline: Pettitte Exits, but Yankees Beat Rays
text: Compared with the injury to the Yankees’ starting pitcher on Saturday, Sunday’s mishap was merely mundane. Unlike A. J. Burnett, who cut the palms of his hands when angrily slamming them into a clubhouse door Saturday, Andy Pettitte was merely throwing a pitch when he strained his left groin muscle Sunday.

headline: Mississippi Invaded by Idealism
text: The comedian Dick Gregory used to joke bitterly during the civil rights era, that you could always spot a white moderate in Mississippi. He was the “cat who wants to lynch you from a low tree.”

headline: Location in a Donizetti Opera
text: Klaatu barada nikto!

headline: Shedding Darkness on an Eakins Painting
text: PHILADELPHIA  The critic Clement Greenberg once described Thomas Eakins’s signature brand of darkness as “an ideal chiaroscuro.” Eakins was known to knock down even the brightness of a cheerful blue sky with a sober dimming wash.

headline: Metalcore, Screamo and Hugs
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — As éminences grises go, the members of Sum 41 are especially green. But at the Vans Warped Tour, which sprawled over the Nassau Coliseum parking lot on Saturday, it doesn’t take much to be a veteran.

headline: Five and Five: No. 48, Air Force
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 48, is Air Force. You can find a larger Air Force preview here.

headline: Will Gulf Containment Cap Hold?
text: NBC's Lester Holt and John Hofmeister, a former president of Shell Oil, discuss BP's extension of a crucial well test into a third day. (Video: NBC)

headline: Five and Five: No. 47, Clemson
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the coming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 47, is Clemson. You can find a larger Clemson preview here.

headline: Warped 2010
text: Photos from the Vans Warped Tour at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Woods Knows His Trouble Spot
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Tiger Woods came to St. Andrews thinking he could win the British Open. When he departed Sunday after tying for 23rd, he was satisfied only in that he knew why he never really had a chance to hoist to the claret jug.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include housing starts for June (Tuesday); and weekly jobless claims, existing home sales for June and leading economic indicators for June (Thursday).

headline: Drug Gang Suspected in Mexico Party Massacre
text: MEXICO CITY  Gunmen burst into a birthday party where celebrators were dancing to live music and opened fire early Sunday, killing at least 17 people in an attack that was violent even by the bloody standards of Mexico’s drug war.

headline: Making Museums Fun for All
text: Discovery Kids is entering the educational online gaming business with a twist: one component of its new history and science game, called Seek Your Own Proof, is intended to get children offline and into museums.

headline: Glamour’s Weight-Gain Secret
text: If September 2007 was the high point of the hefty fashion magazine, with more than 700 pages of ads in Vogue and about 400 each in Elle and InStyle, then 2009 was more apropos to the ethos of the fashion world: svelte and petite.

headline: China’s Censors Rein in ‘Vulgar’ Reality TV Show
text: BEIJING — When viewers tuned into China’s most popular dating show this spring, they saw beautiful women, brutal rejections and plenty of money worshiping, as when a female contestant was asked by a possible date whether she would like to go for a bicycle ride.

headline: Online, a Journalist Adds a Business Role
text: Kelly Wallace’s move from television to the Internet embodies the lingering differences between the forms.

headline: Blown Call on Slide Lets Mets Escape Sweep
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A blown save was counteracted by a blown call Sunday, and the Mets escaped from San Francisco with a victory they were happy to take but probably did not deserve.

headline: Tax-Free Living in Pakistan
text: So few of the Pakistani rich pay taxes that one neighborhood hired transgender tax collectors to embarrass residents into paying. Adam B. Ellick follows them a week before the tax deadline.

headline: Stopwatches? Sensor Technology Puts the Laptop in Lap
text: Technology in swimming was once limited to a razor and a stopwatch.

headline: Record of M.T.A.’s New Cost-Cutter Alarms Skeptics
text: It may be one of the toughest tasks in New York government: taming the bloat of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, long considered one of the most unwieldy bureaucracies in the state.

headline: After Tumult, Debt Worries Ease in Europe
text: Just two months ago, Europe’s sovereign debt problems seemed grave enough to imperil the global economic recovery. Now, at least some investors are treating it as the crisis that wasn’t.

headline: In a Changing Village, the Pool Tables Look the Same
text: BREWSTER, N.Y.

headline: Surgeon Who Repaired Racer’s Heart Joins Him as He Puts It to Test
text: A year and a half removed from open-heart surgery, Greg O’Keeffe decided to test himself. He would try to run a triathlon, and he would dare his surgeon to do it, too.

headline: Pakistan’s Elite Pay Few Taxes, Widening Gap
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Much of Pakistan’s capital city looks like a rich Los Angeles suburb. Shiny sport utility vehicles purr down gated driveways. Elegant multistory homes are tended by servants. Laundry is never hung out to dry.

headline: Pakistan Hires Transgender Workers to Shame Tax Delinquents
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — In one of Karachi’s most posh neighborhoods, only half of the 500,000 residents paid their property, maintenance and water taxes last year.

headline: New York Is Not Just Hot, but Parched
text: They are the casualties in a profoundly parched region: the yellowed lawns; the scorched median strips on highways from Westhampton, N.Y., to West Orange, N.J.; and the orangy brown tree on the island in the lake in Central Park.

headline: A.I.G. Is Said to Be Hiring Briton to Lead Asian Unit
text: The American International Group plans to name Mark Tucker, former head of Prudential of Britain, to lead the Asian life insurance subsidiary that Prudential once hoped to buy, a person familiar with the decision said on Sunday.

headline: Virginia Man Flies Home on Waiver
text: WASHINGTON  A Muslim man from Virginia who was prevented for weeks from returning to the United States after studying in Yemen is home again. But his lawyer said the man, Yahya Wehelie, 26, remained on the no-fly list and was permitted to fly to New York on Saturday only under a waiver granted by federal authorities.

headline: Palin, Shakespeare and the Ground Zero Mosque
text: Sarah Palin isn’t just weighing in on competitive Republican races. Ground Zero, in heavily Democratic New York City, was her target for Sunday afternoon.

headline: A Fast-Paced City Tries to Be a Gentler Place to Grow Old
text: New York City has given pedestrians more time to cross at more than 400 intersections in an effort to make streets safer for older residents. The city has sent yellow school buses, filled not with children but with elderly people, on dozens of grocery store runs over the past seven months.

headline: Staring Down Lenders, Selig Complicates Rangers’ Sale
text: BOSTON  The Texas Rangers have started the second half of the season much the way they played before the All-Star break: like a confident team eager to make the playoffs for the first time since 1999. In their first games back, they won three of four against the Red Sox at Fenway Park to maintain a four-and-a-half-game lead in the American League West.

headline: M.T.A. Deficit Means Riders May Pay More
text: Riders of New York’s transportation system are about to learn a tough lesson of recessionary politics: In times of crisis, nothing is sacred.

headline: Booming Demand for TV on the Internet in China
text: SHANGHAI — Internet TV has arrived in China.

headline: Above the Crowds, but Not Above Lawbreaking
text: MOSCOW  A young man pushed several buttons on an outdoor intercom, and after the piercing sound of the lock release, he vanished, like an experienced thief, into the cool shadow of the building’s lobby. A few minutes later, he stepped onto the roof and gazed down at Moscow.

headline: Medical Worker Under Inquiry Is Killed Outside a SoHo Club
text: An emergency medical worker, under investigation for his actions preceding the death last year of a woman who had collapsed in a sandwich shop, was shot and killed outside a Manhattan nightclub early Sunday.

headline: A Bill to Stop Illegal Hotels, and a Protest
text: When the State Legislature recently passed a bill meant to stop the use of residential apartments as hotel rooms, tenant advocates and some elected officials spoke favorably of the measure, saying it would end a dangerous and unregulated practice.

headline: The Problem of Plagiarism in School
text: To the Editor:

headline: Questioning BP’s Conduct, From Ohio to Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bazaar Strike Ends in Tehran
text: TEHRAN  Merchants at the Grand Bazaar here returned to work on Sunday, ending a strike that some observers saw as protest against the government of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

headline: Drug Patent Agreements
text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Second for Golf’s Latest Near-Miss Man
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  There has been pain the last week for Lee Westwood: he played at St. Andrews with a ruptured plantaris muscle in his lower leg. But his second-place finish at the British Open still hurt quite a bit less than his many other missed opportunities at the world’s great golf tournaments.

headline: Scientist Says U.S. Wanted to Swap Him for Hikers
text: TEHRAN  The Iranian scientist who American officials say defected to the United States only to be pressured by Iran to return home has made his first appearance since his arrival last week in Tehran, adding details to what he says was his abduction, psychological torture and eventual release by American intelligence agents.

headline: Obama’s Business Plan
text: JUST as Congress finally passed its sweeping financial reform bill last week, a chorus of high-profile chief executives and business lobbying groups were criticizing President Obama and what they see as a new era of big, stifling government and heavy regulation. Ivan Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon, delivered a particularly stinging rebuke: In remarks to the Economic Club of Washington, he blamed President Obama for “an increasingly hostile environment for investment and job creation” and lambasted an administration that is “reaching into every sector of American life” and “making it harder to raise capital and create new businesses.”

headline: Death in Police Encounter Stirs Calls for Change in Egypt
text: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  The two undercover police officers seemed unfazed by the bystanders, who watched as the officers beat a 28-year-old man in the lobby of a building here last month, one witness said.

headline: Out of Prison, Still Not Free
text: Madrid

headline: After Training, Still Scrambling for Employment
text: In what was beginning to feel like a previous life, Israel Valle had earned $18 an hour as an executive assistant to a designer at a prominent fashion label. Now, he was jobless and struggling to find work. He decided to invest in upgrading his skills.

headline: Sorenstam Says Forget the Arms; Focus on the Feet
text: More so than in her playing days, Annika Sorenstam is around amateur golfers at her golf academy in Orlando, Fla., and in charity events. I asked her recently to name the two things she saw amateur players do wrong most often. She said:

headline: Two Teens Drown in Bronx River
text: Two teenagers drowned in the Bronx River on Sunday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Obama Wins Unlikely Allies in Immigration
text: At a time when the prospects for immigration overhaul seem most dim, supporters have unleashed a secret weapon: a group of influential evangelical Christian leaders.

headline: Restoring New York Streets to Their Bumpier Pasts
text: On a stretch of Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, a construction site hummed with the usual activity. Workers encircled a crane removing dirt from a trench. Others mixed concrete in a wheelbarrow.

headline: Doctor for Prison Inmates Resigns Amid Questions About His Certification
text: The doctor in charge of medical care for 12,000 New York City jail inmates abruptly resigned last week after questions arose about his professional certification, forcing city officials and executives at the company that employed the doctor to race to find a temporary replacement.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Oil and Water
text: In the wake of the oil spill, O'Neil and Samantha Sevin are struggling to preserve their Cajun livelihood and culture.

headline: TARP Audit Questions Rush to Close Auto Dealers
text: DETROIT  President Obama’s auto task force pressed General Motors and Chrysler to close scores of dealerships without adequately considering the jobs that would be lost or having a firm idea of the cost savings that would be achieved, an audit of the process has concluded.

headline: The Pundit Delusion
text: The latest hot political topic is the “Obama paradox”  the supposedly mysterious disconnect between the president’s achievements and his numbers. The line goes like this: The administration has had multiple big victories in Congress, most notably on health reform, yet President Obama’s approval rating is weak. What follows is speculation about what’s holding his numbers down: He’s too liberal for a center-right nation. No, he’s too intellectual, too Mr. Spock, for voters who want more passion. And so on.

headline: French Heiress vs. Daughter and Political Intrigue
text: PARIS — An aging heiress. An angry daughter. A society photographer. A renegade butler and an embittered accountant. Secret tapes. A famous company with a nasty past and long political connections. An unpopular president and a cabinet minister with a taste for money, and tales of illegal cash donations in envelopes.

headline: In a World of Online News, Burnout Starts Younger
text: ARLINGTON, Va.  In most newsrooms, the joke would have been obvious.

headline: The Roots of White Anxiety
text: In March of 2000, Pat Buchanan came to speak at Harvard University’s Institute of Politics. Harvard being Harvard, the audience hissed and sneered and made wisecracks. Buchanan being Buchanan, he gave as good as he got. While the assembled Ivy Leaguers accused him of homophobia and racism and anti-Semitism, he accused Harvard  and by extension, the entire American elite  of discriminating against white Christians.

headline: Reform Moves Ahead
text: Less than four months after Congress approved historic health care reform legislation, the Obama administration has been making good progress in bringing some early benefits to fruition and issuing rules to guide the reform process. Despite all of the critics’ hype and scare tactics, some polls suggest that the public perception of reform is slowly improving.

headline: A Popular Principal, Wounded by Government’s Good Intentions
text: BURLINGTON, Vt.  It’s hard to find anyone here who believes that Joyce Irvine should have been removed as principal of Wheeler Elementary School.

headline: That Noisy Coal Mine Alarm
text: If a sense of urgency is needed beyond the deaths of 29 coal miners last April in West Virginia, Congressional lawmakers better heed the latest news from the Upper Big Branch mine where the explosion occurred. A company electrician has admitted that he was ordered to bypass a methane detector alarm when it kept interrupting the flow of coal.

headline: Albany’s Latest Excuse to Shirk Its Duty
text: New York’s state budget is now officially more than 15 weeks late. The main reason for the latest delay is that Gov. David Paterson and several Democratic senators whose votes are crucial want to give state universities more freedom to run their own campuses. New York’s state universities badly need improvement, but the proposals on the table are not good enough and this is not the right time to do it.

headline: The Next Financial Crisis (the Stamp Bubble?)
text: In a world in which anything, it seems, can be turned into a risky investment instrument, consider the “forever” stamp. Did you think it was just a device for the post office to guarantee that a first-class stamp would always be postage enough for a first-class letter? Imagine if the stamps caught the eye of some Wall Street whiz. Like tulips and mortgages, the little sticker with the Liberty Bell has the makings of a nice financial crisis.

headline: Policing the Web’s Lurid Precincts
text: Ricky Bess spends eight hours a day in front of a computer near Orlando, Fla., viewing some of the worst depravities harbored on the Internet. He has seen photographs of graphic gang killings, animal abuse and twisted forms of pornography. One recent sighting was a photo of two teenage boys gleefully pointing guns at another boy, who is crying.

headline: Call for Justice Sets Off a Debate
text: NEWBERRY, S.C.  Before dawn on June 2, law enforcement officials here say, a white man shot and killed a black co-worker at close range. Then, he tied his body to the back of a truck and dragged it for nearly 11 miles before the rope broke, leaving the mangled corpse of the victim, Anthony Hill, on a bloody patch of road.

headline: Two Teenagers Drown in Bronx River
text: Two teenagers drowned on Sunday afternoon as one tried to rescue the other at a popular but off-limits swimming spot in the Bronx, the authorities and witnesses said.

headline: Post-Mortem: No Hair Shirt for Steve Jobs
text: By now, most people know what happens when your fingers come in contact with the lower left-hand corner of the iPhone 4 — are you there? — but it took the touch of an old-line, nontech tester of technology to get Apple to admit as much.

headline: Golf as a Rehabilitative Tool for Amputees
text: The National Amputee Golf Association announced this year that it was opening its national championships to men and women with disabilities other than a major joint amputation. Blind golfers and golfers with various physical challenges or mobility limitations can now compete as associate members of the amputee association.

headline: Lottery Numbers
BP Pressed to Assess ‘Seep’ Near Its Well
text: July 19, 9:50 a.m. | Updated Lest residents around the Gulf of Mexico rest too easy after the tenth effort by BP to seal its gushing seabed well seemed to work, the federal government Sunday night ordered the company to be prepared to open the valves on its well cap if reports of oil and gas seeping from the seabed nearby were confirmed. [On Monday morning, Thad W. Allen, who is overseeing the operation for the government, issued a statement allowing pressure testing of the well to continue into Tuesday, as the gas and oil seeps were investigated.]

headline: Sports Replay: July 18
text: The day in sports, from the German Grand Prix to the Calgary Stampede to the Tour de France.

headline: As Niche Gets Crowded, Studio Watches Its Back
text: LOS ANGELES — In April, Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chief executive of DreamWorks Animation, voiced public fury at Warner Brothers for having abruptly converted its “Clash of the Titans” into 3-D and releasing it a week after his company’s 3-D film, “How to Train Your Dragon.”

headline: Rescued From Blight, Falling Back Into Decay
text: Hundreds of buildings, from the South Bronx to central Brooklyn, whose renovation and rescue from ruinous debt were critical to the rebirth of blighted neighborhoods, are again in severe financial trouble. That poses a dilemma for the city, which began unloading the properties in the mid-1990s as part of an arduous effort to divest itself of thousands of decrepit buildings seized because of tax delinquencies.

headline: In a Partnership of Unequals, a Start-Up Suffers
text: Technology start-ups and big companies work together all the time  refining ideas, seeking mutual advantage and accelerating the pace of development of new products and services. But these odd-couple relationships can be fraught with peril.

headline: Testing Everything Because You’ll Try Anything
text: Inside a low-slung building off a nondescript road in a quiet central New Jersey suburb is the most powerful room in golf.

headline: From Insider, a Comics Venture to Help Newcomers
text: If the comic book writer Robert Kirkman were a superhero, his name might be the Midas Touch.

headline: SnagFilms to Expand Distribution of Documentaries
text: LOS ANGELES  The little business of documentary film just got bigger.

headline: Deal for Healthscope of Australia
text: The Carlyle Group and TPG Capital agreed to buy the Australian hospital operator Healthscope Ltd. for 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.7 billion), beating a bid from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: For Cajuns, What Now?
text: For the Cajuns, whose rustic French-American culture is almost wholly dependent on the natural bayous that open to the Gulf of Mexico, the oil spill has forced the question of whether they can preserve their way of life — and if so, at what cost?

headline: Cajuns on Gulf Worry They May Need to Move  Again
text: CHAUVIN, La.  Stanley Sevin knew it was time to have the difficult conversation with his parents when he saw the oil sheen shimmering under his family’s dock on the bayou. He had been putting it off ever since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in April.

headline: Colombia’s Picture-Perfect Beauty Queens
text: At first glance, the woman gazing at her reflection in a photograph by Carl Bower looks ecstatic. Eyebrows raised, she grins and reveals two rows of snow-white teeth. Her eyes, though, betray a sense of hesitation, and her hands are folded, somewhat unnaturally, behind her back. At her side, a man with a scruffy beard mimics her expression.

headline: Word of the Day | largess
text: largess •\lär-ˈzhes, lär-ˈjes also ˈlär-ˌjes\• noun

headline: Pepsi Fires a Salvo to Restart the Cola Wars
text: THE cola wars shaped not just the soft drink industry but also Madison Avenue, inspiring the satirical newspaper The Onion to declare, in a 1997 headline, “Ad Industry Veterans Honored With Cola War Memorial.” Now Pepsi is engaging in a bit of war re-enactment, remaking a well-known comparative commercial, but with a twist, replacing Coke and Pepsi with the sugarless versions Coke Zero and Pepsi Max.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: Mamedyarov Leads in Dortmund
text: Le Quang Liem beat Ruslan Ponomariov Sunday, allowing Shakhriyar Mamedyarov to take over sole possession of first place at the elite Sparkassen Chess-Meeting tournament.

headline: Paulo Moura, a Force in Brazilian Music, Dies at 77
text: Paulo Moura, a virtuoso instrumentalist and a composer, arranger and orchestrator of numerous styles of Brazilian popular music, died on July 12 in Rio de Janeiro. He was 77.

headline: Mystery for White House: Where Did the Jobs Go?
text: Welcome as it is, progress toward finally capping the gulf oil leak hasn’t resolved the biggest conundrum facing President Obama before the midterm elections.

headline: Where the Bloggers Are Concentrated
text: As might be expected, 21- to 35-year-olds now constitute a majority of all bloggers, making up 53.3 percent of that population, according to analysis by the social media consulting firm Sysomos.

headline: Officials Say Boeing Won a Jet Order From Emirates
text: Boeing obtained an order for up to 30 of its wide-body 777 jets from Emirates Airline of Dubai in a deal that would be worth nearly $7 billion at list prices, industry officials said Sunday.

headline: News Quiz | July 19, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Wall Street May Finally Breathe Easier
text: Wall Street’s summer may have officially started. Goldman Sachs last week settled fraud charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Senate passed sweeping financial reform legislation. Even hapless BP appears to have finally capped its oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A.I.G. Is Said to Be Hiring Briton to Lead Asian Unit
text: The American International Group planned to name Mark Tucker, former head of Prudential of Britain, to lead the Asian life insurance subsidiary that Prudential once hoped to buy, a person familiar with the decision said on Sunday, The New York Times’s Duff Wilson reported.

headline: Deal for Healthscope of Australia
text: The private equity firms TPG and Carlyle have won a bidding war for Australia’s Healthscope, agreeing to pay $1.73 billion for the hospital owner in the nation’s largest buyout deal since 2007, Reuters reported.

headline: Telefónica Withdraws Bid for Brazilian Joint Venture
text: Telefonica of Spain over the weekend withdrew its 7.15 billion euro ($9.26 billion) bid to take full control of its Brazilian wireless joint venture with Portugal Telecom after the deal was vetoed by the Portuguese government, The New York Times’s Raphael Minder reported.

headline: The Men Who Ended Goldman’s War
text: Last Wednesday at around 3 p.m., the Securities and Exchange Commission and Goldman Sachs settled an epic, seismic battle — one waged over whether the storied investment bank defrauded investors in a transaction that regulators said Goldman had built to self-destruct, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports.

headline: Inflows Lift Polar Capital Assets to $2.6 billion
text: Polar Capital said client assets under management rose 2.5 percent in the three months to June, with client inflows more than offsetting fund losses from recent market volatility, Reuters reported.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Papaverous
text: Today’s word, in association with the treasured Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: AXA-NAB Extend $11.5 Billion Takeover Deal
text: National Australia Bank, the takeover target AXA Asia Pacific and France’s AXA SA agreed to extend an $11.5 billion acquisition agreement to Aug. 31, signaling they were far from resolving regulatory obstacles, Reuters reported.

headline: BP-Apache Talks on Prudhoe Bay Stake Said to Stall
text: BP‘s talks to sell half its stake in Alaska’s Prudhoe Bay oil field to Apache stalled twice over the weekend, raising doubts about whether the deal will be completed, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Summer Rite of Passage
text: WHO are the teenage boys who jump from the cliffs pictured here?

headline: Holding Bankers’ Feet to the Fire
text: From Gretchen Morgenson’s Fair Game Column:

headline: Tomkins Gets $4.5 Billion Canadian Bid Approach
text: The British engineering company Tomkins has received a bid approach from a Canadian consortium, which values it at close to £2.9 billion ($4.45 billion) and has opened its books to the suitors, Reuters reported.

headline: Green Dot I.P.O. Gets Valentine From Congress
text: Green Dot, a prepaid debit-card company, could see strong demand for its initial public offering this week because of the financial reform bill, which exempted prepaid cards from its harshest restrictions, Reuters reported.

headline: In a Partnership of Unequals, a Start-Up Suffers
text: Technology start-ups and big companies work together all the time — refining ideas, seeking mutual advantage and accelerating the pace of development of new products and services. But these odd-couple relationships can be fraught with peril, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

headline: After Tumult, Debt Worries Ease in Europe
text: Just two months ago, Europe’s sovereign debt problems seemed grave enough to imperil the global economic recovery. Now, at least some investors are treating it as the crisis that wasn’t, The New York Times’s Graham Bowley writes.

headline: Biden: Wall Street Reform Helps By Ending Uncertainty
text: The passage of Wall Street reforms by Congress helps the economic recovery under way by easing uncertainty that had been holding back investment, Vice President Joe Biden said on Sunday, Reuters reported.

headline: Google Buys Metaweb to Improve Search Results
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Altman: Obama’s Business Plan
text: From Roger C. Altman, an investment banker and a former deputy secretary of the Treasury, writing in The New York Times’s Op/Ed Pages:

headline: Giants 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit@NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: BP Said to Canvass Investors on Possible Break-Up
text: BP has started canvassing shareholders about a restructuring following its Gulf of Mexico oil spill, which could include a break up of the business, The Sunday Times reported.

headline: Bankers Worried Over European Bank Stress Tests
text: Senior bankers and regulators across Europe are worried that markets could misinterpret the outcome of a test of how resilient European banks are to economic shocks, The Financial Times said on Monday.

headline: Reliance in Deal Talks With Quicksilver, Report Says
text: The Indian energy company Reliance Industries is in talks with Texas-based Quicksilver Resources about several potential deals, including a possible buyout of the American company, which develops shale gas and coal-bed methane, The Daily News & Analysis reported, citing sources familiar with the development.

headline: U.A.E. Regulator Urges Higher Buyout Offer for Aabar
text: The Emirates’ market watchdog is calling on Aabar Investments‘ top shareholder to boost its offer to buy out minority shareholders by more than a third, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Is Another Economics Possible?
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Frescoes Revamped at Ancient Roman Villa
text: “A blinding vision.” That’s how the first century B.C. Roman architect and theoretician Vitruvius described the fresco technique popular during his time, and it’s an apt description for the newly revamped rooms of an ancient villa that is showcased at the Palazzo Massimo, part of the Roman National Museum.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: We’re asking this question every Monday this summer for our Summer Reading Student Challenge. You can post your answer here anytime until next Monday, July 26, when we’ll close this post and open a new one with the same question.

headline: Private Equity Group Buys 3 Failed Banks
text: North American Financial Holdings, run by the former chief of Bank of America‘s investment banking unit, bought three failed United States lenders, as the number of banks taken over by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation this year hit 96, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: On Hiatus
text: A note to readers: Idea of the Day is taking a two-week summer break and will return the first week in August. — The editors

headline: Maker of iPad Cases Wins Shopify Competition (and $100,000)
text: The Shopify Build-A-Business competition for new Web stores today announced the winner of its $100,000 grand prize.

headline: Sony Offers Tiny 3-D Cameras
text: Sony electronics is really pushing 3-D technology in the home, with its 3-D TVs and 3-D video games and movies. This week it brought more dimensionality into the electronics market by announcing a new crop of 3-D pocket cameras, the DSC-TX9 and DSC-WX5.

headline: Private Equity Lawyer Starts Firm
text: The private equity lawyer Matthew Hudson has attracted the backing of a group of buyout shops to hang his own shingle,  MJ Hudson, a new law firm that will advise clients on the creation of specialist investment funds and structuring deals, Financial News reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Bullish on Oil
text: Bets by hedge funds and other large speculators on higher oil prices increased by the largest amount in more than three years last week, just as the commodity began to slide, the second straight week money managers lined up on the wrong side of the market, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Hungary Resists New Budget Cuts Despite Pressure
text: BERLIN — Facing growing public anger over years of budget cuts, Hungary’s conservative government insisted Monday that it would not impose further austerity measures despite pressure from its international creditors.

headline: Kinder Morgan to Go Public?
text: Kinder Morgan, the pipeline giant that was taken private in a $22 billion leveraged buyout three years ago, is proceeding with plans for an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported, citing people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: A New Senator and a Vote on Jobless Benefits
text: The Senate intends to welcome an interim senator from West Virginia this week and quickly put him to work on a vote to extend long-stalled unemployment benefits.

headline: Most Arguments in the Car Are Over Directions, Says Survey
text: In the so-called war between the sexes one of the biggest sources of contention is the automobile — at least, according to a couple of recent surveys.

headline: RealD Raises $200 Million in I.P.O.
text: Shares in RealD, which licenses the 3-D technology used by a majority of movie theater chains in the United States, climbed more 21 percent in the company’s market debut Friday.

headline: Does Middle East Oil Get a Carbon Subsidy?
text: The federal government’s position on ethanol fuel is that it must contribute less to global warming than gasoline does, or why bother promoting it. Yet by some calculations, ethanol is worse because it encourages the destruction of forests to make way for new farmland, many assert. Burning trees releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere; what is more, the trees are no longer there to absorb carbon dioxide.

headline: Abu Dhabi Aircraft and Sikorsky in Joint Venture
text: A young Abu Dhabi aviation company on Monday started an $800 million joint venture with Sikorsky to service military aircraft across the Middle East, building on the emirate’s efforts to develop a homegrown aerospace industry, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: And in today’s Morning Take-Out:

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Cuckoo for Cocoa?
text: The mystery trader who bought 241,000 tons of cocoa beans Friday, driving prices of the commodity to their highest level since 1977, was Anthony Ward, co-founder of  the British hedge fund Armajaro Holdings, according to press reports.

headline: Nokia Siemens Agrees to Pay Cash for Division of Motorola

headline: BP Considers New Plan to Permanently Seal Well
text: As scientists on Monday allayed concerns that BP’s well in the Gulf of Mexico was damaged, the company said it was considering an alternative plan that could permanently seal the gusher sooner than had been anticipated.

headline: Major Ship in U.S. Fleet Will Visit South Korea

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: The digital mailbag spilled forth questions from bros today, from yet more people with dietary restrictions, from birthday celebrators and nice if narrow-minded people looking for good food, decently priced. I have done my best answering. Expand on the responses in the comments below. And of course: Send me your questions!

headline: Investors Study Earnings for Clues About the Economy

headline: Making Homes Safer for Dementia Patients
text: Just about everyone with an older parent living alone worries about falls, and there is no shortage of suggestions for how to elder-proof a home in order to minimize trips and slips. But experts say it is also important to minimize household dangers for people with dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Sarah Silverman and New Hampshire: Perfect Together
text: In need of a last-minute vacation idea? Why not try the state where Sarah Silverman grew up, was given a diagnosis of enuresis (bed-wetting) and took as many as 16 Xanax a day, and where her therapist hanged himself?

headline: In a Visit to Pakistan, Clinton Encounters a Less Hostile Reception
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The last time Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was in Pakistan, less than a year ago, she was asked when the United States would stop killing innocent civilians in its covert drone attacks. She, in turn, suggested that officials in the Pakistani government knew where Al Qaeda’s leaders were hiding.

headline: BP Is Not Doing Well

headline: A Physician’s a Musician, and Safety Is His Mission
text: His preferred get-up is a plain white lab coat. He often raps from the perspective of a disease. And his latest track is an ode to mass-transit safety.

headline: Where Fuel Prices Pinch
text: High gasoline prices are hurting rural parts of Mississippi, where people in some counties spend more than 13 percent of their income on fuel.

headline: Another View: Why No Restrictions on Leverage?
text: Ron Resnick, a co-founder of CounselWorks, argues that the financial regulatory overhaul fails to deal with a basic cause of the financial crisis: the enormous and risky overuse of leverage.

headline: Is There A Jobs Mystery?
text: Brad DeLong wonders why John Harwood makes so much of the supposed excessive rise in unemployment, even given the slump in GDP. Brad argues that the old Okun’s Law — in which a one-point fall in GDP caused only about a half-point rise in unemployment — didn’t hold in the last two recessions, either.

headline: The Trouble With Meritocracy
text: For anyone with an appropriate skepticism toward meritocracy and its works, there’s an obvious critique of my suggestion, in today’s column, that America might be better off if our top-flight colleges welcomed more students from demographics — the white working class, rural America, evangelical Christians, etc. — that are currently viewed with suspicion and hostility by the highly-educated elite. Part of the problem with meritocracy is that it homogenizes in the name of diversity: It skims the cream from every race and class and population, puts all of the best and brightest through the same educational conveyor belt, and comes out with a ruling class that’s cosmetically diverse but intellectually conformist, and that tends to huddle together rather than spreading out to enrich the country as a whole. This is Christopher Lasch’s lament in “The Revolt of the Elites” — that meritocracy co-opts people who might otherwise become its critics, sapping local communities of their intellectual vitality and preventing any kind of rival power centers from emerging. And it’s something that Angelo Codevilla gets right (while getting a number of other things wrong) in his recent blast against the American elite:

headline: Britain Hires Banker to Sell RBS and Lloyds Stakes
text: The British government hired an American investment banker on Monday to help it manage and sell its stakes in two of the country’s largest banks, Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports.

headline: The Early Word: Battle Over Benefits
text: President Obama is expected to make a Rose Garden statement Monday morning blasting Republicans for standing in the way of an extension of unemployment benefits that has been stalled in the Senate.

headline: Utilities and Environmentalists Haggle Over Climate Bill
text: Utility executives plan to head to Washington this week to weigh in on the latest iterations of legislation to control carbon dioxide emissions. Among them are Michael G. Morris, president and chief executive of American Electric Power, and James Rogers, chairman of Duke Energy.

headline: Testing for Lung Cancer Genes
text: Many people who never smoked or lived or worked with smokers still get lung cancer, explains Jane Brody in her recent Personal Health column. And “recent discoveries of unusual genetic abnormalities in lung cancers that afflict nonsmokers have spawned targeted treatments that can buy patients years of quality time,” she writes. Several readers had questions for the Consults blog about specific genes and mutations associated with lung cancer. Here, Dr. Derek Raghavan of the Cleveland Clinic responds.

headline: Mad Men City | Ask a Real Mad Man
text: This week, Ed McCabe, who worked for a number of major advertising agencies and is a founder of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, responded to readers’ questions about his life and career in advertising in the 1960s.

headline: Monday Reading: Focus Returns to Unemployment
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Free Man, Polanski Is Seen at Swiss Concert
text: The director Roman Polanski returned to public life beyond his house arrest, days after the Swiss authorities said they were declining a request by the United States to extradite the filmmaker to face sentencing on a 33-year-old sex charge. Reuters reported that Mr. Polanski was seen on Saturday night at the conclusion of the Montreux Jazz Festival, where his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner, performed a concert on Lake Geneva. Mr. Polanski also gave a television interview to the Swiss station TSR in which he thanked the people of Gstaad, where he had been under house arrest in his chalet since December. “I’m not sure what I will do hereafter,” Mr. Polanski said, according to Reuters. “For the moment I’m happy to be free.”

headline: Numberplay: Rare Coincidences Are Very Common!
text: “Wow!” “Amazing!” “Unbelievable!” “What are the chances of that?” Most, if not all of you, have uttered words like this at some time in your life. The paradoxical title of today’s Numberplay, then, is true: rare coincidences are really common.

headline: An Online Pivot on the Gulf Oil Gusher
text: The Obama administration, clearly hoping that pressure tests on the capped BP seabed oil well succeed, is trying to pivot its online narrative on the disaster from response to recovery. On July 7, the government unveiled RestoreTheGulf.gov, a government Web site that will eventually completely supplant the DeepwaterHorizonResponse.com site that was hurriedly created in the spring to provide the latest information on everything from the oil flow to fishery closures. One problem with that site from the start, to my mind, was the mashup of information coming from BP and the federal government. This lack of delineation perhaps reflected the murky, and troubling, sense of who was in charge through the first month or so.

headline: Eggplant on the Grill
text: Eggplant is at its best in the summer months, which, as luck would have it, is also when backyard grills start seeing regular use. It’s a wonderful coincidence, because eggplants love smoke. The vegetable’s flesh absorbs the flavor from the grill as easily as it does olive oil.

headline: A Break in the Excitement
text: If you feel the need to be revived today  perhaps even resuscitated  you are not alone. It was inevitable, of course, that our rollicking sports summer of everything would hit a dead patch, a sort of cosmic payback for all the fun of the World Cup, for staid old Wimbledon spawning the longest tennis match in the history of the world. Yes, for all that excitement, we got a final round of the British Open that is now classified as the clinical cure for insomnia (the DVD should be available at online drugstores any day now).

headline: A Revived Hammer Films Draws ‘Harry Potter’ Star Into Its Macabre Web
text: Which one of these facts is more exciting: That Daniel Radcliffe has committed to making a horror movie for the venerable British horror studio Hammer Films? Or that Hammer Films, the home of gory, goopy, Gothic fright films like “Frankenstein and the Monster From Hell,” “Dracula Has Risen From the Grave” and “The Quatermass Xperiment” (better known on United States shores as “The Creeping Unknown”) is back in bloodthirsty business?

headline: Case Study | It’s Michelada Time
text: While it continues to astonish me how the michelada — the Mexican doctored beer that is a godsend in these dog days — remains unknown even to many of my well-traveled drink-hound friends, there’s also something about that which I enjoy. Most Mexican restaurants in New York, both high and low on the ladder, pull a puzzled face when you request one.

headline: Real Estate Money Is Scarce for Private Equity
text: Private equity real estate fund-raising fell in the second quarter to its lowest level since 2004, suggesting that a recovery has yet to take root in the investment property market.

text: Many versions of this salad are made throughout the Mediterranean. This one, slightly spicy, is North African. When grilling whole eggplants, seek out smaller ones, as they will grill more quickly and evenly than the large, bulbous ones.

You can find pomegranate molasses in Middle Eastern markets; it has a distinct sweet-and-sour flavor. When grilling whole eggplants, seek out smaller ones.

text: I’ve enjoyed variations of this simple preparation in Southern Italy. The Italians often fry the eggplant, but I prefer to grill it. You can use an outdoor grill or a panini grill. Serve this dish as part of an antipasto or as a side dish.

headline: Home Birth May Add a Wrinkle

headline: In Pictures | Stefan Ruiz’s Istanbul

He knew of the beauty, the history and the unique meeting of east and west, but Ruiz says he wasn’t aware of how the modern the city has become, referring to places like the swirling Kanyon Mall or the modern art museum. “I wouldn’t have even gone to the Sakirin Mosque if it weren’t for this shoot,” he says of the designer Zeynep Fadillioglu’s striking modern house of worship, the first in Turkey designed by a woman.

headline: Defined by Soccer: Patrick Phungwayo

Based in Alexandra — a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people — the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.

headline: Polls Find Wide Support For Jobless Benefit Extension

headline: A New Pumping Device Brings Hope for Cheney

headline: Palin Biography for Young Readers Postponed
text: A biography of Sarah Palin for young readers that was scheduled for a fall publication has been postponed. Zondervan, a Christian publisher that is part of HarperCollins, told The Associated Press that October is not “an optimal time” for the book to come out. A new publication date was not announced. The book, “Speaking Up,” is by Kim Washburn and is part of a series of biographies for teens. Ms. Washburn told The A.P. that she had been told that the book was on hold “indefinitely” and that she was surprised by the decision.

headline: A Look at The Washington Post’s ‘Top Secret America’
text: The Washington Post published the opening installment of its Top Secret America project, a two-year investigation into the national security buildup in the United States that followed the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

headline: Lollapalunch | Meet the Music Fest’s First Culinary Director
text: “Alan Richman once told me that all chefs are failed guitarists, and I’m sure the converse is also true,” says the Chicago chef Graham Elliot Bowles, who played guitar and sang in a band throughout high school and assumed he’d eventually turn pro. He still plays acoustic guitar and even records some of it. You might hear a track or two interspersed among the playlists piped into the dining room at his eponymous restaurant.

headline: Sadr Calls for New Iraqi Government
text: BAGHDAD  Moktada al-Sadr, the anti-American cleric in exile with a sizable bloc of followers in Iraq’s new Parliament, took his first direct public step into the country’s protracted political impasse on Monday, meeting in Syria with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s top rival to lead a new government.

headline: A Video from Outside Hebron
text: Here’s my latest video, from near the southern Hebron Hills, from my recent trip to the Middle East. I try to make the argument that while we can disagree about details, about history, about solutions, a starting point is simply an acknowledgment that Israel’s West Bank policy is profoundly unfair. But somehow I imagine that there will be disagreement about that as well — and go ahead and record your disagreements here.

headline: Steps Forward, and Backward, in Treating Diabetes
text: Catch the headline in The Times? “Warning Urged on Diabetes Pill,” it stated. “F.D.A. Proposes a Strongly Worded Label on Hazards of Heart Disease to User.”

headline: With This Rinse, Performance Improves
text: Exercise scientists say they have stumbled on an amazing discovery. Athletes can improve their performance in intense bouts of exercise, lasting an hour or so, if they merely rinse their mouths with a carbohydrate solution. They don’t even have to swallow it.

text: Electronic Arts, the video game maker, made a point in recent months of standing by Tiger Woods, even as other companies withdrew from sponsorships.

text: The “Still Life” festival on Sunday in the Ruhr region in western Germany offered some surreal images and video footage of the autobahn without cars and overrun with pedestrians.

headline: The Changing Face of S.B.A. Borrowers
text: Two things struck me about Stephanie Clifford’s recent report that Sam’s Club is offering Small Business Administration loans and both have to do with the borrower she featured: Michael Golata, a delivery driver in Louisville, who applied online for a $10,000 loan and was approved within a day.

headline: More Misery From Tick Bites
text: Q. A friend recently fell quite ill with something called ehrlichiosis. What is it and how can I avoid getting it?

headline: To Get an Internship at City Hall, It’s Not Always What You Know
text: They are the children and relatives of boldface names, like Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs; Peter G. Peterson, co-founder of the Blackstone Group; and Laurence A. Tisch, who was a hotel mogul and chief executive of CBS.

headline: African Studies Give Women Hope in H.I.V. Fight
text: VULINDLELA, South Africa  With an AIDS vaccine still out of reach, two rigorous new studies have found different ways to sharply cut H.I.V. infections among women and schoolgirls, who make up a majority of the newly infected in sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: Forging a Coherent Oceans Policy
text: The White House on Monday announced that it was forming a new National Ocean Council to try to make sense of the dozens of laws and overlapping agencies governing policy on oceans, coasts and the Great Lakes. The new body, which will include 24 officials from various federal agencies, will not have the power to propose new laws or regulations. Rather it will set broad policy goals and try to referee between conflicting commercial and recreational uses of the nation’s aquatic resources.

headline: Why Some Sugar-Free Products Raise Blood Sugar
text: In the latest “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores why some foods labeled “sugar free” may still raise blood sugar. The culprits are sugar alcohols that are sometimes paired with artificial sweeteners. He writes:

headline: Maitres du Temps| Time Keepers

headline: Defining a Successful Parent

text: A ventricular assist device is a mechanical pump that  improves a diseased heart’s pumping ability.

headline: New System To Help Gowanus Canal Breathe Easier
text: The semi-mysterious black pipes that appeared in the Gowanus Canal several months ago are now literally breathing life into the canal. The pipes are part of a new oxygenation system that as of Monday temporarily takes the place of the canal’s flushing tunnel, which has been pulled off line for a major overhaul.

headline: Private Jet Operators Link to Foreign Carriers
text: How does a private jet service woo customers in the middle of a recession? Go after the first-class airline passenger, of course. Two fractional jet ownership companies have announced agreements with foreign carriers that would let them pursue airlines’ premium customers.

headline: Fallout From the iPhone 4 Press Conference
text: “You are now entering the Steve Jobs Reality Distortion Field.” These were the words I heard from several journalists when I first started writing about Apple for Bits last year.

headline: NASA’s Messenger Spacecraft Discovers Surprises on Mercury
text: On its third swing past Mercury, NASA’s Mercury Messenger spacecraft discovered an unexpectedly young lava plain, rapid rufflings of the planet’s weak magnetic field and an unanticipated dance of elements in the thin atmosphere.

headline: Quote Unquote | Case Closed
text: –George Clooney’s style becomes part of his testimony in his Italian lawsuit. Imagine being falsely accused of wearing long jean shorts!

headline: Northrop Sees Private Equity Interest in Ship Unit
text: Northrop Grumman‘s chief executive, Wesley G. Bush, told Bloomberg News that private equity firms might be interested in acquiring the company’s shipbuilding unit, which the military contractor is considering selling or spinning off.

headline: Risks: Depression Linked to Later Dementia
text: A new study suggests that people with depression are significantly more likely to develop dementia later in life.

headline: Kovalchuk Re-Signs With Devils
text: Ilya Kovalchuk, the high-scoring forward who was the most coveted N.H.L. free agent this year, has re-signed with the Devils, the team announced on Monday. A news conference is tentatively scheduled for Tuesday at Prudential Center.

headline: Patterns: A Thin White Line Among Doctors?
text: One in three physicians say they do not believe they should always report an incompetent or significantly impaired colleague, a new study reports.

headline: Screening: Gaps Found in Breast Cancer Testing
text: One-fifth of American women ages 50 to 74 have fallen behind on mammography screenings for breast cancer, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are reporting.

headline: Virtual Tiger Woods Takes a Tumble
text: Electronic Arts, the video game maker, made a point in recent months of standing by Tiger Woods, even as other companies withdrew from sponsorships.

headline: A Doctor Discovers a Patient in the Mirror
text: The first thing I do is convince myself it isn’t a lump. Not difficult, as I’ve felt plenty of lumps, and mine does not fit the category. They are usually small, or soft and cystlike, or part of a general lumpy-bumpiness. This one, I tell myself, is nothing more than dense tissue.

headline: Tourmalet and Back Again
text: Riders will cross the Col du Tourmalet, the Tour de France’s most challenging mountain peak, from both sides in two consecutive stages. Explore the highest road in the central Pyrenées.

headline: Birds Chose Different Path to Manage Their Sexes
text: Some 300 million years ago, the living ancestor of humans was a reptile. Like turtles and alligators today, it let the temperature at which its eggs were incubated decide their sex.

headline: A Surfing Icon Embraces a Mellower Wave
text: BEND, Ore.  Four hours from the nearest surf, 4,000 feet above sea level and 4 decades removed from the days when he was known as Mr. Pipeline for deep and daring tube rides at one of the world’s most treacherous wave spots, Gerry Lopez shouldered a board beneath ponderosa pines on his way to the banks of the Deschutes River.

headline: A Record Number of Drugs Are Being Tested to Treat Mental Illness
text: There are a record 313 drugs under research and development to treat mental illness, the pharmaceutical manufacturers’ association says in a new report.

headline: Trailer: 'Family Guy' Season 8 DVD
text: The new "Family Guy" collection includes an episode that was not shown on television because its abortion-related subject matter was too controversial.

headline: Polio: Setbacks in a Mostly Successful Fight to Eliminate a Paralyzing Disease
text: The battle to eliminate polio, which has been more than 99 percent successful and has hovered on the verge of victory for a decade, has sustained new setbacks.

headline: Walking Coffins
text: Controversial French description of Muslim full-face veils.

headline: Not Starting Means Never Having to Quit
text: My husband’s fate was sealed at age 11, when he smoked his first cigarette. As he put it, “I got hooked that very day.” Although he tried repeatedly to quit, he rarely abstained from nicotine longer than a tortured week or two.

headline: E-Books Top Hardcovers at Amazon
text: Monday was a day for the history books  if those will even exist in the future.

headline: Financial Rules May Help Stabilize Some City Taxes
text: The financial regulations approved by Congress last week could hamper the ability of investment banks to make huge profits but should also reduce the big swings in the taxes the city collects from Wall Street, according to a new study from a private economist.

text: If hotel pools aren’t enough to cool you down, there’s a less crowded alternative for travelers to New York City: outdoor showers.

headline: A Two-Part Egg Mystery May Have One Answer
text: Every year, the female macaroni penguin lays two eggs. Peculiarly, the first is smaller than the second. Stranger still is that she kicks the first egg out of the nest before it hatches.

headline: Flowers, for Me? Yes. Now Stick ’Em Up.

headline: The Return of Coal
