headline: A Discovery Could Help Date Monkey-Ape Split
text: There are a few important differences between Old World monkeys and apes. Old World monkeys, like baboons and macaques, have tails and a great deal of agility, enabling them to jump and swing from tree branches.

headline: Yale Repertory Theater Receives $950,000 Gift
text: At a time when many artistic institutions have seen a drop in donations, Yale Repertory Theater announced on Monday that it had received a $950,000 gift from the Robina Foundation, a Minnesota-based nonprofit group. The gift will go toward supporting the Yale Center for New Theater, a program that Robina helped create in 2008 to promote the creation of new plays and musicals through residencies, readings, workshops and productions. James Bundy, the Rep’s artistic director, said in a statement that the grant would mean that new work can “reach a wider audience.” “Those activities will have a direct impact on the training of professionals in training at the School of Drama and on the field at large,” he added.

headline: Adventures in Very Recent Evolution
text: Ten thousand years ago, people in southern China began to cultivate rice and quickly made an all-too-tempting discovery  the cereal could be fermented into alcoholic liquors. Carousing and drunkenness must have started to pose a serious threat to survival because a variant gene that protects against alcohol became almost universal among southern Chinese and spread throughout the rest of China in the wake of rice cultivation.

headline: Cognac's Little-Known Relative
text: One family is largely responsible for introducing rustic, earthy Armagnac to the world outside Gascony.

headline: I.B.M. Moves to Concentrate Power at Top
text: I.B.M. is reshuffling its top management one level below the chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, giving greater responsibility to four senior executives.

headline: California Blacks Split Over Marijuana Measure
text: SACRAMENTO  Ron Allen says he knows all too well the ravages of drug addiction.

headline: On Our Radar: China’s Environmental Woes
text: China’s gold mining industry faces regulatory scrutiny after its worst disaster in years: the accidental release of 2.4 million gallons of acid-laced waste into the Ting River.

headline: Education Panel Delays Vote to Weaken Its Own Authority
text: Updated, 6:00 p.m. | The Panel for Educational Policy, the successor to the old Board of Education, is controlled by appointees of the mayor, so it summarily approves just about everything that comes before it. But has the city quietly been trying to make a near-toothless panel even less relevant?

headline: Tracking the Evolution of Malaria
text: Malaria is an ancient and persistent disease. It wasn’t eradicated in the United States until the 1950s, and it is still devastating in developing countries around the world. The latest estimate from the World Health Organization is that in 2008 the disease killed more than a million people and afflicted 247 million others.

headline: Book Shelf | Deluxe Comics
text: The comic book industry may rightly be concerned with what the digital revolution will mean for business, but two lavish new editions show that printed matter is not going down without a fight.

headline: Female Afghan Governor Fears Taliban Deal
text: On the eve of an international conference in Afghanistan, the country’s only female governor told Britain’s Channel 4 News that Afghan women should not have to sacrifice their rights as part of any peace agreement with the Taliban.

headline: Analysts Think Bank of America Is Too Pessimistic
text: 5:16 p.m. | Updated Did Bank of America sell its prospects short on Friday when it said new banking regulations would cost the bank billions of dollars in future revenue? Some analysts believe the bank was overly critical and pessimistic when it came to describing the effect of the new regulations.

headline: Medical Groups Criticize Insurers on Rating Doctors
text: Updated: As insurers try to steer more patients to doctors deemed less expensive and/or judged to provide better care, the companies are coming under increasing criticism from physicians and medical organizations questioning the accuracy of these evaluations.

headline: Taking Lessons From What Went Wrong
text: Disasters teach more than successes.

headline: The Tax Man Cometh: H&R Block May Get Bid
text: A former employee of H&R Block who once tried to convince the nation’s largest tax company that the future was in computerized preparation now has his sights on taking over at his old firm, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Musical Spells Cast in Theatrical Margins
text: Few terms in the realms of musical composition and theater are as imprecise, let alone patronizing, as incidental music. The phrase has long been applied to music that provides atmosphere, accompanies an action or enhances the mood or moment in a play. The word incidental suggests that such music should call no attention to itself.

headline: Attention Disorders Can Take a Toll on Marriage
text: Does your husband or wife constantly forget chores and lose track of the calendar? Do you sometimes feel that instead of living with a spouse, you’re raising another child?

headline: An Actor Caught in the Act of Acting Aggrieved
text: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.  Is an actor ever truly offstage? Ferenc Molnar’s comedy “The Guardsman” turns on the notion that the question is essentially rhetorical. The husband and wife who earn their living before the footlights in this backstage romance are striking poses and reaching for effects even when their only audience is a hand mirror.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Contempt'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Jean-Luc Godard's avant-garde film.

headline: Palin Backs ‘Granite Grizzly’
text: Say hello to the newest “Mama Grizzly.”

headline: Readers Respond to a Need for Wheel Etiquette
text: New York’s sidewalks are crowded enough with pedestrians, but when riders on scooters, skateboards and in-line skates are added to the strips of concrete that flank the city’s streets, run-ins are inevitable. It takes a swift foot to guide those wheels between other feet and knees. But parents and older citizens who wobble their way on these modes of transportation should be taken off the sidewalk, according to Niels Aaboe, who wrote this weekend’s Complaint Box in the Metropolitan section.

headline: Seamus Mullen Has Left Boqueria
text: Seamus Mullen, the chef who has been in partnership with Yann de Rochefort at the Boqueria restaurants in the Flatiron District since 2006, and in SoHo since 2008, has left.

headline: No More Flattery From Scaasi
text: AFTER 55 years in the dress business, Arnold Scaasi announced on Monday that he is hanging up his shears and closing his made-to-order dress business. Never mind that Mr. Scaasi has long been removed from the heavy action of Fashion Week, or that he is perhaps more broadly known today for selling costume jewelry on HSN and for criticizing Michelle Obama’s style. From his perch at 16 East 52nd Street, the designer (who dressed five first ladies during his career) had continued making custom gowns, about 20 each month.

headline: The Washington Post Aims High on Monday
text: It took two years to prepare and includes a 5,400-word article and multiple interactive databases.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: The work of Bob Strong of Reuters, whose photograph at Combat Outpost Nolen leads Monday’s report, has appeared twice this month in Pictures of the Day; on July 8 (Slide 2) and July 9 (Slide 4). Reuters also compiled his work in 2009 in “All Quiet on the Afghan Eastern Front.”

headline: Banned TV Episode Has Its Day on DVD
text: In many ways, the “Family Guy” episode “Partial Terms of Endearment” is typical of that audacious Fox animated comedy, teeming with rapid-fire jokes and willfully offensive non sequiturs about disabled animals, God, Nazis, bodily functions and the sexual habits of “Sesame Street” characters.

headline: How ‘Family Guy’ Tried to Talk About Abortion
text: Offending delicate sensibilities is not exactly a challenge for the creative team at “Family Guy,” the animated Fox comedy that has broadcast episodes about the legalization of marijuana and the existence (or non-existence) of God, and a show about Down syndrome that drew it into an unintended conflict with Sarah Palin.

headline: Palin Biography for Teens Is Postponed ‘Indefinitely’
text: A biography of Sarah Palin for young readers that was scheduled for a fall publication has been postponed. Zondervan, a Christian publisher that is part of HarperCollins, told The Associated Press that October is not “an optimal time” for the book to come out. A new publication date was not announced. The book, “Speaking Up,” by Kim Washburn, is part of a series of biographies for teens. Ms. Washburn told The A.P. that she had been informed that the book was on hold “indefinitely” and that she was surprised by the decision.

headline: High Line Founders To Get Jane Jacobs Medal
text: This year’s Jane Jacobs Medals, awarded since 2007 by the Rockefeller Foundation to individuals whose work “creates new ways of seeing and understanding New York City,” will go to Joshua David and Robert Hammond, the founders of Friends of the High Line, and Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, a founder of the Central Park Conservancy, the Rockefeller Foundation is to announce on Tuesday. Mr. David and Mr. Hammond will each receive $60,000, of which each will donate $20,000 to Friends of the High Line, which maintains the High Line park jointly with the city. Ms. Rogers will receive $80,000 and will donate the full amount to the Foundation for Landscape Studies, an organization she founded in 2006.

headline: Horror Studio Revives, Grabs Daniel Radcliffe
text: Which one of these facts is more exciting: That Daniel Radcliffe, below, has committed to making a horror movie for the venerable British horror studio Hammer Films? Or that Hammer Films, the home of gory, goopy, Gothic fright films like “Frankenstein and the Monster From Hell,” “Dracula Has Risen From the Grave” and “The Quatermass Xperiment” (better known on American shores as “The Creeping Unknown”) is back in bloodthirsty business? Press representatives for the studio said on Monday that Mr. Radcliffe, the “Harry Potter” star who is soon to be unencumbered of those boy-wizard movies, will play the lead in an adaptation of Susan Hill’s horror novel “The Woman in Black,” to be written by Jane Goldman (“Kick-Ass”) and directed by James Watkins (“Eden Lake”). The studio also said that Hammer Films, which helped the careers of Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing, is slowly reviving after lying dormant since the 1980s. Now owned by the Exclusive Media Group, the Hammer brand will appear on “The Resident,” a coming horror movie starring Hilary Swank, and “Let Me In,” a remake of the Swedish vampire film “Let the Right One In,” directed by Matt Reeves (“Cloverfield”).

headline: Historian and Wife to Pay for Mean Online Reviews
text: A British historian will pay damages to rivals who said he defamed them in pseudonymous comments on the amazon.co.uk Web site. In the spring British literary circles were abuzz over a mysterious Amazon commenter who used the handle Historian to trash works by authors like Rachel Polonsky (“dense,” “pretentious”) and Robert Service (“rubbish,” “an awful book”) while lauding Orlando Figes, an author and history professor at Birkbeck College in London, whose book “The Whisperers” was called a “beautiful and necessary” account of Soviet history. Mr. Figes initially said that Historian was his wife, Stephanie Palmer, a lawyer and lecturer at Cambridge University. A few days later Mr. Figes said he had written the reviews and that he had pointed the finger at Ms. Palmer “without thinking this through rationally.” The Guardian has since reported that Mr. Figes and Ms. Palmer will pay unspecified damages and legal costs to the authors and have promised not to post any more reviews of their works.

headline: Need a Mortgage? Don’t Get Pregnant
text: Expectant parents shopping for a home are not the only ones concerned about the date of the baby’s arrival.

headline: The Play on Madoff, Without Wiesel
text: HUDSON, N.Y.  Two months after Elie Wiesel used legal threats to shut down a play that imagined his relationship with his former money manager, Bernard L. Madoff, that work  revised, with a new character replacing Mr. Wiesel  will have its first performances this week. The playwright, Deborah Margolin, is also trying to move forward, yet remains deeply shaken by her clash with Mr. Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and Holocaust survivor.

headline: New Umberto Eco Novel
text: Umberto Eco, below, is coming out with a new novel in the fall of 2012, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt announced on Monday. The novel, titled “The Prague Cemetery,” is the story of a secret agent who “weaves plots, conspiracies, intrigues and attacks, and helps determine the historical and political fate of the Continent,” his publisher said. Mr. Eco, 78, is widely known for his philosophical writings and his fiction, especially “The Name of the Rose.” His most recent novel, “The Mysterious Flame of Queen Loana,” was published in 2005.

headline: A Free Man, Polanski Is Seen at Montreux Festival
text: Roman Polanski returned to public life beyond his house arrest over the weekend, days after the Swiss authorities said they were declining a request by the United States to extradite the filmmaker to face sentencing on a 33-year-old sex charge. Reuters reported that Mr. Polanski, left, with his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner, was seen on Saturday night at the conclusion of the Montreux Jazz Festival, where Ms. Seigner performed. Mr. Polanski, 76, also gave a television interview to the Swiss station TSR in which he thanked the people of Gstaad, where he had been under house arrest in his chalet since December. “I’m not sure what I will do hereafter,” Mr. Polanski said, according to Reuters. “For the moment I’m happy to be free.” Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was set free last Monday after the Swiss justice ministry said the United States had failed to provide the records of a January hearing in Los Angeles County Superior Court that could have shown that Mr. Polanski had already served his sentence.

headline: Asked & Answered | Tamra Davis
text: More than 20 years since his death from a heroin overdose, Jean-Michel Basquiat remains a central character in the downtown New York scene. The prolific artist left behind some 1,000 paintings and as many drawings — an extraordinary output for any artist, let alone a 27-year-old — many of which are now considered masterpieces. But in his wake, the reticent Basquiat also launched a mini-industry covering his life.

headline: Yale Repertory Theater Receives $950,000 Gift
text: At a time when many artistic institutions have seen a drop in donations, Yale Repertory Theater announced on Monday that it had received a $950,000 gift from the Robina Foundation, a Minnesota-based nonprofit group. The gift will go toward supporting the Yale Center for New Theater, a program that Robina helped create in 2008 to promote the creation of new plays and musicals through residencies, readings, workshops and productions. James Bundy, the Rep’s artistic director, said in a statement that the grant would mean that new work can “reach a wider audience.” “Those activities will have a direct impact on the training of professionals in training at the School of Drama and on the field at large,” he added.

headline: The Anatomy of a Citywide Traffic Jam
text: In a 2003 television advertisement being shown in a loop with other commercials at the exhibition “Cars, Culture, and the City,” a black Lamborghini curls through the streets of New York, inspiring fantasies in anyone lucky enough to gaze at its sleek body and slick maneuvers.

headline: Vogue Ad Pages Rise 24 Percent for September
text: The September fashion magazines — the magazine world’s most glamorous economic barometer — are looking healthier this year after a grim 2009.

headline: How a New Baby Could Hurt Your Mortgage Approval
text: It’s a typical life event: a couple learns they are expecting a baby, so they begin shopping for a larger home.

headline: It’s a Canadian Summer for U.S. Television
text: American fans of scripted network television this summer can thank Canada.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Contempt’
text: This week, A. O. Scott finds Jean-Luc Godard’s 1963 film “Contempt” irresistible. The movie, he says, is about two things: “the romance and futility of cinema and the romance and futility of love.” Yet Mr. Scott is unsure the director would distinguish between the two, saying “his passion for his chosen art form is as volatile and intense as any great love affair.” Have you seen Mr. Godard’s film? Please share your thoughts on the film and where it ranks in the director’s filmography.

headline: Mayor Says $500 Million Can Be Saved Yet Not Harm Services
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a plan Monday to consolidate and modernize portions of New York City’s government that he said would save taxpayers $500 million over the next four years and $500 million more each year after, all without cutting services.

headline: How to Catch a Bird: Make Your Own Trap
text: We’ve worked out an effective routine over the past few days. We spend our mornings at the women’s cooperative trying to catch the two species of starlings when they are most active there, and then the afternoons at the mission trying to catch the two species of sparrows and the one species of bulbul. The wind is too strong in the morning for nets, so we rely only on traps. They are proving somewhat effective, at least when the birds are on the ground. Unfortunately, they rarely seem to come to the ground. This behavior has surprised us a lot, but there is not much we can do other than be patient.

headline: ‘Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg: The Letters’
text: Jack Kerouac [New York, NY] to Allen Ginsberg [Paterson, NJ] January 13, 1950

headline: Pen Pals: Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and the Literary World They Made
text: In one of Allen Ginsberg’s more crazily virtuosic letters to his sometime soul mate, Jack Kerouac, Ginsberg included an apology of sorts. “I was too intent on self-fulfillment, and rather crude about it, with all my harlequinade and conscious manipulation of your pity,” he wrote. He also looked back on his life as an artist and described it witheringly: “Art has been for me, when I did not deceive myself, a meager compensation for what I desire.” And he acknowledged being worn, enervated and world-weary. “I am sick of this damned life!” he complained.

headline: Ponomariov Retakes Lead in Dortmund
text: All the games were decisive on Monday at the Sparkassen Chess-Meeting tournament, but the most important in terms of the standings was the win by Ruslan Ponomariov over Shakhriyar Mamedyarov.

headline: 5 Apples. 60 Seconds. Go.
text: Typically when television creators want to gather ideas, they huddle in a writers’ room or maybe head out to a long expense-account lunch. When the creators of “Minute to Win It” need inspiration, they head to Target or a hardware store.

headline: ‘Damages’ to Live Again, on DirecTV
text: DirecTV, which contributed to saving the much-acclaimed drama “Friday Night Lights,” will now keep alive another much-honored but low-rated series: “Damages,” which will move from FX to the satellite company for two more seasons starting next year.

headline: Federal Court Grants Bail to Conrad Black
text: Conrad M. Black, the jailed former newspaper magnate, was granted bail by a federal appeals court on Monday, weeks after the Supreme Court sent his 2007 conviction for back to a lower court, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Mad Men City | Then and Now
text: WARNING: The following post reveals the period of time covered in the upcoming Season 4 premiere of “Mad Men.” It does not contain any further spoilers.

headline: Loona Bimbertons Of The World, Unite!
text: Henry Farrell explains it all. One of his commenters says that the US term for what Henry calls Bimberton-kicking is “hippie-punching”, which is about right; although when it comes to politics the proper term is DFH.

headline: Goldman Employee Denies Fraud
text: Days after Goldman Sachs agreed to pay $550 million to settle securities fraud claims, a midlevel employee of the bank filed a 13-page reply denying the charges and sought dismissal of the case.

headline: As a Blunt General Moves Out, Another Moves Up
text: Poorly chosen words sunk Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal as head of the Afghan mission. He was replaced by his more judicious boss, Gen. David H. Petraeus. The man chosen to replace General Petraeus, Marine Gen. James N. Mattis, described as a warrior’s warrior, is also known for his own brand of blunt talk.

headline: No Discipline for Cuzzi Over Latest Missed Call
text: Baseball officials have decided not to discipline the umpire Phil Cuzzi, who missed a call at home plate and angered members of both teams Sunday in the Mets’ 4-3 win over the Giants in San Francisco.

headline: Contador Apologizes on YouTube
text: Within the past hour, Alberto Contador, the Spanish cyclist who took over the lead in this year’s Tour de France on Monday in controversial circumstances, posted an apology to his main rival, Andy Schleck, on YouTube.

headline: Bad Heir Day
text: There’s a fair bit of commentary out there about how absurd it is that estate taxes, having gone to zero this year, will spring back next year. Much of the commentary makes it sound as if this is news, or reflects a dysfunctional Congress, or those darn liberals doing their liberal thing, or something like that.

headline: Fabrice Tourre Denies S.E.C.’s Fraud Charges
text: Days after Goldman Sachs agreed to pay $550 million to settle securities fraud claims, Fabrice P. Tourre, a midlevel employee of the bank, filed a 13-page reply categorically denying the charges against him and sought dismissal of the case, Louise Story of The New York Times reports.

headline: Jenkins Considers Retiring, but Ryan Pulls Him Back In
text: This off-season, as Kris Jenkins attempted to return from his second major knee operation, he also conducted an experiment. He told himself, “I’m retiring this year,” and he said he repeated that notion until he believed it.

headline: Water Levels Near Record at Three Gorges Dam in China
text: BEIJING  Surging waters in the Yangtze River tested the strength of the Three Gorges Dam early Tuesday, as some of the fastest flowing floodwaters in more than a decade slammed against the world’s largest hydroelectric project, according to official Chinese news reports.

headline: Annoyances Mount Over the Body Scanner
text: YOU may think of this as the summer of the heat wave. I prefer to think of it as the summer of the body scanner.

headline: Russians and Their Crops Wilt Under Heat Wave
text: MOSCOW  A blistering heat wave has made life miserable for millions in Russia and northeastern Europe, few of whom have air conditioners, and destroyed millions of acres of Russian wheat, setting back an agricultural revival that was just reaching its stride after years of faltering efforts.

headline: Aeroflot Is Pressed to Buy Russian
text: MOSCOW  Aeroflot, the national airline of the Soviet Union, and now Russia, has defied stereotypes, transforming itself into a stylish choice for European business travelers by retraining staff members and importing airplanes.

headline: Troops to Go to Mexican Border Aug. 1
text: Hundreds of National Guard troops will begin deployment to the United States-Mexico border on Aug. 1, part of the Obama administration’s effort to increase security and stem the flow of weapons, cash and people into the United States, the administration announced Monday.

headline: Fox’s McCarver Backtracks, but Not Very Far
text: Tim McCarver backtracked Monday from the comparison he made Saturday between the Yankees’ treatment of Joe Torre’s legacy as manager to the way World War II despots, “primarily in Russia and Germany,” airbrushed former generals out of photographs “after they had shot ’em.”

headline: Traded by Knicks, Lee Was Still a Team Player
text: When Marni Jaffer was about to deliver her husband’s eulogy to a crowd of 300-plus mourners, she noticed a familiar face rising above the others in the back of the funeral chapel. She had never met the man, but she recognized him from her television screen.

headline: Citing Weak Banks, Moody’s Downgrades Ireland’s Debt
text: Ireland’s efforts to pull out of a deep economic slump suffered a setback on Monday after a major firm downgraded the country’s bond rating, citing a weak banking system and rising debt.

text: GULF SHORES, Ala.  Nick Wilmott bent down on the beach near the high-tide mark and touched one of the reddish-brown pads of oil. It had washed up overnight from the BP spill off Louisiana and had yet to be cleaned up by the machines that sweep the beaches here every night.

headline: Devils Keep Kovalchuk, but Deal Will Cost Them Some Veterans
text: Ilya Kovalchuk, the potent wing who was the N.H.L.’s most-coveted free agent this off-season, decided Monday to re-sign with the Devils. A news conference is scheduled for Tuesday afternoon at Prudential Center in Newark, the team said.

headline: As Cameron and Obama Meet, BP Will Be Top Issue
text: LONDON  On the eve of a White House meeting with President Obama, Prime Minister David Cameron on Monday stepped into the furor over BP’s lobbying for a prisoner-transfer agreement between Britain and Libya by saying he considered the release of the convicted Lockerbie bomber from a Scottish prison last year to be “completely and utterly wrong.”

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: In Los Angeles, Unsolved Killings Reflected Era
text: LOS ANGELES  It was the most painful sort of ordinary.

headline: New Potential for A.I.G. Deals
text: The American International Group boss, Robert H. Benmosche, may have unlocked two deals by chopping his chief executive in Asia. One is the flotation of the American International Assurance division in Hong Kong, which should now proceed after a false start. The other is an eventual merger of A.I.A. and the Asian portion of its big rival — and recent failed suitor — the British Prudential.

headline: For Henry, Rivalry Endures Change in Uniform
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Once an Arsenal man, always an Arsenal man. Just askThierry Henry.

headline: Afghan Plan on Transfer of Security Gets Support
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United States and European nations attending an international conference here on Tuesday are expected to endorse President Hamid Karzai’s plan for Afghan forces to take the lead on security throughout the country by 2014, according to Western officials and diplomats.

headline: ESPN Gives Its Magazine a Tighter Embrace
text: SINCE its first issue in 1998, ESPN The Magazine has played dual roles  part brand extension and part independent publication.

headline: Deals at Air Show Bode Well for Recovery
text: FARNBOROUGH, England — In the best evidence yet of a strengthening recovery in the commercial aviation sector, the world’s two largest makers of aircraft on Monday announced more than $24 billion worth of orders. Much of that came from leasing companies eager to help airlines bolster capacity as global air traffic recovered.

headline: Boy, 15, Is Killed in One of Several Overnight Shootings in Brooklyn
text: A 15-year-old boy was shot and killed early Monday in Brooklyn, according to the police, who found him lying mortally wounded outside a church.

headline: Pathology of Errors
text: As pathologists help doctors diagnose breast cancer at an earlier, more survivable stage, the potential for mistakes has grown.

headline: Three Arrows, a Co-op That Loves Its Committees
text: Hi, Jen and David  it’s your Realtor, Sasha, calling. I don’t want to clog your voice mail, but I just found a summer property at Three Arrows that I absolutely think you should see. Actually, it’s not a property. Don’t call it a property. They hate the word “property.” They call it a site, and what you really buy is the house on it. The land itself is owned by Three Arrows. It’s a co-op, like in the city, only it’s in Putnam Valley, N.Y., up past Peekskill.

headline: Ways to Help States Recover
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pinning Hope on August for Relief From July
text: Why don’t we just write off July? No need to waste another second on it. It’s dead to us. Let’s think instead about August.

headline: Business News Outlet Rises to Focus on China, in English
text: HONG KONG — Many news organizations around the world have been cutting back on staff, resources and coverage. But a new media outfit backed by one of Hong Kong’s most prominent businessmen is bucking that trend.

headline: Average, or Even Median, Is a Lot of Money
text: Geoff Lynch, 40, and his bride, Carmela Rea, 38, don’t consider themselves average. Nor does Ali Yenal, 38, think of himself that way. Maybe they aren’t. But their apartments are.

Accountability for Wasted Projects in Iraq

headline: Stricter Rules Likely to Make Fewer Eligible for City Rent Subsidies
text: Nadeah Rasheed got an offer in 2008 that she could not refuse: find a stable job and the city would pay virtually all her rent. If everything went as planned, she and her two daughters would leave homelessness behind forever.

headline: Who Lives in This Room?
text: What exactly is a living room? Is it a formal room for special occasions, or a casual space for everyday life? The meaning has been unclear ever since the late 17th century, when architects first considered what “living” in the home meant.

headline: Being Neutral Is Oh So Hard to Do
text: In the opening paragraph of his dissent in Christian Legal Society v. Martinez (June 28, 2010) Justice Samuel Alito names the principle he finds animating the majority opinion: “no freedom for expression that offends prevailing standards of political correctness in our country’s institutions of higher learning.” I have come to think he is right.

headline: Prone to Error: Earliest Steps to Find Cancer
text: Monica Long had expected a routine appointment. But here she was sitting in her new oncologist’s office, and he was delivering deeply disturbing news.

headline: State’s Exams Became Easier to Pass, Education Officials Say
text: New York State education officials acknowledged on Monday that their standardized exams had become easier to pass over the last four years and said they would recalibrate the scoring for tests taken this spring, which is almost certain to mean thousands more students will fail.

headline: McCarver Backtracks From Comment but Not From His Opinion
text: Tim McCarver backtracked Monday from the comparison he made Saturday between the Yankees’ treatment of Joe Torre’s legacy as manager to the way World War II despots, “primarily in Russia and Germany,” airbrushed former generals out of photographs “after they had shot ’em.”

headline: Doubt About Pathology Opinions for Early Breast Cancer
text: Advances in imaging technology mean that more and more breast cancers are being detected at the earliest stages — sometimes when the rogue cells are as tiny as a few grains of salt. But now there are new questions about whether many pathologists are able to render reliable opinions on such tiny lesions, according to an extensive New York Times examination of breast cancer cases.

headline: Reclaimed Jewel Whose Attraction Can Be Perilous
text: It is New York City’s only freshwater river, a gurgling, meandering relic of the pastoral terrain that almost 400 years ago beguiled early European explorers and traders.

headline: Sling Is Focus as Prosecutor in Crane Fall Wraps Case
text: After four weeks of technical testimony about a deadly crane collapse, a prosecutor tried Monday to focus a judge’s attention on the piece of evidence that has been the center of the prosecution’s case since the former Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, held it as he announced the indictment last year: a sling.

headline: Is a Slump a Reason for Concern? Not to Jeter
text: When Derek Jeter heard the word “slump,” he reacted as if he had heard a curse word in church. His face showed distaste; his tone was professional but dismissive.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the annual Broadway in Bryant Park series featuring performers from Broadway and Off Broadway productions misidentified the shows from which cast members will be performing this Thursday at 12:30 p.m. They are “Chicago,” “A Little Night Music,” “Falling for Eve” and “Rock of Ages.” Cast members from the shows listed in the report  “The Phantom of the Opera,” “Billy Elliot,” “Memphis,” “South Pacific” and “The Radio City Christmas Spectacular”  performed last week.

headline: Corrections
text: THE ARTS

headline: International Players Keep Rising to the Top in Major Tournaments
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The results of the last two major golf championships  a resounding seven-stroke victory by Louis Oosthuizen of South Africa at the British Open on Sunday and the United States Open win by Graeme McDowell of Northern Ireland a month earlier at Pebble Beach  have had an effect well beyond the borders of their countries.

headline: The Republicans and the Constitution
text: Listen carefully as the votes on Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court are taken beginning this week. Most court nominations are about judicial philosophy or social issues, but Ms. Kagan’s has become a flashpoint for a much larger debate about the fundamental role of American government.

headline: Iraq’s Conflict, Reflected in a Family Tragedy
text: SAMARRA, Iraq  When the Americans arrived, Hamid Ahmad, a former air force warrant officer imprisoned under Saddam Hussein, imagined a new life for his family, freed from the burdens of tyranny. In seven hard years, nothing went as planned.

headline: Far From Bronx and Bombast, a Bucolic Setting
text: TRINITY, Fla.  It is, in short, peaceful and unremarkable. George Steinbrenner’s final resting place, an unmarked, salt-and-pepper marble mausoleum, sits just inside the gates of the 60-acre Trinity Memorial Gardens cemetery. Deer roam nearby and dragonflies flit. A long tree line buffers the cemetery from a new school and some budding subdivisions.

headline: Conserving a Conservation Fund
text: In 1964, Congress approved a quiet little environmental program to provide a steady revenue stream to save America’s disappearing open spaces from development. Conceived under Dwight Eisenhower, proposed by John F. Kennedy and signed into law by Lyndon Johnson, the Land and Water Conservation Fund would be underwritten by royalties from offshore oil and gas leases. This gave it a fitting symmetry: dollars raised from depleting one natural resource would protect another.

headline: Associated Name
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I know you’re all excited about the word GYP, but let’s start by looking at the theme entries.

headline: A City Outsources Everything. Sky Doesn’t Fall.
text: MAYWOOD, Calif.  Not once, not twice, but three times in the last two weeks, Andrew Quezada says, he was stopped and questioned by the authorities here.

headline: Art in Moscow, Still Forbidden
text: The decision by a Moscow court to fine the organizers of an art exhibition, “Forbidden Art  2006,” is a reminder about the continued limits on freedom of expression in Russia.

headline: Petraeus’s Successor Is Known for Impolitic Words
text: WASHINGTON — To those who have served under him, Gen. James N. Mattis is the consummate Marine commander, a warrior who chooses to lead from the front lines and speaks bluntly rather than concerning himself with political correctness.

headline: A Universe of Us
text: We think of ourselves as individuals  perhaps, in philosophical moments, as the merger of body and soul. Most of us are barely aware of the estimated 10 trillion individual cells that make up the human body or of the 100 trillion or more bacteria that live collaboratively and benignly within and upon us. Whatever else we are, we are also a complex ecosystem, a habitat.

headline: Better Late Than Never, the Mets Have the Lineup They Pictured
text: PHOENIX  For the first time in almost 14 months, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel put a combination of names together in a lineup Monday night that was, more or less, the way it was supposed to have looked on opening day.

headline: It’s Official: Special Election for Byrd’s Seat
text: West Virginia lawmakers have passed legislation that will allow the state to hold a special election this year to fill the Senate seat long held by the late Robert C. Byrd.

headline: Europe Considers New Penalties for Iran
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union is considering tough new sanctions against Iran to protest its nuclear program, including banning investment in the oil and gas sector and tightening restrictions on shipping and finance.

headline: Photo Replay: July 19
text: A view of the day in sports, from the mountains of France to a pool in Puerto Rico.

headline: A Gay Campaign? Both Sides Demur
text: OKLAHOMA CITY  One of the more unlikely showdowns for the fall elections is taking shape here in this staunchly conservative state, where same-sex marriage is constitutionally banned and the Legislature frequently takes on issues like abortion.

headline: Looking for Time Bombs and Tea Leaves on Gay Marriage

headline: Obama Resubmits Nomination
text: President Obama still wants the Senate to confirm Donald Berwick as administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and he resubmitted his nomination to the Senate on Monday. The president put Mr. Berwick in the job July 7 using a recess appointment, a procedure that lets the president fill positions without confirmation when Congress is not in session. Resubmitting the nomination is “simply a formality,” said Reid Cherlin, an administration spokesman.

headline: The Technocracy Boom
text: When historians look back on the period between 2001 and 2011, they will be amazed that a nation that professed to hate bureaucracy produced so much of it.

headline: We’re Not Ready
text: We were told by oil industry executives and their acolytes and enablers in government that deep-water drilling in the Gulf of Mexico would not cause the kind of catastrophe that we’ve been watching with an acute and painful sense of helplessness for the past three months. Advances in technology, they said, would ward off the worst-case scenarios. Fail-safe systems like the blowout preventer a mile below the surface at the Deepwater Horizon rig site would keep wildlife and the environment safe.

headline: Liability at Issue in Oil Flow Rate in Gulf
text: When BP suggested over the weekend that it might leave the Gulf of Mexico well capped until it completed the relief wells, Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, suggested that the company might have an ulterior motive  to limit its own spiraling legal liability.

text: Unusual Step Recalled With Blowout Preventer

headline: Krush Is U.S. Women’s Chess Champion; Playoff Will Decide U.S. Junior
text: Irina Krush won the United States Women’s Championship on Monday, but the U.S. Junior title will have to be decided in a three-way playoff Tuesday between Ray Robson, Samuel Shankland and Parker Zhao.

headline: Abuse Allegations Reported in Peacekeeping Missions
text: There have been 45 allegations of sexual exploitation and abuse against personnel in United Nations peacekeeping and special political missions worldwide this year, with 18 involving minors, according to United Nations statistics. Most cases remain under investigation.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Upside of Segregation
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Richard Thompson Ford of Stanford Law School debate the possible benefits of a segregated school.

headline: Finding Community in the Shadows
text: For three years, Andrea Star Reese, a former filmmaker, has been photographing homeless people living in West Harlem. Her first project, “The Urban Cave,” will be exhibited at Visa pour l’Image, the international festival of photojournalism held in Perpignan, France, beginning Aug. 28. James Estrin met with Ms. Reese, 58, in New York, where she lives. Their conversation has been edited and condensed for space.

headline: Small Businesses Go After Offshore Tax Havens
text: Offshore tax havens have a new critic: small businesses.

headline: Son Is Held After Father Is Found Slain
text: A man in his 70s was found stabbed to death in an apartment on the Upper West Side on Monday night, and the police took his son into custody.

headline: Stephen H. Schneider, Climatologist, Is Dead at 65
text: Stephen H. Schneider, an influential climatologist who used the results of complex scientific models he developed to become a leader in pressing for action to address global warming, died Monday in London. He was 65.

headline: James Gammon, Character Actor, Dies at 70
text: James Gammon, a squint-eyed, froggy-voiced character actor who was best known as the manager in the baseball film comedy “Major League,” one of the rough-hewn American types — cowboys, rednecks and the alcoholic family patriarchs in the plays of Sam Shepard — that were his specialty, died Friday at his home in Costa Mesa, Calif. He was 70.

headline: Denise Jefferson, 65, Director of the Ailey School, Is Dead
text: Denise Jefferson, an internationally known dance educator who as the longtime director of the Ailey School oversaw the training of generations of world-class performers, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 65 and a Manhattan resident.

headline: News Quiz | July 20, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Appearing After Goldman Deal
text: The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission is appearing before Congress days after the passage of sweeping financial regulation that gives the agency new powers and a landmark settlement of civil fraud charges with Goldman Sachs, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Why Should Hefner Have All the Fun?
text: Hugh Hefner, the octogenarian owner of Playboy Enterprises, is looking to take the company private by making a bid to acquire all the stock of the company he doesn’t already own.

headline: S.E.C. May Add 800 New Positions as Part of Overhaul
text: The top United States securities regulator will need to add about 800 new positions to carry out its part of the massive financial overhaul legislation, the head of the agency said in testimony to be delivered on Tuesday, Reuters said.

headline: Swiss Court Backs Transfer of UBS Client Data to U.S.
text: A court in Switzerland has cleared the way for the transfer to Washington of bank data about a UBS client, following the Swiss Parliament’s approval of a key tax deal, Reuters reported.

headline: Motorola’s Path to Breakup
text: Motorola is getting closer to splitting itself up, with the announcement of a deal to sell its Networks division to Nokia Siemens Networks. Next year, the remainder of Motorola is splitting into two companies.

headline: Draft Communiqué Sets 2014 as Target for Afghan Military to Lead
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  More than 40 foreign ministers and international leaders gathered in Kabul on Tuesday to show their support for Afghanistan and to chart the course for the country to take responsibility for security, improve its governance and reduce corruption over the next five years.

headline: Leaders Renew Vows of Support for Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  American, European and other foreign leaders met here Tuesday to pledge anew their support for Afghanistan, agree to entrust it with more spending decisions, and embrace its president’s commitment for Afghan forces to take charge of security by 2014. They acknowledged that neither the public in their own countries nor the Afghan people had much patience left.

headline: Closed, for Now
text: WHO is the U.S. government’s top official in the Gulf response effort?

headline: Tucker Said to Tell A.I.G. Staff He’ll Triple A.I.A. Value
text: Mark Tucker, who was named head of American International Group‘s main Asia division, told staff that he planned to triple the unit’s value to $100 billion, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of his remarks.

headline: I.B.M. Moves to Concentrate Power at Top
text: I.B.M. is reshuffling its top management one level below the chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, giving greater responsibility to four senior executives.

headline: E.C.B. Winds Down Bond Purchases
text: The European Central Bank’s intervention in bond markets has come nearly to a standstill, bank data indicated Monday, in a sign that policy makers no longer see an urgent need to continue supporting debt issued by Greece, Spain and other European countries, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reported.

headline: Interactive Data 2Q Earnings Hit by Buyout Costs
text: The Interactive Data Corporation said Monday that its second-quarter earnings fell 24 percent, largely because of an uptick in expenses related to its pending takeover by private equity firms, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Investors Back China News Outlet
text: Many news organizations around the world have been cutting back on staff, resources and coverage. But a new media outfit backed by one of Hong Kong’s most prominent businessmen is bucking that trend, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Toll Brothers to Invest in Distressed Real Estate
text: Toll Brothers, the luxury home builder, said Monday that it planned to begin an investment fund to buy up distressed real estate assets, including loan portfolios and land for development.

headline: Exxon Offers to Buy $2.7 Billion in XTO Debt
text: Exxon Mobil on Monday said it was offering to buy up to $2.7 billion in outstanding debt securities issued by its new subsidiary, XTO Energy, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Strong Q2 for Asset Managers?
text: American asset managers are expected to post strong quarterly results compared with last year’s dismal showings, but still face challenges from erratic stock markets that have encouraged many retail investors to focus on less risky products, Reuters reported.

headline: Tata Steel Said to Be in Talks Over Refinancing Loans
text: India’s Tata Steel has started talks with lenders, including Citigroup, to refinance as much as £3.5 billion ($5.4 billion) in loans for its British unit, Bloomberg News reported, citing sources with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Einhorn Stocks Up on Apple
text: David Einhorn, the hedge-fund manager known for shorting Lehman Brothers before it collapsed, said he bought shares of Apple in the second quarter because the iPhone maker’s growth is undervalued, Bloomberg News reported.

text: Harbinger Capital Partners, the hedge fund run by Philip Falcone, has chosen Nokia Siemens Networks to build and operate its planned high-speed mobile phone network in the United States, in a $7 billion, eight-year deal, according to news reports.

headline: China Warily Eyes U.S.-Korea Drills
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States and South Korea announced Tuesday that the first in a series of large-scale naval exercises off Japan and the Korean Peninsula would begin next week, despite objections from China.

text: Wall Street’s hottest new product is fear.

headline: With Lineup Back Together, Piece of Mets’ Rotation Implodes
text: PHOENIX — The Mets finally had the lineup they had been waiting to field for months, with Carlos Beltran and Jose Reyes playing together for the first time since May 20, 2009. The fact that the lineup managed only two runs was a little disappointing for the Mets, but hardly the focus of concern on Monday night.

headline: Explaining the Changing Face of S.B.A. Borrowers
text: A few years back, I made the acquaintance of a hard-working woman named Blanca Castillo. Ms. Castillo lived in Richmond, Va., with her husband Joel, where the two ran a small company that hauled trash from Washington to landfills in central Virginia. It was a harsh living: the Castillos, immigrants from Honduras (here legally), were essentially subcontractors to another company working 16-hour days. Nonetheless, they had assembled a fleet of four trucks and three employees to drive them.

headline: Cooling Your Laptop, or Your Lap?
text: A number of companies make cooling pads that are supposed to decrease the heat from laptop computers. You put these pads under a laptop, and, generally, a USB cable connected to it sends power to a fan, which draws heat out of the computer.

text: Green Dot, a prepaid debit card company, on Monday increased the number of shares it plans to offer in its initial public offering by 8 percent, Reuters reported.

text: Stocks closed a lightly traded session higher Tuesday despite disappointing earnings from Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson.

headline: Training Programs or Sweatshops?
text: From across Asia, about 190,000 migrant trainees toil in Japanese factories and farms. Allegations of labor abuses against these workers are widespread.

Schwartz reports.

text: 1. Yes, I do write my own headlines. If the economics thing doesn’t work out, I might try standup comedy — or maybe become a Mad Man.

headline: U.S. Home Construction Declined by 5% in June

headline: Profits Rise at Bank of New York and State Street
