text: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is attempting to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

headline: Julianne Moore’s New Musical Is All Right for the Kids
text: We’d be the first to tell you – and Julianne Moore would be the second – that her films are best appreciated by viewers with a certain amount of life experience.

headline: A Worried View of the Amazon From Within its Forest
text: Lou Gold, a longtime commenter who lives in the Brazilian portion of the Amazon basin, is an invaluable member of the worldwide Dot Earth community (people from more than 200 countries have visited the blog). He reacted strongly to my recent cautiously upbeat statement — made while conducting an onstage interview with a Brazilian ecologist — about prospects that the rain forests there could persist through this century even as human numbers and appetites crest. Gold posted a series of comments following the Amazon piece, and has consolidated them with a post on his blog, Visionshare. You can read the full post below.

headline: Japan Training Program Is Said to Exploit Workers
text: HIROSHIMA, Japan  Six young Chinese women arrived in this historic city three summers ago, among the tens of thousands of apprentices brought to Japan each year on the promise of job training, good pay and a chance at a better life back home.

headline: No New Apartments
text: The housing start numbers for June show that activity remains moribund, which is hardly a surprise.  When you build way too much of something, you get a glut that takes time to work off.

headline: The Recipe for Clouds Goes Open-Source
text: Ah, the cloud. It sounds like such a wonderful, fluffy place where computers hum away all day long and information roams free.

headline: Leaders Take Pains to Stress What’s Still Special in the U.S.-Britain Relationship
text: WASHINGTON — It was not quite the Tony Blair-Bill Clinton love fest of 1997, but President Obama and the newly minted British prime minister, David Cameron, appeared game to do everything they could on Tuesday to take some of the recent chill out of the relationship between their countries.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Extension of Unemployment Benefits
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The ‘Super Skimmer’ That Wasn’t
text: When I was aboard a Coast Guard cutter last week at the site of BP’s blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico, a monster of a ship showed up to join the armada of drilling rigs, production ships, supply boats and skimmers in the area.

headline: Social Networking for Cars
text: On Twitter, no one knows you’re a car.

headline: Europe Proposes to End Coal Mining Subsidies by 2014
text: It has been one of the most acrimonious debates in memory for officials at the European Commission, the executive body that runs the European Union. Should the commission allow nations to subsidize unprofitable coal mines to preserve jobs and help vulnerable regions? Or should it halt the aid to show the European Union’s commitment to reducing dependence on fossil fuels?

headline: Mercury Prize Hoping 2010 Nominees Will Shine Brighter
text: When the winner of your annual music prize, which has historically focused a spotlight on less-recognized pop artists, fails to sell significant amounts of records and splits with her label in the wake of her victory, what do you do for an encore? Try going a little more mainstream.

headline: Nevada Retains Highest State Unemployment Rate
text: For the second consecutive month, Nevada has beat out Michigan in the race for the state with the highest  unemployment rate.

headline: No Surprise: Manchin Is Running for Senate
text: 1:21 p.m. | Updated Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia announced on Tuesday morning that, as expected, he would run in this year’s special election for the Senate seat long held by the late Robert C. Byrd.

headline: Goldman Says Clients Stay Loyal Despite S.E.C. Case
text: David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, said Tuesday that the firm had not experienced a major loss of business as a result of the securities fraud case that it settled with Securities and Exchange Commission, saying that Goldman’s clients were “pretty supportive.”

headline: Letter: Passengers’ Rights
text: To the Editor: As someone who travels internationally several times a year, I read your Practical Traveler column, “Delayed? They’ll Put You Up” (July 18), about how the European Union airlines compensate for delays, and wondered why United States airlines do not have similar policies for passengers. But then I remembered that until recently, United States airlines could keep passengers on planes for hours with no food, water, clean bathrooms and certainly no compensation.

headline: Letter: Dining in Montreal
text: To the Editor: I read with interest Rusha Haljuci’s answer to a question in the July 11 Q&A, “A Food-Focused Overnight in Montreal,” about dining in the city, and I reread Peter Meehan’s “These Chefs Believe in Sticking Close to Home“ (April 6, 2008). My son lives in the Plateau district of Montreal, and I visit regularly. We eat out several times each visit, and while I agree with the restaurant recommendations of Ms. Haljuci and Mr. Meehan, neither of them mentions that there are many restaurants where you can bring your own wine (“apportez votre vin”).

headline: Release of Lockerbie Convict Was ‘Wrong,’ Cameron Says
text: Updated | 4:50 p.m. My colleague Helene Cooper reports, “Britain’s Prime Minister, David Cameron, said on Tuesday that he did not see any point to an additional investigation into the release of the convicted Lockerbie bomber from a Scottish prison last year, maintaining that such an inquiry would only confirm his belief that the release was ill-advised and wrong.”

headline: Kabul Conference: A City Under Lockdown
text: Security was so tight during the Kabul conference that no one was allowed on the streets of the city except police officers, soldiers and people who had special badges permitting them to enter the conference compound.

headline: Letters: The Desert War
text: Robert F. Worth suggests that U.S. policy may be inadequate in preventing Yemen from becoming “the next Afghanistan,” but embedded in his article is a way out: support of “secular” and “godless” and, yes, “socialist” Yemenis who actually were dominant in Aden as late as the 1980s. Those who raise alarms about “Islamo-fascism” should be comforted by such a policy, as it only mimics U.S. policy on the eastern front from 1941 to 1945. Unfortunately, the current U.S. administration, spooked by the false allegation that it is “socialist,” will be reluctant to take this path; but it may be the only way out.GERALD HORNEProfessor of History, University of Houston,Houston

headline: Letters: Extreme Sports, Medieval Division
text: Dashka Slater makes it sound like all American jousters are huge, hulking, foulmouthed brutes. That couldn’t be further from the truth. Granted, each and every person who does this type of thing is often tough as nails, and they play up that aspect for the crowd, but there are many, many more jousters who compete regularly overseas and don’t have to throw how tough they are in your face.

headline: Letter: Till Death Do They Part
text: Ideology has separated families through history, but modern America is famously tolerant of diversity, and this tends to be true even in the familial cryonics context. Wives have honored their husbands’ commitment to cryonics, even when disagreeing. At the Cryonics Institute, about a third of the members are women, and more than half of our patients are women (50 out of 98). At a guess, this is because mothers are special objects of love.

headline: Letters: The Ethicist, Outing the Transgender Dater
text: I am a transgender person who was dismayed to read your July 11 column. The only truly ethical answer to this question is: never.

headline: Letter: Lives, Night of 130 Teenagers
text: Michael Krikorian’s actions were illegal, his girlfriend was irresponsible and the 15-year-old girl is lucky to be O.K. with such a negligent adult “in charge” of the party. Frankly, I find it amazing that the writer was willing to acknowledge his own inaction, passivity and gross negligence.LENORE H. FORSTEDWynnewood, Pa.

headline: Vain Glorious | Lancôme’s La Rose Déco
text: What: Lancôme La Rose Déco, a new highlighter and bronzer.

headline: Icahn Makes Another Run at Lions Gate
text: Carl C. Icahn is back on the prowl for Lions Gate Entertainment, but this time he is offering less money for the movie studio than he did before.

headline: How Corporation Chief Was Voted Off Roosevelt I.
text: Roosevelt Island has a Dickensian past full of prisons, workhouses and insane asylums, and there have been wisecracks that its governing in more modern times — it opened as a planned community in 1975 — has not evolved much past that.

headline: Zen Gardening
text: Wendy Johnson, who helped pioneer the concept of organic gardening, gardens by a mountain creek with a view of  the Pacific Ocean.

headline: The Orchid King
text: The Florida home of Robert Fuchs is an orchid lover's fantasy on a 10-acre plot.

headline: Test Yourself | July 20, 2010
text: Last week we experimented with a week of English vocabulary, reading and grammar questions inspired by Times articles, and readers were enthusiastic.

headline: Committee Approves Kagan’s Nomination to Supreme Court
text: President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court, Solicitor General Elena Kagan, was endorsed by the Senate Judiciary Committee in a 13-to-6 vote on Tuesday.

headline: Children’s Money Questions: Why Is That Person Asking for Money?
text: This question is a particularly tough one, since it may come when your child encounters, for the first time, people who have so little money they feel the need to ask others for help.

headline: Sumner Redstone: The Spoken Word Performance
text: At The Daily Beast, Peter Lauria published a fairly light-hearted item about a girl group that Sumner Redstone, the 87-year-old chair of Viacom and CBS, had a corporate crush on. In return, Mr. Lauria received what seemed like an offer he couldn’t refuse on his voice mail.

headline: Governments Get Together to Talk Clean
text: Two dozen countries representing 80 percent of the world’s commercial energy consumption on Tuesday announced initiatives to build more efficient appliances and buildings, “smart” electric grids and electric vehicles.

headline: Witness Cancellations Thwart Hearings on Oil Spill
text: KENNER, La.  Government investigators looking into the causes of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion are colliding with a frequent obstacle: witnesses canceling their scheduled testimonies.

headline: Ruby Kobo | Lucky Charms
text: Yuvi Alpert and Danna Kobo, two jet-setting 26-year-old jewelers based in New York, are taking the concept of “global nomad” quite literally with their new label, Ruby Kobo. Alpert, a Californian who was raised in Tel Aviv, has crisscrossed the world trawling for precious stones and talismanic objects in far-flung holy sites from the Himalayas to South America. Kobo, who grew up in Hong Kong, apprenticed under the godfather of bling, Jacob the Jeweler.

headline: A Russian Warning on Retreating Ice
text: Sea ice in the Arctic is again in rapid retreat this summer, putting the region on pace to match the record lows seen in 2007, the head of Russia’s environmental agency said Tuesday, according to a Bloomberg News report.

headline: Spanish Armada — er, Armadillo
text: I didn’t plan on getting stuck for three and a half hours at La Balsa, a tiny town that straddles the Peru-Ecuador border. But my collective taxi had arrived from San Ignacio, Peru, at 9 a.m., and the lone immigration official (stuck in La Balsa for a month, she lamented) told me that the first bus from  the Ecuadorian side wouldn’t leave until 12:30.

headline: Some Complications in BP’s Asset Sales
text: 5:00 p.m. | Updated BP announced late Tuesday afternoon that it had agreed to sell $7 billion of onshore oil and gas assets in Texas, New Mexico, western Canada and Egypt to Apache.

headline: Michael Moore Not Bowled Over by U.S. Offerings at His Film Festival
text: It wouldn’t be a conversation with Michael Moore without a little bit of provocation.

headline: Duke Suspends Researcher and Halts Cancer Studies
text: The Duke University School of Medicine has suspended a researcher and stopped patient enrollment in three cancer studies upon learning of reports that the researcher had overstated his academic credentials.

headline: City Adds to Asbestos Oversight
text: Three months after a safety inspector admitted to falsifying hundreds of reports concluding that buildings were free of cancer-causing asbestos, the city agency that licensed him  and still licenses nearly 550 others  says it has taken steps to ensure better oversight.

headline: Lincoln Center’s Restaurant Has a Name
text: It’s still a construction site. It has half a staff. And it won’t be open until September.

headline: TimesCast | July 20, 2010
text: Today, the Senate prepares to pass legislation extending jobless benefits, Goldman Sachs earnings slump, and a look at the evolution of skateboarding that adds steep hills and a lot of speed.

headline: Communist Teacher Blamed for Improper Cuba Trip
text: Yes, the history teacher with the pictures of Che Guevara and Fidel Castro on his classroom walls really was a communist.

headline: I (Almost) Live in the Cloud
text: How close are we to moving our lives entirely into the cloud?

headline: For a Celiac Sufferer, a New Mystery Illness
text: The problems began not long after I moved in with my future wife. I was losing weight at an alarming rate, drifting for hours after meals in a confused fog. My acid reflux was so bad I felt like I had a golf ball lodged in my throat. I suffered from otherworldly constipation and had no sex drive. My tongue swelled like a wet sponge. It seemed everything I ate contributed to my misery.

headline: Cuts in Home Care Put Elderly and Disabled at Risk
text: HILLSBORO, Ore.  As states face severe budget shortfalls, many have cut home-care services for the elderly or the disabled, programs that have been shown to save states money in the long run because they keep people out of nursing homes.

headline: Goldman Plans to Stay in Private Equity Business
text: David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, said Tuesday that the firm had no plans to spin off its private equity business after Congressional passage of new financial regulations that would restrict the bank holding company in allocating money to alternative investments.

headline: Senate Panel Backs Kagan Nomination, With One Republican Vote
text: WASHINGTON  Solicitor General Elena Kagan moved one step closer to becoming a Supreme Court justice on Tuesday when the Senate Judiciary Committee voted 13 to 6, almost entirely along party lines, to forward her nomination to the full Senate for consideration.

headline: Come to Massachusetts: We Love Cannibals!
text: Michigan wasn’t interested in subsidizing “The Woman,” a cannibalism-themed horror movie that was turned down by the state’s film incentives program in May. But Massachusetts appears to have bitten.

headline: The  Insider | Angelo Bianchi
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

headline: American Activists Plan Gaza Flotilla Ship Named for Obama Book
text: A group of Americans opposed to Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza is raising money online to pay for a ship from the United States to take part in a new protest flotilla scheduled to set sail for the Palestinian territory in September or October.

headline: Snapshots of Parenting A.D.H.D.
text: Consumer Reports, having had its say about the iPhone, has now set its sights on treatments for A.D.H.D. The company’s health division released the results today of a survey of more than 900 parents whose children were diagnosed with the disorder, and the result is a snapshot into how it feels to raise a child with A.D.H.D.

headline: London Theater Journal: Arthur Miller, Pinteresquely
text: During intermission at the Apollo Theater on Monday night, I overheard the following exchange, delivered with contented grimness by two pale, plump, bespectacled British men.

headline: Hearts Running ’Round Like Chickens and Whatnot
text: Ah, the challenges of finding love in the city.

headline: Lindsay Lohan Starts Jail Term
text: In contrast to her tearful court appearance earlier this month when she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating terms of her her probation, Lindsay Lohan kept her composure Tuesday as she arrived at the Beverly Hills courtroom of Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court, where the actress surrendered to begin her prison sentence.

headline: Breaking a World Record for Gaming
text: People are constantly breaking world records. This month alone, a record was broken for the longest tennis match, a mind-blowing 11 hours and 5 minutes. The record was also recently broken for the world’s largest salad, weighing in at 29,579 pounds. (No word on the salad dressing.)

headline: How Do You Eat Watermelons?
text: For many years, it seemed as if there were only three ways to eat a watermelon: split open and attacked with a spoon, cut into triangular slices or included in a fruit salad. The first two required a great deal of spitting, and even the third was a bit of a hassle, because before the development of the seedless watermelon hybrid, a lot of work went into cutting up watermelon for salad.

headline: Shankland Is U.S. Junior Chess Champion
text: Samuel Shankland won a three-way playoff on Tuesday in St. Louis.

headline: Citigroup Names 2 Co-Heads of Industrials Group
text: Citigroup announced Tuesday that it had named Wes Walraven and Wayne Beckmann as the new co-heads of the bank’s global industrials group.

headline: Easing the Pain of Lung Cancer
text: Several readers had questions for the Consults blog about the complications of lung cancer. Dr. Derek Raghavan of the Cleveland Clinic responds.

headline: How to Make 100 Enemies Lists
text: No one goes into the hospitality business to be hated. The most unsettling and least lovable aspect of this two-tined enterprise — the starting of, and the writing about the starting of, a new restaurant — has been an unrelenting hate wave. I volunteered for these twin gigs, so I ask for neither a wide berth nor the slightest break. Somewhere along the way I forgot the old macrobiotic axiom: the bigger the front, the bigger the back.

headline: Mad Men City | A Shirt, and a Promise
text: Viewers who are versed in “Mad Men” know that Don Draper keeps a stack of neatly pressed shirts in his drawer at work in the event of a late-night bender or liaison. In January 1964, the manufacturer of Arrow shirts started a campaign promising that a crisp white button-down would act as a magnet for a repulsed wife.

headline: Cleaning Up Intersection of Ancient and Modern
text: JERUSALEM — The director of the Israel Museum was leading a visitor to see a provocative contemporary sculpture of a naked African youth when, stepping over protective cloths and around an exhibit of late Canaanite sarcophagi, he nearly ran into four workmen carrying the million-year-old horns of a wild bull.

headline: Immortalized by Not Dying: Woody Allen Goes Digital
text: With the possible exception of his invention of the orgasmatron, Woody Allen is not necessarily known as an early adopter of cutting-edge technology. Still, Mr. Allen has taken a bold leap into the 21st century and recorded audiobook editions of the four collections of humorous essays he wrote between 1971 and 2007, the digital agency ClearMetrics said on Tuesday.

headline: Greek Rail System’s Debt Adds to Economic Woes
text: ATHENS  In 2009, bankers for Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley pitched the Greek government on a plan to overhaul its money-losing railway system. Among the ideas was to lay off half of the system’s 7,000 workers and have the government take on roughly half of the company’s 8 billion euros in debt.

headline: More Federal Scrutiny for Johnson & Johnson
text: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that the company had reduced its forecast of 2010 earnings per share to $4.65 to $4.75.

headline: Skateboarding Glides Into New Phase
text: GOLDENDALE, Wash.  Here in the high desert east of the Cascades, where towering windmills quietly whir overhead, skaters hurtle downhill along a ribbon of blacktop six at a time wearing helmets and motorcycle leathers, hay bales stacked along switchbacks for the inevitable wipeouts.

headline: Media Seek Looser Guantánamo Rules
text: After nearly a decade of uneasy coexistence at Guantánamo Bay, the Pentagon and the news media are now locked in a dispute that will test how strictly the government can limit what reporters there are allowed to reveal.

headline: Ristretto | Rock Star, Barista
text: This past weekend, the musicians performing at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago found something not normally spotted in the green room (which was actually a creaky old field house next to the supervisor’s office for Union Park): a full coffee bar from Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea. With Michael Phillips, the current World Barista Champion, and Stephen Morrissey, the 2008 World Barista Champion, among the staff pulling shots of La Tortuga from Honduras and pouring cold-brewed Thiriku from Kenya on ice, the scene was rock-star baristas making coffee for rock stars.

headline: Honda to Introduce Plug-In Hybrids and Electric Car by 2012
text: For a company whose product line ranks among the most fuel-efficient in the world, Honda tends to speak softly of its bona fides, usually conceding the green-hued megaphone to its archrival, Toyota. However, if Tuesday’s pronouncements by its chief executive, Takanobu Ito, at Honda’s Japanese sales headquarters offer any indication, the quiet achiever is mounting an offensive.

headline: What Is Your Doctor Saying About You?
text: We’ve all seen our doctors scribbling in our charts after the exam. Now new research is exploring whether it’s a good idea to let a patient read the doctor’s notes, reports the Informed Patient column in today’s Wall Street Journal.

headline: Goldman Call Turns Testy Over Fraud Case
text: David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, seemed satisfied on Tuesday that its clients had “pretty much” stuck by the firm in the wake of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s civil fraud case. Still, at least one analyst is concerned that a lingering possibility of criminal charges is affecting how investors view the firm and preventing some institutions from holding its stock.

headline: Grilled Thick Lamb Chops with Stout-Citrus Glaze
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Pouring Stout Into the Pan Instead of the Glass
text: I ADMIT it: When it comes to beer, I like pale, watery lagers. I know this is wrong, but while I admire the craft with which more full-flavored brews are made, their bitter hoppiness just isn’t a taste I enjoy.

headline: Knicks Keep Stoudemire Off National Team
text: Amar’e Stoudemire will not play for the United States national team this summer because of insurance concerns about his surgically repaired left knee.

headline: Politicians Seeing the World Using Someone Else’s Money
text: Times may be tough for most New Yorkers, but city officials continued to enjoy one traditional perk of elected office — seeing the world on other people’s dimes.

headline: A Cottage in Stone and Glass
text: A couple renovates a 15th-century stone barn with a glass-walled extension for 895,000 pounds, or $1.4 million at $1.53 to the pound.

headline: The Lifeboat Foundation: Battling Asteroids, Nanobots and A.I.
text: Do antimatter fears keep you up at night? Has your day been ruined by worries about black holes? Are you paralyzed by the oncoming threat of ecophages and nonreplicating nanoweapons?

headline: Now Dressing | Lindsay Lohan’s Prison Look
text: For the next 90 days, Lindsay Lohan is only allowed to wear an orange jumpsuit — no jewelry, no makeup, and definitely no nail polish. It’s such a shame, because she’d look great in the following fall looks, chosen especially for the fashion-conscious parole violator by the girls in T’s fashion closet.

headline: Martin Dunn Speaks About Leaving The Daily News
text: The editor of The Daily News of New York unexpectedly announced on Tuesday that he was leaving the paper after seven years at the helm.

headline: Youngest Senator Succeeds the Oldest
text: 3:21 p.m. | Updated The oldest senator has been replaced by the youngest.

headline: Flashblood
text: When heroin addicts inject themselves with another user’s blood in an attempt to share the high.

headline: A Push for Old Times’ Sake Falls Short
text: PAU, France  In the closing moments of Tuesday’s stage of the Tour de France, just as in the old days when he dominated this race, Lance Armstrong tried to win.

headline: E.U. Test May Need to Fail Some Banks
text: FRANKFURT — Will Europe’s bank stress tests be a success if nobody fails?

headline: Downhill Longboarding Grows Up
text: The sport of downhill longboarding is the fastest growing segment of skateboarding. The best riders in the world compete at the Maryhill Festival of Speed, North America's premier longboarding race.

headline: How to Get Cheaper Hybrid Rentals
text: Updated: Picture changed.Here’s one way to potentially get a cheaper hybrid rental: join a car sharing program.

headline: Woods, From Tee to Green
Google Updates Its Image Search
text: 3:37 p.m. | Updated  to include information from the press conference by Claire Cain Miller.

headline: Home Prices Across the Nation
How a Market Crisis Unfolded
text: Years of mortgage lending excesses began to take their toll on the financial sector in early 2007. Here are some of the key events in the upheaval, from the bursting of the tech bubble to the rescue of A.I.G.

headline: The Humble Bus Takes Off
text: HIGH-SPEED rail may be getting lots of attention — and money — from the Obama administration, but it turns out the transportation success story of the last few years is the bus.

headline: Harley-Davidson Considers Moving Production Out of Wisconsin
text: The days of Wisconsin-made Harley-Davidsons may be numbered.

headline: Jobless Benefit Extension Clears Senate Hurdle
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate cleared the way Tuesday for more unemployment pay to reach millions of Americans who have been out of work for six months or more as the Democratic-led Congress pruned one more item off the list of issues it hopes to tackle in an intensely polarized election year.

headline: Panel Urges F.D.A. to Revoke Approval of Drug for Breast Cancer Treatment
text: Updated: An advisory committee recommended Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration revoke approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, saying the drug was not helping patients.

headline: Chianti Classicos With an Identity Crisis
text: THE issue was staring us right in the face, a dozen times over. We were tasting Chianti Classico riservas, which theoretically are the best Chianti Classicos each producer has to offer, wines worthy of the extra aging that the law requires in order to be designated “riserva.”

headline: Pairings: Tuscan Steaks With Grilled-Fennel Panzanella
text: How do you make Chianti Classico riserva a summertime wine? First, you serve it cool, cellar temperature, not room temperature. Then, you pour it with food that has a hot weather vibe.

headline: Q&A: Sites En Route from Frankfurt to Munich
text: Q.

headline: S.E.C. Pursuing More Cases Tied to Financial Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  Days after the Securities and Exchange Commission secured a $550 million settlement from Goldman Sachs, the agency’s chairwoman said on Tuesday that the commission was pursuing several other investigations related to the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: ‘They Want Their Story to Be Told’
text: Our friends on the Lens blog have a remarkably intimate slide show up today by Andrea Star Reese, a former filmmaker who has been photographing homeless people in West Harlem for three years. “They have joined this project with me as a collaboration,” Ms. Reese, 58, says of her subjects. “They want their story to be told. And that’s what interests them. That’s what keeps them engaged.” Check it out on Lens.

headline: New Setting for Gary Shteyngart
text: Leaving ‘Absurdistan’ Behind

headline: Quote Unquote | Pale Shelter
text: Dita von Teese defends her high-maintenance look to Vogue UK. Isn’t constantly avoiding sunlight sort of time consuming?

headline: New York Requires Alcohol Interlocks for First-Time Drunken Drivers
text: On Aug. 15, a new zero tolerance policy begins for driving drunk in New York State. Under the provisions of what’s being called Leandra’s Law, anyone convicted of misdemeanor or felony drunken driving will  be required to install (for a minimum of six months) an ignition interlock breathalyzer device that won’t allow the car to start if it detects a threshold level of alcohol on the driver’s breath.

headline: Inside the Renovated Israel Museum
text: A look at the Jerusalem museum and its collections as it completes a three-year, $100 million renewal.

headline: More Depression Debt
text: As I noted in this post, the debt-GDP ratio rose much more under Hoover than it did under FDR:

headline: Bound to a Rocking Chair, Wishing Upon a Star
text: As part of its third program at the Joyce Theater, Pilobolus unveiled a work that broke the company’s artistic mold. For “Contradance,” receiving its New York premiere on Monday evening, two former dancers choreographed a production without the assistance of one of Pilobolus’s artistic directors.

headline: A Palace Apartment
text: A two-bedroom apartment in a former palace is on the market for $618,000 in the second-home destination of Dubrovnik, Croatia.

headline: How Hot Is It? Where, Exactly?
text: In Tuesday’s NYC column, Clyde Haberman smartly points out that the oft-quoted high temperatures of the day, taken in Central Park, are much cooler than the temperatures we actually experience. “The park is the Garden of Eden compared with the city’s streets,” Mr. Haberman writes. “It is absolute heaven compared with most subway platforms.”

headline: Country and Rock, Delivered With Rawness
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.  John McCauley, gaunt and scraggly, clutched an electric guitar at Maxwell’s here on Monday night, finger-picking a lone song, “Houston, TX,” by himself. His band, Deer Tick, had spent the past hour digging into roadhouse country and rawboned rock ’n’ roll, with a bluntly effective fervor. This solo interlude seemed like an unscheduled detour, announced on the fly. But it was a clear, vital moment in an unfocused show.

headline: Nature, Nurture and Human Capital
text: Most parents have concluded by the time their children hit toddlerhood that they are who they are (nature) but that you should do everything you can to teach them to identify colors, gain admission to the best preschool, and advise them to wait to eat marshmallows (nurture).

headline: A More Diverse Diversity
text: Tim Fernholz has a lot of complaints about my column this week, but I suppose this is the main one:

headline: At Your Next Destination: Nickelodeon
text: In case DVDs and video games aren’t enough to keep your children’s attention while on vacation, Nickelodeon cable channel is pairing up with travel companies to provide themed entertainment at your destination.

headline: Handling a Pop Star, Cattle Prod Included
text: It’s been four years since Carl Hiaasen’s last novel for adults, “Nature Girl.” That should have been long enough for America’s pop culture in general, and Florida’s in particular, to have yielded a shooting gallery’s worth of new targets. It’s been enough time to place the excesses of a flaming pop tart, à la Lindsay Lohan, in Mr. Hiaasen’s satirical cross hairs.

headline: ‘Star Island’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Jets Create a Ring of Honor at New Stadium
text: There are perks to playing in a football stadium not named after another team, and the Jets announced one on Tuesday: the creation of a Ring of Honor when they co-open the New Meadowlands Stadium (at least until they sell the naming rights) with the Giants next month.

headline: With Sale of Assets, BP Bets on More Deep Wells
text: Despite the April 20 Deepwater Horizon disaster, BP has no plans to leave the Gulf of Mexico or stop drilling for oil in other deep ocean waters.

headline: Apple’s Profit Rises 78% on Appeal of New Devices
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The iPhone 4 antenna may be causing static for some Apple investors, but the company is showing no signs of slowing down.

headline: Transforming Gulou
text: A government-initiated redevelopment plan will transform one of the oldest neighborhoods in Beijing into a polished tourist attraction.

headline: Shylock as Rock Star
text: There are hot tickets, and there are red-hot tickets. “The Merchant of Venice” is the latter. The chance to see Al Pacino as Shylock at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, for free, has turned Central Park West and the walkway that stretches from the open-air theater to the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir into a 21st-century Hooverville, albeit a well-behaved, well-fed, literarily inclined one.

headline: Diane Pernet | Film Noir
text: It’s difficult to stand out in the front row, but Diane Pernet’s all-black ensemble, towering hair and lace mantilla keep the designer/editor/filmmaker/journalist from blending in among starlets and Voguettes. Pernet is the voice behind “A Shaded View of Fashion,” a fashion-forward blog that roots for young designers. Once a women’s-wear designer in New York, Pernet started her editorial career only after moving to Paris, her home now for 20 years — and the world’s most unforgiving fashion capital. “In New York, anything goes and who cares? People can be their own person and nobody’s judging you,” she says. “But Paris is judging you constantly.”

headline: A Financial Bright Spot for Democrats
text: 5:41 p.m. | Updated

headline: On London Stages, Powdered Eggs and Things Not Said
text: LONDON  Even with senses as jangled by jet lag as mine are, it’s impossible not to notice that belts are being worn tighter in London this summer. I awoke on Friday, my first morning here, to the nip of pervasive economic anxiety. I couldn’t pick up a paper without seeing the word “austerity” or some variation on “squeeze” or “pinch” featured prominently. The tabloids prickled with references to governmental budget cuts and their impact on the health system, schools, the job market, museums, mass transit and  a bit nearer to my heart, or at least to my reason for being here  theaters.

headline: Aquavit
text: IT has been a Swedish summer here in New York. There seem to be Stieg Larsson novels on every fourth lap on the D train choogling over the Manhattan Bridge, on every third iPad glowing in the dark of the jitney driving east on the Long Island Expressway toward Montauk.

headline: Reviewing Aquavit
text: The restaurant Aquavit is the subject of this week’s review, its fourth such accounting in The New York Times since its arrival in Manhattan in 1987. Bryan Miller took the first shot in 1988, back when it was located in one of the Rockefeller Townhouses, awarding the restaurant two stars. My predecessors Ruth Reichl and William Grimes followed in 1995 and in 2001, respectively, awarding three stars. And when the restaurant moved east, in 2005, Frank Bruni wrote about it in a Diner’s Journal column.

headline: No Shortage of Books on Oil Spill
text: Any readers clamoring to relive the oil-darkened spring of 2010 will have plenty of opportunity. Publishers have bought at least six books relating to the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico on April 20, and several more proposals are circulating.

headline: BP Sells $7 Billion in Assets to Apache
text: The troubled oil giant BP announced Tuesday that it had agreed to sell $7 billion of onshore oil and gas assets in Texas, New Mexico, western Canada and Egypt to the Apache Corporation, Jad Mouawad of The New York Times reports.

headline: An Argentine Pop-Up for SoHo
text: An outdoor pop-up restaurant will set up shop in the yard of the SoHo Grand hotel Aug. 3 to 6, from 6 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. It’s another session of the Hunger, started in the spring by the chef Camille Becerra and the nightlife entrepreneurs Alan Philips and Josh Shames of the Sky Group. An Argentine barbecue, or asado, with assorted grilled meats, will be served and there will be a communal table seating 70. Tango music will add a sexy beat. Reservations, from thehungernyc.com, are $65 including tax and tip. There will also be a cash bar.

headline: Calling Indie Brides and D.I.Y.-ers
text: “TIGHTER, tighter.” Elizabeth Lippman was rasping instructions to Marcey, a sales assistant. Quick to oblige, Marcey adjusted the clamps on her gown to give it its requisite cling. “I feel like Scarlett O’Hara,” Ms. Lippman murmured. Sure, but could she breathe? “That’s irrelevant!” she said.

headline: In Verse, a Hoodlum’s Rage and War’s Spoils
text: Listen. Listen harder. That’s what the British playwright Howard Barker needs you to do during “Gary the Thief” and “Plevna: Meditations on Hatred,” his two short, dense plays produced by the Potomac Theater Project/NYC at Atlantic Stage 2.

headline: Woody Allen’s Talk Therapy: Audiobooks by a Technophobe
text: With the possible exception of his invention of the orgasmatron, Woody Allen is not necessarily known as an early adopter of cutting-edge technology. Still, Mr. Allen has taken a bold leap into the 21st century and recorded audiobook editions of the four collections of humorous essays he published from 1971 to 2007, the digital agency ClearMetrics said on Tuesday.

headline: In Guernsey, a Fusing of Stone and Glass
text: ISLE OF GUERNSEY  As a child, Julia Martin loved visiting the aviary next door to an old barn dating back to the 15th century. At the time she never paid much attention to the neglected building, and certainly never imagined calling it home. But about 25 years later home it became, and not before it was renovated by a local architect.

headline: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
text: A soldier identified by The Mail Online as 25-year-old Pvt. Pirthraj Thapa of the Gurkhas, who lost his left leg in a mine explosion in Afghanistan, waited for a cortege to pass in Wootton Bassett, England, with four members of the First Battalion, Royal Gurkha Rifles, who were killed by an Afghan soldier last week.

headline: Beijing Continues Its March of Modernization
text: The neighborhood of Gulou, which boasts a pair of brick towers dating back hundreds of years, is about to be turned into a polished tourist attraction.

headline: BP Is Given Another 24 Hours for Testing
text: HOUSTON  Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral who commands the spill response, on Tuesday gave BP another 24 hours for testing its capped oil well, keeping it shut while BP and government officials weigh whether to kill the well permanently by pumping heavy mud into it.

headline: Mad Men City | Time & Life Building
text: ALERT: While this week of “Mad Men” posts endeavors to remain spoiler-free, this one is informed by a close advance viewing of the episode to be broadcast Sunday. It describes New York City locations mentioned in the episode and, in doing so, gives away only the most benign plot points, like the location of the main characters’ new office. Nonetheless, if you want to go into Sunday’s episode knowing absolutely nothing in advance, save this post until next week.

headline: PBS Ombudsman Criticizes Shultz Series
text: A three-part PBS series about the Reagan-era Secretary of State George Shultz has come under scrutiny in recent days for its financing ties to his friends and associates.

headline: A-Wah in Chinatown
text: Just south of Chatham Square in Chinatown, A-Wah specializes in Hong Kong cuisine.

headline: A-Wah
text: 5 Catherine Street (East Broadway), (212) 925-8308.

headline: Finger-Pointing on Oil Shifts to Bush Era
text: House Democrats sought Tuesday to use a hearing on the Interior Department’s role in the Gulf Coast oil spill to blame the Bush administration for regulatory failures that may have contributed to the April 20 explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig.

headline: S.E.C. Pursuing More Cases Tied to Financial Crisis
text: Days after the Securities and Exchange Commission secured a $550 million settlement from the banking giant Goldman Sachs, the agency’s chairwoman said Tuesday that the S.E.C. was pursuing several other investigations related to the 2008 financial crisis, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: A City Tour for V.I.P.’s Attending the Kabul Conference
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the opening scenes of Shakespeare’s play “Measure for Measure,” the Duke of Vienna takes off his fine clothes and disguises himself as an ordinary friar so that he can wander the streets and learn what the common people really think about the governance of his city.

headline: The Castello Plan in Ditmas Park
text: A new wine bar on Cortelyou Road in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn.

headline: The Castello Plan in Brooklyn
text: 1213 Cortelyou Road (Argyle Road), Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, (718) 856-8888; thecastelloplan.com.

headline: A Friend, an Artist and a Personal Interview
text: “Nobody loves a genius child.” Those are words from Langston Hughes’s poem “Genius Child,” used as the hyperbolic epigraph in Tamra Davis’s worshipful documentary portrait, “Jean-Michel Basquiat: The Radiant Child.”

headline: American Sweets With Lots of Japanese Character
text: Hiroyuki Takahachi, the owner of two Japanese restaurants, has opened a bright, cross-cultural bakery-cafe with a classic cast-iron facade.

headline: Duke Scientist Suspended Over Rhodes Scholar Claims
text: Duke University School of Medicine has suspended a researcher and stopped patient enrollment in three cancer studies upon learning of reports that the researcher had overstated his academic credentials.

headline: Chanterelles and Day Lilies Available, Briefly
text: A little rain, and out pop the chanterelles in the woods near Michael and Linda Hoffman’s Honey Hollow Farm in Middleburgh, N.Y. Mr. Hoffman cultivates some mushrooms, but not the little golden, nutty-tasting chanterelles that he finds in the wild. “We should have them for another week or so,” Ms. Hoffman said, “but it will depend on the weather.” Sautéed chanterelles are delicious in tarts, on salads or mixed with buttery fresh corn. They should be cooked, and before they go into the pan, it’s best to scrape off the outer layer of skin on the stems. The Hoffmans also harvest fragrant, fresh day-lily buds for Chinese stir-fries and hot-and-sour soup.

headline: Fresh Start for a Rebirth Stalled by a Recession
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Once stigmatized as a rough neighborhood, this city’s downtown has turned around in the last decade, when a new opera hall, museums, a hockey arena and a convention center began attracting suburban residents taking advantage of a growing light-rail system.

headline: Ghee, Indian-Style Butter, With a Kick
text: Ghee, a butter with the milk solids and water removed, is an Indian staple that deserves to be in more American kitchens. Sandeep Agarwal, whose family has been in the ghee business in northern India since 1889, left a career on Wall Street and now makes and sells plain ghees, as well as seasoned ones, which Indian cooks concoct at home. His are commercially made in Piscataway, N.J., and flavored with spices, ginger, garlic or herbs. Any of them would be excellent with steamed lobster or corn. Following ayurvedic principles, the butter is made during periods of the full or waxing moon. All are organic and shelf-stable and can be used for frying up to 400 degrees.

headline: Discounts for Dining and Cookware
text: Blackboard Eats, a Web site started by food writers and other professionals offering subscribers discounts at restaurants in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, is adding online shopping for food, cookware and other culinary items. This new component, called Everywhere, starts on July 21 and, as with the restaurants, has savings of up to 30 percent and special offers. It opens with cheeses from Murray’s Cheese, knives from macknife.com and all the coffee and tea at Intelligentsia Coffee.

headline: Michael Moore Unmoved by American Films
text: It wouldn’t be a conversation with Michael Moore without a bit of provocation. On Tuesday Mr. Moore, the “Sicko” and “Bowling for Columbine” filmmaker, called to discuss the lineup for his sixth-annual Traverse City Film Festival, which he holds each year to bring independent movies and their creators to that economically depressed Michigan town. Asked to pick a highlight or two from the festival, which runs this year from Tuesday to Aug. 1, Mr. Moore replied that “one of the highlights is actually a lowlight.” “I’m showing very, very few American independent feature films this year,” he continued, “because they simply  the great ones  don’t exist.” Mr. Moore said he hoped his festival would fill this gap with a lineup of foreign romantic comedies like “Will You Marry Us?” (from Switzerland), “Castaway on the Moon” (from South Korea) and “Heartbreaker” (from France), which he deemed superior to their American counterparts. Pending visa approvals, Mr. Moore said he hoped to bring some Cuban filmmakers to the festival.

headline: Love Conquers All on Monday Night
text: For the fifth consecutive week ABC drew the most viewers on Monday night, as “The Bachelorette” and the season finale of “True Beauty” set the network in first place in every hour in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Bachelorette” garnered the night’s most viewers, averaging 9.9 million from 8 to 10 p.m., while “True Beauty” eked out a lead at 10 with a more modest audience of 5.5 million viewers. CBS ranked second on the night with reruns of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 (6.2 million) followed by a “CSI: Miami” repeat at 10 (5.4 million). NBC was third, drawing 4.2 million at 9 for “Last Comic Standing” and 5 million at 10 for “Dateline.” Fox finished close behind in fourth, garnering 5.6 million at 8 for “Lie to Me” and 3.6 million at 9 for “The Good Guys.”

headline: Lindsay Lohan Starts Her Jail Sentence
text: In contrast to her tearful court appearance earlier this month when she was sentenced to 90 days in jail for violating terms of her probation, Lindsay Lohan kept her composure on Tuesday as she arrived at the Beverly Hills, Calif., courtroom of Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court, where she surrendered to begin her jail sentence. The Associated Press reported that about an hour after Ms. Lohan, 24, surrendered and was handcuffed, she was taken in an unmarked Sheriff’s Department car to the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., where she was photographed, above, and will spend most of her sentence in an isolated cell. Ms. Lohan, the star of “Mean Girls,” “Freaky Friday” and other films, was arrested twice in 2007 on charges of drunken driving. As part of her probation she was ordered to attend a May hearing but missed it. Ms. Lohan was then fitted with a monitoring device, and Judge Revel ruled that Ms. Lohan had violated the terms of her release.

headline: Soros Group Giving $11 Million to Arts Organizations
text: The Open Society Institute, founded by George Soros, left, has awarded $11 million to 70 small and mid-sized New York City cultural organizations, the institute is set to announce on Wednesday. The two-year grants, to be managed by the nonprofit Fund for the City of New York, will provide arts groups with general operating support. “General support money is the hardest money to come by,” Mary McCormick, the president of the fund, said. “When money is so tight, it is what gives cultural groups some breathing room.” The grants range from $65,000 to $250,000 for organizations with budgets of $75,000 to $7 million. Those selected will receive half of their money next week, Ms. McCormick said, and the remainder in June 2011. Groups in all five boroughs were evaluated on artistic excellence in dance, theater or music as well as their education programs. Among the recipients are the Mark Morris Dance Group, Ballet Hispanico, the Epic Theater Ensemble and the New York Youth Symphony.

headline: Leasing Start-Up Is Making Noise at Air Show
text: FARNBOROUGH, England — Amid a flurry of new plane purchases by the world’s leading jet-leasing companies, a newcomer, the Air Lease Corporation, added to a rapidly expanding fleet on Tuesday, announcing orders for 69 planes valued at about $4.7 billion.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Artists Boycott Brandeis Museum
text: Three prominent artists whose work was to appear at the Rose Art Museum of Brandeis University in September have withdrawn, boycotting the show because the university has not pledged to reverse a decision made last year to consider selling parts of the museum’s permanent collection, The Boston Globe reported. The painter April Gornik told The Globe that she and the painter Eric Fischl, above, along with the video artist Bill Viola, decided not to take part in the show, “Atmospheric Conditions,” until the university makes a legally binding promise not to sell any works. In January 2009, as Brandeis’s finances eroded, its trustees voted to “transition” the museum into a teaching center and gallery, followed by “an orderly sale or other disposition” of its works to raise money for the school. It backed off that plan and recently said it was working with Sotheby’s to make money by lending works from the collection or entering into partnerships with other institutions. “Atmospheric Conditions” will be replaced with an exhibition of the work of the Pop painter James Rosenquist, who told The Globe that he opposes sales from the collection but does not believe boycotting the Rose is the right strategy.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: To the Summer Harvest

headline: New York Mandates Cleaner Heating Oil
text: It’s official: New York State is drastically reducing sulfur in home heating oil.

headline: Gunfight Kills 2 Americans Who Trained Afghan Army
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A seemingly routine training practice in marksmanship went fatally wrong on Tuesday when an Afghan Army sergeant turned his weapon on an American trainer and a gunfight began. When it was over, the sergeant, two American trainers and an Afghan soldier who had been standing nearby lay dead.

headline: Julianne Moore’s Musical: All Right for the Kids
text: We’d be the first to tell you  and Julianne Moore, a star of “The Kids Are All Right” and “Boogie Nights,” would be the second  that her films are best appreciated by viewers with a certain amount of life experience. But that does not apply to “Freckleface Strawberry,” a coming Off Broadway show adapted from Ms. Moore’s children’s book of the same title, which is aimed at young theatergoers. The musical version of “Freckleface Strawberry” will begin previews at New World Stages on Sept. 9 and open on Oct. 4, the show’s publicists said on Tuesday. The production is directed by Buddy Crutchfield with choreography by Gail Pennington Crutchfield, and has a book by Rose Caiola and Gary Kupper and music and lyrics by Mr. Kupper.

headline: Leopold Museum to Pay $19 Million for Painting Seized by Nazis
text: A dispute that dragged on for more than a decade over the ownership of an Egon Schiele painting seized by the Nazis has finally been resolved.

headline: Rejected by Michigan, Horror Film Heads East
text: Michigan wasn’t interested in subsidizing “The Woman,” a cannibalism-themed horror movie that the state’s film incentives program turned down in May. But Massachusetts appears to have bitten. Andrew van den Houten, a producer of the film, said it was set to begin production in Greenfield, Mass., on Aug. 2, with help from that state’s similar program. Mr. van den Houten said the Massachusetts subsidy is slightly smaller than what he had hoped to get from Michigan. “It cost us about $50,000,” he said, in a telephone interview on Tuesday. In rejecting “The Woman,” Michigan officials, citing content restrictions that sometimes affect state film subsidies, said that its graphic content would not cast Michigan in a positive light.

headline: Now, Chefs Court Farmers for the Best Ingredients
text: MIDDLEBURGH, N.Y.

headline: After Sports Careers, Vying in the Real Estate Arena
text: For years, the only involvement many retired athletes had with real estate was deciding where to open a steak house with their name on it.

text: Carpenter and chef. Father and son. They paused there, in tranquillity, amid all the construction-site bedlam on a recent morning at the nonexistent west wall of the forthcoming kitchen of Lincoln, the $20 million Italian restaurant scheduled to open this fall at Lincoln Center.

text: A 19th-century house in Virginia, a solar-domed home in Florida and a town house in California.

text: The Tea Party has officially entered the United States Congress.

headline: Cashman Sees Depth in Rotation, Not a Hole
text: The Yankees reported to work on Tuesday with their best record this late in a season since 1998. That is one of the 27 championship years listed on the wall above the right-field bleachers at Yankee Stadium. Another is 2009, which helps when considering the crisis of the moment.

headline: Top Editor at The Daily News Is Departing
text: The editor of The Daily News said Tuesday that he was leaving after seven years at the helm so he could care for his ailing wife, news that few in the paper’s newsroom saw coming. The News then promptly announced it had found a replacement in keeping with its tabloid tradition: the editor of The Boston Herald.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,175 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Baseball Players Join First Lady’s Anti-Obesity Campaign
text: Michelle Obama has enlisted Major League Baseball and its players’ association for a new public service advertising campaign to promote her program to eliminate childhood obesity.

headline: Bulldozers Meet Historic Chinese Neighborhood
text: BEIJING — Mao slept here. So, too, did the imperial eunuchs who found themselves unemployed after China’s last emperor was sent packing. For much of the last 700 years, however, the most prominent residents of the quarter just north of the Forbidden City have been a pair of massive brick towers whose drums and bells helped Beijing’s citizenry keep track of the hour.

headline: French Players Face Charges
text: The police detained two members of France’s World Cup team, Franck Ribéry and Karim Benzema, as part of an investigation into a high-end prostitution ring in Paris. Ribéry and Benzema are accused of soliciting sex from Zahia Dehar, 18, a prostitute who told the police she was a minor when she had sex with them. Though Dehar said recently she had not told them her age, the players will soon be questioned by a judge, according to the newspaper Le Monde. Prostitution is legal in France, but soliciting it is not, and clients risk a penalty of up to $60,300 and three years in jail for employing an under-age prostitute.

headline: Subpoena for Toyota Over Defects in Steering
text: A federal grand jury in New York has subpoenaed Toyota Motor, seeking information on steering-related defects in its vehicles. The move could widen an investigation into the automaker’s handling of a recall in 2005.

headline: U.S.C. President-Elect Cleans House
text: LOS ANGELES  The University of Southern California swiftly rebuked the key figures who helped land its athletic program on probation, firing the athletic director Mike Garrett, returning Reggie Bush’s Heisman Trophy, and beefing up the compliance staff. The university also plans to remove from campus jerseys and murals of Bush and the basketball star O. J. Mayo.

headline: U.S. Approves American-British Airline Alliance
text: American Airlines and British Airways won final approval on Tuesday to expand a trans-Atlantic alliance on flights between the United States and Europe.

headline: Suspect Denies Role in Kennedy Airport Plot
text: A former government official of Guyana testified on Tuesday that he was not involved in a chilling terrorism scheme aimed at New York City, saying that he had feigned interest in the plan because he hoped its architects would help him raise money to build a mosque.

headline: Questions in Officer’s Killing of C.E.O. in Newark
text: NEWARK  Returning to New Jersey for his 30th high school reunion, DeFarra Gaymon had the kind of life one would not mind describing to old friends: he was a C.E.O., married, father of four. But Mr. Gaymon, who was in the Chess Club, the French Club, the Italian Club and the student coalition at Montclair High School, never made it to the party on Friday night at the Crowne Plaza Meadowlands.

headline: City Is Owed $100 Million, and Is Ready to Get Tough
text: When the mayor’s office  with a certain amount of pardonable fanfare  released a report on Monday claiming it could save the city’s taxpayers $500 million using belt-tightening measures over the next four years, the No. 1 biggest item, at an estimated $100 million, was, to steal a phrase from the Gambino family, to pursue “enhanced enforcement against delinquent debtors.”

headline: Water Dispute Increases India-Pakistan Tension
text: BANDIPORE, Kashmir — In this high Himalayan valley on the Indian-controlled side of Kashmir, the latest battle line between India and Pakistan has been drawn.

headline: Bit by Electronic Bit, a Cantor’s Voice Is Restored
text: He was called the Jewish Caruso. Indeed, fervent enthusiasts sometimes referred to Caruso as the Italian Yossele Rosenblatt.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Urges Limits for Avastin
text: An advisory committee recommended on Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration revoke approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, saying the drug was not helping patients.

headline: Devils’ Deal With Kovalchuk Is Rejected by the N.H.L.
text: Hours after the Devils announced signing the high-scoring forward Ilya Kovalchuk to a 17-year, $102 million contract, the N.H.L. rejected it Tuesday night because it would circumvent the league’s salary cap.

headline: Piniella Is Ready for Retirement
text: The record will show that Lou Piniella announced his retirement Tuesday, the day after his starting pitcher gave up five runs in one inning. Piniella, a born hitter, never had much patience for pitchers. Once this tedious Chicago Cubs season ends, they will never torment him again.

headline: Ex-Official Says Afghan and Iraq Wars Increased Threats to Britain
text: LONDON  The former director general of Britain’s domestic intelligence agency said Tuesday that the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had greatly increased the terrorist threat to Britain and that intelligence available before the Iraq war had not been sufficient to justify the invasion of that country.

headline: Social Security Loses $50 Million a Year in Benefit Overpayment
text: Social Security is paying roughly $50 million a year too much to people who collect state pensions but fail to declare that income, according to the system’s inspector general.

headline: Maine Giving Social Security Another Look
text: Lawmakers in Maine have found an unusual tool for tackling their state’s pension woes: Social Security.

headline: Turkey: Kurdish Separatists Kill 6 Soldiers, Military Says
text: Six Turkish soldiers were killed by Kurdish separatists near the Iraq border, military officials said Tuesday. Militants from the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K., fired on an army unit Monday night, setting off a firefight that was joined by helicopters and land forces and that lasted until morning in the Cukurca area of Hakkari Province. The P.K.K. accuses the government of not being serious in its stated effort to increase the rights of Turkey’s nearly 12 million Kurds.

headline: A Smell of Pot and Privilege in the City
text: The Bloomberg administration has quietly been fixing up its sons and daughters with cool summer internships, as reported Tuesday in The New York Times. Which is probably fine: It is hard to see nepotism as much of a sin when it is really just another chapter of Darwinism, the drive possessed by all creatures to finagle a better future for their offspring.

headline: In Newark, a Contract and a City Are Worlds Apart
text: NEWARK  Inside the tall glass atrium of Prudential Center on Tuesday, well-dressed people smiled and congratulated one another for the 17-year, $102 million contract that the Devils handed to Ilya Kovalchuk.

headline: Shutdown of Blogging Site Sparks Dispute
text: A free blogging site, Blogetery.com, went dark less than two weeks ago, and its disappearance is stirring controversy about the obligations of Internet services and threats to free speech on the Web.

headline: The Dreaded P-Word?
text: IT’S no surprise that in recent years some on the left have embraced the term “progressive” as a substitute for “liberal.” The right has so demonized “the L-word” that during a Democratic debate in 2007, Hillary Clinton, asked by a voter whether she was a liberal, said that she preferred to identify herself as  of course  a “modern progressive.”

text: Years later, Grace Dunham still remembers a typical sixth-grade day at St. Ann’s School: She played guitar, made papier-mâché aliens for Jupiter’s moon Europa, went to puppetry, had some lunch and then dropped an egg off a balcony for a project that involved creating protective covers to prevent eggs from breaking.

Sampson, the State Senate leader, performed legal work for a Queens real estate broker who was being investigated by state authorities on allegations of fraud and predatory lending, and was disciplined for acting as a notary for the broker after his notary license had expired, according to state documents.

headline: Britain’s Leader Carves Identity as Budget Cutter
text: LONDON — In the five years David Cameron spent rebuilding the Conservative Party in opposition, opinion polls showed that as he sought to rebrand it by offering a compassionate but persistently fuzzy image, voters had trouble defining what sort of a prime minister he would make.

headline: Perfection in the Horseshoe Pit
text: DEFIANCE, Ohio  From behind a neat, ranch-style house on Melody Lane came the clinking and clanking rhythm of iron striking iron.

headline: For Those Deported, Court Rulings Come Too Late
text: Vincenzo Donnoli was 9 when his family immigrated legally to Brooklyn. He attended Erasmus Hall High School, married and divorced in Flatbush, ran a landscaping business and had five children. But at 51 he is back  alone and jobless  in Pomarico, the hill town in southern Italy where his father was a shepherd, as a deportee banned for life from returning to the United States.

headline: Governor to Offer Plan to Overhaul Atlantic City
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is expected to announce plans on Wednesday for an overhaul of the troubled Atlantic City gambling district and the possible closing of the ailing Meadowlands Racetrack, an adviser to the governor said Tuesday.

headline: Overcome by Heat and Inertia
text: WASHINGTON

headline: What 7 Republicans Could Do
text: The hour is late, but there is still a sliver of time to pass a serious energy bill out of this Congress. To do so, though, would require President Obama to rustle up votes with a passion that he has failed to exhibit up to now, and, more importantly, it would require at least seven Republican senators to put the national interest above party and politics. Yes, I know that is all unlikely. You can laugh now. But just remember this: If we don’t get a serious energy bill out of this Congress, and Republicans retake the House and Senate, we may not have another shot until the next presidential term or until we get a “perfect storm”  a climate or energy crisis that is awful enough to finally end our debate on these issues but not so awful as to end the world. But, hey, by 2012, China should pretty much own the clean-tech industry and we’ll at least be able to get some good deals on electric cars.

headline: Goldman’s Go-Round
text: When Goldman Sachs released its first-quarter results in April, its strong profits were overshadowed by news of a lawsuit from the Securities and Exchange Commission accusing the firm of fraud in a sale of mortgage-related securities. When it released its second-quarter results on Tuesday, its plunging profits  down 82 percent from the same period a year earlier  overshadowed the $550 million it paid to settle the S.E.C. case last week.

headline: After Talking of Testimony, Blagojevich May Bypass It
text: CHICAGO  For months, Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, has made it clear to anyone who would listen that he planned to testify in his corruption trial. In fact, he suggested, he could barely wait another instant to get up there and tell his story.

headline: A Promising Preventive
text: It is easy to understand why the results of a modest-size scientific study in South Africa were met with ecstatic applause on Tuesday at an international AIDS conference in Vienna. Researchers have shown that a vaginal gel could cut a woman’s risk of infection with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, by almost 40 percent.

headline: Knicks Won’t Let Stoudemire Play at World Championship
text: As they moved from handshake to signature to news conference, the Knicks accepted certain risks with Amar’e Stoudemire. For $100 million, they got an elite player, but one who had serious knee and eye operations in the last five years.

headline: Five and Five: No. 45, Nevada
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 45, is Nevada. You can find a larger Nevada preview here.

headline: Hiring and Fairness
text: Boston, Chicago and San Francisco set a welcome example earlier in the decade when they abandoned counterproductive policies that often barred former offenders from municipal jobs, no matter how minor their crime nor how distant in the past. Connecticut, New Mexico and Minnesota have recently passed laws protecting the employment rights of former offenders. Other states should quickly follow.

headline: California’s Great De-Rocking Debate
text: Pity poor serpentine, the official state rock in California. After 45 years, it is in danger of being dethroned.

headline: Pettitte Is Hoping for Early Return
text: Andy Pettitte was back in the Yankee Stadium clubhouse Tuesday before his team opened a two-game series with the Los Angeles Angels, and his disposition was, as usual, friendly and plain-spoken.

headline: West Virginia Governor to Seek Byrd’s Senate Seat
text: Joe Manchin III, West Virginia’s popular Democratic governor, announced on Tuesday that he would run in this year’s special election for the Senate seat formerly held by the late Robert C. Byrd.

headline: Georgia Will Have Republican Primary Runoff
text: ATLANTA — Karen Handel, a former secretary of state who was endorsed by Sarah Palin, came in first in Georgia’s Republican gubernatorial primary Tuesday evening and will face Nathan Deal, a former Congressman, in an Aug. 10 runoff.

headline: Lover’s Woe
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — MONET or MANET? Which are you going to go with when you need a five-letter Impressionist painter? Here’s my rule of thumb. If the subject is a person like Olympia or the absinthe drinker, it’s Manet all the way. For natural settings like haystacks or water lilies, or for buildings, go with Monet. “Manet for mankind” is my mantra. It works today.

headline: Eyewear, With a Bit of Disney and a Touch of Apple
text: A wind tunnel. A concierge. A store that’s shaped like an eyeball.

headline: Fans Jockey as Rodriguez Nears 600
text: Kevin Long, the Yankees’ hitting coach, did not know how to describe what he saw, but he said he sensed a special focus lately in Alex Rodriguez. His 600th home run could be here sooner rather than later.

headline: Sweet Lou and A-Rod: Tough Love in Seattle
text: It may be hard to remember now, but Alex Rodriguez was viewed with reverence when he played for the Seattle Mariners from 1994 through 2000. A lot has changed since he left.

headline: Perez Is Back and Bound for the Bullpen
text: PHOENIX  Reunion week continued for the Mets on Tuesday as another player from the recent past trickled in. With little fanfare or reception, Oliver Perez returned to the team for the first time in six weeks, and he is expected to be activated Wednesday to begin his new career as a reliever.

headline: Staying at Home, With a Little Help
text: As states face severe budget shortfalls, many have cut home-care services for the elderly and  the disabled.

headline: Fed in Hot Seat Again on Economic Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON  With unemployment high and inflation low, a question is being asked more often and more loudly: Can and should the Federal Reserve do more to get the economy moving?

headline: House Panel’s NASA Spending Bill Cuts Back Obama Plan
text: An authorization bill put together by a House committee for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration would greatly scale back President Obama’s plans to spur a commercial market for the launching of people into space and would direct the agency to continue developing its own rocket.

headline: Goldman Keeps Pay Ratio at 43% of Revenue
text: Is Goldman Sachs rebasing compensation at a lower level? For a second quarter in a row, the investment bank’s pay ratio was 43 percent of revenue; in the past, Goldman paid out around 50 percent to staff. For ordinary mortals, the numbers are still staggering: on an annualized basis, $545,000 is being set aside for each of the firm’s employees. But it does look like Goldman might finally be listening to its critics.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a dispute over the play “Imagining Madoff,” by Deborah Margolin, misstated the number of characters in another of her plays, “Three Seconds in the Key.” There are seven; it is not a one-woman show.

headline: France: Check Your Jacket, Sir?
text: The French police have arrested an Air France flight attendant accused of stealing tens of thousands of dollars in cash, traveler’s checks and jewelry from dozing business-class passengers on dozens of international flights, judicial officials said Tuesday. Authorities arrested the flight attendant on the tarmac at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris early Friday, according to a report in the newspaper Le Figaro. An investigation began in January after five passengers aboard an Air France flight to Paris from Tokyo reported the disappearance of a total of $5,000 in cash.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: In Colombia, Pillories and the Lonely Planet People
text: I love visiting Colombia, for much the same reasons that I love visiting the Bronx: both are saddled with outdated reputations that scare people away from visiting, which makes for fewer visitors, which makes them even better places to visit.

headline: Japan: Decision on U.S. Base Not Likely Before November
text: Japan’s defense minister said Tuesday that a decision on relocating an American air base on Okinawa may not be possible until at least November, further delaying resolution of a dispute that has hurt Tokyo’s relations with Washington. The defense minister, Toshimi Kitazawa, said a decision might have to wait until after a local governor’s election, as his government faces stiff local resistance to keeping the base, the United States Marine Air Station Futenma, on the island. Japan’s former prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, had announced that Tokyo would move the base to a less populated part of the island. But Okinawans fiercely oppose the base, which has become a symbol of a heavy American military presence.

headline: Burundi: Journalist Who Criticized Military Is Charged With Treason
text: A journalist has been arrested and charged with treason for publishing an article suggesting that Burundi’s military was not capable of defending the country against terrorist attacks, Human Rights Watch said Tuesday. The group condemned the arrest on Saturday of Jean-Claude Kavumbagu, the editor of the online news agency Net Press, for writing in a July 12 article that the Shabab, a militant Islamist insurgency in Somalia, could easily attack Burundi. The Shabab have claimed responsibility for bombings in Kampala, Uganda, that killed 76 people, many of whom were watching televised soccer matches on the last day of the World Cup. The terrorist group has threatened to next attack Burundi, which contributes troops to the African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia.

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ Gang Returns to the Beach
text: MTV has signed new contracts with its biggest stars: the cast of “Jersey Shore.”

headline: Democrats Have Edge in Money
text: The Democratic House and Senate campaign committees have a $19 million edge in fund-raising over Republicans, according to disclosure reports filed Tuesday, an advantage that Democrats hope will help protect their majorities in Congress in the midterm elections. In the House, the re-election committees for Democrats and Republicans each raised $9 million in June. But after the first six months of the year, Democrats have $34 million in the bank, compared with $17 million for Republicans. In the Senate, Democrats outperformed Republicans last month, raising $7 million compared with $4 million. Yet Democrats have only a slight edge in the amount of money on hand, with $22 million, compared with $20 million for Republicans. The financial edge, a bright spot for Democrats in a challenging environment, will allow the party to invest more in competitive races and begin television advertising earlier.

headline: Avoiding an Injury, Hughes Still Exits Early
text: In their previous two games before Tuesday night, the Yankees lost two starting pitchers early because of injury.

headline: Young Players Show Sharp Skills in Biel
text: Three players are tied for first after two hard-fought rounds at a tournament featuring some of the top young players in the world.

headline: Fireworks on Memorial Day
text: It was Memorial Day evening and the scanner was pretty quiet. I went for coffee and a doughnut in Upper Manhattan when the police dispatcher came over with: explosion — the bomb squad, emergency services unit and Fire Department are rushing to the scene, at Murray Street and 27th Avenue, Queens. There had been cookouts and block parties. People were standing around, watching the firefighters. The majority of homes had American flags draped on them. The air was filled with the sounds of fire engines, walkie-talkies and news reporters asking questions. Neighbors had baffled looks. Police officers stood guard behind the yellow tape, waiting to find out what happened.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Certain Types of Sneakers Prevent Injuries?
text: A few years ago, the military began analyzing the shapes of recruits’ feet. Injuries during basic training were rampant, and military authorities hoped that by fitting soldiers with running shoes designed for their foot types, injury rates would drop. Trainees obediently began clambering onto a high-tech light table with a mirror beneath it, designed to help outline a subject’s foot. Evaluators classified the recruits as having high, normal or low arches, and they passed out running shoes accordingly.

headline: A Prettier Way to Browse the Social Web
text: A new iPad application makes Twitter and Facebook feeds a whole lot prettier.

headline: Many States Adopt National Standards for Their Schools
text: Less than two months after the nation’s governors and state school chiefs released their final recommendations for national education standards, 27 states have adopted them and about a dozen more are expected to do so in the next two weeks.

headline: Runs Are What Mets Need

headline: Weak Times Sq. Car Bomb Is Called Intentional
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Tuesday that the failed Times Square car bomber, Faisal Shahzad, deliberately purchased weak bomb ingredients in an effort to avoid detection by the authorities.

headline: A Punch and a Counterpunch in Pennsylvania Senate Race
text: This hard-hitting advertisement against Representative Joe Sestak, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Pennsylvania, marks the debut of a hawkish, pro-Israel group, the Emergency Committee for Israel, led by William Kristol, editor of the conservative Weekly Standard. It also serves as a shot across the bow to candidates in other states whom Mr. Kristol and his fellow neoconservatives deem insufficiently supportive of Israel. The 30-second advertisement began running July 13 in Philadelphia and its suburbs on CNN and Fox and appeared during two Phillies games; it is to run through early next week.

Gates.

headline: Can Greece’s Rail System Scare Up an Investor?

text: Since he took over as energy secretary last year, Steven Chu, a Nobel laureate in physics, has urged Americans to help cool the planet by painting their roofs a lighter color that reflects sunlight.

headline: Former Kosovo Leader to Be Retried
text: PARIS  More than two years after trial judges acquitted the former prime minister of Kosovo of murder, rape and torture, an appeals panel at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague on Wednesday ordered him to be retried because the intimidation of witnesses had undermined his trial and produced “a miscarriage of justice.”

text: MOSCOW  Militants attacked a hydroelectric power plant in Russia’s restive North Caucasus region on Wednesday, killing two guards before setting off several bombs that forced the facility to be shut down, Russian investigators said.
