headline: The Web Means the End of Forgetting
text: Four years ago, Stacy Snyder, then a 25-year-old teacher in training at Conestoga Valley High School in Lancaster, Pa., posted a photo on her MySpace page that showed her at a party wearing a pirate hat and drinking from a plastic cup, with the caption “Drunken Pirate.” After discovering the page, her supervisor at the high school told her the photo was “unprofessional,” and the dean of Millersville University School of Education, where Snyder was enrolled, said she was promoting drinking in virtual view of her under-age students. As a result, days before Snyder’s scheduled graduation, the university denied her a teaching degree. Snyder sued, arguing that the university had violated her First Amendment rights by penalizing her for her (perfectly legal) after-hours behavior. But in 2008, a federal district judge rejected the claim, saying that because Snyder was a public employee whose photo didn’t relate to matters of public concern, her “Drunken Pirate” post was not protected speech.

headline: Wednesday Reading: More on Unemployment

headline: Orchestras Seek BFF by Cellphone Texts

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Releases Longer Video of Sherrod Speech
text: The president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People apologized Tuesday to a black civil servant whose ouster the civil rights organization had originally cheered.  Shirley Sherrod was fired from the Department of Agriculture for remarks she made in a speech in March. But after a 43-minute video was released putting her remarks into context, Benjamin T. Jealous, the N.A.A.C.P. president, apologized. On The Lede blog, you can watch the longer clip and compare it to the shorter version that was originally circulated.

headline: From ‘Cage’ to ‘Desert': Upward Mobility in Drag Queen Roles
text: Nick Adams is moving up in the world of drag queens. The musical theater actor, currently in the Broadway revival of “La Cage aux Folles” as the crabbiest of the Cagelle dancers, Angelique, has been cast in the meatier role of the catty drag queen Felicia in the North American company of the musical “Priscilla, Queen of the Desert.”

headline: Seeking to Shine (Not to Be Shiny)

headline: A New Chapter for the Cubs and U.S.C.
text: The house cleanings came on the same day, but in different time zones and might as well have been in different universes, for all the two organizations had in common. Cubs Manager Lou Piniella announced his retirement Tuesday, departing as a man widely considered an excellent manager done in by a cursed and/or serially mismanaged franchise. That came on the same day that the University of Southern California, a storied, über-successful franchise, axed the man who was widely considered a colossally bad manager,, athletic director Mike Garrett.

headline: Morgan Stanley Faulted on Tax Windfall Disclosure

headline: Now Booking | Sweden’s Treehotel
text: If the Jetsons relocated to the Swedish Arctic, they might feel right at home at the new Treehotel, which opened officially a few days ago. The project is a collection of four houses perched among the pine trees in the village of Harads. The husband-and-wife team Britta and Kent Lindvall, along with a few of their architect and designer friends, dreamed up the structures, which range from the outrageous to the opulent. There’s the aggressively twiggy Nest and the trippy Mirrorcube, a 13-by-13-foot mass wrapped in mirrored glass (tinted with an ultraviolet, invisible-to-humans color that deflects birds), along with the Cabin, which is situated over the slope of a hill overlooking the Lulea River. The view from the deck changes literally with the wind, but don’t worry: urban planning students from the nearby Lulua University can vouch for its safety. The compound also has a tree sauna and a tree breakfast-and-meeting room. Two more houses — the disc-shaped UFO and the self-explanatory Room With a View — are set to open in the fall.

headline: Rep. Capito Passes on Senate Run
text: Representative Shelley Moore Capito, widely viewed as the Republicans’ best hope in West Virginia’s special Senate election, announced Wednesday that she was passing on the race.

headline: Thailand Revokes Visa of Russian Musician Accused of Rape
text: Thailand has revoked the visa of the Russian conductor and pianist Mikhail Pletnev, who has a home there, after his arrest this month on charges that he raped a 14-year-old boy. An Agence France-Presse report quoted a Thai immigration official as saying on Wednesday that Mr. Pletnev, the founder of the Russian National Orchestra, could be deported even if the child rape charges were dropped.

headline: For Oysters, a ‘Remedy’ Turned Catastrophe
text: In late April, just days into what has turned out to be the largest oil spill in American history, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, with the support of local parish officials, ordered the opening of giant valves on the Mississippi River, releasing torrents of freshwater that they hoped would push oil back out to sea.

headline: Bad Weather Could Delay Work on Well, Official Says
text: Bad weather may delay work at BP’s well in the Gulf of Mexico, but even if the sea and sky remain relatively calm, additional precautions will be taken before any effort is made to permanently stem the flow of oil, the official overseeing the federal spill response said Wednesday.

headline: Like Lemmings, but Wetter
text: Here is one more indicator for the Summer 2010 Heat Index: Attendance at city beaches is through the sizzling blue roof and has already far surpassed the total for all of last year.

headline: Refusing to Quit the Tour de France
text: While Lance Armstrong’s attempt to win Tuesday’s stage of the Tour de France at the age of 38 stole the headlines, Jens Voigt, a German support rider on a rival team who is one day older than the former champion, won praise from many cycling fans just for refusing to quit the race.

headline: Yankees Waiting for Granderson to Get Hot
text: Curtis Granderson went 7 for 16 in the Yankees’ four-game series in Seattle leading into the All-Star break. He is 2 for 15 with six strikeouts since, causing Joe Girardi to wonder whether the four-day layoff came at a bad time for Granderson. The break might not have helped Granderson, but it is hard to gauge exactly how much it has hurt him. The whole season, Granderson acknowledged, has been a struggle for him, as reflected by his .233 average heading into Wednesday’s game against the Angels.

headline: Gap Plugged in Nuclear Fusion Project

headline: ‘Anything Goes’ Returns to Broadway in March
text: Reno Sweeney has a Broadway theater and performance dates. Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday that its revival of “Anything Goes,” starring Sutton Foster (“Thoroughly Modern Millie”) as the spunky singer Reno, will begin preview performances on March 10 at the Stephen Sondheim Theater (formerly Henry Miller’s Theater) and open on April 7. Kathleen Marshall is directing the Cole Porter musical, which will feature a new book by Timothy Crouse and John Weidman, based on the original book by P.G. Wodehouse, Guy Bolton, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse.

headline: London Theater Journal: Mark Rylance, With an Accent
text: The ghost of Molière keeps showing up at the same place in London, a rather surly specter with only slight variations in his disguise. The last time I visited the Comedy Theater, in January, it was to see Martin Crimp’s contemporary reworking of Molière’s “Misanthrope,” which had Londoners lining up to see a beautiful British movie star (Keira Knightley by name) play a beautiful American movie star.

text: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the Republican minority leader, said Wednesday that the nation was hungry for government to provide a check-and-balance on the administration, but he conceded that he did not know how the two parties would work together if Republicans won in November.

headline: Making the Video as Good as the Trip

headline: From Untouchable to Businesswoman
text: PLENTY of people exchanging free hugs in Times Square last Sunday traveled a long way to reach New York, but it’s safe to say that few covered anything like the distances Kakuben Lalabhai Parmar had. This is not just a matter of mileage, although certainly it’s a hike from Madhutra, a rural village in the western Indian state of Gujarat, to 42nd Street.

headline: After Talk of Testifying, Blagojevich Bypasses It
text: CHICAGO  Since his arrest in late 2008, Rod R. Blagojevich, the indicted former governor of Illinois, has proclaimed his innocence in a published memoir, on couches beside numerous talk show hosts and to just about any random well-wisher who approached him on the street.

headline: Belts That Spare Muffy the Heartbreak
text: THEY used to call it the breakup belt. Women (and it has always been women) of a certain sort and class historically committed themselves to memorializing the bonds of a relationship by stitching a needlepoint belt for the Loved One. The motifs varied: a monogram, a family cipher, an Old School motto, a series of signal flags. It should be obvious, of course, how unwise it is to add emotion to handwork, how every needle thrust and stitch signifies a debt in labor and love that cannot be repaid.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Rehearsals to Start (Finally)

headline: Warhol, Target: It’s All Good
text: STEPHEN BURROWS, a breakthrough African-American designer, once picked up inspiration from Halston and Warhol, hanging out at Max’s Kansas City and Studio 54. Now he’s teamed up with Target, which is opening in Harlem this Sunday. “Doing a project like this would have been the kiss of death,” Mr. Burrows said. “Now it is a source of creativity.” The line shows off his signature bold colors (pictured with him from left, hand print T-shirt, $19.99, and leopard skirt, $24.99; hooded dress, $34.99; and off-shoulder dress, $34.99). The Target store, its first in Manhattan, will also have lines from Isabel and Ruben Toledo and Marcus Samuelsson. East Harlem Target, 517 East 117 Street, (212) 835-0860. The Burrows line will be available in limited quantities Aug. 1 at target.com.

headline: 4 Oil Firms Commit $1 Billion for Gulf Rapid-Response Plan

headline: Garment Factories, Changing Women’s Roles in Poor Countries
text: While visiting garment factories in Bangladesh on assignment recently, I met young women who had migrated from villages to the city in search of jobs that they needed to support their families back home. It is a fairly standard story in this part of the world.

headline: So Far, Biel Is a Just So Story
text: After three rounds, Wesley So of the Philippines leads the elite section of the Biel Chess Festival.

headline: Nilas Martins Retires From City Ballet
text: Nilas Martins, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, has quietly retired from the company after several seasons of dwindling appearances. The City Ballet spokesman, Rob Daniels, confirmed the departure of Mr. Martins — the son of Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief — after the company’s brochure for next season appeared without the dancer’s name, although he is still listed on City Ballet’s Web site. Four other principals retired this past season, some with fanfare, including the star Darci Kistler, who is the wife of Peter Martins. Nilas Martins decided to leave after being accepted late in the season as a fellow at the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center, Mr. Daniels said, adding that Mr.  Martins underwent knee surgery in the winter and performed only a few times in the spring.

headline: Facebook Tops 500 Million Users
text: Facebook, the social network created in the dormitories of Harvard six years ago, said on Wednesday that it now had 500 million members.

headline: Shoppers on a ‘Diet’ Tame the Urge to Buy

headline: Airgas Rejects Latest Air Products Takeover Bid

headline: Choice, Referendum and Midterm Elections’ Real Meaning

headline: Simmons Is Back in Conn. Senate Race

headline: Japanese Reggae?
text: The Japanese have been making reggae almost as long as Jamaicans have been exporting it. This phenomenon could have started as early as the mid-’70s, when the film “The Harder They Come” grafted the crime drama to Kingston’s reggae scene and became an international cult classic. Or, more likely, it began sometime around 1979, when Bob Marley landed for the first time in the Land of the Rising Sun. Since then, the reggae scene in Japan has cycled through several styles and sub-subcultures, but only in recent years has one crucial aspect of its identity fully emerged: Finally,  Japanese reggae stars are singing in Japanese.

headline: As Honda Ramps Up E.V.’s and Hybrids, Fuel Cell Program Lags
text: TORRANCE, Calif. — Honda’s program on the FCX Clarity hydrogen fuel cell vehicle marks the two-year anniversary on Sunday of delivery of the first cars to retail customers.

headline: French Riders Rise Amid Tougher Testing
text: PAU, France  The Frenchmen in the Tour de France welcomed Wednesday’s day off from racing, but not simply because they needed to rest their bodies before the final push to Paris, where the 2,263-mile Tour ends Sunday. Those riders also needed time to let their success sink in.

headline: Making Action Videos

headline: Madoff Trustee Seeks $3.6 Billion From Hedge Fund

headline: At-Bat, Shared by Two Hitters, Ends on Three-Run Homer
text: When Colin Curtis gulped his cup of Gatorade and jumped off the Yankees’ bench to grab a bat during the seventh inning at Yankee Stadium, it was right around lunchtime in suburban Seattle, where his parents live. They often watch his games on the Internet, but only later did it occur to Curtis that on Wednesday, of all days, they may not have been watching.

headline: Estate Tax Hiatus Could Reduce Charitable Bequests
text: Strange as it may sound, the elimination of the federal estate tax this year could actually reduce incentives for rich people to leave bequests to charities.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks Mutual Fund Fee Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday proposed new limits on the sales fees that mutual fund companies charge investors on shares that are sold through brokers.

headline: Theater for a New Audience to Stage ‘Merchant’
text: New York theatergoers may have their choice of Shylocks during the 2010-11 season.

headline: Hitting the Road, With Apps
text: I was about to embark on a three-and-a-half-hour trek home to Connecticut from Maine after a beach weekend. I had two youngsters in the back seat and, my wife and I would quickly discover, no food.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: Fire from Israeli shells killed a Palestinian militant and wounded seven people, including a 10-year-old girl, in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, Reuters reported, citing reports from Palestinian medical workers and an official with a militant group. An Israeli military spokeswoman said soldiers opened fire on militants suspected of preparing to fire a rocket at them. Officials with a militant group active in Gaza said the dead man was one of their members.

headline: Conrad Black Released From Jail on $2 Million Bond
text: A federal judge in Chicago released the former newspaper baron Conrad M. Black from prison on $2 million bond on Wednesday, while she decides whether to throw out his 2007 conviction for defrauding shareholders of Hollinger International, Reuters reports.

headline: New Guidelines Seek to Reduce Repeat Caesareans
text: Most women who have had Caesarean sections can safely give birth the normal way later, studies have shown, but in recent years hospitals, doctors and insurers have been refusing to let them even try, insisting on repeat Caesareans instead.

headline: Souls Suspended on a String in the Shadows of a Russian City Under Siege
text: War buffs who can settle down in front of the History channel for marathon viewings are decidedly not the audience for “The Battle of Stalingrad,” the puppet-theater piece by the Georgian writer and director Rezo Gabriadze that returns to the Lincoln Center Festival this year after first being presented in 2002. (It replaces a new show of his that was not completed in time for the run.) In spite of its documentary-worthy title, Mr. Gabriadze’s play is not a straightforward dramatization of that monumental and bloody battle but a quirky theatrical poem on the vagaries of life itself.

headline: Bits Pics: Robot Competitions
text: The robots in these photos are being controlled by contestants in China’s tenth annual National Robot Competition.

headline: Senate Ballot Grows in West Virginia
text: Representative Shelley Moore Capito may not be running in this year’s special Senate election in West Virginia – but at least one of Gov. Joe Manchin III’s fellow Democrats is.

headline: Putting the Egg in Eggplant Parmigiana
text: Eggplants have started to appear in New York farmers’ markets, and tomatoes are not far off. In fact, there were non-greenhouse tomatoes at the Union Square Greenmarket as early as the second week in July. This means that my fancy has turned to thoughts of eggplant parmigiana, as it does even out of season.

headline: Pity the Supplicant, Beware the Gatekeeper
text: Anyone who has waited in line at the post office or tried to get some officious bureaucrat to process an application will respond to the central dilemma of “La Porta Della Legge,” the Italian composer Salvatore Sciarrino’s latest opera, which had its North American premiere courtesy of the Lincoln Center Festival on Tuesday night at John Jay College.

headline: David Cameron, Conservative
text: Prior to his ascension to 10 Downing Street, David Cameron’s leadership of Britain’s Tories tended to inspire sympathetic noises from what you might call “reformist” American conservatives — including Reihan Salam, David Frum, David Brooks, and of course yours truly. Others were more skeptical, to put it mildly. National Review’s The Corner, for instance, was thick with election-time dismissals of Cameron’s unprincipled squishiness, and grim predictions about how the “shallow, pandering” Tory leader would no doubt sell out the cause of small government to at the first opportunity.

headline: The Colonial Era, Updated
text: American heritage brands may be all the rage, but between the fixation on what purists refer to as “brand DNA” and the obsession with details like historically correct socks, things are starting to feel a little earnest — never a good look. What happened to the fun of dressing up?

headline: No Money to Fix Your Car? Write a Best Seller
text: Getting his name on a best-seller list seems like an effortless task for Ken Follett these days, but it took more than a few tries before this prodigious genre author made it there. Mr. Follett spent the better part of the 1970s working as a newspaper journalist and book publisher in Britain before writing his first few novels, none of which endured.

headline: ‘The Korean War’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Peter Stein Withdraws from ‘Boris Godunov’
text: The German director Peter Stein has withdrawn from a major new Metropolitan Opera production, Mussorgsky’s “Boris Godunov,” scheduled to open in October, for personal reasons the Met said on Wednesday. Stephen Wadsworth will take his place. The high-profile production will be conducted by Valery Gergiev and star René Pape who will sing “Boris” for the first time at the house. A Met spokesman declined to elaborate. Performances are scheduled to run in October and March. Mr. Stein recently directed the marathon production of the “The Demons” on Governors Island as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: Carpet-Bombing Falsehoods About a War That’s Little Understood
text: North Korea, like Cuba, is a country suspended in time, one that exists off modernity’s grid. It’s a place where the cold war never ended, where the heirloom paranoia is taken down and polished daily.

headline: A Feline Matron, Catnip for Seasoned Actresses
text: AS conceived by Ingmar Bergman in “Smiles of a Summer Night,” the long-retired courtesan Mrs. Armfeldt whom film audiences met in 1955 was not quite the creature we know as Madame Armfeldt in Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler’s latter-day operetta “A Little Night Music.” Mrs. Armfeldt, Bergman writes in the screenplay, is “a very small lady,” first discovered in a very large room, sitting in her bed, which is also enormous, amusing herself with her morning solitaire. There she receives a fateful visit from her actress daughter, the glamorous, fraying Desirée.

headline: Restricted Access and Over-Sharing
text: There are many pleasurable things that do not distract from completing a full day’s work. A cup of coffee in the morning. A friendly dog.

headline: Beauty Spots
Street Life as Still Life
text: SINCE the mid-1960s, when the plein-air artist Rackstraw Downes began painting New York City’s ventilation towers, highway underpasses, demolition sites and dumps, “I’ve seen some funny things, let me tell you,” he said.

headline: A Business Built of Kewpie Dolls Is Struggling to Survive
text: For most of the 78 years since its founding in Omaha, the Oriental Trading Company has been the life of the party.

headline: ‘Bad Boy’ Star Loses Support Abroad
text: LOS ANGELES  Mel Gibson’s recorded rants, now part of a domestic violence investigation here, are taking a toll where it can hurt an aging action star the most: among foreign film buyers.

headline: Unseen Kafka Writings Inch Closer To The Light
text: A list of manuscripts, letters and journals written by Franz Kafka that languished in safety deposit boxes in Tel Aviv and Zurich for decades will soon be released, the Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Mad Men’-ese
text: As the fourth season of the AMC series “Mad Men” kicks off, some of the show’s fans are gearing up to play another round of a peculiar language game: trying to spot flaws in the meticulously constructed dialogue portraying 1960s Madison Avenue.

headline: Eminem’s Tops Again
text: Eminem has notched a fourth week at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, beating out new albums by Korn, Newsboys, Sting and M.I.A. Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) sold another 196,000 copies in the United States last week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Korn’s “Korn III: Remember Who You Are” (Roadrunner) is the highest charting new release, opening at No. 2 with 63,000 sales. Other new albums included “Born Again” (Inpop) by the Christian rock band Newsboys, which reached No. 4 with 45,000 sales. Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 3 with 50,000 sales and, in its 17th week on the chart, Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) sold 41,000 copies to take the fifth spot, bringing its total to just under 1.5 million.

headline: Reality Leads the Pack
text: Reality shows delivered the highest ratings on Tuesday night as “America’s Got Talent” and “Hell’s Kitchen” tied as the night’s top-rated programs among viewers 18 to 49, the demographic most favored by advertisers. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC’s “America’s Got Talent” easily won over the largest audience in total viewers, 10.4 million, while “Hell’s Kitchen,” broadcast an hour earlier, on Fox, from 8 to 10 p.m., garnered a much smaller audience of 6.5 million. Fox ranked third for the night, lagging behind both NBC and CBS, which broadcast a lineup of repeats including “NCIS” (9.6 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (7.1 million), and “The Good Wife” (5.3 million). ABC was fourth over all for the night, despite a strong showing for its reality show “Wipeout” at 8 (8.3 million). ABC’s “Downfall” at 9 drew a less impressive 3.3 million viewers while “Primetime” garnered 3 million at 10.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Rehearsals to Start
text: Julie Taymor’s musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” looks increasingly like a go for Broadway. After a year of uncertainty about the fate of the $50 million extravaganza, a spokesman for the show said on Wednesday that Ms. Taymor and the full cast of the show were scheduled to begin rehearsals on Aug. 16. Choreography rehearsals, including aerial flying lessons, began on Monday for the actor-musician Reeve Carney, who will play Peter Parker and his web-slinging alter-ego Spider-Man, and some cast members. An announcement is likely soon about performance dates for the show, which has music and lyrics by U2’s Bono and the Edge. Preview performances are expected to start in November at the Hilton Theater.

headline: Mad Men City | Answers From a Real Mad Man
text: Following is the first set of responses from Ed McCabe, who worked for a number of major advertising agencies and is a founder of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. La Guardia and J.F.K. to get full-body scanners. Metropolitan area starts practicing sucking in stomach.

headline: A ‘Merchant’ Encore
text: Off Broadway’s Theater for a New Audience announced on Wednesday that its critically acclaimed 2007 production of “The Merchant of Venice,” starring F. Murray Abraham as Shylock and directed by Darko Tresnjak, will return to New York for a two-week run starting Feb. 27, at Pace University’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts. “Merchant” is one of four productions on the new 2010-11 schedule. (It is also a play that is now enjoying another much-praised run in New York, starring Al Pacino as Shylock at the Delacorte Theater; the Public Theater is considering a Broadway transfer for that production.) Theater for a New Audience will also produce a “Macbeth” that will reunite the director Arin Arbus, right, and the actor John Douglas Thompson, below right, who enjoyed critical and audience praise for their 2009 production of “Othello.” Mr. Thompson played the title role in that production, as he will in “Macbeth,” which is scheduled to run from March 12 to April 22 at the Duke on 42nd Street. To start the season the theater company will present Yale Repertory Theater’s “Notes from Underground” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center’s Jerome Robbins Theater Nov. 7 to 20. The fourth production will be the Off Broadway debut of the New York company Fiasco Theater and its production of Shakespeare’s “Cymbeline,” which will run Jan. 13 to 30 at the New Victory Theater.

headline: Shultz PBS Series Raises Ethics Questions
text: A three-part PBS series about the former secretary of state George P. Shultz, near right, with President Ronald Reagan, has come under scrutiny for its financing ties to Mr. Shultz’s friends and associates. Michael Getler, the PBS ombudsman, has sided with the critics, writing in a column on Friday on PBS.org that the series suffered from “at least the appearance of a conflict of interest,” adding, “It doesn’t mean that funders exerted any editorial influence, but it left me feeling they didn’t have to.” The connections were listed in a review in The New York Times, and liberal media-monitoring groups like FAIR encouraged people to complain to PBS. Even before the first installment of the series, “Turmoil and Triumph,” had its debut on July 12, it was knocked by television critics for being too long and for treating its subject with reverence. Mr. Getler said he thought the “deification of Shultz” was unnecessary and distracting. PBS said in a statement that it believed the series “fully meets our standards for editorial integrity” and reiterated that “no PBS funder is permitted to exercise editorial control over content.”

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ a Go
text: MTV has signed new contracts with its biggest stars: those from “Jersey Shore.” MTV said Tuesday night that the cast members would be back for the show’s third season. The announcement is a vote of confidence in the show, given that the second season does not even start until next week. The young regulars  including Nicole Polizzi, better known as Snooki (above right, with Jenni Farley, a k a Jwoww), and Mike Sorrentino, better known as the Situation  became breakout stars when the boozy reality show made its debut last winter. An MTV spokeswoman confirmed that one of the eight cast members, Angelina Pivarnick, would not return for the third season. Some cast mates discovered this year that they could earn tens of thousands of dollars through club appearances and other outside activities, and there were reports that they were holding up production while demanding big raises from MTV. It is unknown what price was agreed upon, but MTV wasted no time in confirming the deal after the Web site TMZ declared “peace in Seaside Heights,” the locale where the first season was filmed. “MTV is pleased that the Jersey Shore cast are returning to Seaside Heights to continue production on Season 3,” the network said in a statement. “Not only have they become a part of the MTV family, but fans worldwide have fallen in love with them.” MTV isn’t kidding about the “worldwide” part; the network has exported the series to dozens of countries.

headline: S.E.C. Moves to Restrict Mutual Fund Fees
text: Mutual fund fees, one of the biggest costs for millions of Americans who manage their investments, are headed for an overhaul that could lessen the amounts that investors pay for sales and marketing activities of brokers, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: The New Dating Tools: A Card and a Wink
text: LORI CHEEK was walking through the meatpacking district of Manhattan when she spotted a handsome man sitting with friends amid the dinner crowd outside Pastis.

headline: Iran Now Says Nuclear Scientist Was Double Agent
text: TEHRAN  Iran fired a new salvo on Wednesday in what is becoming a bizarre propaganda war over the supposed defection and later return of an Iranian nuclear scientist, with Iran’s semiofficial media suggesting that he was a covert operative who had provided “valuable information” about the Central Intelligence Agency’s inner workings.

headline: Spiced Rosé Gelatin With Peaches
text: 2 cups rosé wine

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Wiggle Room
text: The names still ring out like incantations: Tang. Reddi-Wip. Pringles. Kool-Aid. Bac-Os. To my childhood ears, they were more than just supermarket products. They were passwords. Say the right phrases in the right order, and a door would slide open onto a secret world where the ground is dusted with instant cocoa, perfectly symmetrical potato chips twirl down from tree branches and the rivers run with bright red bug juice.

headline: Blueberry Gelatin
text: 1 pint blueberries

headline: Translating Poetry to the Stage, With or Without Words
text: BOSTON  Since the poet and critic  Anne Carson and the dancer-choreographer Rashaun Mitchell are each exceptional artists, their occasional collaborations  which began in 2004  would be historically remarkable even if they were artistically barren. But “Bracko” and “Nox,” the two main works in which they have come together, are events where different kinds of poetry become layered upon one another with extraordinary eloquence. Words, dance, translation, cultural commentary, lighting, music  all add discrete but overlapping zones of beauty, meaning, drama.

headline: The Yoga Mogul
text: There is so much going on in John Friend’s life right now that an assistant once teased him about waking just before dawn and calling to ask for coffee, only to be reminded that he, Friend, was in Quito, Munich or Seoul, while the assistant was back at home base in the Woodlands, a cushy suburb north of Houston. That Friend, the founder of Anusara, one of the world’s fastest-growing styles of yoga, has an assistant is itself significant; many people still picture yogis as serene guys who live in respectable deprivation in places like Mysore or Pune, India, and wait for disciples to find them. Not Friend.

headline: A Pop Chart for Web Era Challenges Billboard’s
text: Billboard’s charts of albums and singles, published in their current form since the 1950s, are the last word in music rankings. But has the magazine’s methodology kept pace with changes in technology and music consumption?

headline: Scripting a Life Much Like Hers
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Ratings Rules May Sink Hard-to-Value Securities
text: New regulations could force the credit rating agencies to stop issuing recommendations on certain hard-to-value securities, torpedoing the market for many structured products.

headline: Mousewives
text: Internet-surfing housewives.

headline: Songs of the Saints, With Love, From Pakistan
text: Hands waved overhead. Voices shouted lyrics and whooped with delight. Children were hoisted onto parents’ shoulders. In the tightly packed crowd a few dancers made room to jump. T-shirts were tossed to fans from the stage.

headline: Museum Gift Shops
text: SUSAN WEBER is nothing if not persistent. After getting her master’s degree in 1985 in a program run jointly by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and the Parsons School of Design, she was rejected for a curatorial position at Cooper-Hewitt. So Ms. Weber, who was married at the time to the financier George Soros (they have since divorced), began working at the Open Society Institute that her husband had founded.

headline: The New ‘Angels in America’ Poster
text: Here’s a first look at the artwork for the Signature Theater Company’s revival of Tony Kushner’s play “Angels in America,” which will begin its Off Broadway run on Sept. 14.

headline: Larry Keith, Television and Stage Actor, Dies at 79
text: Larry Keith, a veteran television and stage actor who was in the original cast of the soap opera “All My Children” and who was also the first American to play Henry Higgins in “My Fair Lady” on Broadway, died on July 17 in Manhattan. He was 79 and a Manhattan resident.

headline: The (More Than) Full Varèse: Completed Works and Others
text: Lincoln Center has taken the idiosyncratic view in recent years that because classical music is the center’s main business, the Lincoln Center Festival should mostly steer clear of it. Last summer the festival’s classical programming was a single duo-piano recital. So it was heartening to see the music of Edgard Varèse given a prominent berth this year.

headline: Animal House
text: A few of the animal-friendly design solutions created by pet owners in their homes.

headline: Raising the Bar on Pet Décor
text: THERE was a time when pets were pets. They had bowls and beds, and that was about it. Then something changed.

headline: The Fedfail Index
text: Ben Bernanke’s testimony today, as expected, lacked all sense of urgency. Hey, the economy’s a bit disappointing, and maybe someday we might think about doing something about it …

headline: Hard-to-Find Play Worthy of the Hall of Fame
text: You are East, defending against six spades doubled. West’s one-diamond opening showed 11 to 15 high-card points and at least a doubleton diamond.

headline: Tea Time for Gardeners
text: When blended, these herbs can be transformed into homemade tea.

headline: Making Tea From Plants Grown in the Backyard
text: THE first Tea Party got one thing right: drinking tea is un-American. Camellia sinensis, the common tea shrub, will survive in most warm, humid climates. But tea plantations never took root in American soil.

headline: Tunes That Are Steeped in an Old-School Style
text: Big-framed, blustery Blind Boy Paxton and slim, straight-backed Frank Fairfield were passing time while tuning up their instruments. Mr. Paxton stopped in the middle, meta-style, to outline their roles in the performance. He’d be “buffoonin’,” he explained. He gestured to Mr. Fairfield. “And he’s the straight white man.” Nervous laughter all around, including a very authentic-sounding 1930s movie giggle from Mr. Fairfield.

headline: Israeli Court Calls Lying for Sex Rape
text: Updated | Thursday | 12:56 p.m. A married Arab man who lied to a Jewish woman to get her to sleep with him — telling her that he was a single Jew interested in a long-term relationship — was convicted of rape in a Jerusalem court on Tuesday for the consensual sex the couple engaged in two years ago.

headline: The House Inherited Them
text: BARRYTOWN, N.Y.

headline: Inside Rokeby House
text: A look at the sprawling 195-year-old house and the small village of barns, cottages and carriage houses on the property that family members, friends and tenants share.

headline: Leafy Murals Spill Across a Manhattan Condo
text: Last week, two murals were painted on the walls of the Griffin Court Condominium, at 800 10th Avenue on the corner of West 53rd Street — one of trees with leaves glowing in the sunlight, the other of the same trees in shadow. Corinne Ulmann, a 34-year-old architectural designer, is the artist.

headline: Talking with Wendell Castle, Art Furniture Icon
text: Forty years ago, Wendell Castle, a designer who is known for his art furniture, introduced a collection of lamps. They were plastic, they were colorful and they bombed — he didn’t sell one. Last month, at the Design Miami/Basel fair in Switzerland, the collection was reintroduced. R 20th Century gallery presented five designs in editions of eight, made from the same molds that the designer — still going strong at 77 — created in 1969 (at right, Mr. Castle with his Benny lamp). Several have already sold.

headline: Showerheads in a Rainbow of Colors
text: Most hand-held showerheads have a limited color palette: chrome, black or white. But the new Icon hand shower from Grohe, the shower-fixture manufacturer, comes in a rainbow. Part of the company’s Rainshower Collection, it now comes in white with green accents and in pink (a portion of the proceeds from the latter version benefits the Breast Cancer Research Foundation); in October, it will also be available in blue, purple, red, orange or yellow.

headline: Custom Quilts With a Sense of Place
text: When Emily Fischer, an architect in Brooklyn, was laid off a year ago, she decided on a career change. She had long had an interest in cartography and had been quilting since childhood, so she began to make quilts decorated with images of maps.

headline: Finn Stone’s Ball Chair
text: The indoor-outdoor Ball Chair by Finn Stone, a London artist and designer, combines 1970s styling with 21st-century sustainability. Made of recycled injection-molded plastic coated with glossy paint, the chair was inspired by Mr. Stone’s collection of vintage fiberglass furniture.

headline: Wii Exercise Doesn’t Beat the Gym
text: Using a Nintendo Wii Fit may not be too damaging on your knees. But it’s also not that beneficial for your heart.

headline: Cordless Vacuum Cleaners From Electrolux
text: With students heading back to school soon, Electrolux is introducing two new space-saving cordless stick vacuum cleaners for “smaller spaces, condos, quick pickups and dorms,” said Jackie Cooper, an Electrolux spokeswoman. “They’re not necessarily designed just for students, but they’re great for them.”

headline: Moving Media To the Droid
text: Q. How do I copy music and picture files from my computer to my Motorola Droid?

headline: Sales at CITE and Bo Concept
text: The CITE showroom in SoHo is offering 40 to 50 percent off its Concept Collection of sofas, dining tables and chairs through July 31 (the DN sectional sofa, originally $4,195, is $2,517; the MD dining table, originally $2,100, is $1,050; and the EL dining chair, originally $390, is $195); 131 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 431-7272 or citenyc.com.

headline: Lugar to Vote for Kagan
text: Richard G. Lugar of Indiana has become the second Republican senator to back President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, Solicitor General Elena Kagan.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Obscene Photos
text: On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Brad Stone, who wrote an article about how Internet companies keep offensive images off their sites and services by having people filter them. He reports that the disturbing nature of what these workers see — day after day, hour after hour — can take a psychological toll on them.

headline: E.M.T. Is Arrested in 5 Sexual Assaults in Brooklyn
text: An emergency medical technician for the Fire Department was arrested in a string of armed sexual assaults dating to 2001, including an attack on an 11-year-old girl July 11 this year, the police said Wednesday.

headline: G.M., Eclipsed at Home, Soars to Top in China
text: SHANGHAI  A decade ago, this city had five car dealerships selling Buicks, the top-selling General Motors brand in China. Today it has 27.

headline: Heat Has Solid Backup Plan
text: When LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh formed their South Beach superfriends club, it left fans of jilted rivals only one resort: sneer at the rest of the lineup.

headline: Senate Gives Final Approval to Jobless Benefits
text: WASHINGTON – The Senate gave final approval Wednesday evening to legislation providing added unemployment benefits through November to millions of Americans who have been out of work for six months or more, ending a politically charged fight.

headline: The Politics of Extending Jobless Benefits
text: Gail Collins: David, I’m on the way to Kentucky to take a look at Rand Paul and hoping to resurrect the long-defunct practice of bringing souvenirs back from the campaign trail. Do you think your kids would like a retired thoroughbred? I understand there are currently a lot of unemployed horses around here and the stable fees would give you an incentive to jump-start a new book project.

headline: Hope Against Hepatitis C
text: New medicines are being developed that are expected to transform the care of patients with hepatitis C, making treatment far more effective and far less grueling.

headline: The Detail Man for the Executive Traveler
text: The antithesis of an accidental tourist — he packs light and scores frequent upgrades — Martin Rapp is a deluxe edition of the species formerly known as the humble travel agent. As the senior vice president of leisure sales for Altour, a global firm with an executive clientele, Mr. Rapp, 69, has been to every continent except Antarctica. When he isn’t scouting exotic locales, he divides his time between Manhattan and Sag Harbor.

headline: Clint Hartung, Once a Promising Giant, Dies at 87
text: Any ballplayer who makes it to the big leagues has achieved much and can be said to have succeeded beyond the expectations he generated in youth. But Clint Hartung is largely, and perhaps unfairly, remembered as the exception to the rule.

headline: Scouts Are Drawn to Wrigley: Let’s Watch Two
text: CHICAGO  For those teams shopping for potential bargains as baseball’s trading deadline approaches, Wrigley Field was the right place to be on Wednesday. Even as trade rumors continued to swirl around Roy Oswalt, the Houston Astros’ ace, his teammate Brett Myers and the Cubs’ Ted Lilly  each of whom will cost a lot less than Oswalt will  hooked up in a pitching duel on a postcard-perfect afternoon.

headline: Don’t Write Off Men Just Yet
text: The yang of America’s labor force is this: over a 40-year career, a man earns $431,000 more than a woman on average, according to the Center for American Progress.

headline: A Tougher Conflict Policy at Harvard Medical School
text: Professors at Harvard Medical School will no longer be able to take industry money to speak for drug or medical device companies or accept gifts, travel or meals under a new conflict-of-interest policy announced Wednesday.

headline: Trojans’ Culture of Fun Meets Era of Compliance
text: LOS ANGELES  When Pat Haden, the incoming athletic director, spoke of installing a culture of compliance in the University of Southern California’s athletic program, he said that complying with N.C.A.A. rules would be what everyone in the department would think about morning, afternoon and night.

headline: G4 Channel to Become 4G in a Week of Sprint Promotion
text: NEXT week the cable channel G4 will morph into 4G.

headline: Afghan Deadline Is Cutting Two Ways
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced a new strategy for Afghanistan in December, he argued that by setting a deadline of next summer to begin drawing down troops he would create a sense of urgency for the Afghan government to take the lead in the fight, while acknowledging the limits of America’s patience with the longest war in its history.

headline: With a Player Under Investigation, Saban Criticizes Agents
text: HOOVER, Ala.  Alabama Coach Nick Saban started throwing stones at the agents who jeopardize the eligibility of college players, and Ralph Cindrich, an agent for N.F.L. players, picked up those stones and threw them right back.

headline: Bond Forms Between Wright and Mays
text: PHOENIX  About an hour before the start of last Sunday’s game at AT&T Park in San Francisco, some fans strolling toward their seats or a concession stand stopped and stared at a young man walking briskly past.

headline: Program to Help Prevent Foreclosures Falls Short
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s program to help homeowners avoid foreclosure has fallen far short of its goals, in part because the Treasury Department has failed to spell out what its objectives should be, according to an assessment offered to Congress on Wednesday.

headline: Weather Bane
text: A few days ago, a carbon-emitting, climate-controlled 737 whisked me from one Washington to another, leaving the naturally air-conditioned paradise of a summer in Seattle for a plunge into Hades on the Potomac.

headline: The Next Deadline
text: American combat troops are on target to leave Iraq by the end of August. President Obama  with the backing of his generals  is right to keep to his timetable, despite a recent series of bloody attacks by insurgents.

headline: In Afflicted, a Doctor Finds Her Following
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Betty Stevenson used heroin for many years and spent seven years in prison for forgery. She finally cleaned up, only to discover that she been infected with hepatitis C from contaminated needles and had serious liver disease.

headline: Misdirection of National Intelligence
text: After four bosses in five years, the intelligence community needs sustained and credible leadership. James Clapper Jr., who was nominated by President Obama to succeed the ousted Dennis Blair as director of national intelligence, certainly seems up to the job.

headline: License to Kill
text: In Idaho and Montana, in early 2009, gray wolves were removed from the endangered species list and left to the mercy of state “management plans.” Those plans have been crafted to satisfy hunters rather than protect the wolves or the ecosystem in which they play an essential role. They all but guarantee the slow extinction of the roughly 1,700 wolves left in the Rocky Mountain West.

headline: Faster Than a Speeding Blog
text: The Obama administration has been shamed by its rush to judgment after it forced the resignation of a black midlevel official in the Agriculture Department who was wrongly accused of racism by the right-wing blogosphere. Shirley Sherrod was sandbagged by a two-and-a-half-minute clip from a 45-minute speech in which the real message was reconciliation.

headline: Conflict Resurfaces With Lessons on Nation-Building
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s team is busy these days managing a troop drawdown in Iraq and a troop escalation in Afghanistan, hoping in both cases to build governments that can manage their own countries. Virtually forgotten is the last such American project overseas, still incomplete but reaching a critical juncture this week.

headline: I.B.M. Unveils a New Generation of Mainframes
text: The mainframe business is to I.B.M. what manufacturing is to the American economy, a shrinking but strategically vital part of the franchise.

headline: Powerlifting Trash Cans as Test of Physical Fitness
text: Their physiques have not been featured in calendars like those of their civil service colleagues in the Fire Department. They may not possess the athleticism of triathletes or running backs, or the powerful grace of gymnasts.

headline: The Nanny and the Senators
text: There was a stir in the Reception Room just outside the Senate chamber, and it had nothing to do with unemployment benefits.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Somali Refugees Fear Loss of Ugandan Haven
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — “Sometimes I get these bad dreams,” said Ahmed Uleh, his eyes hidden behind shiny aviator sunglasses. “Like they are trying to cut off my head.”

headline: Christie Urges Rescue for Stalled Meadowlands Complex
text: With the Xanadu entertainment and shopping complex three years behind schedule and in need of an estimated $875 million to open, Gov. Chris Christie said Wednesday that it was time for the state to help resuscitate the project.

headline: Police Say They Have the City’s Bouquet Bandit in Hand
text: A man whose past may have inspired his modus operandi was arrested Wednesday on suspicion that he was the so-called Bouquet Bandit, who delivered robbery notes affixed to flowers or plants in two recent bank robberies in Manhattan, the authorities said.

headline: Fire Alarm Prompts Visitors to Flee the Statue of Liberty
text: Fears that a fire had erupted inside the Statue of Liberty on Wednesday led several hundred visitors to flee its crown, observation deck, pedestal and base, officials said.

headline: Kovalchuk Deal Denied Over Issue of Longevity
text: The N.H.L. rejected the Devils’ 17-year, $102 million contract with Ilya Kovalchuk because the Devils and Kovalchuk did not believe he would still be playing hockey in the final years of the deal, which would have expired when he was 44.

headline: Flo Rida Feat. T Pain, 2008
text: Notes: The Across Lite notepad includes two clues for the center square. The numbering for the print and online versions is different, since the print version has the number 36 in the center square.

headline: Trial Focuses on Iran Ties of Kennedy Plot Suspect
text: The trial of two men accused of plotting to attack Kennedy International Airport took an unexpected twist on Wednesday when prosecutors suggested that one of the men, a former government official in Guyana, had spied on behalf of the Iranian government.

headline: Mixed Feelings as Rodriguez Nears 600
text: On Aug. 11, 2001, Mark McGwire extended his Popeye forearms for a fastball from the Mets’ Glendon Rusch at Shea Stadium. He ripped the pitch 390 feet, out near the home bullpen and altered baseball history forever.

headline: Christie Makes Bold and Risky Moves on 2 Fronts
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Gov. Chris Christie on Wednesday called for a daring approach to a long-festering set of problems, with thousands of jobs and millions in state revenue at stake: a state takeover of Atlantic City’s withering casino district and a retreat from the government’s longtime role in running sports sites.

headline: Critics Assail U.S. Plan to Settle With KeySpan
text: WASHINGTON — A price-fixing scheme by KeySpan Energy Corporation, the wholesale electricity provider, that may have cost New York State customers $300 million could be resolved with a $12 million civil penalty paid to the federal government under a settlement awaiting approval by a federal judge.

headline: Senate Democrats’ Plan to Aid Small Businesses Hits G.O.P. Resistance
text: WASHINGTON  Perhaps the last best hope of Democrats to pass legislation aimed at creating jobs before the November elections seemed to be crumbling in the Senate on Wednesday as Republicans signaled that they would block a bill to expand government lending programs and grant an array of tax breaks to small businesses.

headline: Manuel Calls Meeting, Hoping It Has Same Results as Earlier One
text: PHOENIX  With his team hoping to avoid an embarrassing sweep at the hands of a last-place team, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel called a team meeting before Wednesday’s game against the Arizona Diamondbacks.

headline: HUD to Investigate Mortgage Loan Denials
text: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said Wednesday that it would investigate the lending practices of certain mortgage lenders to see if any prospective borrowers had been illegally denied a mortgage because they were pregnant or on short-term disability.

headline: NBC Interview With Shirley Sherrod
text: Chuck Todd talks to Shirley Sherrod, an official in the Agriculture Department who was fired because of a misleading video clip and then offered her job back. (Video via NBC)

headline: Ralph Houk, Yankees Manager, Dies at 90
text: Ralph Houk, a third-string catcher for the Yankees who went on to win three straight American League pennants and two World Series championships in his first seasons as their manager, died Wednesday at his home in Winter Haven, Fla. He was 90.

headline: Houk, One of Berra’s Backups, Didn’t Do Much
text: John McMullen once said that there was nothing more limited than being a limited partner of George Steinbrenner’s. In a similar vein for players, there was little more limited than being Yogi Berra’s backup.

headline: ‘Barefoot Bandit’ Started Life on the Run Early
text: CAMANO ISLAND, Wash.  The “Barefoot Bandit” is not all Colton Harris-Moore has been called in his short splash of life.

headline: Troubled Childhood for ‘Barefoot Bandit’
text: An examination of the early life and troubles of Colton Harris-Moore, the “Barefoot Bandit,” suggests that he spent much of his time alone and hungry.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Workers on Doomed Rig Voiced Concern About Safety
text: WASHINGTON  A confidential survey of workers on the Deepwater Horizon in the weeks before the oil rig exploded showed that many of them were concerned about safety practices and feared reprisals if they reported mistakes or other problems.

headline: BP Sparring With Partners on Well Costs
text: Newly released documents show intensified sparring over liability among the partners in the blown-out Gulf of Mexico well.

headline: Day 92: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Weather May Delay Work in Gulf

headline: 2 Americans in Cases Tied to Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON  A 20-year-old Virginia man who had made threatening statements about the television show “South Park” was arrested on Wednesday and charged with supporting the Shabab, a Somalia-based terrorist group, after he allegedly tried to board a flight to Africa with his infant son.

headline: Oakland, Seeking Financial Lift, Approves Giant Marijuana Farms
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  This city, which has been at the vanguard of medical marijuana legalization on everything from taxation to trade schools to the unionization of marijuana workers, voted Tuesday to permit industrial-size marijuana farms.

headline: Morgan’s Effort to Cut Risk Appears to Pay Off
text: Morgan Stanley’s postcrisis conversion to reducing risk finally seems to be paying off. James P. Gorman, its chief executive, presided over $1.4 billion of earnings from continuing operations in the second quarter, according to earnings released Wednesday. That is the first time in a year and a half that Morgan Stanley has managed to put in a more impressive performance than most of its competitors.

headline: Republicans Form Caucus for Tea Party in the House
text: Members of the freshly minted House Tea Party Caucus spent their first day of existence Wednesday trying to clarify just who they are  a tricky task when the Tea Party opposes big government and the caucus members work in the heart of it.

headline: Barajas Plays Hard to Get
text: PHOENIX — Rod Barajas was wearing Mike Pelfrey’s jersey during batting practice on Tuesday. Pelfrey, who had a miserable outing the night before, jokingly asked Barajas to wear it so that fans would boo him instead of Pelfrey.

headline: Prosecutor’s 2006 Firing Won’t Result in Charges
text: WASHINGTON  A special prosecutor has decided not to bring any criminal charges in connection with the firing of a United States attorney in 2006 in a political controversy that dogged the George W. Bush administration until its final days, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.

headline: 3 Arrested in Rare Beverly Hills Killing
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The police arrested three suspects Wednesday in the death of a 21-year-old college student found Tuesday morning outside his home in Beverly Hills, which has seen only three killings in as many years, none in the upscale, hillside neighborhood where this killing occurred.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,179 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Literary Agent Plans E-Book Editions
text: The literary agent Andrew Wylie said on Wednesday that he would begin his own publishing venture, called Odyssey Editions, which will produce e-book editions of titles by some of his clients, including Saul Bellow, John Updike and Philip Roth.

headline: Six Items or Fewer
text: A month-long experiment encourages a shopping diet by wearing six items already found in your closet.

headline: Peter Walls, General in Zimbabwe, Dies at 83
text: PARIS — Lt. Gen. Peter Walls, the last commander of white Rhodesian forces in what is now Zimbabwe, who played a central and sometimes ambiguous role in the first days of his country’s transition to majority rule only to fall out bitterly with its first black leader, died on Tuesday in South Africa, where he lived in exile. He was 83.

headline: Stanley Greene’s Redemption and Revenge
text: Stanley Greene, 61, is a founding member of Noor Images, a photography collective, agency and foundation in Amsterdam. His books include the autobiographical “Black Passport” and “Open Wound: Chechnya 1994-2003.” He won the W. Eugene Smith Grant in 2003. Michael Kamber spoke with him in Paris in May. Their remarks have been condensed.

headline: I.M.F. Backs Efforts in Europe to Cut Deficits
text: The International Monetary Fund lent its support Wednesday to Europe’s budget deficit reduction efforts, pulling away from previous calls for stimulus even as it warned of a “moderate and uneven” recovery in the region, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: Utah: 21 Injured in Bumpy Flight
text: Federal transportation safety officials are investigating an incident involving a United Airlines flight on its way from Washington, D.C., to Los Angeles that was forced to land in Denver on Tuesday because of turbulence. The flight, with 255 passengers and 10 crew members aboard, ran into trouble about 34,000 feet above Missouri. Four flight attendants and 17 passengers were treated at area hospitals and released.

headline: Massachusetts: Chief Justice Retires
text: Margaret H. Marshall, the chief justice of the top court in Massachusetts, announced Wednesday that she would retire early to spend time with her husband, who she said has Parkinson’s disease. Chief Justice Marshall, 66, wrote the majority opinion in the 2003 ruling that made Massachusetts the first state to allow same-sex marriage. Her husband, Anthony Lewis, is a former columnist for The New York Times.

headline: West Virginia: Capito Declines to Run
text: Representative Shelley Moore Capito, viewed as the Republicans’ best hope in a special Senate election to fill the seat Robert C. Byrd held until his death, announced Wednesday that she would not run. Ms. Capito said she could be more effective in the House. Gov. Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, declared on Tuesday that he was running in the November election to fill the seat until 2012.

headline: F.D.I.C. Sends Insurance Payouts to Thousands
text: Thanks to the overhaul of financial rules becoming law Wednesday, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation can truthfully say ”the check is in the mail” to about 9,500 customers of banks that failed in 2008.

headline: Gaza: 2 Militants Killed by Israeli Shells
text: Two Palestinian militants were killed and six were wounded Wednesday in an Israeli shelling in the northern Gaza Strip, Palestinian witnesses and officials at a hospital said. The shelling took place in Beit Hanun, a town bordering Israel. Israel said its forces fired shells at a group of gunmen who approached the electric fence at the border with an object that looked like a rocket. One of the dead was a member of the Islamic Jihad movement and died at the scene, according to witnesses; another Palestinian died later at the hospital.

headline: News Quiz | July 22, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: No Fed Plans to Give More Support, Bernanke Says
text: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, in saying that it had no immediate plans to provide additional support to the economy, dashed the hopes of some economists and executives who have been pushing for action to add momentum to the sluggish recovery, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Will Stress Tests Overcome Resistance in Germany?
text: The debt crisis rattling Spain has finally allowed the central bank to override powerful local politicians and push through an overhaul of the very same institutions whose extravagant lending contributed to the country’s woes.

headline: Word of the Day | prate
text: prate •\ˈprat\• verb, noun

headline: Asian Shares Fall After Fed Cites Uncertainty
text: Asian stock markets were lower Thursday, hit by sharp falls on Wall Street after the  Federal Reserve chairman,  Ben S. Bernanke confirmed fears that the world’s largest economy has weakened, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Woeful Diamondbacks Sweep Mets
text: PHOENIX  After finding success in the weeks following a team meeting in his office in May, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel tried the trick again Wednesday, although this time in the more spacious visitors clubhouse at Chase Field.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Debacchate
text: Today’s word, in association with the superlative Oxford English Dictionary, is
