headline: Facebook Tops 500 Million Users
text: Facebook, the social network created in the dormitories of Harvard six years ago, said on Wednesday that it now had 500 million members, The New York Times’s Jenna Wortham reported.

headline: Terra-Gen Raises $1.2 Billion for Wind Farm
text: From Camille Ricketts at VentureBeat:

headline: Roche Profit Up on Genentech Synergies
text: A little more than a year after acquiring Genentech, Roche said Thursday that its profits for the first half of this year had risen by 37 percent from the same period a year before as exceptional costs associated with the merger had fallen.

headline: Standard Bearers
text: WHO developed the recommended national education standards?

headline: Paulson & Company to Go Retail, Report Says
text: Paulson & Company, the hedge fund linked to civil fraud charges against Goldman Sachs, will begin a new fund that will be open to retail investors, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Camelot Shares Fall in Debut
text: Shares of Camelot Information Systems fell 3 percent their market debut Wednesday, after pricing its initial public offering at the bottom of its expected range.

headline: Ackermann Named Europe’s Banker of the Year
text: Deutsche Bank‘s chief executive, Josef Ackermann, was elected “best European banker of the year” on Wednesday by a group of financial journalists known as 20+1, which cited the strategy he has implemented since he took over the bank in 2002, leading Deutsche to become more competitive globally.

headline: U.S. Lifts Ban on Indonesian Special Forces Unit
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The United States is lifting a ban of more than a decade on military contact with an elite Indonesian special forces unit implicated in past killings of civilians and other abuses, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced Thursday, after meeting here with President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono of Indonesia.

headline: A Facebook I.P.O.? When It ‘Makes Sense,’ Zuckerberg Says
text: Facebook will sell stock in a initial public offering when the time is right, its chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, said in an ABC-TV interview, Reuters reported.

headline: Do Celebrity Endorsements Influence Your Behavior?
text: To promote her initiative to combat childhood obesity, Michelle Obama recruited Major League baseball players to be featured in an ad campaign. Do you think that will help get kids’ attention and induce them to adopt a healthier diet and lifestyle?

headline: Spirit Finance Is Said to Be on the Block
text: Spirit Finance is up for sale, with its owners, including Macquarie Group, seeking about $3.5 billion for the American real estate investment trust, according to news reports.

headline: Morgan’s Effort to Cut Risk Appears to Pay Off
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Dispiriting Data Before Stress Test Results
text: The governments and regulators of the European Union still have a lot of work ahead to shore up the reputation of their individual banking systems, as data demonstrates that weaker members are leaning on the European Central Bank as never before, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: In Visit, Clinton Criticizes Vietnam on Rights
text: HANOI, Vietnam  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton chided Vietnam on Thursday for intolerance of dissent and infringement of Internet freedom, even as she celebrated its 15 years of normalized relations with the United States.

headline: Stanley Black & Decker: A Merger That Works?
text: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline: Citic May Raise $11 Billion in I.P.O., Report Says
text: Citic Group, the Chinese state-owned investment company, may raise as much as 80 billion renminbi ($11.8 billion) in a planned initial public offering in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News said, citing a report in China Daily.

headline: With Banking, Question Everything
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Tiger Management May Look to Expand
text: Is Julian Robertson’s Tiger Management set to roar again?

headline: Washington Redskins 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill Unarmed Palestinian
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces shot to death an unarmed Palestinian man early on Thursday at the edge of a Jewish settlement in the northern West Bank, Israeli military and Palestinian officials said. The Palestinian Authority government condemned the killing, calling it a "breach of the rule of law."

headline: N.Y.C. Pensions Mull Wading into Hedge Funds
text: New York City’s pension funds for police officers, firefighters and civil employees are seeking proposals from hedge fund consultants as they weigh whether to invest in loosely regulated investment pools, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Blackstone and PAI Said to Eye Sale of United Biscuits
text: The Blackstone Group and PAI Partners appear to be looking for an exit from their investment in United Biscuits, the British food company.

headline: China to Review Everbright’s Shanghai I.P.O.
text: China’s securities regulator said it would look at China Everbright Bank‘s application for an initial public offering in Shanghai next Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Starting Over in Lexington: ‘Blowing the Doors Off’
text: As I’ve written from time to time, SRC purchased a business in Lexington, Ky., late last year. When I recently called up Rob Shear, the factory’s chief executive, he told me that things continued to go well. Well, that’s not exactly what he said. “We are blowing the doors off,” he told me.

headline: Q.&A.: Fixing Firefox’s Password Memory
text: Q.

headline: Swedbank Profits Soar Above Expectations
text: Swedbank, the Swedish banking group, posted a much stronger-than-expected second-quarter operating profit on Thursday as loan losses came in well below expectations, Reuters reported.

headline: Copano Energy Taps TPG for $300 Million
text: TPG Capital is investing $300 million in a natural gas company, Copano Energy, which it will use to fund shale gas production developments, Reuters reported.

headline: Green Dot Prices Its I.P.O. Above Expected Range
text: It seems like investors were feeling pretty good about Green Dot Wednesday. The prepaid debit card company priced its initial public offering above the expected range, after previously increasing the size of its I.P.O.

headline: Santander Said to Seek $4.6 Billion I.P.O. in Britain
text: Banco Santander is planning to take 20 percent of its British unit public in a £3 billion initial public offering in London this autumn, The Financial Times reported Thursday, as the Spanish lender seeks to raise funds to buy a retail banking network from Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: SurgiVision Pares I.P.O. Price Range
text: SurgiVision, a medical device maker, slashed the price of its expected initial public offering on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Rolls-Royce Updates the Classic Picnic Basket
text: “A return to the golden age of picnicking,” is how Rolls-Royce describes the significance of its new bespoke picnic set introduced at the Salon Privé, a display of high-end automobiles and other luxury brands, including watches and champagne.

headline: U.S. Pay Czar Said Set to Release Bonus Details
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master for compensation in the Obama administration, is set to release a report as early as Friday detailing the payouts to financial firms’ top earners during the height of the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Couche-Tard Raises Offer for Casey’s
text: Alimentation Couche-Tard of Canada on Thursday made a small increase in  its tender offer for Casey’s General Stores, the latest move in a three-month battle for control of the Midwestern convenience store operator.

headline: In Shadow of Overhaul, Ford Yanks Bond Deal
text: Ford Motor‘s financing division has withdrawn plans for a new debt sale, in what marks the first shiver in the bond market from the sweeping financial legislation signed by President Obama Wednesday, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Throats Slit Before Staten Island Fire, Police Say
text: As a single mother in a terrible job market, Leisa Jones had been doing everything she could to hold things together, working part time as a department store security guard during the holidays and, more recently, attending beauty school. Her neighbors said she had made the second-floor apartment on Staten Island where she lived with her four children  two boys and two girls  a place where good manners and good behavior mattered.

headline: G.M. to Buy Lender AmeriCredit for $3.5 Billion
text: General Motors said on Thursday that it has agreed to buy AmeriCredit for $3.5 billion in cash, the carmaker’s first effort to reestablish an in-house lending arm after selling off GMAC in 2006.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The numbers have spoken, and Credit Suisse’s earnings confirm that trading profit is down for the quarter, not just in the States but abroad. Sovereign debt and regulatory fears are driving the gamblers to hold their wagers for the moment, or be wiped out in markets stalked by sudden volatility. So the question is — can the financial sector keep leading the recovery, and if it doesn’t, what will?

headline: On Our Radar: China Tops Energy Charts
text: China overtakes the United States as the world’s largest energy user.

headline: San Francisco Museum Picks Norwegian Firm for Expansion
text: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta to design an expansion that will increase its gallery and public space by about 100,000 square feet, the museum is to announce on Thursday. Initial design concepts are to be unveiled next spring.

headline: Bill Murray Continues to Be Bill Murray as Bill Murray Week Continues
text: In time, history will show that this week was won not by Republicans or Democrats, not by the White House or its political opponents, but by Bill Murray. A few days ago Mr. Murray — who has all but become his whimsical if slightly forlorn “Lost in Translation” character — told GQ magazine that he had accepted his role in the “Garfield” movie because he believed it was being made by the Coen brothers. (So why the sequel, hmm?) For a follow-up, he began his appearance Wednesday on “Late Show With David Letterman” with some literal Dumpster diving — as in, he went for a swim in a waste bin filled with water and what appeared to be some actual garbage. (This seemed to go on for a lot longer on the television broadcast than it does in the above video clip.)

headline: Times Co. Posts Operating Profit Gain
text: The New York Times Company reported on Thursday that its second-quarter profit excluding some one-time items more than doubled as it posted its first gain in three years.

headline: Schottcast: Almanacs – The Oldest Guides to Everything
text: Co-vocabularists may be interested to know of a new BBC radio documentary on the genesis and evolution of the almanac – presented by Ben Schott.

headline: Filling the Global Energy Research Gap
text: Earlier this week, the International Energy Agency released a batch of new findings and reports as its contribution to the Obama administration’s “Clean Energy Ministerial” meeting in Washington. One report concluded that China’s total energy use now tops that of the United States, just a couple of years behind its rise to the top position on lists of emitters of carbon dioxide. (China almost immediately disputed the agency’s conclusion.)

headline: G.M. Spends $3.5 Billion for Lender to Subprime
text: DETROIT  General Motors said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy a financing company, AmeriCredit, for $3.5 billion so it can lease more vehicles and increase sales to consumers with lower credit ratings.

headline: KeySpan Settlement Plan Draws Criticism
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Blackstone’s 2nd-Quarter Profit Rises to $205 Million
text: The Blackstone Group on Thursday reported a $205 million profit for the second quarter, as gains in its real estate arm offset weakness in its private equity and hedge fund operations.

headline: Counterpoint
text: Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The New York Times, explains an important musical technique.

headline: The Softer Side of Dell
text: A very different Dell has started to emerge.

headline: The Early Word: Echo Chamber
text: The administration will spend another day picking up the pieces from a scandal turned not-so-scandalous.

headline: Report Criticizes 2008 Chinese Crackdown in Tibet
text: BEIJING  A detailed report by Human Rights Watch says Chinese security forces violated international law in suppressing the Tibetan protests and riots of 2008 by indiscriminately beating, detaining and fatally shooting civilians in towns across the vast Tibetan plateau in western China.

headline: Markets Sharply Higher on Earnings
text: Corporations from AT&T to U.P.S. say business is finally picking up  and investors are cheering.

headline: HATIF
text: The acronymic name for a service established in Germany to help people escape radical Muslim groups.

headline: Some Last Bits of Splendor With Harvey Pekar
text: Tara Seibel, a Cleveland cartoonist and graphic designer, has a particularly vivid memory of the last time she saw Harvey Pekar.

headline: Poetry Pairing | July 22, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: G.M. to Buy Lender AmeriCredit for $3.5 Billion
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: The End Is Near for Ennio & Michael
text: After 32 years in Greenwich Village, Ennio & Michael will close this fall, owing more than $200,000 in rent to its landlord, New York University.

headline: Indonesia Moves to Block Pornographic Web Sites
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia is taking steps to block pornographic Web sites before the start of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan, the country’s information minister said Thursday, defying local criticism that the plan amounted to censorship and was unworkable.

headline: Does a Manipulated Market Advance Clean Power?
text: The Justice Department says that a wholesale electricity supplier in New York City manipulated the market for several years to keep prices high. At first glance, this might seem to have an environmental advantage. More expensive electricity encourages efficient use, and high wholesale prices may encourage companies to build new power plants — possibly wind or solar — that are almost certainly cleaner than the old ones.

headline: Tutu Says It’s Time to Slow Down and Sip Tea
text: PARIS  After decades at the forefront of the struggle against apartheid and injustice, Desmond Tutu, the former Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, announced Thursday that he would begin reducing his public appearances in October, on his 79th birthday.

headline: Thursday Reading: On Shopping Diets
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: An Anti-Quota Bill and a TV Officer’s Arrest
text: Updated, 3:07 p.m. | Fresh from signing one piece of controversial police-related legislation, Gov. David A Paterson is facing another.

headline: Existing Home Sales Fell 5.1% in June
text: Sales of existing homes slowed in June for the second consecutive month, reflecting the impact of the deadline for a government tax credit, the National Association of Realtors said on Thursday.

headline: Deborah Voigt to Become a Pistol-Packin’ Annie
text: Debbie, get your gun.

headline: Spill Commission Hires Counsel
text: The presidential panel investigating the BP oil spill has taken on one of George W. Bush’s top lawyers in the Florida recount battle as its chief counsel, the commission announced on Thursday.

headline: Mad Men City | Fly Eastern
text: One of several Benton & Bowles advertisements for Eastern Air Lines.

headline: Debt-Laden Dubai World Tries to Win Over Creditors
text: Dubai World formally presented its $23.5 billion restructuring plan to scores of creditor banks on Thursday as it seeks an end to its months-old debt crisis, but the state-owned company made clear that negotiations over the deal could continue for some time, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Off the Menu: Ai Fiori, Michael White’s Latest Restaurant
text: Michael White, the chef and partner in Convivio, Alto and Marea, who is also in the throes of trying to open Osteria Morini, his new place on Lafayette Street, has piled even more on his plate. Working with Chris Cannon and his other partners in the Alta Marea restaurant group, he will be executive chef at Ai Fiori, the second-floor restaurant in the Setai Fifth Avenue, 400 Fifth Avenue (37th Street), set to open in late fall. The restaurant will feature the food of the Italian Mediterranean coast, with some French Riviera influences, and have about 185 seats with another 40 at the bar. Though the hotel shares its name with the Setai Wall Street, which also has a second-floor restaurant (SHO Shaun Hergatt), each is owned by a different company.

headline: Fed Would Act if Needed, Chairman Says
text: WASHINGTON  A day after signaling that he had no immediate plans to take further steps to prop up the economy, the Federal Reserve chairman said Thursday that he was prepared to do so if the outlook worsened.

headline: Avoiding One Mistake After Another
text: Researchers who study recreational golf know a lot about our game, and they all agree on one thing: the truly awful shots – hopelessly errant tee shots or short chips that fly over greens – ruin most rounds by average golfers. If 105 is a typical score for you, you are likely to have about eight awful shots per round, while someone who shoots around 80 will probably have just two. That’s according to Mark Broadie, a Columbia University professor who has spent years analyzing data from average golfers.

headline: No Calm Before the Comic-Con Storm
text: SAN DIEGO — There was a time when Comic-Con’s Wednesday “preview night” was the calm before the storm, when entertainment industry folks got to take a quick stroll around the trade show floor to eye the competition and do some networking. Not this year. It was fanboy gridlock at the San Diego Convention Center.

headline: Persistent Issue of Race Is in the Spotlight, Again
text: WASHINGTON  It was exactly one year ago on Thursday that President Obama plunged into a thicket of racial politics by declaring that a white police officer in Cambridge, Mass., had “acted stupidly” in arresting a black Harvard University professor in his own home. Suddenly, the president whose election suggested the promise of a postracial future was thrust into the wounds of the past.

headline: Guards for Somali Leader Join Islamists
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali officials acknowledged on Thursday that members of Somalia’s presidential guard had defected to the Shabab, the radical Islamist insurgent group that claimed responsibility for the recent bombings in Uganda that killed more than 70 people watching the final game of the World Cup.

headline: In Search of a Republican Agenda
text: Perhaps you’ve seen this clip, from last weekend’s “Meet the Press,” in which Pete Sessions, Republican of Texas, labors to offer any specifics whatsoever when pressed about what the G.O.P. would actually do if it managed to reclaim some share of power this November:

headline: HUD Accepting Complaints About Mortgage Lenders
text: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that it wouldtake complaints from individuals who believe they have been harmed by the practices of certain lenders who may have illegally denied mortgages because applicants were pregnant or on short-term disability.

headline: Anna Chapman Slinks Back, in Several Guises
text: The spy who purloined no state secrets but stole a million hearts may be gone from our shores forever, but her plastic surrogate is now yours for the having.

headline: Joe Gagnon Is Right
text: He calls on the Fed to implement a plan based on the ideas of someone the central bank seems to have been ignoring — a macroeconomist by the name of Ben Bernanke.

headline: More Changes At ‘Nightline’ And NBC
text: Bill Weir was named a co-host of ABC News’s “Nightline” on Thursday, replacing Martin Bashir, who is taking a job at ABC’s chief rival, NBC News.

headline: Contractor Is Acquitted in Crane Collapse
text: A rigging contractor was found not guilty on Thursday in connection with a crane collapse in Manhattan two years ago that killed seven people.

headline: Porsche Hybrid Racecar to Compete in America
text: The orange-and-white Porsche 911 GT3 R Hybrid that will race in Petit Le Mans at Road Atlanta this fall won’t appear all that different from other Porsche GT cars on the grid, but the technology inside this one-off Porsche is special.

headline: Popcast: M.I.A.’s New Album
text: Since the Sri Lankan-British rapper M.I.A. emerged six years ago with beats borrowed from the third world and songs that name-drop terrorist groups, critics and fans have been following the political breadcrumbs in her work and her life story, trying to figure out what it all adds up to. Does her use of tiger imagery, for example, really mean she supports the Tamil Tigers, or are those just metaphors in a  bigger story? And does her engagement to Benjamin Bronfman, a son of the billionaire music executive Edgar Bronfman Jr., conflict with her apparent stance as a militant champion of the world’s poor, as a recent profile in The New York Times Magazine suggested?

headline: Drug War Statement Upstaged at AIDS Gathering
text: VIENNA — Some of the world’s top AIDS experts issued a radical manifesto this week at the 18th International AIDS Conference: They declared the war on drugs a 50-year-old failure and called for it to be abandoned.

headline: Spies, Spider Venom and Sex Appeal
text: “Who is Salt?” is the question posed, for the past month or so, on the side of just about every bus in the land. To the extent that “Salt” is a mystery, the question is apt enough. Is she — played at high velocity and with steely ferocity by Angelina Jolie — a Russian mole, a C.I.A. superassassin or a little of both? But to the much greater extent that “Salt,” directed by Phillip Noyce from a screenplay by Kurt Wimmer, is an action movie, the more salient question might be: What does Salt do?

headline: A Museum Display of Galileo Has a Saintly Feel
text: FLORENCE, Italy  The Galileo case is often seen starkly as science’s first decisive blow against not only faith but also the power of the Roman Catholic Church. It has never been quite that simple, though. Galileo was a believer, devastated at being convicted, in 1633, of heresy for upending the biblical view of the universe.

headline: Internet Air Kisses
text: Fashion designers have been somewhat slow to embrace the more commercial elements of modern technology, like selling their clothes online or on mobile devices, perhaps hesitant about sullying their brands. Social media, however, they seem to have caught on to right away.

headline: Highly Paid College Coaches Slam Amateur Athletes’ Professional Agents
text: Today we thank the Southeastern Conference for reminding us it’s almost college football season, when big-time educational institutions hit the “hold” button on their ethical standards and all but light candles daily in hopes that their school does not end up at the top of the N.C.A.A. enforcement police blotter. This year, many of those hopes have already been extinguished and what was originally called the S.E.C.’s “Media Days” have officially been renamed the “Blame Everything on Those Dastardly Agents Days.”

headline: Reborn in Central Park, Concert ‘Capeman’ Sets Its Cast
text: The Public Theater‘s coming concert performances of “The Capeman” will look increasingly familiar to audiences who caught that Paul Simon–Derek Walcott musical collaboration during its original short-lived Broadway run. On Thursday the Public announced a round of casting for its concerts (scheduled for Aug. 14 through 16 at the Delacorte Theater) that includes several veterans of the Broadway production, which ran for just 68 total performances in 1998.

headline: Urban Crop Circles and Twitter’s Noon Nadir
text: Let’s hear it for small stuff — from patches in the urban landscape, to a restaurant wine list, to the price of a 99 cent bar of soap!

headline: FacePlant App Eases Path to iPhone Video Chats
text: FaceTime, the video calling application for the iPhone 4, aims to revolutionize the way we communicate on our cellphones.

headline: When Weather Makes Migraines Worse
text: Many of the migraine sufferers who recently wrote in to the Consults blog noted that summertime heat or shifts in weather can trigger migraine attacks. Dr. David Dodick, a neurologist at the Mayo Clinic in Arizona, responds.

headline: Manhattan’s Rooftop Bars: Heaven’s Gates
text: Shaken or stirred? Red or white? Draft or bottled? For most of the year these are the biggest questions confronting the thirsty New Yorker. And no answer is wrong.

headline: Federal ‘Sting’ Slams Gene Tests
text: Updated: An undercover investigation of some firms that sell genetic test kits to consumers found misleading test results and “egregious examples of deceptive marketing,” according to a report published today by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: Indoor Living and the Global Greenhouse
text: The Garrison Institute, just down the hill from my home in the Hudson River valley, has organized an exploration of the role of the human mind, with all of its strengths and weaknesses, in both creating the climate challenge and potentially overcoming it. The next effort is a session for a variety of specialists in studies of buildings and behavior.

headline: Q&A: Crete, Without a Car, for Two Older Travelers
text: Q.

headline: Capturing the Perfect Moment From Video
text: It’s not often that new printer software steals the show from printer hardware, but Canon has just released a new series of inkjet printers with software that enables you to easily print still images from video.

headline: Rebuilding Solomon’s Temple, in São Paulo
text: This week, as Jews around the world observed the fasting day of Tisha B’av, commemorating the destruction of the First and Second Jewish Temples in ancient Jerusalem, a Brazilian megachurch received planning permission to build a 10,000-seat replica of Solomon’s Temple in the city of São Paulo.

headline: A Different Lens on Bullying
text: “What Really Happened to Phoebe Prince?”The Slate editor Emily Bazelon has been a most tenacious reporter on the story of the teenager in South Hadley, Mass., who committed suicide earlier this year, and of the six classmates who face criminal charges for reportedly driving her to it.

headline: Failure to Communicate
text: SINCE the very first bunk bed, roommates have annoyed each other. They leave their clothes all over the floor; they host overnight guests unannounced. Big deal. You tell them to pick up their stuff; you work out a “sexile” schedule.

headline: Not the Redeem Team, but Still Chasing a Dream
text: LAS VEGAS  The last time the United States won a world championship in men’s basketball, in 1994, players like Steve Smith, Dan Majerle and Mark Price dotted the roster.

headline: Dispatches From the Frontlines of the Roommate Wars
text: In the next issue of The Times’s Education Life quarterly, which will be available in Sunday’s newspaper, Abigail Sullivan Moore writes that high technology has further destabilized the always delicate balance between roommates.

headline: Seeing Things | California Design Biennial in Pasadena
text: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and the director of exhibitions management and publications at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles.

headline: Trump Jr. Sells West Side Condo
text: WHAT do you look for in an apartment building? Do you prefer brick, or do you hold out for glass? Must it have a doorman?

headline: Two Leaders Engage in a Lung-Defying Duel
text: COL DU TOURMALET, France  When the finish line in Thursday’s stage of the Tour de France grew closer and the fog enveloping the top of the Tourmalet pass grew thicker, the two best overall Tour riders  Alberto Contador and Andy Schleck  had decided that enough was enough.

headline: Theater Talkback: Doing Your Homework
text: At Peter Stein’s marathon production of “The Demons” on Governors Island the other weekend, I must have seen half a dozen patrons toting around their battered-looking copies of the Dostoyevsky novel on which the show was based. Since I myself had just finished plowing through the chunky novel, I guessed that they had not quite made the deadline, and were hoping to churn through those last wild chapters during the lunch and dinner breaks.

headline: What We’re Reading: Friend Rentals
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Spies Like Her?
text: Images from “Salt,” starring Angelina Jolie.

headline: Geese Return to Prospect Park. Sort Of.
text: The geese are back. Two weeks after the nearly complete extermination of the Canada goose population at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, 28 geese have been seen meandering along the shore of the lake there.

headline: Quote Unquote | Red Shoes
text: – The Republican Senate primary candidate, Ken Buck, told the crowd at the Independence Institute’s Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms Party why they should vote for him over his female opponent, Jane Norton. Buck prefers to wear flats when he performs.

headline: TimesCast | July 22, 2010
text: Today, illegal immigrants fear reporting crimes, U.S. soccer goalie Tim Howard on the team's future, and a group goes on a fashion diet living on six items or less.

headline: Fed Would Act if Needed, Chairman Says
text: A day after stating that the Federal Reserve had no imminent plans to provide additional support to the economy, its chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, emphasized on Thursday that the central bank was prepared to take action if needed, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reported.

headline: A Comic-Con Farewell to San Diego?
text: SAN DIEGO— Will Comic-Con be leaving San Diego? Hollywood sure hopes so.

headline: Official Denies BP Put Cost Ahead of Safety at Oil Rig
text: KENNER, La. — Government investigators on Thursday pressed a BP official who supervised the Deepwater Horizon about whether the company took shortcuts to save money and time by selecting riskier equipment at the oil rig.

headline: Test Yourself | July 22, 2010
text: We’re experimenting with a week of history questions based on archival Times articles about key events that happened during the week of July 19-25. Tell us what you think, below.

headline: Q&A: Rumors, Cyberbullying and Anonymity
text: Last week in this space, I shared excerpts from an interview with David Mikkelson, half of the husband-and-wife team behind Snopes.com, the online clearinghouse for Internet rumors and urban legends. It was part of a "CBS News Sunday Morning" segment about online rumors that won't ultimately air.

headline: Best in Show: NYC Men’s Market Week (Part 1)
text: This week, New York City hosts thousands of buyers who have traveled to our stifling city to visit trade shows in order to view new spring/summer 2011 merchandise, available for wholesale purchase and then soon to be seen in a store near you. Here are some highlights from some of the Blue, TMRW, Designer’s Collective and MRket shows.

headline: Storm Threat Forces Ships to Leave Oil Spill Site
text: As the threat of a storm stalled efforts to permanently seal BP’s blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico, the government said Thursday that the well would be left closed off and unattended if ships had to leave the area.

headline: Queen’s Daimler Goes to Auction
text: If you can’t quite afford to live like a royal, this is your best chance to at least drive like one. RM Auctions is scheduled to sell a 1984 Daimler Double Six long-wheelbase sedan formerly owned by Queen Elizabeth II. The sale will be held during the annual Sports and Classics of Monterey auction held from Aug. 12-14 in California.

headline: New Mutual Fund Rules Won’t Limit Advice
text: In today’s New York Times, our colleague Edward Wyatt has an article about the Securities and Exchange Commission’s efforts to rid the mutual fund industry of 12b-1 fees, which can cost investors hundreds or even thousands of dollars if they hang on to a sizable investment for long enough.

headline: Posthumous Curiosity After Sale of British TV Cat’s Ashes
text: The Great American-British Television Détente was, for a time, one of the crowning achievements in international diplomacy of the last half-century. Having been raised on steady diets of “Gilligan’s Island,” “Charlie’s Angels” and “Punky Brewster,” U.S. viewers learned to acclimate their palettes to exotic British fare like “Monty Python,” “The Office” and “Doctor Who,” to embrace British-cultivated personalities like Simon Cowell and Susan Boyle, and to begrudgingly tolerate “The Benny Hill Show.”

headline: U.P.S., Citing a Strong Performance, Raises Outlook
text: United Parcel Service, the package delivery company, said Thursday that its second-quarter net income increased 90 percent and raised its earnings outlook for the year, citing encouraging indications of future global trade.

headline: Stop the Sand Berms, Scientists Plead
text: In an open letter to Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral overseeing the Gulf of Mexico oil spill response, almost two dozen coastal scientists from Louisiana and around the country have urged the federal government to halt the construction of sand berms in the gulf, calling the project ineffective in the fight against the oil and a waste of resources that could have heavy environmental consequences.

headline: One Homecoming
text: In late April the family readiness officer, Tina Morgan, began calling and e-mailing each of 48 anxious First Anglico families with news about the company’s return to Camp Pendleton. (Anglico units — the name stands for Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company — are part of the Marine Corps.) And even though a lot of private, superstitious things had been put off by many who were waiting for the good news, I elected to wait a little longer, until I was sure my Marine had both feet on friendly soil. I’d seen enough just-about-to-retire cop movies to know that having the end in sight slows the clock and multiplies the already too plentiful ways that things can go wrong before the actual, final, blessed end of the deployment.

headline: Tipsy Diaries: Rooftop Remedies
text: Frank Bruni takes a look at the highs and lows of rooftop bars around New York City.

headline: ‘Encino Man’ Comes to Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO— It wasn’t the man clad as an elf or the guy in the full-body Scooby-Doo costume that caused the most craned necks outside the main hall of Comic-Con International on Thursday. It was Pauly Shore, he of “Son in Law” and “Encino Man” fame.

headline: Mad Men City | Answers From a Real Mad Man, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Ed McCabe, who worked for a number of major advertising agencies and is a founder of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

headline: World Court Rules Kosovo Declaration Was Legal
text: PRAGUE  Kosovo’s unilateral declaration of independence from Serbia in 2008 did not violate international law, the United Nations’ highest court said Thursday in a ruling that Kosovo heralded as a victory but that legal experts warned could spur separatist movements around the world.

headline: New York Sues BofA and Merrill for Pension Losses
text: The State of New York is suing Bank of America and its Merrill Lynch securities firm over the companies’ merger and Merrill’s subprime mortgage exposure, hoping to recover more money on its own than by joining existing class-action litigation, Reuters reports.

headline: Extra Weight Adds to Economic Woes
text: Years of being overweight not only contributes to health problems but also to a person’s economic woes, new research suggests.

headline: Tent Revival
text: Yep, another cool thing coming out of Portland, Ore.: Beckel Canvas Products (beckelcanvas.com; 800-237-3362). Since 1964, the family-run company has been making made-to-order canvas bags and tents for glampers and G.I. Joes and Janes alike. Stylish enough for any adventure, the “possibilities bag” was created by the founder Bob Beckel to “carry whatever you could possibly need,” whether you’re transporting a picnic or a passel of teacup dogs. Offered in natural white, olive and red, each piece is stamped with “eena” on the label — the Chinook Indian word for beaver (an animal known for its lodge-building skills). For more rough-going adventures, there’s the “war bag,” which holds, as Beckel explains, “everything you’d need to go to war,” as well as miner tents and outhouses.

headline: For U.S., Versatility Is a Key in Roster Selection
text: LAS VEGAS – While none of the 2008 Olympians are playing in the FIBA world championship this summer, there is much to be learned from how that roster was constructed.

headline: No Matter How You Cut It, a July That’s Too Hot
text: Elizabeth Barrett Browning, in that famous sonnet  “How do I love thee? Let me count the ways”  did not count the ways she loved hot weather.

headline: The Mel Gibson Soap Opera Invades Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO— Mel Gibson may not lend his voice to “Megamind,” the forthcoming superhero movie from DreamWorks Animation, but that didn’t keep him (or at least the controversy surrounding him) from invading the film’s big Comic-Con presentation on Thursday.

headline: States Cut Aid to the Homebound
text: A couple of decades back, people who think about how we care for older Americans — and who noticed how many more of them there were, and how much longer they were living — sounded the alarm about the way the United States was spending Medicaid dollars.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A woman pauses on the banks of the Seine, in Paris.

headline: More S.I. Homes Can Trade Septic Tanks for Sewers
text: Here at City Room, we believe that sewerage is a right all New Yorkers should enjoy. Back in February, we cheered when Meadowmere and Warnerville in southeastern Queens stepped gingerly into the modern age of wastewater treatment. Now it’s Staten Island’s turn.

headline: Democrats Abandon Sweeping Energy Plan
text: After a meeting of Senate Democrats, party leaders on Thursday said they had abandoned hope of passing a comprehensive energy bill this summer and would pursue a more limited measure focused on responding to the gulf oil spill and tightening  energy efficiency standards.

headline: House Passes Jobless Benefit Extension
text: WASHINGTON — The House approved legislation on Thursday that would restore unemployment pay for millions of Americans who have exhausted their standard benefits. The bill was sent to President Obama for his signature, and administration officials said Mr. Obama would sign it immediately.

headline: Housekeeping: Twitter
text: Co-vocabularists can now follow the (t)witterings of Ben Schott at http://twitter.com/benschott – and via the c-column.

headline: Deborah Voigt, Meet Ethel Merman
text: Debbie and Annie: let’s take a look.

headline: The Effects of the Credit Card Act
text: Credit card issuers have stopped many of the “deceptive” or “unfair” practices outlawed by the Credit Card Act, but they are still engaging in others, according to a report released Thursday by the Pew Charitable Trusts’ Safe Credit Card Project.

headline: Pitchforked | Croatian Sausage With Wolf Parade
text: The members of Wolf Parade, good eaters all, were game to try Chicago food while playing at the sold-out Pitchfork Music Festival on Saturday. Did they want to try Hot Doug’s? The Publican?

headline: In Asia, a Gulf’s Worth of Oil Awaits Transport
text: ATYRAU, Kazakhstan  Even as the petroleum industry continues drilling in the Gulf of Mexico at considerable expense and risk, a single field here in Central Asia stands ready to produce two-thirds as much oil each day as the entire gulf does, with less danger to the environment.

headline: After the Recession, a Gradual Recovery in the City
text: New York City is gradually recovering from a deep but surprisingly short recession that ended in November, but its manufacturing industries are not pitching in by adding jobs, economists from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Thursday.

headline: Dear FloFab: We Sat Next to Visigoths!
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Coaching Vanderbilt Football, Not Pouring Concrete
text: HOOVER, Ala. — The news media assembled for the Southeastern Conference media days were thrown a changeup Thursday morning in the form of Vanderbilt’s new football coach, Robbie Caldwell. He replaced Bobby Johnson, who abruptly stepped down on July 14.

headline: Army Chief to Serve 3 More Years in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The government extended the term of Pakistan’s army chief by three years on Thursday, a move backed by the United States as it seeks to encourage Pakistan as a more reliable ally against Taliban and Qaeda militants.

headline: Waiting Around for ‘The Hobbit’
text: 4:13 p.m. | Updated SAN DIEGO— At Comic-Con, even the lines have lines. One way to join the line for a Thursday morning rundown on the “Hobbit” movies from staff members of TheOneRing.net, a fan site that has consistently broken news about the Middle Earth movies, was to first get in another line for those without credentials (even if you already had one). Then you could scoot through the big registration room, out the other end, and into the Hobbit line — just in time to grab one of about 300 seats.

headline: Is This the End of the Hybrid Price Premium?
text: By pricing the coming hybrid version of the luxury MKZ (due in showrooms this fall) at $35,180, the same price as its gas counterpart, Lincoln may be starting a trend toward erasing the price premium for gas-electric drivetrains.

headline: In Rare Deadly Attack, Rocket Hits Iraq’s Green Zone
text: BAGHDAD  A rocket attack on Thursday on the Green Zone, the heavily barricaded section of this city that contains the main government buildings and the United States Embassy, killed three foreign contractors who work for the embassy, and wounded 15, including two American citizens.

headline: Democrats Make $28 Million TV Buy
text: The Democrats’ strategy to preserve their House majority became clearer Thursday as the party made a $28 million investment in television advertising for the final weeks of the fall campaign, a plan that is designed to build a firewall to protect freshmen and longtime incumbents.

headline: Pet Owners, Squeezed by Oil Spill, Turn to Shelters
text: VIOLET, La. — The trail of oil has invaded the marshes of St. Bernard Parish, seeping into the psyche of fishermen and flowing into the overcrowded shelter at the St. Bernard Parish Animal Services where Sasha, Melodie and Benny pace their cages awaiting adoption.

headline: Yankees to Honor Houk With Armband
text: The Yankees will add another to their collection of uniform tributes in honor of key figures who have died this season when they don a black armband to commemorate the life of Ralph Houk, the former Yankees player and manager, who died Wednesday at the age of 90.

headline: With No Obama Push, Senate Punts on Climate
text: As signs grew that the Senate was in no mood to set up a trading system for curbing carbon dioxide emissions, as I noted how the climate policy debate had circled back lately to the emissions-capping plan for power plants that had been proposed in the 2000 Bush campaign for the presidency, I found myself thinking about the vacuum that’s persisted where President Obama should have been on this issue (if he planned to live up to his campaign commitments). Today Democrats conceded there was no chance for a broad energy bill this session.

headline: M.&A. Market Not Expected to Shake Its Chill Soon
text: The mergers and acquisitions market will continue to be relatively slow in the near term as the world economy tries to recover from the recession, a panel of corporate development experts told deal makers and other financial professionals at the Argyle Executive Forum in New York on Thursday.

headline: Baseball Using Minor Leagues for a Drug Test
text: Major League Baseball announced Thursday that it would immediately expand its drug-testing program by drawing blood from minor league players to test for human growth hormone.

headline: Kinks in the Ethanol Message-Machine?
text: The ethanol industry is feverishly lobbying lawmakers in an effort to hang onto billions of dollars in subsidies that are set to expire — although there appears to be some discord on the message front.

headline: Too Much Crying?
text: Lee Skallerup Bessette knows crying. Her son cried like clockwork every night for months. We humans are programmed to respond with all our neurons when a baby cries, and having had a colicky baby myself I know it’s a toss up as to who suffers most during the wailing — the parent or the child.

headline: From ‘Wicked’ To A Much Smaller Stage
text: Gregory Maguire, whose novel “Wicked: The Life and Times of the Wicked Witch of the West” became the basis for the mega-hit Broadway musical “Wicked,” has dipped into the fairy tale universe again to write his first-ever play. It’s short, like its subject.

headline: First Family to Visit Gulf Coast
text: Before beginning their long-planned summer vacation on Martha’s Vineyard, America’s first family will head to Florida’s oil-stricken Gulf Coast.

headline: Should Patients Read the Doctor’s Notes?
text: Their request seemed simple enough: the patient and his wife, both in their 70s, wanted a copy of what I’d written in their medical file. During their visit, I had watched them refer to a well-thumbed collection of doctors’ notes and medication lists, so when they asked for a copy of my note just before leaving, I assumed it would simply be added to the others.

headline: Whose Records Are They Anyway?
text: Earlier this week, readers debated whether they should have access to the notes doctors write about them. In this week’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen explores the issue further, including the laws giving patients access to their medical records and why many doctors still resist.

Staple, who owns Staple Design and the Lower East Side art gallery/boutique Reed Space, has brought a downtown electric cool to the sporty California eyewear label.

headline: 36 Hours in Florence
text: WITH its Renaissance treasures and centuries-old stately palazzi, Florence is sometimes treated like a living museum rather than a vibrant city with contemporary culture. That myth is harder to sustain these days, thanks in part to Matteo Renzi, the city’s 35-year-old mayor, who was elected last year with promises to stir up the Tuscan capital. Evidence of a more youthful and revitalized Florence is everywhere. Dilapidated piazzas have been refreshed, contemporary art galleries have sprung up, and old-school palazzi have been turned into trendy restaurants. Traffic has also improved, making the city even more pleasant to navigate.

headline: French Connection: K.G.B. Colonel Plotting to Break the Isolation
text: Based on true, surprisingly little-known events that hastened the downfall of the Soviet Union, Christian Carion’s espionage drama, “Farewell (L’Affaire Farewell),” is a refreshing reminder in the age of the Bourne movies that spies are real people leading everyday lives. (We’ll know more about that when a movie is made about the 10 Russian agents sent home this month by the United States.)

headline: A Weekend in Florence
text: Piazzas have been refreshed, contemporary art galleries have sprung up, and palazzi have been turned into trendy restaurants.

headline: House Tour: Gaining Serenity
text: A rental home in Orient, N.Y., offers serenity from atop a widow’s walk overlooking Long Island Sound.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: House Tour: Orient Point, N.Y.
