text: The Texas Rangers’ auction is on — and it looks like Mark Cuban may be there with his paddle raised.

headline: S.E.C. Grants Delay on Ratings Disclosure for Bonds
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday that it was issuing a six-month reprieve on a provision in the recent financial overhaul legislation, allowing issuers of asset-backed bonds to omit credit ratings from their offering documents, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: RPI Snaps Up $5 Million for Custom Photos
text: From VentureBeat:

headline: A New Story for the Old Champion Schumacher
text: For more than a decade, Michael Schumacher drove like a metronome, stacking up 91 Formula One victories and seven world titles. No other driver had ever achieved anything like it. But like so many record-breaking sportsmen, Schumacher came across looking like a cold, calculating, ruthless, armor-skinned robot — with more than a dash of arrogance.

headline: Ford’s Rebound Rolls on as It Posts $2.6 Billion Profit
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — In two years, the Ford Motor Company has gone from losing the most money in its history to earning $26 million a day.

headline: Detroit Continues to Inspire Techno Music Producer
text: Berry Gordy Jr., founder of Motown Records, claimed that Detroit’s assembly lines inspired the sound of his label’s music. The originators of techno dance music, which also got its start in the city, were subject to these surrounding influences, as well, though the mood of the town had changed dramatically by the early 1980s.

headline: Antidepressant Maker Taps $24 Million
text: A group of investors seem quite cheered by Euthymics Bioscience‘s prospects, ponying up $24 million in a first round of financing for the developer of next-generation antidepressants.

headline: U.K. Media Tycoon Said Close to Deal for Channel Five
text: Richard Desmond, the British newspaper baron, shook hands Friday morning on a £100 million ($154 million) deal to buy struggling U.K. national broadcaster, Channel Five, from owner RTL, The Guardian reported.

headline: On Our Radar: Haiti’s Vanishing Forests
text: Reversing decades of deforestation is seen as critical to Haiti’s future. “Planting trees is not just some quaint side project,” a United Nations official says. “It’s the key to rebuilding the country.”

headline: UBS Taps Hong Kong Banker Yam for Board
text: UBS said Friday that it had nominated the former central banker of Hong Kong, Joseph Yam, to join its board of directors next April.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The real stress of the stress tests is in waiting for them to come out, and then trying to find some ad hoc rationale for the inevitable market reaction. It’s been a nail-biter of a morning, with results for 91 European banks set to be released in just a few hours.

headline: In Greece, Stress Tests Not So Hard to Pass
text: In Greece, five of the six banks surveyed are expected to pass the Europe-wide stress tests, the results of which will be released on Friday at midday Eastern time, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: So Holds Lead in Biel, as Negi Gets on the Board
text: Most of the games in Round 4 on Thursday ended in draws, allowing Wesley So to maintain his lead.

headline: Complaint Box | That Was My Cab!
text: A couple of months ago, I downloaded CabSense, a new iPhone app that identifies the best corners in New York City to catch a cab. Now I just need an app that helps me avoid being intercepted by transit bandits.

headline: Strong Earnings and Europe’s Bank News Lift Stocks
text: Stocks climbed Friday as companies continued to report good quarterly earnings and the results of stress tests of European banks did not reveal any negative surprises.

headline: Passions on Display at E.P.A. Meeting
text: If the Environmental Protection Agency had hoped that the hundreds of landowners, students, community activists, environmentalists, and oil and gas representatives invited to a hotel ballroom in southwestern Pennsylvania on Thursday night would really stay on point, they were surely disappointed.

headline: A Queen Works the Crowd at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO — There she was, the Academy Award winner Helen Mirren — she was introduced that way — working the crowd in Hall H at Comic-Con here. It really was like the Cannes Film Festival, with bad food. (On the culinary front, the safest bet inside the convention center would appear to be the bananas, but they cost $2.75 each, no kidding). Ms. Mirren, best known for her Oscar-winning turn as Queen Elizabeth II in “The Queen,” was radiant, and said all the things an actress is supposed to say. “This miraculously came along for me,” she said of her role as a bloody assassin in “Red,” Summit Entertainment’s movie based on a graphic novel. Ms. Mirren said it was delightful working with a cast that included Bruce Willis, John Malkovich and Karl Urban. “It was an unknown world to me, an unknown gen-re,” she said, getting the French pronunciation just right.

headline: Back to School? Not Without a Visa
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Economic Insecurity: The Long View
text: Americans have climbed a historic peak of pain and uncertainty in the past decade, as the economic insecurity of the American families is greater than at any time on record.

headline: Talk Shows Turn to the Internet A-List
text: The height of summer should offer a cornucopia of guests to the late-night talk shows, from paparazzi magnets with new blockbusters to promote (“Salt,” anyone?) to the stars of cult television shows that are about to have their premieres (like, oh, “Mad Men.” “Mad Men”! “MAD MEN”!) But when these higher-wattage names can’t be conjured up (or would rather be at Comic-Con), the talk-shows can always rely on the accidental celebrities of popular Internet videos.

headline: Treasury to Sell 1.5 Billion More Citigroup Shares
text: The Treasury Department said Friday that it plans to sell an additional 1.5 billion shares in Citigroup, as the federal government continues to wind down its stake in the firm.

headline: Henry’s Goal Just the Beginning as M.L.S. Eyes More World Cup Veterans
text: When Thierry Henry first joined Arsenal in 1999, it took the French striker eight games to score his first goal, the lone strike in a 1-0 win over Southampton on Sept. 18, 1999. Then 22, Henry had most of his career ahead of him. Now, a month before his 33rd birthday, his goal-scoring days are more numbered, so he wasted no time opening his account for his new team. He scored Thursday in his New York Red Bulls debut, an exhibition game against Tottenham Hotspur.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on July 11 about Helen Hunt’s playing the Stage Manager in the current Off Broadway production of “Our Town,” at the Barrow Street Theater, misstated the number of actors who have played the role in the current production. Ms. Hunt is the sixth actor, not the fifth, to take on the part.

headline: What We’re Reading: Flipboard
text: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times stopped here on the Web:

headline: ‘Our Town’: Female Stage Managers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nocturnalist | Aerial Acrobatics
text: Were it not for the large man seated on a folding chair on Thursday night outside a nondescript door in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it would have been difficult to tell that the building behind him hosted anything at all, let alone the House of Yes, a school and performance space for acrobats and aerialists.

headline: #Shakespalin
text: Twitter tag for Sarah Palinesque reworkings of Shakespearean quotes.

headline: For Chronic Care, Try Turning to Your Employer
text: IF you are one of the 133 million American grappling with a chronic illness like diabetes, asthma or heart disease, where do you turn for help managing your condition?

headline: Verizon Posts a Loss After Paying for Buyouts
text: Despite the iPhone’s strong gravitational pull, Verizon is managing to attract more new customers than AT&T, the phone’s exclusive American carrier. Verizon also beat analysts’ profit estimates for the second quarter, excluding one-time charges.

headline: Young Dancers: Arts and the City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Senate Backs Small-Business Lending Fund
text: It appeared dead on Wednesday, but it came back to life on Thursday: A fund to encourage small banks to make loans to small businesses, pulled from the Senate’s small-business jobs bill for lack of Republican support, has found its way back into the bill after all. Late Thursday evening, the Senate voted, 60 to 37, to end debate on an amendment that would restore the lending fund to the jobs bill. Two Republicans joined 58 members of the Democratic caucus to overcome a Republican-threatened filibuster. Our colleague David Herszenhorn has the details at The Caucus.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: The Power of Green
text: While the Comic-Con hordes are poised to get their first look at the “Green Lantern” feature film, that righteous, ring-bearing superhero is already all over this week’s hardcover list. The collected edition of “Blackest Night,” the event series about life, death and undeath in the DC universe, lands at No. 1 on the hardcover list. At No. 2 and No. 3 are collected editions of Blackest Night stories that ran in the monthly Green Lantern and Green Lantern Corps series. Expect to see the other hardcover collections of related stories hit in the weeks ahead.

headline: The Early Word: Climate Bill on Ice
text: So much for a comprehensive climate change bill this summer.

headline: Is There Such a Thing as a ‘Mini-Migraine’?
text: Many readers of the Consults blog wanted to learn more about “mini-migraines,” low-level headaches that are not as debilitating as full-blown migraine attacks.

headline: Where to Play Thierry Henry?
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Thierry Henry made his American debut Thursday night in an exhibition match against Tottenham Hotspur and scored the Red Bulls’ only goal in a 2-1 loss.

headline: When Pneumonia Follows Severe Dementia
text: The 323 residents living in Boston-area nursing homes had entered the final stages of dementia.

headline: Friday Reading: The End of Hybrid Pricing Premiums?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: July 25 — 31
text: Art

headline: London Theater Journal: Bright Young Things in a Dimming Light
text: I spent the better part of Wednesday night nursing a hangover. (Vicariously, I mean. I have had exactly two martinis – oh, all right, and one bloody Mary — since I arrived in London.) The big hit now at the National Theater stretches out the masochistic pleasure of one really, really long morning-after to more than three hours of stage time. And capacity audiences are positively wallowing in the experience.

headline: Her Words, His Movement, Their Collaboration
text: AFTER years of invitations the visual artist Jenny Holzerfinally agreed to participate in Summer Stages Dance, thrilling Richard Colton, who founded and directs the Concord, Mass., festival with Amy Spencer. Now he had just one problem.

headline: Jean-Claude And The Invisibles
text: One of these days someone will write a sequel to Liaquat Ahamed’s Lords Of Finance; where LoF was about the men who helped the Great Depression happen, Lords of Finance: The Next Generation will be about the men who helped turn the financial crisis of 2008 into a lost decade of high unemployment and deflation.

headline: After a Century, A Composer’s Day in the Sun
text: AH, the soul of the artist! Penniless Fritz loves penniless Grete but feels compelled to abscond until he has given birth to his elusive masterpiece, an opera. From suicidal depression, Grete bounces to the heights as the top courtesan of Venice, then slides off the grid into sordid backstreet prostitution. There, in a nutshell, is the action of what music historians say was the operatic sensation of 1912: “Der Ferne Klang” (“The Distant Sound”) by Franz Schreker, who was born Franz Schrecker and pronounced the name SHRAY-ker to match the doctored spelling. The libretto, like those of the seven other operas he went on to write, was his own.

headline: Posing as Fitness
text: A few years ago, the pop singer Sting confided to an interviewer that a specific yoga asana, or posture, had enabled him to have sexual intercourse with his wife, the star of a line of yoga videos, for as long as eight hours at a time. “Your stomach,” he said, “goes as near to the spine as you can make it, . . . and you never lose control, you just keep going.” The news of this priapic tour de force “went around the world,” in Sting’s own words, “like a forest fire.” Then he admitted he had been joking. His epic bouts of lovemaking, he said, included “four hours of begging, then a movie and then dinner.”

headline: Diane Sawyer Interviews Mark Zuckerberg
text: It’s been a busy week for Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s founder and chief executive. The site recorded 500 million users, making it, by population, the third largest country in the world — yet this milestone also brought with it a little extra scrutiny.

headline: We All Scream, but Not for Ice Cream
text: In a summer of 90-plus temperatures and smothering humidity, New Yorkers should be grasping for ice cream, frozen yogurt and iced coffees and teas — anything that would produce droplets of cold, wet frost on a cup grasped in a sweaty, overheated hand. But in the summer of 2010, could it be that it’s even too hot for ice cream?

headline: Montana Soccer-Mom Moment
text: I live in northwest Montana, and I have a teenager, and my teenager plays sports. That means a lot of driving — over-the-Rocky-Mountains-and-back-in-one-day kind of driving. I think about Meriwether Lewis every time I cross the Continental Divide, usually with sleeping soccer players wearing headphones in the back of my Suburban. I want to say, “Can you imagine everything depending on your horse and your ability to dream of an ocean past the mountains?” But it isn’t worth the eye-rolling.

headline: Border Rap
text: You’re the former president of Mexico. What do you think of the Arizona immigration bill that is scheduled to take effect this week? It would require immigrants to carry their registration papers at all times and risk jail for not complying.  I think there’s a big misunderstanding on the value of migrants. Unfortunately, since Sept. 11, that very sad day, we have not advanced on the issue. On the contrary, xenophobes have taken over; governments like the one in Arizona are taking negative decisions with a very blinded look at the future.

headline: The Art of the Deal as Entertainment
text: A few days back, when I asked a pal in Hollywood about a movie he had a hand in, he told me that the “project” came together as the result of its female star’s decision to drop her ineffectual old agent in favor of a more influential new one who, in order to demonstrate his power and elevate his ambitious new client’s status, saw fit to build a “package” around her with the help of another client’s script. When I asked my friend what the movie was about — plot-wise, not conference-call-wise or power-lunch-wise — my question appeared to throw him off. Who cares about the story in the film, my friend’s faintly baffled manner seemed to indicate (and aren’t most plots awfully similar nowadays?), compared with the spellbinding story around the film?

headline: A Legacy in Letters
text: The problem I have with epistolary novels is that as I’m reading one I can’t help thinking, Who writes letters this long? Is it typed out or hand­written? Shipping options: Snail mail? Fed­Ex for next-day delivery? Or is it sent as an attachment? In other words, I get self-conscious and distracted, the last thing you want to be when you’re reading a book. Or when you’re reading a letter, for that matter.

headline: How to Get Your Free iPhone Bumper
text: When Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, said the company would offer free iPhone 4 bumpers and cases, he didn’t mention there would be an app for that. But of course, there is.

headline: Was That a Break-In I Saw?
text: Walking down a busy thoroughfare, my boyfriend and I saw a young man clamber onto the awning of a restaurant, pull himself onto the fire escape, climb to the top floor, open a darkened window and slip inside. I found this suspicious, but my boyfriend suggested that he might have lost his keys and entered his own apartment. We phoned the restaurant, and the person who answered said he would investigate. I was reluctant to call the police, fearing they might escalate the situation, but now I wish I had. Thoughts? S.C., SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Take Me to an Elks Lodge and Don’t Step on It
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

headline: 2011 Toyota Avalon
text: Since the current third-generation Avalon appeared five years ago, an update was overdue.

headline: High-debt History
text: Continuing the Chatauqua on Reinhart-Rogoff: it’s a pretty devastating observation that the only observations of high debt / low growth for the United States come from the immediate postwar years, when post-war demobilization naturally led to falling real GDP. But what about the broader picture?

headline: A Pop-Up Theme Park for ‘Tron’
text: SAN DIEGO— “Tron: Legacy,” a movie that explores what it might be like to live inside a ruthless video game, is so omnipresent at this year’s Comic-Con that people are referring to it as “Comic-Tron.” In the Gaslamp Quarter here on Thursday night, it was certainly all about that movie, which the Walt Disney Company will release on Dec. 17.

headline: Digital Tools for Making Brilliant Mistakes
text: Imperfections attract, or at least that must be the guiding belief behind a new digital camera described on an e-commerce site as producing “a soft, out-of-focus feel that brings back the feeling of your old Super 8mm home movies.” A sample video made with the Digital Harinezumi backs it up: nearly three minutes of found-this-in-the-attic aesthetics. It’s just the sort of crude quality that digital camcorders elbowed aside years ago.

headline: Parents Losing Sleep
text: The math is exhausting.

headline: Ugly Truths
text: Judgment is everywhere these days. It thrives on comment boards, on blogs. Public figures from politicians to the Real Housewives talk about not playing a “blame game” even as they blithely blame everyone but themselves. The novelist Joshua Mohr is acutely aware of this phenomenon and has smartly woven it into his wry and unnerving story of bad love gone rotten, “Termite Parade.”

headline: Dear Ecuador: It’s Not You, It’s Me
text: There’s no easy way to say this, Ecuador, but it’s over. It was what it was: a quickie ranchera bus ride from the Peruvian border, a brief swing through Loja, and a flight to Quito before I slipped out your northern door. You deserved so much more.

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | A Pop Star Grows Up
text: As you may know, our Summer Reading Challenge is continuing on a weekly basis all summer, and each week yields a “favorite” student comment that gets featured here. If you haven’t entered yet this week, you can do so through this Sunday, here.

headline: What ‘Platonic’ Means Online
text: Why would one person seek another in our cynical world if not for goods, services, sex or money?

headline: Genever and Dutch Food at Vandaag
text: With interest in the ancient Dutch style of gin known as genever  growing in cocktail circles, it was only a matter of time before a genever bar opened in New York. Vandaag, near the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Sixth Street in the East Village, will be the first when it has its soft opening on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Premiere Event Planned for Times Square
text: Heard of this television series, “Mad Men”? A few guys and a few gals work in an agency, sell a couple ads, have a couple laughs? Are you so eager for the premiere of its fourth season that you’d leave your home and brave Times Square to watch it an hour before the rest of the East Coast? Or are you so sick to death of that show’s rabid fan base that you’d like to arm yourself with a few advance details so you can ruin the surprises for your “Mad Men”-worshiping friends? (Seriously, though, don’t do that.) Would you just like to meet the actress who plays Peggy Olsen?

headline: The Insatiable Years
text: Allegra Goodman’s new novel has so many appealing ingredients. Where, then, to start the list? Perhaps, as with food labels, it would be best to begin with the biggest: an irresistible story. Then add four strong characters: two sisters, and the two men who orbit them. Then there’s the narrative voice: sweet but not cloyingly so, nourishing but not heavy, serving up zesty nuggets of truth. And the spicing is piquant but not too assertive, thanks to memorable appearances by (among others) a Bialystok rabbi, a bookshop called Yorick’s, a collection of letters from a long-dead mother and a tribe of tree-huggers.

headline: Man Will Appeal Prison Term for Lying During Seduction in Jerusalem
text: Sabbar Kashur, a married Palestinian man who was convicted of “rape by deception” by an Israeli court this week, for telling a Jewish woman that he was a Jewish bachelor interested in a long-term relationship before they had consensual sex, will appeal an 18-month prison sentence, according to CNN.

headline: Iraq, Again
text: Karl Rove now tells us that his “biggest mistake” was not fighting back against the perception that the Bush administration deliberately misled us into the Iraq war. His main evidence that nothing like that happened is the fact that a 2005 commission found no wrongdoing.

headline: Creatures of the Revolution
text: Alexander Hamilton, eulogizing the renowned general Nathanael Greene in 1789, claimed that without the American Revolution, Greene’s true genius might never have been revealed. Jack Rakove, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian at Stanford University, applies Hamilton’s insight about Greene to the entire cohort of Revolutionary leaders in his elegantly written new book. Part collective biography, part narrative history of the years 1773 to 1792, “Revolutionaries” adeptly explores the factors that led these remarkable men to reject British sovereignty and create a new nation. “The Revolution made them,” Rakove asserts, “as much as they made the Revolution.”

headline: Israel Puts Off Crisis Over Conversion Law
text: JERUSALEM — A growing crisis between American Jews and the Israeli government over a proposed law on religious conversion was averted — or at least delayed — this week, with both sides agreeing to a six-month period of negotiation. But the depth of American anger and the byzantine complexity of Israeli politics suggest that a solution is a long way off.

headline: Votes Are In, and the Fin Has Won
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Full Disclosure | Comporta, Portugal
text: About an hour south of Lisbon lies Comporta, a quiet stretch of Portuguese coast that some of the country’s oldest families as well as designers like Jacques Grange and Christian Louboutin have turned into their secret summer holiday. Dotted with thatched fishermen cottages, pine forests and rice fields, Comporta doesn’t look like much at first glance. And that’s how sun-seeking summer residents would like to keep it. But a recent tour of the pristine beaches (much of the area is preserved by a private company, Herdade da Comporta), boho-style boutiques and the charming shacks that have been glammed up by families and fashion folks alike revealed that this hidden piece of paradise might be the next “It” destination on the Montauk-Jose Ignacio- Ibiza circuit. The Aman resort is betting on the same — it’s opening a property here in 2012.

headline: Video: Anthony Tommasini on Counterpoint
text: There is a whole language of technical jargon to describe music. Though these words and concepts are very handy to musicians, they tend to mystify non-musicians. Even people who go to concerts all the time, upon being confronted with terms like chromatic harmony, passacaglia and sonata form may have no real idea what they mean.

headline: Rock of Ages
text: The Velvet Underground sang of dope and beauty, good times and damnation, the lust for experience and the deliverance of grace. Their ­second- or third-most-famous anthem was about a jaded 5-year-old named Ginny (or Jenny, depending on the listener). One bored day, she turned on a New York radio station, and “she couldn’t believe what she heard at all.” Emancipation called: “She started dancin’ to that fine, fine music” (Lou Reed approximating a soul falsetto for that “fine, fine” part). The walls around her tiny uptight world tumbled: “You know her life was saved by rock ’n’ roll.”

headline: Officials Plan to Eliminate 170,000 Canada Geese in New York
text: Updated 11:25 p.m. | A longer, fuller version of this article can be read here.

headline: A Cruise to Antarctica Cools It on Rates
text: A voyage to Antarctica, a bucket-list trip for many, often requires a five-figure budget. But the travel industry’s downturn has forged at least one short-but-sweet deal on departures to the southernmost continent.

headline: Carrying On
text: Two-thirds of the way through her vivid account of the aftermath of the carnage we glamorize as the Great War, Juliet Nicolson recalls the extraordinary British success of “J’Accuse,” a silent film directed by the French war veteran and pacifist Abel Gance, which ended with the hallucinatory image of an army of the dead rising from no man’s land to confront an audience of cringing civilians. Through the caption, “J’Accuse,” these wraiths demanded whether the survivors’ salvation had been worth the blood price. The 2,000 men Gance recruited for the scene were French soldiers on leave from Verdun. Eighty percent of them, Nicolson informs us, would be killed in the fighting.

headline: G.M.’s Free Ride on the Government’s Dime
text: Extra cash is not always a good thing for a corporation. This may be the case with General Motors.

headline: Smoking Up the Grill With Eggplant
text: Few foods are as suited to summer grilling as the eggplant, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: 1941 Tatra T 87
text: Paul Greenstein says his Tatra is a fairly stealthy ride on the streets of Los Angeles.

headline: Easier Living, by Design
text: In 1950, industrial designers Mary and Russel Wright published the “Guide to Easier Living,” a handbook for the modern home intended to liberate women from old-fashioned formal entertaining, and families from old-fashioned and high-maintenance furniture.

headline: The Errors of Our Ways
text: In 1650, Oliver Cromwell asked the Church of Scotland to reconsider its decision to side with the royalists instead of him. “I beseech you, in the bowels of Christ, think it possible you may be mistaken.” The church didn’t think it possible, of course, so Oliver’s army took Scotland.

headline: In Big Condé Nast Shift, Sauerberg Becomes President; Townsend Remains Chief
text: Condé Nast announced on Friday that it is splitting the job of its chief executive officer and president in two, the latest in a series of high-level management reshuffling that has shaken the magazine publishing world’s crown jewel.

headline: Oil Rig’s Siren Was Kept Silent, Technician Says
text: KENNER, La.  The emergency alarm on the Deepwater Horizon was not fully activated the day the oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 people and setting off the massive spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a rig worker on Friday told a government panel investigating the accident.

headline: If It Causes Stress, Is It Really a Vacation Home?
text: EVERYONE needs a place to live, but no one needs a second home. So choosing which vacation home to buy and where should be enjoyable. Still, people routinely buy second homes that end up being less than they expected, or worse.

headline: Rival Studios Resolve Dispute Over ‘Precious’
text: More than a year after the Lee Daniels film “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ By Sapphire” caught the attention of moviegoers – and two rival film studios – at the Sundance Film Festival, a lawyer for Lionsgate said that it had reached an agreement with the Weinstein Company and that a lawsuit involving the film’s rights has been dismissed, Reuters reported.

headline: Weekend Competition: Damned Dems & Wretched Reps
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to abandon any pretense of bipartisanship and offer novel definitions of Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Study Confirms Some BP Oil Stayed Deep
text: Federal oceanographers have released their second report assessing how much of the oil that gushed from the Gulf of Mexico seabed since the blowout of the BP well may have dispersed in ocean depths rather than rising to the surface. The new analysis confirms the previous conclusion that some oil did in fact drift and disperse in waters between 3,300 and 4,300 feet beneath the surface.

headline: The Stockbrokers That Customers Like Best
text: Edward Jones ranked highest for investor satisfaction among full-service brokerage firms, according to a new study from J. D. Power & Associates.

headline: At War With Itself
text: The scandal known as the Dreyfus Affair still resonates after more than a century, though it has been blurred for most Americans by time and distance. It is the goal of the Oxford historian Ruth Harris to extricate the story from the myths it has generated, on both the left and the right, and to trace its tortuous evolution from 1894 to 1906 in all of its human complexity. Combining an even-tempered tone with generosity of imagination, she has achieved that goal, charting a steady course through the voluminous literature that the affair inspired and exploring the reactions of scores of soldiers, politicians, journalists, salonnières and ordinary citizens. A helpful “Dramatis Personae” at the end of the book lists nearly 150 people, all of whom are given substantial treatment during the course of the narrative.

headline: Mad Men City | Answers From a Real Mad Man, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Ed McCabe, who worked for a number of major advertising agencies and is a founder of Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

headline: The Heart of a Realist
text: When the former diplomat and Pulitzer Prize-winning writer George F. Kennan died in 2005, obituary writers were quick to proclaim him one of the most influential Americans of his age. By conceiving the “containment” strategy that guided United States foreign policy throughout the cold war, Kennan not only stamped his ideas on an entire era of the nation’s history but also, eulogists suggested, pointed the way to the ultimate American victory over Soviet Communism.

headline: Hit Men, Freudians and Furriers
text: English on her father’s side, Mary-Kay Wilmers, the editor of The London Review of Books, is related on her Russian mother’s side to the dangerous and flamboyant Eitingons. In this chatty and often engaging group biography, she portrays three of them: Max (1881-1943), a psychiatrist and member of Freud’s inner circle; Motty (1885-1956), furrier extraordinaire, who continued an already successful family business (“We never talked about money,” one relative remarked, “because we had so much of it”); and Leonid (1899-1981), a dashing assassin for the Soviet secret police (“I hold my life no more precious,” he explained, “than the secrets the state has entrusted me with”).

headline: Tour Comes Down to Final Time Trial
text: BORDEAUX, France  Andy Schleck, who is only eight seconds behind the leader, Alberto Contador, in the Tour de France, is not delirious when he says he may beat Contador in Saturday’s time trial. He knows exactly what he is up against.

headline: Paying Extra Attention to Worker Health
text: In the latest Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad looks at the chronic care programs offered by many businesses.

headline: After the Climate Bill Failure
text: With the Senate slinking away from any effort to control climate-altering carbon emissions, the frustrated and perplexed are asking, now what? Can federal and state governments move ahead under existing law to achieve some or all of the greenhouse gas reductions envisioned in the failed legislation?

headline: Up Front: Miranda Seymour
text: Among Miranda Seymour’s many books are biographies of Mary Shelley and Henry James; stories set on the island of Corfu; five historical novels; a compendium of useful information for gardeners; a memoir about growing up in an English manor house; and full-length portraits of two little-known but very adventurous ladies, the record-breaking racing driver Hellé Nice and the actress Virginia Cherrill, star of Chaplin’s “City Lights,” who was once married to Cary Grant.

headline: Inside the List
text: WHAT THE DOG SAID: “The Obama Diaries,” Laura Ingraham’s snarky commentary on a fictional stash of secret White House journals she “discovered” in the garage of the Watergate complex, enters at No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Wait a minute, nonfiction? Yes, and there are precedents. In 1991, a reader wrote to the Book Review to complain about the appearance of “Millie’s Book,” an autobiography of the White House springer spaniel transcribed by Barbara Bush, on the nonfiction list. “Everybody knows that only a very few, very talented dogs can talk, and then only on ‘America’s Funniest Home Videos,’ ” Jack O’Dea of Grand Coulee, Wash., wrote. The folks who create the best-seller list — which is compiled independently of the Book Review — were following their own policy on the gray area of satire, as well as the lead of the publisher and the Library of Congress; both classified the book, which recounts actual events from a canine point of view, as nonfiction.

headline: How Are Koreans Different? Please Ask
text: On the Screen

headline: Vandals Damage Memorial to Egyptian Woman Killed in Germany
text: BERLIN  Vandals damaged several pieces of a memorial to a pregnant Egyptian woman who was stabbed to death in a Dresden courtroom last year, the police said Friday.

headline: Test Yourself | July 23, 2010
text: We’re experimenting with a week of history questions based on archival Times articles about key events that happened during the week of July 19-25. Tell us what you think, below.

headline: Liberal Elites and Conservative Illusions
text: In a post earlier this week, I quoted a passage from Angelo Codevilla’s critique of the American overclass, about the present elite’s relative cultural and political homogeneity, that seemed to me essentially correct. Now I’m going to mention some things that I think he gets wrong, because I think they’re characteristic conservative errors about the state of our politics in general, and the relationship between the highly-educated mass upper class and the rest of the country in particular.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CITRUS COUNTY,  by John Brandon (McSweeney’s Rectangulars, $22.) With a smart hero somehow mean and bighearted at once, Brandon grippingly hybridizes the crime novel with the novel of rural adolescent longing, even as he subverts the expectations of both.

headline: Paperback Row
text: UNDER THE DOME,  by Stephen King (Gallery, $19.99.) One beautiful autumn day, an enormous transparent dome descends over a small Maine town. A devious second selectman takes control of the police department and, backed by a squad of goons, sweeps to power while a town leader congratulates them on doing “a hell of a job.” Interlocking stories and more than 100 characters create a sense that a real community is being described in this novel, even as King entertains and makes larger points.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Stockbrokers That Customers Like Best
text: From Jennifer Saranow Schultz at Bucks:

headline: ‘Animal Farm’ Musical May Arrive Before Pigs Fly
text: Has the theater world found another “Lion King”? For their next stage project, Elton John and Lee Hall are adapting a work about talking animals that no English-language reader of the last 65 years could possibly be unfamiliar with and is still widely taught in schools. Oh, and before you break out your checkbook to buy tickets or to invest, you should also know it’s a metaphor for the rise of Stalinism.

headline: Weekdays, Creating Ads. Sunday, Invoking Spirits.
text: Sometime around 9:30 a.m. on weekdays, Itzhak Beery enters a second-floor office in Greenwich Village to preside over his piece of the material world. It is an advertising agency, the latest he has owned in a 30-year career. Five computers await him, each thrumming with software for graphic design. Shelves hold the awards he has won.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Going on Tour
text: Borrowing a strategy from the spring’s biggest reality show, “American Idol,” the summer’s biggest reality show, “America’s Got Talent,” is taking its top contestants on tour.

headline: In a Family of Power Siblings, One Focuses on the Table
text: ZEKE EMANUEL was dismembering a duck.

headline: App Smart Extra: Funtoxication
text: Fun apps can make for a safer road trip with children, since bickering siblings are one of the more potent distractions for a driver. I wrote about a bunch of apps to keep children entertained on road trips in this week’s App Smart column.

headline: Star Filly Rachel Alexandra Joins the Party at Monmouth
text: The Monmouth Park formula is a simple one: spread a lot of money around fewer races and reap the rewards. It has worked beyond all expectations through the first 27 days of the 50-day “Elite Meet,” which has included quality racing, big fields and triple-digit increases in betting handle. Now, Monmouth is digging into its bank account again to attract one of the sport’s biggest names.

headline: TimesCast | July 23, 2010
text: Today, Tropical Storm Bonnie halts spill response efforts, European banks face a stress test, and New Orleans gender-bending bounce rap scene breaks out and goes national.

headline: Prospect Partying | Fashion’s Night Outerborough
text: “I take full responsibility for this amazing weather,” said Mayor Bloomberg at last night’s annual Prospect Park Summer Soirée. No doubt the guests were thankful for the breeze. Guests at the disco-themed party hosted by the park’s junior committee, which was chaired by T editor Sally Singer, boogied down to music by DJ Scott Devendorf of the National – including Chris Taylor of the band Grizzly Bear, Dana Lorenz of Fenton, J. Crew’s Jenna Lyons, designers Jeffrey Costello and Robert Tagliapietra, and Suno designers Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty. (“I thought about wearing my white polyester suit, but I thought I’d better not,” said the mayor of the evening’s theme.) Singer’s guests included 2010 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund finalists, who could be found chatting in the boathouse: designer Prabal Gurung, jewelry designers Pamela Love and Eddie Borgo (with stylist Keegan Singh close by) and Altuzarra’s Joseph Altuzarra (who worked up quite a sweat not on the dance floor but rather from his favorite backpack: “I don’t suggest wearing a backpack to a disco party,” he said). CFDA alumni Philip Crangi, Sophie Théallet and Vena Cava’s Sophie Buhai and Lisa Mayock gave a warm and excited toast to the 2010 gang. Between drinks, dancing and bidding in the fund-raiser auction (a tax-deductible Lanvin shoulder bag!), the far-out draw of the night were the electric boat rides that designer Mandy Coon coined “groovy.” We can dig it.

headline: London Theater Journal: O’Neill and Williams, With Something in Common
text: “Oh, they’ll grow out of it,” I said to myself at the National Theater on Thursday, watching the work of two exceptionally bleak young playwrights. In the book-ended full-length plays that I saw in their final double bill at the small Cottesloe Theater, these fledgling dramatists were condemning all their young characters to lonely, trapped, sexually tormented existences from which there was no escape. To borrow a phrase that one of those writers would use elsewhere, the unhappy souls who inhabit “Beyond the Horizon” and “Spring Storm” are destined to live out a life sentence of “solitary confinement inside their own skins.”

headline: 7 Banks in Europe Fail Stress Tests for Scant Capital
text: Seven of Europe’s 91 largest banks could not survive an unexpected decline in economic growth or a sharp deterioration in the value of European government bonds and will need to raise more capital, regulators said Friday in releasing results of closely watched bank stress tests.

headline: Flowers for Monisha – a Woman in F1
text: It really struck me as outlandish when the official questioner at yet another official Formula One press conference introduced Monisha Kaltenborn as the first woman to ever to be the subject of such a press conference.

headline: The Week in Pictures, July 23
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: In ’08 Downturn, Some Managed to Eke Out Millions
text: EVEN in a bad year, some people can get very lucky.

headline: Two Cases, One Approach: Put the City on Trial
text: Two cases of municipal tragedy wound their way through the Manhattan courts this week, each, though very different in their facts, bound by similar tactics: putting the city on trial.

headline: Obama Urges Action on Small Business Bill
text: President Obama, fresh from his victory lap after Senate passage of a bill to extend unemployment insurance, called on lawmakers to finish work on a small-business jobs proposal that had been held up by partisan fighting.

headline: Daniel Schorr, Journalist, Dies at 93
text: Daniel Schorr, whose aggressive reporting over 70 years as a respected broadcast and print journalist brought him into conflict with censors, the Nixon administration and network superiors, died on Friday in Washington. He was 93.

headline: Europe’s Gap
text: Listening to the comments of Jean-Claude Trichet and others, you might have the impression that Europe is well on the way to recovering from its slump. So I took a look at the actual numbers, and even though I sort of knew what they said, it was a bit of a shock.

headline: Daniel Schorr, Journalist, Enemy Of Nixon and His Own Bosses, Dies at 93
text: Robert D. Hershey Jr. has the Times obituary:

headline: Israel: Military Kills a Palestinian
text: The Israeli military said soldiers had opened fire on three Palestinians approaching Barkan, a Jewish settlement in the northern West Bank, before dawn on Thursday, suspecting that one was armed. One Palestinian was killed, they said, and the two others fled. The Palestinian Authority government condemned the killing.

headline: Of Friends and Fighters
text: West Point isn’t the most natural environment for a kid like me: a chubby, Indian-born, vegetarian Hindu. Sometimes, I join my friends and family in marveling how on earth I ended up there, perhaps more so how I made it through. But when considering the recipe to my success at the academy, my heart finds the key ingredient in people like First Lt. Christopher Goeke. Then Cadet Goeke, Chris was my dear friend, my West Point classmate, and my polar opposite.

headline: Design Goes to the White House
text: Design had its day in the sun on Wednesday (and a hot sun it was, with temperatures in the 90s) in Washington, D.C. The winners of the National Design Awards, sponsored by the Cooper Hewitt, National Design Museum — along with the finalists and jury members — attended a Teen Design Fair at the Smithsonian American Art Museum’s Renwick Gallery, where a sort of speed-dating setup had more than 400 students hopping from table to table learning what is like to be, say, a graphic designer (from this year’s honoree in communication design, Stephen Doyle) or an interior designer (William Sofield, another honoree). One juror, Jenna Lyons of J. Crew, drew a crowd at her table, as did the fashion guru and keynote speaker Tim Gunn, who advised the students, “Whatever you do, do it 150 percent.”

headline: Subaru Recalls Outback and Legacy for Transmission Problem
text: Subaru is recalling 809 of its 2010-11 Outbacks and Legacys because no lubrication hole was drilled on the 6-speed manual transmission.

headline: Alexander a No on Kagan
text: Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, announced on Friday that he would not support Solicitor General Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court, citing his concern over her decision to ban military recruiters from parts of the campus while she was dean of Harvard Law School.

headline: The Right Ball Can Be as Important as the Right Club
text: Where was Paula Creamer’s trademark pink ball when she won this month’s United States Women’s Open?

headline: Rangel Speaks, and Asks for Time
text: In his first news conference since learning his fellow lawmakers would put up him on trial for ethics violations, Representative Charles B. Rangel urged his constituents and the press to be patient, saying he would not address the specifics of the charges against him until the proceedings begin next week.

headline: Helen Simmons and Phil Collen
text: ON stage the hard-rocking guitarist is known as the short-haired shirtless one. But Phil Collen can also be a master of understatement.

headline: Microsoft Grabs Hold of ARM
text: Microsoft flicked a dash of mystery into the air on Friday by announcing a new, improved and extended tie-up with ARM.

headline: Margaux Laskey, Scott Garapolo
text: Margaux Jane Treloar Laskey and Scott Charles Garapolo were married Saturday evening in a nondenominational ceremony at the Calvin Coolidge State Historic Site in Plymouth, Vt. Paul H. Worden, a Zen Buddhist priest who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: The Dark Clouds Devised by Europe’s Bank Testers
text: FRANKFURT  For the stress tests to achieve their goal of restoring the good name of European banking, everything hinges on whether the criteria that regulators used was tough enough to convince investors in the coming days.

headline: Soccer’s Growth in the U.S. Seems Steady
text: The vuvuzelas have gone quiet, the national flags have been put away, and the cable sports networks are back to talking about baseball. But the World Cup in South Africa has left its mark on soccer in the United States, and, if pattern holds, it will help the sport continue to grow in this country.

headline: Armed and (Possibly) Dangerous at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO— One of the weirdest of the many weird rituals at Comic-Con is “weapons-tagging.” Many attendees come armed, and a watchful security squad has to make sure it’s all in fun. So mock weapons have to be tagged at a special booth just inside the San Diego Convention Center.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Allegra Goodman
text: This week: Allegra Goodman dicusses her novel “The Cookbook Collector”; Stefanie Syman talks about the long history of yoga in America; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Vic Ziegel, Sportswriter and Editor, Dies at 72
text: Vic Ziegel, who cast a wry eye on the sports world in nearly half a century as a sportswriter, columnist and editor in New York, died Friday morning. He was 72 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Mad Men City | Your Photos
text: This week on City Room, we brought you the news from 1964, the story behind the famous eating establishment Jimmy’s La Grange, the Time & Life building, advertisements from that year, a real supernumerary from the Metropolitan Opera and a real Mad Man.

headline: For Most Occupations, Pay Is Highest in San Francisco Area
text: Of all the country’s major metro areas, the San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland area of California has the highest average pay for civilian workers.  It was, in fact, 20 percent above the national average in 2009.

headline: A Brighter Day for Gulf Fisheries
text: In a rare bit of good news for the Gulf Coast, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has announced that it is reopening more than 26,000 square miles of federal waters in the gulf to commercial and recreational fishing. The waters reopened represent roughly one-third of the total area that had been closed to fishing because of the oil spill and lie southeast of BP’s blown-out well.

headline: Parenting Wisdom from ‘Mad Men’
text: Sunday is National Parents Day. It is also the return of the TV show “Mad Men.”

headline: Married, but Sleeping Alone
text: MY grandparents had a secret. When I was growing up in Savannah, Ga., in the 1970s, my paternal grandparents lived in the house immediately behind us. (My uncle lived next door in a set-up my father likened to Faulkner.) But my grandparents did something in their otherwise typical suburban home that was always something of a mystery to me.

headline: The Unexpected Costs of Owning a Second Home
text: In this weekend’s “Wealth Matters” column, Paul Sullivan offers a sobering reminder of just how “relaxing” second home ownership can be.

headline: Student Crossword | Disasters
text: “Disasters teach more than successes. While that idea may sound paradoxical, it is widely accepted among engineers,” begins a recent Science Times article, “Taking Lessons From What Went Wrong.”

headline: In Santa Fe, an Early Look at a New Opera
text: SANTA FE, N.M. -– Opera companies typically do not want critics anywhere near a dress rehearsal for a major new production. The goal of a final dress is to plow through the performance without stopping. But sometimes singers do not sing full out, in order to conserve their voices. A dress rehearsal is the last chance to correct musical details and fiddle with staging. It’s not a place for critics.

headline: Immigration Officer Sentenced in Sex-Coercion Case
text: The federal immigration officer had already pleaded guilty to coercing oral sex from a 22-year-old Colombian woman who was seeking a green card as the wife of an American citizen. But the officer, Isaac R. Baichu, whose demands for sex were caught on tape by the woman in December 2007, still hoped to avoid his negotiated sentence, 1½ to 4½ years in prison, when he appeared in a Queens courtroom in a wheelchair on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Any Remedies for the Mets?
text: Now that the Mets are halfway to the collapse of 2010, does anyone have any suggestions?

headline: They Trailed in the Balloting, but Are Winners All the Same
text: EVEN as a student in the 1980s, Carl Madson knew he simply had to have a Jaguar E-Type. Indeed, he bought one, but it would be decades before he made his first drive in the red car, which was voted runner-up in the Collectible Car of the Year contest.

headline: Audi RS5 to Arrive in U.S. in 2012
text: Ending months of speculation, Audi’s North America chief executive, Johan de Nysschen, revealed on Friday that the German automaker would begin delivery of its RS5 to North American dealerships in early 2012. The ultrahigh-performance version of the A5 two-door coupe will be sold here as a 2012 model, Mr. de Nysschen said in an interview at The Times.

headline: The Dark Clouds Devised by Europe’s Bank Testers
text: For the stress tests to achieve their goal of restoring the good name of European banking, everything hinges on whether the criteria that regulators used was tough enough to convince investors, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing and Matthew Saltmarsh report.

headline: Now Shopping | Rag & Bone’s New Lines (and New Space)
text: Rag & Bone might have ruffled some downtown feathers with the opening of its new store in the former Cafe Colonial space, but the three new companion collections to its women’s line are frill-free. The simply titled, Jean, Shirt and Knit are the epitome of modern basics. They’re showcased in the sun-drenched NoLIta location, which is ideally located on the southeast corner of Elizabeth and Houston Streets — perhaps not so ideal for the regular customers of Cafe Colonial, which became an institution in its 15 years of feeding the neighborhood.

headline: Oil Giant Fined for Shipping Sludge to Ivory Coast
text: A Dutch court on Friday imposed the maximum fine of 1 million Euros, or $1.28 million, on the oil trading company Trafigura for illegally exporting highly toxic sludge that ended up dumped in Ivory Coast. The stinking waste was eventually linked to the deaths of 16 people and thousands of illnesses in 2006.

headline: Living in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn
text: A Brooklyn neighborhood adjacent to Prospect Park offers attractive tree-lined blocks of houses and prewar apartment buildings, along with a sense of community.

headline: Taking Sportbike Power to the Open Road
text: Middlefield, Mass.

headline: 2010 Honda VFR1200F
text: The new VFR1200F is a machine bristling with innovation.

headline: ‘The Cookbook Collector’
text: Chapter One

headline: Longer Unemployment Equals Worse Re-employment
text: Compared to people out of work for only a short while, people who have been unemployed for long periods of time are more likely to say that the new job they eventually find is worse than their old one.

headline: Learning to Live With a Shiftless Motorcycle
text: THE dual-clutch transmission, once a racing-bred option reserved for exotic sports cars, is quickly filtering into the automotive mainstream. Even the Volkswagen Golf offers a version, giving buyers the choice of manually changing gears or letting the transmission shift automatically, all without ever needing to push a clutch pedal.

headline: How to Cook Camel
text: I have been learning a lot about the area and its inhabitants. Kalacha lies at the northern tip of the Chalbi desert, which extends south for probably 60 miles or more. Lake Turkana lies to the west; most of the famous hominid fossils found in Turkana are from the western side of the lake, and not near to where we are. To the north is Ethiopia. Before reaching Ethiopia, however, is a mountain range called the Huri hills. I will not have time to get there on this trip, but they are said to have some of the best grazing land in all of Kenya. The area is green because of continual moisture from clouds. Unfortunately, there is no permanent water source in the hills, so the herdsman move their cattle between the Huris and the springs along the edge of the Chalbi after the water from the rainy season dries up.

headline: Forty Years Ago, Another Contract Dispute
text: Ilya Kovalchuk’s (almost) $100 million Devils deal reminded me of the telephone call I got one summer day 40 years ago. It was from Brad Park’s “agent,” a relatively new job title in the world of sports. Park, after his sophomore season, was an All-Star with the Rangers, and slated to earn about $14,000.

headline: The Decline and Fall of the Bachelor Pad
text: Bachelors have been walloped, but many are taking their lumps and moving on.

headline: Goodbye, Hello
text: JUST after 7 on a Sunday night in late summer, Tim Foster will take the stage of a Civil War-era theater at Bowdoin College and instruct the 500 new freshmen arrayed before him to “reprogram yourselves.”

headline: ‘What is Left the Daughter’
text: Chapter One

headline: Off the Menu: Valentino’s on the Green
text: The stately building in Bayside, Queens, next to the Clearview Golf Course, with a view of the Throgs Neck Bridge, was once the home of Rudolph Valentino. So the Italian restaurant and catering space that will open there in September will be called Valentino’s on the Green. After Valentino’s departure it became a summer residence for Fiorello H. La Guardia, so the restaurant’s two dining rooms will be the Valentino Room and the Fiorello Room.

headline: Advice on the Transition From Applicant to College Student
text: In just a few weeks, hundreds of thousands of teenagers will begin packing suitcases and the trunks of their parents’ cars for what promises to be a long ride. They will be traveling the winding road not just from home to college, but from their former lives as applicants to their new incarnations as actual, first-year students.

headline: Chic in Review | That’s Professor Franco to You
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Allegra Goodman
text: This week: Allegra Goodman dicusses her novel “The Cookbook Collector”; Stefanie Syman talks about the long history of yoga in America; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Buyout Groups Persist in Pursuing Failing Banks
text: 12:55 p.m. | Corrected Private equity firms and hedge funds are still trying to take over community banks a year after the government instituted strict new rules that made it more difficult for nonbanking institutions to acquire failed banks. But the takeovers have been slow going, Matthew Goldstein of Reuters reports, with fewer than two dozen of the more than 236 banks shut by the government since January 2009 sold at auction to private equity firms and hedge funds.

headline: F.D.A. Approves First Generic Blood Thinner
text: The Food and Drug Administration Friday approved the first generic version of Sanofi-Aventis’s big-selling blood thinner Lovenox, in an action that could offer hints of how the agency will handle generic biotechnology drugs.

headline: On Films and TV, Cats and Dogs Playing Cute
text: This is the way the world will end: not with a bang, but with a woof. Or perhaps a meow. Or, more likely, both.

headline: A, as in Apple
text: A glitchy computer is nobody’s friend, especially a laptop. With good guidance, do-it-yourselfers with some basic knowledge of how a PC works can sometimes fix a problem with a desktop box, but cracking open a densely packed portable machine requires a much more advanced skill set.

headline: For Bobby Fischer, the Drama Won’t Die
text: THE life of Bobby Fischer was one strange odyssey, in which he went from chess prodigy (at 14, the youngest United States champion ever), to the vanquisher of the famed Boris Spassky in 1972 in a match followed around the world, to a fugitive from the United States on charges of violating a trade embargo, to an increasingly odd recluse, one who denounced Jews and praised the attacks on the World Trade Center in 2001.

headline: Accuser of Paterson Aide Meets With Prosecutors
text: Sherr-una Booker, the woman who has accused a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson of domestic violence, met with representatives from the Bronx district attorney’s office on Friday in what could be a prelude to a formal investigation.

headline: Admissions Highs and Lows
text: This month and next, colleges and universities are putting final touches on the class of 2014. While most institutions have wrapped things up for the fall, a few wait-listed students may yet get a fat envelope.

headline: ‘Revolutionaries’
text: Prologue: The World Beyond Worcester

headline: An iPhone App Has TKTS Information, but Not Its Endorsement
text: A new iPhone application being sold by an independent theatrical producer that promises up-to-the-minute information on discounted Broadway and Off-Broadway tickets sold at the TKTS booth in Times Square has been met with skepticism by the Theater Development Fund, which runs the TKTS discount program and which raised questions about the accuracy of the application.

headline: Differing ‘Visions’ for Nassau Coliseum Site
text: Hempstead

headline: No Longer Business as Usual, Condé’s Townsend Says
text: The management shifts at Condé Nast on Friday, the end result of a six-month study by corporate efficiency experts McKinsey & Company, signaled a fundamental restructuring of the advertising-based business model that has long sustained the company.

headline: Now Drinking | Matcha Pops Up
text: Alissa White’s antidote to New York’s hustle and bustle came in the form of matcha, the Japanese powdered green tea. To that end, White decided to open a pop-up shop in June to help promote her online business, Matcha Source, which sells everything from premium teas to tulip-shaped bamboo whisks.

headline: Preparations for 2012 Said to Be on Schedule
text: Sebastian Coe, chairman of the London Organizing Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, said he remained upbeat about preparations for the 2012 Games despite Britain’s economic woes, which have prompted proposals for deep budget cuts by its government. Coe said his organizing committee, which is not a government agency, had raised enough money to keep preparations going at full speed.

headline: A.M. Stern Building Pushes the Boundary of Luxe
text: THE designers of 1280 Fifth Avenue  a condominium rising on East 109th Street at the northeast corner of Central Park  have strong connections to Manhattan’s famous patch of green. The beige limestone building is the work of Robert A.M. Stern Architects, whose 15 Central Park West, at the park’s southwest corner, has been setting condo price records. The airy interiors are by Andre Kikoski, who recently designed the Wright, an award-winning restaurant in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, at 89th and Fifth Avenue.

headline: Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn
text: KIMBERLEE AULETTA grew up in Midtown, and for a long time Manhattan was where she imagined she would stay. Despite family roots in Brooklyn, where her father had grown up, she had never really considered moving there.

headline: Duvall, Nearly 80, Is Still a Darling of Hollywood
text: WHEN it came time to fill the lead role in “Get Low”  which embellishes the real-life story of a septuagenarian Tennessee hermit who gave his own “funeral party” in 1938 while still alive  the options weren’t plentiful for the people behind the film. The hermit, Felix Bush, is a worn-out man who has exiled himself to a cabin for four decades, haunted by a youthful trespass. The object of nasty countywide gossip, Felix has a short fuse but comports himself with grizzled dignity. “It’s the kind of role where you want to blur the line between the legend and gravitas of the character and the legend and gravitas of the performer,” the film’s director, Aaron Schneider, said by phone. “Our list of actors was short: Our list was Robert Duvall.”

headline: Slower Sales After Home Buyer Tax Credit Ends
text: THE market for lower-priced housing is now hurting more than the market for higher-priced homes in many New Jersey communities.

headline: Kenneth S. Horn
text: Mr. Horn, 53, is the president and founder of Alchemy Properties Inc., a real estate development company that specializes in condominiums, including Lion’s Head in Chelsea and Hudson Hill on West 58th Street. Among Alchemy’s recent projects is the 95-unit Griffin Court on 10th Avenue and 53rd Street, which has one of the largest outdoor murals in the city.

headline: A Couple Find a Studio Has Staying Power
text: DECADES before Carrie Bradshaw settled into her apartment in an East Side brownstone, the neighborhood was a mecca for young single women seeking a taste of the big city. And among the legions drawn to the area was a 21-year-old design school graduate named Robbin Brosterman, who in 1980 moved to a one-bedroom apartment on East 57th Street.

headline: Seeking to Close Off an Exit
text: SOME borrowers know it might take years for the value of their homes to exceed the size of their mortgages, so they simply walk away from loan and property, even though they can still afford them.

headline: The Roller-Coaster Ride Called a Short Sale
text: WITH property values down by as much as 30 percent in New York City, some homeowners who bought at the height of the market are finding themselves underwater and are being forced to sell their homes in short sales.

headline: Escape From Quirkyville
text: EVERY now and again, during the six years that Mary Beth and Alan Maginn lived in a one-bedroom apartment on the ground floor of a two-family row house in Park Slope, they toyed with the idea of moving.

headline: White Plains, Bellwether
text: INCREASINGLY, White Plains mirrors the real estate fortunes of the county as a whole, and that was apparent once again last week when the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service issued its quarterly report on the state of the housing market.

text: And then there were three.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: The Hungarian region of Tokaj is known for its sweet wine. Evan Rail gets an up-close look at this remote terrain in the Carpathian foothills and enjoys tastings at a few of its intimate vineyards.

headline: A Mash Note to Offbeat New Yorkers
text: Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: A Goya Tour of Madrid
text: Trace the Spanish painter’s trajectory and discover the city’s hidden gems.

headline: What Age for Which Chores?
text: I don’t remember exactly how old my son was during that first visit to my friend Amy’s house. But I distinctly remember the highchair beside her kitchen table. Her twins are six months older than my first born, and she also had an older daughter, so she was far more relaxed about, well, everything, than I was.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Helmand Province and Elsewhere
text: On Thursday, Pictures of the Day called out the exceptional work being done by Associated Press photographers in Afghanistan. Not to be repetitive, but Kevin Frayer and Rodrigo Abd of The A.P. once again distinguished themselves on Friday, leading the report.

headline: Back to a Land Well Visited: Teenage Angst
text: JOEL SCHUMACHER knows how to endure. Best known for creating big-budget Hollywood entertainment like “Batman Forever” and adapting John Grisham thrillers like “The Client,” he has floundered since the widely panned “Batman & Robin” in 1997. (The nipples and enlarged codpieces of its superhero suits were just one aspect that came in for ribbing.) Despite some modest hits, like “Phone Booth,” most of his movies in recent years (including “Phantom of the Opera” and “The Number 23”) have disappointed at the box office.

headline: Sanofi-Aventis’s Biotech Play for Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis has made an informal takeover approach to Genzyme, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday, as the French drug maker seeks to bolster its biotechnology offerings.

headline: Postal Sleuths, Freudian Roiling and Female Revenge
text: AS many DVD distributors cut back on releases of older films — “deep library,” in industry parlance — it’s a particular pleasure to welcome a new company to the field. Olive Films (olivefilms.com), a theatrical and home video distributor, has announced an ambitious schedule of releases drawn from the rich Paramount library. Here’s a look at the first five, set to come out this week with a list price of $24.95 each.

headline: People, Places and Menace: Moody Paranoia
text: BUILDINGS were crucial to the conspiracy thrillers of the mid-1970s, as monolithic symbols of dread (the Los Angeles Convention Center in “The Parallax View,” the San Francisco hotels and office towers of “The Conversation” ) or illusory havens (the Upper East Side brownstone of “Three Days of the Condor””).

headline: The Latino Lag
text: THE odyssey of Hilda Segovia offers a vivid illustration of why Hispanic students are often less prepared to weather the adventure of college and more vulnerable to giving up once they begin.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The south end of Manhattan will be a hub of food activity this weekend. First, there’s the City of Water Day celebration on Saturday at Governors Island from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Food vendors like the Dosa Man, Kwik Meal, the Jamaican Dutchy and others will offer street food. There will be live music, narrated tours and short films playing. The nearby New Amsterdam Market (South Street between Beekman Street and Peck’s Slip) will get into the festive mood from 11.a.m. until 4 p.m. with some additional specials on sale, including a stand from Marlow & Daughters’, which will sell totes filled with cheese, charcuterie and fixings for a picnic.

headline: Backpacks Among the Briefcases
text: HANNAH WOLFE traveled to school by air last year. It required precise timing, a skill she honed when she and her friends moved to what they called Rosy — a sprawling apartment complex on Roosevelt Island that doubles as a dorm. All her classes at Marymount Manhattan College were on the Upper East Side, and to get there, she took two buses and a tram that glides 250 feet above the East River and offers postcard views of Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Lakers Make Ripples With Off-Season Improvements
text: Their changes have not been as drastic as the waves created in South Beach, but the Lakers have also fortified their roster this off-season while aiming for a three-peat next season.

headline: Vain Glorious | Watermill Paradiso 2010
text: What exactly does art smell like? According to Loc Dong, a senior perfumer at International Flavors and Fragrances, it’s a combination of slightly odd ingredients like ambrette seeds, cashmeran and kaffir lime leaves mixed with a heady dose of rose absolute Bulgaria.

headline: Wheelies: A Congressional Parking Perk, Even When Out of Office
text: 5:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Prep, Forward and Back
text: JUST like European currency, European men’s wear has been in the dumps lately. Suddenly all that rigorous, over-designed and unwearable stuff cranked out by Raf Simons and his ilk seems as inadvertently retro as a Eurail Pass.

headline: The Accidental Giant of Higher Education
text: NANCY L. ZIMPHER, the new chancellor of the State University of New York, is a woman with a plan. From 1998 to 2003, when she was chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, it was “The Milwaukee Idea.” From 2003 to May 2009, when she was president of the University of Cincinnati, it was “UC/21.”

headline: Earned Housing
text: At Marist College, where housing is assigned by merit, you better be good (or you’ll end up in a small room).

headline: The Science of Roommates
text: FIRST-YEAR roommates matter. Though they may go their separate ways sophomore year, their reach can ripple throughout the college years and after.

headline: Louisiana-Style Grit From a New York Newbie
text: At Joe’s Pub on Wednesday night, Dylan LeBlanc’s throat was stuck somewhere down near Shreveport, La. His manner, too. “I’ve been in New York all week  it’s been quite an experience,” he said and, you sensed, really meant it. The ineluctable aw-shucks-ness of it all was overwhelming.

headline: The Look
text: “Take Ivy” is a volume of photographs that studies the preppy look and its reference point.

headline: Variations on a Theme
text: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: quirky theme housing. Text by Joanna Nikas.

headline: ‘Glee’ Goes to College
text: JENNIFER GOEBEL arranged her freshman year around “Glee,” the hit show about a high school show choir. On “Glee” nights, five classmates would huddle around the TV set in her dorm room at Millsaps College, in Jackson, Miss. Somewhere along the line she began to wonder why Millsaps didn’t have its own version of the fictional song-and-dance troupe. Soon enough, there was Major Melodies, a club of 15 students performing to standing-room-only crowds.

headline: Need to Know
text: Historically, the master’s degree in business came out of the field of economics, and public administration out of political science, says Stuart I. Bretschneider, chairman of the public administration department at Syracuse University. The master’s of public administration, he says, is “a management degree where people get an awful lot of exposure to context,” whether poverty in Africa or war in Iraq.

headline: Actress/Activist
text: JUST before Memorial Day, Ashley Judd graduated from Harvard. In a universitywide commencement ceremony, she shared billing with Rose Kennedy Schlossberg, daughter of Caroline, who was getting her bachelor’s degree, and Meryl Streep, who was awarded an honorary degree. Ms. Judd’s father and “a mess of girlfriends” were in Cambridge, Mass., for the ceremony. Her husband, Dario Franchitti, could not attend because of the Indianapolis 500, which he would win that weekend for the second time. He watched live via Harvard’s Internet feed, and they texted.

headline: Forget Technology; It’s My Brother’s ID
text: USING Adobe Photoshop, under-age drinkers can probably make an ID convincing enough to buy beer from an overworked gas station clerk. Or they can take a chance with an online novelty-card site. Yet the most popular way of pretending to be 21 remains decidedly low tech: using identification that belongs to older friends or siblings. In a study of some 1,100 under-age students by University of Missouri researchers, published this month in the journal Addictive Behaviors, 69 percent with fake IDs said friends or relatives had given them one.

headline: Is Your Student Card a Little Too Smart?
text: Once upon a time, a student ID was merely a laminated card good for getting into campus buildings and a discount at the movies. But magnetic strips and wireless chips have revolutionized this little piece of plastic, turning it into a one-stop source for security and commerce (with expanded uses that have raised a few eyebrows). Students swipe IDs to open doors, operate washer/dryers, buy stuff, reserve tickets, withdraw cash from an A.T.M., or even say “here” in class.

headline: Administrative Glut
text: Andrew Hacker is a professor of sociology at Queens College; Claudia Dreifus is an adjunct professor at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs. This essay is adapted from "Higher Education? How Colleges Are Wasting Our Money and Failing Our Kids — and What We Can Do About It," to be published in August by Times Books.

headline: The Ongoing Influence of ‘Groundhog Day’
text: SAN DIEGO— The inspiration for “Drive Angry 3D,” the coming revenge flick starring Nicolas Cage as a crazed father on a hunt for his daughter’s killers, was inspired by — “Groundhog Day”? Well, yes, sort of.

headline: The Left Hand’s Chance at the Right Hand’s Spotlight
text: It’s not unusual that the most poignant and intimate moments in solo recitals come in the encores, when the artist is fully warmed up, any nerves have dissipated and a comfortable rapport has been established with the audience. Performers often feel free to choose simpler, less showy pieces after demonstrating their technique during strenuous programs.

headline: Urban Wisdom … With a Beat
College Roommates, Rich and Famous
text: Before becoming big successes, these erstwhile college students shared a room. We asked a few of them to remember the experience.

headline: Survival of the Fittest
text: THE class of 2014 began as a long, not-so-gray line outside the basketball arena, winding its way up the stairs onto the hardwood court. It was only June, yet about 1,390 first-year students — plebes, they will be called — were already reporting for class at the United States Military Academy, West Point.

headline: Top Insurgents Escaped Prison Days After Iraq Took Over
text: BAGHDAD  An outsize ceremonial skeleton key traded hands last week in the official transfer of Camp Cropper, the last jail in Iraq that had been under American control. The Iraqi government was, one American general said, “equipped, prepared and poised to take over.”

headline: Cycling Fans on Twitter Root for Dopers to Get Caught
text: Updated | 9:01 p.m. As a remarkably entertaining edition of the Tour de France comes to an end this weekend, some of the most passionate fans of professional cycling are paying less attention to what’s happening in the race than they are to news of a federal investigation into the allegation that Lance Armstrong engaged in systematic doping to win it on seven previous occasions.

text: FLAKE, cow, loser, slut, idiot, airhead, trash, penguin, creep, moron, midget, freak, Oompa-Loompa, nobody.

headline: Hasbro’s Toy TV Makes an Appearance at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO— One of the biggest coming-out parties at this year’s Comic-Con belonged to the Hub, the coming children’s cable network backed by Hasbro and Discovery Communications. Prepping to go live on Oct. 10, the Hub – which will take the place of Discovery Kids in about 60 million homes and compete with the Disney Channel and Nickelodeon — took over an entire ballroom at the Marriott next door to the San Diego Convention Center.

headline: Are They Installations With Sound or Graffiti With Music? Yes!
text: “Christian Marclay: Festival” at the Whitney Museum is aptly titled, since the exhibition, up through Sept. 26, is also a kind of music festival. In the late 1970s, Mr. Marclay, an artist-composer-performer, became one of the first musicians to use a turntable as an instrument, and he is equally known in the art world for music-related collages and videos. Most of his works on display at the Whitney  whether made of found objects, still or moving images, texts, LP’s or even clothes  are intended to be used as musical scores in one way or another. And they are being used, often repeatedly, by a rotating roster of performers that includes some of the biggest names in avant-garde music.

headline: On the Street | Tiptop
text: The fedora popped up two years ago and is now seen everywhere, from the beaches of Fire Island Pines to Manhattan.
