headline: Rival Studios Resolve Dispute Over ‘Precious’
text: More than a year after the Lee Daniels film “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire” caught the attention of moviegoers  and two rival film studios  at the Sundance Film Festival, a lawyer for the Lionsgate studio said it had reached an agreement with the Weinstein Company and that a lawsuit involving the film’s rights has been dismissed, Reuters reported. In February 2009 Lionsgate announced that it had paid $5.5 million for the rights to “Precious,” which won the Grand Jury Prize at that year’s Sundance festival. The announcement came as a surprise to Harvey Weinstein, who said he believed that his company had already struck a deal to buy the film. The studios sued each other, and a portion of that suit filed by the Weinstein Company against the producers of “Precious” was dismissed in September 2009 after a judge said the company did not have a signed agreement for the transfer of film rights. Matthew Gershman, a lawyer for Lionsgate, told Reuters that its dispute with the Weinstein Company “was amicably resolved to both parties’ mutual satisfaction,” but did not give further details. “Precious” was nominated for six Academy Awards and won two, for best supporting actress (Mo’Nique) and adapted screenplay (Geoffrey S. Fletcher).

headline: OMG: Justin Bieber Will Do ‘C.S.I.’
text: What better way for Justin Bieber, above, to begin his transition from floppy-haired pop singer to serious grown-up than by appearing on a CBS crime procedural that dispatches its guest stars in the most graphic ways imaginable? On Thursday CBS said that Mr. Bieber has been cast in the season premiere of “C.S.I.”, which is scheduled for Sept. 23. According to a news release the 16-year-old singer will play Jason McCann, “a troubled teen who is faced with a terrible decision regarding his only brother  a decision that leads him into an explosive confrontation with the C.S.I.s.” The release added that this appearance is “the beginning of an emotional story that will conclude later in the season,” suggesting that Mr. Bieber will return to induce further squeals from Laurence Fishburne, Jerry Bruckheimer and the whole “C.S.I.” gang.

headline: Tkts on Your Iphone
text: An iPhone application that promises up-to-the-minute information on discounted Broadway and Off-Broadway tickets sold at the TKTS booth in Times Square has been met with skepticism by the Theater Development Fund, which runs the TKTS discount program and which raised questions about the accuracy of the application. This week, Ken Davenport, the president of Davenport Theatrical Enterprises and a producer of Broadway and Off-Broadway productions including “Oleanna” and “Altar Boyz,” introduced an iPhone app called At the Booth. The program, which is sold for 99 cents, says on its Web site (atthebooth.com) that it “lists all the Broadway and Off-Broadway shows available at the TKTS booth every day and at what price.” On Friday, Victoria Bailey, the executive director of the Theater Development Fund, said in a statement that the fund was preparing its own iPhone application and was “concerned that this recently released app may not provide an accurate picture of ticket availability and line lengths considering the fluidity of both.” In a telephone interview Mr. Davenport declined to specify where the TKTS data provided by the At the Booth app comes from. “It’s not brain surgery,” he said.

headline: Making Squid the Meat of a Story
text: LONDON  If your idea of a science fiction writer is a scrawny guy with computer-glow pallor who’s a little too interested in whether warp speed is a realistic rate of travel, China Miéville is not that person.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Is Going on Tour
text: Borrowing a strategy from television’s biggest reality show, “American Idol,” the summer’s biggest reality show, “America’s Got Talent,” is taking its top contestants on tour. AEG Live, a tour producer, and FremantleMedia, which produces “America’s Got Talent” with Simon Cowell, said Thursday that the tour would visit 25 cities beginning Oct. 1, two weeks after a winner is named on the NBC series. Live tours are a mainstay of Fox’s “Idol” after each season, but this year is the first time that “Got Talent” is trying one. The show’s host, Jerry Springer, will also host the stage show, the organizers said. Above, a scene from the show.

headline: ‘Animal Farm,’ the Musical
text: Has the theater world found another “Lion King”? For their next stage project, Elton John, far left, and Lee Hall are adapting a work about talking animals that no English-language reader of the last 65 years could possibly be unfamiliar with. Oh, and before you break out your checkbook to buy tickets or to invest, you should also know that it’s a metaphor for the rise of Stalinism. Yes, “Animal Farm,” George Orwell’s not-so-adorable allegory that taught us that all animals are equal but some animals are more equal than others, is being prepared as a musical by Mr. Hall and Mr. John, the creative team behind “Billy Elliot the Musical,” The Daily Mail of London reported. Mr. Hall, who also wrote the screenplay for the film version of “Billy Elliot,” told The Daily Mail that it took about two years to secure the rights for the project, and that it would probably take another two years before the musical is finished. No producers are officially attached yet, and no actors have been announced to play Napoleon, Snowball and their oppressed and corrupted barnyard pals.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Premiere Is Set for Times Square
text: Heard of this television series, “Mad Men”? A few guys and a few gals work in an agency, sell a couple ads, have a couple laughs? Are you so eager for the premiere of its fourth season that you’d leave your home and brave Times Square to watch it an hour before the rest of the East Coast? Or are you so sick of that show’s rabid fan base that you’d like to arm yourself with a few advance details so you can ruin the surprises for your “Mad Men”-worshiping friends? (Seriously, though, don’t do that.) Would you just like to meet the actress who plays Peggy Olsen? An event on Sunday night may satisfy all of these contingencies. AMC said it would show the “Mad Men” premiere in Duffy Square (between 45th and 47th Streets and Broadway and Seventh Avenue) at 9 p.m.  that’s one whole hour earlier than the poor saps who pay for cable television every month will get to see it. The screening will be preceded by “Mad Men” costume contests and other events, and is to be attended by Elisabeth Moss, an Emmy Award-nominated star of the series. Spoiler alert: Season 4 will pick up where Season 3 left off!

headline: 401(k) Fees Gain a Bit of Clarity

headline: Intense Debate in Canada Over Longer Census

headline: A Village Preserved, Green and All: Brian May’s Photographic Recovery
text: The name T. R. Williams does not ring many bells in photohistorical circles today. But in Victorian London he was a kind of rock star, whose instruments were marvels of scientific novelty  the stereoscopic camera and viewer, developed in the 1850s, were the earliest forerunners of the View-Master and the current 3-D movie craze.

headline: What Has Reid Done for Nevada? Ask Angle
text: The conventional tack, when running against a party leader in Congress, is to argue that he is so focused on national posturing that he has abandoned their home state. But in taking on Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, Sharron Angle is taking the leader’s conventional argument – that power in Congress can be wielded to do more for the state – and running with it.

text: Courtney St. George Giknis and Benjamin Robert Krahn were married Saturday in Middlebury, Vt. The Rev. Michael J. Marco, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Mead Memorial Chapel on the campus of Middlebury College.

headline: Solange Sandstrom, Howard Singer
text: Solange Helen Sandstrom and Howard Lee Singer are to be married Sunday in Narragansett, R.I. Rabbi Joel I. Braude is to officiate in the Narragansett Town Beach Clubhouse.

headline: Brianne Kennedy, Michael Riley
text: Brianne Shelford Kennedy and Michael Christopher Riley are to be married Sunday at the Westin St. Francis hotel in San Francisco. The Rt. Rev. Edward C. Chalfant, a retired Episcopal bishop of the Diocese of Maine, is to officiate.

headline: Sadia Shepard, Andreas Burgess
text: Sadia Shepard and Andreas Burgess were married Saturday at the Slocum’s River Reserve in South Dartmouth, Mass. The Rev. Alton Wasson, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the ceremony, which incorporated elements of Judaism, Christianity and Islam.

headline: Jennifer Frontera, Joseph Hickey
text: Dr. Jennifer Ann Frontera and Joseph Patrick Hickey were married Saturday at St. Andrew’s Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. John P. McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Margaret Young and Peter Hurst Jr.
text: Margaret Jeanette Young and Peter Frederick Hurst Jr. are to be married Sunday at the bride’s home in Oak Bluffs, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard. The Rev. Dr. Anthony L. Bennett, a Baptist minister, is to officiate.

headline: Charlotte Gray, Christopher Platts
text: Charlotte Elizabeth Gray, a daughter of Cynthia M. Gray and Lincoln D. Gray of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married there Friday to Christopher Wilke Platts, a son of Elizabeth M. Platts and Howard G. Platts of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Donald M. Ashman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Presidio Chapel at El Presidio de Santa Bárbara State Historic Park.

headline: Aarti Kakkar, Jeffrey Evans
text: Dr. Aarti Kakkar and Dr. Jeffrey Alexander Evans were married Saturday at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla. Pandit Vishnu Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Amanda Sachs, Dieter Mangold
text: Amanda Hope Sachs and Dieter Mangold were married Friday in New York. Blanca Martinez, a staff member of the City Clerk’s office, officiated at the Manhattan Municipal Chapel.

headline: Richa Sapra and Kaushal Mehta
text: Richa Sapra and Kaushal Mehta were married Saturday by Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, at the Hyatt Regency in Princeton, N.J.

headline: Ariane Anthony, Jeffrey Bauer
text: Ariane Elizabeth Anthony and Jeffrey Todd Bauer were married Tuesday afternoon. The Rev. Lukasz Misko, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Notre Dame in New York.

headline: Sondra Lender, Ben Fussiner
text: Sondra Lender and Ben Fussiner were married Saturday evening at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, a Connecticut justice of the peace and a Democrat representing the state’s Third Congressional District, officiated.

headline: Kerith Davies, Thomas Knechtel
text: Kerith Rhiannon Davies and Thomas Lee Knechtel were married Saturday at Red Sky Ranch, a golf club in Wolcott, Colo. The Rev. Donald J. Bissett, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: How Would You Design Your 401(k) Statement?
text: Is there anything less enthralling than the topic of 401(k) fees? Probably not. But I wrote about them anyway in this week’s Your Money column because they can significantly affect the health of your retirement savings.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,404 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

text: The premier event at the Summer Nationals in New Orleans is the Spingold Knockout Teams, which starts on Monday.

headline: Superheros Tangle in Copyright Battles
text: SAN DIEGO— Lawyers on a Friday afternoon panel at Comic-Con were supposed to be talking about the legal challenges of social media and the battles over copyright, notably a case that involves the Walt Disney Company’s Marvel Entertainment and the heirs to the comic book artist Jack Kirby (Spider-Man among many others).

headline: Barclays Boss Weighs In on Bailouts and Stress Tests
text: Robert E. Diamond Jr., the president of Barclays, has a lot to say about bank bailouts, stress tests and executive bonuses.

headline: Ad Rules Stall, Keeping Cereal a Cartoon Staple
text: Lucky Charms. Froot Loops. Cocoa Pebbles. A ConAgra frozen dinner with corn dog and fries. McDonald’s Happy Meals.

headline: Day 94: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Storm Halts Response Efforts

headline: Scientists Confirm Underwater Plumes Are From Spill
text: Florida researchers said Friday that they had for the first time conclusively linked vast plumes of microscopic oil droplets drifting in the Gulf of Mexico to the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: Quickly Shifting Gears When Disaster Strikes
text: BELLE CHASSE, La.  Along the road between the river and the bayou in Boothville, there is a huge sign, impossible to miss, tied to the side of a 40-foot container: “Oil Spill Response Supplies.”

headline: Getting Trendy
text: Whenever I draw a chart comparing actual growth with the pre-crisis trend, as I did in my last post, I get two kinds of complaints. Some readers complain that that’s not how you do it — that you have to draw a trend through the middle of the past scatter of points, not start at a business cycle peak. Others complain that a year like 2007, or 2000, is a bad choice because output was inflated by a bubble.

headline: Settlement Sheds Little Light on N.C.A.A. No-Agent Rule
text: MINNEAPOLIS  For Andy Oliver, what’s done is done, although it may not be for others. After settling his lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. for $750,000 last October, Oliver threw himself into his professional baseball career and arrived in the majors this season in what turned out to be an almost monthlong stint with the Detroit Tigers. He no longer wishes to talk about the case.

headline: Agencies Plan to Reduce Canada Geese Population in New York State by Two-Thirds
text: Officials plan to reduce the number of Canada geese in New York State by two-thirds, eventually trimming the population to 85,000 from 250,000, according to a report prepared by several city, state and federal agencies.

headline: Storm Surge of Oil?
text: A tropical weather system could exacerbate the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico by pushing oil inland on a storm surge.

headline: School Chief Dismisses 241 Teachers in Washington
text: Michelle Rhee, the reform-minded chancellor who took over the District of Columbia public schools three years ago, on Friday fired 241 teachers, or 5 percent of the district’s total. All but a few of those dismissed had received the lowest rating under a new evaluation system that for the first time held them accountable for their students’ standardized test scores.

headline: U.S. Agency Trims Estimate of the Deficit
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday trimmed its estimate of the federal budget deficit for this year but said the weak economy had led it to increase its deficit projection for next year.

headline: Off-Field Troubles Greet SEC Football Kickoff Week
text: HOOVER, Ala.  For 60 minutes here this week the turmoil around the Southeastern Conference was interrupted by the homespun, uncomplicated media presentation of Robbie Caldwell, Vanderbilt’s interim head football coach. While talking about the coming season, he delighted the crowd with tales of working on a turkey farm and his varied skills, such as pouring concrete.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Dell’s Trouble Kicking the Intel Habit
text: Perplexed.

headline: Summer Rituals: Horse Riding
text: A ten year old Manhattan resident, Oliver Ritter, spends his summers in Long Island riding horses and building self-confidence.

headline: McChrystal Ends Service With Regret and a Laugh
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal retired on Friday with the full pageantry of a 17-gun salute, an Army marching band and an emotional send-off from the secretary of defense, but with his own acknowledgment that he was not leaving the military on his own terms.

headline: Rules of the Pool
text: To the Editor:

headline: Burnett Has Command Over His Pitches and His Emotions in Return
text: A. J. Burnett had lost himself in recent outings, but on Friday night he was a picture of everything he has not been. In five scoreless innings, Burnett commanded his fastball and displayed good body language in the Yankees’ 7-1 win over the Kansas City Royals.

headline: Credit Score Is the Tyrant in Lending
text: The other day, a mortgage broker named Deb Killian called me, more or less out of the blue. Ms. Killian has been in the business since 1994. She and her husband run Charter Oak Lending Group, a small firm based in Danbury, Conn., that they founded in 1996. She is a member of the board of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers. By her estimate, she has closed more than 3,500 loans during her career.

headline: Guineans Will Bolster Peace Efforts in Somalia
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  Guinea has agreed to send hundreds of troops to Somalia to bolster the African Union’s peacekeeping force in the country after Somali insurgents claimed responsibility for bombings in Uganda during the World Cup final that killed 76 people.

headline: Turkey: 102 Military Officers Charged With Plotting Coup
text: An Istanbul court on Friday ordered the arrest of 102 active and retired military officers, charging them with plotting to overthrow Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan’s government in 2003. Among the suspects are retired Gen. Cetin Dogan, a former commander of Turkey’s Land Forces; Ozden Ornek, a former Naval Force commander, and a former Air Force commander, Ibrahim Firtina. The arrests stemmed from an investigation into assassinations of prominent members of society and bombings in major cities that were found to have been an effort to create chaos that would lead to a military takeover of Turkey’s civilian government. The accused face up to 20 years in jail if convicted. The military claims that the documents on which the charges are based are forgeries.

headline: Multiple Nicknames; Dwindling Openings
text: There was a time, in the not-so-distant past, when Shaquille O’Neal rumbled across the country collecting nicknames and championship rings by the bundle, his career one great, giddy joyride, set to his own thumping soundtrack. He was the Diesel and the Big Aristotle, the Big Cactus and the Big Witness and always the life of the party.

headline: Same-Sex Marriages
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nixon and Khrushchev Argue In Public As U.S. Exhibit Opens; Accuse Each Other Of Threats
text: Moscow, July 24--Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev debated in public today the merits of washing machines, capitalism, free exchange of ideas, summit meetings, rockets and ultimatums.

headline: Bella Abzug, 77, Congresswoman And a Founding Feminist, Is Dead
text: Bella S. Abzug, New Yorker, feminist, antiwar activist, politician and lawyer, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 77.

headline: Workers’ Wages in China and Bangladesh
text: To the Editor:

headline: Balfour a Leader for Half a Century
text: The death of the Earl of Balfour puts an end to a career which for distinction and length of service has few equals in modern English history. At the Congress of 1878 in Berlin, he was already well known as a promising young statesman. Long after all the other participants in that congress were dead, Balfour was Lord President of the Privy Council and playing tennis and golf in his seventy-ninth year. The one English statesman with whom his name was continuously linked, and whose career covered the same period, was the late Earl of Oxford and Asquith.

headline: Andrea Doria and Stockholm Collide; 1,134 Passengers Abandon Italian Ship In Fog At Sea; All Saved, Many Injured
text: The trans-Atlantic liners Andrea Doria and Stockholm collided in a heavy Atlantic fog at 11:22 o'clock last night, forty-five miles south of Nantucket Island.

headline: Netherlands: Oil Trading Company Fined in Dumping of Toxic Sludge
text: A Dutch court on Friday imposed the maximum fine of $1.28 million dollars on the oil trading company Trafigura for illegally exporting highly toxic sludge that ended up dumped in Ivory Coast and that was eventually linked to the deaths of 16 people and thousands of illnesses in 2006. The court also found the company guilty of covering up the hazardous nature of the waste, including high levels of caustic soda, sulfur compounds and hydrogen sulfide, when it first tried to unload it in Amsterdam. After Trafigura balked at treatment costs, the sludge was pumped back on board the ship Probo Koala, which left with its load. Trafigura denied wrongdoing, but it paid $200 million to Ivory Coast for cleanup and $50 million to nearly 30,000 victims. Another criminal lawsuit is before a court in The Hague.

headline: His Family Slain, a Boy’s Life of Rage Emerges
text: A neighbor called them “the brigade” as they walked past his building most every morning. First came the mother, Leisa Jones, pushing her 2-year-old son, Jermaine Sinclair, in a stroller. The girls, Brittney, 10, and Melonie, 7, tagged behind, followed by their older brother, C. J.

headline: Thrown to the Wolves
text: The Shirley Sherrod story tells us so much about ourselves, and none of it is pretty. The most obvious and shameful fact is that the Obama administration, which runs from race issues the way thoroughbreds bolt from the starting gate, did not offer this woman anything resembling fair or respectful treatment before firing and publicly humiliating her.

headline: Dr. Carl G. Jung Is Dead at 85; Pioneer in Analytic Psychology
text: ZURICH, Switzerland, June 6--Professor Carl Gustav Jung, one of the founders of analytic psychology, died today at his villa in Kuessnacht on Lake Lucerne. He was 85 years old. The famed psychologist was beset by heart and circulatory troubles and began to fail several weeks ago.

headline:
Congress Adjourns At 3:50 A.M., Far Short Of GOP Economy Goal; Forrestal Is New
Defense Chief
text: Washington, Sunday, July 27--President Truman signed in dramatic circumstances yesterday the history-making legislation unifying the nation's armed forces. Immediately afterward he nominated the Secretary of the Navy, James Forrestal of New York, to head the program as Secretary of Defense.

headline: Rangel in Talks on Settlement of Ethics Cases
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel and the House ethics committee have been exploring a settlement to the numerous accusations against him, which would allow the 20-term congressman to avoid an ugly public trial and could prevent further political damage to Democrats nationally.

headline: Leaving Mets Put Herzog on a Path to the Hall
text: When Whitey Herzog’s baseball Hall of Fame plaque is unveiled Sunday, his bronze likeness will be topped with a St. Louis Cardinals cap, emblematic of the team he managed to the 1982 World Series championship. But if history had played out differently, that likeness of Herzog might have sported a Mets cap.

headline: E.P.A. Considers Risks of Gas Extraction
text: CANONSBURG, Pa.  The streams of people came to the public meeting here armed with stories of yellowed and foul-smelling well water, deformed livestock, poisoned fish and itchy skin. One resident invoked the 1968 zombie thriller “Night of the Living Dead,” which, as it happens, was filmed just an hour away from this southwestern corner of Pennsylvania.

headline: In Family’s Death, Trying to Fathom the Unfathomable
text: For who knows how long, C. J. Jones had been sending out flares.

headline: My Old Kentucky Zombies
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: Beyond the Stoop
text: About 70,000 blocks make up New York City, each one with its own stories. Take a core sample from just one, South Elliott Place, between Lafayette and Dekalb.

headline: Military Send-Off for McChrystal
text: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who was fired by President Obama last month after disparaging remarks by him and his staff members about top civilian leaders appeared in Rolling Stone magazine, retired in a military ceremony Friday night at Fort McNair.

headline: The Stories of One Brooklyn Block
text: EVERY morning on her way to school, 7-year-old Estella Quy walks by a stocky middle-aged man with a pointy salt-and-pepper goatee hanging out on the stoop of 61 South Elliott Place. She walks by him again every afternoon.

headline: New Jersey’s Medical Marijuana Law Loses Planned Grower and Dispensers
text: Five months before its new medical marijuana law is set to take effect, New Jersey this week moved further away from having answers to basic questions about how the law will work  specifically, who will grow the marijuana and who will dispense it.

headline: There’s No E in Blanco, Even After Two Years
text: LOS ANGELES  Long streaks have not been kind to the punchless Mets on this trip, but Saturday will be the second anniversary since something of note happened. Mets fans may feel as if that was the last time their team scored a run, but it was actually the last time catcher Henry Blanco made an error.

headline: Leo Durocher, Fiery Ex-Manager, Dies at 86
text: Leo Durocher, perhaps major league baseball's best example of the win-at-all-costs manager, one who viewed the game not as a challenging pastime for talented athletes but as a sports relative of guerilla warfare, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 86 years old.

headline: Truce Is Signed, Ending The Fighting In Korea; P.O.W. Exchange Near; Rhee Gets U.S. Pledge; Eisenhower Bids Free World Stay Vigilant
text: Tokyo, Monday, July 27--Communist and United Nations delegates in Panmunjom signed an armistice at 10:01 A.M. today [9:01 P.M., Sunday, Eastern daylight time]. Under the truce terms, hostilities in the three-year-old Korean war are to cease at 10 o'clock tonight [9 A.M., Monday, Eastern daylight time].

headline: Dengue Fever? What About It, Key West Says
text: A woman planning a Florida vacation in Key West called the health department there last week to ask if it were true that the city was being evacuated because of an epidemic of dengue fever.

headline: What, Them Worry?
text: In just a few months, Europe’s leaders have gone from panic to complacency about the future of the Continent’s common currency, the euro.

headline: Clinton Wedding Is Leaving Some Feeling Left Out
text: So, just what does it take to score an invitation to the hottest  not to mention most secretive  political wedding of the summer?

headline: Paul Hasn’t Yet Done the Full LeBron
text: Chris Paul’s rumored desire to leave New Orleans has drawn instant parallels to LeBron James’s leap from Cleveland to Miami. The comparisons are natural.

headline: Still Captives of Iran
text: It has been nearly a year since three Americans were arrested while hiking along the Iran-Iraq border. The families of Shane Bauer, Joshua Fattal and Sarah Shourd have campaigned ceaselessly for their release. Despite countless appeals to Iranian officials, the three are still being held in Tehran’s infamous Evin prison.

headline: Death of a First Lady ; Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Dies of Cancer at 64
text: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, the widow of President John F. Kennedy and of the Greek shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis, died of a form of cancer of the lymphatic system yesterday at her apartment in New York City. She was 64 years old.

headline:
Austria Formally Declares War on Servia; Russia Threatens, Already Moving
Troops; Peace of Europe Now In Kaiser's Hands
text: VIENNA, July 28- Upon the issue of the formal declaration of war against Servia today Emperor Franz Josef gave orders for the removal of the Summer Court from Ischl to the capital. His entourage tried to persuade him that Vienna air would not suit him, but the aged Emperor replied:

headline: Doin’ Just Fine, Alone With Her Wigs
text: To borrow Wendy Williams’s trademark greeting: “Wendy, how you doin?’ ” If it’s a Sunday, the answer is: fantastic. Ms. Williams, 46, treats her day of rest from “The Wendy Williams Show” as just that, preferably ensconced in her she-cave in the suburbs of Essex County, N.J. Her husband, Kevin Hunter, 38, and son, Kevin Hunter Jr., 9, know better than to attempt to pry the gossip and advice queen away from a day of bad television and great wigs. MICHAEL WILSON

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Honest Tests
text: Congress did the right thing with the No Child Left Behind Act of 2002 when it required states to document student performance in yearly tests in exchange for federal aid. Parents and policy makers need to know how well their schools are doing. And any serious discussion of reforms needs accurate data and rigorous comparisons with other schools’ performance. Most states immediately undermined the effort by employing weak tests and setting passing scores too low.

headline: Change Comes to a Place That Doesn’t Care for It
text: WASHINGTON  When Carte P. Goodwin strode on to the floor to join the Senate this week, the young West Virginia Democrat was more than the 60th vote to break a stubborn impasse over unemployment pay. He was also the symbol of the unsettled nature of an institution that for all its stately decorum is in severe turmoil.

headline: Amid Splendor, Charles Weds Diana
text: LONDON, July 29 -- In a blaze of martial and spiritual pageantry on a glorious summer morning, the Prince of Wales took as his wife today a shy and charming member of one of the kingdom's greatest families.

headline: Hammarskjold Greatly Extended U.N.'s Scope Through Leadership and Personal Initiatives
text: Dag Hjalmar Agne Carl Hammarskjold was a respected Swedish diplomat but little known to the rest of the world when, in 1953, he became Secretary General of the United Nations.

headline: Photo Replay: July 23
text: A view of the day in sports, from cyclists and a horse side-by-side to the blur of a Formula-One car.

headline: North Korea’s Latest Tantrum
text: North Korea is threatening a “physical response” to joint American-South Korean naval exercises scheduled to begin on Sunday off the Korean Peninsula. China, which has abetted its neighbor’s excesses for too long, needs to ensure that the North’s bluster is only bluster. And it needs to tone down its own.

headline: Henry Ford Is Dead at 83 in Dearborn
text: DETROIT, April 7--Henry Ford, noted automotive pioneer, died at 11:40 tonight at the age of 83. He had retired a little more than a year and a half ago from active direction of the great industrial empire he founded in 1903.

headline: Cruiser Sunk, 1,196 Casualties; Took Atom Bomb Cargo to Guam
text: Washington, Aug. 14--The American heavy cruiser Indianapolis was sunk by enemy action in the Philippine Sea with 1,196 casualties, every man aboard, the Navy announced today.

headline: Web Tool for Finding Detainees
text: The government unveiled a Web application on Friday that is intended to make finding immigration detainees easier. The change was a part of a broader overhaul of the detention system. Those searching for a detainee must enter the detainee’s “alien number” and country of birth, or the person’s exact name, birth date and country of birth into a form, which will return a detainee’s location and instructions for arranging a visit. “If it functions properly, it will be of tremendous assistance,” said Joanne Lin, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, whose nationwide affiliates represent many detainees. Some advocacy groups were concerned that foreign spellings or a lack of information could still make it difficult for family members to find some individuals.

headline: Our Post-Post-Racial Summer, Ctd.
text: So, gang, given the tremendous volume of traffic and comments for last week’s column on racism, the N.A.A.C.P. and Al Qaeda, it seems like we’ve found fertile ground for debate. And, indeed, so did the blogosphere as a whole this week, making it clear that our age of post-racial harmony remains but a twinkle in Chris Matthews’s eye.

headline: Primo Levi, Holocaust Writer is Dead at	 67
text: Primo Levi, whose autobiographical writings drew on his experiences as an Auschwitz survivor and his training as a chemist, died today in Turin. He was 67 years old.

headline: Ranger Takes Close-Up Moon Photos Revealing Craters Only 3 Feet Wide; Data Gained on Landing Site for Man
text: Pasadena, Calif., July 31 - Ranger 7 radioed to earth today the first close-up pictures of the moon- a historic collection of 4,000 pictures one thousand times as clear as anything ever seen through earth-bound telescopes.

headline: After Waiting So Long, Rangel Dropped the Prize
text: Lenox Avenue, Election Day, 1996.

headline: The Oil Spill as a Teachable Moment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Questions Surround Law That Limits Frisk Data
text: It was with a note of triumph that Gov. David A. Paterson, standing with lawmakers, civil libertarians and others, signed a bill last week halting the New York Police Department’s policy of keeping a computer database of people stopped by officers on the street but found to have done nothing wrong.

headline: A Hat So In, It’s Got to Be Out
text: The celebrities started it. Five or six years ago, a few highly visible heads began appearing in structured hats with a flattish crown and a short brim. Zac Efron. Justin Timberlake. Brad Pitt? That guy could hardly peel his off.

headline: Readers’ Questions Answered
text: Q. In Verdi Park, at Broadway and 72nd Street, if you follow the statue of Verdi’s gaze about 20 feet upward into the trees in front of it, you will spot a large fake owl perched on a branch. Who put it there and why? It’s very amusing.

headline: Third Republican Backs Kagan
text: Senator Susan Collins of Maine said she would vote to confirm Elena Kagan to the United States Supreme Court, becoming the third Republican to endorse her. Senators Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Richard G. Lugar of Indiana have also announced their support. The full Senate is expected to vote on Ms. Kagan’s nomination during the week of Aug. 2.

headline: The Candidate Was Cold; You Can Ask His Mother
text: CHICAGO  For a sense of how the discrepancies in the biography of Representative Mark S. Kirk, a Republican candidate for the United States Senate, are piling up, consider this: His mother this week found herself called on by his campaign to confirm publicly that, yes, indeed, Mr. Kirk was really, really cold after a boating accident landed him in Lake Michigan when he was 16.

headline: Potential Found in a New Approach to Alzheimer’s
text: A potentially promising approach to treating Alzheimer’s disease has been developed by researchers studying sirtuin, a protein thought capable of extending lifespan in laboratory animals.

headline: Bay Batting Seventh, Pagan Third and Other Notes
text: LOS ANGELES — The latest Mets slumping batting order included a couple of changes Friday, most notably as Jason Bay was dropped to seventh in the order and Angel Pagan was third, where he may stay for some time, according to Manager Jerry Manuel.

headline: A Summer School That Might Have Pleased Paul Bunyan
text: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y.  A reed-thin teenager skittered up a 45-foot wooden pole, his sharp metal spurs digging into the wood as he ascended. Another student, ax in hands, flailed away at a block of white pine. On nearby Lower St. Regis Lake, a brawny young man tried his feet at the slippery sport of logrolling.

headline: Sources of Woods Used for Saunas
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The usual difficulty of solving a Saturday puzzle, plus a curveball we’re just not expecting, is a potent combination. Has David J. Kahn created a bit of carnage out there (or for Bostonians, Kahnage)? Since skullduggery is afoot, I’ll tell all below, but for those who would prefer only partial disclosure, highlight this space: [it’s a rebus!].

headline: Mauritania: Raid Hits Al Qaeda, but Fails to Free French Hostage
text: French-backed Mauritanian forces killed six presumed members of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb in a dawn raid in the Sahara on Thursday that prevented a planned attack on “Mauritanian objectives,” the French Defense Ministry said Friday. But they failed to recover a French civilian, Michel Germaneau, thought to have been abducted by the group last April while doing humanitarian work in Niger, French and Mauritanian officials said. The group has threatened to execute Mr. Germaneau, 78, if France does not accept a prisoner exchange. The same group executed a British hostage last year after its ransom demands were not met, the Defense Ministry said.

headline: While Waiting for A-Rod, a Show in the Sky
text: What fans at Yankee Stadium came hoping to see Friday was Alex Rodriguez hitting his 600th career home run. What they got first was a dousing rain shower and a crackling lightning display during a delay that lasted 1 hour 25 minutes during a game against Kansas City.

headline: Bloggingheads: Jobs Benefits Battle
text: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Byron York of the Washington Examiner debate whether unemployment benefits prolong joblessness.

headline: For Insurers, Fight Is Now Over Details
text: The legislative battle over the health care overhaul ended months ago, but it is hard to tell from the intense effort now under way by insurance companies to retool a critical provision.

headline: Doubts Persist as Most Europe Banks Pass Stress Tests
text: FRANKFURT  A vast majority of European banks passed a round of stress tests meant to measure the likelihood that they could survive an economic or market calamity, regulators said on Friday.

headline: My Little Pony, Out to Win
text: AMAGANSETT, N.Y.

headline: Condé Nast Is Changing Its Blueprint
text: Is the era of the $12 magazine subscription coming to an end?

headline: Jazz Piano Giants Spanning the Years
text: OVER the past decade and a half, the Litchfield Jazz Festival in Kent and the  Caramoor Jazz Festival in Katonah, N.Y., have reliably presented a selection of top players. But this year, taken together  both festivals are running from Aug. 6 to 8  they are offering more: a multigenerational history of jazz piano featuring the giants who made it.

headline: Strong Data From Britain and Germany Raise Hopes
text: LONDON  Britain and Germany reported surprisingly optimistic economic data on Friday, offering a welcome respite from the otherwise gloomy outlook around the world.

headline: A Popular Deferral Strategy Loses Fight in U.S. Tax Court
text: Corporate executives could be scrambling to raise billions of dollars in cash this year to pay personal tax bills on their stock options because of a recent United States Tax Court ruling.

headline: Roll Over, Aquinas: Altar Boyz Defeat Sin With Pop
text: Do you have to be Catholic to appreciate “Altar Boyz,” a musical spoof about a Christian boy band now at Gateway Playhouse in Bellport? No, but it probably helps  even though one of the fictional group’s singers is Jewish.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Opposes Plan to Tighten Use of Painkillers
text: An advisory committee for the Food and Drug Administration voted overwhelmingly on Friday to reject a plan proposed by the agency to reduce the misuse and abuse of long-acting painkillers like the drug OxyContin.

headline: Sanofi Said to Have Offered to Make a Bid for Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis has made an informal takeover approach to Genzyme, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday, as the French drug maker seeks to bolster its biotechnology offerings.

headline: Afternoon Tea (Sit Up Straight, Eloise)
text: They may have cut the prices, but tea at the Palm Court is still a refined and elegant affair, where patrons tend to speak softly and sit up straight as they take a step back in time. After a bumpy reopening this spring following an extensive restoration, a new executive chef, Willis Loughhead, has retooled the menu, offering an adult tea starting at $45, rather than $65, and a children’s tea for $28. A typical afternoon between 2 and 5 p.m. might find the land of Eloise, Truman Capote, John Lennon and Jackie O. inhabited by Saudi princes, a woman reliving childhood memories of her father operating an elevator at the hotel or, as on Tuesday, a group of women chatting about business and television.

headline: Putting a Mother, or Two, on Trial
text: The face of Evelyn Laverty is one you might see on a waitress working 12-hour shifts to support her family or a perpetually overwhelmed mother of five in a trailer park  someone you might think is in her 40s, but turns out to be 20 or so. Too young to be that hard.

headline: ‘New Voices’ Showcase Features Young Talent
text: LISA COONEY, the director of education for the Paper Mill Playhouse, based in Millburn, freely admits, “Student performances aren’t for everybody.” So she was surprised last year by the audience for “New Voices,” an annual show that features the dancing, acting and singing talents of 120 New Jersey show business hopefuls, ages 10 through 18.

headline: An A.I.G. Failure Would Have Cost Goldman Sachs, Documents Show
text: Since the United States government stepped in to rescue the American International Group in the fall of 2008, Goldman Sachs has maintained that it would have faced few if any losses had the insurer failed. Though it was the insurer’s biggest trading partner, Goldman contended that it had bought credit insurance from financial institutions that would have protected it, but it declined to identify the institutions.

headline: Inquiry Begun of S.E.C. Timing in Goldman Fraud Case
text: WASHINGTON  The inspector general of the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether political or other factors influenced the timing of the filing and subsequent settlement of the commission’s securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs, according to letters between his office and a Republican congressman.

headline: At the Pollock House, Photos of the Painter
text: JACKSON POLLOCK was known for a violent intensity that marked not only his work  some of the most innovative and influential paintings of the Abstract Expressionist movement  but also his turbulent life. Fortunately, on an August morning in 1953, the photographer Tony Vaccaro caught his subject in a good mood.

headline: Green, Inside and Out
text: Among Armonk’s many opportunities for outdoor dining, few places offer a more pleasing setting than the shaded patio at the Café at Mariani Gardens. It’s a serene spot, a perfect place to take a breather after a walk through the handsomely arranged flowers, trees and shrubs.

headline: Doug Ohlson, Painter of Vivid Abstracts, Dies at 73
text: It could be said that Doug Ohlson’s determination to be a painter came out of the blue. He was born in the middle of the Great Depression in Cherokee, Iowa, 50 miles east of the Missouri River. His father, a farmer and the son of a Swedish immigrant, expected his three sons to carry on the family tradition.

headline: A Taste of Ethiopia in the Suburbs
text: LUCKY Mount Kisco has snagged the rarest of rare in Westchester County — an Ethiopian restaurant — and it’s a honey. The food at Lalibela is rich and delicious.

headline: Boldly Going Beyond the Dog
text: Despite its name, Super Duper Weenie is not just about hot dogs. It is also about a range of condiments and side dishes made from scratch, including fresh-cut French fries cooked to crispy perfection and coleslaw, prepared daily, with hints of horseradish and celery seed.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Private Meets Public
text: Someone could make a funny mash-up video for YouTube of all the times Tami Taylor has a glass of white wine in front of her when she is in her living room. Never rosé? Never a Stella Artois? Apparently not. But given the crisis that has broken out over her informal counseling sessions with Becky on “Friday Night Lights,” she has every reason to want to take the edge off, however uncreatively she may choose.

headline: Lottery Numbers
At Sunset Grille, Meals and Technicolor Views
text: ONE of the pleasures of summer — dining outdoors — can be enjoyed to its fullest at dinnertime at Sunset Grille in Norwalk, where a meal at the water’s edge comes with a glorious Technicolor sunset off Long Island Sound. Adding to the festive air are big blue umbrellas over individual tables, refreshing breezes off the sound and live music on Friday and Sunday evenings (weather permitting).

headline: King of Shish Kabob (With Mother-in-Law’s Help)
text: Ask Michael Ibrahim why he’s the King of Shish Kabob, as he calls his Middle Eastern restaurant in Woodland Park, and he laughs.

headline: A Tidy Selection of New American Tastes
text: DISH, in Red Bank, is a worthy place to go, with good, satisfying food frequently spiking to very good. But if you go, prepare for two distractions.

headline: Not a Drop Lost
text: Unlike recorked bottles, those with reclosed screw caps don’t leak when stored on their sides in refrigerators. Paumanok’s 2009 whites and its 2009 rosé are all screw-capped and thus handy for summer use.

headline: Portuguese Conviviality, and Inexpensive Wine
text: “NOW I know why you love this place,” we overheard a man at the next table saying at Tasca Convivio. He was talking to the friends who had introduced him to the two-month-old Portuguese restaurant in Mineola. They were clearly enjoying their array of appetizers: baby clams tossed with linguiça sausage, tomatoes, garlic and white wine; a casserole of charred Portuguese sausage flamed in cachaça, a distilled spirit; and jumbo shrimp in the shell sautéed with pancetta, hot peppers, garlic and lemon and served atop garlic bread.

headline: Big Hit Celebrated, but It’s Not Rodriguez’s
text: A milestone was reached in the Bronx on Friday night, just as the Yankees had hoped. The crowd responded with a long and sustained standing ovation, serenading the prominent Yankee as the ball was retrieved, a keepsake for the collection of  Jorge Posada.

headline: Celebrity Is Hidden, but the Atmosphere Is on Display
text: An enormous Mylar-coated cube was perched on a sliver of red carpet next to the fountain in Bryant Park on a steamy Friday evening, and a line of more than 100 people soon snaked from the box’s lone door around the fountain. The people all waited for one thing: to discover who occupied the gift-wrapped cell.

headline: N.Y. Fed Fills Oversight Post
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Friday named Sarah J. Dahlgren, who has been in charge of monitoring the American International Group, as the head of bank supervision starting Jan. 1.

headline: Investors Approve Magna Plan for Buyout
text: OTTAWA  Magna International said on Friday that three-quarters of its common shareholders had approved a buyout plan to end the voting control now held by the company’s founder and chairman, Frank Stronach.

headline: Fischer’s Friends
text: After the chess champion Bobby Fischer settled in Iceland, he spent much of his time with a small group of people that he trusted. Though he died more than two years ago, that small group of confidants remain loyal and protective of him and his legacy.

headline: Congressman Wants Banks to Return Some Bonuses
text: A congressman hopes to recoup payouts that were considered excessive from six banks that have yet to repay taxpayer bailout money. Representative Peter Welch, a Democrat of Vermont who is seeking re-election, plans to send a letter on Monday to the heads of those banks requesting the names and pay packages awarded to their top earners at the height of the crisis in late 2008. He also plans to ask them to reimburse the government for those payouts and to halt any future ones until the taxpayer money is returned. Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master for compensation, put the six companies on a list of 17 banks that he found made $1.6 billion of questionable payments to senior bankers in 2008 and early 2009. But he stopped short of demanding the money back, noting he did not have the legal authority. Mr. Welch said in an interview that he understood Mr. Feinberg had limited power to recoup the money but said Congress needed to take a tougher stance.

headline: Adapting Eisner for the Big Screen
text: One of the seminal works of Will Eisner, the comic book writer and artist, is headed for the big screen. “A Contract with God,” a graphic novel composed of four interlocking stories set in the tenements of the Bronx during the Depression, will be written and produced by Darren Dean. The semi-autobiographical work originally had trouble finding a publisher, as Eisner, who died in 2005,  wrote in an essay for The New York Times Book Review in 1990: “It was, in format and style, as great a departure from the comic-book conventions as I could master. It was the story of one man’s perception of his relationship with God. The book was rejected by the major publishing houses but was ultimately published in 1978 by a small, now defunct publisher, Baronet Books, which got it into establishment bookstores. It got no reviews, neither was it an instant commercial success. The response from adults who chanced on it, however, was warm and encouraging. I had, at last, connected with a serious adult audience. Ultimately it acquired a word-of-mouth following and remains in print to this day.

headline: Bay Breaks Out, and Pulls Mets With Him

headline: Level Playing Fields, in Soccer and Finance
text: OVER the last month, one question seemed to be on everyone’s mind at the economic conferences I attended in Europe: How did referees miss a goal that England scored against Germany in their World Cup match? The goal in question struck the crossbar, bounced down and landed a full yard inside the goal, then flew out onto the field, all in the blink of an eye.

headline: Feeling Gloomy? Maybe It’s Time to Buy

headline: When a Justice and a Case Are Too Close
text: WASHINGTON — With a full Senate vote expected soon, Elena Kagan’s confirmation to the Supreme Court is all but assured. But that does not mean her presence will be fully felt when the court returns in October. Ms. Kagan has identified 11 cases in which she would step aside because she worked on them as solicitor general. That amounts to more than a quarter of the cases on the calendar so far — including the very first argument and three of the first four. Yet those absences will not end the debate over when Ms. Kagan and other justices should recuse themselves. If anything, her confirmation hearings only highlighted how vague the standards for recusal by Supreme Court justices are.

headline: There’s a Battle Outside and It Is Still Ragin’
text: THE glittering young blonde in a low-cut gown is sipping champagne in a swank Manhattan restaurant back in the day when things were still swank. She is on a first date with an advertising man as dashing as his name, Don Draper. So you don’t really expect her to break the ice by talking about bad news. “The world is so dark right now,” she says. “One of the boys killed in Mississippi, Andrew Goodman  he’s from here. A girlfriend of mine knew him from summer camp.” Her date is too busy studying her décolletage, so she fills in the dead air. “Is that what it takes to change things?” she asks. He ventures no answer.

headline: We’re Gonna Be Sorry
text: When I first heard on Thursday that Senate Democrats were abandoning the effort to pass an energy/climate bill that would begin to cap greenhouse gases that cause global warming and promote renewable energy that could diminish our addiction to oil, I remembered something that Joe Romm, the climateprogress.org blogger, once said: The best thing about improvements in health care is that all the climate-change deniers are now going to live long enough to see how wrong they were.

headline: Toyota Still Doesn’t Get It

headline: Garden Time

headline: Syrians’ New Ardor for a Turkey Looking Eastward
