text: My past disappointments involving career, women and sports teams now recede amid the greatest frustration of all: We may never get to hear the Blago-Rahmbo tapes.

headline: China Faces Criticism for Sentence of Journalist
text: BEIJING — Human rights groups are strongly criticizing the Chinese government for imposing a harsh prison sentence Friday on an ethnic Uighur journalist and intellectual who gave an interview to a Hong Kong news publication last August, just weeks after deadly ethnic rioting shook the western region of Xinjiang.

headline: Next Big Battle in Washington: Bush’s Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  An epic fight is brewing over what Congress and President Obama should do about the expiring Bush tax cuts, with such substantial economic and political consequences that it could shape the fall elections and fiscal policy for years to come.

headline: Caruana Leads Biel, but Not by Much
text: After beating Wesley So in Round 5 to take over the lead, Fabiano Caruana held onto it in Round 6 on Saturday. But a group of five players only trails him by half a point.

headline: At Hunters Point, a Shrinking Bridge Does Not Appease
text: If it gets built, the bridge over Yosemite Slough will surely be a monument to political compromise.

headline: A Legal Battle Over Jim Thorpe’s Remains
text: POTTAWATOMIE COUNTY, Okla.  The northeast corner of Garden Grove Cemetery is a crowded one. But Jack Thorpe, the 73-year-old son of Jim Thorpe, sees room for at least one more.

headline: Stretch | When Yoga Hurts
text: As Cathy Lilly folded into downward dog at a workshop in January, a novice instructor, eager to help, lifted Ms. Lilly’s thumbs and angled them forward. Her thumbs are still recovering from the strain.

headline: Artists See Increase in U.S.-Cuba Cultural Exchanges
text: HAVANA  The venue is undistinguished: a cramped theater tucked beneath a downtown apartment block. Tickets cost just five Cuban pesos, or 23 cents. The set, for want of wood, is a beautiful creation of string.

headline: Jury Volunteer Stirs Up a Pension Fund Tempest
text: Two years ago, a San Francisco accountant, Craig Weber, noticed a flier posted at the Mission Bay public library. It sought volunteers for the civil grand jury, a panel of 19 citizens empowered to investigate local government.

headline: Attorney General Candidate Failed to Vote for 18 Years
text: Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney and a Democratic candidate for attorney general, did not cast her first ballot in an election until 2002, nearly two decades after she first registered to vote, according to election records.

headline: Umpire Doug Harvey to Enter Hall of Fame
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  No statistical equivalents of 600 home runs, 300 wins or 3,000 strikeouts exist to measure umpires by, which might explain why only nine are members of the National Baseball Hall of Fame, including Doug Harvey, who will be inducted on Sunday.

headline: Stampede at German Music Festival Kills 18
text: BERLIN  A stampede inside a tunnel at a popular techno music festival killed 18 people and injured dozens more on Saturday, police officials said.

headline: Cécile Aubry, Actress and Writer of Children’s Stories, Dies at 81
text: Cécile Aubry, a French actress who had a short but glamorous film career and who later became a writer, creating a children’s television series, died Monday in Dourdan, outside of Paris. She was 81.

headline: Creativity Is Needed to Fill Vacant Stores
text: Union Square, in the heart of downtown San Francisco, is just the kind of retail shopping district that should be resisting the recession pretty well. It’s full of hotels and the free-spending tourists and business travelers who occupy them; it’s adjacent to the downtown high-rise district and the many thousands of people who work there. It even has a big parking garage and good transit connections.

headline: Elks Lodge No. 3
text: The historic San Francisco Elks Lodge No.3 hides in plain sight, tucked inside a Union Square building that also houses the Kensington Park Hotel and Farallon Restaurant. While not the lodge’s first home, the Spanish Gothic gem was built by Elks in 1925, and it currently serves around 1,000 local members.

headline: Stampede at German Music Festival
text: Panic as a crowd surged through a jammed entrance tunnel killed at least 18 people at the Love Parade festival in Duisburg in western Germany.

headline: Umpires’ Signs: The Movie
text: A batter hits a grounder, hustles down the line and arrives at first base almost simultaneously with the ball. How do the other players and the spectators know if the batter is out or safe?

headline: Giants Add Bulluck to Linebacker Corps
text: The Giants agreed to terms with the former Titans linebacker Keith Bulluck on Saturday, said Bulluck’s agent, Gary Wichard. Bulluck is coming off surgery on the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee but is likely to start at middle linebacker for the Giants, who are trying to replace Antonio Pierce.

headline: Boston Landmark’s Glowing Makeover
text: When the Boston Red Sox return from the West Coast this week, a strange sight will await their fans at Fenway Park. About 1,200 feet from home plate, beyond the Green Monster and six stories over Kenmore Square, the famous Citgo sign will be dark. It could be disorienting.

headline: Vettel on Pole, by the Thinnest of Margins
text: Now that was a close qualifying session. And an exciting one. Sebastian Vettel clinched the pole at the German Grand Prix, but for a moment it looked as if Fernando Alonso would just edge him out on his last lap. In the end, Alonso slotted his car into second position on the grid by two thousandths of a second.

headline: It’s Sizzling, Not Dazzling, as Rachel Alexandra Wins
text: OCEANPORT, N.J.  Rachel Alexandra did her job. She showed up Saturday, battled the oppressive heat, won the Lady’s Secret Stakes at Monmouth Park and even put a few extra fans in the seats. Despite temperatures that reached 103 degrees on the Jersey Shore, 12,859 turned out for the chance to see one of racing’s most popular horses.

headline: Young Viewers Depart, and Fewer Young Drivers Enter
text: When the green flag waved to start the Daytona 500 in February, marking the beginning of the Nascar Sprint Cup season, not a single rookie driver was in the 43-car field. The last time that happened?

headline: Aging Transit Systems Face Budget Crunch
text: More riders, aging mass transit systems and inadequate money for maintenance and upgrades  a familiar story line for commuters and those faced with the task of keeping the trains running. What is new this summer is that the problems are making headlines again, in part because of an extended heat wave that has smothered so much of the country.

headline: Court Under Roberts Is Most Conservative in Decades
text: WASHINGTON  When Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and his colleagues on the Supreme Court left for their summer break at the end of June, they marked a milestone: the Roberts court had just completed its fifth term.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Surgery Probably Ends Maine’s Time With Mets
text: LOS ANGELES — The right-hander John Maine had arthroscopic surgery Friday to clean out scar tissue in his right shoulder, meaning his career with the Mets is essentially over. The Mets are not expected to tender him a contract for next year.

headline: Daring to Pose a Challenge to the Oil Culture
text: DULAC, La.  In this region so threatened by the BP oil spill, it has often seemed to residents that the only thing worse than losing tens of thousands of seafood industry jobs would be to lose their other major job source: the oil industry.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 17 this weekend about the composer Franz Schreker refers incorrectly to Wendall K. Harrington, an artist who creates video projections and who helped stage a recent Los Angeles Opera production of Schreker’s “Die Gezeichneten” (“Those Who Bear the Mark”). Ms. Harrington is a woman.

headline: DAY 95: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Officials Are Preparing to Resume Response Efforts

headline: Few Runs, Few Hits, No Explanations
text: LOS ANGELES  This time, it was Oliver Perez walking slowly off the mound with his eyes fixed on the ground after James Loney hit a game-winning home run in the 13th inning.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this article misstated the revenue Zynga was expected to take in this year, according to the Inside Network. It is as much as $500 million, not $835 million.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: For 2 New U.S. Champions, Diverging Paths Ahead
text: The two newest United States champions have very different future plans.

headline: Slow Boat to China = Big Fuel Savings
text: 10:50 p.m. | Updated From slow food to slow blogging to working less, it seems slow is the new fast these days. Now the same is true at sea, at least while the economy is in the doldrums.

headline: Lucky to Be Yankee and Lucky to Be Alive
text: When Ralph Houk died Wednesday at 90, his obituaries told of his two-decade career as a major league manager, notably his first three Yankees teams, beginning in 1961, that won two World Series and three American League pennants.

headline: Labor Dispute Means Future May Be Now
text: N.F.L. training camps open this week — the Cowboys started in San Antonio on Saturday, and by Aug. 1, every team will be in camp. But this year, the annual exercise in perspiration comes with a sobering caveat: this could be the last normal training camp until 2012.

headline: Helping Out Next Generation
text: Orel Hershiser, an ESPN analyst and a former pitching star and coach, won 204 games and had 2,014 strikeouts in 18 seasons with the Dodgers, Indians, Giants and Mets. He was recently a coach for the Little League Baseball Appreciation Game in Beverly Hills, Calif., organized by Subway Restaurants as part of the Baseball Designs Tour. Balls decorated by Little Leaguers and autographed by athletes and celebrities will be auctioned online in August to benefit the Little League Urban Initiative. JOE BRESCIA

headline: Lottery Numbers
No. 600 Has to Wait, but Excitement Doesn’t
text: Nothing is ever simple with Alex Rodriguez.

headline: Iowa Dam Ruptures Under Torrential Rain
text: DELHI, Iowa  Heavy rain ruptured the Lake Delhi dam on Saturday, sending a torrent into the Maquoketa River below and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of homes and vacation cabins in eastern Iowa. Officials estimated that 8,000 people were affected by the flooding. No injuries or deaths were reported.

headline: Ponomariov Clinches at Least a Tie for First in Dortmund
text: While Ruslan Ponomariov wrapped up at least a share of first place on Saturday, Vladimir Kramnik, the defending champion and top seed, lost again and is tied for fourth in the elite tournament.

headline: Pep Rally for an Uneasy Democratic Team
text: President Obama addressed today, via video, a gathering that included some of his earliest and most hard-core supporters from the 2008 campaign. But he yielded about a quarter of his four-minute message to Rachel Maddow, using edited clips of her MSNBC show to tout his administration’s accomplishments over the past 18 months.

headline: A Quaint Parade to Honor the Greats
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — The National Baseball Hall of Fame added a new wrinkle to its weekend of festivities surrounding the annual induction ceremonies. On Saturday, fans lined Main Street for an early evening parade of Hall of Famers that began with Bob Feller, 91, from the class of 1962, to the newest ones, Andre Dawson, Whitey Herzog and Doug Harvey.

headline: Life According to Herzog
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Whitey Herzog sounded moved Saturday during a news conference in advance of his Hall of Fame induction when he recalled a moment with Gil Hodges after the Mets won the 1969 World Series. Hodges was, of course, the manager who led the Miracle Mets and Herzog was the team’s director of player development.

headline: More Than Just a Game for Jon Miller
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Along his path to becoming a play-by-play announcer, the young Jon Miller bought the Strat-O-Matic game and played it at home near San Francisco. Anyone who knows the board game knows its understated brilliance and its appeal to the obsessive baseball fan.

headline: Five Big Questions Heading Into Training Camp
text: N.F.L. training camps open this week and the uncertainty extends far beyond the usual position battles. Contract negotiations have been complicated by the labor unrest hovering over the league. Still, new quarterbacks have brought excitement from D.C. to Denver. A look at some of the major questions as camps open.

headline: Vows: Kim and Terry
text: Kim Garris and Terry Minogue met over six years ago through their roommates. Their relationship progressed when Terry went to a Knicks game and sought out Kim, then a Knicks City Dancer.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the premiere of the fourth season of “Mad Men” misspelled part of the name of the advertising agency featured on the show. It is Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, not Sterling Cooper Draper Bryce. The article also referred imprecisely to 1964 as “those days before the pill.” While birth-control pills were not widely available to single women until late in the decade, they were available on a limited basis in 1964, having been approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 1960.

headline: Miami Dolphins 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Bengali Cuisine in the Suburbs of Mumbai
text: It’s no secret that Mumbai, with its economic might and reputation as “the city of dreams,” attracts migrants and transplants from all over India. Among this crowd, there’s a sizable contingent of Bengalis, homesick for the kabobs and biryanis of Calcutta. Luckily for them — and for food-curious visitors — the quickly expanding chain Hangla’s (Bengali for “glutton”) is making Calcutta-style street food increasingly available, particularly across the city’s northern suburbs.

headline: As Tensions Rise, U.S. and S. Korea Begin Drills
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States and South Korea began their largest joint war games in years on Sunday, with a nuclear powered American aircraft carrier prowling off the east coast of South Korea while North Korea threatened to retaliate and reportedly put its military on alert for war.

headline: One Way to Lower a Doctor’s Bill
text: In his book, “Secrets of a Stingy Scoundrel: 100 Dirty Little Money-Grubbing Secrets,” Consumerist.com’s contributing editor Phil Villarreal shares one way to get a lower medical bill.

headline: Chocolate And Copper
text: Interesting story in today’s Times about Anthony Ward, aka Chocfinger. I actually wrote about a somewhat similar case 14 years ago, in that case in the copper market; back then, I did a bit of analysis in terms of the old Samuelson model of intertemporal speculation and realized that cornering the market in a storable commodity can indeed be profitable, under the right conditions.

headline: Commenting Reminder
text: If you use obscenities, your comment won’t be published, no matter how well-reasoned. I’m not a prude, but the Times has rules. So find another way to make your point, OK?

headline: The Sunday Word: Tax Talk
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated Only two work weeks remain before lawmakers return to their districts for the summer recess and begin the campaign season in earnest.

headline: A 19th-Century Piano Is So Square, It’s Cool
text: Richard K. Lieberman lifted the lid on the piano and asked the roomful of lecturers at LaGuardia Community College, “Who’s going to play?” No hands went up, but one of the teachers sneaked across the hall and found Eric Anderson, a 26-year-old history major who turned out to be a pretty good pianist.

headline: BP Is Expected to Replace Chief With American
text: BP’s board is expected on Monday to name an American, Robert Dudley, as its chief executive, replacing Tony Hayward, whose repeated stumbles during the company’s three-month oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico alienated federal and state officials as well as residents of the Gulf Coast.

headline: Search Widens for U.S. Sailors in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  As a huge manhunt for two missing American servicemen widened throughout a dangerous region of eastern Afghanistan on Sunday, a Taliban spokesman said that one had been killed in an ambush and the other captured.

headline: Teammate Lets Alonso Pass Him to Win German Grand Prix
text: Updated | 12:26 p.m.

headline: Martin Wolf Is Shrill
text: He has a long post arguing that the tax-cutting radical right, not liberal advocates of stimulus spending, poses the real threat to US solvency. (And yes, it is possible to have a solvency problem, even here.) Wolf’s argument and main points are similar to those I made in a recent column; that’s not a criticism, because we need more people saying this.

headline: The Economics Of Market Corners (Nostalgic Wonkery)
text: Aha. An update on Chocfinger: I was trying to remember exactly how the underlying model behind my old copper-corner column worked. It was actually an application of the logic of my even older reciprocal dumping (pdf) work with Jim Brander.

headline: Despite Flaws, Stress Tests May Satisfy Markets
text: FRANKFURT — The stress tests conducted by European regulators last week did not give investors all the information they wanted about the condition of the region’s banks, but the exercise may have given them enough to begin to answer the question of which institutions are creditworthy and which are not.

headline: A Few Minutes With Bob Feller
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Outside a memorabilia store Saturday, Bob Feller sat under a canopy, meticulously signing baseballs and photographs for $30, $40 and up.

headline: Third Time Is a Relief as Contador Takes the Tour
text: PARIS — On his way to the finish line of a long and bumpy Tour de France, the Spanish rider Alberto Contador let his success sink in.

headline: A Master of Minimalism (and More)
text: Artists often argue that their works are wrongly categorized, and they are not alone. While introducing compositions by Terry Riley on Friday evening at Bargemusic in Brooklyn, members of the Voxare Quartet said they disagreed with the Minimalist label assigned to Mr. Riley.

headline: Californians Benefit From a Textbook Auction
text: NEW ORLEANS  At the Summer North American Championships here, the final of the Grand National Teams was scheduled to end late Sunday. (Details are at acbl.org.) In Saturday’s semifinals District 23 (Los Angeles County), represented by Jill Meyers, Ed Davis, Mitch Dunitz and Walter Schafer Jr., defeated District 10 (Mid-South Bridge Conference), John Onstott, Iype Koshy and Allan and David Siebert. And District 11 (Kentucky, western Ohio, central Indiana and West Virginia), Doug Simson, Walter Johnson and Dennis and Jerry Clerkin, beat District 16 (Texas and Mexico), Dan Morse, Ira Hessel, Greg Hinze and Hemant and Justin Lall.

headline: Growing Up Paupers in a Land of Privilege
text: Alexandra Pelosi’s approach hasn’t changed much since her first documentary, “Journeys With George” in 2002, in which her subject, George W. Bush, compared her to a head cold. Like a kid sister with a camera, she tags along, asking annoying questions. It isn’t subtle, but through ingratiation and obstinance she ends up seeing a lot.

headline:
View Is Bleaker Than
Official Portrayal of War in Afghanistan
text: This article was written and reported by C. J. Chivers, Carlotta Gall, Andrew W. Lehren, Mark Mazzetti, Jane Perlez, and Eric Schmitt, with contributions from Jacob Harris and Alan McLean.

headline: Text From a Selection of the Secret Dispatches
text: A selection of the reports from a six-year archive of classified military documents published by WikiLeaks.

headline: Pakistan Aids Insurgency in Afghanistan, Reports Assert
text: Americans fighting the war in Afghanistan have long harbored strong suspicions that Pakistan’s military spy service has guided the Afghan insurgency with a hidden hand, even as Pakistan receives more than $1 billion a year from Washington for its help combating the militants, according to a trove of secret military field reports made public Sunday.

headline: Piecing Together the Reports, and Deciding What to Publish
text: The articles published today are based on thousands of United States military incident and intelligence reports — records of engagements, mishaps, intelligence on enemy activity and other events from the war in Afghanistan — that were made public on Sunday on the Internet. The New York Times, The Guardian newspaper in London, and the German magazine Der Spiegel were given access to the material several weeks ago. These reports are used by desk officers in the Pentagon and troops in the field when they make operational plans and prepare briefings on the situation in the war zone. Most of the reports are routine, even mundane, but many add insights, texture and context to a war that has been waged for nearly nine years.

headline: Strategic Plans Spawned Bitter End for a Lonely Outpost
text: Nothing in the documents made public on Sunday offers as vivid a miniature of the Afghan war so far — from hope to heartbreak — as the field reports from one lonely base: Combat Outpost Keating.

headline: In Disclosing Secret Documents, WikiLeaks Seeks ‘Transparency’
text: WikiLeaks.org, the online organization that posted tens of thousands of classified military field reports about the Afghan war on Sunday, says its goal in disclosing secret documents is to reveal “unethical behavior” by governments and corporations.

headline: The War Logs: Reaction to Disclosure of Military Documents on Afghan War
text: The At War blog is following reaction to the release of an archive of classified military documents described here that paints a grim portrait of the war in Afghanistan. The New York Times had access to the documents and published a series of reports.

headline: The War Logs
text: An archive of classified military documents offers an unvarnished view of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: The Limits of the Coded World
text: In an influential article in the Annual Review of Neuroscience, Joshua Gold of the University of Pennsylvania and Michael Shadlen of the University of Washington sum up experiments aimed at discovering the neural basis of decision-making. In one set of experiments, researchers attached sensors to the parts of monkeys’ brains responsible for visual pattern recognition. The monkeys were then taught to respond to a cue by choosing to look at one of two patterns. Computers reading the sensors were able to register the decision a fraction of a second before the monkeys’ eyes turned to the pattern. As the monkeys were not deliberating, but rather reacting to visual stimuli, researchers were able to plausibly claim that the computer could successfully predict the monkeys’ reaction. In other words, the computer was reading the monkeys’ minds and knew before they did what their decision would be.

headline: A Tired, Struggling Wright Is Playing Again
text: LOS ANGELES — Exhausted or not, David Wright is back on the field Sunday, and even doubled in his first at-bat against the Dodgers in the final game of the Mets’ 11-game West Coast road trip.

headline: The Band Plays On, Competing With the Past
text: “Do you miss Mikey?”

headline: A Home-Wrecking Humanitarian, Footnote Free
text: Angelina Jolie has accrued an Oscar, several Golden Globes, a Global Humanitarian Action Award, a Freedom Award and a seat on the Council on Foreign Relations. She has managed all this while building herself into one of the few viable female Hollywood stars who can carry a film single-handedly and squelching all competition for the title of World’s Yummiest Mummy.

headline: A Thai Take on Myth and Modernity
text: Very schematically, the Pichet Klunchun Dance Company’s hourlong production of “Chui Chai”  which was performed this weekend at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater as part of the Lincoln Center Festival  takes us from Thai traditions to Thai modernity. On the way there’s a fair sprinkling of (sigh) deconstruction.

headline: 'Chui Chai'
text: Images from a performance by the Pichet Klunchun Dance Company.

headline: Hit With a Hammer
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — “You mean every Monday through Thursday puzzle in The Times has a theme?”

headline: Jazz and Classical Meet to Learn and Improvise
text: Improvisation, a fundamental quality of jazz, is by nature a risky business. The act usually involves a confrontation between two perspectives  that of a composer and that of a performer or performers  with the goal of achieving a combination informed and enriched by both perspectives. At its idealistic peak, as in recent large-ensemble works by the composer and bandleader Anthony Braxton, improvisation can represent a vision of collaborative democracy.

headline: New CDs
text: KORN

headline: Sexual Outlaw on the Gay Frontier
text: When the author Justin Spring finally tracked down the executor of Samuel Steward’s estate, he had no idea what this sexual outlaw and little-known literary figure had left behind after his death in 1993.

headline: 'Secret Historian'
text: Images from a new book about the gay literary figure and tattoo artist Samuel Steward.

headline: Rickey Henderson’s Lasting Impact
text: LOS ANGELES — The Hall of Fame induction ceremony was being shown on television in the Mets’ clubhouse before Sunday’s game. When Rickey Henderson was shown, Mets catcher Josh Thole recalled his first interaction with Henderson, the great leadoff hitter and base stealer.

headline: Noonday Ritual on City Street
text: Come shine, come rain, the Canadian choreographer-dancer Paul-André Fortier is performing a 30-minute solo, “30 x 30,” at noon each day for 30 consecutive days in the open air at 1 New York Plaza in Lower Manhattan. Saturday’s performance, part of the River to River Festival, was Day 9: a sunny but breezy day, whereas on Day 8 he had reportedly danced through a downpour.

headline: The War Logs Articles
text: The New York Times on Sunday published highlights of a six-year archive of classified military documents that was obtained by an organization called WikiLeaks. The documents cover the period from 2004 to 2009, and portray American forces as being starved for resources and battling an insurgency that was getter larger and better coordinated year by year. The Times, along with The Guardian newspaper in London and the German magazine Der Spiegel, was given access to the material several weeks ago, and The Times has spent a month examining the data for disclosures and patterns and verifying the information for the articles that it published Sunday.

headline: After Runs Don’t Flow, Mets Hope Ideas Will
text: LOS ANGELES  In the wake of another shutout that ended a disastrous 2-9 trip, the Mets headed back to New York perhaps facing some changes.

headline: A New Look at Gay History
text: Justin Spring talks about his new book "Secret Historian: The Life and Times of Samuel Steward, Professor, Tattoo Artist, and Sexual Renegade." (Video courtesy of Jeff Lunger and Samuel Steward)

headline: Suspense, and a Brief Scare, in the Wait for No. 600
text: After the Yankees’ 12-6 victory over the Kansas City Royals on Sunday, Alex Rodriguez left Yankee Stadium with a purple mark on his left hand, a smile on his face and  for the third day  a total of 599 home runs in his eventful career.

headline: Overdue Debut for Composer and Exiled Prince
text: SANTA FE, N.M.  When an opera company presents a world premiere by a living composer, the opera in question usually represents the composer’s current style and approach. This was not the case on Saturday night for the absurdly overdue premiere of Lewis Spratlan’s “Life Is a Dream” here at the Santa Fe Opera.

headline: Hackers With Enigmatic Motives Vex Companies
text: The world of hackers can be roughly divided into three groups. “Black hats” break into corporate computer systems for fun and profit, taking credit card numbers and e-mail addresses to sell and trade with other hackers, while the “white hats” help companies stop their disruptive counterparts.

headline: Iranian Negotiator Agrees to Meet With European Diplomat
text: ISTANBUL  In an apparent effort to garner international support for its nuclear program, Iran has agreed to meet with the European Union’s foreign affairs chief in early September, after the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

headline: Fraternity of the Wired Works in the Wee Hours
text: NEW YORK  After college, most people do their best to avoid having to pull any more all-nighters. But for some, even after graduation, the wee hours of the morning are the most productive.

headline: Eight Hours on an Island of Noise
text: “I need to feel the beat  turn it up now,” M.I.A. chanted during her strange, blurry headlining set at Hard NYC on Saturday on Governors Island. Beat and noise, often the same thing, were the core of this eight-hour dance-music festival: slamming, twitching, throbbing, booping and buzzing virtually nonstop from two stages on South Island Field. It was noise as celebration and assault, as science experiment and come-on, using high-tech equipment to generate visceral, body-moving effects. Subwoofers and strobe lights pumped and flickered into the night.

headline: Peak Performances Announces New Season
text: The innovative Peak Performances series at Montclair State University in New Jersey has announced its 2010-11 season, running from Sept. 1 through May 8, which begins with “Everywhere Is the Best Seat,” a sound-and-light installation by the architect and composer Christopher Janney, who is known for creating sonic and light environments in public spaces. The lineup also includes a revival of the 1998 play “Jet Lag,” opening on Sept. 23. Conceived by the New York theater company Builders Association and the New York architecture team Diller Scofidio & Renfro, it is a story based on two tragic incidents that deal with the uses and abuses of technology. And “Double Vision,” a multimedia dance performance presented by Carolyn Carlson that runs from Oct. 14 to 17. Other performers include the jazz composer and pianist Fred Hersch; the Belgian theater director and artist Jan Fabre; and the performance artist Robert Whitman. Choreographers are well represented too, among them Crystal Pite, Liz Lerman and Robyn Orlin.

headline: Assault at Comic-Con as Action Turned Real
text: Comic-Con International, the annual pop-culture convention that ended in San Diego on Sunday, seems to operate on a wing and a prayer when it comes to safety. There are no metal detectors, attendees often show up in masks, and swords and scythes are commonplace. A convention center that is too small for the crowds adds to the combustible mix. Even so, attendees have historically been exceptionally well behaved. So it was jarring on Saturday when word raced through the gathering that there had been a stabbing in Hall H, the room that seats 6,500 and where the big Hollywood studios parade their stars. The reality was much less threatening than the rumor, if still scary: An argument between two men over a seat escalated until one of the men stabbed the other in the face with a pen, resulting in a minor cut “on or near the eyelid,” according to the San Diego police. The attacker, wearing a blood-spattered Harry Potter shirt, was arrested and booked on suspicion of assault with a deadly weapon. Neither man was identified. A spokesman for Comic-Con declined to comment.

headline: Berlin Gives Facelift to Moore Sculpture
text: A nine-ton bronze sculpture that is one of Henry Moore’s heaviest and his last monumental work before his death in 1986, has recently been restored and reinstalled in front of the circular mirror pond outside the entrance to the House of World Cultures, a contemporary arts center in Berlin. According to The Art Newspaper the surface of “Large Divided Oval: Butterfly” had suffered from pollution and vandalism. The work, above, could not be restored in situ, so it was sent to the Noack Foundry in Berlin, where it was originally cast. “Butterfly” was initially a loan to the city of West Berlin in 1986. (It had been placed in front of the Congress Hall as part of Berlin’s 750th anniversary in 1987.) At the time the city council wanted the sculpture permanently and wrote to Moore asking if he would donate it. But the letter arrived just before his death and went unanswered. In 1988 it was sold by the Henry Moore Foundation for nearly $2.6 million, then a huge price for a public sculpture.

headline: A New Role for Molina
text: He was Mark Rothko, the tortured artist, in the Tony-winning play “Red,” which ended its Broadway run last month. Now Alfred Molina will be the one torturing others. The British actor is joining the cast of the new “Law & Order: Los Angeles” as Deputy District Attorney Morales. (The show will have its premiere in the fall, though a specific start date  and the first name of Molina’s character  have not been announced, according to The Associated Press.) While the original “Law & Order” ended its 20-year run in May, “Law & Order: Los Angeles” will join other spinoffs in the series that are still being produced, “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent.”

headline: Déjà Vu: ‘Inception’ Rules the Box Office
text: Even a gun-wielding Angelina Jolie couldn’t interrupt the dreamy run “Inception” is having at the North American box office. For the second weekend in a row “Inception” (Warner Brothers) was No. 1, selling about $43.5 million for a new domestic total of $143.7 million. Strong word of mouth, stellar reviews and hunger for original stories at the multiplex has fueled continued interest in the complicated film, directed by Christopher Nolan and starring Leonardo DiCaprio. Ms. Jolie, starring as a C.I.A. officer in Columbia Pictures’ “Salt,” was second with about $35.6 million. That result proved Ms. Jolie to be one of the few remaining stars who can anchor a major Hollywood release. The animated film “Despicable Me” (Universal Pictures) powered forward in third place, selling about $24.1 million for a new domestic total of $161.7 million and solidifying its position as one of the breakout hits of the year. “The Sorcerer’s Apprentice,” a flop that will likely result in a write-down at Walt Disney Studios, was fourth in its second weekend with $9.7 million ($42.6 million total). Disney-Pixar’s “Toy Story 3” rounded out the top five with $9 million ($379.5 million total). The only other wide release of the weekend, the inexpensive “Ramona and Beezus” from 20th Century Fox, got off to a slow start in sixth place with $8 million.

headline: Equity of Test Is Debated as Children Compete for Gifted Kindergarten
text: Teachers at the Bloomingdale Head Start program in Manhattan tell Alexis Stewart that her 4-year-old son, Chase, is bright.

headline: Dressing Up a Construction Site
text: Construction sites in Lower Manhattan are numerous, and many are dressed up with contemporary art. The latest such installation  a map of imaginary terrain with a large river snaking around lakes and tributaries  surrounds Titanic Park, at Fulton and Pearl Streets. It is the work of the California artist Lordy Rodriguez, known for inventing his own topographies. Here he has created a digitally printed composition on vinyl mesh that wraps around the triangular site, which is being renovated and is due to reopen in September. Called “Water Movements,” above, it is the latest work in a program of the Alliance for Downtown New York, a nonprofit business improvement district that received a $1.5 million grant from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation for these projects. “It’s yet another example of how temporary interventions can transform a community,” said Elizabeth H. Berger, president of the alliance. “This project is not just beautiful but thought provoking on many levels.”

headline: A Town House for ‘Hedda Gabler’
text: Yet another adaptation of Ibsen’s oft-produced ode to the frustrations of modern womanhood, “Hedda Gabler,” is coming to New York this summer. But what will distinguish the production of this 1890 drama is where it takes place. Rather than a traditional theater, John Gould Rubin, the former executive director of the LAByrinth Theater Company who is now an independent director, is staging the play in a Manhattan town house. But only ticketholders will know the exact location. The address will be revealed upon confirmation of a reservation. The play, which runs from Aug. 10 to 13 and Aug. 19 to Sept. 4, is free. Reservations can be made at (212) 982-6475 or heddagablerrsvp@gmail.com. Caitlin FitzGerald, above, known for her role as the eldest daughter in the movie “It’s Complicated” with Meryl Streep, is playing Hedda Gabler.

headline: Khmer Rouge Figure Is Found Guilty of War Crimes
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  A United Nations-backed tribunal on Monday found a 67-year-old former prison warden of the Khmer Rouge guilty of crimes against humanity and war crimes for overseeing the torture and killing of more than 14,000 prisoners. He was the first major figure to be tried in the murderous regime since it was toppled 30 years ago.

headline: Sporting Wins Challenge
text: Sporting Portugal came to Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., with the purpose of winning the Barclays New York Challenge. With help from a goal by Jaime Valdes in the 48th minute of Sporting’s 2-2 tie with Tottenham Hotspur on Sunday in searing 93-degree heat, it eventually was able to.

headline: Saying Goodbye to ‘Walking Man,’ With a Walk
text: LOS ANGELES  Most people in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles did not know Marc Abrams by name when he died at his home on Wednesday. But by the weekend, news had sped through town that he was the local celebrity dubbed Walking Man, for his daily, often day-long, marches through these hilly streets.

headline: Inquiry Into Staten Island Fire Shifts to Mother
text: The conclusion came just hours after firefighters pulled the bodies of a mother and her four children from a charred house on Staten Island last week: that the oldest of the children, a 14-year-old boy, had deliberately started the fire after slitting his sisters’ throats.

headline: Adding Punch to Influence Public Opinion
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Japanese Village Creates Art From Hues of Rice
text: INAKADATE, Japan  Nearly two decades ago, Koichi Hanada, a clerk in the village hall, received an unusual request from his superior: find a way to bring tourists to this small community in rural northern Japan, which has rice paddies and apple orchards, but not much else.

headline: Hearing on Lockerbie Sets Off More Finger-Pointing
text: LONDON  A coming Senate hearing in Washington has set off a new round of political disavowals by British and Scottish officials who laid the groundwork for last year’s release of the former Libyan intelligence agent convicted in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing.

headline: Wedding Is Talk of the Town, but Nobody’s Talking
text: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — This small town in the Hudson Valley is thrilled that the wedding of the year will be happening here on Saturday. Thrilled — even though no one can talk about it.

headline: That Cheap, Roomy Loft Can Now Be a Legal One, Too
text: Over the years, Michael Kronberg, a 46-year-old artist, grew to accept, if not always love, the quirks and pitfalls that came with living in his loft in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: States Hooked on Gambling for Revenue
text: From the beginning of our joy ride with legalized gambling, there was a worry that more gambling would mean more overextended suckers addicted to slots, poker tables, lotteries and roulette wheels.

headline: As English Spreads, Indonesians Fear for Their Language
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Paulina Sugiarto’s three children played together at a mall here the other day, chattering not in Indonesia’s national language, but English. Their fluency often draws admiring questions from other Indonesian parents Ms. Sugiarto encounters in this city’s upscale malls.

headline: When a Drug Fails
text: The flameout of an enormously expensive drug to treat advanced breast cancer will pose a critical test for the Food and Drug Administration. Will the agency have the courage to reverse course when a medical treatment that it approved based on preliminary evidence flops badly in follow-up studies?

headline: The I.M.F. We Need
text: Just a year after the Group of 20 agreed to triple the resources of the International Monetary Fund to $750 billion, the head of the fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, is asking for $250 billion more to bolster its lending war chest.

headline: Cities View Homesteads as a Source of Income
text: BEATRICE, Neb.  Give away land to make money?

headline: The House Should Listen and Learn
text: A “tough on crime” federal law that requires harsher prison terms for people arrested with crack cocaine than with the powdered version of the drug is scientifically indefensible and hugely unfair. A bill that reduces this onerous sentencing disparity has passed the Senate easily. The House, which has been vacillating over whether or not to schedule a vote on the Senate bill, needs to show the same good sense.

headline: Third Tour de France Victory for Alberto Contador
text: After three weeks and more than 2,200 miles atop his bike, the Spanish rider Alberto Contador let his success sink in.

headline: Round Up the Usual Lobbyists
text: Even before the blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico was finally capped, an army of more than 600 lobbyists was at work in Washington trying to put a lid on a rush of government proposals to crack down on the oil and gas industry. This is the natural order in the world of government and the K Street lobbying industry. They co-exist so handsomely. But new data provide worthwhile insight into just how tight the hand-in-glove relationship of government and the industry has become.

headline: At the White House, Losing a Game of Phone Tag
text: The White House switchboard  able to conjure up Santa Claus at a moment’s notice for a young Caroline Kennedy  is famous for its ability to track down anyone, anywhere, anytime.

headline: On Pleasant Avenue, a Grisly Past Fades, and a Target Moves In
text: One August morning in 1882, a police officer discovered the body of a man in an empty lot on Pleasant Avenue in East Harlem. His clothes were covered in mud. His skull had been fractured, his throat cut. The stab wound was of such force that it penetrated to the spinal column. The police believed the man was a peddler who was the victim of a robbery, for there was nothing of value found in his pockets.

headline: Lutherans Offer Warm Welcome to Gay Pastors
text: With a laying on of hands, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America on Sunday welcomed into its fold seven openly gay pastors who had until recently been barred from the church’s ministry.

headline: Four Ways to Kill a Climate Bill
text: IF President Obama and Congress had announced that no financial reform legislation would pass unless Goldman Sachs agreed to the bill, we would conclude our leaders had been standing in the Washington sun too long. Yet when it came to addressing climate change, that is precisely the course the president and Congress took. Lacking support from those most responsible for the problem, they have given up on passing a major climate bill this year.

headline: A Dam Gives Way in Iowa, and Residents Tally Losses
text: DELHI, Iowa — When your life and livelihood are so dependent on a lake, as Chris Stender’s are, a flood like the one that hit his hometown here over the weekend throws everything into a muddy tailspin.

headline: Brazil’s President Works to Lend Popularity to a Protégée
text: GARANHUNS, Brazil — With less than three months until the presidential election, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is trying to make enough of his magic dust stick to his chosen successor, Dilma Rousseff, to persuade voters to elect her as the first female president of Brazil, Latin America’s largest country.

headline: Christie Says Show Is Bad for the State
text: Some five million Americans may love “Jersey Shore,” but Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey says he thinks the MTV show, about a group of Italian-Americans sharing a beach house in Seaside Heights, is a “negative” for his state.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wall Street Still Doesn’t Have a Sheriff
text: THE current range of opinion on the Securities and Exchange Commission’s $550 million settlement in the Goldman Sachs fraud suit lines up closely with that evoked by previous S.E.C. settlements with corporate defendants. Some Americans are outraged that Goldman “got off easy,” while others feel the deal could be a model for gaining some measure of justice against those responsible for Wall Street’s meltdown.

headline: Who Cooked the Planet?
text: Never say that the gods lack a sense of humor. I bet they’re still chuckling on Olympus over the decision to make the first half of 2010  the year in which all hope of action to limit climate change died  the hottest such stretch on record.

headline: Mexican Officials Say Prisoners Acted as Hit Men
text: MEXICO CITY  Prisoners in a northern Mexico jail were allowed out at night to carry out murder-for-hire jobs using jail guards’ weapons and vehicles, officials said Sunday, revealing a level of corruption that is stunning even in a country where prison breakouts are common as guards look the other way.

headline: Art, Until Harvest Time
text: Intricate artwork using rice paddies as a canvas is bringing tourists to a small community in rural northern Japan.

headline: The Right and the Climate
text: Climate change legislation has been dying in the Senate for months now, but Harry Reid’s decision to finally admit as much — in the midst of an endless East Coast heat wave, no less — has supporters of cap-and-trade casting about for somebody to blame. They’ve blamed the Obama administration, for prioritizing health care reform over an energy bill. They’ve blamed the American people, for being too concerned with economic issues to grapple with longer-term threats. And they’ve blamed figures like Lindsey Graham and John McCain, erstwhile supporters of cap-and-trade who have steadily backpedaled away from it.

headline: Industries Find Surging Profits in Deeper Cuts
text: By most measures, Harley-Davidson has been having a rough ride.

headline: One Last Shot for Ben Davis
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Ben Davis was the best high school baseball player I ever saw. I doubt I actually faced him, because I rarely played in the big varsity games against teams like Malvern Prep in suburban Philadelphia, where Davis and his brother, Glenn, were stars. But my younger brother faced him; I know that for sure.

headline: Dickey Shows His Competitive Side
text: LOS ANGELES – R.A. Dickey’s competitive fire was on display for all to see Sunday as Jerry Manuel removed him from the game over Dickey’s vehement opposition, and his intelligent explanation of events provided some insight into his fierce desire to pitch.

Audience members were milling about uncertainly in the smoke-filled auditorium before the performance I attended, eyeing the pile warily. Nobody could tell if this impressive assemblage was a sculpture or a challenge.

headline: Light Relief, but Penalty Applies
text: During a four-ball stroke-play competition, the team of Al and Ben is paired with the team of Carl and Dave. On the green, Al marks the position of Ben’s ball and tosses it to Ben. Ben replaces the ball in front of Al’s marker and removes the marker. Because Al’s putt is on the same line as Ben’s, Ben decides to stand on the other side of the hole to watch Al’s putt. Al makes the putt, and Ben also makes his after seeing the break in Al’s putt.

headline: Wye Jamison Allanbrook, an Expert on Mozart, Dies at 67
text: Wye Jamison Allanbrook, a musicologist who altered modern ways of thinking about the music of Mozart and his contemporaries, died on July 15 at her home in Oakland, Calif. She was 67.

headline: N.Y. Fed Fills Oversight Post

text: A congressman hopes to recoup payouts that were considered excessive from six banks that have yet to repay taxpayer bailout money, Eric Dash writes in The New York Times.

headline: A.I.G. Failure Would Have Cost Goldman
text: Since the United States government stepped in to rescue the American International Group in the fall of 2008, Goldman Sachs has maintained that it would have faced few if any losses had the insurer failed. Though it was the insurer’s biggest trading partner, Goldman contended that it had bought credit insurance from financial institutions that would have protected it, but it declined to identify the institutions, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times.

headline: Inquiry Begun of S.E.C. Timing in Goldman Case
text: The inspector general of the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether political or other factors influenced the timing of the filing and subsequent settlement of the commission’s securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs, according to letters between his office and a Republican congressman, Edward Wyatt writes in The New York Times.

headline: Dancer Acosta Makes a Return to the London Stage
text: Few dancers today possess the charisma and technical brilliance of Carlos Acosta. Trained in his native Cuba, he found respite from an impoverished background in ballet, and he soon gained world attention when he left home to join the Houston Ballet and, eventually, the Royal Ballet in London. Mr. Acosta returns to London with a run at the Coliseum, from July 28 to Aug. 7 — a performance that is a sequel to his Olivier Award-winning 2009 show, “Tocororo: A Cuban Tale.”

I’ve recently returned from the program’s second annual session where we evaluated our performance.

headline: Calling Lloyd Bridges

text: Remarkably sanguine: That’s the tone of the research notes still coming out from analysts in Europe as they peruse the data released Friday by the Committee of European Banking Supervisors.

headline: Divorce of Hedge Fund Power Couple Shakes Ikos
text: A contested divorce between the two founders of Ikos is rattling one of Europe’s oldest hedge fund groups, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Full Week for Congress Before Vacation
text: The House moves to wrap up its business before a six-week summer break for campaigning while the Senate continues slogging through its remaining business, including a campaign spending disclosure measure and small business aid.

headline: Virgin Active Said to Be in Talks With Buyout Shops
text: Virgin Active, the health and fitness chain owned by Richard Branson’s Virgin Group, has been in talks with private equity firms over a range of options, according to press reports.

headline: Apollo to Launch Its Own Bank, Report Says
text: Thwarted by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in their efforts to buy failed lenders, private equity companies have been looking at other ways to get their hands on financial firms.

headline: China Everbright May Raise $2.95 Billion in I.P.O.
text: China Everbright Bank may raise 20 billion yuan ($2.95 billion) in an initial public offering of yuan-denominated shares in China, Bloomberg News said, citing a report in Century Weekly magazine.

headline: For Hybrid Cars, a Hybrid Invention
text: A company with a different approach to the electric car battery problem got a small boost recently when the Patent Office said it would issue a patent on its concept: using a storage device called a capacitor in conjunction with a traditional battery.

headline: SKS Microfinance May Raise $344 Million in I.P.O.
text: SKS Microfinance, the Indian lender backed by Sequoia Capital and George Soros, raised its initial public offering to as much as 16.3 billion rupees ($344 million) after six quarters of gains by the key equity index, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Five Vegetables and 15-Grain Rice Pot
text: This Japanese rice pot made with mushrooms, carrots, edamame, burdock and seaweed is an austere, quietly flavored dish, with equally subtle textures. It’s the dish that Abe Hiroki, the 34 year-old executive chef at EN Japanese Brasserie, ate as a child growing up in Fukuoka City, on the island of Kyushu.

headline: Onyx Sees Promise in Myeloma Drug
text: A new last-ditch treatment for patients with multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow, might be getting closer to market.

headline: Accel-KKR Sells iTradeNetwork for $525 Million
text: Accel-KKR said on Monday that it has agreed to sell iTradeNetwork, a software technology focused on the food industry, to Roper Industries for $525 million in cash.

headline: Stocks Finish Stronger; Dow and Nasdaq Reach Highest Points Since April

headline: Morning Take-Out
Video of First Khmer Rouge Trial
text: As my colleague Seth Mydans reports from Cambodia, the first Khmer Rouge leader to face justice at a United Nations-backed tribunal, the warden of a notorious prison in Phnom Penh, was found guilty on Monday of crimes against humanity and war crimes for overseeing the torture and killing of more than 14,000 prisoners.

headline: Clues Shift Attention in S.I. Fire to Mother

headline: Move to Limit Cantonese on Chinese TV Is Assailed

headline: Europe to Investigate Antitrust Complaints Over I.B.M. Mainframes
text: BERLIN  The European Commission opened investigations Monday into whether I.B.M. had abused its dominant position in mainframe computers, signaling that the era of aggressive prosecution of American technology leaders in Europe did not end with the Microsoft antitrust case.

headline: Anger in Cambodia Over Khmer Rouge Sentence
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — For 30 years since the brutal Khmer Rouge regime was driven from power, Cambodians have lived with unresolved trauma, with skulls and bones from killing fields still lying in the open and with parents hiding the pain of their past from their children.

headline: Early Word: Wikileaked
text: Washington is astir over the publication of nearly 92,000 classified military documents detailing strategy correspondence about the war in Afghanistan among American officials from January 2004 to December 2009.

headline: A Parting on the Left is Now a Parting on the Right
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared novel definitions of Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Next Steps on Climate and Energy
text: The 20th century ended on Friday, at least in relation to the discourse over what to do about global warming. The end came with the failure of a seven-year effort in the Senate to pass a climate bill centered on a cap-and-trade system for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases. Such a system had worked effectively for easily measured, and mitigated, emissions of conventional pollutants from power plants and other industrial sources. But carbon dioxide, the most important human-generated greenhouse gas, poses an entirely different set of challenges.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, July 26
text: Highlights from Monday’s media coverage in The New York Times:

headline: On Our Radar: Climate Bill Post-Mortem
text: Some liberal activists bid good riddance to the failed Kerry-Lieberman climate bill. “We polled our members about whether we should be fighting for the bill and it wasn’t even close. The answer was no,” the political director of an influential group says.

headline: Five Moments From Comic-Con We Wished We’d Seen
text: Every summer we get tantalizingly closer to attending the San Diego Comic-Con, only to have that weekend-long celebration of fantasy, science-fiction and general geekery taken away from us, like a precious One Ring, unfairly stolen from our grubby, Gollum-like clutches. This year, we actually had hotel rooms booked, plane and train tickets purchased and a whole itinerary planned before circumstances arose that required us to remain in New York. (Let’s just say we got word that the Green Goblin and the Kingpin were back in town.)

headline: Preparing for Fantasy Season With Footballguys
text: Chase Stuart, a Fifth Down contributor, is a senior staff writer and statistical analyst at Footballguys.com.

headline: Fantasy Advice on Young Running Backs
text: Chase Stuart is a senior staff writer and statistical analyst at Footballguys.com, an encyclopedic resource for fantasy football knowledge.

headline: New Report Asks: ‘Private Equity, Public Loss?’
text: Just what’s going on with private equity? Activity in the industry is on the rise, so a fresh report on the industry is timely.

headline: Ferrari Fined After Win in Germany
text: Formula One has fined Ferrari $100,000 for team orders hours after one of its drivers slowed down in the Grand Prix of Germany on Sunday to allow his teammate to pass.

headline: Latest M.T.A. Capital Investment: Water Coolers
text: You are about to spend $99 a month to ride the subway. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is about to spend half a million a year on water coolers.

headline: London Theater Journal: ‘Legally Blonde’ Daring to be Dumb
text: The program for the London production of “Legally Blonde,” the 2007 Broadway musical based on the 2001 film, has a glossary of Americanisms for those unversed in the languages of Malibu and Ivy League New England. But British audience members don’t really need to know what the LSATs or sorority houses are, any more than a child needs to understand the medieval Arabic origins of “Aladdin” to attend a Christmas pantomime.

headline: Monday Reading: Latest on the Bush-Era Tax Cuts
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: The good news for health insurers is likely to continue this week, as Aetna and WellPoint follow UnitedHealth Group in reporting their second-quarter earnings. UnitedHealth, which announced its results last week, set the bar high for its fellow companies by reporting a 31 percent increase in profits for the three months that ended June 30. If you missed it, you can read the company’s release.

headline: Europe Imposes New Sanctions on Iran
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union intensified the economic isolation of Iran over its nuclear program by ordering its toughest economic sanctions yet against the Iranian government on Monday. European energy companies and insurers affected by the new controls promised to comply.

headline: Cunningham’s ‘Xover’ Will Open Fall for Dance Festival
text: Merce Cunningham‘s “Xover,” which includes a seven-and-a-half minute duet that was one of the longest he composed in his career, will make its New York debut as part of New York City Center’s 2010 Fall for Dance Festival, City Center said Monday. The work, whose title is pronounced “crossover” and which was first presented at Dartmouth College in 2007, will be performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company as part of the first of five festival programs, on Sept. 28 and 29, and will feature music by John Cage and scenery by Robert Rauschenberg. Other highlights of the festival, which runs through Oct. 9, include a new work by the classical Indian dancer and choreographer Madhavi Mudgal, called “Vistaar,” with music by her brother, Madhup Mudgal; the festival debuts of 10 international troupes including Company Rafaela Carrasco of Spain,  Shu-Yi & (Dancers) Company of Taiwan and Tero Saarinen Company of Finland; and the premiere of “Peace of Mind: The Remix,” a collaboration between the tap dancer and choreographer Jason Samuels Smith and the hip-hop dancer Mr. Wiggles, performed by Jason Samuels Smith & Friends.

headline: Can Foods Trigger Migraines?
text: Can allergies to certain foods trigger migraines? What about food additives like MSG? Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic responds to readers’ questions about migraines.

headline: Old Dog’s New Career: Star
text: At 6:15 Sunday morning, Chichi, a k a Uncle Chichi, a poodle from the West Village who may be the oldest dog in the world, found himself in a chauffeured limo on his way to Times Square to shoot a segment for “Good Morning America” — see video below — about his distinguished age. Sunday’s appearance followed on the heels of a similar one on the Los Angeles station KTLA.

headline: Raul and Real Madrid Move On Without Each Other

headline: Mysteries Of Deflation (Wonkish)
text: Jon Hilsenrath has a nice piece on the puzzles of gradual deflation, Japan-style. But I’m not sure whether readers will understand quite what the puzzle is — and they certainly wouldn’t gather from the article that there’s actually a literature about this puzzle.

headline: Plastiki Wraps Up an 8,300-Mile Voyage
text: The Plastiki, a boat made of bottles that set sail from San Francisco in March, glided past the Sydney Opera House at midday local time Monday in a grand finale to a voyage intended to highlight the problem of plastic waste.

headline: For Real Madrid, Two Goodbyes Feel Monumental

headline: New Generics Study Lauds Savings
text: Generic drugs saved the nation’s health care system more than $824 billion from 2000 to  2009, according to an analysis by IMS Health, a health information company that tracks drug sales.

headline: More Corner Logic (Still Wonkish)
text: I think I need to say a bit more about the logic of market corners. Along the way, I can say something about reciprocal dumping, which was what was in the back of my mind when I wrote that old Sumitomo article.

headline: Sunshine and Show Tunes
text: A selection of readers’ photos and commentary about memories of summer theater camp.

headline: Where Longtime Friends Make the Best Neighbors
text: The surprise at Caroline Bass’s recent party was not how the oppressive heat had finally lifted or how quickly guests devoured her feta and watermelon skewers and roast beef crostini.

headline: Law Firm Donates More to Rice Campaign
text: The state’s most influential personal injury law firm continues to pour money into the campaign coffers of Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney, who is generally viewed as the front-runner in the attorney general’s race.

headline: Eurostar Offers Redesigned Web Site
text: Eurostar, the high-speed rail service that connects London with the rest of Europe through the English Channel Tunnel, has started a new Web site touting its leisure-focused service. The site, called Europe by Eurostar, offers the usual timetable and ticket booking options, but adds a layer of art, food, fashion and music listings available via the rail service, mostly focusing on hidden gems instead of the usual tourist spots.

headline: Have They No Shame? No
text: One of the things anyone who irritates the hard right quickly gets used to — you see it all the time in comments on this blog — are the constant accusations that you’re lying, even when you did no such thing, simply because you didn’t present the fact or mention some other facts in a way that suits the commenter. If I say “the economy added 236,000 jobs a month under Clinton”, I’ll get “That’s a lie! Krugman doesn’t mention the dot-com bubble!” or “That’s cherry-picking! What about Jimmy Carter?” etc..

headline: Answers About Medicare: Part 3
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Lessons From Divorce
text: Is it possible to have an amicable — truly amicable — divorce? Is there something about the process — the physical and emotional ripping of entwined lives — that magnifies anger? Do you have to come to hate someone to build up the momentum to leave them?

headline: The Two-Track Lawyer Market
text: The Association for Legal Career Professionals released its annual report last week on employment and salaries for new lawyers.
