headline: Obama to Appear on ABC’s ‘The View’
text: President Obama will be joining the co-hosts of “The View” this week, in an appearance that ABC said would be “the first time in history a sitting United States president has visited a daytime talk show.” In a news release, ABC said the presidential episode would be broadcast on Thursday after being taped on Wednesday. Read more about the television appearance on ArtsBeat.

headline: With Pacino, ‘Merchant of Venice’ Will Transfer to Broadway
text: Though “The Merchant of Venice” concludes with the resolution of one of literature’s most notorious debts, Shylock isn’t finished with Antonio – or with New York – just yet.

headline: Promoting Literacy the Curious George Way
text: The Library of Congress has chosen Curious George, the children’s book character, to star in its new public service advertising campaign.

headline: Reading as a Luxury Good
text: I enjoyed Gary Shteyngart’s gently humorous essay on escaping from the tyranny of instant communication, but it also left me feeling more than a little depressed about the future of reading. Here’s the New York novelist describing how he finds time and mental room to actually read novels:

headline: Bedbugs Spread Like Weeds, and Vice Versa
text: From clothing outlets to publishing houses to (perhaps) movie theaters, bedbugs are pressing in from all directions now, and virtually everyone in the world who has had to deal directly with the little biting nuisances are “upset and concerned.”

headline: Afghans and NATO Differ on Civilian Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan officials said Monday that 52 people were killed in southern Afghanistan on Friday when a rocket fired by coalition forces slammed into a house where women and children had taken shelter from fighting between NATO troops and militants. But American officials disputed the account.

headline: From the Bean Pot to the Table
text: When you have a big, savory pot of beans at hand, there’s no shortage of dishes you can make: salads, soups, even gratins. Beans offer protein and fiber, and they’re a good source of potassium, calcium, iron and folic acid.

headline: Making End-of-Life Decisions for Pets
text: Given the relatively short life spans of dogs and cats, most animal lovers have faced end-of-life decisions for their pets. In the latest Week in Review section, John F. Burns of The New York Times shares his personal struggle as his beloved cat Scuzzi suffered with his last illness. The cat had lived a roaming and independent life, and Mr. Burns wondered if the cat shouldn’t be allowed to experience a similar ending.

headline: The End of History, With Bubbles
text: I’m not sure which is more exciting, the news that Elizabeth Gilbert’s memoir “Eat, Pray, Love” has inspired a line of perfume or the news that Francis Fukuyama’s treatise “The End of History” has inspired a beer.

headline: Evanovich Takes Her Bounty to Random House
text: The blockbuster novelist Janet Evanovich has taken her scrappy bounty-hunter heroine Stephanie Plum to Random House, leaving her longtime publisher, St. Martin’s Press, after more than two months of contract negotiations fell through.

headline: ‘Super Sad True Love Story’
text: DO NOT GO GENTLE FROM THE DIARIES OF LENNY ABRAMOV

headline: Road to New Confidence at BP Runs Through U.S.
text: LONDON  Robert Dudley, whose appointment as chief executive of BP was announced Tuesday, faces a long road to restore confidence in the embattled company  particularly in the United States, the biggest part of BP’s business.

headline: Love Found Amid Ruins of Empire
text: Gary Shteyngart’s wonderful new novel, “Super Sad True Love Story,” is a supersad, superfunny, superaffecting performance  a book that not only showcases the ebullient satiric gifts he demonstrated in his entertaining 2002 debut, “The Russian Debutante’s Handbook,” but that also uncovers his abilities to write deeply and movingly about love and loss and mortality. It’s a novel that gives us a cutting comic portrait of a futuristic America, nearly ungovernable and perched on the abyss of fiscal collapse, and at the same time it is a novel that chronicles a sweetly real love affair as it blossoms from its awkward, improbable beginnings.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Summer’s Common Scents
text: It’s official: the dog days of summer, having arrived prematurely, have overstayed their welcome. These aren’t just any dog days — these are barking, growling, slobbering, sock-chewing dog days. Relief is illusory; it’s a round of Salty Dogs. The Samurai Shopper can’t bear another whiff of overcooked concrete and wilting air.

headline: Sunshine and Show Tunes: Your Summer Theater Camp Photos
text: In his new book, “Theater Geek,” Mickey Rapkin chronicles the lives of campers during a summer at Stagedoor Manor, a performing arts sleepaway camp in the Catskills that counts Zach Braff, Natalie Portman and Robert Downey Jr. among its famous alumni.

headline: Bikes and Cars: A Lesson in Los Angeles
text: Attending the Copenhagen climate conference last December, Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles had a revelation: his own city needed to do more to promote bicycling as a clean form of transportation.

headline: China Warns U.S. to Stay Out of Islands Dispute
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government reacted angrily on Monday to an announcement by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton that Washington might step into a long-simmering territorial dispute between China and its smaller neighbors in the South China Sea.

headline: Armageddon Wars: Overpopulation Vs. Global Warming
text: A famous 1980 bet — and the future of the planet.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Watch | Open Season
text: Last week, we brought you the stories behind the stories for the new season of “Mad Men.” And Sunday night, the season began anew. Faithful viewers anticipate another illuminating, obsessive, digressive few months of conversation about every political reference, romantic tryst, briefcase style, hairdo, cultural allusion and plot point during the fourth season. Our colleague Ginia Bellafante reviews and recaps the episode on ArtsBeat »

headline: Sanctions Vote Strains Russia-Iran Relations
text: MOSCOW  Tensions between Russia and Iran appeared to grow on Monday over Russian support for sanctions approved last month by the United Nations Security Council.

headline: Icahn Sues Lions Gate Over Move to Block His Bid
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn sued Lions Gate Entertainment on Monday, accusing the movie studio of employing “scorched-earth tactics” to block his hostile takeover bid and an investment fund manager of “enriching” himself “at the expense of all shareholders.”

headline: Part I: Answers to Questions About Internet Privacy
text: Last week, we asked readers to submit questions to Michael Fertik, founder of ReputationDefender, and Paul Ohm, a law professor at the University of Colorado, in response to The New York Times Magazine article “The Web Means the End of Forgetting.”

headline: Ford Unveils 2011 Explorer in Manhattan, Priced at $28,995
text: 3:48 p.m. | Updated

headline: Pressured, Nike to Help Workers in Honduras
text: Facing pressure from universities and student groups, the apparel maker Nike announced on Monday that it would pay $1.54 million to help 1,800 workers in Honduras who lost their jobs when two subcontractors closed their factories.

headline: Leaks Add to Pressure on White House Over Strategy
text: WASHINGTON  The White House sought to reassert control over the public debate on the Afghanistan war on Monday as political reaction to the disclosure of a six-year archive of classified military documents increased pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy.

headline: Undermedia
text: Non-traditional sources of information and investigation that challenge the mainstream media.

headline: Tancredo Likely to Enter Colorado Governor’s Race
text: DENVER — For Republicans, the Colorado governor’s race just keeps getting bumpier, noisier and nastier.

headline: The Rutland Road Readers
text: In Sunday’s Metropolitan section, I did an oral history on a single block of Fort Greene, Brooklyn. But there are some 70,000 blocks in the city, each with its own traditions and characters. Last week, I discovered one in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens that has its own book club.

headline: Screening: Insurance and Colorectal Cancer
text: The number of Americans being screened for colorectal cancer continues to increase, but the vast majority of the uninsured still do not get screened for this cancer, which is the second leading cause of cancer deaths after lung cancer, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports.

headline: Regimens: Finding a Way to Save Money and Blood
text: Hospitals that capture the blood patients lose during emergency internal surgery and infuse it back into patients instead of using banked blood can cut the number of blood products used by half, and reduce costs, a study reports.

headline: Early Signs of a Hotel Rebound
text: The hotel industry in the United States appears to be rebounding this summer, mainly because of strengthening business travel.

headline: Authors Guild Weighs in on E-Books
text: Don’t forget the authors. Last week it was the big book publisher and the big literary agent who sparred over who gets to make e-books out of titles that were published before there were such things. Now the Authors Guild has weighed in — with an eye on digital royalty rates for the writers it represents. In a letter to its members on Monday, the Guild said that publishers were largely to blame for the dispute between Random House and the literary agent Andrew Wylie, which came to a head last week when Mr. Wylie announced that he would begin his own venture to sell e-book rights for older books directly to Amazon, bypassing traditional publishers that already released the books in print and have staked a claim to the e-book rights as well. Random House responded on Thursday by saying it would not do business with the Wylie Agency until the situation was resolved.

headline: Tom Valenti’s West Branch Closes
text: Tom Valenti has closed the Italian brasserie the West Branch, a restaurant at 77th Street and Broadway that he opened in 2008, citing the economy and an inflexible landlord as the reasons.

headline: Lawmakers Seeking Cuts Look at Nonprofit Salaries
text: State and federal officials are starting to take their knives to the pay of leaders of nonprofit groups they do business with to help share the pain of tighter budgets.

headline: In Ruling on iPhones, Apple Loses a Bit of Its Grip
text: Apple likes to maintain tight control over what programs can appear on the iPhone  a task that just became a little bit harder.

headline: Now Showing | “Dennis Hopper Double Standard”
text: Over a five-decade career, Dennis Hopper earned the well-deserved mantle of the rebellious auteur, actor and all-around American artist. Whether it was post-Depression-era angst, the Beat generation’s age of exploration, Vietnam War resistance or 1980s venomous debauchery, Hopper’s performances reflected the shifting psyche of America’s cultural landscape. On screen he appeared unafraid, even fiercely entrenched in the zeitgeist. Now the late actor’s art, much of which is unknown to a large public, is the focus of an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles entitled “Dennis Hopper Double Standard.”

headline: ‘Nervous Breakdown’ Musical Lines Up Its Women (and Men)
text: The cast of the musical adaptation of Pedro Almodóvar‘s “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” will include a few well-known Broadway stalwarts – and will not include at least one well-known newcomer who had been previously connected to the project. On Monday, Lincoln Center Theater said that Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott, de’Adre Aziza, Danny Burstein, Mary Beth Peil and Nikka Graff Lanzarone will be featured in the musical, which is adapted from Mr. Almodóvar’s absurdist 1988 film about the intertwining love lives of a group of men and women. Not on that roster, however, was Jessica Biel, the “7th Heaven” and “A-Team” star, who was thought to be headed for a starring role, according to reports in the spring.

headline: Nostrums: Some Nasal Gels May Harm Sense of Smell
text: A new analysis has concluded that controversial zinc nasal gel products can cause some patients to lose their sense of smell.

headline: Beating Cancer Bonds Two Ballplayers
text: Chris Malec received mail from across the country after learning he had testicular cancer, but a handwritten note from a survivor named Colin Curtis stood out.

headline: Starting Over in Lexington: Taking Ownership
text: As I said in my last post, the folks at our Lexington, Ky., plant are well on their way to becoming owners of their company.

headline: When Exercise Causes Heartburn
text: In the latest “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores the link between exercise and heartburn. Vigorous exercise can increase risk for heartburn, he writes. But the right kind of exercise can also lower risk.

headline: Harlem River, 11:06 A.M.
text: The new Willis Avenue Bridge (right) over the Harlem River was tugged towards its final position on Monday, as workers readied the new onramp to the bridge (foreground). The bridge, linking Manhattan and the South Bronx, will replace the old one (left), which is nearly 110 years old.

headline: Morning Joe With a Jolt
text: For those who find that a cup of joe just isn’t quite enough to get them going in the morning, the Randolph at Broome has started serving coffee with an extra kick, starting at 8 a.m.

headline: Study: Boards Use Peers to Inflate Executive Pay
text: Corporate boards appear to routinely use compensation peer groups to artificially inflate pay for their chief executives, helping to contribute to the cascading increases in executive compensation over the last several years, according to an academic study on corporate governance.

headline: Quote Unquote | Short Cited
text: — Calvin Klein gives Style.com some sartorial advice while in the Hamptons. If he deems shorts too casual, let’s hope Marc Jacobs didn’t attend in one of his signature skirts.

headline: A Portable Movie Theater
text: 4:39 p.m. | Updated with information about where the projector is available.

headline: G.M. to Announce Chevrolet Volt Pricing on Tuesday
text: General Motors said it planned to reveal the price and other ordering details of the Chevrolet Volt on Tuesday, during the Plug-In 2010 Conference in San Jose, Calif.

headline: The Other Law School Arms Race
text: Speaking of the career paths for new lawyers, we’ve noted before that the sour legal job market has encouraged law schools to find creative ways to make their students look more attractive to employers, at least when compared with students from other schools. Intentional grade inflation is one particularly controversial tool schools have been using.

headline: Exploding Moss
text: Explosion of a Sphagnum palustre capsule, recorded at 10,000 frames per second with a 0.097 millisecond exposure; displayed at 15 frames per second. (Clara Hard, Joan Edwards, Dwight Whitaker)

headline: Drama! Intrigue! A Mystery? No, Malaria’s Story
text: Human history marches to the beat of what? A big brass band? A choir singing hymns? The lub-dub of the human heart? Sonia Shah’s tour-de-force history of malaria will convince you that the real soundtrack to our collective fate is none of these: it is the syncopated whine-slap, whine-slap of man and mosquito duking it out over the eons.

headline: Sarah Lerfel | Esprit de Colette
text: To understand Colette — the three-floor hipster emporium in Paris where you can buy both a Lanvin frock and a lunchbox (filled with finger foods!) — you must understand its 34-year-old creative director, Sarah Lerfel. At first blush, she appears bookish, even dainty, with her long A-line skirt and her adorable pixie cut. Then again, she has unexpected tattoos designed by two of her favorite graffiti artists — one on her shoulder by the French night-life personality André (a friend) and another on her ankle by the Brooklyn-based Kaws.

headline: Buying Old New Homes
text: As the new home market collapsed, the most amazing statistic was the supply of really old “new” homes that remained on the market.  Finally, it appears that some of the ancients are finding buyers.

headline: In India, British Leader to Focus on Business Ties
text: NEW DELHI  British Prime Minister David Cameron has quickly earned a reputation as a relentless cost-cutter. So maybe it should not be surprising that his next official visit is to India, where phone calls can cost less than a penny a minute, and prices of new cars begin at under $3,000.

headline: Numberplay: I Bet You’re Wondering How Telepathy Works?
text: You’ve been thinking about someone, perhaps after a long time. Suddenly the phone rings, and guess what? It’s the person you were thinking about. Telepathy? Coincidence?

headline: Basel Group Reaches Accord on Bank Capital Rules
text: 8:55 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz provide more details of the agreement in Basel.

headline: How Much Credit Card Rewards Cost the Poor
text: In a Your Money column earlier this year, “The Damage of Card Rewards,” my colleague Ron Lieber hypothesized that the poor are actually the ones subsidizing the credit card rewards of the affluent.

headline: Goldman Allowed to Keep Issuing Securities
text: Goldman Sachs will remain qualified as an issuer of securities after settling civil fraud charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission this month, the agency ruled.

headline: What Do You Lack? Probably Vitamin D
text: Vitamin D promises to be the most talked-about and written-about supplement of the decade. While studies continue to refine optimal blood levels and recommended dietary amounts, the fact remains that a huge part of the population — from robust newborns to the frail elderly, and many others in between — are deficient in this essential nutrient.

headline: What’s for Sale on the Bug Market?
text: In an article I wrote for Monday’s newspaper, I took a look at the underground world of cybersecurity and the discussion over when security experts, or hackers, should disclose a flaw in an online system.

headline: Arabic Channel Bombed in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  On Sunday, a journalist for Al Arabiya, an Arabic-language news channel, sat in the newsroom and explained that his staff had recently returned to the bureau after being forced to leave for weeks by threats from Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

headline: Rabies: United Nations Adds a New Web Site to Its Arsenal in Fight Against Rabies
text: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has begun a global rabies Web site to encourage nations around the world to bring the disease under control.

headline: Two Guys Trying Their Best to Grow Old Disgracefully
text: The VCR first appeared more than 30 years ago, which means that pale jokes about not being able to set the device’s clock also first appeared more than 30 years ago. They weren’t funny then, and certainly aren’t funny now, yet there one sits a few minutes into “Viagara Falls,” a painful geriatric comedy now at the Little Shubert Theater.

headline: Verizon Landline Calls Interrupted in Manhattan
text: Updated, 11:56 p.m. | Verizon’s phone service failed in a swath of Manhattan on Monday, but was returned to normal later in the day.

headline: Bringing Data Mining Into the Mainstream
text: 5:50 p.m. | Updated to add link to the conference.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Lolita'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Stanley Kubrick's 1962 film adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's startling 1955 novel.

headline: We Don’t Need to Shoot Birds
text: We’ve had a lot of success the past few days. As we capture more and more birds, we attract more and more spectators. At the school, we sometimes have over 100 young girls forming a semicircle around our car between classes. They watch intently everything we do. They whisper in Swahili, and Wilson tells me they are discussing the needles and syringes we use to collect blood samples.

headline: City Investigates Deaths at Techno Festival
text: BERLIN — As the blame for a fatal stampede at an overcrowded music festival passed between the German authorities and event organizers, prosecutors said Monday that they had opened an investigation to determine whether criminal negligence was involved in the deaths.

headline: Lifesaving Medications, Through a Back Door
text: One of my big headaches at the moment is a patient  call him Ralph  who appears to be one of the most successful small-time alchemists in all of New York.

headline: Parents as Teammates
text: Speaking of equal parenting, last week’s letter from the mom who was disappointed in her husband’s parenting, while he was angry that she was the favored parent, brought a thoughtful letter from Marc and Amy Vachon. They guest-post periodically on Motherlode, and their book, “Equally Shared Parenting: Rewriting the Rules for a New Generation of Parents,” is a primer on a collaborative lifestyle.

headline: Excerpt From 'The Big C'
text: Linney stars as a dutiful, repressed, 42-year-old teacher, mother and wife in suburban Minneapolis who has advanced, incurable cancer and has decided against treatment. The half-hour comedy debuts in August.

headline: Citi Discovers Security Flaw in iPhone Application
text: After Citigroup on Monday discovered a potential security flaw in the Apple iPhone app that its customers use to access its Web site, the bank urged customers to upgrade to a newer version of the software, which it says will correct the problem.

headline: Permanently High Unemployment
text: Brad DeLong, commenting on Greg Mankiw, writes:

headline: Bulluck Hoping to Be in Middle of Giants’ Defense
text: The phone call from the Giants came just two weeks ago, but Keith Bulluck had his eye on them since early last season. He grew up in Rockland County, N.Y., attended Syracuse, and lives in Edgewater, N.J. He spent his entire 10-year N.F.L. career as a Tennessee Titans linebacker. But when the Titans did not give him a new contract early last year  and then did not make a move despite Bulluck’s playing well last season  the Giants popped up on his radar as a potential next stop.

headline: The Customer Service? It Was Excellent, Said the Luggage
text: I WAS an airline brat and grew up traveling. But I’ve never mastered being able to go on long-haul trips with only a carry-on.

headline: Unmasking Silent Killer in Epilepsy
text: On July 9, 2009, Steve Wulchin went to wake his 19-year-old son, Eric, in their home in Boulder, Colo. Eric had been given a diagnosis of epilepsy three years earlier, but other than that, his father said, “there was nothing out of the ordinary.” His seizures had been well controlled; he had not had one in six months.

headline: Hornets Indicate Paul Will Stay in New Orleans
text: The drama-laden story line of Chris Paul’s summer took another swerve Monday when, after meeting with New Orleans Hornets officials, Paul said he had no intention of leaving the team.

headline: A Band Reunites, Channeling Its Frantic Teenager Vibe
text: Before it was emo it was emocore, and before that, emotional hardcore. Somewhere in that initial compression came Cap’n Jazz, a band of relatively clean-cut Chicago teenagers making ragged music, hardcore molting its skin to let a little of the inner hurt peek through.

headline: High-Speed Video Shows How Sphagnum Moss Spreads
text: Plants may seem sedate and nonviolent, but that may be because most people do not take ultra-high-speed videos of them.

headline: New Insight Into a Caterpillar’s Crawl
text: For caterpillars, what you see on the outside as they crawl is not necessarily what is going on inside.

headline: Some Like It Warm (If They’re Marmots)
text: Warmer temperatures in the Colorado Rockies have produced a population boom of yellow-bellied marmots, at least in one well-studied valley.

headline: U.S. Publishes Diplomatic Correspondence on Lockerbie Convict’s Release
text: On Monday, the State Department took the unusual step of publishing the complete text of a diplomatic letter online, in response to a Sunday Times of London article — “Revealed: Document Exposes U.S. Double-Talk on Lockerbie” — which used excerpts from the previously undisclosed letter to suggest that the Obama administration had “secretly advised Scottish ministers that it would be ‘far preferable’ to free the Lockerbie bomber than jail him in Libya.”

headline: Sometimes, the In-Flight Movie Feels Extra Creepy
text: A stone-faced woman in a slinky red dress holds a bag at the foot of a white path. Blackout. She is now farther downstage. Blackout. She opens the bag. Blackout. A threatening man, a pilot, appears behind her. Blackout. She takes out a knife. Blackout. And just when the tension reaches its peak, “Red Over Red,” a downtown thriller about plane crashes, remains in darkness for what seems like an eternity.

headline: Two Obamas Are Going to Spain
text: President Obama will be home alone in the White House next week as the first lady, Michelle Obama, and one of their daughters,  Sasha, travel to Spain  trip with unidentified family friends, her office announced on Monday. President Obama and their daughter, Malia, who is at camp, will not be on the trip.

headline: English Club Has Rough Tour of U.S.
text: Lost in the news of Manchester United’s tour of North America, the New York Football Challenge and visits by Inter Milan, A.C. Milan, Glasgow Celtic and Real Madrid is the luckless story of Portsmouth’s North American sojourn.

headline: Coulda Woulda Shoulda
text: Sigh.

headline: Now Booking | Mallorca’s Cap Rocat
text: The island-loving jet set of Europe now has a new Mallorca hideaway. Cap Rocat, on a protected promontory on the southern flank of the Bay of Palma, is a 19th-century military fortress that has been converted into one of the region’s more remarkable hotels. Twenty minutes from Palma, the sprawling structure is almost completely buried and all but imperceptible from both land and sea. Only the canopies of the lounges on the terrace are visible on the horizon.

headline: Not Just Window Dressing
text: MUCH of the lore surrounding the South American window artist who went by the name of Victor Hugo, and was the lover of Roy Halston Frowick, centers around his rather memorable ability in the 1970s to make Halston’s sophisticated designs seem downright shocking.

headline: Readers Say Down With Cab Theft, Why Can’t We Share?
text: Much like a mother bear protecting her cub, even docile humans are roused when someone steps in the path between them and their taxi.

headline: Following a Script to Escape a Nightmare
text: ALBUQUERQUE  Her car is racing at a terrifying speed through the streets of a large city, and something gruesome, something with giant eyeballs, is chasing her, closing in fast.

headline: Toying With Freedom After Prison
text: Given that the laconic characters of “In God’s Hat” seldom waste their breath, it’s tempting to sum up the play with a single word: terrific. Still, the story begs for more description, if only to ponder why this noirish tale of loutish people feels so downright thrilling.

headline: Hero of Comic-Book World Gets Real
text: Typically, the appearance of Alan Moore’s name on a comic book has been a harbinger of heady, consequential writing inside: a promise of mighty champions empowered through mystical or superscientific methods and whose conflicts would challenge the reader’s perceptions of heroism and humanity.

headline: Is Religion Special?
text: A number of responses to my column on Christian Legal Society v. Martinez — a Supreme Court decision upholding Hastings Law School’s right to withhold official recognition from a Christian group that restricted its membership to co-believers who not only talked the talk but walked the walk — complain that there is too much parsing of minutiae and counting of angels dancing on the head of a pin and not enough consideration of the big substantive issues at stake, issues like discrimination against gays and the separation of church and state.

headline: Alan Moore Digs Up ‘Unearthing’ and Lays His Comics Career to Rest
text: 6:03 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Miramax Deadline Could Re-Open Door for Weinsteins
text: An investment group that includes the construction executive Ronald N. Tutor must make a nonrefundable $40 million payment toward the purchase of Miramax Films from the Walt Disney Company by Wednesday, or see the bidding again thrown open to other suitors, possibly including the Miramax co-founders Bob and Harvey Weinstein, according to people who were briefed on the prospective sale.

headline: Should Nightmares Have Happy Endings?
text: Therapy may help people who suffer from chronic nightmares learn how to turn bad dreams into good ones. But now some experts wonder if changing your nightmares from scary to safe is always a good idea, reports Sarah Kershaw in Science Times.

headline: Gas Station Attendant Among 4 Killed in Separate Attacks
text: The police are asking for the public’s help to identify two men (see video below) who walked into a Flushing gas station early Sunday and fatally shot the attendant.

headline: Citi Finds Security Flaw in iPhone Application
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: Advance on AIDS Raises Questions as Well as Joy
text: VIENNA  The best AIDS-prevention news in years was released here last week at a world conference on the disease: a vaginal gel, called a microbicide, that can be used without a man knowing it, gave women a 39 percent chance of avoiding infection with the deadly virus.

headline: A Bride’s Best Friends for Never
text: Imbibe gently, if at all, before attending “Bachelorette,” the sensational new comedy by Leslye Headland set during a toxic party on the eve of a swanky Manhattan wedding. Bottles of bubbly are consumed with breathtaking dispatch by pretty young things in party dresses in this scarifying tale of mean-girl malice and generational malaise. Even confirmed teetotalers may emerge from the McGinn/Cazale Theater, where the play opened on Monday night, feeling the urge to slither into a cab and check into rehab.

headline: Answers About Migraine
text: Several new posts on the Consults blog offer useful advice for migraine sufferers.

headline: Randolph Sees Opportunity in Knicks’ System
text: Entering his third N.B.A. season, Anthony Randolph and the word potential are nearly synonymous. With the Golden State Warriors, Randolph showed glimpses of a bright today and a sparkling tomorrow, but injuries and spats with Warriors Coach Don Nelson stagnated his basketball growth.

headline: Cap’n Jazz Reunites at the Brooklyn Bowl
text: The reconstituted Chicago band played Sunday night, along with the Death Set, No Age and Lightning Bolt.

headline: Big Dog, Small House
text: Q. Now that I am in my own apartment, I want very much to have a big dog but am told the apartment is not large enough. What can I do?

headline: Translating Stories of Life Forms Etched in Stone
text: In 1909, Charles Walcott, a paleontologist and secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, discovered one of the greatest and most famous fossil troves high in the Canadian Rockies on Burgess Pass in British Columbia. The slabs of Burgess Shale that Walcott excavated contained the earliest known examples at the time of many major animal groups in the fossil record, in rocks that were about 505 million years old.

headline: Fossils From Just Before the Cambrian
text: We now have fossil records from the time immediately preceding the Cambrian, which reveal a world whose oceans were teeming with a variety of life forms.

headline: Miramax Deadline Could Reopen Door for Weinsteins
text: From Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes at Media Decoder:

headline: Oliver Stone Controversy
text: Oliver Stone found himself the catalyst of an online brush fire on Monday after he made comments published in The Sunday Times of London that were interpreted as anti-Semitic. In an interview with The Times to promote his documentary “South of the Border,” which is about South American politics, Mr. Stone defended Hitler. “Hitler was a Frankenstein, but there was also a Dr. Frankenstein,” he said. “German industrialists, the Americans and the British. He had a lot of support. Hitler did far more damage to the Russians than the Jewish people.” Mr. Stone then proceeded to discuss what he called “the Jewish domination of the media,” adding with an expletive that Israel had messed up “United States foreign policy for years.” Bloggers quickly picked up on the comments, and the American Jewish Committee issued a news release condemning him. “By invoking this grotesque, toxic stereotype, Oliver Stone has outed himself as an anti-Semite,” the committee’s executive director, David Harris, said in the release. Mr. Stone, whose next Hollywood movie, “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” will be released by 20th Century Fox on Sept. 24, has stirred controversy with his comments in this arena before. In January the director told a gathering of television critics that “Hitler is an easy scapegoat” while discussing his Showtime nonfiction mini-series, “Secret History of America.” At that time the Simon Wiesenthal Center harshly rebuked him for the remarks. A spokesman for Mr. Stone was not immediately available to comment.

headline: Janet Evanovich Moves On
text: The novelist Janet Evanovich, below, has taken her scrappy bounty-hunter heroine Stephanie Plum to Random House, leaving her longtime publisher, St. Martin’s Press, after more than two months of negotiations fell through. “We’ve had a good relationship, and I truly am sorry that we’re unable to come to terms,” said Matthew Shear, publisher at St. Martin’s Press. “But it’s a negotiation like anything else and it didn’t work. And I hope it works well for her elsewhere.” Mr. Shear declined to comment on a report on Deadline.com that Ms. Evanovich had sought $50 million as an advance for her next four novels. Random House said on Monday that Ms. Evanovich had jumped to its Ballantine Bantam Dell imprint; it acquired the world rights to four new novels, including two Stephanie Plum tales and two in Ms. Evanovich’s “Unmentionable” series. Random House declined to disclose the financial terms of the contract. Ms. Evanovich has been with St. Martin’s Press since the publication of “Four to Score,” the fourth novel in her Stephanie Plum series, in 1998. Her last 11 novels have made their debut at No. 1 on The New York Times’s best-seller list, and her 33 novels have combined sales of more than 75 million copies worldwide, according to Random House.

headline: Cunningham’s ‘Xover’ Will Open Fall For Dance Festival
text: Merce Cunningham’s “Xover,” which includes a seven-and-a-half-minute duet that was one of the longest he composed in his career, will make its New York debut as part of City Center’s 2010 Fall for Dance Festival, City Center said on Monday. The work, whose title is pronounced “crossover” and which was first presented at Dartmouth College in 2007 (with Daniel Madoff and Julie Cunningham, above) will be performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company as part of the first of five festival programs, on Sept. 28 and 29, and will feature music by John Cage and scenery by Robert Rauschenberg. Other highlights of the festival, which runs through Oct. 9, include a new work by the classical Indian dancer and choreographer Madhavi Mudgal, called “Vistaar,” with music by her brother, Madhup Mudgal; the festival debuts of 10 international troupes, including Company Rafaela Carrasco of Spain, Shu-Yi & (Dancers) Company of Taiwan and Tero Saarinen Company of Finland; and the premiere of “Peace of Mind: The Remix,” a collaboration between the tap dancer and choreographer Jason Samuels Smith and the hip-hop dancer Mr. Wiggles, performed by Jason Samuels Smith & Friends.

headline: Obama to Appear on ‘The View’
text: President Obama will be joining the hosts of “The View” this week, in an appearance that ABC said would be “the first time in history a sitting United States president has visited a daytime talk show.” In a news release on Monday, ABC said that the presidential episode would be broadcast on Thursday. It will be taped on Wednesday. Mr. Obama’s chat with the unpredictable co-hosts, including the staunch liberal Joy Behar and the equally staunch conservative Elisabeth Hasselbeck, is emblematic of his administration’s outreach to unconventional media outlets. “Given the difficulty of reaching people in this hyperactive media environment, we look for opportunities to reach people in environments that are not traditional forums for political newsmakers,” Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, said in an e-mail message. “That’s why we have been willing to have the president on Leno, Letterman and ESPN.” Mr. Pfeiffer said an appearance on “The View” had been contemplated for several weeks because the president was scheduled to be in New York City for a fund-raiser.

headline: ‘Nervous Breakdown’ Cast Lined Up
text: The cast of the musical adaptation of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” from Pedro Almodóvar, below, will include a few well-known Broadway stalwarts. On Monday Lincoln Center Theater said that Patti LuPone, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Sherie Rene Scott, de’Adre Aziza, Danny Burstein, Mary Beth Peil and Nikka Graff Lanzarone would be featured in the musical, which is adapted from Mr. Almodóvar’s absurdist 1988 film about the intertwining love lives of a group of men and women. Not on that roster, however, was Jessica Biel, the “7th Heaven” and “A-Team” star, who was thought to be headed for a starring role, according to reports in the spring. A representative for the theater company said on Monday that Ms. Biel would not be in the cast, and that additional casting would be announced in the weeks ahead. The musical, which features a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek, is being directed by Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific”); it will begin previews at the Belasco Theater on Oct. 2.

headline: Authors Guild Weighs In On E-Books
text: Last week it was the big book publisher and the big literary agent who sparred over who gets to make e-books out of titles that were published before there were such things. Now the Authors Guild has weighed in. In a letter to its members on Monday, the Guild said that publishers were largely to blame for the dispute between Random House and the literary agent Andrew Wylie, which came to a head last week when Mr. Wylie announced that he would begin his own venture to sell e-book rights for older books directly to Amazon, bypassing traditional publishers that have already released the books in print and have staked a claim to the e-book rights as well. Random House responded on Thursday by saying it would not do business with the Wylie Agency until the situation was resolved. The Guild estimated that the authors represented by Mr. Wylie in the e-books deal with Amazon would make three times the amount in royalties than traditional publishers were offering. The Guild, which has more than 8,000 members, saved some criticism for Mr. Wylie, however. “That the Wylie/Odyssey agreement is reportedly exclusive raises many questions and concerns,” the Guild said. “Amazon has, time and again, wielded its clout in the industry ruthlessly, with little apparent regard for its relationships with authors or publishers or, for that matter, antitrust rules.”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Lolita’
text: “How did they ever make a movie of “Lolita?” asks the trailer for Stanley Kubrick’s 1962 adaptation of the Vladimir Nabokov novel. This week, A. O. Scott looks back at the film about the relationship between a middle-aged professor and a 15-year-old girl. Mr. Scott is compelled by the tone Mr. Kubrick brings to the controversial subject matter. “Kubrick’s world always feels just a little bit off,” he says. “But our disorientation is the strongest evidence of the filmmaker’s mastery.” Have you seen “Lolita?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Radiation Questions Over a Body Scanner
text: IN about two years, if all goes according to the plans of the Transportation Security Administration, those vintage airport magnetometer metal detectors will be replaced by electronic body scanner machines at all 2,200 security checkpoints in all 450 commercial airports in the United States.

headline: Obama Assails Republicans on Campaign Finance
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday sought political advantage from the expected defeat of a campaign finance measure that he has championed by pre-emptively attacking its Republican opponents for “nothing less than a vote to allow corporate and special-interest takeovers of our elections.”

headline: Hints of Earth Splash a Saturnian Moon Landscape
text: The lakes of southern Titan are shrinking.

headline: ResCap Auction Advances, but Hurdles Remain
text: An auction of Ally Financial‘s Residential Capital unit has advanced into the second round, with some would-be buyers circling the assets, but a sale of the mortgage lender still faces hurdles, Reuters reports, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: A Little Help Making Lemonade
text: “Breakthrough” is a summer reality show on NBC starring Tony Robbins, the self-help author and motivational speaker. That alone is something of a breakthrough  after more than 30 years in the high-end advice business, Mr. Robbins at last has his own network show.

headline: Behind ‘War Logs,’ a New Kind of Alliance
text: It is perhaps fitting that the war in Afghanistan, a conflict rife with asymmetrical information — who is the enemy, who are the allies — has helped produce a new kind of asymmetrical journalism.

headline: A Pied Piper of Rap, Followed on Twitter
text: “I don’t show my face,” Lil B proclaimed on Saturday night. “Nobody ’bout to see me.”

headline: A Child Bride, Craving More Than a Glimpse of an American Life
text: SANTA FE, N.M.  The premiere production of an important American opera, Lewis Spratlan’s “Life Is a Dream,” 32 years after it was written, has rightly been claiming most of the attention at the Santa Fe Opera here this summer. But there are four other enticing productions. Offenbach’s “Contes d’Hoffmann,” directed by Christopher Alden, and Mozart’s “Zauberflöte” opened this month; Britten’s “Albert Herring” is coming soon.

headline: Expanding the Boundaries of a West African Instrument
text: There were no Western instruments onstage when the Malian griot Bassekou Kouyate and his band, Ngoni Ba, performed at SummerStage in Central Park on Sunday afternoon. Ngoni Ba is a string band  four sizes of ngoni, a four-stringed African lute that’s an ancestor of the banjo  with Mr. Kouyate’s wife, Amy Sacko, as lead singer, along with two percussionists playing calabashes and tama, a West African pressure drum. The band wore African clothes, and the songs were in Bambara, Mali’s main language. One, a meditative 17th-century praise song that Ms. Sacko sang in expanding arabesques, delved into 2,000-year-old Malian history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
text: A deadly stampede at a German music festival over the weekend has raised accusations of negligence aimed at event organizers, politicians and the police, who have defended their actions in one of the deadliest public events in recent years. Judy Dempsey reports that the stampede, at the Love Parade festival in the western city of Duisburg, left 19 dead and 340 injured on Saturday as participants crowded into an underpass that was on the way to the entrance. Victims were crushed against the walls of the tunnel and trampled underfoot, investigators said, and many of those who died were suffocated.

headline: Genzyme Said to Rebuff Sanofi’s Takeover Approach
text: Genzyme, the world’s largest maker of drugs for rare genetic diseases, rebuffed Sanofi-Aventis‘s takeover approach last week, Bloomberg News reports, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: A Newfangled Sandbox Arrives (Check Out the Canals)
text: Manhattan playgrounds are serious stuff.

headline: Oliver Stone Controversy
text: Oliver Stone found himself the catalyst of an online brush fire on Monday after he made comments published in The Sunday Times of London that were interpreted as anti-Semitic. In an interview with The Times to promote his documentary “South of the Border,” which is about South American politics, Mr. Stone defended Hitler. “Hitler was a Frankenstein, but there was also a Dr. Frankenstein,” he said. “German industrialists, the Americans and the British. He had a lot of support. Hitler did far more damage to the Russians than the Jewish people.”

headline: Japanese Tale With Western Flourishes
text: In some ways, Nintendo’s handheld DS game machine represents the last vestige of video games’ old identity as playthings for children.

headline: Learning From Disasters (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Medicare Rules May Curb Use of Anemia Drugs for Dialysis
text: Yet more restrictions in the use of anemia drugs are on the way.

headline: On-Time Trains in New York
text: Local transit agencies proclaimed 2009 to be a banner year for the on-time performance of commuter trains, reporting that their trains failed to arrive within 5:59 of the schedule only 1 out of every 20 trips. But the overall performance can mask wide differences on different routes and at different times of day. On some trains during rush hour, trains are late as much as 1 out of every 5 trips.

headline: Guiding Your Sleep While You’re Awake
text: Nightmares resulting from traumatic events usually fade over time, as the haunting images and terrifying plots become less intense. The dreams may also naturally evolve into what some specialists call “mastery dreams,” in which the dreamer has found a way to ease the pain or horror — say, confronting a rapist or saving someone from a fire.

headline: Blagojevich Corruption Trial Wraps Up
text: CHICAGO  In arguments that will end the corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, a federal prosecutor on Monday spoke directly to an issue that legal analysts had long suggested as a possible flaw in the government’s case: It does not matter, the prosecutor told jurors, that Mr. Blagojevich never really seemed to complete most of the get-rich schemes he dreamed up.

headline: Panel Seen Approving F-35 Engine, Risking Veto
text: Despite increasing calls from lawmakers for deficit reduction, one military program opposed by the White House and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates  an alternate engine for the joint strike fighter  so far refuses to die.

headline: Never a Lab Rat
text: At an estimated 13 pounds — bigger than most house cats — it was bigger than any other rat ever known. Bone fragments were excavated in caves in East Timor, located near the eastern end of the Indonesian archipelago, and scientists have now pieced together enough of them to describe the giant rat, which may have lived as recently as 1,000 years ago. People have lived in East Timor for 40,000 years, hunting and eating the rats. The scientists speculate that recent large-scale clearing of the rainforests for agriculture may have driven the rodents to extinction. The findings appear in the Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Five Omens for China’s Future
text: For China, July could be called “the month of five symbols.” The demographic, financial and monetary milestones give insight into the future of the world’s third-biggest economy. With them in mind, investors might want to think five times about how they proceed.

headline: Teams of Physicists Closing in on the ‘God Particle’
text: A thousand physicists working at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., reported in Paris on Monday that they had not found the “God particle,” yet. But they are beginning to figure out where it is not.

headline: Disney Seeks $40 Million in Advance on Miramax
text: LOS ANGELES  An investment group that includes the construction executive Ronald N. Tutor must make a nonrefundable $40 million payment toward the purchase of Miramax Films from the Walt Disney Company by Wednesday to move forward with a deal, according to people briefed on the sale.

headline: Bringing Garden Sounds Indoors
text: The Summergarden concerts at the Museum of Modern Art once stretched through the summer, filling the museum’s Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden with contemporary classical music on weekend evenings. Often the programs, assembled by Joel Sachs and performed by members of the New Juilliard Ensemble (which Mr. Sachs directs), were arranged thematically, sometimes with a single composer as the focus. But Mr. Sachs does not have that luxury in these parlous times: Summergarden has been reduced to four Sundays, two devoted to concerts by the Juilliard players, and two by ensembles from Jazz at Lincoln Center.

headline: Deal Over Claims to Rescued Torahs’ Provenances
text: A nonprofit group from Maryland that restores Torahs has promised it will describe the provenances of its rescued Torahs only “if there is documentation or an independent verifiable witness to such history,” according to an agreement with Maryland officials.

headline: A Teacher’s Legacy, Celebrated at the Piano
text: The International Keyboard Institute & Festival at Mannes College the New School for Music devoted Saturday to commemorating the centenary of Leonard Shure, a pianist who made sterling recordings well into his 70s, and who died in 1995, at 84. Some of Saturday’s activities looked at Shure’s work directly, through a videotape of a master class, for example, or an examination of his recordings.

headline: Let There Be Dimmers on Our Glowing Planet
text: America roared into the electric age and didn’t stop to consider what it had wrought until just short of the 100th anniversary of Thomas Edison’s incandescent light bulb.

headline: Distracted Spouses (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Tobacco’s Lure (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pac-10 Is Making Plans to Raise Profile and Income
text: When college sports fans think of the Pacific-10 Conference, John Wooden at U.C.L.A., O. J. Simpson at Southern California, John Elway at Stanford and Steve Prefontaine at Oregon are just a few of the legends who come to mind.

headline: Retailers Pay More to Get Cargo (No Guarantee)
text: The grills shaped like kegs and toolboxes, ordered for a Father’s Day promotion at Cost Plus World Market, arrived too late for the holiday. At the Container Store, platinum-color hangers, advertised in a summer sale catalog, were delivered days after the sale began. At True Value Hardware, the latecomers were fans and portable chairs.

headline: In Cuba, Revolution Day Without Castro at Podium
text: SANTA CLARA, Cuba — Raúl Castro is known among Cubans as a pragmatist, not an orator. But the Cuban president surprised even those accustomed to his reticence on Monday, when he chose not to address an expectant crowd gathered to celebrate Revolution Day in this university town.

headline: In the Heat of a Summer Night, Fanning Donizetti’s Flames of Operatic Ardor
text: KATONAH, N.Y.  Like a dressmaker altering an outfit to suit local styles, Donizetti refitted his opera “Maria di Rohan” to reflect differing tastes and expectations in various European cities. First fashioned for Vienna, the libretto and roles were retailored for Paris and Naples. The work received a rare outing at Caramoor on Saturday evening, in the Viennese version, with a few items included from later editions, as part of the excellent Bel Canto at Caramoor series.

headline: An Insurgent Campaign for a Shaving Gel
text: IN a video on the Web site for Edge shave gel, EdgeShaveZone.com, the comedian John Caparulo explains what irritates him about pickup basketball games.

headline: Suite Dreams
text: St. Paul

headline: Getting Lost in the Fog of War
text: Washington

headline: At Military Contractor’s Trial, a $100,000 Buckle
text: Several years ago, David H. Brooks, the chief executive and chairman of a body-armor company enriched by United States military contracts, became fixated on the idea of a memory-erasing pill.

headline: Botanical Gardens Look for New Lures
text: For the last quarter century, the Cleveland Botanical Garden went all out for its biennial Flower Show, the largest outdoor garden show in North America. With themed gardens harking back to the Roman empire, or an 18th-century English estate, the event would draw 25,000 to 30,000 visitors.

headline: Long-Term Economic Pain
text: The pain coursing through American families is all too real and no one seems to know what to do about it. A rigorous new analysis for the Rockefeller Foundation shows that Americans are more economically insecure now than they have been in a quarter of a century, and the trend lines suggest that things will only get worse.

headline: Must One C-Section Beget Another?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Honduras Faces Criticism Over Journalist Killings After a Coup
text: MEXICO CITY  The Honduran government’s failure to investigate the killings of seven journalists this year has fostered “a climate of lawlessness that is allowing criminals to kill journalists with impunity,” the Committee to Protect Journalists concluded in a report released Tuesday.

headline: Leaked Documents Offer Candid Look at Afghan War
text: To the Editor:

headline: Central Bankers Reach Initial Accord on Global Standards
text: Even as investors applauded the mostly positive results of recent stress tests of European banks, central bankers and regulators reached a preliminary agreement Monday on new standards to reinforce the stability of the global financial system.

headline: In Islamic Center Fight, Lessons in Prepositions and Fear-Mongering
text: Rick A. Lazio, a former Republican congressman trying to become New York’s next governor, wants the state’s attorney general to investigate the finances of a planned Islamic community center on Park Place, two blocks from the World Trade Center site.

headline: Yemen: Fighting Intensifies Between Rebels and Government
text: Fighting in northern Yemen intensified on Monday, with dozens of people killed in battles between Houthi rebels and tribesmen loyal to the government, according to witnesses and government officials. The rebels captured two strategic military posts and injured a prominent tribal chief who is a member of Yemen’s Parliament, prompting other lawmakers to call for a more forceful government counterattack against the rebels. The government reached a formal truce in February with the Houthis  named for the family of the rebel leader  but fighting in recent weeks has led many to fear a renewal of the war, which has raged intermittently since 2004.

headline: 95% of Trains Are on Time? Riders Beg to Differ
text: By official accounts, 2009 was a banner year for the commuter railroads that serve New York City. Of all the trains that ran last year, the railroads said, nearly 96 percent were on time — one of the best performances since they began keeping records.

headline: $700,000 Awarded to Official Passed Over for Promotion
text: The United Nations Dispute Tribunal has awarded more than $700,000 to a former senior official in the Department of Economic and Social Affairs for breach of contract, a decision the world organization will appeal, said Martin Nesirky, the spokesman for the secretary general. The official, Guido Bertucci, 61, an Italian, resorted to the tribunal after he was not promoted to assistant secretary general in 2008 despite United Nations guidelines that give preference to internal candidates, his lawyer, François Loriot, said. The lawyer for the United Nations, Susan Maddox, refused the tribunal’s demand that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon reveal how the promotion decision was reached. Judge Michael F. Adams awarded Mr. Bertucci $655,000, covering lost wages and pension, including $10,000 because of the United Nations’ refusal to provide the information, and legal fees.

headline: The Long Strategy
text: I was a liberal Democrat when I was young. I used to wear a green Army jacket with political buttons on it  for Hubert Humphrey, Birch Bayh, John F. Kennedy and Franklin Roosevelt. I even wore that jacket in my high school yearbook photo.

headline: With New Stars, Reality Shows See Costs Rise
text: Snooki had kissed The Situation, Ronnie had hugged Sammi goodbye and the cameras had stopped rolling. Last summer, “Jersey Shore” wasn’t yet a runaway hit; it was just another reality show in the works for MTV. Nonetheless, the show’s executive producer, SallyAnn Salsano, sat the young cast members down and gave them each a gift  and a warning.

headline: Iraqi Militants Stealing Blood for the Injured
text: MOSUL, Iraq  Members of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia have been holding up blood banks and hospitals at gunpoint, stealing blood for their wounded fighters rather than risk having them arrested at medical facilities, according to Iraqi doctors, employees at health centers and the Sunni insurgents themselves.

headline: Pines, Beetles and Bears
text: White bark pine forests are in trouble all across Wyoming, Idaho and Montana. Great swaths of trees are dead or dying after being attacked by the mountain pine beetle and a disease called white pine blister rust. The forests used to be protected by harsh winters and cool summers. But warmer winters and summers have allowed the beetle to breed more quickly and to move to the higher elevations favored by white bark pines.

headline: New York State of Mind
text: I have lived in New York for 32 years, but it was only in 2000, when I moved downtown, that I finally felt settled in the city.

headline: Harlem Helps Raise Coffee in Ethiopia
text: From a 542-square-foot office above a bustling intersection in Harlem, the Rev. Nicholas S. Richards is building what he hopes will be a 7,000-mile bridge to the eastern highlands of Ethiopia.

headline: Daily Paper for Children Defies the Craze for Digital
text: PARIS  When Elisa Cammarota gets home from school, she tosses off her knapsack and reads her newspaper from front to back.

headline: Cuts in Home Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Autopsies Suggest Mother, Not Son, Was Killer in Staten Island Case
text: The city medical examiner’s office uncovered traces of smoke in the lungs of a mother found dead with her four children in a burnt home on Staten Island last week, suggesting that she was alive when the house was set ablaze.

headline: N.F.L. Asserts Greater Risks of Head Injury
text: The National Football League is producing a poster that bluntly alerts its players to the long-term effects of concussions, using words like “depression” and “early onset of dementia” that those close to the issue described as both staggering and overdue.

headline: Beyond the Reach of Our Understanding
text: A family dead in Staten Island, four children and a young mother, their home up in flames. At first, the news that came in on the morning radio shows seemed tragic but comprehensible: These were deaths that could have been prevented, investigators reminded the public, with a simple, cheap fire detector.

headline: The Numbers Behind a July That’s Headed for the Books
text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the last lap of the sweatiest race. At the front of the pack, to the surprise of no one who has recently stepped foot on a subway platform or wrung out a dripping undershirt, is July 2010.

headline: Pakistan’s Double Game
text: There is a lot to be disturbed by in the battlefield reports from Afghanistan released Sunday by WikiLeaks. The close-up details of war are always unsettling, even more so with this war, which was so badly neglected and bungled by President George W. Bush.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mayweather and Pacquiao Can’t Seem to Agree
text: Surreal negotiations between representatives for Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather Jr. included a flap over drug testing, an election in the Philippines, a gag order, a 3 a.m. conference call and a firm denial that the second round of discussions even took place.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,190 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: New Health Official Faces Hostility in Senate
text: WASHINGTON  Unlike many other health policy experts, Dr. Donald M. Berwick, the new chief of Medicare and Medicaid, has extensive real world experience.

headline: Some Backup for Goldman on A.I.G.
text: For almost two years, Goldman Sachs has been spinning what many believed was a far-fetched tale.

headline: Jailed Investment Adviser Asks for a Bail of $2 Million
text: The money manager Kenneth I. Starr, facing a criminal trial on charges he defrauded his celebrity and socialite clients of at least $59 million, asked to be released from jail on bail of $2 million.

headline: Agency Agrees to Pay City Over $120 Million by 2014
text: Bowing to pressure from auditors, the organization that oversees economic development in New York City has agreed to hand over more than $20 million in rental payments each year to the city.

headline: Let the Spending Begin
text: The starter’s gun went off last week in the squalid new race for unlimited campaign cash. The Federal Election Commission approved the creation of two “independent” campaign committees, one each from the left and right, expressly designed to take advantage of the new world of no rules.

headline: Nobel Peace Prize City
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — When Times crosswords are reprinted in book form, they’re often given titles, something only the Sunday puzzles are granted the first time around.

headline: Lessons of the Census
text: The 2010 census, in its final stages, has apparently been a success  something not thought possible just a couple years ago, when unsteady management, political interference and other problems threatened to derail the effort. The count was salvaged only after last-minute scrambling and major new spending  and after new leaders were put in place by the Obama administration.

headline: Bloggingheads: Politics As Total War
text: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Conor Friedersdorf of The American Scene debate the power of political provocateurs.

headline: Service Unions Agree to End a Long Dispute
text: The Service Employees International Union and Unite Here, the nation’s main union for hotel and restaurant workers, announced on Monday night that they had settled a bitter 18-month dispute in which each occasionally undermined the other’s union organizing drives.

headline: Two Calls to Bullpen, but None for Chamberlain
text: CLEVELAND  The first time Manager Joe Girardi needed a reliever to preserve a one-run lead in the eighth inning this season, he called on Dave Robertson. Ever since that night in Boston, the second game of the year, the eighth inning has been the domain of Joba Chamberlain. It does not appear to be that way anymore, with Chamberlain never warming up as Robertson, and then Boone Logan, combined to record three pivotal outs Monday night in the Yankees’ 3-2 comeback victory over the Cleveland Indians.

headline: Lake’s Views and Revenue Yield to Muck and Fears in Iowa
text: DELHI, Iowa  What was a sparkling lake last week is now a muddy graveyard. The skeletons are mangled white boatlifts wedged in rocky sandbars.

headline: Rule Change Could Put Steinbrenner Up for Hall This Year
text: In the aftermath of his death July 13, George Steinbrenner was widely endorsed for a place in the Hall of Fame. Because of a change in the election procedures announced Monday, his chance could come as soon as December.

headline: Corrections
text: A subheading on Saturday with an obituary about the actor Larry Keith erroneously credited him with a distinction. As the obituary noted, he was the first American actor to play the part of Henry Higgins in the Broadway musical “My Fair Lady”; he was not “Broadway’s first Henry Higgins.”

headline: Leak May Hurt Efforts to Build War Support
text: WASHINGTON  The disclosure of a six-year archive of classified military documents increased pressure on President Obama to defend his military strategy as Congress prepares to deliberate financing of the Afghanistan war.

headline: Photo Replay: July 26
text: A look at the day in sports, from swimmers in sync to football players in the heat.

headline: As Deadline Nears, Chips Are Starting to Fall
text: When Justin Upton signed a six-year, $51.25 million contract extension with the Arizona Diamondbacks in March, he tied himself to a team that had just finished last in the National League West. But Upton could see a path to contention.

headline: Day 97: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: BP Could Start Final Process to Seal Well Next Week

headline: Bronx Storm Was a Tornado
text: The ferocious windstorm that splintered trees and uprooted signs in the Bronx on Sunday afternoon turns out to have been a tornado. On Monday, the National Weather Service declared it an EF-1 tornado, with winds of 100 miles an hour.

headline: Talk of Job Security as Mets Stay in a Slump
text: The last time the Mets were in the midst of a 2-9 crisis was in the middle of May, when Jeff Wilpon flew to Atlanta to meet with his baseball staff. At the time, Wilpon, the team’s chief operating officer, chose a course of patience that temporarily worked as the Mets won 21 of their next 29 games.

headline: Able to Sing, Able to Fight for Their Rights
text: A group of aging folk singers slowly enters a church basement in Manhattan where they are to give a concert. Observing them maneuver to their places behind the microphones — some are blind, others are in wheelchairs, some are accompanied by family members, others by home health aides — it is clear that this concert is going to be a little out of the ordinary.

headline: Ask.com Reverts to Its Q.& A. Origins
text: Jeeves may be gone, but according to Ask.com, he’s anything but forgotten.

headline: Mets’ Struggling Offense Has Put Burden on Pitchers
text: As the Mets continue their slide into mediocrity, they lead the league in at least one category: walk-off losses.

headline: Surprising Winners at Two Strong Opens
text: Underdogs won the Najdorf Memorial Festival and the Andorra Open, which both ended Sunday.

headline: Gatlin to Run in Estonia
text: The former 100-meter Olympic champion Justin Gatlin has secured a two-meet deal in Estonia early next month to mark his comeback from a four-year drug ban that ended last Saturday. Gatlin will run the 100 meters at the Bigbank Estonian GP Final on Aug. 3 in Rakvere and the ERGO Games Tallinn 2010 on Aug. 8 in Tallinn. Directors of top meets in Europe are excluding past drug offenders from their meets. “I’m grateful that there are people who believe in me and my character and want me to entertain their country,” Gatlin said in a phone interview.

headline: Judith Peabody, Socialite and Volunteer,  Dies at 80
text: Judith D. Peabody, a doyenne of New York society known equally for her philanthropy and volunteer work, especially on behalf of people with AIDS and their families, died on Sunday in her Fifth Avenue apartment in Manhattan. She was 80.

headline: Girardi’s Reasons Aren’t Clear, but His Message Is
text: CLEVELAND — The binder that Joe Girardi consults during games is loaded with charts, scouting reports and trends, data that help him make decisions but that none of us will ever see. Therefore, there is no way of knowing exactly which statistics Girardi was looking at Monday when he called on Dave Robertson instead of Joba Chamberlain to face Asdrubal Cabrera with a runner on first, no outs in the eighth and the Yankees leading, 3-2. He said afterward that he liked the matchup — Cabrera was 0 for 5 against Chamberlain and had never faced Robertson — and hinted that Robertson seemed more likely to exploit Cabrera’s weaknesses, whatever they were.

headline: Nathan Quinones Dies at 79; Led New York City Schools
text: Nathan Quinones, who as the chancellor of the New York City school system in the mid-1980s pushed to reduce dropout rates and institute tougher achievement standards but who resigned six months before the end of his term in the face of public pressure, died Sunday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 79.

headline: Anthony Rolfe Johnson, Farmer Turned Opera Star, Dies at 69
text: Anthony Rolfe Johnson, an Englishman who began his professional life as a farmer and ended it as a distinguished lyric tenor who had performed to glowing notices in the world’s most storied opera houses and concert halls, died on July 21 in London. He was 69.

headline: News Quiz | July 27, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Deutsche Bank Posts $1.5 Billion Profit
text: Deutsche Bank said that profit in the second quarter was 1.16 billion euros, or $1.5 billion, a 9 percent increase compared to the same period last year, but a decline of 34 percent from the first quarter of 2010, as Germany’s largest bank earned less from its investment banking business.

headline: UBS Posts $1.9 Billion Profit in Second Quarter
text: UBS of Switzerland on Tuesday reported a profit of 2 billion Swiss francs in the second quarter, as investment banking income rose, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Shrinking BP: $30 Billion in Asset Sales Planned
text: BP said on Tuesday that it plans to sell $30 billion in assets over the next 18 months, as it announced a record $17 billion loss for its second quarter tied to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports.

headline: Tomkins Board Backs $4.37 Billion Bid
text: The board of Tomkins, the British engineering and manufacturing company, said it is backing a £2.87 billion($4.44 billion) takeover bid from private equity firm Onex and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Why Is Race Hard to Talk About?
text: Last week a black Agriculture Department official was fired after a doctored video was circulated that appeared to show her admitting to a racist act. Before the truth came out (and she was rehired), the video caused quite a stir. Why do you think race is such an incendiary topic?

headline: San Miguel Plans $1.6 Billion Issue
text: San Miguel Corporation, the largest food and beverage maker of the Philippines, said Tuesday that its board had approved a stock issue of about 75 billion pesos, or $1.6 billion, to finance “investments and acquisitions.”

headline: BofA’s Krawcheck Adds to Executive Team
text: Bank of America on Monday appointed a former colleague of Sallie Krawcheck as its Merrill Lynch global wealth management unit’s new chief investment officer, Reuters reported.

headline: Examiner Finds Some ‘Dishonesty’ in Tribune Sale
text: The court-appointed examiner investigating the Tribune Company‘s bankruptcy said he has found some evidence of dishonesty in the 2007 leveraged buyout of the company, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

headline: Brokerage Firms Said to Suffer Muni Fund Fallout
text: Proof that low risk actually does mean low risk sometimes: Wall Street’s brokerage firms are having to pay out large sums in compensation to people who lost millions in the crisis on what should have been secure investments in the municipal bonds market, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Debating the Securitization of Mortgages
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Tradition and History in a Hong Kong District
text: Visitors to Hong Kong looking for a glimpse of tradition and history need not  stray far from the Central district. A walking tour through Sheung Wan, the neighborhood immediately west of Central, offers traditional wholesale stores and some striking and important sites.

headline: Green Bay Packers 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Legg Mason Says Costs Push Quarterly Profit Down
text: Legg Mason said Monday that its quarterly earnings had decreased more than expected as expenses rose and investors pulled money out of many of its funds, Reuters reported.

headline: Vivendi Argues for Dismissal of Jury Verdict
text: A potential multibillion-dollar judgment against Vivendi for misleading shareholders hung in the balance as a Manhattan judge weighed whether a recent United States Supreme Court ruling limited damages.

headline: WaMu Examiner is Former D.O.J. Official

headline: Buyout Shops in Talks to Buy Harrington, Report Says

headline: Barton Biggs Not Ready to Bet on BP
text: Barton Biggs, the hedge fund manager who became more optimistic about stocks this month, said that BP is still “too speculative” to buy, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Guy Hands Looks East

headline: CIT Posts $142.1 Million Quarterly Profit
text: The CIT Group, the big lender to small mid-sized companies, said on Tuesday that it earned $142.1 million for its second quarter, as it continues rebuilding itself after its restructuring last year.

headline: Fujifilm Adds a Compact 15X Zoom Camera
text: Fujifilm has reprised last year’s well-reviewed FinePix F200EXR camera with a tempting new model that has a versatile 15X zoom shoe-horned into a compact chassis.

headline: How I Managed to Take a Vacation
text: I just returned to the shop from a week of vacation with my wife and kids. This is the first time I’ve been away for an entire workweek since 2003. Did I want to go? Yes and no.

headline: MakeMyTrip Eyes $100 Million Road to Nasdaq

headline: Relativity Media to Take a Public Bow?
text: Ryan Kavanaugh, one of Hollywood’s most prominent film financiers, is mulling a possible initial public offering of his firm Relativity Media, after signing a deal to acquire the 45-person marketing and distribution staff of Liberty Media’s Starz Overture film studio, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Lion Capital to Buy Picard From BC Partners
text: Lion Capital, the British private equity firm, said it had entered into exclusive talks to buy Picard, the French frozen-food chain, from BC Partners.

headline: At Meadow Brook Auction, Chryslers Bring Bidders, High and Low
text: Bids were taken on 100 cars on Saturday at RM Auctions’ Vintage Cars of Meadow Brook sale in Rochester, Mich. With a roster of offerings that included three Duesenbergs, three Cords, numerous Packards and a variety of other expensive classics, a Chrysler brought the highest price.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Ah Goldman, where would we be without you? Not a day goes by that you’re not hustling to make news. The bank’s full settlement with the S.E.C. is here, for those who missed it. But today we turn to payments from years past, like the ones the government made to A.I.G., so that it could make them to the Goldmanites, who kind of didn’t need them anyway as it turns out.

headline: A Sigh of Relief Over Dodd-Frank Act
text: It seems that venture capitalists are feeling pretty lucky when it comes to the Dodd-Frank Act, the financial reform bill signed into law last week.

headline: Strong Earnings at UBS and Deutsche Bank Bolster Shares
text: Shares of UBS of Switzerland and Deutsche Bank of Germany rose sharply after the companies reported second-quarter earnings on Tuesday, signaling renewed confidence in European banks after official stress tests showed that most large institutions were solid.

headline: U.S. Markets Mixed as Consumer Confidence Falls
text: Wall Street struggled Tuesday on reports that consumers had become more pessimistic about the job market and the overall economic recovery.

headline: Barclay Brothers Sell 10% InterContinental Stake
text: The billionaire Barclay brothers sold their 10 percent stake in Britain’s InterContinental Hotels for about 335 million pounds ($520 million) after the hotelier’s shares rose 88 percent in a year, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Daiwa Posts Consecutive Quarterly Loss
text: Daiwa Securities Group, Japan’s second-largest brokerage, reported a second straight quarterly loss as underwriting fees and trading profit slumped, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Ma! He’s Looking At Me Funny!
text: That’s basically the thrust of Mort Zuckerman’s op-ed accusing Obama of “demonizing” business.

headline: Greenpeace in Its Salad Days
text: With offices in 40 countries and some three million supporters, Greenpeace is unquestionably one of the world’s most influential environmental groups.

headline: Change Comes to ‘The Daily Show’ (and to Jon Stewart’s Chin)
text: Sweetie, sit down. We need to have a talk. You know that there comes a time in a boy’s life – and this is all perfectly natural – when he starts turning into a man. His arms and legs grow longer and his voice deepens (though probably not as much as he hoped they would); he starts to look at his classmates differently; he would really benefit from deodorant, though he doesn’t yet realize this himself; and the lyrics of the Smiths and Mötley Crüe seem so deep and meaningful to him that he will spend hours copying them out on the front of his binder.

headline: The Warren Mystery
text: I have to say, I don’t get the administration waffling on Elizabeth Warren at all.

headline: One Way to Judge a Nursing Home
text: While looking at nursing homes for my mother, I always asked the tour guides if I could talk to the nurses’ aides. This seemed to me a logical request. After all, these were the women — and they were all women — who would spend the most time with my mother, who would notice small changes that raised big questions, who would make her feel cared for. Or not.

headline: How Punctual Is Your Train?

headline: BP Envisions Leaner Future Under Its New Chief
text: LONDON  Three months after its giant oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a chastened BP outlined a new strategy on Tuesday to revamp operations and practices around the world and turn it into a leaner operator under a new leader.

headline: China Pushes to End Public Shaming
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government has called for an end to the public shaming of criminal suspects, a time-honored cudgel of Chinese law enforcement but one that has increasingly rattled the public.

headline: Stimulus Counterfactual
text: Robert Hall makes a telling point in Jon Hilsenrath’s article today examining the effect of the stimulus program:

headline: Daniel Craig to Star in Film Versions of Stieg Larsson Novels
text: Remember a few months back when MGM announced that it was putting its James Bond movie franchise on indefinite hold, and some silly blog came up with advice for its star while he waited for the situation to resolve itself? Turns out he didn’t need our help.
