text: So what’s the upshot of the release of 92,000 classified documents on the war in Afghanistan?

headline: Nocturnalist | Weaving Détente on the High Line
text: We came expecting a picnic; we left knowing how to card wool and spin yarn.

headline: MedCottage and Granny Pod
text: The name (and nickname) of a high-tech portable dwelling designed to house elderly or disabled relatives.

headline: Running Back Turnover and How It Affects Your Fantasy Draft
text: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he pens The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver, and tight end.

headline: BP Plans to Be ‘More Focused’ After Asset Sales
text: 10:52 a.m. | Updated Executives of BP explained on a conference call on Tuesday that its operations would be “more focused” once the company sells $25 billion to $30 billion worth of assets over the next 18 months in order to meet liabilities from the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico and restore its cash position.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Salary Edition
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: No Overtime for Steve Carell as NBC Acknowledges He’s Leaving ‘The Office’
text: Short of the day NBC gathers its employees in the Dunder Mifflin break room to give Steve Carell his farewell cake and gold watch, the network has made its clearest public acknowledgment to date that Mr. Carell will be leaving “The Office” after its coming seventh season, and that it intends to keep the series going without him.

headline: On Our Radar: Record Heat in Moscow
text: Record heat bakes Moscow as peat and forest fires blanket the city in haze.

headline: BP Shares Fall as Asset Sale Plan Grows
text: Shares of BP dropped in New York and London on Tuesday after the oil company said it planned to sell off $30 billion in assets, more than it had previously announced.

headline: Meet Google’s Space Commander
text: Google, as you may know, runs a search engine and sells ads. How odd then that Tiffany Montague works at the company.

headline: Europe Unleashes Online Gambling to Fill Coffers
text: PARIS — Across Europe, cash-strapped governments looking for ways to reduce yawning budget gaps are embracing online gambling, a source of revenue they once viewed with wary skepticism.

headline: Tennessee Official Says Islam May Be a ‘Cult’
text: Updated | 11:51 a.m. Tennessee’s lieutenant governor, Ron Ramsey, has been asked to explain recent comments captured on video in which he suggested that Muslim Americans might not have a constitutionally protected right to worship in the United States.

headline: Clashing Pacific and Atlantic Patterns Shaped Super Snows
text: The press office of Columbia University’s Earth Institute* is particularly good at its job — and it’s a job that’s ever more vital as traditional news media coverage of science shrinks. The release below, on work clarifying what did — and didn’t — contribute to the extraordinary snows of last winter is a prime example of a solid, contextualized account.

headline: Security Researchers Catalog Mobile Vulnerabilities
text: A group of researchers and security experts from the mobile security company Lookout announced on Tuesday that they were creating a catalog of applications for mobile phones, calling their effort  the App Genome Project.

headline: With Asian Industry Astir, More Job-Seekers Go East
text: HONG KONG — Shahrzad Moaven quit a public relations job in London and moved to this teeming metropolis four months ago to take up what she saw as a more exciting post: communications director at the exclusive jeweler Carnet.

headline: New York Send-Off | Circumnavigation
text: Jan Benzel is an editor at The Times who is being reassigned to Paris. Before she leaves, she is trying to do all the things in the city that every New Yorker should do, at least once.

headline: Doodled Dandies
text: If the proliferation of men’s-wear blogs and dapper new clothing lines are any indication, the boys are beginning to preen again. But the real peacock of fashion has always been the dandy. Though Beau Brummell would get his cravat in a knot at the idea being the poster boy for male frippery — he actually advocated a restrained, gentlemanly glamour — he has become the poster boy for flamboyant dressing and a life devoted to aesthetics.

headline: Audi Unveils Sleek New A7 Sportback in Munich
text: As he introduced Audi’s new A7 Sportback on Monday evening at the Pinakothek der Moderne art museum in Munich, Rupert Stadler, Audi’s chairman, quoted Oscar Wilde.

headline: Republicans Make Hay of Rangel Contributions
text: 2:21 p.m. | Updated Washington Republicans – who have had a field day in general with the ethics accusations against Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York – are looking to use his troubles to their advantage on the campaign trail as well.

headline: Painting Isn’t a Caravaggio, but Still Gets a Public Unveiling
text: This has been a busy week for the little-seen painting known as “The Martyrdom of St. Lawrence,” whose restored canvas was unveiled on Tuesday hours after the official newspaper of the Vatican said it was not a lost work by Caravaggio, The Associated Press reported.

headline: What We’re Reading: Technology Obsession
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times were reading:

headline: The Chevy Volt’s Sticker: $41,000
text: General Motors began taking orders for the long-awaited Chevrolet Volt on Tuesday, pricing the plug-in hybrid car at $41,000.

headline: Concrete Jungle: Animals vs. People Edition
text: With New York leading the way in the eradication of Canada geese, it was only a matter of time before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would be asked for his take. And it is this: What’s bad for the goose is good for the people.

headline: Using Pretax Money to Cover Concierge Practice Fees
text: To make up for more limited Medicare and insurance reimbursements, a growing number of doctors nationwide are changing their business models and moving toward so-called concierge practices.

headline: Imax Takes Its Goggles To Russia
text: Imax, the large-format movie exhibitor, has been on a tear thanks to Hollywood’s newfound fascination with 3-D. On Tuesday came word of another expansion for the chain, this time in Russia.

headline: Goldman Starts Derivatives Clearing Service
text: Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that it was starting a service to facilitate central clearing for clients in all listed and privately traded derivatives asset classes, Reuters reports.

headline: Test Yourself | July 27, 2010
text: This week, in conjunction with Math for America, we’re providing math problems based on Times articles. Today’s question was written by Gary Rubenstein at MfA, based on a Times movie review by A. O. Scott.

headline: The Volt, G.M.’s Plug-In Car, Gets a $41,000 Price Tag
text: DETROIT  General Motors on Tuesday put the base price of its Chevrolet Volt, a plug-in car capable of driving about 40 miles on battery power without using gasoline, at $41,000 before a $7,500 federal tax credit.

headline: ‘Our Town’ to Close
text: Nothing lasts forever in Grover’s Corners — and nor does any production of “Our Town,” Thornton Wilder’s play about life and loss in that fictitious New Hampshire community. On Tuesday the producers of the critically acclaimed Off Broadway production of “Our Town” — the longest running in the play’s 72-year history — announced that the show would hold its final performance on Sept. 12, more than a year and a half after its run began at the Barrow Street Theater.

headline: G.M. Prices Chevrolet Volt at $41,000
text: From our colleagues at Green:

headline: Sake Rewards the Adventurous Drinker
text: WALKING along East Ninth Street, one senses rather than sees Sakaya’s storefront, its presence indicated by a discreet sign and, in the window, a sugidama, a sphere of bundled cedar branches that was traditionally hung from the roof of sake breweries. Inside the understated shop, devoted to the discovery and exploration of good sake, pale cedar paneling provides a soothing aroma that sharpens the curiosity.

headline: Helping a Flower Garden Survive Summer
text: Tips for protecting your flowers and plants.

headline: Genzyme’s Defenses, and Other Thoughts
text: 1:50 p.m. | Updated The M.&A. market remains relatively quiet, so once again I’ll focus on a number of stories instead of just one.

headline: Theater for Audiences of One
text: You move from room to room in a mansion, experiencing acts of kindness  like being gently led in a ballroom dance or receiving a hand massage. Or, blindfolded, you set out on a journey in five segments with different themes: you can remove the blindfold at any point, but that’s where the journey ends. Or perhaps you wander through an Old World hotel as employees tell their stories and ask you questions in turn.

headline: Judge Counsels 9/11 Workers to Settle
text: The federal district court judge overseeing litigation by 9/11 workers who sued the city over health problems related to exposure to environmental risks exchanged his courtroom for a school auditorium Monday night so he could directly answer their questions about a settlement.

headline: Answers to Midsummer Flower Woes
text: I COULD blame the weather for my garden troubles: the late frost, the drenching spring, the summer heat and drought. Or I could blame the men who trampled the young plants as they installed a fence around the garden’s borders. And I could hold the woodchuck, moles and insects accountable for the gnawed roots, broken stems and wasted foliage.

headline: TimesCast | July 27, 2010
text: Today, the appointment of an American to be BP's new chief, a look the complicated relationship between WikiLeaks and major news outlets and the building of a chateau using 13th-century techniques.

headline: House Approves Measure to Pay for Combat Operations
text: WASHINGTON – The House on Tuesday approved and sent to President Obama an overdue measure to pay for combat operations in Afghanistan and Iraq, but Democrats splintered badly on the troop money in the aftermath of disclosures of classified information showing the war has not been going as well as portrayed.

headline: White House Officially Supports Campaign Finance Bill
text: With the Senate debating legislation on Tuesday that would require corporations, unions and other special interests to disclose the donors that bankroll their political advertisements, the Obama administration issued a statement formally endorsing the measure, which is expected to be defeated.

headline: Democrats Split on War Spending Bill
text: Representative David R. Obey, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, intends to vote against the war spending bill before the House on Tuesday, signaling a deepening split in the Democratic Party over the war in Afghanistan in the wake of the disclosure of classified documents showing that the conflict has not been going as well as portrayed. Read more on the At War blog.

headline: Inside Out | A Bookish Mix
text: There is a definite art to filling bookshelves. I don’t think there is any right or wrong way; the only thing that doesn’t work for me is when they are empty. While scouring design books, I find that I am always drawn to rooms where an entire wall is devoted to books. Books, quite obviously, give depth to a room, since they are one of the sure signs that someone with a pulse actually lives there, and the colors of the spines give a wall that random pattern that modern interiors so often lack.

headline: Susan Kamil Moves Up At Random House
text: Susan Kamil, the Random House editor responsible for “The Imperfectionists” and “The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society,” has been promoted to publisher of the Random House and Dial Press imprints, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Deborah Needleman Takes Over WSJ Magazine
text: Deborah Needleman, former editor of the much-lauded, much-mourned Domino, has been given an expanded role at The Wall Street Journal as the organization looks to remake its weekend lifestyle and leisure publications.

headline: Notes on Climate Change
text: In response to my column yesterday, David Leonhardt offers two good reasons to think that climate change isn’t going to be a replay of the great overpopulation and resource-scarcity debates of the 1960s and 1970s, in which optimists like Julian Simon were ultimately vindicated and doomsayers like Paul “The Population Bomb” Ehrlich were proven wrong:

headline: Rays Turn the Tables With Garza’s No-Hitter
text: Matt Garza’s no-hitter in a 5-0 victory over Detroit on Monday night was Tampa Bay’s first and the fifth one in the major leagues this season. It was welcomed by the Rays, who have been no-hit three times in the past calendar year and did not secure a hit off starter Max Scherzer on Monday until Matt Joyce’s grand slam in the sixth inning.

text: Links from around the Web.

headline: British Leader Calls Gaza ‘a Prison Camp’
text: During a speech in Turkey on Tuesday, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain called Gaza “a prison camp.” Speaking in Ankara, the capital, Mr. Cameron said:

headline: Can Migraines Damage the Brain?
text: Can migraines lead to memory loss or damage the brain? Can they lead to depression or strokes? Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic responds to readers of the Consults blog.

text: A talented and daring actress on the rise — at 46.

headline: The Calm After the Storm Day
text: I used to know when I was dreaming. Hard to tell nowadays.

headline: Greek Salad With Giant Beans and Arugula
text: This substantial summer salad provides plenty of protein, in addition to nutrient-rich tomatoes, peppers and arugula. I love using peppery wild arugula, but regular will do.

headline: Apple Brings (Magic) Multitouch to the Computer
text: Apple has been pitching the iPad as “magical and revolutionary” for several months now, and on Tuesday, the company introduced more magic to its product line. No, not a magic iWand; instead Apple announced the Magic Trackpad.

headline: Variations on Baba Ghanouj
text: Having made baba ghanouj dozens of times, I am still not sure of two things: one, how to spell it (there are several acceptable variations); and two, what makes it authentic, genuine, definitive.

headline: Once Merry, Now Cool, in Frankfurt
text: The once-working- class neighborhood of Bornheim now abounds with boutiques, historic bars and new restaurants.

headline: Singing for Their Rights
text: “I’m not done yet,” the Disabled in Action Singers insisted during a recent performance in a Manhattan church basement. Everything in their renditions of ’60s-style protest songs made clear it was so. Decades after they blocked city buses and protested at Metropolitan Transportation Authority meetings — and 20 years after the passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act — the singers are still actively pressing for rights and understanding for those who face daily limitations because of personal disabilities and public obstacles. James Estrin captures their recent performance, as well as their colorful history, on the Lens blog. Read and see more at Lens.

headline: Best in Show | Men’s Market Week (Part Deux)
text: Rounding out men’s market week was Capsule, a trade show favorite, which was bursting with rising indie talent and hard-to-find Japanese designers. Although every booth had something different to offer and its own interpretations of trends for spring/summer 2011, we came across a few key looks that dominated the show. Above, a slideshow of our favorites.

headline: London Theater Journal: Finding My Way in the Dark
text: On Saturday, I wandered through dark corridors, looking for glimmers of light. That’s both literally and metaphorically. I spent the afternoon at the Almeida Theater in Islington in the company of a young woman losing herself to madness, begging those around her to see what she sees. In the evening, I donned a white Venetian mask to roam through a labyrinth of crepuscular passages in an office building in the docklands of East London.

headline: Raging Mel? There’s an App for That
text: If you’ve heard the invective-filled rants attributed to Mel Gibson, you may have wondered how the subject of those rages — Mr. Gibson’s ex –captured those tirades for posterity (or court) with such clarity. Some celebrity-sleuthing Web sites say it was done using an iPhone app.

headline: ‘97 Orchard’
text: CHAPTER ONE: THE GLOCKNER FAMILY

headline: In a Tenement’s Meager Kitchens, a Historian Looks for Insight
text: When Richard Dreyfuss, in “Jaws,” wanted to trace the eating habits of a tiger shark, he cut open its stomach and let the contents  a few fish and a Louisiana license plate among them  spill out onto a dock.

headline: Another Oil Leak Hits Gulf of Mexico
text: NEW ORLEANS  A wellhead in southeastern Louisiana was spewing a mist of oil and gas up to 100 feet into the air after being hit by a tug boat early Tuesday morning, officials said. It is at least the third unrelated oil leak in the area since the Deepwater Horizon spill began 99 days earlier.

headline: Q&A: Chicago With Two Granddaughters
text: Q.

headline: A Packard Pickup Among a Pack of Priceless Classics
text: ROCHESTER, Mich. –- They are gorgeous. They are for sale. They represent millions of dollars worth of rolling sculpture. They were the vehicles up for bidding Saturday at the annual Vintage Motor Cars of Meadow Brook event held by RM Auctions in conjunction with the Concours d’Élégance of America, which took place here Sunday on the campus of Oakland University.

headline: Toronto Film Festival Offers Look at Lineup
text: Robert Redford, Woody Allen, Ben Affleck and Emilio Estevez are among the actors who have directed films that will appear at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. The festival’s officials on Tuesday announced a partial slate of 51 films,  including 25 world premieres. The lineup includes “The Conspirator,” directed by Mr. Redford, about the aftermath of the Lincoln assassination; “You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger,” directed by Mr. Allen, about Londoners in troubled relationships; “The Town,” directed by Mr. Affleck, about a heist crew; and “The Way,” directed by Mr. Estevez, about a doctor learning lessons as he goes abroad to collect the remains of a dead son. The festival begins on Sept. 9 and ends on Sept. 19. View the current list of announced films here.

headline: Body of Missing U.S. Sailor Is Found in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The body of a missing American sailor who was captured in Logar Province was found Sunday, according to a statement released Tuesday from a NATO spokesman.

headline: U.S. Military Chief Presses Iraqis to End Deadlock, Citing Risks to Security Gains
text: BAGHDAD  As the top American military officer arrived here to press Iraq’s leaders for a resolution to their political impasse, the country’s new Parliament canceled an already postponed session on Tuesday and announced that it would not even try to meet again until further notice.

headline: Choc Finger
text: Nickname bestowed on a British fund manager who bought a vast quantity of cocoa beans.

headline: No Breastfeeding Allowed
text: My ninth grade English teacher had a very strict definition of irony, but I suspect this would qualify.

headline: Appeals Court Rejects Effort to Create Hybrid Taxi Fleet
text: The Bloomberg administration’s years-long attempt to force the city’s cab owners to switch from gas guzzlers to hybrid vehicles was rejected by a federal appeals court Tuesday morning.

headline: Iranian Exiles Struggle to Stay Involved
text: A political tract hammered out by an Iranian feminist this spring presents a snapshot of activism from exile.

headline: Tobacco Funds Shrink as Obesity Fight Intensifies
text: When the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation decided in 1991 to take on Joe Camel, it became the nation’s largest private funding source for fighting smoking. The foundation spent $700 million to help knock the cartoon character out of advertisements, finance research and advocacy for higher cigarette taxes and smoke-free air laws and, ultimately, to aid in reducing the nation’s smoking rate almost by half.

headline: Top Consumer Complaints in 2009
text: The fastest-growing consumer complaint in 2009 was about bogus offers to help save homes from foreclosure, according to a new survey of state and local consumer agencies released Tuesday.

headline: David Bouley Sells 10th Street Coop
text: The chef and restaurateur David Bouley has sold his apartment on East 10th Street. The two-bedroom co-op was listed with Mary Traub at Olshan Realty, and had been on and off the market since 2007, when it was originally listed for $2.4 million. According to public records, it sold this month for $1.4 million.

headline: Ex-Regulators Get Set to Lobby on New Financial Rules
text: WASHINGTON  As the battle over toughened financial restrictions moves to a new front, the regulatory agencies that will create hundreds of new rules for the nation’s banks will face a lobbying blitz from companies intent on softening the blow. And many of the lobbyists the regulators hear from will be their former colleagues.

headline: S.E.C. Expands Process for Public Comments on New Financial Rules
text: WASHINGTON  Faced with drafting scores of regulations and conducting multiple studies over the next year, the Securities and Exchange Commission is expanding its public comment process to solicit input from investors and Wall Street before the formal rules are drafted, the chairwoman of the agency said Tuesday.

headline: Are the Rich Just Lucky?
text: There but for the grace of God go they.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Sweet Cheeks Baby Food
text: In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

headline: Tornadoes in the City: They Hit, but Rarely
text: The Bronx isn’t Kansas, but yes, Dorothy, that was a tornado that sent trees flying and utility poles crashing on Sunday afternoon. The National Weather Service says the twister churned through a half-mile slice of Riverdale with winds of 100 miles an hour for 10 minutes.

headline: Polygamist Convictions Overturned
text: The Utah Supreme Court on Tuesday morning threw out the rape convictions of the polygamous sect leader Warren S. Jeffs and sent the case back for a new trial, ruling that the instructions given to the jury during his prosecution were faulty.

headline: Apple Brings (Magic) Multitouch to the Computer
text: Over at the Gadgetwise blog, I wrote a post about Apple’s latest “magical” device: the Magic Trackpad, which is a mouse replacement that also offers full multitouch capabilities.

headline: Wind Drives Growing Use of Batteries
text: The rapid growth of wind farms, whose output is hard to schedule reliably or even predict, has the nation’s electricity providers scrambling to develop energy storage to ensure stability and improve profits.

headline: Baked Limas With Tomatoes and Peppers
text: These beautiful baked beans have a very sweet taste, though they contain only the natural sugars in the red pepper, tomatoes and beans themselves. Serve them on their own or with grains, as a main dish or a side.

headline: Big Names Missing From Booker Prize List
text: Celebrity authors were conspicuously absent from the list of 13 finalists for this year’s Man Booker Prize for fiction announced on Tuesday. The winner, who will receive a prize of about $77,000, will be named on Oct. 12. Andrew Motion, the chairman of the judges, said in a statement: “Here are 13 exceptional novels — books we have chosen for their intrinsic quality, without reference to the past work of their authors. Wide-ranging in their geography and their concern, they tell powerful stories which make the familiar strange and cover an enormous range of history and feeling.” The Booker is Britain’s best-known literary award, and brings with it prestige and, of course, an increase in book sales.

headline: Giant Lima Bean Ragout (or Soup)
text: The vegetables that flavor this dish are cooked separately, then simmered for another 30 minutes with the beans. For added flavor, add a Parmesan rind when you cook the beans, or add it during the final simmer as instructed below. In summer, the dish is enjoyable just slightly warmed.

headline: Baked Large Limas With Spinach and Feta
text: This Greek-inspired dish makes a hearty one-dish meal, and it’s a great way to include nutrient-dense spinach in your diet. If you use baby spinach, the preparation will go quickly as the beans simmer.

headline: A Return at ‘Idol’ Could Mean More Changes
text: Signaling that changes might be coming to “American Idol,” one of its original executive producers, Nigel Lythgoe, is expected to return to that position next season, four people with knowledge of the hiring negotiations said this week.

headline: Part II: Answers to Questions About Internet Privacy
text: Michael Fertik, founder of ReputationDefender, and Paul Ohm, a law professor at the University of Colorado, agreed to respond to questions from readers in connection with The New York Times Magazine article “The Web Means the End of Forgetting.”

text: Jason and Justin Sablich, The Times’s in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Brothers Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

headline: Where Voters Stand on Campaign Finance
text: The White House’s opposition to unlimited spending by corporations and unions in elections is a popular stance. But, the president’s efforts notwithstanding, it seems doubtful that campaign finance reform will be much of a priority to voters in November.

headline: Disney Purchases Playdom, a Social Game Start-Up

headline: In the N.B.A., the New Boss Isn’t the Same as the Old Boss
text: A growing number of executives running N.B.A. franchises incorporate knowledge about what happens on the basketball court and in the courtroom, while others bring advanced college degrees to their work. Together, they have created what the Portland Trail Blazers’ owner, Paul Allen, termed “the new generation of N.B.A. executives.”

headline: A Screaming Child on a Plane
text: Sometimes it feels as if my job is to chronicle stories of children misbehaving (or not) on airplanes. A flight attendant telling a mother to give her child Benadryl. Or asking a toddler to leave the plane. An airline losing children who are flying solo. A mother entertaining a cranky baby cross country. Or changing a diaper on a seat because there are no changing tables in the restroom.

headline: C.D.R. and Goldman to Buy HGI Holdings

text: If you ever had any question about how seriously Andrew Romanoff was taking his Senate bid, the Denver Post has one answer.  The newspaper reported this week that the Colorado Democrat sold his own house to help fill his campaign war chest.

headline: Most Ironbound Day Laborers Report Being Cheated
text: Nearly all day laborers who gather for work in the Ironbound neighborhood of Newark have had employers who have either paid them less than promised or not paid them at all, according to a Seton Hall University report on wage theft and workplace conditions among day laborers.

headline: Look Building Is Named a Landmark
text: It was in the Look Building, the cakelike office tower in Midtown Manhattan, that a very young Bob Dylan recorded “The Times They Are a-Changin’.”

headline: Crossing the Chalbi Desert, With No Blanket, and No Shocks
text: Before we departed Kalacha, we made the rounds to revisit all of our sites. We went back to the primary school to sign the guest book, the women’s clinic to give them some money for their cement, the hospital to give a tip to the doctor who let us charge our cellphones, and the mission to give a tip for letting us use their satellite Internet to post these pieces.

headline: Ugly Duckling Grows New Feathers and Learns to Strut Them
text: During the early to mid years of the last decade, makeover shows seemed to provide the perfect complement to our pipe-dream economic models. While people were living in mock Tudors they couldn’t afford, reality series like “Extreme Makeover” and “The Swan” told us that any woman could look like Angelina Jolie. Rhinoplasty, collagen, eyelid lifts, dermabrasion and a radical recalibration of muscle-to-fat ratios best achieved by a strategy of liposuction and 23-hour-a-day personal training were all it took. The anachronistic charms of “Plain Jane” come at us from a whole new world.

headline: Hyundai Releases Equus Details
text: Hyundai on Monday released details of its coming Equus flagship sedan, including that the premium model will, like the Ford Flex, have a rear-seat refrigerator.

headline: Leaked Documents May Be Opportunity for Intelligence Community
text: When I opened my news feed Monday morning and saw the reports of the tens of thousands of leaked military documents, my reaction was likely similar to those that played out the world over — shock, curiosity, contempt for the source. As I read more, I was relieved to see that the leaks did not seem to include anything too sensitive or too earth-shattering.

headline: Hungary Sued in Holocaust Art Claim
text: For more than two decades the heirs of a world-renowned Jewish collector have been petitioning the Hungarian government to return more than $100 million worth of art, most of which has been hanging in Hungarian museums, where it was left for safekeeping during World War II or placed after being stolen by the Nazis and later returned to Hungary.

headline: The Joyce Ponders New Sites
text: The Joyce Theater, the pre-eminent presenter of dance in downtown Manhattan, is facing an uncertain future. With the expiration of its lease in Chelsea approaching and a promised move to ground zero still remote, the group has been forced to consider alternative sites where it might have to move after 35 years on Eighth Avenue.

headline: A Kinder, Gentler Development
text: In a 22,000-acre development in South Carolina, just a third of the land will be developed and thousands of acres will be part of a managed forest preserve.

headline: A Vision Challenges the Planned Community Stereotype in South Carolina
text: BLUFFTON, S.C.  This month Palmetto Bluff, a high-end resort community near Hilton Head, S.C., will break ground on an organic garden. In this age of eating local food and sustainable growing, the concept is hardly novel.

headline: Bloggingheads: Dangerous Leaks?
text: Julian Sanchez, left, of the Cato Institute, and Stewart A. Baker, author of "Skating on Stilts," debate the WikiLeaks Afghanistan files.

headline: 18 States and District of Columbia Are Finalists for Education Grants
text: Eighteen states and the District of Columbia were named as finalists on Tuesday in the second round of a national competition for $3.4 billion in federal financing to support an overhaul of education policies.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Combat Outpost Nolen and Elsewhere
text: Today’s lead image, by Rodrigo Abd of The Associated Press (his second in less than a week), shows American soldiers under attack at Combat Oupost Nolen in the Arghandab Valley of Afghanistan. In Washington, President Obama, in his first public statement on leaked military documents concerning the Afghanistan war, sought to blunt any suggestion that they should force a rethinking of the nation’s commitment to the war effort. (Slide 4.)

headline: Surviving an Epic Night of Being Everything and Nothing
text: LONDON  How elastic can a single ego be? Mine was stretched in all directions during the approximately 40 minutes I spent being pushed through the halls and, it seemed, the walls of an office building in East London this month. I was exalted and excoriated, hailed as a genius, reviled as a charlatan and mistaken for both a rock star and a bag of garbage.

headline: Dispatch | On the Normandy Coast
text: Just two hours northwest of Paris and an hour or so south of the better-known — and far more crowded — Norman towns of Deauville and Trouville, Etretat feels like a secret weekend escape. Accessed from Paris by an almost absurdly bucolic train ride to Breauté Le Havre (followed by a short bus ride into Etretat; directions are here), the seaside town has just 1,000 inhabitants, many of them erstwhile Parisians who retire there for its spectacular vistas, lovely gardens, mild weather and such local delicacies as goat cheese, Calvados, apple jam and salted caramel.

headline: Student Injury at Protest Leads to Battle in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — A macabre legal wrangle is under way over who should pay the hospital bill for an American art student who lost an eye after being struck by a tear-gas canister fired by an Israeli border police officer at a Palestinian-led protest in the West Bank.

headline: The Questioner Matters, Not Just the Question
text: Asking people what they think about policy is tricky. Frame the question just so, and you can get just about any answer you want. Different framing can help explain why Americans often seem to simultaneously hold contradictory views, such as on the relative priorities of job growth versus deficit reduction.

headline: Avoiding a Large Phone Bill When Traveling
text: UBIQUITOUS connectivity has its downside, especially when it comes to the price of using your cellphone abroad. The proliferation of smartphones and the increased use of data have made it easier than ever to rack up huge communications bills while traveling overseas, even on a short trip.

headline: Campaign Finance Bill Is Set Aside
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday refused to take up a bill that would require more disclosure of the role of corporations, unions and other special interests in bankrolling political advertisements, after Democrats failed to persuade even one Republican to support it.

headline: BP’s Garage Sale: A Look at Which Assets May Go
text: BP is concentrating on selling $25 billion to $30 billion in assets that are on the periphery of its huge energy empire as the company becomes leaner. The “more focused” BP described by Tony Hayward, its outgoing chief executive, is likely to see only an 8 to 10 percent decline in its overall energy production because of its asset sales, which are aimed at covering the costs of its disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: House Hunting in ... Cornwall, England
text: A THREE-BEDROOM HOUSE ON AN ISLAND IN CORNWALL

headline: At Home on a Rock
text: A three-bedroom 1,700-square-foot home set on top of a tiny island in Cornwall is on the market for 1.25 million pounds, or around $2 million.

headline: Homes for $580,000
text: A two-bedroom contemporary in Dallas, a four-bedroom antebellum house in Mississippi and a three-bedroom Greek Revival in Maine.

headline: What You Get for ... $580,000
text: PORT GIBSON, MISS.

headline: Reviewing the Lion
text: This week’s restaurant review is of the Lion, John DeLucie’s scene-y new restaurant on Ninth Street, where Village used to be. It has its charms and distractions. You go see what you think, then post a comment below. Of particular interest this week, at least in terms of our discussion below, is the notion of restaurants in which the point of the dining room is as much to see and be seen as it is to eat. As a  historical example, do you remember 44, in the Royalton? The seating there was as rigorously codified as the caste system, at least on first blush. And in addition to some number of restaurants in the meatpacking district, I suppose there are a few restaurants on the Upper East Side as well — Orsay, for instance. So tell us. What are your favorite scene restaurants and why? Or, just as good, your least favorite! Comment approvers are standing by.

headline: The Lion Opens His Den
text: THE Lion’s tale begins in 2006, with Graydon Carter. That year, Mr. Carter, the satirical-magazine outsider who had ascended Manhattan society to become editor of Vanity Fair, opened the Waverly Inn, a nostalgic West Village restaurant with no published telephone number and a dining room filled only with the people he wanted in it: the city’s media and celebrity elite.

headline: ‘The Bachelorette’ Keeps ABC in Lead
text: The men-tell-all episode of “The Bachelorette” attracted 8.9 million viewers on Monday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, putting that ABC reality show on top of the ratings for the sixth consecutive week. The two-hour broadcast won both the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, while ABC’s special edition of “20/20,” featuring interviews with the “Bachelor” creator Mike Fleiss, drew six million viewers at 10. CBS ranked second with comedy reruns. NBC was third, and Fox finished fourth. On Sunday ratings for “Mad Men” inched up slightly, compared with a year ago, as 2.9 million viewers watched the start of the fourth season, a record for a premiere of that AMC series but just 100,000 more viewers than last year.

headline: ‘Our Town’ to Close
text: Nothing lasts forever in Grover’s Corners  nor does any production of “Our Town,” Thornton Wilder’s play about life and loss in that fictitious New Hampshire community. On Tuesday the producers of the critically acclaimed Off Broadway production of “Our Town”  the longest-running in the play’s 72-year history  announced that the show would hold its final performance on Sept. 12, more than a year and a half after its run began at the Barrow Street Theater. David Cromer, the director of the production, will reprise his performance as the Stage Manager for the last three weeks of the run, starting Aug. 24. Helen Hunt (“As Good as It Gets”) is playing the Stage Manager through Sunday; from Aug. 3 to Aug. 22, Michael McKean (of last season’s “Superior Donuts” on Broadway) will play the character, as he did earlier this summer.

headline: NBC Confirms That Carell Is Leaving ‘The Office’
text: NBC did not immediately comment last month when Steve Carell, who plays the incompetent manager Michael Scott on “The Office,” said he felt “it was time for my character to go” at the end of his seven-year contract after the show’s coming seventh season. But now in an interview with The Associated Press, Angela Bromstad, NBC’s president of prime-time entertainment, indicated that the network was preparing for a future without Mr. Carell, an increasingly visible star of film comedies like “Date Night” and “Dinner for Schmucks.” “We’ve been lucky to have had him as long as we’ve had,” Ms. Bromstad told The A.P. “These things happen when you have such a major movie star in a show.” She added, “Not to diminish the departure of Steve, because that will impact the show, but we have tremendous faith in the writers and actors to keep it alive.”

headline: Oliver Stone Apologizes For Remarks About Jews
text: Oliver Stone, right, apologized late Monday for comments he made about Hitler and the Holocaust that were published in The Sunday Times of London. The remarks, which included a reference to “the Jewish domination of the media” and a remark that “Hitler did far more damage to the Russians than the Jewish people,” were criticized by Jewish groups as anti-Semitic. “In trying to make a broader historical point about the range of atrocities the Germans committed against many people, I made a clumsy association about the Holocaust, for which I am sorry and I regret,” Mr. Stone said in a statement. “Jews obviously do not control media or any other industry. The fact that the Holocaust is still a very important, vivid and current matter today is, in fact, a great credit to the very hard work of a broad coalition of people committed to the remembrance of this atrocity  and it was an atrocity.” Mr. Stone had made the comments during an interview with the London newspaper to promote his documentary “South of the Border,” which is about South American politics.

headline: Mets Face Cardinals Without Bay and Manuel
text: The Mets opened a series with the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday night at Citi Field without leftfielder Jason Bay and Manager Jerry Manuel.

headline: Toronto Film Festival Releases Partial Lineup
text: Robert Redford, Woody Allen, Ben Affleck and Emilio Estevez are among the actors who have directed films that will appear at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. On Tuesday the festival’s officials announced a partial slate of 51 films, including 25 world premieres. The lineup includes “The Conspirator,” directed by Mr. Redford, about the aftermath of the Lincoln assassination; “You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger,” directed by Mr. Allen, about Londoners in troubled relationships; “The Town,” directed by Mr. Affleck, about a heist crew; and “The Way,” directed by Mr. Estevez, about a doctor learning lessons as he goes abroad to collect the remains of a dead son. The festival runs from Sept. 9 to 19.

headline: Man Booker Prize Announces Long List
text: Celebrity authors were conspicuously absent from the list of 13 finalists for this year’s Man Booker Prize for fiction, announced on Tuesday. The winner, who will receive about $77,000, will be named on Oct. 12. Andrew Motion, the chairman of the judges, said in a statement: “Here are 13 exceptional novels  books we have chosen for their intrinsic quality, without reference to the past work of their authors. Wide-ranging in their geography and their concern, they tell powerful stories which make the familiar strange and cover an enormous range of history and feeling.” The Booker is Britain’s best-known literary award, and brings with it prestige and, of course, increased book sales. On the list are “Parrot and Olivier in America,” by Peter Carey; “Room,” by Emma Donoghue; “The Betrayal,” by Helen Dunmore; “In a Strange Room,” by Damon Galgut; “The Finkler Question,” by Howard Jacobson; “The Long Song,” by Andrea Levy; “C,” by Tom McCarthy; “The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet,” by David Mitchell; “February,” by Lisa Moore; “Skippy Dies,” by Paul Murray; “Trespass,” by Rose Tremain; “The Slap,” by Christos Tsiolkas; and “The Stars in the Bright Sky,” by Alan Warner.

headline: In Shanghai, in Search of Authenticity
text: SHANGHAI — Many Americans who move here end up in high-rise buildings surrounded by other expatriates. But Nichol Bradford wanted a more authentic experience. “I wasn’t moving halfway around the world, leaving everything I knew and everyone I loved, to play it safe,” said Ms. Bradford, 38, a video game executive who relocated from Los Angeles in 2008. “I certainly wasn’t going to live in a building that could have been in any other city.”

headline: Now On View: Restored Work That Isn’t a Caravaggio
text: This has been a busy week for the little-seen painting known as “The Martyrdom of St. Lawrence,” a detail of which is below. Its restored canvas was unveiled on Tuesday hours after the official newspaper of the Vatican said it was not a lost work by Caravaggio, The Associated Press reported. Last week the newspaper, L’Osservatore Romano, ran a front-page article on the painting, which depicts St. Lawrence and his executioners and was kept in a private room in a Jesuit church in Rome, with the headline, “A New Caravaggio.” An accompanying article said further tests would be required before its authorship could be determined. In a follow-up article on Monday, L’Osservatore said the painting was not the work of that Italian master, who has received increased attention this year on the 400th anniversary of his death. Antonio Paolucci, director of the Vatican Museums, said the work was “modest” and not of Caravaggio’s quality.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Looking Up
text: In mid-June, DreamWorks Animation was worried enough about the soft box-office performance of “Shrek Forever After” that it warned that second-quarter earnings would be “meaningfully below” last year. Shares plunged.

headline: BP Focusing on Investors, Too
text: BP is sounding decisive and radical. The beleaguered British oil major is expanding its existing asset disposal program to $30 billion and looking to cut debt after announcing a $32 billion charge on its Gulf of Mexico oil spill in Tuesday’s earnings report. And Tony Hayward is to step down as chief executive. But for Mr. Hayward’s American successor, Robert Dudley, one big challenge is to turn this into a convincing story for the company’s stock.

headline: A Tribute to Merce Cunningham
text: The River to River Festival’s “We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment” commemorated the first anniversary of Merce Cunningham’s death.

headline: Five Choreographers, One Tribute
text: Monday was the first anniversary of the death of the choreographer Merce Cunningham. The Cunningham company gave its first posthumous performance last year in Rockefeller Park, in Battery Park City, and that’s where the River to River Festival observed his death this year by presenting a commemorative performance called “We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An Event for Merce,” featuring work by five choreographers. I don’t envy the dancers having to maintain strict technical rigor while facing straight into the glare of the sun, but the weather, the early-evening light and the views were glorious.

headline: Star-Cross’d Songs for Star-Cross’d Lovers
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.

headline: Wild Caspian Caviar Returns
text: THERE will be a fresh supply of wild caviar from the Caspian Sea on holiday blini this fall and winter, for the first time in two years. The international convention that regulates trade in endangered species issued quotas for the catch on July 23.

headline: Intro to Aperol
text: Adapted from Pegu Club, Manhattan

headline: Lima Bean Spread With Feta and Za’atar
text: Adapted from “Purple Citrus & Sweet Perfume” by Silvena Rowe (Random House)

headline: Madeira Martinez
text: Adapted from Pegu Club, Manhattan

headline: Kataifi-Wrapped Shrimp With Pine Nut Tarator
text: Adapted from “Purple Citrus & Sweet Perfume” by Silvena Rowe (Random House)

headline: A London Chef Looks to a Different East
text: ON the BBC’s Saturday morning cooking show, “Saturday Kitchen,” last month, the British chef Silvena Rowe, six feet tall with azure eyes and bleached blond hair streaked with purple to match the cover of her new cookbook, “Purple Citrus & Sweet Perfume,” told the audience she had something to announce.

headline: From Roof to Table
text: Red and yellow watermelons, ripe strawberries, squash blossoms, heads of romaine and Bibb lettuces and fresh chickpeas are among the crops being lowered, using a pulley system, from the rooftop garden on a building in Greenwich Village. These will supply the kitchen of Bell Book & Candle, a restaurant opening in a month or so on the building’s ground floor. John Mooney, above, the chef, and his partner, Mick O’Sullivan, are growing more than 70 varieties of herbs, vegetables and fruits using a hydroponic automatic watering system of vertically planted structures, like little towers studded with openings for the plants. The pulley system is an alternative to hauling produce down six flights of stairs (there’s no elevator). The partners are sharing their harvest with neighborhood restaurants, but once they open, Mr. O’Sullivan estimates they will grow about 60 percent of their own restaurant’s produce.

headline: New in Queens: LIC Market
text: On a trendy shoestring, with recycled materials, Alex Schindler has turned a storefront in Long Island City, Queens, into LIC Market, a restaurant and shop. (The foot rail at the bar where breakfast is served is made out of a plumbing pipe.) The shelves in front are filled with packaged foods. Many of these come from Mr. Schindler’s restaurant kitchen, including delectably sweet-sour pickled baby carrots, fresh-tasting chunky tomato sauce, dense fig jam and earthy black olive tapenade. Oatmeal, granola and coffee are also sold.

headline: To Enhance Flavor, Just Add Water
text: WHEN fine-tuning the flavor of dishes and drinks, I’ve always turned to the usual bench of taste and aroma boosters: salt and pepper, lemon juice, herbs and spices, this or that condiment. One ingredient that never, ever came to mind was water. Water has no flavor to give. It doesn’t boost, it dilutes.

headline: Korean-Style Tacos Across America
text: A phenomenon that started in Southern California has rapidly spread across the United States.

headline: The Commodore
text: LIKE all good dive bars, the Commodore keeps it simple.

headline: Near Yale, a 32-Story Gamble Rises in New Haven
text: NEW HAVEN  This city of 123,000 has long struggled to reconcile its two faces: The intellectual oasis of Yale University and the upscale area it has spawned, and a more turbulent side that includes the 1970 Black Panther trials, a recent Supreme Court ruling that white firefighters had been unfairly denied promotions because of their race and crime that still plagues parts of the city.

headline: Dijon Mustard Made With Walnuts
text: This new walnut mustard made in Burgundy takes no prisoners. It’s seriously forceful, tart and pungent, the way Dijon mustard used to be before it was tempered for global tastes. It has the added allure of ground walnuts, giving it more texture and earthier flavor than the company’s plain Dijon. Use it to season a salad dressing made with walnut oil.

headline: At Greenmarkets, the Peaches of Summer
text: The Greenmarkets are fragrant with the lush aroma of peaches, as more farms than ever pick their fruit when ripe. Weeks of hot weather without much rain have helped concentrate their flavor; the best peaches are on the small side. They drip juice with the first bite. Handle them with care and plan to use them without delay. Any bruised ones can be cut up into muffin batter, chutneys, mousses or simply swirled into the morning yogurt.

headline: The Tortilla Takes a Road Trip to Korea
text: TOMAS LEE has long dreamed of selling American consumers on Korean barbecue.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Medieval Meals

headline: Former ‘Idol’ Producer Is Said to Be Coming Back
text: Signaling that changes might be coming to “American Idol,” one of its original executive producers, Nigel Lythgoe, is expected to return to that position next season, four people with knowledge of hiring negotiations said this week.

headline: An Amazon-Facebook Alliance to Make Shopping More Social
text: On Tuesday, Amazon.com took a step toward making the shopping experience on its Web site more social.

headline: Eataly, an Italian Food Hall, Opening Soon
text: EATALY, a giant Italian food hall opening in a month or so on West 23rd Street near Fifth Avenue, is a culinary extravaganza, from arancini to zabaglione.

headline: U.S. Decision on Pipeline Is Delayed
text: The State Department said it would delay its decision on a permit for a contentious $7 billion pipeline project intended to deliver crude oil from the oil sands of the province of Alberta in Canada, to refineries on the Texas Gulf Coast.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Evercore Hires Senior Access Executive
text: After five years as the head of mergers and acquisitions at Access Industries, Philip Kassin wanted a career change.

headline: A Penthouse in Shanghai
text: The 900-square-foot one-bedroom apartment of Nichol Bradford, an expatriate from Los Angeles, is in a 1933 building.

headline: New York to Pay $7 Million for Sean Bell Shooting
text: Closing a key chapter in one of the most controversial police shootings in recent memory, New York City agreed on Tuesday to pay more than $7 million to settle a federal lawsuit filed by the family and two friends of Sean Bell, a 23-year-old black man who was fatally shot by the police in 2006 on what would have been his wedding day.

headline: How to Tame a Schoolyard Bully
text: To the Editor:

headline: Questions About Yale Cancer Patient’s Benefactor
text: The story of Mandi Schwartz has been heard far and wide: a Yale hockey player stricken with leukemia, she needs a stem-cell transplant to survive, and her family and friends are searching everywhere to find her one.

headline: A Secret Archive of What We Already Knew
text: To the Editor:

headline: Foreclosure Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: Views on Carbon Caps, Sustainability Science
text: Below I’ve linked to a semi-random sample of the reading I’ve been trying to fit in while discussing population, climate, the energy challenge and humanity’s emerging role as a planetary manager at the Aspen Environment Forum. While at the meeting, I couldn’t help notice that the trees are watching:

headline: Pakistan Media Say Reports on Leaked Documents Unfairly Malign Spy Agency
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Almost all of the political and current affairs talk shows on Pakistani television news networks took a defensive stance Tuesday on the release of military documents that suggested ties between Pakistan’s spy agency and Afghan insurgents. The consensus was this: Pakistan and its intelligence agencies are unjustifiably criticized and painted in a negative light. Hosts and guests rued the fact that while the country has been hit by a devastating and almost unrelenting wave of terrorism, it is not really understood or acknowledged fully by the outside world.

headline: Global Airline Pilots Not Happy About Israeli Security Program
text: Pilots of commercial airlines that fly into Israel are expressing increased opposition to a security program imposed by the country’s Ministry of Transport that they say could subject inbound flights to possible attack by Israeli warplanes.

headline: Albany’s Two Payrolls: One Is Anybody’s Guess
text: ALBANY  As Gov. David A. Paterson calls lawmakers back to work on the budget this week, he has announced that the fiscal situation is so serious that he must begin laying off state workers. But there is one wrinkle, as officials try to pare government spending: No one knows for sure how big the state work force actually is.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Nontraditional Taco?
text: Korean barbecue is not the Mexican tortilla’s only new dance partner. John T. Edge has written of breakfast tacos, stuffed with eggs and potatoes, here before, and let’s not overlook the Choco Taco (for which Serious Eats has kindly provided a recipe). Tell us your favorite nontraditional taco, or any spin on a popular Mexican dish, in the comments section below, whether it’s from a restaurant, street vendor, or your kitchen.

headline: Moving Day at Biel
text: There were four decisive results in the penultimate round of the Biel Chess Festival on Tuesday and Fabiano Caruana and Maxime Vachier-Lagrave are now tied for the lead.

headline: Debt And Growth, Yet Again
text: John Irons and Josh Bivens have the best takedown yet of the Reinhart-Rogoff paper (pdf) claiming that debt over 90 percent of GDP leads to drastically slower growth. R-R specifically highlight the case of the United States:

headline: Diplomat Harsh on Leaders in Testimony for Iraq Inquiry
text: LONDON  In the years Hans Blix has spent relating his struggle to deter the United States and Britain from going to war in Iraq, he has rarely spoken with the disdain for President George W. Bush and his top aides that he displayed on Tuesday before Britain’s official inquiry into the war.

headline: From Joy on the Fields of England to Joy Among the Thoroughbreds
text: LONDON

headline: Illegal Immigrants Caught on a Yacht, in a Web of Maritime Laws
text: Gaea Rich and her family were in full holiday mode aboard their yacht on the Fourth of July as they motored from Stamford, Conn., across Long Island Sound and into Oyster Bay, off the North Shore of Long Island.

headline: Lockheed Says Several Parts for F-35s Are Failing
text: Lockheed Martin said Tuesday that several parts on the most complex version of its F-35 Joint Strike Fighter were failing more often than expected, a problem that is slowing flight testing on a model tailored for the Marines.

headline: Bohemian Grove Enclave
text: The infamous Bohemian Grove enclave in the redwood forests north of San Francisco.

headline: Rangel Settlement Talks Continue
text: Hoping to avert a public ethics hearing that could damage himself and other Democrats, lawyers for Rep. Charles B. Rangel met with the House ethics committee today looking to work out a last-minute settlement to the charges against him.

headline: Redwoods Hideaway for the Elite Goes On, but Protest Days Fade
text: MONTE RIO, Calif.

headline: From Blagojevich Lawyer, Final Argument With Drama
text: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich has never been one for understatement, so it seemed fitting on Tuesday when a defense lawyer in his corruption case offered a final argument peppered with whispers, shouts, gasps, sarcasm and slang  an effort so full of drama that the presiding judge likened it to a show.

headline: Russia's YouTube Whistle-Blower
text: A police officer in Russia uses the Internet to challenge the country's leaders to address rampant corruption.

headline: Left Out of Olympics, Wisconsin Roads Still Lure Cyclists
text: Last October, the International Olympic Committee tossed out Chicago’s bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics in the first round, ultimately choosing Rio de Janeiro. For many a Chicagoan it was a crushing blow.

headline: Obama and Boehner Spar on Tax Cuts
text: President Obama and a Republican Congressional leader squared off at the White House on Tuesday over whether to extend all of the Bush tax cuts that otherwise expire after this year, and in so doing defined the battle lines for the emerging election-season fight.

headline: A Fair Exchange
text: Washington

headline: Photo Replay: July 27
text: A view of the day in sports, from hoops in Taiwan to heats in Barcelona.

headline: In a Sweltering City, It’s Coolest Before Dawn
text: A man wearing sunglasses, for once unneeded, checked a pay phone for loose change and swept across Flatbush Avenue, a cup of hot coffee in his hand, the only figure moving on that slumbering colossus of commerce at 5 a.m. on Tuesday.

headline: Restaurant Grading Begins in New York
text: By the end of Wednesday, several restaurant windows in New York are quite likely to display a new attraction alongside the usual menus and reviews: a brilliantly colored placard bearing a letter grade.

headline: Stop Raiding the Ivory Tower
text: Stony Brook, N.Y.

headline: Democrats Split as House Backs War Funds
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives agreed on Tuesday to provide $37 billion to continue financing America’s two wars, but the vote showed deepening divisions and anxiety among Democrats over the course of the nearly nine-year-old conflict in Afghanistan.

headline: Abrupt Shake-Up at the Top Ranks of ABC
text: 10:23 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — Stephen McPherson, the president of ABC Entertainment, abruptly resigned late Tuesday after a six-year reign known more for internal volatility than for hit programming.

headline: Finally, Beltran Gets a Touch of Revenge
text: Adam Wainwright threw a curveball for his first pitch to Carlos Beltran on Tuesday, and dutifully, Beltran took it. It felt like an Old-Timers’ game, if Mookie Wilson guided a little roller up along first, and Bill Buckner let it skip between his legs  a pair linked in history reenacting their memorable moment.

headline: Obama Meets With Big Donors
text: President Obama met with about 50 of the Democratic Party’s biggest donors on Tuesday night at an upscale Washington hotel, but aides excluded reporters from the event since the president did not give a speech.

headline: Lost in a Maze
text: WASHINGTON

headline: On the Surface, Gulf Oil Spill Is Vanishing Fast; Concerns Stay
text: The oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico appears to be dissolving far more rapidly than anyone expected, a piece of good news that raises tricky new questions about how fast the government should scale back its response to the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: In Study, 2 Economists Say Intervention Helped Avert a 2nd Depression
text: WASHINGTON  Like a mantra, officials from both the Bush and Obama administrations have trumpeted how the government’s sweeping interventions to prop up the economy since 2008 helped avert a second Depression.

headline: Want the Good News First?
text: Grand Isle, La.

headline: The Impact of Another Kind of Stimulus
text: On Wednesday, Alan Blinder, the Princeton economist and former Federal Reserve vice chairman, and Mark Zandi, chief economist of Moody’s Analytics, will release a new analysis of the federal government’s response to the Great Recession. As far as I know, it’s the first serious attempt at analyzing the effect both of the stimulus programs passed by Congress and of the various financial-market policies put in place by the Fed, the Treasury and Congress. My colleague Sewell Chan has the details.

headline: New Rules to Protect Swimmers Proposed
text: In a special meeting that included independent experts from the Child Welfare League of America, the U.S.A. Swimming board of directors drafted legislation aimed at strengthening and expanding the organization’s umbrella for protecting athletes from being sexually abused by people affiliated with the sport.

headline: Cameron Urges Change in Gaza
text: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday condemned the partial Israeli blockade of Gaza, describing Gaza as “a prison camp.”

headline: Rethinking Criminal Sentences
text: A federal conviction for white-collar fraud is no guarantee of a heavy prison sentence. When five defendants in the fraud case involving the American International Group were sentenced, they could have faced life in prison; instead, a judge handed down sentences of one to four years for causing more than $500 million in losses. A Ponzi-scheme criminal who caused more than $40 million in losses got 25 years. A man convicted of securities fraud that caused more than $50 million in losses got a three-and-a-half-year sentence.

headline: Owner of Devils Expects Quick Decision by Arbitrator on Kovalchuk
text: LONG BRANCH, N.J.  Jeff Vanderbeek, the Devils’ owner, said Tuesday night that he thought an arbitrator would make a prompt decision regarding wing Ilya Kovalchuk’s 17-year, $102 million contract with the team, which the National Hockey League rejected last week.

headline: Death Penalty Is Challenged Before a Trial in 3 Killings
text: NEW HAVEN  The defense in the Cheshire triple-murder case made a broad challenge to Connecticut’s death penalty law on Tuesday, but the judge indicated that he would reject it and that the trial of one of the parolees charged in the killings would begin as scheduled in September.

headline: Texas Battles Health Law Even as It Follows It
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  There are more uninsured residents of Texas  6.1 million and counting  than there are people in 33 states. The state’s elected officials might be expected, therefore, to cheer a federal health care law that is likely to deliver billions of dollars from Washington to Austin and cover millions of low-income Texans.

headline: BP’s Blueprint for Emerging From Crisis
text: BP said on Tuesday that it had set aside $32.2 billion to pay for the biggest offshore oil spill in United States history.

headline: West Virginian Helps Put the Classic in a New PGA Event
text: After a week in St. Andrews, Scotland, followed by a week in Ontario, Canada, some PGA Tour pros at the Greenbrier’s Old White Course for this week’s Greenbrier Classic may feel they have been transported back to a more elegant time and place.

headline: Keeping Politics in the Shadows
text: Free speech implies responsibility. The Supreme Court said earlier this year that corporations and unions have the First Amendment right to spend whatever they want on independent political ads, but many businesses don’t want the responsibility that comes with that new right. They want to make their unlimited donations anonymously so the public will not know who is flooding the airwaves. On Tuesday, the Republicans in the Senate voted to let them get away with it.

headline: Some Justice for Cambodia
text: Thirty years later, Cambodia’s “killing fields” are still haunting. A Buddhist memorial displays 5,000 haphazardly arranged human skulls  a tiny fraction of the 1.7 million Cambodians butchered by the Khmer Rouge.

headline: Billy Loes, Quirky Pitcher for Dodgers, Dies at 80
text: Billy Loes, a leading pitcher for three pennant-winning Brooklyn Dodgers teams of the 1950s with an image as an eccentric that seemed a perfect fit for a franchise long known for its colorful characters, died July 15 at a hospice in Tucson. He was 80.

headline: Bankers’ Pay
text: In 2009, there was a lot of talk about reasonable limits on bankers’ compensation, after some breathtakingly risky lending almost crippled the financial system. A czar was appointed. Politicians said the bankers had better not use their bailouts for bonuses.

headline: Picture This, and Risk Arrest
text: One afternoon, Duane P. Kerzic was arrested by the Amtrak police while taking pictures of a train pulling into Pennsylvania Station. At first, the police asked him to delete the images from his camera, but he refused. He ended up handcuffed to the wall of a holding cell while an officer wrote a ticket for trespassing.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Jack Tatum, Whose Tackle Paralyzed Player, Dies at 61
text: Jack Tatum, the former Oakland Raiders player who earned the nickname the Assassin for his brutal hits, none of them more devastating than a blow that left New England Patriots wide receiver Darryl Stingley paralyzed in 1978, died Tuesday in Oakland, Calif. He was 61.

headline: Second Half Is Santana’s Season
text: This is Johan Santana’s time of the year. After holding the Dodgers to a run and five hits over seven innings, he improved to 4-0 with a 0.65 earned run average in his last four starts.

headline: Like Much Vegas Stagewear
text: And now for something completely different.

headline: More Troops for Somalia, but No Peace to Keep
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  If there is one place on the African continent that could benefit from new thinking, it is Somalia, a country that has been mired in mutating forms of civil war for nearly 20 years.

headline: Titans Sue Trojans and Kiffin Over Hiring
text: When the Southern California Coach Lane Kiffin landed in New York on Monday for the Pacific-10 Conference’s first East Coast media tour, he clicked on a picture that was sent by his old Trojan friend Steve Sarkisian, who is now Washington’s coach.

headline: Founding a Charity at 6, and Walking Across the Country for It at 12
text: SAN CARLOS, Ariz.  He cuts a tiny figure in the vastness of the upland desert, the expanse of scrub and brush and saguaro cactuses and red ragged mountains. He is a red-headed boy with a sunburned nose and sunglasses, and he moves with a step not graceful, nor terribly fast, but steady and determined, his mouth set in a hard line.

headline: Concussion Symptoms Developed Late for Bay
text: According to the timeline presented by the Mets on Tuesday, left fielder Jason Bay ran into the outfield wall in Los Angeles on Friday night but did not feel concussion symptoms until Sunday night while flying home after the team wrapped up a 2-9 trip.

headline: Democrats Confirm More House Seats in Play
text: Democrats added another 20 House seats to their list of targeted districts, officials confirmed Tuesday evening, raising the party’s commitment in television advertising for the final weeks of the campaign to more than $49 million.

headline: Francoeur, Possible Trade Bait, Makes the Most of an Unexpected Start
text: As Saturday’s nonwaiver trading deadline approaches, Jeff Francoeur has heard the rumors and fretted that he may not finish the season as a member of the Mets.

headline: Yankees Are Foiled by a Pitcher in His Debut
text: CLEVELAND  Josh Tomlin last pitched in Durham, N.C., handling a Class AAA lineup that included J. J. Furmaniak, Angel Chavez and Jose Lobaton. His assignment at Progressive Field on Tuesday was a bit more challenging: to subdue the mighty Yankees, the highest-scoring team in baseball. In a sense, he already held the advantage. The Yankees, for reasons they cannot pinpoint, often succumb to pitchers they have never faced before. Add to the list Tomlin, who in his major league debut outdueled C. C. Sabathia to lift the Cleveland Indians to a 4-1 victory.

headline: Whipped-Cream Pie Tradition Will Continue, but With Safety in Mind
text: CLEVELAND  When shoving whipped-cream pies in his teammates’ faces, A. J. Burnett abides by one rule. “I always try to somewhat think safety first,” Burnett said.

headline: The Case for $320,000 Kindergarten Teachers
text: How much do your kindergarten teacher and classmates affect the rest of your life?

headline: Kindergarten and Class
text: A new paper by Raj Chetty and five other economists – the subject of my column this week – suggests kindergarten can have lasting effects on students. Students who learn more in kindergarten appear to earn more, to be less likely to become teenage parents and even to be less likely to die young.

headline: Russian Court, in Case Against Newspaper Editor, Hands Opposition a Rare Victory
text: MOSCOW  For more than a year, a crusading editor of an opposition newspaper in a Moscow suburb has been trying to fend off charges that he fomented extremism by publishing articles that created “negative stereotypes and negative images of members of the security forces,” among other faults.

headline: Videos Rouse Russian Anger Toward Police
text: NOVOROSSIYSK, Russia  One day last fall, a police officer here put on his uniform and sat on a drab tan couch before a video camera. In a halting monotone, he recorded two video appeals to Vladimir V. Putin, 13 minutes in all.

headline: Awaiting a Full Embrace of Same-Sex Weddings
text: CAPE TOWN — It was another picture-perfect wedding at the foot of Table Mountain, recalled the Rev. Daniel Brits. Inside the chapel, a female vocalist sang “Wind Beneath My Wings” before he led the nervous couple through their vows surrounded by family and friends a few weeks ago.

headline: Thinking Back to Teaneck Armory, and Playing for the Sake of Playing
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: Old Friends, White Water and Roasted Ants in Colombia
text: Six weeks without seeing a familiar face can wear on any traveler, no matter how warm and welcoming the unfamiliar faces are. So I’d been looking forward to Week 7, when two close friends – my high school classmates Jon Chapman and Doug Mollenauer – would fly down from the States. The plan: meet in Bogotá and hop a seven-hour bus to Santander province, known as Colombia’s adventure tourism hot spot, among other things. (Among the other things: it’s Colombia’s roasted-ant-consumption hot spot, but I had downplayed that aspect to them.)

headline: Haiti Investigates Prison Shootings
text: An independent commission of inquiry into the Jan. 19 killings of a dozen or more inmates at a prison in Les Cayes, Haiti, was formally established by presidential decree this week, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Turning 30, an Office Product Works at Home
text: IN a new commercial for Super Sticky Notes by Post-it, the 3M brand, scheduled to begin next Monday, a Jack Russell terrier eyes an orange note with a drawing of a bone that is affixed several feet above on a kitchen wall. After a few jumps, he sinks his teeth into the note, then hangs suspended by it.

headline: Egypt: Trial Opens for Officers Charged in Man’s Death While in Custody
text: Two police officers accused of using excessive force against a 28-year-old man who died in police custody in June made their first court appearance on Tuesday, in a case that human rights advocates say is a test of the government’s willingness to root out a culture of police abuse. During the hearing, lawyers for the family of the victim, Khaled Said, gave a judge a witness list, including people who they said saw the officers, Mahmoud Saleh, 33, and Awad Ismael Suleiman, 31, beat Mr. Said to death. Two autopsies conducted by the authorities concluded that Mr. Said had choked on a packet of marijuana. The two officers said nothing during the hearing, and the trial was adjourned until Sept. 25.

headline: Haiti: Talk of a Wyclef Jean Presidential Run
text: Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-American musician admired in his homeland as a celebrity who never forgot his roots, appears to be contemplating a run for the Haitian presidency in the Nov. 28 elections. On Tuesday, as Haiti buzzed with speculation that Mr. Jean, 37, was poised to declare his candidacy, his family issued a statement that said: “At this time, Wyclef Jean has not announced his intent to run for Haitian president. If and when a decision is made, the media will be alerted immediately.” Presidential aspirants must register during the first week of August. President René Préval is ineligible to run for a third term.

headline: Disney Buys Playdom in $763 Million Deal, Becoming Hollywood Leader in Social Games
text: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company on Tuesday became Hollywood’s leader in the booming social game business by acquiring Playdom in a deal worth as much as $763.2 million.

headline: Smashing Pumpkins, Repenting for the Past
text: Billy Corgan made himself ingratiating when he led Smashing Pumpkins at Terminal 5 on Monday night. Between songs that vent frustrated fury or plunge into tumultuous love -- rarely anything in between -- he smiled a lot. He thanked the audience repeatedly. He jokingly apologized to longtime fans "for what I’ve done to you." He pretended he would abruptly end the concert, then reversed himsef, declaring, "The concert ends when you say so. I’m your little rock and roll puppet. I do what you want me to do." Then he raised both hands in the air, moving like a marionette.

headline: A Vision of Diane Arbus on Juniper Blvd.
text: There was drama enough on the other side of the police line in Middle Village, Queens, on July 9. But Ángel Franco couldn’t take his eyes off the young girl who had gathered a little bouquet for herself in Juniper Valley Park and was trying to peer through crime-scene tape that seemed to have been set at just the height necessary to thwart her.

headline: Phys Ed: Does Lucky Underwear Improve Athletic Performance?
text: Athletes are a notoriously superstitious lot. For years, Michael Jordan wore the shorts from his national-championship-winning University of North Carolina days under his Chicago Bulls uniform. Serena Williams won’t change her socks at tournaments she’s winning. Other professional athletes carry lucky charms or perform rituals, like bouncing a basketball in elaborate sequences before a free throw or kissing the golf ball before a putt. Jason Giambi (the former Yankee and current Colorado Rockies first baseman) has said that he slips on a pair of “lucky” thong underwear when his batting average falls. The thong’s reputation is so potent that slumping teammates reportedly beg to borrow it.

headline: M.T.A. to Propose New Fare Increases
text: New Yorkers will soon be asked to pay more to ride trains and buses that just weeks ago suffered the severest service cuts in a generation. The series of fare increases will be unveiled on Wednesday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Massachusetts Nears a Change to Electoral Votes
text: BOSTON  Ten years after George W. Bush defeated Al Gore for president despite losing the popular vote, Massachusetts is close to joining a handful of other states in passing a law that would try to prevent such a twist from happening again.

headline: John Callahan, Cartoonist, Dies at 59
text: John Callahan, a quadriplegic, alcoholic cartoonist whose work in newspapers and magazines made irreverent, impolitic sport of people with disabilities and diseases and those who would pity and condescend to them, died on Saturday in Portland, Ore. He was 59 and lived in Portland.

headline: Anatomy of an 0-for-4 Night by Rodriguez
text: CLEVELAND — Pitchers often talk about establishing their fastball, then working off that pitch to throw their secondary stuff. That was C. C. Sabathia’s approach on Tuesday night.

headline: Year of the Women in Oklahoma
text: In Oklahoma, it’s not the year of the woman. It’s the year of the women.

headline: Greece: In Statement, Guerrilla Group Claims the Killing of a Journalist
text: Greece’s deadliest active guerrilla group, Sect of Revolutionaries, claimed responsibility on Tuesday for last week’s fatal shooting of a reporter in Athens, according to Ta Nea, a left-leaning Greek newspaper. The paper’s Web site said it received a compact disc with a seven-page statement from the group claiming responsibility for the execution-style shooting of the reporter, Sokratis Giolias, 37, outside his home. A police spokesman said the statement’s authenticity had not been confirmed.

headline: France: Hostage Held by Islamists May Have Died Before Rescue Attempt
text: The death of the French hostage Michel Germaneau at the hands of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb may have occurred even before a failed rescue operation last week that killed six Qaeda fighters, Prime Minister François Fillon said Tuesday. Al Qaeda announced Sunday that it had executed Mr. Germaneau, 78, an aid worker with a heart condition, in retaliation for the raid. But Mr. Fillon said on Europe1 radio that he might have been dead when France got an ultimatum threatening to kill him, 10 days before the rescue attempt. Mr. Germaneau was captured in Niger in April; his body has not been recovered.

headline: Delta’s Black Oystermen Seeking Cleanup Work and Clinging to Hope
text: POINTE A LA HACHE, La.  Way down in the delta, just south of the Belle Chasse Ferry at Beshel’s Marina here, black men with work-worn hands and several generations of fishing in their blood sat around on old milk crates, hoping for a piece of the oil cleanup action that seems to have bypassed their little stretch of the bayou.

headline: The Frugal Traveler: Touring Colombia
text: Seth Kugel, the New York Times Frugal Traveler, spends time in newly tourist-friendly Colombia.

headline: Lawmakers Offer Bills to Address Spill Issues
text: WASHINGTON  House and Senate Democratic leaders introduced bills on Tuesday responding to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, with provisions to overhaul the federal regulation of offshore drilling, lift liability limits on companies responsible for damaging spills and funnel more money to spill-related research and restoration projects.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,192 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:
