text: In 2009, there was a lot of talk about reasonable limits on bankers’ compensation, after some breathtakingly risky lending almost crippled the financial system. A czar was appointed. Politicians said the bankers had better not use their bailouts for bonuses.

headline: No Survivors Reported in Pakistan Plane Crash
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani passenger plane crashed in fog and intense rain in the Himalayan foothills near this capital city on Wednesday morning, killing all 152 people on board in the country’s deadliest domestic plane crash, according to civil aviation and airline officials.

text: bohemian •\bo-he’me-ən\• adjective, noun

headline: Britain: Calling Gaza a ‘Prison Camp,’ Cameron Condemns Israeli Blockade
text: Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday condemned the partial Israeli blockade of Gaza, describing Gaza as "a prison camp." In a speech to a business audience in Ankara, Turkey, Mr. Cameron urged Turkey and Israel "not to give up" on their friendship. But he said the Israeli military attack on a Turkish aid ship bound for Gaza, in which nine Turkish citizens were killed, was "completely unacceptable," and urged Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to ensure a "swift, transparent and rigorous" Israeli inquiry into what occurred. In unusually blunt language for a British prime minister speaking about Arab-Israeli tensions, he added: "Let me also be clear that the situation in Gaza must change. Humanitarian goods and people must flowin both directions. Gaza cannot and must not be allowed to remain a prison camp." A spokesman for the Israeli Embassy in London blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas, which won elections in Gaza in 2006, for the situation there because it uses the territory to attack Israel. "The people of Gaza are the prisoners of the terrorist organization Hamas," the Israeli statement said.

headline: A Newspaper for Les Enfants
text: WHO is the founder and editor of the French newspaper Mon Quotidien? WHO, unconventionally speaking, works on the paper?

headline: Tiger Global Said to Buy Into LinkedIn
text: Tiger Global Management, a hedge fund founded by Chase Coleman, paid $20 million for a stake in LinkedIn, valuing the professional-networking website at more than $2 billion, two people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Ground Broken for Wind Energy Project in Mojave
text: Renewable energy developers broke ground Tuesday for a major expansion of wind-power generation in the Mojave Desert north of Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported.

text: Wall Street struggled Tuesday on reports that consumers had become more pessimistic about the job market and the overall economic recovery.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Busts Trades on Botched Bancorp Swap
text: A botched share swap last month in which 10 times more U.S. Bancorp shares were issued than planned, angering and confusing investors, led the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday to cancel three days of trades in the stock.

headline: Hess to Acquire American Oil & Gas
text: Hess Corporation, a United States energy company, said Tuesday that it would acquire the independent American Oil & Gas in an all-stock deal worth about $445 million as it expands its holdings in the Bakken oil play of North Dakota by around 85,000 acres.

headline: Telefonica Strikes Vivo Deal for $9.8 Billion
text: Telefónica of Spain won full control of the mobile phone joint venture it had with Portugal Telecom in Brazil after raising its bid for a third time, to 7.5 billion euros, thereby overcoming opposition from the Portuguese government, Raphael Minder reports in The New York Times.

headline: Do You Feel Awkward Talking to Your Friends in Person?
text: Housing officials at colleges and universities are finding that roommates are having difficulties resolving their differences because they feel uncomfortable having face-to-face conversations. Do you find it easier to converse with friends via text or instant message instead of in person?

headline: United’s Continental Deal Cleared for Take-Off in Europe
text: The parent company of United Airlines won unconditional regulatory approval from the European Union on Tuesday for its $3.17 billion buy of Continental Airlines that will create the world’s largest carrier, Reuters reported.

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Thai Union to Buy MWB in $884 Million Deal
text: Thai Union Frozen Products, a seafood exporter, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy MW Brands, a tuna canner, from Trilantic Capital Partners to form one of the world’s largest seafood companies. The deal values MW Brands at 680 million euros, or $884 million.

headline: Playlist: The Roots
text: The Roots' daily gig as the house band for “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” doesn't keep them from playing huge shows in Prospect Park or DJ-ing in Williamsburg.  Melena Ryzik reports.

headline: Private Equity Hits Back on Negative Report
text: The private equity industry, it seems, has not taken too kindly to a report from a London think-tank that took P.E. shops to task for charging high fees while providing disappointing average returns.

headline: Carlyle’s UCI International Eyes $200 Million I.P.O.
text: UCI International, a supplier of replacement parts for light and heavy-duty vehicles, is looking to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering, Renaissance Capital reported.

headline: Hong Kong Land Sale Brings in $1.3 Billion
text: Hong Kong on Wednesday auctioned a plot of land for 10.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.3 billion) in its third-most expensive land sale, beating forecasts and adding to fears of a bubble in one of the world’s hottest property markets, Reuters reported.

headline: Looking for Wedge From Spain, Catalonia Bans Bullfighting
text: MADRID  Lawmakers in the northeastern Spanish region of Catalonia voted to ban bullfighting on Wednesday, dealing the most significant blow so far to a tradition considered by many Spaniards to be an essential part of their cultural patrimony.

headline: 25 Dead in Afghanistan as Bus Hits Mine
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 25 people were killed early Wednesday in southern Afghanistan when a bus struck a roadside mine, officials said.

headline: The Age of Laura Linney
text: WITH THREE EMMYS, three Oscar nominations and two Tony nominations to her credit, Laura Linney could have easily been forgiven for treating her third Tony nomination — for “Time Stands Still,” which ran from January to March of this year — with a bit of a shrug, especially since she was certain she wouldn’t win. The statuette for Best Actress in a Play was expected to go to Viola Davis, for “Fences.” (And indeed it did.)

headline: Shares Fall As Data Says The Economy Is Weakening
text: Stocks fell on Wednesday after orders for durable goods unexpectedly decreased and the Federal Reserve said economic growth slowed in some areas.

headline: Health Department Revamps Restaurant Inspection Web Site
text: On Wednesday, as the New York City health department begins letter-grading restaurant inspections, designating an A, B or C to rate the cleanliness of more than 24,000 restaurants in the five boroughs, it is also activating a new Web site that will “offer much more information and be more user-friendly,” said Daniel Kass, a deputy commissioner.

headline: How Did We Know The Stimulus Was Too Small?
text: Those of us who say that the stimulus was too small are often accused of after-the-fact rationalization: you said this would work, but now that it hasn’t, you’re just saying it wasn’t big enough. The quick answer to that accusation is that people like me said that the stimulus was too small in advance. But the longer answer is that it’s all in the math: Keynesian analysis provides numbers as well as qualitative predictions, and given reasonable projections of the economy’s path in January 2009, the proposed stimulus just wasn’t big enough. Let’s go back to the tape, January 9, 2009:

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: It’s all about semantics. On a conference call Tuesday, BP said it was planning to “high-grade” its assets — newspeak for selling off whatever it must to keep its balance sheet in balance. That’s just one of the steps the oil giant will take as it embarks on what one hopes will be a safer chapter in its history. The full blueprint is here.

headline: Cap and Trade Is Dead. Long Live Cap and Trade.
text: Hard on the heels of the Senate Democratic leadership’s decision to put aside climate legislation intended to cap carbon dioxide emissions, another carbon-capping precinct was heard from this week.

headline: Military Cutbacks Redirect Boeing to Commercial Side
text: After a surge in military spending sustained Boeing through a downturn in civilian orders and manufacturing problems with a new jetliner over the last decade, the pendulum is swinging the other way.

headline: A New Concept in Health Care
text: It’s one of the hottest concepts to emerge from the discussions about how best to overhaul the nation’s health care system: accountable care organizations. The idea is to encourage groups of doctors or hospitals to work together to oversee medical care so quality improves and costs go down. Having captured the fancy of Washington, the organizations are even a part of the new health care law.

headline: Tell Us How the Heat Has Changed Your Life
text: On Sunday night, my wife and I settled in to watch “Mad Men” and we realized that it had been weeks since we had sat on our sofa. Our living room is an island without air-conditioning, and the July heat wave has forced us to abandon this room completely for cooler climes. (It was either that or prowl the streets before dawn.)

headline: Fed’s Report Shows Slowing Growth
text: While the economy has continued to pick up, growth has become uneven in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday in its latest regional report. In some regions, the Fed said, economic activity had started to slow.

headline: For Budget Chief, Not All Farewells Are Fond
text: WASHINGTON  There probably won’t be a lot of gift baskets or teary farewells from House Democrats when Peter R. Orszag officially steps down as White House budget director on Friday. This partly reflects the friction that always exists between a budget director, who seeks to impose the president’s priorities, and Congress, which tends to have a few of its own.

headline: Casey’s Rebuffs Couche-Tard, Unveils Buyback Plan
text: 12:12 p.m. | Updated with Couche-Tard statement Casey’s General Stores said on Wednesday that it has rejected the latest hostile offer by Alimentation Couche-Tard and will instead buy back up to 25 percent of its outstanding shares.

headline: More City Preschoolers Are Perfect, Test Scores Show
text: The number of prekindergarten students acing the city’s gifted and talented test spiked this year, with 1,000 4- and 5-year-olds reaching the 99th percentile, the highest possible, on the nationally scaled exam, the Department of Education said on Tuesday.

headline: Early Word: Off to New Jersey and New York
text: President’s Itinerary: Mr. Obama is traveling today to Edison, N.J., to have lunch with small-business owners and discuss the economy and small-business legislation in Congress. Afterward, the president will attend two Democratic Party fund-raisers in New York City. The Wall Street Journal estimates that about 50 people are expected to attend each fund-raiser, each paying $30,400, which is the maximum individual contribution permissible in a two-year election cycle. Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue Magazine, is hosting one event at her home. The guests will have a chance to meet one-on-one with Mr. Obama, who, as the Journal noted, is up to “a tough task given the many Wall Street executives who are put off by his rhetoric and policies.”  On his quick trip, the president will also sit down for an interview on ABC’s “The View.”

headline: Cheyenne Jackson Tells Us What He Can About His New ‘Glee’ Role
text: For the second time, Cheyenne Jackson has been cast in a key role on “Glee.” And he says he’s really looking forward to making his first appearance on the show.

headline: The S.S. World Trade Center Sets Sail

headline: Michigan Governor Warns of Oil Spill Threat
text: BATTLE CREEK, Mich.  Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm expressed growing worry on Wednesday that an oil spill, believed to be among the largest ever in the Midwest, might reach Lake Michigan if efforts to contain the oil were not strengthened.

headline: Mutual Respect: Scenes From the Aretha Franklin-Condoleezza Rice Concert
text: In a moment of cultural bipartisanship that political wags (i.e., the anchors on ABC’s “Good Morning America”) are already referring to as “the Diva and the Diplomat,” Aretha Franklin and Condoleezza Rice teamed up on Tuesday night at the Mann Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia for a concert to benefit inner-city youth programs and education initiatives. A review of the concert by Steve Smith will follow; in the meantime, The Associated Press has posted the above video package which features Ms. Franklin and Ms. Rice’s duet on “I Say a Little Prayer.” (Only one performer sings, and it’s the one you’re expecting.)

headline: Wednesday Reading: More Social Shopping on Amazon
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A New Risk Factor: Your Social Life
text: Social relationships are just as important to health as other common risk factors like smoking, lack of exercise or obesity, new research shows.

headline: Blanc Brings Accountability to France Job
text: Since Laurent Blanc was named coach of France, he has introduced a sense of accountability lacking under his predecessor, Raymond Domenech.

headline: Patient Voices: Scleroderma
text: Tightening skin, stiffening joints, digestive difficulties and shortness of breath — six people with scleroderma speak.

headline: Ask an Expert About Scleroderma
text: In the latest Patient Voices series, six men and women talk about scleroderma, a disease that causes gradual hardening of the skin and blood vessels and that can damage the lungs and other organs. Like many autoimmune disorders, scleroderma remains something of a mystery, though researchers are exploring new treatments for the disease.

headline: Paul Revere, Rat Zoos and the GTL Index
text: The sunsetting of a 2002 agreement on community gardens has some advocates and bloggers feeling like Paul Revere.

headline: The Originals | Tarik Malak
text: “Having one foot firmly placed in the fashion world with the other in the world of technology is my biggest asset at this point,” says Tarik Malak, the Parisian-born owner of digital media’s freshest face, Swell NY. Malak has already made a name for himself with La Boutique, the company he co-founded and brought to the forefront of the photo retouching world, working with clients like Diane von Furstenberg, Redken and Swarovski. With the switch from still photography to moving images being one of the most relevant topics of discussion in the fashion world today, this new agency finds itself in a fantastic position.

headline: An End to Gay-Adoption Bans?
text: Data drives policy. Or, at least, it should. In recent months there have been several studies suggesting that children raised by same-sex couples are certainly no worse off (and in some ways are arguably better off) than children raised by heterosexual couples.

headline: A Push for Action on Renewables
text: With a cap on carbon dioxide an apparent nonstarter in the Senate these days, some clean energy and climate advocates have shifted their sights to a scaled-back but still ambitious goal: passage of a national renewable electricity standard.

headline: Nimoy Photos Show People’s All-Human Personalities
text: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.  A few people have bought a Leonard Nimoy photograph without knowing who Leonard Nimoy is. Most likely they are migrants who arrived here through a wormhole from the Gamma Quadrant, where “Star Trek” reruns have yet to penetrate.

headline: The Voices of Scleroderma
text: The latest installment of Patient Voices focuses on scleroderma, an autoimmune disease that can lead to hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. The symptoms and severity of scleroderma can vary, making it difficult to accomplish everyday tasks or, in some cases, threatening vital organs.

headline: My So-Called Quantitative Life
text: Last night, I fell into a deep sleep almost as soon as my head hit the pillow.

headline: Mini Returns to Rallying Roots
text: Nearly a half-century after little Mini took on the mighty of automobile rally racing, and beat them, the brand is about to get down in the mud — and gravel and wet — once again.

headline: The Young Women of the F.L.D.S.
text: Inside the lives of some of the Yearning for Zion Ranch’s exiles.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Double Double Bill
text: Perhaps lies loom larger in the open air. I have rarely been as conscious of the levels of duplicity in the “Henry IV” plays as I was on Sunday at Shakespeare’s Globe, where I saw a double header of Dominic Dromgoole’s productions of Parts I and II. It was a good day for theater al fresco: sunny, breezy, achingly clear. Only man – that great pretender — was vile, at least as embodied on the stage, which of course made the six hours it takes to perform “Henry IV: Parts I and II” pass all the faster.

headline: S.E.C. Said to See New Limits on Its Disclosures
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission apparently no longer has to comply with requests for information from the public, including those filed under the Freedom of Information Act, because of a little-noticed provision in the new financial regulations that became law last week, the Fox Business Network reports.

headline: Ex-Judge Recommends No Charges Against Paterson
text: Updated, 1:28 p.m. | The retired judge investigating Gov. David A. Paterson‘s intervention in a domestic violence case involving a former top aide will not recommend any charges against the governor, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Tilting Power to Executive Branch
text: In his latest Political Times column, The Times’s Matt Bai considers how recent efforts from Peter Orszag, the outgoing budget director, and other White House officials appear to have “signaled that an administration populated from the top down by Capitol Hill alumni is intent on altering the balance of power between the branches of government.”  Post a Comment

headline: Standards Raised, More Students Fail Tests
text: Applying new, tougher standards, state education officials said Wednesday that more than half of public school students in New York City failed their English exams this year, and 54 percent of them passed in math.

headline: The Arcade Fire: Beyond Indie
text: QUEBEC

headline: Quote Unquote | Bio Hazzard
text: –The Coco & Igor star, Anna Mouglalis, questions whether Coco Chanel would have approved of the film. At least she doesn’t have to question how disappointed Karl Lagerfeld was.

headline: Another Big Gift for Yale Theater
text: Yale Repertory Theater is on a fund-raising hot streak. After announcing last week that it had received a $950,000 donation from the Robina Foundation, the theater said on Tuesday that it had received a $1 million gift from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation aimed at supporting new commissions and productions under the auspices of the Yale Center for New Theater.

headline: PayPal Sends Checks in India
text: New Delhi — PayPal’s business in India has hit another barrier. This week the company told customers here, which include thousands of small Internet businesses with foreign clients, that beginning Aug. 1 they will no longer be able to transfer cash electronically from the online payment network into their local bank accounts. Instead, PayPal will send them a check.

headline: The Web’s View of Stocks
text: Ever get overwhelmed trying to keep up with all the information available online about stocks and what that information could mean for your investments?

headline: Move to Restrict Pain Killers Puts Onus on Doctors
text: In an unusual move, a state government is developing regulations meant to stop doctors from prescribing higher doses of powerful  and often dangerous  pain killers for patients who are not benefiting from them.

headline: What We’re Reading: Tech Heirlooms
text: Here’s where the tech reporters and editors of the New York Times paused on the Web:

headline: How to Make Chess Sizzle
text: For years, chess players have bemoaned that chess is not as popular as poker, particularly when it comes to attracting television coverage.

headline: Russia Moves to Sell Shares in State Companies
text: MOSCOW  The Russian government, which just a few years ago was salting away billions of dollars in oil revenue, is now confronting such a gaping budget deficit that ministers approved a wide-ranging plan on Wednesday to sell off state property, senior officials said.

headline: Why Don’t More Cameras Offer GPS?
text: I’ve seen a lot of new point-and-shoot cameras over the past couple of weeks as camera makers announce their new summer lineups. A few have demonstrated solid new improvements that should deliver better photos. But one feature that I had been hoping to see — a built-in GPS receiver for geo-tagging photos — wasn’t offered on a single new camera.

headline: New York State May Increase Taxes on Hotels
text: If New York’s state budget passes, tourists could wind up paying more for hotels booked through third parties like Liberty Travel, Globus Tours and Travelocity.

headline: Bangladesh Garment Workers Awarded Higher Pay
text: MUMBAI, India  A government oversight board in Bangladesh nearly doubled minimum wages in the important garment industry on Wednesday, but the new benchmark is still well short of what workers’ groups had been demanding.

headline: He’s Like a Rainbow: Ronnie Wood of the Rolling Stones to Have Art Show in Ohio
text: They may be only the paintings and other artworks created by a well-known rock ‘n’ roll guitarist, but the Butler Institute of American Art likes them — enough to give Ronnie Wood of the Rolling Stones an eight-week exhibition there that the museum says is the first American show of Mr. Wood’s art.

headline: TimesCast | July 28, 2010
text: Today, oil on the Gulf's surface is clearing up faster than expected, a Russian policeman uses YouTube to battle corruption and New York City begins a grading system to keep restaurants in check.

headline: The Outlier
text: I was about to post a hail-and-farewell to the veteran journalist Daniel Schorr, who died last week, not only because of his long and distinguished broadcast career, but also because I’d heard him capably analyzing the news on NPR’s “Weekend Edition” just a couple of weeks ago. He was about to turn 94.

headline: Fantasy Football Rankings: Running Backs
text: Jason and Justin Sablich, The Times’s in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Brothers Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

headline: Former Nazi Guard, 88, Charged in Mass Murder of Jews
text: BERLIN  German prosecutors have charged an 88-year-old former Nazi guard with aiding in the murders of 430,000 Jews at the Belzec death camp during World War II, and with shooting 10 people himself during his time there.

headline: Summer Pleasures | A Pool Among the Dunes
text: Perhaps if I had been able to fix this image in my mind a month ago, I would have survived the dog days of July with a little more … well, cool. When Judy and Ted Goldsmith approached Madderlake Designs to design a pool at their house on the Long Island shore about a decade ago, the brief was as follows: Include a lap pool for Ted and a wading pool for Judy and the grandchildren, and make it all invisible from the house. “All they wanted to see was waving grasses,” said Tom Pritchard, a partner in Madderlake, which started out in 1971 as an elegant plant store with an architectural practice on the side, and which is now a thriving architecture and landscape design firm, with projects from Connecticut to Colorado.

headline: In the Middle of Nowhere, Snooping on Sea Turtles
text: From the porch of my cabin here at the Palmyra Atoll National Wildlife Refuge in the Central Pacific my eyes take in an iconic tropical island paradise — white, sandy beaches; palm trees swaying in the gentle breeze; sea birds diving into the water and big fish jumping out of the water … and I know just around the corner are gorgeous coral reefs teeming with brightly colored fish in the crystal blue sea. We are smack in the middle of nowhere, just above the equator in the Pacific — about a thousand miles south of Hawaii.

headline: Jury Deliberation Begins in Blagojevich Trial
text: CHICAGO  Jurors on Wednesday began deliberating the fate of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois who was impeached and ousted from office and now faces 24 counts in a federal corruption trial.

headline: Summer’s Stock: Angst
text: THE beach read has become an accepted, even cherished, facet of American culture. When we leap past Memorial Day and sandy shores beckon, even serious readers are allowed to stuff something light in their tote bags. One year it’s the badly written roman à clef by the assistant at Vogue, the next it’s the badly written thriller yoking together international intrigue and arcane history. Nobody is expected to plop down amid the dunes, slather on the SPF 15 and crack open Dostoyevsky.

headline: M.T.A. Moves Ahead With Plan to Raise Fares and Tolls
text: Updated, 11:36 a.m. Thursday | The $104 monthly MetroCard moved one step closer to reality on Wednesday as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted to start the process of implementing a sprawling set of fare increases on the region’s buses, trains and bridges.

headline: Test Yourself | July 28, 2010
text: This week, in conjunction with Math for America, we’re providing math problems based on Times articles. Today’s question was written by Patrick Honner at MfA, based on a Times article by Justin Gillis about the Gulf oil spill.

headline: Alvin Ailey Celebrates 50 Years
text: Images of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater from the past and present.

headline: Photographer Sues ‘Fela!’ Producers Over Image Used in Show
text: A Brooklyn photographer is suing the producers of the Broadway musical “Fela!” in federal court for copyright and trademark infringement, seeking at least $150,000 in damages for their use of her 1977 photograph of the legendary Nigerian nightclub of the Afrobeat musician Fela Kuti.

headline: Seeing the World Around You Through Your Phone
text: I have faith that once the novelty of the coolest new smartphone feature wears off, I will again walk the streets with my eyes open to the world around me, not to the screen of a smartphone.

headline: An Oil Slick to Rival Oklahoma
text: With no more oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico from the the blown-out BP well, the surface oil slick seems to be breaking down rapidly, as Campbell Robertson and I report in Wednesday’s paper. That the surface oil would fade away is no surprise: scientists have long understood how oil weathers and dissipates in the environment.

headline: Judge Blocks Arizona’s Immigration Law
text: PHOENIX  A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the most controversial parts of Arizona’s immigration enforcement law from going into effect, a ruling that at least temporarily squashed a state policy that had inflamed the national debate over immigration.

headline: Uncertainty in Senate Over Hearing on Russia Treaty
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John Kerry, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, put the New Start arms control treaty with Russia on his panel’s schedule for next week but then left open the possibility on Wednesday that he might not call a vote after all.

headline: The Roving Runner Rides a Bike
text: Our Roving Runner columnist Brian Fidelman has been sidelined by injury, but that hasn’t stopped him from exploring New York by bicycle. Recently he wrote about tackling three mountain biking trails in the city.

headline: A Look at Icahn’s Canadian Challenge to Lions Gate
text: I unfortunately do not have the time today for a full post, but I wanted to follow up on my post on Tuesday about the dispute between Lions Gate Entertainment and Carl C. Icahn and my promise to comment on the British Columbia lawsuit as soon as I obtained the papers. Set forth below is a copy of the amended petition that Mr. Icahn’s funds filed on with the Supreme Court of British Columbia, where the movie studio has its headquarters. This is the equivalent of a complaint filed in an American court.

headline: What Not to Say to Your Insurer
text: Updated: Fixed a typo in the second paragraph

headline: Summer's Sturm und Drang
text: A look at some of the gloomy shows on New York stages this summer.

headline: West Virginia Coal Baron Takes Greenbrier Back to the Future
text: After a week in St. Andrews, Scotland, followed by a week in Ontario, Canada, some touring pros at the Greenbrier’s Old White Course for this week’s Greenbrier Classic may feel they have been transported back to a more elegant time and place.

headline: Mark Twain’s Southern Cooking
text: Reviewing Jane Ziegelman’s “97 Orchard” in today’s Arts section, Dwight Garner talks entertainingly about the recent fad for “food historicism,” predicting it will eventually yield titles like “1897: The Year the Oysters Tasted a Bit Dubious.”

headline: Europe’s Two-Speed Economy: North Vs. South
text: The danger of a two-speed recovery across the 16-member euro zone, economists warn, is getting worse with every new notch of belt-tightening that European governments apply to reduce high debts and deficits.

headline: Making Them Look Like All-Stars
text: As Ben Shpigel pointed out in his report about the Yankees’ 4-1 loss to the Cleveland Indians on Tuesday night, the Yankees continued a troubling trend. They have now lost six straight games to pitchers making their major league debut, a streak that stretches to 2004. Here is what the neophytes did against the Yankees, and what they have done since.

headline: In Praise of Progress
text: David Brooks: Gail, as you know, I am often powerless. I mean that in the literal as well as political sense. About four times a year my Maryland neighborhood loses electricity. We lost it for nine days or so during the snow last winter. We stuck it out in the freezing house for three days before fleeing to Embassy Suites. We just lost it for two as a result of a recent summer storm.

headline: The White Anxiety Debate, Continued
text: Princeton’s Thomas Espenshade, the co-author of “No Longer Separate, Not Yet Equal: Race and Class in Elite College Admission and Campus Life,” has written a response to my recent interpretation of his book’s findings:

headline: The High Low | Calypso Shirtdress, $95
text: What: Calypso ShirtdressHow Much: $95 at calypso-celle.comWho: T’s associate fashion editor, Bifen Xu

headline: Eminem Stays on Top
text: Eminem fended off a new release by the rapper Rick Ross to remain in the top spot on the Billboard album chart for the fifth week in a row. Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) sold 187,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Ross’s “Teflon Don” (Maybach Music/Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam) reached No. 2 with 176,000. Sheryl Crow’s new album “100 Miles From Memphis” (A&M) opened at No. 3 with 55,000 sales, Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 4 with 47,000, and the new “Kidz Bop 18” (Razor & Tie) is No. 5 with 43,000. Also new this week, the soundtrack to the Jonas Brothers’ new television series, “Jonas L.A.” (Disney), opened at No. 7 with 32,000.

headline: Staples Hit With String of Burglaries, Police Say
text: Four men with a seemingly limitless appetite for office supplies have burglarized Staples stores in Manhattan at least seven times this year, the police say. The police released the above photographs of the suspects Tuesday night.

headline: Shopping With Madeline Weinrib
text: The New York textile designer uses summer table accessories to change the mood of a room.

headline: Reliable Dictation, Down to a ‘T’
text: Nuance, the company that makes Dragon NaturallySpeaking for Windows, is in a pretty sweet position: It’s essentially a monopoly. One by one, its competitors in the speech-recognition business have either left the market (Philips), gone out of business (Lernout & Hauspie) or turned over its product to Nuance (I.B.M.). Even the sole Mac speech-recognition program, MacSpeech Dictate, can no longer be considered a kind of rival; Nuance bought it this year.

headline: Making Do With Public Money
text: In a year when millionaires around the country are tapping their bank accounts to fuel their own campaigns for governor and the United States Senate, one candidate in Connecticut hopes to turn his lack of a fortune into an asset.

headline: Food Photography: Four Manual Settings You Need to Know for Shooting Food
text: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

headline: Berra, in the Hospital Since Mid-July, Is Released
text: Yogi Berra, who missed Old-Timers’ Day at Yankee Stadium and the Baseball Hall of Fame induction ceremony in Cooperstown, N.Y., after injuries from a fall on July 16, was released from the hospital Wednesday morning.

headline: Williamsburg, 2:00 P.M.
text: Driggs Pizza. Woof.

headline: Candidates Matches Moved to Russia
text: Despite the threat of a boycott and a public letter of protest about their format, the candidates matches for the World Chess Championship have been moved to Kazan, Russia, from Azerbaijan, by the World Chess Federation, according to several reports.

headline: Theo Albrecht, Who Helped Build Aldi Grocery Chain, Dies at 88
text: FRANKFURT — Theo Albrecht, who with his brother Karl used lessons learned in the lean years of postwar Germany to build an international grocery empire, died Saturday in Essen, Germany. He was 88.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: For A-Rod’s 600th, It’s Not Just When but Where
text: Alex Rodriguez looked a bit off Tuesday night in his pursuit of home run No. 600. But he still has a 41 percent chance of reaching the milestone at Progressive Field in Cleveland over the next two days, say our friends at SeatGeek.com and HitTrackerOnline.com.

headline: 152 Killed in Plane Crash Near Islamabad
text: Two Americans were among the dead when a jetliner slammed into wooded hills near Islamabad amid dense fog and heavy rain on Wednesday.

headline: Bloomberg Wields His Wallet to Push His Agenda
text: When he’s not busy running city government, sparring with Albany lawmakers or jetting to the tropics, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been known to hold a good fund-raiser.

headline: With Squeeze on Credit, Microlending Blossoms
text: Amanda Keppert is convinced that she would have lost Mandy’s Korner, her hot dog stand in San Jose, Calif., if she had not received a type of loan that is more common in the third world than in the United States.

headline: Paris Collections
text: Alexander McQueen showed a collection that seemed to almost dare anyone to match him for know-how and imagination.

headline: ‘Inception’: The Critic In the Mirror

headline: Can Microloans Help American Small Businesses?
text: Despite being based in one of America’s great centers of entrepreneurship (Silicon Valley), Amanda Keppert and her hot dog business, pictured above, needed the help of a tool more commonly associated with centers of third world poverty: microfinance. Ms. Keppert, as Kristina Shevory writes in a just published article, obtained a $6,500 loan through Kiva, which has lent more than $140 million in 53 countries.

headline: Brazil on Track for 2014 Despite Early Criticism of Stadium Plan
text: Less than a month after the conclusion of a successful World Cup tournament in South Africa, the Brazilian sports minister touted the promise of the 2014 tournament in Brazil and responded to familiar concerns over the readiness of stadiums.

headline: In Arkansas, a Castle Rises
text: BRAD FIRE CLOUD, stonecutter, paused from his toil on a recent steamy Arkansas morning as sweat streamed into his short, black beard. Dressed in the dun-colored tunic and pants of a feudal worker  albeit one wearing OSHA-mandated steel-toed boots  Mr. Fire Cloud assessed the 70-pound chunk of limestone he had been hewing into a smooth block with hammer and chisel. “This’ll be for an archway of the castle,” he said in the melodious drawl of his native Ozark Mountains, while nodding toward the massive fortress taking shape in the forest clearing behind him.

headline: 1900: Raspberry Vinegar
text: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article titled “Women Here and There — Their Frills and Fancies.” You may halve or quarter the recipe.

headline: Raspberry Vinegar Tart
text: By Allison Kave, the owner of First Prize Pies in Manhattan

headline: 2010: Raspberry Vinegar Float
text: By Joanne Weir, the author of “Tequila”

headline: Raspberry Vinegar: 1900
text: There are preserves makers who responsibly focus on sustenance, like jams, and then there are preserves makers who home in on impractical pleasures, like syrups and vinegars for cocktails.

headline: A Novartis Giveaway of Medicine
text: The Swiss drug giant Novartis plans to give away up to 250,000 bottles of its new liquid children’s medicine, Triaminic Fever Reducer Pain Reliever, in an effort to woo parents frustrated by a nationwide recall and shortage of a competing product  liquid children’s Tylenol.

headline: Obama Meets Small-Business Owners
text: EDISON, N.J. – President Obama met with several small-business owners at a sandwich shop here on Wednesday to promote his economic agenda and additional stimulus measures pending in the Senate, as Democrats seek election-year support from a business group that traditionally allies with Republicans.

headline: Lazard’s Case for a Restructuring Rebound
text: Restructuring revenue fell in the second quarter for Lazard, the independent investment bank and one of the biggest players in the reorganization business. But the firm sees that unit picking up steam again soon.

headline: Mysteries and Obscurities, Many by Ghosts
text: Lately it’s been too hot to think, never mind schlep around Chelsea, though a large summer group show at David Zwirner called “The Evryali Score” has made such exertions worthwhile.

headline: Huge Set for ‘The Ring’ Arrives at the Met
text: The leviathan has landed. The 45-ton set for the Metropolitan Opera’s new Wagner “Ring” cycle created by Robert Lepage has arrived at the house. On Wednesday, it passed a key test when it was rolled from a wing onto center stage. The trial run was delayed by several hours when an inspecting engineer found that the metal structure underneath the stage needed some touch-up welding.

headline: Lady Gaga: When Surface Is Depth
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Meal Brought to You by the Letter A
text: The joy inside Spark’s Deli was not entirely unalloyed on Wednesday, even as the restaurant, in Long Island City, Queens, posted a big blue A — the first letter grade assigned in city health officials’ new inspection regime.

headline: A Quirk in Samsung’s New Phones
text: I’ve been testing two Samsung Galaxy S phones for some weeks — the Captivate from AT&T and the Vibrant from T-Mobile. Both are great phones. But I noticed something unusual when I tried to use television apps on them.

headline: Parenting in the Side-View Mirror
text: My 16-year-old son has his learner’s permit. Which means I am having flashbacks. To my father starting me out between the lines of an empty parking lot in a shopping mall (back when malls were still closed on Sundays). To my mother hanging on to the passenger-side handle and trying not to be obvious about it. To the car simulators and “Death on Prom Night” films that were part of my school’s driver-education class (back when school budgets allowed). To the fact that neither my parents nor my instructor wanted to take me on the highway, so the first time I switched lanes in fast-moving traffic was alone after I had my license.

headline: Pairing Okra With Corn Pancakes
text: I’d never eaten okra until I lived in England as a student in the 1970s, when I had it in back-street Indian restaurants that probably weren’t very good but  offered cheap, very flavorful food. Come to think of it, I’d never eaten Indian food before either — and had never even seen many of its components. I have a clear memory of picking a cardamom pod out of my dinner and asking the waiter what it was. (He kindly gave me a dozen or so pods to put in my pocket and take back to my damp, chilly room, where I happily gnawed on them over the next few days.)

headline: Snowe to Vote Yes on Kagan Nomination
text: Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine announced Wednesday that she would vote to confirm Solicitor General Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court, making her the fourth Senate Republican to back Ms. Kagan, President Obama’s nominee.

headline: Migraines and the Menstrual Cycle
text: Several readers had questions for the Consults blog about hormones and migraines. Here, Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic responds to one reader who wondered if birth control pills can prevent migraines tied to the menstrual cycle.

headline: ConocoPhillips to Sell Its Stake in Lukoil
text: ConocoPhillips said Wednesday that it would sell its entire holdings in the Russian oil company Lukoil by the end of next year, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Damon Dash, Hip-Hop Entrepreneur, Sells Condo
text: “CAN I get a whoop whoop?” the singers call out in a song by the rapper Jay-Z.

headline: Hans Zimmer Extracts the Secrets of the ‘Inception’ Score
text: Having systematically picked apart the critical arguments for and against Christopher Nolan‘s film “Inception” and the many possible meanings of that dream-within-a-dream-within-a-dream caper, the Web this week went another level into the movie by focusing on its music.

headline: Vain Glorious | Hampton Sun Serious Shimmer Cooling Spray
text: What: Hampton Sun Serious Shimmer Cooling Spray in Bronze.

headline: Congress Moves to Narrow Cocaine Sentencing Disparities
text: The House of Representatives passed a bill on Wednesday that would reduce the disparities between mandatory federal sentences for crack and powder cocaine violations, a step toward ending what legal experts say have been unfairly harsh punishments imposed mainly on blacks.

headline: Russia Moves to Sell Shares in State Companies
text: The Russian government, which just a few years ago was salting away billions of dollars in oil revenue, is now confronting such a gaping budget deficit that ministers approved a wide-ranging plan Wednesday to sell off state property, senior officials said, according to The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer.

headline: Nascar Team Owner in Plane Crash
text: Jack Roush, the co-owner of Roush Fenway Racing, and a passenger, Brenda Strickland of Plymouth, Mich., were hospitalized Tuesday evening for injuries after a plane he was piloting crashed and split apart while attempting to land at Wittman Regional Airport in Oshkosh, Wis.

headline: The $41,000 Question: Is the Chevy Volt Worth the Money?
text: General Motors, after announcing on Tuesday that the Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid car would cost $41,000, was unfazed by inevitable comparisons to the Nissan Leaf, a battery electric car that will arrive in select markets at the end of the year, around the same time as the Volt. At $32,780, the Leaf is far less expensive.

headline: The First Letter Grade Is Assigned in Long Island City
text: Over on City Room, the Dining section’s Glenn Collins paid witness to the first letter grade assigned in city health officials’ new inspection regime. Spark’s Deli in Long Island City, Queens, was the lucky recipient.

headline: Viñoly to Design Kennedy Institute
text: The architect Rafael Viñoly has been chosen to design the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate, a memorial and educational center dedicated to the career of Mr. Kennedy, who died of cancer in 2009, the institute announced Wednesday. A white-and-gray complex overlooking Boston Harbor, the institute will stand beside the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum on the campus of the University of Massachusetts, Boston. It will include classrooms, a replica of Mr. Kennedy’s Senate office and a re-creation of the Senate chamber with interactive desktops to provide information about the senators who have served in those seats and their voting records. Construction is expected to begin in the fall.

headline: A 6-Acre Preserve Where Artists Roam
text: Water Mill, N.Y.

headline: Biden Welcomes Troops Back Home
text: The White House kicked off Wednesday a month of events intended to mark the reduction of United States forces in Iraq, the culmination of a campaign promise that helped vault Barack Obama to the presidency.

headline: California Fires Rage On
text: Tens of thousands of people were ordered to evacuate as wildfires continued to spread across southern California.

headline: Mona Simpson Writes for Crowds, and Avoids Them
text: MONA SIMPSON wanted to see the Matisse.

headline: Democrats to Talk Up the Tea Party
text: Many Republicans have been very eager to associate themselves with Tea Party followers, hoping to tap into the movement’s deep enthusiasm. Now Democrats say they are more than willing to help Republicans do so.

headline: In Competition for Your Nose
text: THERE are dozens of glass bottles on the new bar at the Naturopathica day spa in East Hampton, N.Y., each with the name of an essential oil  tea tree, tobacco, vetivert, ylang-ylang, to name just a few  and each stamped with the date that the plant’s essence was distilled.

headline: Chart Abuse
text: Maybe it’s the former graphics/art director in me, but I get really offended when people use charts to confuse rather than to clarify.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kandahar Province and Elsewhere
text: Rodrigo Abd of The Associated Press continued his incisive work in Afghanistan on Wednesday, as did Brennan Linsley, another member of The A.P.’s distinguished team. Immersion is the theme of the slide show’s finale.

headline: An Underground Duo Finds Unfamiliar Perch Atop the Charts
text: The Black Keys had just finished bashing through a song called “Strange Times” at Central Park SummerStage on Tuesday night when Dan Auerbach, the band’s guitarist and singer, made an announcement. “We’re going to bring some friends out to help us out with some new songs,” he said cheerfully, eyes scanning the crowd. “So don’t be alarmed,” he added. “They’re locals.”

headline: Telefónica Wins Full Control of Brazil Phone Venture
text: MADRID  Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications company, has won full control of Vivo, the mobile phone venture it had with Portugal Telecom in Brazil, after raising its bid for a third time, to 7.5 billion euros, thereby overcoming opposition from the Portuguese government.

headline: Embracing the Old, Winking at Fans
text: Billy Corgan made himself ingratiating when he led Smashing Pumpkins at Terminal 5 on Monday night. Between songs that vent frustrated fury or plunge into tumultuous love  rarely anything in between  he smiled a lot. He thanked the audience repeatedly. He jokingly apologized to longtime fans “for what I’ve done to you.” He pretended he would abruptly end the concert, then reversed himself, declaring: “The concert ends when you say so. I’m your little rock ’n’ roll puppet. I do what you want me to do.” Then he raised both hands in the air, moving like a marionette.

headline: ‘Step Away From the Camera!’
text: At the risk of compromising national security, Lens would like to present this nighttime view of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, taken on Tuesday by George Hahn, a 39-year-old Web site designer who lives nearby in Manhattan.

headline: Lending Tightened in 2nd Quarter for Businesses in Europe
text: FRANKFURT  Business loans were harder to come by in the second quarter of 2010, the European Central Bank said Wednesday, as banks themselves had trouble raising money to lend to customers.

headline: A Former Secretary of State Has an Audience With the Queen
text: PHILADELPHIA  Heard the one about the secretary of state and the Queen of Soul? There was no question that Condoleezza Rice had been a subject of intense scrutiny for crowds far tougher than the one she faced at the Mann Center for the Performing Arts here on Tuesday. Still, this engagement was not without its own pressure. Ms. Rice, revealed as a classically trained pianist during her years in government, was here by royal edict: Aretha Franklin, having learned of Ms. Rice’s avocation, proposed a summit meeting for a charity concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra.

headline: Forever 21: Four Floors, One Mission. Go.
text: FOR a shopping trip, you need free time and a desire for beauty. For an invasion, you need a brigade. Forever 21 in Times Square is all battlefield, four floors of fast fashion and sensory deprivation. It required a tactical team.

headline: If It’s Summer, It Must Be Mostly Mozart Time Again
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival, now in its 44th year, has been able to coast for long stretches on the strength of its attractively alliterative name. It did so through the 1970s; but as inertia took its toll, Lincoln Center installed Gerard Schwarz as music director, presumably hoping he would bring consistency to the festival orchestra’s performances and freshen up its programs. That worked until Lincoln Center came up with the ill-conceived notion of commemorating the bicentenary of Mozart’s death by playing every note of his music, and shunting some of the dullest works onto the 1992 Mostly Mozart schedule.

headline: That’s Life: ‘Come Fly Away’ to Close
text: “Come Fly Away,” the Broadway musical that married the choreography of Twyla Tharp with the music of Frank Sinatra, announced it will close at the Marquis Theater on Sunday, Sept. 5. The show will have played 26 previews and 187 regular performances. A national tour is scheduled to open in Chicago next March.

headline: Plus-Size Wars
text: Earlier this year, the editors of V, a magazine so recherché it can make Vogue seem like Redbook, published an issue featuring large models in expensive body-baring clothes. In one photograph, a woman in a strapless bathing suit, cut to reveal three rolls of flesh, grabs at her platform stilettos. In another, Tara Lynn, a size 16 model, is clad in nothing but a pair of Dior sandals.

headline: Cherry Lane Says Stage to Darken Over Deficit
text: The Cherry Lane Theater will not produce plays on its main stage for a year beginning in September, and possibly longer, to buy time to cope with a deficit of roughly $167,000 through the 2010 fiscal year.

headline: Georgian Minister Rues Nightclub Photo
text: Updated | Thursday | 10:00 a.m. Among the lessons Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili has probably learned this week: the next time he decides to appoint a 28-year-old woman with little more professional experience than working for her family’s bread company to run a government ministry, he really should remember to ask her to remove any photographs posted on the Web that even appear to suggest that she has danced on a table with strippers in a nightclub.

headline: Learning a Language From an Expert, on the Web
text: The message from the 14-year-old Tunisian skateboarder was curt. “Totally wrong,” he said of my French. My conjugation was off and I should study spelling. On a scale of one to five, he said, my French practice essay was worth a one. Then he disappeared into the anonymity of the Internet.

headline: Islam Meets Reality TV in Malaysia
text: On “Imam Muda,” or “Young Leader” — a Malaysian foray into religious-themed reality television — contestants vie for a cash prize, an all-expenses-paid pilgrimage to Mecca and a job as an imam.

headline: Testifying to a Time Gone by and Absent Friends
text: Of all of New York’s mid-’90s hip-hop bruisers, Fat Joe is an unlikely survivor. At best a deliberate rapper  and at worst lumpy  he’s succeeded with consistent applications of pressure and heart, as well as a willingness to abandon his grimy roots, as needed, in search of a hit.

text: CLOSING

headline: In the War on Bedbugs, a New Attack Strategy
text: Bedbugs, the seed-size insects that have invaded mattresses, couches and laundry baskets everywhere, are now officially on New York City’s hit list.

text: Portraits by Leonard Nimoy.

headline: Yoga’s Serious. Except When It’s Not.
text: IN mid-July, while the oil slick in the Gulf and the Goldman Sachs settlement were dominating the news, a blog named YogaDork had a worldwide exclusive.

headline: Marveling at Wonders Out of This World
text: WASHINGTON  When I was very young, I cherished a collection of “space cards”  trading cards that accompanied packs of bubble gum  offering exotic visions that supposedly would soon be within reach: space ships gliding through Saturn’s rings; explorers enduring a Venus dust storm; loopy Technicolor Martians making their first contact with visiting Earthlings.

headline: Dissecting the Reality of a Tax Fantasy
text: Over at Fortune, Allan Sloan explains how the managers of the biggest buyout firms are able to fulfill a dream that eludes most people — namely, “pay as little in taxes as possible” and “have someone else pick up the tab” for any taxes that remain.

headline: Militant Alliance Adds to Somalia’s Turmoil
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  An insurgent commander based in the semiautonomous region of Puntland in northern Somalia has pledged his allegiance to the Shabab militant group, a move that threatens to destabilize a part of Somalia that had been relatively peaceful.

text: Bright Lights,

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Obama on “The View.” Impossibility of controlling the conversation may adequately prepare him for the November elections.

headline: Election-Year Sparring Threatens Oil Bill
text: If Democrats thought scaling back their clean energy bills would ease the political challenges of passing legislation addressing drilling regulation and the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, they were wrong.

headline: The Hikers in Iran: One Year Later
text: This Saturday will mark the one year anniversary of the detainment and imprisonment of three young Americans in Iran. On July 31, 2009, Shane Bauer, Sarah Shourd, and Josh Fattal were hiking in the Zagros Mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan.

headline: The Nonpersistence of ... What’s That Remembering Thing Called Again?
text: A single overarching preoccupation connects the six brooding stories in Anthony Doerr’s “Memory Wall.” It is Mr. Doerr’s relentless fascination with memory and with the way memories are destroyed, eroded, drowned, faded or eaten away. “How can it be such a frail, perishable thing?” he asks about memory in the title story. He finds an assortment of somber ways to answer that question again and again.

headline: Group Reports Progress Fighting Corporate Bribery
text: PARIS  Efforts to stop companies in advanced economies from bribing foreign officials to win contracts are improving, although a “disturbing” number of governments are still not keeping their commitments in this area, an advocacy group said in a report released Wednesday.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Anthony Doerr
text: Anthony Doerr’s new collection, “Memory Wall,” is reviewed in Thursday’s paper.

headline: A Reality Show Where Islam Is the Biggest Star
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Bright studio spotlights illuminated the faces of four nervous young men, arms linked as they anxiously awaited their fate. Cameramen stood poised, ready to capture the climactic moment. Finally, the chief judge broke the suspense.

headline: Degrees of Style Amid the Swelter
text: IN the cool of the evening light/ the girls in their summer clothes pass me by ... me by ... me by. ...

headline: Winston Churchill Goes Digital
text: CAMBRIDGE, England — You’re a high school or college student, or a journalist, psychologist or historian, and you have a paper to write on Winston Churchill’s “finest hour” speech from June 18, 1940, arguably his most stirring moment in World War II. But you want to go beyond the famous lyric of defiance he delivered in the House of Commons and learn how he progressed in his own mind to that moment, and what private doubts he had — as he did — about Britain’s ability to withstand Hitler.

headline: Both Sides of the Border
text: FOR her new fall line, the designer Pamela Love found somewhat unlikely inspiration in Mexico’s Day of the Dead and the Wild West (Two Tone Dagger Cuff, sterling silver and bronze, $1,150; Triple Finger Rope Ring, sterling silver, $415).

headline: State of the Climate: Hottest Decade on Record
text: The past decade was the hottest recorded, part of an unequivocal pattern of warming dating back 50 years, a National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration report declared on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Fela!’ Producers Sued Over Image in Show
text: A Brooklyn photographer is suing the producers of the Broadway musical “Fela!” in federal court for copyright and trademark infringement, seeking at least $150,000 in damages for their use of her 1977 photograph of the legendary Nigerian nightclub of the Afrobeat musician Fela Kuti. The lawsuit, filed on Monday in Manhattan, argues that the producers did not seek or have the permission of the photographer, Marilyn Nance, to use the image of the nightclub, known as the Shrine, in a projection shown during the musical. Ms. Nance’s lawyer, Edward C. Greenberg, said in an interview that the image is used during 40 percent of the show (with Sahr Ngaujah, above) and is rendered in a “Fela!” souvenir book. A spokesman for the production, Richard Kornberg, disputed that the image was displayed for 40 percent of the show, saying it was “far less than that.” He also said the projection was only a fragment of a photograph. Mr. Kornberg said that the producers had been unaware that the photograph was taken by Ms. Nance and that she had a copyright on it, and said the photo would be replaced by Thursday. He also noted that Ms. Nance did not seek copyright protection for the photograph until seeing the show on Broadway. Her lawyer, Mr. Greenberg, confirmed that timing.

headline: ‘Talent’ Is Still Tops
text: “America’s Got Talent” helped lift NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday night, but crime show repeats on CBS posed a serious challenge. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 9.5 million viewers tuned in to “Talent” to watch the final 12 performers compete. NBC drew much lower ratings earlier in the night with the first of its six specials called “Breakthrough With Tony Robbins” (3.1 million). CBS finished a very close second for the night over all, while ABC ranked third with a two-hour repeat of “Wipeout” (6.9 million), followed by “Primetime” (4.6 million). Fox finished in fourth place with “Hell’s Kitchen” (6.2 million) and the premiere of “MasterChef” at 9 (5.7 million).

headline: The Rapper’s Edge
text: Eminem fended off a new release by the rapper Rick Ross to remain in the top spot on the Billboard album chart for the fifth week in a row. Eminem’s “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope) sold 187,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Ross’s “Teflon Don” (Maybach Music/Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam) reached No. 2 with 176,000. Sheryl Crow’s new album, “100 Miles From Memphis” (A&M), opened at No. 3 with 55,000 sales; Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 4 with 47,000; and the new “Kidz Bop 18” (Razor & Tie) is No. 5 with 43,000. Also new this week, the soundtrack to the Jonas Brothers’ new television series, “Jonas L.A.” (Disney), opened at No. 7 with 32,000.

headline: ‘Ring’ Set Is Rolled In at the Met
text: The leviathan has landed. The 45-ton set (part of it, above) for the Metropolitan Opera’s new Wagner “Ring” cycle created by Robert Lepage has arrived at the house. On Wednesday it passed a key test when it was rolled from a wing onto center stage. The trial run was delayed by several hours when an inspecting engineer found that the metal structure under the stage needed some touch-up welding. Last spring the Met installed massive steel girders to support the part of the stage in the wing where the set will be stored between performances. Recently arrived from a warehouse outside Montreal, the set consists of two 26-foot towers that bear an axis on which planks can seesaw up and down into various configurations. The axis can rise and fall. A platform in front of the plank structure will be the site of 90 percent of the action, the Met’s general manager, Peter Gelb, said. The sound of the hydraulic machinery used to reconfigure the set could be heard several levels below. John Sellars, the Met’s assistant manager for technical issues, said the machinery would be soundproofed. Mr. Lepage’s concept revolves around sophisticated computer-driven projections, or “virtual scenery,” that will be cast onto the planks. “Das Rheingold,” the cycle’s first opera, is scheduled for the season’s opening night, Sept. 27.

headline: Saves Those Stripes, Grab Some Scarves
text: Four questions for Tomoko Ogura, women’s fashion director, Barneys New York Co-op, Barneys.com.

headline: He’s Like a Rainbow: A Ronnie Wood Art Show
text: They may be only the paintings and other artworks created by a well-known rock ’n’ roll guitarist, but the Butler Institute of American Art likes them  enough to give Ronnie Wood, above, of the Rolling Stones, an eight-week exhibition there that the museum says is the first American show of Mr. Wood’s art. The institute, in Youngstown, Ohio, plans to present the exhibition, “Ronnie Wood: Paintings, Drawings and Prints,” from Sept. 21 to Nov. 21. It will feature about 60 works by Mr. Wood, who also played with the Jeff Beck Group and the Faces before joining the Stones. In a telephone interview, Louis A. Zona, executive director of the Butler Institute, said the show was the culmination of more than four years spent trying to persuade Mr. Wood to exhibit his work there. He added that what impressed him about Mr. Wood’s work, which tends to depict his rock ’n’ roll colleagues, including Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, was not the celebrity of the man who created them but the quality of the art. “He has done a number of cartoons,” Dr. Zona said of Mr. Wood, “spoofs on English culture, and they look like they were done by Daumier, just wonderful things. He’s very, very talented.”

headline: Another Big Gift for Yale Theater
text: Yale Repertory Theater is on a fund-raising hot streak. After announcing last week that it had received a $950,000 donation from the Robina Foundation, the theater said on Tuesday that it had received $1 million from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation aimed at supporting new commissions and productions through the Yale Center for New Theater. Steven Padla, a theater spokesman, noted that “Yale commissions fewer artists, but pays them more and also provides the developmental support and resources that the artists themselves believe will be most beneficial to their individual creative processes.” One project already commissioned, a new musical by Adam Bock and Todd Almond based on the Shirley Jackson novel “We Have Always Lived in the Castle,” is to begin rehearsals soon and have its premiere in September. The Yale Center for New Theater was established in 2008 with a grant from the Robina Foundation.

headline: Teams Title Is Decided in Louisiana
text: NEW ORLEANS  At the Summer Nationals here the Grand National Teams, which started in bridge clubs across North America and ended on Sunday night, was won by District 11 (Kentucky, western Ohio, central Indiana and West Virginia), represented by Doug Simson, Walter Johnson and Dennis and Jerry Clerkin. They defeated District 23 (Los Angeles County), Jill Meyers, Ed Davis, Mitch Dunitz and Walter Schafer Jr., 142 international match points to 112.

headline: Avis Bids $1.3 Billion for Dollar Thrifty
text: 8:32 p.m. | Updated with Dollar Thrifty’s response — The New York Times has more. The Avis Budget Group on Wednesday unveiled a $1.3 billion cash-and-stock offer for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, topping an earlier bid by Hertz Global Holdings.

headline: A Bag That Says ‘Beach Day!’
text: THE Industrial Dipped Coal Bag, a canvas bag with a signature broad horizontal stripe, crested as an “It” bag for men and a few women this summer.

headline: Blood, Sweat and Chalk: Q. and A. With Tim Layden
text: With some training camps already under way and another N.F.L. season around the corner, the Sports Illustrated senior writer Tim Layden has given fans another way to enjoy the game: he has written a book that explains football, through famous coaches and the concepts they helped make famous.

headline: Home Is a Place to Hang His Hats
text: THE milliner Victor Osborne, who left Brooklyn to open a store on the Lower East Side, has returned, opening a charming diminutive outpost in Williamsburg. Summer best sellers include a men’s Toyo Trilby ($200) and the asymmetrical fedora ($180) inspired by Marlene Dietrich. “ ‘The Devil Is a Woman’-era Dietrich,” clarified Mr. Osborne, shown in his new store. He not only makes his hats, he also makes his hat forms, an art learned at Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design in London. Prices are $85 to $225; custom hats start at $250. Friday to Sunday, noon to 8 p.m. Victor Osborne, 358 Grand Street (Marcy Avenue), (718) 388-8480, victorosborne.com.

text: Images from a benefit for the Watermill Center.

headline: Have a Question? Ask Facebook
text: People already use their Facebook status updates to ask their friends questions, like recommendations for a babysitter, a restaurant or a vacation.

headline: The Technology for Monitoring Elderly Relatives
text: “IF I ever need to go to a nursing home, kill me first.”

headline: Technologies Help Adult Children Monitor Aging Parents
text: IN the wee hours of July 14, Elizabeth Roach, a 70-year-old widow, got out of bed and went to the living room of her Virginia ranch home. She sat in her favorite chair for 15 minutes, then returned to bed.

headline: Comic-Book Heroes Made From Reality
text: WHAT do Jesus, Lady Gaga, J. K. Rowling, David Beckham and the cast of “Glee” have in common? They are each the subject of a biographical comic book from Bluewater Productions.

headline: Bernhardt’s Customizable Curio Table
text: Bernhardt’s Curio table is the furniture equivalent of a pair of jeans: classic and essential, yet customizable. There is a standard wood version in walnut or maple, but more-adventurous types can choose from a range of colors like orange and lime.

headline: A Trove of Antique European Textiles
text: Those seeking antique textiles from Europe can save the plane fare by visiting the online retailer Textiletrunk.com. The site is run by Wendy Lewis, who lives in Vermont and has spent more than a decade researching textiles at European flea markets and the Victoria & Albert Museum in London.

headline: For the Garden, European Planters
text: The concrete planters that were introduced in European gardens in the 1930s and remained popular for decades were coveted for their sensuous, sculptural forms — particularly the well-known hourglass — and handkerchief-style containers. Original examples of these and other pots made between the 1930s and ’70s are sold at Inner Gardens, a nursery and landscape-design company with three stores in the Los Angeles area.

text: MADELINE WEINRIB, the New York textile designer, started her career as a painter. “I did my first rug collection almost as a lark,” she said.

headline: Liz O’Brien’s New Showroom
text: Liz O’Brien’s new showroom, her third in 17 years, covers 2,400 square feet with chocolate-brown lacquered floors in a ground-level space on East 61st Street. “People who come here sit down and hang out for a while, and on Fifth Avenue it wasn’t like that,” said Ms. O’Brien, who specializes in 20th-century decorative arts. “I thought it was a sign of the times, that people were too busy. But now I’m thinking it might be the space itself.”

headline: The Nantucket Antiques Show Opens on Friday
text: The 33rd annual Nantucket Antiques Show, Friday to Monday, is scheduled to have 22 dealers from the United States and Europe, including William Nickerson Antiques, which will show 18th- and 19th-century furniture and Shaia Oriental rugs, and the Silver Fund, a London firm specializing in Georg Jensen silver. Phoebe Booth Antiques, a Manhattan firm that sells English furniture and decorative items, will show a number of pieces, including an Arts and Crafts ebonized fireside chair, circa 1890, at left, that has its “original woven rush seat,” Ms. Booth said (it is listed at $2,850).

headline: Sales at Alessi and A&G Merch
text: All Alessi bar accessories are being discounted 20 percent during August (the Pop wine cooler, originally $205, is $164; a set of three Banana Boys caps, shown, regularly $38, is $30; the 5052 Wine Cooler, originally $232, is $185); 130 Greene Street (Prince Street), (212) 941-7300, and 30 East 60th Street (Madison Avenue), (212) 317-9880 or alessi-shop.com.

headline: Betsey Johnson, Fashion Designer
text: The Plaza Hotel in Manhattan opens its Eloise suite today. As befits the hotel-dwelling storybook heroine whose favorite words include “Charge it, please,” it won’t be cheap. In fact, it will be so pricey you may wish to hide any mention of the place from the kiddies: It starts at $995 a night; to add an adjoining room for grown-ups, the nightly rate begins at $2,045.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Wikimania and Socks by Subscription
text: Wikipedia recently held its annual Wikimania conference, and Noam Cohen of The New York Times went to Gdansk, Poland, to check it out. In a discussion with Bettina Edelstein on this week’s Tech Talk podcast, he shares his observations on Wikipedia’s plans to become more diverse, to develop encyclopedias in less-common languages and to have more experts contributing articles to the project.

headline: Cameron Warns Pakistan on ‘the Export of Terror’

headline: Congress Rethinks Its Ban on Internet Gambling

headline: Inquiry Starts on Charities That Help Yale Athlete
text: The Connecticut attorney general started an investigation Wednesday into two charities run by the man spearheading efforts to help Mandi Schwartz, the Yale hockey player whose battle with leukemia has attracted widespread attention.

headline: In Price War, New Kindle Sells for $139
text: SEATTLE  Amazon.com will introduce two new versions of the Kindle e-reader on Thursday, one for $139, the lowest price yet for the device.

headline: Money Approved for Design of Suicide Barrier on Golden Gate Bridge
text: SAN FRANCISCO  For 73 years, people have poured onto the picturesque red-colored span of the Golden Gate Bridge to take pictures, ride bicycles, commute and, in close to two dozen cases each year, to jump to their deaths, an act transportation officials moved to stop Wednesday by authorizing money for a suicide barrier.

headline: Transparency Is Only the Beginning
text: IN his office in TriBeCa, James Carpenter is surrounded by sheets of glass  thick and thin, wavy and flat, transparent and opaque. Many are samples for his latest projects, which range from the newly renovated and reopened Israel Museum in Jerusalem to a 10-story office building planned for a prominent site in the Manhattan meatpacking district.
