text: To the Editor:

headline: Envoy Says Corruption Helps Taliban Win Recruits
text: WASHINGTON  Rampant corruption in Afghanistan provides the Taliban with their No. 1 recruiting tool, the Obama administration’s special representative to the region, Richard C. Holbrooke, said Wednesday. But he insisted that the United States was taking adequate precautions to cut down on the misuse of billions of dollars in American aid to the country.

headline: A Video Game on Broadway, With Taps, Too
text: CHASE BROCK never imagined he’d choreograph a video game, much less one involving Broadway dance routines. Until last summer Mr. Brock, 27, knew very little about video games at all. “I had a Super Nintendo very briefly in the ’90s,” he said recently. “And I had, like, five games. But major video game stuff I knew nothing about, and I’d never played a Wii.”

headline: The Best Kind of Warrior
text: To the Editor:

headline: In China, Pollution Worsens Despite New Efforts
text: BEIJING  China, the world’s most prodigious emitter of greenhouse gas, continues to suffer the downsides of unbridled economic growth despite a raft of new environmental initiatives.

headline: U.N. Appoints New Director of Troubled Watchdog Group
text: UNITED NATIONS — Moving to fix the deeply troubled agency that investigates the United Nations, the General Assembly on Wednesday approved the appointment of a new director for the unit after years of battles over its independence.

headline: Iran: Plants to Use Benzene to Increase Gas Production
text: Trying to offset the effect of sanctions on the country’s nuclear program, Iran said Wednesday that it would increase domestic gasoline production by converting two petrochemical plants so they could produce gasoline by processing benzene. Iran is the world’s fifth-largest exporter of crude oil, but a lack of refining capacity forces it to import about 30 percent of its gasoline. The plan to increase production was announced by the oil minister, Masoud Mirkazemi, who predicted that Iran would become a net exporter of gasoline by 2015. Benzene, a product derived from natural gas, can be further processed to produce gasoline for use in cars and other vehicles. Experts said, however, that the product would burn poorly and contain more impurities than regular gasoline, causing damage to engines.

headline: The Kids Are All Right
text: While conducting my never-ending search for cheerful news, I noticed that one of New York’s senators made the Top 10 in a list of the 50 most beautiful people on Capitol Hill.

headline: No Savior Seen as M.T.A. Takes Step to Raise Fares and Tolls
text: Before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board pushed ahead a plan on Wednesday to raise fares next year, there were the familiar laments laced with indignation from riders and their advocates.

headline: Judge Rejects Forest Service’s Plan on Fire Retardant
text: SEATTLE  A federal judge has ruled that the federal Forest Service’s plan for using fire retardant to fight wildfires violates the law because it does not ensure protections for threatened and endangered species of fish and other animals.

headline: We’re Number One!
text: I’ve seen a peculiar meme surfacing here and there lately — the assertion that people like me are exaggerating how bad our current difficulties are, that things were actually worse in the 70s and 80s. I wonder where that’s coming from — and I really do; it has the feel of one of those things being disseminated on talk radio or something, and I think I hear a faint chant of Jimmy Carter! Jimmy Carter! in the background.

headline: Obama Hits Two Manhattan Fund-Raisers
text: NEW YORK – After an afternoon of populism, lunching with small-business owners in New Jersey and gabbing with the opinionated ladies of ABC-TV’s “The View,” President Obama ended his day on Wednesday at separate $30,400-a-person fund-raisers here in Manhattan.

headline: 1 Soldier or 20 Schools?
text: The war in Afghanistan will consume more money this year alone than we spent on the Revolutionary War, the War of 1812, the Mexican-American War, the Civil War and the Spanish-American War  combined.

headline: Avis Bids $1.3 Billion for Dollar Thrifty, Exceeding Hertz’s Offer
text: The Avis Budget Group on Wednesday unveiled a $1.3 billion cash-and-stock offer for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, topping a bid by Hertz Global Holdings.

headline: Spam, Spam, Spam, Spam
text: I’m going to try an experiment here. As regular readers know, a lot of comment inches on every post are taken up by the same few ranters, who say the same thing every time; it kind of degrades the experience for everyone else. But I’m not going to edit out hostile comments (and by the way, neither I nor the various other people who moderate here ever have.) What I’m going to try instead is a three-inch rule: if it takes up more than about 3 inches on my screen, I’m going to tag it as spam. I don’t know if the other moderators will follow suit, but I’m suggesting they do.

headline: In Haiti, a Lesson for U.S. Health Care
text: IN February, a month after Haiti’s earthquake, I went down to Port-au-Prince as part of a team that was helping to reactivate cardiac care in the city’s public hospital. For several months since, I have observed how the earthquake and its aftermath profoundly changed Haiti’s health care system. Over that time, I have come to the unorthodox conclusion that Haiti’s tragic experience may show us a way to improve health care in the United States.

headline: Learning to Be a True Utility Player
text: Richmond W. Benichak, 19, expects to graduate from New York University in 2013 with a sports management degree; this summer he is the finance intern for the Newark Bears, an independent minor league baseball team. His job, for which he is nominally paid, includes reconciling contracts with a stringent budget as well as monitoring game-night promotions like the wing-eating contest. Originally from Woodbridge, Conn., he sleeps in Queens and takes two classes at N.Y.U., but virtually lives at the ballpark in Newark.

headline: Obama Trumpets Democrats’ Small-Business Bona Fides
text: WASHINGTON  At the core of some of the major policy fights in Washington these days is a ferocious competition between Republicans and Democrats over which party is the champion of America’s small businesses  a mantle that each side views as crucial to shaping economic policy and winning the November elections.

headline: Bloggingheads: False Hope of Victory?
text: Will Wilkinson, left, of the Cato Institute and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate WikiLeaks and victory in Afghanistan.

headline: Death-Benefit Accounts Seem to Slight Survivors
text: The package arrived at Cindy Lohman’s home in Great Mills, Md., just two weeks after she learned that her son, Ryan, a 24-year-old Army sergeant, had been killed by a bomb in Afghanistan. It was a thick envelope from Prudential Financial Inc., which handles life insurance for the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: Sanofi-Aventis Said to Be Likely to Bid $18 Billion for Genzyme
text: Sanofi-Aventis is likely to make an unsolicited offer of up to $70 a share for Genzyme, raising the stakes for what could become one of the year’s biggest deals, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: Informants Who Aided U.S. Named in Classified Reports
text: Some of the tens of thousands of Pentagon documents released this week by WikiLeaks contain identifying information about Afghan informants who aided United States and NATO forces, potentially jeopardizing their future cooperation or even putting them at risk of reprisal.

headline: Arizona Ruling Acts as a Warning to Other States
text: A federal judge in Arizona on Wednesday broadly vindicated the Obama administration’s high-stakes move to challenge that state’s tough immigration law and to assert the primary authority of the federal government over state lawmakers in immigration matters.

headline: U.S. Military Scrutinizes Leaks for Risks to Afghans
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is reviewing tens of thousands of classified battlefield reports made public this week about the war in Afghanistan to determine whether Afghan informants were identified and could be at risk of reprisals, American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Job Subsidies Also Provide Help to Private Sector
text: CHICAGO — States are putting hundreds of thousands of people directly into jobs through programs reminiscent of the more ambitious work projects of the Great Depression.

headline: For Some City Fitness Buffs, Intense Heat Is No Deterrent
text: To escape the relentless heat, some seek out shade, basements or air-conditioned cocoons. Others head for places even hotter than the awful outdoors.

headline: Lottery Numbers
La Russa’s Lineup Card Leaps From a Keen Mind
text: Every manager’s desk is pretty much the same. A watch, a newspaper, ticket envelopes. A pair of glasses, some pens, a lineup card. The last item makes Tony La Russa’s desk different. He has the same small, light blue cards as everyone else. But his are far more likely to list the pitcher eighth.

headline: Rider’s Vision of Bigger Ramps Helps Launch Big Air
text: It started with some math and stolen lumber. Ten years later, and minus a spleen, Mat Hoffman’s pursuit of big air on his freestyle BMX bike led to a ramp the height of a two-story house that sent him flying more than 50 feet above an Oklahoma field in 2001.

headline: The Burqa and the Body Electric
text: The clash between religious liberty and the state goes back centuries. Is there a way to move past it?

headline: For Rangel and House Ethics Panel, the Brinkmanship Continues
text: With the prospect of a damaging public ethics trial looming less than a day away, Representative Charles B. Rangel and the House Committee on Standards of Public Conduct continued their brinkmanship on Wednesday.

headline: Showdown in Arizona
text: The federal judge who ruled on Arizona’s tragic, noxious new immigration law on Wednesday did not stop all of it from taking effect Thursday, but she preliminarily halted the worst of it. And although appeals are certain, Judge Susan Bolton offered clear and well-reasoned arguments affirming the federal government’s final authority over immigration enforcement. We hope this is the beginning of the end of the misbegotten Arizona rules and what they represent.

headline: Bell Case Underlines Limits of Wrongful-Death Payouts
text: The $3.25 million settlement that the city announced this week with the estate of Sean Bell, who was shot to death by the police in 2006, serves as a reminder of a ruthless truth about calculating settlements: It is generally cheaper to settle a case in which there was a death than one in which there was a serious injury.

headline: To Pack a Stadium, Provide Video Better Than TV
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  How do you keep football fans as regular visitors to stadiums when the television coverage of every play is so good?

headline: Swastika Is Deemed ‘Universal’ Hate Symbol
text: The swastika now shows up so often as a generic symbol of hatred that the Anti-Defamation League, in its annual tally of hate crimes against Jews, will no longer automatically count its appearance as an act of anti-Semitism.

headline: Tony La Russa and the Logic Behind the Lineup
text: In the top of the eighth inning on Sunday, in a tie game at Wrigley Field, the St. Louis Cardinals’ No. 7 hitter got on base to put runners on first and second. This, of course, brought up the No. 8 hitter. But because it was a Cardinals lineup, that was pitcher Chris Carpenter’s spot. He left for a pinch-hitter, ending his night after seven innings.

headline: Inquiry by State Clears Paterson of Criminal Acts
text: Gov. David A. Paterson and his advisers made errors of judgment in their handling of a domestic violence case involving a top aide, but their actions were not criminal, a retired judge who investigated the case announced on Wednesday.

headline: Investment Banks in a New World
text: Picking the chief of an investment bank used to be a relatively straightforward process. By and large, the business group that made the most money got to put its man forward.

headline: N.C.A.A. Sanctions Will Take a Toll on the Trojans
text: At the W hotel on Lexington Avenue in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday night, the Pac-10 unveiled its new logo, philosophy and direction. Years of apathy about marketing disappeared in a literal cloud of smoke: at a cocktail reception, the Pac-10’s new logo was projected on a wall of smoke piped into the Whiskey Blue lounge.

headline: Pac-10 Leader Envisions a Premier TV Channel
text: Larry Scott, the Pacific-10 commissioner, intends to start a television channel like the one that the Big Ten started in 2007.

headline: Who Profits? Who Learns?
text: Enrollment at for-profit colleges and trade schools has tripled in the last decade to about 1.8 million, or nearly 10 percent of the nation’s higher education students. These schools, partly because they serve poorer students who need more support, receive almost a quarter of the federal aid. This year, federal financing for financial aid is expected to total $145 billion.

headline: Opponents Are Learning: Don’t Test Gardner’s Arm
text: CLEVELAND  Being fast has its advantages for Brett Gardner, who excels at chasing down fly balls, stealing bases and beating out grounders. It can also overshadow some of his other talents, which were on display Tuesday night, when he threw out the Indians’ Shin-Soo Choo at the plate on a perfect one-hopper to end the first inning.

headline: Cow Cover

headline: Energy Subsidies  Good and Bad
text: Congress must soon decide whether to extend federal tax subsidies for renewable energy that expire at the end of the year. The subsidies for wind, solar and geothermal energy are necessary to give these energy sources the help they need to compete with oil, coal and natural gas. While it renews those subsidies, Congress should end tax breaks for corn ethanol, which can stand on its own and is of dubious environmental benefit.

headline: In Paterson Case, Cuomo Sidesteps Vulnerability
text: The phone call, on a Wednesday night in February, in which a besieged Gov. David A. Paterson asked Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo to investigate his administration’s handling of a domestic violence case involving one of Mr. Paterson’s most trusted aides, set up an odd and fraught situation: one candidate for governor asking another to examine whether he or others in his administration had committed a crime.

headline: Airspace to Be Closed Near Clinton Wedding
text: Swarms of photographers, reporters and plain old curious folk are expected to descend on the upstate New York town of Rhinebeck when Chelsea Clinton gets married there on Saturday. Now it appears they will have to make do with whatever they can see through the hedges — if they can even get that close.

headline: Get Out of Jail Free

That is the conclusion of the United States Copyright Office, which has granted an exemption to the Digital Millennium Copyright Act that will legalize “jailbreaking”  modifying a phone so it runs applications that aren’t approved by Apple.

headline: Mets Call Up Career Minor Leaguer Too Good for the Minors

headline: Ex-Leader of Carpenters Union Pleads Guilty to Racketeering

headline: 20 Years After an Open, a Coach Tees Up Again

headline: Yankees Win While Waiting for Rodriguez to Hit 600th

Sliding headfirst, Rodriguez wrapped his hands around the bag, ripping it from the ground, and for a moment he lay there on his back with the base in his hands. The longer it takes for Rodriguez to hit his 600th career home run, the more his priorities may be shifting.

headline: Egypt: Attorney General Addresses Police Abuse Case
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., left, said Wednesday during a visit to Cairo that he hoped an investigation into the death of a man in police custody last month would be carried out “in a transparent way” and that anyone responsible “would be held accountable.” His comments came a day after two police officers charged with using excessive force to subdue the man, Khaled Said, made their first appearance in an Alexandria courtroom. Mr. Said’s death led to weeks of demonstrations against police brutality and calls to overhaul the security services.

headline: Luis Corvalán Dies at 93; Led Communists in Chile

headline: Theo Albrecht, Who Helped Build the Aldi Grocery Chain, Dies at 88

headline: Al Goodman, R&B Singer, Dies at 67

headline: Willem Breuker, Dutch Composer and Bandleader, Dies at 65
text: Willem Breuker, a Dutch composer, multireedist and bandleader whose jump-cut style and theatrical panache made him a contrarian hero of European jazz, died on July 23 in Amsterdam. He was 65.

text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: 20 Years After His Only Open, Dartmouth Coach Is Teeing It Up Again
text: On the tee sheets for the United States Senior Open, he is listed as Richard Parker Jr., Lebanon, N.H., but around Dartmouth College, he is just “Coach” or “Rich.” That is also how he is mostly known by the listeners of his Saturday morning radio show on WTSL-AM (1400), and by the folks who see him behind the counter at the nine-hole Carter Golf Club in Lebanon, where he is both the golf director and general manager.

headline: Aug. 1-7
text: Art

headline: What We’re Reading: Drinkers Have Better Vocabularies
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Obama Defends Education Program
text: WASHINGTON  Saying that reforming education is perhaps “the economic issue of our time,” President Obama went before a major civil rights organization on Thursday to defend his main education program against criticisms from some minority and teachers groups.

headline: Obama’s View
text: President Obama took a turn on the couch with the women of ABC’s “The View” this week, answering questions on topics that ranged from the war in Afghanistan to the actor Mel Gibson’s anger and sparring with the show’s resident conservative over jobs and the economy.

headline: TNK-BP Eyeing BP’s Venezuela Assets
text: TNK-BP, the Russian joint venture of the troubled oil giant, said Thursday that it was interested in the Venezuelan assets of BP, which is in the process of selling off up to $30 billion in holdings in the wake of its Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Agonized Return to a Voice and a Vision
text: WHEN William Brittelle performed at the Bell House in Brooklyn in April, a small miracle occurred, so subtle that most spectators might have missed it. Mr. Brittelle, a singer and composer, was presenting his “Television Landscape,” a set of flamboyant, richly orchestrated art-rock songs. But time was running short. Rushing to finish, Mr. Brittelle signaled to the drummer to skip the technical preparation for the last song, then looked out at the sound engineer and pointed to his microphone.

headline: Nuclear Forensics Skill Is Declining in U.S., Report Says
text: The nation’s ability to identify the source of a nuclear weapon used in a terrorist attack is fragile and eroding, according to a report released Thursday by the National Research Council.

headline: London Theater Journal: 12 and Miserable
text: “Spur of the Moment,” a stirring new play about a 12-year-old girl written by a girl who was 17 at the time, isn’t much of an advertisement for the pleasures of being young. But Anya Reiss’s broken-hearted, funny drama at the Royal Court Theater does remind you that unhappiness can be a fertile muse.

headline: Nipping Down to Hell With Philip Glass
text: IN 1993 I attended the premiere of Philip Glass’s opera “Orphée” at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and was unimpressed. The production, by Francesca Zambello, was striking, and the gifted singing actors gave their all. But the work did not cohere stylistically, and Mr. Glass’s score seemed automatic-pilot Minimalism.

headline: Sounds of a Composer Given Voice by His Muse
text: PETER LIEBERSON: ‘RED GARUDA,’ RILKE SONGS, BAGATELLES,

headline: Oil Spill Crime? Send In the BP Squad
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: The Work Of Depressions
text: I’ve been surprised by a lot of things since the financial crisis broke, few of them good. One of the truly amazing things, however, is the return of full, 1930s-type liquidationism — the idea that a slump serves a useful purpose, and that stimulating the economy, even through monetary policy, is a mistake. And so we have Raghuram Rajan in today’s FT arguing that with 9.5 percent unemployment, long-term unemployment at record levels, and falling inflation, we need to … raise interest rates:

headline: Off the Menu: Three New Restaurants for Battery Park City
text: Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group just announced that it will open three new restaurants in Battery Park City next year.

headline: London Underground | Ping-Pong City
text: Summertime seems to attract retro-sporting trends in London. Last year, you could not move in London Fields for all the hula-hooping hipsters. This summer, the craze is for Ping-Pong. It is everywhere. Jean Nouvel’s red tables at the Serpentine Pavilion are in high demand, and starting this week, Ping!, the London Ping-Pong Project, is installing 100 tables in public spaces around the city. Now anyone can challenge a handsome stranger to a game.

headline: Mother’s Death in Staten Island Fire Is Ruled a Suicide
text: The deaths of four children in a fire on Staten Island on July 22 have been ruled homicides, while their mother died by her own hand, according to autopsy results released by the city medical examiner’s office Thursday morning.

headline: How Do You Know It’s Summer on the Internet?
text: Governors may not be falling, our children’s test scores may be (is?) plummeting, but it’s still a slow news day in some corners of the Web. Here are a few ways  you can tell.

headline: An Amazonian Fish on Display in Chelsea Market
text: There is a new fish in town. The paiche, also known as the arapaima — a gigantic, fairly bizarre freshwater species from the Amazon — will be on display at Lobster Place in the Chelsea Market until 2 p.m. on Thursday.

headline: Did We Stutter? Film Society to Pay Tribute to John Hughes
text: If the emotional tribute to the filmmaker John Hughes at the Academy Awards ceremony in March – not to mention this touching appraisal by A. O. Scott of The New York Times – did not give you sufficient opportunity to grieve for him, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is planning a two-day celebration of Mr. Hughes’s films that hopefully won’t interfere with your detention obligations. On Thursday the Film Society said it would host “John Hughes: We Can’t Forget About Him,” a series of events scheduled for Sept. 19 and 20.

headline: 100,000 Hail Hitler; U.S. Athletes Avoid Nazi Salute to Him
text: Berlin, Aug. 1 -- A gray sky that threatened rain without ever really fulfilling that threat lowered today over the opening ceremonies of the eleventh and greatest Olympic-Games of modern times. It was not a misfortune, because there stood out in sharper relief all the brilliant coloring of this most picturesque of ceremonies, which comes only once every four years.

headline: Ex-Slave's Son, 78, Financier, Is Dead
text: DURHAM, N. C., Aug. 1--Charles Clinton Spaulding, president of five companies comprising the largest all-Negro enterprise in the world, died at his home here today on his seventy-eighth birthday.

headline: Iraqi Insurgents Plant Qaeda Flag in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  In a brazen late-afternoon attack in the heart of this city’s most prominent Sunni neighborhood, gunmen struck two police checkpoints on Thursday before a series of roadside bombs detonated on police and army patrols responding to the violence.

headline: James Baldwin, Eloquent Writer In Behalf of Civil Rights, Is Dead
text: James Baldwin, whose passionate, intensely personal essays in the 1950's and 60's on racial discrimination in America made him an eloquent voice of the civil-rights movement, died of stomach cancer early yesterday at his home in St. Paul de Vence in southern France. He was 63 years old.

headline:
President Harding Dies Suddenly; Stroke of Apoplexy at 7:30 P.M.; Calvin 
Coolidge Is President
text: San Francisco, Aug. 2 -- President Harding died at 7:30 o'clock tonight [11:30 o'clock New York time] of a stroke of apoplexy.

headline: On Our Radar: BP Writes Off Spill Costs
text: BP deducts $10 billion from its United States taxes for oil spill cleanup costs. “We have followed the I.R.S. regulations as they’re currently written,” said Tony Hayward, the company’s outgoing chief executive. [MarketWatch]

headline: Ernie Pyle Is Killed on Ie Island; Foe Fired When All Seemed Safe
text: GUAM, April, 18--Ernie Pyle died today on Ie Island, just west of Okinawa, like so many of the doughboys he had written about. The nationally known war correspondent was killed instantly by Japanese machine-gun fire.

headline:
Nautilus Sails Under the Pole and 1,830 Miles of Arctic Icecap in Pacific-to-Atlantic 
Passage
text: Washington, Aug. 8 -- History's first undersea voyage across the top of the world, a distance of 1,830 miles under the polar icecap, was disclosed at the White House today.

headline: Louis Armstrong, Jazz Trumpeter and Singer, Dies
text: Louis Armstrong, the celebrated jazz trumpeter and singer, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his home in the Corona section of Queens. He had observed his 71st birthday Sunday.

headline: England Declares War on Germany
text: London, Wednesday, Aug. 5-- War is on between England and Germany. An ultimatum to the German Government that the neutrality of Belgium must be respected was rejected by the Kaiser's Government and the British Foreign Office announced last night that a state of war existed.

headline: Test Ban Treaty Signed in Moscow; Leaders Rejoice
text: Moscow, Aug. 5 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union signed the test ban treaty today at a ceremony that was both solemn and joyous.

headline: John Huston, Film Director, Writer and Actor, Dies at 81
text: John Huston, the legendary director and scenarist who made such classic films as ''The Maltese Falcon,'' ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' ''The Asphalt Jungle'' and ''The African Queen,'' died yesterday in Middletown, R.I., at the age of 81. Associates said he had died in his sleep of complications from emphysema.

headline: House Tour: Light in the Berkshires
text: Photos of a hillside home in Great Barrington, Mass.

headline: Within the Fed, Worries of Deflation
text: WASHINGTON  A subtle but significant shift appears to be occurring within the Federal Reserve over the course of monetary policy as the economic recovery is weakening.

headline: First Atomic Bomb Dropped on Japan; Missile Is Equal to 20,000 Tons of TNT; Truman Warns Foe of a 'Rain of Ruin'
text: Washington, Aug. 6 -- The White House and War Department announced today that an atomic bomb, possessing more power than 20,000 tons of TNT, a destructive force equal to the load of 2,000 B-29's and more than 2,000 times the blast power of what previously was the world's most devastating bomb, had been dropped on Japan.

headline: Lucille Ball, Spirited Doyenne Of TV Comedies, Dies at 77
text: Lucille Ball, the irrepressible queen of television comedy for nearly a quarter-century, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles a week after undergoing heart surgery there. She was 77 years old.

headline: Are Migraines Linked to a Heart Defect?
text: Several readers of the Consults blog had questions about migraines and patent foramen ovale, a fairly common condition that causes blood to flow through a hole between the heart’s chambers. While many people have this defect, most have no symptoms and don’t even know they have it. Researchers are exploring the links between patent foramen ovale and migraine headaches, explains Dr. David Dodick of the Mayo Clinic.

headline: What? We Might Be the Real Losers?
text: “Dinner for Schmucks,” directed by Jay Roach (“Meet the Parents”) and based on a 12-year-old French movie known in English as “The Dinner Game,” is in some ways an exemplary modern Hollywood comedy. It treads a careful boundary between nasty and sweet, balancing the rude humor of humiliation with an affirming, tolerant, almost scolding final message: Be nice! It dabbles in sexual naughtiness without dreaming of going too far into complicated zones of lust and betrayal. (The French version, as you might expect, goes much further.)

headline: Bookshelf | Chicken or Beef?
text: An airline coming out with a cookbook — it sounds like the start of a warmed-over, foil-wrapped joke. But Singapore Airlines isn’t kidding with “Above & Beyond,” a collection of 50 recipes from the 10 current and former chefs of the airline’s International Culinary Panel, including Alfred Portale, Gordon Ramsay, Georges Blanc and Sam Leong.

headline: Dr. Bunche of U.N., Nobel Winner, Dies
text: Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, former United Nations Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs and winner of the 1950 Nobel Peace Prize, died early yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 67 years old.

headline: Congress Backs President on Southeast Asia Moves; Khanh Sets State of Siege
text: Washington, Aug. 7 -- The House of Representatives and the Senate approved today the resolution requested by President Johnson to strengthen his hand in dealing with Communist aggression in Southeast Asia.

headline: Judge Refuses to Vacate Verdicts in Astor Trial
text: Updated 5:00 p.m. |The judge in the trial of Brooke Astor’s son denied a defense motion to vacate convictions against him and a lawyer who had done estate planning for Mrs. Astor, the doyenne of Manhattan society until her death in 2007.

headline: Popcast: Ricky Skaggs on God and Music and More
text: Is good music a gift from the divine, no matter how much helter-skelter the musicians might get involved in? Ricky Skaggs, the renowned bluegrass singer, thinks so. In an interview on Popcast, The Times’s weekly music podcast, he talks about the religious themes on his new album, “Mosaic,” and how the Beatles’ music remains indelibly blessed.

headline: The New New Deal: Public Money for Private Jobs
text: Call it W.P.A. Lite: a stimulus program that uses taxpayer funds to put hundreds of thousands of unemployed people directly into jobs.

headline: Poetry Pairing | July 29, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by former U.S. Poet Laureate Ted Kooser.

headline: A Fed Member Warns of Deflation
text: In a new paper released today, James Bullard of the St. Louis Fed says the central bank’s stated policy of maintaining interest rates “exceptionally low” for “an extended period” could lead to one of two steady states.

headline: Population Research Presents a Sobering Prognosis
text: With 267 people being born every minute and 108 dying, the world’s population will top seven billion next year, a research group projects, while the ratio of working-age adults to support the elderly in developed countries declines precipitously because of lower birthrates and longer life spans.

headline: Answers About Medicare: Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Judge in Morris Case Revises Charges
text: Updated 3:56 p.m. | A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan dismissed 13 charges on Thursday in a criminal case against the political consultant Hank Morris, but ruled that some of the most serious ones could remain.

headline: A College Freshman’s Proud Independence Melts in Summer
text: “Becca! Get up,” my brother yells into my room. I barely manage a “why?” before my brother says: “You’re supposed to get up. Mom and Dad said.”

headline: Citigroup Pays $75 Million to Settle Subprime Claims
text: Citigroup agreed on Thursday to pay $75 million to settle federal claims that it failed to disclose vast holdings of subprime mortgage investments that were deteriorating during the financial crisis and ultimately crippled the bank.

headline: Regulators Warned Company on Pipeline Corrosion
text: BATTLE CREEK, Mich.  The company responsible for a massive oil spill here was warned in January by federal regulators about insufficient monitoring of corrosion on the pipeline that federal officials say leaked more than one million gallons of oil into a major waterway this week.

headline: Porsche 918 Spyder Plug-In Hybrid Is Only the Start of Green Program
text: Citing an “overwhelming response from the public and customers,” Porsche said on Wednesday that it intended to move its ultrapowerful and gorgeously styled 918 Spyder plug-in hybrid from concept to production model. The decision complements a second, more modest environmentally themed test program announced on Monday that would put three battery-operated versions of the popular Boxster into what the company calls “field tests.”

headline: The Real Junkmen of Kings County
text: HERE’S Frankie Fidilio rolling down Avenue U in Brooklyn on the second-hottest day of the year in his blue 1986 GMC Suburban. The van has no air-conditioning, but that’s the least of its problems.

headline: TimesCast | July 29, 2010
text: Today, the nationwide impact of the injunction against Arizona's immigration law, inside the Appleseed Project, which teaches marksmanship and American history, and a look at Moscow's sweltering summer.

headline: Citigroup Settles Subprime Claims for $75 Million
text: 3:48 p.m. | Updated  Citigroup has agreed to pay $75 million to settle federal claims that it failed to disclose vast holdings of subprime mortgage investments that crippled the bank during the financial crisis, The New York Times’s Eric Dash and Louise Story report.

headline: Sherrod Says She Will Sue Blogger
text: 2:07 p.m. | Updated  SAN DIEGO — Addressing a group of black journalists, Shirley Sherrod, the fired Agriculture Department employee, said Thursday that younger African-Americans, whether they work in newsrooms, corporate suites or the Oval Office, ought to study up on the civil rights struggles that their ancestors endured.

headline: Theater Talkback: Preaching to the Choir on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’?
text: This summer, ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. The playwright Theresa Rebeck wrote about the perils of being too funny, and the composer Jason Robert Brown discussed the ethics of downloading sheet music.

headline: Q&A: From London to St.-Rémy and Avignon
text: My wife and I are planning a trip to London, Paris and Provence in September. We plan to stay about four days in each location. Any sightseeing ideas? From Paris we’d take a TGV to Avignon. How do we get from there to St.-Rémy?

headline: Sherrod Announces She’ll Sue Breitbart
text: The ousted Agriculture Department official Shirley Sherrod said Thursday that she intended to sue Andrew Breitbart, the conservative Web site operator that publicized a misleading video about her last week.

headline: Keeping Score: The Unusual Case of Inexperience Winning the Day
text: In Josh Tomlin’s seven-inning, three-hit major league debut against the Yankees on Tuesday, much was made of the Yankees’ recent struggles against pitchers making their major league debuts.

headline: When Photography and National Security Meet
text: On Tuesday, The New York Times’s columnist Jim Dwyer wrote about a photographer, Duane P. Kerzic, who was arrested by the Amtrak police while taking pictures of a train that he was preparing to enter in a photo contest sponsored by the railroad itself.

headline: Letters From Camp
text: Sleep-away camp is about getting back to nature — the paper-and-pencil kind, finished off with a postage stamp.

headline: Pop Rocks | Irene Neuwirth
text: The Los Angeles-based jeweler Irene Neuwirth decided to go bold with her fall collection, which she designed around this striking pendant, made of chrysoprase, moonstone, aquamarine, rose of France and onyx. “With everyone designing really safe pieces of late, I thought it was a good time to be over the top and vivid,” Neuwirth says. A recent road trip across northern Spain also had a hand in her creative process. “I found a lot of big, colorful jewelry in the thrift stores there, which inspired me to make a costume line that was precious.” The necklace is $38,580 at Barneys New York.

headline: Dance Theater Workshop Announces New Season
text: As talks continue about a possible merger between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, the theater on Thursday announced a full 2010-11 season featuring the work of choreographers from Europe, Africa and of course the United States. The lineup includes a collaboration between the German dance maker and performer Raimund Hoghe and Faustin Linyekula of Congo; new work by Richard Move, who will recreate a 1963 interview with Martha Graham; and the French choreographer Alain Buffard’s “Les Inconsolés,” a work set to Schubert and Throbbing Gristle. Also on the schedule will be revivals from the Trisha Brown Dance Company, the first time that troupe will appear at the theater. Complete information is at dancetheaterworkshop.org. Representatives for the theater said merger talks would probably conclude late in the fall.

headline: Body of Second Missing U.S. Sailor Found
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United States military has recovered the body of the second of two American sailors abducted last week in a dangerous region south of Kabul, but it was not clear precisely how he had died.

headline: Test Yourself | July 29, 2010
text: Friday, July 30 11:50 a.m. | Updated  This week, in conjunction with Math for America, we’re providing math problems based on Times articles. Today’s question was written by Patrick Honner at MfA, based on a Times Magazine article by James Traub about Mariano Rivera. (It deals with the baseball statistic known as earned run average, defined by Princeton’s WordNet as “the average number of earned runs allowed by the pitcher for every nine innings pitched.”)

headline: Republicans Block Bill to Aid Small Business
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Thursday rejected a bill to aid small businesses with expanded loan programs and tax breaks, in a procedural blockade that underscored how fiercely determined the party’s leaders are to deny Democrats any further legislative accomplishments ahead of November’s midterm elections.

headline: Surprise, Surprise:  Monaco Signs for Another 10 Years
text: I noticed a week or two ago that Bernie Ecclestone, the F1 commercial promoter, made a comment somewhere saying that F1 could survive very well without the Monaco Grand Prix. I didn’t look very deeply into what he was talking about or what the context was. But now I understand.

headline: Priceline Adds Rental Cars to iPhone App
text: If you just landed but haven’t booked a rental car yet, you may be able to use a new feature on your iPhone to name your own price as soon as the captain says its O.K. to turn on your phone. Priceline.com has expanded its popular Hotel Negotiator app for the iPhone and iPod Touch to include a Name Your Own Price rental car service.

headline: YouTube Gives Users Their 15 Minutes of Fame
text: As of Thursday, you can subject your friends and family to 50 percent more of your baby making that cute cooing noise or your dog doing that funny dance.

headline: Lawmakers Call On Six Firms to Claw Back Bonuses
text: More than 40 members of Congress called on six big financial firms on Thursday to halt their executive bonuses and return money to the government from bonuses that were challenged by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Treasury‘s departing special master for executive compensation.

headline: Questions Swirl About Damaged Japanese Tanker
text: Shipping officials said Thursday that they were examining the hull of a Japanese oil tanker that was mysteriously damaged this week as it traversed a strategically vital waterway between Iran and the Arabian Peninsula. The ship’s owner has said that it may have been attacked.

headline: Avis Goes to War for Dollar Thrifty
text: Avis has finally arrived.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Marketing Success
text: Last week, I wrote about what a powerful, yet underused, ally sound can be in marketing. This week, taking a page from those smart real estate people who slip a tray of chocolate chip cookies into the oven 10 minutes before a home showing, I’m going to suggest you turn up the olfactory factor.

headline: Video Shows Michigan Oil Spill
text: As my colleague Emma Graves Fitzsimmons reports from Michigan, the Environmental Protection Agency now estimates that more than one million gallons of oil may have spilled from a pipeline into the Kalamazoo River this week, which is far more than the pipeline’s owner, Enbridge Energy Partners, initially estimated.

headline: For Goldman Sachs, Remaking a Hub in Battery Park City
text: Goldman Sachs has begun to unveil the designs it has on remaking its new neighborhood of Battery Park City.

headline: Fantasy Football Rankings: Wide Receivers
text: Jason and Justin Sablich, The Times’s in-house fantasy football experts, are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Brothers Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season and are now on Twitter.

headline: Tote Sweet
text: Summertime is tote time. Totes for the fresh corn from the farmer’s market. Totes for the towel and suntan lotion at the beach. Totes for lugging around all that reading you meant to catch up on. You get the picture. Now the students at the Polo Fashion School, a collaboration between the Hetrick-Martin Institute and Polo Ralph Lauren, have designed paint-splattered tote bags that proudly declare “I Kiss Boys” or “I Kiss Girls.” Proceeds benefit the institute, the nation’s oldest social service organization supporting lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender youth. Whatever your preference, you can totes tell it like it is while carting around your summer essentials. Available for $20 at Maison 24 — in Bridgehampton and the Fire Island Pines, or online.

headline: APD
text: Unlikely initialism for an urban style of bicycling – Aggressive Pursuit of Destination.

headline: Training Wheels for Your iPad
text: Have you ever noticed how some gadgets are so easy to use that you can’t figure them out?

headline: Bits Pics: Looking Inside Apple’s New Trackpad
text: The Web site iFixit posted a detailed look at the guts of Apple’s new Magic Trackpad.

headline: Police Toss Out Arrest Warrant for Chinese Reporter in Hiding
text: BEIJING  For China’s investigative journalists, who grapple with heavy-handed censors and accusations of bribe-taking, the case of a Shanghai-based reporter appears to offer a positive turn.

headline: A Dining Explosion in a Tiny Basque Town
text: TRY to imagine the gustatory experience of running up a mountain. Drawing a blank?

headline: Delightful Bites in Hondarribia
text: Talented young chefs are dreaming up innovative cuisine in Spain.

headline: In Britain, Dorms Have Summer Jobs
text: WHEN I walked into the Victorian hall at Oxford University’s Keble College last month, I was sure I had entered a far more genuine Hogwarts experience than anything Universal could have created at the new Harry Potter theme park in Orlando. Before me was a Gothic dining hall nearly the length of a football field, filled with long wooden tables illuminated by reading lamps. From the cathedral-high brick walls hung portraits of the college’s former wardens and founders beneath stained glass windows. As I lingered over a breakfast of sausages, roasted tomato, baked beans and eggs, I found myself staring up at the image of the college’s namesake, the Rev. John Keble, and could have sworn I saw him fidget within his frame. All that was missing was a flurry of owls delivering the mail.

headline: Sleeping in a British Dorm
text: From singles to family suites, universities are renting out their rooms.

headline: In Frodo’s Footsteps
text: SLOWLY but surely, our ship was shrinking.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Veritas, in Cambridge, Mass.
text: BASICS

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A couple relaxes below the Manhattan Bridge, in the New York’s Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: From Fires to Fish, Heat Wave Batters Russia
text: RYBKHOZ, Russia  This is a country that knows how to handle the cold, swaggering about during the most brutal of winters. But the heat is another story. And there has never been heat like this.

headline: Rangel Case Poses Test for Democrats as Elections Near
text: WASHINGTON  In laying out 13 charges of ethical violations committed by Representative Charles B. Rangel, the House ethics committee set the stage for a rare public trial of the Democratic Congressman this fall, a potential embarrassment for the Democratic leadership during the election season.

headline: Dickey and Davis Help Mets to First Series Win Since June
text: The Mets have said all year that their goal is to win the National League East. But in the last month they have harnessed a shorter-term aspiration: to win a series.

headline: How Fast Can a Cloud Run?
text: The cloud has been put on notice: It’s being watched.

headline: Toasting the InterContinental’s Opening
text: The glassification of seedy old Times Square marched on Thursday morning with the official “vine-cutting” ceremony to celebrate the opening of the new 36-story InterContinental Hotel, which has brought 607 guest rooms, a Todd English restaurant, lounge and cafe and several measures of eco-friendliness to a long stretch of 44th Street at Eighth Avenue. The hotel, which named its meeting rooms after Manhattan parks, uses compact fluorescent and L.E.D. lights, low-flow toilets, “green” housekeeping products and off-site composting.

headline: When Unemployed Means Unhealthy Too
text: “I used to have a doctor,” she said, matter-of-factly, “but when I got laid off six months ago I lost my insurance.” Ms. C. shifted in her chair while I took notes during our first medical visit. “So I didn’t do anything about my knee, but when it got so painful that I couldn’t walk, I had to go to the emergency room.”

headline: Asked and Answered | Ron Galella
text: Ron Galella has been called a “creep,” a “parasite” and a “stalker.” These are just a few of the litany of insults hurled by the talking heads in “Smash His Camera,” a new documentary about the preeminent American paparazzo.

headline: A Weekend in East Hampton
text: The lavish seaside village on Long Island has hardly slowed down.

headline: Pelosi Defends Democrats on Ethics
text: With clouds swirling over Representative Charles B. Rangel, Speaker Nancy Pelosi defended Democrats’ record on ethics on Thursday.

headline: Five and Five: No. 42, Northwestern
text: Paul Myerberg is getting you ready for the upcoming college football season over at Pre-Snap Read. The Quad will also feature a daily look at each of Paul’s top 50 teams in the country heading into the season opener. Today’s team, No. 42, is Northwestern. You can find a larger Northwestern preview at Pre-Snap Read.

headline: Editor of Chess Informant Dies
text: Zdenko Krnic, 62, the long-time editor and director of Chess Informant died on July 23 from injuries sustained after being hit by a motorcycle in Belgrade, Serbia, on his way home from work. His death was reported on the company’s Web site.

headline: Sarkozy Toughens on Illegal Roma
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy has ordered the expulsion of illegal Roma and itinerant immigrants and the dismantlement of their camps in a move that has been labeled by human rights groups as xenophobic and criticized by his political opponents.

headline: Rangel to Stand Trial Before House Ethics Panel
text: The House ethics committee laid out 13 charges of House rules violations against Representative Charles B. Rangel today after he failed to reach a settlement to avoid the rare and potentially embarrassing proceeding.

headline: The TV Watch: Obama Takes in ‘The View’
text: An appearance by President Obama on the ABC daytime talk show “The View” was broadcast on Thursday morning. Jackie Calmes of The New York Times wrote about it here for The Caucus blog; below, The Times’s Alessandra Stanley offers some of her thoughts about the interview. Post your comments about Mr. Obama’s visit to “The View” here.

headline: M.P.A.A. Ends Talks With Kerrey
text: The Motion Picture Association of America said it ended negotiations with Bob Kerrey, the former United States senator who for months has been in talks to become the association’s chief executive. Bob Pisano, the group’s president, has been serving as its interim chief executive since Dan Glickman left in April to become the president of Refugees International. The M.P.A.A. said in a statement that its search for a new chief executive would continue. When asked for comment, Mr. Kerrey said, “We simply could not reach agreement.”

headline: ‘New Photography 2010’ Coming to MoMA
text: When it comes to photography there is nothing new about appropriation, specifically, photographing other photographs, often from magazine ads, then enlarging and exhibiting them in galleries. It is an art form that has been practiced for decades by Andy Warhol, Richard Prince and Dash Snow. Generally, however, those doing the appropriating start with someone else’s work.

headline: A Stable and Its Dakota Connection
text: Q. Did the Dakota Stables, once at Broadway and 75th, have any connection to the Dakota apartment house? ... Michael S. Lambe, Carmel, N.Y.

headline: 36 Hours in East Hampton
text: A SLUGGISH economy and a tepid real estate market have done little to dampen the humming social scene that is the Hamptons. Lately, the loudest buzz on the East End of Long Island has been from Montauk, where shabby motels and quaint restaurants are being remade into boho-chic establishments. Yet the lavish seaside villages of the Hamptons have hardly slowed down. That’s especially true in East Hampton, arguably the center of the social swirl. A raft of luxurious boutiques and restaurants has opened. Beloved old hotels and barrooms have been renovated. And celebrities — most recently Madonna — are snapping up property in the area.

headline: Four Corners, Two Wheels
text: WE had awakened before dawn to get a jump on the desert heat and rolled out under a headlight moon, pedaling fast in the cool morning of the Dolores River Canyon. There were no cars, not out here. There was only the sound of bike tires on asphalt, the river’s murmur, the cascading song of a canyon wren and that beginning-of-the-world smell of river mud in the blue morning. Horses nuzzled the rough cottonwoods by the riverbank. Pale sandstone walls rose up around us and caught the colors of sunrise.

headline: Silicon Valley Venture Capitalists Are Feeling Glum
text: Confidence among venture capitalists in Silicon Valley weakened in the second quarter, according to a new industry report, as concerns over financing, the economy and new regulations added to an already tough working environment.

headline: What the Financial Overhaul Means for Renters
text: There’s some good news for tenants in the recently signed financial overhaul legislation.

headline: Gas and a Six-Pack of Squid
text: AT Tom’s Citgo in Rockaway Park, you can fill up, check the oil, and pick up a bag of squid and the fishing report.

headline: How Did William Shatner Interview a D.C. Sniper? He Asked.
text: LOS ANGELES — In an interview to  be televised Thursday night, one of the D.C. snipers, Lee Boyd Malvo, said he and the other convicted gunman, John Muhammad, had co-conspirators.

headline: A Brigantine Beneath Washington Street
text: The 18th-century vessel unearthed two weeks ago in Lower Manhattan has begun to emerge from the mist of history.

headline: Why So Many Predators?
text: This morning I woke up to a huge splash just offshore. I don’t even look any more as I know it is a large predator, either a jack or a shark, feeding in the lagoon. You get used to them here. You have to. The six scientists from the American Museum of Natural History, at this field station for two weeks to study sea turtles, regularly see at least 10 sharks, and sometimes we see 40 to 50 in a day if we concentrate. I am particularly fond of the shark pups – the size of my forearm or so – but the often-curious larger sharks (black tips in the shallow flats as well as Galapagos sharks on the deeper dives) can be a bit disconcerting, especially if you are concentrating on something else and only notice them as they swim past for a closer look. Other scientists have had close encounters with tiger sharks, but I have not yet seen them. I just see evidence of them on the turtles. When we are checking turtles over in the health analyses, we see healed wounds that make me crazy trying to figure out how the turtles survived. In some, the shell looks like a cookie with a bite out of it.

headline: Shakespeare to ‘Scrubs’ to a Stint Off Broadway
text: WHAT does a guy do when he’s still in his 30s and has already achieved everything he ever dreamed about?

headline: Edna St. Vincent Millay’s Home; the Apollo; Irons Galore
text: In 1950, a few days after the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay was found dead at the bottom of a narrow staircase in her 1890s farmhouse in Austerlitz, N.Y., her actress sister, Norma Millay Ellis, moved in. Ellis stayed there until her death in 1986 and treated the place like a shrine.

headline: Nissan Leaf Rollout Plan Has Some Surprises
text: Just hours after confirming that its coming Leaf would match the Chevrolet Volt’s eight-year, 100,000-mile battery warranty, Nissan disclosed the rollout schedule for the brand’s fully electric compact car.

headline: Deflation Risks
text: Good news: more people at the Fed are taking the risk of a Japanese-type trap seriously.

headline: The Avant-Garde, No Longer Avant
text: In a grainy black-and-white film from the 1960s, the artists Vito Acconci and Stephen Kaltenbach try to push each other out of the picture frame. In another of similar vintage, Bruce Nauman bounces in a corner as if in an autistic trance. In a color film called “Freedom” from 1970, Yoko Ono tries to get out of her purple bra by breaking the connecting cord in front as a droning sound composed by John Lennon plays in the background.

headline: Slipping Away With Two Country Gentlemen
text: Genial, intractable, unvarnished, in control: these were all equally true of Willie Nelson and Levon Helm on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall. Each led his working band, engaging a cross-section of old-time American music, from folk and country to gospel, blues, early jazz, rock ’n’ roll. Both men were radiant with authority and its trickier cousin, authenticity. The difference between them came down to effort.

headline: Who’s That Joking While You’re Out Jogging?
text: COMEDY is a treacherous business under the best of circumstances. Telling jokes to paying customers from a nightclub stage can be fun, but there are risks: you could be heckled by a drunk, upstaged by a noisy bachelorette party or, even worse, ignored.

headline: New Restrictions Placed on Debt Settlement Companies
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday announced restrictions on companies that purport to help borrowers get rid of crippling amounts of debt. The effort aims to address complaints about lenders that charge huge fees but fail to reduce the obligations of customers in debt.

headline: In Basel, Eternal Work In Progress
text: Never again.

headline: Lessons From Two Important Climate Forecasts
text: This is a tale of two climate forecasts — one successful, the other not. The successful forecast is described in a nice post on Realclimate.org commemorating the approaching 35th anniversary of “Climatic Change: Are We on the Bring of a Pronounced Global warming?” This pivotal paper was written by Wallace Broecker, one of the deans of modern climate science. (To get a feel for Broecker’s work and approach, please read this fine 1998 profile by my onetime colleague William K. Stevens.)

headline: Ristretto | Kyoto to Stay
text: Recently, Bryan Waites adjusted the two slow-drip coffee makers that he brought from Japan and set up on the counter of Caffetteria SoHo, a coffee bar that opened in Manhattan last month. Before, it took around 14 hours for each one to produce 1.5 liters of coffee, which is served iced. Now it’s 18 hours.

headline: Mets Hold Onto Niese as Phillies Acquire Oswalt
text: The Philadelphia Phillies acquired Roy Oswalt from the Houston Astros in a deal that will help them this year and possibly for two more. The Phillies will send J.A. Happ and two prospects to the Astros for Oswalt and cash. Oswalt waived his no-trade clause, moving the deal forward.

headline: Beveridge Worries
text: — Woody Allen

headline: America’s Laziest States
text: Bloomberg Businessweek has a provocative ranking of which states are “laziest,” based on how their residents report spending their time (primarily via data from the American Time Use Survey).

headline: Where the Ascetic Meets the Athletic
text: The story of yoga in America, as many journalists have pointed out, is the story of assimilation, diversification and, more recently, commodification. Although there are many devoted students of yoga, who regard it as an exacting physical and spiritual discipline, there are also many trendy yoga consumers today, who regard it simply as another form of exercise like spinning or Pilates, as a hip new way to stay fit and lower stress, or even as a celebrity-inspired fad. Arguing that the varieties of yogic experience in America can “leave you metaphorically standing on your head,” a recent article in The Hindustan Times noted there are now such things as circus yoga, nude yoga, pre- and postnatal yoga, acro yoga (acrobatics), Christian yoga, hip-hop yoga, even yoga for dogs (“doga”).

headline: Pakistani Journalists Bemoan Chaos After Plane Crash
text: Reporters and editors at the Pakistani newspaper Dawn have criticized the government for what they describe as a chaotic emergency response to a plane crash outside the capital, Islamabad, that killed 152 people on Wednesday.

headline: James Is the Story, Even When ESPN Doesn’t Want It
text: Covering LeBron James with standard journalistic rigor is getting to be a problem for ESPN.

headline: French Mother Indicted in Smothering of Infants
text: PARIS  A nursing assistant in her mid-40s from a small village in northern France was charged with murder Thursday in the smothering of eight of her own infants, born in secret over nearly two decades. It appeared to be France’s worst case of infanticide.

headline: Council Approves Plan for Domino Site
text: The City Council approved on Thursday the long-delayed, $1.5 billion plan to turn the crumbling Domino Sugar refinery into a residential development on the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, waterfront with glass-and-masonry towers, stores and a quarter-mile esplanade.

headline: Free Coffee at At65 Cafe
text: Giorgio Milos, the 2008 barista champion of Italy, columnist and Illy Caffe “master barista,” will be giving away coffee on Friday from noon to 2 p.m. at a pushcart set up in front of At65 Cafe, by the entrance to Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center.

headline: To Win Dollar, Avis Would Sell More Assets
text: With the unveiling of its takeover bid for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, the Avis Budget Group is arguing that its offer is financially superior to an earlier, agreed proposal by Hertz Global Holdings.

headline: Dragon NaturallySpeaking 11
text: Nuance's Dragon NaturallySpeaking 11 improves on the company's previous dictation programs, but does not make any fundamental changes.

headline: When Pets Reach Across the Aisle
text: Kids say the smartest things. A few minutes into a screening of “Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore,” a child near me turned to his mother and asked, “Why is Kitty Galore called Kitty Galore?”

headline: Questions About Caregiving and the Law
text: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices in Kansas City, Mo., and on occasion fields questions about caregiving and the law from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves can’t offer personal legal advice. Check back in the coming weeks for his answers.

headline: Afghanistan’s Green Zone
text: SANGIN, Afghanistan — To those who spent time in Baghdad during 2003-2009, the phrase “Green Zone” conjures up a walled sanctuary on the Tigris, with Americans in uniforms or suits occupying gaudy Baathist palaces and only the occasional interruption of war from the city beyond.

If you guessed “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse,” you are of course not wrong, but the correct answer today is “Charlie St. Cloud.”

text: We all get the first-tee jitters. We have all experienced the frustration of hitting it great on the practice range and then dubbing one when it finally counts.

headline: A Kite That Couldn’t Be Tied Down
text: IN honor of Persephone!” she announced, cracking open a pinkish orb. She handed me half and I stared, shocked, at the gleaming maroon seeds. She was plucking them with abandon, letting the juice stain her fingers, not caring. I tried to breathe.

headline: Getting the Old Band Back Together
text: A messy, comedic sprawl that leaks at the seams, the Romanian director Radu Mihaileanu’s “Concert” aspires to be something like a French-Russian answer to “The Producers.” Lunging wildly between satirical farce and teary sentimentality, the movie follows the misadventures of a ragtag symphony orchestra that travels from Moscow to Paris under false pretenses.

headline: History at 500 Yards
text: The Appleseed Project is dedicated to teaching every American how to fire a bullet through a man-sized target from up to five hundred yards.

headline: Standardized English Tests to Resume in Iran Amid Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON  The Educational Testing Service, the company that offers the Test of English as a Foreign Language, announced Thursday that it would resume registering students for its tests inside Iran after striking a deal with a bank willing to process payments.

headline: The Appleseed Project: A Call to Arms
text: The group, dedicated to teaching every American how to fire a bullet, ran a training course in Carmi, Ill.

headline: Firing Line
text: One June morning last year, Jack Dailey drove from his home in North Carolina’s Piedmont country, through verdant, hilly farmland to a rifle range near the town of Ramseur. Eleven men and a woman had mustered there for a weeklong boot camp run by the Appleseed Project, a group Dailey started that is dedicated to teaching every American how to fire a bullet through a man-size target out to 500 yards. So far Appleseed has taught 25,000 people to shoot; 7,000 more will learn by the end of this year. Its instructors teach this skill not for the purpose of hunting or sport. They see marksmanship as fundamental to Americans’ ability to defend their liberty, whether against foreigners or the agents of a (hypothetical) tyrannical government. Appleseed frames this activity as being somewhere between a historical re-enactment and a viable last resort. I came to find out how serious they were.

headline: With Failure as an Ingredient, He Made His Own Magic
text: “Brion Gysin was a subversive,” we are told in a wall text just off the elevator at this New Museum retrospective. Gay and itinerant, he had “no family, no clique, no fixed profession and, often, no fixed address.” He lived on multiple continents. He communed or collaborated with William S. Burroughs, Alice B. Toklas and the Rolling Stones. His artwork was shape-shifting; his methods fell outside the pantheon of recognized mediums.

text: It was like Earth Day for the New York City Council on Thursday as members passed legislation to improve air quality and expand recycling programs.

Recently, he has also been in hot pursuit of some New York real estate, and it seems he’s finally got his man — or co-op, in this case.

text: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Fire Department has worked to bolster its counterterrorism and disaster preparedness repertoires in all sorts of ways – from practical to conceptual.

headline: In the Tour Van: Marley, Gucci Mane and More
text: A YEAR or so ago Wavves was a one-man, noise-pop band, tricked out with a drummer for live shows, playing in underground clubs with scratchy sound. Its second album, “Wavvves” (2009), attracted a lot of critical acclaim and blog love. Now the group, let by Nathan Williams, a former record shop manager, has gained in size and ambition. Its third album, “King of the Beach,” due out Tuesday from Fat Possum, fine-tunes the D.I.Y. California feel with better production, more melody and less thrash. In the meantime Wavves, from San Diego, has gone through some typical young-band growing pains  including lineup changes, embarrassingly blunt blog posts and interviews, and onstage meltdowns.

headline: David Bouley Sells Apartment

headline: In Case This Wasn’t Clear, It’s All About the Mattress
text: Shakespeare’s romantic comedy “Twelfth Night” juggles many elements: gender-bending, mistaken identities, court intrigue, class struggles. But in the version now at the Theater at St. Clement’s, it all resolves to the bed. The central stage furnishing is a framed mattress on wheels, the better to accommodate just about every couple in the play.

headline: Letters: The New Abortion Providers
text: The photo of Dr. Emily Godfrey on the cover gave me goose bumps. I applaud her willingness to stand up and be seen as an advocate and a physician, meeting her patients’ needs as they arise. My ob-gyn (along with other doctors in her large practice) has provided care for me through cervical surgery, the birth of my two children and an abortion after my second child was born. I expect she will guide me through whatever else life may bring, because she is my doctor when I need her and not when it suits her.

headline: Deft Surgery for a Painting Under the Scalpel
text: If art conservation is like surgery, then early handlers of Thomas Eakins’s masterpiece, “The Gross Clinic,” violated the Hippocratic oath: “First, do no harm.”

headline: Where Classical, Rock, Pop and Folk Meet
text: Ethel is a string quartet that has always wanted to be a rock band. From its start, in 1998, it has used amplification as well as the same pedals and sound-processing devices that rock bands use, and it plays only new music, including pieces by its members. In its Wednesday evening concert at Damrosch Park, as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors, Ethel moved more decisively into the pop world by joining forces with performing songwriters from several corners of rock, pop and folk music.

headline: No More Barges but Plenty of Beauty
text: AS American canals go, the Erie, which famously linked Buffalo to Albany in the early 19th century, gets all the glory. But at its peak in the 1860s, the V-shaped Delaware and Raritan Canal running through central New Jersey was no pipsqueak transportation system. One year it even outdid the Erie in tonnage carried. And since the early 1970s the narrow waterway has been the centerpiece of a 70-mile-long state park popular with bikers, walkers, fishermen and boaters.
