headline: Disc in Hand, Expecting to Fly
text: IT’S 6 in the morning, and I nod to Peter, the investment manager; Tom, the retail designer; and Eli, his son, among a dozen or so others who have quietly made their way to this field in Pelham, N.Y., for our twice-a-week game of ultimate. Dew still clings to the turf, and there is very little talking as we go through our pregame rituals: the slow stretches, the light jogs, the marking off of the field with orange cones. Even the warm-up throws of the disc, working out the kinks of forehands and backhands, are nearly silent as we prepare to play.

headline: Bankrupt Rangers Owe Rodriguez $24.9 Million
text: Alex Rodriguez is owed a lot of money, and he wants to make sure he gets it all. That is the focus of the objection he filed in a bankruptcy court in Texas on Wednesday.

headline: Did The Americans With Disabilities Act Work?
text: I don’t know whether it’s the lingering influence of a long era of conservative dominance (which forced liberals to grapple seriously with their critics on the right) or a consequence of the internet age (which places endless studies and PDFs and policy documents at the fingertips of every columnist and blogger), but I feel like there’s been a definite drop-off in what you might call “sentimental liberal” arguments for policy measures, in which the good intentions of a given piece of legislation are treated as the only argument necessary to justify its passage. Even when liberals are making the contemporary equivalent of Robert Fulghum’s sententious claim that “it will be a great day when our schools have all the money they need, and our air force has to have a bake-sale to buy a bombers,” they usually have a Congressional Budget Office report to back it up.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Movies

headline: ‘Come Fly Away’ to Close on Broadway in September
text: “Come Fly Away,” the Broadway musical that married the choreography of Twyla Tharp with the music of Frank Sinatra, announced it would close at the Marquis Theater on Sept. 5. (At right, Karine Plantadit and Keith Roberts.) It will have played 26 previews and 187 regular performances. A national tour is scheduled to open in Chicago in March. The show’s weekly grosses climbed after the musical opened last March, hitting a peak of $918,318 in the final week of April. But grosses have since declined steadily. Last week the show grossed $574,485 and sold about half of the 1,611 seats in the Marquis. Ms. Tharp was nominated for a Tony for her choreography, but the award went to Bill T. Jones, the choreographer of “Fela!”

headline: American Ballet Theater to Return to Cuba for Havana Festival
text: American Ballet Theater will perform in Cuba for the first time in 50 years as part of the Havana International Ballet Festival, Rachel Moore, the company’s executive director, announced on Thursday. The appearance, on Nov. 3-6, is part of a celebration of the 90th birthday of Alicia Alonso, director of the National Ballet of Cuba and a former member of American Ballet Theater, who was honored in June in New York with a performance by the company at the Metropolitan Opera. The trip to Cuba comes at Ms. Alonso’s personal invitation. The festival will feature principal dancers and soloists from American Ballet Theater and include a performance of “Theme and Variations,” the ballet George Balanchine created for American Ballet Theater and Ms. Alonso in 1947, as well as other works. The company last performed in Cuba in 1960. “This historic visit to Cuba is significant on many levels,” Ms. Moore said in a statement. “It honors A.B.T.’s past by recognizing the contributions of Alicia Alonso and looks to the future by establishing an international dialogue with our artistic counterparts in Cuba.”

headline: With the End of a Legal Dispute, a Schiele Comes to Manhattan
text: A 1912 Egon Schiele painting, above, at the center of a legal dispute that dragged on for more than a decade, is now on view in New York at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan. The battle over its ownership was finally resolved last week when the Leopold Museum in Vienna agreed to pay $19 million to the heirs of Lea Bondi Jaray, a Jewish gallery owner in Vienna, from whom the work, “Portrait of Wally,” was seized by a Nazi agent in 1938. In 1997 the painting was lent to the Museum of Modern Art for an exhibition of Schiele paintings and subpoenaed by the Manhattan district attorney’s office amid claims that it did not rightfully belong to the Leopold, whose founder acquired it in 1954. The painting was eventually seized by the United States government. The government has now dismissed its case against the Leopold Museum and released the work, which will remain on display in Manhattan through Aug. 18 before going back to the Leopold.

headline: Biking America's Southwest
text: Bikers take a five-day, 400-mile cycling trip through remote and spectacular canyon-country roads.

headline: Rafael Viñoly Design Is Chosen for Edward M. Kennedy Institute
text: The architect Rafael Viñoly has been chosen to design the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate, a memorial and educational center dedicated to the career of Mr. Kennedy, who died of cancer in 2009, the institute announced on Wednesday. A white-and-gray complex overlooking Boston Harbor, the complex, above, will stand beside the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum at the University of Massachusetts, Boston. It will include classrooms, a replica of Mr. Kennedy’s Senate office and a re-creation of the Senate chamber with interactive desktops to provide information about the senators who have served in those seats and their voting records. Construction is expected to begin in the fall.

headline: Beer and Bait at Tom’s
text: A gas station in the Rockaways, Queens, that has been serving beer and bait since 1972.

headline: ‘Talent’ Pares Down Competition
text: Four more performers advanced to the semifinals of “America’s Got Talent” on Wednesday as that NBC reality show topped the night’s ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 9.5 million viewers tuned in to “America’s Got Talent.” CBS was in second place over all with a lineup that included “Big Brother” (6.6 million). Fox ranked third, averaging 5.3 million viewers for “So You Think You Can Dance.” ABC finished a distant fourth with comedy reruns followed by a repeat of “Castle” (3.5 million).

headline: Kanye West’s Next Video: A Personal Apocalypse
text: When you’ve had the kind of 2009 that Kanye West endured, how do you organize your 2010 charm offensive to tell your audience you’re not the same person you used to be? If you’re Mr. West, you release a music video teeming with debauchery, degradation and the specter of death. In a coming video for his single “Power,” created by the artist Marco Brambilla, Mr. West, above, is seen standing imposingly with a heavy chain around his neck. As he raps, the camera slowly zooms out in one continuous, unedited take to reveal him in a classical structure, surrounded by female attendants partly or entirely nude; some kneel before him on all fours, others wear devil horns and others are suspended upside down from the ceiling. The sword of Damocles hangs over Mr. West’s head, and behind him an unseen executioner is preparing to strike him with a blade. In a telephone interview, Mr. Brambilla explained that he was drawn to the project because, he said, “it’s kind of apocalyptic, in a very personal way.” The video is to be posted on Mr. West’s Web site sometime next week, Mr. Brambilla said, and will be provided to MTV and other music channels.

headline: Dance Theater Workshop Announces New Season
text: As talks continue about a possible merger between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, the theater on Thursday announced a full 2010-11 season featuring the work of choreographers from Europe, Africa and of course the United States. The lineup includes a collaboration between the German choreographer and performer and Faustin Linyekula of Congo; new work by Richard Move, who will recreate a 1963 interview with Martha Graham; and the French choreographer Alain Buffard’s “Inconsolés,” a work set to Schubert and . Complete information and schedule is at dancetheaterworkshop.org. Representatives for the theater said merger talks would probably conclude in late fall.

headline: Small Business Jobs Bill Stalls in Senate
text: Democrats attempting to wrap up work on a small business jobs bill were stymied Thursday morning when they were unable to break a Republican filibuster. In calling for a vote to end debate on the bill, Harry Reid, the majority leader, said that he had won the support of one Republican — enough to reach the 60-vote threshold. But when the vote was counted, all the Republicans held together. The final tally was 58 to 42 — Mr. Reid switched his vote to no in a procedural maneuver that allows him to call for another vote and try again.

headline: From the Killing Fields, on a Mission of Truth
text: “Some say that almost two million people died in the killing fields,” declares Thet Sambath, a polite, soft-spoken Cambodian journalist for The Phnom Penh Post, in the opening moments of the documentary “Enemies of the People.” He adds, “Nobody understands why so many people were killed at that time.”

headline: Mets Take Intentional Pass on Possible Trades
text: Two ace pitchers changed teams this month for precisely the kind of commodities the Mets could have offered. Three weeks ago, when the Seattle Mariners traded Cliff Lee to the Texas Rangers, the major prize was a rookie first baseman. On Thursday, when the Houston Astros shipped Roy Oswalt to the Philadelphia Phillies, a young left-handed starter headlined the package.

headline: How Phoebe Prince’s Father Feels
text: Over on Slate.com, Emily Bazelon writes of her interview with Jeremy Prince, the father of Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide in January after being bullied at school, the first interview given by either of her parents.

headline: 2 Big Internet Gambling Companies to Merge
text: Two of the biggest European operators of Internet betting sites, PartyGaming and Bwin Interactive Entertainment, said Thursday that they planned to merge, forming the world’s largest publicly traded online gambling company, The New York Times’s Eric Pfanner reports from Paris.

headline: Charming Socialites, Although Palm Beach Is Still Out of Reach
text: In “The Extra Man,” a whimsical, screwball ode to urban eccentricity, Kevin Kline and Paul Dano, as unlikely roommates in a shabby apartment on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, play out a comic pas de deux. The movie, directed by Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman (the team who achieved critical glory with “American Splendor,” then slipped with “The Nanny Diaries”), shows few of the familiar signposts of contemporary Manhattan. The wispy tale of Louis Ives (Mr. Dano), a shy, inhibited young man who loses his job as a New Jersey prep school teacher and moves to New York with hopes of becoming a novelist, was adapted for the screen from a Jonathan Ames novel by the directors in collaboration with the author.

headline: Ben Roethlisberger’s Journey to Notoriety
text: Before the two Super Bowl titles, the $102 million contract and the well-chronicled accusations of sexual assault, Ben Roethlisberger was a college quarterback in 2004, about to realize his dream of playing in the N.F.L.

headline: How Can You Enjoy Your Own Funeral? For Starters, Don’t Die
text: “Get Low,” the first feature directed by Aaron Schneider, is based on one of those true stories that seem indistinguishable from legend. In the late 1930s a man from East Tennessee named Felix Breazeale decided to give himself a funeral before he was even dead. It was, by all accounts, a lively affair, with musical entertainment and a raffle to attract the public, and it left behind a vapor trail of mystery. Who was this character? What was he thinking?

headline: A New York Protest of Arizona Immigration Law
text: They gathered at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge on Thursday, hundreds drawn to a march and rally against an immigration law that was to go into effect thousands of miles away in Arizona, until a federal judge blocked the most controversial parts of the law from going into effect.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Brothers With $550 Million Fraud
text: WASHINGTON  Samuel and Charles Wyly, the billionaire brothers from Dallas who are large donors to philanthropies and to conservative causes, were charged Thursday with conducting an extensive securities fraud that the Securities and Exchange Commission said reaped $550 million in undisclosed gains.

headline: The Man, the Magazine, the Mansion: The World According to Hef
text: It doesn’t bode well that in the opening moments of Brigitte Berman’s doting, overlong hagiography,  “Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel,” the putative voice of God belongs to Gene Simmons, the smarmy, cynical leader of the rock band Kiss. Mr. Simmons remarks with a slight smirk that he doesn’t know any man who wouldn’t give his left testicle to be Mr. Hefner.

headline: At This Neighborhood Joint, Gas and a Six-Pack of Squid
text: At Tom’s Citgo in Rockaway Park, you can fill up, check the oil, and pick up a bag of squid and the fishing report.

headline: Do the Notorious Paparazzo’s Photos Qualify as Art or Just Agita?
text: The celebrity photographer Ron Galella, the subject of “Smash His Camera,” may not be a household name, but as the title of this documentary suggests, he inspires some very strong feelings. The movie, directed by Leon Gast, is a portrait of Mr. Galella, a dogged, large-framed man whose vocation, for more than four decades, has been chasing down famous people and, whether they want him to or not, snapping pictures of them.

text: Kristian R. Dyer covers the N.F.L. for FoxSports.com and is the publisher of the subscription site GreenAndWhiteReport.com, which covers the Jets. He can be reached at KristianRDyer@yahoo.com and followed at twitter.com/kdyer1012.

headline: Wyly Brothers Charged With $550 Million Fraud
text: 7:55 p.m. | Updated Samuel and Charles Wyly, the billionaire brothers from Dallas who are large donors to conservative causes, were charged late Thursday with conducting an extensive securities fraud that the Securities and Exchange Commission said reaped them $550 million in undisclosed gains, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

headline: Alan G. Parker Revisits Sid Vicious’s Worst Moment
How Should ‘Microphone’ be Abbreviated?
text: In my recent column on the expression "rock the mic," I wrote that "the M.C.'s of early hip-hop took the verb [rock] in a new direction, transforming the microphone (abbreviated in rap circles as mic, not mike) into an emblem of stylish display." Laurence Reich e-mails regarding mic: "I must confess I have never seen that word before. I've only seen mike for that usage." Ted Estersohn e-mails: "As far as I can tell mic the short form has always been spelled in audio and engineering circles with a 'c,' like an abbreviation and not like the boy's name."

headline: Telling a Soldier’s Tale
text: Sincere performances elevate an underdeveloped script and awkward filmmaking in “The Dry Land,” a coming-home drama as inexpressive as its traumatized lead.

headline: A Portrait of Depression

text: Updated | July 31 2:40 p.m.:  Clarifying the source of the information about Google’s revenue in China.

headline: DeMint Backs Rossi in Washington
text: Senator Jim DeMint is at it again.

headline: For Crittenden, a Bad Time to Be at Citigroup
text: Gary L. Crittenden, the former chief financial officer of Citigroup, joined the bank in February 2007, a few months before the subprime mortgage crisis erupted, shaking the financial system. At the time he told The New York Times that this was “the best job I could ever imagine.”

headline: A State of Transformation
text: In “What’s the Matter With Kansas?,” a documentary spun from Thomas Frank’s 2004 book, the director-producer Joe Winston and the producer Laura Cohen ostensibly seek the reasons for the transformation of a once-fiercely populist Democratic state into a Republican redoubt. They spend much of the film, shot in 2006, looking at Immanuel Baptist Church in Wichita, led by the Rev. Terry Fox, a firebrand preacher railing against gay marriage, the Koran, abortion and the A.C.L.U.

headline: Cloned Livestock Gain a Foothold in Europe
text: ALBRIGHTON, England  Many Europeans recoil at the very idea of cloning animals. But a handful of breeders in Switzerland, Britain and possibly other countries have imported semen and embryos from cloned animals or their progeny from the United States, seeking to create more consistently plump and productive livestock.

headline: Pentagon Report Places Blame for Suicides
text: WASHINGTON — At a time of record-high military suicides, commanders are ignoring the mental health problems of American soldiers and not winnowing out enough of those with records of substance abuse and crime, a United States Army report has concluded.

headline: Tourists Discover You Can’t Get There From Here
text: TEEC NOS POS, Ariz.  What if you traveled hundreds or even thousands of miles to be in four states at one time, and got only two?

headline: White House Seeks to Clarify F.B.I. Powers vis-à-vis E-Mail
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has asked Congress to give clear authority to the Federal Bureau of Investigation to obtain records related to the context of e-mails and other Internet-based communications without first obtaining a warrant from a judge.

headline: Serious Adulthood Waiting to Happen
text: Sunny is a former high school honors student who dropped out of college a year or so ago to tend her father, who’s dying of cancer. Now she’s working at a bowling alley in Pensacola, Fla.; dating her well-meaning but unambitious boyfriend, Neal; hanging with her best friend, Amy, who is rearing a baby after a shotgun marriage to the child’s dim father; and flirting with her former school rival, Isaac, an aspiring comedian down from New York City for the holidays. She’s bored out of her mind.

headline: Report Suggests Paterson Allowed Evidence to Be Leaked
text: In her report on Wednesday clearing Gov. David A. Paterson of witness tampering, the independent counsel who conducted the investigation raised what amounted to a new accusation: that the governor failed to deliver on a promise of full cooperation by allowing evidence in the case to be shared with witnesses.

headline: Ellen DeGeneres Leaving ‘American Idol’
text: LOS ANGELES  Walking away from a five-year contract worth tens of millions of dollars, Ellen DeGeneres said Thursday evening that she was leaving “American Idol” on Fox after just one season because it was not a “right fit” for her. In bowing out, she joins the infamous judge Simon Cowell, who departed in May.

headline: Gates Assails WikiLeaks Over Release of Reports
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday denounced the disclosure this week of 75,000 classified documents about the Afghanistan war by the Web site WikiLeaks, asserting that the security breach had endangered lives and damaged the ability of others to trust the United States government to protect their secrets.

headline: Revamped Patriots Want Brady to Remain
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Even before Bill Belichick had the reminders of past Patriots glory removed from the players’ areas of Gillette Stadium, this felt like a transition for the team that has dominated the conversation and expectations of the N.F.L. for nearly a decade. But when the pictures of Rodney Harrison and Willie McGinest and Troy Brown were packed and put into storage, one by one, the message was unmistakable, the break with an extraordinary run complete.

headline: For Star Boarder, Trying Hollywood May Be Next Move
text: Shaun White has been preparing for a return to skateboard competition at the X Games by practicing on a large ramp set up on the Paramount Pictures studio lot in Hollywood.

headline: Catch of the Day
text: In the late fall of 2009, bluefin tuna came inshore along the New Jersey coast and began to crash the surface of the ocean, chasing bait. For days, fast, open fishing boats played run-and-gun with them across the waters near Deal and Asbury Park, not 30 miles from New York City as the gannet flies.

headline: Back to a Summer Idyll, With New Anxieties
text: PHOENIX, La.  At the Zion Travelers day camp here on the east bank of the Mississippi River, the morning begins with clap-and-stomp chants, two dozen children in an air-conditioned white trailer, shouting and shimmying and stamping their feet.

headline: Frenzy of Speculation Over Clinton’s Wedding
text: Of all the grave questions news organizations are grappling with these days, one that is truly stumping them is which superlative to attach to Chelsea Clinton’s wedding.

headline: FDA Links Hormone Spray to Breast Growth in Children
text: A hormone spray prescribed to stop hot flashes in menopausal women has caused breasts to sprout in children who were inadvertently exposed to it through skin contact with women using it, the Food and Drug Administration said. The agency is urging users to keep children away from skin that has been sprayed. The product, Evamist, which contains estrogen, is supposed to be sprayed on the forearm. Since Evamist was approved in 2007, the drug agency has received eight reports of abnormal breast development in boys and girls ages 3 to 5 who had contact with women using it. In some cases the children recovered when the exposure was stopped. Pets have also been affected.

headline: Taliban Make Inroads in Strategic Province
text: In the strategic northern province of Baghlan, Afghans deprived of jobs and government services  are turning to Taliban courts for speedy justice and drifting toward those who will pay them — either local strongmen or the Taliban.

headline: In Midterm Elections, Afghan War Barely Surfaces
text: BENSALEM, Pa.  Asked what he considers the major issues in this year’s midterm Congressional elections, Claude Nicolas, 24, paused from munching on a sushi roll and crisply ticked off three: jobs, the economy and immigration.

headline: Getting Into Med School Without Hard Sciences
text: For generations of pre-med students, three things have been as certain as death and taxes: organic chemistry, physics and the Medical College Admission Test, known by its dread-inducing acronym, the MCAT.

headline: Gulf of Mexico Has Long Been Dumping Site
text: HOUMA, La. — Loulan Pitre Sr. was born on the Gulf Coast in 1921, the son of an oysterman. Nearly all his life, he worked on the water, abiding by the widely shared faith that the resources of the Gulf of Mexico were limitless.

headline: More Time on Mound Instills More Trust
text: Jerry Manuel has removed R. A. Dickey from scoreless outings twice in the past five days. But unlike their views about Sunday’s game, manager and pitcher did not disagree with each other Thursday.

text: DENVER  In September 2008, a Guatemalan immigrant named Francis Hernandez sped his S.U.V. through a busy Aurora intersection and plowed into a pickup truck, knocking it into an ice cream parlor.

headline: Liquidationism Further Refuted
text: Following up on an earlier post: Heather Boushey shows that far from requiring an unusual amount of reallocation of workers across sectors, this recession has been unusually broadly spread across the economy.

headline: Yep, She’s Gone
text: As Brian Stelter reports, Fox announced on Thursday that Ellen DeGeneres, the comedian and talk show host, will not return to her post as a judge on the coming tenth season of “American Idol,” joining Simon Cowell and that “Pants on the Ground” guy to brave the elements of a world outside the protective bubble of “Idol.”

headline: The Clintons, All Quiet Now? What Torture!
text: Chelsea Clinton’s wedding this weekend will be a pleasant departure for her family: an important personal milestone that doesn’t double as a fund-raiser.

headline: Emotions Flare After Immigration Law Is Blocked
text: PHOENIX  As the Arizona governor on Thursday formally appealed a federal judge’s ruling that prevented the most contested parts of the state’s immigration law from taking effect, a burst of protest and recrimination made clear the ruling had hardly soothed emotions in the state.

headline: Taliban Exploit Openings in Neglected Province
text: PUL-I-KUMRI, Afghanistan  Almost unnoticed, this strategic northern province is slipping away from government control.

headline: Lawyers, Far From Gulf, Skirmish on Spill Claims

headline: The Stone-Throwing Kids

headline: Turkey Softens Law That Jailed Young Kurds
text: BATMAN, Turkey  Berivan Sayaca, a vivacious 15-year-old Kurdish girl, dreamed of escaping her life as a seamstress and studying law. Instead, she was convicted of supporting terrorism by attending a protest rally and sentenced to nearly eight years behind bars.

headline: Breaking a Promise on Surveillance
text: It is just a technical matter, the Obama administration says: We just need to make a slight change in a law to make clear that we have the right to see the names of anyone’s e-mail correspondents and their Web browsing history without the messy complication of asking a judge for permission.

headline: Gov. Paterson’s Non-Exoneration
text: Gov. David Paterson’s team has said many absurd things about his office’s attempt to interfere with assault charges against one of Mr. Paterson’s closest aides, but perhaps the most absurd of all was the claim that he was “exonerated” by the report issued by the former chief judge of New York State.

headline: Day 100: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Effort to Permanently Plug Well Is Progressing

headline: When Less Was No Longer More
text: Not long after the wrenching end of the Vietnam War, skyscrapers with pointed tops, stony-looking concrete walls and decorative marble bases — in other words, new buildings made to look like old ones — began to rise in American cities.

headline: Congressman Rangel Faces His Peers
text: It is disheartening for the nation that Representative Charles Rangel, once one of the most powerful members of Congress, must face 13 charges of violating House ethics rules.

headline: Coming Up on Innings Mark, Hughes Looks to Stay Strong
text: CLEVELAND  Phil Hughes said he felt strong, as if he could have kept pitching after the Yankees season ended last November, with his innings count at 111 2/3. Barring an injury or a catastrophic first inning, Hughes will surpass that total Friday against the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: The Beltway’s Lethal Ride
text: There is a chilling warning for the nation’s commuters in the scathing analysis of last year’s collision of two Washington subway trains that killed nine people and left dozens injured. According to the findings of the National Transportation Safety Board, automatic train control circuits had been malfunctioning for years on the region’s sprawling Metro system. The system’s managers were found to be negligent.

headline: Autopsies in Fire Find Mother Died by Suicide and Children Were Murdered
text: The deaths of four children in a house fire on Staten Island on July 22 have been ruled homicides, while their mother died by her own hand, according to autopsy results released by the city medical examiner’s office on Thursday.

headline: An Inquiry Ends With Some of the Same Questions It Began With
text: It became perhaps one of the most basic aims of the investigation into the Paterson administration’s involvement with a domestic abuse case against one of Gov. David A. Paterson’s most senior aides: find out what the governor knew of the episode  its possible violence, its handling by the courts  and when he knew it.

headline: Added to the Recall List: Millions of Frozen Mice
text: Take mice from freezer. Thaw (but not in the microwave, please). Feed to pet snakes.

text: We could be in for a long, slow decade. There’s a confluence of forces that are probably going to retard economic vitality.

text: After a decade of active duty in the Army, Robert Blagojevich knows the military definition of collateral damage. He may soon personify the legal system’s version, and unfairly so.

headline: Curbing Your Enthusiasm
text: Why does the Obama administration keep looking for love in all the wrong places? Why does it go out of its way to alienate its friends, while wooing people who will never waver in their hatred?

headline: Kerrey Ends Talks With Movie Group
text: LOS ANGELES — The Motion Picture Association of America and Bob Kerrey, the former Nebraska governor and United States senator, said on Thursday they had ended negotiations for Mr. Kerrey to become the association’s chief executive.

text: Toyota, the Japanese automaker, said Thursday that it was recalling almost 373,000 of its 2000 to 2004 Avalon sedans because of a steering problem that could cause a crash.

headline: Outrage Aside, Drivers Fuel High Parking Meter Profits
text: Thanks to revenue largely generated in the city’s outlying neighborhoods, cash flow to the private company running the city’s parking meter system is stronger than expected. The firm plans to increase revenue even further by stepping up enforcement on the 36,000 meters in the second half of 2010, according to new documents reviewed by the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Rehabbed, a Punk Dive Grows Up
text: To most of its patrons, the Fireside Bowl is simply a bowling alley in Logan Square, but not that long ago it was arguably the best punk-rock club in Chicago.

headline: Michael Batterberry, Influential Food Editor, Dies at 78
text: Michael Batterberry, a food writer and historian who with his wife founded two enduring, influential magazines, Food & Wine and Food Arts, died on Wednesday in Manhattan.

headline: Convictions in Astor Case Are Upheld
text: The judge in the trial of Brooke Astor’s son denied a defense motion on Thursday to vacate convictions against him and a lawyer who had done estate planning for Mrs. Astor, the doyenne of Manhattan society until her death in 2007.

headline: Momentum for a Revitalized Arts District
text: In 2000, Bill Schwartz, founder of the San Francisco Theater Festival, began working toward a new kind of theater district in San Francisco’s Mid-Market area. He organized panel discussions, rallied his theater colleagues, met with elected officials and worked with the city’s redevelopment office, which since 1995 had been surveying the area as a possible redevelopment zone.

headline: In Mission, Aging Hospital Is Seen as a Bargaining Chip
text: St. Luke’s hospital, in San Francisco’s Mission district, has been clinging to life for years.

headline: Episcopal Committee Is Working on Gay Rite
text: Armed with a new $400,000 grant and the support of the Episcopal Church, a Berkeley seminary is convening priests from across the country to craft the liturgical rite for same-sex couples to receive religious blessings.

headline: Valencia Street Looks Better, but the Cost Was High
text: San Francisco just completed a $6.1 million face-lift on Valencia Street  wider sidewalks, trees, bike racks, lighting and art. But if this were actual cosmetic surgery, an old joke might apply: the operation was a success, but the patient died.

headline: Exxon Shares Have Fallen Too Much
text: Disgruntled investors have wiped more than $40 billion off the value of Exxon Mobil since its splurge on the gas giant XTO Energy — almost exactly the latter firm’s price tag. With Congress ditching carbon emissions rules, clean-burning gas looks like a bad bet. Yet to assume that XTO has zero value seems wrongheaded.

text: BARNES & NOBLE customers are about to see a lot more of the Nook.

text: Even as political pressure grows to reduce the federal budget deficit, a blue-ribbon board led by former top national security officials called on Thursday for more spending on weapons systems.

headline: I.M.F. Judges Fiscal Reform as Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON  The financial overhaul bill signed by President Obama last week failed to simplify the complicated regulatory architecture that oversees the banking and securities industries, according to an assessment by the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Audio Tycoon’s Newsweek Bid Said to Be Favored
text: As the Washington Post Company prepares to sell Newsweek to the most appealing bidder, it is closely examining an offer from Sidney Harman, the California billionaire who made his fortune selling audio equipment.

text: SAN FRANCISCO  The Justice Department has joined a whistle-blower in accusing Oracle, the business software giant, of defrauding the federal government by overcharging for software.

headline: In Comeback for Japan, Sony Swings to a Profit
text: TOKYO Sony said Thursday that it swung to a profit of 25.7 billion yen, or $294 million, in the April-June quarter, buoyed by a turnaround in its television and video game businesses.

headline: Water Vendors Profit From the Heat
text: With the sun pounding down on Church Avenue in central Brooklyn, Johanna Washington dipped her fingers into an ice-cold cooler and shook her head as a man in a blue T-shirt approached, water bottles in hand.

headline: Two Online Gambling Operators in Europe to Merge
text: Two of the biggest European operators of Internet betting sites, PartyGaming and Bwin Interactive Entertainment, said Thursday that they planned to merge, forming the world’s largest publicly traded online gambling company.

headline: Fewer Public School Teachers Receive Tenure
text: More New York City public school teachers were denied tenure this year, the Department of Education said on Thursday, a sign that principals were beginning to heed Chancellor Joel I. Klein’s call that they get rid of ineffective teachers before they earned job protection.

headline: Plan to Aid 9/11 Victims Is Rejected in House
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Thursday blocked a Democratic plan to provide billions of dollars for medical treatment to rescue workers and residents of New York City who suffered illnesses from the toxic dust and debris at ground zero.

headline: Council Approves Plan to Build Flushing Commons
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg won a victory for his development agenda on Thursday when the City Council approved a plan to build hundreds of apartments and thousands of square feet of office and retail space in the heart of Flushing, Queens, one of the city’s most densely populated neighborhoods.

headline: Judge Pares Fraud Case Involving a Political Consultant
text: A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan dismissed 13 charges on Thursday in a criminal case against the political consultant Hank Morris, but ruled that some of the most serious ones could remain.

headline: In the Revamped Pac-10, Everyone Likes Los Angeles
text: PASADENA, Calif.  When the Pacific-10 Conference athletic directors meet at a hotel here Friday to begin hashing out realignment of the soon-to-be 12-team conference into two football divisions, there may be a consensus on just one thing.

headline: In Details of Subcommittee’s Inquiry, a Revealing Look at Rangel’s Actions
text: After a 21-month inquiry, an investigative subcommittee of the House ethics committee found reason to believe that Representative Charles B. Rangel violated numerous House rules, including the requirement that members act at all times in a way that “reflects creditably on the House.”

headline: The Yankees Keep Winning, as Rodriguez Keeps Waiting
text: CLEVELAND  Hot dogs cost a dollar on Thursday night, which could be one reason why the largest crowd since the Indians’ home opener flocked to Progressive Field. Another, this one more plausible, involved the desire to see a singular event, a home run slugged by a certain third baseman, before the Yankees skipped town for a more meaningful series against Tampa Bay.

headline: Britain: After Auction, a New Owner for Churchill’s Wartime Dentures
text: A specialist at one of Britain’s leading medical museums called them “the teeth that saved the world,” and a private British investor who bought a set of Winston Churchill’s wartime dentures at auction on Thursday appeared to agree. The anonymous buyer paid the equivalent of $23,750, more than three times the pre-sale estimate, after bidding at an auction house in Aylsham that recently sold one of Churchill’s half-smoked cigars for the equivalent of $6,130. The dentures were sold by the family of Derek Cudlipp, the dental technician commissioned by Churchill to make them, and had been kept for years in a drawer in the Cudlipp family home. Mr. Cudlipp’s son Nigel told the BBC that his father had told him that Churchill would flick the dentures out and “throw them across the room” when he was angered by setbacks to the Allied cause, and that the prime minister tore up Mr. Cudlipp’s enlistment papers at Downing Street, telling him “he would be more important to the war effort if he stayed in London to repair his dentures.”

headline: Yemen: President Makes Offer to Rebels
text: President Ali Abdullah Saleh offered for the first time on Thursday to bring leaders of an armed rebel faction into Yemen’s political process, apparently in an effort to quell rising violence in the north of the country. The Yemeni government has fought an intermittent war since 2004 with the rebels  known as Houthis after the family of their leader  and had consistently designated them terrorists. The conflict has displaced hundreds of thousands of people, and Western leaders warned that it was distracting Yemen’s government from fighting Al Qaeda’s resurgent regional branch. At least three senior Houthi representatives have now been invited to participate in a national dialogue involving Yemen’s governing coalition and a group of opposition parties, said Muhammad al-Basha, a spokesman for the Yemeni Embassy in Washington.

headline: Park Stumbles After an Indians Fill-In Shines
text: CLEVELAND — The lowlight for the Yankees came at the end of an otherwise complete night. Chan Ho Park got the first two outs in the ninth inning, then put the next five runners on base — three walks, two singles — as the Indians tagged him for three runs. His struggles were far more noticeable after Cleveland third baseman Andy Marte pitched a perfect top of the inning after being called on to bail out a taxed bullpen.

headline: France: Police Question Labor Minister
text: The police in Paris questioned the embattled French labor minister, Éric Woerth, for almost eight hours on Thursday about his role in a deepening scandal involving France’s richest woman, who has been accused of making illegal cash donations to conservative politicians. Mr. Woerth, who is also a treasurer in President Nicolas Sarkozy’s party, has denied accepting $190,000 in illegal cash donations made by Liliane Bettencourt, 87, heiress to the L’Oréal fortune, in 2007 for Mr. Sarkozy’s campaign. Mr. Woerth has said that he will resign as treasurer next month. Mrs. Bettencourt was questioned on Monday.

headline: The Owner Made a Promise: No Layoffs
text: Recently, I came across this article about a business owner named Julia Billen, who turned the recession into a growth opportunity. When the economy soured, revenues at Warmly Yours, Ms. Billen’s $6.8 million radiant heating business, plummeted. Instead of laying off any of her 60 employees, she assured them their jobs were safe and took steps to not just survive but thrive.

headline: Tip of the Week: Controlling the Music Player From the Taskbar
text: You can control the music player software right from the Windows 7 taskbar on your computer. Just hover the mouse cursor over the minimized icon for the Windows Media Player in the taskbar to get a thumbnail version of the playback controls that lets you pause, play or jump to the next or previous track in your playlist. The Windows version of iTunes offers similar taskbar controls. Mac users can right- or control-click on the iTunes icon in the Dock to get a menu of playback controls to control the music — without having to bring the iTunes window to the front of the screen.

The Concours’ new home is the Inn at St. John’s, a former seminary in Plymouth, Mich.,  that has been renovated as a conference center that includes an 118-room hotel and 27-hole golf course.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Deflation — it sounds like fun. Things get cheaper, right, so what’s the big deal? Sadly, a widespread slide in prices has more nefarious effects than that other bugbear, inflation, first because it signals a retreat in demand and, second, because people quickly understand that if they wait longer, they will have to pay even less — a vicious cycle spurred by a seemingly harmless virtue, thrift. Well, James Bullard, head of the St. Louis Fed, is worried about it. You can read his full essay here, or a quick summary.

Ernie from “Sesame Street” and the Thing from the Fantastic Four peeling carrots in the nude.6. A scrimmage between the Syracuse Orangemen and the Netherlands national football team that is overrun by tigers.8. headline: 2 Tested at U.S. Embassy in Paris After Handling Suspicious Mail

Patin. The contents of the envelope, after “preliminary results of testing,” were not believed to be harmful, and there was no threatening message, Mr. Patin said.

headline: Inflationistas And Deflationistas
text: A followup on the question of deflation risks: it’s worth bearing in mind that the last year and a half has been a fairly clean test of alternative views about how the economy works. When the economy slumped, budget deficits skyrocketed, and the Fed began large-scale asset purchases, there were two kinds of people: people who divide people into two kinds, and people who don’t On one side were people who said that deficits would drive interest rates way up, crowding out private investment, and that all that money printing would lead to high inflation. On the other were those who said that we’d entered a Japan-type liquidity trap, which meant that (a) there was a savings glut, so deficits would not crowd out private investment and interest rates would stay low (b) increases in the monetary base would just sit there, (c) the risk was deflation, not inflation.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Another New Home For Janet Evanovich
text: The No. 1 hardcover book this week belongs to someone who is no stranger to that ranking. Janet Evanovich takes the top spot with “Troublemaker,” a graphic-novel version of her series about a Nascar driver named Sam Hooker and a mechanic named Alexandra Barnaby. (A .pdf-file excerpt of the comic can be found here.) Ms. Evanovich wrote the book with her daughter, Alexandra, and it is illustrated by Joelle Jones and published by Dark Horse Comics. This week it was announced that Ms. Evanovich would leave her longtime publisher, St. Martin’s Press, and head to the Ballantine Bantam Dell imprint of Random House in a deal that would include two of the author’s Stephanie Plum adventures. According to Random House, Ms. Evanovich’s novels have combined sales of more than 75 million copies. Perhaps that’s why Dark Horse previously said “Troublemaker,” the first of two graphic novels, would have a print run of 100,000 copies.

headline: The Ascent of Man: Museum of Natural History Offers a New iPhone App
text: Among the crucial questions that occur on visits to the American Museum of Natural History: How did man get from a knuckle-dragging primate to a majestic bipedal creature? How did the mighty Tyrannosaurus rex use its tiny forelimbs to subdue its prey? And how do you get to the nearest bathroom? If you have an Apple mobile device, a new application created by the museum can help you with all of those queries.

headline: The Born Identity
text: When I heard that Huggies had begun to sell a “limited-edition jeans diaper,” and that its bigger rival Pampers was offering a new diaper line carrying the imprimatur of the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley, it struck me as a throwback. Could there be a more absurd example of the sort of mindless conspicuous consumption that marked the years before “credit default swap” entered the national vocabulary? I seem to remember a lot of declarations that the urge to buy anything signaling nonthrifty behavior had been left behind as decisively as a house with an upside-down mortgage. Even TV commercials said so!

headline: I Tweet, Therefore I Am
text: On a recent lazy Saturday morning, my daughter and I lolled on a blanket in our front yard, snacking on apricots, listening to a download of E. B. White reading “The Trumpet of the Swan.” Her legs sprawled across mine; the grass tickled our ankles. It was the quintessential summer moment, and a year ago, I would have been fully present for it. But instead, a part of my consciousness had split off and was observing the scene from the outside: this was, I realized excitedly, the perfect opportunity for a tweet.

headline: Capping Stress in New Orleans

headline: Impersonating a Reviewer
text: I work for a company that creates iPhone apps. When we release a new one, our boss urges the staff to download it at the App Store and give it a five-star rating, even employees who don’t own a device that can run it. I think such false reviews are wrong in themselves and that our boss should not pressure employees in this way, but I want to support our company. What to do? NAME WITHHELD, DALLAS

headline: Unnatural Science
text: Deconstructing science is a fool’s game. In the ’90s, literary critics used to try. They’d argue that science is a system of metaphors, complete with a style and an ideology, rather than the royal road to the truth. They were laughed at as cultural relativists, posers high on Gaul­oises and nut jobs who didn’t believe in gravity.

headline: Taking It to the Banks

text: The Red Bull cars were wickedly fast in the morning practice session, doing something like a second faster than the nearest competitor. In the afternoon, however, although Sebastian Vettel still managed to put his Red Bull on top of the time sheets, Fernando Alonso showed that Ferrari’s return to top form is still looking good. The teams interlaced nicely: Vettel was followed by Alonso, then Mark Webber in the other Red Bull, and then Felipe Massa in the other Ferrari.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A GREAT UNRECORDED HISTORY: A New Life of E. M. Forster,  by Wendy Moffat (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $32.50.) Moffat’s well-written and perceptive biography does not make Forster’s sexuality explain everything, though of course it explains a great deal.

headline: Paperback Row
text: COLD: Adventures in the World’s Frozen Plaves, by Bill Streever.   (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.99.) This unusual book explores such topics as why animals in the Far North tend to be big; how wool and Gore-Tex keep a person warm; the invention of air-conditioners; and scientists’ attempts to reach absolute zero (it turned out to be impossible, but along the way “rubber, ivory, feathers and sponges phosphoresced with their own bluish glow”). FAR NORTH, by Marcel Theroux. (Picador, $15.) In Theroux’s sad yet strangely hopeful post­apocalyptic novel, the sole inhabitant of a deserted Siberian town witnesses a plane crash and sets out to investigate.

headline: Drink What You Know
text: There are only two cocktails: “a slug of whiskey” and a martini. This isn’t my opinion, but the law as laid down by Bernard DeVoto in his book “The Hour,” first published in 1948 and recently reissued. It so happens that I’ve owned a copy of this book for a long time and often wondered if anyone would ever bring it back into print and whether the world would find it as engaging and infuriating as I do.

headline: Queen of Pop
text: Whenever it seems as if he might be running out of oxen to gore, Carl Hiaasen comes up with fresh victims for his killing wit. In STAR ISLAND (Knopf, $26.95), Florida’s most entertainingly indignant social critic is in high dudgeon about those prodigal celebrities who descend on Miami with their uncouth fans and surly entourages, selfishly appropriating South Beach as their personal playground. Bundling up the most outrageous demands and self-indulgent behavior of this egocentric tribe into one over-the-top caricature, Hiaasen presents us with Cherry Pye, a 22-year-old pop star whose every display of narcissistic excess will send a frisson of horrified delight up your spine.

headline: Up Front: Abraham Verghese
text: Real doctors who write books seem to be as common these days as fake doctors on television. But Abraham Verghese, whose recent novel, “Cutting for Stone,” became a best seller, is the rare physician to succeed with both fiction and nonfiction.

headline: Not a Day Over Infinity
text: In his remarkable Pulitzer Prize-­winning book, “The Beak of the Finch,” Jonathan Weiner followed Peter and Rosemary Grant, biologists who had spent years studying birds in the Galápagos Islands. Their work showed that finches evolve rapidly in response to changes in the food supply, a discovery that ran counter to Darwin’s idea that natural selection operates only very slowly. Weiner’s portrait of this scientific couple worked well as a narrative portal to that story of evolutionary biology.

headline: Daughters of the Dust
text: Beverly Jensen’s book “The Sisters From Hardscrabble Bay” may be a collection of stories, but thanks to its chronological sweep (from 1916 to 1987), its multiple settings (from New Brunswick — so vividly rendered that it becomes another character — to Boston to coastal Maine) and a good half-dozen of the richest fictional characters I’ve encountered anywhere, the book delivers the emotional rush of a novel, indeed of a great novel. Of course, when a book is this satisfying, it probably doesn’t matter what we call it, only that we have it, although in this case, sadly, we’ll never have another. Jensen died of cancer in 2003, before any of her stories made it into print. In fact, it’s not clear she intended for them to be published, which may explain their remarkable intimacy and unflinching honesty.

headline: Colonials Abroad
text: In the decades before the Declaration of Independence, thousands of American colonists visited London. Wealthy Southern plantation owners and New England merchants, husbands and wives, children and slaves all arrived in what was thought to be the most exciting city in the world. Some went shopping for exquisite silver, fashionable furniture and the latest books; others traded their goods and engaged in political arguments in noisy coffee houses. A sojourn in London was part of the education of the sons (and sometimes daughters) of wealthy colonial families because, as one contemporary observed, “more is learnt of mankind here in a month than can be in a year in any other part of the world.”

headline: Medicare and Mayberry’s Finest
text: The federal Health and Human Services agency is celebrating the 45th anniversary of Medicare with a host of features, including a television advertisement featuring none other than Andy Griffith. (Check out the historic photograph of L.B.J. signing the Medicare law, with Lady Bird in the background, within the advertisement.)

headline: The New Staples | Aji Amarillo, Buckwheat, Aloe
text: In The New Staples, Merrill Stubbs of Food52 highlights ingredients making their way into restaurants and refrigerators, plus recipes from top chefs to help you put them to use.

headline: Paying for Dental Implants
text: The latest Patient Money column focuses on dental implants, which are often a better option than dentures or other types of dental work for replacing lost teeth.

headline: Curious Cases
text: In his wide-ranging, technically daring story collection, “The Surf Guru,” no occupation is too offbeat for Doug Dorst. Over the course of fragmented vignettes, an aging, entrepreneurial surfer realizes he’s past his prime. A young woman tries and fails to pass a big-rig driving test. A bloodthirsty general decapitates an enemy in a fictitious foreign war.

headline: Stray Questions for: Jennifer Egan
text: Jennifer Egan is the author of five works of fiction, most recently “A Visit From the Goon Squad.”In your new book, the term “Goon Squad” refers to the passage of time. When Ringo Starr turned 70 recently, he told The Times that he still feels 24 inside. How old do you feel inside, and how do you think the passage of time affects our core identities?My mom used to say that if someone woke her up in the middle of the night and asked how old she was, she’d answer 27. Hearing her, I’d think: That’s ridiculous; your job as my mom is to be old. Now, in my mid-40s, I find that I identify with people even younger than that — teenagers! If I had to pick one age, it would probably be 17: that period of looking like an adult but not quite being one, of pretending to be “yourself” (whoever that is) and praying that people will believe you; of having wild hopes about what kind of life you might have but also fearing you’ll never make it out of the house — all of that still feels so immediate. Sometimes I’ll watch teenagers and find myself not quite believing I’m older than they are — even wondering, delusionally, if they can see any difference between us. And yet my own kids will be teenagers soon, and when I talk to actual teens I’m vividly aware, of course, that they’re children.

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | Housewives
text: Today we present our ninth Summer Reading Student Challenge “favorite.” This week we had a whopping 60 entries – the most we’ve had so far – so I brought in the big guns to help me choose: our lesson-plan writer Shannon Doyne and college student Carrie Montgomery, a 2009 Times Scholar who has just begun a stint interning at The Learning Network.

headline: Time and Inner Space
text: Rhythm is everything in the six stories Anthony Doerr has to tell in his strange and beautiful new collection, “Memory Wall.” His tales, long or short, all seem somehow to undulate, to surge and recede like the tides. They move gracefully back and forth between different places and different — often impossibly distant — times. If their tempo were any less sure, they might feel tricky, overdetermined, forcibly literary. But Doerr maintains a steady pulse that feels oddly familiar: whether from bedtime stories or something yet older is hard to tell.

headline: Taking Calls From Veterans on the Brink
text: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.  Melanie Poorman swiveled in her chair and punched a button on the phone. The caller, an Iraq war veteran in his 30s, had recently broken up with his girlfriend and was watching a movie, “Body of War,” that was triggering bad memories. He started to cry.

headline: A Wedding and a Funeral
text: Ayelet Waldman attracts so much Internet ire for her self-­revelatory essays and her groaning board of a Twitter feed that I have come to think of her as Ay-yi-yi-let. There she goes again, alerting the world to her abortion; her bipolar disorder; her hot, hot sex life with her husband, Michael Chabon, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist (whom, she alleged in this newspaper, she loves more than their four children). It sometimes seems not so much writing as “slashing my wrists and hemorrhaging all over the computer screen,” to quote one of Waldman’s frequent, frantic blog posts from sun-dappled Berkeley.

headline: Complaint Box | The Pigeon Menace
text: For the fourth time in a week, I woke up to the sound of a pigeon pecking my window screen, trying to nibble its way into my bedroom in the early morning. In just a few months, a community of city birds had established itself in the gap between my building and the one to the west, jeopardizing the quality of the little light and air that the Tenement House Act of 1901 guarantees me.

headline: Up From Darkness
text: One dark and electrically stormy night, the lights blinked out in our rented Maine cabin. Lacking candles or a flashlight, my mother knew just what to do: she poured the hamburger grease from a frying pan into a teacup, then tore a few dangling strands of cotton from the open knee of my bell-bottom jeans. She set the wick in the fat and struck a match. A teenager at the time, I’d never been quite so impressed with parental competence.

text: For all the attention that’s been given to supposedly nervous corporate executives, business spending is not the American economy’s problem right now.

headline: Expert Answers About Scleroderma
text: Does scleroderma, the mysterious disorder that causes thickening of the skin and other problems, run in families? Is it related to other diseases? How long can you live with scleroderma? Those are among the questions posed by readers of the Consults blog.  This week, two experts joined Consults to answer readers’ questions: Dr. John Varga, of Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, and Dr. Virginia Steen, of Georgetown University. Both doctors also serve on the advisory board of the Scleroderma Foundation.Is Scleroderma Inherited?

headline: Explosive Inheritance
text: The tale that Lyndall Gordon unveils in “Lives Like Loaded Guns” is so lurid, so fraught with forbidden passions, that readers may be disappointed to find that no actual gun goes off in this feverish account of the Dickinson family “feuds.” There are metaphorical guns galore, including Dickinson’s self-portrait as lethal wallflower: “My Life had stood — a Loaded Gun — / In Corners — till a Day / The Owner passed — identified — / And carried Me away.” Gordon, who has written highly regarded biographies of Charlotte Brontë, T. S. Eliot and Mary Wollstonecraft, detects two patterns of “explosive inheritance” in Dickinson, who happened to have a grandmother named Gunn: eruptions in the lives and in the poems.

headline: London Theater Journal: All Aboard
text: On Thursday afternoon, I found myself drenched in silent tears in Waterloo Station, while hordes of little boys and girls around me remained contentedly dry-eyed. You see, there was this family of genuinely good people who, after having their father (also genuinely good) taken away by some sadly mistaken police, had lost all their money and had to move from a posh townhouse to a threadbare existence in a country cottage, where they continued to believe (as their Dad had said), “There’s always hope,” but…

headline: The 356, a Porsche to Appreciate
text: BUYERS of collector cars sometimes justify purchases in terms of their investment potential, which can be significant even in times when stocks and real estate are shaky. But in recent years, the returns have been strongest for cream-of-the-crop classics  cars typically so pristine and valuable that they are rarely driven.

headline: Police Scrutinized in Report on Paterson
text: An inquiry into the Paterson administration’s handling of a domestic violence case involving a senior aide also revealed shortcomings in the New York Police Department’s dealings with the episode  lapses, mistakes or confusion that began with a series of 911 calls last fall.

headline: Yesterday’s Banker
text: The last couple of years have not been good for the reputation of bankers. When their ludicrous bets on American mortgages went bad in 2007 and 2008, bringing the whole financial industry to the brink of disaster, they looked like fools; and their behavior since has only cast them in an even worse light. Their uncanny knack for extracting gigantic profits from the current low interest rates, when the rest of the economy is struggling, raises the suspicion that there is something exploitative about what they do, a fear exacerbated by the startling bonuses they continue to pay themselves through good times and bad. Perhaps most disturbing is that, in their public appearances, the men who run the big financial institutions in this country and wield such enormous power seem to display so shallow and unreflective a worldview.

headline: Hitting the Century Mark, and Still Behind His Desk
text: For all the big-time clients and complex cases he has handled in more than 70 years as a business litigator, George C. Seward said it was his first case, a simple theft allegation, that stands out.

headline: A Lively Debate on Climate Change
text: At the Bowery Hotel in New York on Tuesday, Christopher Monckton, the Third Viscount Monckton of Benchley, debated Eric Bates, executive editor of Rolling Stone magazine, on the topic of climate change. Lord Monckton is an outspoken climate change skeptic, while Rolling Stone recently published a cover story maintaining that climate skeptics have  enabled polluting industries to murder the climate.

headline: Saratoga Gothic
text: In addition to publishing six books of poetry as well as eight of cultural history and criticism, Geoffrey O’Brien is the editor in chief of the Library of America, whose handsome, authoritative volumes now more or less constitute the nation’s literary canon. But however central the novelist Mansfield Tracy Walworth (1830-73) may be to O’Brien’s crackerjack new history of one family’s mayhem, it seems safe to say that he will not soon be joining Welty, Wharton and Whitman at the right-hand reaches of the Library’s long, august shelf.

text: The Greek economy might be in the doldrums, but the island of Mykonos is hopping this summer as the usual stylish suspects descended upon its sunny shore. Here’s a look at some of the places keeping the island’s raucous spirit afloat these days.

headline: Patricia Clarkson, Directors’ Stealth Weapon
text: SINCE her 1998 breakout role as a German actress in druggy decline in “High Art,” Patricia Clarkson has eked out an uncommon niche: she’s a character actress with a name you know.

headline: Behind Brown Eyes
text: Writing about the songs of Van Morrison is rightly seen as something of a paradox. Perhaps that’s because, for all his scholarly use of multiple musical styles and his references to Yeats and Joyce, the Belfast Cowboy’s work is more sensual than it is intellectual. Which makes the renowned rock critic Greil Marcus, who’s written definitively on Elvis and Bob Dylan, the right man to plumb that work. Combining an incantatory prose style with careful reporting and inventive, sometimes infuriating judgments, Marcus manages to illuminate Morrison’s cerebral soul music — even if, as the singer once claimed, “the process is beyond words.”

headline: A Digital Home for the ‘Big Questions’
text: As part of its grantmaking, the John Templeton Foundation awards a lucrative annual prize to the thinker who has made an “exceptional contribution to affirming life’s spiritual dimension, whether through insight, discovery or practical works. ” And for the last three years the foundation has also sponsored an essay series, gathering leading scientists, scholars and public figures to discuss such big questions as “Does moral action depend on reasoning?” and “Does the free market corrode moral character?”

headline: Obsession
text: In a book about alcoholic, promiscuous, big-spending divas, we’re conditioned to expect a rise and a fall and then redemption. But “Furious Love,” a joint biography that concentrates on what tabloids called “the marriage of the century,” offers a long, wavy line rather than the familiar arc. And it makes for an indulgent, plenty-of-fun book about Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton’s traveling circus of money, booze and mutual obsession.

headline: Superbrakes for Civilians? The Cost Is the Obstacle

The gap may be narrowing, though: high-tech materials similar to those on the racetrack began showing up in exotic sports cars about 10 years ago, and some luxury models now offer them as well.

Vogue followed up in its current issue with “Classic Revival, a spread that showed off the sort of tightly structured handbags Grace Kelly favored in “Rear Window.”

headline: Tucking In Tires at the Top to Improve Traction, Ride and Mileage
text: BLACK art is an apt description of tire design, an activity whose major advances include the invention of the pneumatic tire in the 19th century and, in the 20th century, the development of steel-belted radials and tubeless tires.

headline: Letters From Johannesburg
text: Nadine Gordimer was born in 1923 into a land on fire. This is no metaphor, she explains in “A South African Childhood,” the first essay in “Telling Times,” a big new collection of her nonfiction. The gold-mining town that was her birthplace, in the Transvaal region east of Johannesburg, was dotted with man-made hills of coal dust, the relics of old collieries. Some of them, she writes, mimicked natural hills: “real earth had blown on to them to hold a growth of sparse grass and perhaps even a sinewy peppercorn or peach tree.” But inside, they were burning: “They had caught fire at some time or other in their years of disuse, and had continued to burn, night and day, ever since. Neither rain nor time could put the fires out. . . . I have asked people who have studied such things how long it may be expected to go on burning before it consumes itself. Nobody seems to know; it shares with the idea of Hades its heat and vague eternity.”

It was a far cry from the last outing of a Simon play on his home turf, Broadway: The fall revival of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” closed a week after opening because of poor box office.

headline: Turning Right
text: Over the past decade, “neocon” has become an all-purpose term of abuse among critics of the right. Yet few of these critics appear to realize that from the beginning there have been two very different branches of neoconservative thinking. The first aimed to bring sober, dispassionate analysis and a skeptical temper to questions of domestic policy; the second specialized in devising cogent, often highly polemical arguments in favor of a militarily aggressive foreign policy.

headline: Parting Twin Curtains of Repression
text: CENSORSHIP has long been a fact of life for filmmakers in China, but in recent years no director has clashed with the Chinese authorities as often, or as visibly, as Lou Ye. At two of the last five editions of the Cannes Film Festival, with the global media spotlight trained on the south of France, Mr. Lou, 45, has walked up the red carpet to present a movie that was being screened, in competition, without the permission of the Film Bureau in Beijing.

headline: July’s Toll Worst for U.S. Troops in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The deaths of at least 66 soldiers, Marines, sailors and airmen have made July the deadliest-ever month for American troops in the nine-year war in Afghanistan. The tally includes six American service members who died in four separate attacks in southern Afghanistan on Thursday and Friday.

headline: When the Roosterfish Start to Run, Anglers Just Try to Keep Up
text: CABO PULMO, Mexico  The sun was high and hot as a group of five fly anglers stood 20 yards above the surf break on a beach north of here, peering out into the Sea of Cortez. “What’s that?” one of the anglers called out uncertainly, not wishing to raise a false alarm for misidentifying a rock as our quarry. A dark torpedo coalesced in a wave that crested 50 yards offshore, joined soon after by an accomplice on each side.

headline: Drug of Choice
text: The Drug Enforcement Administration Museum and Visitors Center may be America’s most uninspiring attempt at war commemoration. Its low-budget displays, stuffed into a sterile building near the Pentagon, strive for a good-versus-evil story line but exude uncertainty. Snapshots of officers atop piles of impounded narcotics fail to convey the urgency of battle. Confiscated drug paraphernalia showcase wily ingenuity as much as social menace. But across the Potomac, next to Congressional Cemetery, rises a more fitting tribute to the “war on drugs”: Washington’s city jail, through which 18,000 inmates pass each year, 89 percent of them black and three-quarters of them incarcerated for nonviolent of­fenses. With its X-shaped towers surrounded by razor wire, the sprawling complex devours resources but, most criminologists agree, does comparably little to protect the public. It stands as a monument to punitive government bloat.

headline: The French Charmer You Don’t Know Yet
text: THE release of “Presenting Sacha Guitry,” a four-film collection on Criterion’s budget Eclipse label, is great news, but the title is disheartening: Are we really still at the point where one of France’s greatest filmmakers, fully the peer of Jean Renoir and François Truffaut, needs to be introduced to the American public?

headline: Bewitched and Bewhiskered

headline: Taymor’s ‘Tempest’ Will Be Showcased at New York Film Festival
text: A brave new reworking of Shakespeare‘s “The Tempest” directed by Julie Taymor will be the centerpiece film of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Friday. Ms. Taymor’s cinematic adaptation of “The Tempest” – her first filmed version of Shakespeare since “Titus,” her stylized 1999 take on “Titus Andronicus” – will be shown in the festival on Oct. 2 at Alice Tully Hall. In a gender-bending twist on the play, Ms. Taymor’s “Tempest” stars Helen Mirren as the sorceress Prospera. It also features Felicity Jones as her daughter, Miranda; Ben Whishaw as Ariel; Djimon Hounsou as Caliban; Alfred Molina as Stephano; Alan Cumming as Sebastian; Chris Cooper as Antonio; David Strathairn as Alonso; and Russell Brand as Trinculo. Ms. Taymor’s directing credits include the film “Across the Universe” as well as the Broadway musical “The Lion King” and – maybe, just maybe – “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark.” The festival runs from Sept. 24 through Oct. 10 and will open with David Fincher‘s “The Social Network.”

headline: Memory’s Harvest
text: Michelle Hoover’s first novel demonstrates how difficult it is to render a real person’s life into fiction. As the Web site dedicated to the book explains, “The Quickening” was inspired by a journal written by Hoover’s great-grandmother, Melva Current, in the last years of her life. Loosely based on that telling, the novel recounts the hardships of two families on neighboring Midwestern farms during the Great Depression.

headline: What Fish Should We Eat?
text: I have a review in this weekend’s Book Review of “Four Fish: The Future of the Last Wild Food,” by Paul Greenberg. The book is a good and important read, I think, that boils down to a discussion of the push and pull of our desire to eat wild fish, and the promise and the fear of consuming the wild variety. “Four Fish” raises important questions for people interested in food, about what fish we should be eating, what fish we should be farming, what fish we should (not) be catching in the sea. It is a book to change minds.

headline: The Benefits of Volunteerism, if the Service Is Real

headline: Obama Sees Auto Revival as a Success
text: DETROIT  President Obama came here on Friday to promote an economic success story, but even before he could get out of Washington, he was handed new evidence of the continued challenge he faces from the sputtering recovery.

headline: Even When It’s in Florida, Viewers Flock to ‘Jersey Shore’
text: 5:45 p.m. | Updated The programmers at MTV must have pumped their fists when the overnight ratings for “Jersey Shore” arrived on Friday. (Although they might not have been so thrilled Friday afternoon after seeing reports that one of the show’s stars, Nicole Polizzi, known as Snooki, had been arrested in Seaside Heights, N.J., and accused of disorderly conduct.) The premiere of the second season of “Jersey Shore” attracted 5.3 million viewers on Thursday night, according to Nielsen, the network’s biggest season premiere in more than seven years. The series about young people partying at the beach — it’s really that simple — was a sensation last winter for MTV, peaking at 4.8 million viewers for the finale. But Thursday night’s ratings indicate that the show has legs, even in the summer. Among MTV’s core demographic of viewers 12 to 34 years old, the season premiere is the No. 1 cable telecast of the year. The series will follow the cast’s exploits in South Beach, last spring in Florida; it is now filming their return to Seaside Heights this summer.

headline: Afghan Women Fear Loss of Modest Gains
text: MAHMUD-E RAQI, Afghanistan  Women’s precarious rights in Afghanistan have begun seeping away. Girls’ schools are closing; working women are threatened; advocates are attacked; and terrified families are increasingly confining their daughters to home.

headline: Case Study | Bachelor’s Jam
text: Sometimes an idea comes along that’s so elementally brilliant I feel no compunction about stealing it outright. That’s what I thought I was doing with this recipe when a friend told me he’d read it in the new “River Cottage Preserves Handbook,” written by Pam Corbin. It’s called bachelor’s jam, or sometimes officer’s jam, and it isn’t jam at all but rather a whip-smart method of both preserving the overflow of ripening summer fruit and infusing spirits with the same in a manner befitting, well, a bachelor and/or an officer. This makes for a “preserve” that comes into its own just in time to bring a welcome hit of summer fruit to the holidays. Once I started digging and found that the chef Roger Vergé has written on what is known as confiture de vieux garçon, and that it is also an old and well-loved treat in Germany (known as rumtopf, or “rum pot”), I felt a bit less guilty about my plagiarism.

headline: Mets Place Bay on Disabled List
text: The Mets said Friday that left fielder Jason Bay had been put on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to July 26 because he is still suffering headaches after sustaining a concussion.

headline: Asking for It?
text: My husband’s brother is married to a woman who participates in many charities. We’re invited to buy tickets to all their summer fund-raisers. For most of the year, this sister-in-law and her husband are civil, but distant — except when she wants us to support one of her causes. My husband thinks we owe her a personal response every time, as in: “Dear S-I-L, We’re sorry, but. ...” I think he’s insane! The response card goes back to the charity, not to her. And she probably invites hundreds of her “closest” friends. What do you think? Anonymous

headline: A Conductor Playing an Instrument More Often Than He Holds the Baton
text: Richard Auldon Clark had a good idea when he formed the Manhattan Chamber Orchestra in 1987. His favored repertory was American contemporary music, and though many of his choices were of the conservatively neo-Romantic sort, Mr. Clark also turned his attention to experimenters like Henry Cowell and Dave Soldier and made some fine recordings of music from both ends of the spectrum.

headline: The ‘Great Recession’ Earns Its Title
text: Last year, I questioned why people were bandying about the term “Great Recession” so freely, and wondered whether the dramatic designation was warranted. I had reason for skepticism: An informal search of news archives showed that every recession of the last several decades had, at some point, received this special nickname.

headline: Taking Fans on a Walk, Going Beyond His Hits
text: Over the years Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers have made a lot of repetitive songs that don’t force you to think about them as such. Sometimes they’ve got sweet bridges and tiny solos; they’re layered and warm and bar-band authentic. They’re about rock ’n’ roll as sacrament, highways, the sun in your hair, boys and girls turning one anothers’ heads. They’re locked into their sentimentality and carry a promise that Mr. Petty will never change much.

headline: When Mostly Mozart Was Mostly Chopin
text: One of the more inventive additions to the Mostly Mozart schedule in recent seasons has been A Little Night Music, a series of recitals in the Kaplan Penthouse at 10:30 p.m. They give anyone who attends the evening’s main performance at Avery Fisher Hall plenty of time to get across 65th Street and may appeal as well to listeners who have not attended the earlier concert. (On Wednesday, for example, someone who, like me, had heard the standard Mostly Mozart performance on Tuesday could have spent the early evening listening to the string quartet Ethel collaborating with pop singers in Damrosch Park.)

headline: ‘A Terrible Parricide’
text: In this Sunday’s Book Review, Thomas Mallon reviews Geoffrey O’Brien’s “Fall of the House of Walworth,” about a sensational parricide in an old and influential family in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in 1873 — sensational enough, in fact, to merit O’Brien’s subtitle: “A Tale of Madness and Murder in Gilded Age America.” In the case, the deranged novelist Mansfield Tracy Walworth, largely forgotten now, but of some note in his own day, was shot to death by his son, Frank, in a Manhattan hotel room; Frank’s motivation, it seems, was his father’s brutal treatment of his mother, Ellen Walworth, one of the founders of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Mallon has high praise for O’Brien’s “crackerjack new history,” and you should certainly read his elegant review first. But if we do say so, The New York Times’s anonymous account on June 4, 1873, the day after the killing, is a surprisingly moving piece of journalism as well, full of passion and personal interest, a crackerjack little melodrama; such is the startling story, headlined “A Terrible Parricide”:

headline: Taymor’s ‘Tempest’ Is Set for Film Festival
text: A reworking of “The Tempest” directed by Julie Taymor, below, will be the centerpiece of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Friday. Ms. Taymor’s cinematic adaptation of Shakespeare’s play  her first filmed version of Shakespeare since “Titus,” her stylized 1999 take on “Titus Andronicus”  will be shown in the festival on Oct. 2 at Alice Tully Hall. In a gender-bending twist on the play, Ms. Taymor’s “Tempest” stars Helen Mirren as the sorceress Prospera. It also features Felicity Jones as her daughter, Miranda; Ben Whishaw as Ariel; Djimon Hounsou as Caliban; Alfred Molina as Stephano; and Russell Brand as Trinculo. Ms. Taymor’s directing credits include the film “Across the Universe” as well as the Broadway musical “The Lion King” and  maybe, just maybe  “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” The festival runs from Sept. 24 through Oct. 10.

headline: Museum Offers a New Iphone App
text: Among the crucial questions that occur on visits to the American Museum of Natural History: How did man get from a knuckle-dragging primate to a majestic bipedal creature? How did the mighty Tyrannosaurus rex use its tiny forelimbs to subdue its prey? And how do you get to the nearest bathroom? If you have an Apple mobile device, a new application can help you with all of those queries. In a news release the museum said its American Museum of Natural History Explorer application available free from the iTunes store, is compatible with the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch and connects to the institution’s wireless network to put information at visitors’ fingertips. In addition to providing a GPS and turn-by-turn walking directions to any of the exhibitions, theaters, shops, restaurants and bathrooms in the building, the application also provides additional details on more than 140 displays (including the blue whale, of course), customizable tours, a fossil treasure hunt for children and connections to Facebook and Twitter. (Above, visitors at the museum.)
