headline: Bullock Wants To Be Removed From Oil-Spill Video
text: Sandra Bullock, above, is seeking to withdraw from a celebrity-filled campaign to draw attention to the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico amid questions about the corporate sponsorship of the group behind the campaign. Ms. Bullock, a New Orleans resident, is among the celebrities who appear in “Be the One,” a video that describes the oil spill’s national implications. A credit at the end of the video says it is presented by Women of the Storm, and among the partners listed at the campaign’s Web site, restorethegulf.com, is the America’s Wetland Foundation. Prompted by a report by The Huffington Post that said Women of the Storm and the foundation were financed by oil companies, including BP, Shell, ExxonMobil, Citgo and Chevron, Ms. Bullock said she would seek to be removed from the campaign. In a statement reported by the Web site ThinkProgress.org, a publicist for Ms. Bullock wrote: “At no time was she made aware that any organization, oil company or otherwise had influence over Women of the Storm or its message. We have immediately asked for her participation in the P.S.A. be removed until the facts can be determined.” Officials for the America’s Wetland Foundation told The Huffington Post that the contributions it received from the oil companies were for scientific and ecological research.

headline: A Digital Home for ‘Big Questions’
text: As part of its grant making, the John Templeton Foundation awards a lucrative annual prize to a thinker who has made an “exceptional contribution to affirming life’s spiritual dimension, whether through insight, discovery or practical works.” And for the last three years the foundation has also sponsored an essay series, gathering leading scientists, scholars and public figures to discuss big questions like “Does moral action depend on reasoning?” and “Does the free market corrode moral character?” Now the foundation has created a Web site devoted to the subject, titled  what else?  BigQuestionsOnline.com. “We’re convinced that many educated readers are tired of the usual ideological divides and culture-war polemics in discussing the great issues of human purpose and meaning,” Gary Rosen, the site’s editor in chief, said. The site has assembled a collection of well-known columnists, bloggers and video contributors, including authors (Robert Wright, Virginia Postrel, Susan Jacoby, Christine Rosen), scientists (David Gelernter, Paul Davies, David Sloan Wilson) and scholars (William Galston, Walter Russell Mead, Robert P. George).

headline: Reruns Versus a ‘Rookie’
text: CBS led a close race in the ratings on Thursday night as crime show reruns helped the network earn the most viewers on average in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s repeat of “The Mentalist” delivered the night’s largest audience with 7.4 million viewers at 10, easily outperforming ABC’s “Boston Med” (4.7 million) in the time slot. But ABC fared better the rest of the night, as a repeat of its game show “Wipeout” tied CBS’s “Big Brother” at 8 with 6.4 million viewers and as ABC’s “Rookie Blue” (6.8 million) edged ahead of a “CSI” rerun (6 million) on CBS. Fox ranked third over all with a “Glee” repeat (3.8 million) and a results episode of “So You Think You Can Dance” (5.8 million). NBC placed fourth with reruns.

text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: ‘Jersey Shore’ Scores; Snooki Is Arrested
text: The programmers at MTV must have pumped their fists when the overnight ratings for “Jersey Shore” arrived on Friday. (Although they might not have been so thrilled Friday afternoon after seeing reports that one of the show’s stars, Nicole Polizzi, known as Snooki, had been arrested in Seaside Heights, N.J., and accused of disorderly conduct.) The premiere of the second season of “Jersey Shore” attracted 5.3 million viewers on Thursday night, according to Nielsen, the network’s biggest season premiere in more than seven years. The series about young people partying at the beach  it’s really that simple  was a sensation last winter for MTV, peaking at 4.8 million viewers for the finale. But Thursday night’s ratings indicate that the show has legs, even in the summer. Among MTV’s core demographic of viewers 12 to 34 years old, the season premiere is the No. 1 cable telecast of the year. The series will follow the cast’s exploits in South Beach, last spring in Florida; it is now filming their return to Seaside Heights this summer.

headline: Schomburg Center’s Home Is Harlem, Say Leaders
text: The rumors started circulating soon after Howard Dodson announced this spring that he would step down as director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. He had been forced out, some said. The 10 million holdings of the center, a research unit of the New York Public Library, would be moved to the library’s main home at Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, some said, or they would be parceled out to branches. There was even a rumor that the Schomburg, known as the premier institution of its kind, would move to New Jersey.

headline: Shaking the Salzburg Halls With the Wild and Modern
text: SALZBURG, Austria  These days, when the directors of the Salzburg Festival champion a major living composer, they do it up right. One of the highlights of this summer’s 90th-anniversary festival is the premiere of the German composer Wolfgang Rihm’s latest music-theater work, “Dionysus.” The production opened on Tuesday at the Haus für Mozart.

headline: Athleticism and Warmth at the Keyboard
text: Popular media sometimes transmit highbrow culture, and Liszt’s Hungarian Rhapsody No. 2, with its frenetic, tail-chasing character, has been used in several cartoons. But there is nothing funny about its demands on the performer.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, July 30
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Tofu Takes to a Simple, Spicy Salad
text: I HAVE probably eaten 30 times at Szechuan Gourmet, a Chinese restaurant not far from the New York Times building. The pressed tofu and celery salad is so unusual and so good that I can honestly say I have never gone there (except maybe the first time or two) without ordering it.

headline: 3-Year-Olds Can Inject Life Into a Dull Season
text: Horse racing definitely needs a dose of excitement in the dog days of summer.

headline: Nelson Says ‘No’ to Kagan
text: Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska announced Friday that he will not vote to confirm Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court, becoming the first Democrat to oppose the president’s nominee.

headline: Predators and Prey, and Catching Turtles
text: As I said in a previous post, scientists have noted a pattern of a higher ratio of “standing” predator to prey biomass on the atoll, which contrasts with most other marine and terrestrial ecosystems (for example, think about the small ratios of top mammalian predators to grazers on the African savanna). They hypothesize that extremely high rates of production in the prey, including algae; corals, clams and other invertebrates; and smaller fish, supports the predators. This is coupled with high rates at which prey are eaten or otherwise die (called “turnover”). Another possibility is that the larger-bodied fish can live on relatively low amounts of food for many years, even decades, when protected from fishing.

headline: A Three-Time Three No-Trump to Triumph
text: NEW ORLEANS  At the Summer North American Championships here, the Wagar Women’s Knockout Teams final finished in the early hours of Friday morning.

headline: An Irresistible Salad of Celery and Tofu
text: A salad of celery, pressed tofu and chili oil. Sounds good, right? All I can tell you is that there isn’t a person I’ve made this for (or ordered it for, because I did learn it from a restaurant), who hasn’t loved it.

headline: Esther Fu and Patrick Mirville
text: Esther Fu, a daughter of Tek Chu Chew of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Wo-Wai Fu, was married Saturday to Patrick Yves Mirville, a son of Evelyne T. Mirville and Yves Mirville of Bensalem, Pa. The Rev. Andrew Hyun, a minister, officiated at Ici, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Men’s Engagement Rings Proclaim, ‘He’s Taken’
text: WHEN, on a snowy February midnight in Central Park, Bennett Konesni, a farmer and musician on Shelter Island, N.Y., proposed to Edith Gawler, a fiddler and architecture student from Maine, he presented her with two gifts.

text: AT the pool on the roof of the Hotel Gansevoort, you can tell when a particularly beautiful woman has walked through the door not because the men turn their heads  the men check out everyone  but because the bronzed beauties who decorate the pool’s edges also raise their heads, ever so slightly, from their celebrity gossip magazines.

headline: Picking Up, Poolside
text: At the Hotel Gansevoort, swimming isn’t the only sport.

text: The day in sports included track and field championships in Europe and the start of N.F.L. training camps across the United States.

headline: Arizona’s Law, Activist Judges and Anchor Babies
text: While President Obama’s odd characterization on “The View” of African-Americans as a  “mongrel people” has set the blogosphere aflutter, it was something else he told the assembled ladies that struck me as more significant. According to Sam Youngman of The Hill, in a discussion on racism, “Obama noted ‘there’s still a reptilian side of our brain’ that leads people to not trust others ‘if somebody sounds different or looks different.’ ”

headline:
As Some Young
Muslims Turn to Radicalism, Concern Grows
text: FRANKFURT  Before Abi left her parents’ house in northern Germany last year, she asked her father, “Daddy, what can I bring you from my journey?” He looked up from his book and answered, “Some perfumed oil.” “Will do,” she said, hugging him goodbye.

headline: New Trouble for Terrorist Who Helped Prosecutors
text: Nine years ago, an Algerian man charged in the failed “millennium plot” to blow up Los Angeles International Airport took an unusual step: he pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan and became the rare convicted Islamic terrorist to cooperate with the United States government.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Brazilian Goalie Is Charged in Ex-Lover’s Killing
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  The police said Friday that they had charged the goalie of Brazil’s most popular soccer club, Flamengo, with murder in the disappearance of a former lover who claimed to have had his child.

headline: From Guantánamo to Algeria: An Unwilling Repatriate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sudan: Violent Clashes Erupt Over Peace Talks for Darfur
text: Violent clashes among displaced Sudanese erupted in Kalma camp in the southern Darfur region this week, leaving about 10 people dead, Alain Le Roy, the head of United Nations peacekeeping operations, told the Security Council on Friday. The fighting pitted supporters of peace talks between rebel groups and the Sudanese government, taking place in Doha, Qatar, against opponents of reconciliation. Surging tension has plagued the region in western Sudan this year as fighting has resumed between the government and the rebels, and as fractious tribes battle among themselves, according to United Nations reports. Around 600 people, largely combatants, have died in the past few months, the reports said, with 400 killed in May, making it the deadliest month in Darfur since peacekeeping troops first deployed there in December 2007.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE BREUCKELEN DISTILLING COMPANY is joining a long  and long-gone  tradition of Brooklyn booze-making, though its equipment does not resemble the gritty clandestine stills that one imagines existed during Prohibition. Its still is a 16-foot-tall gleaming copper unit that cost roughly $100,000, and is located in a clean, spacious storefront on an industrial stretch of 19th Street, just west of the Gowanus Expressway (near the Home Depot).

headline: It’s Always Sunny in Targetland
text: On the second story of East River Plaza, at 116th Street, wide sliding doors open onto an evenly lighted, color-coordinated, climate-controlled space and then slide shut again, cutting off the waft of 95-degree air plaguing the sidewalks of East Harlem.

headline: Russia: Chairwoman Steps Down From Human Rights Council
text: The chairwoman of President Dmitri A. Medvedev’s human rights advisory council abruptly stepped down on Friday, apparently after growing disenchanted with the political situation in Russia. The official, Ella Pamfilova, left, gave no official explanation for her resignation but also offered no public words of support for Mr. Medvedev’s policies. “This is my personal decision; no one coerced me,” she told the Interfax news agency. Mr. Medvedev has promised to strengthen respect for human rights and the rule of law in Russia, but he has come under criticism from advocacy groups, which contend that he has carried out few significant changes since he took office in 2008.

headline: Families of Hikers Jailed in Iran Mark First Anniversary With Rally
text: The families of three young American hikers jailed in Iran held a protest rally on Friday outside the Iranian Mission to the United Nations to demand their release. The rally, attended by about 50 people, was the first of around 30 similar protests organized by friends of the three in cities around the world. The other demonstrations are taking place Saturday, the first anniversary of the hikers’ imprisonment. Iran has accused the three  Shane M. Bauer, Sarah E. Shourd and Joshua F. Fattal  of spying but has not produced evidence or put them on trial. The three were on a trip from Syria to hike in northern Iraq when they either strayed or were forced across the border into Iran. “Enough is enough!” Mr. Fattal’s mother, Laura Fattal, told the crowd in English and Persian. “The hikers need to come home.”

headline: Flu Vaccines Are Approved and Urged for Most
text: The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that it had approved vaccines for the next flu season, expected to start in the fall, and health officials are recommending vaccination for everyone 6 months old and older.

headline: Turtles, a Nap and a Visit With Mom
text: In the 18 years since he was elected to the State Assembly, Keith L. T. Wright has spent most weekdays in Albany. On weekends Mr. Wright, 55, who is also chairman of the Manhattan Democratic Party, is back home in Harlem — in the three-bedroom, rent-stabilized apartment where he was raised — with his wife, Susan, 54, special events manager at the  their son Jordan, 15; and, when he visits, their son Jared, 22, a senior at the State University at Albany.

headline: Small Newspapers Cater to City’s Many Ethnic Groups
text: In the last few weeks, a Greek-language newspaper investigated a suicide off the George Washington Bridge, a Russian newspaper surveyed the local Russian diaspora about the newly arrested spies, and a newspaper that focuses on the African and African-American populations gave tips to illegal immigrants on how to avoid getting stopped while driving. Here are excerpts, translated with help from the New York Community Media Alliance.

headline: Ten Years of Telling Tales
text: THOSE who consider storytelling solely children’s entertainment might be surprised by the performances at the Mohegan Colony Storytelling and Music Festival, celebrating its 10th anniversary this month. Carol Birch’s repertory, for instance, includes works by Carl Sandburg and Ray Bradbury, and sometimes a cappella singing. Gina Bergamini integrates belly dancing into her performances, and encourages audience participation. And Ken Corsbie’s Caribbean tales range from literary works to stories of the immigrant experience.

headline: Enjoying the Drive-In Without the Cars
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — THE evening had all the makings of an audience-participation spectacle à la “The Rocky Horror Picture Show,” with loyalists dressed up as their favorite characters belting out songs they knew by heart.

headline: Homegrown Jazz, in Three Flavors
text: THE New Haven Jazz Festival has had its ups and downs, even going dark for a year in 2007. But through it all, the festival has provided a stage for homegrown voices with reputations for distinctive work. And so it will again, on Aug. 14 and 21, when three New Haven natives  Joe Morris, Noah Baerman and Robby Ameen  bring small groups to the festival’s stage.

headline: That Familiar Play-Along Celebration of Menopause
text: Port Washington, N.Y.

headline: Bard College Revives a Composer’s World
text: TORN between an allegiance to his modernist mentor and an affinity for the Romantic tradition, the Viennese composer Alban Berg produced some of the most complex, conflicted  yet lyrical  music ever written. Debates about Berg’s legacy continue 75 years after his death.

headline: Finding the Link Between Werewolves and Karaoke
text: MUSEUMGOERS at the Wadsworth Atheneum who walk from the central courtyard through the nondescript door labeled “Enter” will find themselves standing beside a toilet stall, a urinal and two grungy sinks in a dark and cramped space created by Justin Lowe. “Justin poured beer all over so there’d be that stale smell,” said Patricia Hickson, curator of contemporary art at the Wadsworth.

headline: Different but Celebrated, Hilliard and Tyree Retire
text: One will be remembered for toughness during a distinguished career. The other will be remembered for a remarkable catch. On Friday, both wide receivers ended their careers as Giants.

headline: There May Be ‘No Better Place,’ but There Is a Better Slogan
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Quick, what do you think about when you hear the words “Columbus, Ohio”?

headline: Finding the Good Ears
text: Connecticut’s corn crop had been running about two weeks early, but has slowed a bit because of heat and lack of rain. Corn is widely available directly from growers, at farmers’ markets and farm stands, usually into October. The going rate this summer is 50 cents an ear or $5 to $6 a dozen (or 13).

headline: An Enduring Summer Treat, Improved by Science
text: PAWCATUCK

headline: Italian Favorites Served With Old World Flair
text: WITH new-millennial Italian restaurants trending toward a more light-handed and region-specific take on traditional fare — led by young chefs whose fresh, fetishized burrata is flown in daily from Apulia and whose pizzas are topped not with pepperoni but with figs and gorgonzola — I thought it might be edifying to return to one of Westchester’s venerable old-school establishments: Lusardi’s.

headline: Stem Cell Trial Wins Approval of F.D.A.
text: The world’s first authorized test in people of a therapy derived from human embryonic stem cells has been cleared by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: U.S. Plans Trade Complaint Against Guatemala
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced Friday that it would file a complaint against Guatemala claiming labor law violations under the Central America Free Trade Agreement, the first time Washington has pursued such a case against a free-trade partner.

headline: ABC Names New Head of Entertainment Group
text: ABC made it official Friday, naming Paul Lee president of the ABC Entertainment Group. He succeeds Stephen McPherson, who abruptly offered his resignation on Tuesday, which ABC quickly accepted.

headline: Democrats and Republicans Receive August Instructions
text: A year after town halls focused on health care spooked Democrats and energized Republicans, leaders in the House on both sides of the aisle are sending their members home for this August recess with a specific set of instructions.

headline: The Sweet Corn? Grown Right Over There
text: THE Red Gold potatoes that studded the white corn chowder came from E. R. & Son Organic Farm in Colts Neck.

headline: A Sin and a Shame
text: The treatment of workers by American corporations has been worse  far more treacherous  than most of the population realizes. There was no need for so many men and women to be forced out of their jobs in the downturn known as the great recession.

headline: Unlikely Harvest for 2 Young Farmers
text: LAST fall, Amanda Merrow and Catherine Baldwin’s first wheat harvest here was over in three hours and yielded only four buckets of hard spring wheat. “It was almost a joke,” said Mike Collins, a veteran East Hampton farmer whom the young women had consulted. “I told the girls to mow it and till it under,” he said of the tiny patch of land clotted with wild mustard and other weeds.

headline: Berkman Is Joining Yankees
text: On a May night in Milwaukee, after another dispiriting loss by his only major league team, Lance Berkman saw no point in denying the obvious. The Houston Astros, he acknowledged, were a bad team going nowhere.

headline: Reminders of Steinbrenner as Yankees Return to Tampa
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees arrived from Cleveland after 3 a.m. Friday, on the eve of a weighty series against the Rays. A capacity crowd of cowbell-ringing fans at Tropicana Field awaited Alex Rodriguez’s 600th career home run and a possible coup in the American League East. Such was the backdrop for the Yankees’ first trip here since their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, who lived in Tampa and detested the Rays, died July 13 at the age of 80.

headline: Billionaire Brothers Long Suspected of Tax Evasion
text: WASHINGTON  Sam and Charles Wyly have long cultivated an image as active philanthropists, funneling millions of dollars to arts groups, colleges, literacy programs and animal shelters.

headline: Nocturnalist | Until Dawn
text: Scenes from a night on the town, from 11:15 p.m. until morning.

headline: Still Feeling the Effects of a Concussion, Bay Goes to the Disabled List
text: Jason Bay was put on the 15-day disabled list Friday because he was still experiencing headaches after he sustained a concussion a week before in Los Angeles.

headline: Women’s Grand Prix Begins in Mongolia
text: There were three decisive games in Round 1 of the fifth leg of the series to select a challenger for the women’s world championship.

headline: In Maine Village, Lobster Goes Briskly; Traffic, No
text: WISCASSET, Me.  The summer traffic backups in this village of old sea captains’ homes are infamous in Maine, lines of inching cars and trucks that seem to extend all the way into autumn.

headline: Empty Spots in a Norman Rockwell Downtown
text: LARCHMONT, N.Y.  This village has long been one of suburban New York’s handsomest, blessed with an almost quaint Norman Rockwell downtown of shops, where mannequins are elegantly sheathed and brocaded pillows glisten.

headline: Debate Heats Up About Mosque Near Ground Zero
text: An influential Jewish organization on Friday announced its opposition to a proposed Islamic center and mosque two blocks north of ground zero in Lower Manhattan, intensifying a fierce national debate about the limits of religious freedom and the meaning of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Army Broadens Inquiry Into WikiLeaks Disclosure
text: WASHINGTON  Army investigators are broadening their inquiry into the recent disclosure of classified military information to include friends and associates who may have helped the person they suspect was the leaker, Pfc. Bradley Manning, people with knowledge of the investigation said Friday.

headline: Group Says China’s Official Oil Spill Figure May Be Too Low
text: BEIJING  Greenpeace is raising questions about whether the Chinese government has been underreporting the size of one of the country’s worst oil spills, near the northern port city of Dalian.

headline: Shared History
text: Two families linked by a piano during World War II reconnect.

headline: Mother’s Savior: A Revelation
text: The white-haired woman wet her index finger, then bent toward the shoulder of the man seated at the bench of a grand piano. He gave a quick nod, and she flipped to the next page in the score of Chopin’s Berceuse, a cradle song.

headline: Tampering With Gas Line Caused Blast, Officials Say
text: LOS ANGELES  An explosion on Friday caused by tampering with a gas line at a South Los Angeles industrial building killed one employee and critically injured another who was propelled across the street by the blast, officials said.

headline: For Teen Inmates, Freedom By Swimming
text: Dr. Jane Katz, 67, a swim teacher in New York City for more than a half-century, imparts her lesson to young people in detention: survival in the water, help stay afloat in life.

headline: On Busy Day for Jets, Coles Returns for Third Stint
text: The Jets added an old friend to their roster and announced contract extensions for their coach and general manager. The team should change its slogan to “Never a dull moment.”

headline: Let’s Make It Real
text: At the beginning of his much, much, much discussed visit to “The View,” Barack Obama squished himself into a long, low banquette where the five women who converse on the program were seated.

headline: Obama’s ‘Race’ War
text: Americans are engaged in a war over a word: racism.

headline: No Afghan Ally Left Behind
text: A TALIBAN spokesman announced Thursday that the group is poring over the tens of thousands of classified military documents published by WikiLeaks this week, looking for the names of pro-American Afghans.

headline: Girl Scouts Try to Shed Campfire Image
text: Two years shy of their 100th birthday, the Girl Scouts are going through a midlife crisis of sorts, rethinking everything except their cookie recipes.

headline: Boy Scout’s Jamboree
text: The organization is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year, but its numbers have been falling.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Congress Broken?
text: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Ross Douthat, Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, debate Congressional reform.

headline: Boy Scouts Seek a Way to Rebuild Ranks
text: FORT A.P. HILL, Va. — Her crown glinting in the morning sun, Miss America was telling 45,000 Boy Scouts and their leaders the other day how thrilled she was to be here at the National Scout Jamboree, to be among “the most amazing young women ...”

headline: Until Dawn
text: THE counter in Winston Parker’s hand read “0000.” It was 11 p.m. on a Friday night, and Mr. Parker, a doorman at the Box, a risqué cabaret and nightclub on the Lower East Side, was about to open the place up for the evening.

headline: Killing Rattles Self-Image of a New Jersey Town
text: SUMMIT, N.J.  From the park bench where he was relaxing after work, Abelino Mazariego would have been looking across this wealthy suburb’s old-fashioned main street at the gilded clock of a jewelry store. Behind him, an American flag flew and water whispered in a fountain where Summit’s parents like to bring their toddlers between shopping errands.

headline: Power Player
text: THERE are times when Maurice Vaughn, the former major league baseball player universally called Mo, is treated like a businessman  usually when he is deep in talks to buy ratty apartment buildings and make them habitable again.

headline: Frequent Sound at a Wine Tasting
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle has been made possible in part by the great state of Arizona. Here’s the New Age mecca just south of Flagstaff and a national monument that’s just a stone’s (or red rock’s) throw away.

headline: Summer Camp for the Cool and Career-Conscious 13-Year-Old
text: Come to Manhattan, a Web site urges young people, and experience a new sleep-away camp “in a totally cool, totally New York environment.”

headline: Nevada Candidate Accused of Making Disparaging Remarks
text: Brian Sandoval, the Republican candidate for governor in Nevada, came under political fire after a television news director in Las Vegas accused him of making a disparaging remark about Hispanics during an interview.

headline: Out of Frying Pan, Into August
text: In this month of record-contesting heat, a West Village epidemiologist has given up washing her clothes because her building’s ground-floor laundry room feels like a hot, stale dungeon. A former dancer who lives near Prospect Park has all but given up clothes, cooking dinner in her underwear though she knows the neighbors can see.

headline: Massachusetts: Lawmakers Hope to Expand Gambling
text: State lawmakers proposed Friday to allow casino gambling in Massachusetts with a plan to allow three resort casinos and to let the state’s racetracks compete for two slot-parlor licenses. But Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, said he would support only one slot parlor, leaving open the possibility of a veto. The legislature, set to adjourn for the year, will most likely hold a final vote on Saturday.

headline: Immigration Law Protesters Show Up at Citi Field
text: Opponents of Arizona’s anti-immigration law protested at Citi Field on Friday as the Mets took on the Arizona Diamondbacks. Before the game, several dozen protesters in front of the stadium handed out leaflets and stickers urging the repeal of the law and urging Major League Baseball to move the All-Star Game from Phoenix in 2011.

headline: Yankees Fade Late, and Rays Inch Closer
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees do not fear the Rays. They respect them. The Rays’ success in 2008 taught them that, and their revival in 2010 has reinforced it. Every time the Yankees have won over the last five weeks, the Rays have seemed to match them. That streak ended Friday night, when Tampa Bay outshined the Yankees on all fronts, if only by a drop.

headline: Ethics Trial Expected for California Congresswoman
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, will face charges of misusing her office and is expected to contest the claims in a House trial, the second powerful House Democrat to opt for such a public airing in recent days, Congressional officials said Friday.

headline: A Tougher Car Safety Agency
text: The United States has done a fairly good job so far of policing the safety of cars and trucks. The number of deaths in traffic accidents dropped to an estimated 34,000 last year  the least since the 1950s. But that is still too many deaths.

headline: The Fight Over Education in Washington
text: Congress is unlikely to take up its school financing bill, the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, until next year. But teachers unions and other forces of the status quo are already trying to subvert the measure by discrediting President Obama’s signature education initiative, the Race to the Top, which requires the states to make reforms in exchange for federal grants.

headline: Detention and the Disabled
text: The Department of Homeland Security has been working to clean up the immigration-justice system it inherited from the Bush administration, a sprawling detention-and-deportation operation plagued by overcrowding, mistreatment and shocking medical neglect. Ongoing scrutiny from legal experts and human-rights advocates shows how much work remains.

headline: Attacks on Mexicans Leave Neighborhood in Turmoil
text: Police officers patrolling by foot, car and helicopter have turned Port Richmond Avenue, a busy commercial strip on Staten Island, into something like an armed encampment. Reporters have descended en masse. Community leaders dash from crisis meeting to crisis meeting.

headline: Feckless and Cruel
text: In a shameful bout of election-year politicking, the House has rejected badly needed help for rescue workers and residents still suffering from the Sept. 11, 2001, destruction of the World Trade Center. What should have been swift bipartisan approval of a plan for medical and economic compensation turned into an ugly political brawl.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Hard Luck
text: Is anyone going to catch a break before this season of “Friday Night Lights” ends? The pain extended even to Mindy (literal physical pain) who seems to have endured 38-plus hours of labor to give birth to Stephen Hannibal Riggins. (Is Hannibal showing up in baby-naming books these days? This is news.)

headline: Economic Growth Slowed
text: Winnie O'Kelley and Catherine Rampell on today's sobering economic economic growth numbers and what they mean for U.S. economy.

headline: David Alexander, Overseer of Rhodes Selection, Is Dead at 77
text: David Alexander, a former president of Pomona College in California who for 17 years oversaw the selection of Rhodes scholars from the United States, died Sunday at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 77.

headline: When a Mets Error Opens the Door, the Diamondbacks Kick It Down
text: In baseball, sometimes small mistakes can balloon, as a crack in a wall leads to a flood. Case in point: what happened to the Mets Friday night at Citi Field when they lost, 9-6, to the lowly Arizona Diamondbacks, who have not defeated anyone else lately.

headline: Ben Keith, Musician and Sideman to Neil Young, Dies at 73
text: Ben Keith, a multi-instrumentalist who was a mainstay of Nashville’s recording studios for many years but who was best known for his long association with Neil Young, died on Monday at Mr. Young’s ranch in Northern California, where he had been living. He was 73.

headline: The Chess Olympiad, in Khanty-Mansiysk. Where? Khanty-Mansiysk.
text: As the biennial Chess Olympiad approaches, the World Chess Federation has released a schedule of charter flights to the site of the event.

headline: Nokia Siemens in Talks with Private Equity Firms
text: Nokia Siemens Networks, the telecommunications equipment maker, is in talks with several private equity firms about a potential investment in exchange for a minority stake, people briefed on the matter said. Such investment could be for at least $1 billion for up to a third of Nokia Siemens. But the talks — with firms like the Blackstone Group and TPG Capital — are in the early stages and may not lead to a transaction, these people said. Nokia Siemens is looking to shore up its operations and provide additional financing. Last week, the company acquired Motorola’s wireless networking equipment unit for $1.2 billion.

headline: Cleveland Browns 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Q. and A.: Pinning Photos to a Map, Or Not
text: Q.

headline: Sweat | Making the Water a Comfort Zone
text: “I AM NOT going in there,” said the trembling teenage girl standing at the shallow end of the pool. With her were a half-dozen other girls equally embarrassed to be paraded out in bathing suits and threatened with a swimming lesson.

headline: Memories of a Porsche 356
text: This Sunday’s Automobiles section takes a long look at the classic Porsche of the pre-911 era, the 356.  My research for this article goes all the way back to my teenage years, when I was thrashing a Volkswagen down back roads, imagining I was driving a Porsche racecar.

headline: Cincinnati Bengals 2010 Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com and a writer for CBSSports.com’s N.F.L. blog. He can be contacted at andy.benoit –at – NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: The Problem With (Bad) Tests
text: Does a new study on kindergarten suggest that standardized tests are irretrievably flawed?

headline: The Saturday Word: The Economy
text: President Obama criticized Senate Republicans on Saturday for blocking Democrats’ attempt to expand loan programs and tax breaks for small businesses, while Republicans condemned Mr. Obama’s policies as job-killers.

headline: Vettel’s Ominous Pole Position
text: This is starting to look definitive, if you ask me. Sebastian Vettel today scored a very, very strong pole position, sending his teammate at Red Bull, Mark Webber, more than half a second behind him. But that is still two Red Bulls on the front row, and that first corner at the Hungaroring is a sharp one, and coming through it in first position is essential at this street circuit in the country.

headline: Officials Optimistic That Cement Will Kill BP Well
text: HOUSTON  BP’s volatile oil well in the Gulf of Mexico may finally be locked down and filled with cement within a matter of days.

headline: Red Bulls to Introduce Márquez on Tuesday
text: 7:39 p.m. | Updated  The Red Bulls on Saturday said they would convene a news conference at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., at 1:15 p.m. on Tuesday to introduce the club’s newest designated player.

headline: Deals Aimed to Solve Old Yankee Problems
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Yankees are in a brutal stretch of 36 games in 37 days, which is one reason, Joe Girardi said, why they have upgraded their offense with the separate acquisitions Friday of Lance Berkman and Austin Kearns. Here is another reason: these deals, at a pittance to the Yankees, solved problems that they thought had been fixed in the off-season.

headline: Clockwise Spirals
text: Why are deflationistas like me worried about the possibility of deflation? In a word, history.

headline: Trebelhorn Is Happily Back Where He Started
text: KEIZER, Ore.  Before a game recently, Tom Trebelhorn grabbed a brown magic marker and crouched in front of his regal-looking desk, a recent acquisition by the Salem-Keizer Volcanoes’ front office.

headline: Afghan Women: Fearing a Taliban Future
text: In her article “Afghan Women Fear Loss of Modest Gains,” Alissa J. Rubin writes: “For women, instability, as much as the Taliban themselves, is the enemy. Women are casualties of the fighting, not only in the already conservative and embattled Pashtun south and east, but also in districts in the north and center of the country where other armed groups have sprung up.” In this post, she provides additional insight on Afghan women.

headline: Tracking Gulf’s Fate as Slicks Recede
text: .As BP and its team prepare to seal the wrecked Macondo well with mud and cement early next week, and the extent of oil on the surface of the Gulf of Mexico has receded, biologists and other scientists are mulling the long-term prospects for the ecosystems of the despoiled region and the communities that rely on them.

headline: Bitten Apple Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — As today’s grid took on more and more letters, a repetitive pattern emerged that I found helpful. Was that true for you as well?

headline: Two Point Nine One

headline: Floods in Pakistan Kill at Least 800
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Floods driven by record-breaking rainfall have killed at least 800 people and destroyed thousands of homes over the past week, officials said Saturday, in the latest disaster to test Pakistan’s already strained government.

headline: The Big Day: Chelsea Clinton’s Wedding
text: The Caucus is in Rhinebeck, N.Y., for the former first daughter’s wedding day. Check back for updates throughout the day. The Times’s article on Chelsea Clinton’s wedding is here.

headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills a Hamas Official
text: JERUSALEM  A commander of the Hamas military wing was killed in an Israeli missile strike in central Gaza early Saturday, according to the Islamist militant group.

headline: Get a Diploma, but Then Get a Passport
text: This interview with Quintin E. Primo III, co-founder and chief executive of Capri Capital Partners, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Capri is a real estate investment and development firm based in Chicago.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Jets’ Harris Says Little but Speaks Volumes
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  David Harris plays for the N.F.L’s most quotable coach (Rex Ryan), beside a loquacious linebacker (Bart Scott), on a Jets team so colorful that HBO will film training camp when practices start Monday.

headline: Fighting Words
text: The European Parliament recently voted to ban the sale of meat and dairy products from cloned animals and from the offspring of clones.

headline: Prime Number
text: 1300: The estimated number of people who have ended their lives by jumping from the Golden Gate Bridge since it opened in 1937. Transportation officials in California have agreed to hang a steel mesh net 20 feet below the span to catch jumpers. The decision to build and install the $45 million net follows decades of debate over its aesthetic impact and multimillion-dollar cost, and whether potential jumpers would simply go elsewhere to kill themselves.

headline: What Would Roosevelt Do?
text: ACROSS the United States, thousands of federally financed stimulus projects are under way, aimed at bolstering the economy and putting people to work. The results so far have not been spectacular.

headline: Back Then: 1971
text: Last week, The New York Times, The Guardian of London and the German magazine Der Spiegel published articles based on thousands of secret military and intelligence reports on the war in Afghanistan obtained by the group Wikileaks.

headline: When Family Ties Bind Business Relationships
text: Q. The bleak job market has you considering working in a family member’s business. What are the biggest differences between working for relatives and working for strangers?

headline: India Digs Under Top of the World to Match Rival
text: ROHTANG PASS, India  The name of this white-knuckle pass, one of the highest in the world, means “pile of corpses” in the Tibetan language. Every year a few dozen people die trying to cross these spiky Himalayan peaks.

headline: Turbines Too Loud? Here, Take $5,000
text: IONE, Ore.  Residents of the remote high-desert hills near here have had an unusual visitor recently, a fixer working out the kinks in clean energy.

headline: $200 Textbook vs. Free. You Do the Math.
text: INFURIATING Scott G. McNealy has never been easier. Just bring up math textbooks.

headline: Wales Takes a Turn in the Spotlight
text: To the uninitiated, Wales has always seemed like the British version of flyover country. You may have heard the put-downs: it’s merely a hard-to-reach place on the southwest coast of the sceptered isle that is lacking in vowels, five-star hotels and links land. What could possibly interest the jaded golf traveler whose trek through Ireland, England and the hallowed grounds of Scotland detours around Wales every time.

headline: Gap in N.L. East Starts With Bullpen
text: By trading for Roy Oswalt on Thursday, the Philadelphia Phillies undoubtedly strengthened their starting rotation. But the bullpen remains the biggest difference between the Phillies and the first-place Atlanta Braves in the National League East.

headline: The Mexican Border’s Lost World
text: TIJUANA, Mexico — Never a particularly pretty place, the border is at its ugliest right now, with violence, tensions and temperatures all on high.

headline: Outsourced, but Still Local
text: WHEN I was 14, I got a job in a local dental office. I worked there after school and during the summer through high school. It was a defining experience. Walking in the door of that office, I had to switch from high school student to empathetic professional.

headline: Running Government as a Cash Business
text: The lawyer for Rod R. Blagojevich urged jurors last week to acquit his client of corruption charges, in part because Mr. Blagojevich, the chatty former governor of Illinois, was simply too dull to carry out the devious schemes of which he stands accused.

headline: Missouri to Vote on Health Law
text: ST. CHARLES, Mo.  For all its symbolic import, the first plebiscite on the Obama health care law, to be held Tuesday in Missouri, seems likely to be a low-turnout affair among an electorate dominated by Republican primary voters and conservative activists.

headline: With Friends Like This ...
text: IS it a blinding statement of the obvious to say that trust in the world’s banks has suffered lately? Indeed, just when you think you’re ready to move past the steady drumbeat of disconcerting revelations, something else crops up to test your faith.

headline: Small Step on Small Fees, but Big Charges Remain
text: PICTURE a tiny hole in the hull of a ship on a long ocean voyage. It is slowly letting in water. If the hole isn’t plugged, the leak will eventually slow the vessel drastically  maybe even sink it.

headline: Rethinking the Afghanistan War’s What-Ifs
text: WASHINGTON — Long before Afghanistan became the longest shooting war in American history, the question loomed: Could it have turned out differently?

headline: For No Signs of Trouble, Kill the Alarm
text: When an oil worker told investigators on July 23 that an alarm to warn of explosive gas on the Transocean rig in the Gulf of Mexico had been intentionally disabled months before, it struck many people as reckless.

headline: The Academic-Industrial Complex
text: WHAT does Shirley Ann Jackson know about shipping parcels? For that matter, what does Steven B. Sample understand about mutual funds?

headline: After Stroke Scans, Patients Face Serious Health Risks
text: When Alain Reyes’s hair suddenly fell out in a freakish band circling his head, he was not the only one worried about his health. His co-workers at a shipping company avoided him, and his boss sent him home, fearing he had a contagious disease.

headline: Many Indigent Refugees to Lose Federal Assistance
text: WASHINGTON  The Social Security Administration is about to terminate cash assistance for thousands of indigent refugees who are severely disabled or over the age of 64.

headline: Is It Hot in Here? Must Be Global Warming.
text: In any debate over climate change, conventional wisdom holds that there is no reflex more absurd than invoking the local weather.

headline: In Information War, Documentary Is Latest Salvo
text: MOSCOW  A new documentary film about the Belarussian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, portrays him as a bumbling tyrant enamored of Hitler and Stalin. He has political opponents killed, journalists silenced and elections rigged in the film, all while keeping his faltering country locked in a Soviet time warp.

headline: A Richter Scale for Markets
text: It’s tempting to pull out the old earthquake metaphor when talking about the latest financial crises. How else to describe the economic devastation — the tremors in the subprime mortgage market, the seismic collapse of Lehman Brothers, and the aftershocks reverberating in Europe?

headline: A Trip to Tibet, With My Handlers Nearby
text: LHASA, Tibet — One warm morning on the campus of Tibet University, a couple of foreign journalists on a government-run tour of Tibet quietly broke away from the group to talk to students standing on a grassy lawn. Security guards dashed in and waved the students away.

headline: Is Italy Too Italian?
text: “THIS tradition is finita,” says Luciano Barbera, as he opens the door to an underground warehouse. Dozens of large wooden boxes are stacked to the ceiling, containing nearly 80 tons of colorful thread, wound in spools and idling like sunbathers at a beach, absorbing moisture in a cavernous room kept naturally cool and humid by a creek that burbles under the floor.

headline: In Italy, Choosing Tradition Over Growth
text: An Italian fine textile company’s debt woes, like those of the country, can be traced to a mistrust of those not in the family, and an aversion to risk and growth.

headline: Koneru Takes the Lead in Mongolia
text: The top seed from India won her second game to start the fifth Women’s Grand Prix tournament.

headline: A Call to Fix the Fundamentals
text: IN 2005, Raghuram G. Rajan told a meeting of the world’s top central bankers, Alan Greenspan included, that the global financial system was threatened from within and might well be facing a full-blown crisis. At the time, he says, he was roundly criticized. But given what happened a few years later we may not want to dismiss his recent assertion that the global economy is vulnerable to another implosion.

headline: India’s Himalayan Tunnel
text: India is building a tunnel to bypass the dangerous Rohtang Pass as part of a plan to match China for regional and global power.

headline: The Amanpour Era Begins
text: I’ll be with the new host of This Week this week — tomorrow.

headline: What They’re Not Telling You
text: There is a lot of heated talk in Washington these days about the deficit, unfortunately little of it serious. Playing on Americans’ deep anxiety about the economy, Republican politicians have seized the deficit issue as their own — eagerly blaming the stimulus and even an extension of unemployment insurance for the problem — while denying their own culpability for helping dig this deep hole with years of irresponsible tax cuts.

headline: Queens Man Fatally Stabbed at Subway Station
text: A 27-year-old Queens man was fatally stabbed at an elevated subway station late Friday after his mother said he ran to help his younger brother, who was being beaten near a video store in the Woodhaven neighborhood.

headline: Death of a Farm
text: Farms go out of business for many reasons, but few farms do merely because the soil has failed. That is the miracle of farming. If you care for the soil, it will last — and yield — nearly forever. America is such a young country that we have barely tested that. For most of our history, there has been new land to farm, and we still farm as though there always will be.

headline: Health Care Memories
text: Do you remember how public hatred of the health care reform was going to be the dominant issue in the midterm elections? Do you remember how there was going to be a firestorm of disapproval over the Democrats’ use of reconciliation to pass the legislation despite the fact that they only had 59 out of 100 Senators?

headline: The Mark of an Overdose
text: Voices of patients who received radiation overdoses from a procedure called a CT brain perfusion scan.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the growth of the online game company Zynga misstated its predicted revenue. According to the Inside Network, which tracks Facebook apps, Zynga is expected to take in as much as $500 million this year, not $835 million.

headline: House Inquiry on Waters Tied to Bank
text: WASHINGTON  When Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, called Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. in late 2008 to ask him to host a special meeting that would feature a California bank executive she knew well, was the request on behalf of a trade association, or a bank in which her husband owned stock?

headline: Middle-Class Tax Cuts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Economic Indicator: Even Cheaper Knockoffs
text: In this economy, even counterfeiters are trading down.

headline: Mad Men and Bad Girls
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Trading Deadline: Who Went Where
text: Some notable names were moved before today’s 4 p.m. Eastern trading deadline, but Adam Dunn was not one of them. The Yankees were busy, adding Lance Berkman and Kerry Wood, while the Dodgers bolstered their rotation by adding Ted Lilly. Continue reading to see how the rest of it unfolded.

headline: Alex Higgins, the Bombastic ‘People’s Champion’ of Pro Snooker, Dies at 61
text: The rogues of sport are legion. Gifted, charismatic and reckless, they burn with hubris, flout convention, seize championships and rouse fans. Bobby Fischer at the chessboard. Mike Tyson in the ring. On the links, the young John Daly and the not-so-young Tiger Woods. Alex Higgins  smoker, drinker, brawler, gambler, womanizer and two-time world snooker champion  was an exemplar of the type.

headline: Kiss This War Goodbye
text: IT was on a Sunday morning, June 13, 1971, that The Times published its first installment of the Pentagon Papers. Few readers may have been more excited than a circle of aspiring undergraduate journalists who’d worked at The Harvard Crimson. Though the identity of The Times’s source wouldn’t eke out for several days, we knew the whistle-blower had to be Daniel Ellsberg, an intense research fellow at M.I.T. and former Robert McNamara acolyte who’d become an antiwar activist around Boston. We recognized the papers’ contents, as reported in The Times, because we’d heard the war stories from the loquacious Ellsberg himself.

headline: A French Castle Built of Stone and Dreams
text: TREIGNY, France  Maryline Martin, like a lot of little French girls, was besotted with the Middle Ages, with castles and maidens and knights. She worked for Pier 1 Imports for a while, then came back to this part of Burgundy and thought she would grow mushrooms. She worked instead in an agency trying to find work for the jobless, but the fakery and cynicism involved outraged her, she said.

headline: Pros vs. Joes: Q. and A. With Michael Strahan
text: N.F.L. training camps are opening, and Michael Strahan says he is happy that he will be in a comfortable television studio. Those wilting two-a-day workouts are one of the few football rituals that Strahan, a former All-Pro defensive end for the Giants, says he does not miss since he retired in 2008. A key member of the team that won Super Bowl XLII, Strahan gets his sports fix now as a co-host of “Pros vs. Joes” on Spike TV. The reality show pits amateurs against professionals in various sports. He is also an analyst for “Fox NFL Sunday.”

headline: The Great (Double) Game
text: The trove of WikiLeaks about the faltering U.S. war effort in Afghanistan has provoked many reactions, but for me it contains one clear message. It’s actually an old piece of advice your parents may have given you before you went off to college: “If you are in a poker game and you don’t know who the sucker is, it’s probably you.”

headline: Despite Rule, BP Used Dispersant, Panel Finds
text: The Coast Guard approved dozens of requests by BP to spread hundreds of thousands of gallons of surface oil dispersants in the Gulf of Mexico despite the Environmental Protection Agency’s directive on May 26 that they should be used only rarely, according to documents and correspondence analyzed by a Congressional subcommittee.

headline: Play Bargaining
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Did the title tip you off as to the theme? It didn’t for me, but it wasn’t too long before the trick revealed itself — a long A sound replaces a long E sound at the end of one word in 10 common phrases.

headline: Another Pill That Could Cause a Revolution
text: Could the decades-long global impasse over abortion worldwide be overcome  by little white pills costing less than $1 each?

headline: Four Deformations of the Apocalypse
text: IF there were such a thing as Chapter 11 for politicians, the Republican push to extend the unaffordable Bush tax cuts would amount to a bankruptcy filing. The nation’s public debt  if honestly reckoned to include municipal bonds and the $7 trillion of new deficits baked into the cake through 2015  will soon reach $18 trillion. That’s a Greece-scale 120 percent of gross domestic product, and fairly screams out for austerity and sacrifice. It is therefore unseemly for the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, to insist that the nation’s wealthiest taxpayers be spared even a three-percentage-point rate increase.

headline: Mistaken as an Iranian Martyr, Then Hounded
text: FRANKFURT  Zahra Soltani, whom everyone calls Neda, will never forget the day she saw her death announced on television, accompanied by the picture she had posted on her Facebook page. “They said that I was killed during the protests against the presidential elections,” she said, shaking her head.

headline: Eight Million Bodies in the Naked City
text: YOU could argue that when one assumes a “chicken fight” position at a crowded field of drunken and sweaty hipsters on Governors Island for a concert featuring M.I.A. and other musicians, it’s only fitting to do so topless. Chickens are generally a clothing-free bunch, so wearing nothing but a fedora above the waist is really the purest tribute to the pose.

headline: Learning From WikiLeaks
text: Saco, Me.

headline: For One Senate Seat in Illinois, Two Elections on the Same Day
text: CHICAGO  In all the fuss over the Senate seat that President Obama left behind here, and whether it was offered up in a nefarious trade, some people demanded a clean start. Let the voters of Illinois elect someone to fill the vacancy.

headline: In Pakistan, Echoes of American Betrayal
text: Karachi, Pakistan

headline: For Champion Olympic Swimmer, a Simpler Time
text: TUCSON  It was a curly blue ribbon, much thinner than the ones Amanda Beard collected as a child for winning swim races. Holding none of her seven Olympic medals, it held no value except in the eyes of her playful 10-month-old son.

headline: American Muslims Make Video to Rebut Militants
text: A recent spate of arrests of Muslims accused of terrorism in the United States has revealed that many of them were radicalized by militant preaching they found on the Internet.

headline: Immigration Policy Aims to Help Military Families
text: The Obama administration, responding to requests from Democratic and Republican lawmakers, has taken steps to make it easier for illegal immigrants who are spouses and family members of Americans serving in the military to gain legal status.

headline: Hottest July Ever? Not Quite
text: After weeks of brutal temperatures that flirted with the record books, July ended with a beautiful day in New York, offering the city much-needed relief, but foiling the chance to make history.

headline: The Latest Challenge for Woods Takes Him to One of His Favorite Places
text: The World Golf Championships are back and so is Tiger Woods, who takes his 2010 golf redemption tour to the friendly confines of Akron, Ohio, to defend his W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational title this week at the South Course of Firestone Country Club  a course he has all but owned for more than a decade.

headline: How to Revive Gulf Fishing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Slow Start to an Oil-Delayed Shrimping Season
text: Gary Skinner did not expect much when the shrimping season opened more than a month late in Alabama’s Mobile Bay.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:
